7.1.0	This NASA image is a composite of several satellite-based views of Earth.
7.1.1	To make the whole-Earth image, NASA scientists combine observations of different parts of the planet.
7.1.2	Viewed from space, Earth offers no clues about the diversity of life forms that reside there.
7.1.3	The first forms of life on Earth are thought to have been microorganisms that existed for billions of years in the ocean before plants and animals appeared.
7.1.4	The mammals, birds, and flowers so familiar to us are all relatively recent, originating 130 to 200 million years ago.
7.1.5	Humans have inhabited this planet for only the last 2.5 million years, and only in the last 200,000 years have humans started looking like we do today.
7.1.6	Figure 1.2
7.1.7	Formerly called blue-green algae, these (a) cyanobacteria, shown here at 300x magnification under a light microscope, are some of Earth’s oldest life forms.
7.1.8	These (b) stromatolites along the shores of Lake Thetis in Western Australia are ancient structures formed by the layering of cyanobacteria in shallow waters.
7.1.9	(credit a: modification of work by NASA; credit b: modification of work by Ruth Ellison; scale-bar data from Matt Russell)
7.1.10	What is biology?
7.1.11	In simple terms, biology is the study of living organisms and their interactions with one another and their environments.
7.1.12	This is a very broad definition because the scope of biology is vast.
7.1.13	Biologists may study anything from the microscopic or submicroscopic view of a cell to ecosystems and the whole living planet (Figure 1.2).
7.1.14	Listening to the daily news, you will quickly realize how many aspects of biology are discussed every day.
7.1.15	For example, recent news topics include Escherichia coli
7.1.16	(Figure 1.3) outbreaks in spinach and Salmonella contamination in peanut butter.
7.1.17	Other subjects include efforts toward finding a cure for AIDS, Alzheimer’s disease, and cancer.
7.1.18	On a global scale, many researchers are committed to finding ways to protect the planet, solve environmental issues, and reduce the effects of climate change.
7.1.19	All of these diverse endeavors are related to different facets of the discipline of biology.
7.1.20	Figure 1.3 Escherichia coli (E. coli) bacteria, seen in this scanning electron micrograph, are normal residents of our digestive tracts that aid in the absorption of vitamin K and other nutrients.
7.1.21	However, virulent strains are sometimes responsible for disease outbreaks.
7.1.22	(credit:
7.1.23	Eric Erbe, digital colorization by Christopher Pooley, both of USDA, ARS, EMU)
7.1.24	The Process of Science Biology is a science, but what exactly is science?
7.1.25	What does the study of biology share with other scientific disciplines?
7.1.26	Science (from the Latin scientia, meaning “knowledge”) can be defined as knowledge that covers general truths or the operation of general laws, especially when acquired and tested by the scientific method.
7.1.27	It becomes clear from this definition that the application of the scientific method plays a major role in science.
7.1.28	The scientific method is a method of research with defined steps that include experiments and careful observation.
7.1.29	The steps of the scientific method will be examined in detail later, but one of the most important aspects of this method is the testing of hypotheses by means of repeatable experiments.
7.1.30	A hypothesis is a suggested explanation for an event, which can be tested.
7.1.31	Although using the scientific method is inherent to science, it is inadequate in determining what science is.
7.1.32	This is because it is relatively easy to apply the scientific method to disciplines such as physics and chemistry, but when it comes to disciplines like archaeology, psychology, and geology, the scientific method becomes less applicable as it becomes more difficult to repeat experiments.
7.1.33	These areas of study are still sciences, however.
7.1.34	Consider archeology—even though one cannot perform repeatable experiments, hypotheses may still be supported.
7.1.35	For instance, an archeologist can hypothesize that an ancient culture existed based on finding a piece of pottery.
7.1.36	Further hypotheses could be made about various characteristics of this culture, and these hypotheses may be found to be correct or false through continued support or contradictions from other findings.
7.1.37	A hypothesis may become a verified theory.
7.1.38	A theory is a tested and confirmed explanation for observations or phenomena.
7.1.39	Science may be better defined as fields of study that attempt to comprehend the nature of the universe.
7.1.40	What would you expect to see in a museum of natural sciences?
7.1.41	Frogs?
7.1.42	Plants?
7.1.43	Dinosaur skeletons?
7.1.44	Exhibits about how the brain functions?
7.1.45	A planetarium?
7.1.46	Gems and minerals?
7.1.47	Or, maybe all of the above?
7.1.48	Science includes such diverse fields as astronomy, biology, computer sciences, geology, logic, physics, chemistry, and mathematics (Figure 1.4).
7.1.49	However, those fields of science related to the physical world and its phenomena and processes are considered natural sciences.
7.1.50	Thus, a museum of natural sciences might contain any of the items listed above.
7.1.51	Figure 1.4
7.1.52	The diversity of scientific fields includes astronomy, biology, computer science, geology, logic, physics, chemistry, mathematics, and many other fields.
7.1.53	(credit:
7.1.54	“Image Editor”/Flickr)
7.1.55	There is no complete agreement when it comes to defining what the natural sciences include, however.
7.1.56	For some experts, the natural sciences are astronomy, biology, chemistry, earth science, and physics.
7.1.57	Other scholars choose to divide natural sciences into life sciences, which study living things and include biology, and physical sciences, which study nonliving matter and include astronomy, geology, physics, and chemistry.
7.1.58	Some disciplines such as biophysics and biochemistry build on both life and physical sciences and are interdisciplinary.
7.1.59	Natural sciences are sometimes referred to as “hard science” because they rely on the use of quantitative data; social sciences that study society and human behavior are more likely to use qualitative assessments to drive investigations and findings.
7.1.60	Not surprisingly, the natural science of biology has many branches or subdisciplines.
7.1.61	Cell biologists study cell structure and function, while biologists who study anatomy investigate the structure of an entire organism.
7.1.62	Those biologists studying physiology, however, focus on the internal functioning of an organism.
7.1.63	Some areas of biology focus on only particular types of living things.
7.1.64	For example, botanists explore plants, while zoologists specialize in animals.
7.1.65	Scientific Reasoning One thing is common to all forms of science: an ultimate goal “to know.
7.1.66	”
7.1.67	Curiosity and inquiry are the driving forces for the development of science.
7.1.68	Scientists seek to understand the world and the way it operates.
7.1.69	To do this, they use two methods of logical thinking: inductive reasoning and deductive reasoning.
7.1.70	Inductive reasoning is a form of logical thinking that uses related observations to arrive at a general conclusion.
7.1.71	This type of reasoning is common in descriptive science.
7.1.72	A life scientist such as a biologist makes observations and records them.
7.1.73	These data can be qualitative or quantitative, and the raw data can be supplemented with drawings, pictures, photos, or videos.
7.1.74	From many observations, the scientist can infer conclusions (inductions) based on evidence.
7.1.75	Inductive reasoning involves formulating generalizations inferred from careful observation and the analysis of a large amount of data.
7.1.76	Brain studies provide an example.
7.1.77	In this type of research, many live brains are observed while people are doing a specific activity, such as viewing images of food.
7.1.78	The part of the brain that “lights up” during this activity is then predicted to be the part controlling the response to the selected stimulus, in this case, images of food.
7.1.79	The “lighting up” of the various areas of the brain is caused by excess absorption of radioactive sugar derivatives by active areas of the brain.
7.1.80	The resultant increase in radioactivity is observed by a scanner.
7.1.81	Then, researchers can stimulate that part of the brain to see if similar responses result.
7.1.82	Deductive reasoning or deduction is the type of logic used in hypothesis-based science.
7.1.83	In deductive reason, the pattern of thinking moves in the opposite direction as compared to inductive reasoning.
7.1.84	Deductive reasoning is a form of logical thinking that uses a general principle or law to forecast specific results.
7.1.85	From those general principles, a scientist can extrapolate and predict the specific results that would be valid as long as the general principles are valid.
7.1.86	Studies in climate change can illustrate this type of reasoning.
7.1.87	For example, scientists may predict that if the climate becomes warmer in a particular region, then the distribution of plants and animals should change.
7.1.88	These predictions have been made and tested, and many such changes have been found, such as the modification of arable areas for agriculture, with change based on temperature averages.
7.1.89	Both types of logical thinking are related to the two main pathways of scientific study: descriptive science and hypothesisbased science.
7.1.90	Descriptive (or discovery) science, which is usually inductive, aims to observe, explore, and discover, while hypothesis-based science, which is usually deductive, begins with a specific question or problem and a potential answer or solution that can be tested.
7.1.91	The boundary between these two forms of study is often blurred, and most scientific endeavors combine both approaches.
7.1.92	The fuzzy boundary becomes apparent when thinking about how easily observation can lead to specific questions.
7.1.93	For example, a gentleman in the 1940s observed that the burr seeds that stuck to his clothes and his dog’s fur had a tiny hook structure.
7.1.94	On closer inspection, he discovered that the burrs’ gripping device was more reliable than a zipper.
7.1.95	He eventually developed a company and produced the hook-and-loop fastener popularly known today as Velcro.
7.1.96	Descriptive science and hypothesis-based science are in continuous dialogue.
7.1.97	The Scientific Method Biologists study the living world by posing questions about it and seeking science-based responses.
7.1.98	This approach is common to other sciences as well and is often referred to as the scientific method.
7.1.99	The scientific method was used even in ancient times, but it was first documented by England’s Sir Francis Bacon (1561–1626) (Figure 1.5), who set up inductive methods for scientific inquiry.
7.1.100	The scientific method is not exclusively used by biologists but can be applied to almost all fields of study as a logical, rational problem-solving method.
7.1.101	Sir Francis Bacon (1561–1626) is credited with being the first to define the scientific method.
7.1.102	(credit: Paul van Somer)
7.1.103	The scientific process typically starts with an observation (often a problem to be solved) that leads to a question.
7.1.104	Let’s think about a simple problem that starts with an observation and apply the scientific method to solve the problem.
7.1.105	One Monday morning, a student arrives at class and quickly discovers that the classroom is too warm.
7.1.106	That is an observation that also describes a problem: the classroom is too warm.
7.1.107	The student then asks a question:
7.1.108	“Why is the classroom so warm?
7.1.109	” Proposing a Hypothesis Recall that a hypothesis is a suggested explanation that can be tested.
7.1.110	To solve a problem, several hypotheses may be proposed.
7.1.111	For example, one hypothesis might be, “
7.1.112	The classroom is warm because no one turned on the air conditioning.
7.1.113	”
7.1.114	But there could be other responses to the question, and therefore other hypotheses may be proposed.
7.1.115	A second hypothesis might be, “
7.1.116	The classroom is warm because there is a power failure, and so the air conditioning doesn’t work.
7.1.117	”
7.1.118	Once a hypothesis has been selected, the student can make a prediction.
7.1.119	A prediction is similar to a hypothesis
7.1.120	but it typically has the format “
7.1.121	If . . .
7.1.122	then . . . .
7.1.123	”
7.1.124	For example, the prediction for the first hypothesis might be, “
7.1.125	If the student turns on the air conditioning, then the classroom will no longer be too warm.
7.1.126	”
7.1.127	Testing a Hypothesis A valid hypothesis must be testable.
7.1.128	It should also be falsifiable, meaning that it can be disproven by experimental results.
7.1.129	Importantly, science does not claim to “prove” anything because scientific understandings are always subject to modification with further information.
7.1.130	This step—openness to disproving ideas
7.1.131	—is what distinguishes sciences from nonsciences.
7.1.132	The presence of the supernatural, for instance, is neither testable nor falsifiable.
7.1.133	To test a hypothesis, a researcher will conduct one or more experiments designed to eliminate one or more of the hypotheses.
7.1.134	Each experiment will have one or more variables and one or more controls.
7.1.135	A variable is any part of the experiment that can vary or change during the experiment.
7.1.136	The control group contains every feature of the experimental group except it is not given the manipulation that is hypothesized about.
7.1.137	Therefore, if the results of the experimental group differ from the control group, the difference must be due to the hypothesized manipulation, rather than some outside factor.
7.1.138	Look for the variables and controls in the examples that follow.
7.1.139	To test the first hypothesis, the student would find out if the air conditioning is on.
7.1.140	If the air conditioning is turned on but does not work, there should be another reason, and this hypothesis should be rejected.
7.1.141	To test the second hypothesis, the student could check if the lights in the classroom are functional.
7.1.142	If so, there is no power failure and this hypothesis should be rejected.
7.1.143	Each hypothesis should be tested by carrying out appropriate experiments.
7.1.144	Be aware that rejecting one hypothesis does not determine whether or not the other hypotheses can be accepted; it simply eliminates one hypothesis that is not valid (Figure 1.6).
7.1.145	Using the scientific method, the hypotheses that are inconsistent with experimental data are rejected.
7.1.146	While this “warm classroom” example is based on observational results, other hypotheses and experiments might have clearer controls.
7.1.147	For instance, a student might attend class on Monday and realize she had difficulty concentrating on the lecture.
7.1.148	One observation to explain this occurrence might be, “When I eat breakfast before class, I am better able to pay attention.
7.1.149	”
7.1.150	The student could then design an experiment with a control to test this hypothesis.
7.1.151	In hypothesis-based science, specific results are predicted from a general premise.
7.1.152	This type of reasoning is called deductive reasoning: deduction proceeds from the general to the particular.
7.1.153	But the reverse of the process is also possible: sometimes, scientists reach a general conclusion from a number of specific observations.
7.1.154	This type of reasoning is called inductive reasoning, and it proceeds from the particular to the general.
7.1.155	Inductive and deductive reasoning are often used in tandem to advance scientific knowledge (Figure 1.7).
7.1.156	The scientific method may seem too rigid and structured.
7.1.157	It is important to keep in mind that, although scientists often follow this sequence, there is flexibility.
7.1.158	Sometimes an experiment leads to conclusions that favor a change in approach; often, an experiment brings entirely new scientific questions to the puzzle.
7.1.159	Many times, science does not operate in a linear fashion; instead, scientists continually draw inferences and make generalizations, finding patterns as their research proceeds.
7.1.160	Scientific reasoning is more complex than the scientific method alone suggests.
7.1.161	Notice, too, that the scientific method can be applied to solving problems that aren’t necessarily scientific in nature.
7.1.162	Two Types of Science: Basic Science and Applied Science
7.1.163	The scientific community has been debating for the last few decades about the value of different types of science.
7.1.164	Is it valuable to pursue science for the sake of simply gaining knowledge, or does scientific knowledge only have worth if we can apply it to solving a specific problem or to bettering our lives?
7.1.165	This question focuses on the differences between two types of science: basic science and applied science.
7.1.166	Basic science or “pure” science seeks to expand knowledge regardless of the short-term application of that knowledge.
7.1.167	It is not focused on developing a product or a service of immediate public or commercial value.
7.1.168	The immediate goal of basic science is knowledge for knowledge’s sake, though this does not mean that, in the end, it may not result in a practical application.
7.1.169	In contrast, applied science or “technology,” aims to use science to solve real-world problems, making it possible, for example, to improve a crop yield, find a cure for a particular disease, or save animals threatened by a natural disaster (Figure 1.8).
7.1.170	In applied science, the problem is usually defined for the researcher.
7.1.171	Figure 1.8
7.1.172	After Hurricane Ike struck the Gulf Coast in 2008, the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service rescued this brown pelican.
7.1.173	Thanks to applied science, scientists knew how to rehabilitate the bird.
7.1.174	(credit: FEMA)
7.1.175	Some individuals may perceive applied science as “useful” and basic science as “useless.
7.1.176	”
7.1.177	A question these people might pose to a scientist advocating knowledge acquisition would be, “What for?
7.1.178	”
7.1.179	A careful look at the history of science, however, reveals that basic knowledge has resulted in many remarkable applications of great value.
7.1.180	Many scientists think that a basic understanding of science is necessary before an application is developed; therefore, applied science relies on the results generated through basic science.
7.1.181	Other scientists think that it is time to move on from basic science and instead to find solutions to actual problems.
7.1.182	Both approaches are valid.
7.1.183	It is true that there are problems that demand immediate attention; however, few solutions would be found without the help of the wide knowledge foundation generated through basic science.
7.1.184	One example of how basic and applied science can work together to solve practical problems occurred after the discovery of DNA structure led to an understanding of the molecular mechanisms governing DNA replication.
7.1.185	Strands of DNA, unique in every human, are found in our cells, where they provide the instructions necessary for life.
7.1.186	During DNA replication, DNA makes new copies of itself, shortly before a cell divides.
7.1.187	Understanding the mechanisms of DNA replication enabled scientists to develop laboratory techniques that are now used to identify genetic diseases, pinpoint individuals who were at a crime scene, and determine paternity.
7.1.188	Without basic science, it is unlikely that applied science would exist.
7.1.189	Another example of the link between basic and applied research is the Human Genome Project, a study in which each human chromosome was analyzed and mapped to determine the precise sequence of DNA subunits and the exact location of each gene.
7.1.190	(The gene is the basic unit of heredity; an individual’s complete collection of genes is his or her genome.)
7.1.191	Other less complex organisms have also been studied as part of this project in order to gain a better understanding of human chromosomes.
7.1.192	The Human Genome Project (Figure 1.9) relied on basic research carried out with simple organisms and, later, with the human genome.
7.1.193	An important end goal eventually became using the data for applied research, seeking cures and early diagnoses for genetically related diseases.
7.1.194	Figure 1.9
7.1.195	The Human Genome Project was a 13-year collaborative effort among researchers working in several different fields of science.
7.1.196	The project, which sequenced the entire human genome, was completed in 2003.
7.1.197	(credit: the U.S. Department of Energy Genome Programs (http://genomics.energy.gov))
7.1.198	While research efforts in both basic science and applied science are usually carefully planned, it is important to note that some discoveries are made by serendipity, that is, by means of a fortunate accident or a lucky surprise.
7.1.199	Penicillin was discovered when biologist Alexander Fleming accidentally left a petri dish of Staphylococcus bacteria open.
7.1.200	An unwanted mold grew on the dish, killing the bacteria.
7.1.201	The mold turned out to be Penicillium, and a new antibiotic was discovered.
7.1.202	Even in the highly organized world of science, luck—when combined with an observant, curious mind—can lead to unexpected breakthroughs.
7.1.203	Reporting Scientific Work
7.1.204	Whether scientific research is basic science or applied science, scientists must share their findings in order for other researchers to expand and build upon their discoveries.
7.1.205	Collaboration with other scientists—when planning, conducting, and analyzing results—are all important for scientific research.
7.1.206	For this reason, important aspects of a scientist’s work are communicating with peers and disseminating results to peers.
7.1.207	Scientists can share results by presenting them at a scientific meeting or conference, but this approach can reach only the select few who are present.
7.1.208	Instead, most scientists present their results in peer-reviewed manuscripts that are published in scientific journals.
7.1.209	Peer-reviewed manuscripts are scientific papers that are reviewed by a scientist’s colleagues, or peers.
7.1.210	These colleagues are qualified individuals, often experts in the same research area, who judge whether or not the scientist’s work is suitable for publication.
7.1.211	The process of peer review helps to ensure that the research described in a scientific paper or grant proposal is original, significant, logical, and thorough.
7.1.212	Grant proposals, which are requests for research funding, are also subject to peer review.
7.1.213	Scientists publish their work so other scientists can reproduce their experiments under similar or different conditions to expand on the findings.
7.1.214	The experimental results must be consistent with the findings of other scientists.
7.1.215	A scientific paper is very different from creative writing.
7.1.216	Although creativity is required to design experiments, there are fixed guidelines when it comes to presenting scientific results.
7.1.217	First, scientific writing must be brief, concise, and accurate.
7.1.218	A scientific paper needs to be succinct but detailed enough to allow peers to reproduce the experiments.
7.1.219	The scientific paper consists of several specific sections—introduction, materials and methods, results, and discussion.
7.1.220	This structure is sometimes called the “IMRaD” format.
7.1.221	There are usually acknowledgment and reference sections as well as an abstract (a concise summary) at the beginning of the paper.
7.1.222	There might be additional sections depending on the type of paper and the journal where it will be published; for example, some review papers require an outline.
7.1.223	The introduction starts with brief, but broad, background information about what is known in the field.
7.1.224	A good introduction also gives the rationale of the work; it justifies the work carried out and also briefly mentions the end of the paper, where the hypothesis or research question driving the research will be presented.
7.1.225	The introduction refers to the published scientific work of others and therefore requires citations following the style of the journal.
7.1.226	Using the work or ideas of others without proper citation is considered plagiarism.
7.1.227	The materials and methods section includes a complete and accurate description of the substances used, and the method and techniques used by the researchers to gather data.
7.1.228	The description should be thorough enough to allow another researcher to repeat the experiment and obtain similar results, but it does not have to be verbose.
7.1.229	This section will also include information on how measurements were made and what types of calculations and statistical analyses were used to examine raw data.
7.1.230	Although the materials and methods section gives an accurate description of the experiments, it does not discuss them.
7.1.231	Some journals require a results section followed by a discussion section, but it is more common to combine both.
7.1.232	If the journal does not allow the combination of both sections, the results section simply narrates the findings without any further interpretation.
7.1.233	The results are presented by means of tables or graphs, but no duplicate information should be presented.
7.1.234	In the discussion section, the researcher will interpret the results, describe how variables may be related, and attempt to explain the observations.
7.1.235	It is indispensable to conduct an extensive literature search to put the results in the context of previously published scientific research.
7.1.236	Therefore, proper citations are included in this section as well.
7.1.237	Finally, the conclusion section summarizes the importance of the experimental findings.
7.1.238	While the scientific paper almost certainly answered one or more scientific questions that were stated, any good research should lead to more questions.
7.1.239	Therefore, a well-done scientific paper leaves doors open for the researcher and others to continue and expand on the findings.
7.1.240	Review articles do not follow the IMRAD format because they do not present original scientific findings, or primary literature; instead, they summarize and comment on findings that were published as primary literature and typically include extensive reference sections.response, but it is not always easy to define life.
7.1.241	For example, a branch of biology called virology studies viruses, which exhibit some of the characteristics of living entities but lack others.
7.1.242	It turns out that although viruses can attack living organisms, cause diseases, and even reproduce, they do not meet the criteria that biologists use to define life.
7.1.243	Consequently, virologists are not biologists, strictly speaking.
7.1.244	Similarly, some biologists study the early molecular evolution that gave rise to life; since the events that preceded life are not biological events, these scientists are also excluded from biology in the strict sense of the term.
7.1.245	From its earliest beginnings, biology has wrestled with three questions: What are the shared properties that make something “alive”?
7.1.246	And once we know something is alive, how do we find meaningful levels of organization in its structure?
7.1.247	And, finally, when faced with the remarkable diversity of life, how do we organize the different kinds of organisms so that we can better understand them?
7.1.248	As new organisms are discovered every day, biologists continue to seek answers to these and other questions.
7.1.249	Properties of Life
7.1.250	All living organisms share several key characteristics or functions: order, sensitivity or response to the environment, reproduction, adaptation, growth and development, regulation, homeostasis, energy processing, and evolution.
7.1.251	When viewed together, these nine characteristics serve to define life.
7.1.252	Organisms are highly organized, coordinated structures that consist of one or more cells.
7.1.253	Even very simple, single-celled organisms are remarkably complex: inside each cell, atoms make up molecules; these in turn make up cell organelles and other cellular inclusions.
7.1.254	In multicellular organisms (Figure 1.10), similar cells form tissues.
7.1.255	Tissues, in turn, collaborate to create organs (body structures with a distinct function).
7.1.256	Organs work together to form organ systems.
7.1.257	Figure 1.11
7.1.258	The leaves of this sensitive plant (Mimosa pudica) will instantly droop and fold when touched.
7.1.259	After a few minutes, the plant returns to normal.
7.1.260	(credit:
7.1.261	Alex Lomas) Organisms respond to diverse stimuli.
7.1.262	For example, plants can bend toward a source of light, climb on fences and walls, or respond to touch (Figure 1.11).
7.1.263	Even tiny bacteria can move toward or away from chemicals (a process called chemotaxis) or light (phototaxis).
7.1.264	Movement toward a stimulus is considered a positive response, while movement away from a stimulus is considered a negative response.
7.1.265	Reproduction Single-celled organisms reproduce by first duplicating their DNA, and then dividing it equally as the cell prepares to divide to form two new cells.
7.1.266	Multicellular organisms often produce specialized reproductive germline cells that will form new individuals.
7.1.267	When reproduction occurs, genes containing DNA are passed along to an organism’s offspring.
7.1.268	These genes ensure that the offspring will belong to the same species and will have similar characteristics, such as size and shape.
7.1.269	Growth and Development Organisms grow and develop following specific instructions coded for by their genes.
7.1.270	These genes provide instructions that will direct cellular growth and development, ensuring that a species’ young (Figure 1.12) will grow up to exhibit many of the same characteristics as its parents.
7.1.271	Figure 1.12
7.1.272	Although no two look alike, these kittens have inherited genes from both parents and share many of the same characteristics.
7.1.273	(credit: Rocky Mountain Feline Rescue) Regulation Even the smallest organisms are complex and require multiple regulatory mechanisms to coordinate internal functions, respond to stimuli, and cope with environmental stresses.
7.1.274	Two examples of internal functions regulated in an organism are nutrient transport and blood flow.
7.1.275	Organs (groups of tissues working together) perform specific functions, such as carrying oxygen throughout the body, removing wastes, delivering nutrients to every cell, and cooling the body.
7.1.276	Figure 1.13 Polar bears (Ursus maritimus) and other mammals living in ice-covered regions maintain their body temperature by generating heat and reducing heat loss through thick fur and a dense layer of fat under their skin.
7.1.277	(credit:
7.1.278	“longhorndave”/Flickr)
7.1.279	In order to function properly, cells need to have appropriate conditions such as proper temperature, pH, and appropriate concentration of diverse chemicals.
7.1.280	These conditions may, however, change from one moment to the next.
7.1.281	Organisms are able to maintain internal conditions within a narrow range almost constantly, despite environmental changes, through homeostasis (literally, “steady state”)—the ability of an organism to maintain constant internal conditions.
7.1.282	For example, an organism needs to regulate body temperature through a process known as thermoregulation.
7.1.283	Organisms that live in cold climates, such as the polar bear (Figure 1.13), have body structures that help them withstand low temperatures and conserve body heat.
7.1.284	Structures that aid in this type of insulation include fur, feathers, blubber, and fat.
7.1.285	In hot climates, Figure 1.14
7.1.286	The California condor (Gymnogyps californianus) uses chemical energy derived from food to power flight.
7.1.287	California condors are an endangered species; this bird has a wing tag that helps biologists identify the individual.
7.1.288	(credit: Pacific Southwest Region U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service)
7.1.289	All organisms use a source of energy for their metabolic activities.
7.1.290	Some organisms capture energy from the sun and convert it into chemical energy in food; others use chemical energy in molecules they take in as food (Figure 1.14).
7.1.291	Levels of Organization of Living Things Living things are highly organized and structured, following a hierarchy that can be examined on a scale from small to large.
7.1.292	The atom is the smallest and most fundamental unit of matter.
7.1.293	It consists of a nucleus surrounded by electrons.
7.1.294	Atoms form molecules.
7.1.295	A molecule is a chemical structure consisting of at least two atoms held together by one or more chemical bonds.
7.1.296	Many molecules that are biologically important are macromolecules, large molecules that are typically formed by polymerization (a polymer is a large molecule that is made by combining smaller units called monomers, which are simpler than macromolecules).
7.1.297	An example of a macromolecule is deoxyribonucleic acid (DNA)
7.1.298	(Figure 1.15), which contains the instructions for the structure and functioning of all living organisms.
7.1.299	Some cells contain aggregates of macromolecules surrounded by membranes; these are called organelles.
7.1.300	Organelles are small structures that exist within cells.
7.1.301	Examples of organelles include mitochondria and chloroplasts, which carry out indispensable functions: mitochondria produce energy to power the cell, while chloroplasts enable green plants to utilize the energy in sunlight to make sugars.
7.1.302	All living things are made of cells; the cell itself is the smallest fundamental unit of structure and function in living organisms.
7.1.303	(This requirement is why viruses are not considered living: they are not made of cells.
7.1.304	To make new viruses, they have to invade and hijack the reproductive mechanism of a living cell; only then can they obtain the materials they need to reproduce.)
7.1.305	Some organisms consist of a single cell and others are multicellular.
7.1.306	Cells are classified as prokaryotic or eukaryotic.
7.1.307	Prokaryotes are single-celled or colonial organisms that do not have membranebound nuclei; in contrast, the cells of eukaryotes do have membrane-bound organelles and a membrane-bound nucleus.
7.1.308	In larger organisms, cells combine to make tissues, which are groups of similar cells carrying out similar or related functions.
7.1.309	Organs are collections of tissues grouped together performing a common function.
7.1.310	Organs are present not only in animals but also in plants.
7.1.311	An organ system is a higher level of organization that consists of functionally related organs.
7.1.312	Mammals have many organ systems.
7.1.313	For instance, the circulatory system transports blood through the body and to and from the lungs; it includes organs such as the heart and blood vessels.
7.1.314	Organisms are individual living entities.
7.1.315	For example, each tree in a forest is an organism.
7.1.316	Single-celled prokaryotes and single-celled eukaryotes are also considered organisms and are typically referred to as microorganisms.
7.1.317	All the individuals of a species living within a specific area are collectively called a population.
7.1.318	For example, a forest may include many pine trees.
7.1.319	All of these pine trees represent the population of pine trees in this forest.
7.1.320	Different populations may live in the same specific area.
7.1.321	For example, the forest with the pine trees includes populations of flowering plants and also insects and microbial populations.
7.1.322	A community is the sum of populations inhabiting a particular area.
7.1.323	For instance, all of the trees, flowers, insects, and other populations in a forest form the forest’s community.
7.1.324	The forest itself is an ecosystem.
7.1.325	An ecosystem consists of all the living things in a particular area together with the abiotic, non-living parts of that environment such as nitrogen in the soil or rain water.
7.1.326	At the highest level of organization (Figure 1.16), the biosphere is the collection of all ecosystems, and it represents the zones of life on earth.
7.1.327	It includes land, water, and even the atmosphere to a certain extent.
7.1.328	The biological levels of organization of living things are shown.
7.1.329	From a single organelle to the entire biosphere, living organisms are parts of a highly structured hierarchy.

7.1.343	”:
7.1.344	modification of work by The fact that biology, as a science, has such a broad scope has to do with the tremendous diversity of life on earth.
7.1.345	The source of this diversity is evolution, the process of gradual change during which new species arise from older species.
7.1.346	Evolutionary biologists study the evolution of living things in everything from the microscopic world to ecosystems.
7.1.347	The evolution of various life forms on Earth can be summarized in a phylogenetic tree (Figure 1.17).
7.1.348	A phylogenetic tree is a diagram showing the evolutionary relationships among biological species based on similarities and differences in genetic or physical traits or both.
7.1.349	A phylogenetic tree is composed of nodes and branches.
7.1.350	The internal nodes represent ancestors and are points in evolution when, based on scientific evidence, an ancestor is thought to have diverged to form two new species.
7.1.351	The length of each branch is proportional to the time elapsed since the split.
7.1.352	This phylogenetic tree was constructed by microbiologist Carl Woese using data obtained from sequencing ribosomal RNA genes.
7.1.353	The tree shows the separation of living organisms into three domains: Bacteria, Archaea, and Eukarya.
7.1.354	Bacteria and Archaea are prokaryotes, single-celled organisms lacking intracellular organelles.
7.1.355	(credit: Eric Gaba; NASA Astrobiology Institute)Carl Woese and the Phylogenetic Tree
7.1.356	In the past, biologists grouped living organisms into five kingdoms: animals, plants, fungi, protists, and bacteria.
7.1.357	The organizational scheme was based mainly on physical features, as opposed to physiology, biochemistry, or molecular biology, all of which are used by modern systematics.
7.1.358	The pioneering work of American microbiologist Carl Woese in the early 1970s has shown, however, that life on Earth has evolved along three lineages, now called domains—Bacteria, Archaea, and Eukarya.
7.1.359	The first two are prokaryotic cells with microbes that lack membrane-enclosed nuclei and organelles.
7.1.360	The third domain contains the eukaryotes and includes unicellular microorganisms together with the four original kingdoms (excluding bacteria).
7.1.361	Woese defined Archaea as a new domain, and this resulted in a new taxonomic tree (Figure 1.17).
7.1.362	Many organisms belonging to the Archaea domain live under extreme conditions and are called extremophiles.
7.1.363	To construct his tree, Woese used genetic relationships rather than similarities based on morphology (shape).
7.1.364	Woese’s tree was constructed from comparative sequencing of the genes that are universally distributed, present in every organism, and conserved (meaning that these genes have remained essentially unchanged throughout evolution).
7.1.365	Woese’s approach was revolutionary because comparisons of physical features are insufficient to differentiate between the prokaryotes that appear fairly similar in spite of their tremendous biochemical diversity and genetic variability (Figure 1.18).
7.1.366	The comparison of homologous DNA and RNA sequences provided Woese with a sensitive device that revealed the extensive variability of prokaryotes, and which justified the separation of the prokaryotes into two domains: bacteria and archaea.
7.1.367	These images represent different domains.
7.1.368	The (a) bacteria in this micrograph belong to Domain Bacteria, while the (b) extremophiles (not visible) living in this hot vent belong to Domain Archaea.
7.1.369	Both the (c) sunflower and (d) lion are part of Domain Eukarya.
7.1.370	(credit a: modification of work by Drew March; credit b: modification of work by Steve Jurvetson; credit c: modification of work by Michael Arrighi; credit d:
7.1.371	modification of work by Leszek Leszcynski)Branches of Biological Study
7.1.372	The scope of biology is broad and therefore contains many branches and subdisciplines.
7.1.373	Biologists may pursue one of those subdisciplines and work in a more focused field.
7.1.374	For instance, molecular biology and biochemistry study biological processes at the molecular and chemical level, including interactions among molecules such as DNA, RNA, and proteins, as well as the way they are regulated.
7.1.375	Microbiology, the study of microorganisms, is the study of the structure and function of single-celled organisms.
7.1.376	It is quite a broad branch itself, and depending on the subject of study, there are also microbial physiologists, ecologists, and geneticists, among others.
7.1.377	Forensic science is the application of science to answer questions related to the law.
7.1.378	Biologists as well as chemists and biochemists can be forensic scientists.
7.1.379	Forensic scientists provide scientific evidence for use in courts, and their job involves examining trace materials associated with crimes.
7.1.380	Interest in forensic science has increased in the last few years, possibly because of popular television shows that feature forensic scientists on the job.
7.1.381	Also, the development of molecular techniques and the establishment of DNA databases have expanded the types of work that forensic scientists can do.
7.1.382	Their job activities are primarily related to crimes against people such as murder, rape, and assault.
7.1.383	Their work involves analyzing samples such as hair, blood, and other body fluids and also processing DNA (Figure 1.19) found in many different environments and materials.
7.1.384	Forensic scientists also analyze other biological evidence left at crime scenes, such as insect larvae or pollen grains.
7.1.385	Students who want to pursue careers in forensic science will most likely be required to take chemistry and biology courses as well as some intensive math courses.
7.1.386	Another field of biological study, neurobiology, studies the biology of the nervous system, and although it is considered a branch of biology, it is also recognized as an interdisciplinary field of study known as neuroscience.
7.1.387	Because of its interdisciplinary nature, this subdiscipline studies different functions of the nervous system using molecular, cellular, developmental, medical, and computational approaches.
7.1.388	Paleontology, another branch of biology, uses fossils to study life’s history (Figure 1.20).
7.1.389	Zoology and botany are the study of animals and plants, respectively.
7.1.390	Biologists can also specialize as biotechnologists, ecologists, or physiologists, to name just a few areas.
7.1.391	This is just a small sample of the many fields that biologists can pursue.
7.1.392	Biology is the culmination of the achievements of the natural sciences from their inception to today.
7.1.393	Excitingly, it is the cradle of emerging sciences, such as the biology of brain activity, genetic engineering of custom organisms, and the biology of evolution that uses the laboratory tools of molecular biology to retrace the earliest stages of life on earth.
7.1.394	A scan of news headlines—whether reporting on immunizations, a newly discovered species, sports doping, or a genetically-modified food—demonstrates the way biology is active in and important to our everyday world.  
7.2.0	Atoms are the building blocks of molecules found in the universe—air, soil, water, rocks . . .
7.2.1	and also the cells of all living organisms.
7.2.2	In this model of an organic molecule, the atoms of carbon (black), hydrogen (white), nitrogen (blue), oxygen (red), and sulfur (yellow) are shown in proportional atomic size.
7.2.3	The silver rods indicate chemical bonds.
7.2.4	Elements in various combinations comprise all matter, including living things.
7.2.5	Some of the most abundant elements in living organisms include carbon, hydrogen, nitrogen, oxygen, sulfur, and phosphorus.
7.2.6	These form the nucleic acids, proteins, carbohydrates, and lipids that are the fundamental components of living matter.
7.2.7	Biologists must understand these important building blocks and the unique structures of the atoms that make up molecules, allowing for the formation of cells, tissues, organ systems, and entire organisms.
7.2.8	All biological processes follow the laws of physics and chemistry, so in order to understand how biological systems work, it is important to understand the underlying physics and chemistry.
7.2.9	For example, the flow of blood within the circulatory system follows the laws of physics that regulate the modes of fluid flow.
7.2.10	The breakdown of the large, complex molecules of food into smaller molecules—and the conversion of these to release energy to be stored in adenosine triphosphate (ATP)—is a series of chemical reactions that follow chemical laws.
7.2.11	The properties of water and the formation of hydrogen bonds are key to understanding living processes.
7.2.12	Recognizing the properties of acids and bases is important, for example, to our understanding of the digestive process.
7.2.13	Therefore, the fundamentals of physics and chemistry are important for gaining insight into biological processes.
7.2.14	At its most fundamental level, life is made up of matter.
7.2.15	Matter is any substance that occupies space and has mass.
7.2.16	Elements are unique forms of matter with specific chemical and physical properties that cannot be broken down into smaller substances by ordinary chemical reactions.
7.2.17	There are 118 elements, but only 92 occur naturally.
7.2.18	The remaining elements are synthesized in laboratories and are unstable.
7.2.19	Each element is designated by its chemical symbol, which is a single capital letter or, when the first letter is already “taken” by another element, a combination of two letters.
7.2.20	Some elements follow the English term for the element, such as C for carbon and Ca for calcium.
7.2.21	Other elements’ chemical symbols derive from their Latin names; for example, the symbol for sodium is Na, referring to natrium, the Latin word for sodium.
7.2.22	The four elements common to all living organisms are oxygen (O), carbon (C), hydrogen (H), and nitrogen (N).
7.2.23	In the nonliving world, elements are found in different proportions, and some elements common to living organisms are relatively rare on the earth as a whole, as shown in Table 2.1.
7.2.24	For example, the atmosphere is rich in nitrogen and oxygen but contains little carbon and hydrogen, while the earth’s crust, although it contains oxygen and a small amount of hydrogen, has little nitrogen and carbon.
7.2.25	In spite of their differences in abundance, all elements and the chemical reactions between them obey the same chemical and physical laws regardless of whether they are a part of the living or non-living world.
7.2.26	To understand how elements come together, we must first discuss the smallest component or building block of an element, the atom.
7.2.27	An atom is the smallest unit of matter that retains all of the chemical properties of an element.
7.2.28	For example, one gold atom has all of the properties of gold in that it is a solid metal at room temperature.
7.2.29	A gold coin is simply a very large number of gold atoms molded into the shape of a coin and containing small amounts of other elements known as impurities.
7.2.30	Gold atoms cannot be broken down into anything smaller while still retaining the properties of gold.
7.2.31	An atom is composed of two regions: the nucleus, which is in the center of the atom and contains protons and neutrons, and the outermost region of the atom which holds its electrons in orbit around the nucleus, as illustrated in Figure 2.2.
7.2.32	Atoms contain protons, electrons, and neutrons, among other subatomic particles.
7.2.33	The only exception is hydrogen (H), which is made of one proton and one electron with no neutrons.
7.2.34	Elements, such as helium, depicted here, are made up of atoms.
7.2.35	Atoms are made up of protons and neutrons located within the nucleus, with electrons in orbitals surrounding the nucleus.
7.2.36	Protons and neutrons have approximately the same mass, about 1.67 Å~ 10-24 grams.
7.2.37	Scientists arbitrarily define this amount of mass as one atomic mass unit (amu) or one Dalton, as shown in Table 2.2.
7.2.38	Although similar in mass, protons and neutrons differ in their electric charge.
7.2.39	A proton is positively charged whereas a neutron is uncharged.
7.2.40	Therefore, the number of neutrons in an atom contributes significantly to its mass, but not to its charge.
7.2.41	Electrons are much smaller in mass than protons, weighing only 9.11 Å~ 10-28 grams, or about 1/1800 of an atomic mass unit.
7.2.42	Hence, they do not contribute much to an element’s overall atomic mass.
7.2.43	Therefore, when considering atomic mass, it is customary to ignore the mass of any electrons and calculate the atom’s mass based on the number of protons and neutrons alone.
7.2.44	Although not significant contributors to mass, electrons do contribute greatly to the atom’s charge, as each electron has a negative charge equal to the positive charge of a proton.
7.2.45	In uncharged, neutral atoms, the number of electrons orbiting the nucleus is equal to the number of protons inside the nucleus.
7.2.46	In these atoms, the positive and negative charges cancel each other out, leading to an atom with no net charge.
7.2.47	Accounting for the sizes of protons, neutrons, and electrons, most of the volume of an atom—greater than 99 percent—is, in fact, empty space.
7.2.48	With all this empty space, one might ask why so-called solid objects do not just pass through one another.
7.2.49	The reason they do not is that the electrons that surround all atoms are negatively charged and negative charges repel each other.
7.2.50	Atoms of each element contain a characteristic number of protons and electrons.
7.2.51	The number of protons determines an element’s atomic number and is used to distinguish one element from another.
7.2.52	The number of neutrons is variable, resulting in isotopes, which are different forms of the same atom that vary only in the number of neutrons they possess.
7.2.53	Together, the number of protons and the number of neutrons determine an element’s mass number, as illustrated in Figure 2.3.
7.2.54	Note that the small contribution of mass from electrons is disregarded in calculating the mass number.
7.2.55	This approximation of mass can be used to easily calculate how many neutrons an element has by simply subtracting the number of protons from the mass number.
7.2.56	Since an element’s isotopes will have slightly different mass numbers, scientists also determine the atomic mass, which is the calculated mean of the mass number for its naturally occurring isotopes.
7.2.57	Often, the resulting number contains a fraction.
7.2.58	For example, the atomic mass of chlorine (Cl) is 35.45 because chlorine is composed of several isotopes, some (the majority) with atomic mass 35 (17 protons and 18 neutrons) and some with atomic mass 37 (17 protons and 20 neutrons).
7.2.59	Isotopes are different forms of an element that have the same number of protons but a different number of neutrons.
7.2.60	Some elements—such as carbon, potassium, and uranium—have naturally occurring isotopes.
7.2.61	Carbon-12 contains six protons, six neutrons, and six electrons; therefore, it has a mass number of 12 (six protons and six neutrons).
7.2.62	Carbon-14 contains six protons, eight neutrons, and six electrons; its atomic mass is 14 (six protons and eight neutrons).
7.2.63	These two alternate forms of carbon are isotopes.
7.2.64	Some isotopes may emit neutrons, protons, and electrons, and attain a more stable atomic configuration (lower level of potential energy); these are radioactive isotopes, or radioisotopes.
7.2.65	Radioactive decay (carbon-14 losing neutrons to eventually become carbon-12) describes the energy loss that occurs when an unstable atom’s nucleus releases radiation.
7.2.66	Carbon is normally present in the atmosphere in the form of gaseous compounds like carbon dioxide and methane.
7.2.67	Carbon-14 (14C) is a naturally occurring radioisotope that is created in the atmosphere from atmospheric 14N (nitrogen) by the addition of a neutron and the loss of a proton because of cosmic rays.
7.2.68	This is a continuous process, so more 14C is always being created.
7.2.69	As a living organism incorporates 14C initially as carbon dioxide fixed in the process of photosynthesis, the relative amount of 14C in its body is equal to the concentration of 14C in the atmosphere.
7.2.70	When an organism dies, it is no longer ingesting 14C, so the ratio between 14C and 12C will decline as 14C decays gradually to 14N by a process called beta decay—the emission of electrons or positrons.
7.2.71	This decay gives off energy in a slow process.
7.2.72	After approximately 5,730 years, half of the starting concentration of 14C will have been converted back to 14N.
7.2.73	The time it takes for half of the original concentration of an isotope to decay back to its more stable form is called its half-life.
7.2.74	Because the half-life of 14C is long, it is used to date formerly living objects such as old bones or wood.
7.2.75	Comparing the ratio of the 14C concentration found in an object to the amount of 14C detected in the atmosphere, the amount of the isotope that has not yet decayed can be determined.
7.2.76	On the basis of this amount, the age of the material, such as the pygmy mammoth shown in Figure 2.4, can be calculated with accuracy if it is not much older than about 50,000 years.
7.2.77	Other elements have isotopes with different half lives.
7.2.78	For example, 40K (potassium-40) has a half-life of 1.25 billion years, and 235U (Uranium 235) has a half-life of about 700 million years.
7.2.79	Through the use of radiometric dating, scientists can study the age of fossils or other remains of extinct organisms to understand how organisms have evolved from earlier species.
7.2.80	The age of carbon-containing remains less than about 50,000 years old, such as this pygmy mammoth, can be determined using carbon dating.
7.2.81	The different elements are organized and displayed in the periodic table.
7.2.82	Devised by Russian chemist Dmitri Mendeleev (1834–1907) in 1869, the table groups elements that, although unique, share certain chemical properties with other elements.
7.2.83	The properties of elements are responsible for their physical state at room temperature: they may be gases, solids, or liquids.
7.2.84	Elements also have specific chemical reactivity, the ability to combine and to chemically bond with each other.
7.2.85	In the periodic table, shown in Figure 2.5, the elements are organized and displayed according to their atomic number and are arranged in a series of rows and columns based on shared chemical and physical properties.
7.2.86	In addition to providing the atomic number for each element, the periodic table also displays the element’s atomic mass.
7.2.87	Looking at carbon, for example, its symbol (C) and name appear, as well as its atomic number of six (in the upper left-hand corner) and its atomic mass of 12.11.
7.2.88	The periodic table shows the atomic mass and atomic number of each element.
7.2.89	The atomic number appears above the symbol for the element and the approximate atomic mass appears below it.
7.2.90	The periodic table groups elements according to chemical properties.
7.2.91	The differences in chemical reactivity between the elements are based on the number and spatial distribution of an atom’s electrons.
7.2.92	Atoms that chemically react and bond to each other form molecules.
7.2.93	Molecules are simply two or more atoms chemically bonded together.
7.2.94	Logically, when two atoms chemically bond to form a molecule, their electrons, which form the outermost region of each atom, come together first as the atoms form a chemical bond.
7.2.95	It should be stressed that there is a connection between the number of protons in an element, the atomic number that distinguishes one element from another, and the number of electrons it has.
7.2.96	In all electrically neutral atoms, the number of electrons is the same as the number of protons.
7.2.97	Thus, each element, at least when electrically neutral, has a characteristic number of electrons equal to its atomic number.
7.2.98	An early model of the atom was developed in 1913 by Danish scientist Niels Bohr (1885–1962).
7.2.99	The Bohr model shows the atom as a central nucleus containing protons and neutrons, with the electrons in circular orbitals at specific distances from the nucleus, as illustrated in Figure 2.6.
7.2.100	These orbits form electron shells or energy levels, which are a way of visualizing the number of electrons in the outermost shells.
7.2.101	These energy levels are designated by a number and the symbol
7.2.102	“
7.2.103	n.”
7.2.104	For example, 1n represents the first energy level located closest to the nucleus.
7.2.105	The Bohr model was developed by Niels Bohrs in 1913.
7.2.106	In this model, electrons exist within principal shells.
7.2.107	An electron normally exists in the lowest energy shell available, which is the one closest to the nucleus.
7.2.108	Energy from a photon of light can bump it up to a higher energy shell, but this situation is unstable, and the electron quickly decays back to the ground state.
7.2.109	In the process, a photon of light is released.
7.2.110	Electrons fill orbitals in a consistent order: they first fill the orbitals closest to the nucleus, then they continue to fill orbitals of increasing energy further from the nucleus.
7.2.111	If there are multiple orbitals of equal energy, they will be filled with one electron in each energy level before a second electron is added.
7.2.112	The electrons of the outermost energy level determine the energetic stability of the atom and its tendency to form chemical bonds with other atoms to form molecules.
7.2.113	Under standard conditions, atoms fill the inner shells first, often resulting in a variable number of electrons in the outermost shell.
7.2.114	The innermost shell has a maximum of two electrons but the next two electron shells can each have a maximum of eight electrons.
7.2.115	This is known as the octet rule, which states, with the exception of the innermost shell, that atoms are more stable energetically when they have eight electrons in their valence shell, the outermost electron shell.
7.2.116	Examples of some neutral atoms and their electron configurations are shown in Figure 2.7.
7.2.117	Notice that in this Figure 2.7, helium has a complete outer electron shell, with two electrons filling its first and only shell.
7.2.118	Similarly, neon has a complete outer 2n shell containing eight electrons.
7.2.119	In contrast, chlorine and sodium have seven and one in their outer shells, respectively, but theoretically they would be more energetically stable if they followed the octet rule and had eight.
7.2.120	Bohr diagrams indicate how many electrons fill each principal shell.
7.2.121	Group 18 elements (helium, neon, and argon are shown) have a full outer, or valence, shell.
7.2.122	A full valence shell is the most stable electron configuration.
7.2.123	Elements in other groups have partially filled valence shells and gain or lose electrons to achieve a stable electron configuration.
7.2.124	An atom may give, take, or share electrons with another atom to achieve a full valence shell, the most stable electron configuration.
7.2.125	Looking at this figure, how many electrons do elements in group 1 need to lose in order to achieve a stable electron configuration?
7.2.126	How many electrons do elements in groups 14 and 17 need to gain to achieve a stable configuration?
7.2.127	Understanding that the organization of the periodic table is based on the total number of protons (and electrons) helps us know how electrons are distributed among the outer shell.
7.2.128	The periodic table is arranged in columns and rows based on the number of electrons and where these electrons are located.
7.2.129	Take a closer look at the some of the elements in the table’s far right column in Figure 2.5.
7.2.130	The group 18 atoms helium (He), neon (Ne), and argon (Ar) all have filled outer electron shells, making it unnecessary for them to share electrons with other atoms to attain stability; they are highly stable as single atoms.
7.2.131	Their non-reactivity has resulted in their being named the inert gases (or noble gases).
7.2.132	Compare this to the group 1 elements in the left-hand column.
7.2.133	These elements, including hydrogen (H), lithium (Li), and sodium (Na), all have one electron in their outermost shells.
7.2.134	That means that they can achieve a stable configuration and a filled outer shell by donating or sharing one electron with another atom or a molecule such as water.
7.2.135	Hydrogen will donate or share its electron to achieve this configuration, while lithium and sodium will donate their electron to become stable.
7.2.136	As a result of losing a negatively charged electron, they become positively charged ions.
7.2.137	Group 17 elements, including fluorine and chlorine, have seven electrons in their outmost shells, so they tend to fill this shell with an electron from other atoms or molecules, making them negatively charged ions.
7.2.138	Group 14 elements, of which carbon is the most important to living systems, have four electrons in their outer shell allowing them to make several covalent bonds (discussed below) with other atoms.
7.2.139	Thus, the columns of the periodic table represent the potential shared state of these elements’ outer electron shells that is responsible for their similar chemical characteristics.
7.2.140	Although useful to explain the reactivity and chemical bonding of certain elements, the Bohr model of the atom does not accurately reflect how electrons are spatially distributed surrounding the nucleus.
7.2.141	They do not circle the nucleus like the earth orbits the sun, but are found in electron orbitals.
7.2.142	These relatively complex shapes result from the fact that electrons behave not just like particles, but also like waves.
7.2.143	Mathematical equations from quantum mechanics known as wave functions can predict within a certain level of probability where an electron might be at any given time.
7.2.144	The area where an electron is most likely to be found is called its orbital.
7.2.145	Recall that the Bohr model depicts an atom’s electron shell configuration.
7.2.146	Within each electron shell are subshells, and each subshell has a specified number of orbitals containing electrons.
7.2.147	While it is impossible to calculate exactly where an electron is located, scientists know that it is most probably located within its orbital path.
7.2.148	Subshells are designated by the letter s, p, d, and f.
7.2.149	The s subshell is spherical in shape and has one orbital.
7.2.150	Principal shell 1n has only a single s orbital, which can hold two electrons.
7.2.151	Principal shell 2n has one s and one p subshell, and can hold a total of eight electrons.
7.2.152	The p subshell has three dumbbell-shaped orbitals, as illustrated in Figure 2.8.
7.2.153	Subshells d and f have more complex shapes and contain five and seven orbitals, respectively.
7.2.154	These are not shown in the illustration.
7.2.155	Principal shell 3n has s, p, and d subshells and can hold 18 electrons.
7.2.156	Principal shell 4n has s, p, d and f orbitals and can hold 32 electrons.
7.2.157	Moving away from the nucleus, the number of electrons and orbitals found in the energy levels increases.
7.2.158	Progressing from one atom to the next in the periodic table, the electron structure can be worked out by fitting an extra electron into the next available orbital.
7.2.159	The s subshells are shaped like spheres.
7.2.160	Both the 1n and 2n principal shells have an s orbital, but the size of the sphere is larger in the 2n orbital.
7.2.161	Each sphere is a single orbital.
7.2.162	p subshells are made up of three dumbbellshaped orbitals.
7.2.163	Principal shell 2n has a p subshell, but shell 1 does not.
7.2.164	The closest orbital to the nucleus, called the 1s orbital, can hold up to two electrons.
7.2.165	This orbital is equivalent to the innermost electron shell of the Bohr model of the atom.
7.2.166	It is called the 1s orbital because it is spherical around the nucleus.
7.2.167	The 1s orbital is the closest orbital to the nucleus, and it is always filled first, before any other orbital can be filled.
7.2.168	Hydrogen has one electron; therefore, it has only one spot within the 1s orbital occupied.
7.2.169	This is designated as 1s1, where the superscripted 1 refers to the one electron within the 1s orbital.
7.2.170	Helium has two electrons; therefore, it can completely fill the 1s orbital with its two electrons.
7.2.171	This is designated as 1s2, referring to the two electrons of helium in the 1s orbital.
7.2.172	On the periodic table Figure 2.5, hydrogen and helium are the only two elements in the first row (period); this is because they only have electrons in their first shell, the 1s orbital.
7.2.173	Hydrogen and helium are the only two elements that have the 1s and no other electron orbitals in the electrically neutral state.
7.2.174	The second electron shell may contain eight electrons.
7.2.175	This shell contains another spherical s orbital and three “
7.2.176	dumbbell” shaped p orbitals, each of which can hold two electrons, as shown in Figure 2.8.
7.2.177	After the 1s orbital is filled, the second electron shell is filled, first filling its 2s orbital and then its three p orbitals.
7.2.178	When filling the p orbitals, each takes a single electron; once each p orbital has an electron, a second may be added.
7.2.179	Lithium (Li) contains three electrons that occupy the first and second shells.
7.2.180	Two electrons fill the 1s orbital, and the third electron then fills the 2s orbital.
7.2.181	Its electron configuration is 1s22s1.
7.2.182	Neon (Ne), on the other hand, has a total of ten electrons: two are in its innermost 1s orbital and eight fill its second shell (two each in the 2s and three p orbitals); thus, it is an inert gas and energetically stable as a single atom that will rarely form a chemical bond with other atoms.
7.2.183	Larger elements have additional orbitals, making up the third electron shell.
7.2.184	While the concepts of electron shells and orbitals are closely related, orbitals provide a more accurate depiction of the electron configuration of an atom because the orbital model specifies the different shapes and special orientations of all the places that electrons may occupy.
7.2.185	All elements are most stable when their outermost shell is filled with electrons according to the octet rule.
7.2.186	This is because it is energetically favorable for atoms to be in that configuration and it makes them stable.
7.2.187	However, since not all elements have enough electrons to fill their outermost shells, atoms form chemical bonds with other atoms thereby obtaining the electrons they need to attain a stable electron configuration.
7.2.188	When two or more atoms chemically bond with each other, the resultant chemical structure is a molecule.
7.2.189	The familiar water molecule, H2O, consists of two hydrogen atoms and one oxygen atom; these bond together to form water, as illustrated in Figure 2.9.
7.2.190	Atoms can form molecules by donating, accepting, or sharing electrons to fill their outer shells.
7.2.191	Two or more atoms may bond with each other to form a molecule.
7.2.192	When two hydrogens and an oxygen share electrons via covalent bonds, a water molecule is formed.
7.2.193	Chemical reactions occur when two or more atoms bond together to form molecules or when bonded atoms are broken apart.
7.2.194	The substances used in the beginning of a chemical reaction are called the reactants (usually found on the left side of a chemical equation), and the substances found at the end of the reaction are known as the products (usually found on the right side of a chemical equation).
7.2.195	An arrow is typically drawn between the reactants and products to indicate the direction of the chemical reaction; this direction is not always a “one-way street.
7.2.196	”
7.2.197	For the creation of the water molecule shown above, the chemical equation would be: An example of a simple chemical reaction is the breaking down of hydrogen peroxide molecules, each of which consists of two hydrogen atoms bonded to two oxygen atoms (H2O2).
7.2.198	The reactant hydrogen peroxide is broken down into water, containing one oxygen atom bound to two hydrogen atoms (H2O), and oxygen, which consists of two bonded oxygen atoms (O2).
7.2.199	In the equation below, the reaction includes two hydrogen peroxide molecules and two water molecules.
7.2.200	This is an example of a balanced chemical equation, wherein the number of atoms of each element is the same on each side of the equation.
7.2.201	According to the law of conservation of matter, the number of atoms before and after a chemical reaction should be equal, such that no atoms are, under normal circumstances, created or destroyed.
7.2.202	Even though all of the reactants and products of this reaction are molecules (each atom remains bonded to at least one other atom), in this reaction only hydrogen peroxide and water are representatives of compounds: they contain atoms of more than one type of element.
7.2.203	Molecular oxygen, on the other hand, as shown in Figure 2.10,consists of two doubly bonded oxygen atoms and is not classified as a compound but as a mononuclear molecule.
7.2.204	The oxygen atoms in an O2 molecule are joined by a double bond.
7.2.205	Some chemical reactions, such as the one shown above, can proceed in one direction until the reactants are all used up.
7.2.206	The equations that describe these reactions contain a unidirectional arrow and are irreversible.
7.2.207	Reversible reactions are those that can go in either direction.
7.2.208	In reversible reactions, reactants are turned into products, but when the concentration of product goes beyond a certain threshold (characteristic of the particular reaction), some of these products will be converted back into reactants; at this point, the designations of products and reactants are reversed.
7.2.209	This back and forth continues until a certain relative balance between reactants and products occurs—a state called equilibrium.
7.2.210	These situations of reversible reactions are often denoted by a chemical equation with a double headed arrow pointing towards both the reactants and products.
7.2.211	For example, in human blood, excess hydrogen ions (H+) bind to bicarbonate ions (HCO3 -) forming an equilibrium state with carbonic acid (H2CO3).
7.2.212	If carbonic acid were added to this system, some of it would be converted to bicarbonate and hydrogen ions.
7.2.213	In biological reactions, however, equilibrium is rarely obtained because the concentrations of the reactants or products or both are constantly changing, often with a product of one reaction being a reactant for another.
7.2.214	To return to the example of excess hydrogen ions in the blood, the formation of carbonic acid will be the major direction of the reaction.
7.2.215	However, the carbonic acid can also leave the body as carbon dioxide gas (via exhalation) instead of being converted back to bicarbonate ion, thus driving the reaction to the right by the chemical law known as law of mass action.
7.2.216	These reactions are important for maintaining the homeostasis of our blood.
7.2.217	Some atoms are more stable when they gain or lose an electron (or possibly two) and form ions.
7.2.218	This fills their outermost electron shell and makes them energetically more stable.
7.2.219	Because the number of electrons does not equal the number of protons, each ion has a net charge.
7.2.220	Cations are positive ions that are formed by losing electrons.
7.2.221	Negative ions are formed by gaining electrons and are called anions.
7.2.222	Anions are designated by their elemental name being altered to end in “
7.2.223	-ide”: the anion of chlorine is called chloride, and the anion of sulfur is called sulfide, for example.
7.2.224	This movement of electrons from one element to another is referred to as electron transfer.
7.2.225	As Figure 2.11 illustrates, sodium
7.2.226	(Na) only has one electron in its outer electron shell.
7.2.227	It takes less energy for sodium to donate that one electron than it does to accept seven more electrons to fill the outer shell.
7.2.228	If sodium loses an electron, it now has 11 protons, 11 neutrons, and only 10 electrons, leaving it with an overall charge of +1.
7.2.229	It is now referred to as a sodium ion.
7.2.230	Chlorine (Cl) in its lowest energy state (called the ground state) has seven electrons in its outer shell.
7.2.231	Again, it is more energy-efficient for chlorine to gain one electron than to lose seven.
7.2.232	Therefore, it tends to gain an electron to create an ion with 17 protons, 17 neutrons, and 18 electrons, giving it a net negative (–1) charge.
7.2.233	It is now referred to as a chloride ion.
7.2.234	In this example, sodium will donate its one electron to empty its shell, and chlorine will accept that electron to fill its shell.
7.2.235	Both ions now satisfy the octet rule and have complete outermost shells.
7.2.236	Because the number of electrons is no longer equal to the number of protons, each is now an ion and has a +1 (sodium cation) or –1 (chloride anion) charge.
7.2.237	Note that these transactions can normally only take place simultaneously: in order for a sodium atom to lose an electron, it must be in the presence of a suitable recipient like a chlorine atom.
7.2.238	In the formation of an ionic compound, metals lose electrons and nonmetals gain electrons to achieve an octet.
7.2.239	Ionic bonds are formed between ions with opposite charges.
7.2.240	For instance, positively charged sodium ions and negatively charged chloride ions bond together to make crystals of sodium chloride, or table salt, creating a crystalline molecule with zero net charge.
7.2.241	Certain salts are referred to in physiology as electrolytes (including sodium, potassium, and calcium), ions necessary for nerve impulse conduction, muscle contractions and water balance.
7.2.242	Many sports drinks and dietary supplements provide these ions to replace those lost from the body via sweating during exercise.
7.2.243	Another way the octet rule can be satisfied is by the sharing of electrons between atoms to form covalent bonds.
7.2.244	These bonds are stronger and much more common than ionic bonds in the molecules of living organisms.
7.2.245	Covalent bonds are commonly found in carbon-based organic molecules, such as our DNA and proteins.
7.2.246	Covalent bonds are also found in inorganic molecules like H2O, CO2, and O2.
7.2.247	One, two, or three pairs of electrons may be shared, making single, double, and triple bonds, respectively.
7.2.248	The more covalent bonds between two atoms, the stronger their connection.
7.2.249	Thus, triple bonds are the strongest.
7.2.250	The strength of different levels of covalent bonding is one of the main reasons living organisms have a difficult time in acquiring nitrogen for use in constructing their molecules, even though molecular nitrogen, N2, is the most abundant gas in the atmosphere.
7.2.251	Molecular nitrogen consists of two nitrogen atoms triple bonded to each other and, as with all molecules, the sharing of these three pairs of electrons between the two nitrogen atoms allows for the filling of their outer electron shells, making the molecule more stable than the individual nitrogen atoms.
7.2.252	This strong triple bond makes it difficult for living systems to break apart this nitrogen in order to use it as constituents of proteins and DNA.
7.2.253	The formation of water molecules provides an example of covalent bonding.
7.2.254	The hydrogen and oxygen atoms that combine to form water molecules are bound together by covalent bonds, as shown in Figure 2.9.
7.2.255	The electron from the hydrogen splits its time between the incomplete outer shell of the hydrogen atoms and the incomplete outer shell of the oxygen atoms.
7.2.256	To completely fill the outer shell of oxygen, which has six electrons in its outer shell but which would be more stable with eight, two electrons (one from each hydrogen atom) are needed:
7.2.257	hence the well-known formula H2O.
7.2.258	The electrons are shared between the two elements to fill the outer shell of each, making both elements more stable.
7.2.259	There are two types of covalent bonds: polar and nonpolar.
7.2.260	In a polar covalent bond, shown in Figure 2.12, the electrons are unequally shared by the atoms and are attracted more to one nucleus than the other.
7.2.261	Because of the unequal distribution of electrons between the atoms of different elements, a slightly positive (δ+) or slightly negative (δ–) charge develops.
7.2.262	This partial charge is an important property of water and accounts for many of its characteristics.
7.2.263	Water is a polar molecule, with the hydrogen atoms acquiring a partial positive charge and the oxygen a partial negative charge.
7.2.264	This occurs because the nucleus of the oxygen atom is more attractive to the electrons of the hydrogen atoms than the hydrogen nucleus is to the oxygen’s electrons.
7.2.265	Thus oxygen has a higher electronegativity than hydrogen and the shared electrons spend more time in the vicinity of the oxygen nucleus than they do near the nucleus of the hydrogen atoms, giving the atoms of oxygen and hydrogen slightly negative and positive charges, respectively.
7.2.266	Another way of stating this is that the probability of finding a shared electron near an oxygen nucleus is more likely than finding it near a hydrogen nucleus.
7.2.267	Either way, the atom’s relative electronegativity contributes to the development of partial charges whenever one element is significantly more electronegative than the other, and the charges generated by these polar bonds may then be used for the formation of hydrogen bonds based on the attraction of opposite partial charges.
7.2.268	(Hydrogen bonds, which are discussed in detail below, are weak bonds between slightly positively charged hydrogen atoms to slightly negatively charged atoms in other molecules.)
7.2.269	Since macromolecules often have atoms within them that differ in electronegativity, polar bonds are often present in organic molecules.
7.2.270	Nonpolar covalent bonds form between two atoms of the same element or between different elements that share electrons equally.
7.2.271	For example, molecular oxygen (O2) is nonpolar because the electrons will be equally distributed between the two oxygen atoms.
7.2.272	Another example of a nonpolar covalent bond is methane (CH4), also shown in Figure 2.12.
