7.2.273	Carbon has four electrons in its outermost shell and needs four more to fill it.
7.2.274	It gets these four from four hydrogen atoms, each atom providing one, making a stable outer shell of eight electrons.
7.2.275	Carbon and hydrogen do not have the same electronegativity but are similar; thus, nonpolar bonds form.
7.2.276	The hydrogen atoms each need one electron for their outermost shell, which is filled when it contains two electrons.
7.2.277	These elements share the electrons equally among the carbons and the hydrogen atoms, creating a nonpolar covalent molecule.
7.2.278	Whether a molecule is polar or nonpolar depends both on bond type and molecular shape.
7.2.279	Both water and carbon dioxide have polar covalent bonds, but carbon dioxide is linear, so the partial charges on the molecule cancel each other out.
7.2.280	Ionic and covalent bonds between elements require energy to break.
7.2.281	Ionic bonds are not as strong as covalent, which determines their behavior in biological systems.
7.2.282	However, not all bonds are ionic or covalent bonds.
7.2.283	Weaker bonds can also form between molecules.
7.2.284	Two weak bonds that occur frequently are hydrogen bonds and van der Waals interactions.
7.2.285	Without these two types of bonds, life as we know it would not exist.
7.2.286	Hydrogen bonds provide many of the critical, lifesustaining properties of water and also stabilize the structures of proteins and DNA, the building block of cells.
7.2.287	When polar covalent bonds containing hydrogen form, the hydrogen in that bond has a slightly positive charge because hydrogen’s electron is pulled more strongly toward the other element and away from the hydrogen.
7.2.288	Because the hydrogen is slightly positive, it will be attracted to neighboring negative charges.
7.2.289	When this happens, a weak interaction occurs between the δ+of the hydrogen from one molecule and the δ– charge on the more electronegative atoms of another molecule, usually oxygen or nitrogen, or within the same molecule.
7.2.290	This interaction is called a hydrogen bond.
7.2.291	This type of bond is common and occurs regularly between water molecules.
7.2.292	Individual hydrogen bonds are weak and easily broken; however, they occur in very large numbers in water and in organic polymers, creating a major force in combination.
7.2.293	Hydrogen bonds are also responsible for zipping together the DNA double helix.
7.2.294	Like hydrogen bonds, van der Waals interactions are weak attractions or interactions between molecules.
7.2.295	Van der Waals attractions can occur between any two or more molecules and are dependent on slight fluctuations of the electron densities, which are not always symmetrical around an atom.
7.2.296	For these attractions to happen, the molecules need to be very close to one another.
7.2.297	These bonds—along with ionic, covalent, and hydrogen bonds—contribute to the three-dimensional structure of the proteins in our cells that is necessary for their proper function.
7.2.298	Pharmaceutical chemists are responsible for the development of new drugs and trying to determine the mode of action of both old and new drugs.
7.2.299	They are involved in every step of the drug development process.
7.2.300	Drugs can be found in the natural environment or can be synthesized in the laboratory.
7.2.301	In many cases, potential drugs found in nature are changed chemically in the laboratory to make them safer and more effective, and sometimes synthetic versions of drugs substitute for the version found in nature.
7.2.302	After the initial discovery or synthesis of a drug, the chemist then develops the drug, perhaps chemically altering it, testing it to see if the drug is toxic, and then designing methods for efficient large-scale production.
7.2.303	Then, the process of getting the drug approved for human use begins.
7.2.304	In the United States, drug approval is handled by the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) and involves a series of large-scale experiments using human subjects to make sure the drug is not harmful and effectively treats the condition it aims to treat.
7.2.305	This process often takes several years and requires the participation of physicians and scientists, in addition to chemists, to complete testing and gain approval.
7.2.306	An example of a drug that was originally discovered in a living organism is Paclitaxel (Taxol), an anti-cancer drug used to treat breast cancer.
7.2.307	This drug was discovered in the bark of the pacific yew tree.
7.2.308	Another example is aspirin, originally isolated from willow tree bark.
7.2.309	Finding drugs often means testing hundreds of samples of plants, fungi, and other forms of life to see if any biologically active compounds are found within them.
7.2.310	Sometimes, traditional medicine can give modern medicine clues to where an active compound can be found.
7.2.311	For example, the use of willow bark to make medicine has been known for thousands of years, dating back to ancient Egypt.
7.2.312	It was not until the late 1800s, however, that the aspirin molecule, known as acetylsalicylic acid, was purified and marketed for human use.
7.2.313	Occasionally, drugs developed for one use are found to have unforeseen effects that allow these drugs to be used in other, unrelated ways.
7.2.314	For example, the drug minoxidil (Rogaine) was originally developed to treat high blood pressure.
7.2.315	When tested on humans, it was noticed that individuals taking the drug would grow new hair.
7.2.316	Eventually the drug was marketed to men and women with baldness to restore lost hair.
7.2.317	The career of the pharmaceutical chemist may involve detective work, experimentation, and drug development, all with the goal of making human beings healthier.
7.2.318	Why do scientists spend time looking for water on other planets?
7.2.319	Why is water so important?
7.2.320	It is because water is essential to life as we know it.
7.2.321	Water is one of the more abundant molecules and the one most critical to life on Earth.
7.2.322	Approximately 60–70 percent of the human body is made up of water.
7.2.323	Without it, life as we know it simply would not exist.
7.2.324	The polarity of the water molecule and its resulting hydrogen bonding make water a unique substance with special properties that are intimately tied to the processes of life.
7.2.325	Life originally evolved in a watery environment, and most of an organism’s cellular chemistry and metabolism occur inside the watery contents of the cell’s cytoplasm.
7.2.326	Special properties of water are its high heat capacity and heat of vaporization, its ability to dissolve polar molecules, its cohesive and adhesive properties, and its dissociation into ions that leads to the generation of pH. Understanding these characteristics of water helps to elucidate its importance in maintaining life.
7.2.327	One of water’s important properties is that it is composed of polar molecules: the hydrogen and oxygen within water molecules (H2O) form polar covalent bonds.
7.2.328	While there is no net charge to a water molecule, the polarity of water creates a slightly positive charge on hydrogen and a slightly negative charge on oxygen, contributing to water’s properties of attraction.
7.2.329	Water’s charges are generated because oxygen is more electronegative than hydrogen, making it more likely that a shared electron would be found near the oxygen nucleus than the hydrogen nucleus, thus generating the partial negative charge near the oxygen.
7.2.330	As a result of water’s polarity, each water molecule attracts other water molecules because of the opposite charges between water molecules, forming hydrogen bonds.
7.2.331	Water also attracts or is attracted to other polar molecules and ions.
7.2.332	A polar substance that interacts readily with or dissolves in water is referred to as hydrophilic (hydro-
7.2.333	= “water”; -philic =
7.2.334	“loving
7.2.335	”).
7.2.336	In contrast, non-polar molecules such as oils and fats do not interact well with water, as shown in Figure 2.13 and separate from it rather than dissolve in it, as we see in salad dressings containing oil and vinegar (an acidic water solution).
7.2.337	These nonpolar compounds are called hydrophobic (hydro- = “water”; -phobic =
7.2.338	“fearing”).
7.2.339	The formation of hydrogen bonds is an important quality of the liquid water that is crucial to life as we know it.
7.2.340	As water molecules make hydrogen bonds with each other, water takes on some unique chemical characteristics compared to other liquids and, since living things have a high water content, understanding these chemical features is key to understanding life.
7.2.341	In liquid water, hydrogen bonds are constantly formed and broken as the water molecules slide past each other.
7.2.342	The breaking of these bonds is caused by the motion (kinetic energy) of the water molecules due to the heat contained in the system.
7.2.343	When the heat is raised as water is boiled, the higher kinetic energy of the water molecules causes the hydrogen bonds to break completely and allows water molecules to escape into the air as gas (steam or water vapor).
7.2.344	On the other hand, when the temperature of water is reduced and water freezes, the water molecules form a crystalline structure maintained by hydrogen bonding (there is not enough energy to break the hydrogen bonds) that makes ice less dense than liquid water, a phenomenon not seen in the solidification of other liquids.
7.2.345	Oil and water do not mix.
7.2.346	As this macro image of oil and water shows, oil does not dissolve in water but forms droplets instead.
7.2.347	This is due to it being a nonpolar compound.
7.2.348	(credit: Gautam Dogra).
7.2.349	The formation of hydrogen bonds is an important quality of the liquid water that is crucial to life as we know it.
7.2.350	As water molecules make hydrogen bonds with each other, water takes on some unique chemical characteristics compared to other liquids and, since living things have a high water content, understanding these chemical features is key to understanding life.
7.2.351	In liquid water, hydrogen bonds are constantly formed and broken as the water molecules slide past each other.
7.2.352	The breaking of these bonds is caused by the motion (kinetic energy) of the water molecules due to the heat contained in the system.
7.2.353	When the heat is raised as water is boiled, the higher kinetic energy of the water molecules causes the hydrogen bonds to break completely and allows water molecules to escape into the air as gas (steam or water vapor).
7.2.354	On the other hand, when the temperature of water is reduced and water freezes, the water molecules form a crystalline structure maintained by hydrogen bonding (there is not enough energy to break the hydrogen bonds) that makes ice less dense than liquid water, a phenomenon not seen in the solidification of other liquids.
7.2.355	Water’s lower density in its solid form is due to the way hydrogen bonds are oriented as it freezes: the water molecules are pushed farther apart compared to liquid water.
7.2.356	With most other liquids, solidification when the temperature drops includes the lowering of kinetic energy between molecules, allowing them to pack even more tightly than in liquid form and giving the solid a greater density than the liquid.
7.2.357	The lower density of ice, illustrated and pictured in Figure 2.14, an anomaly, causes it to float at the surface of liquid water, such as in an iceberg or in the ice cubes in a glass of ice water.
7.2.358	In lakes and ponds, ice will form on the surface of the water creating an insulating barrier that protects the animals and plant life in the pond from freezing.
7.2.359	Without this layer of insulating ice, plants and animals living in the pond would freeze in the solid block of ice and could not survive.
7.2.360	The detrimental effect of freezing on living organisms is caused by the expansion of ice relative to liquid water.
7.2.361	The ice crystals that form upon freezing rupture the delicate membranes essential for the function of living cells, irreversibly damaging them.
7.2.362	Cells can only survive freezing if the water in them is temporarily replaced by another liquid like glycerol.
7.2.363	Hydrogen bonding makes ice less dense than liquid water.
7.2.364	The (a) lattice structure of ice makes it less dense than the freely flowing molecules of liquid water, enabling it to (b) float on water.
7.2.365	Water’s high heat capacity is a property caused by hydrogen bonding among water molecules.
7.2.366	Water has the highest specific heat capacity of any liquids.
7.2.367	Specific heat is defined as the amount of heat one gram of a substance must absorb or lose to change its temperature by one degree Celsius.
7.2.368	For water, this amount is one calorie.
7.2.369	It therefore takes water a long time to heat and long time to cool.
7.2.370	In fact, the specific heat capacity of water is about five times more than that of sand.
7.2.371	This explains why the land cools faster than the sea.
7.2.372	Due to its high heat capacity, water is used by warm blooded animals to more evenly disperse heat in their bodies: it acts in a similar manner to a car’s cooling system, transporting heat from warm places to cool places, causing the body to maintain a more even temperature.
7.2.373	Water also has a high heat of vaporization, the amount of energy required to change one gram of a liquid substance to a gas.
7.2.374	A considerable amount of heat energy (586 cal) is required to accomplish this change in water.
7.2.375	This process occurs on the surface of water.
7.2.376	As liquid water heats up, hydrogen bonding makes it difficult to separate the liquid water molecules from each other, which is required for it to enter its gaseous phase (steam).
7.2.377	As a result, water acts as a heat sink or heat reservoir and requires much more heat to boil than does a liquid such as ethanol (grain alcohol), whose hydrogen bonding with other ethanol molecules is weaker than water’s hydrogen bonding.
7.2.378	Eventually, as water reaches its boiling point of 100Åã Celsius (212Åã Fahrenheit), the heat is able to break the hydrogen bonds between the water molecules, and the kinetic energy (motion) between the water molecules allows them to escape from the liquid as a gas.
7.2.379	Even when below its boiling point, water’s individual molecules acquire enough energy from other water molecules such that some surface water molecules can escape and vaporize: this process is known as evaporation.
7.2.380	The fact that hydrogen bonds need to be broken for water to evaporate means that a substantial amount of energy is used in the process.
7.2.381	As the water evaporates, energy is taken up by the process, cooling the environment where the evaporation is taking place.
7.2.382	In many living organisms, including in humans, the evaporation of sweat, which is 90 percent water, allows the organism to cool so that homeostasis of body temperature can be maintained.
7.2.383	Since water is a polar molecule with slightly positive and slightly negative charges, ions and polar molecules can readily dissolve in it.
7.2.384	Therefore, water is referred to as a solvent, a substance capable of dissolving other polar molecules and ionic compounds.
7.2.385	The charges associated with these molecules will form hydrogen bonds with water, surrounding the particle with water molecules.
7.2.386	This is referred to as a sphere of hydration, or a hydration shell, as illustrated in Figure 2.15 and serves to keep the particles separated or dispersed in the water.
7.2.387	When ionic compounds are added to water, the individual ions react with the polar regions of the water molecules and their ionic bonds are disrupted in the process of dissociation.
7.2.388	Dissociation occurs when atoms or groups of atoms break off from molecules and form ions.
7.2.389	Consider table salt (NaCl, or sodium chloride): when NaCl crystals are added to water, the molecules of NaCl dissociate into Na+ and Cl– ions, and spheres of hydration form around the ions, illustrated in Figure 2.15.
7.2.390	The positively charged sodium ion is surrounded by the partially negative charge of the water molecule’s oxygen.
7.2.391	The negatively charged chloride ion is surrounded by the partially positive charge of the hydrogen on the water molecule.
7.2.392	Have you ever filled a glass of water to the very top and then slowly added a few more drops?
7.2.393	Before it overflows, the water forms a dome-like shape above the rim of the glass.
7.2.394	This water can stay above the glass because of the property of cohesion.
7.2.395	In cohesion, water molecules are attracted to each other (because of hydrogen bonding), keeping the molecules together at the liquid-gas (water-air) interface, although there is no more room in the glass.
7.2.396	Cohesion allows for the development of surface tension, the capacity of a substance to withstand being ruptured when placed under tension or stress.
7.2.397	This is also why water forms droplets when placed on a dry surface rather than being flattened out by gravity.
7.2.398	When a small scrap of paper is placed onto the droplet of water, the paper floats on top of the water droplet even though paper is denser (heavier) than the water.
7.2.399	Cohesion and surface tension keep the hydrogen bonds of water molecules intact and support the item floating on the top.
7.2.400	It’s even possible to “float” a needle on top of a glass of water if it is placed gently without breaking the surface tension, as shown in Figure 2.16.
7.2.401	These cohesive forces are related to water’s property of adhesion, or the attraction between water molecules and other molecules.
7.2.402	This attraction is sometimes stronger than water’s cohesive forces, especially when the water is exposed to charged surfaces such as those found on the inside of thin glass tubes known as capillary tubes.
7.2.403	Adhesion is observed when water “climbs” up the tube placed in a glass of water: notice that the water appears to be higher on the sides of the tube than in the middle.
7.2.404	This is because the water molecules are attracted to the charged glass walls of the capillary more than they are to each other and therefore adhere to it.
7.2.405	This type of adhesion is called capillary action, and is illustrated in Figure 2.17.
7.2.406	The weight of the needle is pulling the surface downward; at the same time, the surface tension is pulling it up, suspending it on the surface of the water and keeping it from sinking.
7.2.407	Notice the indentation in the water around the needle.
7.2.408	These cohesive forces are related to water’s property of adhesion, or the attraction between water molecules and other molecules.
7.2.409	This attraction is sometimes stronger than water’s cohesive forces, especially when the water is exposed to charged surfaces such as those found on the inside of thin glass tubes known as capillary tubes.
7.2.410	Adhesion is observed when water “climbs” up the tube placed in a glass of water: notice that the water appears to be higher on the sides of the tube than in the middle.
7.2.411	This is because the water molecules are attracted to the charged glass walls of the capillary more than they are to each other and therefore adhere to it.
7.2.412	This type of adhesion is called capillary action, and is illustrated in Figure 2.17.
7.2.413	Capillary action in a glass tube is caused by the adhesive forces exerted by the internal surface of the glass exceeding the cohesive forces between the water molecules themselves.  
7.2.414	Why are cohesive and adhesive forces important for life?
7.2.415	Cohesive and adhesive forces are important for the transport of water from the roots to the leaves in plants.
7.2.416	These forces create a “pull” on the water column.
7.2.417	This pull results from the tendency of water molecules being evaporated on the surface of the plant to stay connected to water molecules below them, and so they are pulled along.
7.2.418	Plants use this natural phenomenon to help transport water from their roots to their leaves.
7.2.419	Without these properties of water, plants would be unable to receive the water and the dissolved minerals they require.
7.2.420	In another example, insects such as the water strider, shown in Figure 2.18, use the surface tension of water to stay afloat on the surface layer of water and even mate there.
7.2.421	The pH of a solution indicates its acidity or alkalinity.
7.2.422	litmus or pH paper, filter paper that has been treated with a natural water-soluble dye so it can be used as a pH indicator, to test how much acid (acidity) or base (alkalinity) exists in a solution.
7.2.423	You might have even used some to test whether the water in a swimming pool is properly treated.
7.2.424	In both cases, the pH test measures the concentration of hydrogen ions in a given solution.
7.2.425	Hydrogen ions are spontaneously generated in pure water by the dissociation (ionization) of a small percentage of water molecules into equal numbers of hydrogen (H+) ions and hydroxide (OH-) ions.
7.2.426	While the hydroxide ions are kept in solution by their hydrogen bonding with other water molecules, the hydrogen ions, consisting of naked protons, are immediately attracted to un-ionized water molecules, forming hydronium ions (H30+).
7.2.427	Still, by convention, scientists refer to hydrogen ions and their concentration as if they were free in this state in liquid water.
7.2.428	The concentration of hydrogen ions dissociating from pure water is 1 Å~
7.2.429	10-7 moles H+ ions per liter of water.
7.2.430	Moles (mol) are a way to express the amount of a substance (which can be atoms, molecules, ions, etc), with one mole being equal to 6.02 x 1023 particles of the substance.
7.2.431	Therefore, 1 mole of water is equal to 6.02 x 1023 water molecules.
7.2.432	The pH is calculated as the negative of the base 10 logarithm of this concentration.
7.2.433	The log10 of 1 Å~ 10-7 is -7.0, and the negative of this number (indicated by the “p” of “pH”) yields a pH of 7.0, which is also known as neutral pH.
7.2.434	The pH inside of human cells and blood are examples of two areas of the body where near-neutral pH is maintained.
7.2.435	Non-neutral pH readings result from dissolving acids or bases in water.
7.2.436	Using the negative logarithm to generate positive integers, high concentrations of hydrogen ions yield a low pH number, whereas low levels of hydrogen ions result in a high pH. An acid is a substance that increases the concentration of hydrogen ions (H+) in a solution, usually by having one of its hydrogen atoms dissociate.
7.2.437	A base provides either hydroxide ions (OH–) or other negatively charged ions that combine with hydrogen ions, reducing their concentration in the solution and thereby raising the pH.
7.2.438	In cases where the base releases hydroxide ions, these ions bind to free hydrogen ions, generating new water molecules.
7.2.439	The stronger the acid, the more readily it donates H+.
7.2.440	For example, hydrochloric acid (HCl) completely dissociates into hydrogen and chloride ions and is highly acidic, whereas the acids in tomato juice or vinegar do not completely dissociate and are considered weak acids.
7.2.441	Conversely, strong bases are those substances that readily donate OH– or take up hydrogen ions.
7.2.442	Sodium hydroxide (NaOH) and many household cleaners are highly alkaline and give up OH– rapidly when placed in water, thereby raising the pH.
7.2.443	An example of a weak basic solution is seawater, which has a pH near 8.0, close enough to neutral pH that marine organisms adapted to this saline environment are able to thrive in it.
7.2.444	The pH scale is, as previously mentioned, an inverse logarithm and ranges from 0 to 14 (Figure 2.19).
7.2.445	Anything below 7.0 (ranging from 0.0 to 6.9) is acidic, and anything above 7.0 (from 7.1 to 14.0) is alkaline.
7.2.446	Extremes in pH in either direction from 7.0 are usually considered inhospitable to life.
7.2.447	The pH inside cells (6.8) and the pH in the blood (7.4) are both very close to neutral.
7.2.448	However, the environment in the stomach is highly acidic, with a pH of 1 to 2.
7.2.449	So how do the cells of the stomach survive in such an acidic environment?
7.2.450	How do they homeostatically maintain the near neutral pH inside them?
7.2.451	The answer is that they cannot do it and are constantly dying.
7.2.452	New stomach cells are constantly produced to replace dead ones, which are digested by the stomach acids.
7.2.453	It is estimated that the lining of the human stomach is completely replaced every seven to ten days.
7.2.454	The pH scale measures the concentration of hydrogen ions (H+) in a solution.
7.2.455	So how can organisms whose bodies require a near-neutral pH ingest acidic and basic substances (a human drinking orange juice, for example) and survive?
7.2.456	Buffers are the key.
7.2.457	Buffers readily absorb excess H+ or OH–, keeping the pH of the body carefully maintained in the narrow range required for survival.
7.2.458	Maintaining a constant blood pH is critical to a person’s well-being.
7.2.459	The buffer maintaining the pH of human blood involves carbonic acid (H2CO3), bicarbonate ion (HCO3 –), and carbon dioxide (CO2).
7.2.460	When bicarbonate ions combine with free hydrogen ions and become carbonic acid, hydrogen ions are removed, moderating pH changes.
7.2.461	Similarly, as shown in Figure 2.20, excess carbonic acid can be converted to carbon dioxide gas and exhaled through the lungs.
7.2.462	This prevents too many free hydrogen ions from building up in the blood and dangerously reducing the blood’s pH. Likewise, if too much OH– is introduced into the system, carbonic acid will combine with it to create bicarbonate, lowering the pH. Without this buffer system, the body’s pH would fluctuate enough to put survival in jeopardy.
7.2.463	This diagram shows the body’s buffering of blood pH levels.
7.2.464	The blue arrows show the process of raising pH as more CO2 is made.
7.2.465	The purple arrows indicate the reverse process: the lowering of pH as more bicarbonate is created.
7.2.466	Other examples of buffers are antacids used to combat excess stomach acid.
7.2.467	Many of these over-the-counter medications work in the same way as blood buffers, usually with at least one ion capable of absorbing hydrogen and moderating pH, bringing relief to those that suffer
7.2.468	“heartburn” after eating.
7.2.469	The unique properties of water that contribute to this capacity to balance pH—as well as water’s other characteristics—are essential to sustaining life on Earth.
7.2.470	Cells are made of many complex molecules called macromolecules, such as proteins, nucleic acids (RNA and DNA), carbohydrates, and lipids.
7.2.471	The macromolecules are a subset of organic molecules (any carbon-containing liquid, solid, or gas) that are especially important for life.
7.2.472	The fundamental component for all of these macromolecules is carbon.
7.2.473	The carbon atom has unique properties that allow it to form covalent bonds to as many as four different atoms, making this versatile element ideal to serve as the basic structural component, or “backbone,” of the macromolecules.
7.2.474	Individual carbon atoms have an incomplete outermost electron shell.
7.2.475	With an atomic number of 6 (six electrons and six protons), the first two electrons fill the inner shell, leaving four in the second shell.
7.2.476	Therefore, carbon atoms can form up to four covalent bonds with other atoms to satisfy the octet rule.
7.2.477	The methane molecule provides an example: it has the chemical formula CH4.
7.2.478	Each of its four hydrogen atoms forms a single covalent bond with the carbon atom by sharing a pair of electrons.
7.2.479	This results in a filled outermost shell.
7.2.480	Hydrocarbons are organic molecules consisting entirely of carbon and hydrogen, such as methane (CH4) described above.
7.2.481	We often use hydrocarbons in our daily lives as fuels—like the propane in a gas grill or the butane in a lighter.
7.2.482	The many covalent bonds between the atoms in hydrocarbons store a great amount of energy, which is released when these molecules are burned (oxidized).
7.2.483	Methane, an excellent fuel, is the simplest hydrocarbon molecule, with a central carbon atom bonded to four different hydrogen atoms, as illustrated in Figure 2.21.
7.2.484	The geometry of the methane molecule, where the atoms reside in three dimensions, is determined by the shape of its electron orbitals.
7.2.485	The carbons and the four hydrogen atoms form a shape known as a tetrahedron, with four triangular faces; for this reason, methane is described as having tetrahedral geometry.
7.2.486	Methane has a tetrahedral geometry, with each of the four hydrogen atoms spaced 109.5Åã apart.
7.2.487	As the backbone of the large molecules of living things, hydrocarbons may exist as linear carbon chains, carbon rings, or combinations of both.
7.2.488	Furthermore, individual carbon-to-carbon bonds may be single, double, or triple covalent bonds, and each type of bond affects the geometry of the molecule in a specific way.
7.2.489	This three-dimensional shape or conformation of the large molecules of life (macromolecules) is critical to how they function.
7.2.490	Hydrocarbon chains are formed by successive bonds between carbon atoms and may be branched or unbranched.
7.2.491	Furthermore, the overall geometry of the molecule is altered by the different geometries of single, double, and triple covalent bonds, illustrated in Figure 2.22.
7.2.492	The hydrocarbons ethane, ethene, and ethyne serve as examples of how different carbon-to-carbon bonds affect the geometry of the molecule.
7.2.493	The names of all three molecules start with the prefix “
7.2.494	eth-,
7.2.495	” which is the prefix for two carbon hydrocarbons.
7.2.496	The suffixes “-ane,” “-ene,” and “
7.2.497	-yne
7.2.498	” refer to the presence of single, double, or triple carbon-carbon bonds, respectively.
7.2.499	Thus, propane, propene, and propyne follow the same pattern with three carbon molecules, butane, butane, and butyne for four carbon molecules, and so on.
7.2.500	Double and triple bonds change the geometry of the molecule: single bonds allow rotation along the axis of the bond, whereas double bonds lead to a planar configuration and triple bonds to a linear one.
7.2.501	These geometries have a significant impact on the shape a particular molecule can assume.
7.2.502	When carbon forms single bonds with other atoms, the shape is tetrahedral.
7.2.503	When two carbon atoms form a double bond, the shape is planar, or flat.
7.2.504	Single bonds, like those found in ethane, are able to rotate.
7.2.505	Double bonds, like those found in ethene cannot rotate, so the atoms on either side are locked in place.
7.2.506	So far, the hydrocarbons we have discussed have been aliphatic hydrocarbons, which consist of linear chains of carbon atoms.
7.2.507	Another type of hydrocarbon, aromatic hydrocarbons, consists of closed rings of carbon atoms.
7.2.508	Ring structures are found in hydrocarbons, sometimes with the presence of double bonds, which can be seen by comparing the structure of cyclohexane to benzene in Figure 2.23.
7.2.509	Examples of biological molecules that incorporate the benzene ring include some amino acids and cholesterol and its derivatives, including the hormones estrogen and testosterone.
7.2.510	The benzene ring is also found in the herbicide 2,4-D. Benzene is a natural component of crude oil and has been classified as a carcinogen.
7.2.511	Some hydrocarbons have both aliphatic and aromatic portions; beta-carotene is an example of such a hydrocarbon.
7.2.512	Carbon can form five-and six membered rings.
7.2.513	Single or double bonds may connect the carbons in the ring, and nitrogen may be substituted for carbon.
7.2.514	The three-dimensional placement of atoms and chemical bonds within organic molecules is central to understanding their chemistry.
7.2.515	Molecules that share the same chemical formula but differ in the placement (structure) of their atoms and/or chemical bonds are known as isomers.
7.2.516	Structural isomers (like butane and isobutene shown in Figure 2.24a) differ in the placement of their covalent bonds: both molecules have four carbons and ten hydrogens (C4H10), but the different arrangement of the atoms within the molecules leads to differences in their chemical properties.
7.2.517	For example, due to their different chemical properties, butane is suited for use as a fuel for cigarette lighters and torches, whereas isobutene is suited for use as a refrigerant and a propellant in spray cans.
7.2.518	Geometric isomers, on the other hand, have similar placements of their covalent bonds but differ in how these bonds are made to the surrounding atoms, especially in carbon-to-carbon double bonds.
7.2.519	In the simple molecule butene (C4H8), the two methyl groups (CH3) can be on either side of the double covalent bond central to the molecule, as illustrated in Figure 2.24b.
7.2.520	When the carbons are bound on the same side of the double bond, this is the cis configuration; if they are on opposite sides of the double bond, it is a trans configuration.
7.2.521	In the trans configuration, the carbons form a more or less linear structure, whereas the carbons in the cis configuration make a bend (change in direction) of the carbon backbone.
7.2.522	In triglycerides (fats and oils), long carbon chains known as fatty acids may contain double bonds, which can be in either the cis or trans configuration, illustrated in Figure 2.25.
7.2.523	Fats with at least one double bond between carbon atoms are unsaturated fats.
7.2.524	When some of these bonds are in the cis configuration, the resulting bend in the carbon backbone of the chain means that triglyceride molecules cannot pack tightly, so they remain liquid (oil) at room temperature.
7.2.525	On the other hand, triglycerides with trans double bonds (popularly called trans fats), have relatively linear fatty acids that are able to pack tightly together at room temperature and form solid fats.
7.2.526	In the human diet, trans fats are linked to an increased risk of cardiovascular disease, so many food manufacturers have reduced or eliminated their use in recent years.
7.2.527	In contrast to unsaturated fats, triglycerides without double bonds between carbon atoms are called saturated fats, meaning that they contain all the hydrogen atoms available.
7.2.528	Saturated fats are a solid at room temperature and usually of animal origin.
7.2.529	These space-filling models show a cis (oleic acid) and a trans (eliadic acid) fatty acid.
7.2.530	Notice the bend in the molecule cause by the cis configuration.
7.2.531	Enantiomers are molecules that share the same chemical structure and chemical bonds but differ in the three-dimensional placement of atoms so that they are mirror images.
7.2.532	As shown in Figure 2.26, an amino acid alanine example, the two structures are non-superimposable.
7.2.533	In nature, only the L-forms of amino acids are used to make proteins.
7.2.534	Some D forms of amino acids are seen in the cell walls of bacteria, but never in their proteins.
7.2.535	Similarly, the D-form of glucose is the main product of photosynthesis and the L-form of the molecule is rarely seen in nature.
7.2.536	D-alanine and L-alanine are examples of enantiomers or mirror images.
7.2.537	Only the L-forms of amino acids are used to make proteins.
7.2.538	Functional groups are groups of atoms that occur within molecules and confer specific chemical properties to those molecules.
7.2.539	They are found along the “carbon backbone” of macromolecules.
7.2.540	This carbon backbone is formed by chains and/or rings of carbon atoms with the occasional substitution of an element such as nitrogen or oxygen.
7.2.541	Molecules with other elements in their carbon backbone are substituted hydrocarbons.
7.2.542	The functional groups in a macromolecule are usually attached to the carbon backbone at one or several different places along its chain and/or ring structure.
7.2.543	Each of the four types of macromolecules—proteins, lipids, carbohydrates, and nucleic acids—has its own characteristic set of functional groups that contributes greatly to its differing chemical properties and its function in living organisms.
7.2.544	A functional group can participate in specific chemical reactions.
7.2.545	Some of the important functional groups in biological molecules are shown in Figure 2.27; they include: hydroxyl, methyl, carbonyl, carboxyl, amino, phosphate, and sulfhydryl.
7.2.546	These groups play an important role in the formation of molecules like DNA, proteins, carbohydrates, and lipids.
7.2.547	Functional groups are usually classified as hydrophobic or hydrophilic depending on their charge or polarity characteristics.
7.2.548	An example of a hydrophobic group is the non-polar methane molecule.
7.2.549	Among the hydrophilic functional groups is the carboxyl group found in amino acids, some amino acid side chains, and the fatty acids that form triglycerides and phospholipids.
7.2.550	This carboxyl group ionizes to release hydrogen ions (H+) from the COOH group resulting in the negatively charged COO- group; this contributes to the hydrophilic nature of whatever molecule it is found on.
7.2.551	Other functional groups, such as the carbonyl group, have a partially negatively charged oxygen atom that may form hydrogen bonds with water molecules, again making the molecule more hydrophilic.
7.2.552	The functional groups shown here are found in many different biological molecules.
7.2.553	Hydrogen bonds between functional groups (within the same molecule or between different molecules) are important to the function of many macromolecules and help them to fold properly into and maintain the appropriate shape for functioning.
7.2.554	Hydrogen bonds are also involved in various recognition processes, such as DNA complementary base pairing and the binding of an enzyme to its substrate, as illustrated in Figure 2.28.
7.2.555	Matter is anything that occupies space and has mass.
7.2.556	It is made up of elements.
7.2.557	All of the 92 elements that occur naturally have unique qualities that allow them to combine in various ways to create molecules, which in turn combine to form cells, tissues, organ systems, and organisms.
7.2.558	Atoms, which consist of protons, neutrons, and electrons, are the smallest units of an element that retain all of the properties of that element.
7.2.559	Electrons can be transferred, shared, or cause charge disparities between atoms to create bonds, including ionic, covalent, and hydrogen bonds, as well as van der Waals interactions.
7.2.560	Water has many properties that are critical to maintaining life.
7.2.561	It is a polar molecule, allowing for the formation of hydrogen bonds.
7.2.562	Hydrogen bonds allow ions and other polar molecules to dissolve in water.
7.2.563	Therefore, water is an excellent solvent.
7.2.564	The hydrogen bonds between water molecules cause the water to have a high heat capacity, meaning it takes a lot of added heat to raise its temperature.
7.2.565	As the temperature rises, the hydrogen bonds between water continually break and form anew.
7.2.566	This allows for the overall temperature to remain stable, although energy is added to the system.
7.2.567	Water also exhibits a high heat of vaporization, which is key to how organisms cool themselves by the evaporation of sweat.
7.2.568	Water’s cohesive forces allow for the property of surface tension, whereas its adhesive properties are seen as water rises inside capillary tubes.
7.2.569	The pH value is a measure of hydrogen ion concentration in a solution and is one of many chemical characteristics that is highly regulated in living organisms through homeostasis.
7.2.570	Acids and bases can change pH values, but buffers tend to moderate the changes they cause.
7.2.571	These properties of water are intimately connected to the biochemical and physical processes performed by living organisms, and life would be very different if these properties were altered, if it could exist at all.
7.2.572	The unique properties of carbon make it a central part of biological molecules.
7.2.573	Carbon binds to oxygen, hydrogen, and nitrogen covalently to form the many molecules important for cellular function.
7.2.574	Carbon has four electrons in its outermost shell and can form four bonds.
7.2.575	Carbon and hydrogen can form hydrocarbon chains or rings.
7.2.576	Functional groups are groups of atoms that confer specific properties to hydrocarbon (or substituted hydrocarbon) chains or rings that define their overall chemical characteristics and function.
7.3.0	Food provides the body with the nutrients it needs to survive.
7.3.1	Many of these critical nutrients are biological macromolecules, or large molecules, necessary for life.
7.3.2	These macromolecules (polymers) are built from different combinations of smaller organic molecules (monomers).
7.3.3	What specific types of biological macromolecules do living things require?
7.3.4	How are these molecules formed?
7.3.5	What functions do they serve?
7.3.6	In this chapter, these questions will be explored.
7.3.7	As you’ve learned, biological macromolecules are large molecules, necessary for life, that are built from smaller organic molecules.
7.3.8	There are four major classes of biological macromolecules (carbohydrates, lipids, proteins, and nucleic acids); each is an important cell component and performs a wide array of functions.
7.3.9	Combined, these molecules make up the majority of a cell’s dry mass (recall that water makes up the majority of its complete mass).
7.3.10	Biological macromolecules are organic, meaning they contain carbon.
7.3.11	In addition, they may contain hydrogen, oxygen, nitrogen, and additional minor elements.  
7.3.12	Most macromolecules are made from single subunits, or building blocks, called monomers.
7.3.13	The monomers combine with each other using covalent bonds to form larger molecules known as polymers.
7.3.14	In doing so, monomers release water molecules as byproducts.
7.3.15	This type of reaction is known as dehydration synthesis, which means “to put together while losing water.
7.3.16	”  
7.3.17	In a dehydration synthesis reaction (Figure 3.2), the hydrogen of one monomer combines with the hydroxyl group of another monomer, releasing a molecule of water.
7.3.18	At the same time, the monomers share electrons and form covalent bonds.
7.3.19	As additional monomers join, this chain of repeating monomers forms a polymer.
7.3.20	Different types of monomers can combine in many configurations, giving rise to a diverse group of macromolecules.
7.3.21	Even one kind of monomer can combine in a variety of ways to form several different polymers: for example, glucose monomers are the constituents of starch, glycogen, and cellulose.  
7.3.22	Polymers are broken down into monomers in a process known as hydrolysis, which means “to split water,” a reaction in which a water molecule is used during the breakdown (Figure 3.3).
7.3.23	During these reactions, the polymer is broken into two components: one part gains a hydrogen atom (H+) and the other gains a hydroxyl molecule (OH–) from a split water molecule.  
7.3.24	Dehydration and hydrolysis reactions are catalyzed, or “sped up,” by specific enzymes; dehydration reactions involve the formation of new bonds, requiring energy, while hydrolysis reactions break bonds and release energy.
7.3.25	These reactions are similar for most macromolecules, but each monomer and polymer reaction is specific for its class.
7.3.26	For example, in our bodies, food is hydrolyzed, or broken down, into smaller molecules by catalytic enzymes in the digestive system.
7.3.27	This allows for easy absorption of nutrients by cells in the intestine.
7.3.28	Each macromolecule is broken down by a specific enzyme.
7.3.29	For instance, carbohydrates are broken down by amylase, sucrase, lactase, or maltase.
7.3.30	Proteins are broken down by the enzymes pepsin and peptidase, and by hydrochloric acid.
7.3.31	Lipids are broken down by lipases.
7.3.32	Breakdown of these macromolecules provides energy for cellular activities.  
7.3.33	Most people are familiar with carbohydrates, one type of macromolecule, especially when it comes to what we eat.
7.3.34	To lose weight, some individuals adhere to “low-carb” diets.
7.3.35	Athletes, in contrast, often “carb-load” before important competitions to ensure that they have enough energy to compete at a high level.
7.3.36	Carbohydrates are, in fact, an essential part of our diet; grains, fruits, and vegetables are all natural sources of carbohydrates.
7.3.37	Carbohydrates provide energy to the body, particularly through glucose, a simple sugar that is a component of starch and an ingredient in many staple foods.
7.3.38	Carbohydrates also have other important functions in humans, animals, and plants.  
7.3.39	Carbohydrates can be represented by the stoichiometric formula (CH2O)n, where n is the number of carbons in the molecule.
7.3.40	In other words, the ratio of carbon to hydrogen to oxygen is 1:2:1 in carbohydrate molecules.
7.3.41	This formula also explains the origin of the term
7.3.42	“carbohydrate”:
7.3.43	the components are carbon (“carbo”) and the components of water (hence, “hydrate”).
7.3.44	Carbohydrates are classified into three subtypes: monosaccharides, disaccharides, and polysaccharides.  
7.3.45	Monosaccharides (mono-
7.3.46	= “one”; sacchar- =
7.3.47	“sweet”) are simple sugars, the most common of which is glucose.
7.3.48	In monosaccharides, the number of carbons usually ranges from three to seven.
7.3.49	Most monosaccharide names end with the suffix -ose.
7.3.50	If the sugar has an aldehyde group (the functional group with the structure R-CHO), it is known as an aldose, and if it has a ketone group (the functional group with the structure RC(=O)R'), it is known as a ketose.
7.3.51	Depending on the number of carbons in the sugar, they also may be known as trioses (three carbons), pentoses (five carbons), and or hexoses (six carbons).
7.3.52	See Figure 3.4 for an illustration of the monosaccharides.  
7.3.53	The chemical formula for glucose is C6H12O6.
7.3.54	In humans, glucose is an important source of energy.
7.3.55	During cellular respiration, energy is released from glucose, and that energy is used to help make adenosine triphosphate (ATP).
7.3.56	Plants synthesize glucose using carbon dioxide and water, and glucose in turn is used for energy requirements for the plant.
7.3.57	Excess glucose is often stored as starch that is catabolized (the breakdown of larger molecules by cells) by humans and other animals that feed on plants.  
7.3.58	Galactose (part of lactose, or milk sugar) and fructose (found in sucrose, in fruit) are other common monosaccharides.
7.3.59	Although glucose, galactose, and fructose all have the same chemical formula (C6H12O6), they differ structurally and chemically (and are known as isomers) because of the different arrangement of functional groups around the asymmetric carbon; all of these monosaccharides have more than one asymmetric carbon (Figure 3.5).  
7.3.60	Monosaccharides can exist as a linear chain or as ring-shaped molecules; in aqueous solutions they are usually found in ring forms (Figure 3.6).
7.3.61	Glucose in a ring form can have two different arrangements of the hydroxyl group (OH) around the anomeric carbon (carbon 1 that becomes asymmetric in the process of ring formation).
7.3.62	If the hydroxyl group is below carbon number 1 in the sugar, it is said to be in the alpha (α) position, and if it is above the plane, it is said to be in the beta (β) position.  
7.3.63	Disaccharides (di- =
7.3.64	“two”) form when two monosaccharides undergo a dehydration reaction (also known as a condensation reaction or dehydration synthesis).
7.3.65	During this process, the hydroxyl group of one monosaccharide combines with the hydrogen of another monosaccharide, releasing a molecule of water and forming a covalent bond.
7.3.66	A covalent bond formed between a carbohydrate molecule and another molecule (in this case, between two monosaccharides) is known as a glycosidic bond (Figure 3.7).
7.3.67	Glycosidic bonds (also called glycosidic linkages) can be of the alpha or the beta type.  
7.3.68	Common disaccharides include lactose, maltose, and sucrose (Figure 3.8).
7.3.69	Lactose is a disaccharide consisting of the monomers glucose and galactose.
7.3.70	It is found naturally in milk.
7.3.71	Maltose, or malt sugar, is a disaccharide formed by a dehydration reaction between two glucose molecules.
7.3.72	The most common disaccharide is sucrose, or table sugar, which is composed of the monomers glucose and fructose.  
7.3.73	A long chain of monosaccharides linked by glycosidic bonds is known as a polysaccharide (poly-
7.3.74	= “many”).
7.3.75	The chain may be branched or unbranched, and it may contain different types of monosaccharides.
7.3.76	The molecular weight may be 100,000 daltons or more depending on the number of monomers joined.
7.3.77	Starch, glycogen, cellulose, and chitin are primary examples of polysaccharides.  
7.3.78	Starch is the stored form of sugars in plants and is made up of a mixture of amylose and amylopectin (both polymers of glucose).
7.3.79	Plants are able to synthesize glucose, and the excess glucose, beyond the plant’s immediate energy needs, is stored as starch in different plant parts, including roots and seeds.
7.3.80	The starch in the seeds provides food for the embryo as it germinates and can also act as a source of food for humans and animals.
7.3.81	The starch that is consumed by humans is broken down by enzymes, such as salivary amylases, into smaller molecules, such as maltose and glucose.
7.3.82	The cells can then absorb the glucose.  
7.3.83	Starch is made up of glucose monomers that are joined by α 1-4 or α 1-6 glycosidic bonds.
7.3.84	The numbers 1-4 and 1-6 refer to the carbon number of the two residues that have joined to form the bond.
7.3.85	As illustrated in Figure 3.9, amylose is starch formed by unbranched chains of glucose monomers (only α 1-4 linkages), whereas amylopectin is a branched polysaccharide (α 1-6 linkages at the branch points).  
7.3.86	Glycogen is the storage form of glucose in humans and other vertebrates and is made up of monomers of glucose.
7.3.87	Glycogen is the animal equivalent of starch and is a highly branched molecule usually stored in liver and muscle cells.
7.3.88	Whenever blood glucose levels decrease, glycogen is broken down to release glucose in a process known as glycogenolysis.  
7.3.89	Cellulose is the most abundant natural biopolymer.
7.3.90	The cell wall of plants is mostly made of cellulose; this provides structural support to the cell.
7.3.91	Wood and paper are mostly cellulosic in nature.
7.3.92	Cellulose is made up of glucose monomers that are linked by β 1-4 glycosidic bonds (Figure 3.10).  
7.3.93	As shown in Figure 3.10, every other glucose monomer in cellulose is flipped over, and the monomers are packed tightly as extended long chains.
7.3.94	This gives cellulose its rigidity and high tensile strength—which is so important to plant cells.
7.3.95	While the β 1-4 linkage cannot be broken down by human digestive enzymes, herbivores such as cows, koalas, buffalos, and horses are able, with the help of the specialized flora in their stomach, to digest plant material that is rich in cellulose and use it as a food source.
7.3.96	In these animals, certain species of bacteria and protists reside in the rumen (part of the digestive system of herbivores) and secrete the enzyme cellulase.
7.3.97	The appendix of grazing animals also contains bacteria that digest cellulose, giving it an important role in the digestive systems of ruminants.
7.3.98	Cellulases can break down cellulose into glucose monomers that can be used as an energy source by the animal.
7.3.99	Termites are also able to break down cellulose because of the presence of other organisms in their bodies that secrete cellulases.  
7.3.100	Carbohydrates serve various functions in different animals.
7.3.101	Arthropods (insects, crustaceans, and others) have an outer skeleton, called the exoskeleton, which protects their internal body parts (as seen in the bee in Figure 3.11).
7.3.102	This exoskeleton is made of the biological macromolecule chitin, which is a polysaccharide-containing nitrogen.
7.3.103	It is made of repeating units of N-acetyl-β-d-glucosamine, a modified sugar.
7.3.104	Chitin is also a major component of fungal cell walls; fungi are neither animals nor plants and form a kingdom of their own in the domain Eukarya.  
7.3.105	Are carbohydrates good for you?
7.3.106	People who wish to lose weight are often told that carbohydrates are bad for them and should be avoided.
7.3.107	Some diets completely forbid carbohydrate consumption, claiming that a low-carbohydrate diet helps people to lose weight faster.
7.3.108	However, carbohydrates have been an important part of the human diet for thousands of years; artifacts from ancient civilizations show the presence of wheat, rice, and corn in our ancestors’ storage areas.  
7.3.109	Carbohydrates should be supplemented with proteins, vitamins, and fats to be parts of a well-balanced diet.
7.3.110	Calorie-wise, a gram of carbohydrate provides 4.3 Kcal.
7.3.111	For comparison, fats provide 9 Kcal/g, a less desirable ratio.
7.3.112	Carbohydrates contain soluble and insoluble elements; the insoluble part is known as fiber, which is mostly cellulose.
7.3.113	Fiber has many uses; it promotes regular bowel movement by adding bulk, and it regulates the rate of consumption of blood glucose.
7.3.114	Fiber also helps to remove excess cholesterol from the body: fiber binds to the cholesterol in the small intestine, then attaches to the cholesterol and prevents the cholesterol particles from entering the bloodstream, and then cholesterol exits the body via the feces.
7.3.115	Fiber-rich diets also have a protective role in reducing the occurrence of colon cancer.
7.3.116	In addition, a meal containing whole grains and vegetables gives a feeling of fullness.
7.3.117	As an immediate source of energy, glucose is broken down during the process of cellular respiration, which produces ATP, the energy currency of the cell.
7.3.118	Without the consumption of carbohydrates, the availability of “instant energy” would be reduced.
7.3.119	Eliminating carbohydrates from the diet is not the best way to lose weight.
7.3.120	A low-calorie diet that is rich in whole grains, fruits, vegetables, and lean meat, together with plenty of exercise and plenty of water, is the more sensible way to lose weight.  
7.3.121	Lipids include a diverse group of compounds that are largely nonpolar in nature.
7.3.122	This is because they are hydrocarbons that include mostly nonpolar carbon–carbon or carbon–hydrogen bonds.
7.3.123	Non-polar molecules are hydrophobic (“water fearing”), or insoluble in water.
7.3.124	Lipids perform many different functions in a cell.
7.3.125	Cells store energy for long-term use in the form of fats.
7.3.126	Lipids also provide insulation from the environment for plants and animals (Figure 3.12).
7.3.127	For example, they help keep aquatic birds and mammals dry when forming a protective layer over fur or feathers because of their water- repellant hydrophobic nature.
7.3.128	Lipids are also the building blocks of many hormones and are an important constituent of all cellular membranes.
7.3.129	Lipids include fats, oils, waxes, phospholipids, and steroids.  
7.3.130	A fat molecule consists of two main components—glycerol and fatty acids.
7.3.131	Glycerol is an organic compound (alcohol) with three carbons, five hydrogens, and three hydroxyl (OH) groups.
7.3.132	Fatty acids have a long chain of hydrocarbons to which a carboxyl group is attached, hence the name “
7.3.133	fatty acid.
7.3.134	”
7.3.135	The number of carbons in the fatty acid may range from 4 to 36; most common are those containing 12–18 carbons.
7.3.136	In a fat molecule, the fatty acids are attached to each of the three carbons of the glycerol molecule with an ester bond through an oxygen atom (Figure 3.13).
7.3.137	During this ester bond formation, three water molecules are released.
7.3.138	The three fatty acids in the triacylglycerol may be similar or dissimilar.
7.3.139	Fats are also called triacylglycerols or triglycerides because of their chemical structure.
7.3.140	Some fatty acids have common names that specify their origin.
7.3.141	For example, palmitic acid, a saturated fatty acid, is derived from the palm tree.
7.3.142	Arachidic acid is derived from Arachis hypogea, the scientific name for groundnuts or peanuts.  
7.3.143	Fatty acids may be saturated or unsaturated.
7.3.144	In a fatty acid chain, if there are only single bonds between neighboring carbons in the hydrocarbon chain, the fatty acid is said to be saturated.
7.3.145	Saturated fatty acids are saturated with hydrogen; in other words, the number of hydrogen atoms attached to the carbon skeleton is maximized.
7.3.146	Stearic acid is an example of a saturated fatty acid (Figure 3.14)  Most unsaturated fats are liquid at room temperature and are called oils.
7.3.147	If there is one double bond in the molecule, then it is known as a monounsaturated fat (e.g., olive oil), and if there is more than one double bond, then it is known as a polyunsaturated fat (e.g., canola oil).  
7.3.148	When a fatty acid has no double bonds, it is known as a saturated fatty acid because no more hydrogen may be added to the carbon atoms of the chain.
7.3.149	A fat may contain similar or different fatty acids attached to glycerol.
7.3.150	Long straight fatty acids with single bonds tend to get packed tightly and are solid at room temperature.
7.3.151	Animal fats with stearic acid and palmitic acid
7.3.152	(common in meat) and the fat with butyric acid (common in butter) are examples of saturated fats.
7.3.153	Mammals store fats in specialized cells called adipocytes, where globules of fat occupy most of the cell’s volume.
7.3.154	In plants, fat or oil is stored in many seeds and is used as a source of energy during seedling development.
7.3.155	Unsaturated fats or oils are usually of plant origin and contain cis unsaturated fatty acids.
7.3.156	Cis and trans indicate the configuration of the molecule around the double bond.
7.3.157	If hydrogens are present in the same plane, it is referred to as a cis fat; if the hydrogen atoms are on two different planes, it is referred to as a trans fat.
7.3.158	The cis double bond causes a bend or a “kink
7.3.159	” that prevents the fatty acids from packing tightly, keeping them liquid at room temperature (Figure 3.16).
7.3.160	Olive oil, corn oil, canola oil, and cod liver oil are examples of unsaturated fats.
7.3.161	Unsaturated fats help to lower blood cholesterol levels whereas saturated fats contribute to plaque formation in the arteries.  
7.3.162	In the food industry, oils are artificially hydrogenated to make them semi-solid and of a consistency desirable for many processed food products.
7.3.163	Simply speaking, hydrogen gas is bubbled through oils to solidify them.
7.3.164	During this hydrogenation process, double bonds of the cis- conformation in the hydrocarbon chain may be converted to double bonds in the trans- conformation.  
7.3.165	Margarine, some types of peanut butter, and shortening are examples of artificially hydrogenated trans fats.
7.3.166	Recent studies have shown that an increase in trans fats in the human diet may lead to an increase in levels of low-density lipoproteins (LDL), or “bad” cholesterol, which in turn may lead to plaque deposition in the arteries, resulting in heart disease.
7.3.167	Many fast food restaurants have recently banned the use of trans fats, and food labels are required to display the trans fat content.  
7.3.168	Essential fatty acids are fatty acids required but not synthesized by the human body.
7.3.169	Consequently, they have to be supplemented through ingestion via the diet.
7.3.170	Omega-3 fatty acids (like that shown in Figure 3.17) fall into this category and are one of only two known for humans
7.3.171	(the other being omega-6 fatty acid).
7.3.172	These are polyunsaturated fatty acids and are called omega-3 because the third carbon from the end of the hydrocarbon chain is connected to its neighboring carbon by a double bond.  
7.3.173	The farthest carbon away from the carboxyl group is numbered as the omega (ω) carbon, and if the double bond is between the third and fourth carbon from that end, it is known as an omega-3 fatty acid.
7.3.174	Nutritionally important because the body does not make them, omega-3 fatty acids include alpha-linoleic acid (ALA), eicosapentaenoic acid (EPA), and docosahexaenoic acid (DHA), all of which are polyunsaturated.
7.3.175	Salmon, trout, and tuna are good sources of omega-3 fatty acids.
7.3.176	Research indicates that omega-3 fatty acids reduce the risk of sudden death from heart attacks, reduce triglycerides in the blood, lower blood pressure, and prevent thrombosis by inhibiting blood clotting.
7.3.177	They also reduce inflammation, and may help reduce the risk of some cancers in animals.  
7.3.178	Like carbohydrates, fats have received a lot of bad publicity.
7.3.179	It is true that eating an excess of fried foods and other “fatty” foods leads to weight gain.
7.3.180	However, fats do have important functions.
7.3.181	Many vitamins are fat soluble, and fats serve as a long-term storage form of fatty acids: a source of energy.
7.3.182	They also provide insulation for the body.
7.3.183	Therefore, “healthy” fats in moderate amounts should be consumed on a regular basis.  
7.3.184	Wax covers the feathers of some aquatic birds and the leaf surfaces of some plants.
7.3.185	Because of the hydrophobic nature of waxes, they prevent water from sticking on the surface (Figure 3.18).
7.3.186	Waxes are made up of long fatty acid chains esterified to long-chain alcohols.  
7.3.187	Phospholipids are major constituents of the plasma membrane, the outermost layer of animal cells.
7.3.188	Like fats, they are composed of fatty acid chains attached to a glycerol or sphingosine backbone.
7.3.189	Instead of three fatty acids attached as in triglycerides, however, there are two fatty acids forming diacylglycerol, and the third carbon of the glycerol backbone is  occupied by a modified phosphate group (Figure 3.19).
7.3.190	A phosphate group alone attached to a diaglycerol does not qualify as a phospholipid; it is phosphatidate (diacylglycerol 3-phosphate), the precursor of phospholipids.
7.3.191	The phosphate group is modified by an alcohol.
7.3.192	Phosphatidylcholine and phosphatidylserine are two important phospholipids that are found in plasma membranes.  
7.3.193	A phospholipid is an amphipathic molecule, meaning it has a hydrophobic and a hydrophilic part.
7.3.194	The fatty acid chains are hydrophobic and cannot interact with water, whereas the phosphate-containing group is hydrophilic and interacts with water  
7.3.195	The head is the hydrophilic part, and the tail contains the hydrophobic fatty acids.
7.3.196	In a membrane, a bilayer of phospholipids forms the matrix of the structure, the fatty acid tails of phospholipids face inside, away from water, whereas the phosphate group faces the outside, aqueous side (Figure 3.20).  
7.3.197	Phospholipids are responsible for the dynamic nature of the plasma membrane.
7.3.198	If a drop of phospholipids is placed in water, it spontaneously forms a structure known as a micelle, where the hydrophilic phosphate heads face the outside and the fatty acids face the interior of this structure.  
7.3.199	Unlike the phospholipids and fats discussed earlier, steroids have a fused ring structure.
7.3.200	Although they do not resemble the other lipids, they are grouped with them because they are also hydrophobicand insoluble in water.
7.3.201	All steroids have four linked carbon rings and several of them, like cholesterol, have a short tail (Figure 3.21).
7.3.202	Many steroids also have the –OH functional group, which puts them in the alcohol classification (sterols).  
7.3.203	Cholesterol is the most common steroid.
7.3.204	Cholesterol is mainly synthesized in the liver and is the precursor to many steroid hormones such as testosterone and estradiol, which are secreted by the gonads and endocrine glands.
7.3.205	It is also the precursor to Vitamin D. Cholesterol is also the precursor of bile salts, which help in the emulsification of fats and their subsequent absorption by cells.
7.3.206	Although cholesterol is often spoken of in negative terms by lay people, it is necessary for proper functioning of the body.
7.3.207	It is a component of the plasma membrane of animal cells and is found within the phospholipid bilayer.
7.3.208	Being the outermost structure in animal cells, the plasma membrane is responsible for the transport of materials and cellular recognition and it is involved in cell-to-cell communication.  
7.3.209	Proteins are one of the most abundant organic molecules in living systems and have the most diverse range of functions of all macromolecules.
7.3.210	Proteins may be structural, regulatory, contractile, or protective; they may serve in transport, storage, or membranes; or they may be toxins or enzymes.
7.3.211	Each cell in a living system may contain thousands of proteins, each with a unique function.
7.3.212	Their structures, like their functions, vary greatly.
7.3.213	They are all, however, polymers of amino acids, arranged in a linear sequence.  
7.3.214	Enzymes, which are produced by living cells, are catalysts in biochemical reactions (like digestion) and are usually complex or conjugated proteins.
7.3.215	Each enzyme is specific for the substrate (a reactant that binds to an enzyme) it acts on.
7.3.216	The enzyme may help in breakdown, rearrangement, or synthesis reactions.
7.3.217	Enzymes that break down their substrates are called catabolic enzymes, enzymes that build more complex molecules from their substrates are called anabolic enzymes, and enzymes that affect the rate of reaction are called catalytic enzymes.
7.3.218	It should be noted that all enzymes increase the rate of reaction and, therefore, are considered to be organic catalysts.
7.3.219	An example of an enzyme is salivary amylase, which hydrolyzes its substrate amylose, a component of starch.  
7.3.220	Hormones are chemical-signaling molecules, usually small proteins or steroids, secreted by endocrine cells that act to control or regulate specific physiological processes, including growth, development, metabolism, and reproduction.
7.3.221	For example, insulin is a protein hormone that helps to regulate the blood glucose level.
7.3.222	The primary types and functions of proteins are listed in Table 3.1.  
7.3.223	Proteins have different shapes and molecular weights; some proteins are globular in shape whereas others are fibrous in nature.
7.3.224	For example, hemoglobin is a globular protein, but collagen, found in our skin, is a fibrous protein.
7.3.225	Protein shape is critical to its function, and this shape is maintained by many different types of chemical bonds.
7.3.226	Changes in temperature, pH, and exposure to chemicals may lead to permanent changes in the shape of the protein, leading to loss of function, known as denaturation.
7.3.227	All proteins are made up of different arrangements of the same 20 types of amino acids.  
7.3.228	Amino acids are the monomers that make up proteins.
7.3.229	Each amino acid has the same fundamental structure, which consists of a central carbon atom, also known as the alpha (α) carbon, bonded to an amino group (NH2), a carboxyl group (COOH), and to a hydrogen atom.
7.3.230	Every amino acid also has another atom or group of atoms bonded to the central atom known as the R group (Figure 3.22).  
7.3.231	The name "amino acid" is derived from the fact that they contain both amino group and carboxyl-acid-group in their basic structure.
7.3.232	As mentioned, there are 20 amino acids present in proteins.
7.3.233	Ten of these are considered essential amino acids in humans because the human body cannot produce them and they are obtained from the diet.
7.3.234	For each amino acid, the R group (or side chain) is different (Figure 3.23).  
7.3.235	The chemical nature of the side chain determines the nature of the amino acid (that is, whether it is acidic, basic, polar, or nonpolar).
7.3.236	For example, the amino acid glycine has a hydrogen atom as the R group.
7.3.237	Amino acids such as valine, methionine, and alanine are nonpolar or hydrophobic in nature, while amino acids such as serine, threonine, and cysteine are polar and have hydrophilic side chains.
7.3.238	The side chains of lysine and arginine are positively charged, and therefore these amino acids are also known as basic amino acids.
7.3.239	Proline has an R group that is linked to the amino group, forming a ring- like structure.
7.3.240	Proline is an exception to the standard structure of an animo acid since its amino group is not separate from the side chain (Figure 3.23).  
7.3.241	Amino acids are represented by a single upper case letter or a three-letter abbreviation.
7.3.242	For example, valine is known by the letter V or the three-letter symbol val.
7.3.243	Just as some fatty acids are essential to a diet, some amino acids are necessary as well.
7.3.244	They are known as essential amino acids, and in humans they include isoleucine, leucine, and cysteine.
7.3.245	Essential amino acids refer to those necessary for construction of proteins in the body, although not produced by the body; which amino acids are essential varies from organism to organism.  
7.3.246	The sequence and the number of amino acids ultimately determine the protein's shape, size, and function.
7.3.247	Each amino acid is attached to another amino acid by a covalent bond, known as a peptide bond, which is formed by a dehydration reaction.
7.3.248	The carboxyl group of one amino acid and the amino group of the incoming amino acid combine, releasing a molecule of water.
7.3.249	The resulting bond is the peptide bond (Figure 3.24).  
7.3.250	The products formed by such linkages are called peptides.
7.3.251	As more amino acids join to this growing chain, the resulting chain is known as a polypeptide.
7.3.252	Each polypeptide has a free amino group at one end.
7.3.253	This end is called the N terminal, or the amino terminal, and the other end has a free carboxyl group, also known as the C or carboxyl terminal.
7.3.254	While the terms polypeptide and protein are sometimes used interchangeably, a polypeptide is technically a polymer of amino acids, whereas the term protein is used for a polypeptide or polypeptides that have combined together, often have bound non- peptide prosthetic groups, have a distinct shape, and have a unique function.
7.3.255	After protein synthesis (translation), most proteins are modified.
7.3.256	These are known as post-translational modifications.
7.3.257	They may undergo cleavage, phosphorylation, or may require the addition of other chemical groups.
7.3.258	Only after these modifications is the protein completely functional.  
7.3.259	As discussed earlier, the shape of a protein is critical to its function.
7.3.260	For example, an enzyme can bind to a specific substrate at a site known as the active site.
7.3.261	If this active site is altered because of local changes or changes in overall protein structure, the enzyme may be unable to bind to the substrate.
7.3.262	To understand how the protein gets its final shape or conformation, we need to understand the four levels of protein structure: primary, secondary, tertiary, and quaternary.  
7.3.263	The unique sequence of amino acids in a polypeptide chain is its primary structure.
7.3.264	For example, the pancreatic hormone insulin has two polypeptide chains, A and B, and they are linked together by disulfide bonds.
7.3.265	The N terminal amino acid of the A chain is glycine, whereas the C terminal amino acid is asparagine (Figure 3.25).
7.3.266	The sequences of amino acids in the A and B chains are unique to insulin.  
7.3.267	The unique sequence for every protein is ultimately determined by the gene encoding the protein.
7.3.268	A change in nucleotide sequence of the gene’s coding region may lead to a different amino acid being added to the growing polypeptide chain, causing a change in protein structure and function.
7.3.269	In sickle cell anemia, the hemoglobin β chain (a small portion of which is shown in Figure 3.26) has a single amino acid substitution, causing a change in protein structure and function.
7.3.270	Specifically, the amino acid glutamic acid is substituted by valine in the β chain.
7.3.271	What is most remarkable to consider is that a hemoglobin molecule is made up of two alpha chains and two beta chains that each consist of about 150 amino acids.
7.3.272	The molecule, therefore, has about 600 amino acids.
7.3.273	The structural difference between a normal hemoglobin molecule and a sickle cell molecule—which dramatically decreases life expectancy—is a single amino acid of the 600.
7.3.274	What is even more remarkable is that those 600 amino acids are encoded by three nucleotides each, and the mutation is caused by a single base change (point mutation), 1 in 1800 bases.  
7.3.275	Because of this change of one amino acid in the chain, hemoglobin molecules form long fibers that distort the biconcave, or disc-shaped, red blood cells and assume a crescent or “sickle” shape, which clogs arteries (Figure 3.27).
7.3.276	This can lead to myriad serious health problems such as breathlessness, dizziness, headaches, and abdominal pain for those affected by this disease.  
7.3.277	The local folding of the polypeptide in some regions gives rise to the secondary structure of the protein.
7.3.278	The most common are the α-helix and β-pleated sheet structures (Figure 3.28).
7.3.279	Both structures are the α-helix structure—
7.3.280	the helix held in shape by hydrogen bonds.
7.3.281	The hydrogen bonds form between the oxygen atom in the carbonyl group in one amino acid and another amino acid that is four amino acids farther along the chain.  
7.3.282	Every helical turn in an alpha helix has 3.6 amino acid residues.
7.3.283	The R groups (the variant groups) of the polypeptide protrude out from the α-helix chain.
7.3.284	In the β-pleated sheet, the “pleats” are formed by hydrogen bonding between atoms on the backbone of the polypeptide chain.
7.3.285	The R groups are attached to the carbons and extend above and below the folds of the pleat.
7.3.286	The pleated segments align parallel or antiparallel to each other, and hydrogen bonds form between the partially positive nitrogen atom in the amino group and the partially negative oxygen atom in the carbonyl group of the peptide backbone.
7.3.287	The α-helix and β-pleated sheet structures are found in most globular and fibrous proteins and they play an important structural role.  
7.3.288	The unique three-dimensional structure of a polypeptide is its tertiary structure (Figure 3.29).
7.3.289	This structure is in part due to chemical interactions at work on the polypeptide chain.
7.3.290	Primarily, the interactions among R groups creates the complex three-dimensional tertiary structure of a protein.
7.3.291	The nature of the R groups found in the amino acids involved can counteract the formation of the hydrogen bonds described for standard secondary structures.
7.3.292	For example, R groups with like charges are repelled by each other and those with unlike charges are attracted to each other (ionic bonds).
7.3.293	When protein folding takes place, the hydrophobic R groups of nonpolar amino acids lay in the interior of the protein, whereas the hydrophilic R groups lay on the outside.
7.3.294	The former types of interactions are also known as hydrophobic interactions.
7.3.295	Interaction between cysteine side chains forms disulfide linkages in the presence of oxygen, the only covalent bond forming during protein folding.  
7.3.296	All of these interactions, weak and strong, determine the final three-dimensional shape of the protein.
7.3.297	When a protein loses its three-dimensional shape, it may no longer be functional.  
7.3.298	In nature, some proteins are formed from several polypeptides, also known as subunits, and the interaction of these subunits forms the quaternary structure.
7.3.299	Weak interactions between the subunits help to stabilize the overall structure.
7.3.300	For example, insulin (a globular protein) has a combination of hydrogen bonds and disulfide bonds that cause it to be mostly clumped into a ball shape.
7.3.301	Insulin starts out as a single polypeptide and loses some internal sequences in the presence of post-translational modification after the formation of the disulfide linkages that hold the remaining chains together.
7.3.302	Silk (a fibrous protein), however, has a β-pleated sheet structure that is the result of hydrogen bonding between different chains.  
7.3.303	The four levels of protein structure (primary, secondary, tertiary, and quaternary) are illustrated in Figure 3.30.  
7.3.304	Each protein has its own unique sequence and shape that are held together by chemical interactions.
7.3.305	If the protein is subject to changes in temperature, pH, or exposure to chemicals, the protein structure may change, losing its shape without losing its primary sequence in what is known as denaturation.
7.3.306	Denaturation is often reversible because the primary structure of the polypeptide is conserved in the process if the denaturing agent is removed, allowing the protein to resume its function.
7.3.307	Sometimes denaturation is irreversible, leading to loss of function.
7.3.308	One example of irreversible protein denaturation is when an egg is fried.
7.3.309	The albumin protein in the liquid egg white is denatured when placed in a hot pan.
7.3.310	Not all proteins are denatured at high temperatures; for instance, bacteria that survive in hot springs have proteins that function at temperatures close to boiling.
7.3.311	The stomach is also very acidic, has a low pH, and denatures proteins as part of the digestion process; however, the digestive enzymes of the stomach retain their activity under these conditions.  
7.3.312	Protein folding is critical to its function.
7.3.313	It was originally thought that the proteins themselves were responsible for the folding process.
7.3.314	Only recently was it found that often they receive assistance in the folding process from protein helpers known as chaperones (or chaperonins) that associate with the target protein during the folding process.
7.3.315	They act by preventing aggregation of polypeptides that make up the complete protein structure, and they disassociate from the protein once the target protein is folded.  
7.3.316	Nucleic acids are the most important macromolecules for the continuity of life.
7.3.317	They carry the genetic blueprint of a cell and carry instructions for the functioning of the cell.  
7.3.318	The two main types of nucleic acids are deoxyribonucleic acid (DNA) and ribonucleic acid (RNA).
7.3.319	DNA is the genetic material found in all living organisms, ranging from single-celled bacteria to multicellular mammals.
7.3.320	It is found in the nucleus of eukaryotes and in the organelles, chloroplasts, and mitochondria.
7.3.321	In prokaryotes, the DNA is not enclosed in a membranous envelope.  
7.3.322	The entire genetic content of a cell is known as its genome, and the study of genomes is genomics.
