7.3.323	In eukaryotic cells but not in prokaryotes, DNA forms a complex with histone proteins to form chromatin, the substance of eukaryotic chromosomes.
7.3.324	A chromosome may contain tens of thousands of genes.
7.3.325	Many genes contain the information to make protein products; other genes code for RNA products.
7.3.326	DNA controls all of the cellular activities by turning the genes “on” or “off.
7.3.327	”  
7.3.328	The other type of nucleic acid, RNA, is mostly involved in protein synthesis.
7.3.329	The DNA molecules never leave the nucleus but instead use an intermediary to communicate with the rest of the cell.
7.3.330	This intermediary is the messenger RNA (mRNA).
7.3.331	Other types of RNA—like rRNA, tRNA, and microRNA—are involved in protein synthesis and its regulation.  
7.3.332	DNA and RNA are made up of monomers known as nucleotides.
7.3.333	The nucleotides combine with each other to form a polynucleotide, DNA or RNA.
7.3.334	Each nucleotide is made up of three components: a nitrogenous base, a pentose (five- carbon) sugar, and a phosphate group (Figure 3.31).
7.3.335	Each nitrogenous base in a nucleotide is attached to a sugar molecule, which is attached to one or more phosphate groups.  
7.3.336	The nitrogenous bases, important components of nucleotides, are organic molecules and are so named because they contain carbon and nitrogen.
7.3.337	They are bases because they contain an amino group that has the potential of binding an extra hydrogen, and thus, decreases the hydrogen ion concentration in its environment, making it more basic.
7.3.338	Each nucleotide in DNA contains one of four possible nitrogenous bases: adenine (A), guanine (G) cytosine (C), and thymine (T).  
7.3.339	Adenine and guanine are classified as purines.
7.3.340	The primary structure of a purine is two carbon-nitrogen rings.
7.3.341	Cytosine, thymine, and uracil are classified as pyrimidines which have a single carbon-nitrogen ring as their primary structure (Figure 3.31).
7.3.342	Each of these basic carbon-nitrogen rings has different functional groups attached to it.
7.3.343	In molecular biology shorthand, the nitrogenous bases are simply known by their symbols A, T, G, C, and U. DNA contains A, T, G, and C
7.3.344	whereas RNA contains A, U, G, and C.  The pentose sugar in DNA is deoxyribose, and in RNA, the sugar is ribose (Figure 3.31).
7.3.345	The difference between the sugars is the presence of the hydroxyl group on the second carbon of the ribose and hydrogen on the second carbon of the deoxyribose.
7.3.346	The carbon atoms of the sugar molecule are numbered as 1′, 2′, 3′, 4′, and 5′ (1′ is read as “one prime”).
7.3.347	The phosphate residue is attached to the hydroxyl group of the 5′ carbon of one sugar and the hydroxyl group of the 3′ carbon of the sugar of the next nucleotide, which forms a 5′–3′ phosphodiester linkage.
7.3.348	The phosphodiester linkage is not formed  by simple dehydration reaction like the other linkages connecting monomers in macromolecules: its formation involves the removal of two phosphate groups.
7.3.349	A polynucleotide may have thousands of such phosphodiester linkages.  
7.3.350	DNA has a double-helix structure (Figure 3.32).
7.3.351	The sugar and phosphate lie on the outside of the helix, forming the backbone of the DNA.
7.3.352	The nitrogenous bases are stacked in the interior, like the steps of a staircase, in pairs; the pairs are bound to each other by hydrogen bonds.
7.3.353	Every base pair in the double helivx is separated from the next base pair by 0.34 nm.
7.3.354	The two strands of the helix run in opposite directions, meaning that the 5′ carbon end of one strand will face the 3′ carbon end of its matching strand.
7.3.355	(This is referred to as antiparallel orientation and is important to DNA replication and in many nucleic acid interactions.)  
7.3.356	Only certain types of base pairing are allowed.
7.3.357	For example, a certain purine can only pair with a certain pyrimidine.
7.3.358	This means A can pair with T, and G can pair with C, as shown in Figure 3.33.
7.3.359	This is known as the base complementary rule.
7.3.360	In other words, the DNA strands are complementary to each other.
7.3.361	If the sequence of one strand is AATTGGCC, the complementary strand would have the sequence TTAACCGG.
7.3.362	During DNA replication, each strand is copied, resulting in a daughter DNA double helix containing one parental DNA strand and a newly synthesized strand.  
7.3.363	Ribonucleic acid, or RNA, is mainly involved in the process of protein synthesis under the direction of DNA.
7.3.364	RNA is usually single-stranded and is made of ribonucleotides that are linked by phosphodiester bonds.
7.3.365	A ribonucleotide in the RNA chain contains ribose (the pentose sugar), one of the four nitrogenous bases (A, U, G, and C), and the phosphate group.  
7.3.366	There are four major types of RNA:
7.3.367	messenger RNA (mRNA), ribosomal RNA (rRNA), transfer RNA (tRNA), and microRNA (miRNA).
7.3.368	The first, mRNA, carries the message from DNA, which controls all of the cellular activities in a cell.
7.3.369	If a cell requires a certain protein to be synthesized, the gene for this product is turned “on” and the messenger RNA is synthesized in the nucleus.
7.3.370	The RNA base sequence is complementary to the coding sequence of the DNA from which it has been copied.
7.3.371	However, in RNA, the base T is absent and U is present instead.
7.3.372	If the DNA strand has a sequence AATTGCGC, the sequence of the complementary RNA is UUAACGCG.
7.3.373	In the cytoplasm, the mRNA interacts with ribosomes and other cellular machinery (Figure 3.34).  
7.3.374	The mRNA is read in sets of three bases known as codons.
7.3.375	Each codon codes for a single amino acid.
7.3.376	In this way, the mRNA is read and the protein product is made.
7.3.377	Ribosomal RNA (rRNA) is a major constituent of ribosomes on which the mRNA binds.
7.3.378	The rRNA ensures the proper alignment of the mRNA and the ribosomes; the rRNA of the ribosome  also has an enzymatic activity (peptidyl transferase) and catalyzes the formation of the peptide bonds between two aligned amino acids.
7.3.379	Transfer RNA (tRNA) is one of the smallest of the four types of RNA, usually 70–90 nucleotides long.
7.3.380	It carries the correct amino acid to the site of protein synthesis.
7.3.381	It is the base pairing between the tRNA and mRNA that allows for the correct amino acid to be inserted in the polypeptide chain.
7.3.382	microRNAs are the smallest RNA molecules and their role involves the regulation of gene expression by interfering with the expression of certain mRNA messages.
7.3.383	Table 3.2 summarizes features of DNA and RNA.  
7.3.384	Even though the RNA is single stranded, most RNA types show extensive intramolecular base pairing between complementary sequences, creating a predictable three-dimensional structure essential for their function.  
7.3.385	As you have learned, information flow in an organism takes place from DNA to RNA to protein.
7.3.386	DNA dictates the structure of mRNA in a process known as transcription, and RNA dictates the structure of protein in a process known as translation.
7.3.387	This is known as the Central Dogma of Life, which holds true for all organisms; however, exceptions to the rule occur in connection with viral infections.  
7.3.388	Proteins, carbohydrates, nucleic acids, and lipids are the four major classes of biological macromolecules
7.3.389	—large molecules necessary for life that are built from smaller organic molecules.
7.3.390	Macromolecules are made up of single units known as monomers that are joined by covalent bonds to form larger polymers.
7.3.391	The polymer is more than the sum of its parts: it acquires new characteristics, and leads to an osmotic pressure that is much lower than that formed by its ingredients; this is an important advantage in the maintenance of cellular osmotic conditions.
7.3.392	A monomer joins with another monomer with the release of a water molecule, leading to the formation of a covalent bond.
7.3.393	These types of reactions are known as dehydration or condensation reactions.
7.3.394	When polymers are broken down into smaller units (monomers), a molecule of water is used for each bond broken by these reactions; such reactions are known as hydrolysis reactions.
7.3.395	Dehydration and hydrolysis reactions are similar for all macromolecules, but each monomer and polymer reaction is specific to its class.
7.3.396	Dehydration reactions typically require an investment of energy for new bond formation, while hydrolysis reactions typically release energy by breaking bonds.  
7.3.397	Carbohydrates are a group of macromolecules that are a vital energy source for the cell and provide structural support to plant cells, fungi, and all of the arthropods that include lobsters, crabs, shrimp, insects, and spiders.
7.3.398	Carbohydrates are classified as monosaccharides, disaccharides, and polysaccharides depending on the number of monomers in the molecule.
7.3.399	Monosaccharides are linked by glycosidic bonds that are formed as a result of dehydration reactions, forming disaccharides and polysaccharides with the elimination of a water molecule for each bond formed.
7.3.400	Glucose, galactose, and fructose are common monosaccharides, whereas common disaccharides include lactose, maltose, and sucrose.
7.3.401	Starch and glycogen, examples of polysaccharides, are the storage forms of glucose in plants and animals, respectively.
7.3.402	The long polysaccharide chains may be branched or unbranched.
7.3.403	Cellulose is an example of an unbranched polysaccharide, whereas amylopectin, a constituent of starch, is a highly branched molecule.
7.3.404	Storage of glucose, in the form of polymers like starch of glycogen, makes it slightly less accessible for metabolism; however, this prevents it from leaking out of the cell or creating a high osmotic pressure that could cause excessive water uptake by the cell.  
7.3.405	Lipids are a class of macromolecules that are nonpolar and hydrophobic in nature.
7.3.406	Major types include fats and oils, waxes, phospholipids, and steroids.
7.3.407	Fats are a stored form of energy and are also known as triacylglycerols or triglycerides.
7.3.408	Fats are made up of fatty acids and either glycerol or sphingosine.
7.3.409	Fatty acids may be unsaturated or saturated, depending on the presence or absence of double bonds in the hydrocarbon chain.
7.3.410	If only single bonds are present, they are known as saturated fatty acids.
7.3.411	Unsaturated fatty acids may have one or more double bonds in the hydrocarbon chain.
7.3.412	Phospholipids make up the matrix of membranes.
7.3.413	They have a glycerol or sphingosine backbone to which two fatty acid chains and a phosphate-containing group are attached.
7.3.414	Steroids are another class of lipids.
7.3.415	Their basic structure has four fused carbon rings.
7.3.416	Cholesterol is a type of steroid and is an important constituent of the plasma membrane, where it helps to maintain the fluid nature of the membrane.
7.3.417	It is also the precursor of steroid hormones such as testosterone.  
7.3.418	Proteins are a class of macromolecules that perform a diverse range of functions for the cell.
7.3.419	They help in metabolism by providing structural support and by acting as enzymes, carriers, or hormones.
7.3.420	The building blocks of proteins (monomers) are amino acids.
7.3.421	Each amino acid has a central carbon that is linked to an amino group, a carboxyl group, a hydrogen atom, and an R group or side chain.
7.3.422	There are 20 commonly occurring amino acids, each of which differs in the R group.
7.3.423	Each amino acid is linked to its neighbors by a peptide bond.
7.3.424	A long chain of amino acids is known as a polypeptide.  
7.3.425	Proteins are organized at four levels: primary, secondary, tertiary, and (optional) quaternary.
7.3.426	The primary structure is the unique sequence of amino acids.
7.3.427	The local folding of the polypeptide to form structures such as the α helix and β-pleated sheet constitutes the secondary structure.
7.3.428	The overall three-dimensional structure is the tertiary structure.
7.3.429	When two or more polypeptides combine to form the complete protein structure, the configuration is known as the quaternary structure of a protein.
7.3.430	Protein shape and function are intricately linked; any change in shape caused by changes in temperature or pH may lead to protein denaturation and a loss in function.  
7.3.431	Nucleic acids are molecules made up of nucleotides that direct cellular activities such as cell division and protein synthesis.
7.3.432	Each nucleotide is made up of a pentose sugar, a nitrogenous base, and a phosphate group.
7.3.433	There are two types of nucleic acids: DNA and RNA.
7.3.434	DNA carries the genetic blueprint of the cell and is passed on from parents to offspring  
7.3.435	(in the form of chromosomes).
7.3.436	It has a double-helical structure with the two strands running in opposite directions, connected by hydrogen bonds, and complementary to each other.
7.3.437	RNA is single-stranded and is made of a pentose sugar (ribose), a nitrogenous base, and a phosphate group.
7.3.438	RNA is involved in protein synthesis and its regulation.
7.3.439	Messenger RNA (mRNA) is copied from the DNA, is exported from the nucleus to the cytoplasm, and contains information for the construction of proteins.
7.3.440	Ribosomal RNA (rRNA) is a part of the ribosomes at the site of protein synthesis, whereas transfer RNA (tRNA) carries the amino acid to the site of protein synthesis.
7.3.441	microRNA regulates the use of mRNA for protein synthesis.  
7.3.442	Figure 3.2
7.3.443	In the dehydration synthesis reaction depicted above, two molecules of glucose are linked together to form the disaccharide maltose.
7.3.444	In the process, a water molecule is formed.
7.3.445	Figure 3.3
7.3.446	In the hydrolysis reaction shown here, the disaccharide maltose is broken down to form two glucose monomers with the addition of a water molecule.
7.3.447	Note that this reaction is the reverse of the synthesis reaction shown in Figure 3.2.
7.3.448	Figure 3.4 Monosaccharides are classified based on the position of their carbonyl group and the number of carbons in the backbone.
7.3.449	Aldoses have a carbonyl group (indicated in green) at the end of the carbon chain, and ketoses have a carbonyl group in the middle of the carbon chain.
7.3.450	Trioses, pentoses, and hexoses have three, five, and six carbon backbones, respectively.
7.3.451	Figure 3.6 Five and six carbon monosaccharides exist in equilibrium between linear and ring forms.
7.3.452	When the ring forms, the side chain it closes on is locked into an α or β position.
7.3.453	Fructose and ribose also form rings, although they form five-membered rings as opposed to the six-membered ring of glucose.
7.3.454	Figure 3.7 Sucrose is formed when a monomer of glucose and a monomer of fructose are joined in a dehydration reaction to form a glycosidic bond.
7.3.455	In the process, a water molecule is lost.
7.3.456	By convention, the carbon atoms in a monosaccharide are numbered from the terminal carbon closest to the carbonyl group.
7.3.457	In sucrose, a glycosidic linkage is formed between carbon 1 in glucose and carbon 2 in fructose.
7.3.458	Figure 3.8
7.3.459	Common disaccharides include maltose (grain sugar), lactose (milk sugar), and sucrose (table sugar).
7.3.460	Figure 3.9 Amylose and amylopectin are two different forms of starch.
7.3.461	Amylose is composed of unbranched chains of glucose monomers connected by α 1,4 glycosidic linkages.
7.3.462	Amylopectin is composed of branched chains of glucose monomers connected by α 1,4 and α 1,6 glycosidic linkages.
7.3.463	Because of the way the subunits are joined, the glucose chains have a helical structure.
7.3.464	Glycogen (not shown) is similar in structure to amylopectin but more highly branched.
7.3.465	Figure 3.10
7.3.466	In cellulose, glucose monomers are linked in unbranched chains by β 1-4 glycosidic linkages.
7.3.467	Because of the way the glucose subunits are joined, every glucose monomer is flipped relative to the next one resulting in a linear, fibrous structure.
7.3.468	Figure 3.11 Insects have a hard outer exoskeleton made of chitin, a type of polysaccharide.
7.3.469	(credit: Louise Docker)
7.3.470	Obesity is a worldwide health concern, and many diseases such as diabetes and heart disease are becoming more prevalent because of obesity.
7.3.471	This is one of the reasons why registered dietitians are increasingly sought after for advice.
7.3.472	Registered dietitians help plan nutrition programs for individuals in various settings.
7.3.473	They often work with patients in health care facilities, designing nutrition plans to treat and prevent diseases.
7.3.474	For example, dietitians may teach a patient with diabetes how to manage blood sugar levels by eating the correct types and amounts of carbohydrates.
7.3.475	Dietitians may also work in nursing homes, schools, and private practices.
7.3.476	To become a registered dietitian, one needs to earn at least a bachelor’s degree in dietetics, nutrition, food technology, or a related field.
7.3.477	In addition, registered dietitians must complete a supervised internship program and pass a national exam.
7.3.478	Those who pursue careers in dietetics take courses in nutrition, chemistry, biochemistry, biology, microbiology, and human physiology.
7.3.479	Dietitians must become experts in the chemistry and physiology (biological functions) of food (proteins, carbohydrates, and fats).
7.3.480	Figure 3.12 Hydrophobic lipids in the fur of aquatic mammals, such as this river otter, protect them from the elements.
7.3.481	(credit: Ken Bosma)
7.3.482	Figure 3.13 Triacylglycerol is formed by the joining of three fatty acids to a glycerol backbone in a dehydration reaction.
7.3.483	Three molecules of water are released in the process.
7.3.484	Figure 3.14 Stearic acid is a common saturated fatty acid.
7.3.485	Figure 3.15 Oleic acid is a common unsaturated fatty acid.
7.3.486	Figure 3.16 Saturated fatty acids have hydrocarbon chains connected by single bonds only.
7.3.487	Unsaturated fatty acids have one or more double bonds.
7.3.488	Each double bond may be in a cis or trans configuration.
7.3.489	In the cis configuration, both hydrogens are on the same side of the hydrocarbon chain.
7.3.490	In the trans configuration, the hydrogens are on opposite sides.
7.3.491	A cis double bond causes a kink in the chain.
7.3.492	Figure 3.17 Alpha-linolenic acid is an example of an omega-3 fatty acid.
7.3.493	It has three cis double bonds and, as a result, a curved shape.
7.3.494	For clarity, the carbons are not shown.
7.3.495	Each singly bonded carbon has two hydrogens associated with it, also not shown.
7.3.496	Figure 3.18
7.3.497	Waxy coverings on some leaves are made of lipids.
7.3.498	(credit: Roger Griffith) Figure 3.19
7.3.499	A phospholipid is a molecule with two fatty acids and a modified phosphate group attached to a glycerol backbone.
7.3.500	The phosphate may be modified by the addition of charged or polar chemical groups.
7.3.501	Two chemical groups that may modify the phosphate, choline and serine, are shown here.
7.3.502	Both choline and serine attach to the phosphate group at the position labeled R via the hydroxyl group indicated in green.
7.3.503	Figure 3.20
7.3.504	The phospholipid bilayer is the major component of all cellular membranes.
7.3.505	The hydrophilic head groups of the phospholipids face the aqueous solution.
7.3.506	The hydrophobic tails are sequestered in the middle of the bilayer.
7.3.507	Figure 3.21 Steroids such as cholesterol and cortisol are composed of four fused hydrocarbon rings.
7.3.508	Figure 3.22
7.3.509	Amino acids have a central asymmetric carbon to which an amino group, a carboxyl group, a hydrogen atom, and a side chain (R group) are attached.
7.3.510	Figure 3.24 Peptide bond formation is a dehydration synthesis reaction.
7.3.511	The carboxyl group of one amino acid is linked to the amino group of the incoming amino acid.
7.3.512	In the process, a molecule of water is released.
7.3.513	Cytochrome c is an important component of the electron transport chain, a part of cellular respiration, and it is normally found in the cellular organelle, the mitochondrion.
7.3.514	This protein has a heme prosthetic group, and the central ion of the heme gets alternately reduced and oxidized during electron transfer.
7.3.515	Because this essential protein’s role in producing cellular energy is crucial, it has changed very little over millions of years.
7.3.516	Protein sequencing has shown that there is a considerable amount of cytochrome c amino acid sequence homology among different species; in other words, evolutionary kinship can be assessed by measuring the similarities or differences among various species’ DNA or protein sequences.
7.3.517	Scientists have determined that human cytochrome c contains 104 amino acids.
7.3.518	For each cytochrome c molecule from different organisms that has been sequenced to date, 37 of these amino acids appear in the same position in all samples of cytochrome c.
7.3.519	This indicates that there may have been a common ancestor.
7.3.520	On comparing the human and chimpanzee protein sequences, no sequence difference was found.
7.3.521	When human and rhesus monkey sequences were compared, the single difference found was in one amino acid.
7.3.522	In another comparison, human to yeast sequencing shows a difference in the 44th position.
7.3.523	Figure 3.25
7.3.524	Bovine serum insulin is a protein hormone made of two peptide chains, A (21 amino acids long) and B (30 amino acids long).
7.3.525	In each chain, primary structure is indicated by three-letter abbreviations that represent the names of the amino acids in the order they are present.
7.3.526	The amino acid cysteine (cys) has a sulfhydryl (SH) group as a side chain.
7.3.527	Two sulfhydryl groups can react in the presence of oxygen to form a disulfide (S-S) bond.
7.3.528	Two disulfide bonds connect the A and B chains together, and a third helps the A chain fold into the correct shape.
7.3.529	Note that all disulfide bonds are the same length, but are drawn different sizes for clarity.
7.3.530	Figure 3.26
7.3.531	The beta chain of hemoglobin is 147 residues in length, yet a single amino acid substitution leads to sickle cell anemia.
7.3.532	In normal hemoglobin, the amino acid at position seven is glutamate.
7.3.533	In sickle cell hemoglobin, this glutamate is replaced by a valine.
7.3.534	Figure 3.27
7.3.535	In this blood smear, visualized at 535x magnification using bright field microscopy, sickle cells are crescent shaped, while normal cells are disc-shaped.
7.3.536	(credit: modification of work by Ed Uthman; scale-bar data from Matt Russell) Figure 3.28
7.3.537	The α-helix and β-pleated sheet are secondary structures of proteins that form because of hydrogen bonding between carbonyl and amino groups in the peptide backbone.
7.3.538	Certain amino acids have a propensity to form an α-helix, while others have a propensity to form a β-pleated sheet.
7.3.539	Figure 3.29
7.3.540	The tertiary structure of proteins is determined by a variety of chemical interactions.
7.3.541	These include hydrophobic interactions, ionic bonding, hydrogen bonding and disulfide linkages.
7.3.542	Figure 3.30
7.3.543	The four levels of protein structure can be observed in these illustrations.
7.3.544	(credit: modification of work by National Human Genome Research Institute)
7.3.545	Figure 3.31
7.3.546	A nucleotide is made up of three components: a nitrogenous base, a pentose sugar, and one or more phosphate groups.
7.3.547	Carbon residues in the pentose are numbered 1′ through 5′ (the prime distinguishes these residues from those in the base, which are numbered without using a prime notation).
7.3.548	The base is attached to the 1′ position of the ribose, and the phosphate is attached to the 5′ position.
7.3.549	When a polynucleotide is formed, the 5′ phosphate of the incoming nucleotide attaches to the 3′ hydroxyl group at the end of the growing chain.
7.3.550	Two types of pentose are found in nucleotides, deoxyribose (found in DNA) and ribose (found in RNA).
7.3.551	Deoxyribose is similar in structure to ribose, but it has an H instead of an OH at the 2′ position.
7.3.552	Bases can be divided into two categories: purines and pyrimidines.
7.3.553	Purines have a double ring structure, and pyrimidines have a single ring.
7.3.554	Figure 3.32
7.3.555	Native DNA is an antiparallel double helix.
7.3.556	The phosphate backbone (indicated by the curvy lines) is on the outside, and the bases are on the inside.
7.3.557	Each base from one strand interacts via hydrogen bonding with a base from the opposing strand.
7.3.558	(credit: Jerome Walker/Dennis Myts) Figure 3.34
7.3.559	A ribosome has two parts: a large subunit and a small subunit.
7.3.560	The mRNA sits in between the two subunits.
7.3.561	A tRNA molecule recognizes a codon on the mRNA, binds to it by complementary base pairing, and adds the correct amino acid to the growing peptide chain.   
7.4.0	Close your eyes and picture a brick wall.
7.4.1	What is the basic building block of that wall?
7.4.2	A single brick, of course.
7.4.3	Like a brick wall, your body is composed of basic building blocks, and the building blocks of your body are cells.
7.4.4	Your body has many kinds of cells, each specialized for a specific purpose.
7.4.5	Just as a home is made from a variety of building materials, the human body is constructed from many cell types.
7.4.6	For example, epithelial cells protect the surface of the body and cover the organs and body cavities within.
7.4.7	Bone cells help to support and protect the body.
7.4.8	Cells of the immune system fight invading bacteria.
7.4.9	Additionally, blood and blood cells carry nutrients and oxygen throughout the body while removing carbon dioxide.
7.4.10	Each of these cell types plays a vital role during the growth, development, and day-to-day maintenance of the body.
7.4.11	In spite of their enormous variety, however, cells from all organisms—even ones as diverse as bacteria, onion, and human—share certain fundamental characteristics.
7.4.12	A cell is the smallest unit of a living thing.
7.4.13	A living thing, whether made of one cell (like bacteria) or many cells (like a human), is called an organism.
7.4.14	Thus, cells are the basic building blocks of all organisms.
7.4.15	Several cells of one kind that interconnect with each other and perform a shared function form tissues, several tissues combine to form an organ (your stomach, heart, or brain), and several organs make up an organ system (such as the digestive system, circulatory system, or nervous system).
7.4.16	Several systems that function together form an organism (like a human being).
7.4.17	Here, we will examine the structure and function of cells.
7.4.18	There are many types of cells, all grouped into one of two broad categories: prokaryotic and eukaryotic.
7.4.19	For example, both animal and plant cells are classified as eukaryotic cells, whereas bacterial cells are classified as prokaryotic.
7.4.20	Before discussing the criteria for determining whether a cell is prokaryotic or eukaryotic, let’s first examine how biologists study cells.
7.4.21	Microscopy Cells vary in size.
7.4.22	With few exceptions, individual cells cannot be seen with the naked eye, so scientists use microscopes (micro- = “small”; -scope =
7.4.23	“to look at”) to study them.
7.4.24	A microscope is an instrument that magnifies an object.
7.4.25	Most photographs of cells are taken with a microscope, and these images can also be called micrographs.
7.4.26	The optics of a microscope’s lenses change the orientation of the image that the user sees.
7.4.27	A specimen that is right-side up and facing right on the microscope slide will appear upside-down and facing left when viewed through a microscope, and vice versa.
7.4.28	Similarly, if the slide is moved left while looking through the microscope, it will appear to move right, and if moved down, it will seem to move up.
7.4.29	This occurs because microscopes use two sets of lenses to magnify the image.
7.4.30	Because of the manner by which light travels through the lenses, this system of two lenses produces an inverted image (binocular, or dissecting microscopes, work in a similar manner, but include an additional magnification system that makes the final image appear to be upright).
7.4.31	Light Microscopes
7.4.32	To give you a sense of cell size, a typical human red blood cell is about eight millionths of a meter or eight micrometers (
7.4.33	abbreviated as eight μm) in diameter; the head of a pin of is about two thousandths of a meter (two mm) in diameter.
7.4.34	That means about 250 red blood cells could fit on the head of a pin.
7.4.35	Most student microscopes are classified as light microscopes (Figure 4.2a).
7.4.36	Visible light passes and is bent through the lens system to enable the user to see the specimen.
7.4.37	Light microscopes are advantageous for viewing living organisms, but since individual cells are generally transparent, their components are not distinguishable unless they are colored with special stains.
7.4.38	Staining, however, usually kills the cells.
7.4.39	Light microscopes commonly used in the undergraduate college laboratory magnify up to approximately 400 times.
7.4.40	Two parameters that are important in microscopy are magnification and resolving power.
7.4.41	Magnification is the process of enlarging an object in appearance.
7.4.42	Resolving power is the ability of a microscope to distinguish two adjacent structures as separate: the higher the resolution, the better the clarity and detail of the image.
7.4.43	When oil immersion lenses are used for the study of small objects, magnification is usually increased to 1,000 times.
7.4.44	In order to gain a better understanding of cellular structure and function, scientists typically use electron microscopes.
7.4.45	Most light microscopes used in a college biology lab can magnify cells up to approximately 400 times and have a resolution of about 200 nanometers.
7.4.46	(b) Electron microscopes provide a much higher magnification, 100,000x, and a have a resolution of 50 picometers.
7.4.47	Electron Microscopes
7.4.48	In contrast to light microscopes, electron microscopes (Figure 4.2b) use a beam of electrons instead of a beam of light.
7.4.49	Not only does this allow for higher magnification and, thus, more detail (Figure 4.3), it also provides higher resolving power.
7.4.50	The method used to prepare the specimen for viewing with an electron microscope kills the specimen.
7.4.51	Electrons have short wavelengths (shorter than photons) that move best in a vacuum, so living cells cannot be viewed with an electron microscope.
7.4.52	In a scanning electron microscope, a beam of electrons moves back and forth across a cell’s surface, creating details of cell surface characteristics.
7.4.53	In a transmission electron microscope, the electron beam penetrates the cell and provides details of a cell’s internal structures.
7.4.54	As you might imagine, electron microscopes are significantly more bulky and expensive than light microscopes.
7.4.55	These Salmonella bacteria appear as tiny purple dots when viewed with a light microscope.
7.4.56	(b)
7.4.57	This scanning electron microscope micrograph shows Salmonella bacteria (in red) invading human cells (yellow).
7.4.58	Even though subfigure (b) shows a different Salmonella specimen than subfigure (a), you can still observe the comparative increase in magnification and detail.
7.4.59	Cell Theory
7.4.60	The microscopes we use today are far more complex than those used in the 1600s by Antony van Leeuwenhoek, a Dutch shopkeeper who had great skill in crafting lenses.
7.4.61	Despite the limitations of his now-ancient lenses, van Leeuwenhoek observed the movements of protista (a type of single-celled organism) and sperm, which he collectively termed “animalcules.
7.4.62	”
7.4.63	In a 1665 publication called Micrographia, experimental scientist Robert Hooke coined the term “cell” for the box-like structures he observed when viewing cork tissue through a lens.
7.4.64	In the 1670s, van Leeuwenhoek discovered bacteria and protozoa.
7.4.65	Later advances in lenses, microscope construction, and staining techniques enabled other scientists to see some components inside cells.
7.4.66	By the late 1830s, botanist Matthias Schleiden and zoologist Theodor Schwann were studying tissues and proposed the unified cell theory, which states that all living things are composed of one or more cells, the cell is the basic unit of life, and new cells arise from existing cells.
7.4.67	Rudolf Virchow later made important contributions to this theory.
7.4.68	Cells fall into one of two broad categories: prokaryotic and eukaryotic.
7.4.69	Only the predominantly single-celled organisms of the domains Bacteria and Archaea are classified as prokaryotes (pro-
7.4.70	= “before”; -kary- =
7.4.71	“nucleus”).
7.4.72	Cells of animals, plants, fungi, and protists are all eukaryotes (ceu- = “true”) and are made up of eukaryotic cells.
7.4.73	Components of Prokaryotic Cells
7.4.74	All cells share four common components: 1) a plasma membrane, an outer covering that separates the cell
7.4.75	’s interior from its surrounding environment; 2) cytoplasm, consisting of a jelly-like cytosol within the cell in which other cellular components are found; 3) DNA, the genetic material of the cell; and 4) ribosomes, which synthesize proteins.
7.4.76	However, prokaryotes differ from eukaryotic cells in several ways.
7.4.77	A prokaryote is a simple, mostly single-celled (unicellular) organism that lacks a nucleus, or any other membrane-bound organelle.
7.4.78	We will shortly come to see that this is significantly different in eukaryotes.
7.4.79	Prokaryotic DNA is found in a central part of the cell: the nucleoid.
7.4.80	This figure shows the generalized structure of a prokaryotic cell.
7.4.81	All prokaryotes have chromosomal DNA localized in a nucleoid, ribosomes, a cell membrane, and a cell wall.
7.4.82	The other structures shown are present in some, but not all, bacteria.
7.4.83	Most prokaryotes have a peptidoglycan cell wall and many have a polysaccharide capsule (Figure 4.5).
7.4.84	The cell wall acts as an extra layer of protection, helps the cell maintain its shape, and prevents dehydration.
7.4.85	The capsule enables the cell to attach to surfaces in its environment.
7.4.86	Some prokaryotes have flagella, pili, or fimbriae.
7.4.87	Flagella are used for locomotion.
7.4.88	Pili are used to exchange genetic material during a type of reproduction called conjugation.
7.4.89	Fimbriae are used by bacteria to attach to a host cell.
7.4.90	Cell Size
7.4.91	At 0.1 to 5.0 μm in diameter, prokaryotic cells are significantly smaller than eukaryotic cells, which have diameters ranging from 10 to 100 μm (Figure 4.6).
7.4.92	The small size of prokaryotes allows ions and organic molecules that enter them to quickly diffuse to other parts of the cell.
7.4.93	Similarly, any wastes produced within a prokaryotic cell can quickly diffuse out.
7.4.94	This is not the case in eukaryotic cells, which have developed different structural adaptations to enhance intracellular transport.
7.4.95	This figure shows relative sizes of microbes on a logarithmic scale (recall that each unit of increase in a logarithmic scale represents a 10-fold increase in the quantity being measured).
7.4.96	Small size, in general, is necessary for all cells, whether prokaryotic or eukaryotic.
7.4.97	Let’s examine why that is so.
7.4.98	First, we’ll consider the area and volume of a typical cell.
7.4.99	Not all cells are spherical in shape, but most tend to approximate a sphere.
7.4.100	You may remember from your high school geometry course that the formula for the surface area of a sphere is 4πr2, while the formula for its volume is 4πr3/3.
7.4.101	Thus, as the radius of a cell increases, its surface area increases as the square of its radius, but its volume increases as the cube of its radius (much more rapidly).
7.4.102	Therefore, as a cell increases in size, its surface area-to-volume ratio decreases.
7.4.103	This same principle would apply if the cell had the shape of a cube (Figure 4.7).
7.4.104	If the cell grows too large, the plasma membrane will not have sufficient surface area to support the rate of diffusion required for the increased volume.
7.4.105	In other words, as a cell grows, it becomes less efficient.
7.4.106	One way to become more efficient is to divide; another way is to develop organelles that perform specific tasks.
7.4.107	These adaptations lead to the development of more sophisticated cells called eukaryotic cells.
7.4.108	Have you ever heard the phrase “form follows function?
7.4.109	”
7.4.110	It’s a philosophy practiced in many industries.
7.4.111	In architecture, this means that buildings should be constructed to support the activities that will be carried out inside them.
7.4.112	For example, a skyscraper should be built with several elevator banks; a hospital should be built so that its emergency room is easily accessible.
7.4.113	Our natural world also utilizes the principle of form following function, especially in cell biology, and this will become clear as we explore eukaryotic cells ( Figure 4.8).
7.4.114	Unlike prokaryotic cells, eukaryotic cells have: 1) a membrane-bound nucleus; 2) numerous membrane-bound organelles such as the endoplasmic reticulum, Golgi apparatus, chloroplasts, mitochondria, and others; and 3) several, rod-shaped chromosomes.
7.4.115	Because a eukaryotic cell’s nucleus is surrounded by a membrane, it is often said to have a “true nucleus.
7.4.116	”
7.4.117	The word “organelle” means “little organ,” and, as already mentioned, organelles have specialized cellular functions, just as the organs of your body have specialized functions.
7.4.118	At this point, it should be clear to you that eukaryotic cells have a more complex structure than prokaryotic cells.
7.4.119	Organelles allow different functions to be compartmentalized in different areas of the cell.
7.4.120	Before turning to organelles, let’s first examine two important components of the cell: the plasma membrane and the cytoplasm.
7.4.121	The Plasma Membrane Like prokaryotes, eukaryotic cells have a plasma membrane ( Figure 4.9), a phospholipid bilayer with embedded proteins that separates the internal contents of the cell from its surrounding environment.
7.4.122	A phospholipid is a lipid molecule with two fatty acid chains and a phosphate-containing group.
7.4.123	The plasma membrane controls the passage of organic molecules, ions, water, and oxygen into and out of the cell.
7.4.124	Wastes (such as carbon dioxide and ammonia) also leave the cell by passing through the plasma membrane.
7.4.125	The eukaryotic plasma membrane is a phospholipid bilayer with proteins and cholesterol embedded in it.
7.4.126	The plasma membranes of cells that specialize in absorption are folded into fingerlike projections called microvilli (singular = microvillus); ( Figure 4.10).
7.4.127	Such cells are typically found lining the small intestine, the organ that absorbs nutrients from digested food.
7.4.128	This is an excellent example of form following function.
7.4.129	People with celiac disease have an immune response to gluten, which is a protein found in wheat, barley, and rye.
7.4.130	The immune response damages microvilli, and thus, afflicted individuals cannot absorb nutrients.
7.4.131	This leads to malnutrition, cramping, and diarrhea.
7.4.132	Patients suffering from celiac disease must follow a gluten-free diet.
7.4.133	Microvilli, shown here as they appear on cells lining the small intestine, increase the surface area available for absorption.
7.4.134	These microvilli are only found on the area of the plasma membrane that faces the cavity from which substances will be absorbed.
7.4.135	The Cytoplasm
7.4.136	The cytoplasm is the entire region of a cell between the plasma membrane and the nuclear envelope (a structure to be discussed shortly).
7.4.137	It is made up of organelles suspended in the gel-like cytosol, the cytoskeleton, and various chemicals ( Figure 4.8).
7.4.138	Even though the cytoplasm consists of 70 to 80 percent water, it has a semi-solid consistency, which comes from the proteins within it.
7.4.139	However, proteins are not the only organic molecules found in the cytoplasm.
7.4.140	Glucose and other simple sugars, polysaccharides, amino acids, nucleic acids, fatty acids, and derivatives of glycerol are found there, too.
7.4.141	Ions of sodium, potassium, calcium, and many other elements are also dissolved in the cytoplasm.
7.4.142	Many metabolic reactions, including protein synthesis, take place in the cytoplasm.
7.4.143	The Nucleus Typically, the nucleus is the most prominent organelle in a cell ( Figure 4.8).
7.4.144	The nucleus (plural = nuclei) houses the cell’s DNA and directs the synthesis of ribosomes and proteins.
7.4.145	Let’s look at it in more detail ( Figure 4.11).
7.4.146	The nucleus stores chromatin (DNA plus proteins) in a gel-like substance called the nucleoplasm.
7.4.147	The nucleolus is a condensed region of chromatin where ribosome synthesis occurs.
7.4.148	The boundary of the nucleus is called the nuclear envelope.
7.4.149	It consists of two phospholipid bilayers: an outer membrane and an inner membrane.
7.4.150	The nuclear membrane is continuous with the endoplasmic reticulum.
7.4.151	Nuclear pores allow substances to enter and exit the nucleus.
7.4.152	The Nuclear Envelope
7.4.153	The nuclear envelope is a double-membrane structure that constitutes the outermost portion of the nucleus ( Figure 4.11).
7.4.154	Both the inner and outer membranes of the nuclear envelope are phospholipid bilayers.
7.4.155	The nuclear envelope is punctuated with pores that control the passage of ions, molecules, and RNA between the nucleoplasm and cytoplasm.
7.4.156	The nucleoplasm is the semi-solid fluid inside the nucleus, where we find the chromatin and the nucleolus.
7.4.157	Chromatin and Chromosomes To understand chromatin, it is helpful to first consider chromosomes.
7.4.158	Chromosomes are structures within the nucleus that are made up of DNA, the hereditary material.
7.4.159	You may remember that in prokaryotes, DNA is organized into a single circular chromosome.
7.4.160	In eukaryotes, chromosomes are linear structures.
7.4.161	Every eukaryotic species has a specific number of chromosomes in the nuclei of its body’s cells.
7.4.162	For example, in humans, the chromosome number is 46, while in fruit flies, it is eight.
7.4.163	Chromosomes are only visible and distinguishable from one another when the cell is getting ready to divide.
7.4.164	When the cell is in the growth and maintenance phases of its life cycle, proteins are attached to chromosomes, and they resemble an unwound, jumbled bunch of threads.
7.4.165	These unwound protein-chromosome complexes are called chromatin ( Figure 4.12); chromatin describes the material that makes up the chromosomes both when condensed and decondensed.
7.4.166	This image shows various levels of the organization of chromatin (DNA and protein).
7.4.167	(b)
7.4.168	This image shows paired chromosomes.
7.4.169	The Nucleolus
7.4.170	We already know that the nucleus directs the synthesis of ribosomes, but how does it do this?
7.4.171	Some chromosomes have sections of DNA that encode ribosomal RNA.
7.4.172	A darkly staining area within the nucleus called the nucleolus (plural = nucleoli) aggregates the ribosomal RNA with associated proteins to assemble the ribosomal subunits that are then transported out through the pores in the nuclear envelope to the cytoplasm.
7.4.173	Ribosomes Ribosomes are the cellular structures responsible for protein synthesis.
7.4.174	When viewed through an electron microscope, ribosomes appear either as clusters (polyribosomes) or single, tiny dots that float freely in the cytoplasm.
7.4.175	They may be attached to the cytoplasmic side of the plasma membrane or the cytoplasmic side of the endoplasmic reticulum and the outer membrane of the nuclear envelope ( Figure 4.8).
7.4.176	Electron microscopy has shown us that ribosomes, which are large complexes of protein and RNA, consist of two subunits, aptly called large and small ( Figure 4.13).
7.4.177	Ribosomes receive their “orders” for protein synthesis from the nucleus where the DNA is transcribed into messenger RNA (mRNA).
7.4.178	The mRNA travels to the ribosomes, which translate the code provided by the sequence of the nitrogenous bases in the mRNA into a specific order of amino acids in a protein.
7.4.179	Amino acids are the building blocks of proteins.
7.4.180	Ribosomes are made up of a large subunit (top) and a small subunit (bottom).
7.4.181	During protein synthesis, ribosomes assemble amino acids into proteins.
7.4.182	Because proteins synthesis is an essential function of all cells (including enzymes, hormones, antibodies, pigments, structural components, and surface receptors), ribosomes are found in practically every cell.
7.4.183	Ribosomes are particularly abundant in cells that synthesize large amounts of protein.
7.4.184	For example, the pancreas is responsible for creating several digestive enzymes and the cells that produce these enzymes contain many ribosomes.
7.4.185	Thus, we see another example of form following function.
7.4.186	Mitochondria Mitochondria (singular = mitochondrion) are often called the “powerhouses” or “energy factories” of a cell because they are responsible for making adenosine triphosphate (ATP), the cell’s main energy-carrying molecule.
7.4.187	ATP represents the short-term stored energy of the cell.
7.4.188	Cellular respiration is the process of making ATP using the chemical energy found in glucose and other nutrients.
7.4.189	In mitochondria, this process uses oxygen and produces carbon dioxide as a waste product.
7.4.190	In fact, the carbon dioxide that you exhale with every breath comes from the cellular reactions that produce carbon dioxide as a byproduct.
7.4.191	In keeping with our theme of form following function, it is important to point out that muscle cells have a very high concentration of mitochondria that produce ATP.
7.4.192	Your muscle cells need a lot of energy to keep your body moving.
7.4.193	When your cells don’t get enough oxygen, they do not make a lot of ATP.
7.4.194	Instead, the small amount of ATP they make in the absence of oxygen is accompanied by the production of lactic acid.
7.4.195	Mitochondria are oval-shaped, double membrane organelles ( Figure 4.14) that have their own ribosomes and DNA.
7.4.196	Each membrane is a phospholipid bilayer embedded with proteins.
7.4.197	The inner layer has folds called cristae.
7.4.198	The area surrounded by the folds is called the mitochondrial matrix.
7.4.199	The cristae and the matrix have different roles in cellular respiration.
7.4.200	This electron micrograph shows a mitochondrion as viewed with a transmission electron microscope.
7.4.201	This organelle has an outer membrane and an inner membrane.
7.4.202	The inner membrane contains folds, called cristae, which increase its surface area.
7.4.203	The space between the two membranes is called the intermembrane space, and the space inside the inner membrane is called the mitochondrial matrix.
7.4.204	ATP synthesis takes place on the inner membrane.
7.4.205	(credit: modification of work by Matthew Britton; scale-bar data from Matt Russell)
7.4.206	Peroxisomes Peroxisomes are small, round organelles enclosed by single membranes.
7.4.207	They carry out oxidation reactions that break down fatty acids and amino acids.
7.4.208	They also detoxify many poisons that may enter the body.
7.4.209	(Many of these oxidation reactions release hydrogen peroxide, H2O2, which would be damaging to cells; however, when these reactions are confined to peroxisomes, enzymes safely break down the H2O2 into oxygen and water.)
7.4.210	For example, alcohol is detoxified by peroxisomes in liver cells.
7.4.211	Glyoxysomes, which are specialized peroxisomes in plants, are responsible for converting stored fats into sugars.
7.4.212	Vesicles and Vacuoles Vesicles and vacuoles are membrane-bound sacs that function in storage and transport.
7.4.213	Other than the fact that vacuoles are somewhat larger than vesicles, there is a very subtle distinction between them: The membranes of vesicles can fuse with either the plasma membrane or other membrane systems within the cell.
7.4.214	Additionally, some agents such as enzymes within plant vacuoles break down macromolecules.
7.4.215	The membrane of a vacuole does not fuse with the membranes of other cellular components.
7.4.216	Animal Cells versus Plant Cells
7.4.217	At this point, you know that each eukaryotic cell has a plasma membrane, cytoplasm, a nucleus, ribosomes, mitochondria, peroxisomes, and in some, vacuoles, but there are some striking differences between animal and plant cells.
7.4.218	While both animal and plant cells have microtubule organizing centers (MTOCs), animal cells also have centrioles associated with the MTOC: a complex called the centrosome.
7.4.219	Animal cells each have a centrosome and lysosomes, whereas plant cells do not.
7.4.220	Plant cells have a cell wall, chloroplasts and other specialized plastids, and a large central vacuole, whereas animal cells do not.
7.4.221	The Centrosome
7.4.222	The centrosome is a microtubule-organizing center found near the nuclei of animal cells.
7.4.223	It contains a pair of centrioles, two structures that lie perpendicular to each other ( Figure 4.15).
7.4.224	Each centriole is a cylinder of nine triplets of microtubules.
7.4.225	The centrosome consists of two centrioles that lie at right angles to each other.
7.4.226	Each centriole is a cylinder made up of nine triplets of microtubules.
7.4.227	Nontubulin proteins (indicated by the green lines) hold the microtubule triplets together.
7.4.228	The centrosome (the organelle where all microtubules originate) replicates itself before a cell divides, and the centrioles appear to have some role in pulling the duplicated chromosomes to opposite ends of the dividing cell.
7.4.229	However, the exact function of the centrioles in cell division isn’t clear, because cells that have had the centrosome removed can still divide, and plant cells, which lack centrosomes, are capable of cell division.
7.4.230	Lysosomes Animal cells have another set of organelles not found in plant cells: lysosomes.
7.4.231	The lysosomes are the cell’s “garbage disposal.
7.4.232	”
7.4.233	In plant cells, the digestive processes take place in vacuoles.
7.4.234	Enzymes within the lysosomes aid the breakdown of proteins, polysaccharides, lipids, nucleic acids, and even worn-out organelles.
7.4.235	These enzymes are active at a much lower pH than that of the cytoplasm.
7.4.236	Therefore, the pH within lysosomes is more acidic than the pH of the cytoplasm.
7.4.237	Many reactions that take place in the cytoplasm could not occur at a low pH, so again, the advantage of compartmentalizing the eukaryotic cell into organelles is apparent.
7.4.238	The Cell Wall If you examine Figure 4.8b, the diagram of a plant cell, you will see a structure external to the plasma membrane called the cell wall.
7.4.239	The cell wall is a rigid covering that protects the cell, provides structural support, and gives shape to the cell.
7.4.240	Fungal and protistan cells also have cell walls.
7.4.241	While the chief component of prokaryotic cell walls is peptidoglycan, the major organic molecule in the plant cell wall is cellulose ( Figure 4.16), a polysaccharide made up of glucose units.
7.4.242	Have you ever noticed that when you bite into a raw vegetable, like celery, it crunches?
7.4.243	That’s because you are tearing the rigid cell walls of the celery cells with your teeth.
7.4.244	Cellulose is a long chain of β-glucose molecules connected by a 1-4 linkage.
7.4.245	The dashed lines at each end of the figure indicate a series of many more glucose units.
7.4.246	The size of the page makes it impossible to portray an entire cellulose molecule.
7.4.247	Chloroplasts Like the mitochondria, chloroplasts have their own DNA and ribosomes, but chloroplasts have an entirely different function.
7.4.248	Chloroplasts are plant cell organelles that carry out photosynthesis.
7.4.249	Photosynthesis is the series of reactions that use carbon dioxide, water, and light energy to make glucose and oxygen.
7.4.250	This is a major difference between plants and animals; plants (autotrophs) are able to make their own food, like sugars, while animals (heterotrophs) must ingest their food.
7.4.251	Like mitochondria, chloroplasts have outer and inner membranes, but within the space enclosed by a chloroplast’s inner membrane is a set of interconnected and stacked fluid-filled membrane sacs called thylakoids ( Figure 4.17).
7.4.252	Each stack of thylakoids is called a granum (plural = grana).
7.4.253	The fluid enclosed by the inner membrane that surrounds the grana is called the stroma.
7.4.254	The chloroplast has an outer membrane, an inner membrane, and membrane structures called thylakoids that are stacked into grana.
7.4.255	The space inside the thylakoid membranes is called the thylakoid space.
7.4.256	The light harvesting reactions take place in the thylakoid membranes, and the synthesis of sugar takes place in the fluid inside the inner membrane, which is called the stroma.
7.4.257	Chloroplasts also have their own genome, which is contained on a single circular chromosome.
7.4.258	The chloroplasts contain a green pigment called chlorophyll, which captures the light energy that drives the reactions of photosynthesis.
7.4.259	Like plant cells, photosynthetic protists also have chloroplasts.
7.4.260	Some bacteria perform photosynthesis, but their chlorophyll is not relegated to an organelle.
7.4.261	Previously, we mentioned vacuoles as essential components of plant cells.
7.4.262	If you look at Figure 4.8b, you will see that plant cells each have a large central vacuole that occupies most of the area of the cell.
7.4.263	The central vacuole plays a key role in regulating the cell’s concentration of water in changing environmental conditions.
7.4.264	Have you ever noticed that if you forget to water a plant for a few days, it wilts?
7.4.265	That’s because as the water concentration in the soil becomes lower than the water concentration in the plant, water moves out of the central vacuoles and cytoplasm.
7.4.266	As the central vacuole shrinks, it leaves the cell wall unsupported.
7.4.267	This loss of support to the cell walls of plant cells results in the wilted appearance of the plant.
7.4.268	The central vacuole also supports the expansion of the cell.
7.4.269	When the central vacuole holds more water, the cell gets larger without having to invest a lot of energy in synthesizing new cytoplasm.
7.4.270	The endomembrane system (endo = “within”) is a group of membranes and organelles (Figure 4.18) in eukaryotic cells that works together to modify, package, and transport lipids and proteins.
7.4.271	It includes the nuclear envelope, lysosomes, and vesicles, which we’ve already mentioned, and the endoplasmic reticulum and Golgi apparatus, which we will cover shortly.
7.4.272	Although not technically within the cell, the plasma membrane is included in the endomembrane system because, as you will see, it interacts with the other endomembranous organelles.
7.4.273	The endomembrane system does not include the membranes of either mitochondria or chloroplasts.
7.4.274	The Endoplasmic Reticulum
7.4.275	The endoplasmic reticulum (ER) (Figure 4.18) is a series of interconnected membranous sacs and tubules that collectively modifies proteins and synthesizes lipids.
7.4.276	However, these two functions are performed in separate areas of the ER: the rough ER and the smooth ER, respectively.
7.4.277	The hollow portion of the ER tubules is called the lumen or cisternal space.
7.4.278	The membrane of the ER, which is a phospholipid bilayer embedded with proteins, is continuous with the nuclear envelope.
7.4.279	Rough ER
7.4.280	The rough endoplasmic reticulum (RER) is so named because the ribosomes attached to its cytoplasmic surface give it a studded appearance when viewed through an electron microscope.
7.4.281	This transmission electron micrograph shows the rough endoplasmic reticulum and other organelles in a pancreatic cell.
7.4.282	Ribosomes transfer their newly synthesized proteins into the lumen of the RER where they undergo structural modifications, such as folding or the acquisition of side chains.
7.4.283	These modified proteins will be incorporated into cellular membranes—the membrane of the ER or those of other organelles—or secreted from the cell (such as protein hormones, enzymes).
7.4.284	The RER also makes phospholipids for cellular membranes.
7.4.285	If the phospholipids or modified proteins are not destined to stay in the RER, they will reach their destinations via transport vesicles that bud from the RER’s membrane
7.4.286	(Figure 4.18).
7.4.287	Since the RER is engaged in modifying proteins (such as enzymes, for example) that will be secreted from the cell, you would be correct in assuming that the RER is abundant in cells that secrete proteins.
7.4.288	This is the case with cells of the liver, for example.
7.4.289	Smooth ER
7.4.290	The smooth endoplasmic reticulum (SER) is continuous with the RER but has few or no ribosomes on its cytoplasmic surface (Figure 4.18).
7.4.291	Functions of the SER include synthesis of carbohydrates, lipids, and steroid hormones; detoxification of medications and poisons; and storage of calcium ions.
7.4.292	In muscle cells, a specialized SER called the sarcoplasmic reticulum is responsible for storage of the calcium ions that are needed to trigger the coordinated contractions of the muscle cells.
7.4.293	The Golgi Apparatus We have already mentioned that vesicles can bud from the ER and transport their contents elsewhere, but where do the vesicles go?
7.4.294	Before reaching their final destination, the lipids or proteins within the transport vesicles still need to be sorted, packaged, and tagged so that they wind up in the right place.
7.4.295	Sorting, tagging, packaging, and distribution of lipids and proteins takes place in the Golgi apparatus (also called the Golgi body), a series of flattened membranes.
7.4.296	The Golgi apparatus in this white blood cell is visible as a stack of semicircular, flattened rings in the lower portion of the image.
7.4.297	Several vesicles can be seen near the Golgi apparatus.
7.4.298	(credit: modification of work by Louisa Howard)
7.4.299	The receiving side of the Golgi apparatus is called the cis face.
7.4.300	The opposite side is called the trans face.
7.4.301	The transport vesicles that formed from the ER travel to the cis face, fuse with it, and empty their contents into the lumen of the Golgi apparatus.
7.4.302	As the proteins and lipids travel through the Golgi, they undergo further modifications that allow them to be sorted.
7.4.303	The most frequent modification is the addition of short chains of sugar molecules.
7.4.304	These newly modified proteins and lipids are then tagged with phosphate groups or other small molecules so that they can be routed to their proper destinations.
7.4.305	Finally, the modified and tagged proteins are packaged into secretory vesicles that bud from the trans face of the Golgi.
7.4.306	While some of these vesicles deposit their contents into other parts of the cell where they will be used, other secretory vesicles fuse with the plasma membrane and release their contents outside the cell.
7.4.307	In another example of form following function, cells that engage in a great deal of secretory activity (such as cells of the salivary glands that secrete digestive enzymes or cells of the immune system that secrete antibodies) have an abundance of Golgi.
7.4.308	In plant cells, the Golgi apparatus has the additional role of synthesizing polysaccharides, some of which are incorporated into the cell wall and some of which are used in other parts of the cell.
7.4.309	Lysosomes
7.4.310	In addition to their role as the digestive component and organelle-recycling facility of animal cells, lysosomes are considered to be parts of the endomembrane system.
7.4.311	Lysosomes also use their hydrolytic enzymes to destroy pathogens (disease-causing organisms) that might enter the cell.
7.4.312	A good example of this occurs in a group of white blood cells called macrophages, which are part of your body’s immune system.
7.4.313	In a process known as phagocytosis or endocytosis, a section of the plasma membrane of the macrophage invaginates (folds in) and engulfs a pathogen.
7.4.314	The invaginated section, with the pathogen inside, then pinches itself off from the plasma membrane and becomes a vesicle.
7.4.315	The vesicle fuses with a lysosome.
7.4.316	The lysosome’s hydrolytic enzymes then destroy the pathogen.
7.4.317	A macrophage has engulfed (phagocytized) a potentially pathogenic bacterium and then fuses with a lysosomes within the cell to destroy the pathogen.
7.4.318	Other organelles are present in the cell but for simplicity are not shown.
7.4.319	If you were to remove all the organelles from a cell, would the plasma membrane and the cytoplasm be the only components left?
7.4.320	No.
7.4.321	Within the cytoplasm, there would still be ions and organic molecules, plus a network of protein fibers that help maintain the shape of the cell, secure some organelles in specific positions, allow cytoplasm and vesicles to move within the cell, and enable cells within multicellular organisms to move.
7.4.322	Collectively, this network of protein fibers is known as the cytoskeleton.
7.4.323	There are three types of fibers within the cytoskeleton: microfilaments, intermediate filaments, and microtubules (Figure 4.22).
7.4.324	Here, we will examine each.
7.4.325	Microfilaments thicken the cortex around the inner edge of a cell; like rubber bands, they resist tension.
7.4.326	Microtubules are found in the interior of the cell where they maintain cell shape by resisting compressive forces.
7.4.327	Intermediate filaments are found throughout the cell and hold organelles in place.
7.4.328	Microfilaments Of the three types of protein fibers in the cytoskeleton, microfilaments are the narrowest.
7.4.329	They function in cellular movement, have a diameter of about 7 nm, and are made of two intertwined strands of a globular protein called actin (Figure 4.23).
7.4.330	For this reason, microfilaments are also known as actin filaments.
7.4.331	Actin is powered by ATP to assemble its filamentous form, which serves as a track for the movement of a motor protein called myosin.
7.4.332	This enables actin to engage in cellular events requiring motion, such as cell division in animal cells and cytoplasmic streaming, which is the circular movement of the cell cytoplasm in plant cells.
7.4.333	Actin and myosin are plentiful in muscle cells.
7.4.334	When your actin and myosin filaments slide past each other, your muscles contract.
7.4.335	Microfilaments also provide some rigidity and shape to the cell.
7.4.336	They can depolymerize (disassemble) and reform quickly, thus enabling a cell to change its shape and move.
7.4.337	White blood cells (your body’s infection-fighting cells) make good use of this ability.
7.4.338	They can move to the site of an infection and phagocytize the pathogen.
7.4.339	Intermediate Filaments Intermediate filaments are made of several strands of fibrous proteins that are wound together (Figure 4.24).
7.4.340	These elements of the cytoskeleton get their name from the fact that their diameter, 8 to 10 nm, is between those of microfilaments and microtubules.
7.4.341	Intermediate filaments consist of several intertwined strands of fibrous proteins.
7.4.342	Intermediate filaments have no role in cell movement.
7.4.343	Their function is purely structural.
7.4.344	They bear tension, thus maintaining the shape of the cell, and anchor the nucleus and other organelles in place.
7.4.345	Figure 4.22 shows how intermediate filaments create a supportive scaffolding inside the cell.
7.4.346	The intermediate filaments are the most diverse group of cytoskeletal elements.
7.4.347	Several types of fibrous proteins are found in the intermediate filaments.
7.4.348	You are probably most familiar with keratin, the fibrous protein that strengthens your hair, nails, and the epidermis of the skin.
7.4.349	Microtubules
7.4.350	As their name implies, microtubules are small hollow tubes.
7.4.351	The walls of the microtubule are made of polymerized dimers of α-tubulin and β-tubulin, two globular proteins (Figure 4.25).
7.4.352	With a diameter of about 25 nm, microtubules are the widest components of the cytoskeleton.
7.4.353	They help the cell resist compression, provide a track along which vesicles move through the cell, and pull replicated chromosomes to opposite ends of a dividing cell.
7.4.354	Like microfilaments, microtubules can dissolve and reform quickly.
7.4.355	Microtubules are hollow.
7.4.356	Their walls consist of 13 polymerized dimers of α-tubulin and β-tubulin (right image).
7.4.357	The left image shows the molecular structure of the tube.
7.4.358	Microtubules are also the structural elements of flagella, cilia, and centrioles (the latter are the two perpendicular bodies of the centrosome).
7.4.359	In fact, in animal cells, the centrosome is the microtubule-organizing center.
7.4.360	In eukaryotic cells, flagella and cilia are quite different structurally from their counterparts in prokaryotes, as discussed below.
7.4.361	Flagella and Cilia
7.4.362	To refresh your memory, flagella (singular = flagellum) are long, hair-like structures that extend from the plasma membrane and are used to move an entire cell (for example, sperm, Euglena).
7.4.363	When present, the cell has just one flagellum or a few flagella.
7.4.364	When cilia (singular = cilium) are present, however, many of them extend along the entire surface of the plasma membrane.
7.4.365	They are short, hair-like structures that are used to move entire cells (such as paramecia) or substances along the outer surface of the cell (for example, the cilia of cells lining the Fallopian tubes that move the ovum toward the uterus, or cilia lining the cells of the respiratory tract that trap particulate matter and move it toward your nostrils.)
7.4.366	Despite their differences in length and number, flagella and cilia share a common structural arrangement of microtubules called a “9 + 2 array.
7.4.367	”
7.4.368	This is an appropriate name because a single flagellum or cilium is made of a ring of nine microtubule doublets, surrounding a single microtubule doublet in the center (Figure 4.26).
7.4.369	You already know that a group of similar cells working together is called a tissue.
7.4.370	As you might expect, if cells are to work together, they must communicate with each other, just as you need to communicate with others if you work on a group project.
7.4.371	Let’s take a look at how cells communicate with each other.
7.4.372	Extracellular Matrix of Animal Cells Most animal cells release materials into the extracellular space.
7.4.373	The primary components of these materials are proteins, and the most abundant protein is collagen.
7.4.374	Collagen fibers are interwoven with carbohydrate-containing protein molecules called proteoglycans.
7.4.375	Collectively, these materials are called the extracellular matrix (Figure 4.27).
7.4.376	Not only does the extracellular matrix hold the cells together to form a tissue, but it also allows the cells within the tissue to communicate with each other.
7.4.377	How can this happen?
7.4.378	The extracellular matrix consists of a network of proteins and carbohydrates.
7.4.379	Cells have protein receptors on the extracellular surfaces of their plasma membranes.
7.4.380	When a molecule within the matrix binds to the receptor, it changes the molecular structure of the receptor.
7.4.381	The receptor, in turn, changes the conformation of the microfilaments positioned just inside the plasma membrane.
7.4.382	These conformational changes induce chemical signals inside the cell that reach the nucleus and turn “on” or “off” the transcription of specific sections of DNA, which affects the production of associated proteins, thus changing the activities within the cell.
7.4.383	Blood clotting provides an example of the role of the extracellular matrix in cell communication.
7.4.384	When the cells lining a blood vessel are damaged, they display a protein receptor called tissue factor.
7.4.385	When tissue factor binds with another factor in the extracellular matrix, it causes platelets to adhere to the wall of the damaged blood vessel, stimulates the adjacent smooth muscle cells in the blood vessel to contract (thus constricting the blood vessel), and initiates a series of steps that stimulate the platelets to produce clotting factors.
7.4.386	Intercellular Junctions Cells can also communicate with each other via direct contact, referred to as intercellular junctions.
7.4.387	There are some differences in the ways that plant and animal cells do this.
7.4.388	Plasmodesmata are junctions between plant cells, whereas animal cell contacts include tight junctions, gap junctions, and desmosomes.
7.4.389	Plasmodesmata
7.4.390	In general, long stretches of the plasma membranes of neighboring plant cells cannot touch one another because they are separated by the cell wall that surrounds each cell (Figure 4.8b).
7.4.391	How then, can a plant transfer water and other soil nutrients from its roots, through its stems, and to its leaves?
7.4.392	Such transport uses the vascular tissues (xylem and phloem) primarily.
7.4.393	There also exist structural modifications called plasmodesmata (singular = plasmodesma), numerous channels that pass between cell walls of adjacent plant cells, connect their cytoplasm, and enable materials to be transported from cell to cell, and thus throughout the plant.
7.4.394	A plasmodesma is a channel between the cell walls of two adjacent plant cells.
7.4.395	Plasmodesmata allow materials to pass from the cytoplasm of one plant cell to the cytoplasm of an adjacent cell.
7.4.396	Tight Junctions
7.4.397	A tight junction is a watertight seal between two adjacent animal cells (Figure 4.29).
7.4.398	The cells are held tightly against each other by proteins (predominantly two proteins called claudins and occludins).
7.4.399	Tight junctions form watertight connections between adjacent animal cells.
7.4.400	Proteins create tight junction adherence.
7.4.401	(credit: modification of work by Mariana Ruiz Villareal)
7.4.402	This tight adherence prevents materials from leaking between the cells; tight junctions are typically found in epithelial tissues that line internal organs and cavities, and comprise most of the skin.
7.4.403	For example, the tight junctions of the epithelial cells lining your urinary bladder prevent urine from leaking out into the extracellular space.
7.4.404	Desmosomes Also found only in animal cells are desmosomes, which act like spot welds between adjacent epithelial cells (Figure 4.30).
7.4.405	Short proteins called cadherins in the plasma membrane connect to intermediate filaments to create desmosomes.
7.4.406	The cadherins join two adjacent cells together and maintain the cells in a sheet-like formation in organs and tissues that stretch, like the skin, heart, and muscles.
7.4.407	A desmosome forms a very strong spot weld between cells.
7.4.408	It is created by the linkage of cadherins and intermediate filaments.
7.4.409	(credit: modification of work by Mariana Ruiz Villareal) Gap Junctions Gap junctions in animal cells are like plasmodesmata in plant cells in that they are channels between adjacent cells that allow for the transport of ions, nutrients, and other substances that enable cells to communicate (Figure 4.31).
7.4.410	Structurally, however, gap junctions and plasmodesmata differ.
7.4.411	A gap junction is a protein-lined pore that allows water and small molecules to pass between adjacent animal cells.
7.4.412	(credit: modification of work by Mariana Ruiz Villareal)
7.4.413	Gap junctions develop when a set of six proteins (called connexins) in the plasma membrane arrange themselves in an elongated donut-like configuration called a connexon.
7.4.414	When the pores (“doughnut holes”) of connexons in adjacent animal cells align, a channel between the two cells forms.
7.4.415	Gap junctions are particularly important in cardiac muscle: The electrical signal for the muscle to contract is passed efficiently through gap junctions, allowing the heart muscle cells to contract in tandem.
7.5.0	Introduction
7.5.1	The plasma membrane, which is also called the cell membrane, has many functions, but the most basic one is to define the borders of the cell and keep the cell functional.
7.5.2	The plasma membrane is selectively permeable.
7.5.3	This means that the membrane allows some materials to freely enter or leave the cell, while other materials cannot move freely, but require the use of a specialized structure, and occasionally, even energy investment for crossing.
7.5.4	A cell’s plasma membrane defines the cell, outlines its borders, and determines the nature of its interaction with its environment (see Table 5.1 for a summary).
7.5.5	Cells exclude some substances, take in others, and excrete still others, all in controlled quantities.
7.5.6	The plasma membrane must be very flexible to allow certain cells, such as red blood cells and white blood cells, to change shape as they pass through narrow capillaries.
7.5.7	These are the more obvious functions of a plasma membrane.
7.5.8	In addition, the surface of the plasma membrane carries markers that allow cells to recognize one another, which is vital for tissue and organ formation during early development, and which later plays a role in the “self” versus “non-self” distinction of the immune response.
7.5.9	Among the most sophisticated functions of the plasma membrane is the ability to transmit signals by means of complex, integral proteins known as receptors.
7.5.10	These proteins act both as receivers of extracellular inputs and as activators of intracellular processes.
7.5.11	These membrane receptors provide extracellular attachment sites for effectors like hormones and growth factors, and they activate intracellular response cascades when their effectors are bound.
7.5.12	Occasionally, receptors are hijacked by viruses (HIV, human immunodeficiency virus, is one example) that use them to gain entry into cells, and at times, the genes encoding receptors become mutated, causing the process of signal transduction to malfunction with disastrous consequences.
7.5.13	Fluid Mosaic Model
7.5.14	The existence of the plasma membrane was identified in the 1890s, and its chemical components were identified in 1915.
7.5.15	The principal components identified at that time were lipids and proteins.
7.5.16	The first widely accepted model of the plasma membrane’s structure was proposed in 1935 by Hugh Davson and James Danielli; it was based on the “railroad track” appearance of the plasma membrane in early electron micrographs.
7.5.17	They theorized that the structure of the plasma membrane resembles a sandwich, with protein being analogous to the bread, and lipids being analogous to the filling.
7.5.18	In the 1950s, advances in microscopy, notably transmission electron microscopy (TEM), allowed researchers to see that the core of the plasma membrane consisted of a double, rather than a single, layer.
7.5.19	A new model that better explains both the microscopic observations and the function of that plasma membrane was proposed by S.J. Singer and Garth L. Nicolson in 1972.
7.5.20	The explanation proposed by Singer and Nicolson is called the fluid mosaic model.
7.5.21	The model has evolved somewhat over time, but it still best accounts for the structure and functions of the plasma membrane as we now understand them.
7.5.22	The fluid mosaic model describes the structure of the plasma membrane as a mosaic of components—including phospholipids, cholesterol, proteins, and carbohydrates—that gives the membrane a fluid character.
7.5.23	Plasma membranes range from 5 to 10 nm in thickness.
7.5.24	For comparison, human red blood cells, visible via light microscopy, are approximately 8 μm wide, or approximately 1,000 times wider than a plasma membrane.
7.5.25	The membrane does look a bit like a sandwich.
7.5.26	The fluid mosaic model of the plasma membrane describes the plasma membrane as a fluid combination of phospholipids, cholesterol, and proteins.
7.5.27	Carbohydrates attached to lipids (glycolipids) and to proteins (glycoproteins) extend from the outward-facing surface of the membrane.
7.5.28	The principal components of a plasma membrane are lipids (phospholipids and cholesterol), proteins, and carbohydrates attached to some of the lipids and some of the proteins.
7.5.29	A phospholipid is a molecule consisting of glycerol, two fatty acids, and a phosphate-linked head group.
7.5.30	Cholesterol, another lipid composed of four fused carbon rings, is found alongside the phospholipids in the core of the membrane.
7.5.31	The proportions of proteins, lipids, and carbohydrates in the plasma membrane vary with cell type, but for a typical human cell, protein accounts for about 50 percent of the composition by mass, lipids (of all types) account for about 40 percent of the composition by mass, with the remaining 10 percent of the composition by mass being carbohydrates.
7.5.32	However, the concentration of proteins and lipids varies with different cell membranes.
7.5.33	For example, myelin, an outgrowth of the membrane of specialized cells that insulates the axons of the peripheral nerves, contains only 18 percent protein and 76 percent lipid.
7.5.34	The mitochondrial inner membrane contains 76 percent protein and only 24 percent lipid.
7.5.35	The plasma membrane of human red blood cells is 30 percent lipid.
7.5.36	Carbohydrates are present only on the exterior surface of the plasma membrane and are attached to proteins, forming glycoproteins, or attached to lipids, forming glycolipids.
7.5.37	Phospholipids
7.5.38	The main fabric of the membrane is composed of amphiphilic, phospholipid molecules.
7.5.39	The hydrophilic or “water-loving” areas of these molecules (which look like a collection of balls in an artist’s rendition of the model)
7.5.40	(Figure 5.2) are in contact with the aqueous fluid both inside and outside the cell.
7.5.41	Hydrophobic, or water-hating molecules, tend to be non-polar.
7.5.42	They interact with other non-polar molecules in chemical reactions, but generally do not interact with polar molecules.
7.5.43	When placed in water, hydrophobic molecules tend to form a ball or cluster.
7.5.44	The hydrophilic regions of the phospholipids tend to form hydrogen bonds with water and other polar molecules on both the exterior and interior of the cell.
7.5.45	Thus, the membrane surfaces that face the interior and exterior of the cell are hydrophilic.
7.5.46	In contrast, the interior of the cell membrane is hydrophobic and will not interact with water.
7.5.47	Therefore, phospholipids form an excellent two-layer cell membrane that separates fluid within the cell from the fluid outside of the cell.
7.5.48	A phospholipid molecule (Figure 5.3) consists of a three-carbon glycerol backbone with two fatty acid molecules attached to carbons 1 and 2, and a phosphate-containing group attached to the third carbon.
