7.5.49	This arrangement gives the overall molecule an area described as its head (the phosphate-containing group), which has a polar character or negative charge, and an area called the tail (the fatty acids), which has no charge.
7.5.50	The head can form hydrogen bonds, but the tail cannot.
7.5.51	A molecule with this arrangement of a positively or negatively charged area and an uncharged, or non-polar, area is referred to as amphiphilic or “dual-loving.
7.5.52	”
7.5.53	This phospholipid molecule is composed of a hydrophilic head and two hydrophobic tails.
7.5.54	The hydrophilic head group consists of a phosphate-containing group attached to a glycerol molecule.
7.5.55	The hydrophobic tails, each containing either a saturated or an unsaturated fatty acid, are long hydrocarbon chains.
7.5.56	This characteristic is vital to the structure of a plasma membrane because, in water, phospholipids tend to become arranged with their hydrophobic tails facing each other and their hydrophilic heads facing out.
7.5.57	In this way, they form a lipid bilayer—a barrier composed of a double layer of phospholipids that separates the water and other materials on one side of the barrier from the water and other materials on the other side.
7.5.58	In fact, phospholipids heated in an aqueous solution tend to spontaneously form small spheres or droplets (called micelles or liposomes), with their hydrophilic heads forming the exterior and their hydrophobic tails on the inside.
7.5.59	In an aqueous solution, phospholipids tend to arrange themselves with their polar heads facing outward and their hydrophobic tails facing inward.
7.5.60	(credit: modification of work by Mariana Ruiz Villareal) Proteins Proteins make up the second major component of plasma membranes.
7.5.61	Integral proteins (some specialized types are called integrins) are, as their name suggests, integrated completely into the membrane structure, and their hydrophobic membranespanning regions interact with the hydrophobic region of the the phospholipid bilayer (Figure 5.2).
7.5.62	Single-pass integral membrane proteins usually have a hydrophobic transmembrane segment that consists of 20–25 amino acids.
7.5.63	Some span only part of the membrane—associating with a single layer—while others stretch from one side of the membrane to the other, and are exposed on either side.
7.5.64	Some complex proteins are composed of up to 12 segments of a single protein, which are extensively folded and embedded in the membrane (Figure 5.5).
7.5.65	This type of protein has a hydrophilic region or regions, and one or several mildly hydrophobic regions.
7.5.66	This arrangement of regions of the protein tends to orient the protein alongside the phospholipids, with the hydrophobic region of the protein adjacent to the tails of the phospholipids and the hydrophilic region or regions of the protein protruding from the membrane and in contact with the cytosol or extracellular fluid.
7.5.67	Integral membranes proteins may have one or more alpha-helices that span the membrane (examples 1 and 2), or they may have beta-sheets that span the membrane (example 3).
7.5.68	(credit: “Foobar”/Wikimedia Commons)
7.5.69	Chapter 5 | Structure and Function of Plasma Membranes 139 Peripheral proteins are found on the exterior and interior surfaces of membranes, attached either to integral proteins or to phospholipids.
7.5.70	Peripheral proteins, along with integral proteins, may serve as enzymes, as structural attachments for the fibers of the cytoskeleton, or as part of the cell’s recognition sites.
7.5.71	These are sometimes referred to as “cell-specific” proteins.
7.5.72	The body recognizes its own proteins and attacks foreign proteins associated with invasive pathogens.
7.5.73	Carbohydrates Carbohydrates are the third major component of plasma membranes.
7.5.74	They are always found on the exterior surface of cells and are bound either to proteins (forming glycoproteins) or to lipids (forming glycolipids)
7.5.75	(Figure 5.2).
7.5.76	These carbohydrate chains may consist of 2–60 monosaccharide units and can be either straight or branched.
7.5.77	Along with peripheral proteins, carbohydrates form specialized sites on the cell surface that allow cells to recognize each other.
7.5.78	These sites have unique patterns that allow the cell to be recognized, much the way that the facial features unique to each person allow him or her to be recognized.
7.5.79	This recognition function is very important to cells, as it allows the immune system to differentiate between body cells (called “self”) and foreign cells or tissues (called “non-self”).
7.5.80	Similar types of glycoproteins and glycolipids are found on the surfaces of viruses and may change frequently, preventing immune cells from recognizing and attacking them.
7.5.81	These carbohydrates on the exterior surface of the cell—the carbohydrate components of both glycoproteins and glycolipids—are collectively referred to as the glycocalyx (meaning “sugar coating”).
7.5.82	The glycocalyx is highly hydrophilic and attracts large amounts of water to the surface of the cell.
7.5.83	This aids in the interaction of the cell with its watery environment and in the cell’s ability to obtain substances dissolved in the water.
7.5.84	As discussed above, the glycocalyx is also important for cell identification, self/non-self determination, and embryonic development, and is used in cell-cell attachments to form tissues.
7.5.85	Membrane Fluidity
7.5.86	The mosaic characteristic of the membrane, described in the fluid mosaic model, helps to illustrate its nature.
7.5.87	The integral proteins and lipids exist in the membrane as separate but loosely attached molecules.
7.5.88	These resemble the separate, multicolored tiles of a mosaic picture, and they float, moving somewhat with respect to one another.
7.5.89	The membrane is not like a balloon, however, that can expand and contract; rather, it is fairly rigid and can burst if penetrated or if a cell takes in too much water.
7.5.90	However, because of its mosaic nature, a very fine needle can easily penetrate a plasma membrane without causing it to burst, and the membrane will flow and self-seal when the needle is extracted.
7.5.91	The mosaic characteristics of the membrane explain some but not all of its fluidity.
7.5.92	There are two other factors that help maintain this fluid characteristic.
7.5.93	One factor is the nature of the phospholipids themselves.
7.5.94	In their saturated form, the fatty acids in phospholipid tails are saturated with bound hydrogen atoms.
7.5.95	There are no double bonds between adjacent carbon atoms.
7.5.96	This results in tails that are relatively straight.
7.5.97	In contrast, unsaturated fatty acids do not contain a maximal number of hydrogen atoms, but they do contain some double bonds between adjacent carbon atoms; a double bond results in a bend in the string of carbons of approximately 30 degrees (Figure 5.3).
7.5.98	Thus, if saturated fatty acids, with their straight tails, are compressed by decreasing temperatures, they press in on each other, making a dense and fairly rigid membrane.
7.5.99	If unsaturated fatty acids are compressed, the “kinks” in their tails elbow adjacent phospholipid molecules away, maintaining some space between the phospholipid molecules.
7.5.100	This “elbow room” helps to maintain fluidity in the membrane at temperatures at which membranes with saturated fatty acid tails in their phospholipids would “freeze” or solidify.
7.5.101	The relative fluidity of the membrane is particularly important in a cold environment.
7.5.102	A cold environment tends to compress membranes composed largely of saturated fatty acids, making them less fluid and more susceptible to rupturing.
7.5.103	Many organisms (fish are one example) are capable of adapting to cold environments by changing the proportion of unsaturated fatty acids in their membranes in response to the lowering of the temperature.
7.5.104	Animals have an additional membrane constituent that assists in maintaining fluidity.
7.5.105	Cholesterol, which lies alongside the phospholipids in the membrane, tends to dampen the effects of temperature on the membrane.
7.5.106	Thus, this lipid functions as a buffer, preventing lower temperatures from inhibiting fluidity and preventing increased temperatures from increasing fluidity too much.
7.5.107	Thus, cholesterol extends, in both directions, the range of temperature in which the membrane is appropriately fluid and consequently functional.
7.5.108	Cholesterol also serves other functions, such as organizing clusters of transmembrane proteins into lipid rafts.
7.5.109	Plasma membranes must allow certain substances to enter and leave a cell, and prevent some harmful materials from entering and some essential materials from leaving.
7.5.110	In other words, plasma membranes are selectively permeable—they allow some substances to pass through, but not others.
7.5.111	If they were to lose this selectivity, the cell would no longer be able to sustain itself, and it would be destroyed.
7.5.112	Some cells require larger amounts of specific substances than do other cells; they must have a way of obtaining these materials from extracellular fluids.
7.5.113	This may happen passively, as certain materials move back and forth, or the cell may have special mechanisms that facilitate transport.
7.5.114	Some materials are so important to a cell that it spends some of its energy, hydrolyzing adenosine triphosphate (ATP), to obtain these materials.
7.5.115	Red blood cells use some of their energy doing just that.
7.5.116	All cells spend the majority of their energy to maintain an imbalance of sodium and potassium ions between the interior and exterior of the cell.
7.5.117	The most direct forms of membrane transport are passive.
7.5.118	Passive transport is a naturally occurring phenomenon and does not require the cell to exert any of its energy to accomplish the movement.
7.5.119	In passive transport, substances move from an area of higher concentration to an area of lower concentration.
7.5.120	A physical space in which there is a range of concentrations of a single substance is said to have a concentration gradient.
7.5.121	Selective Permeability Plasma membranes are asymmetric: the interior of the membrane is not identical to the exterior of the membrane.
7.5.122	In fact, there is a considerable difference between the array of phospholipids and proteins between the two leaflets that form a membrane.
7.5.123	On the interior of the membrane, some proteins serve to anchor the membrane to fibers of the cytoskeleton.
7.5.124	There are peripheral proteins on the exterior of the membrane that bind elements of the extracellular matrix.
7.5.125	Carbohydrates, attached to lipids or proteins, are also found on the exterior surface of the plasma membrane.
7.5.126	These carbohydrate complexes help the cell bind substances that the cell needs in the extracellular fluid.
7.5.127	This adds considerably to the selective nature of plasma membranes.
7.5.128	The exterior surface of the plasma membrane is not identical to the interior surface of the same membrane.
7.5.129	Recall that plasma membranes are amphiphilic
7.5.130	: They have hydrophilic and hydrophobic regions.
7.5.131	This characteristic helps the movement of some materials through the membrane and hinders the movement of others.
7.5.132	Lipid-soluble material with a low molecular weight can easily slip through the hydrophobic lipid core of the membrane.
7.5.133	Substances such as the fat-soluble vitamins
7.5.134	A, D, E, and K readily pass through the plasma membranes in the digestive tract and other tissues.
7.5.135	Fat-soluble drugs and hormones also gain easy entry into cells and are readily transported into the body’s tissues and organs.
7.5.136	Molecules of oxygen and carbon dioxide have no charge and so pass through membranes by simple diffusion.
7.5.137	Polar substances present problems for the membrane.
7.5.138	While some polar molecules connect easily with the outside of a cell, they cannot readily pass through the lipid core of the plasma membrane.
7.5.139	Additionally, while small ions could easily slip through the spaces in the mosaic of the membrane, their charge prevents them from doing so.
7.5.140	Ions such as sodium, potassium, calcium, and chloride must have special means of penetrating plasma membranes.
7.5.141	Simple sugars and amino acids also need help with transport across plasma membranes, achieved by various transmembrane proteins (channels).
7.5.142	Diffusion Diffusion is a passive process of transport.
7.5.143	A single substance tends to move from an area of high concentration to an area of low concentration until the concentration is equal across a space.
7.5.144	You are familiar with diffusion of substances through the air.
7.5.145	For example, think about someone opening a bottle of ammonia in a room filled with people.
7.5.146	The ammonia gas is at its highest concentration in the bottle; its lowest concentration is at the edges of the room.
7.5.147	The ammonia vapor will diffuse, or spread away, from the bottle, and gradually, more and more people will smell the ammonia as it spreads.
7.5.148	Materials move within the cell’s cytosol by diffusion, and certain materials move through the plasma membrane by diffusion (Figure 5.8).
7.5.149	Diffusion expends no energy.
7.5.150	On the contrary, concentration gradients are a form of potential energy, dissipated as the gradient is eliminated.
7.5.151	Diffusion through a permeable membrane moves a substance from an area of high concentration (extracellular fluid, in this case) down its concentration gradient (into the cytoplasm).
7.5.152	(credit: modification of work by Mariana Ruiz Villareal)
7.5.153	Each separate substance in a medium, such as the extracellular fluid, has its own concentration gradient, independent of the concentration gradients of other materials.
7.5.154	In addition, each substance will diffuse according to that gradient.
7.5.155	Within a system, there will be different rates of diffusion of the different substances in the medium.
7.5.156	Factors That Affect Diffusion Molecules move constantly in a random manner, at a rate that depends on their mass, their environment, and the amount of thermal energy they possess, which in turn is a function of temperature.
7.5.157	This movement accounts for the diffusion of molecules through whatever medium in which they are localized.
7.5.158	A substance will tend to move into any space available to it until it is evenly distributed throughout it.
7.5.159	After a substance has diffused completely through a space, removing its concentration gradient, molecules will still move around in the space, but there will be no net movement of the number of molecules from one area to another.
7.5.160	This lack of a concentration gradient in which there is no net movement of a substance is known as dynamic equilibrium.
7.5.161	While diffusion will go forward in the presence of a concentration gradient of a substance, several factors affect the rate of diffusion.
7.5.162	•
7.5.163	Extent of the concentration gradient: The greater the difference in concentration, the more rapid the diffusion.
7.5.164	The closer the distribution of the material gets to equilibrium, the slower the rate of diffusion becomes.
7.5.165	•
7.5.166	Mass of the molecules diffusing
7.5.167	: Heavier molecules move more slowly; therefore, they diffuse more slowly.
7.5.168	The reverse is true for lighter molecules.
7.5.169	•
7.5.170	Temperature: Higher temperatures increase the energy and therefore the movement of the molecules, increasing the rate of diffusion.
7.5.171	Lower temperatures decrease the energy of the molecules, thus decreasing the rate of diffusion.
7.5.172	• Solvent density: As the density of a solvent increases, the rate of diffusion decreases.
7.5.173	The molecules slow down because they have a more difficult time getting through the denser medium.
7.5.174	If the medium is less dense, diffusion increases.
7.5.175	Because cells primarily use diffusion to move materials within the cytoplasm, any increase in the cytoplasm’s density will inhibit the movement of the materials.
7.5.176	An example of this is a person experiencing dehydration.
7.5.177	As the body’s cells lose water, the rate of diffusion decreases in the cytoplasm, and the cells’ functions deteriorate.
7.5.178	Neurons tend to be very sensitive to this effect.
7.5.179	Dehydration frequently leads to unconsciousness and possibly coma because of the decrease in diffusion rate within the cells.
7.5.180	•
7.5.181	Solubility: As discussed earlier, nonpolar or lipid-soluble materials pass through plasma membranes more easily than polar materials, allowing a faster rate of diffusion.
7.5.182	•
7.5.183	Surface area and thickness of the plasma membrane: Increased surface area increases the rate of diffusion, whereas a thicker membrane reduces it.
7.5.184	•
7.5.185	Distance travelled: The greater the distance that a substance must travel, the slower the rate of diffusion.
7.5.186	This places an upper limitation on cell size.
7.5.187	A large, spherical cell will die because nutrients or waste cannot reach or leave the center of the cell, respectively.
7.5.188	Therefore, cells must either be small in size, as in the case of many prokaryotes, or be flattened, as with many single-celled eukaryotes.
7.5.189	A variation of diffusion is the process of filtration.
7.5.190	In filtration, material moves according to its concentration gradient through a membrane; sometimes the rate of diffusion is enhanced by pressure, causing the substances to filter more rapidly.
7.5.191	This occurs in the kidney, where blood pressure forces large amounts of water and accompanying dissolved substances, or solutes, out of the blood and into the renal tubules.
7.5.192	The rate of diffusion in this instance is almost totally dependent on pressure.
7.5.193	One of the effects of high blood pressure is the appearance of protein in the urine, which is “squeezed through” by the abnormally high pressure.
7.5.194	Facilitated transport
7.5.195	In facilitated transport, also called facilitated diffusion, materials diffuse across the plasma membrane with the help of membrane proteins.
7.5.196	A concentration gradient exists that would allow these materials to diffuse into the cell without expending cellular energy.
7.5.197	However, these materials are ions are polar molecules that are repelled by the hydrophobic parts of the cell membrane.
7.5.198	Facilitated transport proteins shield these materials from the repulsive force of the membrane, allowing them to diffuse into the cell.
7.5.199	The material being transported is first attached to protein or glycoprotein receptors on the exterior surface of the plasma membrane.
7.5.200	This allows the material that is needed by the cell to be removed from the extracellular fluid.
7.5.201	The substances are then passed to specific integral proteins that facilitate their passage.
7.5.202	Some of these integral proteins are collections of beta pleated sheets that form a pore or channel through the phospholipid bilayer.
7.5.203	Others are carrier proteins which bind with the substance and aid its diffusion through the membrane.
7.5.204	Channels
7.5.205	The integral proteins involved in facilitated transport are collectively referred to as transport proteins, and they function as either channels for the material or carriers.
7.5.206	In both cases, they are transmembrane proteins.
7.5.207	Channels are specific for the substance that is being transported.
7.5.208	Channel proteins have hydrophilic domains exposed to the intracellular and extracellular fluids; they additionally have a hydrophilic channel through their core that provides a hydrated opening through the membrane layers (Figure 5.9).
7.5.209	Passage through the channel allows polar compounds to avoid the nonpolar central layer of the plasma membrane that would otherwise slow or prevent their entry into the cell.
7.5.210	Aquaporins are channel proteins that allow water to pass through the membrane at a very high rate.
7.5.211	Facilitated transport moves substances down their concentration gradients.
7.5.212	They may cross the plasma membrane with the aid of channel proteins.
7.5.213	(credit: modification of work by Mariana Ruiz Villareal)
7.5.214	Channel proteins are either open at all times or they are “gated,” which controls the opening of the channel.
7.5.215	The attachment of a particular ion to the channel protein may control the opening, or other mechanisms or substances may be involved.
7.5.216	In some tissues, sodium and chloride ions pass freely through open channels, whereas in other tissues a gate must be opened to allow passage.
7.5.217	An example of this occurs in the kidney, where both forms of channels are found in different parts of the renal tubules.
7.5.218	Cells involved in the transmission of electrical impulses, such as nerve and muscle cells, have gated channels for sodium, potassium, and calcium in their membranes.
7.5.219	Opening and closing of these channels changes the relative concentrations on opposing sides of the membrane of these ions, resulting in the facilitation of electrical transmission along membranes (in the case of nerve cells) or in muscle contraction (in the case of muscle cells).
7.5.220	Carrier Proteins Another type of protein embedded in the plasma membrane is a carrier protein.
7.5.221	This aptly named protein binds a substance and, in doing so, triggers a change of its own shape, moving the bound molecule from the outside of the cell to its interior (Figure 5.10); depending on the gradient, the material may move in the opposite direction.
7.5.222	Carrier proteins are typically specific for a single substance.
7.5.223	This selectivity adds to the overall selectivity of the plasma membrane.
7.5.224	The exact mechanism for the change of shape is poorly understood.
7.5.225	Proteins can change shape when their hydrogen bonds are affected, but this may not fully explain this mechanism.
7.5.226	Each carrier protein is specific to one substance, and there are a finite number of these proteins in any membrane.
7.5.227	This can cause problems in transporting enough of the material for the cell to function properly.
7.5.228	When all of the proteins are bound to their ligands, they are saturated and the rate of transport is at its maximum.
7.5.229	Increasing the concentration gradient at this point will not result in an increased rate of transport.
7.5.230	Some substances are able to move down their concentration gradient across the plasma membrane with the aid of carrier proteins.
7.5.231	Carrier proteins change shape as they move molecules across the membrane.
7.5.232	(credit: modification of work by Mariana Ruiz Villareal)
7.5.233	An example of this process occurs in the kidney.
7.5.234	Glucose, water, salts, ions, and amino acids needed by the body are filtered in one part of the kidney.
7.5.235	This filtrate, which includes glucose, is then reabsorbed in another part of the kidney.
7.5.236	Because there are only a finite number of carrier proteins for glucose, if more glucose is present than the proteins can handle, the excess is not transported and it is excreted from the body in the urine.
7.5.237	In a diabetic individual, this is described as “spilling glucose into the urine.
7.5.238	”
7.5.239	A different group of carrier proteins called glucose transport proteins, or GLUTs, are involved in transporting glucose and other hexose sugars through plasma membranes within the body.
7.5.240	Channel and carrier proteins transport material at different rates.
7.5.241	Channel proteins transport much more quickly than do carrier proteins.
7.5.242	Channel proteins facilitate diffusion at a rate of tens of millions of molecules per second, whereas carrier proteins work at a rate of a thousand to a million molecules per second.
7.5.243	Osmosis Osmosis is the movement of water through a semipermeable membrane according to the concentration gradient of water across the membrane, which is inversely proportional to the concentration of solutes.
7.5.244	While diffusion transports material across membranes and within cells, osmosis transports only water across a membrane and the membrane limits the diffusion of solutes in the water.
7.5.245	Not surprisingly, the aquaporins that facilitate water movement play a large role in osmosis, most prominently in red blood cells and the membranes of kidney tubules.
7.5.246	Mechanism Osmosis is a special case of diffusion.
7.5.247	Water, like other substances, moves from an area of high concentration to one of low concentration.
7.5.248	An obvious question is what makes water move at all?
7.5.249	Imagine a beaker with a semipermeable membrane separating the two sides or halves (Figure 5.11).
7.5.250	On both sides of the membrane the water level is the same, but there are different concentrations of a dissolved substance, or solute, that cannot cross the membrane (otherwise the concentrations on each side would be balanced by the solute crossing the membrane).
7.5.251	If the volume of the solution on both sides of the membrane is the same, but the concentrations of solute are different, then there are different amounts of water, the solvent, on either side of the membrane.
7.5.252	In osmosis, water always moves from an area of higher water concentration to one of lower concentration.
7.5.253	In the diagram shown, the solute cannot pass through the selectively permeable membrane, but the water can.
7.5.254	To illustrate this, imagine two full glasses of water.
7.5.255	One has a single teaspoon of sugar in it, whereas the second one contains one-quarter cup of sugar.
7.5.256	If the total volume of the solutions in both cups is the same, which cup contains more water?
7.5.257	Because the large amount of sugar in the second cup takes up much more space than the teaspoon of sugar in the first cup, the first cup has more water in it.
7.5.258	Returning to the beaker example, recall that it has a mixture of solutes on either side of the membrane.
7.5.259	A principle of diffusion is that the molecules move around and will spread evenly throughout the medium if they can.
7.5.260	However, only the material capable of getting through the membrane will diffuse through it.
7.5.261	In this example, the solute cannot diffuse through the membrane, but the water can.
7.5.262	Water has a concentration gradient in this system.
7.5.263	Thus, water will diffuse down its concentration gradient, crossing the membrane to the side where it is less concentrated.
7.5.264	This diffusion of water through the membrane—osmosis—will continue until the concentration gradient of water goes to zero or until the hydrostatic pressure of the water balances the osmotic pressure.
7.5.265	Osmosis proceeds constantly in living systems.
7.5.266	Tonicity Tonicity describes how an extracellular solution can change the volume of a cell by affecting osmosis.
7.5.267	A solution's tonicity often directly correlates with the osmolarity of the solution.
7.5.268	Osmolarity describes the total solute concentration of the solution.
7.5.269	A solution with low osmolarity has a greater number of water molecules relative to the number of solute particles; a solution with high osmolarity has fewer water molecules with respect to solute particles.
7.5.270	In a situation in which solutions of two different osmolarities are separated by a membrane permeable to water, though not to the solute, water will move from the side of the membrane with lower osmolarity (and more water) to the side with higher osmolarity (and less water).
7.5.271	This effect makes sense if you remember that the solute cannot move across the membrane, and thus the only component in the system that can move—the water—moves along its own concentration gradient.
7.5.272	An important distinction that concerns living systems is that osmolarity measures the number of particles (which may be molecules) in a solution.
7.5.273	Therefore, a solution that is cloudy with cells may have a lower osmolarity than a solution that is clear, if the second solution contains more dissolved molecules than there are cells.
7.5.274	Hypotonic Solutions
7.5.275	Three terms—hypotonic, isotonic, and hypertonic—are used to relate the osmolarity of a cell to the osmolarity of the extracellular fluid that contains the cells.
7.5.276	In a hypotonic situation, the extracellular fluid has lower osmolarity than the fluid inside the cell, and water enters the cell.
7.5.277	(In living systems, the point of reference is always the cytoplasm, so the prefix hypo- means that the extracellular fluid has a lower concentration of solutes, or a lower osmolarity, than the cell cytoplasm.)
7.5.278	It also means that the extracellular fluid has a higher concentration of water in the solution than does the cell.
7.5.279	In this situation, water will follow its concentration gradient and enter the cell.
7.5.280	Hypertonic Solutions
7.5.281	As for a hypertonic solution, the prefix hyper- refers to the extracellular fluid having a higher osmolarity than the cell’s cytoplasm; therefore, the fluid contains less water than the cell does.
7.5.282	Because the cell has a relatively higher concentration of water, water will leave the cell.
7.5.283	Isotonic Solutions
7.5.284	In an isotonic solution, the extracellular fluid has the same osmolarity as the cell.
7.5.285	If the osmolarity of the cell matches that of the extracellular fluid, there will be no net movement of water into or out of the cell, although water will still move in and out.
7.5.286	Blood cells and plant cells in hypertonic, isotonic, and hypotonic solutions take on characteristic appearances.
7.5.287	Tonicity in Living Systems
7.5.288	In a hypotonic environment, water enters a cell, and the cell swells.
7.5.289	In an isotonic condition, the relative concentrations of solute and solvent are equal on both sides of the membrane.
7.5.290	There is no net water movement; therefore, there is no change in the size of the cell.
7.5.291	In a hypertonic solution, water leaves a cell and the cell shrinks.
7.5.292	If either the hypo- or hyper- condition goes to excess, the cell’s functions become compromised, and the cell may be destroyed.
7.5.293	A red blood cell will burst, or lyse, when it swells beyond the plasma membrane’s capability to expand.
7.5.294	Remember, the membrane resembles a mosaic, with discrete spaces between the molecules composing it.
7.5.295	If the cell swells, and the spaces between the lipids and proteins become too large, the cell will break apart.
7.5.296	In contrast, when excessive amounts of water leave a red blood cell, the cell shrinks, or crenates.
7.5.297	This has the effect of concentrating the solutes left in the cell, making the cytosol denser and interfering with diffusion within the cell.
7.5.298	The cell’s ability to function will be compromised and may also result in the death of the cell.
7.5.299	Various living things have ways of controlling the effects of osmosis—a mechanism called osmoregulation.
7.5.300	Some organisms, such as plants, fungi, bacteria, and some protists, have cell walls that surround the plasma membrane and prevent cell lysis in a hypotonic solution.
7.5.301	The plasma membrane can only expand to the limit of the cell wall, so the cell will not lyse.
7.5.302	In fact, the cytoplasm in plants is always slightly hypertonic to the cellular environment, and water will always enter a cell if water is available.
7.5.303	This inflow of water produces turgor pressure, which stiffens the cell walls of the plant (Figure 5.13).
7.5.304	In nonwoody plants, turgor pressure supports the plant.
7.5.305	Conversly, if the plant is not watered, the extracellular fluid will become hypertonic, causing water to leave the cell.
7.5.306	In this condition, the cell does not shrink because the cell wall is not flexible.
7.5.307	However, the cell membrane detaches from the wall and constricts the cytoplasm.
7.5.308	This is called plasmolysis.
7.5.309	Plants lose turgor pressure in this condition and wilt (Figure 5.14).
7.5.310	The turgor pressure within a plant cell depends on the tonicity of the solution that it is bathed in.
7.5.311	Without adequate water, the plant on the left has lost turgor pressure, visible in its wilting; the turgor pressure is restored by watering it (right).
7.5.312	(credit: Victor M. Vicente Selvas)
7.5.313	Tonicity is a concern for all living things.
7.5.314	For example, paramecia and amoebas, which are protists that lack cell walls, have contractile vacuoles.
7.5.315	This vesicle collects excess water from the cell and pumps it out, keeping the cell from lysing as it takes on water from its environment.
7.5.316	A paramecium’s contractile vacuole, here visualized using bright field light microscopy at 480x magnification, continuously pumps water out of the organism’s body to keep it from bursting in a hypotonic medium.
7.5.317	(credit: modification of work by NIH; scale-bar data from Matt Russell)
7.5.318	Many marine invertebrates have internal salt levels matched to their environments, making them isotonic with the water in which they live.
7.5.319	Fish, however, must spend approximately five percent of their metabolic energy maintaining osmotic homeostasis.
7.5.320	Freshwater fish live in an environment that is hypotonic to their cells.
7.5.321	These fish actively take in salt through their gills and excrete diluted urine to rid themselves of excess water.
7.5.322	Saltwater fish live in the reverse environment, which is hypertonic to their cells, and they secrete salt through their gills and excrete highly concentrated urine.
7.5.323	In vertebrates, the kidneys regulate the amount of water in the body.
7.5.324	Osmoreceptors are specialized cells in the brain that monitor the concentration of solutes in the blood.
7.5.325	If the levels of solutes increase beyond a certain range, a hormone is released that retards water loss through the kidney and dilutes the blood to safer levels.
7.5.326	Animals also have high concentrations of albumin, which is produced by the liver, in their blood.
7.5.327	This protein is too large to pass easily through plasma membranes and is a major factor in controlling the osmotic pressures applied to tissues.
7.5.328	Active transport mechanisms require the use of the cell’s energy, usually in the form of adenosine triphosphate (ATP).
7.5.329	If a substance must move into the cell against its concentration gradient—that is, if the concentration of the substance inside the cell is greater than its concentration in the extracellular fluid (and vice versa)—the cell must use energy to move the substance.
7.5.330	Some active transport mechanisms move small-molecular weight materials, such as ions, through the membrane.
7.5.331	Other mechanisms transport much larger molecules.
7.5.332	Electrochemical Gradient
7.5.333	We have discussed simple concentration gradients
7.5.334	—differential concentrations of a substance across a space or a membrane—
7.5.335	but in living systems, gradients are more complex.
7.5.336	Because ions move into and out of cells and because cells contain proteins that do not move across the membrane and are mostly negatively charged, there is also an electrical gradient, a difference of charge, across the plasma membrane.
7.5.337	The interior of living cells is electrically negative with respect to the extracellular fluid in which they are bathed, and at the same time, cells have higher concentrations of potassium (K+) and lower concentrations of sodium (Na+) than does the extracellular fluid.
7.5.338	So in a living cell, the concentration gradient of Na+ tends to drive it into the cell, and the electrical gradient of Na+ (a positive ion) also tends to drive it inward to the negatively charged interior.
7.5.339	The situation is more complex, however, for other elements such as potassium.
7.5.340	The electrical gradient of K+, a positive ion, also tends to drive it into the cell, but the concentration gradient of K+ tends to drive K+ out of the cell (Figure 5.16).
7.5.341	The combined gradient of concentration and electrical charge that affects an ion is called its electrochemical gradient.
7.5.342	Moving Against a Gradient To move substances against a concentration or electrochemical gradient, the cell must use energy.
7.5.343	This energy is harvested from ATP generated through the cell’s metabolism.
7.5.344	Active transport mechanisms, collectively called pumps, work against electrochemical gradients.
7.5.345	Small substances constantly pass through plasma membranes.
7.5.346	Active transport maintains concentrations of ions and other substances needed by living cells in the face of these passive movements.
7.5.347	Much of a cell’s supply of metabolic energy may be spent maintaining these processes.
7.5.348	(Most of a red blood cell’s metabolic energy is used to maintain the imbalance between exterior and interior sodium and potassium levels required by the cell.)
7.5.349	Because active transport mechanisms depend on a cell’s metabolism for energy, they are sensitive to many metabolic poisons that interfere with the supply of ATP.
7.5.350	Two mechanisms exist for the transport of small-molecular weight material and small molecules.
7.5.351	Primary active transport moves ions across a membrane and creates a difference in charge across that membrane, which is directly dependent on ATP.
7.5.352	Secondary active transport describes the movement of material that is due to the electrochemical gradient established by primary active transport that does not directly require ATP.
7.5.353	Carrier Proteins for Active Transport
7.5.354	An important membrane adaption for active transport is the presence of specific carrier proteins or pumps to facilitate movement: there are three types of these proteins or transporters (Figure 5.17).
7.5.355	A uniporter carries one specific ion or molecule.
7.5.356	A symporter carries two different ions or molecules, both in the same direction.
7.5.357	An antiporter also carries two different ions or molecules, but in different directions.
7.5.358	All of these transporters can also transport small, uncharged organic molecules like glucose.
7.5.359	These three types of carrier proteins are also found in facilitated diffusion, but they do not require ATP to work in that process.
7.5.360	Some examples of pumps for active transport are Na+-K+ ATPase, which carries sodium and potassium ions, and H+-K+ ATPase, which carries hydrogen and potassium ions.
7.5.361	Both of these are antiporter carrier proteins.
7.5.362	Two other carrier proteins are Ca2+ ATPase and H+ ATPase, which carry only calcium and only hydrogen ions, respectively.
7.5.363	Both are pumps.
7.5.364	A uniporter carries one molecule or ion.
7.5.365	A symporter carries two different molecules or ions, both in the same direction.
7.5.366	An antiporter also carries two different molecules or ions, but in different directions.
7.5.367	(credit: modification of work by “Lupask”/Wikimedia Commons)
7.5.368	Primary Active Transport
7.5.369	The primary active transport that functions with the active transport of sodium and potassium allows secondary active transport to occur.
7.5.370	The second transport method is still considered active because it depends on the use of energy as does primary transport (Figure 5.18).
7.5.371	Primary active transport moves ions across a membrane, creating an electrochemical gradient (electrogenic transport).
7.5.372	(credit: modification of work by Mariana Ruiz Villareal)
7.5.373	One of the most important pumps in animals cells is the sodium-potassium pump (Na+-K+ ATPase), which maintains the electrochemical gradient (and the correct concentrations of Na+ and K+) in living cells.
7.5.374	The sodium-potassium pump moves K+ into the cell while moving Na+ out at the same time, at a ratio of three Na+ for every two K+ ions moved in.
7.5.375	The Na+- K+ ATPase exists in two forms, depending on its orientation to the interior or exterior of the cell and its affinity for either sodium or potassium ions.
7.5.376	The process consists of the following six steps.
7.5.377	1.
7.5.378	With the enzyme oriented towards the interior of the cell, the carrier has a high affinity for sodium ions.
7.5.379	Three ions bind to the protein.
7.5.380	2.
7.5.381	ATP is hydrolyzed by the protein carrier and a low-energy phosphate group attaches to it.
7.5.382	3.
7.5.383	As a result, the carrier changes shape and re-orients itself towards the exterior of the membrane.
7.5.384	The protein’s affinity for sodium decreases and the three sodium ions leave the carrier.
7.5.385	4.
7.5.386	The shape change increases the carrier’s affinity for potassium ions, and two such ions attach to the protein.
7.5.387	Subsequently, the low-energy phosphate group detaches from the carrier.
7.5.388	5.
7.5.389	With the phosphate group removed and potassium ions attached, the carrier protein repositions itself towards the interior of the cell.
7.5.390	The carrier protein, in its new configuration, has a decreased affinity for potassium, and the two ions are released into the cytoplasm.
7.5.391	The protein now has a higher affinity for sodium ions, and the process starts again.
7.5.392	Several things have happened as a result of this process.
7.5.393	At this point, there are more sodium ions outside of the cell than inside and more potassium ions inside than out.
7.5.394	For every three ions of sodium that move out, two ions of potassium move in.
7.5.395	This results in the interior being slightly more negative relative to the exterior.
7.5.396	This difference in charge is important in creating the conditions necessary for the secondary process.
7.5.397	The sodium-potassium pump is, therefore, an electrogenic pump (a pump that creates a charge imbalance), creating an electrical imbalance across the membrane and contributing to the membrane potential.
7.5.398	Secondary Active Transport (Co-transport)
7.5.399	Secondary active transport brings sodium ions, and possibly other compounds, into the cell.
7.5.400	As sodium ion concentrations build outside of the plasma membrane because of the action of the primary active transport process, an electrochemical gradient is created.
7.5.401	If a channel protein exists and is open, the sodium ions will be pulled through the membrane.
7.5.402	This movement is used to transport other substances that can attach themselves to the transport protein through the membrane (Figure 5.19).
7.5.403	Many amino acids, as well as glucose, enter a cell this way.
7.5.404	This secondary process is also used to store high-energy hydrogen ions in the mitochondria of plant and animal cells for the production of ATP.
7.5.405	The potential energy that accumulates in the stored hydrogen ions is translated into kinetic energy as the ions surge through the channel protein ATP synthase, and that energy is used to convert ADP into ATP.
7.5.406	In addition to moving small ions and molecules through the membrane, cells also need to remove and take in larger molecules and particles (see Table 5.2 for examples).
7.5.407	Some cells are even capable of engulfing entire unicellular microorganisms.
7.5.408	You might have correctly hypothesized that the uptake and release of large particles by the cell requires energy.
7.5.409	A large particle, however, cannot pass through the membrane, even with energy supplied by the cell.
7.5.410	Endocytosis Endocytosis is a type of active transport that moves particles, such as large molecules, parts of cells, and even whole cells, into a cell.
7.5.411	There are different variations of endocytosis, but all share a common characteristic: The plasma membrane of the cell invaginates, forming a pocket around the target particle.
7.5.412	The pocket pinches off, resulting in the particle being contained in a newly created intracellular vesicle formed from the plasma membrane.
7.5.413	Phagocytosis Phagocytosis (the condition of “cell eating”) is the process by which large particles, such as cells or relatively large particles, are taken in by a cell.
7.5.414	For example, when microorganisms invade the human body, a type of white blood cell called a neutrophil will remove the invaders through this process, surrounding and engulfing the microorganism, which is then destroyed by the neutrophil (Figure 5.20).
7.5.415	In phagocytosis, the cell membrane surrounds the particle and engulfs it.
7.5.416	(credit: Mariana Ruiz Villareal)
7.5.417	In preparation for phagocytosis, a portion of the inward-facing surface of the plasma membrane becomes coated with a protein called clathrin, which stabilizes this section of the membrane.
7.5.418	The coated portion of the membrane then extends from the body of the cell and surrounds the particle, eventually enclosing it.
7.5.419	Once the vesicle containing the particle is enclosed within the cell, the clathrin disengages from the membrane and the vesicle merges with a lysosome for the breakdown of the material in the newly formed compartment (endosome).
7.5.420	When accessible nutrients from the degradation of the vesicular contents have been extracted, the newly formed endosome merges with the plasma membrane and releases its contents into the extracellular fluid.
7.5.421	The endosomal membrane again becomes part of the plasma membrane.
7.5.422	Pinocytosis A variation of endocytosis is called pinocytosis.
7.5.423	This literally means “cell drinking” and was named at a time when the assumption was that the cell was purposefully taking in extracellular fluid.
7.5.424	In reality, this is a process that takes in molecules, including water, which the cell needs from the extracellular fluid.
7.5.425	Pinocytosis results in a much smaller vesicle than does phagocytosis, and the vesicle does not need to merge with a lysosome.
7.5.426	In pinocytosis, the cell membrane invaginates, surrounds a small volume of fluid, and pinches off.
7.5.427	(credit: Mariana Ruiz Villareal)
7.5.428	A variation of pinocytosis is called potocytosis.
7.5.429	This process uses a coating protein, called caveolin, on the cytoplasmic side of the plasma membrane, which performs a similar function to clathrin.
7.5.430	The cavities in the plasma membrane that form the vacuoles have membrane receptors and lipid rafts in addition to caveolin.
7.5.431	The vacuoles or vesicles formed in caveolae (singular caveola) are smaller than those in pinocytosis.
7.5.432	Potocytosis is used to bring small molecules into the cell and to transport these molecules through the cell for their release on the other side of the cell, a process called transcytosis.
7.5.433	Receptor-mediated Endocytosis A targeted variation of endocytosis employs receptor proteins in the plasma membrane that have a specific binding affinity for certain substances.
7.5.434	In receptor-mediated endocytosis, uptake of substances by the cell is targeted to a single type of substance that binds to the receptor on the external surface of the cell membrane.
7.5.435	(credit: modification of work by Mariana Ruiz Villareal)
7.5.436	In receptor-mediated endocytosis, as in phagocytosis, clathrin is attached to the cytoplasmic side of the plasma membrane.
7.5.437	If uptake of a compound is dependent on receptor-mediated endocytosis and the process is ineffective, the material will not be removed from the tissue fluids or blood.
7.5.438	Instead, it will stay in those fluids and increase in concentration.
7.5.439	Some human diseases are caused by the failure of receptor-mediated endocytosis.
7.5.440	For example, the form of cholesterol termed low-density lipoprotein or LDL (also referred to as “bad” cholesterol) is removed from the blood by receptor-mediated endocytosis.
7.5.441	In the human genetic disease familial hypercholesterolemia, the LDL receptors are defective or missing entirely.
7.5.442	People with this condition have life-threatening levels of cholesterol in their blood, because their cells cannot clear LDL particles from their blood.
7.5.443	Although receptor-mediated endocytosis is designed to bring specific substances that are normally found in the extracellular fluid into the cell, other substances may gain entry into the cell at the same site.
7.5.444	Flu viruses, diphtheria, and cholera toxin all have sites that cross-react with normal receptor-binding sites and gain entry into cells.
7.5.445	Exocytosis
7.5.446	The reverse process of moving material into a cell is the process of exocytosis.
7.5.447	Exocytosis is the opposite of the processes discussed above in that its purpose is to expel material from the cell into the extracellular fluid.
7.5.448	Waste material is enveloped in a membrane and fuses with the interior of the plasma membrane.
7.5.449	This fusion opens the membranous envelope on 158 Chapter 5 | Structure and Function of Plasma Membranes
7.5.450	This OpenStax book is available for free at http://cnx.org/content/col11448/1.10 the exterior of the cell, and the waste material is expelled into the extracellular space (Figure 5.23).
7.5.451	Other examples of cells releasing molecules via exocytosis include the secretion of proteins of the extracellular matrix and secretion of neurotransmitters into the synaptic cleft by synaptic vesicles.
7.6.0	Introduction
7.6.1	Virtually every task performed by living organisms requires energy.
7.6.2	Energy is needed to perform heavy labor and exercise, but humans also use a great deal of energy while thinking, and even during sleep.
7.6.3	In fact, the living cells of every organism constantly use energy.
7.6.4	Nutrients and other molecules are imported, metabolized (broken down) and possibly synthesized into new molecules, modified if needed, transported around the cell, and may be distributed to the entire organism.
7.6.5	For example, the large proteins that make up muscles are actively built from smaller molecules.
7.6.6	Complex carbohydrates are broken down into simple sugars that the cell uses for energy.
7.6.7	Just as energy is required to both build and demolish a building, energy is required for both the synthesis and breakdown of molecules.
7.6.8	Additionally, signaling molecules such as hormones and neurotransmitters are transported between cells.
7.6.9	Pathogenic bacteria and viruses are ingested and broken down by cells.
7.6.10	Cells must also export waste and toxins to stay healthy, and many cells must swim or move surrounding materials via the beating motion of cellular appendages like cilia and flagella.
7.6.11	The cellular processes listed above require a steady supply of energy.
7.6.12	From where, and in what form, does this energy come?
7.6.13	How do living cells obtain energy, and how do they use it?
7.6.14	This chapter will discuss different forms of energy and the physical laws that govern energy transfer.
7.6.15	This chapter will also describe how cells use energy and replenish it, and how chemical reactions in the cell are performed with great efficiency.
7.6.16	Scientists use the term bioenergetics to discuss the concept of energy flow (Figure 6.2) through living systems, such as cells.
7.6.17	Cellular processes such as the building and breaking down of complex molecules occur through stepwise chemical reactions.
7.6.18	Some of these chemical reactions are spontaneous and release energy, whereas others require energy to proceed.
7.6.19	Just as living things must continually consume food to replenish what has been used, cells must continually produce more energy to replenish that used by the many energy-requiring chemical reactions that constantly take place.
7.6.20	All of the chemical reactions that take place inside cells, including those that use energy and those that release energy, are the cell’s metabolism.
7.6.21	Most life forms on earth get their energy from the sun.
7.6.22	Plants use photosynthesis to capture sunlight, and herbivores eat those plants to obtain energy.
7.6.23	Carnivores eat the herbivores, and decomposers digest plant and animal matter.
7.6.24	During the chemical reactions of photosynthesis, energy is provided in the form of a very high-energy molecule called ATP, or adenosine triphosphate, which is the primary energy currency of all cells.
7.6.25	Just as the dollar is used as currency to buy goods, cells use molecules of ATP as energy currency to perform immediate work.
7.6.26	The sugar (glucose) is stored as starch or glycogen.
7.6.27	Energy-storing polymers like these are broken down into glucose to supply molecules of ATP.
7.6.28	Solar energy is required to synthesize a molecule of glucose during the reactions of photosynthesis.
7.6.29	In photosynthesis, light energy from the sun is initially transformed into chemical energy that is temporally stored in the energy carrier molecules ATP and NADPH
7.6.30	(nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide phosphate).
7.6.31	The stored energy in ATP and NADPH is then used later in photosynthesis to build one molecule of glucose from six molecules of CO2.
7.6.32	This process is analogous to eating breakfast in the morning to acquire energy for your body that can be used later in the day.
7.6.33	Under ideal conditions, energy from 18 molecules of ATP is required to synthesize one molecule of glucose during the reactions of photosynthesis.
7.6.34	Glucose molecules can also be combined with and converted into other types of sugars.
7.6.35	When sugars are consumed, molecules of glucose eventually make their way into each living cell of the organism.
7.6.36	Inside the cell, each sugar molecule is broken down through a complex series of chemical reactions.
7.6.37	The goal of these reactions is to harvest the energy stored inside the sugar molecules.
7.6.38	The harvested energy is used to make high-energy ATP molecules, which can be used to perform work, powering many chemical reactions in the cell.
7.6.39	The amount of energy needed to make one molecule of glucose from six molecules of carbon dioxide is 18 molecules of ATP and 12 molecules of NADPH (each one of which is energetically equivalent to three molecules of ATP), or a total of 54 molecule equivalents required for the synthesis of one molecule of glucose.
7.6.40	This process is a fundamental and efficient way for cells to generate the molecular energy that they require.
7.6.41	Plants, like this oak tree and acorn, use energy from sunlight to make sugar and other organic molecules.
7.6.42	Both plants and animals (like this squirrel) use cellular respiration to derive energy from the organic molecules originally produced by plants.
7.6.43	Metabolic Pathways
7.6.44	The processes of making and breaking down sugar molecules illustrate two types of metabolic pathways.
7.6.45	A metabolic pathway is a series of interconnected biochemical reactions that convert a substrate molecule or molecules, step-by-step, through a series of metabolic intermediates, eventually yielding a final product or products.
7.6.46	In the case of sugar metabolism, the first metabolic pathway synthesized sugar from smaller molecules, and the other pathway broke sugar down into smaller molecules.
7.6.47	These two opposite processes—the first requiring energy and the second producing energy—are referred to as anabolic (building) and catabolic (breaking down) pathways, respectively.
7.6.48	Consequently, metabolism is composed of building (anabolism) and degradation (catabolism).
7.6.49	There is more to the complexity of metabolism than understanding the metabolic pathways alone.
7.6.50	Metabolic complexity varies from organism to organism.
7.6.51	Photosynthesis is the primary pathway in which photosynthetic organisms like plants (the majority of global synthesis is done by planktonic algae) harvest the sun’s energy and convert it into carbohydrates.
7.6.52	The by-product of photosynthesis is oxygen, required by some cells to carry out cellular respiration.
7.6.53	During cellular respiration, oxygen aids in the catabolic breakdown of carbon compounds, like carbohydrates.
7.6.54	Among the products of this catabolism are CO2 and ATP.
7.6.55	In addition, some eukaryotes perform catabolic processes without oxygen (fermentation); that is, they perform or use anaerobic metabolism.
7.6.56	Organisms probably evolved anaerobic metabolism to survive (living organisms came into existence about 3.8 billion years ago, when the atmosphere lacked oxygen).
7.6.57	Despite the differences between organisms and the complexity of metabolism, researchers have found that all branches of life share some of the same metabolic pathways, suggesting that all organisms evolved from the same ancient common ancestor (Figure 6.4).
7.6.58	Evidence indicates that over time, the pathways diverged, adding specialized enzymes to allow organisms to better adapt to their environment, thus increasing their chance to survive.
7.6.59	However, the underlying principle remains that all organisms must harvest energy from their environment and convert it to ATP to carry out cellular functions.
7.6.60	Anabolic and Catabolic Pathways Anabolic pathways require an input of energy to synthesize complex molecules from simpler ones.
7.6.61	Synthesizing sugar from CO2 is one example.
7.6.62	Other examples are the synthesis of large proteins from amino acid building blocks, and the synthesis of new DNA strands from nucleic acid building blocks.
7.6.63	These biosynthetic processes are critical to the life of the cell, take place constantly, and demand energy provided by ATP and other high-energy molecules like NADH (nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide) and NADPH (Figure 6.5).
7.6.64	ATP is an important molecule for cells to have in sufficient supply at all times.
7.6.65	The breakdown of sugars illustrates how a single molecule of glucose can store enough energy to make a great deal of ATP, 36 to 38 molecules.
7.6.66	This is a catabolic pathway.
7.6.67	Catabolic pathways involve the degradation (or breakdown) of complex molecules into simpler ones.
7.6.68	Molecular energy stored in the bonds of complex molecules is released in catabolic pathways and harvested in such a way that it can be used to produce ATP.
7.6.69	Other energy-storing molecules, such as fats, are also broken down through similar catabolic reactions to release energy and make ATP (Figure 6.5).
7.6.70	It is important to know that the chemical reactions of metabolic pathways don’t take place spontaneously.
7.6.71	Each reaction step is facilitated, or catalyzed, by a protein called an enzyme.
7.6.72	Enzymes are important for catalyzing all types of biological reactions—those that require energy as well as those that release energy.
7.6.73	Anabolic pathways are those that require energy to synthesize larger molecules.
7.6.74	Catabolic pathways are those that generate energy by breaking down larger molecules.
7.6.75	Both types of pathways are required for maintaining the cell’s energy balance.
7.6.76	Energy is defined as the ability to do work.
7.6.77	As you’ve learned, energy exists in different forms.
7.6.78	For example, electrical energy, light energy, and heat energy are all different types of energy.
7.6.79	While these are all familiar types of energy that one can see or feel, there is another type of energy that is much less tangible.
7.6.80	This energy is associated with something as simple as an object held above the ground.
7.6.81	In order to appreciate the way energy flows into and out of biological systems, it is important to understand more about the different types of energy that exist in the physical world.
7.6.82	Types of Energy
7.6.83	When an object is in motion, there is energy associated with that object.
7.6.84	In the example of an airplane in flight, there is a great deal of energy associated with the motion of the airplane.
7.6.85	This is because moving objects are capable of enacting a change, or doing work.
7.6.86	Think of a wrecking ball.
7.6.87	Even a slow-moving wrecking ball can do a great deal of damage to other objects.
7.6.88	However, a wrecking ball that is not in motion is incapable of performing work.
7.6.89	Energy associated with objects in motion is called kinetic energy.
7.6.90	A speeding bullet, a walking person, the rapid movement of molecules in the air (which produces heat), and electromagnetic radiation like light all have kinetic energy.
7.6.91	Now what if that same motionless wrecking ball is lifted two stories above a car with a crane?
7.6.92	If the suspended wrecking ball is unmoving, is there energy associated with it?
7.6.93	The answer is yes.
7.6.94	The suspended wrecking ball has energy associated with it that is fundamentally different from the kinetic energy of objects in motion.
7.6.95	This form of energy results from the fact that there is the potential for the wrecking ball to do work.
7.6.96	If it is released, indeed it would do work.
7.6.97	Because this type of energy refers to the potential to do work, it is called potential energy.
7.6.98	Objects transfer their energy between kinetic and potential in the following way: As the wrecking ball hangs motionless, it has 0 kinetic and 100 percent potential energy.
7.6.99	Once it is released, its kinetic energy begins to increase because it builds speed due to gravity.
7.6.100	At the same time, as it nears the ground, it loses potential energy.
7.6.101	Somewhere mid-fall it has 50 percent kinetic and 50 percent potential energy.
7.6.102	Just before it hits the ground, the ball has nearly lost its potential energy and has near-maximal kinetic energy.
7.6.103	Other examples of potential energy include the energy of water held behind a dam (Figure 6.6), or a person about to skydive out of an airplane.
7.6.104	Water behind a dam has potential energy.
7.6.105	Moving water, such as in a waterfall or a rapidly flowing river, has kinetic energy.
7.6.106	Potential energy is not only associated with the location of matter (such as a child sitting on a tree branch), but also with the structure of matter.
7.6.107	A spring on the ground has potential energy if it is compressed; so does a rubber band that is pulled taut.
7.6.108	The very existence of living cells relies heavily on structural potential energy.
7.6.109	On a chemical level, the bonds that hold the atoms of molecules together have potential energy.
7.6.110	Remember that anabolic cellular pathways require energy to synthesize complex molecules from simpler ones, and catabolic pathways release energy when complex molecules are broken down.
7.6.111	The fact that energy can be released by the breakdown of certain chemical bonds implies that those bonds have potential energy.
7.6.112	In fact, there is potential energy stored within the bonds of all the food molecules we eat, which is eventually harnessed for use.
7.6.113	This is because these bonds can release energy when broken.
7.6.114	The type of potential energy that exists within chemical bonds, and is released when those bonds are broken, is called chemical energy (Figure 6.7).
7.6.115	Chemical energy is responsible for providing living cells with energy from food.
7.6.116	The release of energy is brought about by breaking the molecular bonds within fuel molecules.
7.6.117	The molecules in gasoline (octane, the chemical formula shown) contain chemical energy within the chemical bonds.
7.6.118	This energy is transformed into kinetic energy that allows a car to race on a racetrack.
7.6.119	Free Energy
7.6.120	After learning that chemical reactions release energy when energy-storing bonds are broken, an important next question is how is the energy associated with chemical reactions quantified and expressed?
7.6.121	How can the energy released from one reaction be compared to that of another reaction?
7.6.122	A measurement of free energy is used to quantitate these energy transfers.
7.6.123	Free energy is called Gibbs free energy (abbreviated with the letter G) after Josiah Willard Gibbs, the scientist who developed the measurement.
7.6.124	Recall that according to the second law of thermodynamics, all energy transfers involve the loss of some amount of energy in an unusable form such as heat, resulting in entropy.
7.6.125	Gibbs free energy specifically refers to the energy associated with a chemical reaction that is available after entropy is accounted for.
7.6.126	In other words, Gibbs free energy is usable energy, or energy that is available to do work.
7.6.127	Every chemical reaction involves a change in free energy, called delta G (ΔG).
7.6.128	The change in free energy can be calculated for any system that undergoes such a change, such as a chemical reaction.
7.6.129	To calculate ΔG, subtract the amount of energy lost to entropy (denoted as ΔS) from the total energy change of the system.
7.6.130	This total energy change in the system is called enthalpy and is denoted as ΔH .
7.6.131	The formula for calculating ΔG is as follows, where the symbol T refers to absolute temperature in Kelvin (degrees Celsius + 273): ΔG = ΔH − TΔS
7.6.132	The standard free energy change of a chemical reaction is expressed as an amount of energy per mole of the reaction product (either in kilojoules or kilocalories, kJ/mol or kcal/mol; 1 kJ = 0.239 kcal) under standard pH, temperature, and pressure conditions.
7.6.133	Standard pH, temperature, and pressure conditions are generally calculated at pH 7.0 in biological systems, 25 degrees Celsius, and 100 kilopascals (1 atm pressure), respectively.
7.6.134	It is important to note that cellular conditions vary considerably from these standard conditions, and so standard calculated ΔG values for biological reactions will be different inside the cell.
7.6.135	Endergonic Reactions and Exergonic Reactions
7.6.136	If energy is released during a chemical reaction, then the resulting value from the above equation will be a negative number.
7.6.137	In other words, reactions that release energy have a ΔG < 0.
7.6.138	A negative ΔG also means that the products of the reaction have less free energy than the reactants, because they gave off some free energy during the reaction.
7.6.139	Reactions that have a negative ΔG and consequently release free energy are called exergonic reactions.
7.6.140	Think: exergonic means energy is exiting the system.
7.6.141	These reactions are also referred to as spontaneous reactions, because they can occur without the addition of energy into the system.
7.6.142	Understanding which chemical reactions are spontaneous and release free energy is extremely useful for biologists, because these reactions can be harnessed to perform work inside the cell.
7.6.143	An important distinction must be drawn between the term spontaneous and the idea of a chemical reaction that occurs immediately.
7.6.144	Contrary to the everyday use of the term, a spontaneous reaction is not one that suddenly or quickly occurs.
7.6.145	The rusting of iron is an example of a spontaneous reaction that occurs slowly, little by little, over time.
7.6.146	If a chemical reaction requires an input of energy rather than releasing energy, then the ΔG for that reaction will be a positive value.
7.6.147	In this case, the products have more free energy than the reactants.
7.6.148	Thus, the products of these reactions can be thought of as energy-storing molecules.
7.6.149	These chemical reactions are called endergonic reactions, and they are nonspontaneous.
7.6.150	An endergonic reaction will not take place on its own without the addition of free energy.
7.6.151	Let’s revisit the example of the synthesis and breakdown of the food molecule, glucose.
7.6.152	Remember that the building of complex molecules, such as sugars, from simpler ones is an anabolic process and requires energy.
7.6.153	Therefore, the chemical reactions involved in anabolic processes are endergonic reactions.
7.6.154	On the other hand, the catabolic process of breaking sugar down into simpler molecules releases energy in a series of exergonic reactions.
7.6.155	Like the example of rust above, the breakdown of sugar involves spontaneous reactions, but these reactions don’t occur instantaneously.
7.6.156	Figure 6.8 shows some other examples of endergonic and exergonic reactions.
7.6.157	Later sections will provide more information about what else is required to make even spontaneous reactions happen more efficiently.
7.6.158	An important concept in the study of metabolism and energy is that of chemical equilibrium.
7.6.159	Most chemical reactions are reversible.
7.6.160	They can proceed in both directions, releasing energy into their environment in one direction, and absorbing it from the environment in the other direction (Figure 6.9).
7.6.161	The same is true for the chemical reactions involved in cell metabolism, such as the breaking down and building up of proteins into and from individual amino acids, respectively.
7.6.162	Reactants within a closed system will undergo chemical reactions in both directions until a state of equilibrium is reached.
7.6.163	This state of equilibrium is one of the lowest possible free energy and a state of maximal entropy.
7.6.164	Energy must be put into the system to push the reactants and products away from a state of equilibrium.
7.6.165	Either reactants or products must be added, removed, or changed.
7.6.166	If a cell were a closed system, its chemical reactions would reach equilibrium, and it would die because there would be insufficient free energy left to perform the work needed to maintain life.
7.6.167	In a living cell, chemical reactions are constantly moving towards equilibrium, but never reach it.
7.6.168	This is because a living cell is an open system.
7.6.169	Materials pass in and out, the cell recycles the products of certain chemical reactions into other reactions, and chemical equilibrium is never reached.
7.6.170	In this way, living organisms are in a constant energy-requiring, uphill battle against equilibrium and entropy.
7.6.171	This constant supply of energy ultimately comes from sunlight, which is used to produce nutrients in the process of photosynthesis.
7.6.172	Exergonic and endergonic reactions result in changes in Gibbs free energy.
7.6.173	Exergonic reactions release energy; endergonic reactions require energy to proceed.
7.6.174	Activation Energy There is another important concept that must be considered regarding endergonic and exergonic reactions.
7.6.175	Even exergonic reactions require a small amount of energy input to get going before they can proceed with their energy-releasing steps.
7.6.176	These reactions have a net release of energy, but still require some energy in the beginning.
7.6.177	This small amount of energy input necessary for all chemical reactions to occur is called the activation energy (or free energy of activation) and is abbreviated EA (Figure 6.10).
7.6.178	Why would an energy-releasing, negative ΔG reaction actually require some energy to proceed?
7.6.179	The reason lies in the steps that take place during a chemical reaction.
7.6.180	During chemical reactions, certain chemical bonds are broken and new ones are formed.
7.6.181	For example, when a glucose molecule is broken down, bonds between the carbon atoms of the molecule are broken.
7.6.182	Since these are energy-storing bonds, they release energy when broken.
7.6.183	However, to get them into a state that allows the bonds to break, the molecule must be somewhat contorted.
7.6.184	A small energy input is required to achieve this contorted state.
7.6.185	This contorted state is called the transition state, and it is a high-energy, unstable state.
7.6.186	For this reason, reactant molecules don’t last long in their transition state, but very quickly proceed to the next steps of the chemical reaction.
7.6.187	Free energy diagrams illustrate the energy profiles for a given reaction.
7.6.188	Whether the reaction is exergonic or endergonic determines whether the products in the diagram will exist at a lower or higher energy state than both the reactants and the products.
7.6.189	However, regardless of this measure, the transition state of the reaction exists at a higher energy state than the reactants, and thus, EA is always positive.
7.6.190	Where does the activation energy required by chemical reactants come from?
7.6.191	The source of the activation energy needed to push reactions forward is typically heat energy from the surroundings.
7.6.192	Heat energy (the total bond energy of reactants or products in a chemical reaction) speeds up the motion of molecules, increasing the frequency and force with which they collide; it also moves atoms and bonds within the molecule slightly, helping them reach their transition state.
7.6.193	For this reason, heating up a system will cause chemical reactants within that system to react more frequently.
7.6.194	Increasing the pressure on a system has the same effect.
7.6.195	Once reactants have absorbed enough heat energy from their surroundings to reach the transition state, the reaction will proceed.
7.6.196	The activation energy of a particular reaction determines the rate at which it will proceed.
7.6.197	The higher the activation energy, the slower the chemical reaction will be.
7.6.198	The example of iron rusting illustrates an inherently slow reaction.
7.6.199	This reaction occurs slowly over time because of its high EA.
7.6.200	Additionally, the burning of many fuels, which is strongly exergonic, will take place at a negligible rate unless their activation energy is overcome by sufficient heat from a spark.
7.6.201	Once they begin to burn, however, the chemical reactions release enough heat to continue the burning process, supplying the activation energy for surrounding fuel molecules.
7.6.202	Like these reactions outside of cells, the activation energy for most cellular reactions is too high for heat energy to overcome at efficient rates.
7.6.203	In other words, in order for important cellular reactions to occur at appreciable rates (number of reactions per unit time), their activation energies must be lowered (Figure 6.10); this is referred to as catalysis.
7.6.204	This is a very good thing as far as living cells are concerned.
7.6.205	Important macromolecules, such as proteins, DNA, and RNA, store considerable energy, and their breakdown is exergonic.
7.6.206	If cellular temperatures alone provided enough heat energy for these exergonic reactions to overcome their activation barriers, the essential components of a cell would disintegrate.
7.6.207	Thermodynamics refers to the study of energy and energy transfer involving physical matter.
7.6.208	The matter and its environment relevant to a particular case of energy transfer are classified as a system, and everything outside of that system is called the surroundings.
7.6.209	For instance, when heating a pot of water on the stove, the system includes the stove, the pot, and the water.
7.6.210	Energy is transferred within the system (between the stove, pot, and water).
7.6.211	There are two types of systems: open and closed.
7.6.212	An open system is one in which energy can be transferred between the system and its surroundings.
7.6.213	The stovetop system is open because heat can be lost into the air.
7.6.214	A closed system is one that cannot transfer energy to its surroundings.
7.6.215	Biological organisms are open systems.
7.6.216	Energy is exchanged between them and their surroundings, as they consume energystoring molecules and release energy to the environment by doing work.
7.6.217	Like all things in the physical world, energy is subject to the laws of physics.
7.6.218	The laws of thermodynamics govern the transfer of energy in and among all systems in the universe.
7.6.219	The First Law of Thermodynamics
7.6.220	The first law of thermodynamics deals with the total amount of energy in the universe.
7.6.221	It states that this total amount of energy is constant.
7.6.222	In other words, there has always been, and always will be, exactly the same amount of energy in the universe.
7.6.223	Energy exists in many different forms.
7.6.224	According to the first law of thermodynamics, energy may be transferred from place to place or transformed into different forms, but it cannot be created or destroyed.
7.6.225	The transfers and transformations of energy take place around us all the time.
7.6.226	Light bulbs transform electrical energy into light energy.
7.6.227	Gas stoves transform chemical energy from natural gas into heat energy.
7.6.228	Plants perform one of the most biologically useful energy transformations on earth: that of converting the energy of sunlight into the chemical energy stored within organic molecules (Figure 6.2).
7.6.229	Some examples of energy transformations are shown in Figure 6.11.
7.6.230	The challenge for all living organisms is to obtain energy from their surroundings in forms that they can transfer or transform into usable energy to do work.
7.6.231	Living cells have evolved to meet this challenge very well.
7.6.232	Chemical energy stored within organic molecules such as sugars and fats is transformed through a series of cellular chemical reactions into energy within molecules of ATP.
7.6.233	Energy in ATP molecules is easily accessible to do work.
7.6.234	Examples of the types of work that cells need to do include building complex molecules, transporting materials, powering the beating motion of cilia or flagella, contracting muscle fibers to create movement, and reproduction.
7.6.235	Shown are two examples of energy being transferred from one system to another and transformed from one form to another.
7.6.236	Humans can convert the chemical energy in food, like this ice cream cone, into kinetic energy (the energy of movement to ride a bicycle).
7.6.237	Plants can convert electromagnetic radiation (light energy) from the sun into chemical energy.
7.6.238	The Second Law of Thermodynamics A living cell’s primary tasks of obtaining, transforming, and using energy to do work may seem simple.
7.6.239	However, the second law of thermodynamics explains why these tasks are harder than they appear.
7.6.240	None of the energy transfers we’ve discussed, along with all energy transfers and transformations in the universe, is completely efficient.
7.6.241	In every energy transfer, some amount of energy is lost in a form that is unusable.
7.6.242	In most cases, this form is heat energy.
7.6.243	Thermodynamically, heat energy is defined as the energy transferred from one system to another that is not doing work.
7.6.244	For example, when an airplane flies through the air, some of the energy of the flying plane is lost as heat energy due to friction with the surrounding air.
7.6.245	This friction actually heats the air by temporarily increasing the speed of air molecules.
7.6.246	Likewise, some energy is lost as heat energy during cellular metabolic reactions.
7.6.247	This is good for warm-blooded creatures like us, because heat energy helps to maintain our body temperature.
7.6.248	Strictly speaking, no energy transfer is completely efficient, because some energy is lost in an unusable form.
7.6.249	An important concept in physical systems is that of order and disorder (also known as randomness).
7.6.250	The more energy that is lost by a system to its surroundings, the less ordered and more random the system is.
7.6.251	Scientists refer to the measure of randomness or disorder within a system as entropy.
7.6.252	High entropy means high disorder and low energy (Figure 6.12).
7.6.253	To better understand entropy, think of a student’s bedroom.
7.6.254	If no energy or work were put into it, the room would quickly become messy.
7.6.255	It would exist in a very disordered state, one of high entropy.
7.6.256	Energy must be put into the system, in the form of the student doing work and putting everything away, in order to bring the room back to a state of cleanliness and order.
7.6.257	This state is one of low entropy.
7.6.258	Similarly, a car or house must be constantly maintained with work in order to keep it in an ordered state.
