7.6.259	Left alone, the entropy of the house or car gradually increases through rust and degradation.
7.6.260	Molecules and chemical reactions have varying amounts of entropy as well.
7.6.261	For example, as chemical reactions reach a state of equilibrium, entropy increases, and as molecules at a high concentration in one place diffuse and spread out, entropy also increases.
7.6.262	All physical systems can be thought of in this way: Living things are highly ordered, requiring constant energy input to be maintained in a state of low entropy.
7.6.263	As living systems take in energy-storing molecules and transform them through chemical reactions, they lose some amount of usable energy in the process, because no reaction is completely efficient.
7.6.264	They also produce waste and by-products that aren’t useful energy sources.
7.6.265	This process increases the entropy of the system’s surroundings.
7.6.266	Since all energy transfers result in the loss of some usable energy, the second law of thermodynamics states that every energy transfer or transformation increases the entropy of the universe.
7.6.267	Even though living things are highly ordered and maintain a state of low entropy, the entropy of the universe in total is constantly increasing due to the loss of usable energy with each energy transfer that occurs.
7.6.268	Essentially, living things are in a continuous uphill battle against this constant increase in universal entropy.
7.6.269	Entropy is a measure of randomness or disorder in a system.
7.6.270	Gases have higher entropy than liquids, and liquids have higher entropy than solids.
7.6.271	Even exergonic, energy-releasing reactions require a small amount of activation energy in order to proceed.
7.6.272	However, consider endergonic reactions, which require much more energy input, because their products have more free energy than their reactants.
7.6.273	Within the cell, where does energy to power such reactions come from?
7.6.274	The answer lies with an energysupplying molecule called adenosine triphosphate, or ATP.
7.6.275	ATP is a small, relatively simple molecule (Figure 6.13), but within some of its bonds, it contains the potential for a quick burst of energy that can be harnessed to perform cellular work.
7.6.276	This molecule can be thought of as the primary energy currency of cells in much the same way that money is the currency that people exchange for things they need.
7.6.277	ATP is used to power the majority of energy-requiring cellular reactions.
7.6.278	ATP is the primary energy currency of the cell.
7.6.279	It has an adenosine backbone with three phosphate groups attached.
7.6.280	As its name suggests, adenosine triphosphate is comprised of adenosine bound to three phosphate groups (Figure 6.13).
7.6.281	Adenosine is a nucleoside consisting of the nitrogenous base adenine and a five-carbon sugar, ribose.
7.6.282	The three phosphate groups, in order of closest to furthest from the ribose sugar, are labeled alpha, beta, and gamma.
7.6.283	Together, these chemical groups constitute an energy powerhouse.
7.6.284	However, not all bonds within this molecule exist in a particularly high-energy state.
7.6.285	Both bonds that link the phosphates are equally high-energy bonds ( phosphoanhydride bonds) that, when broken, release sufficient energy to power a variety of cellular reactions and processes.
7.6.286	These high-energy bonds are the bonds between the second and third (or beta and gamma) phosphate groups and between the first and second phosphate groups.
7.6.287	The reason that these bonds are considered “high-energy” is because the products of such bond breaking—adenosine diphosphate (ADP) and one inorganic phosphate group (Pi)—have considerably lower free energy than the reactants:
7.6.288	ATP and a water molecule.
7.6.289	Because this reaction takes place with the use of a water molecule, it is considered a hydrolysis reaction.
7.6.290	In other words, ATP is hydrolyzed into ADP in the following reaction: ATP + H2O
7.6.291	→ ADP +
7.6.292	Pi + free energy Like most chemical reactions, the hydrolysis of ATP to ADP is reversible.
7.6.293	The reverse reaction regenerates ATP from ADP + Pi.
7.6.294	Indeed, cells rely on the regeneration of ATP just as people rely on the regeneration of spent money through some sort of income.
7.6.295	Since ATP hydrolysis releases energy, ATP regeneration must require an input of free energy.
7.6.296	The formation of ATP is expressed in this equation: ADP + Pi + free energy
7.6.297	→ ATP + H2O
7.6.298	Two prominent questions remain with regard to the use of ATP as an energy source.
7.6.299	Exactly how much free energy is released with the hydrolysis of ATP, and how is that free energy used to do cellular work?
7.6.300	The calculated ΔG for the hydrolysis of one mole of ATP into ADP and Pi is −7.3 kcal/mole (−30.5 kJ/mol).
7.6.301	Since this calculation is true under standard conditions, it would be expected that a different value exists under cellular conditions.
7.6.302	In fact, the ΔG for the hydrolysis of one mole of ATP in a living cell is almost double the value at standard conditions: 14 kcal/mol (−57 kJ/mol).
7.6.303	ATP is a highly unstable molecule.
7.6.304	Unless quickly used to perform work, ATP spontaneously dissociates into ADP + Pi, and the free energy released during this process is lost as heat.
7.6.305	The second question posed above, that is, how the energy released by ATP hydrolysis is used to perform work inside the cell, depends on a strategy called energy coupling.
7.6.306	Cells couple the exergonic reaction of ATP hydrolysis with endergonic reactions, allowing them to proceed.
7.6.307	One example of energy coupling using ATP involves a transmembrane ion pump that is extremely important for cellular function.
7.6.308	This sodium-potassium pump (Na+/K+ pump) drives sodium out of the cell and potassium into the cell (Figure 6.14).
7.6.309	A large percentage of a cell’s ATP is spent powering this pump, because cellular processes bring a great deal of sodium into the cell and potassium out of the cell.
7.6.310	The pump works constantly to stabilize cellular concentrations of sodium and potassium.
7.6.311	In order for the pump to turn one cycle (exporting three Na+ ions and importing two K+ ions), one molecule of ATP must be hydrolyzed.
7.6.312	When ATP is hydrolyzed, its gamma phosphate doesn’t simply float away, but is actually transferred onto the pump protein.
7.6.313	This process of a phosphate group binding to a molecule is called phosphorylation.
7.6.314	As with most cases of ATP hydrolysis, a phosphate from ATP is transferred onto another molecule.
7.6.315	In a phosphorylated state, the Na+/K+ pump has more free energy and is triggered to undergo a conformational change.
7.6.316	This change allows it to release Na+ to the outside of the cell.
7.6.317	It then binds extracellular K+, which, through another conformational change, causes the phosphate to detach from the pump.
7.6.318	This release of phosphate triggers the K+ to be released to the inside of the cell.
7.6.319	Essentially, the energy released from the hydrolysis of ATP is coupled with the energy required to power the pump and transport Na+ and K+ ions.
7.6.320	ATP performs cellular work using this basic form of energy coupling through phosphorylation.
7.6.321	Often during cellular metabolic reactions, such as the synthesis and breakdown of nutrients, certain molecules must be altered slightly in their conformation to become substrates for the next step in the reaction series.
7.6.322	One example is during the very first steps of cellular respiration, when a molecule of the sugar glucose is broken down in the process of glycolysis.
7.6.323	In the first step of this process, ATP is required for the phosphorylation of glucose, creating a high-energy but unstable intermediate.
7.6.324	This phosphorylation reaction powers a conformational change that allows the phosphorylated glucose molecule to be converted to the phosphorylated sugar fructose.
7.6.325	Fructose is a necessary intermediate for glycolysis to move forward.
7.6.326	Here, the exergonic reaction of ATP hydrolysis is coupled with the endergonic reaction of converting glucose into a phosphorylated intermediate in the pathway.
7.6.327	Once again, the energy released by breaking a phosphate bond within ATP was used for the phosphorylation of another molecule, creating an unstable intermediate and powering an important conformational change.
7.6.328	A substance that helps a chemical reaction to occur is a catalyst, and the special molecules that catalyze biochemical reactions are called enzymes.
7.6.329	Almost all enzymes are proteins, made up of chains of amino acids, and they perform the critical task of lowering the activation energies of chemical reactions inside the cell.
7.6.330	Enzymes do this by binding to the reactant molecules, and holding them in such a way as to make the chemical bond-breaking and bond-forming processes take place more readily.
7.6.331	It is important to remember that enzymes don’t change the ΔG of a reaction.
7.6.332	In other words, they don’t change whether a reaction is exergonic (spontaneous) or endergonic.
7.6.333	This is because they don’t change the free energy of the reactants or products.
7.6.334	They only reduce the activation energy required to reach the transition state.
7.6.335	Enzyme Active Site and Substrate Specificity
7.6.336	The chemical reactants to which an enzyme binds are the enzyme’s substrates.
7.6.337	There may be one or more substrates, depending on the particular chemical reaction.
7.6.338	In some reactions, a single-reactant substrate is broken down into multiple products.
7.6.339	In others, two substrates may come together to create one larger molecule.
7.6.340	Two reactants might also enter a reaction, both become modified, and leave the reaction as two products.
7.6.341	The location within the enzyme where the substrate binds is called the enzyme’s active site.
7.6.342	The active site is where the “action” happens, so to speak.
7.6.343	Since enzymes are proteins, there is a unique combination of amino acid residues (also called side chains, or R groups) within the active site.
7.6.344	Each residue is characterized by different properties.
7.6.345	Residues can be large or small, weakly acidic or basic, hydrophilic or hydrophobic, positively or negatively charged, or neutral.
7.6.346	The unique combination of amino acid residues, their positions, sequences, structures, and properties, creates a very specific chemical environment within the active site.
7.6.347	This specific environment is suited to bind, albeit briefly, to a specific chemical substrate (or substrates).
7.6.348	Due to this jigsaw puzzle-like match between an enzyme and its substrates (which adapts to find the best fit between the transition state and the active site), enzymes are known for their specificity.
7.6.349	The “best fit” results from the shape and the amino acid functional group’s attraction to the substrate.
7.6.350	There is a specifically matched enzyme for each substrate and, thus, for each chemical reaction; however, there is flexibility as well.
7.6.351	The fact that active sites are so perfectly suited to provide specific environmental conditions also means that they are subject to influences by the local environment.
7.6.352	It is true that increasing the environmental temperature generally increases reaction rates, enzyme-catalyzed or otherwise.
7.6.353	However, increasing or decreasing the temperature outside of an optimal range can affect chemical bonds within the active site in such a way that they are less well suited to bind substrates.
7.6.354	High temperatures will eventually cause enzymes, like other biological molecules, to denature, a process that changes the natural properties of a substance.
7.6.355	Likewise, the pH of the local environment can also affect enzyme function.
7.6.356	Active site amino acid residues have their own acidic or basic properties that are optimal for catalysis.
7.6.357	These residues are sensitive to changes in pH that can impair the way substrate molecules bind.
7.6.358	Enzymes are suited to function best within a certain pH range, and, as with temperature, extreme pH values (acidic or basic) of the environment can cause enzymes to denature.
7.6.359	Induced Fit and Enzyme Function
7.6.360	For many years, scientists thought that enzyme-substrate binding took place in a simple “lock-and-key” fashion.
7.6.361	This model asserted that the enzyme and substrate fit together perfectly in one instantaneous step.
7.6.362	However, current research supports a more refined view called induced fit (Figure 6.16).
7.6.363	The induced-fit model expands upon the lock-and-key model by describing a more dynamic interaction between enzyme and substrate.
7.6.364	As the enzyme and substrate come together, their interaction causes a mild shift in the enzyme’s structure that confirms an ideal binding arrangement between the enzyme and the transition state of the substrate.
7.6.365	This ideal binding maximizes the enzyme’s ability to catalyze its reaction.
7.6.366	When an enzyme binds its substrate, an enzyme-substrate complex is formed.
7.6.367	This complex lowers the activation energy of the reaction and promotes its rapid progression in one of many ways.
7.6.368	On a basic level, enzymes promote chemical reactions that involve more than one substrate by bringing the substrates together in an optimal orientation.
7.6.369	The appropriate region (atoms and bonds) of one molecule is juxtaposed to the appropriate region of the other molecule with which it must react.
7.6.370	Another way in which enzymes promote the reaction of their substrates is by creating an optimal environment within the active site for the reaction to occur.
7.6.371	Certain chemical reactions might proceed best in a slightly acidic or non-polar environment.
7.6.372	The chemical properties that emerge from the particular arrangement of amino acid residues within an active site create the perfect environment for an enzyme’s specific substrates to react.
7.6.373	You’ve learned that the activation energy required for many reactions includes the energy involved in manipulating or slightly contorting chemical bonds so that they can easily break and allow others to reform.
7.6.374	Enzymatic action can aid this process.
7.6.375	The enzyme-substrate complex can lower the activation energy by contorting substrate molecules in such a way as to facilitate bond-breaking, helping to reach the transition state.
7.6.376	Finally, enzymes can also lower activation energies by taking part in the chemical reaction itself.
7.6.377	The amino acid residues can provide certain ions or chemical groups that actually form covalent bonds with substrate molecules as a necessary step of the reaction process.
7.6.378	In these cases, it is important to remember that the enzyme will always return to its original state at the completion of the reaction.
7.6.379	One of the hallmark properties of enzymes is that they remain ultimately unchanged by the reactions they catalyze.
7.6.380	After an enzyme is done catalyzing a reaction, it releases its product(s).
7.6.381	According to the induced-fit model, both enzyme and substrate undergo dynamic conformational changes upon binding.
7.6.382	The enzyme contorts the substrate into its transition state, thereby increasing the rate of the reaction.
7.6.383	Control of Metabolism
7.6.384	Through Enzyme Regulation
7.6.385	It would seem ideal to have a scenario in which all of the enzymes encoded in an organism’s genome existed in abundant supply and functioned optimally under all cellular conditions, in all cells, at all times.
7.6.386	In reality, this is far from the case.
7.6.387	A variety of mechanisms ensure that this does not happen.
7.6.388	Cellular needs and conditions vary from cell to cell, and change within individual cells over time.
7.6.389	The required enzymes and energetic demands of stomach cells are different from those of fat storage cells, skin cells, blood cells, and nerve cells.
7.6.390	Furthermore, a digestive cell works much harder to process and break down nutrients during the time that closely follows a meal compared with many hours after a meal.
7.6.391	As these cellular demands and conditions vary, so do the amounts and functionality of different enzymes.
7.6.392	Since the rates of biochemical reactions are controlled by activation energy, and enzymes lower and determine activation energies for chemical reactions, the relative amounts and functioning of the variety of enzymes within a cell ultimately determine which reactions will proceed and at which rates.
7.6.393	This determination is tightly controlled.
7.6.394	In certain cellular environments, enzyme activity is partly controlled by environmental factors, like pH and temperature.
7.6.395	There are other mechanisms through which cells control the activity of enzymes and determine the rates at which various biochemical reactions will occur.
7.6.396	Regulation of Enzymes by Molecules Enzymes can be regulated in ways that either promote or reduce their activity.
7.6.397	There are many different kinds of molecules that inhibit or promote enzyme function, and various mechanisms exist for doing so.
7.6.398	In some cases of enzyme inhibition, for example, an inhibitor molecule is similar enough to a substrate that it can bind to the active site and simply block the substrate from binding.
7.6.399	When this happens, the enzyme is inhibited through competitive inhibition, because an inhibitor molecule competes with the substrate for active site binding (Figure 6.17).
7.6.400	On the other hand, in noncompetitive inhibition, an inhibitor molecule binds to the enzyme in a location other than an allosteric site and still manages to block substrate binding to the active site.
7.6.401	Competitive and noncompetitive inhibition affect the rate of reaction differently.
7.6.402	Competitive inhibitors affect the initial rate but do not affect the maximal rate, whereas noncompetitive inhibitors affect the maximal rate.
7.6.403	Some inhibitor molecules bind to enzymes in a location where their binding induces a conformational change that reduces the affinity of the enzyme for its substrate.
7.6.404	This type of inhibition is called allosteric inhibition (Figure 6.18).
7.6.405	Most allosterically regulated enzymes are made up of more than one polypeptide, meaning that they have more than one protein subunit.
7.6.406	When an allosteric inhibitor binds to an enzyme, all active sites on the protein subunits are changed slightly such that they bind their substrates with less efficiency.
7.6.407	There are allosteric activators as well as inhibitors.
7.6.408	Allosteric activators bind to locations on an enzyme away from the active site, inducing a conformational change that increases the affinity of the enzyme’s active site(s) for its substrate(s).
7.6.409	Allosteric inhibitors modify the active site of the enzyme so that substrate binding is reduced or prevented.
7.6.410	In contrast, allosteric activators modify the active site of the enzyme so that the affinity for the substrate increases.
7.6.411	Many enzymes don’t work optimally, or even at all, unless bound to other specific non-protein helper molecules, either temporarily through ionic or hydrogen bonds or permanently through stronger covalent bonds.
7.6.412	Two types of helper molecules are cofactors and coenzymes.
7.6.413	Binding to these molecules promotes optimal conformation and function for their respective enzymes.
7.6.414	Cofactors are inorganic ions such as iron (Fe++) and magnesium (Mg++).
7.6.415	One example of an enzyme that requires a metal ion as a cofactor is the enzyme that builds DNA molecules, DNA polymerase, which requires bound zinc ion (Zn++) to function.
7.6.416	Coenzymes are organic helper molecules, with a basic atomic structure made up of carbon and hydrogen, which are required for enzyme action.
7.6.417	The most common sources of coenzymes are dietary vitamins (Figure 6.20).
7.6.418	Some vitamins are precursors to coenzymes and others act directly as coenzymes.
7.6.419	Vitamin C is a coenzyme for multiple enzymes that take part in building the important connective tissue component, collagen.
7.6.420	An important step in the breakdown of glucose to yield energy is catalysis by a multi-enzyme complex called pyruvate dehydrogenase.
7.6.421	Pyruvate dehydrogenase is a complex of several enzymes that actually requires one cofactor (a magnesium ion) and five different organic coenzymes to catalyze its specific chemical reaction.
7.6.422	Therefore, enzyme function is, in part, regulated by an abundance of various cofactors and coenzymes, which are supplied primarily by the diets of most organisms.
7.6.423	Vitamins are important coenzymes or precursors of coenzymes, and are required for enzymes to function properly.
7.6.424	Multivitamin capsules usually contain mixtures of all the vitamins at different percentages.
7.6.425	Enzyme Compartmentalization
7.6.426	In eukaryotic cells, molecules such as enzymes are usually compartmentalized into different organelles.
7.6.427	This allows for yet another level of regulation of enzyme activity.
7.6.428	Enzymes required only for certain cellular processes can be housed separately along with their substrates, allowing for more efficient chemical reactions.
7.6.429	Examples of this sort of enzyme regulation based on location and proximity include the enzymes involved in the latter stages of cellular respiration, which take place exclusively in the mitochondria, and the enzymes involved in the digestion of cellular debris and foreign materials, located within lysosomes.
7.6.430	Feedback Inhibition in Metabolic Pathways Molecules can regulate enzyme function in many ways.
7.6.431	A major question remains, however: What are these molecules and where do they come from?
7.6.432	Some are cofactors and coenzymes, ions, and organic molecules, as you’ve learned.
7.6.433	What other molecules in the cell provide enzymatic regulation, such as allosteric modulation, and competitive and noncompetitive inhibition?
7.6.434	The answer is that a wide variety of molecules can perform these roles.
7.6.435	Some of these molecules include pharmaceutical and non-pharmaceutical drugs, toxins, and poisons from the environment.
7.6.436	Perhaps the most relevant sources of enzyme regulatory molecules, with respect to cellular metabolism, are the products of the cellular metabolic reactions themselves.
7.6.437	In a most efficient and elegant way, cells have evolved to use the products of their own reactions for feedback inhibition of enzyme activity.
7.6.438	Feedback inhibition involves the use of a reaction product to regulate its own further production (Figure 6.21).
7.6.439	The cell responds to the abundance of specific products by slowing down production during anabolic or catabolic reactions.
7.6.440	Such reaction products may inhibit the enzymes that catalyzed their production through the mechanisms described above.
7.6.441	Metabolic pathways are a series of reactions catalyzed by multiple enzymes.
7.6.442	Feedback inhibition, where the end product of the pathway inhibits an upstream step, is an important regulatory mechanism in cells.
7.6.443	The production of both amino acids and nucleotides is controlled through feedback inhibition.
7.6.444	Additionally, ATP is an allosteric regulator of some of the enzymes involved in the catabolic breakdown of sugar, the process that produces ATP.
7.6.445	In this way, when ATP is abundant, the cell can prevent its further production.
7.6.446	Remember that ATP is an unstable molecule that can spontaneously dissociate into ADP.
7.6.447	If too much ATP were present in a cell, much of it would go to waste.
7.6.448	On the other hand, ADP serves as a positive allosteric regulator (an allosteric activator) for some of the same enzymes that are inhibited by ATP.
7.6.449	Thus, when relative levels of ADP are high compared to ATP, the cell is triggered to produce more ATP through the catabolism of sugar.
7.7.0	The electrical energy plant in Figure 7.1 converts energy from one form to another form that can be more easily used.
7.7.1	This type of generating plant starts with underground thermal energy (heat) and transforms it into electrical energy that will be transported to homes and factories.
7.7.2	Like a generating plant, plants and animals also must take in energy from the environment and convert it into a form that their cells can use.
7.7.3	Energy enters an organism’s body in one form and is converted into another form that can fuel the organism’s life functions.
7.7.4	In the process of photosynthesis, plants and other photosynthetic producers take in energy in the form of light (solar energy) and convert it into chemical energy, glucose, which stores this energy in its chemical bonds.
7.7.5	Then, a series of metabolic pathways, collectively called cellular respiration, extracts the energy from the bonds in glucose and converts it into a form that all living things can use—both producers, such as plants, and consumers, such as animals.
7.7.6	Energy production within a cell involves many coordinated chemical pathways.
7.7.7	Most of these pathways are combinations of oxidation and reduction reactions.
7.7.8	Oxidation and reduction occur in tandem.
7.7.9	An oxidation reaction strips an electron from an atom in a compound, and the addition of this electron to another compound is a reduction reaction.
7.7.10	Because oxidation and reduction usually occur together, these pairs of reactions are called oxidation reduction reactions, or redox reactions.
7.7.11	Electrons and Energy
7.7.12	The removal of an electron from a molecule, oxidizing it, results in a decrease in potential energy in the oxidized compound.
7.7.13	The electron (sometimes as part of a hydrogen atom), does not remain unbonded, however, in the cytoplasm of a cell.
7.7.14	Rather, the electron is shifted to a second compound, reducing the second compound.
7.7.15	The shift of an electron from one compound to another removes some potential energy from the first compound (the oxidized compound) and increases the potential energy of the second compound (the reduced compound).
7.7.16	The transfer of electrons between molecules is important because most of the energy stored in atoms and used to fuel cell functions is in the form of high-energy electrons.
7.7.17	The transfer of energy in the form of electrons allows the cell to transfer and use energy in an incremental fashion—in small packages rather than in a single, destructive burst.
7.7.18	This chapter focuses on the extraction of energy from food; you will see that as you track the path of the transfers, you are tracking the path of electrons moving through metabolic pathways.
7.7.19	Electron Carriers
7.7.20	In living systems, a small class of compounds functions as electron shuttles: They bind and carry high-energy electrons between compounds in pathways.
7.7.21	The principal electron carriers we will consider are derived from the B vitamin group and are derivatives of nucleotides.
7.7.22	These compounds can be easily reduced (that is, they accept electrons) or oxidized (they lose electrons).
7.7.23	Nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide (NAD)
7.7.24	(Figure 7.2) is derived from vitamin B3, niacin.
7.7.25	NAD+ is the oxidized form of the molecule; NADH is the reduced form of the molecule after it has accepted two electrons and a proton (which together are the equivalent of a hydrogen atom with an extra electron).
7.7.26	NAD+ can accept electrons from an organic molecule according to the general equation: RH Reducing agent + NAD+
7.7.27	Oxidizing agent →
7.7.28	NADH Reduced + R Oxidized
7.7.29	When electrons are added to a compound, they are reduced.
7.7.30	A compound that reduces another is called a reducing agent.
7.7.31	In the above equation, RH is a reducing agent, and NAD+ is reduced to NADH.
7.7.32	When electrons are removed from compound, it oxidized.
7.7.33	A compound that oxidizes another is called an oxidizing agent.
7.7.34	In the above equation, NAD+ is an oxidizing agent, and RH is oxidized to R. Similarly, flavin adenine dinucleotide (FAD+) is derived from vitamin B2, also called riboflavin.
7.7.35	Its reduced form is FADH2.
7.7.36	A second variation of NAD, NADP, contains an extra phosphate group.
7.7.37	Both NAD+ and FAD+ are extensively used in energy extraction from sugars, and NADP plays an important role in anabolic reactions and photosynthesis.
7.7.38	The oxidized form of the electron carrier (NAD+) is shown on the left and the reduced form (NADH) is shown on the right.
7.7.39	The nitrogenous base in NADH has one more hydrogen ion and two more electrons than in NAD+.
7.7.40	ATP in Living Systems
7.7.41	A living cell cannot store significant amounts of free energy.
7.7.42	Excess free energy would result in an increase of heat in the cell, which would result in excessive thermal motion that could damage and then destroy the cell.
7.7.43	Rather, a cell must be able to handle that energy in a way that enables the cell to store energy safely and release it for use only as needed.
7.7.44	Living cells accomplish this by using the compound adenosine triphosphate (ATP).
7.7.45	ATP is often called the “energy currency” of the cell, and, like currency, this versatile compound can be used to fill any energy need of the cell.
7.7.46	How?
7.7.47	It functions similarly to a rechargeable battery.
7.7.48	When ATP is broken down, usually by the removal of its terminal phosphate group, energy is released.
7.7.49	The energy is used to do work by the cell, usually by the released phosphate binding to another molecule, activating it.
7.7.50	For example, in the mechanical work of muscle contraction, ATP supplies the energy to move the contractile muscle proteins.
7.7.51	Recall the active transport work of the sodium-potassium pump in cell membranes.
7.7.52	ATP alters the structure of the integral protein that functions as the pump, changing its affinity for sodium and potassium.
7.7.53	In this way, the cell performs work, pumping ions against their electrochemical gradients.
7.7.54	ATP Structure and Function
7.7.55	At the heart of ATP is a molecule of adenosine monophosphate (AMP), which is composed of an adenine molecule bonded to a ribose molecule and to a single phosphate group (Figure 7.3).
7.7.56	Ribose is a five-carbon sugar found in RNA, and AMP is one of the nucleotides in RNA.
7.7.57	The addition of a second phosphate group to this core molecule results in the formation of adenosine diphosphate (ADP); the addition of a third phosphate group forms adenosine triphosphate (ATP).
7.7.58	ATP (adenosine triphosphate) has three phosphate groups that can be removed by hydrolysis to form ADP (adenosine diphosphate) or AMP
7.7.59	(adenosine monophosphate).The negative charges on the phosphate group naturally repel each other, requiring energy to bond them together and releasing energy when these bonds are broken.
7.7.60	The addition of a phosphate group to a molecule requires energy.
7.7.61	Phosphate groups are negatively charged and thus repel one another when they are arranged in series, as they are in ADP and ATP.
7.7.62	This repulsion makes the ADP and ATP molecules inherently unstable.
7.7.63	The release of one or two phosphate groups from ATP, a process called dephosphorylation, releases energy.
7.7.64	Energy from ATP Hydrolysis is the process of breaking complex macromolecules apart.
7.7.65	During hydrolysis, water is split, or lysed, and the resulting hydrogen atom (H+) and a hydroxyl group (OH-) are added to the larger molecule.
7.7.66	The hydrolysis of ATP produces ADP, together with an inorganic phosphate ion (Pi), and the release of free energy.
7.7.67	To carry out life processes, ATP is continuously broken down into ADP, and like a rechargeable battery, ADP is continuously regenerated into ATP by the reattachment of a third phosphate group.
7.7.68	Water, which was broken down into its hydrogen atom and hydroxyl group during ATP hydrolysis, is regenerated when a third phosphate is added to the ADP molecule, reforming ATP.
7.7.69	Obviously, energy must be infused into the system to regenerate ATP.
7.7.70	Where does this energy come from?
7.7.71	In nearly every living thing on earth, the energy comes from the metabolism of glucose.
7.7.72	In this way, ATP is a direct link between the limited set of exergonic pathways of glucose catabolism and the multitude of endergonic pathways that power living cells.
7.7.73	Phosphorylation Recall that, in some chemical reactions, enzymes may bind to several substrates that react with each other on the enzyme, forming an intermediate complex.
7.7.74	An intermediate complex is a temporary structure, and it allows one of the substrates (such as ATP) and reactants to more readily react with each other; in reactions involving ATP, ATP is one of the substrates and ADP is a product.
7.7.75	During an endergonic chemical reaction, ATP forms an intermediate complex with the substrate and enzyme in the reaction.
7.7.76	This intermediate complex allows the ATP to transfer its third phosphate group, with its energy, to the substrate, a process called phosphorylation.
7.7.77	Phosphorylation refers to the addition of the phosphate (~P).
7.7.78	This is illustrated by the following generic reaction:
7.7.79	A + enzyme + ATP →
7.7.80	⎡ ⎣A − enzyme − ∼ P⎤⎦
7.7.81	→ B + enzyme + ADP + phosphate ion
7.7.82	When the intermediate complex breaks apart, the energy is used to modify the substrate and convert it into a product of the reaction.
7.7.83	The ADP molecule and a free phosphate ion are released into the medium and are available for recycling through cell metabolism.
7.7.84	Substrate Phosphorylation ATP is generated through two mechanisms during the breakdown of glucose.
7.7.85	A few ATP molecules are generated (that is, regenerated from ADP) as a direct result of the chemical reactions that occur in the catabolic pathways.
7.7.86	A phosphate group is removed from an intermediate reactant in the pathway, and the free energy of the reaction is used to add the third phosphate to an available ADP molecule, producing ATP (Figure 7.4).
7.7.87	This very direct method of phosphorylation is called substrate-level phosphorylation.
7.7.88	In phosphorylation reactions, the gamma phosphate of ATP is attached to a protein.
7.7.89	Oxidative Phosphorylation Most of the ATP generated during glucose catabolism, however, is derived from a much more complex process, chemiosmosis, which takes place in mitochondria (Figure 7.5) within a eukaryotic cell or the plasma membrane of a prokaryotic cell.
7.7.90	Chemiosmosis, a process of ATP production in cellular metabolism, is used to generate 90 percent of the ATP made during glucose catabolism and is also the method used in the light reactions of photosynthesis to harness the energy of sunlight.
7.7.91	The production of ATP using the process of chemiosmosis is called oxidative phosphorylation because of the involvement of oxygen in the process.
7.7.92	In eukaryotes, oxidative phosphorylation takes place in mitochondria.
7.7.93	In prokaryotes, this process takes place in the plasma membrane.
7.7.94	You have read that nearly all of the energy used by living cells comes to them in the bonds of the sugar, glucose.
7.7.95	Glycolysis is the first step in the breakdown of glucose to extract energy for cellular metabolism.
7.7.96	Nearly all living organisms carry out glycolysis as part of their metabolism.
7.7.97	The process does not use oxygen and is therefore anaerobic.
7.7.98	Glycolysis takes place in the cytoplasm of both prokaryotic and eukaryotic cells.
7.7.99	Glucose enters heterotrophic cells in two ways.
7.7.100	One method is through secondary active transport in which the transport takes place against the glucose concentration gradient.
7.7.101	The other mechanism uses a group of integral proteins called GLUT proteins, also known as glucose transporter proteins.
7.7.102	These transporters assist in the facilitated diffusion of glucose.
7.7.103	Glycolysis begins with the six carbon ring-shaped structure of a single glucose molecule and ends with two molecules of a three-carbon sugar called pyruvate.
7.7.104	Glycolysis consists of two distinct phases.
7.7.105	The first part of the glycolysis pathway traps the glucose molecule in the cell and uses energy to modify it so that the six-carbon sugar molecule can be split evenly into the two three-carbon molecules.
7.7.106	The second part of glycolysis extracts energy from the molecules and stores it in the form of ATP and NADH, the reduced form of NAD.
7.7.107	First Half of Glycolysis (Energy-Requiring Steps)
7.7.108	Step 1.
7.7.109	The first step in glycolysis (Figure 7.6) is catalyzed by hexokinase, an enzyme with broad specificity that catalyzes the phosphorylation of six-carbon sugars.
7.7.110	Hexokinase phosphorylates glucose using ATP as the source of the phosphate, producing glucose-6-phosphate, a more reactive form of glucose.
7.7.111	This reaction prevents the phosphorylated glucose molecule from continuing to interact with the GLUT proteins, and it can no longer leave the cell because the negatively charged phosphate will not allow it to cross the hydrophobic interior of the plasma membrane.
7.7.112	Step 2.
7.7.113	In the second step of glycolysis, an isomerase converts glucose-6-phosphate into one of its isomers, fructose-6-phosphate.
7.7.114	An isomerase is an enzyme that catalyzes the conversion of a molecule into one of its isomers.
7.7.115	(This change from phosphoglucose to phosphofructose allows the eventual split of the sugar into two three-carbon molecules.).
7.7.116	Step 3.
7.7.117	The third step is the phosphorylation of fructose-6-phosphate, catalyzed by the enzyme phosphofructokinase.
7.7.118	A second ATP molecule donates a high-energy phosphate to fructose-6-phosphate, producing fructose-1,6-bisphosphate.
7.7.119	In this pathway, phosphofructokinase is a rate-limiting enzyme.
7.7.120	It is active when the concentration of ADP is high; it is less active when ADP levels are low and the concentration of ATP is high.
7.7.121	Thus, if there is “sufficient” ATP in the system, the pathway slows down.
7.7.122	This is a type of end product inhibition, since ATP is the end product of glucose catabolism.
7.7.123	Step 4.
7.7.124	The newly added high-energy phosphates further destabilize fructose-1,6-bisphosphate.
7.7.125	The fourth step in glycolysis employs an enzyme, aldolase, to cleave 1,6-bisphosphate into two three-carbon isomers: dihydroxyacetone-phosphate and glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate.
7.7.126	Step 5.
7.7.127	In the fifth step, an isomerase transforms the dihydroxyacetone-phosphate into its isomer, glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate.
7.7.128	Thus, the pathway will continue with two molecules of a single isomer.
7.7.129	At this point in the pathway, there is a net investment of energy from two ATP molecules in the breakdown of one glucose molecule.
7.7.130	The first half of glycolysis uses two ATP molecules in the phosphorylation of glucose, which is then split into two three-carbon molecules.
7.7.131	Second Half of Glycolysis (Energy-Releasing Steps)
7.7.132	So far, glycolysis has cost the cell two ATP molecules and produced two small, three-carbon sugar molecules.
7.7.133	Both of these molecules will proceed through the second half of the pathway, and sufficient energy will be extracted to pay back the two ATP molecules used as an initial investment and produce a profit for the cell of two additional ATP molecules and two even higher-energy NADH molecules.
7.7.134	Step 6.
7.7.135	The sixth step in glycolysis (Figure 7.7) oxidizes the sugar (glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate), extracting high-energy electrons, which are picked up by the electron carrier NAD+, producing NADH.
7.7.136	The sugar is then phosphorylated by the addition of a second phosphate group, producing 1,3-bisphosphoglycerate.
7.7.137	Note that the second phosphate group does not require another ATP molecule.
7.7.138	The second half of glycolysis involves phosphorylation without ATP investment (step 6) and produces two NADH and four ATP molecules per glucose.
7.7.139	Here again is a potential limiting factor for this pathway.
7.7.140	The continuation of the reaction depends upon the availability of the oxidized form of the electron carrier, NAD+.
7.7.141	Thus, NADH must be continuously oxidized back into NAD+ in order to keep this step going.
7.7.142	If NAD+ is not available, the second half of glycolysis slows down or stops.
7.7.143	If oxygen is available in the system, the NADH will be oxidized readily, though indirectly, and the high-energy electrons from the hydrogen released in this process will be used to produce ATP.
7.7.144	In an environment without oxygen, an alternate pathway (fermentation) can provide the oxidation of NADH to NAD+.
7.7.145	Step 7.
7.7.146	In the seventh step, catalyzed by phosphoglycerate kinase (an enzyme named for the reverse reaction), 1,3-bisphosphoglycerate donates a high-energy phosphate to ADP, forming one molecule of ATP.
7.7.147	(This is an example of substrate-level phosphorylation.)
7.7.148	A carbonyl group on the 1,3-bisphosphoglycerate is oxidized to a carboxyl group, and 3-phosphoglycerate is formed.
7.7.149	Step 8.
7.7.150	In the eighth step, the remaining phosphate group in 3-phosphoglycerate moves from the third carbon to the second carbon, producing 2-phosphoglycerate (an isomer of 3-phosphoglycerate).
7.7.151	The enzyme catalyzing this step is a mutase (isomerase).
7.7.152	Step 9.
7.7.153	Enolase catalyzes the ninth step.
7.7.154	This enzyme causes 2-phosphoglycerate to lose water from its structure; this is a dehydration reaction, resulting in the formation of a double bond that increases the potential energy in the remaining phosphate bond and produces phosphoenolpyruvate (PEP).
7.7.155	Step 10.
7.7.156	The last step in glycolysis is catalyzed by the enzyme pyruvate kinase (the enzyme in this case is named for the reverse reaction of pyruvate’s conversion into PEP) and results in the production of a second ATP molecule by substratelevel phosphorylation and the compound pyruvic acid (or its salt form, pyruvate).
7.7.157	Many enzymes in enzymatic pathways are named for the reverse reactions, since the enzyme can catalyze both forward and reverse reactions (these may have been described initially by the reverse reaction that takes place in vitro, under non-physiological conditions).
7.7.158	Outcomes of Glycolysis Glycolysis starts with glucose and ends with two pyruvate molecules, a total of four ATP molecules and two molecules of NADH.
7.7.159	Two ATP molecules were used in the first half of the pathway to prepare the six-carbon ring for cleavage, so the cell has a net gain of two ATP molecules and 2 NADH molecules for its use.
7.7.160	If the cell cannot catabolize the pyruvate molecules further, it will harvest only two ATP molecules from one molecule of glucose.
7.7.161	Mature mammalian red blood cells are not capable of aerobic respiration—the process in which organisms convert energy in the presence of oxygen—and glycolysis is their sole source of ATP.
7.7.162	If glycolysis is interrupted, these cells lose their ability to maintain their sodium-potassium pumps, and eventually, they die.
7.7.163	The last step in glycolysis will not occur if pyruvate kinase, the enzyme that catalyzes the formation of pyruvate, is not available in sufficient quantities.
7.7.164	In this situation, the entire glycolysis pathway will proceed, but only two ATP molecules will be made in the second half.
7.7.165	Thus, pyruvate kinase is a rate-limiting enzyme for glycolysis.
7.7.166	If oxygen is available, aerobic respiration will go forward.
7.7.167	In eukaryotic cells, the pyruvate molecules produced at the end of glycolysis are transported into mitochondria, which are the sites of cellular respiration.
7.7.168	There, pyruvate will be transformed into an acetyl group that will be picked up and activated by a carrier compound called coenzyme A (CoA).
7.7.169	The resulting compound is called acetyl CoA. CoA is made from vitamin B5, pantothenic acid.
7.7.170	Acetyl CoA can be used in a variety of ways by the cell, but its major function is to deliver the acetyl group derived from pyruvate to the next stage of the pathway in glucose catabolism.
7.7.171	Breakdown of Pyruvate
7.7.172	In order for pyruvate, the product of glycolysis, to enter the next pathway, it must undergo several changes.
7.7.173	The conversion is a three-step process (Figure 7.8).
7.7.174	Step 1.
7.7.175	A carboxyl group is removed from pyruvate, releasing a molecule of carbon dioxide into the surrounding medium.
7.7.176	The result of this step is a two-carbon hydroxyethyl group bound to the enzyme (pyruvate dehydrogenase).
7.7.177	This is the first of the six carbons from the original glucose molecule to be removed.
7.7.178	This step proceeds twice (remember: there are two pyruvate molecules produced at the end of glycolsis) for every molecule of glucose metabolized; thus, two of the six carbons will have been removed at the end of both steps.
7.7.179	Step 2.
7.7.180	The hydroxyethyl group is oxidized to an acetyl group, and the electrons are picked up by NAD+, forming NADH.
7.7.181	The high-energy electrons from NADH will be used later to generate ATP.
7.7.182	Step 3.
7.7.183	The enzyme-bound acetyl group is transferred to CoA, producing a molecule of acetyl CoA. Upon entering the mitochondrial matrix, a multi-enzyme complex converts pyruvate into acetyl CoA.
7.7.184	In the process, carbon dioxide is released and one molecule of NADH is formed.
7.7.185	Note that during the second stage of glucose metabolism, whenever a carbon atom is removed, it is bound to two oxygen atoms, producing carbon dioxide, one of the major end products of cellular respiration.
7.7.186	Acetyl CoA to CO2
7.7.187	In the presence of oxygen, acetyl CoA delivers its acetyl group to a four-carbon molecule, oxaloacetate, to form citrate, a six-carbon molecule with three carboxyl groups; this pathway will harvest the remainder of the extractable energy from what began as a glucose molecule.
7.7.188	This single pathway is called by different names: the citric acid cycle (for the first intermediate formed—citric acid, or citrate—when acetate joins to the oxaloacetate), the TCA cycle (since citric acid or citrate and isocitrate are tricarboxylic acids), and the Krebs cycle, after Hans Krebs, who first identified the steps in the pathway in the 1930s in pigeon flight muscles.
7.7.189	Citric Acid Cycle Like the conversion of pyruvate to acetyl CoA, the citric acid cycle takes place in the matrix of mitochondria.
7.7.190	Almost all of the enzymes of the citric acid cycle are soluble, with the single exception of the enzyme succinate dehydrogenase, which is embedded in the inner membrane of the mitochondrion.
7.7.191	Unlike glycolysis, the citric acid cycle is a closed loop: The last part of the pathway regenerates the compound used in the first step.
7.7.192	The eight steps of the cycle are a series of redox, dehydration, hydration, and decarboxylation reactions that produce two carbon dioxide molecules, one GTP/ATP, and reduced forms of NADH and FADH2
7.7.193	(Figure 7.9).
7.7.194	This is considered an aerobic pathway because the NADH and FADH2 produced must transfer their electrons to the next pathway in the system, which will use oxygen.
7.7.195	If this transfer does not occur, the oxidation steps of the citric acid cycle also do not occur.
7.7.196	Note that the citric acid cycle produces very little ATP directly and does not directly consume oxygen.
7.7.197	In the citric acid cycle, the acetyl group from acetyl CoA is attached to a four-carbon oxaloacetate molecule to form a six-carbon citrate molecule.
7.7.198	Through a series of steps, citrate is oxidized, releasing two carbon dioxide molecules for each acetyl group fed into the cycle.
7.7.199	In the process, three NAD+ molecules are reduced to NADH, one FAD molecule is reduced to FADH2, and one ATP or GTP (depending on the cell type) is produced (by substrate-level phosphorylation).
7.7.200	Because the final product of the citric acid cycle is also the first reactant, the cycle runs continuously in the presence of sufficient reactants.
7.7.201	(credit: modification of work by “Yikrazuul”/Wikimedia Commons) Steps in the Citric Acid Cycle Step 1.
7.7.202	Prior to the start of the first step, a transitional phase occurs during which pyruvic acid is converted to acetyl CoA.
7.7.203	Then, the first step of the cycle begins: This is a condensation step, combining the two-carbon acetyl group with a fourcarbon oxaloacetate molecule to form a six-carbon molecule of citrate.
7.7.204	CoA is bound to a sulfhydryl group (-SH) and diffuses away to eventually combine with another acetyl group.
7.7.205	This step is irreversible because it is highly exergonic.
7.7.206	The rate of this reaction is controlled by negative feedback and the amount of ATP available.
7.7.207	If ATP levels increase, the rate of this reaction decreases.
7.7.208	If ATP is in short supply, the rate increases.
7.7.209	Step 2.
7.7.210	In step two, citrate loses one water molecule and gains another as citrate is converted into its isomer, isocitrate.
7.7.211	Step 3.
7.7.212	In step three, isocitrate is oxidized, producing a five-carbon molecule, α-ketoglutarate, together with a molecule of CO2 and two electrons, which reduce NAD+ to NADH.
7.7.213	This step is also regulated by negative feedback from ATP and NADH, and a positive effect of ADP.
7.7.214	Steps 3 and 4.
7.7.215	Steps three and four are both oxidation and decarboxylation steps, which release electrons that reduce NAD+ to NADH and release carboxyl groups that form CO2 molecules.
7.7.216	α-Ketoglutarate is the product of step three, and a succinyl group is the product of step four.
7.7.217	CoA binds the succinyl group to form succinyl CoA.
7.7.218	The enzyme that catalyzes step four is regulated by feedback inhibition of ATP, succinyl CoA, and NADH.
7.7.219	Step 5.
7.7.220	In step five, a phosphate group is substituted for coenzyme A, and a high-energy bond is formed.
7.7.221	This energy is used in substrate-level phosphorylation (during the conversion of the succinyl group to succinate) to form either guanine triphosphate (GTP) or ATP.
7.7.222	There are two forms of the enzyme, called isoenzymes, for this step, depending upon the type of animal tissue in which they are found.
7.7.223	One form is found in tissues that use large amounts of ATP, such as heart and skeletal muscle.
7.7.224	This form produces ATP.
7.7.225	The second form of the enzyme is found in tissues that have a high number of anabolic pathways, such as liver.
7.7.226	This form produces GTP.
7.7.227	GTP is energetically equivalent to ATP; however, its use is more restricted.
7.7.228	In particular, protein synthesis primarily uses GTP.
7.7.229	Step 6.
7.7.230	Step six is a dehydration process that converts succinate into fumarate.
7.7.231	Two hydrogen atoms are transferred to FAD, producing FADH2.
7.7.232	The energy contained in the electrons of these atoms is insufficient to reduce NAD+ but adequate to reduce FAD.
7.7.233	Unlike NADH, this carrier remains attached to the enzyme and transfers the electrons to the electron transport chain directly.
7.7.234	This process is made possible by the localization of the enzyme catalyzing this step inside the inner membrane of the mitochondrion.
7.7.235	Step 7.
7.7.236	Water is added to fumarate during step seven, and malate is produced.
7.7.237	The last step in the citric acid cycle regenerates oxaloacetate by oxidizing malate.
7.7.238	Another molecule of NADH is produced in the process.
7.7.239	Products of the Citric Acid Cycle
7.7.240	Two carbon atoms come into the citric acid cycle from each acetyl group, representing four out of the six carbons of one glucose molecule.
7.7.241	Two carbon dioxide molecules are released on each turn of the cycle; however, these do not necessarily contain the most recently added carbon atoms.
7.7.242	The two acetyl carbon atoms will eventually be released on later turns of the cycle; thus, all six carbon atoms from the original glucose molecule are eventually incorporated into carbon dioxide.
7.7.243	Each turn of the cycle forms three NADH molecules and one FADH2 molecule.
7.7.244	These carriers will connect with the last portion of aerobic respiration to produce ATP molecules.
7.7.245	One GTP or ATP is also made in each cycle.
7.7.246	Several of the intermediate compounds in the citric acid cycle can be used in synthesizing non-essential amino acids; therefore, the cycle is amphibolic (both catabolic and anabolic).
7.7.247	You have just read about two pathways in glucose catabolism—glycolysis and the citric acid cycle—that generate ATP.
7.7.248	Most of the ATP generated during the aerobic catabolism of glucose, however, is not generated directly from these pathways.
7.7.249	Rather, it is derived from a process that begins with moving electrons through a series of electron transporters that undergo redox reactions.
7.7.250	This causes hydrogen ions to accumulate within the matrix space.
7.7.251	Therefore, a concentration gradient forms in which hydrogen ions diffuse out of the matrix space by passing through ATP synthase.
7.7.252	The current of hydrogen ions powers the catalytic action of ATP synthase, which phosphorylates ADP, producing ATP.
7.7.253	Electron Transport Chain
7.7.254	The electron transport chain (Figure 7.10) is the last component of aerobic respiration and is the only part of glucose metabolism that uses atmospheric oxygen.
7.7.255	Oxygen continuously diffuses into plants; in animals, it enters the body through the respiratory system.
7.7.256	Electron transport is a series of redox reactions that resemble a relay race or bucket brigade in that electrons are passed rapidly from one component to the next, to the endpoint of the chain where the electrons reduce molecular oxygen, producing water.
7.7.257	There are four complexes composed of proteins, labeled I through IV in Figure 7.10, and the aggregation of these four complexes, together with associated mobile, accessory electron carriers, is called the electron transport chain.
7.7.258	The electron transport chain is present in multiple copies in the inner mitochondrial membrane of eukaryotes and the plasma membrane of prokaryotes.
7.7.259	The electron transport chain is a series of electron transporters embedded in the inner mitochondrial membrane that shuttles electrons from NADH and FADH2 to molecular oxygen.
7.7.260	In the process, protons are pumped from the mitochondrial matrix to the intermembrane space, and oxygen is reduced to form water.
7.7.261	Complex I
7.7.262	To start, two electrons are carried to the first complex aboard NADH.
7.7.263	This complex, labeled I, is composed of flavin mononucleotide (FMN) and an iron-sulfur (Fe-S)-containing protein.
7.7.264	FMN, which is derived from vitamin B2, also called riboflavin, is one of several prosthetic groups or co-factors in the electron transport chain.
7.7.265	A prosthetic group is a nonprotein molecule required for the activity of a protein.
7.7.266	Prosthetic groups are organic or inorganic, non-peptide molecules bound to a protein that facilitate its function; prosthetic groups include co-enzymes, which are the prosthetic groups of enzymes.
7.7.267	The enzyme in complex
7.7.268	I is NADH dehydrogenase and is a very large protein, containing 45 amino acid chains.
7.7.269	Complex I can pump four hydrogen ions across the membrane from the matrix into the intermembrane space, and it is in this way that the hydrogen ion gradient is established and maintained between the two compartments separated by the inner mitochondrial membrane.
7.7.270	Q and Complex II Complex II directly receives FADH2, which does not pass through
7.7.271	complex I. The compound connecting the first and second complexes to the third is ubiquinone (Q).
7.7.272	The Q molecule is lipid soluble and freely moves through the hydrophobic core of the membrane.
7.7.273	Once it is reduced, (QH2), ubiquinone delivers its electrons to the next complex in the electron transport chain.
7.7.274	Q receives the electrons derived from NADH from complex I and the electrons derived from FADH2 from complex II, including succinate dehydrogenase.
7.7.275	This enzyme and FADH2 form a small complex that delivers electrons directly to the electron transport chain, bypassing the first complex.
7.7.276	Since these electrons bypass and thus do not energize the proton pump in the first complex, fewer ATP molecules are made from the FADH2 electrons.
7.7.277	The number of ATP molecules ultimately obtained is directly proportional to the number of protons pumped across the inner mitochondrial membrane.
7.7.278	Complex III
7.7.279	The third complex is composed of cytochrome b, another Fe-S protein, Rieske center (2Fe-2S center), and cytochrome c proteins; this complex is also called cytochrome oxidoreductase.
7.7.280	Cytochrome proteins have a prosthetic group of heme.
7.7.281	The heme molecule is similar to the heme in hemoglobin, but it carries electrons, not oxygen.
7.7.282	As a result, the iron ion at its core is reduced and oxidized as it passes the electrons, fluctuating between different oxidation states: Fe++ (reduced) and Fe+++ (oxidized).
7.7.283	The heme molecules in the cytochromes have slightly different characteristics due to the effects of the different proteins binding them, giving slightly different characteristics to each complex.
7.7.284	Complex III pumps protons through the membrane and passes its electrons to cytochrome c for transport to the fourth complex of proteins and enzymes (cytochrome c is the acceptor of electrons from Q; however, whereas Q carries pairs of electrons, cytochrome c can accept only one at a time).
7.7.285	Complex IV
7.7.286	The fourth complex is composed of cytochrome proteins c, a, and a3.
7.7.287	This complex contains two heme groups (one in each of the two cytochromes, a, and a3) and three copper ions (a pair of CuA and one CuB in cytochrome a3).
7.7.288	The cytochromes hold an oxygen molecule very tightly between the iron and copper ions until the oxygen is completely reduced.
7.7.289	The reduced oxygen then picks up two hydrogen ions from the surrounding medium to make water (H2O).
7.7.290	The removal of the hydrogen ions from the system contributes to the ion gradient used in the process of chemiosmosis.
7.7.291	Chemiosmosis
7.7.292	In chemiosmosis, the free energy from the series of redox reactions just described is used to pump hydrogen ions (protons) across the membrane.
7.7.293	The uneven distribution of H+ ions across the membrane establishes both concentration and electrical gradients (thus, an electrochemical gradient), owing to the hydrogen ions’ positive charge and their aggregation on one side of the membrane.
7.7.294	If the membrane were open to diffusion by the hydrogen ions, the ions would tend to diffuse back across into the matrix, driven by their electrochemical gradient.
7.7.295	Recall that many ions cannot diffuse through the nonpolar regions of phospholipid membranes without the aid of ion channels.
7.7.296	Similarly, hydrogen ions in the matrix space can only pass through the inner mitochondrial membrane through an integral membrane protein called ATP synthase (Figure 7.11).
7.7.297	This complex protein acts as a tiny generator, turned by the force of the hydrogen ions diffusing through it, down their electrochemical gradient.
7.7.298	The turning of parts of this molecular machine facilitates the addition of a phosphate to ADP, forming ATP, using the potential energy of the hydrogen ion gradient.
7.7.299	Chemiosmosis (Figure 7.12) is used to generate 90 percent of the ATP made during aerobic glucose catabolism; it is also the method used in the light reactions of photosynthesis to harness the energy of sunlight in the process of photophosphorylation.
7.7.300	Recall that the production of ATP using the process of chemiosmosis in mitochondria is called oxidative phosphorylation.
7.7.301	The overall result of these reactions is the production of ATP from the energy of the electrons removed from hydrogen atoms.
7.7.302	These atoms were originally part of a glucose molecule.
7.7.303	At the end of the pathway, the electrons are used to reduce an oxygen molecule to oxygen ions.
7.7.304	The extra electrons on the oxygen attract hydrogen ions (protons) from the surrounding medium, and water is formed.
7.7.305	ATP Yield
7.7.306	The number of ATP molecules generated from the catabolism of glucose varies.
7.7.307	For example, the number of hydrogen ions that the electron transport chain complexes can pump through the membrane varies between species.
7.7.308	Another source of variance stems from the shuttle of electrons across the membranes of the mitochondria.
7.7.309	(The NADH generated from glycolysis cannot easily enter mitochondria.)
7.7.310	Thus, electrons are picked up on the inside of mitochondria by either NAD+ or FAD+.
7.7.311	As you have learned earlier, these FAD+ molecules can transport fewer ions; consequently, fewer ATP molecules are generated when FAD+ acts as a carrier.
7.7.312	NAD+ is used as the electron transporter in the liver and FAD+ acts in the brain.
7.7.313	Another factor that affects the yield of ATP molecules generated from glucose is the fact that intermediate compounds in these pathways are used for other purposes.
7.7.314	Glucose catabolism connects with the pathways that build or break down all other biochemical compounds in cells, and the result is somewhat messier than the ideal situations described thus far.
7.7.315	For example, sugars other than glucose are fed into the glycolytic pathway for energy extraction.
7.7.316	Moreover, the five-carbon sugars that form nucleic acids are made from intermediates in glycolysis.
7.7.317	Certain nonessential amino acids can be made from intermediates of both glycolysis and the citric acid cycle.
7.7.318	Lipids, such as cholesterol and triglycerides, are also made from intermediates in these pathways, and both amino acids and triglycerides are broken down for energy through these pathways.
7.7.319	Overall, in living systems, these pathways of glucose catabolism extract about 34 percent of the energy contained in glucose.
7.7.320	In aerobic respiration, the final electron acceptor is an oxygen molecule, O2.
7.7.321	If aerobic respiration occurs, then ATP will be produced using the energy of high-energy electrons carried by NADH or FADH2 to the electron transport chain.
7.7.322	If aerobic respiration does not occur, NADH must be reoxidized to NAD+ for reuse as an electron carrier for the glycolytic pathway to continue.
7.7.323	How is this done?
7.7.324	Some living systems use an organic molecule as the final electron acceptor.
7.7.325	Processes that use an organic molecule to regenerate NAD+ from NADH are collectively referred to as fermentation.
7.7.326	In contrast, some living systems use an inorganic molecule as a final electron acceptor.
7.7.327	Both methods are called anaerobic cellular respiration in which organisms convert energy for their use in the absence of oxygen.
7.7.328	Anaerobic Cellular Respiration Certain prokaryotes, including some species of bacteria and Archaea, use anaerobic respiration.
7.7.329	For example, the group of Archaea called methanogens reduces carbon dioxide to methane to oxidize NADH.
7.7.330	These microorganisms are found in soil and in the digestive tracts of ruminants, such as cows and sheep.
7.7.331	Similarly, sulfate-reducing bacteria and Archaea, most of which are anaerobic ( Figure 7.13), reduce sulfate to hydrogen sulfide to regenerate NAD+ from NADH.
7.7.332	The green color seen in these coastal waters is from an eruption of hydrogen sulfide-producing bacteria.
7.7.333	These anaerobic, sulfate-reducing bacteria release hydrogen sulfide gas as they decompose algae in the water.
7.7.334	The enzyme used in this reaction is lactate dehydrogenase (LDH).
7.7.335	The reaction can proceed in either direction, but the reaction from left to right is inhibited by acidic conditions.
7.7.336	Such lactic acid accumulation was once believed to cause muscle stiffness, fatigue, and soreness, although more recent research disputes this hypothesis.
7.7.337	Once the lactic acid has been removed from the muscle and circulated to the liver, it can be reconverted into pyruvic acid and further catabolized for energy.
7.7.338	Alcohol Fermentation
7.7.339	Another familiar fermentation process is alcohol fermentation ( Figure 7.15) that produces ethanol, an alcohol.
7.7.340	The first chemical reaction of alcohol fermentation is the following (CO2 does not participate in the second reaction):
7.7.341	Pyruvic acid
7.7.342	→ CO2 + acetaldehyde
7.7.343	+ NADH
7.7.344	→ ethanol
7.7.345	+
7.7.346	NAD+ The first reaction is catalyzed by pyruvate decarboxylase, a cytoplasmic enzyme, with a coenzyme of thiamine pyrophosphate (TPP, derived from vitamin B1 and also called thiamine).
7.7.347	A carboxyl group is removed from pyruvic acid, releasing carbon dioxide as a gas.
7.7.348	The loss of carbon dioxide reduces the size of the molecule by one carbon, making acetaldehyde.
7.7.349	The second reaction is catalyzed by alcohol dehydrogenase to oxidize NADH to NAD+ and reduce acetaldehyde to ethanol.
7.7.350	The fermentation of pyruvic acid by yeast produces the ethanol found in alcoholic beverages.
7.7.351	Ethanol tolerance of yeast is variable, ranging from about 5 percent to 21 percent, depending on the yeast strain and environmental conditions.
7.7.352	Fermentation of grape juice into wine produces CO2 as a byproduct.
7.7.353	Fermentation tanks have valves so that the pressure inside the tanks created by the carbon dioxide produced can be released.
7.7.354	Other Types of Fermentation
7.7.355	Other fermentation methods occur in bacteria.
7.7.356	Many prokaryotes are facultatively anaerobic.
7.7.357	This means that they can switch between aerobic respiration and fermentation, depending on the availability of oxygen.
7.7.358	Certain prokaryotes, like Clostridia, are obligate anaerobes.
7.7.359	Obligate anaerobes live and grow in the absence of molecular oxygen.
7.7.360	Oxygen is a poison to these microorganisms and kills them on exposure.
7.7.361	It should be noted that all forms of fermentation, except lactic acid fermentation, produce gas.
7.7.362	The production of particular types of gas is used as an indicator of the fermentation of specific carbohydrates, which plays a role in the laboratory identification of the bacteria.
7.7.363	Various methods of fermentation are used by assorted organisms to ensure an adequate supply of NAD+ for the sixth step in glycolysis.
7.7.364	Without these pathways, that step would not occur and no ATP would be harvested from the breakdown of glucose.
7.7.365	You have learned about the catabolism of glucose, which provides energy to living cells.
7.7.366	But living things consume more than glucose for food.
7.7.367	How does a turkey sandwich end up as ATP in your cells?
7.7.368	This happens because all of the catabolic pathways for carbohydrates, proteins, and lipids eventually connect into glycolysis and the citric acid cycle pathways (see Figure 7.17).
7.7.369	Metabolic pathways should be thought of as porous—that is, substances enter from other pathways, and intermediates leave for other pathways.
7.7.370	These pathways are not closed systems.
7.7.371	Many of the substrates, intermediates, and products in a particular pathway are reactants in other pathways.
7.7.372	Connections of Other Sugars to Glucose Metabolism Glycogen, a polymer of glucose, is an energy storage molecule in animals.
7.7.373	When there is adequate ATP present, excess glucose is shunted into glycogen for storage.
7.7.374	Glycogen is made and stored in both liver and muscle.
7.7.375	The glycogen will be hydrolyzed into glucose monomers (G-1-P) if blood sugar levels drop.
7.7.376	The presence of glycogen as a source of glucose allows ATP to be produced for a longer period of time during exercise.
7.7.377	Glycogen is broken down into G-1-P and converted into G-6-P in both muscle and liver cells, and this product enters the glycolytic pathway.
7.7.378	Sucrose is a disaccharide with a molecule of glucose and a molecule of fructose bonded together with a glycosidic linkage.
7.7.379	Fructose is one of the three dietary monosaccharides, along with glucose and galactose (which is part of the milk sugar, the disaccharide lactose), which are absorbed directly into the bloodstream during digestion.
7.7.380	The catabolism of both fructose and galactose produces the same number of ATP molecules as glucose.
7.7.381	Connections of Proteins to Glucose Metabolism Proteins are hydrolyzed by a variety of enzymes in cells.
7.7.382	Most of the time, the amino acids are recycled into the synthesis of new proteins.
7.7.383	If there are excess amino acids, however, or if the body is in a state of starvation, some amino acids will be shunted into the pathways of glucose catabolism (Figure 7.16).
7.7.384	Each amino acid must have its amino group removed prior to entry into these pathways.
7.7.385	The amino group is converted into ammonia.
7.7.386	In mammals, the liver synthesizes urea from two ammonia molecules and a carbon dioxide molecule.
7.7.387	Thus, urea is the principal waste product in mammals produced from the nitrogen originating in amino acids, and it leaves the body in urine.
7.7.388	The carbon skeletons of certain amino acids (indicated in boxes) derived from proteins can feed into the citric acid cycle.
7.7.389	Connections of Lipid and Glucose Metabolisms
7.7.390	The lipids that are connected to the glucose pathways are cholesterol and triglycerides.
7.7.391	Cholesterol is a lipid that contributes to cell membrane flexibility and is a precursor of steroid hormones.
7.7.392	The synthesis of cholesterol starts with acetyl groups and proceeds in only one direction.
7.7.393	The process cannot be reversed.
7.7.394	Triglycerides are a form of long-term energy storage in animals.
7.7.395	Triglycerides are made of glycerol and three fatty acids.
7.7.396	Animals can make most of the fatty acids they need.
7.7.397	Triglycerides can be both made and broken down through parts of the glucose catabolism pathways.
7.7.398	Glycerol can be phosphorylated to glycerol-3-phosphate, which continues through glycolysis.
7.7.399	Fatty acids are catabolized in a process called beta-oxidation that takes place in the matrix of the mitochondria and converts their fatty acid chains into two carbon units of acetyl groups.
7.7.400	The acetyl groups are picked up by CoA to form acetyl CoA that proceeds into the citric acid cycle.
7.7.401	Glycogen from the liver and muscles, hydrolyzed into glucose-1-phosphate, together with fats and proteins, can feed into the catabolic pathways for carbohydrates.
7.7.402	Cellular respiration must be regulated in order to provide balanced amounts of energy in the form of ATP.
7.7.403	The cell also must generate a number of intermediate compounds that are used in the anabolism and catabolism of macromolecules.
7.7.404	Without controls, metabolic reactions would quickly come to a stand still as the forward and backward reactions reached a state of equilibrium.
7.7.405	Resources would be used inappropriately.
7.7.406	A cell does not need the maximum amount of ATP that it can make all the time: At times, the cell needs to shunt some of the intermediates to pathways for amino acid, protein, glycogen, lipid, and nucleic acid production.
7.7.407	In short, the cell needs to control its metabolism.
7.7.408	Regulatory Mechanisms
7.7.409	A variety of mechanisms is used to control cellular respiration.
7.7.410	Some type of control exists at each stage of glucose metabolism.
7.7.411	Access of glucose to the cell can be regulated using the GLUT proteins that transport glucose (Figure 7.18).
7.7.412	Different forms of the GLUT protein control passage of glucose into the cells of specific tissues.
7.7.413	GLUT4 is a glucose transporter that is stored in vesicles.
7.7.414	A cascade of events that occurs upon insulin binding to a receptor in the plasma membrane causes GLUT4-containing vesicles to fuse with the plasma membrane so that glucose may be transported into the cell.
7.7.415	Some reactions are controlled by having two different enzymes—one each for the two directions of a reversible reaction.
7.7.416	Reactions that are catalyzed by only one enzyme can go to equilibrium, stalling the reaction.
7.7.417	In contrast, if two different enzymes (each specific for a given direction) are necessary for a reversible reaction, the opportunity to control the rate of the reaction increases, and equilibrium is not reached.
7.7.418	A number of enzymes involved in each of the pathways—in particular, the enzyme catalyzing the first committed reaction of the pathway—are controlled by attachment of a molecule to an allosteric site on the protein.
7.7.419	The molecules most commonly used in this capacity are the nucleotides ATP, ADP, AMP, NAD+, and NADH.
7.7.420	These regulators, allosteric effectors, may increase or decrease enzyme activity, depending on the prevailing conditions.
7.7.421	The allosteric effector alters the steric structure of the enzyme, usually affecting the configuration of the active site.
7.7.422	This alteration of the protein’s (the enzyme’s) structure either increases or decreases its affinity for its substrate, with the effect of increasing or decreasing the rate of the reaction.
7.7.423	The attachment signals to the enzyme.
7.7.424	This binding can increase or decrease the enzyme’s activity, providing feedback.
7.7.425	This feedback type of control is effective as long as the chemical affecting it is attached to the enzyme.
7.7.426	Once the overall concentration of the chemical decreases, it will diffuse away from the protein, and the control is relaxed.
7.7.427	Control of Catabolic Pathways Enzymes, proteins, electron carriers, and pumps that play roles in glycolysis, the citric acid cycle, and the electron transport chain tend to catalyze non-reversible reactions.
7.7.428	In other words, if the initial reaction takes place, the pathway is committed to proceeding with the remaining reactions.
7.7.429	Whether a particular enzyme activity is released depends upon the energy needs of the cell (as reflected by the levels of ATP, ADP, and AMP).
7.7.430	Glycolysis
7.7.431	The control of glycolysis begins with the first enzyme in the pathway, hexokinase (Figure 7.19).
7.7.432	This enzyme catalyzes the phosphorylation of glucose, which helps to prepare the compound for cleavage in a later step.
7.7.433	The presence of the negatively charged phosphate in the molecule also prevents the sugar from leaving the cell.
7.7.434	When hexokinase is inhibited, glucose diffuses out of the cell and does not become a substrate for the respiration pathways in that tissue.
7.7.435	The product of the hexokinase reaction is glucose-6-phosphate, which accumulates when a later enzyme, phosphofructokinase, is inhibited.
7.7.436	The glycolysis pathway is primarily regulated at the three key enzymatic steps (1, 2, and 7) as indicated.
7.7.437	Note that the first two steps that are regulated occur early in the pathway and involve hydrolysis of ATP.
7.7.438	Phosphofructokinase is the main enzyme controlled in glycolysis.
7.7.439	High levels of ATP, citrate, or a lower, more acidic pH decrease the enzyme’s activity.
7.7.440	An increase in citrate concentration can occur because of a blockage in the citric acid cycle.
7.7.441	Fermentation, with its production of organic acids like lactic acid, frequently accounts for the increased acidity in a cell; however, the products of fermentation do not typically accumulate in cells.
7.7.442	The last step in glycolysis is catalyzed by pyruvate kinase.
7.7.443	The pyruvate produced can proceed to be catabolized or converted into the amino acid alanine.
7.7.444	If no more energy is needed and alanine is in adequate supply, the enzyme is inhibited.
7.7.445	The enzyme’s activity is increased when fructose-1,6-bisphosphate levels increase.
7.7.446	(Recall that fructose-1,6-bisphosphate is an intermediate in the first half of glycolysis.)
7.7.447	The regulation of pyruvate kinase involves phosphorylation by a kinase (pyruvate kinase kinase), resulting in a less-active enzyme.
7.7.448	Dephosphorylation by a phosphatase reactivates it.
7.7.449	Pyruvate kinase is also regulated by ATP (a negative allosteric effect).
7.7.450	If more energy is needed, more pyruvate will be converted into acetyl CoA through the action of pyruvate dehydrogenase.
7.7.451	If either acetyl groups or NADH accumulate, there is less need for the reaction and the rate decreases.
7.7.452	Pyruvate dehydrogenase is also regulated by phosphorylation: A kinase phosphorylates it to form an inactive enzyme, and a phosphatase reactivates it.
7.7.453	The kinase and the phosphatase are also regulated.
7.7.454	Citric Acid Cycle
7.7.455	The citric acid cycle is controlled through the enzymes that catalyze the reactions that make the first two molecules of NADH (Figure 7.9).
7.7.456	These enzymes are isocitrate dehydrogenase and α-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase.
7.7.457	When adequate ATP and NADH levels are available, the rates of these reactions decrease.
7.7.458	When more ATP is needed, as reflected in rising ADP levels, the rate increases.
7.7.459	α-Ketoglutarate dehydrogenase will also be affected by the levels of succinyl CoA—a subsequent intermediate in the cycle—causing a decrease in activity.
7.7.460	A decrease in the rate of operation of the pathway at this point is not necessarily negative, as the increased levels of the α-ketoglutarate not used by the citric acid cycle can be used by the cell for amino acid (glutamate) synthesis.
7.7.461	Electron Transport Chain Specific enzymes of the electron transport chain are unaffected by feedback inhibition, but the rate of electron transport through the pathway is affected by the levels of ADP and ATP.
7.7.462	Greater ATP consumption by a cell is indicated by a buildup of ADP.
7.7.463	As ATP usage decreases, the concentration of ADP decreases, and now, ATP begins to build up in the cell.
7.7.464	This change is the relative concentration of ADP to ATP triggers the cell to slow down the electron transport chain.
7.8.0	This world map shows Earth’s distribution of photosynthesis as seen via chlorophyll a concentrations.
7.8.1	On land, this is evident via terrestrial plants, and in oceanic zones, via phytoplankton.
7.8.2	The processes in all organisms—from bacteria to humans—require energy.
7.8.3	To get this energy, many organisms access stored energy by eating, that is, by ingesting other organisms.
7.8.4	But where does the stored energy in food originate?
7.8.5	All of this energy can be traced back to photosynthesis.
7.8.6	Photosynthesis is essential to all life on earth; both plants and animals depend on it.
7.8.7	It is the only biological process that can capture energy that originates in outer space (sunlight) and convert it into chemical compounds (carbohydrates) that every organism uses to power its metabolism.
7.8.8	In brief, the energy of sunlight is captured and used to energize electrons, which are then stored in the covalent bonds of sugar molecules.
7.8.9	How long lasting and stable are those covalent bonds?
7.8.10	The energy extracted today by the burning of coal and petroleum products represents sunlight energy captured and stored by photosynthesis almost 200 million years ago.
7.8.11	Plants, algae, and a group of bacteria called cyanobacteria are the only organisms capable of performing photosynthesis (Figure 8.2).
