7.8.12	Because they use light to manufacture their own food, they are called photoautotrophs (literally, “self-feeders using light”).
7.8.13	Other organisms, such as animals, fungi, and most other bacteria, are termed heterotrophs (“other feeders”), because they must rely on the sugars produced by photosynthetic organisms for their energy needs.
7.8.14	A third very interesting group of bacteria synthesize sugars, not by using sunlight’s energy, but by extracting energy from inorganic chemical compounds; hence, they are referred to as chemoautotrophs.
7.8.15	Photoautotrophs including (a) plants, (b) algae, and (c) cyanobacteria synthesize their organic compounds via photosynthesis using sunlight as an energy source.
7.8.16	Cyanobacteria and planktonic algae can grow over enormous areas in water, at times completely covering the surface.
7.8.17	In a (d) deep sea vent, chemoautotrophs, such as these (e) thermophilic bacteria, capture energy from inorganic compounds to produce organic compounds.
7.8.18	The ecosystem surrounding the vents has a diverse array of animals, such as tubeworms, crustaceans, and octopi that derive energy from the bacteria.
7.8.19	The importance of photosynthesis is not just that it can capture sunlight’s energy.
7.8.20	A lizard sunning itself on a cold day can use the sun’s energy to warm up.
7.8.21	Photosynthesis is vital because it evolved as a way to store the energy in solar radiation (the “photo-” part) as high-energy electrons in the carbon-carbon bonds of carbohydrate molecules (the “-synthesis” part).
7.8.22	Those carbohydrates are the energy source that heterotrophs use to power the synthesis of ATP via respiration.
7.8.23	Therefore, photosynthesis powers 99 percent of Earth’s ecosystems.
7.8.24	When a top predator, such as a wolf, preys on a deer (Figure 8.3), the wolf is at the end of an energy path that went from nuclear reactions on the surface of the sun, to light, to photosynthesis, to vegetation, to deer, and finally to wolf.
7.8.25	The energy stored in carbohydrate molecules from photosynthesis passes through the food chain.
7.8.26	The predator that eats these deer receives a portion of the energy that originated in the photosynthetic vegetation that the deer consumed.
7.8.27	(credit: modification of work by Steve VanRiper, U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service)
7.8.28	Main Structures and Summary of Photosynthesis Photosynthesis is a multi-step process that requires sunlight, carbon dioxide (which is low in energy), and water as substrates (Figure 8.4).
7.8.29	After the process is complete, it releases oxygen and produces glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate (GA3P), simple carbohydrate molecules (which are high in energy) that can subsequently be converted into glucose, sucrose, or any of dozens of other sugar molecules.
7.8.30	These sugar molecules contain energy and the energized carbon that all living things need to survive.
7.8.31	Photosynthesis uses solar energy, carbon dioxide, and water to produce energy-storing carbohydrates.
7.8.32	Oxygen is generated as a waste product of photosynthesis.
7.8.33	Photosynthesis uses solar energy, carbon dioxide, and water to produce energy-storing carbohydrates.
7.8.34	Oxygen is generated as a waste product of photosynthesis.
7.8.35	The basic equation for photosynthesis is deceptively simple.
7.8.36	In reality, the process takes place in many steps involving intermediate reactants and products.
7.8.37	Glucose, the primary energy source in cells, is made from two three-carbon GA3Ps.
7.8.38	Although the equation looks simple, the many steps that take place during photosynthesis are actually quite complex.
7.8.39	Before learning the details of how photoautotrophs turn sunlight into food, it is important to become familiar with the structures involved.
7.8.40	In plants, photosynthesis generally takes place in leaves, which consist of several layers of cells.
7.8.41	The process of photosynthesis occurs in a middle layer called the mesophyll.
7.8.42	The gas exchange of carbon dioxide and oxygen occurs through small, regulated openings called stomata (singular: stoma), which also play roles in the regulation of gas exchange and water balance.
7.8.43	The stomata are typically located on the underside of the leaf, which helps to minimize water loss.
7.8.44	Each stoma is flanked by guard cells that regulate the opening and closing of the stomata by swelling or shrinking in response to osmotic changes.
7.8.45	In all autotrophic eukaryotes, photosynthesis takes place inside an organelle called a chloroplast.
7.8.46	For plants, chloroplastcontaining cells exist in the mesophyll.
7.8.47	Chloroplasts have a double membrane envelope (composed of an outer membrane and an inner membrane).
7.8.48	Within the chloroplast are stacked, disc-shaped structures called thylakoids.
7.8.49	Embedded in the thylakoid membrane is chlorophyll, a pigment (molecule that absorbs light) responsible for the initial interaction between light and plant material, and numerous proteins that make up the electron transport chain.
7.8.50	The thylakoid membrane encloses an internal space called the thylakoid lumen.
7.8.51	As shown in Figure 8.6, a stack of thylakoids is called a granum, and the liquid-filled space surrounding the granum is called stroma or “bed
7.8.52	” (not to be confused with stoma or “mouth,” an opening on the leaf epidermis).
7.8.53	The Two Parts of Photosynthesis Photosynthesis takes place in two sequential stages: the light-dependent reactions and the light independent-reactions.
7.8.54	In the light-dependent reactions, energy from sunlight is absorbed by chlorophyll and that energy is converted into stored chemical energy.
7.8.55	In the light-independent reactions, the chemical energy harvested during the light-dependent reactions drive the assembly of sugar molecules from carbon dioxide.
7.8.56	Therefore, although the light-independent reactions do not use light as a reactant, they require the products of the light-dependent reactions to function.
7.8.57	In addition, several enzymes of the light-independent reactions are activated by light.
7.8.58	The light-dependent reactions utilize certain molecules to temporarily store the energy: These are referred to as energy carriers.
7.8.59	The energy carriers that move energy from light-dependent reactions to light-independent reactions can be thought of as “full” because they are rich in energy.
7.8.60	After the energy is released, the “empty” energy carriers return to the light-dependent reaction to obtain more energy.
7.8.61	Figure 8.7 illustrates the components inside the chloroplast where the light-dependent and light-independent reactions take place.
7.8.62	Photosynthesis takes place in two stages: light dependent reactions and the Calvin cycle.
7.8.63	Light-dependent reactions, which take place in the thylakoid membrane, use light energy to make ATP and NADPH.
7.8.64	The Calvin cycle, which takes place in the stroma, uses energy derived from these compounds to make GA3P from CO2.
7.8.65	How can light be used to make food?
7.8.66	When a person turns on a lamp, electrical energy becomes light energy.
7.8.67	Like all other forms of kinetic energy, light can travel, change form, and be harnessed to do work.
7.8.68	In the case of photosynthesis, light energy is converted into chemical energy, which photoautotrophs use to build carbohydrate molecules (Figure 8.9).
7.8.69	However, autotrophs only use a few specific components of sunlight.
7.8.70	What Is Light Energy?
7.8.71	The sun emits an enormous amount of electromagnetic radiation (solar energy).
7.8.72	Humans can see only a fraction of this energy, which portion is therefore referred to as “visible light.
7.8.73	”
7.8.74	The manner in which solar energy travels is described as waves.
7.8.75	Scientists can determine the amount of energy of a wave by measuring its wavelength, the distance between consecutive points of a wave.
7.8.76	A single wave is measured from two consecutive points, such as from crest to crest or from trough to trough.
7.8.77	The wavelength of a single wave is the distance between two consecutive points of similar position (two crests or two troughs) along the wave.
7.8.78	Visible light constitutes only one of many types of electromagnetic radiation emitted from the sun and other stars.
7.8.79	Scientists differentiate the various types of radiant energy from the sun within the electromagnetic spectrum.
7.8.80	The electromagnetic spectrum is the range of all possible frequencies of radiation (Figure 8.11).
7.8.81	The difference between wavelengths relates to the amount of energy carried by them.
7.8.82	The sun emits energy in the form of electromagnetic radiation.
7.8.83	This radiation exists at different wavelengths, each of which has its own characteristic energy.
7.8.84	All electromagnetic radiation, including visible light, is characterized by its wavelength.
7.8.85	Each type of electromagnetic radiation travels at a particular wavelength.
7.8.86	The longer the wavelength (or the more stretched out
7.8.87	it appears in the diagram), the less energy is carried.
7.8.88	Short, tight waves carry the most energy.
7.8.89	This may seem illogical, but think of it in terms of a piece of moving a heavy rope.
7.8.90	It takes little effort by a person to move a rope in long, wide waves.
7.8.91	To make a rope move in short, tight waves, a person would need to apply significantly more energy.
7.8.92	The electromagnetic spectrum (Figure 8.11) shows several types of electromagnetic radiation originating from the sun, including X-rays and ultraviolet (UV) rays.
7.8.93	The higher-energy waves can penetrate tissues and damage cells and DNA, explaining why both X-rays and UV rays can be harmful to living organisms.
7.8.94	Absorption of Light Light energy initiates the process of photosynthesis when pigments absorb the light.
7.8.95	Organic pigments, whether in the human retina or the chloroplast thylakoid, have a narrow range of energy levels that they can absorb.
7.8.96	Energy levels lower than those represented by red light are insufficient to raise an orbital electron to a populatable, excited (quantum) state.
7.8.97	Energy levels higher than those in blue light will physically tear the molecules apart, called bleaching.
7.8.98	So retinal pigments can only “see”
7.8.99	(absorb) 700
7.8.100	nm to 400 nm light, which is therefore called visible light.
7.8.101	For the same reasons, plants pigment molecules absorb only light in the wavelength range of 700 nm to 400 nm; plant physiologists refer to this range for plants as photosynthetically active radiation.
7.8.102	The visible light seen by humans as white light actually exists in a rainbow of colors.
7.8.103	Certain objects, such as a prism or a drop of water, disperse white light to reveal the colors to the human eye.
7.8.104	The visible light portion of the electromagnetic spectrum shows the rainbow of colors, with violet and blue having shorter wavelengths, and therefore higher energy.
7.8.105	At the other end of the spectrum toward red, the wavelengths are longer and have lower energy.
7.8.106	The colors of visible light do not carry the same amount of energy.
7.8.107	Violet has the shortest wavelength and therefore carries the most energy, whereas red has the longest wavelength and carries the least amount of energy.
7.8.108	(credit: modification of work by NASA)
7.8.109	Understanding Pigments Different kinds of pigments exist, and each has evolved to absorb only certain wavelengths (colors) of visible light.
7.8.110	Pigments reflect or transmit the wavelengths they cannot absorb, making them appear in the corresponding color.
7.8.111	Chlorophylls and carotenoids are the two major classes of photosynthetic pigments found in plants and algae; each class has multiple types of pigment molecules.
7.8.112	There are five major chlorophylls: a, b, c and d and a related molecule found in prokaryotes called bacteriochlorophyll.
7.8.113	Chlorophyll a and chlorophyll
7.8.114	b are found in higher plant chloroplasts and will be the focus of the following discussion.
7.8.115	With dozens of different forms, carotenoids are a much larger group of pigments.
7.8.116	The carotenoids found in fruit—such as the red of tomato (lycopene), the yellow of corn seeds (zeaxanthin), or the orange of an orange peel (β-carotene)—are used as advertisements to attract seed dispersers.
7.8.117	In photosynthesis, carotenoids function as photosynthetic pigments that are very efficient molecules for the disposal of excess energy.
7.8.118	When a leaf is exposed to full sun, the light-dependent reactions are required to process an enormous amount of energy; if that energy is not handled properly, it can do significant damage.
7.8.119	Therefore, many carotenoids reside in the thylakoid membrane, absorb excess energy, and safely dissipate that energy as heat.
7.8.120	Each type of pigment can be identified by the specific pattern of wavelengths it absorbs from visible light, which is the absorption spectrum.
7.8.121	The graph in Figure 8.13 shows the absorption spectra for chlorophyll a, chlorophyll b, and a type of carotenoid pigment called β-carotene (which absorbs blue and green light).
7.8.122	Notice how each pigment has a distinct set of peaks and troughs, revealing a highly specific pattern of absorption.
7.8.123	Chlorophyll a absorbs wavelengths from either end of the visible spectrum (blue and red), but not green.
7.8.124	Because green is reflected or transmitted, chlorophyll appears green.
7.8.125	Carotenoids absorb in the short-wavelength blue region, and reflect the longer yellow, red, and orange wavelengths.
7.8.126	Chlorophyll a, (b) chlorophyll b, and (c) β-carotene are hydrophobic organic pigments found in the thylakoid membrane.
7.8.127	Chlorophyll a and b, which are identical except for the part indicated in the red box, are responsible for the green color of leaves.
7.8.128	β-carotene is responsible for the orange color in carrots.
7.8.129	Each pigment has (d) a unique absorbance spectrum.
7.8.130	Many photosynthetic organisms have a mixture of pigments; using them, the organism can absorb energy from a wider range of wavelengths.
7.8.131	Not all photosynthetic organisms have full access to sunlight.
7.8.132	Some organisms grow underwater where light intensity and quality decrease and change with depth.
7.8.133	Other organisms grow in competition for light.
7.8.134	Plants on the rainforest floor must be able to absorb any bit of light that comes through, because the taller trees absorb most of the sunlight and scatter the remaining solar radiation.
7.8.135	Plants that commonly grow in the shade have adapted to low levels of light by changing the relative concentrations of their chlorophyll pigments.
7.8.136	(credit: Jason Hollinger)
7.8.137	When studying a photosynthetic organism, scientists can determine the types of pigments present by generating absorption spectra.
7.8.138	An instrument called a spectrophotometer can differentiate which wavelengths of light a substance can absorb.
7.8.139	Spectrophotometers measure transmitted light and compute from it the absorption.
7.8.140	By extracting pigments from leaves and placing these samples into a spectrophotometer, scientists can identify which wavelengths of light an organism can absorb.
7.8.141	Additional methods for the identification of plant pigments include various types of chromatography that separate the pigments by their relative affinities to solid and mobile phases.
7.8.142	How Light-Dependent Reactions Work
7.8.143	The overall function of light-dependent reactions is to convert solar energy into chemical energy in the form of NADPH and ATP.
7.8.144	This chemical energy supports the light-independent reactions and fuels the assembly of sugar molecules.
7.8.145	The light-dependent reactions are depicted in Figure 8.15.
7.8.146	Protein complexes and pigment molecules work together to produce NADPH and ATP.
7.8.147	A photosystem consists of a light-harvesting complex and a reaction center.
7.8.148	Pigments in the lightharvesting complex pass light energy to two special chlorophyll a molecules in the reaction center.
7.8.149	The light excites an electron from the chlorophyll a pair, which passes to the primary electron acceptor.
7.8.150	The excited electron must then be replaced.
7.8.151	In (a) photosystem II, the electron comes from the splitting of water, which releases oxygen as a waste product.
7.8.152	In (b) photosystem I, the electron comes from the chloroplast electron transport chain discussed below.
7.8.153	The actual step that converts light energy into chemical energy takes place in a multiprotein complex called a photosystem, two types of which are found embedded in the thylakoid membrane,
7.8.154	photosystem II (PSII) and photosystem I (PSI)
7.8.155	(Figure 8.16).
7.8.156	The two complexes differ on the basis of what they oxidize (that is, the source of the low-energy electron supply) and what they reduce (the place to which they deliver their energized electrons).
7.8.157	Both photosystems have the same basic structure; a number of antenna proteins to which the chlorophyll molecules are bound surround the reaction center where the photochemistry takes place.
7.8.158	Each photosystem is serviced by the lightharvesting complex, which passes energy from sunlight to the reaction center; it consists of multiple antenna proteins that contain a mixture of 300–400 chlorophyll a and b molecules as well as other pigments like carotenoids.
7.8.159	The absorption of a single photon or distinct quantity or “packet” of light by any of the chlorophylls pushes that molecule into an excited state.
7.8.160	In short, the light energy has now been captured by biological molecules but is not stored in any useful form yet.
7.8.161	The energy is transferred from chlorophyll to chlorophyll until eventually (after about a millionth of a second), it is delivered to the reaction center.
7.8.162	Up to this point, only energy has been transferred between molecules, not electrons.
7.8.163	The reaction center contains a pair of chlorophyll a molecules with a special property.
7.8.164	Those two chlorophylls can undergo oxidation upon excitation; they can actually give up an electron in a process called a photoact.
7.8.165	It is at this step in the reaction center, this step in photosynthesis, that light energy is converted into an excited electron.
7.8.166	All of the subsequent steps involve getting that electron onto the energy carrier NADPH for delivery to the Calvin cycle where the electron is deposited onto carbon for long-term storage in the form of a carbohydrate.
7.8.167	PSII and PSI are two major components of the photosynthetic electron transport chain, which also includes the cytochrome complex.
7.8.168	The cytochrome complex, an enzyme composed of two protein complexes, transfers the electrons from the carrier molecule plastoquinone (Pq) to the protein plastocyanin (Pc), thus enabling both the transfer of protons across the thylakoid membrane and the transfer of electrons from PSII to PSI.
7.8.169	The reaction center of PSII (called P680) delivers its high-energy electrons, one at the time, to the primary electron acceptor, and through the electron transport chain
7.8.170	(Pq to cytochrome complex to plastocyanine) to PSI.
7.8.171	P680’s missing electron is replaced by extracting a low-energy electron from water; thus, water is split and PSII is re-reduced after every photoact.
7.8.172	Splitting one H2O molecule releases two electrons, two hydrogen atoms, and one atom of oxygen.
7.8.173	Splitting two molecules is required to form one molecule of diatomic O2 gas.
7.8.174	About 10 percent of the oxygen is used by mitochondria in the leaf to support oxidative phosphorylation.
7.8.175	The remainder escapes to the atmosphere where it is used by aerobic organisms to support respiration.
7.8.176	As electrons move through the proteins that reside between PSII and PSI, they lose energy.
7.8.177	That energy is used to move hydrogen atoms from the stromal side of the membrane to the thylakoid lumen.
7.8.178	Those hydrogen atoms, plus the ones produced by splitting water, accumulate in the thylakoid lumen and will be used synthesize ATP in a later step.
7.8.179	Because the electrons have lost energy prior to their arrival at PSI, they must be re-energized by PSI, hence, another photon is absorbed by the PSI antenna.
7.8.180	That energy is relayed to the PSI reaction center (called P700).
7.8.181	P700 is oxidized and sends a highenergy electron to NADP+ to form NADPH.
7.8.182	Thus, PSII captures the energy to create proton gradients to make ATP, and PSI captures the energy to reduce NADP+ into NADPH.
7.8.183	The two photosystems work in concert, in part, to guarantee that the production of NADPH will roughly equal the production of ATP.
7.8.184	Other mechanisms exist to fine tune that ratio to exactly match the chloroplast’s constantly changing energy needs.
7.8.185	Generating an Energy Carrier:
7.8.186	ATP As in the intermembrane space of the mitochondria during cellular respiration, the buildup of hydrogen ions inside the thylakoid lumen creates a concentration gradient.
7.8.187	The passive diffusion of hydrogen ions from high concentration (in the thylakoid lumen) to low concentration (in the stroma) is harnessed to create ATP, just as in the electron transport chain of cellular respiration.
7.8.188	The ions build up energy because of diffusion and because they all have the same electrical charge, repelling each other.
7.8.189	To release this energy, hydrogen ions will rush through any opening, similar to water jetting through a hole in a dam.
7.8.190	In the thylakoid, that opening is a passage through a specialized protein channel called the ATP synthase.
7.8.191	The energy released by the hydrogen ion stream allows ATP synthase to attach a third phosphate group to ADP, which forms a molecule of ATP (Figure 8.16).
7.8.192	The flow of hydrogen ions through ATP synthase is called chemiosmosis because the ions move from an area of high to an area of low concentration through a semi-permeable structure.
7.8.193	After the energy from the sun is converted into chemical energy and temporarily stored in ATP and NADPH molecules, the cell has the fuel needed to build carbohydrate molecules for long-term energy storage.
7.8.194	The products of the light-dependent reactions, ATP and NADPH, have lifespans in the range of millionths of seconds, whereas the products of the lightindependent reactions (carbohydrates and other forms of reduced carbon) can survive for hundreds of millions of years.
7.8.195	The carbohydrate molecules made will have a backbone of carbon atoms.
7.8.196	Where does the carbon come from?
7.8.197	It comes from carbon dioxide, the gas that is a waste product of respiration in microbes, fungi, plants, and animals.
7.8.198	The Calvin Cycle
7.8.199	In plants, carbon dioxide (CO2) enters the leaves through stomata, where it diffuses over short distances through intercellular spaces until it reaches the mesophyll cells.
7.8.200	Once in the mesophyll cells, CO2 diffuses into the stroma of the chloroplast—
7.8.201	the site of light-independent reactions of photosynthesis.
7.8.202	These reactions actually have several names associated with them.
7.8.203	Another term, the Calvin cycle, is named for the man who discovered it, and because these reactions function as a cycle.
7.8.204	Others call it the Calvin-Benson cycle to include the name of another scientist involved in its discovery.
7.8.205	The most outdated name is dark reactions, because light is not directly required (Figure 8.17).
7.8.206	However, the term dark reaction can be misleading because it implies incorrectly that the reaction only occurs at night or is independent of light, which is why most scientists and instructors no longer use it.
7.8.207	Light reactions harness energy from the sun to produce chemical bonds, ATP, and NADPH.
7.8.208	These energycarrying molecules are made in the stroma where carbon fixation takes place.
7.8.209	The light-independent reactions of the Calvin cycle can be organized into three basic stages: fixation, reduction, and regeneration.
7.8.210	Stage 1:
7.8.211	Fixation
7.8.212	In the stroma, in addition to CO2, two other components are present to initiate the light-independent reactions: an enzyme called ribulose-1,5-bisphosphate carboxylase/oxygenase (RuBisCO), and three molecules of ribulose bisphosphate (RuBP), as shown in Figure 8.18.
7.8.213	RuBP has five atoms of carbon, flanked by two phosphates.
7.8.214	RuBisCO catalyzes a reaction between CO2 and RuBP.
7.8.215	For each CO2 molecule that reacts with one RuBP, two molecules of another compound (3-PGA) form.
7.8.216	PGA has three carbons and one phosphate.
7.8.217	Each turn of the cycle involves only one RuBP and one carbon dioxide and forms two molecules of 3-PGA.
7.8.218	The number of carbon atoms remains the same, as the atoms move to form new bonds during the reactions (3 atoms from 3CO2 + 15 atoms from 3RuBP = 18 atoms in 3 atoms of 3-PGA).
7.8.219	This process is called carbon fixation, because CO2 is “fixed” from an inorganic form into organic molecules.
7.8.220	Stage 2:
7.8.221	Reduction ATP and NADPH are used to convert the six molecules of 3-PGA into six molecules of a chemical called glyceraldehyde 3-phosphate (G3P).
7.8.222	That is a reduction reaction because it involves the gain of electrons by 3-PGA.
7.8.223	Recall that a reduction is the gain of an electron by an atom or molecule.
7.8.224	Six molecules of both ATP and NADPH are used.
7.8.225	For ATP, energy is released with the loss of the terminal phosphate atom, converting it into ADP; for NADPH, both energy and a hydrogen atom are lost, converting it into NADP+.
7.8.226	Both of these molecules return to the nearby light-dependent reactions to be reused and reenergized.
7.8.227	Stage 3:
7.8.228	Regeneration
7.8.229	Interestingly, at this point, only one of the G3P molecules leaves the Calvin cycle and is sent to the cytoplasm to contribute to the formation of other compounds needed by the plant.
7.8.230	Because the G3P exported from the chloroplast has three carbon atoms, it takes three “
7.8.231	turns” of the Calvin cycle to fix enough net carbon to export one G3P.
7.8.232	But each turn makes two G3Ps, thus three turns make six G3Ps.
7.8.233	One is exported while the remaining five G3P molecules remain in the cycle and are used to regenerate RuBP, which enables the system to prepare for more CO2 to be fixed.
7.8.234	Three more molecules of ATP are used in these regeneration reactions.
7.8.235	The harsh conditions of the desert have led plants like these cacti to evolve variations of the lightindependent reactions of photosynthesis.
7.8.236	These variations increase the efficiency of water usage, helping to conserve water and energy.
7.8.237	(credit: Piotr Wojtkowski)
7.8.238	The Energy Cycle
7.8.239	Whether the organism is a bacterium, plant, or animal, all living things access energy by breaking down carbohydrate molecules.
7.8.240	But if plants make carbohydrate molecules, why would they need to break them down, especially when it has been shown that the gas organisms release as a “waste product” (CO2) acts as a substrate for the formation of more food in photosynthesis?
7.8.241	Remember, living things need energy to perform life functions.
7.8.242	In addition, an organism can either make its own food or eat another organism—either way, the food still needs to be broken down.
7.8.243	Finally, in the process of breaking down food, called cellular respiration, heterotrophs release needed energy and produce “waste” in the form of CO2 gas.
7.8.244	In nature, there is no such thing as waste.
7.8.245	Every single atom of matter and energy is conserved, recycling over and over infinitely.
7.8.246	Substances change form or move from one type of molecule to another, but their constituent atoms never disappear (Figure 8.20).
7.8.247	CO2 is no more a form of waste than oxygen is wasteful to photosynthesis.
7.8.248	Both are byproducts of reactions that move on to other reactions.
7.8.249	Photosynthesis absorbs light energy to build carbohydrates in chloroplasts, and aerobic cellular respiration releases energy by using oxygen to metabolize carbohydrates in the cytoplasm and mitochondria.
7.8.250	Both processes use electron transport chains to capture the energy necessary to drive other reactions.
7.8.251	These two powerhouse processes, photosynthesis and cellular respiration, function in biological, cyclical harmony to allow organisms to access life-sustaining energy that originates millions of miles away in a burning star humans call the sun.
7.8.252	Photosynthesis consumes carbon dioxide and produces oxygen.
7.8.253	Aerobic respiration consumes oxygen and produces carbon dioxide.
7.8.254	These two processes play an important role in the carbon cycle.
7.9.0	Have you ever become separated from a friend while in a crowd?
7.9.1	If so, you know the challenge of searching for someone when surrounded by thousands of other people.
7.9.2	If you and your friend have cell phones, your chances of finding each other are good.
7.9.3	A cell phone’s ability to send and receive messages makes it an ideal communication device.
7.9.4	Introduction Imagine what life would be like if you and the people around you could not communicate.
7.9.5	You would not be able to express your wishes to others, nor could you ask questions to find out more about your environment.
7.9.6	Social organization is dependent on communication between the individuals that comprise that society; without communication, society would fall apart.
7.9.7	As with people, it is vital for individual cells to be able to interact with their environment.
7.9.8	This is true whether a cell is growing by itself in a pond or is one of many cells that form a larger organism.
7.9.9	In order to properly respond to external stimuli, cells have developed complex mechanisms of communication that can receive a message, transfer the information across the plasma membrane, and then produce changes within the cell in response to the message.
7.9.10	In multicellular organisms, cells send and receive chemical messages constantly to coordinate the actions of distant organs, tissues, and cells.
7.9.11	The ability to send messages quickly and efficiently enables cells to coordinate and fine-tune their functions.
7.9.12	While the necessity for cellular communication in larger organisms seems obvious, even single-celled organisms communicate with each other.
7.9.13	Yeast cells signal each other to aid mating.
7.9.14	Some forms of bacteria coordinate their actions in order to form large complexes called biofilms or to organize the production of toxins to remove competing organisms.
7.9.15	The ability of cells to communicate through chemical signals originated in single cells and was essential for the evolution of multicellular organisms.
7.9.16	The efficient and error-free function of communication systems is vital for all life as we know it.
7.9.17	There are two kinds of communication in the world of living cells.
7.9.18	Communication between cells is called intercellular signaling, and communication within a cell is called intracellular signaling.
7.9.19	An easy way to remember the distinction is by understanding the Latin origin of the prefixes: inter- means "between" (for example, intersecting lines are those that cross each other) and intra- means "inside" (like intravenous).
7.9.20	Chemical signals are released by signaling cells in the form of small, usually volatile or soluble molecules called ligands.
7.9.21	A ligand is a molecule that binds another specific molecule, in some cases, delivering a signal in the process.
7.9.22	Ligands can thus be thought of as signaling molecules.
7.9.23	Ligands interact with proteins in target cells, which are cells that are affected by chemical signals; these proteins are also called receptors.
7.9.24	Ligands and receptors exist in several varieties; however, a specific ligand will have a specific receptor that typically binds only that ligand.
7.9.25	Forms of Signaling There are four categories of chemical signaling found in multicellular organisms: paracrine signaling, endocrine signaling, autocrine signaling, and direct signaling across gap junctions (Figure 9.2).
7.9.26	The main difference between the different categories of signaling is the distance that the signal travels through the organism to reach the target cell.
7.9.27	Not all cells are affected by the same signals.
7.9.28	In chemical signaling, a cell may target itself (autocrine signaling), a cell connected by gap junctions, a nearby cell (paracrine signaling), or a distant cell (endocrine signaling).
7.9.29	Paracrine signaling acts on nearby cells, endocrine signaling uses the circulatory system to transport ligands, and autocrine signaling acts on the signaling cell.
7.9.30	Signaling via gap junctions involves signaling molecules moving directly between adjacent cells.
7.9.31	Paracrine Signaling Signals that act locally between cells that are close together are called paracrine signals.
7.9.32	Paracrine signals move by diffusion through the extracellular matrix.
7.9.33	These types of signals usually elicit quick responses that last only a short amount of time.
7.9.34	In order to keep the response localized, paracrine ligand molecules are normally quickly degraded by enzymes or removed by neighboring cells.
7.9.35	Removing the signals will reestablish the concentration gradient for the signal, allowing them to quickly diffuse through the intracellular space if released again.
7.9.36	One example of paracrine signaling is the transfer of signals across synapses between nerve cells.
7.9.37	A nerve cell consists of a cell body, several short, branched extensions called dendrites that receive stimuli, and a long extension called an axon, which transmits signals to other nerve cells or muscle cells.
7.9.38	The junction between nerve cells where signal transmission occurs is called a synapse.
7.9.39	A synaptic signal is a chemical signal that travels between nerve cells.
7.9.40	Signals within the nerve cells are propagated by fast-moving electrical impulses.
7.9.41	When these impulses reach the end of the axon, the signal continues on to a dendrite of the next cell by the release of chemical ligands called neurotransmitters by the presynaptic cell (the cell emitting the signal).
7.9.42	The neurotransmitters are transported across the very small distances between nerve cells, which are called chemical synapses (Figure 9.3).
7.9.43	The small distance between nerve cells allows the signal to travel quickly; this enables an immediate response, such as, Take your hand off the stove!
7.9.44	When the neurotransmitter binds the receptor on the surface of the postsynaptic cell, the electrochemical potential of the target cell changes, and the next electrical impulse is launched.
7.9.45	The neurotransmitters that are released into the chemical synapse are degraded quickly or get reabsorbed by the presynaptic cell so that the recipient nerve cell can recover quickly and be prepared to respond rapidly to the next synaptic signal.
7.9.46	The distance between the presynaptic cell and the postsynaptic cell—called the synaptic gap—is very small and allows for rapid diffusion of the neurotransmitter.
7.9.47	Enzymes in the synapatic cleft degrade some types of neurotransmitters to terminate the signal.
7.9.48	Endocrine Signaling Signals from distant cells are called endocrine signals, and they originate from endocrine cells.
7.9.49	(In the body, many endocrine cells are located in endocrine glands, such as the thyroid gland, the hypothalamus, and the pituitary gland.)
7.9.50	These types of signals usually produce a slower response but have a longer-lasting effect.
7.9.51	The ligands released in endocrine signaling are called hormones, signaling molecules that are produced in one part of the body but affect other body regions some distance away.
7.9.52	Hormones travel the large distances between endocrine cells and their target cells via the bloodstream, which is a relatively slow way to move throughout the body.
7.9.53	Because of their form of transport, hormones get diluted and are present in low concentrations when they act on their target cells.
7.9.54	This is different from paracrine signaling, in which local concentrations of ligands can be very high.
7.9.55	Autocrine Signaling Autocrine signals are produced by signaling cells that can also bind to the ligand that is released.
7.9.56	This means the signaling cell and the target cell can be the same or a similar cell (the prefix auto- means self, a reminder that the signaling cell sends a signal to itself).
7.9.57	This type of signaling often occurs during the early development of an organism to ensure that cells develop into the correct tissues and take on the proper function.
7.9.58	Autocrine signaling also regulates pain sensation and inflammatory responses.
7.9.59	Further, if a cell is infected with a virus, the cell can signal itself to undergo programmed cell death, killing the virus in the process.
7.9.60	In some cases, neighboring cells of the same type are also influenced by the released ligand.
7.9.61	In embryological development, this process of stimulating a group of neighboring cells may help to direct the differentiation of identical cells into the same cell type, thus ensuring the proper developmental outcome.
7.9.62	Direct Signaling Across Gap Junctions Gap junctions in animals and plasmodesmata in plants are connections between the plasma membranes of neighboring cells.
7.9.63	These water-filled channels allow small signaling molecules, called intracellular mediators, to diffuse between the two cells.
7.9.64	Small molecules, such as calcium ions (Ca2+), are able to move between cells, but large molecules like proteins and DNA cannot fit through the channels.
7.9.65	The specificity of the channels ensures that the cells remain independent but can quickly and easily transmit signals.
7.9.66	The transfer of signaling molecules communicates the current state of the cell that is directly next to the target cell; this allows a group of cells to coordinate their response to a signal that only one of them may have received.
7.9.67	In plants, plasmodesmata are ubiquitous, making the entire plant into a giant, communication network.
7.9.68	Types of Receptors Receptors are protein molecules in the target cell or on its surface that bind ligand.
7.9.69	There are two types of receptors, internal receptors and cell-surface receptors.
7.9.70	Internal receptors Internal receptors, also known as intracellular or cytoplasmic receptors, are found in the cytoplasm of the cell and respond to hydrophobic ligand molecules that are able to travel across the plasma membrane.
7.9.71	Once inside the cell, many of these molecules bind to proteins that act as regulators of mRNA synthesis (transcription) to mediate gene expression.
7.9.72	Gene expression is the cellular process of transforming the information in a cell's DNA into a sequence of amino acids, which ultimately forms a protein.
7.9.73	When the ligand binds to the internal receptor, a conformational change is triggered that exposes a DNA-binding site on the protein.
7.9.74	The ligand-receptor complex moves into the nucleus, then binds to specific regulatory regions of the chromosomal DNA and promotes the initiation of transcription (Figure 9.4).
7.9.75	Transcription is the process of copying the information in a cells DNA into a special form of RNA called messenger RNA (mRNA); the cell uses information in the mRNA (which moves out into the cytoplasm and associates with ribosomes) to link specific amino acids in the correct order, producing a protein.
7.9.76	Internal receptors can directly influence gene expression without having to pass the signal on to other receptors or messengers.
7.9.77	Hydrophobic signaling molecules typically diffuse across the plasma membrane and interact with intracellular receptors in the cytoplasm.
7.9.78	Many intracellular receptors are transcription factors that interact with DNA in the nucleus and regulate gene expression.
7.9.79	Cell-Surface Receptors Cell-surface receptors, also known as transmembrane receptors, are cell surface, membrane-anchored (integral) proteins that bind to external ligand molecules.
7.9.80	This type of receptor spans the plasma membrane and performs signal transduction, in which an extracellular signal is converted into an intercellular signal.
7.9.81	Ligands that interact with cell-surface receptors do not have to enter the cell that they affect.
7.9.82	Cell-surface receptors are also called cell-specific proteins or markers because they are specific to individual cell types.
7.9.83	Because cell-surface receptor proteins are fundamental to normal cell functioning, it should come as no surprise that a malfunction in any one of these proteins could have severe consequences.
7.9.84	Errors in the protein structures of certain receptor molecules have been shown to play a role in hypertension (high blood pressure), asthma, heart disease, and cancer.
7.9.85	Each cell-surface receptor has three main components: an external ligand-binding domain, a hydrophobic membrane- spanning region, and an intracellular domain inside the cell.
7.9.86	The ligand-binding domain is also called the extracellular domain.
7.9.87	The size and extent of each of these domains vary widely, depending on the type of receptor.
7.9.88	Cell-surface receptors are involved in most of the signaling in multicellular organisms.
7.9.89	There are three general categories of cell-surface receptors: ion channel-linked receptors, G-protein-linked receptors, and enzyme-linked receptors.
7.9.90	Ion channel-linked receptors bind a ligand and open a channel through the membrane that allows specific ions to pass through.
7.9.91	To form a channel, this type of cell-surface receptor has an extensive membrane-spanning region.
7.9.92	In order to interact with the phospholipid fatty acid tails that form the center of the plasma membrane, many of the amino acids in the membrane-spanning region are hydrophobic in nature.
7.9.93	Conversely, the amino acids that line the inside of the channel are hydrophilic to allow for the passage of water or ions.
7.9.94	When a ligand binds to the extracellular region of the channel, there is a conformational change in the proteins structure that allows ions such as sodium, calcium, magnesium, and hydrogen to pass through  
7.9.95	Gated ion channels form a pore through the plasma membrane that opens when the signaling molecule binds.
7.9.96	The open pore then allows ions to flow into or out of the cell.
7.9.97	G-protein-linked receptors bind a ligand and activate a membrane protein called a G-protein.
7.9.98	The activated G-protein then interacts with either an ion channel or an enzyme in the membrane (Figure 9.6).
7.9.99	All G-protein-linked receptors have seven transmembrane domains, but each receptor has its own specific extracellular domain and G-protein-binding site.
7.9.100	Cell signaling using G-protein-linked receptors occurs as a cyclic series of events.
7.9.101	Before the ligand binds, the inactive G- protein can bind to a newly revealed site on the receptor specific for its binding.
7.9.102	Once the G-protein binds to the receptor, the resultant shape change activates the G-protein, which releases GDP and picks up GTP.
7.9.103	The subunits of the G-protein then split into the α subunit and the βγ subunit.
7.9.104	One or both of these G-protein fragments may be able to activate other proteins as a result.
7.9.105	After awhile, the GTP on the active α subunit of the G-protein is hydrolyzed to GDP and the βγ subunit is deactivated.
7.9.106	The subunits reassociate to form the inactive G-protein and the cycle begins anew.
7.9.107	Heterotrimeric G proteins have three subunits: α, β, and γ.
7.9.108	When a signaling molecule binds to a G-protein- coupled receptor in the plasma membrane, a GDP molecule associated with the α subunit is exchanged for GTP.
7.9.109	The β and γ subunits dissociate from the α subunit, and a cellular response is triggered either by the α subunit or the dissociated βγ pair.
7.9.110	Hydrolysis of GTP to GDP terminates the signal.
7.9.111	G-protein-linked receptors have been extensively studied and much has been learned about their roles in maintaining health.
7.9.112	Bacteria that are pathogenic to humans can release poisons that interrupt specific G-protein-linked receptor function, leading to illnesses such as pertussis, botulism, and cholera.
7.9.113	In cholera (Figure 9.7), for example, the water-borne bacterium Vibrio cholerae produces a toxin, choleragen, that binds to cells lining the small intestine.
7.9.114	The toxin then enters these intestinal cells, where it modifies a G-protein that controls the opening of a chloride channel and causes it to remain continuously active, resulting in large losses of fluids from the body and potentially fatal dehydration as a result.
7.9.115	Transmitted primarily through contaminated drinking water, cholera is a major cause of death in the developing world and in areas where natural disasters interrupt the availability of clean water.
7.9.116	The cholera bacterium, Vibrio cholerae, creates a toxin that modifies G-protein-mediated cell signaling pathways in the intestines.
7.9.117	Modern sanitation eliminates the threat of cholera outbreaks, such as the one that swept through New York City in 1866.
7.9.118	This poster from that era shows how, at that time, the way that the disease was transmitted was not understood.
7.9.119	Enzyme-linked receptors are cell-surface receptors with intracellular domains that are associated with an enzyme.
7.9.120	In some cases, the intracellular domain of the receptor itself is an enzyme.
7.9.121	Other enzyme-linked receptors have a small intracellular domain that interacts directly with an enzyme.
7.9.122	The enzyme-linked receptors normally have large extracellular and intracellular domains, but the membrane-spanning region consists of a single alpha-helical region of the peptide strand.
7.9.123	When a ligand binds to the extracellular domain, a signal is transferred through the membrane, activating the enzyme.
7.9.124	Activation of the enzyme sets off a chain of events within the cell that eventually leads to a response.
7.9.125	One example of this type of enzyme-linked receptor is the tyrosine kinase receptor (Figure 9.8).
7.9.126	A kinase is an enzyme that transfers phosphate groups from ATP to another protein.
7.9.127	The tyrosine kinase receptor transfers phosphate groups to tyrosine molecules (tyrosine residues).
7.9.128	First, signaling molecules bind to the extracellular domain of two nearby tyrosine kinase receptors.
7.9.129	The two neighboring receptors then bond together, or dimerize.
7.9.130	Phosphates are then added to tyrosine residues on the intracellular domain of the receptors (phosphorylation).
7.9.131	The phosphorylated residues can then transmit the signal to the next messenger within the cytoplasm.
7.9.132	Signaling Molecules Produced by signaling cells and the subsequent binding to receptors in target cells, ligands act as chemical signals that travel to the target cells to coordinate responses.
7.9.133	The types of molecules that serve as ligands are incredibly varied and range from small proteins to small ions like calcium (Ca2+).
7.9.134	Small Hydrophobic Ligands Small hydrophobic ligands can directly diffuse through the plasma membrane and interact with internal receptors.
7.9.135	Important members of this class of ligands are the steroid hormones.
7.9.136	Steroids are lipids that have a hydrocarbon skeleton with four fused rings; different steroids have different functional groups attached to the carbon skeleton.
7.9.137	Steroid hormones include the female sex hormone, estradiol, which is a type of estrogen; the male sex hormone, testosterone; and cholesterol, which is an important structural component of biological membranes and a precursor of steriod hormones (Figure 9.9).
7.9.138	Other hydrophobic hormones include thyroid hormones and vitamin D.
7.9.139	In order to be soluble in blood, hydrophobic ligands must bind to carrier proteins while they are being transported through the bloodstream.
7.9.140	Steroid hormones have similar chemical structures to their precursor, cholesterol.
7.9.141	Because these molecules are small and hydrophobic, they can diffuse directly across the plasma membrane into the cell, where they interact with internal receptors.
7.9.142	Water-Soluble Ligands Water-soluble ligands are polar and therefore cannot pass through the plasma membrane unaided; sometimes, they are too large to pass through the membrane at all.
7.9.143	Instead, most water-soluble ligands bind to the extracellular domain of cell- surface receptors.
7.9.144	This group of ligands is quite diverse and includes small molecules, peptides, and proteins.
7.9.145	Other Ligands Nitric oxide (NO) is a gas that also acts as a ligand.
7.9.146	It is able to diffuse directly across the plasma membrane, and one of its roles is to interact with receptors in smooth muscle and induce relaxation of the tissue.
7.9.147	NO has a very short half-life and therefore only functions over short distances.
7.9.148	Nitroglycerin, a treatment for heart disease, acts by triggering the release of NO, which causes blood vessels to dilate (expand), thus restoring blood flow to the heart.
7.9.149	NO has become better known recently because the pathway that it affects is targeted by prescription medications for erectile dysfunction, such as Viagra (erection involves dilated blood vessels).
7.9.150	Once a ligand binds to a receptor, the signal is transmitted through the membrane and into the cytoplasm.
7.9.151	Continuation of a signal in this manner is called signal transduction.
7.9.152	Signal transduction only occurs with cell-surface receptors because internal receptors are able to interact directly with DNA in the nucleus to initiate protein synthesis.
7.9.153	When a ligand binds to its receptor, conformational changes occur that affect the receptor’s intracellular domain.
7.9.154	Conformational changes of the extracellular domain upon ligand binding can propagate through the membrane region of the receptor and lead to activation of the intracellular domain or its associated proteins.
7.9.155	In some cases, binding of the ligand causes dimerization of the receptor, which means that two receptors bind to each other to form a stable complex called a dimer.
7.9.156	A dimer is a chemical compound formed when two molecules (often identical) join together.
7.9.157	The binding of the receptors in this manner enables their intracellular domains to come into close contact and activate each other.
7.9.158	Binding Initiates a Signaling Pathway
7.9.159	After the ligand binds to the cell-surface receptor, the activation of the receptor’s intracellular components sets off a chain of events that is called a signaling pathway or a signaling cascade.
7.9.160	In a signaling pathway, second messengers, enzymes, and activated proteins interact with specific proteins, which are in turn activated in a chain reaction that eventually leads to a change in the cell’s environment (Figure 9.10).
7.9.161	The events in the cascade occur in a series, much like a current flows in a river.
7.9.162	Interactions that occur before a certain point are defined as upstream events, and events after that point are called downstream events.
7.9.163	Signaling pathways can get very complicated very quickly because most cellular proteins can affect different downstream events, depending on the conditions within the cell.
7.9.164	A single pathway can branch off toward different endpoints based on the interplay between two or more signaling pathways, and the same ligands are often used to initiate different signals in different cell types.
7.9.165	This variation in response is due to differences in protein expression in different cell types.
7.9.166	Another complicating element is signal integration of the pathways, in which signals from two or more different cell-surface receptors merge to activate the same response in the cell.
7.9.167	This process can ensure that multiple external requirements are met before a cell commits to a specific response.
7.9.168	The effects of extracellular signals can also be amplified by enzymatic cascades.
7.9.169	At the initiation of the signal, a single ligand binds to a single receptor.
7.9.170	However, activation of a receptor-linked enzyme can activate many copies of a component of the signaling cascade, which amplifies the signal.
7.9.171	Methods of
7.9.172	Intracellular Signaling
7.9.173	The induction of a signaling pathway depends on the modification of a cellular component by an enzyme.
7.9.174	There are numerous enzymatic modifications that can occur, and they are recognized in turn by the next component downstream.
7.9.175	The following are some of the more common events in intracellular signaling.
7.9.176	Phosphorylation One of the most common chemical modifications that occurs in signaling pathways is the addition of a phosphate group (PO4–3) to a molecule such as a protein in a process called phosphorylation.
7.9.177	The phosphate can be added to a nucleotide such as GMP to form GDP or GTP.
7.9.178	Phosphates are also often added to serine, threonine, and tyrosine residues of proteins, where they replace the hydroxyl group of the amino acid (Figure 9.11).
7.9.179	The transfer of the phosphate is catalyzed by an enzyme called a kinase.
7.9.180	Various kinases are named for the substrate they phosphorylate.
7.9.181	Phosphorylation of serine and threonine residues often activates enzymes.
7.9.182	Phosphorylation of tyrosine residues can either affect the activity of an enzyme or create a binding site that interacts with downstream components in the signaling cascade.
7.9.183	Phosphorylation may activate or inactivate enzymes, and the reversal of phosphorylation, dephosphorylation by a phosphatase, will reverse the effect.
7.9.184	In protein phosphorylation, a phosphate group (PO4-3 ) is added to residues of the amino acids serine, threonine, and tyrosine.
7.9.185	Second
7.9.186	Messengers Second messengers are small molecules that propagate a signal after it has been initiated by the binding of the signaling molecule to the receptor.
7.9.187	These molecules help to spread a signal through the cytoplasm by altering the behavior of certain cellular proteins.
7.9.188	Calcium ion is a widely used second messenger.
7.9.189	The free concentration of calcium ions (Ca2+) within a cell is very low because ion pumps in the plasma membrane continuously use adenosine-5'-triphosphate (ATP) to remove it.
7.9.190	For signaling purposes, Ca2+ is stored in cytoplasmic vesicles, such as the endoplasmic reticulum, or accessed from outside the cell.
7.9.191	When signaling occurs, ligand-gated calcium ion channels allow the higher levels of Ca2+ that are present outside the cell (or in intracellular storage compartments) to flow into the cytoplasm, which raises the concentration of cytoplasmic Ca2
7.9.192	+.
7.9.193	The response to the increase in Ca2+ varies, depending on the cell type involved.
7.9.194	For example, in the β-cells of the pancreas, Ca2+ signaling leads to the release of insulin, and in muscle cells, an increase in Ca2+ leads to muscle contractions.
7.9.195	Another second messenger utilized in many different cell types is cyclic AMP (cAMP).
7.9.196	Cyclic AMP is synthesized by the enzyme adenylyl cyclase from ATP (Figure 9.12).
7.9.197	The main role of cAMP in cells is to bind to and activate an enzyme called cAMP-dependent kinase (A-kinase).
7.9.198	A-kinase regulates many vital metabolic pathways: It phosphorylates serine and threonine residues of its target proteins, activating them in the process.
7.9.199	A-kinase is found in many different types of cells, and the target proteins in each kind of cell are different.
7.9.200	Differences give rise to the variation of the responses to cAMP in different cells.
7.9.201	This diagram shows the mechanism for the formation of cyclic AMP (cAMP).
7.9.202	cAMP serves as a second messenger to activate or inactivate proteins within the cell.
7.9.203	Termination of the signal occurs when an enzyme called phosphodiesterase converts cAMP into AMP.
7.9.204	Present in small concentrations in the plasma membrane, inositol phospholipids are lipids that can also be converted into second messengers.
7.9.205	Because these molecules are membrane components, they are located near membrane-bound receptors and can easily interact with them.
7.9.206	Phosphatidylinositol (PI) is the main phospholipid that plays a role in cellular signaling.
7.9.207	Enzymes known as kinases phosphorylate PI to form PI-phosphate (PIP) and PI-bisphosphate (PIP2).
7.9.208	The enzyme phospholipase C cleaves PIP2 to form diacylglycerol (DAG) and inositol triphosphate (IP3) (Figure 9.13).
7.9.209	These products of the cleavage of PIP2 serve as second messengers.
7.9.210	Diacylglycerol (DAG) remains in the plasma membrane and activates protein kinase C (PKC), which then phosphorylates serine and threonine residues in its target proteins.
7.9.211	IP3 diffuses into the cytoplasm and binds to ligand-gated calcium channels in the endoplasmic reticulum to release Ca2
7.9.212	+ that continues the signal cascade.
7.9.213	The enzyme phospholipase C breaks down PIP2 into IP3 and DAG, both of which serve as second messengers.
7.9.214	Inside the cell, ligands bind to their internal receptors, allowing them to directly affect the cell’s DNA and protein-producing machinery.
7.9.215	Using signal transduction pathways, receptors in the plasma membrane produce a variety of effects on the cell.
7.9.216	The results of signaling pathways are extremely varied and depend on the type of cell involved as well as the external and internal conditions.
7.9.217	A small sampling of responses is described below.
7.9.218	Gene Expression
7.9.219	Some signal transduction pathways regulate the transcription of RNA.
7.9.220	Others regulate the translation of proteins from mRNA.
7.9.221	An example of a protein that regulates translation in the nucleus is the MAP kinase ERK.
7.9.222	ERK is activated in a phosphorylation cascade when epidermal growth factor (EGF) binds the EGF receptor (see Figure 9.10).
7.9.223	Upon phosphorylation, ERK enters the nucleus and activates a protein kinase that, in turn, regulates protein translation (Figure 9.14).
7.9.224	ERK is a MAP kinase that activates translation when it is phosphorylated.
7.9.225	ERK phosphorylates MNK1, which in turn phosphorylates eIF-4E, an elongation initiation factor that, with other initiation factors, is associated with mRNA.
7.9.226	When eIF-4E becomes phosphorylated, the mRNA unfolds, allowing protein synthesis in the nucleus to begin.
7.9.227	The second kind of protein with which PKC can interact is a protein that acts as an inhibitor.
7.9.228	An inhibitor is a molecule that binds to a protein and prevents it from functioning or reduces its function.
7.9.229	In this case, the inhibitor is a protein called Iκ-B, which binds to the regulatory protein NF-κB. (The symbol κ represents the Greek letter kappa.)
7.9.230	When Iκ-B is bound to NF-κB, the complex cannot enter the nucleus of the cell, but when Iκ-B is phosphorylated by PKC, it can no longer bind NF-κB, and NF-κB (a transcription factor) can enter the nucleus and initiate RNA transcription.
7.9.231	In this case, the effect of phosphorylation is to inactivate an inhibitor and thereby activate the process of transcription.
7.9.232	Increase in Cellular Metabolism
7.9.233	The result of another signaling pathway affects muscle cells.
7.9.234	The activation of β-adrenergic receptors in muscle cells by adrenaline leads to an increase in cyclic AMP (cAMP) inside the cell.
7.9.235	Also known as epinephrine, adrenaline is a hormone (produced by the adrenal gland attached to the kidney) that readies the body for short-term emergencies.
7.9.236	Cyclic AMP activates PKA (protein kinase A), which in turn phosphorylates two enzymes.
7.9.237	The first enzyme promotes the degradation of glycogen by activating intermediate glycogen phosphorylase kinase (GPK) that in turn activates glycogen phosphorylase (GP) that catabolizes glycogen into glucose.
7.9.238	(Recall that your body converts excess glucose to glycogen for short-term storage.
7.9.239	When energy is needed, glycogen is quickly reconverted to glucose.)
7.9.240	Phosphorylation of the second enzyme, glycogen synthase (GS), inhibits its ability to form glycogen from glucose.
7.9.241	In this manner, a muscle cell obtains a ready pool of glucose by activating its formation via glycogen degradation and by inhibiting the use of glucose to form glycogen, thus preventing a futile cycle of glycogen degradation and synthesis.
7.9.242	The glucose is then available for use by the muscle cell in response to a sudden surge of adrenaline—the “fight or flight” reflex.
7.9.243	Cell Growth Cell signaling pathways also play a major role in cell division.
7.9.244	Cells do not normally divide unless they are stimulated by signals from other cells.
7.9.245	The ligands that promote cell growth are called growth factors.
7.9.246	Most growth factors bind to cell-surface receptors that are linked to tyrosine kinases.
7.9.247	These cell-surface receptors are called receptor tyrosine kinases (RTKs).
7.9.248	Activation of RTKs initiates a signaling pathway that includes a G-protein called RAS, which activates the MAP kinase pathway described earlier.
7.9.249	The enzyme MAP kinase then stimulates the expression of proteins that interact with other cellular components to initiate cell division.
7.9.250	Cell Death
7.9.251	When a cell is damaged, superfluous, or potentially dangerous to an organism, a cell can initiate a mechanism to trigger programmed cell death, or apoptosis.
7.9.252	Apoptosis allows a cell to die in a controlled manner that prevents the release of potentially damaging molecules from inside the cell.
7.9.253	There are many internal checkpoints that monitor a cell’s health; if abnormalities are observed, a cell can spontaneously initiate the process of apoptosis.
7.9.254	However, in some cases, such as a viral infection or uncontrolled cell division due to cancer, the cell’s normal checks and balances fail.
7.9.255	External signaling can also initiate apoptosis.
7.9.256	For example, most normal animal cells have receptors that interact with the extracellular matrix, a network of glycoproteins that provides structural support for cells in an organism.
7.9.257	The binding of cellular receptors to the extracellular matrix initiates a signaling cascade within the cell.
7.9.258	However, if the cell moves away from the extracellular matrix, the signaling ceases, and the cell undergoes apoptosis.
7.9.259	This system keeps cells from traveling through the body and proliferating out of control, as happens with tumor cells that metastasize.
7.9.260	Another example of external signaling that leads to apoptosis occurs in T-cell development.
7.9.261	T-cells are immune cells that bind to foreign macromolecules and particles, and target them for destruction by the immune system.
7.9.262	Normally, T-cells do not target “self” proteins (those of their own organism), a process that can lead to autoimmune diseases.
7.9.263	In order to develop the ability to discriminate between self and non-self, immature T-cells undergo screening to determine whether they bind to so-called self proteins.
7.9.264	If the T-cell receptor binds to self proteins, the cell initiates apoptosis to remove the potentially dangerous cell.
7.9.265	Apoptosis is also essential for normal embryological development.
7.9.266	In vertebrates, for example, early stages of development include the formation of web-like tissue between individual fingers and toes (Figure 9.15).
7.9.267	During the course of normal development, these unneeded cells must be eliminated, enabling fully separated fingers and toes to form.
7.9.268	A cell signaling mechanism triggers apoptosis, which destroys the cells between the developing digits.
7.9.269	The histological section of a foot of a 15-day-old mouse embryo, visualized using light microscopy, reveals areas of tissue between the toes, which apoptosis will eliminate before the mouse reaches its full gestational age at 27 days.
7.9.270	(credit: modification of work by Michal Mañas)
7.9.271	Termination of the Signal Cascade
7.9.272	The aberrant signaling often seen in tumor cells is proof that the termination of a signal at the appropriate time can be just as important as the initiation of a signal.
7.9.273	One method of stopping a specific signal is to degrade the ligand or remove it so that it can no longer access its receptor.
7.9.274	One reason that hydrophobic hormones like estrogen and testosterone trigger
7.9.275	long- lasting events is because they bind carrier proteins.
7.9.276	These proteins allow the insoluble molecules to be soluble in blood, but they also protect the hormones from degradation by circulating enzymes.
7.9.277	Inside the cell, many different enzymes reverse the cellular modifications that result from signaling cascades.
7.9.278	For example, phosphatases are enzymes that remove the phosphate group attached to proteins by kinases in a process called dephosphorylation.
7.9.279	Cyclic AMP (cAMP) is degraded into AMP by phosphodiesterase, and the release of calcium stores is reversed by the Ca2+ pumps that are located in the external and internal membranes of the cell.
7.9.280	Within-cell signaling allows bacteria to respond to environmental cues, such as nutrient levels, some single-celled organisms also release molecules to signal to each other.
7.9.281	Signaling in Yeast Yeasts are eukaryotes (fungi), and the components and processes found in yeast signals are similar to those of cell-surface receptor signals in multicellular organisms.
7.9.282	Budding yeasts (Figure 9.16) are able to participate in a process that is similar to sexual reproduction that entails two haploid cells (cells with one-half the normal number of chromosomes) combining to form a diploid cell (a cell with two sets of each chromosome, which is what normal body cells contain).
7.9.283	In order to find another haploid yeast cell that is prepared to mate, budding yeasts secrete a signaling molecule called mating factor.
7.9.284	When mating factor binds to cell-surface receptors in other yeast cells that are nearby, they stop their normal growth cycles and initiate a cell signaling cascade that includes protein kinases and GTP-binding proteins that are similar to G-proteins.
7.9.285	Budding Saccharomyces cerevisiae yeast cells can communicate by releasing a signaling molecule called mating factor.
7.9.286	In this micrograph, they are visualized using differential interference contrast microscopy, a light microscopy technique that enhances the contrast of the sample.
7.9.287	Signaling in Bacteria Signaling in bacteria enables bacteria to monitor extracellular conditions, ensure that there are sufficient amounts of nutrients, and ensure that hazardous situations are avoided.
7.9.288	There are circumstances, however, when bacteria communicate with each other.
7.9.289	The first evidence of bacterial communication was observed in a bacterium that has a symbiotic relationship with Hawaiian bobtail squid.
7.9.290	When the population density of the bacteria reaches a certain level, specific gene expression is initiated, and the bacteria produce bioluminescent proteins that emit light.
7.9.291	Because the number of cells present in the environment (cell density) is the determining factor for signaling, bacterial signaling was named quorum sensing.
7.9.292	In politics and business, a quorum is the minimum number of members required to be present to vote on an issue.
7.9.293	Quorum sensing uses autoinducers as signaling molecules.
7.9.294	Autoinducers are signaling molecules secreted by bacteria to communicate with other bacteria of the same kind.
7.9.295	The secreted autoinducers can be small, hydrophobic molecules such as acyl-homoserine lactone, (AHL) or larger peptide-based molecules; each type of molecule has a different mode of action.
7.9.296	When AHL enters target bacteria, it binds to transcription factors, which then switch gene expression on or off (Figure 9.17).
7.9.297	The peptide autoinducers stimulate more complicated signaling pathways that include bacterial kinases.
7.9.298	The changes in bacteria following exposure to autoinducers can be quite extensive.
7.9.299	The pathogenic bacterium Pseudomonas aeruginosa has 616 different genes that respond to autoinducers.
7.9.300	Some species of bacteria that use quorum sensing form biofilms, complex colonies of bacteria (often containing several species) that exchange chemical signals to coordinate the release of toxins that will attack the host.
7.9.301	Bacterial biofilms (Figure 9.18) can sometimes be found on medical equipment; when biofilms invade implants such as hip or knee replacements or heart pacemakers, they can cause life-threatening infections.
7.9.302	Research on the details of quorum sensing has led to advances in growing bacteria for industrial purposes.
7.9.303	Recent discoveries suggest that it may be possible to exploit bacterial signaling pathways to control bacterial growth; this process could replace or supplement antibiotics that are no longer effective in certain situations.
7.10.0	Introduction A human, as well as every sexually reproducing organism, begins life as a fertilized egg (embryo) or zygote.
7.10.1	Trillions of cell divisions subsequently occur in a controlled manner to produce a complex, multicellular human.
7.10.2	In other words, that original single cell is the ancestor of every other cell in the body.
7.10.3	Once a being is fully grown, cell reproduction is still necessary to repair or regenerate tissues.
7.10.4	For example, new blood and skin cells are constantly being produced.
7.10.5	All multicellular organisms use cell division for growth and the maintenance and repair of cells and tissues.
7.10.6	Cell division is tightly regulated, and the occasional failure of regulation can have life-threatening consequences.
7.10.7	Single-celled organisms use cell division as their method of reproduction.
7.10.8	The continuity of life from one cell to another has its foundation in the reproduction of cells by way of the cell cycle.
7.10.9	The cell cycle is an orderly sequence of events that describes the stages of a cell’s life from the division of a single parent cell to the production of two new daughter cells.
7.10.10	The mechanisms involved in the cell cycle are highly regulated.
7.10.11	Genomic DNA
7.10.12	Before discussing the steps a cell must undertake to replicate, a deeper understanding of the structure and function of a cell’s genetic information is necessary.
7.10.13	A cell’s DNA, packaged as a double-stranded DNA molecule, is called its genome.
7.10.14	In prokaryotes, the genome is composed of a single, double-stranded DNA molecule in the form of a loop or circle (Figure 10.2).
7.10.15	The region in the cell containing this genetic material is called a nucleoid.
7.10.16	Some prokaryotes also have smaller loops of DNA called plasmids that are not essential for normal growth.
7.10.17	Bacteria can exchange these plasmids with other bacteria, sometimes receiving beneficial new genes that the recipient can add to their chromosomal DNA.
7.10.18	Antibiotic resistance is one trait that often spreads through a bacterial colony through plasmid exchange.
7.10.19	Prokaryotes, including bacteria and archaea, have a single, circular chromosome located in a central region called the nucleoid.
7.10.20	In eukaryotes, the genome consists of several double-stranded linear DNA molecules (Figure 10.3).
7.10.21	Each species of eukaryotes has a characteristic number of chromosomes in the nuclei of its cells.
7.10.22	Human body cells have 46 chromosomes, while human gametes (sperm or eggs) have 23 chromosomes each.
7.10.23	A typical body cell, or somatic cell, contains two matched sets of chromosomes, a configuration known as diploid.
7.10.24	The letter n is used to represent a single set of chromosomes; therefore, a diploid organism is designated 2n.
7.10.25	Human cells that contain one set of chromosomes are called gametes, or sex cells; these are eggs and sperm, and are designated 1n, or haploid.
7.10.26	There are 23 pairs of homologous chromosomes in a female human somatic cell.
7.10.27	The condensed chromosomes are viewed within the nucleus (top), removed from a cell in mitosis and spread out on a slide (right), and artificially arranged according to length (left); an arrangement like this is called a karyotype.
7.10.28	In this image, the chromosomes were exposed to fluorescent stains for differentiation of the different chromosomes.
7.10.29	A method of staining called “chromosome painting
7.10.30	” employs fluorescent dyes that highlight chromosomes in different colors.
7.10.31	Matched pairs of chromosomes in a diploid organism are called homologous (“same knowledge”) chromosomes.
7.10.32	Homologous chromosomes are the same length and have specific nucleotide segments called genes in exactly the same location, or locus.
7.10.33	Genes, the functional units of chromosomes, determine specific characteristics by coding for specific proteins.
7.10.34	Traits are the variations of those characteristics.
7.10.35	For example, hair color is a characteristic with traits that are blonde, brown, or black.
7.10.36	Each copy of a homologous pair of chromosomes originates from a different parent; therefore, the genes themselves are not identical.
7.10.37	The variation of individuals within a species is due to the specific combination of the genes inherited from both parents.
7.10.38	Even a slightly altered sequence of nucleotides within a gene can result in an alternative trait.
7.10.39	For example, there are three possible gene sequences on the human chromosome that code for blood type:
7.10.40	sequence A, sequence B, and sequence O.
7.10.41	Because all diploid human cells have two copies of the chromosome that determines blood type, the blood type (the trait) is determined by which two versions of the marker gene are inherited.
7.10.42	It is possible to have two copies of the same gene sequence on both homologous chromosomes, with one on each (for example, AA, BB, or OO), or two different sequences, such as AB.
7.10.43	Minor variations of traits, such as blood type, eye color, and handedness, contribute to the natural variation found within a species.
7.10.44	However, if the entire DNA sequence from any pair of human homologous chromosomes is compared, the difference is less than one percent.
7.10.45	The sex chromosomes, X and Y, are the single exception to the rule of homologous chromosome uniformity:
7.10.46	Other than a small amount of homology that is necessary to accurately produce gametes, the genes found on the X and Y chromosomes are different.
7.10.47	Eukaryotic Chromosomal Structure and Compaction
7.10.48	If the DNA from all 46 chromosomes in a human cell nucleus was laid out end to end, it would measure approximately two meters; however, its diameter would be only 2 nm.
7.10.49	Considering that the size of a typical human cell is about 10 μm (100,000 cells lined up to equal one meter), DNA must be tightly packaged to fit in the cell’s nucleus.
7.10.50	At the same time, it must also be readily accessible for the genes to be expressed.
7.10.51	During some stages of the cell cycle, the long strands of DNA are condensed into compact chromosomes.
7.10.52	There are a number of ways that chromosomes are compacted.
7.10.53	In the first level of compaction, short stretches of the DNA double helix wrap around a core of eight histone proteins at regular intervals along the entire length of the chromosome (Figure 10.4).
7.10.54	The DNA-histone complex is called chromatin.
7.10.55	The beadlike, histone DNA complex is called a nucleosome, and DNA connecting the nucleosomes is called linker DNA.
7.10.56	A DNA molecule in this form is about seven times shorter than the double helix without the histones, and the beads are about 10 nm in diameter, in contrast with the 2-nm diameter of a DNA double helix.
7.10.57	The next level of compaction occurs as the nucleosomes and the linker DNA between them are coiled into a 30-nm chromatin fiber.
7.10.58	This coiling further shortens the chromosome so that it is now about 50 times shorter than the extended form.
7.10.59	In the third level of packing, a variety of fibrous proteins is used to pack the chromatin.
7.10.60	These fibrous proteins also ensure that each chromosome in a non-dividing cell occupies a particular area of the nucleus that does not overlap with that of any other chromosome.
7.10.61	Double-stranded DNA wraps around histone proteins to form nucleosomes that have the appearance of “beads on a string.
7.10.62	”
7.10.63	The nucleosomes are coiled into a 30-nm chromatin fiber.
7.10.64	When a cell undergoes mitosis, the chromosomes condense even further.
7.10.65	DNA replicates in the S phase of interphase.
7.10.66	After replication, the chromosomes are composed of two linked sister chromatids.
7.10.67	When fully compact, the pairs of identically packed chromosomes are bound to each other by cohesin proteins.
7.10.68	The connection between the sister chromatids is closest in a region called the centromere.
7.10.69	The conjoined sister chromatids, with a diameter of about 1 μm, are visible under a light microscope.
7.10.70	The centromeric region is highly condensed and thus will appear as a constricted area.
7.10.71	The cell cycle is an ordered series of events involving cell growth and cell division that produces two new daughter cells.
7.10.72	Cells on the path to cell division proceed through a series of precisely timed and carefully regulated stages of growth, DNA replication, and division that produces two identical (clone) cells.
7.10.73	The cell cycle has two major phases: interphase and the mitotic phase (Figure 10.5).
7.10.74	During interphase, the cell grows and DNA is replicated.
7.10.75	During the mitotic phase, the replicated DNA and cytoplasmic contents are separated, and the cell divides.
7.10.76	The cell cycle consists of interphase and the mitotic phase.
7.10.77	During interphase, the cell grows and the nuclear DNA is duplicated.
7.10.78	Interphase is followed by the mitotic phase.
7.10.79	During the mitotic phase, the duplicated chromosomes are segregated and distributed into daughter nuclei.
7.10.80	The cytoplasm is usually divided as well, resulting in two daughter cells.
7.10.81	Interphase
7.10.82	During interphase, the cell undergoes normal growth processes while also preparing for cell division.
7.10.83	In order for a cell to move from interphase into the mitotic phase, many internal and external conditions must be met.
7.10.84	The three stages of interphase are called G1, S, and G2.
7.10.85	G1
7.10.86	Phase (First Gap)
7.10.87	The first stage of interphase is called the G1 phase (first gap) because, from a microscopic aspect, little change is visible.
7.10.88	However, during the G1 stage, the cell is quite active at the biochemical level.
7.10.89	The cell is accumulating the building blocks of chromosomal DNA and the associated proteins as well as accumulating sufficient energy reserves to complete the task of replicating each chromosome in the nucleus.
7.10.90	S Phase (Synthesis of DNA)
7.10.91	Throughout interphase, nuclear DNA remains in a semi-condensed chromatin configuration.
