7.10.92	In the S phase, DNA replication can proceed through the mechanisms that result in the formation of identical pairs of DNA molecules—sister chromatids—that are firmly attached to the centromeric region.
7.10.93	The centrosome is duplicated during the S phase.
7.10.94	The two centrosomes will give rise to the mitotic spindle, the apparatus that orchestrates the movement of chromosomes during mitosis.
7.10.95	At the center of each animal cell, the centrosomes of animal cells are associated with a pair of rod-like objects, the centrioles, which are at right angles to each other.
7.10.96	Centrioles help organize cell division.
7.10.97	Centrioles are not present in the centrosomes of other eukaryotic species, such as plants and most fungi.
7.10.98	G2 Phase (Second Gap)
7.10.99	In the G2 phase, the cell replenishes its energy stores and synthesizes proteins necessary for chromosome manipulation.
7.10.100	Some cell organelles are duplicated, and the cytoskeleton is dismantled to provide resources for the mitotic phase.
7.10.101	There may be additional cell growth during G2.
7.10.102	The final preparations for the mitotic phase must be completed before the cell is able to enter the first stage of mitosis.
7.10.103	The Mitotic Phase
7.10.104	The mitotic phase is a multistep process during which the duplicated chromosomes are aligned, separated, and move into two new, identical daughter cells.
7.10.105	The first portion of the mitotic phase is called karyokinesis, or nuclear division.
7.10.106	The second portion of the mitotic phase, called cytokinesis, is the physical separation of the cytoplasmic components into the two daughter cells.
7.10.107	Karyokinesis (Mitosis) Karyokinesis, also known as mitosis, is divided into a series of phases—prophase, prometaphase, metaphase, anaphase, and telophase—that result in the division of the cell nucleus (Figure 10.6).
7.10.108	Karyokinesis is also called mitosis.
7.10.109	During prophase, the “first phase,” the nuclear envelope starts to dissociate into small vesicles, and the membranous organelles (such as the Golgi complex or Golgi apparatus, and endoplasmic reticulum), fragment and disperse toward the periphery of the cell.
7.10.110	The nucleolus disappears (disperses).
7.10.111	The centrosomes begin to move to opposite poles of the cell.
7.10.112	Microtubules that will form the mitotic spindle extend between the centrosomes, pushing them farther apart as the microtubule fibers lengthen.
7.10.113	The sister chromatids begin to coil more tightly with the aid of condensin proteins and become visible under a light microscope.
7.10.114	During prometaphase, the “first change phase,” many processes that were begun in prophase continue to advance.
7.10.115	The remnants of the nuclear envelope fragment.
7.10.116	The mitotic spindle continues to develop as more microtubules assemble and stretch across the length of the former nuclear area.
7.10.117	Chromosomes become more condensed and discrete.
7.10.118	Each sister chromatid develops a protein structure called a kinetochore in the centromeric region (Figure 10.7).
7.10.119	The proteins of the kinetochore attract and bind mitotic spindle microtubules.
7.10.120	As the spindle microtubules extend from the centrosomes, some of these microtubules come into contact with and firmly bind to the kinetochores.
7.10.121	Once a mitotic fiber attaches to a chromosome, the chromosome will be oriented until the kinetochores of sister chromatids face the opposite poles.
7.10.122	Eventually, all the sister chromatids will be attached via their kinetochores to microtubules from opposing poles.
7.10.123	Spindle microtubules that do not engage the chromosomes are called polar microtubules.
7.10.124	These microtubules overlap each other midway between the two poles and contribute to cell elongation.
7.10.125	Astral microtubules are located near the poles, aid in spindle orientation, and are required for the regulation of mitosis.
7.10.126	During prometaphase, mitotic spindle microtubules from opposite poles attach to each sister chromatid at the kinetochore.
7.10.127	In anaphase, the connection between the sister chromatids breaks down, and the microtubules pull the chromosomes toward opposite poles.
7.10.128	During metaphase, the “change phase,” all the chromosomes are aligned in a plane called the metaphase plate, or the equatorial plane, midway between the two poles of the cell.
7.10.129	The sister chromatids are still tightly attached to each other by cohesin proteins.
7.10.130	At this time, the chromosomes are maximally condensed.
7.10.131	During anaphase, the “upward phase,” the cohesin proteins degrade, and the sister chromatids separate at the centromere.
7.10.132	Each chromatid, now called a chromosome, is pulled rapidly toward the centrosome to which its microtubule is attached.
7.10.133	The cell becomes visibly elongated (oval shaped) as the polar microtubules slide against each other at the metaphase plate where they overlap.
7.10.134	During telophase, the “distance phase,” the chromosomes reach the opposite poles and begin to decondense (unravel), relaxing into a chromatin configuration.
7.10.135	The mitotic spindles are depolymerized into tubulin monomers that will be used to assemble cytoskeletal components for each daughter cell.
7.10.136	Nuclear envelopes form around the chromosomes, and nucleosomes appear within the nuclear area.
7.10.137	Cytokinesis Cytokinesis, or “cell motion,” is the second main stage of the mitotic phase during which cell division is completed via the physical separation of the cytoplasmic components into two daughter cells.
7.10.138	Division is not complete until the cell components have been apportioned and completely separated into the two daughter cells.
7.10.139	Although the stages of mitosis are similar for most eukaryotes, the process of cytokinesis is quite different for eukaryotes that have cell walls, such as plant cells.
7.10.140	In cells such as animal cells that lack cell walls, cytokinesis follows the onset of anaphase.
7.10.141	A contractile ring composed of actin filaments forms just inside the plasma membrane at the former metaphase plate.
7.10.142	The actin filaments pull the equator of the cell inward, forming a fissure.
7.10.143	This fissure, or “crack
7.10.144	,” is called the cleavage furrow.
7.10.145	The furrow deepens as the actin ring contracts, and eventually the membrane is cleaved in two (Figure 10.8).
7.10.146	In plant cells, a new cell wall must form between the daughter cells.
7.10.147	During interphase, the Golgi apparatus accumulates enzymes, structural proteins, and glucose molecules prior to breaking into vesicles and dispersing throughout the dividing cell.
7.10.148	During telophase, these Golgi vesicles are transported on microtubules to form a phragmoplast (a vesicular structure) at the metaphase plate.
7.10.149	There, the vesicles fuse and coalesce from the center toward the cell walls; this structure is called a cell plate.
7.10.150	As more vesicles fuse, the cell plate enlarges until it merges with the cell walls at the periphery of the cell.
7.10.151	Enzymes use the glucose that has accumulated between the membrane layers to build a new cell wall.
7.10.152	The Golgi membranes become parts of the plasma membrane on either side of the new cell wall.
7.10.153	During cytokinesis in animal cells, a ring of actin filaments forms at the metaphase plate.
7.10.154	The ring contracts, forming a cleavage furrow, which divides the cell in two.
7.10.155	In plant cells, Golgi vesicles coalesce at the former metaphase plate, forming a phragmoplast.
7.10.156	A cell plate formed by the fusion of the vesicles of the phragmoplast grows from the center toward the cell walls, and the membranes of the vesicles fuse to form a plasma membrane that divides the cell in two.
7.10.157	G0
7.10.158	Phase Not all cells adhere to the classic cell cycle pattern in which a newly formed daughter cell immediately enters the preparatory phases of interphase, closely followed by the mitotic phase.
7.10.159	Cells in G0 phase are not actively preparing to divide.
7.10.160	The cell is in a quiescent (inactive) stage that occurs when cells exit the cell cycle.
7.10.161	Some cells enter G0 temporarily until an external signal triggers the onset of G1.
7.10.162	Other cells that never or rarely divide, such as mature cardiac muscle and nerve cells, remain in G0 permanently.
7.10.163	The length of the cell cycle is highly variable, even within the cells of a single organism.
7.10.164	In humans, the frequency of cell turnover ranges from a few hours in early embryonic development, to an average of two to five days for epithelial cells, and to an entire human lifetime spent in G0 by specialized cells, such as cortical neurons or cardiac muscle cells.
7.10.165	There is also variation in the time that a cell spends in each phase of the cell cycle.
7.10.166	When fast-dividing mammalian cells are grown in culture (outside the body under optimal growing conditions), the length of the cycle is about 24 hours.
7.10.167	In rapidly dividing human cells with a 24-hour cell cycle, the G1 phase lasts approximately nine hours, the S phase lasts 10 hours, the G2 phase lasts about four and one-half hours, and the M phase lasts approximately one-half hour.
7.10.168	In early embryos of fruit flies, the cell cycle is completed in about eight minutes.
7.10.169	The timing of events in the cell cycle is controlled by mechanisms that are both internal and external to the cell.
7.10.170	Regulation of the Cell Cycle by External Events
7.10.171	Both the initiation and inhibition of cell division are triggered by events external to the cell when it is about to begin the replication process.
7.10.172	An event may be as simple as the death of a nearby cell or as sweeping as the release of growthpromoting hormones, such as human growth hormone (HGH).
7.10.173	A lack of HGH can inhibit cell division, resulting in dwarfism, whereas too much HGH can result in gigantism.
7.10.174	Crowding of cells can also inhibit cell division.
7.10.175	Another factor that can initiate cell division is the size of the cell; as a cell grows, it becomes inefficient due to its decreasing surface-tovolume ratio.
7.10.176	The solution to this problem is to divide.
7.10.177	Whatever the source of the message, the cell receives the signal, and a series of events within the cell allows it to proceed into interphase.
7.10.178	Moving forward from this initiation point, every parameter required during each cell cycle phase must be met or the cycle cannot progress.
7.10.179	Regulation at Internal Checkpoints
7.10.180	It is essential that the daughter cells produced be exact duplicates of the parent cell.
7.10.181	Mistakes in the duplication or distribution of the chromosomes lead to mutations that may be passed forward to every new cell produced from an abnormal cell.
7.10.182	To prevent a compromised cell from continuing to divide, there are internal control mechanisms that operate at three main cell cycle checkpoints.
7.10.183	A checkpoint is one of several points in the eukaryotic cell cycle at which the progression of a cell to the next stage in the cycle can be halted until conditions are favorable.
7.10.184	These checkpoints occur near the end of G1, at the G2/M transition, and during metaphase.
7.10.185	The cell cycle is controlled at three checkpoints.
7.10.186	The integrity of the DNA is assessed at the G1 checkpoint.
7.10.187	Proper chromosome duplication is assessed at the G2 checkpoint.
7.10.188	Attachment of each kinetochore to a spindle fiber is assessed at the M checkpoint.
7.10.189	The G1 Checkpoint
7.10.190	The G1 checkpoint determines whether all conditions are favorable for cell division to proceed.
7.10.191	The G1 checkpoint, also called the restriction point (in yeast), is a point at which the cell irreversibly commits to the cell division process.
7.10.192	External influences, such as growth factors, play a large role in carrying the cell past the G1 checkpoint.
7.10.193	In addition to adequate reserves and cell size, there is a check for genomic DNA damage at the G1 checkpoint.
7.10.194	A cell that does not meet all the requirements will not be allowed to progress into the S phase.
7.10.195	The cell can halt the cycle and attempt to remedy the problematic condition, or the cell can advance into G0 and await further signals when conditions improve.
7.10.196	The G2 Checkpoint The G2 checkpoint bars entry into the mitotic phase if certain conditions are not met.
7.10.197	As at the G1 checkpoint, cell size and protein reserves are assessed.
7.10.198	However, the most important role of the G2 checkpoint is to ensure that all of the chromosomes have been replicated and that the replicated DNA is not damaged.
7.10.199	If the checkpoint mechanisms detect problems with the DNA, the cell cycle is halted, and the cell attempts to either complete DNA replication or repair the damaged DNA.
7.10.200	The M Checkpoint The M checkpoint occurs near the end of the metaphase stage of karyokinesis.
7.10.201	The M checkpoint is also known as the spindle checkpoint, because it determines whether all the sister chromatids are correctly attached to the spindle microtubules.
7.10.202	Because the separation of the sister chromatids during anaphase is an irreversible step, the cycle will not proceed until the kinetochores of each pair of sister chromatids are firmly anchored to at least two spindle fibers arising from opposite poles of the cell.
7.10.203	Regulator Molecules of the Cell Cycle
7.10.204	In addition to the internally controlled checkpoints, there are two groups of intracellular molecules that regulate the cell cycle.
7.10.205	These regulatory molecules either promote progress of the cell to the next phase (positive regulation) or halt the cycle (negative regulation).
7.10.206	Regulator molecules may act individually, or they can influence the activity or production of other regulatory proteins.
7.10.207	Therefore, the failure of a single regulator may have almost no effect on the cell cycle, especially if more than one mechanism controls the same event.
7.10.208	Conversely, the effect of a deficient or non-functioning regulator can be wide-ranging and possibly fatal to the cell if multiple processes are affected.
7.10.209	Positive Regulation of the Cell Cycle
7.10.210	Two groups of proteins, called cyclins and cyclin-dependent kinases (Cdks), are responsible for the progress of the cell through the various checkpoints.
7.10.211	The levels of the four cyclin proteins fluctuate throughout the cell cycle in a predictable pattern (Figure 10.11).
7.10.212	Increases in the concentration of cyclin proteins are triggered by both external and internal signals.
7.10.213	After the cell moves to the next stage of the cell cycle, the cyclins that were active in the previous stage are degraded.
7.10.214	The concentrations of cyclin proteins change throughout the cell cycle.
7.10.215	There is a direct correlation between cyclin accumulation and the three major cell cycle checkpoints.
7.10.216	Also note the sharp decline of cyclin levels following each checkpoint (the transition between phases of the cell cycle), as cyclin is degraded by cytoplasmic enzymes.
7.10.217	Cyclins regulate the cell cycle only when they are tightly bound to Cdks.
7.10.218	To be fully active, the Cdk/cyclin complex must also be phosphorylated in specific locations.
7.10.219	Like all kinases, Cdks are enzymes (kinases) that phosphorylate other proteins.
7.10.220	Phosphorylation activates the protein by changing its shape.
7.10.221	The proteins phosphorylated by Cdks are involved in advancing the cell to the next phase.
7.10.222	(Figure 10.12).
7.10.223	The levels of Cdk proteins are relatively stable throughout the cell cycle; however, the concentrations of cyclin fluctuate and determine when Cdk/cyclin complexes form.
7.10.224	The different cyclins and Cdks bind at specific points in the cell cycle and thus regulate different checkpoints.
7.10.225	Cyclin-dependent kinases (Cdks) are protein kinases that, when fully activated, can phosphorylate and thus activate other proteins that advance the cell cycle past a checkpoint.
7.10.226	To become fully activated, a Cdk must bind to a cyclin protein and then be phosphorylated by another kinase.
7.10.227	Since the cyclic fluctuations of cyclin levels are based on the timing of the cell cycle and not on specific events, regulation of the cell cycle usually occurs by either the Cdk molecules alone or the Cdk/cyclin complexes.
7.10.228	Without a specific concentration of fully activated cyclin/Cdk complexes, the cell cycle cannot proceed through the checkpoints.
7.10.229	Although the cyclins are the main regulatory molecules that determine the forward momentum of the cell cycle, there are several other mechanisms that fine-tune the progress of the cycle with negative, rather than positive, effects.
7.10.230	These mechanisms essentially block the progression of the cell cycle until problematic conditions are resolved.
7.10.231	Molecules that prevent the full activation of Cdks are called Cdk inhibitors.
7.10.232	Many of these inhibitor molecules directly or indirectly monitor a particular cell cycle event.
7.10.233	The block placed on Cdks by inhibitor molecules will not be removed until the specific event that the inhibitor monitors is completed.
7.10.234	Negative Regulation of the Cell Cycle
7.10.235	The second group of cell cycle regulatory molecules are negative regulators.
7.10.236	Negative regulators halt the cell cycle.
7.10.237	Remember that in positive regulation, active molecules cause the cycle to progress.
7.10.238	The best understood negative regulatory molecules are retinoblastoma protein (Rb), p53, and p21.
7.10.239	Retinoblastoma proteins are a group of tumor-suppressor proteins common in many cells.
7.10.240	The 53 and 21 designations refer to the functional molecular masses of the proteins (p) in kilodaltons.
7.10.241	Much of what is known about cell cycle regulation comes from research conducted with cells that have lost regulatory control.
7.10.242	All three of these regulatory proteins were discovered to be damaged or non-functional in cells that had begun to replicate uncontrollably (became cancerous).
7.10.243	In each case, the main cause of the unchecked progress through the cell cycle was a faulty copy of the regulatory protein.
7.10.244	Rb, p53, and p21 act primarily at the G1 checkpoint.
7.10.245	p53 is a multi-functional protein that has a major impact on the commitment of a cell to division because it acts when there is damaged DNA in cells that are undergoing the preparatory processes during G1.
7.10.246	If damaged DNA is detected, p53 halts the cell cycle and recruits enzymes to repair the DNA.
7.10.247	If the DNA cannot be repaired, p53 can trigger apoptosis, or cell suicide, to prevent the duplication of damaged chromosomes.
7.10.248	As p53 levels rise, the production of p21 is triggered.
7.10.249	p21 enforces the halt in the cycle dictated by p53 by binding to and inhibiting the activity of the Cdk/cyclin complexes.
7.10.250	As a cell is exposed to more stress, higher levels of p53 and p21 accumulate, making it less likely that the cell will move into the S phase.
7.10.251	Rb exerts its regulatory influence on other positive regulator proteins.
7.10.252	Chiefly, Rb monitors cell size.
7.10.253	In the active, dephosphorylated state, Rb binds to proteins called transcription factors, most commonly, E2F (Figure 10.13).
7.10.254	Transcription factors
7.10.255	“turn on” specific genes, allowing the production of proteins encoded by that gene.
7.10.256	When Rb is bound to E2F, production of proteins necessary for the G1/S transition is blocked.
7.10.257	As the cell increases in size, Rb is slowly phosphorylated until it becomes inactivated.
7.10.258	Rb releases E2F, which can now turn on the gene that produces the transition protein, and this particular block is removed.
7.10.259	For the cell to move past each of the checkpoints, all positive regulators must be “turned on,” and all negative regulators must be
7.10.260	“turned off.
7.10.261	”
7.10.262	Cancer comprises many different diseases caused by a common mechanism: uncontrolled cell growth.
7.10.263	Despite the redundancy and overlapping levels of cell cycle control, errors do occur.
7.10.264	One of the critical processes monitored by the cell cycle checkpoint surveillance mechanism is the proper replication of DNA during the S phase.
7.10.265	Even when all of the cell cycle controls are fully functional, a small percentage of replication errors (mutations) will be passed on to the daughter cells.
7.10.266	If changes to the DNA nucleotide sequence occur within a coding portion of a gene and are not corrected, a gene mutation results.
7.10.267	All cancers start when a gene mutation gives rise to a faulty protein that plays a key role in cell reproduction.
7.10.268	The change in the cell that results from the malformed protein may be minor: perhaps a slight delay in the binding of Cdk to cyclin or an Rb protein that detaches from its target DNA while still phosphorylated.
7.10.269	Even minor mistakes, however, may allow subsequent mistakes to occur more readily.
7.10.270	Over and over, small uncorrected errors are passed from the parent cell to the daughter cells and amplified as each generation produces more non-functional proteins from uncorrected DNA damage.
7.10.271	Eventually, the pace of the cell cycle speeds up as the effectiveness of the control and repair mechanisms decreases.
7.10.272	Uncontrolled growth of the mutated cells outpaces the growth of normal cells in the area, and a tumor (“-oma”) can result.
7.10.273	Proto-oncogenes
7.10.274	The genes that code for the positive cell cycle regulators are called proto-oncogenes.
7.10.275	Proto-oncogenes are normal genes that, when mutated in certain ways, become oncogenes, genes that cause a cell to become cancerous.
7.10.276	Consider what might happen to the cell cycle in a cell with a recently acquired oncogene.
7.10.277	In most instances, the alteration of the DNA sequence will result in a less functional (or non-functional) protein.
7.10.278	The result is detrimental to the cell and will likely prevent the cell from completing the cell cycle; however, the organism is not harmed because the mutation will not be carried forward.
7.10.279	If a cell cannot reproduce, the mutation is not propagated and the damage is minimal.
7.10.280	Occasionally, however, a gene mutation causes a change that increases the activity of a positive regulator.
7.10.281	For example, a mutation that allows Cdk to be activated without being partnered with cyclin could push the cell cycle past a checkpoint before all of the required conditions are met.
7.10.282	If the resulting daughter cells are too damaged to undergo further cell divisions, the mutation would not be propagated and no harm would come to the organism.
7.10.283	However, if the atypical daughter cells are able to undergo further cell divisions, subsequent generations of cells will probably accumulate even more mutations, some possibly in additional genes that regulate the cell cycle.
7.10.284	The Cdk gene in the above example is only one of many genes that are considered proto-oncogenes.
7.10.285	In addition to the cell cycle regulatory proteins, any protein that influences the cycle can be altered in such a way as to override cell cycle checkpoints.
7.10.286	An oncogene is any gene that, when altered, leads to an increase in the rate of cell cycle progression.
7.10.287	Tumor Suppressor Genes
7.10.288	Like proto-oncogenes, many of the negative cell cycle regulatory proteins were discovered in cells that had become cancerous.
7.10.289	Tumor suppressor genes are segments of DNA that code for negative regulator proteins, the type of regulators that, when activated, can prevent the cell from undergoing uncontrolled division.
7.10.290	The collective function of the bestunderstood tumor suppressor gene proteins, Rb, p53, and p21, is to put up a roadblock to cell cycle progression until certain events are completed.
7.10.291	A cell that carries a mutated form of a negative regulator might not be able to halt the cell cycle if there is a problem.
7.10.292	Tumor suppressors are similar to brakes in a vehicle: Malfunctioning brakes can contribute to a car crash.
7.10.293	Mutated p53 genes have been identified in more than one-half of all human tumor cells.
7.10.294	This discovery is not surprising in light of the multiple roles that the p53 protein plays at the G1 checkpoint.
7.10.295	A cell with a faulty p53 may fail to detect errors present in the genomic DNA (Figure 10.14).
7.10.296	Even if a partially functional p53 does identify the mutations, it may no longer be able to signal the necessary DNA repair enzymes.
7.10.297	Either way, damaged DNA will remain uncorrected.
7.10.298	At this point, a functional p53 will deem the cell unsalvageable and trigger programmed cell death (apoptosis).
7.10.299	The damaged version of p53 found in cancer cells, however, cannot trigger apoptosis.
7.10.300	The loss of p53 function has other repercussions for the cell cycle.
7.10.301	Mutated p53 might lose its ability to trigger p21 production.
7.10.302	Without adequate levels of p21, there is no effective block on Cdk activation.
7.10.303	Essentially, without a fully functional p53, the G1 checkpoint is severely compromised and the cell proceeds directly from G1 to S regardless of internal and external conditions.
7.10.304	At the completion of this shortened cell cycle, two daughter cells are produced that have inherited the mutated p53 gene.
7.10.305	Given the non-optimal conditions under which the parent cell reproduced, it is likely that the daughter cells will have acquired other mutations in addition to the faulty tumor suppressor gene.
7.10.306	Cells such as these daughter cells quickly accumulate both oncogenes and non-functional tumor suppressor genes.
7.10.307	Again, the result is tumor growth.
7.10.308	Prokaryotes, such as bacteria, propagate by binary fission.
7.10.309	For unicellular organisms, cell division is the only method to produce new individuals.
7.10.310	In both prokaryotic and eukaryotic cells, the outcome of cell reproduction is a pair of daughter cells that are genetically identical to the parent cell.
7.10.311	In unicellular organisms, daughter cells are individuals.
7.10.312	To achieve the outcome of cloned offspring, certain steps are essential.
7.10.313	The genomic DNA must be replicated and then allocated into the daughter cells; the cytoplasmic contents must also be divided to give both new cells the machinery to sustain life.
7.10.314	In bacterial cells, the genome consists of a single, circular DNA chromosome; therefore, the process of cell division is simplified.
7.10.315	Karyokinesis is unnecessary because there is no nucleus and thus no need to direct one copy of the multiple chromosomes into each daughter cell.
7.10.316	This type of cell division is called binary (prokaryotic) fission.
7.10.317	Binary Fission Due to the relative simplicity of the prokaryotes, the cell division process, called binary fission, is a less complicated and much more rapid process than cell division in eukaryotes.
7.10.318	The single, circular DNA chromosome of bacteria is not enclosed in a nucleus, but instead occupies a specific location, the nucleoid, within the cell (Figure 10.2).
7.10.319	Although the DNA of the nucleoid is associated with proteins that aid in packaging the molecule into a compact size, there are no histone proteins and thus no nucleosomes in prokaryotes.
7.10.320	The packing proteins of bacteria are, however, related to the cohesin and condensin proteins involved in the chromosome compaction of eukaryotes.
7.10.321	The bacterial chromosome is attached to the plasma membrane at about the midpoint of the cell.
7.10.322	The starting point of replication, the origin, is close to the binding site of the chromosome to the plasma membrane (Figure 10.15).
7.10.323	Replication of the DNA is bidirectional, moving away from the origin on both strands of the loop simultaneously.
7.10.324	As the new double strands are formed, each origin point moves away from the cell wall attachment toward the opposite ends of the cell.
7.10.325	As the cell elongates, the growing membrane aids in the transport of the chromosomes.
7.10.326	After the chromosomes have cleared the midpoint of the elongated cell, cytoplasmic separation begins.
7.10.327	The formation of a ring composed of repeating units of a protein called FtsZ directs the partition between the nucleoids.
7.10.328	Formation of the FtsZ ring triggers the accumulation of other proteins that work together to recruit new membrane and cell wall materials to the site.
7.10.329	A septum is formed between the nucleoids, extending gradually from the periphery toward the center of the cell.
7.10.330	When the new cell walls are in place, the daughter cells separate.
7.11.0	Introduction
7.11.1	The ability to reproduce in kind is a basic characteristic of all living things.
7.11.2	In kind means that the offspring of any organism closely resemble their parent or parents.
7.11.3	Hippopotamuses give birth to hippopotamus calves, Joshua trees produce seeds from which Joshua tree seedlings emerge, and adult flamingos lay eggs that hatch into flamingo chicks.
7.11.4	In kind does not generally mean exactly the same.
7.11.5	Whereas many unicellular organisms and a few multicellular organisms can produce genetically identical clones of themselves through cell division, many single-celled organisms and most multicellular organisms reproduce regularly using another method.
7.11.6	Sexual reproduction is the production by parents of two haploid cells and the fusion of two haploid cells to form a single, unique diploid cell.
7.11.7	In most plants and animals, through tens of rounds of mitotic cell division, this diploid cell will develop into an adult organism.
7.11.8	Haploid cells that are part of the sexual reproductive cycle are produced by a type of cell division called meiosis.
7.11.9	Sexual reproduction, specifically meiosis and fertilization, introduces variation into offspring that may account for the evolutionary success of sexual reproduction.
7.11.10	The vast majority of eukaryotic organisms, both multicellular and unicellular, can or must employ some form of meiosis and fertilization to reproduce.
7.11.11	Sexual reproduction requires fertilization, the union of two cells from two individual organisms.
7.11.12	If those two cells each contain one set of chromosomes, then the resulting cell contains two sets of chromosomes.
7.11.13	Haploid cells contain one set of chromosomes.
7.11.14	Cells containing two sets of chromosomes are called diploid.
7.11.15	The number of sets of chromosomes in a cell is called its ploidy level.
7.11.16	If the reproductive cycle is to continue, then the diploid cell must somehow reduce its number of chromosome sets before fertilization can occur again, or there will be a continual doubling in the number of chromosome sets in every generation.
7.11.17	So, in addition to fertilization, sexual reproduction includes a nuclear division that reduces the number of chromosome sets.
7.11.18	Most animals and plants are diploid, containing two sets of chromosomes.
7.11.19	In each somatic cell of the organism (all cells of a multicellular organism except the gametes or reproductive cells), the nucleus contains two copies of each chromosome, called homologous chromosomes.
7.11.20	Somatic cells are sometimes referred to
7.11.21	as “body” cells.
7.11.22	Homologous chromosomes are matched pairs containing the same genes in identical locations along their length.
7.11.23	Diploid organisms inherit one copy of each homologous chromosome from each parent; all together, they are considered a full set of chromosomes.
7.11.24	Haploid cells, containing a single copy of each homologous chromosome, are found only within structures that give rise to either gametes or spores.
7.11.25	Spores are haploid cells that can produce a haploid organism or can fuse with another spore to form a diploid cell.
7.11.26	All animals and most plants produce eggs and sperm, or gametes.
7.11.27	Some plants and all fungi produce spores.
7.11.28	The nuclear division that forms haploid cells, which is called meiosis, is related to mitosis.
7.11.29	As you have learned, mitosis is the part of a cell reproduction cycle that results in identical daughter nuclei that are also genetically identical to the original parent nucleus.
7.11.30	In mitosis, both the parent and the daughter nuclei are at the same ploidy level—diploid for most plants and animals.
7.11.31	Meiosis employs many of the same mechanisms as mitosis.
7.11.32	However, the starting nucleus is always diploid and the nuclei that result at the end of a meiotic cell division are haploid.
7.11.33	To achieve this reduction in chromosome number, meiosis consists of one round of chromosome duplication and two rounds of nuclear division.
7.11.34	Because the events that occur during each of the division stages are analogous to the events of mitosis, the same stage names are assigned.
7.11.35	However, because there are two rounds of division, the major process and the stages are designated with a “
7.11.36	I” or a “II.
7.11.37	”
7.11.38	Thus, meiosis I is the first round of meiotic division and consists of prophase I, prometaphase I, and so on.
7.11.39	Meiosis II, in which the second round of meiotic division takes place, includes prophase II, prometaphase II, and so on.
7.11.40	Meiosis I
7.11.41	Meiosis is preceded by an interphase consisting of the G1, S, and G2 phases, which are nearly identical to the phases preceding mitosis.
7.11.42	The G1 phase, which is also called the first gap phase, is the first phase of the interphase and is focused on cell growth.
7.11.43	The S phase is the second phase of interphase, during which the DNA of the chromosomes is replicated.
7.11.44	Finally, the G2 phase, also called the second gap phase, is the third and final phase of interphase; in this phase, the cell undergoes the final preparations for meiosis.
7.11.45	During DNA duplication in the S phase, each chromosome is replicated to produce two identical copies, called sister chromatids, that are held together at the centromere by cohesin proteins.
7.11.46	Cohesin holds the chromatids together until anaphase II.
7.11.47	The centrosomes, which are the structures that organize the microtubules of the meiotic spindle, also replicate.
7.11.48	This prepares the cell to enter prophase I, the first meiotic phase.
7.11.49	Prophase I
7.11.50	Early in prophase I, before the chromosomes can be seen clearly microscopically, the homologous chromosomes are attached at their tips to the nuclear envelope by proteins.
7.11.51	As the nuclear envelope begins to break down, the proteins associated with homologous chromosomes bring the pair close to each other.
7.11.52	Recall that, in mitosis, homologous chromosomes do not pair together.
7.11.53	In mitosis, homologous chromosomes line up end-to-end so that when they divide, each daughter cell receives a sister chromatid from both members of the homologous pair.
7.11.54	The synaptonemal complex, a lattice of proteins between the homologous chromosomes, first forms at specific locations and then spreads to cover the entire length of the chromosomes.
7.11.55	The tight pairing of the homologous chromosomes is called synapsis.
7.11.56	In synapsis, the genes on the chromatids of the homologous chromosomes are aligned precisely with each other.
7.11.57	The synaptonemal complex supports the exchange of chromosomal segments between non-sister homologous chromatids, a process called crossing over.
7.11.58	Crossing over can be observed visually after the exchange as chiasmata (singular = chiasma)
7.11.59	(Figure 11.2).
7.11.60	In species such as humans, even though the X and Y sex chromosomes are not homologous (most of their genes differ), they have a small region of homology that allows the X and Y chromosomes to pair up during prophase I.
7.11.61	A partial synaptonemal complex develops only between the regions of homology.
7.11.62	Early in prophase I, homologous chromosomes come together to form a synapse.
7.11.63	The chromosomes are bound tightly together and in perfect alignment by a protein lattice called a synaptonemal complex and by cohesin proteins at the centromere.
7.11.64	Located at intervals along the synaptonemal complex are large protein assemblies called recombination nodules.
7.11.65	These assemblies mark the points of later chiasmata and mediate the multistep process of crossover—or genetic recombination—between the non-sister chromatids.
7.11.66	Near the recombination nodule on each chromatid, the double-stranded DNA is cleaved, the cut ends are modified, and a new connection is made between the non-sister chromatids.
7.11.67	As prophase I progresses, the synaptonemal complex begins to break down and the chromosomes begin to condense.
7.11.68	When the synaptonemal complex is gone, the homologous chromosomes remain attached to each other at the centromere and at chiasmata.
7.11.69	The chiasmata remain until anaphase I.
7.11.70	The number of chiasmata varies according to the species and the length of the chromosome.
7.11.71	There must be at least one chiasma per chromosome for proper separation of homologous chromosomes during meiosis I, but there may be as many as 25.
7.11.72	Following crossover, the synaptonemal complex breaks down and the cohesin connection between homologous pairs is also removed.
7.11.73	At the end of prophase I, the pairs are held together only at the chiasmata (Figure 11.3) and are called tetrads because the four sister chromatids of each pair of homologous chromosomes are now visible.
7.11.74	The crossover events are the first source of genetic variation in the nuclei produced by meiosis.
7.11.75	A single crossover event between homologous non-sister chromatids leads to a reciprocal exchange of equivalent DNA between a maternal chromosome and a paternal chromosome.
7.11.76	Now, when that sister chromatid is moved into a gamete cell it will carry some DNA from one parent of the individual and some DNA from the other parent.
7.11.77	The sister recombinant chromatid has a combination of maternal and paternal genes that did not exist before the crossover.
7.11.78	Multiple crossovers in an arm of the chromosome have the same effect, exchanging segments of DNA to create recombinant chromosomes.
7.11.79	Crossover occurs between non-sister chromatids of homologous chromosomes.
7.11.80	The result is an exchange of genetic material between homologous chromosomes.
7.11.81	Prometaphase I
7.11.82	The key event in prometaphase
7.11.83	I is the attachment of the spindle fiber microtubules to the kinetochore proteins at the centromeres.
7.11.84	Kinetochore proteins are multiprotein complexes that bind the centromeres of a chromosome to the microtubules of the mitotic spindle.
7.11.85	Microtubules grow from centrosomes placed at opposite poles of the cell.
7.11.86	The microtubules move toward the middle of the cell and attach to one of the two fused homologous chromosomes.
7.11.87	The microtubules attach at each chromosomes' kinetochores.
7.11.88	With each member of the homologous pair attached to opposite poles of the cell, in the next phase, the microtubules can pull the homologous pair apart.
7.11.89	A spindle fiber that has attached to a kinetochore is called a kinetochore microtubule.
7.11.90	At the end of prometaphase I, each tetrad is attached to microtubules from both poles, with one homologous chromosome facing each pole.
7.11.91	The homologous chromosomes are still held together at chiasmata.
7.11.92	In addition, the nuclear membrane has broken down entirely.
7.11.93	Metaphase I
7.11.94	During metaphase I, the homologous chromosomes are arranged in the center of the cell with the kinetochores facing opposite poles.
7.11.95	The homologous pairs orient themselves randomly at the equator.
7.11.96	For example, if the two homologous members of chromosome 1 are labeled a and b, then the chromosomes could line up a-b, or b-a.
7.11.97	This is important in determining the genes carried by a gamete, as each will only receive one of the two homologous chromosomes.
7.11.98	Recall that homologous chromosomes are not identical.
7.11.99	They contain slight differences in their genetic information, causing each gamete to have a unique genetic makeup.
7.11.100	This randomness is the physical basis for the creation of the second form of genetic variation in offspring.
7.11.101	Consider that the homologous chromosomes of a sexually reproducing organism are originally inherited as two separate sets, one from each parent.
7.11.102	Using humans as an example, one set of 23 chromosomes is present in the egg donated by the mother.
7.11.103	The father provides the other set of 23 chromosomes in the sperm that fertilizes the egg.
7.11.104	Every cell of the multicellular offspring has copies of the original two sets of homologous chromosomes.
7.11.105	In prophase I of meiosis, the homologous chromosomes form the tetrads.
7.11.106	In metaphase I, these pairs line up at the midway point between the two poles of the cell to form the metaphase plate.
7.11.107	Because there is an equal chance that a microtubule fiber will encounter a maternally or paternally inherited chromosome, the arrangement of the tetrads at the metaphase plate is random.
7.11.108	Any maternally inherited chromosome may face either pole.
7.11.109	Any paternally inherited chromosome may also face either pole.
7.11.110	The orientation of each tetrad is independent of the orientation of the other 22 tetrads.
7.11.111	This event—the random (or independent) assortment of homologous chromosomes at the metaphase plate—is the second mechanism that introduces variation into the gametes or spores.
7.11.112	In each cell that undergoes meiosis, the arrangement of the tetrads is different.
7.11.113	The number of variations is dependent on the number of chromosomes making up a set.
7.11.114	There are two possibilities for orientation at the metaphase plate; the possible number of alignments therefore equals 2n, where n is the number of chromosomes per set.
7.11.115	Humans have 23 chromosome pairs, which results in over eight million (223) possible genetically-distinct gametes.
7.11.116	This number does not include the variability that was previously created in the sister chromatids by crossover.
7.11.117	Given these two mechanisms, it is highly unlikely that any two haploid cells resulting from meiosis will have the same genetic composition (Figure 11.4).
7.11.118	To summarize the genetic consequences of meiosis I, the maternal and paternal genes are recombined by crossover events that occur between each homologous pair during prophase I.
7.11.119	In addition, the random assortment of tetrads on the metaphase plate produces a unique combination of maternal and paternal chromosomes that will make their way into the gametes.
7.11.120	Random, independent assortment during metaphase I can be demonstrated by considering a cell with a set of two chromosomes (n = 2).
7.11.121	In this case, there are two possible arrangements at the equatorial plane in metaphase
7.11.122	I.
7.11.123	The total possible number of different gametes is 2n, where n equals the number of chromosomes in a set.
7.11.124	In this example, there are four possible genetic combinations for the gametes.
7.11.125	With n = 23 in human cells, there are over 8 million possible combinations of paternal and maternal chromosomes.
7.11.126	Anaphase I
7.11.127	In anaphase I, the microtubules pull the linked chromosomes apart.
7.11.128	The sister chromatids remain tightly bound together at the centromere.
7.11.129	The chiasmata are broken in anaphase I as the microtubules attached to the fused kinetochores pull the homologous chromosomes apart (Figure 11.5).
7.11.130	Telophase I and Cytokinesis
7.11.131	In telophase, the separated chromosomes arrive at opposite poles.
7.11.132	The remainder of the typical telophase events may or may not occur, depending on the species.
7.11.133	In some organisms, the chromosomes decondense and nuclear envelopes form around the chromatids in telophase I.
7.11.134	In other organisms, cytokinesis—the physical separation of the cytoplasmic components into two daughter cells—occurs without reformation of the nuclei.
7.11.135	In nearly all species of animals and some fungi, cytokinesis separates the cell contents via a cleavage furrow (constriction of the actin ring that leads to cytoplasmic division).
7.11.136	In plants, a cell plate is formed during cell cytokinesis by Golgi vesicles fusing at the metaphase plate.
7.11.137	This cell plate will ultimately lead to the formation of cell walls that separate the two daughter cells.
7.11.138	Two haploid cells are the end result of the first meiotic division.
7.11.139	The cells are haploid because at each pole, there is just one of each pair of the homologous chromosomes.
7.11.140	Therefore, only one full set of the chromosomes is present.
7.11.141	This is why the cells are considered haploid—
7.11.142	there is only one chromosome set, even though each homolog still consists of two sister chromatids.
7.11.143	Recall that sister chromatids are merely duplicates of one of the two homologous chromosomes (except for changes that occurred during crossing over).
7.11.144	In meiosis II, these two sister chromatids will separate, creating four haploid daughter cells.
7.11.145	Meiosis II
7.11.146	In some species, cells enter a brief interphase, or interkinesis, before entering meiosis II.
7.11.147	Interkinesis lacks an S phase, so chromosomes are not duplicated.
7.11.148	The two cells produced in meiosis I go through the events of meiosis II in synchrony.
7.11.149	During meiosis II, the sister chromatids within the two daughter cells separate, forming four new haploid gametes.
7.11.150	The mechanics of meiosis II is similar to mitosis, except that each dividing cell has only one set of homologous chromosomes.
7.11.151	Therefore, each cell has half the number of sister chromatids to separate out as a diploid cell undergoing mitosis.
7.11.152	Prophase II
7.11.153	If the chromosomes decondensed in telophase I, they condense again.
7.11.154	If nuclear envelopes were formed, they fragment into vesicles.
7.11.155	The centrosomes that were duplicated during interkinesis move away from each other toward opposite poles, and new spindles are formed.
7.11.156	Prometaphase II
7.11.157	The nuclear envelopes are completely broken down, and the spindle is fully formed.
7.11.158	Each sister chromatid forms an individual kinetochore that attaches to microtubules from opposite poles.
7.11.159	Metaphase II
7.11.160	The sister chromatids are maximally condensed and aligned at the equator of the cell.
7.11.161	Anaphase II
7.11.162	The sister chromatids are pulled apart by the kinetochore microtubules and move toward opposite poles.
7.11.163	Non-kinetochore microtubules elongate the cell.
7.11.164	The process of chromosome alignment differs between meiosis I and meiosis II.
7.11.165	In prometaphase I, microtubules attach to the fused kinetochores of homologous chromosomes, and the homologous chromosomes are arranged at the midpoint of the cell in metaphase I.
7.11.166	In anaphase I, the homologous chromosomes are separated.
7.11.167	In prometaphase II, microtubules attach to the kinetochores of sister chromatids, and the sister chromatids are arranged at the midpoint of the cells in metaphase II.
7.11.168	In anaphase II, the sister chromatids are separated.
7.11.169	Telophase II and Cytokinesis
7.11.170	The chromosomes arrive at opposite poles and begin to decondense.
7.11.171	Nuclear envelopes form around the chromosomes.
7.11.172	Cytokinesis separates the two cells into four unique haploid cells.
7.11.173	At this point, the newly formed nuclei are both haploid.
7.11.174	The cells produced are genetically unique because of the random assortment of paternal and maternal homologs and because of the recombining of maternal and paternal segments of chromosomes (with their sets of genes) that occurs during crossover.
7.11.175	The entire process of meiosis is outlined in Figure 11.6.
7.11.176	An animal cell with a diploid number of four (2n = 4) proceeds through the stages of meiosis to form four haploid daughter cells.
7.11.177	Comparing Meiosis and Mitosis Mitosis and meiosis are both forms of division of the nucleus in eukaryotic cells.
7.11.178	They share some similarities, but also exhibit distinct differences that lead to very different outcomes (Figure 11.7).
7.11.179	Mitosis is a single nuclear division that results in two nuclei that are usually partitioned into two new cells.
7.11.180	The nuclei resulting from a mitotic division are genetically identical to the original nucleus.
7.11.181	They have the same number of sets of chromosomes, one set in the case of haploid cells and two sets in the case of diploid cells.
7.11.182	In most plants and all animal species, it is typically diploid cells that undergo mitosis to form new diploid cells.
7.11.183	In contrast, meiosis consists of two nuclear divisions resulting in four nuclei that are usually partitioned into four new cells.
7.11.184	The nuclei resulting from meiosis are not genetically identical and they contain one chromosome set only.
7.11.185	This is half the number of chromosome sets in the original cell, which is diploid.
7.11.186	The main differences between mitosis and meiosis occur in meiosis I, which is a very different nuclear division than mitosis.
7.11.187	In meiosis I, the homologous chromosome pairs become associated with each other, are bound together with the synaptonemal complex, develop chiasmata and undergo crossover between sister chromatids, and line up along the metaphase plate in tetrads with kinetochore fibers from opposite spindle poles attached to each kinetochore of a homolog in a tetrad.
7.11.188	All of these events occur only in meiosis I. When the chiasmata resolve and the tetrad is broken up with the homologs moving to one pole or another, the ploidy level—
7.11.189	the number of sets of chromosomes in each future nucleus—has been reduced from two to one.
7.11.190	For this reason, meiosis I is referred to as a reduction division.
7.11.191	There is no such reduction in ploidy level during mitosis.
7.11.192	Meiosis II is much more analogous to a mitotic division.
7.11.193	In this case, the duplicated chromosomes (only one set of them) line up on the metaphase plate with divided kinetochores attached to kinetochore fibers from opposite poles.
7.11.194	During anaphase II, as in mitotic anaphase, the kinetochores divide and one sister chromatid—now referred to as a chromosome—is pulled to one pole while the other sister chromatid is pulled to the other pole.
7.11.195	If it were not for the fact that there had been crossover, the two products of each individual meiosis II division would be identical (like in mitosis).
7.11.196	Instead, they are different because there has always been at least one crossover per chromosome.
7.11.197	Meiosis II is not a reduction division because although there are fewer copies of the genome in the resulting cells, there is still one set of chromosomes, as there was at the end of meiosis I. Meiosis and mitosis are both preceded by one round of DNA replication; however, meiosis includes two nuclear divisions.
7.11.198	The four daughter cells resulting from meiosis are haploid and genetically distinct.
7.11.199	The daughter cells resulting from mitosis are diploid and identical to the parent cell.
7.11.200	Sexual reproduction was an early evolutionary innovation after the appearance of eukaryotic cells.
7.11.201	It appears to have been very successful because most eukaryotes are able to reproduce sexually, and in many animals, it is the only mode of reproduction.
7.11.202	And yet, scientists recognize some real disadvantages to sexual reproduction.
7.11.203	On the surface, creating offspring that are genetic clones of the parent appears to be a better system.
7.11.204	If the parent organism is successfully occupying a habitat, offspring with the same traits would be similarly successful.
7.11.205	There is also the obvious benefit to an organism that can produce offspring whenever circumstances are favorable by asexual budding, fragmentation, or asexual eggs.
7.11.206	These methods of reproduction do not require another organism of the opposite sex.
7.11.207	Indeed, some organisms that lead a solitary lifestyle have retained the ability to reproduce asexually.
7.11.208	In addition, in asexual populations, every individual is capable of reproduction.
7.11.209	In sexual populations, the males are not producing the offspring themselves, so in theory an asexual population could grow twice as fast.
7.11.210	However, multicellular organisms that exclusively depend on asexual reproduction are exceedingly rare.
7.11.211	Why is sexuality (and meiosis) so common?
7.11.212	This is one of the important unanswered questions in biology and has been the focus of much research beginning in the latter half of the twentieth century.
7.11.213	There are several possible explanations, one of which is that the variation that sexual reproduction creates among offspring is very important to the survival and reproduction of the population.
7.11.214	Thus, on average, a sexually reproducing population will leave more descendants than an otherwise similar asexually reproducing population.
7.11.215	The only source of variation in asexual organisms is mutation.
7.11.216	This is the ultimate source of variation in sexual organisms, but in addition, those different mutations are continually reshuffled from one generation to the next when different parents combine their unique genomes and the genes are mixed into different combinations by crossovers during prophase I and random assortment at metaphase I. Life Cycles of Sexually Reproducing Organisms Fertilization and meiosis alternate in sexual life cycles.
7.11.217	What happens between these two events depends on the organism.
7.11.218	The process of meiosis reduces the chromosome number by half.
7.11.219	Fertilization, the joining of two haploid gametes, restores the diploid condition.
7.11.220	There are three main categories of life cycles in multicellular organisms: diploid-dominant, in which the multicellular diploid stage is the most obvious life stage, such as with most animals including humans; haploid- dominant, in which the multicellular haploid stage is the most obvious life stage, such as with all fungi and some algae; and alternation of generations, in which the two stages are apparent to different degrees depending on the group, as with plants and some algae.
7.11.221	Diploid-Dominant Life
7.11.222	Cycle
7.11.223	Nearly all animals employ a diploid-dominant life-cycle strategy in which the only haploid cells produced by the organism are the gametes.
7.11.224	Early in the development of the embryo, specialized diploid cells, called germ cells, are produced within the gonads, such as the testes and ovaries.
7.11.225	Germ cells are capable of mitosis to perpetuate the cell line and meiosis to produce gametes.
7.11.226	Once the haploid gametes are formed, they lose the ability to divide again.
7.11.227	There is no multicellular haploid life stage.
7.11.228	Fertilization occurs with the fusion of two gametes, usually from different individuals, restoring the diploid state (Figure 11.8).
7.11.229	In animals, sexually reproducing adults form haploid gametes from diploid germ cells.
7.11.230	Fusion of the gametes gives rise to a fertilized egg cell, or zygote.
7.11.231	The zygote will undergo multiple rounds of mitosis to produce a multicellular offspring.
7.11.232	The germ cells are generated early in the development of the zygote.
7.11.233	Haploid-Dominant Life Cycle Most fungi and algae employ a life-cycle type in which the “body” of the organism—the ecologically important part of the life cycle—is haploid.
7.11.234	The haploid cells that make up the tissues of the dominant multicellular stage are formed by mitosis.
7.11.235	During sexual reproduction, specialized haploid cells from two individuals, designated the (+)
7.11.236	and (−) mating types, join to form a diploid zygote.
7.11.237	The zygote immediately undergoes meiosis to form four haploid cells called spores.
7.11.238	Although haploid like the “parents,” these spores contain a new genetic combination from two parents.
7.11.239	The spores can remain dormant for various time periods.
7.11.240	Eventually, when conditions are conducive, the spores form multicellular haploid structures by many rounds of mitosis (Figure 11.9).
7.11.241	Alternation of Generations
7.11.242	The third life-cycle type, employed by some algae and all plants, is a blend of the haploid-dominant and diploid-dominant extremes.
7.11.243	Species with alternation of generations have both haploid and diploid multicellular organisms as part of their life cycle.
7.11.244	The haploid multicellular plants are called gametophytes, because they produce gametes from specialized cells.
7.11.245	Meiosis is not directly involved in the production of gametes in this case, because the organism that produces the gametes is already a haploid.
7.11.246	Fertilization between the gametes forms a diploid zygote.
7.11.247	The zygote will undergo many rounds of mitosis and give rise to a diploid multicellular plant called a sporophyte.
7.11.248	Specialized cells of the sporophyte will undergo meiosis and produce haploid spores.
7.11.249	The spores will subsequently develop into the gametophytes (Figure 11.10).
7.11.250	Plants have a life cycle that alternates between a multicellular haploid organism and a multicellular diploid organism.
7.11.251	In some plants, such as ferns, both the haploid and diploid plant stages are free-living.
7.11.252	The diploid plant is called a sporophyte because it produces haploid spores by meiosis.
7.11.253	The spores develop into multicellular, haploid plants called gametophytes because they produce gametes.
7.11.254	The gametes of two individuals will fuse to form a diploid zygote that becomes the sporophyte.
7.11.255	Although all plants utilize some version of the alternation of generations, the relative size of the sporophyte and the gametophyte and the relationship between them vary greatly.
7.11.256	In plants such as moss, the gametophyte organism is the free-living plant, and the sporophyte is physically dependent on the gametophyte.
7.11.257	In other plants, such as ferns, both the gametophyte and sporophyte plants are free-living; however, the sporophyte is much larger.
7.11.258	In seed plants, such as magnolia trees and daisies, the gametophyte is composed of only a few cells and, in the case of the female gametophyte, is completely retained within the sporophyte.
7.11.259	Sexual reproduction takes many forms in multicellular organisms.
7.11.260	However, at some point in each type of life cycle, meiosis produces haploid cells that will fuse with the haploid cell of another organism.
7.11.261	The mechanisms of variation—crossover, random assortment of homologous chromosomes, and random fertilization—are present in all versions of sexual reproduction.
7.11.262	The fact that nearly every multicellular organism on Earth employs sexual reproduction is strong evidence for the benefits of producing offspring with unique gene combinations, though there are other possible benefits as well.
7.12.0	Experimenting with thousands of garden peas, Mendel uncovered the fundamentals of genetics.
7.12.1	Introduction Genetics is the study of heredity.
7.12.2	Johann Gregor Mendel set the framework for genetics long before chromosomes or genes had been identified, at a time when meiosis was not well understood.
7.12.3	Mendel selected a simple biological system and conducted methodical, quantitative analyses using large sample sizes.
7.12.4	Because of Mendel’s work, the fundamental principles of heredity were revealed.
7.12.5	We now know that genes, carried on chromosomes, are the basic functional units of heredity with the capability to be replicated, expressed, or mutated.
7.12.6	Today, the postulates put forth by Mendel
7.12.7	form the basis of classical, or Mendelian, genetics.
7.12.8	Not all genes are transmitted from parents to offspring according to Mendelian genetics, but Mendel’s experiments serve as an excellent starting point for thinking about inheritance.
7.12.9	Johann Gregor Mendel is considered the father of genetics.
7.12.10	Johann Gregor Mendel (1822–1884) (Figure 12.2) was a lifelong learner, teacher, scientist, and man of faith.
7.12.11	As a young adult, he joined the Augustinian Abbey of St. Thomas in Brno in what is now the Czech Republic.
7.12.12	Supported by the monastery, he taught physics, botany, and natural science courses at the secondary and university levels.
7.12.13	In 1856, he began a decade-long research pursuit involving inheritance patterns in honeybees and plants, ultimately settling on pea plants as his primary model system (a system with convenient characteristics used to study a specific biological phenomenon to be applied to other systems).
7.12.14	In 1865, Mendel presented the results of his experiments with nearly 30,000 pea plants to the local Natural History Society.
7.12.15	He demonstrated that traits are transmitted faithfully from parents to offspring independently of other traits and in dominant and recessive patterns.
7.12.16	In 1866, he published his work, Experiments in Plant Hybridization, in the proceedings of the Natural History Society of Brünn.
7.12.17	Mendel’s work went virtually unnoticed by the scientific community that believed, incorrectly, that the process of inheritance involved a blending of parental traits that produced an intermediate physical appearance in offspring; this hypothetical process appeared to be correct because of what we know now as continuous variation.
7.12.18	Continuous variation results from the action of many genes to determine a characteristic like human height.
7.12.19	Offspring appear to be a “blend” of their parents’ traits when we look at characteristics that exhibit continuous variation.
7.12.20	The blending theory of inheritance asserted that the original parental traits were lost or absorbed by the blending in the offspring, but we now know that this is not the case.
7.12.21	Mendel was the first researcher to see it.
7.12.22	Instead of continuous characteristics, Mendel worked with traits that were inherited in distinct classes (specifically, violet versus white flowers); this is referred to as discontinuous variation.
7.12.23	Mendel’s choice of these kinds of traits allowed him to see experimentally that the traits were not blended in the offspring, nor were they absorbed, but rather that they kept their distinctness and could be passed on.
7.12.24	In 1868, Mendel became abbot of the monastery and exchanged his scientific pursuits for his pastoral duties.
7.12.25	He was not recognized for his extraordinary scientific contributions during his lifetime.
7.12.26	In fact, it was not until 1900 that his work was rediscovered, reproduced, and revitalized by scientists on the brink of discovering the chromosomal basis of heredity.
7.12.27	Mendel’s Model System
7.12.28	Mendel’s seminal work was accomplished using the garden pea, Pisum sativum, to study inheritance.
7.12.29	This species naturally self-fertilizes, such that pollen encounters ova within individual flowers.
7.12.30	The flower petals remain sealed tightly until after pollination, preventing pollination from other plants.
7.12.31	The result is highly inbred, or “true-breeding,” pea plants.
7.12.32	These are plants that always produce offspring that look like the parent.
7.12.33	By experimenting with true-breeding pea plants, Mendel avoided the appearance of unexpected traits in offspring that might occur if the plants were not true breeding.
7.12.34	The garden pea also grows to maturity within one season, meaning that several generations could be evaluated over a relatively short time.
7.12.35	Finally, large quantities of garden peas could be cultivated simultaneously, allowing Mendel to conclude that his results did not come about simply by chance.
7.12.36	Mendelian Crosses Mendel performed hybridizations, which involve mating two true-breeding individuals that have different traits.
7.12.37	In the pea, which is naturally self-pollinating, this is done by manually transferring pollen from the anther of a mature pea plant of one variety to the stigma of a separate mature pea plant of the second variety.
7.12.38	In plants, pollen carries the male gametes (sperm) to the stigma, a sticky organ that traps pollen and allows the sperm to move down the pistil to the female gametes (ova) below.
7.12.39	To prevent the pea plant that was receiving pollen from self-fertilizing and confounding his results, Mendel painstakingly removed all of the anthers from the plant’s flowers before they had a chance to mature.
7.12.40	Plants used in first-generation crosses were called P0, or parental generation one, plants (Figure 12.3).
7.12.41	Mendel collected the seeds belonging to the P0 plants that resulted from each cross and grew them the following season.
7.12.42	These offspring were called the F1, or the first filial (filial = offspring, daughter or son), generation.
7.12.43	Once Mendel examined the characteristics in the F1 generation of plants, he allowed them to self-fertilize naturally.
7.12.44	He then collected and grew the seeds from the F1 plants to produce the F2, or second filial, generation.
7.12.45	Mendel’s experiments extended beyond the F2 generation to the F3 and F4 generations, and so on, but it was the ratio of characteristics in the P0−F1−F2 generations that were the most intriguing and became the basis for Mendel’s postulates.
7.12.46	In one of his experiments on inheritance patterns, Mendel crossed plants that were true-breeding for violet flower color with plants true-breeding for white flower color (the P generation).
7.12.47	The resulting hybrids in the F1 generation all had violet flowers.
7.12.48	In the F2 generation, approximately three quarters of the plants had violet flowers, and one quarter had white flowers.
7.12.49	Garden Pea Characteristics Revealed the Basics of Heredity
7.12.50	In his 1865 publication, Mendel reported the results of his crosses involving seven different characteristics, each with two contrasting traits.
7.12.51	A trait is defined as a variation in the physical appearance of a heritable characteristic.
7.12.52	The characteristics included plant height, seed texture, seed color, flower color, pea pod size, pea pod color, and flower position.
7.12.53	For the characteristic of flower color, for example, the two contrasting traits were white versus violet.
7.12.54	To fully examine each characteristic, Mendel generated large numbers of F1 and F2 plants, reporting results from 19,959 F2 plants alone.
7.12.55	His findings were consistent.
7.12.56	What results did Mendel find in his crosses for flower color?
7.12.57	First, Mendel confirmed that he had plants that bred true for white or violet flower color.
7.12.58	Regardless of how many generations Mendel examined, all self-crossed offspring of parents with white flowers had white flowers, and all self-crossed offspring of parents with violet flowers had violet flowers.
7.12.59	In addition, Mendel confirmed that, other than flower color, the pea plants were physically identical.
7.12.60	Once these validations were complete, Mendel applied the pollen from a plant with violet flowers to the stigma of a plant with white flowers.
7.12.61	After gathering and sowing the seeds that resulted from this cross, Mendel found that 100 percent of the F1 hybrid generation had violet flowers.
7.12.62	Conventional wisdom at that time would have predicted the hybrid flowers to be pale violet or for hybrid plants to have equal numbers of white and violet flowers.
7.12.63	In other words, the contrasting parental traits were expected to blend in the offspring.
7.12.64	Instead, Mendel’s results demonstrated that the white flower trait in the F1 generation had completely disappeared.
7.12.65	Importantly, Mendel did not stop his experimentation there.
7.12.66	He allowed the F1 plants to self-fertilize and found that, of F2- generation plants, 705 had violet flowers and 224 had white flowers.
7.12.67	This was a ratio of 3.15 violet flowers per one white flower, or approximately 3:1.
7.12.68	When Mendel transferred pollen from a plant with violet flowers to the stigma of a plant with white flowers and vice versa, he obtained about the same ratio regardless of which parent, male or female, contributed which trait.
7.12.69	This is called a reciprocal cross—a paired cross in which the respective traits of the male and female in one cross become the respective traits of the female and male in the other cross.
7.12.70	For the other six characteristics Mendel examined, the F1 and F2 generations behaved in the same way as they had for flower color.
7.12.71	One of the two traits would disappear completely from the F1 generation only to reappear in the F2 generation at a ratio of approximately 3:1 Upon compiling his results for many thousands of plants, Mendel concluded that the characteristics could be divided into expressed and latent traits.
7.12.72	He called these, respectively, dominant and recessive traits.
7.12.73	Dominant traits are those that are inherited unchanged in a hybridization.
7.12.74	Recessive traits become latent, or disappear, in the offspring of a hybridization.
7.12.75	The recessive trait does, however, reappear in the progeny of the hybrid offspring.
7.12.76	An example of a dominant trait is the violet-flower trait.
7.12.77	For this same characteristic (flower color), white-colored flowers are a recessive trait.
7.12.78	The fact that the recessive trait reappeared in the F2 generation meant that the traits remained separate (not blended) in the plants of the F1 generation.
7.12.79	Mendel also proposed that plants possessed two copies of the trait for the flower-color characteristic, and that each parent transmitted one of its two copies to its offspring, where they came together.
7.12.80	Moreover, the physical observation of a dominant trait could mean that the genetic composition of the organism included two dominant versions of the characteristic or that it included one dominant and one recessive version.
7.12.81	Conversely, the observation of a recessive trait meant that the organism lacked any dominant versions of this characteristic.
7.12.82	So why did Mendel repeatedly obtain 3:1 ratios in his crosses?
7.12.83	To understand how Mendel deduced the basic mechanisms of inheritance that lead to such ratios, we must first review the laws of probability.
7.12.84	Probability Basics Probabilities are mathematical measures of likelihood.
7.12.85	The empirical probability of an event is calculated by dividing the number of times the event occurs by the total number of opportunities for the event to occur.
7.12.86	It is also possible to calculate theoretical probabilities by dividing the number of times that an event is expected to occur by the number of times that it could occur.
7.12.87	Empirical probabilities come from observations, like those of Mendel.
7.12.88	Theoretical probabilities come from knowing how the events are produced and assuming that the probabilities of individual outcomes are equal.
7.12.89	A probability of one for some event indicates that it is guaranteed to occur, whereas a probability of zero indicates that it is guaranteed not to occur.
7.12.90	An example of a genetic event is a round seed produced by a pea plant.
7.12.91	In his experiment, Mendel demonstrated that the probability of the event “round seed
7.12.92	” occurring was one in the F1 offspring of true-breeding parents, one of which has round seeds and one of which has wrinkled seeds.
7.12.93	When the F1 plants were subsequently self-crossed, the probability of any given F2 offspring having round seeds was now three out of four.
7.12.94	In other words, in a large population of F2 offspring chosen at random, 75 percent were expected to have round seeds, whereas 25 percent were expected to have wrinkled seeds.
7.12.95	Using large numbers of crosses, Mendel was able to calculate probabilities and use these to predict the outcomes of other crosses.
7.12.96	The Product Rule and Sum Rule Mendel demonstrated that the pea-plant characteristics he studied were transmitted as discrete units from parent to offspring.
7.12.97	As will be discussed, Mendel also determined that different characteristics, like seed color and seed texture, were transmitted independently of one another and could be considered in separate probability analyses.
7.12.98	For instance, performing a cross between a plant with green, wrinkled seeds and a plant with yellow, round seeds still produced offspring that had a 3:1 ratio of green:yellow seeds (ignoring seed texture) and a 3:1 ratio of round:wrinkled seeds (ignoring seed color).
7.12.99	The characteristics of color and texture did not influence each other.
7.12.100	The product rule of probability can be applied to this phenomenon of the independent transmission of characteristics.
7.12.101	The product rule states that the probability of two independent events occurring together can be calculated by multiplying the individual probabilities of each event occurring alone.
7.12.102	To demonstrate the product rule, imagine that you are rolling a sixsided die (D) and flipping a penny (P) at the same time.
7.12.103	The die may roll any number from 1–6 (D#), whereas the penny may turn up heads (PH) or tails (PT).
7.12.104	The outcome of rolling the die has no effect on the outcome of flipping the penny and vice versa.
7.12.105	There are 12 possible outcomes of this action (Table 12.2), and each event is expected to occur with equal probability.
7.12.106	Of the 12 possible outcomes, the die has a 2/12 (or 1/6) probability of rolling a two, and the penny has a 6/12 (or 1/2) probability of coming up heads.
7.12.107	By the product rule, the probability that you will obtain the combined outcome 2 and heads is: (D2) x (PH)
7.12.108	= (1/6) x (1/2) or 1/12 (Table 12.3).
7.12.109	Notice the word “and” in the description of the probability.
7.12.110	The “and” is a signal to apply the product rule.
7.12.111	For example, consider how the product rule is applied to the dihybrid cross: the probability of having both dominant traits in the F2 progeny is the product of the probabilities of having the dominant trait for each characteristic, as shown here: On the other hand, the sum rule of probability is applied when considering two mutually exclusive outcomes that can come about by more than one pathway.
7.12.112	The sum rule states that the probability of the occurrence of one event or the other event, of two mutually exclusive events, is the sum of their individual probabilities.
7.12.113	Notice the word “or” in the description of the probability.
7.12.114	The “or” indicates that you should apply the sum rule.
7.12.115	In this case, let’s imagine you are flipping a penny (P) and a quarter (Q).
7.12.116	What is the probability of one coin coming up heads and one coin coming up tails?
7.12.117	This outcome can be achieved by two cases: the penny may be heads (PH) and the quarter may be tails (QT), or the quarter may be heads (QH) and the penny may be tails (PT).
7.12.118	Either case fulfills the outcome.
7.12.119	By the sum rule, we calculate the probability of obtaining one head and one tail as [(PH) × (QT)]
7.12.120	+
7.12.121	[(QH) × (PT)]
7.12.122	=
7.12.123	[(1/2) × (1/2)]
7.12.124	+
7.12.125	[(1/2) × (1/2)]
7.12.126	= 1/2 (Table 12.3).
7.12.127	You should also notice that we used the product rule to calculate the probability of PH and QT, and also the probability of PT and QH, before we summed them.
7.12.128	Again, the sum rule can be applied to show the probability of having just one dominant trait in the F2 generation of a dihybrid cross: To use probability laws in practice, it is necessary to work with large sample sizes because small sample sizes are prone to deviations caused by chance.
7.12.129	The large quantities of pea plants that Mendel examined allowed him calculate the probabilities of the traits appearing in his F2 generation.
7.12.130	As you will learn, this discovery meant that when parental traits were known, the offspring’s traits could be predicted accurately even before fertilization.
7.12.131	The seven characteristics that Mendel evaluated in his pea plants were each expressed as one of two versions, or traits.
7.12.132	The physical expression of characteristics is accomplished through the expression of genes carried on chromosomes.
7.12.133	The genetic makeup of peas consists of two similar or homologous copies of each chromosome, one from each parent.
7.12.134	Each pair of homologous chromosomes has the same linear order of genes.
7.12.135	In other words, peas are diploid organisms in that they have two copies of each chromosome.
7.12.136	The same is true for many other plants and for virtually all animals.
7.12.137	Diploid organisms utilize meiosis to produce haploid gametes, which contain one copy of each homologous chromosome that unite at fertilization to create a diploid zygote.
7.12.138	For cases in which a single gene controls a single characteristic, a diploid organism has two genetic copies that may or may not encode the same version of that characteristic.
7.12.139	Gene variants that arise by mutation and exist at the same relative locations on homologous chromosomes are called alleles.
7.12.140	Mendel examined the inheritance of genes with just two allele forms, but it is common to encounter more than two alleles for any given gene in a natural population.
7.12.141	Phenotypes and Genotypes Two alleles for a given gene in a diploid organism are expressed and interact to produce physical characteristics.
7.12.142	The observable traits expressed by an organism are referred to as its phenotype.
7.12.143	An organism’s underlying genetic makeup, consisting of both physically visible and non-expressed alleles, is called its genotype.
7.12.144	Mendel’s hybridization experiments demonstrate the difference between phenotype and genotype.
7.12.145	When true-breeding plants in which one parent had yellow pods and one had green pods were cross-fertilized, all of the F1 hybrid offspring had yellow pods.
7.12.146	That is, the hybrid offspring were phenotypically identical to the true-breeding parent with yellow pods.
7.12.147	However, we know that the allele donated by the parent with green pods was not simply lost because it reappeared in some of the F2 offspring.
7.12.148	Therefore, the F1 plants must have been genotypically different from the parent with yellow pods.
7.12.149	The P1 plants that Mendel used in his experiments were each homozygous for the trait he was studying.
7.12.150	Diploid organisms that are homozygous at a given gene, or locus, have two identical alleles for that gene on their homologous chromosomes.
7.12.151	Mendel’s parental pea plants always bred true because both of the gametes produced carried the same trait.
7.12.152	When P1 plants with contrasting traits were cross-fertilized, all of the offspring were heterozygous for the contrasting trait, meaning that their genotype reflected that they had different alleles for the gene being examined.
7.12.153	Dominant and Recessive Alleles
