7.12.154	Our discussion of homozygous and heterozygous organisms brings us to why the F1 heterozygous offspring were identical to one of the parents, rather than expressing both alleles.
7.12.155	In all seven pea-plant characteristics, one of the two contrasting alleles was dominant, and the other was recessive.
7.12.156	Mendel called the dominant allele the expressed unit factor; the recessive allele was referred to as the latent unit factor.
7.12.157	We now know that these so-called unit factors are actually genes on homologous chromosome pairs.
7.12.158	For a gene that is expressed in a dominant and recessive pattern, homozygous dominant and heterozygous organisms will look identical (that is, they will have different genotypes but the same phenotype).
7.12.159	The recessive allele will only be observed in homozygous recessive individuals.
7.12.160	Several conventions exist for referring to genes and alleles.
7.12.161	For the purposes of this chapter, we will abbreviate genes using the first letter of the gene’s corresponding dominant trait.
7.12.162	For example, violet is the dominant trait for a pea plant’s flower color, so the flower-color gene would be abbreviated as V (note that it is customary to italicize gene designations).
7.12.163	Furthermore, we will use uppercase and lowercase letters to represent dominant and recessive alleles, respectively.
7.12.164	Therefore, we would refer to the genotype of a homozygous dominant pea plant with violet flowers as VV, a homozygous recessive pea plant with white flowers as vv, and a heterozygous pea plant with violet flowers as Vv.
7.12.165	The Punnett Square Approach for a Monohybrid Cross
7.12.166	When fertilization occurs between two true-breeding parents that differ in only one characteristic, the process is called a monohybrid cross, and the resulting offspring are monohybrids.
7.12.167	Mendel performed seven monohybrid crosses involving contrasting traits for each characteristic.
7.12.168	On the basis of his results in F1 and F2 generations, Mendel postulated that each parent in the monohybrid cross contributed one of two paired unit factors to each offspring, and every possible combination of unit factors was equally likely.
7.12.169	To demonstrate a monohybrid cross, consider the case of true-breeding pea plants with yellow versus green pea seeds.
7.12.170	The dominant seed color is yellow; therefore, the parental genotypes were YY for the plants with yellow seeds and yy for the plants with green seeds, respectively.
7.12.171	A Punnett square, devised by the British geneticist Reginald Punnett, can be drawn that applies the rules of probability to predict the possible outcomes of a genetic cross or mating and their expected frequencies.
7.12.172	To prepare a Punnett square, all possible combinations of the parental alleles are listed along the top (for one parent) and side (for the other parent) of a grid, representing their meiotic segregation into haploid gametes.
7.12.173	Then the combinations of egg and sperm are made in the boxes in the table to show which alleles are combining.
7.12.174	Each box then represents the diploid genotype of a zygote, or fertilized egg, that could result from this mating.
7.12.175	Because each possibility is equally likely, genotypic ratios can be determined from a Punnett square.
7.12.176	If the pattern of inheritance (dominant or recessive) is known, the phenotypic ratios can be inferred as well.
7.12.177	For a monohybrid cross of two true-breeding parents, each parent contributes one type of allele.
7.12.178	In this case, only one genotype is possible.
7.12.179	All offspring are Yy and have yellow seeds.
7.12.180	In the P generation, pea plants that are true-breeding for the dominant yellow phenotype are crossed with plants with the recessive green phenotype.
7.12.181	This cross produces F1 heterozygotes with a yellow phenotype.
7.12.182	Punnett square analysis can be used to predict the genotypes of the F2 generation.
7.12.183	A self-cross of one of the Yy heterozygous offspring can be represented in a 2 × 2 Punnett square because each parent can donate one of two different alleles.
7.12.184	Therefore, the offspring can potentially have one of four allele combinations: YY, Yy, yY, or yy (Figure 12.4).
7.12.185	Notice that there are two ways to obtain the Yy genotype: a Y from the egg and a y from the sperm, or a y from the egg and a Y from the sperm.
7.12.186	Both of these possibilities must be counted.
7.12.187	Recall that Mendel’s peaplant characteristics behaved in the same way in reciprocal crosses.
7.12.188	Therefore, the two possible heterozygous combinations produce offspring that are genotypically and phenotypically identical despite their dominant and recessive alleles deriving from different parents.
7.12.189	They are grouped together.
7.12.190	Because fertilization is a random event, we expect each combination to be equally likely and for the offspring to exhibit a ratio of YY:
7.12.191	Yy:yy genotypes of 1:2:1 (Figure 12.4).
7.12.192	Furthermore, because the YY and Yy offspring have yellow seeds and are phenotypically identical, applying the sum rule of probability, we expect the offspring to exhibit a phenotypic ratio of 3 yellow:1 green.
7.12.193	Indeed, working with large sample sizes, Mendel observed approximately this ratio in every F2 generation resulting from crosses for individual traits.
7.12.194	Mendel validated these results by performing an F3 cross in which he self-crossed the dominant- and recessive-expressing F2 plants.
7.12.195	When he self-crossed the plants expressing green seeds, all of the offspring had green seeds, confirming that all green seeds had homozygous genotypes of yy.
7.12.196	When he self-crossed the F2 plants expressing yellow seeds, he found that one-third of the plants bred true, and two-thirds of the plants segregated at a 3:1 ratio of yellow:green seeds.
7.12.197	In this case, the true-breeding plants had homozygous (YY) genotypes, whereas the segregating plants corresponded to the heterozygous (Yy) genotype.
7.12.198	When these plants self-fertilized, the outcome was just like the F1 self-fertilizing cross.
7.12.199	The Test Cross Distinguishes the Dominant Phenotype Beyond predicting the offspring of a cross between known homozygous or heterozygous parents, Mendel also developed a way to determine whether an organism that expressed a dominant trait was a heterozygote or a homozygote.
7.12.200	Called the test cross, this technique is still used by plant and animal breeders.
7.12.201	In a test cross, the dominant-expressing organism is crossed with an organism that is homozygous recessive for the same characteristic.
7.12.202	If the dominant-expressing organism is a homozygote, then all F1 offspring will be heterozygotes expressing the dominant trait (Figure 12.5).
7.12.203	Alternatively, if the dominant expressing organism is a heterozygote, the F1 offspring will exhibit a 1:1 ratio of heterozygotes and recessive homozygotes (Figure 12.5).
7.12.204	The test cross further validates Mendel’s postulate that pairs of unit factors segregate equally.
7.12.205	A test cross can be performed to determine whether an organism expressing a dominant trait is a homozygote or a heterozygote.
7.12.206	In pea plants, round peas (R) are dominant to wrinkled peas (r).
7.12.207	You do a test cross between a pea plant with wrinkled peas (genotype rr) and a plant of unknown genotype that has round peas.
7.12.208	You end up with three plants, all which have round peas.
7.12.209	From this data, can you tell if the round pea parent plant is homozygous dominant or heterozygous?
7.12.210	If the round pea parent plant is heterozygous, what is the probability that a random sample of 3 progeny peas will all be round?
7.12.211	Many human diseases are genetically inherited.
7.12.212	A healthy person in a family in which some members suffer from a recessive genetic disorder may want to know if he or she has the disease-causing gene and what risk exists of passing the disorder on to his or her offspring.
7.12.213	Of course, doing a test cross in humans is unethical and impractical.
7.12.214	Instead, geneticists use pedigree analysis to study the inheritance pattern of human genetic diseases.
7.12.215	Alkaptonuria is a recessive genetic disorder in which two amino acids, phenylalanine and tyrosine, are not properly metabolized.
7.12.216	Affected individuals may have darkened skin and brown urine, and may suffer joint damage and other complications.
7.12.217	In this pedigree, individuals with the disorder are indicated in blue and have the genotype aa.
7.12.218	Unaffected individuals are indicated in yellow and have the genotype AA or Aa.
7.12.219	Note that it is often possible to determine a person’s genotype from the genotype of their offspring.
7.12.220	For example, if neither parent has the disorder but their child does, they must be heterozygous.
7.12.221	Two individuals on the pedigree have an unaffected phenotype but unknown genotype.
7.12.222	Because they do not have the disorder, they must have at least one normal allele, so their genotype gets the “A?
7.12.223	” designation.
7.12.224	Alternatives to Dominance and
7.12.225	Recessiveness Mendel’s experiments with pea plants suggested that: (1) two “units” or alleles exist for every gene; (2) alleles maintain their integrity in each generation (no blending); and (3) in the presence of the dominant allele, the recessive allele is hidden and makes no contribution to the phenotype.
7.12.226	Therefore, recessive alleles can be “carried” and not expressed by individuals.
7.12.227	Such heterozygous individuals are sometimes referred to as “carriers.
7.12.228	”
7.12.229	Further genetic studies in other plants and animals have shown that much more complexity exists, but that the fundamental principles of Mendelian genetics still hold true.
7.12.230	In the sections to follow, we consider some of the extensions of Mendelism.
7.12.231	If Mendel had chosen an experimental system that exhibited these genetic complexities, it’s possible that he would not have understood what his results meant.
7.12.232	Incomplete Dominance Mendel’s results, that traits are inherited as dominant and recessive pairs, contradicted the view at that time that offspring exhibited a blend of their parents’ traits.
7.12.233	However, the heterozygote phenotype occasionally does appear to be intermediate between the two parents.
7.12.234	For example, in the snapdragon, Antirrhinum majus (Figure 12.7), a cross between a homozygous parent with white flowers (CWCW) and a homozygous parent with red flowers (CRCR) will produce offspring with pink flowers (CRCW).
7.12.235	(Note that different genotypic abbreviations are used for Mendelian extensions to distinguish these patterns from simple dominance and recessiveness.)
7.12.236	This pattern of inheritance is described as incomplete dominance, denoting the expression of two contrasting alleles such that the individual displays an intermediate phenotype.
7.12.237	The allele for red flowers is incompletely dominant over the allele for white flowers.
7.12.238	However, the results of a heterozygote self-cross can still be predicted, just as with Mendelian dominant and recessive crosses.
7.12.239	In this case, the genotypic ratio would be 1 CRCR:2 CRCW:1 CWCW, and the phenotypic ratio would be 1:2:1 for red:pink:white.
7.12.240	Codominance
7.12.241	A variation on incomplete dominance is codominance, in which both alleles for the same characteristic are simultaneously expressed in the heterozygote.
7.12.242	An example of codominance is the MN blood groups of humans.
7.12.243	The M and N alleles are expressed in the form of an M or N antigen present on the surface of red blood cells.
7.12.244	Homozygotes (LMLM and LNLN) express either the M or the N allele, and heterozygotes (LMLN) express both alleles equally.
7.12.245	In a self-cross between heterozygotes expressing a codominant trait, the three possible offspring genotypes are phenotypically distinct.
7.12.246	However, the 1:2:1 genotypic ratio characteristic of a Mendelian monohybrid cross still applies.
7.12.247	Multiple Alleles Mendel implied that only two alleles, one dominant and one recessive, could exist for a given gene.
7.12.248	We now know that this is an oversimplification.
7.12.249	Although individual humans (and all diploid organisms) can only have two alleles for a given gene, multiple alleles may exist at the population level such that many combinations of two alleles are observed.
7.12.250	Note that when many alleles exist for the same gene, the convention is to denote the most common phenotype or genotype among wild animals as the wild type (often abbreviated “+”); this is considered the standard or norm.
7.12.251	All other phenotypes or genotypes are considered variants of this standard, meaning that they deviate from the wild type.
7.12.252	The variant may be recessive or dominant to the wild-type allele.
7.12.253	An example of multiple alleles is coat color in rabbits (Figure 12.8).
7.12.254	Here, four alleles exist for the c gene.
7.12.255	The wild-type version, C+C+, is expressed as brown fur.
7.12.256	The chinchilla phenotype, cchcch, is expressed as black-tipped white fur.
7.12.257	The Himalayan phenotype, chch, has black fur on the extremities and white fur elsewhere.
7.12.258	Finally, the albino, or “colorless” phenotype, cc, is expressed as white fur.
7.12.259	In cases of multiple alleles, dominance hierarchies can exist.
7.12.260	In this case, the wildtype allele is dominant over all the others, chinchilla is incompletely dominant over Himalayan and albino, and Himalayan is dominant over albino.
7.12.261	This hierarchy, or allelic series, was revealed by observing the phenotypes of each possible heterozygote offspring.
7.12.262	The complete dominance of a wild-type phenotype over all other mutants often occurs as an effect of “dosage” of a specific gene product, such that the wild-type allele supplies the correct amount of gene product whereas the mutant alleles cannot.
7.12.263	For the allelic series in rabbits, the wild-type allele may supply a given dosage of fur pigment, whereas the mutants supply a lesser dosage or none at all.
7.12.264	Interestingly, the Himalayan phenotype is the result of an allele that produces a temperaturesensitive gene product that only produces pigment in the cooler extremities of the rabbit’s body.
7.12.265	Alternatively, one mutant allele can be dominant over all other phenotypes, including the wild type.
7.12.266	This may occur when the mutant allele somehow interferes with the genetic message so that even a heterozygote with one wild-type allele copy expresses the mutant phenotype.
7.12.267	One way in which the mutant allele can interfere is by enhancing the function of the wildtype gene product or changing its distribution in the body.
7.12.268	One example of this is the Antennapedia mutation in Drosophila (Figure 12.9).
7.12.269	In this case, the mutant allele expands the distribution of the gene product, and as a result, the Antennapedia heterozygote develops legs on its head where its antennae should be.
7.12.270	As seen in comparing the wild-type Drosophila (left) and the Antennapedia mutant (right), the Antennapedia mutant has legs on its head in place of antennae.
7.12.271	Multiple Alleles Confer Drug Resistance in the Malaria Parasite Malaria is a parasitic disease in humans that is transmitted by infected female mosquitoes, including Anopheles gambiae (Figure 12.10a), and is characterized by cyclic high fevers, chills, flu-like symptoms, and severe anemia.
7.12.272	Plasmodium falciparum and P. vivax are the most common causative agents of malaria, and P. falciparum is the most deadly (Figure 12.10b).
7.12.273	When promptly and correctly treated, P. falciparum malaria has a mortality rate of 0.1 percent.
7.12.274	However, in some parts of the world, the parasite has evolved resistance to commonly used malaria treatments, so the most effective malarial treatments can vary by geographic region.
7.12.275	The (a) Anopheles gambiae, or African malaria mosquito, acts as a vector in the transmission to humans of the malaria-causing parasite (b) Plasmodium falciparum, here visualized using false-color transmission electron microscopy.
7.12.276	(credit a: James D. Gathany; credit b: Ute Frevert; false color by Margaret Shear; scale-bar data from Matt Russell)
7.12.277	In Southeast Asia, Africa, and South America, P. falciparum has developed resistance to the anti-malarial drugs chloroquine, mefloquine, and sulfadoxine-pyrimethamine.
7.12.278	P. falciparum, which is haploid during the life stage in which it is infectious to humans, has evolved multiple drug-resistant mutant alleles of the dhps gene.
7.12.279	Varying degrees of sulfadoxine resistance are associated with each of these alleles.
7.12.280	Being haploid, P. falciparum needs only one drug-resistant allele to express this trait.
7.12.281	In Southeast Asia, different sulfadoxine-resistant alleles of the dhps gene are localized to different geographic regions.
7.12.282	This is a common evolutionary phenomenon that occurs because drug-resistant mutants arise in a population and interbreed with other P. falciparum isolates in close proximity.
7.12.283	Sulfadoxineresistant parasites cause considerable human hardship in regions where this drug is widely used as an over-the-counter malaria remedy.
7.12.284	As is common with pathogens that multiply to large numbers within an infection cycle, P. falciparum evolves relatively rapidly (over a decade or so) in response to the selective pressure of commonly used anti-malarial drugs.
7.12.285	For this reason, scientists must constantly work to develop new drugs or drug combinations to combat the worldwide malaria burden.
7.12.286	X-Linked Traits
7.12.287	In humans, as well as in many other animals and some plants, the sex of the individual is determined by sex chromosomes.
7.12.288	The sex chromosomes are one pair of non-homologous chromosomes.
7.12.289	Until now, we have only considered inheritance patterns among non-sex chromosomes, or autosomes.
7.12.290	In addition to 22 homologous pairs of autosomes, human females have a homologous pair of X chromosomes, whereas human males have an XY chromosome pair.
7.12.291	Although the Y chromosome contains a small region of similarity to the X chromosome so that they can pair during meiosis, the Y chromosome is much shorter and contains many fewer genes.
7.12.292	When a gene being examined is present on the X chromosome, but not on the Y chromosome, it is said to be X-linked.
7.12.293	Eye color in Drosophila was one of the first X-linked traits to be identified.
7.12.294	Thomas Hunt Morgan mapped this trait to the X chromosome in 1910.
7.12.295	Like humans, Drosophila males have an XY chromosome pair, and females are XX.
7.12.296	In flies, the wild-type eye color is red (XW) and it is dominant to white eye color (Xw)
7.12.297	(Figure 12.11).
7.12.298	Because of the location of the eye-color gene, reciprocal crosses do not produce the same offspring ratios.
7.12.299	Males are said to be hemizygous, because they have only one allele for any X-linked characteristic.
7.12.300	Hemizygosity makes the descriptions of dominance and recessiveness irrelevant for XY males.
7.12.301	Drosophila males lack a second allele copy on the Y chromosome; that is, their genotype can only be XWY or XwY.
7.12.302	In contrast, females have two allele copies of this gene and can be XWXW, XWXw, or XwXw.
7.12.303	In Drosophila, several genes determine eye color.
7.12.304	The genes for white and vermilion eye colors are located on the X chromosome.
7.12.305	Others are located on the autosomes.
7.12.306	Clockwise from top left are brown, cinnabar, sepia, vermilion, white, and red.
7.12.307	Red eye color is wild-type and is dominant to white eye color.
7.12.308	In an X-linked cross, the genotypes of F1 and F2 offspring depend on whether the recessive trait was expressed by the male or the female in the P1 generation.
7.12.309	With regard to Drosophila eye color, when the P1 male expresses the white-eye phenotype and the female is homozygous red-eyed, all members of the F1 generation exhibit red eyes (Figure 12.12).
7.12.310	The F1 females are heterozygous (XWXw), and the males are all XWY, having received their X chromosome from the homozygous dominant P1 female and their Y chromosome from the P1 male.
7.12.311	A subsequent cross between the XWXw female and the XWY male would produce only red-eyed females (with XWXW or XWXw genotypes) and both red- and white-eyed males (with XWY or XwY genotypes).
7.12.312	Now, consider a cross between a homozygous white-eyed female and a male with red eyes.
7.12.313	The F1 generation would exhibit only heterozygous red-eyed females (XWXw) and only white-eyed males (XwY).
7.12.314	Half of the F2 females would be red-eyed (XWXw) and half would be white-eyed (XwXw).
7.12.315	Similarly, half of the F2 males would be red-eyed (XWY) and half would be white-eyed (XwY).
7.12.316	Punnett square analysis is used to determine the ratio of offspring from a cross between a red-eyed male fruit fly and a white-eyed female fruit fly.
7.12.317	Discoveries in fruit fly genetics can be applied to human genetics.
7.12.318	When a female parent is homozygous for a recessive Xlinked trait, she will pass the trait on to 100 percent of her offspring.
7.12.319	Her male offspring are, therefore, destined to express the trait, as they will inherit their father's Y chromosome.
7.12.320	In humans, the alleles for certain conditions (some forms of color blindness, hemophilia, and muscular dystrophy) are X-linked.
7.12.321	Females who are heterozygous for these diseases are said to be carriers and may not exhibit any phenotypic effects.
7.12.322	These females will pass the disease to half of their sons and will pass carrier status to half of their daughters; therefore, recessive X-linked traits appear more frequently in males than females.
7.12.323	In some groups of organisms with sex chromosomes, the gender with the non-homologous sex chromosomes is the female rather than the male.
7.12.324	This is the case for all birds.
7.12.325	In this case, sex-linked traits will be more likely to appear in the female, in which they are hemizygous.
7.12.326	Human Sex-linked Disorders Sex-linkage studies in Morgan’s laboratory provided the fundamentals for understanding X-linked recessive disorders in humans, which include red-green color blindness, and Types A and B hemophilia.
7.12.327	Because human males need to inherit only one recessive mutant X allele to be affected, X-linked disorders are disproportionately observed in males.
7.12.328	Females must inherit recessive X-linked alleles from both of their parents in order to express the trait.
7.12.329	When they inherit one recessive X-linked mutant allele and one dominant X-linked wild-type allele, they are carriers of the trait and are typically unaffected.
7.12.330	Carrier females can manifest mild forms of the trait due to the inactivation of the dominant allele located on one of the X chromosomes.
7.12.331	However, female carriers can contribute the trait to their sons, resulting in the son exhibiting the trait, or they can contribute the recessive allele to their daughters, resulting in the daughters being carriers of the trait (Figure 12.13).
7.12.332	Although some Y-linked recessive disorders exist, typically they are associated with infertility in males and are therefore not transmitted to subsequent generations.
7.12.333	The son of a woman who is a carrier of a recessive X-linked disorder will have a 50 percent chance of being affected.
7.12.334	A daughter will not be affected, but she will have a 50 percent chance of being a carrier like her mother.
7.12.335	Lethality
7.12.336	A large proportion of genes in an individual’s genome are essential for survival.
7.12.337	Occasionally, a nonfunctional allele for an essential gene can arise by mutation and be transmitted in a population as long as individuals with this allele also have a wild-type, functional copy.
7.12.338	The wild-type allele functions at a capacity sufficient to sustain life and is therefore considered to be dominant over the nonfunctional allele.
7.12.339	However, consider two heterozygous parents that have a genotype of wildtype/ nonfunctional mutant for a hypothetical essential gene.
7.12.340	In one quarter of their offspring, we would expect to observe individuals that are homozygous recessive for the nonfunctional allele.
7.12.341	Because the gene is essential, these individuals might fail to develop past fertilization, die in utero, or die later in life, depending on what life stage requires this gene.
7.12.342	An inheritance pattern in which an allele is only lethal in the homozygous form and in which the heterozygote may be normal or have some altered non-lethal phenotype is referred to as recessive lethal.
7.12.343	For crosses between heterozygous individuals with a recessive lethal allele that causes death before birth when homozygous, only wild-type homozygotes and heterozygotes would be observed.
7.12.344	The genotypic ratio would therefore be 2:1.
7.12.345	In other instances, the recessive lethal allele might also exhibit a dominant (but not lethal) phenotype in the heterozygote.
7.12.346	For instance, the recessive lethal Curly allele in Drosophila affects wing shape in the heterozygote form but is lethal in the homozygote.
7.12.347	A single copy of the wild-type allele is not always sufficient for normal functioning or even survival.
7.12.348	The dominant lethal inheritance pattern is one in which an allele is lethal both in the homozygote and the heterozygote; this allele can only be transmitted if the lethality phenotype occurs after reproductive age.
7.12.349	Individuals with mutations that result in dominant lethal alleles fail to survive even in the heterozygote form.
7.12.350	Dominant lethal alleles are very rare because, as you might expect, the allele only lasts one generation and is not transmitted.
7.12.351	However, just as the recessive lethal allele might not immediately manifest the phenotype of death, dominant lethal alleles also might not be expressed until adulthood.
7.12.352	Once the individual reaches reproductive age, the allele may be unknowingly passed on, resulting in a delayed death in both generations.
7.12.353	An example of this in humans is Huntington’s disease, in which the nervous system gradually wastes away (Figure 12.14).
7.12.354	People who are heterozygous for the dominant Huntington allele (Hh) will inevitably develop the fatal disease.
7.12.355	However, the onset of Huntington’s disease may not occur until age 40, at which point the afflicted persons may have already passed the allele to 50 percent of their offspring.
7.12.356	The neuron in the center of this micrograph (yellow) has nuclear inclusions characteristic of Huntington’s disease (orange area in the center of the neuron).
7.12.357	Huntington’s disease occurs when an abnormal dominant allele for the Huntington gene is present.
7.12.358	(credit: Dr. Steven Finkbeiner, Gladstone Institute of Neurological Disease, The Taube- Koret Center for Huntington's Disease Research, and the University of California San Francisco/Wikimedia)
7.12.359	Mendel generalized the results of his pea-plant experiments into four postulates, some of which are sometimes called “laws,” that describe the basis of dominant and recessive inheritance in diploid organisms.
7.12.360	As you have learned, more complex extensions of Mendelism exist that do not exhibit the same F2 phenotypic ratios (3:1).
7.12.361	Nevertheless, these laws summarize the basics of classical genetics.
7.12.362	Pairs of Unit Factors, or Genes Mendel proposed first that paired unit factors of heredity were transmitted faithfully from generation to generation by the dissociation and reassociation of paired factors during gametogenesis and fertilization, respectively.
7.12.363	After he crossed peas with contrasting traits and found that the recessive trait resurfaced in the F2 generation, Mendel deduced that hereditary factors must be inherited as discrete units.
7.12.364	This finding contradicted the belief at that time that parental traits were blended in the offspring.
7.12.365	Alleles Can Be Dominant or Recessive Mendel’s law of dominance states that in a heterozygote, one trait will conceal the presence of another trait for the same characteristic.
7.12.366	Rather than both alleles contributing to a phenotype, the dominant allele will be expressed exclusively.
7.12.367	The recessive allele will remain “latent” but will be transmitted to offspring by the same manner in which the dominant allele is transmitted.
7.12.368	The recessive trait will only be expressed by offspring that have two copies of this allele (Figure 12.15), and these offspring will breed true when self-crossed.
7.12.369	Since Mendel’s experiments with pea plants, other researchers have found that the law of dominance does not always hold true.
7.12.370	Instead, several different patterns of inheritance have been found to exist.
7.12.371	Equal Segregation of Alleles Observing that true-breeding pea plants with contrasting traits gave rise to F1 generations that all expressed the dominant trait and F2 generations that expressed the dominant and recessive traits in a 3:1 ratio, Mendel proposed the law of segregation.
7.12.372	This law states that paired unit factors (genes) must segregate equally into gametes such that offspring have an equal likelihood of inheriting either factor.
7.12.373	For the F2 generation of a monohybrid cross, the following three possible combinations of genotypes could result: homozygous dominant, heterozygous, or homozygous recessive.
7.12.374	Because heterozygotes could arise from two different pathways (receiving one dominant and one recessive allele from either parent), and because heterozygotes and homozygous dominant individuals are phenotypically identical, the law supports Mendel’s observed 3:1 phenotypic ratio.
7.12.375	The equal segregation of alleles is the reason we can apply the Punnett square to accurately predict the offspring of parents with known genotypes.
7.12.376	The physical basis of Mendel’s law of segregation is the first division of meiosis, in which the homologous chromosomes with their different versions of each gene are segregated into daughter nuclei.
7.12.377	The role of the meiotic segregation of chromosomes in sexual reproduction was not understood by the scientific community during Mendel’s lifetime.
7.12.378	Independent Assortment Mendel’s law of independent assortment states that genes do not influence each other with regard to the sorting of alleles into gametes, and every possible combination of alleles for every gene is equally likely to occur.
7.12.379	The independent assortment of genes can be illustrated by the dihybrid cross, a cross between two true-breeding parents that express different traits for two characteristics.
7.12.380	Consider the characteristics of seed color and seed texture for two pea plants, one that has green, wrinkled seeds (yyrr) and another that has yellow, round seeds (YYRR).
7.12.381	Because each parent is homozygous, the law of segregation indicates that the gametes for the green/wrinkled plant all are yr, and the gametes for the yellow/round plant are all YR.
7.12.382	Therefore, the F1 generation of offspring all are YyRr.
7.12.383	For the F2 generation, the law of segregation requires that each gamete receive either an R allele or an r allele along with either a Y allele or a y allele.
7.12.384	The law of independent assortment states that a gamete into which an r allele sorted would be equally likely to contain either a Y allele or a y allele.
7.12.385	Thus, there are four equally likely gametes that can be formed when the YyRr heterozygote is self-crossed, as follows: YR, Yr, yR, and yr.
7.12.386	Arranging these gametes along the top and left of a 4 × 4 Punnett square (Figure 12.16) gives us 16 equally likely genotypic combinations.
7.12.387	From these genotypes, we infer a phenotypic ratio of 9 round/yellow:3 round/green:3
7.12.388	wrinkled/yellow:1 wrinkled/green (Figure 12.16).
7.12.389	These are the offspring ratios we would expect, assuming we performed the crosses with a large enough sample size.
7.12.390	Because of independent assortment and dominance, the 9:3:3:1 dihybrid phenotypic ratio can be collapsed into two 3:1 ratios, characteristic of any monohybrid cross that follows a dominant and recessive pattern.
7.12.391	Ignoring seed color and considering only seed texture in the above dihybrid cross, we would expect that three quarters of the F2 generation offspring would be round, and one quarter would be wrinkled.
7.12.392	Similarly, isolating only seed color, we would assume that three quarters of the F2 offspring would be yellow and one quarter would be green.
7.12.393	The sorting of alleles for texture and color are independent events, so we can apply the product rule.
7.12.394	Therefore, the proportion of round and yellow F2 offspring is expected to be (3/4) × (3/4)
7.12.395	= 9/16, and the proportion of wrinkled and green offspring is expected to be
7.12.396	(1/4) × (1/4)
7.12.397	= 1/16.
7.12.398	These proportions are identical to those obtained using a Punnett square.
7.12.399	Round, green and wrinkled, yellow offspring can also be calculated using the product rule, as each of these genotypes includes one dominant and one recessive phenotype.
7.12.400	Therefore, the proportion of each is calculated as (3/4) × (1/4)
7.12.401	= 3/16.
7.12.402	The law of independent assortment also indicates that a cross between yellow, wrinkled (YYrr) and green, round (yyRR) parents would yield the same F1 and F2 offspring as in the YYRR x yyrr cross.
7.12.403	The physical basis for the law of independent assortment also lies in meiosis
7.12.404	I, in which the different homologous pairs line up in random orientations.
7.12.405	Each gamete can contain any combination of paternal and maternal chromosomes (and therefore the genes on them) because the orientation of tetrads on the metaphase plane is random.
7.12.406	Forked-Line Method
7.12.407	When more than two genes are being considered, the Punnett-square method becomes unwieldy.
7.12.408	For instance, examining a cross involving four genes would require a 16 × 16 grid containing 256 boxes.
7.12.409	It would be extremely cumbersome to manually enter each genotype.
7.12.410	For more complex crosses, the forked-line and probability methods are preferred.
7.12.411	To prepare a forked-line diagram for a cross between F1 heterozygotes resulting from a cross between AABBCC and aabbcc parents, we first create rows equal to the number of genes being considered, and then segregate the alleles in each row on forked lines according to the probabilities for individual monohybrid crosses (Figure 12.17).
7.12.412	We then multiply the values along each forked path to obtain the F2 offspring probabilities.
7.12.413	Note that this process is a diagrammatic version of the product rule.
7.12.414	The values along each forked pathway can be multiplied because each gene assorts independently.
7.12.415	For a trihybrid cross, the F2 phenotypic ratio is 27:9:9:9:3:3:3:1.
7.12.416	The forked-line method can be used to analyze a trihybrid cross.
7.12.417	Here, the probability for color in the F2 generation occupies the top row (3 yellow:1 green).
7.12.418	The probability for shape occupies the second row (3 round:1 wrinked), and the probability for height occupies the third row (3 tall:1 dwarf).
7.12.419	The probability for each possible combination of traits is calculated by multiplying the probability for each individual trait.
7.12.420	Thus, the probability of F2 offspring having yellow, round, and tall traits is 3 × 3 × 3, or 27.
7.12.421	Probability Method
7.12.422	While the forked-line method is a diagrammatic approach to keeping track of probabilities in a cross, the probability method gives the proportions of offspring expected to exhibit each phenotype (or genotype) without the added visual assistance.
7.12.423	Both methods make use of the product rule and consider the alleles for each gene separately.
7.12.424	Earlier, we examined the phenotypic proportions for a trihybrid cross using the forked-line method; now we will use the probability method to examine the genotypic proportions for a cross with even more genes.
7.12.425	For a trihybrid cross, writing out the forked-line method is tedious, albeit not as tedious as using the Punnett-square method.
7.12.426	To fully demonstrate the power of the probability method, however, we can consider specific genetic calculations.
7.12.427	For instance, for a tetrahybrid cross between individuals that are heterozygotes for all four genes, and in which all four genes are sorting independently and in a dominant and recessive pattern, what proportion of the offspring will be expected to be homozygous recessive for all four alleles?
7.12.428	Rather than writing out every possible genotype, we can use the probability method.
7.12.429	We know that for each gene, the fraction of homozygous recessive offspring will be 1/4.
7.12.430	Therefore, multiplying this fraction for each of the four genes, (1/4) ×
7.12.431	(1/4) ×
7.12.432	(1/4) × (1/4)
7.12.433	, we determine that 1/256 of the offspring will be quadruply homozygous recessive.
7.12.434	For the same tetrahybrid cross, what is the expected proportion of offspring that have the dominant phenotype at all four loci?
7.12.435	We can answer this question using phenotypic proportions, but let’s do it the hard way—using genotypic proportions.
7.12.436	The question asks for the proportion of offspring that are 1) homozygous dominant at A or heterozygous at A, and 2) homozygous at B or heterozygous at B, and so on.
7.12.437	Noting the “or” and “and” in each circumstance makes clear where to apply the sum and product rules.
7.12.438	The probability of a homozygous dominant at A is 1/4 and the probability of a heterozygote at A is 1/2.
7.12.439	The probability of the homozygote or the heterozygote is 1/4 + 1/2 = 3/4 using the sum rule.
7.12.440	The same probability can be obtained in the same way for each of the other genes, so that the probability of a dominant phenotype at A and B and C and D is, using the product rule, equal to 3/4 × 3/4 × 3/4 × 3/4, or 27/64.
7.12.441	If you are ever unsure about how to combine probabilities, returning to the forked-line method should make it clear.
7.12.442	Rules for Multihybrid Fertilization
7.12.443	Predicting the genotypes and phenotypes of offspring from given crosses is the best way to test your knowledge of Mendelian genetics.
7.12.444	Given a multihybrid cross that obeys independent assortment and follows a dominant and recessive pattern, several generalized rules exist; you can use these rules to check your results as you work through genetics calculations (Table 12.5).
7.12.445	To apply these rules, first you must determine n, the number of heterozygous gene pairs (the number of genes segregating two alleles each).
7.12.446	For example, a cross between AaBb and AaBb heterozygotes has an n of 2.
7.12.447	In contrast, a cross between AABb and AABb has an n of 1 because A is not heterozygous.
7.12.448	Linked Genes Violate the Law of Independent Assortment
7.12.449	Although all of Mendel’s pea characteristics behaved according to the law of independent assortment, we now know that some allele combinations are not inherited independently of each other.
7.12.450	Genes that are located on separate nonhomologous chromosomes will always sort independently.
7.12.451	However, each chromosome contains hundreds or thousands of genes, organized linearly on chromosomes like beads on a string.
7.12.452	The segregation of alleles into gametes can be influenced by linkage, in which genes that are located physically close to each other on the same chromosome are more likely to be inherited as a pair.
7.12.453	However, because of the process of recombination, or “crossover,” it is possible for two genes on the same chromosome to behave independently, or as if they are not linked.
7.12.454	To understand this, let’s consider the biological basis of gene linkage and recombination.
7.12.455	Homologous chromosomes possess the same genes in the same linear order.
7.12.456	The alleles may differ on homologous chromosome pairs, but the genes to which they correspond do not.
7.12.457	In preparation for the first division of meiosis, homologous chromosomes replicate and synapse.
7.12.458	Like genes on the homologs align with each other.
7.12.459	At this stage, segments of homologous chromosomes exchange linear segments of genetic material (Figure 12.18).
7.12.460	This process is called recombination, or crossover, and it is a common genetic process.
7.12.461	Because the genes are aligned during recombination, the gene order is not altered.
7.12.462	Instead, the result of recombination is that maternal and paternal alleles are combined onto the same chromosome.
7.12.463	Across a given chromosome, several recombination events may occur, causing extensive shuffling of alleles.
7.12.464	The process of crossover, or recombination, occurs when two homologous chromosomes align during meiosis and exchange a segment of genetic material.
7.12.465	Here, the alleles for gene C were exchanged.
7.12.466	The result is two recombinant and two non-recombinant chromosomes.
7.12.467	When two genes are located in close proximity on the same chromosome, they are considered linked, and their alleles tend to be transmitted through meiosis together.
7.12.468	To exemplify this, imagine a dihybrid cross involving flower color and plant height in which the genes are next to each other on the chromosome.
7.12.469	If one homologous chromosome has alleles for tall plants and red flowers, and the other chromosome has genes for short plants and yellow flowers, then when the gametes are formed, the tall and red alleles will go together into a gamete and the short and yellow alleles will go into other gametes.
7.12.470	These are called the parental genotypes because they have been inherited intact from the parents of the individual producing gametes.
7.12.471	But unlike if the genes were on different chromosomes, there will be no gametes with tall and yellow alleles and no gametes with short and red alleles.
7.12.472	If you create the Punnett square with these gametes, you will see that the classical Mendelian prediction of a 9:3:3:1 outcome of a dihybrid cross would not apply.
7.12.473	As the distance between two genes increases, the probability of one or more crossovers between them increases, and the genes behave more like they are on separate chromosomes.
7.12.474	Geneticists have used the proportion of recombinant gametes (the ones not like the parents) as a measure of how far apart genes are on a chromosome.
7.12.475	Using this information, they have constructed elaborate maps of genes on chromosomes for well-studied organisms, including humans.
7.12.476	Mendel’s seminal publication makes no mention of linkage, and many researchers have questioned whether he encountered linkage but chose not to publish those crosses out of concern that they would invalidate his independent assortment postulate.
7.12.477	The garden pea has seven chromosomes, and some have suggested that his choice of seven characteristics was not a coincidence.
7.12.478	However, even if the genes he examined were not located on separate chromosomes, it is possible that he simply did not observe linkage because of the extensive shuffling effects of recombination.
7.12.479	Testing the Hypothesis of Independent Assortment
7.12.480	To better appreciate the amount of labor and ingenuity that went into Mendel’s experiments, proceed through one of Mendel’s dihybrid crosses.
7.12.481	Question: What will be the offspring of a dihybrid cross?
7.12.482	Background: Consider that pea plants mature in one growing season, and you have access to a large garden in which you can cultivate thousands of pea plants.
7.12.483	There are several true-breeding plants with the following pairs of traits: tall plants with inflated pods, and dwarf plants with constricted pods.
7.12.484	Before the plants have matured, you remove the pollen-producing organs from the tall/inflated plants in your crosses to prevent self-fertilization.
7.12.485	Upon plant maturation, the plants are manually crossed by transferring pollen from the dwarf/constricted plants to the stigmata of the tall/inflated plants.
7.12.486	Hypothesis:
7.12.487	Both trait pairs will sort independently according to Mendelian laws.
7.12.488	When the true-breeding parents are crossed, all of the F1 offspring are tall and have inflated pods, which indicates that the tall and inflated traits are dominant over the dwarf and constricted traits, respectively.
7.12.489	A self-cross of the F1 heterozygotes results in 2,000 F2 progeny.
7.12.490	Test the hypothesis: Because each trait pair sorts independently, the ratios of tall:dwarf and inflated:constricted are each expected to be 3:1.
7.12.491	The tall/dwarf trait pair is called T/t, and the inflated/ constricted trait pair is designated
7.12.492	I/i.
7.12.493	Each member of the F1 generation therefore has a genotype of TtIi.
7.12.494	Construct a grid analogous to Figure 12.16, in which you cross two TtIi individuals.
7.12.495	Each individual can donate four combinations of two traits: TI, Ti, tI, or ti, meaning that there are 16 possibilities of offspring genotypes.
7.12.496	Because the T and I alleles are dominant, any individual having one or two of those alleles will express the tall or inflated phenotypes, respectively, regardless if they also have a t or i allele.
7.12.497	Only individuals that are tt or ii will express the dwarf and constricted alleles, respectively.
7.12.498	As shown in Figure 12.19, you predict that you will observe the following offspring proportions: tall/inflated:tall/constricted:dwarf/ inflated:dwarf/constricted in a 9:3:3:1 ratio.
7.12.499	Notice from the grid that when considering the tall/dwarf and inflated/constricted trait pairs in isolation, they are each inherited in 3:1 ratios.
7.12.500	This figure shows all possible combinations of offspring resulting from a dihybrid cross of pea plants that are heterozygous for the tall/dwarf and inflated/constricted alleles.
7.12.501	Test the hypothesis
7.12.502	: You cross the dwarf and tall plants and then self-cross the offspring.
7.12.503	For best results, this is repeated with hundreds or even thousands of pea plants.
7.12.504	What special precautions should be taken in the crosses and in growing the plants?
7.12.505	Analyze your data: You observe the following plant phenotypes in the F2 generation: 2706 tall/inflated, 930 tall/constricted, 888 dwarf/inflated, and 300 dwarf/constricted.
7.12.506	Reduce these findings to a ratio and determine if they are consistent with Mendelian laws.
7.12.507	Form a conclusion
7.12.508	: Were the results close to the expected 9:3:3:1 phenotypic ratio?
7.12.509	Do the results support the prediction?
7.12.510	What might be observed if far fewer plants were used, given that alleles segregate randomly into gametes?
7.12.511	Try to imagine growing that many pea plants, and consider the potential for experimental error.
7.12.512	For instance, what would happen if it was extremely windy one day?
7.12.513	Epistasis
7.12.514	Mendel’s studies in pea plants implied that the sum of an individual’s phenotype was controlled by genes (or as he called them, unit factors), such that every characteristic was distinctly and completely controlled by a single gene.
7.12.515	In fact, single observable characteristics are almost always under the influence of multiple genes (each with two or more alleles) acting in unison.
7.12.516	For example, at least eight genes contribute to eye color in humans.
7.12.517	In some cases, several genes can contribute to aspects of a common phenotype without their gene products ever directly interacting.
7.12.518	In the case of organ development, for instance, genes may be expressed sequentially, with each gene adding to the complexity and specificity of the organ.
7.12.519	Genes may function in complementary or synergistic fashions, such that two or more genes need to be expressed simultaneously to affect a phenotype.
7.12.520	Genes may also oppose each other, with one gene modifying the expression of another.
7.12.521	In epistasis, the interaction between genes is antagonistic, such that one gene masks or interferes with the expression of another.
7.12.522	“
7.12.523	Epistasis” is a word composed of Greek roots that mean “standing upon.
7.12.524	”
7.12.525	The alleles that are being masked or silenced are said to be hypostatic to the epistatic alleles that are doing the masking.
7.12.526	Often the biochemical basis of epistasis is a gene pathway in which the expression of one gene is dependent on the function of a gene that precedes or follows it in the pathway.
7.12.527	An example of epistasis is pigmentation in mice.
7.12.528	The wild-type coat color, agouti (AA), is dominant to solid-colored fur (aa).
7.12.529	However, a separate gene (C) is necessary for pigment production.
7.12.530	A mouse with a recessive c allele at this locus is unable to produce pigment and is albino regardless of the allele present at locus A (Figure 12.20).
7.12.531	Therefore, the genotypes AAcc, Aacc, and aacc all produce the same albino phenotype.
7.12.532	A cross between heterozygotes for both genes (AaCc x AaCc) would generate offspring with a phenotypic ratio of 9 agouti:3 solid color:4 albino (Figure 12.20).
7.12.533	In this case, the C gene is epistatic to the A gene.
7.12.534	In mice, the mottled agouti coat color (A) is dominant to a solid coloration, such as black or gray.
7.12.535	A gene at a separate locus (C) is responsible for pigment production.
7.12.536	The recessive c allele does not produce pigment, and a mouse with the homozygous recessive cc genotype is albino regardless of the allele present at the A locus.
7.12.537	Thus, the C gene is epistatic to the A gene.
7.12.538	Epistasis can also occur when a dominant allele masks expression at a separate gene.
7.12.539	Fruit color in summer squash is expressed in this way.
7.12.540	Homozygous recessive expression of the W gene (ww) coupled with homozygous dominant or heterozygous expression of the Y gene (YY or Yy) generates yellow fruit, and the wwyy genotype produces green fruit.
7.12.541	However, if a dominant copy of the W gene is present in the homozygous or heterozygous form, the summer squash will produce white fruit regardless of the Y alleles.
7.12.542	A cross between white heterozygotes for both genes (WwYy × WwYy) would produce offspring with a phenotypic ratio of 12 white:3 yellow:1 green.
7.12.543	Finally, epistasis can be reciprocal such that either gene, when present in the dominant (or recessive) form, expresses the same phenotype.
7.12.544	In the shepherd’s purse plant (Capsella bursa-pastoris), the characteristic of seed shape is controlled by two genes in a dominant epistatic relationship.
7.12.545	When the genes A and B are both homozygous recessive (aabb), the seeds are ovoid.
7.12.546	If the dominant allele for either of these genes is present, the result is triangular seeds.
7.12.547	That is, every possible genotype other than aabb results in triangular seeds, and a cross between heterozygotes for both genes (AaBb x AaBb) would yield offspring with a phenotypic ratio of 15 triangular:1 ovoid.
7.12.548	As you work through genetics problems, keep in mind that any single characteristic that results in a phenotypic ratio that totals 16 is typical of a two-gene interaction.
7.12.549	Recall the phenotypic inheritance pattern for Mendel’s dihybrid cross, which considered two non-interacting genes—9:3:3:1.
7.12.550	Similarly, we would expect interacting gene pairs to also exhibit ratios expressed as 16 parts.
7.12.551	Note that we are assuming the interacting genes are not linked; they are still assorting independently into gametes.
7.13.0	Chromosomes are threadlike nuclear structures consisting of DNA and proteins that serve as the repositories for genetic information.
7.13.1	The chromosomes depicted here were isolated from a fruit fly’s salivary gland, stained with dye, and visualized under a microscope.
7.13.2	Akin to miniature bar codes, chromosomes absorb different dyes to produce characteristic banding patterns, which allows for their routine identification.
7.13.3	Introduction
7.13.4	The gene is the physical unit of inheritance, and genes are arranged in a linear order on chromosomes.
7.13.5	The behaviors and interactions of chromosomes during meiosis explain, at a cellular level, the patterns of inheritance that we observe in populations.
7.13.6	Genetic disorders involving alterations in chromosome number or structure may have dramatic effects and can prevent a fertilized egg from developing altogether.
7.13.7	studying heredity in 1843.With the improvement of microscopic techniques during the late 1800s, cell biologists could stain and visualize subcellular structures with dyes and observe their actions during cell division and meiosis.
7.13.8	With each mitotic division, chromosomes replicated, condensed from an amorphous (no constant shape) nuclear mass into distinct X-shaped bodies (pairs of identical sister chromatids), and migrated to separate cellular poles.
7.13.9	Chromosomal Theory of Inheritance
7.13.10	The speculation that chromosomes might be the key to understanding heredity led several scientists to examine Mendel’s publications and re-evaluate his model in terms of the behavior of chromosomes during mitosis and meiosis.
7.13.11	In 1902, Theodor Boveri observed that proper embryonic development of sea urchins does not occur unless chromosomes are present.
7.13.12	That same year, Walter Sutton observed the separation of chromosomes into daughter cells during meiosis (Figure 13.2).
7.13.13	Together, these observations led to the development of the Chromosomal Theory of Inheritance, which identified chromosomes as the genetic material responsible for Mendelian inheritance.
7.13.14	(a)
7.13.15	Walter Sutton and (b)
7.13.16	Theodor Boveri are credited with developing the Chromosomal Theory of Inheritance, which states that chromosomes carry the unit of heredity (genes).
7.13.17	The Chromosomal Theory of Inheritance was consistent with Mendel’s laws and was supported by the following observations:
7.13.18	•
7.13.19	During meiosis, homologous chromosome pairs migrate as discrete structures that are independent of other chromosome pairs.
7.13.20	•
7.13.21	The sorting of chromosomes from each homologous pair into pre-gametes appears to be random.
7.13.22	•
7.13.23	Each parent synthesizes gametes that contain only half of their chromosomal complement.
7.13.24	•
7.13.25	Even though male and female gametes (sperm and egg) differ in size and morphology, they have the same number of chromosomes, suggesting equal genetic contributions from each parent.
7.13.26	•
7.13.27	The gametic chromosomes combine during fertilization to produce offspring with the same chromosome number as their parents.
7.13.28	Despite compelling correlations between the behavior of chromosomes during meiosis and Mendel’s abstract laws, the Chromosomal Theory of Inheritance was proposed long before there was any direct evidence that traits were carried on chromosomes.
7.13.29	Critics pointed out that individuals had far more independently segregating traits than they had chromosomes.
7.13.30	It was only after several years of carrying out crosses with the fruit fly, Drosophila melanogaster, that Thomas Hunt Morgan provided experimental evidence to support the Chromosomal Theory of Inheritance.
7.13.31	Genetic Linkage and
7.13.32	Distances Mendel’s work suggested that traits are inherited independently of each other.
7.13.33	Morgan identified a 1:1 correspondence between a segregating trait and the X chromosome, suggesting that the random segregation of chromosomes was the physical basis of Mendel’s model.
7.13.34	This also demonstrated that linked genes disrupt Mendel’s predicted outcomes.
7.13.35	The fact that each chromosome can carry many linked genes explains how individuals can have many more traits than they have chromosomes.
7.13.36	However, observations by researchers in Morgan’s laboratory suggested that alleles positioned on the same chromosome were not always inherited together.
7.13.37	During meiosis, linked genes somehow became unlinked.
7.13.38	Homologous Recombination
7.13.39	In 1909, Frans Janssen observed chiasmata—the point at which chromatids are in contact with each other and may exchange segments
7.13.40	—prior to the first division of meiosis.
7.13.41	He suggested that alleles become unlinked and chromosomes physically exchange segments.
7.13.42	As chromosomes condensed and paired with their homologs, they appeared to interact at distinct points.
7.13.43	Janssen suggested that these points corresponded to regions in which chromosome segments were exchanged.
7.13.44	It is now known that the pairing and interaction between homologous chromosomes, known as synapsis, does more than simply organize the homologs for migration to separate daughter cells.
7.13.45	When synapsed, homologous chromosomes undergo reciprocal physical exchanges at their arms in a process called homologous recombination, or more simply, “crossing over.
7.13.46	”
7.13.47	To better understand the type of experimental results that researchers were obtaining at this time, consider a heterozygous individual that inherited dominant maternal alleles for two genes on the same chromosome (such as AB) and two recessive paternal alleles for those same genes (such as ab).
7.13.48	If the genes are linked, one would expect this individual to produce gametes that are either AB or ab with a 1:1 ratio.
7.13.49	If the genes are unlinked, the individual should produce AB, Ab, aB, and ab gametes with equal frequencies, according to the Mendelian concept of independent assortment.
7.13.50	Because they correspond to new allele combinations, the genotypes Ab and aB are nonparental types that result from homologous recombination during meiosis.
7.13.51	Parental types are progeny that exhibit the same allelic combination as their parents.
7.13.52	Morgan and his colleagues, however, found that when such heterozygous individuals were test crossed to a homozygous recessive parent (AaBb × aabb), both parental and nonparental cases occurred.
7.13.53	For example, 950 offspring might be recovered that were either AaBb or aabb, but 50 offspring would also be obtained that were either Aabb or aaBb.
7.13.54	These results suggested that linkage occurred most often, but a significant minority of offspring were the products of recombination.
7.13.55	Inheritance patterns of unlinked and linked genes are shown.
7.13.56	In (a), two genes are located on different chromosomes so independent assortment occurs during meiosis.
7.13.57	The offspring have an equal chance of being the parental type (inheriting the same combination of traits as the parents) or a nonparental type (inheriting a different combination of traits than the parents).
7.13.58	In (b), two genes are very close together on the same chromosome so that no crossing over occurs between them.
7.13.59	The genes are therefore always inherited together and all of the offspring are the parental type.
7.13.60	In (c), two genes are far apart on the chromosome such that crossing over occurs during every meiotic event.
7.13.61	The recombination frequency will be the same as if the genes were on separate chromosomes.
7.13.62	(d)
7.13.63	The actual recombination frequency of fruit fly wing length and body color that Thomas Morgan observed in 1912 was 17 percent.
7.13.64	A crossover frequency between 0 percent and 50 percent indicates that the genes are on the same chromosome and crossover occurs some of the time.
7.13.65	Genetic Maps Janssen did not have the technology to demonstrate crossing over so it remained an abstract idea that was not widely accepted.
7.13.66	Scientists thought chiasmata were a variation on synapsis and could not understand how chromosomes could break and rejoin.
7.13.67	Yet, the data were clear that linkage did not always occur.
7.13.68	Ultimately, it took a young undergraduate student and an “all-nighter” to mathematically elucidate the problem of linkage and recombination.
7.13.69	In 1913, Alfred Sturtevant, a student in Morgan’s laboratory, gathered results from researchers in the laboratory, and took them home one night to mull them over.
7.13.70	By the next morning, he had created the first “chromosome map,” a linear representation of gene order and relative distance on a chromosome.
7.13.71	As shown in Figure 13.4, by using recombination frequency to predict genetic distance, the relative order of genes on chromosome 2 could be inferred.
7.13.72	The values shown represent map distances in centimorgans (cM), which correspond to recombination frequencies (in percent).
7.13.73	Therefore, the genes for body color and wing size were 65.5 − 48.5
7.13.74	= 17 cM apart, indicating that the maternal and paternal alleles for these genes recombine in 17 percent of offspring, on average.
7.13.75	To construct a chromosome map, Sturtevant assumed that genes were ordered serially on threadlike chromosomes.
7.13.76	He also assumed that the incidence of recombination between two homologous chromosomes could occur with equal likelihood anywhere along the length of the chromosome.
7.13.77	Operating under these assumptions, Sturtevant postulated that alleles that were far apart on a chromosome were more likely to dissociate during meiosis simply because there was a larger region over which recombination could occur.
7.13.78	Conversely, alleles that were close to each other on the chromosome were likely to be inherited together.
7.13.79	The average number of crossovers between two alleles—that is, their recombination frequency—correlated with their genetic distance from each other, relative to the locations of other genes on that chromosome.
7.13.80	Considering the example cross between AaBb and aabb above, the frequency of recombination could be calculated as 50/1000 = 0.05.
7.13.81	That is, the likelihood of a crossover between
7.13.82	genes A/a and B/b was 0.05, or 5 percent.
7.13.83	Such a result would indicate that the genes were definitively linked, but that they were far enough apart for crossovers to occasionally occur.
7.13.84	Sturtevant divided his genetic map into map units, or centimorgans (cM), in which a recombination frequency of 0.01 corresponds to 1 cM.
7.13.85	By representing alleles in a linear map, Sturtevant suggested that genes can range from being perfectly linked (recombination frequency = 0) to being perfectly unlinked (recombination frequency = 0.5) when genes are on different chromosomes or genes are separated very far apart on the same chromosome.
7.13.86	Perfectly unlinked genes correspond to the frequencies predicted by Mendel to assort independently in a dihybrid cross.
7.13.87	A recombination frequency of 0.5 indicates that 50 percent of offspring are recombinants and the other 50 percent are parental types.
7.13.88	That is, every type of allele combination is represented with equal frequency.
7.13.89	This representation allowed Sturtevant to additively calculate distances between several genes on the same chromosome.
7.13.90	However, as the genetic distances approached 0.50, his predictions became less accurate because it was not clear whether the genes were very far apart on the same chromosome or on different chromosomes.
7.13.91	In 1931, Barbara McClintock and Harriet Creighton demonstrated the crossover of homologous chromosomes in corn plants.
7.13.92	Weeks later, homologous recombination in Drosophila was demonstrated microscopically by Curt Stern.
7.13.93	Stern observed several X-linked phenotypes that were associated with a structurally unusual and dissimilar X chromosome pair in which one X was missing a small terminal segment, and the other X was fused to a piece of the Y chromosome.
7.13.94	By crossing flies, observing their offspring, and then visualizing the offspring’s chromosomes, Stern demonstrated that every time the offspring allele combination deviated from either of the parental combinations, there was a corresponding exchange of an X chromosome segment.
7.13.95	Using mutant flies with structurally distinct X chromosomes was the key to observing the products of recombination because DNA sequencing and other molecular tools were not yet available.
7.13.96	It is now known that homologous chromosomes regularly exchange segments in meiosis by reciprocally breaking and rejoining their DNA at precise locations.
7.13.97	Mendel’s Mapped Traits Homologous recombination is a common genetic process, yet Mendel never observed it.
7.13.98	Had he investigated both linked and unlinked genes, it would have been much more difficult for him to create a unified model of his data on the basis of probabilistic calculations.
7.13.99	Researchers who have since mapped the seven traits investigated by Mendel onto the seven chromosomes of the pea plant genome have confirmed that all of the genes he examined are either on separate chromosomes or are sufficiently far apart as to be statistically unlinked.
7.13.100	Some have suggested that Mendel was enormously lucky to select only unlinked genes, whereas others question whether Mendel discarded any data suggesting linkage.
7.13.101	In any case, Mendel consistently observed independent assortment because he examined genes that were effectively unlinked.
7.13.102	Inherited disorders can arise when chromosomes behave abnormally during meiosis.
7.13.103	Chromosome disorders can be divided into two categories: abnormalities in chromosome number and chromosomal structural rearrangements.
7.13.104	Because even small segments of chromosomes can span many genes, chromosomal disorders are characteristically dramatic and often fatal.
7.13.105	Identification of Chromosomes
7.13.106	The isolation and microscopic observation of chromosomes forms the basis of cytogenetics and is the primary method by which clinicians detect chromosomal abnormalities in humans.
7.13.107	A karyotype is the number and appearance of chromosomes, and includes their length, banding pattern, and centromere position.
7.13.108	To obtain a view of an individual’s karyotype, cytologists photograph the chromosomes and then cut and paste each chromosome into a chart, or karyogram, also known as an ideogram.
7.13.109	This karyotype is of a female human.
7.13.110	Notice that homologous chromosomes are the same size, and have the same centromere positions and banding patterns.
7.13.111	A human male would have an XY chromosome pair instead of the XX pair shown.
7.13.112	(credit:
7.13.113	Andreas Blozer et al)
7.13.114	In a given species, chromosomes can be identified by their number, size, centromere position, and banding pattern.
7.13.115	In a human karyotype, autosomes or “body chromosomes” (all of the non–sex chromosomes) are generally organized in approximate order of size from largest (chromosome 1) to smallest (chromosome 22).
7.13.116	The X and Y chromosomes are not autosomes.
7.13.117	However, chromosome 21 is actually shorter than chromosome 22.
7.13.118	This was discovered after the naming of Down syndrome as trisomy 21, reflecting how this disease results from possessing one extra chromosome 21 (three total).
7.13.119	Not wanting to change the name of this important disease, chromosome 21 retained its numbering, despite describing the shortest set of chromosomes.
7.13.120	The chromosome “arms” projecting from either end of the centromere may be designated as short or long, depending on their relative lengths.
7.13.121	The short arm is abbreviated p (for “petite”), whereas the long arm is abbreviated q (because it follows “p” alphabetically).
7.13.122	Each arm is further subdivided and denoted by a number.
7.13.123	Using this naming system, locations on chromosomes can be described consistently in the scientific literature.
7.13.124	Geneticists Use Karyograms to Identify Chromosomal Aberrations
7.13.125	Although Mendel is referred to as the “father of modern genetics,” he performed his experiments with none of the tools that the geneticists of today routinely employ.
7.13.126	One such powerful cytological technique is karyotyping, a method in which traits characterized by chromosomal abnormalities can be identified from a single cell.
7.13.127	To observe an individual’s karyotype, a person’s cells (like white blood cells) are first collected from a blood sample or other tissue.
7.13.128	In the laboratory, the isolated cells are stimulated to begin actively dividing.
7.13.129	A chemical called colchicine is then applied to cells to arrest condensed chromosomes in metaphase.
7.13.130	Cells are then made to swell using a hypotonic solution so the chromosomes spread apart.
7.13.131	Finally, the sample is preserved in a fixative and applied to a slide.
7.13.132	The geneticist then stains chromosomes with one of several dyes to better visualize the distinct and reproducible banding patterns of each chromosome pair.
7.13.133	Following staining, the chromosomes are viewed using bright-field microscopy.
7.13.134	A common stain choice is the Giemsa stain.
7.13.135	Giemsa staining results in approximately 400–800 bands (of tightly coiled DNA and condensed proteins) arranged along all of the 23 chromosome pairs; an experienced geneticist can identify each band.
7.13.136	In addition to the banding patterns, chromosomes are further identified on the basis of size and centromere location.
7.13.137	To obtain the classic depiction of the karyotype in which homologous pairs of chromosomes are aligned in numerical order from longest to shortest, the geneticist obtains a digital image, identifies each chromosome, and manually arranges the chromosomes into this pattern (Figure 13.5).
7.13.138	At its most basic, the karyogram may reveal genetic abnormalities in which an individual has too many or too few chromosomes per cell.
7.13.139	Examples of this are Down Syndrome, which is identified by a third copy of chromosome 21, and Turner Syndrome, which is characterized by the presence of only one X chromosome in women instead of the normal two.
7.13.140	Geneticists can also identify large deletions or insertions of DNA.
7.13.141	For instance, Jacobsen Syndrome—which involves distinctive facial features as well as heart and bleeding defects—is identified by a deletion on chromosome 11.
7.13.142	Finally, the karyotype can pinpoint translocations, which occur when a segment of genetic material breaks from one chromosome and reattaches to another chromosome or to a different part of the same chromosome.
7.13.143	Translocations are implicated in certain cancers, including chronic myelogenous leukemia.
7.13.144	During Mendel’s lifetime, inheritance was an abstract concept that could only be inferred by performing crosses and observing the traits expressed by offspring.
7.13.145	By observing a karyogram, today’s geneticists can actually visualize the chromosomal composition of an individual to confirm or predict genetic abnormalities in offspring, even before birth.
7.13.146	Disorders in Chromosome Number
7.13.147	Of all of the chromosomal disorders, abnormalities in chromosome number are the most obviously identifiable from a karyogram.
7.13.148	Disorders of chromosome number include the duplication or loss of entire chromosomes, as well as changes in the number of complete sets of chromosomes.
7.13.149	They are caused by nondisjunction, which occurs when pairs of homologous chromosomes or sister chromatids fail to separate during meiosis.
7.13.150	Misaligned or incomplete synapsis, or a dysfunction of the spindle apparatus that facilitates chromosome migration, can cause nondisjunction.
7.13.151	The risk of nondisjunction occurring increases with the age of the parents.
7.13.152	Nondisjunction can occur during either meiosis I or II, with differing results (Figure 13.6).
7.13.153	If homologous chromosomes fail to separate during meiosis
7.13.154	I, the result is two gametes that lack that particular chromosome and two gametes with two copies of the chromosome.
7.13.155	If sister chromatids fail to separate during meiosis II, the result is one gamete that lacks that chromosome, two normal gametes with one copy of the chromosome, and one gamete with two copies of the chromosome.
7.13.156	Aneuploidy
7.13.157	An individual with the appropriate number of chromosomes for their species is called euploid; in humans, euploidy corresponds to 22 pairs of autosomes and one pair of sex chromosomes.
7.13.158	An individual with an error in chromosome number is described as aneuploid, a term that includes monosomy (loss of one chromosome) or trisomy (gain of an extraneous chromosome).
7.13.159	Monosomic human zygotes missing any one copy of an autosome invariably fail to develop to birth because they lack essential genes.
7.13.160	This underscores the importance of “gene dosage” in humans.
7.13.161	Most autosomal trisomies also fail to develop to birth; however, duplications of some of the smaller chromosomes (13, 15, 18, 21, or 22) can result in offspring that survive for several weeks to many years.
7.13.162	Trisomic individuals suffer from a different type of genetic imbalance: an excess in gene dose.
7.13.163	Individuals with an extra chromosome may synthesize an abundance of the gene products encoded by that chromosome.
7.13.164	This extra dose (150 percent) of specific genes can lead to a number of functional challenges and often precludes development.
7.13.165	The most common trisomy among viable births is that of chromosome 21, which corresponds to Down Syndrome.
7.13.166	Individuals with this inherited disorder are characterized by short stature and stunted digits, facial distinctions that include a broad skull and large tongue, and significant developmental delays.
7.13.167	The incidence of Down syndrome is correlated with maternal age; older women are more likely to become pregnant with fetuses carrying the trisomy 21 genotype.
7.13.168	An individual with more than the correct number of chromosome sets (two for diploid species) is called polyploid.
7.13.169	For instance, fertilization of an abnormal diploid egg with a normal haploid sperm would yield a triploid zygote.
7.13.170	Polyploid animals are extremely rare, with only a few examples among the flatworms, crustaceans, amphibians, fish, and lizards.
7.13.171	Polyploid animals are sterile because meiosis cannot proceed normally and instead produces mostly aneuploid daughter cells that cannot yield viable zygotes.
7.13.172	Rarely, polyploid animals can reproduce asexually by haplodiploidy, in which an unfertilized egg divides mitotically to produce offspring.
7.13.173	In contrast, polyploidy is very common in the plant kingdom, and polyploid plants tend to be larger and more robust than euploids of their species (Figure 13.8).
7.13.174	The incidence of having a fetus with trisomy 21 increases dramatically with maternal age.
7.13.175	As with many polyploid plants, this triploid orange daylily (Hemerocallis fulva) is particularly large and robust, and grows flowers with triple the number of petals of its diploid counterparts.
7.13.176	(credit: Steve Karg)
7.13.177	Sex Chromosome Nondisjunction in Humans Humans display dramatic deleterious effects with autosomal trisomies and monosomies.
7.13.178	Therefore, it may seem counterintuitive that human females and males can function normally, despite carrying different numbers of the X chromosome.
7.13.179	Rather than a gain or loss of autosomes, variations in the number of sex chromosomes are associated with relatively mild effects.
7.13.180	In part, this occurs because of a molecular process called X inactivation.
7.13.181	Early in development, when female mammalian embryos consist of just a few thousand cells (relative to trillions in the newborn), one X chromosome in each cell inactivates by tightly condensing into a quiescent (dormant) structure called a Barr body.
7.13.182	The chance that an X chromosome (maternally or paternally derived) is inactivated in each cell is random, but once the inactivation occurs, all cells derived from that one will have the same inactive X chromosome or Barr body.
7.13.183	By this process, females compensate for their double genetic dose of X chromosome.
7.13.184	In so-called “tortoiseshell” cats, embryonic X inactivation is observed as color variegation (Figure 13.9).
7.13.185	Females that are heterozygous for an X-linked coat color gene will express one of two different coat colors over different regions of their body, corresponding to whichever X chromosome is inactivated in the embryonic cell progenitor of that region.
7.13.186	In cats, the gene for coat color is located on the X chromosome.
7.13.187	In the embryonic development of female cats, one of the two X chromosomes is randomly inactivated in each cell, resulting in a tortoiseshell pattern if the cat has two different alleles for coat color.
7.13.188	Male cats, having only one X chromosome, never exhibit a tortoiseshell coat color.
7.13.189	(credit: Michael Bodega)
7.13.190	An individual carrying an abnormal number of X chromosomes will inactivate all but one X chromosome in each of her cells.
7.13.191	However, even inactivated X chromosomes continue to express a few genes, and X chromosomes must reactivate for the proper maturation of female ovaries.
7.13.192	As a result, X-chromosomal abnormalities are typically associated with mild mental and physical defects, as well as sterility.
7.13.193	If the X chromosome is absent altogether, the individual will not develop in utero.
7.13.194	Several errors in sex chromosome number have been characterized.
7.13.195	Individuals with three X chromosomes, called triplo- X, are phenotypically female but express developmental delays and reduced fertility.
7.13.196	The XXY genotype, corresponding to one type of Klinefelter syndrome, corresponds to phenotypically male individuals with small testes, enlarged breasts, and reduced body hair.
7.13.197	More complex types of Klinefelter syndrome exist in which the individual has as many as five X chromosomes.
7.13.198	In all types, every X chromosome except one undergoes inactivation to compensate for the excess genetic dosage.
7.13.199	This can be seen as several Barr bodies in each cell nucleus.
7.13.200	Turner syndrome, characterized as an X0 genotype (i.e., only a single sex chromosome), corresponds to a phenotypically female individual with short stature, webbed skin in the neck region, hearing and cardiac impairments, and sterility.
7.13.201	Duplications and Deletions
7.13.202	In addition to the loss or gain of an entire chromosome, a chromosomal segment may be duplicated or lost.
7.13.203	Duplications and deletions often produce offspring that survive but exhibit physical and mental abnormalities.
7.13.204	Duplicated chromosomal segments may fuse to existing chromosomes or may be free in the nucleus.
7.13.205	Cri-du-chat (from the French for “cry of the cat”) is a syndrome associated with nervous system abnormalities and identifiable physical features that result from a deletion of most of 5p (the small arm of chromosome 5)
7.13.206	(Figure 13.10).
7.13.207	Infants with this genotype emit a characteristic high-pitched cry on which the disorder’s name is based.
7.13.208	This individual with cri-du-chat syndrome is shown at two, four, nine, and 12 years of age.
