7.13.209	Chromosomal Structural Rearrangements Cytologists have characterized numerous structural rearrangements in chromosomes, but chromosome inversions and translocations are the most common.
7.13.210	Both are identified during meiosis by the adaptive pairing of rearranged chromosomes with their former homologs to maintain appropriate gene alignment.
7.13.211	If the genes carried on two homologs are not oriented correctly, a recombination event could result in the loss of genes from one chromosome and the gain of genes on the other.
7.13.212	This would produce aneuploid gametes.
7.13.213	Chromosome Inversions
7.13.214	A chromosome inversion is the detachment, 180° rotation, and reinsertion of part of a chromosome.
7.13.215	Inversions may occur in nature as a result of mechanical shear, or from the action of transposable elements (special DNA sequences capable of facilitating the rearrangement of chromosome segments with the help of enzymes that cut and paste DNA sequences).
7.13.216	Unless they disrupt a gene sequence, inversions only change the orientation of genes and are likely to have more mild effects than aneuploid errors.
7.13.217	However, altered gene orientation can result in functional changes because regulators of gene expression could be moved out of position with respect to their targets, causing aberrant levels of gene products.
7.13.218	An inversion can be pericentric and include the centromere, or paracentric and occur outside of the centromere (Figure 13.11).
7.13.219	A pericentric inversion that is asymmetric about the centromere can change the relative lengths of the chromosome arms, making these inversions easily identifiable.
7.13.220	Pericentric inversions include the centromere, and paracentric inversions do not.
7.13.221	A pericentric inversion can change the relative lengths of the chromosome arms; a paracentric inversion cannot.
7.13.222	When one homologous chromosome undergoes an inversion but the other does not, the individual is described as an inversion heterozygote.
7.13.223	To maintain point-for-point synapsis during meiosis, one homolog must form a loop, and the other homolog must mold around it.
7.13.224	Although this topology can ensure that the genes are correctly aligned, it also forces the homologs to stretch and can be associated with regions of imprecise synapsis.
7.13.225	When one chromosome undergoes an inversion but the other does not, one chromosome must form an inverted loop to retain point-for-point interaction during synapsis.
7.13.226	This inversion pairing is essential to maintaining gene alignment during meiosis and to allow for recombination.
7.13.227	The Chromosome 18 Inversion Not all structural rearrangements of chromosomes produce nonviable, impaired, or infertile individuals.
7.13.228	In rare instances, such a change can result in the evolution of a new species.
7.13.229	In fact, a pericentric inversion in chromosome 18 appears to have contributed to the evolution of humans.
7.13.230	This inversion is not present in our closest genetic relatives, the chimpanzees.
7.13.231	Humans and chimpanzees differ cytogenetically by pericentric inversions on several chromosomes and by the fusion of two separate chromosomes in chimpanzees that correspond to chromosome two in humans.
7.13.232	The pericentric chromosome 18 inversion is believed to have occurred in early humans following their divergence from a common ancestor with chimpanzees approximately five million years ago.
7.13.233	Researchers characterizing this inversion have suggested that approximately 19,000 nucleotide bases were duplicated on 18p, and the duplicated region inverted and reinserted on chromosome 18 of an ancestral human.
7.13.234	A comparison of human and chimpanzee genes in the region of this inversion indicates that two genes—ROCK1 and USP14—that are adjacent on chimpanzee chromosome 17 (which corresponds to human chromosome 18) are more distantly positioned on human chromosome 18.
7.13.235	This suggests that one of the inversion breakpoints occurred between these two genes.
7.13.236	Interestingly, humans and chimpanzees express USP14 at distinct levels in specific cell types, including cortical cells and fibroblasts.
7.13.237	Perhaps the chromosome 18 inversion in an ancestral human repositioned specific genes and reset their expression levels in a useful way.
7.13.238	Because both ROCK1 and USP14 encode cellular enzymes, a change in their expression could alter cellular function.
7.13.239	It is not known how this inversion contributed to hominid evolution, but it appears to be a significant factor in the divergence of humans from other primates.
7.13.240	Translocations
7.13.241	A translocation occurs when a segment of a chromosome dissociates and reattaches to a different, nonhomologous chromosome.
7.13.242	Translocations can be benign or have devastating effects depending on how the positions of genes are altered with respect to regulatory sequences.
7.13.243	Notably, specific translocations have been associated with several cancers and with schizophrenia.
7.13.244	Reciprocal translocations result from the exchange of chromosome segments between two nonhomologous chromosomes such that there is no gain or loss of genetic information.
7.13.245	A reciprocal translocation occurs when a segment of DNA is transferred from one chromosome to another, nonhomologous chromosome.  
7.14.0	Introduction
7.14.1	The three letters “DNA” have now become synonymous with crime solving, paternity testing, human identification, and genetic testing.
7.14.2	DNA can be retrieved from hair, blood, or saliva.
7.14.3	Each person’s DNA is unique, and it is possible to detect differences between individuals within a species on the basis of these unique features.
7.14.4	DNA analysis has many practical applications beyond forensics.
7.14.5	In humans, DNA testing is applied to numerous uses: determining paternity, tracing genealogy, identifying pathogens, archeological research, tracing disease outbreaks, and studying human migration patterns.
7.14.6	In the medical field, DNA is used in diagnostics, new vaccine development, and cancer therapy.
7.14.7	It is now possible to determine predisposition to diseases by looking at genes.
7.14.8	Each human cell has 23 pairs of chromosomes: one set of chromosomes is inherited from the mother and the other set is inherited from the father.
7.14.9	There is also a mitochondrial genome, inherited exclusively from the mother, which can be involved in inherited genetic disorders.
7.14.10	On each chromosome, there are thousands of genes that are responsible for determining the genotype and phenotype of the individual.
7.14.11	A gene is defined as a sequence of DNA that codes for a functional product.
7.14.12	The human haploid genome contains 3 billion base pairs and has between 20,000 and 25,000 functional genes.
7.14.13	Modern understandings of DNA have evolved from the discovery of nucleic acid to the development of the double-helix model.
7.14.14	In the 1860s, Friedrich Miescher (Figure 14.2), a physician by profession, was the first person to isolate phosphaterich chemicals from white blood cells or leukocytes.
7.14.15	He named these chemicals (which would eventually be known as RNA and DNA) nuclein because they were isolated from the nuclei of the cells.
7.14.16	A half century later, British bacteriologist Frederick Griffith was perhaps the first person to show that hereditary information could be transferred from one cell to another “horizontally,” rather than by descent.
7.14.17	In 1928, he reported the first demonstration of bacterial transformation, a process in which external DNA is taken up by a cell, thereby changing morphology and physiology.
7.14.18	He was working with Streptococcus pneumoniae, the bacterium that causes pneumonia.
7.14.19	Griffith worked with two strains, rough (R) and smooth (S).
7.14.20	The R strain is non-pathogenic (does not cause disease) and is called rough because its outer surface is a cell wall and lacks a capsule; as a result, the cell surface appears uneven under the microscope.
7.14.21	The S strain is pathogenic (disease-causing) and has a capsule outside its cell wall.
7.14.22	As a result, it has a smooth appearance under the microscope.
7.14.23	Griffith injected the live R strain into mice and they survived.
7.14.24	In another experiment, when he injected mice with the heat-killed S strain, they also survived.
7.14.25	In a third set of experiments, a mixture of live R strain and heat-killed S strain were injected into mice, and—to his surprise—
7.14.26	the mice died.
7.14.27	Upon isolating the live bacteria from the dead mouse, only the S strain of bacteria was recovered.
7.14.28	When this isolated S strain was injected into fresh mice, the mice died.
7.14.29	Griffith concluded that something had passed from the heat-killed S strain into the live R strain and transformed it into the pathogenic S strain, and he called this the transforming principle (Figure 14.3).
7.14.30	These experiments are now famously known as Griffith's transformation experiments.
7.14.31	Two strains of S. pneumoniae were used in Griffith’s transformation experiments.
7.14.32	The R strain is nonpathogenic.
7.14.33	The S strain is pathogenic and causes death.
7.14.34	When Griffith injected a mouse with the heat-killed S strain and a live R strain, the mouse died.
7.14.35	The S strain was recovered from the dead mouse.
7.14.36	Thus, Griffith concluded that something had passed from the heat-killed S strain to the R strain, transforming the R strain into S strain in the process.
7.14.37	(credit "living mouse": modification of work by NIH; credit "dead mouse": modification of work by Sarah Marriage)
7.14.38	Scientists Oswald Avery, Colin MacLeod, and Maclyn McCarty (1944) were interested in exploring this transforming principle further.
7.14.39	They isolated the S strain from the dead mice and isolated the proteins and nucleic acids, namely RNA and DNA, as these were possible candidates for the molecule of heredity.
7.14.40	They conducted a systematic elimination study.
7.14.41	They used enzymes that specifically degraded each component and then used each mixture separately to transform the R strain.
7.14.42	They found that when DNA was degraded, the resulting mixture was no longer able to transform the bacteria, whereas all of the other combinations were able to transform the bacteria.
7.14.43	This led them to conclude that DNA was the transforming principle.
7.14.44	Forensic Scientists and DNA Analysis DNA evidence was used for the first time to solve an immigration case.
7.14.45	The story started with a teenage boy returning to London from Ghana to be with his mother.
7.14.46	Immigration authorities at the airport were suspicious of him, thinking that he was traveling on a forged passport.
7.14.47	After much persuasion, he was allowed to go live with his mother, but the immigration authorities did not drop the case against him.
7.14.48	All types of evidence, including photographs, were provided to the authorities, but deportation proceedings were started nevertheless.
7.14.49	Around the same time, Dr. Alec Jeffreys of Leicester University in the United Kingdom had invented a technique known as DNA fingerprinting.
7.14.50	The immigration authorities approached Dr. Jeffreys for help.
7.14.51	He took DNA samples from the mother and three of her children, plus an unrelated mother, and compared the samples with the boy’s DNA.
7.14.52	Because the biological father was not in the picture, DNA from the three children was compared with the boy’s DNA.
7.14.53	He found a match in the boy’s DNA for both the mother and his three siblings.
7.14.54	He concluded that the boy was indeed the mother’s son.
7.14.55	Forensic scientists analyze many items, including documents, handwriting, firearms, and biological samples.
7.14.56	They analyze the DNA content of hair, semen, saliva, and blood, and compare it with a database of DNA profiles of known criminals.
7.14.57	Analysis includes DNA isolation, sequencing, and sequence analysis; most forensic DNA analysis involves polymerase chain reaction (PCR) amplification of short tandem repeat (STR) loci and electrophoresis to determine the length of the PCR-amplified fragment.
7.14.58	Only mitochondrial DNA is sequenced for forensics.
7.14.59	Forensic scientists are expected to appear at court hearings to present their findings.
7.14.60	They are usually employed in crime labs of city and state government agencies.
7.14.61	Geneticists experimenting with DNA techniques also work for scientific and research organizations, pharmaceutical industries, and college and university labs.
7.14.62	Students wishing to pursue a career as a forensic scientist should have at least a bachelor's degree in chemistry, biology, or physics, and preferably some experience working in a laboratory.
7.14.63	material, either DNA or RNA.
7.14.64	The bacteriophage infects the host bacterial cell by attaching to its surface, and then it injects its nucleic acids inside the cell.
7.14.65	The phage DNA makes multiple copies of itself using the host machinery, and eventually the host cell bursts, releasing a large number of bacteriophages.
7.14.66	Hershey and Chase labeled one batch of phage with radioactive sulfur, 35S, to label the protein coat.
7.14.67	Another batch of phage were labeled with radioactive phosphorus, 32P. Because phosphorous is found in DNA, but not protein, the DNA and not the protein would be tagged with radioactive phosphorus.
7.14.68	Each batch of phage was allowed to infect the cells separately.
7.14.69	After infection, the phage bacterial suspension was put in a blender, which caused the phage coat to be detached from the host cell.
7.14.70	The phage and bacterial suspension was spun down in a centrifuge.
7.14.71	The heavier bacterial cells settled down and formed a pellet, whereas the lighter phage particles stayed in the supernatant.
7.14.72	In the tube that contained phage labeled with 35S, the supernatant contained the radioactively labeled phage, whereas no radioactivity was detected in the pellet.
7.14.73	In the tube that contained the phage labeled with 32P, the radioactivity was detected in the pellet that contained the heavier bacterial cells, and no radioactivity was detected in the supernatant.
7.14.74	Hershey and Chase concluded that it was the phage DNA that was injected into the cell and carried information to produce more phage particles, thus providing evidence that DNA was the genetic material and not proteins.
7.14.75	In Hershey and Chase's experiments, bacteria were infected with phage radiolabeled with either 35S, which labels protein, or 32P, which labels DNA.
7.14.76	Only 32P entered the bacterial cells, indicating that DNA is the genetic material.
7.14.77	Around this same time, Austrian biochemist Erwin Chargaff examined the content of DNA in different species and found that the amounts of adenine, thymine, guanine, and cytosine were not found in equal quantities, and that it varied from species to species, but not between individuals of the same species.
7.14.78	He found that the amount of adenine equals the amount of thymine, and the amount of cytosine equals the amount of guanine, or A = T and G
7.14.79	= C. This is also known as Chargaff’s rules.
7.14.80	This finding proved immensely useful when Watson and Crick were getting ready to propose their DNA double helix model.
7.14.81	DNA Structure and Sequencing
7.14.82	The building blocks of DNA are nucleotides.
7.14.83	The important components of the nucleotide are a nitrogenous base, deoxyribose (5-carbon sugar), and a phosphate group (Figure 14.5).
7.14.84	The nucleotide is named depending on the nitrogenous base.
7.14.85	The nitrogenous base can be a purine such as adenine (A) and guanine (G), or a pyrimidine such as cytosine (C) and thymine (T).
7.14.86	The nucleotides combine with each other by covalent bonds known as phosphodiester bonds or linkages.
7.14.87	The purines have a double ring structure with a six-membered ring fused to a five-membered ring.
7.14.88	Pyrimidines are smaller in size; they have a single six-membered ring structure.
7.14.89	The carbon atoms of the five-carbon sugar are numbered 1', 2', 3', 4', and 5' (1' is read as “one prime”).
7.14.90	The phosphate residue is attached to the hydroxyl group of the 5' carbon of one sugar of one nucleotide and the hydroxyl group of the 3' carbon of the sugar of the next nucleotide, thereby forming a 5'-3' phosphodiester bond.
7.14.91	In the 1950s, Francis Crick and James Watson worked together to determine the structure of DNA at the University of Cambridge, England.
7.14.92	Other scientists like Linus Pauling and Maurice Wilkins were also actively exploring this field.
7.14.93	Pauling had discovered the secondary structure of proteins using X-ray crystallography.
7.14.94	InWilkins’ lab, researcher Rosalind Franklin was using X-ray diffraction methods to understand the structure of DNA.
7.14.95	Watson and Crick were able to piece together the puzzle of the DNA molecule on the basis of Franklin's data because Crick had also studied X-ray diffraction (Figure 14.6).
7.14.96	In 1962, James Watson, Francis Crick, and Maurice Wilkins were awarded the Nobel Prize in Medicine.
7.14.97	Unfortunately, by then Franklin had died, and Nobel prizes are not awarded posthumously.
7.14.98	Each nucleotide is made up of a sugar, a phosphate group, and a nitrogenous base.
7.14.99	The sugar is deoxyribose in DNA and ribose in RNA.
7.14.100	The work of pioneering scientists (a) James Watson, Francis Crick, and Maclyn McCarty led to our present day understanding of DNA.
7.14.101	Scientist Rosalind Franklin discovered (b) the X-ray diffraction pattern of DNA, which helped to elucidate its double helix structure.
7.14.102	(credit a: modification of work by Marjorie McCarty, Public Library of Science)
7.14.103	Watson and Crick proposed that DNA is made up of two strands that are twisted around each other to form a right-handed helix.
7.14.104	Base pairing takes place between a purine and pyrimidine; namely, A pairs with T and G pairs with C. Adenine and thymine are complementary base pairs, and cytosine and guanine are also complementary base pairs.
7.14.105	The base pairs are stabilized by hydrogen bonds; adenine and thymine form two hydrogen bonds and cytosine and guanine form three hydrogen bonds.
7.14.106	The two strands are anti-parallel in nature; that is, the 3' end of one strand faces the 5' end of the other strand.
7.14.107	The sugar and phosphate of the nucleotides form the backbone of the structure, whereas the nitrogenous bases are stacked inside.
7.14.108	Each base pair is separated from the other base pair by a distance of 0.34 nm, and each turn of the helix measures 3.4 nm.
7.14.109	Therefore, ten base pairs are present per turn of the helix.
7.14.110	The diameter of the DNA double helix is 2 nm, and it is uniform throughout.
7.14.111	Only the pairing between a purine and pyrimidine can explain the uniform diameter.
7.14.112	The twisting of the two strands around each other results in the formation of uniformly spaced major and minor grooves.
7.14.113	DNA has (a) a double helix structure and (b) phosphodiester bonds.
7.14.114	The (c) major and minor grooves are binding sites for DNA binding proteins during processes such as transcription (the copying of RNA from DNA) and replication.
7.14.115	DNA Sequencing Techniques Until the 1990s, the sequencing of DNA (reading the sequence of DNA) was a relatively expensive and long process.
7.14.116	Using radiolabeled nucleotides also compounded the problem through safety concerns.
7.14.117	With currently available technology and automated machines, the process is cheap, safer, and can be completed in a matter of hours.
7.14.118	Fred Sanger developed the sequencing method used for the human genome sequencing project, which is widely used today.
7.14.119	The method is known as the dideoxy chain termination method.
7.14.120	The sequencing method is based on the use of chain terminators, the dideoxynucleotides (ddNTPs).
7.14.121	The dideoxynucleotides, or ddNTPSs, differ from the deoxynucleotides by the lack of a free 3' OH group on the five-carbon sugar.
7.14.122	If a ddNTP is added to a growing a DNA strand, the chain is not extended any further because the free 3' OH group needed to add another nucleotide is not available.
7.14.123	By using a predetermined ratio of deoxyribonucleotides to dideoxynucleotides, it is possible to generate DNA fragments of different sizes.
7.14.124	In Frederick Sanger's dideoxy chain termination method, dye-labeled dideoxynucleotides are used to generate DNA fragments that terminate at different points.
7.14.125	The DNA is separated by capillary electrophoresis on the basis of size, and from the order of fragments formed, the DNA sequence can be read.
7.14.126	The DNA sequence readout is shown on an electropherogram that is generated by a laser scanner.
7.14.127	The DNA sample to be sequenced is denatured or separated into two strands by heating it to high temperatures.
7.14.128	The DNA is divided into four tubes in which a primer, DNA polymerase, and all four nucleotides (A, T, G, and C) are added.
7.14.129	In addition to each of the four tubes, limited quantities of one of the four dideoxynucleotides are added to each tube respectively.
7.14.130	The tubes are labeled as A, T, G, and C according to the ddNTP added.
7.14.131	For detection purposes, each of the four dideoxynucleotides carries a different fluorescent label.
7.14.132	Chain elongation continues until a fluorescent dideoxy nucleotide is incorporated, after which no further elongation takes place.
7.14.133	After the reaction is over, electrophoresis is performed.
7.14.134	Even a difference in length of a single base can be detected.
7.14.135	The sequence is read from a laser scanner.
7.14.136	For his work on DNA sequencing, Sanger received a Nobel Prize in chemistry in 1980.
7.14.137	Gel electrophoresis is a technique used to separate DNA fragments of different sizes.
7.14.138	Usually the gel is made of a chemical called agarose.
7.14.139	Agarose powder is added to a buffer and heated.
7.14.140	After cooling, the gel solution is poured into a casting tray.
7.14.141	Once the gel has solidified, the DNA is loaded on the gel and electric current is applied.
7.14.142	The DNA has a net negative charge and moves from the negative electrode toward the positive electrode.
7.14.143	The electric current is applied for sufficient time to let the DNA separate according to size; the smallest fragments will be farthest from the well (where the DNA was loaded), and the heavier molecular weight fragments will be closest to the well.
7.14.144	Once the DNA is separated, the gel is stained with a DNA-specific dye for viewing it.
7.14.145	DNA can be separated on the basis of size using gel electrophoresis.
7.14.146	Neanderthal Genome:
7.14.147	How Are We Related?
7.14.148	The first draft sequence of the Neanderthal genome was recently published by Richard E. Green et al. in 2010.
7.14.149	[1] Neanderthals are the closest ancestors of present-day humans.
7.14.150	They were known to have lived in Europe and Western Asia before they disappeared from fossil records approximately 30,000 years ago.
7.14.151	Green’s team studied almost 40,000-year-old fossil remains that were selected from sites across the world.
7.14.152	Extremely sophisticated means of sample preparation and DNA sequencing were employed because of the fragile nature of the bones and heavy microbial contamination.
7.14.153	In their study, the scientists were able to sequence some four billion base pairs.
7.14.154	The Neanderthal sequence was compared with that of present-day humans from across the world.
7.14.155	After comparing the sequences, the researchers found that the Neanderthal genome had 2 to 3 percent greater similarity to people living outside Africa than to people in Africa.
7.14.156	While current theories have suggested that all present-day humans can be traced to a small ancestral population in Africa, the data from the Neanderthal genome may contradict this view.
7.14.157	Green and his colleagues also discovered DNA segments among people in Europe and Asia that are more similar to Neanderthal sequences than to other contemporary human sequences.
7.14.158	Another interesting observation was that Neanderthals are as closely related to people from Papua New Guinea as to those from China or France.
7.14.159	This is surprising because Neanderthal fossil remains have been located only in Europe and West Asia.
7.14.160	Most likely, genetic exchange took place between Neanderthals and modern humans as modern humans emerged out of Africa, before the divergence of Europeans, East Asians, and Papua New Guineans.
7.14.161	Several genes seem to have undergone changes from Neanderthals during the evolution of presentday humans.
7.14.162	These genes are involved in cranial structure, metabolism, skin morphology, and cognitive development.
7.14.163	One of the genes that is of particular interest is RUNX2, which is different in modern day humans and Neanderthals.
7.14.164	This gene is responsible for the prominent frontal bone, bell-shaped rib cage, and dental differences seen in Neanderthals.
7.14.165	It is speculated that an evolutionary change in RUNX2 was important in the origin of modern-day humans, and this affected the cranium and the upper body.
7.14.166	DNA Packaging in Cells
7.14.167	When comparing prokaryotic cells to eukaryotic cells, prokaryotes are much simpler than eukaryotes in many of their features (Figure 14.10).
7.14.168	Most prokaryotes contain a single, circular chromosome that is found in an area of the cytoplasm called the nucleoid.
7.14.169	A eukaryote contains a well-defined nucleus, whereas in prokaryotes, the chromosome lies in the cytoplasm in an area called the nucleoid.
7.14.170	In eukaryotic cells, DNA and RNA synthesis occur in a separate compartment from protein synthesis.
7.14.171	In prokaryotic cells, both processes occur together.
7.14.172	What advantages might there be to separating the processes?
7.14.173	What advantages might there be to having them occur together?
7.14.174	The size of the genome in one of the most well-studied prokaryotes, E.coli, is 4.6 million base pairs (approximately 1.1 mm, if cut and stretched out).
7.14.175	So how does this fit inside a small bacterial cell?
7.14.176	The DNA is twisted by what is known as supercoiling.
7.14.177	Supercoiling means that DNA is either under-wound (less than one turn of the helix per 10 base pairs) or over-wound (more than 1 turn per 10 base pairs) from its normal relaxed state.
7.14.178	Some proteins are known to be involved in the supercoiling; other proteins and enzymes such as DNA gyrase help in maintaining the supercoiled structure.
7.14.179	Eukaryotes, whose chromosomes each consist of a linear DNA molecule, employ a different type of packing strategy to fit their DNA inside the nucleus (Figure 14.11).
7.14.180	At the most basic level, DNA is wrapped around proteins known as histones to form structures called nucleosomes.
7.14.181	The histones are evolutionarily conserved proteins that are rich in basic amino acids and form an octamer.
7.14.182	The DNA (which is negatively charged because of the phosphate groups) is wrapped tightly around the histone core.
7.14.183	This nucleosome is linked to the next one with the help of a linker DNA.
7.14.184	This is also known as the “beads on a string” structure.
7.14.185	This is further compacted into a 30 nm fiber, which is the diameter of the structure.
7.14.186	At the metaphase stage, the chromosomes are at their most compact, are approximately 700 nm in width, and are found in association with scaffold proteins.
7.14.187	In interphase, eukaryotic chromosomes have two distinct regions that can be distinguished by staining.
7.14.188	The tightly packaged region is known as heterochromatin, and the less dense region is known as euchromatin.
7.14.189	Heterochromatin usually contains genes that are not expressed, and is found in the regions of the centromere and telomeres.
7.14.190	The euchromatin usually contains genes that are transcribed, with DNA packaged around nucleosomes but not further compacted.
7.14.191	Basics of DNA Replication
7.14.192	The elucidation of the structure of the double helix provided a hint as to how DNA divides and makes copies of itself.
7.14.193	This model suggests that the two strands of the double helix separate during replication, and each strand serves as a template from which the new complementary strand is copied.
7.14.194	What was not clear was how the replication took place.
7.14.195	There were three models suggested (Figure 14.12): conservative, semi-conservative, and dispersive.
7.14.196	The three suggested models of DNA replication.
7.14.197	Grey indicates the original DNA strands, and blue indicates newly synthesized DNA.
7.14.198	In conservative replication, the parental DNA remains together, and the newly formed daughter strands are together.
7.14.199	The semi-conservative method suggests that each of the two parental DNA strands act as a template for new DNA to be synthesized; after replication, each double-stranded DNA includes one parental or “old” strand and one “new” strand.
7.14.200	In the dispersive model, both copies of DNA have double-stranded segments of parental DNA and newly synthesized DNA interspersed.
7.14.201	Meselson and Stahl were interested in understanding how DNA replicates.
7.14.202	They grew E. coli for several generations in a medium containing a “heavy” isotope of nitrogen (15N) that gets incorporated into nitrogenous bases, and eventually into the DNA.
7.14.203	Meselson and Stahl experimented with E. coli grown first in heavy nitrogen (15N) then in 14N. DNA grown in 15N (red band) is heavier than DNA grown in 14N (orange band), and sediments to a lower level in cesium chloride solution in an ultracentrifuge.
7.14.204	When DNA grown in 15N is switched to media containing 14N, after one round of cell division the DNA sediments halfway between the 15N and 14N levels, indicating that it now contains fifty percent 14N.
7.14.205	In subsequent cell divisions, an increasing amount of DNA contains 14N only.
7.14.206	This data supports the semi-conservative replication model.
7.14.207	(credit: modification of work by Mariana Ruiz Villareal)
7.14.208	The E. coli culture was then shifted into medium containing 14N and allowed to grow for one generation.
7.14.209	The cells were harvested and the DNA was isolated.
7.14.210	The DNA was centrifuged at high speeds in an ultracentrifuge.
7.14.211	Some cells were allowed to grow for one more life cycle in 14N and spun again.
7.14.212	During the density gradient centrifugation, the DNA is loaded into a gradient (typically a salt such as cesium chloride or sucrose) and spun at high speeds of 50,000 to 60,000 rpm.
7.14.213	Under these circumstances, the DNA will form a band according to its density in the gradient.
7.14.214	DNA grown in 15N will band at a higher density position than that grown in 14N. Meselson and Stahl noted that after one generation of growth in 14N after they had been shifted from 15N, the single band observed was intermediate in position in between DNA of cells grown exclusively in 15N and
7.14.215	14N.
7.14.216	This suggested either a semi-conservative or dispersive mode of replication.
7.14.217	The DNA harvested from cells grown for two generations in 14N formed two bands: one DNA band was at the intermediate position between 15N and 14N, and the other corresponded to the band of 14N DNA.
7.14.218	These results could only be explained if DNA replicates in a semi-conservative manner.
7.14.219	Therefore, the other two modes were ruled out.
7.14.220	During DNA replication, each of the two strands that make up the double helix serves as a template from which new strands are copied.
7.14.221	The new strand will be complementary to the parental or “old” strand.
7.14.222	When two daughter DNA copies are formed, they have the same sequence and are divided equally into the two daughter cells.
7.14.223	DNA Replication in Prokaryotes DNA replication has been extremely well studied in prokaryotes primarily because of the small size of the genome and the mutants that are available.
7.14.224	E. coli has 4.6 million base pairs in a single circular chromosome and all of it gets replicated in approximately 42 minutes, starting from a single origin of replication and proceeding around the circle in both directions.
7.14.225	This means that approximately 1000 nucleotides are added per second.
7.14.226	The process is quite rapid and occurs without many mistakes.
7.14.227	DNA replication employs a large number of proteins and enzymes, each of which plays a critical role during the process.
7.14.228	One of the key players is the enzyme DNA polymerase, also known as DNA pol, which adds nucleotides one by one to the growing DNA chain that are complementary to the template strand.
7.14.229	The addition of nucleotides requires energy; this energy is obtained from the nucleotides that have three phosphates attached to them, similar to ATP which has three phosphate groups attached.
7.14.230	When the bond between the phosphates is broken, the energy released is used to form the phosphodiester bond between the incoming nucleotide and the growing chain.
7.14.231	In prokaryotes, three main types of polymerases are known: DNA pol I, DNA pol II, and DNA pol III.
7.14.232	It is now known that DNA pol III is the enzyme required for DNA synthesis; DNA pol I and DNA pol II are primarily required for repair.
7.14.233	How does the replication machinery know where to begin?
7.14.234	It turns out that there are specific nucleotide sequences called origins of replication where replication begins.
7.14.235	In E. coli, which has a single origin of replication on its one chromosome (as do most prokaryotes), it is approximately 245 base pairs long and is rich in AT sequences.
7.14.236	The origin of replication is recognized by certain proteins that bind to this site.
7.14.237	An enzyme called helicase unwinds the DNA by breaking the hydrogen bonds between the nitrogenous base pairs.
7.14.238	ATP hydrolysis is required for this process.
7.14.239	As the DNA opens up, Y-shaped structures called replication forks are formed.
7.14.240	Two replication forks are formed at the origin of replication and these get extended bi- directionally as replication proceeds.
7.14.241	Single-strand binding proteins coat the single strands of DNA near the replication fork to prevent the single-stranded DNA from winding back into a double helix.
7.14.242	DNA polymerase is able to add nucleotides only in the 5' to 3' direction (a new DNA strand can be only extended in this direction).
7.14.243	It also requires a free 3'-OH group to which it can add nucleotides by forming a phosphodiester bond between the 3'-OH end and the 5' phosphate of the next nucleotide.
7.14.244	This essentially means that it cannot add nucleotides if a free 3'-OH group is not available.
7.14.245	Then how does it add the first nucleotide?
7.14.246	The problem is solved with the help of a primer that provides the free 3'-OH end.
7.14.247	Another enzyme, RNA primase, synthesizes an RNA primer that is about five to ten nucleotides long and complementary to the DNA.
7.14.248	Because this sequence primes the DNA synthesis, it is appropriately called the primer.
7.14.249	DNA polymerase can now extend this RNA primer, adding nucleotides one by one that are complementary to the template strand.
7.14.250	A replication fork is formed when helicase separates the DNA strands at the origin of replication.
7.14.251	The DNA tends to become more highly coiled ahead of the replication fork.
7.14.252	Topoisomerase breaks and reforms
7.14.253	DNA’s phosphate backbone ahead of the replication fork, thereby relieving the pressure that results from this supercoiling.
7.14.254	Single-strand binding proteins bind to the single-stranded DNA to prevent the helix from re-forming.
7.14.255	Primase synthesizes an RNA primer.
7.14.256	DNA polymerase III uses this primer to synthesize the daughter DNA strand.
7.14.257	On the leading strand, DNA is synthesized continuously, whereas on the lagging strand, DNA is synthesized in short stretches called Okazaki fragments.
7.14.258	DNA polymerase I replaces the RNA primer with DNA.
7.14.259	DNA ligase seals the gaps between the Okazaki fragments, joining the fragments into a single DNA molecule.
7.14.260	The replication fork moves at the rate of 1000 nucleotides per second.
7.14.261	DNA polymerase can only extend in the 5' to 3' direction, which poses a slight problem at the replication fork.
7.14.262	As we know, the DNA double helix is anti-parallel; that is, one strand is in the 5' to 3' direction and the other is oriented in the 3'
7.14.263	to 5' direction.
7.14.264	One strand, which is complementary to the 3' to 5' parental DNA strand, is synthesized continuously towards the replication fork because the polymerase can add nucleotides in this direction.
7.14.265	This continuously synthesized strand is known as the leading strand.
7.14.266	The other strand, complementary to the 5' to 3' parental DNA, is extended away from the replication fork, in small fragments known as Okazaki fragments, each requiring a primer to start the synthesis.
7.14.267	Okazaki fragments are named after the Japanese scientist who first discovered them.
7.14.268	The strand with the Okazaki fragments is known as the lagging strand.
7.14.269	The leading strand can be extended by one primer alone, whereas the lagging strand needs a new primer for each of the short Okazaki fragments.
7.14.270	The overall direction of the lagging strand will be 3' to 5', and that of the leading strand 5' to 3'.
7.14.271	A protein called the sliding clamp holds the DNA polymerase in place as it continues to add nucleotides.
7.14.272	The sliding clamp is a ring-shaped protein that binds to the DNA and holds the polymerase in place.
7.14.273	Topoisomerase prevents the over-winding of the DNA double helix ahead of the replication fork as the DNA is opening up; it does so by causing temporary nicks in the DNA helix and then resealing it.
7.14.274	As synthesis proceeds, the RNA primers are replaced by DNA.
7.14.275	The primers are removed by the exonuclease activity of DNA pol I, and the gaps are filled in by deoxyribonucleotides.
7.14.276	The nicks that remain between the newly synthesized DNA (that replaced the RNA primer) and the previously synthesized DNA are sealed by the enzyme DNA ligase that catalyzes the formation of phosphodiester linkage between the 3'-OH end of one nucleotide and the 5' phosphate end of the other fragment.
7.14.277	Once the chromosome has been completely replicated, the two DNA copies move into two different cells during cell division.
7.14.278	The process of DNA replication can be summarized as follows
7.14.279	: 1.
7.14.280	DNA unwinds at the origin of replication.
7.14.281	2.
7.14.282	Helicase opens up the DNA-forming replication forks; these are extended bidirectionally.
7.14.283	3.
7.14.284	Single-strand binding proteins coat the DNA around the replication fork to prevent rewinding of the DNA.
7.14.285	4.
7.14.286	Topoisomerase binds at the region ahead of the replication fork to prevent supercoiling.
7.14.287	5.
7.14.288	Primase synthesizes RNA primers complementary to the DNA strand.
7.14.289	DNA polymerase starts adding nucleotides to the 3'-OH end of the primer.
7.14.290	7.
7.14.291	Elongation of both the lagging and the leading strand continues.
7.14.292	8.
7.14.293	RNA primers are removed by exonuclease activity.
7.14.294	9.
7.14.295	Gaps are filled by DNA pol by adding dNTPs.
7.14.296	10.
7.14.297	The gap between the two DNA fragments is sealed by DNA ligase, which helps in the formation of phosphodiester bonds.
7.14.298	DNA Replication in Eukaryotes Eukaryotic genomes are much more complex and larger in size than prokaryotic genomes.
7.14.299	The human genome has three billion base pairs per haploid set of chromosomes, and 6 billion base pairs are replicated during the S phase of the cell cycle.
7.14.300	There are multiple origins of replication on the eukaryotic chromosome; humans can have up to 100,000 origins of replication.
7.14.301	The rate of replication is approximately 100 nucleotides per second, much slower than prokaryotic replication.
7.14.302	In yeast, which is a eukaryote, special sequences known as Autonomously Replicating Sequences (ARS) are found on the chromosomes.
7.14.303	These are equivalent to the origin of replication in E. coli.
7.14.304	The number of DNA polymerases in eukaryotes is much more than prokaryotes: 14 are known, of which five are known to have major roles during replication and have been well studied.
7.14.305	They are known as pol α, pol β, pol γ, pol δ, and pol ε.
7.14.306	The essential steps of replication are the same as in prokaryotes.
7.14.307	Before replication can start, the DNA has to be made available as template.
7.14.308	Eukaryotic DNA is bound to basic proteins known as histones to form structures called nucleosomes.
7.14.309	The chromatin (the complex between DNA and proteins) may undergo some chemical modifications, so that the DNA may be able to slide off the proteins or be accessible to the enzymes of the DNA replication machinery.
7.14.310	At the origin of replication, a pre-replication complex is made with other initiator proteins.
7.14.311	Other proteins are then recruited to start the replication process (Table 14.2).
7.14.312	A helicase using the energy from ATP hydrolysis opens up the DNA helix.
7.14.313	Replication forks are formed at each replication origin as the DNA unwinds.
7.14.314	The opening of the double helix causes over-winding, or supercoiling, in the DNA ahead of the replication fork.
7.14.315	These are resolved with the action of topoisomerases.
7.14.316	Primers are formed by the enzyme primase, and using the primer, DNA pol can start synthesis.
7.14.317	While the leading strand is continuously synthesized by the enzyme pol δ, the lagging strand is synthesized by pol ε.
7.14.318	A sliding clamp protein known as PCNA (Proliferating Cell Nuclear Antigen) holds the DNA pol in place so that it does not slide off the DNA.
7.14.319	RNase H removes the RNA primer, which is then replaced with DNA nucleotides.
7.14.320	The Okazaki fragments in the lagging strand are joined together after the replacement of the RNA primers with DNA.
7.14.321	The gaps that remain are sealed by DNA ligase, which forms the phosphodiester bond.
7.14.322	Telomere replication Unlike prokaryotic chromosomes, eukaryotic chromosomes are linear.
7.14.323	As you’ve learned, the enzyme DNA pol can add nucleotides only in the 5' to 3' direction.
7.14.324	In the leading strand, synthesis continues until the end of the chromosome is reached.
7.14.325	On the lagging strand, DNA is synthesized in short stretches, each of which is initiated by a separate primer.
7.14.326	When the replication fork reaches the end of the linear chromosome, there is no place for a primer to be made for the DNA fragment to be copied at the end of the chromosome.
7.14.327	These ends thus remain unpaired, and over time these ends may get progressively shorter as cells continue to divide.
7.14.328	The ends of the linear chromosomes are known as telomeres, which have repetitive sequences that code for no particular gene.
7.14.329	In a way, these telomeres protect the genes from getting deleted as cells continue to divide.
7.14.330	In humans, a six base pair sequence, TTAGGG, is repeated 100 to 1000 times.
7.14.331	The discovery of the enzyme telomerase (Figure 14.16) helped in the understanding of how chromosome ends are maintained.
7.14.332	The telomerase enzyme contains a catalytic part and a built-in RNA template.
7.14.333	It attaches to the end of the chromosome, and complementary bases to the RNA template are added on the 3' end of the DNA strand.
7.14.334	Once the 3' end of the lagging strand template is sufficiently elongated, DNA polymerase can add the nucleotides complementary to the ends of the chromosomes.
7.14.335	Thus, the ends of the chromosomes are replicated.
7.14.336	The ends of linear chromosomes are maintained by the action of the telomerase enzyme.
7.14.337	Telomerase is typically active in germ cells and adult stem cells.
7.14.338	It is not active in adult somatic cells.
7.14.339	For her discovery of telomerase and its action, Elizabeth Blackburn (Figure 14.16) received the Nobel Prize for Medicine and Physiology in 2009.
7.14.340	Elizabeth Blackburn, 2009 Nobel Laureate, is the scientist who discovered how telomerase works.
7.14.341	(credit: US Embassy Sweden)
7.14.342	Telomerase and Aging Cells that undergo cell division continue to have their telomeres shortened because most somatic cells do not make telomerase.
7.14.343	This essentially means that telomere shortening is associated with aging.
7.14.344	With the advent of modern medicine, preventative health care, and healthier lifestyles, the human life span has increased, and there is an increasing demand for people to look younger and have a better quality of life as they grow older.
7.14.345	In 2010, scientists found that telomerase can reverse some age-related conditions in mice.
7.14.346	This may have potential in regenerative medicine.
7.14.347	[2] Telomerase-deficient mice were used in these studies; these mice have tissue atrophy, stem cell depletion, organ system failure, and impaired tissue injury responses.
7.14.348	Telomerase reactivation in these mice caused extension of telomeres, reduced DNA damage, reversed neurodegeneration, and improved the function of the testes, spleen, and intestines.
7.14.349	Thus, telomere reactivation may have potential for treating age-related diseases in humans.
7.14.350	Cancer is characterized by uncontrolled cell division of abnormal cells.
7.14.351	The cells accumulate mutations, proliferate uncontrollably, and can migrate to different parts of the body through a process called metastasis.
7.14.352	Scientists have observed that cancerous cells have considerably shortened telomeres and that telomerase is active in these cells.
7.14.353	Interestingly, only after the telomeres were shortened in the cancer cells did the telomerase become active.
7.14.354	If the action of telomerase in these cells can be inhibited by drugs during cancer therapy, then the cancerous cells could potentially be stopped from further division.
7.14.355	DNA Repair DNA replication is a highly accurate process, but mistakes can occasionally occur, such as a DNA polymerase inserting a wrong base.
7.14.356	Uncorrected mistakes may sometimes lead to serious consequences, such as cancer.
7.14.357	Repair mechanisms correct the mistakes.
7.14.358	In rare cases, mistakes are not corrected, leading to mutations; in other cases, repair enzymes are themselves mutated or defective.
7.14.359	Most of the mistakes during DNA replication are promptly corrected by DNA polymerase by proofreading the base that has been just added (Figure 14.17).
7.14.360	In proofreading, the DNA pol reads the newly added base before adding the next one, so a correction can be made.
7.14.361	The polymerase checks whether the newly added base has paired correctly with the base in the template strand.
7.14.362	If it is the right base, the next nucleotide is added.
7.14.363	If an incorrect base has been added, the enzyme makes a cut at the phosphodiester bond and releases the wrong nucleotide.
7.14.364	This is performed by the exonuclease action of DNA pol III.
7.14.365	Once the incorrect nucleotide has been removed, a new one will be added again.
7.14.366	Some errors are not corrected during replication, but are instead corrected after replication is completed; this type of repair is known as mismatch repair (Figure 14.18).
7.14.367	The enzymes recognize the incorrectly added nucleotide and excise it; this is then replaced by the correct base.
7.14.368	If this remains uncorrected, it may lead to more permanent damage.
7.14.369	How do mismatch repair enzymes recognize which of the two bases is the incorrect one?
7.14.370	In E. coli, after replication, the nitrogenous base adenine acquires a methyl group; the parental DNA strand will have methyl groups, whereas the newly synthesized strand lacks them.
7.14.371	Thus, DNA polymerase is able to remove the wrongly incorporated bases from the newly synthesized, nonmethylated strand.
7.14.372	In eukaryotes, the mechanism is not very well understood, but it is believed to involve recognition of unsealed nicks in the new strand, as well as a short-term continuing association of some of the replication proteins with the new daughter strand after replication has completed.
7.14.373	In mismatch repair, the incorrectly added base is detected after replication.
7.14.374	The mismatch repair proteins detect this base and remove it from the newly synthesized strand by nuclease action.
7.14.375	The gap is now filled with the correctly paired base.
7.14.376	In another type of repair mechanism, nucleotide excision repair, enzymes replace incorrect bases by making a cut on both the 3' and 5' ends of the incorrect base (Figure 14.19).
7.14.377	The segment of DNA is removed and replaced with the correctly paired nucleotides by the action of DNA pol.
7.14.378	Once the bases are filled in, the remaining gap is sealed with a phosphodiester linkage catalyzed by DNA ligase.
7.14.379	This repair mechanism is often employed when UV exposure causes the formation of pyrimidine dimers.
7.14.380	Nucleotide excision repairs thymine dimers.
7.14.381	When exposed to UV, thymines lying adjacent to each other can form thymine dimers.
7.14.382	In normal cells, they are excised and replaced.
7.14.383	A well-studied example of mistakes not being corrected is seen in people suffering from xeroderma pigmentosa (Figure 14.20).
7.14.384	Affected individuals have skin that is highly sensitive to UV rays from the sun.
7.14.385	When individuals are exposed to UV, pyrimidine dimers, especially those of thymine, are formed; people with xeroderma pigmentosa are not able to repair the damage.
7.14.386	These are not repaired because of a defect in the nucleotide excision repair enzymes, whereas in normal individuals, the thymine dimers are excised and the defect is corrected.
7.14.387	The thymine dimers distort the structure of the DNA double helix, and this may cause problems during DNA replication.
7.14.388	People with xeroderma pigmentosa may have a higher risk of contracting skin cancer than those who dont have the condition.
7.14.389	Xeroderma pigmentosa is a condition in which thymine dimerization from exposure to UV is not repaired.
7.14.390	Exposure to sunlight results in skin lesions.
7.14.391	(credit: James Halpern et al.)
7.14.392	Errors during DNA replication are not the only reason why mutations arise in DNA.
7.14.393	Mutations, variations in the nucleotide sequence of a genome, can also occur because of damage to DNA.
7.14.394	Such mutations may be of two types: induced or spontaneous.
7.14.395	Induced mutations are those that result from an exposure to chemicals, UV rays, x-rays, or some other environmental agent.
7.14.396	Spontaneous mutations occur without any exposure to any environmental agent; they are a result of natural reactions taking place within the body.
7.14.397	Mutations may have a wide range of effects.
7.14.398	Some mutations are not expressed; these are known as silent mutations.
7.14.399	Point mutations are those mutations that affect a single base pair.
7.14.400	The most common nucleotide mutations are substitutions, in which one base is replaced by another.
7.14.401	These can be of two types, either transitions or transversions.
7.14.402	Transition substitution refers to a purine or pyrimidine being replaced by a base of the same kind; for example, a purine such as adenine may be replaced by the purine guanine.
7.14.403	Transversion substitution refers to a purine being replaced by a pyrimidine, or vice versa; for example, cytosine, a pyrimidine, is replaced by adenine, a purine.
7.14.404	Mutations can also be the result of the addition of a base, known as an insertion, or the removal of a base, also known as deletion.
7.14.405	Sometimes a piece of DNA from one chromosome may get translocated to another chromosome or to another region of the same chromosome; this is also known as translocation.
7.14.406	These mutation types are shown in.
7.14.407	Mutations in repair genes have been known to cause cancer.
7.14.408	Many mutated repair genes have been implicated in certain forms of pancreatic cancer, colon cancer, and colorectal cancer.
7.14.409	Mutations can affect either somatic cells or germ cells.
7.14.410	If many mutations accumulate in a somatic cell, they may lead to problems such as the uncontrolled cell division observed in cancer.
7.14.411	If a mutation takes place in germ cells, the mutation will be passed on to the next generation, as in the case of hemophilia and xeroderma pigmentosa.  
7.15.0	GENES AND PROTEINS Genes, which are carried on (a) chromosomes, are linearly organized instructions for making the RNA and protein molecules that are necessary for all of processes of life.
7.15.1	The (b) interleukin-2 protein and (c) alpha-2uglobulin protein are just two examples of the array of different molecular structures that are encoded by genes.
7.15.2	Introduction
7.15.3	Since the rediscovery of Mendel’s work in 1900, the definition of the gene has progressed from an abstract unit of heredity to a tangible molecular entity capable of replication, expression, and mutation (Figure 15.1).
7.15.4	Genes are composed of DNA and are linearly arranged on chromosomes.
7.15.5	Genes specify the sequences of amino acids, which are the building blocks of proteins.
7.15.6	In turn, proteins are responsible for orchestrating nearly every function of the cell.
7.15.7	Both genes and the proteins they encode are absolutely essential to life as we know it.
7.15.8	The Genetic Code
7.15.9	The cellular process of transcription generates messenger RNA (mRNA), a mobile molecular copy of one or more genes with an alphabet of A, C, G, and uracil (U).
7.15.10	Translation of the mRNA template converts nucleotide-based genetic information into a protein product.
7.15.11	Protein sequences consist of 20 commonly occurring amino acids; therefore, it can be said that the protein alphabet consists of 20 letters (Figure 15.2).
7.15.12	Each amino acid is defined by a three-nucleotide sequence called the triplet codon.
7.15.13	Different amino acids have different chemistries (such as acidic versus basic, or polar and nonpolar) and different structural constraints.
7.15.14	Variation in amino acid sequence gives rise to enormous variation in protein structure and function.
7.15.15	Structures of the 20 amino acids found in proteins are shown.
7.15.16	Each amino acid is composed of an amino group ( NH3 + ), a carboxyl group (COO-), and a side chain (blue).
7.15.17	The side chain may be nonpolar, polar, or charged, as well as large or small.
7.15.18	It is the variety of amino acid side chains that gives rise to the incredible variation of protein structure and function.
7.15.19	The Central Dogma: DNA Encodes RNA; RNA Encodes Protein
7.15.20	The flow of genetic information in cells from DNA to mRNA to protein is described by the Central Dogma (Figure 15.3), which states that genes specify the sequence of mRNAs, which in turn specify the sequence of proteins.
7.15.21	The decoding of one molecule to another is performed by specific proteins and RNAs.
7.15.22	Because the information stored in DNA is so central to cellular function, it makes intuitive sense that the cell would make mRNA copies of this information for protein synthesis, while keeping the DNA itself intact and protected.
7.15.23	The copying of DNA to RNA is relatively straightforward, with one nucleotide being added to the mRNA strand for every nucleotide read in the DNA strand.
7.15.24	The translation to protein is a bit more complex because three mRNA nucleotides correspond to one amino acid in the polypeptide sequence.
7.15.25	However, the translation to protein is still systematic and colinear, such that nucleotides 1 to 3 correspond to amino acid 1, nucleotides 4 to 6 correspond to amino acid 2, and so on.
7.15.26	Instructions on DNA are transcribed onto messenger RNA.
7.15.27	Ribosomes are able to read the genetic information inscribed on a strand of messenger RNA and use this information to string amino acids together into a protein.
7.15.28	The Genetic Code Is Degenerate and Universal Given the different numbers of “letters” in the mRNA and protein “alphabets,” scientists theorized that combinations of nucleotides corresponded to single amino acids.
7.15.29	Nucleotide doublets would not be sufficient to specify every amino acid because there are only 16 possible two-nucleotide combinations (42).
7.15.30	In contrast, there are 64 possible nucleotide triplets (43), which is far more than the number of amino acids.
7.15.31	Scientists theorized that amino acids were encoded by nucleotide triplets and that the genetic code was degenerate.
7.15.32	In other words, a given amino acid could be encoded by more than one nucleotide triplet.
7.15.33	This was later confirmed experimentally; Francis Crick and Sydney Brenner used the chemical mutagen proflavin to insert one, two, or three nucleotides into the gene of a virus.
7.15.34	When one or two nucleotides were inserted, protein synthesis was completely abolished.
7.15.35	When three nucleotides were inserted, the protein was synthesized and functional.
7.15.36	This demonstrated that three nucleotides specify each amino acid.
7.15.37	These nucleotide triplets are called codons.
7.15.38	The insertion of one or two nucleotides completely changed the triplet reading frame, thereby altering the message for every subsequent amino acid (Figure 15.5).
7.15.39	Though insertion of three nucleotides caused an extra amino acid to be inserted during translation, the integrity of the rest of the protein was maintained.
7.15.40	Scientists painstakingly solved the genetic code by translating synthetic mRNAs in vitro and sequencing the proteins they specified (Figure 15.4).
7.15.41	This figure shows the genetic code for translating each nucleotide triplet in mRNA into an amino acid or a termination signal in a nascent protein.
7.15.42	(credit: modification of work by NIH)
7.15.43	In addition to instructing the addition of a specific amino acid to a polypeptide chain, three of the 64 codons terminate protein synthesis and release the polypeptide from the translation machinery.
7.15.44	These triplets are called nonsense codons, or stop codons.
7.15.45	Another codon, AUG, also has a special function.
7.15.46	In addition to specifying the amino acid methionine, it also serves as the start codon to initiate translation.
7.15.47	The reading frame for translation is set by the AUG start codon near the 5' end of the mRNA.
7.15.48	The genetic code is universal.
7.15.49	With a few exceptions, virtually all species use the same genetic code for protein synthesis.
7.15.50	Conservation of codons means that a purified mRNA encoding the globin protein in horses could be transferred to a tulip cell, and the tulip would synthesize horse globin.
7.15.51	That there is only one genetic code is powerful evidence that all of life on Earth shares a common origin, especially considering that there are about 1084 possible combinations of 20 amino acids and 64 triplet codons.
7.15.52	The deletion of two nucleotides shifts the reading frame of an mRNA and changes the entire protein message, creating a nonfunctional protein or terminating protein synthesis altogether.
7.15.53	Degeneracy is believed to be a cellular mechanism to reduce the negative impact of random mutations.
7.15.54	Codons that specify the same amino acid typically only differ by one nucleotide.
7.15.55	In addition, amino acids with chemically similar side chains are encoded by similar codons.
7.15.56	This nuance of the genetic code ensures that a single-nucleotide substitution mutation might either specify the same amino acid but have no effect or specify a similar amino acid, preventing the protein from being rendered completely nonfunctional.
7.15.57	Question: Would a kiwifruit and strawberry that are approximately the same size (Figure 15.6) also have approximately the same amount of DNA?
7.15.58	Background:
7.15.59	Genes are carried on chromosomes and are made of DNA.
7.15.60	All mammals are diploid, meaning they have two copies of each chromosome.
7.15.61	However, not all plants are diploid.
7.15.62	The common strawberry is octoploid (8n) and the cultivated kiwi is hexaploid (6n).
7.15.63	Research the total number of chromosomes in the cells of each of these fruits and think about how this might correspond to the amount of DNA in these fruits’ cell nuclei.
7.15.64	Read about the technique of DNA isolation to understand how each step in the isolation protocol helps liberate and precipitate DNA.
7.15.65	Hypothesis:
7.15.66	Hypothesize whether you would be able to detect a difference in DNA quantity from similarly sized strawberries and kiwis.
7.15.67	Which fruit do you think would yield more DNA?
7.15.68	Test your hypothesis: Isolate the DNA from a strawberry and a kiwi that are similarly sized.
7.15.69	Perform the experiment in at least triplicate for each fruit.
7.15.70	1.
7.15.71	Prepare a bottle of DNA extraction buffer from 900 mL water, 50 mL dish detergent, and two teaspoons of table salt.
7.15.72	Mix by inversion (cap it and turn it upside down a few times).
7.15.73	2.
7.15.74	Grind a strawberry and a kiwifruit by hand in a plastic bag, or using a mortar and pestle, or with a metal bowl and the end of a blunt instrument.
7.15.75	Grind for at least two minutes per fruit.
7.15.76	3.
7.15.77	Add 10 mL of the DNA extraction buffer to each fruit, and mix well for at least one minute.
7.15.78	4.
7.15.79	Remove cellular debris by filtering each fruit mixture through cheesecloth or porous cloth and into a funnel placed in a test tube or an appropriate container.
7.15.80	5.
7.15.81	Pour ice-cold ethanol or isopropanol (rubbing alcohol) into the test tube.
7.15.82	You should observe white, precipitated DNA.
7.15.83	6.
7.15.84	Gather the DNA from each fruit by winding it around separate glass rods.
7.15.85	Record your observations: Because you are not quantitatively measuring DNA volume, you can record for each trial whether the two fruits produced the same or different amounts of DNA as observed by eye.
7.15.86	If one or the other fruit produced noticeably more DNA, record this as well.
7.15.87	Determine whether your observations are consistent with several pieces of each fruit.
7.15.88	Analyze your data: Did you notice an obvious difference in the amount of DNA produced by each fruit?
7.15.89	Were your results reproducible?
7.15.90	Draw a conclusion: Given what you know about the number of chromosomes in each fruit, can you conclude that chromosome number necessarily correlates to DNA amount?
7.15.91	Can you identify any drawbacks to this procedure?
7.15.92	If you had access to a laboratory, how could you standardize your comparison and make it more quantitative?
7.15.93	Prokaryotic Transcription
7.15.94	The prokaryotes, which include bacteria and archaea, are mostly single-celled organisms that, by definition, lack membranebound nuclei and other organelles.
7.15.95	A bacterial chromosome is a covalently closed circle that, unlike eukaryotic chromosomes, is not organized around histone proteins.
7.15.96	The central region of the cell in which prokaryotic DNA resides is called the nucleoid.
7.15.97	In addition, prokaryotes often have abundant plasmids, which are shorter circular DNA molecules that may only contain one or a few genes.
7.15.98	Plasmids can be transferred independently of the bacterial chromosome during cell division and often carry traits such as antibiotic resistance.
7.15.99	Transcription in prokaryotes (and in eukaryotes) requires the DNA double helix to partially unwind in the region of mRNA synthesis.
7.15.100	The region of unwinding is called a transcription bubble.
7.15.101	Transcription always proceeds from the same DNA strand for each gene, which is called the template strand.
7.15.102	The mRNA product is complementary to the template strand and is almost identical to the other DNA strand, called the nontemplate strand.
7.15.103	The only difference is that in mRNA, all of the T nucleotides are replaced with U nucleotides.
7.15.104	In an RNA double helix, A can bind U via two hydrogen bonds, just as in A–T pairing in a DNA double helix.
7.15.105	The nucleotide pair in the DNA double helix that corresponds to the site from which the first 5' mRNA nucleotide is transcribed is called the +1 site, or the initiation site.
7.15.106	Nucleotides preceding the initiation site are given negative numbers and are designated upstream.
7.15.107	Conversely, nucleotides following the initiation site are denoted with “+” numbering and are called downstream nucleotides.
7.15.108	Initiation of Transcription in Prokaryotes Prokaryotes do not have membrane-enclosed nuclei.
7.15.109	Therefore, the processes of transcription, translation, and mRNA degradation can all occur simultaneously.
7.15.110	The intracellular level of a bacterial protein can quickly be amplified by multiple transcription and translation events occurring concurrently on the same DNA template.
7.15.111	Prokaryotic transcription often covers more than one gene and produces polycistronic mRNAs that specify more than one protein.
7.15.112	Our discussion here will exemplify transcription by describing this process in Escherichia coli, a well-studied bacterial species.
7.15.113	Although some differences exist between transcription in E. coli and transcription in archaea, an understanding of E. coli transcription can be applied to virtually all bacterial species.
7.15.114	Prokaryotic RNA Polymerase Prokaryotes use the same RNA polymerase to transcribe all of their genes.
7.15.115	In E. coli, the polymerase is composed of five polypeptide subunits, two of which are identical.
7.15.116	Four of these subunits, denoted α, α, β, and β' comprise the polymerase core enzyme.
7.15.117	These subunits assemble every time a gene is transcribed, and they disassemble once transcription is complete.
7.15.118	Each subunit has a unique role; the two α-subunits are necessary to assemble the polymerase on the DNA; the β-subunit binds to the ribonucleoside triphosphate that will become part of the nascent “recently born” mRNA molecule; and the β' binds the DNA template strand.
7.15.119	The fifth subunit, σ, is involved only in transcription initiation.
7.15.120	It confers transcriptional specificity such that the polymerase begins to synthesize mRNA from an appropriate initiation site.
7.15.121	Without σ, the core enzyme would transcribe from random sites and would produce mRNA molecules that specified protein gibberish.
7.15.122	The polymerase comprised of all five subunits is called the holoenzyme.
7.15.123	Prokaryotic Promoters
7.15.124	A promoter is a DNA sequence onto which the transcription machinery binds and initiates transcription.
7.15.125	In most cases, promoters exist upstream of the genes they regulate.
7.15.126	The specific sequence of a promoter is very important because it determines whether the corresponding gene is transcribed all the time, some of the time, or infrequently.
7.15.127	Although promoters vary among prokaryotic genomes, a few elements are conserved.
7.15.128	At the -10 and -35 regions upstream of the initiation site, there are two promoter consensus sequences, or regions that are similar across all promoters and across various bacterial species (Figure 15.7).
7.15.129	The -10 consensus sequence, called the -10 region, is TATAAT.
7.15.130	The -35 sequence, TTGACA, is recognized and bound by σ.
7.15.131	Once this interaction is made, the subunits of the core enzyme bind to the site.
7.15.132	The A–T-rich -10 region facilitates unwinding of the DNA template, and several phosphodiester bonds are made.
7.15.133	The transcription initiation phase ends with the production of abortive transcripts, which are polymers of approximately 10 nucleotides that are made and released.
7.15.134	The σ subunit of prokaryotic RNA polymerase recognizes consensus sequences found in the promoter region upstream of the transcription start sight.
7.15.135	The σ subunit dissociates from the polymerase after transcription has been initiated.
7.15.136	Elongation and Termination in Prokaryotes
7.15.137	The transcription elongation phase begins with the release of the σ subunit from the polymerase.
7.15.138	The dissociation of σ allows the core enzyme to proceed along the DNA template, synthesizing mRNA in the 5' to 3' direction at a rate of approximately 40 nucleotides per second.
7.15.139	As elongation proceeds, the DNA is continuously unwound ahead of the core enzyme and rewound behind it (Figure 15.8).
7.15.140	The base pairing between DNA and RNA is not stable enough to maintain the stability of the mRNA synthesis components.
7.15.141	Instead, the RNA polymerase acts as a stable linker between the DNA template and the nascent RNA strands to ensure that elongation is not interrupted prematurely.
7.15.142	During elongation, the prokaryotic RNA polymerase tracks along the DNA template, synthesizes mRNA in the 5' to 3' direction, and unwinds and rewinds the DNA as it is read.
7.15.143	Prokaryotic Termination Signals
7.15.144	Once a gene is transcribed, the prokaryotic polymerase needs to be instructed to dissociate from the DNA template and liberate the newly made mRNA.
7.15.145	Depending on the gene being transcribed, there are two kinds of termination signals.
7.15.146	One is protein-based and the other is RNA-based.
7.15.147	Rho-dependent termination is controlled by the rho protein, which tracks along behind the polymerase on the growing mRNA chain.
7.15.148	Near the end of the gene, the polymerase encounters a run of G nucleotides on the DNA template and it stalls.
7.15.149	As a result, the rho protein collides with the polymerase.
7.15.150	The interaction with rho releases the mRNA from the transcription bubble.
7.15.151	Rho-independent termination is controlled by specific sequences in the DNA template strand.
7.15.152	As the polymerase nears the end of the gene being transcribed, it encounters a region rich in C–G nucleotides.
7.15.153	The mRNA folds back on itself, and the complementary C–G nucleotides bind together.
7.15.154	The result is a stable hairpin that causes the polymerase to stall as soon as it begins to transcribe a region rich in A–T nucleotides.
7.15.155	The complementary U–A region of the mRNA transcript forms only a weak interaction with the template DNA.
7.15.156	This, coupled with the stalled polymerase, induces enough instability for the core enzyme to break away and liberate the new mRNA transcript.
7.15.157	Upon termination, the process of transcription is complete.
7.15.158	By the time termination occurs, the prokaryotic transcript would already have been used to begin synthesis of numerous copies of the encoded protein because these processes can occur concurrently.
7.15.159	The unification of transcription, translation, and even mRNA degradation is possible because all of these processes occur in the same 5' to 3' direction, and because there is no membranous compartmentalization in the prokaryotic cell (Figure 15.9).
7.15.160	In contrast, the presence of a nucleus in eukaryotic cells precludes simultaneous transcription and translation.
7.15.161	Multiple polymerases can transcribe a single bacterial gene while numerous ribosomes concurrently translate the mRNA transcripts into polypeptides.
7.15.162	In this way, a specific protein can rapidly reach a high concentration in the bacterial cell.
7.15.163	Prokaryotes and eukaryotes perform fundamentally the same process of transcription, with a few key differences.
7.15.164	The most important difference between prokaryotes and eukaryotes is the latter’s membrane-bound nucleus and organelles.
7.15.165	With the genes bound in a nucleus, the eukaryotic cell must be able to transport its mRNA to the cytoplasm and must protect its mRNA from degrading before it is translated.
7.15.166	Eukaryotes also employ three different polymerases that each transcribe a different subset of genes.
7.15.167	Eukaryotic mRNAs are usually monogenic, meaning that they specify a single protein.
7.15.168	Initiation of Transcription in Eukaryotes Unlike the prokaryotic polymerase that can bind to a DNA template on its own, eukaryotes require several other proteins, called transcription factors, to first bind to the promoter region and then help recruit the appropriate polymerase.
7.15.169	The Three Eukaryotic RNA Polymerases
7.15.170	The features of eukaryotic mRNA synthesis are markedly more complex those of prokaryotes.
7.15.171	Instead of a single polymerase comprising five subunits, the eukaryotes have three polymerases that are each made up of 10 subunits or more.
7.15.172	Each eukaryotic polymerase also requires a distinct set of transcription factors to bring it to the DNA template.
7.15.173	RNA polymerase I is located in the nucleolus, a specialized nuclear substructure in which ribosomal RNA (rRNA) is transcribed, processed, and assembled into ribosomes (Table 15.1).
7.15.174	The rRNA molecules are considered structural RNAs because they have a cellular role but are not translated into protein.
7.15.175	The rRNAs are components of the ribosome and are essential to the process of translation.
7.15.176	RNA polymerase I synthesizes all of the rRNAs except for the 5S rRNA molecule.
7.15.177	The “S” designation applies to “Svedberg” units, a nonadditive value that characterizes the speed at which a particle sediments during centrifugation.
7.15.178	RNA polymerase II is located in the nucleus and synthesizes all protein-coding nuclear pre-mRNAs.
7.15.179	Eukaryotic premRNAs undergo extensive processing after transcription but before translation.
7.15.180	For clarity, this module’s discussion of transcription and translation in eukaryotes will use the term “mRNAs” to describe only the mature, processed molecules that are ready to be translated.
7.15.181	RNA polymerase II is responsible for transcribing the overwhelming majority of eukaryotic genes.
7.15.182	RNA polymerase III is also located in the nucleus.
7.15.183	This polymerase transcribes a variety of structural RNAs that includes the 5S pre-rRNA, transfer pre-RNAs (pre-tRNAs), and small nuclear pre- RNAs.
7.15.184	The tRNAs have a critical role in translation; they serve as the adaptor molecules between the mRNA template and the growing polypeptide chain.
7.15.185	Small nuclear RNAs have a variety of functions, including “splicing” pre-mRNAs and regulating transcription factors.
7.15.186	A scientist characterizing a new gene can determine which polymerase transcribes it by testing whether the gene is expressed in the presence of a particular mushroom poison, α-amanitin (Table 15.1).
7.15.187	Interestingly, α-amanitin produced by Amanita phalloides, the Death Cap mushroom, affects the three polymerases very differently.
7.15.188	RNA polymerase I is completely insensitive to α-amanitin, meaning that the polymerase can transcribe DNA in vitro in the presence of this poison.
7.15.189	In contrast, RNA polymerase II is extremely sensitive to α-amanitin, and RNA polymerase III is moderately sensitive.
7.15.190	Knowing the transcribing polymerase can clue a researcher into the general function of the gene being studied.
7.15.191	Because RNA polymerase II transcribes the vast majority of genes, we will focus on this polymerase in our subsequent discussions about eukaryotic transcription factors and promoters.
7.15.192	Structure of an RNA Polymerase II Promoter Eukaryotic promoters are much larger and more complex than prokaryotic promoters, but both have a TATA box.
7.15.193	For example, in the mouse thymidine kinase gene, the TATA box is located at approximately -30 relative to the initiation (+1) site (Figure 15.10).
7.15.194	For this gene, the exact TATA box sequence is TATAAAA, as read in the 5' to 3' direction on the nontemplate strand.
7.15.195	This sequence is not identical to the E. coli TATA box, but it conserves the A–T rich element.
7.15.196	The thermostability of A–T bonds is low and this helps the DNA template to locally unwind in preparation for transcription.
7.15.197	A generalized promoter of a gene transcribed by RNA polymerase II is shown.
7.15.198	Transcription factors recognize the promoter.
7.15.199	RNA polymerase II then binds and forms the transcription initiation complex.
7.15.200	The mouse genome includes one gene and two pseudogenes for cytoplasmic thymidine kinase.
7.15.201	Pseudogenes are genes that have lost their protein-coding ability or are no longer expressed by the cell.
7.15.202	These pseudogenes are copied from mRNA and incorporated into the chromosome.
7.15.203	For example, the mouse thymidine kinase promoter also has a conserved CAAT box (GGCCAATCT) at approximately -80.
7.15.204	This sequence is essential and is involved in binding transcription factors.
7.15.205	Further upstream of the TATA box, eukaryotic promoters may also contain one or more GC-rich boxes (GGCG) or octamer boxes (ATTTGCAT).
7.15.206	These elements bind cellular factors that increase the efficiency of transcription initiation and are often identified in more “active” genes that are constantly being expressed by the cell.
7.15.207	Transcription Factors for RNA Polymerase II
7.15.208	The complexity of eukaryotic transcription does not end with the polymerases and promoters.
7.15.209	An army of basal transcription factors, enhancers, and silencers also help to regulate the frequency with which pre-mRNA is synthesized from a gene.
7.15.210	Enhancers and silencers affect the efficiency of transcription but are not necessary for transcription to proceed.
7.15.211	Basal transcription factors are crucial in the formation of a preinitiation complex on the DNA template that subsequently recruits RNA polymerase II for transcription initiation.
7.15.212	The names of the basal transcription factors begin with “TFII” (this is the transcription factor for RNA polymerase II) and are specified with the letters A–J.
7.15.213	The transcription factors systematically fall into place on the DNA template, with each one further stabilizing the preinitiation complex and contributing to the recruitment of RNA polymerase II.
7.15.214	The processes of bringing RNA polymerases I and III to the DNA template involve slightly less complex collections of transcription factors, but the general theme is the same.
7.15.215	Eukaryotic transcription is a tightly regulated process that requires a variety of proteins to interact with each other and with the DNA strand.
7.15.216	Although the process of transcription in eukaryotes involves a greater metabolic investment than in prokaryotes, it ensures that the cell transcribes precisely the pre-mRNAs that it needs for protein synthesis.
7.15.217	The Evolution of Promoters
7.15.218	The evolution of genes may be a familiar concept.
7.15.219	Mutations can occur in genes during DNA replication, and the result may or may not be beneficial to the cell.
7.15.220	By altering an enzyme, structural protein, or some other factor, the process of mutation can transform functions or physical features.
7.15.221	However, eukaryotic promoters and other gene regulatory sequences may evolve as well.
7.15.222	For instance, consider a gene that, over many generations, becomes more valuable to the cell.
