7.15.223	Maybe the gene encodes a structural protein that the cell needs to synthesize in abundance for a certain function.
7.15.224	If this is the case, it would be beneficial to the cell for that gene’s promoter to recruit transcription factors more efficiently and increase gene expression.
7.15.225	Scientists examining the evolution of promoter sequences have reported varying results.
7.15.226	In part, this is because it is difficult to infer exactly where a eukaryotic promoter begins and ends.
7.15.227	Some promoters occur within genes; others are located very far upstream, or even downstream, of the genes they are regulating.
7.15.228	However, when researchers limited their examination to human core promoter sequences that were defined experimentally as sequences that bind the preinitiation complex, they found that promoters evolve even faster than protein-coding genes.
7.15.229	It is still unclear how promoter evolution might correspond to the evolution of humans or other higher organisms.
7.15.230	However, the evolution of a promoter to effectively make more or less of a given gene product is an intriguing alternative to the evolution of the genes themselves.
7.15.231	Promoter Structures for RNA Polymerases I and III
7.15.232	In eukaryotes, the conserved promoter elements differ for genes transcribed by RNA polymerases I, II, and III.
7.15.233	RNA polymerase I transcribes genes that have two GC-rich promoter sequences in the -45 to +20 region.
7.15.234	These sequences alone are sufficient for transcription initiation to occur, but promoters with additional sequences in the region from -180 to -105 upstream of the initiation site will further enhance initiation.
7.15.235	Genes that are transcribed by RNA polymerase III have upstream promoters or promoters that occur within the genes themselves.
7.15.236	Eukaryotic Elongation and Termination
7.15.237	Following the formation of the preinitiation complex, the polymerase is released from the other transcription factors, and elongation is allowed to proceed as it does in prokaryotes with the polymerase synthesizing pre-mRNA in the 5'
7.15.238	to 3' direction.
7.15.239	As discussed previously, RNA polymerase II transcribes the major share of eukaryotic genes, so this section will focus on how this polymerase accomplishes elongation and termination.
7.15.240	Although the enzymatic process of elongation is essentially the same in eukaryotes and prokaryotes, the DNA template is more complex.
7.15.241	When eukaryotic cells are not dividing, their genes exist as a diffuse mass of DNA and proteins called chromatin.
7.15.242	The DNA is tightly packaged around charged histone proteins at repeated intervals.
7.15.243	These DNA–histone histones like thread around a spool.
7.15.244	For polynucleotide synthesis to occur, the transcription machinery needs to move histones out of the way every time it encounters a nucleosome.
7.15.245	This is accomplished by a special protein complex called FACT, which stands for “facilitates chromatin transcription.
7.15.246	”
7.15.247	This complex pulls histones away from the DNA template as the polymerase moves along it.
7.15.248	Once the pre-mRNA is synthesized, the FACT complex replaces the histones to recreate the nucleosomes.
7.15.249	The termination of transcription is different for the different polymerases.
7.15.250	Unlike in prokaryotes, elongation by RNA polymerase II in eukaryotes takes place 1,000–2,000 nucleotides beyond the end of the gene being transcribed.
7.15.251	This premRNA tail is subsequently removed by cleavage during mRNA processing.
7.15.252	On the other hand, RNA polymerases I and III require termination signals.
7.15.253	Genes transcribed by RNA polymerase I contain a specific 18-nucleotide sequence that is recognized by a termination protein.
7.15.254	The process of termination in RNA polymerase III involves an mRNA hairpin similar to rho-independent termination of transcription in prokaryotes.
7.15.255	RNA Processing in Eukaryotes
7.15.256	After transcription, eukaryotic pre-mRNAs must undergo several processing steps before they can be translated.
7.15.257	Eukaryotic (and prokaryotic) tRNAs and rRNAs also undergo processing before they can function as components in the protein synthesis machinery.
7.15.258	mRNA Processing The eukaryotic pre-mRNA undergoes extensive processing before it is ready to be translated.
7.15.259	The additional steps involved in eukaryotic mRNA maturation create a molecule with a much longer half-life than a prokaryotic mRNA.
7.15.260	Eukaryotic mRNAs last for several hours, whereas the typical E. coli mRNA lasts no more than five seconds.
7.15.261	Pre-mRNAs are first coated in RNA-stabilizing proteins; these protect the pre-mRNA from degradation while it is processed and exported out of the nucleus.
7.15.262	The three most important steps of pre-mRNA processing are the addition of stabilizing and signaling factors at the 5' and 3' ends of the molecule, and the removal of intervening sequences that do not specify the appropriate amino acids.
7.15.263	In rare cases, the mRNA transcript can be “edited” after it is transcribed.
7.15.264	RNA Editing in Trypanosomes
7.15.265	The trypanosomes are a group of protozoa that include the pathogen Trypanosoma brucei, which causes sleeping sickness in humans (Figure 15.12).
7.15.266	Trypanosomes, and virtually all other eukaryotes, have organelles called mitochondria that supply the cell with chemical energy.
7.15.267	Mitochondria are organelles that express their own DNA and are believed to be the remnants of a symbiotic relationship between a eukaryote and an engulfed prokaryote.
7.15.268	The mitochondrial DNA of trypanosomes exhibit an interesting exception to The Central Dogma: their pre-mRNAs do not have the correct information to specify a functional protein.
7.15.269	Usually, this is because the mRNA is missing several U nucleotides.
7.15.270	The cell performs an additional RNA processing step called RNA editing to remedy this.
7.15.271	Trypanosoma brucei is the causative agent of sleeping sickness in humans.
7.15.272	The mRNAs of this pathogen must be modified by the addition of nucleotides before protein synthesis can occur.
7.15.273	(credit: modification of work by Torsten Ochsenreiter)
7.15.274	Other genes in the mitochondrial genome encode
7.15.275	40- to 80-nucleotide guide RNAs.
7.15.276	One or more of these molecules interacts by complementary base pairing with some of the nucleotides in the pre-mRNA transcript.
7.15.277	However, the guide RNA has more A nucleotides than the pre-mRNA has U nucleotides to bind with.
7.15.278	In these regions, the guide RNA loops out.
7.15.279	The 3' ends of guide RNAs have a long poly-U tail, and these U bases are inserted in regions of the pre-mRNA transcript at which the guide RNAs are looped.
7.15.280	This process is entirely mediated by RNA molecules.
7.15.281	That is, guide RNAs—rather than proteins—serve as the catalysts in RNA editing.
7.15.282	RNA editing is not just a phenomenon of trypanosomes.
7.15.283	In the mitochondria of some plants, almost all pre-mRNAs are edited.
7.15.284	RNA editing has also been identified in mammals such as rats, rabbits, and even humans.
7.15.285	What could be the evolutionary reason for this additional step in pre-mRNA processing?
7.15.286	One possibility is that the mitochondria, being remnants of ancient prokaryotes, have an equally ancient RNAbased method for regulating gene expression.
7.15.287	In support of this hypothesis, edits made to pre-mRNAs differ depending on cellular conditions.
7.15.288	Although speculative, the process of RNA editing may be a holdover from a primordial time when RNA molecules, instead of proteins, were responsible for catalyzing reactions.
7.15.289	5' Capping
7.15.290	While the pre-mRNA is still being synthesized, a 7-methylguanosine cap is added to the 5' end of the growing transcript by a phosphate linkage.
7.15.291	This moiety (functional group) protects the nascent mRNA from degradation.
7.15.292	In addition, factors involved in protein synthesis recognize the cap to help initiate translation by ribosomes.
7.15.293	3' Poly-A Tail
7.15.294	Once elongation is complete, the pre-mRNA is cleaved by an endonuclease between an AAUAAA consensus sequence and a GU-rich sequence, leaving the AAUAAA sequence on the pre-mRNA.
7.15.295	An enzyme called poly-A polymerase then adds a string of approximately 200 A residues, called the poly-A tail.
7.15.296	This modification further protects the pre-mRNA from degradation and signals the export of the cellular factors that the transcript needs to the cytoplasm.
7.15.297	Pre-mRNA Splicing Eukaryotic genes are composed of exons, which correspond to protein-coding sequences (ex-on signifies that they are expressed), and intervening sequences called introns (int-ron denotes their intervening role), which may be involved in gene regulation but are removed from the pre-mRNA during processing.
7.15.298	Intron sequences in mRNA do not encode functional proteins.
7.15.299	The discovery of introns came as a surprise to researchers in the 1970s who expected that pre-mRNAs would specify protein sequences without further processing, as they had observed in prokaryotes.
7.15.300	The genes of higher eukaryotes very often contain one or more introns.
7.15.301	These regions may correspond to regulatory sequences; however, the biological significance of having many introns or having very long introns in a gene is unclear.
7.15.302	It is possible that introns slow down gene expression because it takes longer to transcribe pre-mRNAs with lots of introns.
7.15.303	Alternatively, introns may be nonfunctional sequence remnants left over from the fusion of ancient genes throughout evolution.
7.15.304	This is supported by the fact that separate exons often encode separate protein subunits or domains.
7.15.305	For the most part, the sequences of introns can be mutated without ultimately affecting the protein product.
7.15.306	All of a pre-mRNA’s introns must be completely and precisely removed before protein synthesis.
7.15.307	If the process errs by even a single nucleotide, the reading frame of the rejoined exons would shift, and the resulting protein would be dysfunctional.
7.15.308	The process of removing introns and reconnecting exons is called splicing (Figure 15.13).
7.15.309	Introns are removed and degraded while the pre-mRNA is still in the nucleus.
7.15.310	Splicing occurs by a sequence-specific mechanism that ensures introns will be removed and exons rejoined with the accuracy and precision of a single nucleotide.
7.15.311	The splicing of pre-mRNAs is conducted by complexes of proteins and RNA molecules called spliceosomes.
7.15.312	Pre-mRNA splicing involves the precise removal of introns from the primary RNA transcript.
7.15.313	The splicing process is catalyzed by protein complexes called spliceosomes that are composed of proteins and RNA molecules called snRNAs.
7.15.314	Spliceosomes recognize sequences at the 5' and 3' end of the intron.
7.15.315	Errors in splicing are implicated in cancers and other human diseases.
7.15.316	What kinds of mutations might lead to splicing errors?
7.15.317	Think of different possible outcomes if splicing errors occur.
7.15.318	Note that more than 70 individual introns can be present, and each has to undergo the process of splicing—in addition to 5' capping and the addition of a poly-A tail—just to generate a single, translatable mRNA molecule.
7.15.319	Processing of tRNAs and rRNAs
7.15.320	The tRNAs and rRNAs are structural molecules that have roles in protein synthesis; however, these RNAs are not themselves translated.
7.15.321	Pre-rRNAs are transcribed, processed, and assembled into ribosomes in the nucleolus.
7.15.322	Pre-tRNAs are transcribed and processed in the nucleus and then released into the cytoplasm where they are linked to free amino acids for protein synthesis.
7.15.323	Most of the tRNAs and rRNAs in eukaryotes and prokaryotes are first transcribed as a long precursor molecule that spans multiple rRNAs or tRNAs.
7.15.324	Enzymes then cleave the precursors into subunits corresponding to each structural RNA.
7.15.325	Some of the bases of pre-rRNAs are methylated; that is, a –CH3 moiety (methyl functional group) is added for stability.
7.15.326	PretRNA molecules also undergo methylation.
7.15.327	As with pre-mRNAs, subunit excision occurs in eukaryotic pre-RNAs destined to become tRNAs or rRNAs.
7.15.328	Mature rRNAs make up approximately 50 percent of each ribosome.
7.15.329	Some of a ribosome’s RNA molecules are purely structural, whereas others have catalytic or binding activities.
7.15.330	Mature tRNAs take on a three-dimensional structure through intramolecular hydrogen bonding to position the amino acid binding site at one end and the anticodon at the other end (Figure 15.14).
7.15.331	The anticodon is a three-nucleotide sequence in a tRNA that interacts with an mRNA codon through complementary base pairing.
7.15.332	This is a space-filling model of a tRNA molecule that adds the amino acid phenylalanine to a growing polypeptide chain.
7.15.333	The anticodon AAG binds the Codon UUC on the mRNA.
7.15.334	The amino acid phenylalanine is attached to the other end of the tRNA.
7.15.335	The synthesis of proteins consumes more of a cell’s energy than any other metabolic process.
7.15.336	In turn, proteins account for more mass than any other component of living organisms (with the exception of water), and proteins perform virtually every function of a cell.
7.15.337	The process of translation, or protein synthesis, involves the decoding of an mRNA message into a polypeptide product.
7.15.338	Amino acids are covalently strung together by interlinking peptide bonds in lengths ranging from approximately 50 amino acid residues to more than 1,000.
7.15.339	Each individual amino acid has an amino group (NH2) and a carboxyl (COOH) group.
7.15.340	Polypeptides are formed when the amino group of one amino acid forms an amide (i.e., peptide) bond with the carboxyl group of another amino acid (Figure 15.15).
7.15.341	This reaction is catalyzed by ribosomes and generates one water molecule.
7.15.342	A peptide bond links the carboxyl end of one amino acid with the amino end of another, expelling one water molecule.
7.15.343	For simplicity in this image, only the functional groups involved in the peptide bond are shown.
7.15.344	The R and R' designations refer to the rest of each amino acid structure.
7.15.345	The Protein Synthesis Machinery
7.15.346	In addition to the mRNA template, many molecules and macromolecules contribute to the process of translation.
7.15.347	The composition of each component may vary across species; for instance, ribosomes may consist of different numbers of rRNAs and polypeptides depending on the organism.
7.15.348	However, the general structures and functions of the protein synthesis machinery are comparable from bacteria to human cells.
7.15.349	Translation requires the input of an mRNA template, ribosomes, tRNAs, and various enzymatic factors.
7.15.350	Ribosomes Even before an mRNA is translated, a cell must invest energy to build each of its ribosomes.
7.15.351	In E. coli, there are between 10,000 and 70,000 ribosomes present in each cell at any given time.
7.15.352	A ribosome is a complex macromolecule composed of structural and catalytic rRNAs, and many distinct polypeptides.
7.15.353	In eukaryotes, the nucleolus is completely specialized for the synthesis and assembly of rRNAs.
7.15.354	Ribosomes exist in the cytoplasm in prokaryotes and in the cytoplasm and rough endoplasmic reticulum in eukaryotes.
7.15.355	Mitochondria and chloroplasts also have their own ribosomes in the matrix and stroma, which look more similar to prokaryotic ribosomes (and have similar drug sensitivities) than the ribosomes just outside their outer membranes in the cytoplasm.
7.15.356	Ribosomes dissociate into large and small subunits when they are not synthesizing proteins and reassociate during the initiation of translation.
7.15.357	In E. coli, the small subunit is described as 30S, and the large subunit is 50S, for a total of 70S (recall that Svedberg units are not additive).
7.15.358	Mammalian ribosomes have a small 40S subunit and a large 60S subunit, for a total of 80S.
7.15.359	The small subunit is responsible for binding the mRNA template, whereas the large subunit sequentially binds tRNAs.
7.15.360	Each mRNA molecule is simultaneously translated by many ribosomes, all synthesizing protein in the same direction: reading the mRNA from 5' to 3' and synthesizing the polypeptide from the N terminus to the C terminus.
7.15.361	The complete mRNA/poly-ribosome structure is called a polysome.
7.15.362	tRNAs
7.15.363	The tRNAs are structural RNA molecules that were transcribed from genes by RNA polymerase III.
7.15.364	Depending on the species, 40 to 60 types of tRNAs exist in the cytoplasm.
7.15.365	Serving as adaptors, specific tRNAs bind to sequences on the mRNA template and add the corresponding amino acid to the polypeptide chain.
7.15.366	Therefore, tRNAs are the molecules that actually “translate” the language of RNA into the language of proteins.
7.15.367	Of the 64 possible mRNA codons—or triplet combinations of A, U, G, and C—three specify the termination of protein synthesis and 61 specify the addition of amino acids to the polypeptide chain.
7.15.368	Of these 61, one codon (AUG) also encodes the initiation of translation.
7.15.369	Each tRNA anticodon can base pair with one of the mRNA codons and add an amino acid or terminate translation, according to the genetic code.
7.15.370	For instance, if the sequence CUA occurred on an mRNA template in the proper reading frame, it would bind a tRNA expressing the complementary sequence, GAU, which would be linked to the amino acid leucine.
7.15.371	As the adaptor molecules of translation, it is surprising that tRNAs can fit so much specificity into such a small package.
7.15.372	Consider that tRNAs need to interact with three factors: 1) they must be recognized by the correct aminoacyl synthetase (see below); 2) they must be recognized by ribosomes; and 3) they must bind to the correct sequence in mRNA.
7.15.373	Aminoacyl tRNA Synthetases
7.15.374	The process of pre-tRNA synthesis by RNA polymerase III only creates the RNA portion of the adaptor molecule.
7.15.375	The corresponding amino acid must be added later, once the tRNA is processed and exported to the cytoplasm.
7.15.376	Through the process of tRNA “charging,” each tRNA molecule is linked to its correct amino acid by a group of enzymes called aminoacyl tRNA synthetases.
7.15.377	At least one type of aminoacyl tRNA synthetase exists for each of the 20 amino acids; the exact number of aminoacyl tRNA synthetases varies by species.
7.15.378	These enzymes first bind and hydrolyze ATP to catalyze a high-energy bond between an amino acid and adenosine monophosphate (AMP); a pyrophosphate molecule is expelled in this reaction.
7.15.379	The activated amino acid is then transferred to the tRNA, and AMP is released.
7.15.380	The Mechanism of Protein Synthesis
7.15.381	As with mRNA synthesis, protein synthesis can be divided into three phases: initiation, elongation, and termination.
7.15.382	The process of translation is similar in prokaryotes and eukaryotes.
7.15.383	Here we’ll explore how translation occurs in E. coli, a representative prokaryote, and specify any differences between prokaryotic and eukaryotic translation.
7.15.384	Initiation of Translation Protein synthesis begins with the formation of an initiation complex.
7.15.385	In E. coli, this complex involves the small 30S ribosome, the mRNA template, three initiation factors (IFs; IF-1, IF-2, and IF-3), and a special initiator tRNA, called tRNAf Met .
7.15.386	The initiator tRNA interacts with the start codon AUG (or rarely, GUG), links to a formylated methionine called fMet, and can also bind IF-2.
7.15.387	Formylated methionine is inserted by
7.15.388	fMet − tRNAf Met at the beginning of every polypeptide chain synthesized by E. coli,
7.15.389	but it is usually clipped off after translation is complete.
7.15.390	When an in-frame AUG is encountered during translation elongation, a non-formylated methionine is inserted by a regular Met-tRNAMet.
7.15.391	In E. coli mRNA, a sequence upstream of the first AUG codon, called the Shine-Dalgarno sequence (AGGAGG), interacts with the rRNA molecules that compose the ribosome.
7.15.392	This interaction anchors the 30S ribosomal subunit at the correct location on the mRNA template.
7.15.393	Guanosine triphosphate (GTP), which is a purine nucleotide triphosphate, acts as an energy source during translation—both at the start of elongation and during the ribosome’s translocation.
7.15.394	In eukaryotes, a similar initiation complex forms, comprising mRNA, the 40S small ribosomal subunit, IFs, and nucleoside triphosphates (GTP and ATP).
7.15.395	The charged initiator tRNA, called Met-tRNAi, does not bind fMet in eukaryotes, but is distinct from other Met-tRNAs in that it can bind IFs.
7.15.396	Instead of depositing at the Shine-Dalgarno sequence, the eukaryotic initiation complex recognizes the 7-methylguanosine cap at the 5' end of the mRNA.
7.15.397	A cap-binding protein (CBP) and several other IFs assist the movement of the ribosome to the 5' cap.
7.15.398	Once at the cap, the initiation complex tracks along the mRNA in the 5' to 3' direction, searching for the AUG start codon.
7.15.399	Many eukaryotic mRNAs are translated from the first AUG, but this is not always the case.
7.15.400	According to Kozak’s rules, the nucleotides around the AUG indicate whether it is the correct start codon.
7.15.401	Kozak’s rules state that the following consensus sequence must appear around the AUG of vertebrate genes: 5'-gccRccAUGG-3'.
7.15.402	The R (for purine) indicates a site that can be either A or G, but cannot be C or U. Essentially, the closer the sequence is to this consensus, the higher the efficiency of translation.
7.15.403	Once the appropriate AUG is identified, the other proteins and CBP dissociate, and the 60S subunit binds to the complex of Met-tRNAi, mRNA, and the 40S subunit.
7.15.404	This step completes the initiation of translation in eukaryotes.
7.15.405	Translation, Elongation, and Termination
7.15.406	In prokaryotes and eukaryotes, the basics of elongation are the same, so we will review elongation from the perspective of E. coli.
7.15.407	The 50S ribosomal subunit of E. coli consists of three compartments: the A (aminoacyl) site binds incoming charged aminoacyl tRNAs.
7.15.408	The P (peptidyl) site binds charged tRNAs carrying amino acids that have formed peptide bonds with the growing polypeptide chain but have not yet dissociated from their corresponding tRNA.
7.15.409	The E (exit) site releases dissociated tRNAs so that they can be recharged with free amino acids.
7.15.410	There is one exception to this assembly line of tRNAs: in E. coli,
7.15.411	fMet − tRNAf
7.15.412	Met is capable of entering the P site directly without first entering the A site.
7.15.413	Similarly, the eukaryotic Met-tRNAi, with help from other proteins of the initiation complex, binds directly to the P site.
7.15.414	In both cases, this creates an initiation complex with a free A site ready to accept the tRNA corresponding to the first codon after the AUG.
7.15.415	During translation elongation, the mRNA template provides specificity.
7.15.416	As the ribosome moves along the mRNA, each mRNA codon comes into register, and specific binding with the corresponding charged tRNA anticodon is ensured.
7.15.417	If mRNA were not present in the elongation complex, the ribosome would bind tRNAs nonspecifically.
7.15.418	Elongation proceeds with charged tRNAs entering the A site and then shifting to the P site followed by the E site with each single-codon “step” of the ribosome.
7.15.419	Ribosomal steps are induced by conformational changes that advance the ribosome by three bases in the 3' direction.
7.15.420	The energy for each step of the ribosome is donated by an elongation factor that hydrolyzes GTP.
7.15.421	Peptide bonds form between the amino group of the amino acid attached to the A-site tRNA and the carboxyl group of the amino acid attached to the P-site tRNA.
7.15.422	The formation of each peptide bond is catalyzed by peptidyl transferase, an RNA-based enzyme that is integrated into the 50S ribosomal subunit.
7.15.423	The energy for each peptide bond formation is derived from GTP hydrolysis, which is catalyzed by a separate elongation factor.
7.15.424	The amino acid bound to the P-site tRNA is also linked to the growing polypeptide chain.
7.15.425	As the ribosome steps across the mRNA, the former P-site tRNA enters the E site, detaches from the amino acid, and is expelled (Figure 15.16).
7.15.426	Amazingly, the E. coli translation apparatus takes only 0.05 seconds to add each amino acid, meaning that a 200-amino acid protein can be translated in just 10 seconds.
7.15.427	Translation begins when an initiator tRNA anticodon recognizes a codon on mRNA.
7.15.428	The large ribosomal subunit joins the small subunit, and a second tRNA is recruited.
7.15.429	As the mRNA moves relative to the ribosome, the polypeptide chain is formed.
7.15.430	Entry of a release factor into the A site terminates translation and the components dissociate.
7.15.431	Many antibiotics inhibit bacterial protein synthesis.
7.15.432	For example, tetracycline blocks the A site on the bacterial ribosome, and chloramphenicol blocks peptidyl transfer.
7.15.433	What specific effect would you expect each of these antibiotics to have on protein synthesis?
7.15.434	Termination of translation occurs when a nonsense codon (UAA, UAG, or UGA) is encountered.
7.15.435	Upon aligning with the A site, these nonsense codons are recognized by release factors in prokaryotes and eukaryotes that instruct peptidyl transferase to add a water molecule to the carboxyl end of the P-site amino acid.
7.15.436	This reaction forces the P-site amino acid to detach from its tRNA, and the newly made protein is released.
7.15.437	The small and large ribosomal subunits dissociate from the mRNA and from each other; they are recruited almost immediately into another translation initiation complex.
7.15.438	After many ribosomes have completed translation, the mRNA is degraded so the nucleotides can be reused in another transcription reaction.
7.15.439	Protein Folding, Modification, and Targeting During and after translation, individual amino acids may be chemically modified, signal sequences may be appended, and the new protein “folds” into a distinct three-dimensional structure as a result of intramolecular interactions.
7.15.440	A signal sequence is a short tail of amino acids that directs a protein to a specific cellular compartment.
7.15.441	These sequences at the amino end or the carboxyl end of the protein can be thought of as the protein’s “train ticket” to its ultimate destination.
7.15.442	Other cellular factors recognize each signal sequence and help transport the protein from the cytoplasm to its correct compartment.
7.15.443	For instance, a specific sequence at the amino terminus will direct a protein to the mitochondria or chloroplasts (in plants).
7.15.444	Once the protein reaches its cellular destination, the signal sequence is usually clipped off.
7.15.445	Many proteins fold spontaneously, but some proteins require helper molecules, called chaperones, to prevent them from aggregating during the complicated process of folding.
7.15.446	Even if a protein is properly specified by its corresponding mRNA, it could take on a completely dysfunctional shape if abnormal temperature or pH conditions prevent it from folding correctly.
7.16.0	GENE EXPRESSION
7.16.1	The genetic content of each somatic cell in an organism is the same, but not all genes are expressed in every cell.
7.16.2	The control of which genes are expressed dictates whether a cell is (a) an eye cell or (b) a liver cell.
7.16.3	It is the differential gene expression patterns that arise in different cells that give rise to (c) a complete organism.
7.16.4	Introduction
7.16.5	Each somatic cell in the body generally contains the same DNA.
7.16.6	A few exceptions include red blood cells, which contain no DNA in their mature state, and some immune system cells that rearrange their DNA while producing antibodies.
7.16.7	In general, however, the genes that determine whether you have green eyes, brown hair, and how fast you metabolize food are the same in the cells in your eyes and your liver, even though these organs function quite differently.
7.16.8	If each cell has the same DNA, how is it that cells or organs are different?
7.16.9	Why do cells in the eye differ so dramatically from cells in the liver?
7.16.10	Whereas each cell shares the same genome and DNA sequence, each cell does not turn on, or express, the same set of genes.
7.16.11	Each cell type needs a different set of proteins to perform its function.
7.16.12	Therefore, only a small subset of proteins is expressed in a cell.
7.16.13	For the proteins to be expressed, the DNA must be transcribed into RNA and the RNA must be translated into protein.
7.16.14	In a given cell type, not all genes encoded in the DNA are transcribed into RNA or translated into protein because specific cells in our body have specific functions.
7.16.15	Specialized proteins that make up the eye (iris, lens, and cornea) are only expressed in the eye, whereas the specialized proteins in the heart (pacemaker cells, heart muscle, and valves) are only expressed in the heart.
7.16.16	At any given time, only a subset of all of the genes encoded by our DNA are expressed and translated into proteins.
7.16.17	The expression of specific genes is a highly regulated process with many levels and stages of control.
7.16.18	This complexity ensures the proper expression in the proper cell at the proper time.
7.16.19	Regulation of Gene Expression For a cell to function properly, necessary proteins must be synthesized at the proper time.
7.16.20	All cells control or regulate the synthesis of proteins from information encoded in their DNA.
7.16.21	The process of turning on a gene to produce RNA and protein is called gene expression.
7.16.22	Whether in a simple unicellular organism or a complex multi-cellular organism, each cell controls when and how its genes are expressed.
7.16.23	For this to occur, there must be a mechanism to control when a gene is expressed to make RNA and protein, how much of the protein is made, and when it is time to stop making that protein because it is no longer needed.
7.16.24	The regulation of gene expression conserves energy and space.
7.16.25	It would require a significant amount of energy for an organism to express every gene at all times, so it is more energy efficient to turn on the genes only when they are required.
7.16.26	In addition, only expressing a subset of genes in each cell saves space because DNA must be unwound from its tightly coiled structure to transcribe and translate the DNA.
7.16.27	Cells would have to be enormous if every protein were expressed in every cell all the time.
7.16.28	The control of gene expression is extremely complex.
7.16.29	Malfunctions in this process are detrimental to the cell and can lead to the development of many diseases, including cancer.
7.16.30	Prokaryotic versus Eukaryotic Gene Expression
7.16.31	To understand how gene expression is regulated, we must first understand how a gene codes for a functional protein in a cell.
7.16.32	The process occurs in both prokaryotic and eukaryotic cells, just in slightly different manners.
7.16.33	Prokaryotic organisms are single-celled organisms that lack a cell nucleus, and their DNA therefore floats freely in the cell cytoplasm.
7.16.34	To synthesize a protein, the processes of transcription and translation occur almost simultaneously.
7.16.35	When the resulting protein is no longer needed, transcription stops.
7.16.36	As a result, the primary method to control what type of protein and how much of each protein is expressed in a prokaryotic cell is the regulation of DNA transcription.
7.16.37	All of the subsequent steps occur automatically.
7.16.38	When more protein is required, more transcription occurs.
7.16.39	Therefore, in prokaryotic cells, the control of gene expression is mostly at the transcriptional level.
7.16.40	Eukaryotic cells, in contrast, have intracellular organelles that add to their complexity.
7.16.41	In eukaryotic cells, the DNA is contained inside the cell’s nucleus and there it is transcribed into RNA.
7.16.42	The newly synthesized RNA is then transported out of the nucleus into the cytoplasm, where ribosomes translate the RNA into protein.
7.16.43	The processes of transcription and translation are physically separated by the nuclear membrane; transcription occurs only within the nucleus, and translation occurs only outside the nucleus in the cytoplasm.
7.16.44	The regulation of gene expression can occur at all stages of the process (Figure 16.2).
7.16.45	Regulation may occur when the DNA is uncoiled and loosened from nucleosomes to bind transcription factors ( epigenetic level), when the RNA is transcribed (transcriptional level), when the RNA is processed and exported to the cytoplasm after it is transcribed ( post-transcriptional level), when the RNA is translated into protein (translational level), or after the protein has been made ( post-translational level).
7.16.46	Prokaryotic transcription and translation occur simultaneously in the cytoplasm, and regulation occurs at the transcriptional level.
7.16.47	Eukaryotic gene expression is regulated during transcription and RNA processing, which take place in the nucleus, and during protein translation, which takes place in the cytoplasm.
7.16.48	Further regulation may occur through post-translational modifications of proteins.
7.16.49	The differences in the regulation of gene expression between prokaryotes and eukaryotes are summarized in Table 16.1.
7.16.50	The regulation of gene expression is discussed in detail in subsequent modules.
7.16.51	Evolution of Gene Regulation Prokaryotic cells can only regulate gene expression by controlling the amount of transcription.
7.16.52	As eukaryotic cells evolved, the complexity of the control of gene expression increased.
7.16.53	For example, with the evolution of eukaryotic cells came compartmentalization of important cellular components and cellular processes.
7.16.54	A nuclear region that contains the DNA was formed.
7.16.55	Transcription and translation were physically separated into two different cellular compartments.
7.16.56	It therefore became possible to control gene expression by regulating transcription in the nucleus, and also by controlling the RNA levels and protein translation present outside the nucleus.
7.16.57	Some cellular processes arose from the need of the organism to defend itself.
7.16.58	Cellular processes such as gene silencing developed to protect the cell from viral or parasitic infections.
7.16.59	If the cell could quickly shut off gene expression for a short period of time, it would be able to survive an infection when other organisms could not.
7.16.60	Therefore, the organism evolved a new process that helped it survive, and it was able to pass this new development to offspring.
7.16.61	Prokaryotic Gene Regulation
7.16.62	The DNA of prokaryotes is organized into a circular chromosome supercoiled in the nucleoid region of the cell cytoplasm.
7.16.63	Proteins that are needed for a specific function, or that are involved in the same biochemical pathway, are encoded together in blocks called operons.
7.16.64	For example, all of the genes needed to use lactose as an energy source are coded next to each other in the lactose (or lac) operon.
7.16.65	In prokaryotic cells, there are three types of regulatory molecules that can affect the expression of operons: repressors, activators, and inducers.
7.16.66	Repressors are proteins that suppress transcription of a gene in response to an external stimulus, whereas activators are proteins that increase the transcription of a gene in response to an external stimulus.
7.16.67	Finally, inducers are small molecules that either activate or repress transcription depending on the needs of the cell and the availability of substrate.
7.16.68	The trp Operon: A Repressor Operon Bacteria such as E. coli need amino acids to survive.
7.16.69	Tryptophan is one such amino acid that E. coli can ingest from the environment.
7.16.70	E. coli can also synthesize tryptophan using enzymes that are encoded by five genes.
7.16.71	These five genes are next to each other in what is called the tryptophan (trp) operon (Figure 16.3).
7.16.72	If tryptophan is present in the environment, then E. coli does not need to synthesize it and the switch controlling the activation of the genes in the trp operon is switched off.
7.16.73	However, when tryptophan availability is low, the switch controlling the operon is turned on, transcription is initiated, the genes are expressed, and tryptophan is synthesized.
7.16.74	The five genes that are needed to synthesize tryptophan in E. coli are located next to each other in the trp operon.
7.16.75	When tryptophan is plentiful, two tryptophan molecules bind the repressor protein at the operator sequence.
7.16.76	This physically blocks the RNA polymerase from transcribing the tryptophan genes.
7.16.77	When tryptophan is absent, the repressor protein does not bind to the operator and the genes are transcribed.
7.16.78	A DNA sequence that codes for proteins is referred to as the coding region.
7.16.79	The five coding regions for the tryptophan biosynthesis enzymes are arranged sequentially on the chromosome in the operon.
7.16.80	Just before the coding region is the transcriptional start site.
7.16.81	This is the region of DNA to which RNA polymerase binds to initiate transcription.
7.16.82	The promoter sequence is upstream of the transcriptional start site; each operon has a sequence within or near the promoter to which proteins (activators or repressors) can bind and regulate transcription.
7.16.83	A DNA sequence called the operator sequence is encoded between the promoter region and the first trp coding gene.
7.16.84	This operator contains the DNA code to which the repressor protein can bind.
7.16.85	When tryptophan is present in the cell, two tryptophan molecules bind to the trp repressor, which changes shape to bind to the trp operator.
7.16.86	Binding of the tryptophan–repressor complex at the operator physically prevents the RNA polymerase from binding, and transcribing the downstream genes.
7.16.87	When tryptophan is not present in the cell, the repressor by itself does not bind to the operator; therefore, the operon is active and tryptophan is synthesized.
7.16.88	Because the repressor protein actively binds to the operator to keep the genes turned off, the trp operon is negatively regulated and the proteins that bind to the operator to silence trp expression are negative regulators.
7.16.89	Catabolite Activator Protein (CAP): An Activator Regulator
7.16.90	Just as the trp operon is negatively regulated by tryptophan molecules, there are proteins that bind to the operator sequences that act as a positive regulator to turn genes on and activate them.
7.16.91	For example, when glucose is scarce, E. coli bacteria can turn to other sugar sources for fuel.
7.16.92	To do this, new genes to process these alternate genes must be transcribed.
7.16.93	When glucose levels drop, cyclic AMP (cAMP) begins to accumulate in the cell.
7.16.94	The cAMP molecule is a signaling molecule that is involved in glucose and energy metabolism in E. coli.
7.16.95	When glucose levels decline in the cell, accumulating cAMP binds to the positive regulator catabolite activator protein (CAP), a protein that binds to the promoters of operons that control the processing of alternative sugars.
7.16.96	When cAMP binds to CAP, the complex binds to the promoter region of the genes that are needed to use the alternate sugar sources (Figure 16.4).
7.16.97	In these operons, a CAP binding site is located upstream of the RNA polymerase binding site in the promoter.
7.16.98	This increases the binding ability of RNA polymerase to the promoter region and the transcription of the genes.
7.16.99	When glucose levels fall, E. coli may use other sugars for fuel but must transcribe new genes to do so.
7.16.100	As glucose supplies become limited, cAMP levels increase.
7.16.101	This cAMP binds to the CAP protein, a positive regulator that binds to an operator region upstream of the genes required to use other sugar sources.
7.16.102	The lac Operon: An Inducer Operon
7.16.103	The third type of gene regulation in prokaryotic cells occurs through inducible operons, which have proteins that bind to activate or repress transcription depending on the local environment and the needs of the cell.
7.16.104	The lac operon is a typical inducible operon.
7.16.105	As mentioned previously, E. coli is able to use other sugars as energy sources when glucose concentrations are low.
7.16.106	To do so, the cAMP–CAP protein complex serves as a positive regulator to induce transcription.
7.16.107	One such sugar source is lactose.
7.16.108	The lac operon encodes the genes necessary to acquire and process the lactose from the local environment.
7.16.109	CAP binds to the operator sequence upstream of the promoter that initiates transcription of the lac operon.
7.16.110	However, for the lac operon to be activated, two conditions must be met.
7.16.111	First, the level of glucose must be very low or non-existent.
7.16.112	Second, lactose must be present.
7.16.113	Only when glucose is absent and lactose is present will the lac operon be transcribed (Figure 16.5).
7.16.114	This makes sense for the cell, because it would be energetically wasteful to create the proteins to process lactose if glucose was plentiful or lactose was not available.
7.16.115	Transcription of the lac operon is carefully regulated so that its expression only occurs when glucose is limited and lactose is present to serve as an alternative fuel source.
7.16.116	If glucose is absent, then CAP can bind to the operator sequence to activate transcription.
7.16.117	If lactose is absent, then the repressor binds to the operator to prevent transcription.
7.16.118	If either of these requirements is met, then transcription remains off.
7.16.119	Only when both conditions are satisfied is the lac operon transcribed.
7.16.120	Eukaryotic Epigenetic Gene Regulation Eukaryotic gene expression is more complex than prokaryotic gene expression because the processes of transcription and translation are physically separated.
7.16.121	Unlike prokaryotic cells, eukaryotic cells can regulate gene expression at many different levels.
7.16.122	Eukaryotic gene expression begins with control of access to the DNA.
7.16.123	This form of regulation, called epigenetic regulation, occurs even before transcription is initiated.
7.16.124	Epigenetic Control: Regulating Access to Genes within the Chromosome
7.16.125	The human genome encodes over 20,000 genes; each of the 23 pairs of human chromosomes encodes thousands of genes.
7.16.126	The DNA in the nucleus is precisely wound, folded, and compacted into chromosomes so that it will fit into the nucleus.
7.16.127	It is also organized so that specific segments can be accessed as needed by a specific cell type.
7.16.128	The first level of organization, or packing, is the winding of DNA strands around histone proteins.
7.16.129	Histones package and order DNA into structural units called nucleosome complexes, which can control the access of proteins to the DNA regions (Figure 16.6a).
7.16.130	Under the electron microscope, this winding of DNA around histone proteins to form nucleosomes looks like small beads on a string (Figure 16.6b).
7.16.131	These beads (histone proteins) can move along the string (DNA) and change the structure of the molecule.
7.16.132	DNA is folded around histone proteins to create (a) nucleosome complexes.
7.16.133	These nucleosomes control the access of proteins to the underlying DNA.
7.16.134	When viewed through an electron microscope (b), the nucleosomes look like beads on a string.
7.16.135	(credit “micrograph
7.16.136	”:
7.16.137	modification of work by Chris Woodcock)
7.16.138	If DNA encoding a specific gene is to be transcribed into RNA, the nucleosomes surrounding
7.16.139	that region of DNA can slide down the DNA to open that specific chromosomal region and allow for the transcriptional machinery (RNA polymerase) to initiate transcription (Figure 16.7).
7.16.140	Nucleosomes can move to open the chromosome structure to expose a segment of DNA, but do so in a very controlled manner.
7.16.141	Nucleosomes can slide along DNA.
7.16.142	When nucleosomes are spaced closely together (top), transcription factors cannot bind and gene expression is turned off.
7.16.143	When the nucleosomes are spaced far apart (bottom), the DNA is exposed.
7.16.144	Transcription factors can bind, allowing gene expression to occur.
7.16.145	Modifications to the histones and DNA affect nucleosome spacing.
7.16.146	In females, one of the two X chromosomes is inactivated during embryonic development because of epigenetic changes to the chromatin.
7.16.147	What impact do you think these changes would have on nucleosome packing?
7.16.148	How the histone proteins move is dependent on signals found on both the histone proteins and on the DNA.
7.16.149	These signals are tags added to histone proteins and DNA that tell the histones if a chromosomal region should be open or closed (Figure 16.8 depicts modifications to histone proteins and DNA).
7.16.150	These tags are not permanent, but may be added or removed as needed.
7.16.151	They are chemical modifications (phosphate, methyl, or acetyl groups) that are attached to specific amino acids in the protein or to the nucleotides of the DNA.
7.16.152	The tags do not alter the DNA base sequence, but they do alter how tightly wound the DNA is around the histone proteins.
7.16.153	DNA is a negatively charged molecule; therefore, changes in the charge of the histone will change how tightly wound the DNA molecule will be.
7.16.154	When unmodified, the histone proteins have a large positive charge; by adding chemical modifications like acetyl groups, the charge becomes less positive.
7.16.155	The DNA molecule itself can also be modified.
7.16.156	This occurs within very specific regions called CpG islands.
7.16.157	These are stretches with a high frequency of cytosine and guanine dinucleotide DNA pairs (CG) found in the promoter regions of genes.
7.16.158	When this configuration exists, the cytosine member of the pair can be methylated (a methyl group is added).
7.16.159	This modification changes how the DNA interacts with proteins, including the histone proteins that control access to the region.
7.16.160	Highly methylated (hypermethylated) DNA regions with deacetylated histones are tightly coiled and transcriptionally inactive.
7.16.161	Histone proteins and DNA nucleotides can be modified chemically.
7.16.162	Modifications affect nucleosome spacing and gene expression.
7.16.163	(credit: modification of work by NIH)
7.16.164	This type of gene regulation is called epigenetic regulation.
7.16.165	Epigenetic means “around genetics.
7.16.166	”
7.16.167	The changes that occur to the histone proteins and DNA do not alter the nucleotide sequence and are not permanent.
7.16.168	Instead, these changes are temporary (although they often persist through multiple rounds of cell division) and alter the chromosomal structure (open or closed) as needed.
7.16.169	A gene can be turned on or off depending upon the location and modifications to the histone proteins and DNA.
7.16.170	If a gene is to be transcribed, the histone proteins and DNA are modified surrounding the chromosomal region encoding that gene.
7.16.171	This opens the chromosomal region to allow access for RNA polymerase and other proteins, called transcription factors, to bind to the promoter region, located just upstream of the gene, and initiate transcription.
7.16.172	If a gene is to remain turned off, or silenced, the histone proteins and DNA have different modifications that signal a closed chromosomal configuration.
7.16.173	In this closed configuration, the RNA polymerase and transcription factors do not have access to the DNA and transcription cannot occur (Figure 16.7).
7.16.174	Eukaryotic Transcription Gene Regulation Like prokaryotic cells, the transcription of genes in eukaryotes requires the actions of an RNA polymerase to bind to a sequence upstream of a gene to initiate transcription.
7.16.175	However, unlike prokaryotic cells, the eukaryotic RNA polymerase requires other proteins, or transcription factors, to facilitate transcription initiation.
7.16.176	Transcription factors are proteins that bind to the promoter sequence and other regulatory sequences to control the transcription of the target gene.
7.16.177	RNA polymerase by itself cannot initiate transcription in eukaryotic cells.
7.16.178	Transcription factors must bind to the promoter region first and recruit RNA polymerase to the site for transcription to be established.
7.16.179	The Promoter and the Transcription Machinery Genes are organized to make the control of gene expression easier.
7.16.180	The promoter region is immediately upstream of the coding sequence.
7.16.181	This region can be short (only a few nucleotides in length) or quite long (hundreds of nucleotides long).
7.16.182	The longer the promoter, the more available space for proteins to bind.
7.16.183	This also adds more control to the transcription process.
7.16.184	The length of the promoter is gene-specific and can differ dramatically between genes.
7.16.185	Consequently, the level of control of gene expression can also differ quite dramatically between genes.
7.16.186	The purpose of the promoter is to bind transcription factors that control the initiation of transcription.
7.16.187	Within the promoter region, just upstream of the transcriptional start site, resides the TATA box.
7.16.188	This box is simply a repeat of thymine and adenine dinucleotides (literally, TATA repeats).
7.16.189	RNA polymerase binds to the transcription initiation complex, allowing transcription to occur.
7.16.190	To initiate transcription, a transcription factor (TFIID) is the first to bind to the TATA box.
7.16.191	Binding of TFIID recruits other transcription factors, including TFIIB, TFIIE, TFIIF, and TFIIH to the TATA box.
7.16.192	Once this complex is assembled, RNA polymerase can bind to its upstream sequence.
7.16.193	When bound along with the transcription factors, RNA polymerase is phosphorylated.
7.16.194	This releases part of the protein from the DNA to activate the transcription initiation complex and places RNA polymerase in the correct orientation to begin transcription; DNA-bending protein brings the enhancer, which can be quite a distance from the gene, in contact with transcription factors and mediator proteins (Figure 16.9).
7.16.195	An enhancer is a DNA sequence that promotes transcription.
7.16.196	Each enhancer is made up of short DNA sequences called distal control elements.
7.16.197	Activators bound to the distal control elements interact with mediator proteins and transcription factors.
7.16.198	Two different genes may have the same promoter but different distal control elements, enabling differential gene expression.
7.16.199	In addition to the general transcription factors, other transcription factors can bind to the promoter to regulate gene transcription.
7.16.200	These transcription factors bind to the promoters of a specific set of genes.
7.16.201	They are not general transcription factors that bind to every promoter complex, but are recruited to a specific sequence on the promoter of a specific gene.
7.16.202	There are hundreds of transcription factors in a cell that each bind specifically to a particular DNA sequence motif.
7.16.203	When transcription factors bind to the promoter just upstream of the encoded gene, it is referred to as a cis-acting element, because it is on the same chromosome just next to the gene.
7.16.204	The region that a particular transcription factor binds to is called the transcription factor binding site.
7.16.205	Transcription factors respond to environmental stimuli that cause the proteins to find their binding sites and initiate transcription of the gene that is needed.
7.16.206	Enhancers and Transcription
7.16.207	In some eukaryotic genes, there are regions that help increase or enhance transcription.
7.16.208	These regions, called enhancers, are not necessarily close to the genes they enhance.
7.16.209	They can be located upstream of a gene, within the coding region of the gene, downstream of a gene, or may be thousands of nucleotides away.
7.16.210	Enhancer regions are binding sequences, or sites, for transcription factors.
7.16.211	When a DNA-bending protein binds, the shape of the DNA changes (Figure 16.9).
7.16.212	This shape change allows for the interaction of the activators bound to the enhancers with the transcription factors bound to the promoter region and the RNA polymerase.
7.16.213	Whereas DNA is generally depicted as a straight line in two dimensions, it is actually a three-dimensional object.
7.16.214	Therefore, a nucleotide sequence thousands of nucleotides away can fold over and interact with a specific promoter.
7.16.215	Turning Genes
7.16.216	Off:
7.16.217	Transcriptional Repressors
7.16.218	Like prokaryotic cells, eukaryotic cells also have mechanisms to prevent transcription.
7.16.219	Transcriptional repressors can bind to promoter or enhancer regions and block transcription.
7.16.220	Like the transcriptional activators, repressors respond to external stimuli to prevent the binding of activating transcription factors.
7.16.221	Eukaryotic Post-transcriptional Gene Regulation RNA is transcribed, but must be processed into a mature form before translation can begin.
7.16.222	This processing after an RNA molecule has been transcribed, but before it is translated into a protein, is called post-transcriptional modification.
7.16.223	As with the epigenetic and transcriptional stages of processing, this post-transcriptional step can also be regulated to control gene expression in the cell.
7.16.224	If the RNA is not processed, shuttled, or translated, then no protein will be synthesized.
7.16.225	RNA splicing, the first stage of post-transcriptional control In eukaryotic cells, the RNA transcript often contains regions, called introns, that are removed prior to translation.
7.16.226	The regions of RNA that code for protein are called exons (Figure 16.10).
7.16.227	After an RNA molecule has been transcribed, but prior to its departure from the nucleus to be translated, the RNA is processed and the introns are removed by splicing.
7.16.228	Alternative RNA Splicing
7.16.229	In the 1970s, genes were first observed that exhibited alternative RNA splicing.
7.16.230	Alternative RNA splicing is a mechanism that allows different protein products to be produced from one gene when different combinations of introns, and sometimes exons, are removed from the transcript (Figure 16.11).
7.16.231	This alternative splicing can be haphazard, but more often it is controlled and acts as a mechanism of gene regulation, with the frequency of different splicing alternatives controlled by the cell as a way to control the production of different protein products in different cells or at different stages of development.
7.16.232	Alternative splicing is now understood to be a common mechanism of gene regulation in eukaryotes; according to one estimate, 70 percent of genes in humans are expressed as multiple proteins through alternative splicing.
7.16.233	How could alternative splicing evolve?
7.16.234	Introns have a beginning and ending recognition sequence; it is easy to imagine the failure of the splicing mechanism to identify the end of an intron and instead find the end of the next intron, thus removing two introns and the intervening exon.
7.16.235	In fact, there are mechanisms in place to prevent such intron skipping, but mutations are likely to lead to their failure.
7.16.236	Such “mistakes” would more than likely produce a nonfunctional protein.
7.16.237	Indeed, the cause of many genetic diseases is alternative splicing rather than mutations in a sequence.
7.16.238	However, alternative splicing would create a protein variant without the loss of the original protein, opening up possibilities for adaptation of the new variant to new functions.
7.16.239	Gene duplication has played an important role in the evolution of new functions in a similar way by providing genes that may evolve without eliminating the original, functional protein.
7.16.240	Control of RNA Stability
7.16.241	Before the mRNA leaves the nucleus, it is given two protective "caps" that prevent the end of the strand from degrading during its journey.
7.16.242	The 5' cap, which is placed on the 5' end of the mRNA, is usually composed of a methylated guanosine triphosphate molecule (GTP).
7.16.243	The poly-A tail, which is attached to the 3' end, is usually composed of a series of adenine nucleotides.
7.16.244	Once the RNA is transported to the cytoplasm, the length of time that the RNA resides there can be controlled.
7.16.245	Each RNA molecule has a defined lifespan and decays at a specific rate.
7.16.246	This rate of decay can influence how much protein is in the cell.
7.16.247	If the decay rate is increased, the RNA will not exist in the cytoplasm as long, shortening the time for translation to occur.
7.16.248	Conversely, if the rate of decay is decreased, the RNA molecule will reside in the cytoplasm longer and more protein can be translated.
7.16.249	This rate of decay is referred to as the RNA stability.
7.16.250	If the RNA is stable, it will be detected for longer periods of time in the cytoplasm.
7.16.251	Binding of proteins to the RNA can influence its stability.
7.16.252	Proteins, called RNA-binding proteins, or RBPs, can bind to the regions of the RNA just upstream or downstream of the protein-coding region.
7.16.253	These regions in the RNA that are not translated into protein are called the untranslated regions, or UTRs.
7.16.254	They are not introns (those have been removed in the nucleus).
7.16.255	Rather, these are regions that regulate mRNA localization, stability, and protein translation.
7.16.256	The region just before the protein-coding region is called the 5' UTR, whereas the region after the coding region is called the 3' UTR (Figure 16.12).
7.16.257	The binding of RBPs to these regions can increase or decrease the stability of an RNA molecule, depending on the specific RBP that binds.
7.16.258	The protein-coding region of mRNA is flanked by 5' and 3' untranslated regions (UTRs).
7.16.259	The presence of RNA-binding proteins at the 5' or 3' UTR influences the stability of the RNA molecule.
7.16.260	RNA Stability and microRNAs
7.16.261	In addition to RBPs that bind to and control (increase or decrease) RNA stability, other elements called microRNAs can bind to the RNA molecule.
7.16.262	These microRNAs, or miRNAs, are short RNA molecules that are only 21–24 nucleotides in length.
7.16.263	The miRNAs are made in the nucleus as longer pre-miRNAs.
7.16.264	These pre-miRNAs are chopped into mature miRNAs by a protein called dicer.
7.16.265	Like transcription factors and RBPs, mature miRNAs recognize a specific sequence and bind to the RNA; however, miRNAs also associate with a ribonucleoprotein complex called the RNA-induced silencing complex (RISC).
7.16.266	RISC binds along with the miRNA to degrade the target mRNA.
7.16.267	Together, miRNAs and the RISC complex rapidly destroy the RNA molecule.
7.16.268	Eukaryotic Translational and Post-translational Gene Regulation
7.16.269	After the RNA has been transported to the cytoplasm, it is translated into protein.
7.16.270	Control of this process is largely dependent on the RNA molecule.
7.16.271	As previously discussed, the stability of the RNA will have a large impact on its translation into a protein.
7.16.272	As the stability changes, the amount of time that it is available for translation also changes.
7.16.273	The Initiation Complex and Translation Rate Like transcription, translation is controlled by proteins that bind and initiate the process.
7.16.274	In translation, the complex that assembles to start the process is referred to as the initiation complex.
7.16.275	The first protein to bind to the RNA to initiate translation is the eukaryotic initiation factor-2 (eIF-2).
7.16.276	The eIF-2 protein is active when it binds to the high-energy molecule guanosine triphosphate (GTP).
7.16.277	GTP provides the energy to start the reaction by giving up a phosphate and becoming guanosine diphosphate (GDP).
7.16.278	The eIF-2 protein bound to GTP binds to the small 40S ribosomal subunit.
7.16.279	When bound, the methionine initiator tRNA associates with the eIF-2/40S ribosome complex, bringing along with it the mRNA to be translated.
7.16.280	At this point, when the initiator complex is assembled, the GTP is converted into GDP and energy is released.
7.16.281	The phosphate and the eIF-2 protein are released from the complex and the large 60S ribosomal subunit binds to translate the RNA.
7.16.282	The binding of eIF-2 to the RNA is controlled by phosphorylation.
7.16.283	If eIF-2 is phosphorylated, it undergoes a conformational change and cannot bind to GTP.
7.16.284	Therefore, the initiation complex cannot form properly and translation is impeded (Figure 16.13).
7.16.285	When eIF-2 remains unphosphorylated, it binds the RNA and actively translates the protein.
7.16.286	Chemical Modifications, Protein Activity, and Longevity Proteins can be chemically modified with the addition of groups including methyl, phosphate, acetyl, and ubiquitin groups.
7.16.287	The addition or removal of these groups from proteins regulates their activity or the length of time they exist in the cell.
7.16.288	Sometimes these modifications can regulate where a protein is found in the cell—for example, in the nucleus, the cytoplasm, or attached to the plasma membrane.
7.16.289	Chemical modifications occur in response to external stimuli such as stress, the lack of nutrients, heat, or ultraviolet light exposure.
7.16.290	These changes can alter epigenetic accessibility, transcription, mRNA stability, or translation—all resulting in changes in expression of various genes.
7.16.291	This is an efficient way for the cell to rapidly change the levels of specific proteins in response to the environment.
7.16.292	Because proteins are involved in every stage of gene regulation, the phosphorylation of a protein (depending on the protein that is modified) can alter accessibility to the chromosome, can alter translation (by altering transcription factor binding or function), can change nuclear shuttling (by influencing modifications to the nuclear pore complex), can alter RNA stability (by binding or not binding to the RNA to regulate its stability), can modify translation (increase or decrease), or can change post-translational modifications (add or remove phosphates or other chemical modifications).
7.16.293	The addition of an ubiquitin group to a protein marks that protein for degradation.
7.16.294	Ubiquitin acts like a flag indicating that the protein lifespan is complete.
7.16.295	These proteins are moved to the proteasome, an organelle that functions to remove proteins, to be degraded (Figure 16.14).
7.16.296	One way to control gene expression, therefore, is to alter the longevity of the protein.
7.16.297	Cancer is not a single disease but includes many different diseases.
7.16.298	In cancer cells, mutations modify cell-cycle control and cells don’t stop growing as they normally would.
7.16.299	Mutations can also alter the growth rate or the progression of the cell through the cell cycle.
7.16.300	One example of a gene modification that alters the growth rate is increased phosphorylation of cyclin B, a protein that controls the progression of a cell through the cell cycle and serves as a cell-cycle checkpoint protein.
7.16.301	For cells to move through each phase of the cell cycle, the cell must pass through checkpoints.
7.16.302	This ensures that the cell has properly completed the step and has not encountered any mutation that will alter its function.
7.16.303	Many proteins, including cyclin B, control these checkpoints.
7.16.304	The phosphorylation of cyclin B, a post-translational event, alters its function.
7.16.305	As a result, cells can progress through the cell cycle unimpeded, even if mutations exist in the cell and its growth should be terminated.
7.16.306	This post-translational change of cyclin B prevents it from controlling the cell cycle and contributes to the development of cancer.
7.16.307	Cancer: Disease of Altered Gene Expression Cancer can be described as a disease of altered gene expression.
7.16.308	There are many proteins that are turned on or off (gene activation or gene silencing) that dramatically alter the overall activity of the cell.
7.16.309	A gene that is not normally expressed in that cell can be switched on and expressed at high levels.
7.16.310	This can be the result of gene mutation or changes in gene regulation (epigenetic, transcription, post-transcription, translation, or post-translation).
7.16.311	Changes in epigenetic regulation, transcription, RNA stability, protein translation, and post-translational control can be detected in cancer.
7.16.312	While these changes don’t occur simultaneously in one cancer, changes at each of these levels can be detected when observing cancer at different sites in different individuals.
7.16.313	Therefore, changes in histone acetylation (epigenetic modification that leads to gene silencing), activation of transcription factors by phosphorylation, increased RNA stability, increased translational control, and protein modification can all be detected at some point in various cancer cells.
7.16.314	Scientists are working to understand the common changes that give rise to certain types of cancer or how a modification might be exploited to destroy a tumor cell.
7.16.315	Tumor Suppressor Genes, Oncogenes, and Cancer
7.16.316	In normal cells, some genes function to prevent excess, inappropriate cell growth.
7.16.317	These are tumor suppressor genes, which are active in normal cells to prevent uncontrolled cell growth.
7.16.318	There are many tumor suppressor genes in cells.
7.16.319	The most studied tumor suppressor gene is p53, which is mutated in over 50 percent of all cancer types.
7.16.320	The p53 protein itself functions as a transcription factor.
7.16.321	It can bind to sites in the promoters of genes to initiate transcription.
7.16.322	Therefore, the mutation of p53 in cancer will dramatically alter the transcriptional activity of its target genes.
7.16.323	Proto-oncogenes are positive cell-cycle regulators.
7.16.324	When mutated, proto-oncogenes can become oncogenes and cause cancer.
7.16.325	Overexpression of the oncogene can lead to uncontrolled cell growth.
7.16.326	This is because oncogenes can alter transcriptional activity, stability, or protein translation of another gene that directly or indirectly controls cell growth.
7.16.327	An example of an oncogene involved in cancer is a protein called myc.
7.16.328	Myc is a transcription factor that is aberrantly activated in Burkett’s Lymphoma, a cancer of the lymph system.
7.16.329	Overexpression of myc transforms normal B cells into cancerous cells that continue to grow uncontrollably.
7.16.330	High B-cell numbers can result in tumors that can interfere with normal bodily function.
7.16.331	Patients with Burkett’s lymphoma can develop tumors on their jaw or in their mouth that interfere with the ability to eat.
7.16.332	Cancer and Epigenetic Alterations Silencing genes through epigenetic mechanisms is also very common in cancer cells.
7.16.333	There are characteristic modifications to histone proteins and DNA that are associated with silenced genes.
7.16.334	In cancer cells, the DNA in the promoter region of silenced genes is methylated on cytosine DNA residues in CpG islands.
7.16.335	Histone proteins that surround that region lack the acetylation modification that is present when the genes are expressed in normal cells.
7.16.336	This combination of DNA methylation and histone deacetylation (epigenetic modifications that lead to gene silencing) is commonly found in cancer.
7.16.337	When these modifications occur, the gene present in that chromosomal region is silenced.
7.16.338	Increasingly, scientists understand how epigenetic changes are altered in cancer.
7.16.339	Because these changes are temporary and can be reversed—for example, by preventing the action of the histone deacetylase protein that removes acetyl groups, or by DNA methyl transferase enzymes that add methyl groups to cytosines in
7.16.340	DNA—
7.16.341	it is possible to design new drugs and new therapies to take advantage of the reversible nature of these processes.
7.16.342	Indeed, many researchers are testing how a silenced gene can be switched back on in a cancer cell to help re-establish normal growth patterns.
7.16.343	Genes involved in the development of many other illnesses, ranging from allergies to inflammation to autism, are thought to be regulated by epigenetic mechanisms.
7.16.344	As our knowledge of how genes are controlled deepens, new ways to treat diseases like cancer will emerge.
7.16.345	Cancer and Transcriptional Control Alterations in cells that give rise to cancer can affect the transcriptional control of gene expression.
7.16.346	Mutations that activate transcription factors, such as increased phosphorylation, can increase the binding of a transcription factor to its binding site in a promoter.
7.16.347	This could lead to increased transcriptional activation of that gene that results in modified cell growth.
7.16.348	Alternatively, a mutation in the DNA of a promoter or enhancer region can increase the binding ability of a transcription factor.
7.16.349	This could also lead to the increased transcription and aberrant gene expression that is seen in cancer cells.
7.16.350	Researchers have been investigating how to control the transcriptional activation of gene expression in cancer.
7.16.351	Identifying how a transcription factor binds, or a pathway that activates where a gene can be turned off, has led to new drugs and new ways to treat cancer.
7.16.352	In breast cancer, for example, many proteins are overexpressed.
7.16.353	This can lead to increased phosphorylation of key transcription factors that increase transcription.
7.16.354	One such example is the overexpression of the epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) in a subset of breast cancers.
7.16.355	The EGFR pathway activates many protein kinases that, in turn, activate many transcription factors that control genes involved in cell growth.
7.16.356	New drugs that prevent the activation of EGFR have been developed and are used to treat these cancers.
7.16.357	Cancer and Post-transcriptional Control Changes in the post-transcriptional control of a gene can also result in cancer.
7.16.358	Recently, several groups of researchers have shown that specific cancers have altered expression of miRNAs.
7.16.359	Because miRNAs bind to the 3' UTR of RNA molecules to degrade them
7.16.360	, overexpression of these miRNAs could be detrimental to normal cellular activity.
7.16.361	Too many miRNAs could dramatically decrease the RNA population leading to a decrease in protein expression.
7.16.362	Several studies have demonstrated a change in the miRNA population in specific cancer types.
7.16.363	It appears that the subset of miRNAs expressed in breast cancer cells is quite different from the subset expressed in lung cancer cells or even from normal breast cells.
7.16.364	This suggests that alterations in miRNA activity can contribute to the growth of breast cancer cells.
7.16.365	These types of studies also suggest that if some miRNAs are specifically expressed only in cancer cells, they could be potential drug targets.
7.16.366	It would, therefore, be conceivable that new drugs that turn off miRNA expression in cancer could be an effective method to treat cancer.
7.16.367	Cancer and Translational/Post-translational Control
7.16.368	There are many examples of how translational or post-translational modifications of proteins arise in cancer.
7.16.369	Modifications are found in cancer cells from the increased translation of a protein to changes in protein phosphorylation to alternative splice variants of a protein.
7.16.370	An example of how the expression of an alternative form of a protein can have dramatically different outcomes is seen in colon cancer cells.
7.16.371	The c-Flip protein, a protein involved in mediating the cell death pathway, comes in two forms: long (c-FLIPL) and short (c-FLIPS).
7.16.372	Both forms appear to be involved in initiating controlled cell death mechanisms in normal cells.
7.16.373	However, in colon cancer cells, expression of the long form results in increased cell growth instead of cell death.
7.16.374	Clearly, the expression of the wrong protein dramatically alters cell function and contributes to the development of cancer.
7.16.375	New Drugs to Combat Cancer:
7.16.376	Targeted Therapies Scientists are using what is known about the regulation of gene expression in disease states, including cancer, to develop new ways to treat and prevent disease development.
7.16.377	Many scientists are designing drugs on the basis of the gene expression patterns within individual tumors.
7.16.378	This idea, that therapy and medicines can be tailored to an individual, has given rise to the field of personalized medicine.
7.16.379	With an increased understanding of gene regulation and gene function, medicines can be designed to specifically target diseased cells without harming healthy cells.
7.16.380	Some new medicines, called targeted therapies, have exploited the overexpression of a specific protein or the mutation of a gene to develop a new medication to treat disease.
7.16.381	One such example is the use of anti-EGF receptor medications to treat the subset of breast cancer tumors that have very high levels of the EGF protein.
7.16.382	Undoubtedly, more targeted therapies will be developed as scientists learn more about how gene expression changes can cause cancer.
7.16.383	Clinical Trial Coordinator
7.16.384	A clinical trial coordinator is the person managing the proceedings of the clinical trial.
7.16.385	This job includes coordinating patient schedules and appointments, maintaining detailed notes, building the database to track patients (especially for long-term follow-up studies), ensuring proper documentation has been acquired and accepted, and working with the nurses and doctors to facilitate the trial and publication of the results.
7.16.386	A clinical trial coordinator may have a science background, like a nursing degree, or other certification.
7.16.387	People who have worked in science labs or in clinical offices are also qualified to become a clinical trial coordinator.
7.16.388	These jobs are generally in hospitals; however, some clinics and doctor’s offices also conduct clinical trials and may hire a coordinator.
7.17.0	BIOTECHNOLOGY AND GENOMICS
7.17.1	In genomics, the DNA of different organisms is compared, enabling scientists to create maps with which to navigate the DNA of different organisms.
7.17.2	Introduction
7.17.3	The study of nucleic acids began with the discovery of DNA, progressed to the study of genes and small fragments, and has now exploded to the field of genomics.
7.17.4	Genomics is the study of entire genomes, including the complete set of genes, their nucleotide sequence and organization, and their interactions within a species and with other species.
7.17.5	The advances in genomics have been made possible by DNA sequencing technology.
7.17.6	Just as information technology has led to Google maps that enable people to get detailed information about locations around the globe, genomic information is used to create similar maps of the DNA of different organisms.
7.17.7	These findings have helped anthropologists to better understand human migration and have aided the field of medicine through the mapping of human genetic diseases.
7.17.8	The ways in which genomic information can contribute to scientific understanding are varied and quickly growing.
7.17.9	Biotechnology Biotechnology is the use of biological agents for technological advancement.
7.17.10	Biotechnology was used for breeding livestock and crops long before the scientific basis of these techniques was understood.
7.17.11	Since the discovery of the structure of DNA in 1953, the field of biotechnology has grown rapidly through both academic research and private companies.
7.17.12	The primary applications of this technology are in medicine (production of vaccines and antibiotics) and agriculture (genetic modification of crops, such as to increase yields).
7.17.13	Biotechnology also has many industrial applications, such as fermentation, the treatment of oil spills, and the production of biofuels (Figure 17.2).
7.17.14	Antibiotics are chemicals produced by fungi, bacteria, and other organisms that have antimicrobial properties.
7.17.15	The first antibiotic discovered was penicillin.
7.17.16	Antibiotics are now commercially produced and tested for their potential to inhibit bacterial growth.
7.17.17	(credit "advertisement": modification of work by NIH; credit "test plate": modification of work by Don Stalons/CDC; scale-bar data from Matt Russell)
7.17.18	Basic Techniques to Manipulate Genetic Material (DNA and RNA)
7.17.19	To understand the basic techniques used to work with nucleic acids, remember that nucleic acids are macromolecules made of nucleotides (a sugar, a phosphate, and a nitrogenous base) linked by phosphodiester bonds.
7.17.20	The phosphate groups on these molecules each have a net negative charge.
7.17.21	An entire set of DNA molecules in the nucleus is called the genome.
7.17.22	DNA has two complementary strands linked by hydrogen bonds between the paired bases.
7.17.23	The two strands can be separated by exposure to high temperatures (DNA denaturation) and can be reannealed by cooling.
7.17.24	The DNA can be replicated by the DNA polymerase enzyme.
7.17.25	Unlike DNA, which is located in the nucleus of eukaryotic cells, RNA molecules leave the nucleus.
7.17.26	The most common type of RNA that is analyzed is the messenger RNA (mRNA) because it represents the proteincoding genes that are actively expressed.
7.17.27	However, RNA molecules present some other challenges to analysis, as they are often less stable than DNA.
7.17.28	DNA and RNA Extraction To study or manipulate nucleic acids, the DNA or RNA must first be isolated or extracted from the cells.
7.17.29	Various techniques are used to extract different types of DNA (Figure 17.3).
7.17.30	Most nucleic acid extraction techniques involve steps to break open the cell and use enzymatic reactions to destroy all macromolecules that are not desired (such as degradation of unwanted molecules and separation from the DNA sample).
7.17.31	Cells are broken using a lysis buffer (a solution which is mostly a detergent); lysis means “to split.
7.17.32	”
7.17.33	These enzymes break apart lipid molecules in the cell membranes and nuclear membranes.
7.17.34	Macromolecules are inactivated using enzymes such as proteases that break down proteins, and ribonucleases (RNAses) that break down RNA.
7.17.35	The DNA is then precipitated using alcohol.
