7.17.36	Human genomic DNA is usually visible as a gelatinous, white mass.
7.17.37	The DNA samples can be stored frozen at –80°C for several years.
7.17.38	This diagram shows the basic method used for extraction of DNA.
7.17.39	RNA analysis is performed to study gene expression patterns in cells.
7.17.40	RNA is naturally very unstable because RNAses are commonly present in nature and very difficult to inactivate.
7.17.41	Similar to DNA, RNA extraction involves the use of various buffers and enzymes to inactivate macromolecules and preserve the RNA.
7.17.42	Gel Electrophoresis
7.17.43	Because nucleic acids are negatively charged ions at neutral or basic pH in an aqueous environment, they can be mobilized by an electric field.
7.17.44	Gel electrophoresis is a technique used to separate molecules on the basis of size, using this charge.
7.17.45	The nucleic acids can be separated as whole chromosomes or fragments.
7.17.46	The nucleic acids are loaded into a slot near the negative electrode of a semisolid, porous gel matrix and pulled toward the positive electrode at the opposite end of the gel.
7.17.47	Smaller molecules move through the pores in the gel faster than larger molecules; this difference in the rate of migration separates the fragments on the basis of size.
7.17.48	There are molecular weight standard samples that can be run alongside the molecules to provide a size comparison.
7.17.49	Nucleic acids in a gel matrix can be observed using various fluorescent or colored dyes.
7.17.50	Distinct nucleic acid fragments appear as bands at specific distances from the top of the gel (the negative electrode end) on the basis of their size (Figure 17.4).
7.17.51	A mixture of genomic DNA fragments of varying sizes appear as a long smear, whereas uncut genomic DNA is usually too large to run through the gel and forms a single large band at the top of the gel.
7.17.52	Shown are DNA fragments from seven samples run on a gel, stained with a fluorescent dye, and viewed under UV light.
7.17.53	(credit: James Jacob, Tompkins Cortland Community College)
7.17.54	Amplification of Nucleic Acid Fragments by Polymerase Chain Reaction
7.17.55	Although genomic DNA is visible to the naked eye when it is extracted in bulk, DNA analysis often requires focusing on one or more specific regions of the genome.
7.17.56	Polymerase chain reaction (PCR) is a technique used to amplify specific regions of DNA for further analysis (Figure 17.5).
7.17.57	PCR is used for many purposes in laboratories, such as the cloning of gene fragments to analyze genetic diseases, identification of contaminant foreign DNA in a sample, and the amplification of DNA for sequencing.
7.17.58	More practical applications include the determination of paternity and detection of genetic diseases.
7.17.59	Polymerase chain reaction, or PCR, is used to amplify a specific sequence of DNA.
7.17.60	Primers—short pieces of DNA complementary to each end of the target sequence—are combined with genomic DNA, Taq polymerase, and deoxynucleotides.
7.17.61	Taq polymerase is a DNA polymerase isolated from the thermostable bacterium Thermus aquaticus that is able to withstand the high temperatures used in PCR.
7.17.62	Thermus aquaticus grows in the Lower Geyser Basin of Yellowstone National Park.
7.17.63	Reverse transcriptase PCR (RT-PCR) is similar to PCR, but cDNA is made from an RNA template before PCR begins.
7.17.64	DNA fragments can also be amplified from an RNA template in a process called reverse transcriptase PCR (RT-PCR).
7.17.65	The first step is to recreate the original DNA template strand (called cDNA) by applying DNA nucleotides to the mRNA.
7.17.66	This process is called reverse transcription.
7.17.67	This requires the presence of an enzyme called reverse transcriptase.
7.17.68	After the cDNA is made, regular PCR can be used to amplify it.
7.17.69	Hybridization, Southern Blotting, and Northern Blotting Nucleic acid samples, such as fragmented genomic DNA and RNA extracts, can be probed for the presence of certain sequences.
7.17.70	Short DNA fragments called probes are designed and labeled with radioactive or fluorescent dyes to aid detection.
7.17.71	Gel electrophoresis separates the nucleic acid fragments according to their size.
7.17.72	The fragments in the gel are then transferred onto a nylon membrane in a procedure called blotting (Figure 17.6).
7.17.73	The nucleic acid fragments that are bound to the surface of the membrane can then be probed with specific radioactively or fluorescently labeled probe sequences.
7.17.74	When DNA is transferred to a nylon membrane, the technique is called Southern blotting, and when RNA is transferred to a nylon membrane, it is called northern blotting.
7.17.75	Southern blots are used to detect the presence of certain DNA sequences in a given genome, and northern blots are used to detect gene expression.
7.17.76	Southern blotting is used to find a particular sequence in a sample of DNA.
7.17.77	DNA fragments are separated on a gel, transferred to a nylon membrane, and incubated with a DNA probe complementary to the sequence of interest.
7.17.78	Northern blotting is similar to Southern blotting, but RNA is run on the gel instead of DNA.
7.17.79	In western blotting, proteins are run on a gel and detected using antibodies.
7.17.80	Molecular Cloning
7.17.81	In general, the word “cloning” means the creation of a perfect replica; however, in biology, the re-creation of a whole organism is referred to as “reproductive cloning.
7.17.82	”
7.17.83	Long before attempts were made to clone an entire organism, researchers learned how to reproduce desired regions or fragments of the genome, a process that is referred to as molecular cloning.
7.17.84	Cloning small fragments of the genome allows for the manipulation and study of specific genes (and their protein products), or noncoding regions in isolation.
7.17.85	A plasmid (also called a vector) is a small circular DNA molecule that replicates independently of the chromosomal DNA.
7.17.86	In cloning, the plasmid molecules can be used to provide a "folder" in which to insert a desired DNA fragment.
7.17.87	Plasmids are usually introduced into a bacterial host for proliferation.
7.17.88	In the bacterial context, the fragment of DNA from the human genome (or the genome of another organism that is being studied) is referred to as foreign DNA, or a transgene, to differentiate it from the DNA of the bacterium, which is called the host DNA.
7.17.89	Plasmids occur naturally in bacterial populations (such as Escherichia coli) and have genes that can contribute favorable traits to the organism, such as antibiotic resistance (the ability to be unaffected by antibiotics).
7.17.90	Plasmids have been repurposed and engineered as vectors for molecular cloning and the large-scale production of important reagents, such as insulin and human growth hormone.
7.17.91	An important feature of plasmid vectors is the ease with which a foreign DNA fragment can be introduced via the multiple cloning site (MCS).
7.17.92	The MCS is a short DNA sequence containing multiple sites that can be cut with different commonly available restriction endonucleases.
7.17.93	Restriction endonucleases recognize specific DNA sequences and cut them in a predictable manner; they are naturally produced by bacteria as a defense mechanism against foreign DNA.
7.17.94	Many restriction endonucleases make staggered cuts in the two strands of DNA, such that the cut ends have a 2- or 4-base single-stranded overhang.
7.17.95	Because these overhangs are capable of annealing with complementary overhangs, these are called “sticky ends.
7.17.96	”
7.17.97	Addition of an enzyme called DNA ligase permanently joins the DNA fragments via phosphodiester bonds.
7.17.98	In this way, any DNA fragment generated by restriction endonuclease cleavage can be spliced between the two ends of a plasmid DNA that has been cut with the same restriction endonuclease (Figure 17.7).
7.17.99	Recombinant DNA Molecules Plasmids with foreign DNA inserted into them are called recombinant DNA molecules because they are created artificially and do not occur in nature.
7.17.100	They are also called chimeric molecules because the origin of different parts of the molecules can be traced back to different species of biological organisms or even to chemical synthesis.
7.17.101	Proteins that are expressed from recombinant DNA molecules are called recombinant proteins.
7.17.102	Not all recombinant plasmids are capable of expressing genes.
7.17.103	The recombinant DNA may need to be moved into a different vector (or host) that is better designed for gene expression.
7.17.104	Plasmids may also be engineered to express proteins only when stimulated by certain environmental factors, so that scientists can control the expression of the recombinant proteins.
7.17.105	Cellular Cloning Unicellular organisms, such as bacteria and yeast, naturally produce clones of themselves when they replicate asexually by binary fission; this is known as cellular cloning.
7.17.106	The nuclear DNA duplicates by the process of mitosis, which creates an exact replica of the genetic material.
7.17.107	Reproductive Cloning Reproductive cloning is a method used to make a clone or an identical copy of an entire multicellular organism.
7.17.108	Most multicellular organisms undergo reproduction by sexual means, which involves genetic hybridization of two individuals (parents), making it impossible for generation of an identical copy or a clone of either parent.
7.17.109	Recent advances in biotechnology have made it possible to artificially induce asexual reproduction of mammals in the laboratory.
7.17.110	Parthenogenesis, or “virgin birth,” occurs when an embryo grows and develops without the fertilization of the egg occurring; this is a form of asexual reproduction.
7.17.111	An example of parthenogenesis occurs in species in which the female lays an egg and if the egg is fertilized, it is a diploid egg and the individual develops into a female; if the egg is not fertilized, it remains a haploid egg and develops into a male.
7.17.112	The unfertilized egg is called a parthenogenic, or virgin, egg.
7.17.113	Some insects and reptiles lay parthenogenic eggs that can develop into adults.
7.17.114	Sexual reproduction requires two cells; when the haploid egg and sperm cells fuse, a diploid zygote results.
7.17.115	The zygote nucleus contains the genetic information to produce a new individual.
7.17.116	However, early embryonic development requires the cytoplasmic material contained in the egg cell.
7.17.117	This idea forms the basis for reproductive cloning.
7.17.118	Therefore, if the haploid nucleus of an egg cell is replaced with a diploid nucleus from the cell of any individual of the same species (called a donor), it will become a zygote that is genetically identical to the donor.
7.17.119	Somatic cell nuclear transfer is the technique of transferring a diploid nucleus into an enucleated egg.
7.17.120	It can be used for either therapeutic cloning or reproductive cloning.
7.17.121	The first cloned animal was Dolly, a sheep who was born in 1996.
7.17.122	The success rate of reproductive cloning at the time was very low.
7.17.123	Dolly lived for seven years and died of respiratory complications (Figure 17.8).
7.17.124	There is speculation that because the cell DNA belongs to an older individual, the age of the DNA may affect the life expectancy of a cloned individual.
7.17.125	Since Dolly, several animals such as horses, bulls, and goats have been successfully cloned, although these individuals often exhibit facial, limb, and cardiac abnormalities.
7.17.126	There have been attempts at producing cloned human embryos as sources of embryonic stem cells, sometimes referred to as cloning for therapeutic purposes.
7.17.127	Therapeutic cloning produces stem cells to attempt to remedy detrimental diseases or defects (unlike reproductive cloning, which aims to reproduce an organism).
7.17.128	Still, therapeutic cloning efforts have met with resistance because of bioethical considerations.
7.17.129	Dolly the sheep was the first mammal to be cloned.
7.17.130	To create Dolly, the nucleus was removed from a donor egg cell.
7.17.131	The nucleus from a second sheep was then introduced into the cell, which was allowed to divide to the blastocyst stage before being implanted in a surrogate mother.
7.17.132	Genetic Engineering Genetic engineering is the alteration of an organism’s genotype using recombinant DNA technology to modify an organism’s DNA to achieve desirable traits.
7.17.133	The addition of foreign DNA in the form of recombinant DNA vectors generated by molecular cloning is the most common method of genetic engineering.
7.17.134	The organism that receives the recombinant DNA is called a genetically modified organism (GMO).
7.17.135	If the foreign DNA that is introduced comes from a different species, the host organism is called transgenic.
7.17.136	Bacteria, plants, and animals have been genetically modified since the early 1970s for academic, medical, agricultural, and industrial purposes.
7.17.137	In the US, GMOs such as Roundup-ready soybeans and borer-resistant corn are part of many common processed foods.
7.17.138	Gene Targeting
7.17.139	Although classical methods of studying the function of genes began with a given phenotype and determined the genetic basis of that phenotype, modern techniques allow researchers to start at the DNA sequence level and ask: "What does this gene or DNA element do?
7.17.140	"
7.17.141	This technique, called reverse genetics, has resulted in reversing the classic genetic methodology.
7.17.142	This method would be similar to damaging a body part to determine its function.
7.17.143	An insect that loses a wing cannot fly, which means that the function of the wing is flight.
7.17.144	The classical genetic method would compare insects that cannot fly with insects that can fly, and observe that the non-flying insects have lost wings.
7.17.145	Similarly, mutating or deleting genes provides researchers with clues about gene function.
7.17.146	The methods used to disable gene function are collectively called gene targeting.
7.17.147	Gene targeting is the use of recombinant DNA vectors to alter the expression of a particular gene, either by introducing mutations in a gene, or by eliminating the expression of a certain gene by deleting a part or all of the gene sequence from the genome of an organism.
7.17.148	Biotechnology in Medicine and Agriculture
7.17.149	It is easy to see how biotechnology can be used for medicinal purposes.
7.17.150	Knowledge of the genetic makeup of our species, the genetic basis of heritable diseases, and the invention of technology to manipulate and fix mutant genes provides methods to treat the disease.
7.17.151	Biotechnology in agriculture can enhance resistance to disease, pest, and environmental stress, and improve both crop yield and quality.
7.17.152	Genetic Diagnosis and Gene Therapy
7.17.153	The process of testing for suspected genetic defects before administering treatment is called genetic diagnosis by genetic testing.
7.17.154	Depending on the inheritance patterns of a disease-causing gene, family members are advised to undergo genetic testing.
7.17.155	For example, women diagnosed with breast cancer are usually advised to have a biopsy so that the medical team can determine the genetic basis of cancer development.
7.17.156	Treatment plans are based on the findings of genetic tests that determine the type of cancer.
7.17.157	If the cancer is caused by inherited gene mutations, other female relatives are also advised to undergo genetic testing and periodic screening for breast cancer.
7.17.158	Genetic testing is also offered for fetuses (or embryos with in vitro fertilization) to determine the presence or absence of disease-causing genes in families with specific debilitating diseases.
7.17.159	Gene therapy is a genetic engineering technique used to cure disease.
7.17.160	In its simplest form, it involves the introduction of a good gene at a random location in the genome to aid the cure of a disease that is caused by a mutated gene.
7.17.161	The good gene is usually introduced into diseased cells as part of a vector transmitted by a virus that can infect the host cell and deliver the foreign DNA (Figure 17.9).
7.17.162	More advanced forms of gene therapy try to correct the mutation at the original site in the genome, such as is the case with treatment of severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID).
7.17.163	Production of Vaccines, Antibiotics, and Hormones Traditional vaccination strategies use weakened or inactive forms of microorganisms to mount the initial immune response.
7.17.164	Modern techniques use the genes of microorganisms cloned into vectors to mass produce the desired antigen.
7.17.165	The antigen is then introduced into the body to stimulate the primary immune response and trigger immune memory.
7.17.166	Genes cloned from the influenza virus have been used to combat the constantly changing strains of this virus.
7.17.167	Antibiotics are a biotechnological product.
7.17.168	They are naturally produced by microorganisms, such as fungi, to attain an advantage over bacterial populations.
7.17.169	Antibiotics are produced on a large scale by cultivating and manipulating fungal cells.
7.17.170	Recombinant DNA technology was used to produce large-scale quantities of human insulin in E. coli as early as 1978.
7.17.171	Previously, it was only possible to treat diabetes with pig insulin, which caused allergic reactions in humans because of differences in the gene product.
7.17.172	In addition, human growth hormone (HGH) is used to treat growth disorders in children.
7.17.173	The HGH gene was cloned from a cDNA library and inserted into E. coli cells by cloning it into a bacterial vector.
7.17.174	Transgenic Animals
7.17.175	Although several recombinant proteins used in medicine are successfully produced in bacteria, some proteins require a eukaryotic animal host for proper processing.
7.17.176	For this reason, the desired genes are cloned and expressed in animals, such as sheep, goats, chickens, and mice.
7.17.177	Animals that have been modified to express recombinant DNA are called transgenic animals.
7.17.178	Several human proteins are expressed in the milk of transgenic sheep and goats, and some are expressed in the eggs of chickens.
7.17.179	Mice have been used extensively for expressing and studying the effects of recombinant genes and mutations.
7.17.180	Transgenic Plants Manipulating the DNA of plants (i.e., creating GMOs) has helped to create desirable traits, such as disease resistance, herbicide and pesticide resistance, better nutritional value, and better shelf-life (Figure 17.10).
7.17.181	Plants are the most important source of food for the human population.
7.17.182	Farmers developed ways to select for plant varieties with desirable traits long before modern-day biotechnology practices were established.
7.17.183	Plants that have received recombinant DNA from other species are called transgenic plants.
7.17.184	Because they are not natural, transgenic plants and other GMOs are closely monitored by government agencies to ensure that they are fit for human consumption and do not endanger other plant and animal life.
7.17.185	Because foreign genes can spread to other species in the environment, extensive testing is required to ensure ecological stability.
7.17.186	Staples like corn, potatoes, and tomatoes were the first crop plants to be genetically engineered.
7.17.187	Transformation of Plants Using Agrobacterium tumefaciens
7.17.188	Gene transfer occurs naturally between species in microbial populations.
7.17.189	Many viruses that cause human diseases, such as cancer, act by incorporating their DNA into the human genome.
7.17.190	In plants, tumors caused by the bacterium Agrobacterium tumefaciens occur by transfer of DNA from the bacterium to the plant.
7.17.191	Although the tumors do not kill the plants, they make the plants stunted and more susceptible to harsh environmental conditions.
7.17.192	Many plants, such as walnuts, grapes, nut trees, and beets, are affected by A. tumefaciens.
7.17.193	The artificial introduction of DNA into plant cells is more challenging than in animal cells because of the thick plant cell wall.
7.17.194	Researchers used the natural transfer of DNA from Agrobacterium to a plant host to introduce DNA fragments of their choice into plant hosts.
7.17.195	In nature, the disease-causing A. tumefaciens have a set of plasmids, called the Ti plasmids (tumorinducing plasmids), that contain genes for the production of tumors in plants.
7.17.196	DNA from the Ti plasmid integrates into the infected plant cell’s genome.
7.17.197	Researchers manipulate the Ti plasmids to remove the tumor-causing genes and insert the desired DNA fragment for transfer into the plant genome.
7.17.198	The Ti plasmids carry antibiotic resistance genes to aid selection and can be propagated in E. coli cells as well.
7.17.199	The Organic Insecticide Bacillus thuringiensis Bacillus thuringiensis
7.17.200	(Bt) is a bacterium that produces protein crystals during sporulation that are toxic to many insect species that affect plants.
7.17.201	Bt toxin has to be ingested by insects for the toxin to be activated.
7.17.202	Insects that have eaten Bt toxin stop feeding on the plants within a few hours.
7.17.203	After the toxin is activated in the intestines of the insects, death occurs within a couple of days.
7.17.204	Modern biotechnology has allowed plants to encode their own crystal Bt toxin that acts against insects.
7.17.205	The crystal toxin genes have been cloned from Bt and introduced into plants.
7.17.206	Bt toxin has been found to be safe for the environment, non-toxic to humans and other mammals, and is approved for use by organic farmers as a natural insecticide.
7.17.207	Flavr Savr Tomato
7.17.208	The first GM crop to be introduced into the market was the Flavr Savr Tomato produced in 1994.
7.17.209	Antisense RNA technology was used to slow down the process of softening and rotting caused by fungal infections, which led to increased shelf life of the GM tomatoes.
7.17.210	Additional genetic modification improved the flavor of this tomato.
7.17.211	The Flavr Savr tomato did not successfully stay in the market because of problems maintaining and shipping the crop.
7.17.212	Mapping Genomes Genomics is the study of entire genomes, including the complete set of genes, their nucleotide sequence and organization, and their interactions within a species and with other species.
7.17.213	Genome mapping is the process of finding the locations of genes on each chromosome.
7.17.214	The maps created by genome mapping are comparable to the maps that we use to navigate streets.
7.17.215	A genetic map is an illustration that lists genes and their location on a chromosome.
7.17.216	Genetic maps provide the big picture (similar to a map of interstate highways) and use genetic markers (similar to landmarks).
7.17.217	A genetic marker is a gene or sequence on a chromosome that co-segregates (shows genetic linkage) with a specific trait.
7.17.218	Early geneticists called this linkage analysis.
7.17.219	Physical maps present the intimate details of smaller regions of the chromosomes (similar to a detailed road map).
7.17.220	A physical map is a representation of the physical distance, in nucleotides, between genes or genetic markers.
7.17.221	Both genetic linkage maps and physical maps are required to build a complete picture of the genome.
7.17.222	Having a complete map of the genome makes it easier for researchers to study individual genes.
7.17.223	Human genome maps help researchers in their efforts to identify human disease-causing genes related to illnesses like cancer, heart disease, and cystic fibrosis.
7.17.224	Genome mapping can be used in a variety of other applications, such as using live microbes to clean up pollutants or even prevent pollution.
7.17.225	Research involving plant genome mapping may lead to producing higher crop yields or developing plants that better adapt to climate change.
7.17.226	Genetic Maps
7.17.227	The study of genetic maps begins with linkage analysis, a procedure that analyzes the recombination frequency between genes to determine if they are linked or show independent assortment.
7.17.228	The term linkage was used before the discovery of DNA.
7.17.229	Early geneticists relied on the observation of phenotypic changes to understand the genotype of an organism.
7.17.230	Shortly after Gregor Mendel (the father of modern genetics) proposed that traits were determined by what are now known as genes, other researchers observed that different traits were often inherited together, and thereby deduced that the genes were physically linked by being located on the same chromosome.
7.17.231	The mapping of genes relative to each other based on linkage analysis led to the development of the first genetic maps.
7.17.232	Observations that certain traits were always linked and certain others were not linked came from studying the offspring of crosses between parents with different traits.
7.17.233	For example, in experiments performed on the garden pea, it was discovered that the color of the flower and shape of the plant’s pollen were linked traits, and therefore the genes encoding these traits were in close proximity on the same chromosome.
7.17.234	The exchange of DNA between homologous pairs of chromosomes is called genetic recombination, which occurs by the crossing over of DNA between homologous strands of DNA, such as nonsister chromatids.
7.17.235	Linkage analysis involves studying the recombination frequency between any two genes.
7.17.236	The greater the distance between two genes, the higher the chance that a recombination event will occur between them, and the higher the recombination frequency between them.
7.17.237	Two possibilities for recombination between two nonsister chromatids during meiosis are shown in Figure 17.11.
7.17.238	If the recombination frequency between two genes is less than 50 percent, they are said to be linked.
7.17.239	Crossover may occur at different locations on the chromosome.
7.17.240	Recombination between
7.17.241	genes A and B is more frequent than recombination between genes B and C because genes A and B are farther apart; a crossover is therefore more likely to occur between them.
7.17.242	The generation of genetic maps requires markers, just as a road map requires landmarks (such as rivers and mountains).
7.17.243	Early genetic maps were based on the use of known genes as markers.
7.17.244	More sophisticated markers, including those based on non-coding DNA, are now used to compare the genomes of individuals in a population.
7.17.245	Although individuals of a given species are genetically similar, they are not identical; every individual has a unique set of traits.
7.17.246	These minor differences in the genome between individuals in a population are useful for the purposes of genetic mapping.
7.17.247	In general, a good genetic marker is a region on the chromosome that shows variability or polymorphism (multiple forms) in the population.
7.17.248	Some genetic markers used in generating genetic maps are restriction fragment length polymorphisms (RFLP), variable number of tandem repeats (VNTRs), microsatellite polymorphisms, and the single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs).
7.17.249	RFLPs (sometimes pronounced “
7.17.250	rif-lips”) are detected when the DNA of an individual is cut with a restriction endonuclease that recognizes specific sequences in the DNA to generate a series of DNA fragments, which are then analyzed by gel electrophoresis.
7.17.251	The DNA of every individual will give rise to a unique pattern of bands when cut with a particular set of restriction endonucleases; this is sometimes referred to as an individual’s DNA “fingerprint.
7.17.252	”
7.17.253	Certain regions of the chromosome that are subject to polymorphism will lead to the generation of the unique banding pattern.
7.17.254	VNTRs are repeated sets of nucleotides present in the non-coding regions of DNA.
7.17.255	Non-coding, or “junk,” DNA has no known biological function; however, research shows that much of this DNA is actually transcribed.
7.17.256	While its function is uncertain, it is certainly active, and it may be involved in the regulation of coding genes.
7.17.257	The number of repeats may vary in individual organisms of a population.
7.17.258	Microsatellite polymorphisms are similar to VNTRs, but the repeat unit is very small.
7.17.259	SNPs are variations in a single nucleotide.
7.17.260	Because genetic maps rely completely on the natural process of recombination, mapping is affected by natural increases or decreases in the level of recombination in any given area of the genome.
7.17.261	Some parts of the genome are recombination hotspots, whereas others do not show a propensity for recombination.
7.17.262	For this reason, it is important to look at mapping information developed by multiple methods.
7.17.263	Physical Maps
7.17.264	A physical map provides detail of the actual physical distance between genetic markers, as well as the number of nucleotides.
7.17.265	There are three methods used to create a physical map: cytogenetic mapping, radiation hybrid mapping, and sequence mapping.
7.17.266	Cytogenetic mapping uses information obtained by microscopic analysis of stained sections of the chromosome (Figure 17.12).
7.17.267	It is possible to determine the approximate distance between genetic markers using cytogenetic mapping, but not the exact distance (number of base pairs).
7.17.268	Radiation hybrid mapping uses radiation, such as x-rays, to break the DNA into fragments.
7.17.269	The amount of radiation can be adjusted to create smaller or larger fragments.
7.17.270	This technique overcomes the limitation of genetic mapping and is not affected by increased or decreased recombination frequency.
7.17.271	Sequence mapping resulted from DNA sequencing technology that allowed for the creation of detailed physical maps with distances measured in terms of the number of base pairs.
7.17.272	The creation of genomic libraries and complementary DNA (cDNA) libraries (collections of cloned sequences or all DNA from a genome) has sped up the process of physical mapping.
7.17.273	A genetic site used to generate a physical map with sequencing technology (a sequence-tagged site, or STS) is a unique sequence in the genome with a known exact chromosomal location.
7.17.274	An expressed sequence tag (EST) and a single sequence length polymorphism (SSLP) are common STSs.
7.17.275	An EST is a short STS that is identified with cDNA libraries, while SSLPs are obtained from known genetic markers and provide a link between genetic maps and physical maps.
7.17.276	cytogenetic map shows the appearance of a chromosome after it is stained and examined under a microscope.
7.17.277	(credit: National Human Genome Research Institute) Integration of Genetic and Physical Maps Genetic maps provide the outline and physical maps provide the details.
7.17.278	It is easy to understand why both types of genome mapping techniques are important to show the big picture.
7.17.279	Information obtained from each technique is used in combination to study the genome.
7.17.280	Genomic mapping is being used with different model organisms that are used for research.
7.17.281	Genome mapping is still an ongoing process, and as more advanced techniques are developed, more advances are expected.
7.17.282	Genome mapping is similar to completing a complicated puzzle using every piece of available data.
7.17.283	Mapping information generated in laboratories all over the world is entered into central databases, such as GenBank at the National Center for Biotechnology Information
7.17.284	(NCBI).
7.17.285	Efforts are being made to make the information more easily accessible to researchers and the general public.
7.17.286	Just as we use global positioning systems instead of paper maps to navigate through roadways, NCBI has created a genome viewer tool to simplify the data-mining process.
7.17.287	Whole-Genome Sequencing
7.17.288	Although there have been significant advances in the medical sciences in recent years, doctors are still confounded by some diseases, and they are using whole-genome sequencing to get to the bottom of the problem.
7.17.289	Whole-genome sequencing is a process that determines the DNA sequence of an entire genome.
7.17.290	Whole-genome sequencing is a brute-force approach to problem solving when there is a genetic basis at the core of a disease.
7.17.291	Several laboratories now provide services to sequence, analyze, and interpret entire genomes.
7.17.292	For example, whole-exome sequencing is a lower-cost alternative to whole genome sequencing.
7.17.293	In exome sequencing, only the coding, exon-producing regions of the DNA are sequenced.
7.17.294	In 2010, whole-exome sequencing was used to save a young boy whose intestines had multiple mysterious abscesses.
7.17.295	The child had several colon operations with no relief.
7.17.296	Finally, whole-exome sequencing was performed, which revealed a defect in a pathway that controls apoptosis (programmed cell death).
7.17.297	A bone-marrow transplant was used to overcome this genetic disorder, leading to a cure for the boy.
7.17.298	He was the first person to be successfully treated based on a diagnosis made by whole-exome sequencing.
7.17.299	Today, human genome sequencing is more readily available and can be completed in a day or two for about $1000.
7.17.300	Strategies Used in Sequencing Projects
7.17.301	The basic sequencing technique used in all modern day sequencing projects is the chain termination method (also known as the dideoxy method), which was developed by Fred Sanger in the 1970s.
7.17.302	The chain termination method involves DNA replication of a single-stranded template with the use of a primer and a regular deoxynucleotide (dNTP), which is a monomer, or a single unit, of DNA.
7.17.303	The primer and dNTP are mixed with a small proportion of fluorescently labeled dideoxynucleotides (ddNTPs).
7.17.304	The ddNTPs are monomers that are missing a hydroxyl group (–OH) at the site at which another nucleotide usually attaches to form a chain (Figure 17.13).
7.17.305	Each ddNTP is labeled with a different color of fluorophore.
7.17.306	Every time a ddNTP is incorporated in the growing complementary strand, it terminates the process of DNA replication, which results in multiple short strands of replicated DNA that are each terminated at a different point during replication.
7.17.307	When the reaction mixture is processed by gel electrophoresis after being separated into single strands, the multiple newly replicated DNA strands form a ladder because of the differing sizes.
7.17.308	Because the ddNTPs are fluorescently labeled, each band on the gel reflects the size of the DNA strand and the ddNTP that terminated the reaction.
7.17.309	The different colors of the fluorophore-labeled ddNTPs help identify the ddNTP incorporated at that position.
7.17.310	Reading the gel on the basis of the color of each band on the ladder produces the sequence of the template strand (Figure 17.14).
7.17.311	A dideoxynucleotide is similar in structure to a deoxynucleotide, but is missing the 3' hydroxyl group (indicated by the box).
7.17.312	When a dideoxynucleotide is incorporated into a DNA strand, DNA synthesis stops.
7.17.313	Frederick Sanger's dideoxy chain termination method is illustrated.
7.17.314	Using dideoxynucleotides, the DNA fragment can be terminated at different points.
7.17.315	The DNA is separated on the basis of size, and these bands, based on the size of the fragments, can be read.
7.17.316	Early Strategies: Shotgun Sequencing and Pair-Wise End
7.17.317	Sequencing
7.17.318	In shotgun sequencing method, several copies of a DNA fragment are cut randomly into many smaller pieces (somewhat like what happens to a round shot cartridge when fired from a shotgun).
7.17.319	All of the segments are then sequenced using the chain-sequencing method.
7.17.320	Then, with the help of a computer, the fragments are analyzed to see where their sequences overlap.
7.17.321	By matching up overlapping sequences at the end of each fragment, the entire DNA sequence can be reformed.
7.17.322	A larger sequence that is assembled from overlapping shorter sequences is called a contig.
7.17.323	As an analogy, consider that someone has four copies of a landscape photograph that you have never seen before and know nothing about how it should appear.
7.17.324	The person then rips up each photograph with their hands, so that different size pieces are present from each copy.
7.17.325	The person then mixes all of the pieces together and asks you to reconstruct the photograph.
7.17.326	In one of the smaller pieces you see a mountain.
7.17.327	In a larger piece, you see that the same mountain is behind a lake.
7.17.328	A third fragment shows only the lake, but it reveals that there is a cabin on the shore of the lake.
7.17.329	Therefore, from looking at the overlapping information in these three fragments, you know that the picture contains a mountain behind a lake that has a cabin on its shore.
7.17.330	This is the principle behind reconstructing entire DNA sequences using shotgun sequencing.
7.17.331	Originally, shotgun sequencing only analyzed one end of each fragment for overlaps.
7.17.332	This was sufficient for sequencing small genomes.
7.17.333	However, the desire to sequence larger genomes, such as that of a human, led to the development of doublebarrel shotgun sequencing, more formally known as pairwise-end sequencing.
7.17.334	In pairwise-end sequencing, both ends of each fragment are analyzed for overlap.
7.17.335	Pairwise-end sequencing is, therefore, more cumbersome than shotgun sequencing, but it is easier to reconstruct the sequence because there is more available information.
7.17.336	Next-generation Sequencing Since 2005,
7.17.337	automated sequencing techniques used by laboratories are under the umbrella of next-generation sequencing, which is a group of automated techniques used for rapid DNA sequencing.
7.17.338	These automated low-cost sequencers can generate sequences of hundreds of thousands or millions of short fragments (25 to 500 base pairs) in the span of one day.
7.17.339	These sequencers use sophisticated software to get through the cumbersome process of putting all the fragments in order.
7.17.340	Comparing Sequences
7.17.341	A sequence alignment is an arrangement of proteins, DNA, or RNA; it is used to identify regions of similarity between cell types or species, which may indicate conservation of function or structures.
7.17.342	Sequence alignments may be used to construct phylogenetic trees.
7.17.343	The following website uses a software program called BLAST (basic local alignment search tool) (http://blast.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/Blast.cgi) .
7.17.344	Under “Basic Blast,” click “Nucleotide Blast.
7.17.345	”
7.17.346	Input the following sequence into the large "query sequence" box: ATTGCTTCGATTGCA.
7.17.347	Below the box, locate the "Species" field and type "human" or "Homo sapiens".
7.17.348	Then click “BLAST” to compare the inputted sequence against known sequences of the human genome.
7.17.349	The result is that this sequence occurs in over a hundred places in the human genome.
7.17.350	Scroll down below the graphic with the horizontal bars and you will see short description of each of the matching hits.
7.17.351	Pick one of the hits near the top of the list and click on "Graphics".
7.17.352	This will bring you to a page that shows where the sequence is found within the entire human genome.
7.17.353	You can move the slider that looks like a green flag back and forth to view the sequences immediately around the selected gene.
7.17.354	You can then return to your selected sequence by clicking the "ATG" button.
7.17.355	Use of Whole-Genome Sequences of Model Organisms
7.17.356	The first genome to be completely sequenced was of a bacterial virus, the bacteriophage fx174 (5368 base pairs); this was accomplished by Fred Sanger using shotgun sequencing.
7.17.357	Several other organelle and viral genomes were later sequenced.
7.17.358	The first organism whose genome was sequenced was the bacterium Haemophilus influenzae; this was accomplished by Craig Venter in the 1980s.
7.17.359	Approximately 74 different laboratories collaborated on the sequencing of the genome of the yeast Saccharomyces cerevisiae, which began in 1989 and was completed in 1996, because it was 60 times bigger than any other genome that had been sequenced.
7.17.360	By 1997, the genome sequences of two important model organisms were available: the bacterium Escherichia coli K12 and the yeast Saccharomyces cerevisiae.
7.17.361	Genomes of other model organisms, such as the mouse
7.17.362	Mus musculus, the fruit fly Drosophila melanogaster, the nematode Caenorhabditis. elegans, and humans Homo sapiens are now known.
7.17.363	A lot of basic research is performed in model organisms because the information can be applied to genetically similar organisms.
7.17.364	A model organism is a species that is studied as a model to understand the biological processes in other species represented by the model organism.
7.17.365	Having entire genomes sequenced helps with the research efforts in these model organisms.
7.17.366	The process of attaching biological information to gene sequences is called genome annotation.
7.17.367	Annotation of gene sequences helps with basic experiments in molecular biology, such as designing PCR primers and RNA targets.
7.17.368	Uses of Genome Sequences DNA microarrays are methods used to detect gene expression by analyzing an array of DNA fragments that are fixed to a glass slide or a silicon chip to identify active genes and identify sequences.
7.17.369	Almost one million genotypic abnormalities can be discovered using microarrays, whereas whole-genome sequencing can provide information about all six billion base pairs in the human genome.
7.17.370	Although the study of medical applications of genome sequencing is interesting, this discipline tends to dwell on abnormal gene function.
7.17.371	Knowledge of the entire genome will allow future onset diseases and other genetic disorders to be discovered early, which will allow for more informed decisions to be made about lifestyle, medication, and having children.
7.17.372	Genomics is still in its infancy, although someday it may become routine to use whole-genome sequencing to screen every newborn to detect genetic abnormalities.
7.17.373	In addition to disease and medicine, genomics can contribute to the development of novel enzymes that convert biomass to biofuel, which results in higher crop and fuel production, and lower cost to the consumer.
7.17.374	This knowledge should allow better methods of control over the microbes that are used in the production of biofuels.
7.17.375	Genomics could also improve the methods used to monitor the impact of pollutants on ecosystems and help clean up environmental contaminants.
7.17.376	Genomics has allowed for the development of agrochemicals and pharmaceuticals that could benefit medical science and agriculture.
7.17.377	It sounds great to have all the knowledge we can get from whole-genome sequencing; however, humans have a responsibility to use this knowledge wisely.
7.17.378	Otherwise, it could be easy to misuse the power of such knowledge, leading to discrimination based on a person's genetics, human genetic engineering, and other ethical concerns.
7.17.379	This information could also lead to legal issues regarding health and privacy.
7.17.380	Applying Genomics
7.17.381	The introduction of DNA sequencing and whole genome sequencing projects, particularly the Human Genome project, has expanded the applicability of DNA sequence information.
7.17.382	Genomics is now being used in a wide variety of fields, such as metagenomics, pharmacogenomics, and mitochondrial genomics.
7.17.383	The most commonly known application of genomics is to understand and find cures for diseases.
7.17.384	Predicting Disease Risk at the Individual Level Predicting the risk of disease involves screening currently healthy individuals by genome analysis at the individual level.
7.17.385	Intervention with lifestyle changes and drugs can be recommended before disease onset.
7.17.386	However, this approach is most applicable when the problem resides within a single gene defect.
7.17.387	Such defects only account for approximately 5 percent of diseases in developed countries.
7.17.388	Most of the common diseases, such as heart disease, are multi-factored or polygenic, which is a phenotypic characteristic that involves two or more genes, and also involve environmental factors such as diet.
7.17.389	In April 2010, scientists at Stanford University published the genome analysis of a healthy individual (Stephen Quake, a scientist at Stanford University, who had his genome sequenced); the analysis predicted his propensity to acquire various diseases.
7.17.390	A risk assessment was performed to analyze Quake’s percentage of risk for 55 different medical conditions.
7.17.391	A rare genetic mutation was found, which showed him to be at risk for sudden heart attack.
7.17.392	He was also predicted to have a 23 percent risk of developing prostate cancer and a 1.4 percent risk of developing Alzheimer’s.
7.17.393	The scientists used databases and several publications to analyze the genomic data.
7.17.394	Even though genomic sequencing is becoming more affordable and analytical tools are becoming more reliable, ethical issues surrounding genomic analysis at a population level remain to be addressed.
7.17.395	PCA3 is a gene that is expressed in prostate epithelial cells and overexpressed in cancerous cells.
7.17.396	A high concentration of PCA3 in urine is indicative of prostate cancer.
7.17.397	The PCA3 test is considered to be a better indicator of cancer than the more well know PSA test, which measures the level of PSA (prostate-specific antigen) in the blood.
7.17.398	In 2011, the United States Preventative Services Task Force recommended against using the PSA test to screen healthy men for prostate cancer.
7.17.399	Their recommendation is based on evidence that screening does not reduce the risk of death from prostate cancer.
7.17.400	Prostate cancer often develops very slowly and does not cause problems, while the cancer treatment can have severe side effects.
7.17.401	The PCA3 test is considered to be more accurate, but screening may still result in men who would not have been harmed by the cancer itself suffering side effects from treatment.
7.17.402	What do you think?
7.17.403	Should all healthy men be screened for prostate cancer using the PCA3 or PSA test?
7.17.404	Should people in general be screened to find out if they have a genetic risk for cancer or other diseases?Pharmacogenomics and Toxicogenomics Pharmacogenomics, also called toxicogenomics, involves evaluating the effectiveness and safety of drugs on the basis of information from an individual's genomic sequence.
7.17.405	Genomic responses to drugs can be studied using experimental animals (such as laboratory rats or mice) or live cells in the laboratory before embarking on studies with humans.
7.17.406	Studying changes in gene expression could provide information about the transcription profile in the presence of the drug, which can be used as an early indicator of the potential for toxic effects.
7.17.407	For example, genes involved in cellular growth and controlled cell death, when disturbed, could lead to the growth of cancerous cells.
7.17.408	Genome-wide studies can also help to find new genes involved in drug toxicity.
7.17.409	Personal genome sequence information can be used to prescribe medications that will be most effective and least toxic on the basis of the individual patient’s genotype.
7.17.410	The gene signatures may not be completely accurate, but can be tested further before pathologic symptoms arise.
7.17.411	Microbial Genomics:
7.17.412	Metagenomics Traditionally, microbiology has been taught with the view that microorganisms are best studied under pure culture conditions, which involves isolating a single type of cell and culturing it in the laboratory.
7.17.413	Because microorganisms can go through several generations in a matter of hours, their gene expression profiles adapt to the new laboratory environment very quickly.
7.17.414	In addition, the vast majority of bacterial species resist being cultured in isolation.
7.17.415	Most microorganisms do not live as isolated entities, but in microbial communities known as biofilms.
7.17.416	For all of these reasons, pure culture is not always the best way to study microorganisms.
7.17.417	Metagenomics is the study of the collective genomes of multiple species that grow and interact in an environmental niche.
7.17.418	Metagenomics can be used to identify new species more rapidly and to analyze the effect of pollutants on the environment (Figure 17.16).
7.17.419	Microbial Genomics: Creation of New Biofuels Knowledge of the genomics of microorganisms is being used to find better ways to harness biofuels from algae and cyanobacteria.
7.17.420	The primary sources of fuel today are coal, oil, wood, and other plant products, such as ethanol.
7.17.421	Although plants are renewable resources, there is still a need to find more alternative renewable sources of energy to meet our population’s energy demands.
7.17.422	The microbial world is one of the largest resources for genes that encode new enzymes and produce new organic compounds, and it remains largely untapped.
7.17.423	Microorganisms are used to create products, such as enzymes that are used in research, antibiotics, and other anti-microbial mechanisms.
7.17.424	Microbial genomics is helping to develop diagnostic tools, improved vaccines, new disease treatments, and advanced environmental cleanup techniques.
7.17.425	Mitochondrial Genomics Mitochondria are intracellular organelles that contain their own DNA.
7.17.426	Mitochondrial DNA mutates at a rapid rate and is often used to study evolutionary relationships.
7.17.427	Another feature that makes studying the mitochondrial genome interesting is that the mitochondrial DNA in most multicellular organisms is passed on from the mother during the process of fertilization.
7.17.428	For this reason, mitochondrial genomics is often used to trace genealogy.
7.17.429	Information and clues obtained from DNA samples found at crime scenes have been used as evidence in court cases, and genetic markers have been used in forensic analysis.
7.17.430	Genomic analysis has also become useful in this field.
7.17.431	In 2001, the first use of genomics in forensics was published.
7.17.432	It was a collaborative attempt between academic research institutions and the FBI to solve the mysterious cases of anthrax communicated via the US Postal Service.
7.17.433	Using microbial genomics, researchers determined that a specific strain of anthrax was used in all the mailings.
7.17.434	Genomics in Agriculture Genomics can reduce the trials and failures involved in scientific research to a certain extent, which could improve the quality and quantity of crop yields in agriculture.
7.17.435	Linking traits to genes or gene signatures helps to improve crop breeding to generate hybrids with the most desirable qualities.
7.17.436	Scientists use genomic data to identify desirable traits, and then transfer those traits to a different organism.
7.17.437	Scientists are discovering how genomics can improve the quality and quantity of agricultural production.
7.17.438	For example, scientists could use desirable traits to create a useful product or enhance an existing product, such as making a drought-sensitive crop more tolerant of the dry season.
7.17.439	Proteins are the final products of genes, which help perform the function encoded by the gene.
7.17.440	Proteins are composed of amino acids and play important roles in the cell.
7.17.441	All enzymes (except ribozymes) are proteins that act as catalysts to affect the rate of reactions.
7.17.442	Proteins are also regulatory molecules, and some are hormones.
7.17.443	Transport proteins, such as hemoglobin, help transport oxygen to various organs.
7.17.444	Antibodies that defend against foreign particles are also proteins.
7.17.445	In the diseased state, protein function can be impaired because of changes at the genetic level or because of direct impact on a specific protein.
7.17.446	A proteome is the entire set of proteins produced by a cell type.
7.17.447	Proteomes can be studied using the knowledge of genomes because genes code for mRNAs, and the mRNAs encode proteins.
7.17.448	Although mRNA analysis is a step in the right direction, not all mRNAs are translated into proteins.
7.17.449	The study of the function of proteomes is called proteomics.
7.17.450	Proteomics complements genomics and is useful when scientists want to test their hypotheses that were based on genes.
7.17.451	Even though all cells of a multicellular organism have the same set of genes, the set of proteins produced in different tissues is different and dependent on gene expression.
7.17.452	Thus, the genome is constant, but the proteome varies and is dynamic within an organism.
7.17.453	In addition, RNAs can be alternately spliced (cut and pasted to create novel combinations and novel proteins) and many proteins are modified after translation by processes such as proteolytic cleavage, phosphorylation, glycosylation, and ubiquitination.
7.17.454	There are also protein-protein interactions, which complicate the study of proteomes.
7.17.455	Although the genome provides a blueprint, the final architecture depends on several factors that can change the progression of events that generate the proteome.
7.17.456	Metabolomics is related to genomics and proteomics.
7.17.457	Metabolomics involves the study of small molecule metabolites found in an organism.
7.17.458	The metabolome is the complete set of metabolites that are related to the genetic makeup of an organism.
7.17.459	Metabolomics offers an opportunity to compare genetic makeup and physical characteristics, as well as genetic makeup and environmental factors.
7.17.460	The goal of metabolome research is to identify, quantify, and catalogue all of the metabolites that are found in the tissues and fluids of living organisms.
7.17.461	Basic Techniques in Protein Analysis
7.17.462	The ultimate goal of proteomics is to identify or compare the proteins expressed from a given genome under specific conditions, study the interactions between the proteins, and use the information to predict cell behavior or develop drug targets.
7.17.463	Just as the genome is analyzed using the basic technique of DNA sequencing, proteomics requires techniques for protein analysis.
7.17.464	The basic technique for protein analysis, analogous to DNA sequencing, is mass spectrometry.
7.17.465	Mass spectrometry is used to identify and determine the characteristics of a molecule.
7.17.466	Advances in spectrometry have allowed researchers to analyze very small samples of protein.
7.17.467	X-ray crystallography, for example, enables scientists to determine the three-dimensional structure of a protein crystal at atomic resolution.
7.17.468	Another protein imaging technique, nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR), uses the magnetic properties of atoms to determine the three-dimensional structure of proteins in aqueous solution.
7.17.469	Protein microarrays have also been used to study interactions between proteins.
7.17.470	Large-scale adaptations of the basic two-hybrid screen (Figure 17.17) have provided the basis for protein microarrays.
7.17.471	Computer software is used to analyze the vast amount of data generated for proteomic analysis.
7.17.472	Genomic- and proteomic-scale analyses are part of systems biology.
7.17.473	Systems biology is the study of whole biological systems (genomes and proteomes) based on interactions within the system.
7.17.474	The European Bioinformatics Institute and the Human Proteome Organization (HUPO) are developing and establishing effective tools to sort through the enormous pile of systems biology data.
7.17.475	Because proteins are the direct products of genes and reflect activity at the genomic level, it is natural to use proteomes to compare the protein profiles of different cells to identify proteins and genes involved in disease processes.
7.17.476	Most pharmaceutical drug trials target proteins.
7.17.477	Information obtained from proteomics is being used to identify novel drugs and understand their mechanisms of action.
7.17.478	Two-hybrid screening is used to determine whether two proteins interact.
7.17.479	In this method, a transcription factor is split into a DNA-binding domain (BD) and an activator domain (AD).
7.17.480	The binding domain is able to bind the promoter in the absence of the activator domain, but it does not turn on transcription.
7.17.481	A protein called the bait is attached to the BD, and a protein called the prey is attached to the AD.
7.17.482	Transcription occurs only if the prey “catches” the bait.
7.17.483	The challenge of techniques used for proteomic analyses is the difficulty in detecting small quantities of proteins.
7.17.484	Although mass spectrometry is good for detecting small amounts of proteins, variations in protein expression in diseased states can be difficult to discern.
7.17.485	Proteins are naturally unstable molecules, which makes proteomic analysis much more difficult than genomic analysis.
7.17.486	Cancer Proteomics Genomes and proteomes of patients suffering from specific diseases are being studied to understand the genetic basis of the disease.
7.17.487	The most prominent disease being studied with proteomic approaches is cancer.
7.17.488	Proteomic approaches are being used to improve screening and early detection of cancer; this is achieved by identifying proteins whose expression is affected by the disease process.
7.17.489	An individual protein is called a biomarker, whereas a set of proteins with altered expression levels is called a protein signature.
7.17.490	For a biomarker or protein signature to be useful as a candidate for early screening and detection of a cancer, it must be secreted in body fluids, such as sweat, blood, or urine, such that largescale screenings can be performed in a non-invasive fashion.
7.17.491	The current problem with using biomarkers for the early detection of cancer is the high rate of false-negative results.
7.17.492	A false negative is an incorrect test result that should have been positive.
7.17.493	In other words, many cases of cancer go undetected, which makes biomarkers unreliable.
7.17.494	Some examples of protein biomarkers used in cancer detection are CA-125 for ovarian cancer and PSA for prostate cancer.
7.17.495	Protein signatures may be more reliable than biomarkers to detect cancer cells.
7.17.496	Proteomics is also being used to develop individualized treatment plans, which involves the prediction of whether or not an individual will respond to specific drugs and the side effects that the individual may experience.
7.17.497	Proteomics is also being used to predict the possibility of disease recurrence.
7.17.498	The National Cancer Institute has developed programs to improve the detection and treatment of cancer.
7.17.499	The Clinical Proteomic Technologies for Cancer and the Early Detection Research Network are efforts to identify protein signatures specific to different types of cancers.
7.17.500	The Biomedical Proteomics Program is designed to identify protein signatures and design effective therapies for cancer patients.   
7.18.0	EVOLUTION AND THE ORIGIN OF SPECIES
7.18.1	All organisms are products of evolution adapted to their environment.
7.18.2	(a) Saguaro (Carnegiea gigantea) can soak up 750 liters of water in a single rain storm, enabling these cacti to survive the dry conditions of the Sonora desert in Mexico and the Southwestern United States.
7.18.3	(b)
7.18.4	The Andean semiaquatic lizard (Potamites montanicola) discovered in Peru in 2010 lives between 1,570 to 2,100 meters in elevation, and, unlike most lizards, is nocturnal and swims.
7.18.5	Scientists still do no know how these cold-blood animals are able to move in the cold (10 to 15°C) temperatures of the Andean night.
7.18.6	Introduction
7.18.7	All species of living organisms, from bacteria to baboons to blueberries, evolved at some point from a different species.
7.18.8	Although it may seem that living things today stay much the same, that is not the case—evolution is an ongoing process.
7.18.9	The theory of evolution is the unifying theory of biology, meaning it is the framework within which biologists ask questions about the living world.
7.18.10	Its power is that it provides direction for predictions about living things that are borne out in experiment after experiment.
7.18.11	The Ukrainian-born American geneticist Theodosius Dobzhansky famously wrote that “nothing makes sense in biology except in the light of evolution.
7.18.12	”
7.18.13	[1]
7.18.14	He meant that the tenet that all life has evolved and diversified from a common ancestor is the foundation from which we approach all questions in biology.
7.18.15	Understanding Evolution Evolution by natural selection describes a mechanism for how species change over time.
7.18.16	That species change had been suggested and debated well before Darwin began to explore this idea.
7.18.17	The view that species were static and unchanging was grounded in the writings of Plato, yet there were also ancient Greeks who expressed evolutionary ideas.
7.18.18	In the eighteenth century, ideas about the evolution of animals were reintroduced by the naturalist Georges-Louis Leclerc Comte de Buffon who observed that various geographic regions have different plant and animal populations, even when the environments are similar.
7.18.19	It was also accepted that there were extinct species.
7.18.20	During this time, James Hutton, a Scottish naturalist, proposed that geological change occurred gradually by the accumulation of small changes from processes operating like they are today over long periods of time.
7.18.21	This contrasted with the predominant view that the geology of the planet was a consequence of catastrophic events occurring during a relatively brief past.
7.18.22	Hutton’s view was popularized in the nineteenth century by the geologist Charles Lyell who became a friend to Darwin.
7.18.23	Lyell’s ideas were influential on Darwin’s thinking:
7.18.24	Lyell’s notion of the greater age of Earth gave more time for gradual change in species, and the process of change provided an analogy for gradual change in species.
7.18.25	In the early nineteenth century, Jean-Baptiste Lamarck published a book that detailed a mechanism for evolutionary change.
7.18.26	This mechanism is now referred to as an inheritance of acquired characteristics by which modifications in an individual are caused by its environment, or the use or disuse of a structure during its lifetime, could be inherited by its offspring and thus bring about change in a species.
7.18.27	While this mechanism for evolutionary change was discredited, Lamarck’s ideas were an important influence on evolutionary thought.
7.18.28	Charles Darwin and Natural Selection
7.18.29	In the mid-nineteenth century, the actual mechanism for evolution was independently conceived of and described by two naturalists: Charles Darwin and Alfred Russel Wallace.
7.18.30	Importantly, each naturalist spent time exploring the natural world on expeditions to the tropics.
7.18.31	From 1831 to 1836, Darwin traveled around the world on H.M.S. Beagle, including stops in South America, Australia, and the southern tip of Africa.
7.18.32	Wallace traveled to Brazil to collect insects in the Amazon rainforest from 1848 to 1852 and to the Malay Archipelago from 1854 to 1862.
7.18.33	Darwin’s journey, like Wallace’s later journeys to the Malay Archipelago, included stops at several island chains, the last being the Galápagos Islands west of Ecuador.
7.18.34	On these islands, Darwin observed species of organisms on different islands that were clearly similar, yet had distinct differences.
7.18.35	For example, the ground finches inhabiting the Galápagos Islands comprised several species with a unique beak shape (Figure 18.2).
7.18.36	The species on the islands had a graded series of beak sizes and shapes with very small differences between the most similar.
7.18.37	He observed that these finches closely resembled another finch species on the mainland of South America.
7.18.38	Darwin imagined that the island species might be species modified from one of the original mainland species.
7.18.39	Upon further study, he realized that the varied beaks of each finch helped the birds acquire a specific type of food.
7.18.40	For example, seed-eating finches had stronger, thicker beaks for breaking seeds, and insect-eating finches had spear-like beaks for stabbing their prey.
7.18.41	Darwin observed that beak shape varies among finch species.
7.18.42	He postulated that the beak of an ancestral species had adapted over time to equip the finches to acquire different food sources.
7.18.43	Wallace and Darwin both observed similar patterns in other organisms and they independently developed the same explanation for how and why such changes could take place.
7.18.44	Darwin called this mechanism natural selection.
7.18.45	Natural selection, also known as “survival of the fittest,” is the more prolific reproduction of individuals with favorable traits that survive environmental change because of those traits; this leads to evolutionary change.
7.18.46	For example, a population of giant tortoises found in the Galapagos Archipelago was observed by Darwin to have longer necks than those that lived on other islands with dry lowlands.
7.18.47	These tortoises were
7.18.48	“selected” because they could reach more leaves and access more food than those with short necks.
7.18.49	In times of drought when fewer leaves would be available, those that could reach more leaves had a better chance to eat and survive than those that couldn’t reach the food source.
7.18.50	Consequently, long-necked tortoises would be more likely to be reproductively successful and pass the long-necked trait to their offspring.
7.18.51	Over time, only long-necked tortoises would be present in the population.
7.18.52	Natural selection, Darwin argued, was an inevitable outcome of three principles that operated in nature.
7.18.53	First, most characteristics of organisms are inherited, or passed from parent to offspring.
7.18.54	Although no one, including Darwin and Wallace, knew how this happened at the time, it was a common understanding.
7.18.55	Second, more offspring are produced than are able to survive, so resources for survival and reproduction are limited.
7.18.56	The capacity for reproduction in all organisms outstrips the availability of resources to support their numbers.
7.18.57	Thus, there is competition for those resources in each generation.
7.18.58	Both Darwin and Wallace’s understanding of this principle came from reading an essay by the economist Thomas Malthus who discussed this principle in relation to human populations.
7.18.59	Third, offspring vary among each other in regard to their characteristics and those variations are inherited.
7.18.60	Darwin and Wallace reasoned that offspring with inherited characteristics which allow them to best compete for limited resources will survive and have more offspring than those individuals with variations that are less able to compete.
7.18.61	Because characteristics are inherited, these traits will be better represented in the next generation.
7.18.62	This will lead to change in populations over generations in a process that Darwin called descent with modification.
7.18.63	Ultimately, natural selection leads to greater adaptation of the population to its local environment; it is the only mechanism known for adaptive evolution.
7.18.64	Papers by Darwin and Wallace
7.18.65	(Figure 18.3) presenting the idea of natural selection were read together in 1858 before the Linnean Society in London.
7.18.66	The following year Darwin’s book, On the Origin of Species, was published.
7.18.67	His book outlined in considerable detail his arguments for evolution by natural selection.
7.18.68	Both (a) Charles Darwin and (b)
7.18.69	Alfred Wallace wrote scientific papers on natural selection that were presented together before the Linnean Society in 1858.
7.18.70	Demonstrations of evolution by natural selection are time consuming and difficult to obtain.
7.18.71	One of the best examples has been demonstrated in the very birds that helped to inspire Darwin’s theory: the Galápagos finches.
7.18.72	Peter and Rosemary Grant and their colleagues have studied Galápagos finch populations every year since 1976 and have provided important demonstrations of natural selection.
7.18.73	The Grants found changes from one generation to the next in the distribution of beak shapes with the medium ground finch on the Galápagos island of Daphne Major.
7.18.74	The birds have inherited variation in the bill shape with some birds having wide deep bills and others having thinner bills.
7.18.75	During a period in which rainfall was higher than normal because of an El Niño, the large hard seeds that large-billed birds ate were reduced in number; however, there was an abundance of the small soft seeds which the small-billed birds ate.
7.18.76	Therefore, survival and reproduction were much better in the following years for the small-billed birds.
7.18.77	In the years following this El Niño, the Grants measured beak sizes in the population and found that the average bill size was smaller.
7.18.78	Since bill size is an inherited trait, parents with smaller bills had more offspring and the size of bills had evolved to be smaller.
7.18.79	As conditions improved in 1987 and larger seeds became more available, the trend toward smaller average bill size ceased.
7.18.80	Field Biologist
7.18.81	Many people hike, explore caves, scuba dive, or climb mountains for recreation.
7.18.82	People often participate in these activities hoping to see wildlife.
7.18.83	Experiencing the outdoors can be incredibly enjoyable and invigorating.
7.18.84	What if your job was to be outside in the wilderness?
7.18.85	Field biologists by definition work outdoors in the “field.
7.18.86	”
7.18.87	The term field in this case refers to any location outdoors, even under water.
7.18.88	A field biologist typically focuses research on a certain species, group of organisms, or a single habitat (Figure 18.4).
7.18.89	A field biologist tranquilizes a polar bear for study.
7.18.90	(credit: Karen Rhode)
7.18.91	One objective of many field biologists includes discovering new species that have never been recorded.
7.18.92	Not only do such findings expand our understanding of the natural world, but they also lead to important innovations in fields such as medicine and agriculture.
7.18.93	Plant and microbial species, in particular, can reveal new medicinal and nutritive knowledge.
7.18.94	Other organisms can play key roles in ecosystems or be considered rare and in need of protection.
7.18.95	When discovered, these important species can be used as evidence for environmental regulations and laws.
7.18.96	Processes and Patterns of Evolution
7.18.97	Natural selection can only take place if there is variation, or differences, among individuals in a population.
7.18.98	Importantly, these differences must have some genetic basis; otherwise, the selection will not lead to change in the next generation.
7.18.99	This is critical because variation among individuals can be caused by non-genetic reasons such as an individual being taller because of better nutrition rather than different genes.
7.18.100	Genetic diversity in a population comes from two main mechanisms: mutation and sexual reproduction.
7.18.101	Mutation, a change in DNA, is the ultimate source of new alleles, or new genetic variation in any population.
7.18.102	The genetic changes caused by mutation can have one of three outcomes on the phenotype.
7.18.103	A mutation affects the phenotype of the organism in a way that gives it reduced fitness—lower likelihood of survival or fewer offspring.
7.18.104	A mutation may produce a phenotype with a beneficial effect on fitness.
7.18.105	And, many mutations will also have no effect on the fitness of the phenotype; these are called neutral mutations.
7.18.106	Mutations may also have a whole range of effect sizes on the fitness of the organism that expresses them in their phenotype, from a small effect to a great effect.
7.18.107	Sexual reproduction also leads to genetic diversity: when two parents reproduce, unique combinations of alleles assemble to produce the unique genotypes and thus phenotypes in each of the offspring.
7.18.108	A heritable trait that helps the survival and reproduction of an organism in its present environment is called an adaptation.
7.18.109	Scientists describe groups of organisms becoming adapted to their environment when a change in the range of genetic variation occurs over time that increases or maintains the “fit” of the population to its environment.
7.18.110	The webbed feet of platypuses are an adaptation for swimming.
7.18.111	The snow leopards’ thick fur is an adaptation for living in the cold.
7.18.112	The cheetahs’ fast speed is an adaptation for catching prey.
7.18.113	Whether or not a trait is favorable depends on the environmental conditions at the time.
7.18.114	The same traits are not always selected because environmental conditions can change.
7.18.115	For example, consider a species of plant that grew in a moist climate and did not need to conserve water.
7.18.116	Large leaves were selected because they allowed the plant to obtain more energy from the sun.
7.18.117	Large leaves require more water to maintain than small leaves, and the moist environment provided favorable conditions to support large leaves.
7.18.118	After thousands of years, the climate changed, and the area no longer had excess water.
7.18.119	The direction of natural selection shifted so that plants with small leaves were selected because those populations were able to conserve water to survive the new environmental conditions.
7.18.120	The evolution of species has resulted in enormous variation in form and function.
7.18.121	Sometimes, evolution gives rise to groups of organisms that become tremendously different from each other.
7.18.122	When two species evolve in diverse directions from a common point, it is called divergent evolution.
7.18.123	Such divergent evolution can be seen in the forms of the reproductive organs of flowering plants which share the same basic anatomies; however, they can look very different as a result of selection in different physical environments and adaptation to different kinds of pollinators (Figure 18.5).
7.18.124	Flowering plants evolved from a common ancestor.
7.18.125	Notice that the (a) dense blazing star (Liatrus spicata) and the (b) purple coneflower (Echinacea purpurea) vary in appearance, yet both share a similar basic morphology.
7.18.126	(credit a: modification of work by Drew Avery; credit b: modification of work by Cory Zanker)
7.18.127	In other cases, similar phenotypes evolve independently in distantly related species.
7.18.128	For example, flight has evolved in both bats and insects, and they both have structures we refer to as wings, which are adaptations to flight.
7.18.129	However, the wings of bats and insects have evolved from very different original structures.
7.18.130	This phenomenon is called convergent evolution , where similar traits evolve independently in species that do not share a common ancestry.
7.18.131	The two species came to the same function, flying, but did so separately from each other.
7.18.132	These physical changes occur over enormous spans of time and help explain how evolution occurs.
7.18.133	Natural selection acts on individual organisms, which in turn can shape an entire species.
7.18.134	Although natural selection may work in a single generation on an individual, it can take thousands or even millions of years for the genotype of an entire species to evolve.
7.18.135	It is over these large time spans that life on earth has changed and continues to change.
7.18.136	Evidence of Evolution
7.18.137	The evidence for evolution is compelling and extensive.
7.18.138	Looking at every level of organization in living systems, biologists see the signature of past and present evolution.
7.18.139	Darwin dedicated a large portion of his book, On the Origin of Species, to identifying patterns in nature that were consistent with evolution, and since Darwin, our understanding has become clearer and broader.
7.18.140	Fossils Fossils provide solid evidence that organisms from the past are not the same as those found today, and fossils show a progression of evolution.
7.18.141	Scientists determine the age of fossils and categorize them from all over the world to determine when the organisms lived relative to each other.
7.18.142	The resulting fossil record tells the story of the past and shows the evolution of form over millions of years (Figure 18.6).
7.18.143	For example, scientists have recovered highly detailed records showing the evolution of humans and horses (Figure 18.6).
7.18.144	The whale flipper shares a similar morphology to appendages of birds and mammals (Figure 18.7) indicating that these species share a common ancestor.
7.18.145	In this (a) display, fossil hominids are arranged from oldest (bottom) to newest (top).
7.18.146	As hominids evolved, the shape of the skull changed.
7.18.147	An artist’s rendition of (b) extinct species of the genus
7.18.148	Equus reveals that these ancient species resembled the modern horse (Equus ferus) but varied in size.
7.18.149	Anatomy and Embryology Another type of evidence for evolution is the presence of structures in organisms that share the same basic form.
7.18.150	For example, the bones in the appendages of a human, dog, bird, and whale all share the same overall construction (Figure 18.7) resulting from their origin in the appendages of a common ancestor.
7.18.151	Over time, evolution led to changes in the shapes and sizes of these bones in different species, but they have maintained the same overall layout.
7.18.152	Scientists call these synonymous parts homologous structures.
7.18.153	The similar construction of these appendages indicates that these organisms share a common ancestor.
7.18.154	Some structures exist in organisms that have no apparent function at all, and appear to be residual parts from a past common ancestor.
7.18.155	These unused structures without function are called vestigial structures.
7.18.156	Other examples of vestigial structures are wings on flightless birds, leaves on some cacti, and hind leg bones in whales.
7.18.157	Another evidence of evolution is the convergence of form in organisms that share similar environments.
7.18.158	For example, species of unrelated animals, such as the arctic fox and ptarmigan, living in the arctic region have been selected for seasonal white phenotypes during winter to blend with the snow and ice
7.18.159	(Figure 18.8ab).
7.18.160	These similarities occur not because of common ancestry, but because of similar selection pressures—the benefits of not being seen by predators.
7.18.161	The white winter coat of the (a) arctic fox and the (b) ptarmigan’s plumage are adaptations to their environments.
7.18.162	(credit a: modification of work by Keith Morehouse)
