7.18.163	Embryology, the study of the development of the anatomy of an organism to its adult form, also provides evidence of relatedness between now widely divergent groups of organisms.
7.18.164	Mutational tweaking in the embryo can have such magnified consequences in the adult that embryo formation tends to be conserved.
7.18.165	As a result, structures that are absent in some groups often appear in their embryonic forms and disappear by the time the adult or juvenile form is reached.
7.18.166	For example, all vertebrate embryos, including humans, exhibit gill slits and tails at some point in their early development.
7.18.167	These disappear in the adults of terrestrial groups but are maintained in adult forms of aquatic groups such as fish and some amphibians.
7.18.168	Great ape embryos, including humans, have a tail structure during their development that is lost by the time of birth.
7.18.169	Biogeography
7.18.170	The geographic distribution of organisms on the planet follows patterns that are best explained by evolution in conjunction with the movement of tectonic plates over geological time.
7.18.171	Broad groups that evolved before the breakup of the supercontinent Pangaea (about 200 million years ago) are distributed worldwide.
7.18.172	Groups that evolved since the breakup appear uniquely in regions of the planet, such as the unique flora and fauna of northern continents that formed from the supercontinent Laurasia and of the southern continents that formed from the supercontinent Gondwana.
7.18.173	The presence of members of the plant family Proteaceae in Australia, southern Africa, and South America is best by their presence prior to the southern supercontinent Gondwana breaking up.
7.18.174	The great diversification of marsupials in Australia and the absence of other mammals reflect Australia’s long isolation.
7.18.175	Australia has an abundance of endemic species—species found nowhere else—which is typical of islands whose isolation by expanses of water prevents species to migrate.
7.18.176	Over time, these species diverge evolutionarily into new species that look very different from their ancestors that may exist on the mainland.
7.18.177	The marsupials of Australia, the finches on the Galápagos, and many species on the Hawaiian Islands are all unique to their one point of origin, yet they display distant relationships to ancestral species on mainlands.
7.18.178	Molecular Biology
7.18.179	Like anatomical structures, the structures of the molecules of life reflect descent with modification.
7.18.180	Evidence of a common ancestor for all of life is reflected in the universality of DNA as the genetic material and in the near universality of the genetic code and the machinery of DNA replication and expression.
7.18.181	Fundamental divisions in life between the three domains are reflected in major structural differences in otherwise conservative structures such as the components of ribosomes and the structures of membranes.
7.18.182	In general, the relatedness of groups of organisms is reflected in the similarity of their DNA sequences—exactly the pattern that would be expected from descent and diversification from a common ancestor.
7.18.183	DNA sequences have also shed light on some of the mechanisms of evolution.
7.18.184	For example, it is clear that the evolution of new functions for proteins commonly occurs after gene duplication events that allow the free modification of one copy by mutation, selection, or drift (changes in a population’s gene pool resulting from chance), while the second copy continues to produce a functional protein.
7.18.185	Misconceptions of Evolution
7.18.186	Although the theory of evolution generated some controversy when it was first proposed, it was almost universally accepted by biologists, particularly younger biologists, within 20 years after publication of On the Origin of Species.
7.18.187	Nevertheless, the theory of evolution is a difficult concept and misconceptions about how it works abound.
7.18.188	Evolution Is Just a Theory Critics of the theory of evolution dismiss its importance by purposefully confounding the everyday usage of the word “theory” with the way scientists use the word.
7.18.189	In science, a “theory” is understood to be a body of thoroughly tested and verified explanations for a set of observations of the natural world.
7.18.190	Scientists have a theory of the atom, a theory of gravity, and the theory of relativity, each of which describes understood facts about the world.
7.18.191	In the same way, the theory of evolution describes facts about the living world.
7.18.192	As such, a theory in science has survived significant efforts to discredit it by scientists.
7.18.193	In contrast, a “theory” in common vernacular is a word meaning a guess or suggested explanation; this meaning is more akin to the scientific concept of “hypothesis.
7.18.194	”
7.18.195	When critics of evolution say evolution is “just a theory,” they are implying that there is little evidence supporting it and that it is still in the process of being rigorously tested.
7.18.196	This is a mischaracterization.
7.18.197	Individuals Evolve Evolution is the change in genetic composition of a population over time, specifically over generations, resulting from differential reproduction of individuals with certain alleles.
7.18.198	Individuals do change over their lifetime, obviously, but this is called development and involves changes programmed by the set of genes the individual acquired at birth in coordination with the individual’s environment.
7.18.199	When thinking about the evolution of a characteristic, it is probably best to think about the change of the average value of the characteristic in the population over time.
7.18.200	For example, when natural selection leads to bill-size change in medium-ground finches in the Galápagos, this does not mean that individual bills on the finches are changing.
7.18.201	If one measures the average bill size among all individuals in the population at one time and then measures the average bill size in the population several years later, this average value will be different as a result of evolution.
7.18.202	Although some individuals may survive from the first time to the second, they will still have the same bill size; however, there will be many new individuals that contribute to the shift in average bill size.
7.18.203	Evolution Explains the Origin of Life
7.18.204	It is a common misunderstanding that evolution includes an explanation of life’s origins.
7.18.205	Conversely, some of the theory’s critics believe that it cannot explain the origin of life.
7.18.206	The theory does not try to explain the origin of life.
7.18.207	The theory of evolution explains how populations change over time and how life diversifies the origin of species.
7.18.208	It does not shed light on the beginnings of life including the origins of the first cells, which is how life is defined.
7.18.209	The mechanisms of the origin of life on Earth are a particularly difficult problem because it occurred a very long time ago, and presumably it just occurred once.
7.18.210	Importantly, biologists believe that the presence of life on Earth precludes the possibility that the events that led to life on Earth can be repeated because the intermediate stages would immediately become food for existing living things.
7.18.211	However, once a mechanism of inheritance was in place in the form of a molecule like DNA either within a cell or pre-cell, these entities would be subject to the principle of natural selection.
7.18.212	More effective reproducers would increase in frequency at the expense of inefficient reproducers.
7.18.213	So while evolution does not explain the origin of life, it may have something to say about some of the processes operating once pre-living entities acquired certain properties.
7.18.214	Organisms Evolve on Purpose Statements such as “organisms evolve in response to a change in an environment
7.18.215	” are quite common, but such statements can lead to two types of misunderstandings.
7.18.216	First, the statement must not be understood to mean that individual organisms evolve.
7.18.217	The statement is shorthand for “a population evolves in response to a changing environment.
7.18.218	”
7.18.219	However, a second misunderstanding may arise by interpreting the statement to mean that the evolution is somehow intentional.
7.18.220	A changed environment results in some individuals in the population, those with particular phenotypes, benefiting and therefore producing proportionately more offspring than other phenotypes.
7.18.221	This results in change in the population if the characteristics are genetically determined.
7.18.222	It is also important to understand that the variation that natural selection works on is already in a population and does not arise in response to an environmental change.
7.18.223	For example, applying antibiotics to a population of bacteria will, over time, select a population of bacteria that are resistant to antibiotics.
7.18.224	The resistance, which is caused by a gene, did not arise by mutation because of the application of the antibiotic.
7.18.225	The gene for resistance was already present in the gene pool of the bacteria, likely at a low frequency.
7.18.226	The antibiotic, which kills the bacterial cells without the resistance gene, strongly selects individuals that are resistant, since these would be the only ones that survived and divided.
7.18.227	Experiments have demonstrated that mutations for antibiotic resistance do not arise as a result of antibiotic.
7.18.228	In a larger sense, evolution is not goal directed.
7.18.229	Species do not become “better” over time; they simply track their changing environment with adaptations that maximize their reproduction in a particular environment at a particular time.
7.18.230	Evolution has no goal of making faster, bigger, more complex, or even smarter species, despite the commonness of this kind of language in popular discourse.
7.18.231	What characteristics evolve in a species are a function of the variation present and the environment, both of which are constantly changing in a non-directional way.
7.18.232	What trait is fit in one environment at one time may well be fatal at some point in the future.
7.18.233	This holds equally well for a species of insect as it does the human species.
7.18.234	Formation of New Species reproduction and have offspring that can then successfully reproduce.
7.18.235	Scientists call such organisms members of the same biological species.
7.18.236	Species and the Ability to Reproduce
7.18.237	A species is a group of individual organisms that interbreed and produce fertile, viable offspring.
7.18.238	According to this definition, one species is distinguished from another when, in nature, it is not possible for matings between individuals from each species to produce fertile offspring.
7.18.239	Members of the same species share both external and internal characteristics, which develop from their DNA.
7.18.240	The closer relationship two organisms share, the more DNA they have in common, just like people and their families.
7.18.241	People’s DNA is likely to be more like their father or mother’s DNA than their cousin or grandparent’s DNA.
7.18.242	Organisms of the same species have the highest level of DNA alignment and therefore share characteristics and behaviors that lead to successful reproduction.
7.18.243	Species’ appearance can be misleading in suggesting an ability or inability to mate.
7.18.244	For example, even though domestic dogs (Canis lupus familiaris) display phenotypic differences, such as size, build, and coat, most dogs can interbreed and produce viable puppies that can mature and sexually reproduce (Figure 18.9).
7.18.245	The (a) poodle and (b) cocker spaniel can reproduce to produce a breed known as (c) the cockapoo.
7.18.246	(credit a: modification of work by Sally Eller, Tom Reese; credit b: modification of work by Jeremy McWilliams; credit c: modification of work by Kathleen Conklin)
7.18.247	In other cases, individuals may appear similar although they are not members of the same species.
7.18.248	For example, even though bald eagles (Haliaeetus leucocephalus) and African fish eagles (Haliaeetus vocifer) are both birds and eagles, each belongs to a separate species group (Figure 18.10).
7.18.249	If humans were to artificially intervene and fertilize the egg of a bald eagle with the sperm of an African fish eagle and a chick did hatch, that offspring, called a hybrid (a cross between two species), would probably be infertile—unable to successfully reproduce after it reached maturity.
7.18.250	Different species may have different genes that are active in development; therefore, it may not be possible to develop a viable offspring with two different sets of directions.
7.18.251	Thus, even though hybridization may take place, the two species still remain separate.
7.18.252	The (a) African fish eagle is similar in appearance to the (b) bald eagle, but the two birds are members of different species.
7.18.253	(credit a: modification of work by Nigel Wedge; credit b: modification of work by U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service)
7.18.254	Populations of species share a gene pool: a collection of all the variants of genes in the species.
7.18.255	Again, the basis to any changes in a group or population of organisms must be genetic for this is the only way to share and pass on traits.
7.18.256	When variations occur within a species, they can only be passed to the next generation along two main pathways: asexual reproduction or sexual reproduction.
7.18.257	The change will be passed on asexually simply if the reproducing cell possesses the changed trait.
7.18.258	For the changed trait to be passed on by sexual reproduction, a gamete, such as a sperm or egg cell, must possess the changed trait.
7.18.259	In other words, sexually-reproducing organisms can experience several genetic changes in their body cells, but if these changes do not occur in a sperm or egg cell, the changed trait will never reach the next generation.
7.18.260	Only heritable traits can evolve.
7.18.261	Therefore, reproduction plays a paramount role for genetic change to take root in a population or species.
7.18.262	In short, organisms must be able to reproduce with each other to pass new traits to offspring.
7.18.263	Speciation
7.18.264	The biological definition of species, which works for sexually reproducing organisms, is a group of actually or potentially interbreeding individuals.
7.18.265	There are exceptions to this rule.
7.18.266	Many species are similar enough that hybrid offspring are possible and may often occur in nature, but for the majority of species this rule generally holds.
7.18.267	In fact, the presence in nature of hybrids between similar species suggests that they may have descended from a single interbreeding species, and the speciation process may not yet be completed.
7.18.268	Given the extraordinary diversity of life on the planet there must be mechanisms for speciation: the formation of two species from one original species.
7.18.269	Darwin envisioned this process as a branching event and diagrammed the process in the only illustration found in On the Origin of Species (Figure 18.11a).
7.18.270	Compare this illustration to the diagram of elephant evolution (Figure 18.11b), which shows that as one species changes over time, it branches to form more than one new species, repeatedly, as long as the population survives or until the organism becomes extinct.
7.18.271	The only illustration in Darwin's On the Origin of Species is (a) a diagram showing speciation events leading to biological diversity.
7.18.272	The diagram shows similarities to phylogenetic charts that are drawn today to illustrate the relationships of species.
7.18.273	(b)
7.18.274	Modern elephants evolved from the Palaeomastodon, a species that lived in Egypt 35–50 million years ago.
7.18.275	For speciation to occur, two new populations must be formed from one original population and they must evolve in such a way that it becomes impossible for individuals from the two new populations to interbreed.
7.18.276	Biologists have proposed mechanisms by which this could occur that fall into two broad categories.
7.18.277	Allopatric speciation (allo- =
7.18.278	"other"; -patric = "homeland") involves geographic separation of populations from a parent species and subsequent evolution.
7.18.279	Sympatric speciation (sym- =
7.18.280	"same"; -patric = "homeland") involves speciation occurring within a parent species remaining in one location.
7.18.281	Biologists think of speciation events as the splitting of one ancestral species into two descendant species.
7.18.282	There is no reason why there might not be more than two species formed at one time except that it is less likely and multiple events can be conceptualized as single splits occurring close in time.
7.18.283	Allopatric Speciation A geographically continuous population has a gene pool that is relatively homogeneous.
7.18.284	Gene flow, the movement of alleles across the range of the species, is relatively free because individuals can move and then mate with individuals in their new location.
7.18.285	Thus, the frequency of an allele at one end of a distribution will be similar to the frequency of the allele at the other end.
7.18.286	When populations become geographically discontinuous, that free-flow of alleles is prevented.
7.18.287	When that separation lasts for a period of time, the two populations are able to evolve along different trajectories.
7.18.288	Thus, their allele frequencies at numerous genetic loci gradually become more and more different as new alleles independently arise by mutation in each population.
7.18.289	Typically, environmental conditions, such as climate, resources, predators, and competitors for the two populations will differ causing natural selection to favor divergent adaptations in each group.
7.18.290	Isolation of populations leading to allopatric speciation can occur in a variety of ways: a river forming a new branch, erosion forming a new valley, a group of organisms traveling to a new location without the ability to return, or seeds floating over the ocean to an island.
7.18.291	The nature of the geographic separation necessary to isolate populations depends entirely on the biology of the organism and its potential for dispersal.
7.18.292	If two flying insect populations took up residence in separate nearby valleys, chances are, individuals from each population would fly back and forth continuing gene flow.
7.18.293	However, if two rodent populations became divided by the formation of a new lake, continued gene flow would be unlikely; therefore, speciation would be more likely.
7.18.294	Biologists group allopatric processes into two categories: dispersal and vicariance.
7.18.295	Dispersal is when a few members of a species move to a new geographical area, and vicariance is when a natural situation arises to physically divide organisms.
7.18.296	Scientists have documented numerous cases of allopatric speciation taking place.
7.18.297	For example, along the west coast of the United States, two separate sub-species of spotted owls exist.
7.18.298	The northern spotted owl has genetic and phenotypic differences from its close relative: the Mexican spotted owl, which lives in the south (Figure 18.12).
7.18.299	The northern spotted owl and the Mexican spotted owl inhabit geographically separate locations with different climates and ecosystems.
7.18.300	The owl is an example of allopatric speciation.
7.18.301	(credit "northern spotted owl": modification of work by John and Karen Hollingsworth; credit "Mexican spotted owl": modification of work by Bill Radke)
7.18.302	Additionally, scientists have found that the further the distance between two groups that once were the same species, the more likely it is that speciation will occur.
7.18.303	This seems logical because as the distance increases, the various environmental factors would likely have less in common than locations in close proximity.
7.18.304	Consider the two owls: in the north, the climate is cooler than in the south; the types of organisms in each ecosystem differ, as do their behaviors and habits; also, the hunting habits and prey choices of the southern owls vary from the northern owls.
7.18.305	These variances can lead to evolved differences in the owls, and speciation likely will occur.
7.18.306	Adaptive Radiation
7.18.307	In some cases, a population of one species disperses throughout an area, and each finds a distinct niche or isolated habitat.
7.18.308	Over time, the varied demands of their new lifestyles lead to multiple speciation events originating from a single species.
7.18.309	This is called adaptive radiation because many adaptations evolve from a single point of origin; thus, causing the species to radiate into several new ones.
7.18.310	Island archipelagos like the Hawaiian Islands provide an ideal context for adaptive radiation events because water surrounds each island which leads to geographical isolation for many organisms.
7.18.311	The Hawaiian honeycreeper illustrates one example of adaptive radiation.
7.18.312	From a single species, called the founder species, numerous species have evolved, including the six shown in Figure 18.13.
7.18.313	The honeycreeper birds illustrate adaptive radiation.
7.18.314	From one original species of bird, multiple others evolved, each with its own distinctive characteristics.
7.18.315	Notice the differences in the species’ beaks in Figure 18.13.
7.18.316	Evolution in response to natural selection based on specific food sources in each new habitat led to evolution of a different beak suited to the specific food source.
7.18.317	The seed-eating bird has a thicker, stronger beak which is suited to break hard nuts.
7.18.318	The nectar-eating birds have long beaks to dip into flowers to reach the nectar.
7.18.319	The insect-eating birds have beaks like swords, appropriate for stabbing and impaling insects.
7.18.320	Darwin’s finches are another example of adaptive radiation in an archipelago.
7.18.321	Sympatric Speciation Can divergence occur if no physical barriers are in place to separate individuals who continue to live and reproduce in the same habitat?
7.18.322	The answer is yes.
7.18.323	The process of speciation within the same space is called sympatric speciation; the prefix “
7.18.324	sym”
7.18.325	means same, so “sympatric” means “same homeland” in contrast to “allopatric” meaning “other homeland.
7.18.326	”
7.18.327	A number of mechanisms for sympatric speciation have been proposed and studied.
7.18.328	One form of sympatric speciation can begin with a serious chromosomal error during cell division.
7.18.329	In a normal cell division event chromosomes replicate, pair up, and then separate so that each new cell has the same number of chromosomes.
7.18.330	However, sometimes the pairs separate and the end cell product has too many or too few individual chromosomes in a condition called aneuploidy (Figure 18.14).
7.18.331	Polyploidy is a condition in which a cell or organism has an extra set, or sets, of chromosomes.
7.18.332	Scientists have identified two main types of polyploidy that can lead to reproductive isolation of an individual in the polyploidy state.
7.18.333	Reproductive isolation is the inability to interbreed.
7.18.334	In some cases, a polyploid individual will have two or more complete sets of chromosomes from its own species in a condition called autopolyploidy (Figure 18.15).
7.18.335	The prefix “auto-
7.18.336	” means “self,
7.18.337	” so the term means multiple chromosomes from one’s own species.
7.18.338	Polyploidy results from an error in meiosis in which all of the chromosomes move into one cell instead of separating.
7.18.339	Autopolyploidy results when mitosis is not followed by cytokinesis.
7.18.340	For example, if a plant species with 2n = 6 produces autopolyploid gametes that are also diploid (2n = 6, when they should be n = 3), the gametes now have twice as many chromosomes as they should have.
7.18.341	These new gametes will be incompatible with the normal gametes produced by this plant species.
7.18.342	However, they could either self-pollinate or reproduce with other autopolyploid plants with gametes having the same diploid number.
7.18.343	In this way, sympatric speciation can occur quickly by forming offspring with 4n called a tetraploid.
7.18.344	These individuals would immediately be able to reproduce only with those of this new kind and not those of the ancestral species.
7.18.345	The other form of polyploidy occurs when individuals of two different species reproduce to form a viable offspring called an allopolyploid.
7.18.346	The prefix “
7.18.347	allo-
7.18.348	” means “other” (recall from allopatric): therefore, an allopolyploid occurs when gametes from two different species combine.
7.18.349	Figure 18.16 illustrates one possible way an allopolyploid can form.
7.18.350	Notice how it takes two generations, or two reproductive acts, before the viable fertile hybrid results.
7.18.351	Alloploidy results when two species mate to produce viable offspring.
7.18.352	In the example shown, a normal gamete from one species fuses with a polyploidy gamete from another.
7.18.353	Two matings are necessary to produce viable offspring.
7.18.354	The cultivated forms of wheat, cotton, and tobacco plants are all allopolyploids.
7.18.355	Although polyploidy occurs occasionally in animals, it takes place most commonly in plants.
7.18.356	(Animals with any of the types of chromosomal aberrations described here are unlikely to survive and produce normal offspring.)
7.18.357	Scientists have discovered more than half of all plant species studied relate back to a species evolved through polyploidy.
7.18.358	With such a high rate of polyploidy in plants, some scientists hypothesize that this mechanism takes place more as an adaptation than as an error.
7.18.359	Reproductive Isolation
7.18.360	Given enough time, the genetic and phenotypic divergence between populations will affect characters that influence reproduction: if individuals of the two populations were to be brought together, mating would be less likely, but if mating occurred, offspring would be non-viable or infertile.
7.18.361	Many types of diverging characters may affect the reproductive isolation, the ability to interbreed, of the two populations.
7.18.362	Reproductive isolation can take place in a variety of ways.
7.18.363	Scientists organize them into two groups: prezygotic barriers and postzygotic barriers.
7.18.364	Recall that a zygote is a fertilized egg: the first cell of the development of an organism that reproduces sexually.
7.18.365	Therefore, a prezygotic barrier is a mechanism that blocks reproduction from taking place; this includes barriers that prevent fertilization when organisms attempt reproduction.
7.18.366	A postzygotic barrier occurs after zygote formation; this includes organisms
7.18.367	that don’t survive the embryonic stage and those that are born sterile.
7.18.368	Some types of prezygotic barriers prevent reproduction entirely.
7.18.369	Many organisms only reproduce at certain times of the year, often just annually.
7.18.370	Differences in breeding schedules, called temporal isolation, can act as a form of reproductive isolation.
7.18.371	For example, two species of frogs inhabit the same area, but one reproduces from January to March, whereas the other reproduces from March to May (Figure 18.17).
7.18.372	These two related frog species exhibit temporal reproductive isolation.
7.18.373	(a)
7.18.374	Rana aurora breeds earlier in the year than (b) Rana boylii.
7.18.375	In some cases, populations of a species move or are moved to a new habitat and take up residence in a place that no longer overlaps with the other populations of the same species.
7.18.376	This situation is called habitat isolation.
7.18.377	Reproduction with the parent species ceases, and a new group exists that is now reproductively and genetically independent.
7.18.378	For example, a cricket population that was divided after a flood could no longer interact with each other.
7.18.379	Over time, the forces of natural selection, mutation, and genetic drift will likely result in the divergence of the two groups (Figure 18.18).
7.18.380	Speciation can occur when two populations occupy different habitats.
7.18.381	The habitats need not be far apart.
7.18.382	The cricket (a) Gryllus pennsylvanicus prefers sandy soil, and the cricket (b)
7.18.383	Gryllus firmus prefers loamy soil.
7.18.384	The two species can live in close proximity, but because of their different soil preferences, they became genetically isolated.
7.18.385	Behavioral isolation occurs when the presence or absence of a specific behavior prevents reproduction from taking place.
7.18.386	For example, male fireflies use specific light patterns to attract females.
7.18.387	Various species of fireflies display their lights differently.
7.18.388	If a male of one species tried to attract the female of another, she would not recognize the light pattern and would not mate with the male.
7.18.389	Other prezygotic barriers work when differences in their gamete cells (eggs and sperm) prevent fertilization from taking place; this is called a gametic barrier.
7.18.390	Similarly, in some cases closely related organisms try to mate, but their reproductive structures simply do not fit together.
7.18.391	For example, damselfly males of different species have differently shaped reproductive organs.
7.18.392	If one species tries to mate with the female of another, their body parts simply do not fit together.
7.18.393	(Figure 18.19).
7.18.394	The shape of the male reproductive organ varies among male damselfly species, and is only compatible with the female of that species.
7.18.395	Reproductive organ incompatibility keeps the species reproductively isolated.
7.18.396	In plants, certain structures aimed to attract one type of pollinator simultaneously prevent a different pollinator from accessing the pollen.
7.18.397	The tunnel through which an animal must access nectar can vary widely in length and diameter, which prevents the plant from being cross-pollinated with a different species (Figure 18.20).
7.18.398	Some flowers have evolved to attract certain pollinators.
7.18.399	The (a) wide foxglove flower is adapted for pollination by bees, while the (b) long, tube-shaped trumpet creeper flower is adapted for pollination by humming birds.
7.18.400	When fertilization takes place and a zygote forms, postzygotic barriers can prevent reproduction.
7.18.401	Hybrid individuals in many cases cannot form normally in the womb and simply do not survive past the embryonic stages.
7.18.402	This is called hybrid inviability because the hybrid organisms simply are not viable.
7.18.403	In another postzygotic situation, reproduction leads to the birth and growth of a hybrid that is sterile and unable to reproduce offspring of their own; this is called hybrid sterility.
7.18.404	Habitat Influence on Speciation Sympatric speciation may also take place in ways other than polyploidy.
7.18.405	For example, consider a species of fish that lives in a lake.
7.18.406	As the population grows, competition for food also grows.
7.18.407	Under pressure to find food, suppose that a group of these fish had the genetic flexibility to discover and feed off another resource that was unused by the other fish.
7.18.408	What if this new food source was found at a different depth of the lake?
7.18.409	Over time, those feeding on the second food source would interact more with each other than the other fish; therefore, they would breed together as well.
7.18.410	Offspring of these fish would likely behave as their parents: feeding and living in the same area and keeping separate from the original population.
7.18.411	If this group of fish continued to remain separate from the first population, eventually sympatric speciation might occur as more genetic differences accumulated between them.
7.18.412	This scenario does play out in nature, as do others that lead to reproductive isolation.
7.18.413	One such place is Lake Victoria in Africa, famous for its sympatric speciation of cichlid fish.
7.18.414	Researchers have found hundreds of sympatric speciation events in these fish, which have not only happened in great number, but also over a short period of time.
7.18.415	Figure 18.21 shows this type of speciation among a cichlid fish population in Nicaragua.
7.18.416	In this locale, two types of cichlids live in the same geographic location but have come to have different morphologies that allow them to eat various food sources.
7.18.417	Cichlid fish from Lake Apoyeque, Nicaragua, show evidence of sympatric speciation.
7.18.418	Lake Apoyeque, a crater lake, is 1800 years old, but genetic evidence indicates that the lake was populated only 100 years ago by a single population of cichlid fish.
7.18.419	Nevertheless, two populations with distinct morphologies and diets now exist in the lake, and scientists believe these populations may be in an early stage of speciation.
7.18.420	Reconnection and Rates of Speciation Speciation occurs over a span of evolutionary time, so when a new species arises, there is a transition period during which the closely related species continue to interact.
7.18.421	Reconnection
7.18.422	After speciation, two species may recombine or even continue interacting indefinitely.
7.18.423	Individual organisms will mate with any nearby individual who they are capable of breeding with.
7.18.424	An area where two closely related species continue to interact and reproduce, forming hybrids, is called a hybrid zone.
7.18.425	Over time, the hybrid zone may change depending on the fitness of the hybrids and the reproductive barriers (Figure 18.22).
7.18.426	If the hybrids are less fit than the parents, reinforcement of speciation occurs, and the species continue to diverge until they can no longer mate and produce viable offspring.
7.18.427	If reproductive barriers weaken, fusion occurs and the two species become one.
7.18.428	Barriers remain the same if hybrids are fit and reproductive: stability may occur and hybridization continues.
7.18.429	Hybrids can be either less fit than the parents, more fit, or about the same.
7.18.430	Usually hybrids tend to be less fit; therefore, such reproduction diminishes over time, nudging the two species to diverge further in a process called reinforcement.
7.18.431	This term is used because the low success of the hybrids reinforces the original speciation.
7.18.432	If the hybrids are as fit or more fit than the parents, the two species may fuse back into one species (Figure 18.23).
7.18.433	Scientists have also observed that sometimes two species will remain separate but also continue to interact to produce some hybrid individuals; this is classified as stability because no real net change is taking place.
7.18.434	Varying Rates of Speciation Scientists around the world study speciation, documenting observations both of living organisms and those found in the fossil record.
7.18.435	As their ideas take shape and as research reveals new details about how life evolves, they develop models to help explain rates of speciation.
7.18.436	In terms of how quickly speciation occurs, two patterns are currently observed: gradual speciation model and punctuated equilibrium model.
7.18.437	In the gradual speciation model, species diverge gradually over time in small steps.
7.18.438	In the punctuated equilibrium model, a new species undergoes changes quickly from the parent species, and then remains largely unchanged for long periods of time afterward (Figure 18.23).
7.18.439	This early change model is called punctuated equilibrium, because it begins with a punctuated or periodic change and then remains in balance afterward.
7.18.440	While punctuated equilibrium suggests a faster tempo, it does not necessarily exclude gradualism.
7.18.441	The primary influencing factor on changes in speciation rate is environmental conditions.
7.18.442	Under some conditions, selection occurs quickly or radically.
7.18.443	Consider a species of snails that had been living with the same basic form for many thousands of years.
7.18.444	Layers of their fossils would appear similar for a long time.
7.18.445	When a change in the environment takes place—such as a drop in the water level—a small number of organisms are separated from the rest in a brief period of time, essentially forming one large and one tiny population.
7.18.446	The tiny population faces new environmental conditions.
7.18.447	Because its gene pool quickly became so small, any variation that surfaces and that aids in surviving the new conditions becomes the predominant form.
7.19.0	THE EVOLUTION OF POPULATIONS Living things may be single-celled or complex, multicellular organisms.
7.19.1	They may be plants, animals, fungi, bacteria, or archaea.
7.19.2	This diversity results from evolution.
7.19.3	Introduction
7.19.4	All life on Earth is related.
7.19.5	Evolutionary theory states that humans, beetles, plants, and bacteria all share a common ancestor, but that millions of years of evolution have shaped each of these organisms into the forms seen today.
7.19.6	Scientists consider evolution a key concept to understanding life.
7.19.7	Natural selection is one of the most dominant evolutionary forces.
7.19.8	Natural selection acts to promote traits and behaviors that increase an organism
7.19.9	’s chances of survival and reproduction, while eliminating those traits and behaviors that are to the organism’s detriment.
7.19.10	But natural selection can only, as its name implies, select—it cannot create.
7.19.11	The introduction of novel traits and behaviors falls on the shoulders of another evolutionary force—mutation.
7.19.12	Mutation and other sources of variation among individuals, as well as the evolutionary forces that act upon them, alter populations and species.
7.19.13	This combination of processes has led to the world of life we see today.
7.19.14	Population Evolution
7.19.15	The mechanisms of inheritance, or genetics, were not understood at the time Charles Darwin and Alfred Russel Wallace were developing their idea of natural selection.
7.19.16	This lack of understanding was a stumbling block to understanding many aspects of evolution.
7.19.17	In fact, the predominant (and incorrect) genetic theory of the time, blending inheritance, made it difficult to understand how natural selection might operate.
7.19.18	Darwin and Wallace were unaware of the genetics work by Austrian monk Gregor Mendel, which was published in 1866, not long after publication of Darwin's book, On the Origin of Species.
7.19.19	Mendel’s work was rediscovered in the early twentieth century at which time geneticists were rapidly coming to an understanding of the basics of inheritance.
7.19.20	Initially, the newly discovered particulate nature of genes made it difficult for biologists to understand how gradual evolution could occur.
7.19.21	But over the next few decades genetics and evolution were integrated in what became known as the modern synthesis—the coherent understanding of the relationship between natural selection and genetics that took shape by the 1940s and is generally accepted today.
7.19.22	In sum, the modern synthesis describes how evolutionary processes, such as natural selection, can affect a population’s genetic makeup, and, in turn, how this can result in the gradual evolution of populations and species.
7.19.23	The theory also connects this change of a population over time, called microevolution, with the processes that gave rise to new species and higher taxonomic groups with widely divergent characters, called macroevolution.
7.19.24	Evolution and Flu Vaccines
7.19.25	Every fall, the media starts reporting on flu vaccinations and potential outbreaks.
7.19.26	Scientists, health experts, and institutions determine recommendations for different parts of the population, predict optimal production and inoculation schedules, create vaccines, and set up clinics to provide inoculations.
7.19.27	You may think of the annual flu shot as a lot of media hype, an important health protection, or just a briefly uncomfortable prick in your arm.
7.19.28	But do you think of it in terms of evolution?
7.19.29	The media hype of annual flu shots is scientifically grounded in our understanding of evolution.
7.19.30	Each year, scientists across the globe strive to predict the flu strains that they anticipate being most widespread and harmful in the coming year.
7.19.31	This knowledge is based in how flu strains have evolved over time and over the past few flu seasons.
7.19.32	Scientists then work to create the most effective vaccine to combat those selected strains.
7.19.33	Hundreds of millions of doses are produced in a short period in order to provide vaccinations to key populations at the optimal time.
7.19.34	Because viruses, like the flu, evolve very quickly (especially in evolutionary time), this poses quite a challenge.
7.19.35	Viruses mutate and replicate at a fast rate, so the vaccine developed to protect against last year’s flu strain may not provide the protection needed against the coming year’s strain.
7.19.36	Evolution of these viruses means continued adaptions to ensure survival, including adaptations to survive previous vaccines.
7.19.37	Population Genetics Recall that a gene for a particular character may have several alleles, or variants, that code for different traits associated with that character.
7.19.38	For example, in the ABO blood type system in humans, three alleles determine the particular blood-type protein on the surface of red blood cells.
7.19.39	Each individual in a population of diploid organisms can only carry two alleles for a particular gene, but more than two may be present in the individuals that make up the population.
7.19.40	Mendel followed alleles as they were inherited from parent to offspring.
7.19.41	In the early twentieth century, biologists in a field of study known as population genetics began to study how selective forces change a population through changes in allele and genotypic frequencies.
7.19.42	The allele frequency (or gene frequency) is the rate at which a specific allele appears within a population.
7.19.43	Until now we have discussed evolution as a change in the characteristics of a population of organisms, but behind that phenotypic change is genetic change.
7.19.44	In population genetics, the term evolution is defined as a change in the frequency of an allele in a population.
7.19.45	Using the ABO blood type system as an example, the frequency of one of the alleles, IA, is the number of copies of that allele divided by all the copies of the ABO gene in the population.
7.19.46	For example, a study in Jordan [1] found a frequency of IA to be 26.1 percent.
7.19.47	The IB and I0 alleles made up 13.4 percent and 60.5 percent of the alleles respectively, and all of the frequencies added up to 100 percent.
7.19.48	A change in this frequency over time would constitute evolution in the population.
7.19.49	The allele frequency within a given population can change depending on environmental factors; therefore, certain alleles become more widespread than others during the process of natural selection.
7.19.50	Natural selection can alter the population’s genetic makeup; for example, if a given allele confers a phenotype that allows an individual to better survive or have more offspring.
7.19.51	Because many of those offspring will also carry the beneficial allele, and often the corresponding phenotype, they will have more offspring of their own that also carry the allele, thus, perpetuating the cycle.
7.19.52	Over time, the allele will spread throughout the population.
7.19.53	Some alleles will quickly become fixed in this way, meaning that every individual of the population will carry the allele, while detrimental mutations may be swiftly eliminated if derived from a dominant allele from the gene pool.
7.19.54	The gene pool is the sum of all the alleles in a population.
7.19.55	Sometimes, allele frequencies within a population change randomly with no advantage to the population over existing allele frequencies.
7.19.56	This phenomenon is called genetic drift.
7.19.57	Natural selection and genetic drift usually occur simultaneously in populations and are not isolated events.
7.19.58	It is hard to determine which process dominates because it is often nearly impossible to determine the cause of change in allele frequencies at each occurrence.
7.19.59	An event that initiates an allele frequency change in an isolated part of the population, which is not typical of the original population, is called the founder effect.
7.19.60	Natural selection, random drift, and founder effects can lead to significant changes in the genome of a population.
7.19.61	Hardy-Weinberg Principle of Equilibrium
7.19.62	In the early twentieth century, English mathematician Godfrey Hardy and German physician Wilhelm Weinberg stated the principle of equilibrium to describe the genetic makeup of a population.
7.19.63	The theory, which later became known as the Hardy-Weinberg principle of equilibrium, states that a population’s allele and genotype frequencies are inherently stable— unless some kind of evolutionary force is acting upon the population, neither the allele nor the genotypic frequencies would change.
7.19.64	The Hardy-Weinberg principle assumes conditions with no mutations, migration, emigration, or selective pressure for or against genotype, plus an infinite population; while no population can satisfy those conditions, the principle offers a useful model against which to compare real population changes.
7.19.65	Working under this theory, population geneticists represent different alleles as different variables in their mathematical models.
7.19.66	The variable p, for example, often represents the frequency of a particular allele, say Y for the trait of yellow in Mendel’s peas, while the variable q represents the frequency of y alleles that confer the color green.
7.19.67	If these are the only two possible alleles for a given locus in the population, p + q = 1.
7.19.68	In other words, all the p alleles and all the q alleles make up all of the alleles for that locus that are found in the population.
7.19.69	But what ultimately interests most biologists is not the frequencies of different alleles, but the frequencies of the resulting genotypes, known as the population’s genetic structure, from which scientists can surmise the distribution of phenotypes.
7.19.70	If the phenotype is observed, only the genotype of the homozygous recessive alleles can be known; the calculations provide an estimate of the remaining genotypes.
7.19.71	Since each individual carries two alleles per gene, if the allele frequencies (p and q) are known, predicting the frequencies of these genotypes is a simple mathematical calculation to determine the probability of getting these genotypes if two alleles are drawn at random from the gene pool.
7.19.72	So in the above scenario, an individual pea plant could be pp (YY), and thus produce yellow peas;
7.19.73	pq (Yy), also yellow; or qq (yy), and thus producing green peas (Figure 19.2).
7.19.74	In other words, the frequency of pp individuals is simply p2; the frequency of pq individuals is 2pq; and the frequency of qq individuals is q2.
7.19.75	And, again, if p and q are the only two possible alleles for a given trait in the population, these genotypes frequencies will sum to one:
7.19.76	p2 + 2pq + q2
7.19.77	= 1.
7.19.78	When populations are in the Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium, the allelic frequency is stable from generation to generation and the distribution of alleles can be determined from the Hardy-Weinberg equation.
7.19.79	If the allelic frequency measured in the field differs from the predicted value, scientists can make inferences about what evolutionary forces are at play.
7.19.80	In plants, violet flower color (V) is dominant over white (v).
7.19.81	If p = 0.8 and q = 0.2 in a population of 500 plants, how many individuals would you expect to be homozygous dominant (VV), heterozygous (Vv), and homozygous recessive (vv)?
7.19.82	How many plants would you expect to have violet flowers, and how many would have white flowers?
7.19.83	In theory, if a population is at equilibrium—that is, there are no evolutionary forces acting upon it
7.19.84	—generation after generation would have the same gene pool and genetic structure, and these equations would all hold true all of the time.
7.19.85	Of course, even Hardy and Weinberg recognized that no natural population is immune to evolution.
7.19.86	Populations in nature are constantly changing in genetic makeup due to drift, mutation, possibly migration, and selection.
7.19.87	As a result, the only way to determine the exact distribution of phenotypes in a population is to go out and count them.
7.19.88	But the Hardy-Weinberg principle gives scientists a mathematical baseline of a non-evolving population to which they can compare evolving populations and thereby infer what evolutionary forces might be at play.
7.19.89	If the frequencies of alleles or genotypes deviate from the value expected from the Hardy-Weinberg equation, then the population is evolving.
7.19.90	Individuals of a population often display different phenotypes, or express different alleles of a particular gene, referred to as polymorphisms.
7.19.91	Populations with two or more variations of particular characteristics are called polymorphic.
7.19.92	The distribution of phenotypes among individuals, known as the population variation, is influenced by a number of factors, including the population’s genetic structure and the environment (Figure 19.3).
7.19.93	Understanding the sources of a phenotypic variation in a population is important for determining how a population will evolve in response to different evolutionary pressures.
7.19.94	Population Genetics Genetic Variance Natural selection and some of the other evolutionary forces can only act on heritable traits, namely an organism’s genetic code.
7.19.95	Because alleles are passed from parent to offspring, those that confer beneficial traits or behaviors may be selected for, while deleterious alleles may be selected against.
7.19.96	Acquired traits, for the most part, are not heritable.
7.19.97	For example, if an athlete works out in the gym every day, building up muscle strength, the athlete’s offspring will not necessarily grow up to be a body builder.
7.19.98	If there is a genetic basis for the ability to run fast, on the other hand, this may be passed to a child.
7.19.99	Heritability is the fraction of phenotype variation that can be attributed to genetic differences, or genetic variance, among individuals in a population.
7.19.100	The greater the hereditability of a population’s phenotypic variation, the more susceptible it is to the evolutionary forces that act on heritable variation.
7.19.101	The diversity of alleles and genotypes within a population is called genetic variance.
7.19.102	When scientists are involved in the breeding of a species, such as with animals in zoos and nature preserves, they try to increase a population’s genetic variance to preserve as much of the phenotypic diversity as they can.
7.19.103	This also helps reduce the risks associated with inbreeding, the mating of closely related individuals, which can have the undesirable effect of bringing together deleterious recessive mutations that can cause abnormalities and susceptibility to disease.
7.19.104	For example, a disease that is caused by a rare, recessive allele might exist in a population, but it will only manifest itself when an individual carries two copies of the allele.
7.19.105	Because the allele is rare in a normal, healthy population with unrestricted habitat, the chance that two carriers will mate is low, and even then, only 25 percent of their offspring will inherit the disease allele from both parents.
7.19.106	While it is likely to happen at some point, it will not happen frequently enough for natural selection to be able to swiftly eliminate the allele from the population, and as a result, the allele will be maintained at low levels in the gene pool.
7.19.107	However, if a family of carriers begins to interbreed with each other, this will dramatically increase the likelihood of two carriers mating and eventually producing diseased offspring, a phenomenon known as inbreeding depression.
7.19.108	Changes in allele frequencies that are identified in a population can shed light on how it is evolving.
7.19.109	In addition to natural selection, there are other evolutionary forces that could be in play: genetic drift, gene flow, mutation, nonrandom mating, and environmental variances.
7.19.110	Genetic Drift
7.19.111	The theory of natural selection stems from the observation that some individuals in a population are more likely to survive longer and have more offspring than others; thus, they will pass on more of their genes to the next generation.
7.19.112	A big, powerful male gorilla, for example, is much more likely than a smaller, weaker one to become the population’s silverback, the pack’s leader who mates far more than the other males of the group.
7.19.113	The pack leader will father more offspring, who share half of his genes, and are likely to also grow bigger and stronger like their father.
7.19.114	Over time, the genes for bigger size will increase in frequency in the population, and the population will, as a result, grow larger on average.
7.19.115	That is, this would occur if this particular selection pressure, or driving selective force, were the only one acting on the population.
7.19.116	In other examples, better camouflage or a stronger resistance to drought might pose a selection pressure.
7.19.117	Another way a population’s allele and genotype frequencies can change is genetic drift (Figure 19.4), which is simply the effect of chance.
7.19.118	By chance, some individuals will have more offspring than others—not due to an advantage conferred by some genetically-encoded trait, but just because one male happened to be in the right place at the right time (when the receptive female walked by) or because the other one happened to be in the wrong place at the wrong time (when a fox was hunting).
7.19.119	Genetic drift in a population can lead to the elimination of an allele from a population by chance.
7.19.120	In this example, rabbits with the brown coat color allele (B) are dominant over rabbits with the white coat color allele (b).
7.19.121	In the first generation, the two alleles occur with equal frequency in the population, resulting in p and q values of .5.
7.19.122	Only half of the individuals reproduce, resulting in a second generation with p and q values of .7 and .3, respectively.
7.19.123	Only two individuals in the second generation reproduce, and by chance these individuals are homozygous dominant for brown coat color.
7.19.124	As a result, in the third generation the recessive b allele is lost.
7.19.125	Small populations are more susceptible to the forces of genetic drift.
7.19.126	Large populations, on the other hand, are buffered against the effects of chance.
7.19.127	If one individual of a population of 10 individuals happens to die at a young age before it leaves any offspring to the next generation, all of its genes—1/10 of the population’s gene pool—will be suddenly lost.
7.19.128	In a population of 100, that’s only 1 percent of the overall gene pool; therefore, it is much less impactful on the population’s genetic structure.
7.19.129	Genetic drift can also be magnified by natural events, such as a natural disaster that kills—at random—a large portion of the population.
7.19.130	Known as the bottleneck effect, it results in a large portion of the genome suddenly being wiped out (Figure 19.5).
7.19.131	In one fell swoop, the genetic structure of the survivors becomes the genetic structure of the entire population, which may be very different from the pre-disaster population.
7.19.132	population leaves to start a new population in a new location or if a population gets divided by a physical barrier of some kind.
7.19.133	In this situation, those individuals are unlikely to be representative of the entire population, which results in the founder effect.
7.19.134	The founder effect occurs when the genetic structure changes to match that of the new population’s founding fathers and mothers.
7.19.135	The founder effect is believed to have been a key factor in the genetic history of the Afrikaner population of Dutch settlers in South Africa, as evidenced by mutations that are common in Afrikaners but rare in most other populations.
7.19.136	This is likely due to the fact that a higher-than-normal proportion of the founding colonists carried these mutations.
7.19.137	As a result, the population expresses unusually high incidences of Huntington’s disease (HD) and Fanconi anemia (FA), a genetic disorder known to cause blood marrow and congenital abnormalities—even cancer.
7.19.138	[2] Testing the Bottleneck Effect Question: How do natural disasters affect the genetic structure of a population?
7.19.139	Background: When much of a population is suddenly wiped out by an earthquake or hurricane, the individuals that survive the event are usually a random sampling of the original group.
7.19.140	As a result, the genetic makeup of the population can change dramatically.
7.19.141	This phenomenon is known as the bottleneck effect.
7.19.142	Hypothesis:
7.19.143	Repeated natural disasters will yield different population genetic structures; therefore, each time this experiment is run, the results will vary.
7.19.144	Test the hypothesis
7.19.145	: Count out the original population using different colored beads.
7.19.146	For example, red, blue, and yellow beads might represent red, blue, and yellow individuals.
7.19.147	After recording the number of each individual in the original population, place them all in a bottle with a narrow neck that will only allow a few beads out at a time.
7.19.148	Then, pour 1/3 of the bottle’s contents into a bowl.
7.19.149	This represents the surviving individuals after a natural disaster kills a majority of the population.
7.19.150	Count the number of the different colored beads in the bowl, and record it.
7.19.151	Then, place all of the beads back in the bottle and repeat the experiment four more times.
7.19.152	Analyze the data: Compare the five populations that resulted from the experiment.
7.19.153	Do the populations all contain the same number of different colored beads, or do they vary?
7.19.154	Remember, these populations all came from the same exact parent population.
7.19.155	Form a conclusion: Most likely, the five resulting populations will differ quite dramatically.
7.19.156	This is because natural disasters are not selective—they kill and spare individuals at random.
7.19.157	Now think about how this might affect a real population.
7.19.158	What happens when a hurricane hits the Mississippi Gulf Coast?
7.19.159	How do the seabirds that live on the beach fare?
7.19.160	Gene Flow
7.19.161	Another important evolutionary force is gene flow: the flow of alleles in and out of a population due to the migration of individuals or gametes (Figure 19.6).
7.19.162	While some populations are fairly stable, others experience more flux.
7.19.163	Many plants, for example, send their pollen far and wide, by wind or by bird, to pollinate other populations of the same species some distance away.
7.19.164	Even a population that may initially appear to be stable, such as a pride of lions, can experience its fair share of immigration and emigration as developing males leave their mothers to seek out a new pride with genetically unrelated females.
7.19.165	This variable flow of individuals in and out of the group not only changes the gene structure of the population, but it can also introduce new genetic variation to populations in different geological locations and habitats.
7.19.166	Mutation Mutations are changes to an organism’s DNA and are an important driver of diversity in populations.
7.19.167	Species evolve because of the accumulation of mutations that occur over time.
7.19.168	The appearance of new mutations is the most common way to introduce novel genotypic and phenotypic variance.
7.19.169	Some mutations are unfavorable or harmful and are quickly eliminated from the population by natural selection.
7.19.170	Others are beneficial and will spread through the population.
7.19.171	Whether or not a mutation is beneficial or harmful is determined by whether it helps an organism survive to sexual maturity and reproduce.
7.19.172	Some mutations do not do anything and can linger, unaffected by natural selection, in the genome.
7.19.173	Some can have a dramatic effect on a gene and the resulting phenotype.
7.19.174	Nonrandom Mating
7.19.175	If individuals nonrandomly mate with their peers, the result can be a changing population.
7.19.176	There are many reasons nonrandom mating occurs.
7.19.177	One reason is simple mate choice; for example, female peahens may prefer peacocks with bigger, brighter tails.
7.19.178	Traits that lead to more matings for an individual become selected for by natural selection.
7.19.179	One common form of mate choice, called assortative mating, is an individual’s preference to mate with partners who are phenotypically similar to themselves.
7.19.180	Another cause of nonrandom mating is physical location.
7.19.181	This is especially true in large populations spread over large geographic distances where not all individuals will have equal access to one another.
7.19.182	Some might be miles apart through woods or over rough terrain, while others might live immediately nearby.
7.19.183	Environmental Variance Genes are not the only players involved in determining population variation.
7.19.184	Phenotypes are also influenced by other factors, such as the environment (Figure 19.7).
7.19.185	A beachgoer is likely to have darker skin than a city dweller, for example, due to regular exposure to the sun, an environmental factor.
7.19.186	Some major characteristics, such as gender, are determined by the environment for some species.
7.19.187	For example, some turtles and other reptiles have temperature-dependent sex determination (TSD).
7.19.188	TSD means that individuals develop into males if their eggs are incubated within a certain temperature range, or females at a different temperature range.
7.19.189	The sex of the American alligator (Alligator mississippiensis) is determined by the temperature at which the eggs are incubated.
7.19.190	Eggs incubated at 30°C produce females, and eggs incubated at 33°C produce males.
7.19.191	(credit: Steve Hillebrand, USFWS)
7.19.192	Geographic separation between populations can lead to differences in the phenotypic variation between those populations.
7.19.193	Such geographical variation is seen between most populations and can be significant.
7.19.194	One type of geographic variation, called a cline, can be seen as populations of a given species vary gradually across an ecological gradient.
7.19.195	Species of warmblooded animals, for example, tend to have larger bodies in the cooler climates closer to the earth’s poles, allowing them to better conserve heat.
7.19.196	This is considered a latitudinal cline.
7.19.197	Alternatively, flowering plants tend to bloom at different times depending on where they are along the slope of a mountain, known as an altitudinal cline.
7.19.198	If there is gene flow between the populations, the individuals will likely show gradual differences in phenotype along the cline.
7.19.199	Restricted gene flow, on the other hand, can lead to abrupt differences, even speciation.
7.19.200	Adaptive Evolution Natural selection only acts on the population’s heritable traits: selecting for beneficial alleles and thus increasing their frequency in the population, while selecting against deleterious alleles and thereby decreasing their frequency—a process known as adaptive evolution.
7.19.201	Natural selection does not act on individual alleles, however, but on entire organisms.
7.19.202	An individual may carry a very beneficial genotype with a resulting phenotype that, for example, increases the ability to reproduce (fecundity), but if that same individual also carries an allele that results in a fatal childhood disease, that fecundity phenotype will not be passed on to the next generation because the individual will not live to reach reproductive age.
7.19.203	Natural selection acts at the level of the individual; it selects for individuals with greater contributions to the gene pool of the next generation, known as an organism’s evolutionary (Darwinian) fitness.
7.19.204	Fitness is often quantifiable and is measured by scientists in the field.
7.19.205	However, it is not the absolute fitness of an individual that counts, but rather how it compares to the other organisms in the population.
7.19.206	This concept, called relative fitness, allows researchers to determine which individuals are contributing additional offspring to the next generation, and thus, how the population might evolve.
7.19.207	There are several ways selection can affect population variation: stabilizing selection, directional selection, diversifying selection, frequency-dependent selection, and sexual selection.
7.19.208	As natural selection influences the allele frequencies in a population, individuals can either become more or less genetically similar and the phenotypes displayed can become more similar or more disparate.
7.19.209	Stabilizing Selection
7.19.210	If natural selection favors an average phenotype, selecting against extreme variation, the population will undergo stabilizing selection (Figure 19.8).
7.19.211	In a population of mice that live in the woods, for example, natural selection is likely to favor individuals that best blend in with the forest floor and are less likely to be spotted by predators.
7.19.212	Assuming the ground is a fairly consistent shade of brown, those mice whose fur is most closely matched to that color will be most likely to survive and reproduce, passing on their genes for their brown coat.
7.19.213	Mice that carry alleles that make them a bit lighter or
7.19.214	a bit darker will stand out against the ground and be more likely to fall victim to predation.
7.19.215	As a result of this selection, the population’s genetic variance will decrease.
7.19.216	Directional Selection
7.19.217	When the environment changes, populations will often undergo directional selection (Figure 19.8), which selects for phenotypes at one end of the spectrum of existing variation.
7.19.218	A classic example of this type of selection is the evolution of the peppered moth in eighteenth- and nineteenth-century England.
7.19.219	Prior to the Industrial Revolution, the moths were predominately light in color, which allowed them to blend in with the light-colored trees and lichens in their environment.
7.19.220	But as soot began spewing from factories, the trees became darkened, and the light-colored moths became easier for predatory birds to spot.
7.19.221	Over time, the frequency of the melanic form of the moth increased because they had a higher survival rate in habitats affected by air pollution because their darker coloration blended with the sooty trees.
7.19.222	Similarly, the hypothetical mouse population may evolve to take on a different coloration if something were to cause the forest floor where they live to change color.
7.19.223	The result of this type of selection is a shift in the population’s genetic variance toward the new, fit phenotype.
7.19.224	Diversifying Selection
7.19.225	Sometimes two or more distinct phenotypes can each have their advantages and be selected for by natural selection, while the intermediate phenotypes are, on average, less fit.
7.19.226	Known as diversifying selection (Figure 19.8), this is seen in many populations of animals that have multiple male forms.
7.19.227	Large, dominant alpha males obtain mates by brute force, while small males can sneak in for furtive copulations with the females in an alpha male’s territory.
7.19.228	In this case, both the alpha males and the “sneaking” males will be selected for, but medium-sized males, which can’t overtake the alpha males and are too big to sneak copulations, are selected against.
7.19.229	Diversifying selection can also occur when environmental changes favor individuals on either end of the phenotypic spectrum.
7.19.230	Imagine a population of mice living at the beach where there is light-colored sand interspersed with patches of tall grass.
7.19.231	In this scenario, light-colored mice that blend in with the sand would be favored, as well as dark-colored mice that can hide in the grass.
7.19.232	Medium-colored mice, on the other hand, would not blend in with either the grass or the sand, and would thus be more likely to be eaten by predators.
7.19.233	The result of this type of selection is increased genetic variance as the population becomes more diverse.
7.19.234	Different types of natural selection can impact the distribution of phenotypes within a population.
7.19.235	In (a) stabilizing selection, an average phenotype is favored.
7.19.236	In (b) directional selection, a change in the environment shifts the spectrum of phenotypes observed.
7.19.237	In (c) diversifying selection, two or more extreme phenotypes are selected for, while the average phenotype is selected against.
7.19.238	Frequency-dependent Selection Another type of selection, called frequency-dependent selection, favors phenotypes that are either common (positive frequency-dependent selection) or rare (negative frequency-dependent selection).
7.19.239	An interesting example of this type of selection is seen in a unique group of lizards of the Pacific Northwest.
7.19.240	Male common side-blotched lizards come in three throat-color patterns: orange, blue, and yellow.
7.19.241	Each of these forms has a different reproductive strategy: orange males are the strongest and can fight other males for access to their females; blue males are medium-sized and form strong pair bonds with their mates; and yellow males (Figure 19.9) are the smallest, and look a bit like females, which allows them to sneak copulations.
7.19.242	Like a game of rock-paper-scissors, orange beats blue, blue beats yellow, and yellow beats orange in the competition for females.
7.19.243	That is, the big, strong orange males can fight off the blue males to mate with the blue’s pairbonded females, the blue males are successful at guarding their mates against yellow sneaker males, and the yellow males can sneak copulations from the potential mates of the large, polygynous orange males.
7.19.244	A yellow-throated side-blotched lizard is smaller than either the blue-throated or orange-throated males and appears a bit like the females of the species, allowing it to sneak copulations.
7.19.245	In this scenario, orange males will be favored by natural selection when the population is dominated by blue males, blue males will thrive when the population is mostly yellow males, and yellow males will be selected for when orange males are the most populous.
7.19.246	As a result, populations of side-blotched lizards cycle in the distribution of these phenotypes—in one generation, orange might be predominant, and then yellow males will begin to rise in frequency.
7.19.247	Once yellow males make up a majority of the population, blue males will be selected for.
7.19.248	Finally, when blue males become common, orange males will once again be favored.
7.19.249	Negative frequency-dependent selection serves to increase the population’s genetic variance by selecting for rare phenotypes, whereas positive frequency-dependent selection usually decreases genetic variance by selecting for common phenotypes.
7.19.250	Sexual Selection Males and females of certain species are often quite different from one another in ways beyond the reproductive organs.
7.19.251	Males are often larger, for example, and display many elaborate colors and adornments, like the peacock’s tail, while females tend to be smaller and duller in decoration.
7.19.252	Such differences are known as sexual dimorphisms (Figure 19.10), which arise from the fact that in many populations, particularly animal populations, there is more variance in the reproductive success of the males than there is of the females.
7.19.253	That is, some males—often the bigger, stronger, or more decorated males—get the vast majority of the total matings, while others receive none.
7.19.254	This can occur because the males are better at fighting off other males, or because females will choose to mate with the bigger or more decorated males.
7.19.255	In either case, this variation in reproductive success generates a strong selection pressure among males to get those matings, resulting in the evolution of bigger body size and elaborate ornaments to get the females’ attention.
7.19.256	Females, on the other hand, tend to get a handful of selected matings; therefore, they are more likely to select more desirable males.
7.19.257	Sexual dimorphism varies widely among species, of course, and some species are even sex-role reversed.
7.19.258	In such cases, females tend to have a greater variance in their reproductive success than males and are correspondingly selected for the bigger body size and elaborate traits usually characteristic of males.
7.19.259	Sexual dimorphism is observed in (a) peacocks and peahens, (b) Argiope appensa spiders (the female spider is the large one), and in (c) wood ducks The selection pressures on males and females to obtain matings is known as sexual selection; it can result in the development of secondary sexual characteristics that do not benefit the individual’s likelihood of survival but help to maximize its reproductive success.
7.19.260	Sexual selection can be so strong that it selects for traits that are actually detrimental to the individual’s survival.
7.19.261	Think, once again, about the peacock’s tail.
7.19.262	While it is beautiful and the male with the largest, most colorful tail is more likely to win the female, it is not the most practical appendage.
7.19.263	In addition to being more visible to predators, it makes the males slower in their attempted escapes.
7.19.264	There is some evidence that this risk, in fact, is why females like the big tails in the first place.
7.19.265	The speculation is that large tails carry risk, and only the best males survive that risk: the bigger the tail, the more fit the male.
7.19.266	This idea is known as the handicap principle.
7.19.267	The good genes hypothesis states that males develop these impressive ornaments to show off their efficient metabolism or their ability to fight disease.
7.19.268	Females then choose males with the most impressive traits because it signals their genetic superiority, which they will then pass on to their offspring.
7.19.269	Though it might be argued that females should not be picky because it will likely reduce their number of offspring, if better males father more fit offspring, it may be beneficial.
7.19.270	Fewer, healthier offspring may increase the chances of survival more than many, weaker offspring.
7.19.271	thus giving females a way to find the fittest mates— males that will pass the best genes to their offspring.
7.19.272	No Perfect Organism Natural selection is a driving force in evolution and can generate populations that are better adapted to survive and successfully reproduce in their environments.
7.19.273	But natural selection cannot produce the perfect organism.
7.19.274	Natural selection can only select on existing variation in the population; it does not create anything from scratch.
7.19.275	Thus, it is limited by a population’s existing genetic variance and whatever new alleles arise through mutation and gene flow.
7.19.276	Natural selection is also limited because it works at the level of individuals, not alleles, and some alleles are linked due to their physical proximity in the genome, making them more likely to be passed on together (linkage disequilibrium).
7.19.277	Any given individual may carry some beneficial alleles and some unfavorable alleles.
7.19.278	It is the net effect of these alleles, or the organism’s fitness, upon which natural selection can act.
7.19.279	As a result, good alleles can be lost if they are carried by individuals that also have several overwhelmingly bad alleles; likewise, bad alleles can be kept if they are carried by individuals that have enough good alleles to result in an overall fitness benefit.
7.19.280	Furthermore, natural selection can be constrained by the relationships between different polymorphisms.
7.19.281	One morph may confer a higher fitness than another, but may not increase in frequency due to the fact that going from the less beneficial to the more beneficial trait would require going through a less beneficial phenotype.
7.19.282	Think back to the mice that live at the beach.
7.19.283	Some are light-colored and blend in with the sand, while others are dark and blend in with the patches of grass.
7.19.284	The dark-colored mice may be, overall, more fit than the light-colored mice, and at first glance, one might expect the lightcolored mice be selected for a darker coloration.
7.19.285	But remember that the intermediate phenotype, a medium-colored coat, is very bad for the mice
7.19.286	—they cannot blend in with either the sand or the grass and are more likely to be eaten by predators.
7.19.287	As a result, the light-colored mice would not be selected for a dark coloration because those individuals that began moving in that direction (began being selected for a darker coat) would be less fit than those that stayed light.
7.19.288	Finally, it is important to understand that not all evolution is adaptive.
7.19.289	While natural selection selects the fittest individuals and often results in a more fit population overall, other forces of evolution, including genetic drift and gene flow, often do the opposite: introducing deleterious alleles to the population’s gene pool.
7.19.290	Evolution has no purpose—it is not changing a population into a preconceived ideal.
7.19.291	It is simply the sum of the various forces described in this chapter and how they influence the genetic and phenotypic variance of a population.
7.20.0	PHYLOGENIES AND THE HISTORY OF LIFE
7.20.1	The life of a bee is very different from the life of a flower, but the two organisms are related.
7.20.2	Both are members the domain Eukarya and have cells containing many similar organelles, genes, and proteins.
7.20.3	Introduction
7.20.4	This bee and Echinacea flower (Figure 20.1) could not look more different, yet they are related, as are all living organisms on Earth.
7.20.5	By following pathways of similarities and changes—both visible and genetic—scientists seek to map the evolutionary past of how life developed from single-celled organisms to the tremendous collection of creatures that have germinated, crawled, floated, swam, flown, and walked on this planet.
7.20.6	Organizing Life on Earth In scientific terms, the evolutionary history and relationship of an organism or group of organisms is called its phylogeny.
7.20.7	A phylogeny describes the relationships of an organism, such as from which organisms it is thought to have evolved, to which species it is most closely related, and so forth.
7.20.8	Phylogenetic relationships provide information on shared ancestry but not necessarily on how organisms are similar or different.
