7.20.9	Phylogenetic Trees Scientists use a tool called a phylogenetic tree to show the evolutionary pathways and connections among organisms.
7.20.10	A phylogenetic tree is a diagram used to reflect evolutionary relationships among organisms or groups of organisms.
7.20.11	Scientists consider phylogenetic trees to be a hypothesis of the evolutionary past since one cannot go back to confirm the proposed relationships.
7.20.12	In other words, a “tree of life” can be constructed to illustrate when different organisms evolved and to show the relationships among different organisms (Figure 20.2).
7.20.13	Unlike a taxonomic classification diagram, a phylogenetic tree can be read like a map of evolutionary history.
7.20.14	Many phylogenetic trees have a single lineage at the base representing a common ancestor.
7.20.15	Scientists call such trees rooted, which means there is a single ancestral lineage (typically drawn from the bottom or left) to which all organisms represented in the diagram relate.
7.20.16	Notice in the rooted phylogenetic tree that the three domains— Bacteria, Archaea, and Eukarya—diverge from a single point and branch off.
7.20.17	The small branch that plants and animals (including humans) occupy in this diagram shows how recent and miniscule these groups are compared with other organisms.
7.20.18	Unrooted trees don’t show a common ancestor but do show relationships among species.
7.20.19	Both of these phylogenetic trees shows the relationship of the three domains of life—Bacteria, Archaea, and Eukarya—but the (a) rooted tree attempts to identify when various species diverged from a common ancestor while the (b) unrooted tree does not.
7.20.20	(credit a: modification of work by Eric Gaba)
7.20.21	In a rooted tree, the branching indicates evolutionary relationships (Figure 20.3).
7.20.22	The point where a split occurs, called a branch point, represents where a single lineage evolved into a distinct new one.
7.20.23	A lineage that evolved early from the root and remains unbranched is called basal taxon.
7.20.24	When two lineages stem from the same branch point, they are called sister taxa.
7.20.25	A branch with more than two lineages is called a polytomy and serves to illustrate where scientists have not definitively determined all of the relationships.
7.20.26	It is important to note that although sister taxa and polytomy do share an ancestor, it does not mean that the groups of organisms split or evolved from each other.
7.20.27	Organisms in two taxa may have split apart at a specific branch point, but neither taxa gave rise to the other.
7.20.28	The root of a phylogenetic tree indicates that an ancestral lineage gave rise to all organisms on the tree.
7.20.29	A branch point indicates where two lineages diverged.
7.20.30	A lineage that evolved early and remains unbranched is a basal taxon.
7.20.31	When two lineages stem from the same branch point, they are sister taxa.
7.20.32	A branch with more than two lineages is a polytomy.
7.20.33	The diagrams above can serve as a pathway to understanding evolutionary history.
7.20.34	The pathway can be traced from the origin of life to any individual species by navigating through the evolutionary branches between the two points.
7.20.35	Also, by starting with a single species and tracing back towards the "trunk" of the tree, one can discover that species' ancestors, as well as where lineages share a common ancestry.
7.20.36	In addition, the tree can be used to study entire groups of organisms.
7.20.37	Another point to mention on phylogenetic tree structure is that rotation at branch points does not change the information.
7.20.38	For example, if a branch point was rotated and the taxon order changed, this would not alter the information because the evolution of each taxon from the branch point was independent of the other.
7.20.39	Many disciplines within the study of biology contribute to understanding how past and present life evolved over time; these disciplines together contribute to building, updating, and maintaining the “tree of life.
7.20.40	”
7.20.41	Information is used to organize and classify organisms based on evolutionary relationships in a scientific field called systematics.
7.20.42	Data may be collected from fossils, from studying the structure of body parts or molecules used by an organism, and by DNA analysis.
7.20.43	By combining data from many sources, scientists can put together the phylogeny of an organism; since phylogenetic trees are hypotheses, they will continue to change as new types of life are discovered and new information is learned.
7.20.44	Limitations of Phylogenetic Trees
7.20.45	It may be easy to assume that more closely related organisms look more alike, and while this is often the case, it is not always true.
7.20.46	If two closely related lineages evolved under significantly varied surroundings or after the evolution of a major new adaptation, it is possible for the two groups to appear more different than other groups that are not as closely related.
7.20.47	For example, the phylogenetic tree in Figure 20.4 shows that lizards and rabbits both have amniotic eggs, whereas frogs do not; yet lizards and frogs appear more similar than lizards and rabbits.
7.20.48	This ladder-like phylogenetic tree of vertebrates is rooted by an organism that lacked a vertebral column.
7.20.49	At each branch point, organisms with different characters are placed in different groups based on the characteristics they share.
7.20.50	Another aspect of phylogenetic trees is that, unless otherwise indicated, the branches do not account for length of time, only the evolutionary order.
7.20.51	In other words, the length of a branch does not typically mean more time passed, nor does a short branch mean less time passed— unless specified on the diagram.
7.20.52	For example, in Figure 20.4, the tree does not indicate how much time passed between the evolution of amniotic eggs and hair.
7.20.53	What the tree does show is the order in which things took place.
7.20.54	Again using Figure 20.4, the tree shows that the oldest trait is the vertebral column, followed by hinged jaws, and so forth.
7.20.55	Remember that any phylogenetic tree is a part of the greater whole, and like a real tree, it does not grow in only one direction after a new branch develops.
7.20.56	So, for the organisms in Figure 20.4, just because a vertebral column evolved does not mean that invertebrate evolution ceased, it only means that a new branch formed.
7.20.57	Also, groups that are not closely related, but evolve under similar conditions, may appear more phenotypically similar to each other than to a close relative.
7.20.58	The Levels of Classification Taxonomy (which literally means “arrangement law”) is the science of classifying organisms to construct internationally shared classification systems with each organism placed into more and more inclusive groupings.
7.20.59	Think about how a grocery store is organized.
7.20.60	One large space is divided into departments, such as produce, dairy, and meats.
7.20.61	Then each department further divides into aisles, then each aisle into categories and brands, and then finally a single product.
7.20.62	This organization from larger to smaller, more specific categories is called a hierarchical system.
7.20.63	The taxonomic classification system (also called the Linnaean system after its inventor, Carl Linnaeus, a Swedish botanist, zoologist, and physician) uses a hierarchical model.
7.20.64	Moving from the point of origin, the groups become more specific, until one branch ends as a single species.
7.20.65	For example, after the common beginning of all life, scientists divide organisms into three large categories called a domain: Bacteria, Archaea, and Eukarya.
7.20.66	Within each domain is a second category called a kingdom.
7.20.67	After kingdoms, the subsequent categories of increasing specificity are: phylum, class, order, family, genus, and species (Figure 20.5).
7.20.68	The taxonomic classification system uses a hierarchical model to organize living organisms into increasingly specific categories.
7.20.69	The common dog, Canis lupus familiaris, is a subspecies of Canis lupus, which also includes the wolf and dingo.
7.20.70	(credit “dog
7.20.71	”:
7.20.72	modification of work by Janneke Vreugdenhil)
7.20.73	The kingdom Animalia stems from the Eukarya domain.
7.20.74	For the common dog, the classification levels would be as shown in Figure 20.5.
7.20.75	Therefore, the full name of an organism technically has eight terms.
7.20.76	For the dog, it is: Eukarya, Animalia, Chordata, Mammalia, Carnivora, Canidae, Canis, and lupus.
7.20.77	Notice that each name is capitalized except for species, and the genus and species names are italicized.
7.20.78	Scientists generally refer to an organism only by its genus and species, which is its two-word scientific name, in what is called binomial nomenclature.
7.20.79	Therefore, the scientific name of the dog is Canis lupus.
7.20.80	The name at each level is also called a taxon.
7.20.81	In other words, dogs are in order Carnivora.
7.20.82	Carnivora is the name of the taxon at the order level; Canidae is the taxon at the family level, and so forth.
7.20.83	Organisms also have a common name that people typically use, in this case, dog.
7.20.84	Note that the dog is additionally a subspecies: the “familiaris” in Canis lupus familiaris.
7.20.85	Subspecies are members of the same species that are capable of mating and reproducing viable offspring, but they are considered separate subspecies due to geographic or behavioral isolation or other factors.
7.20.86	Figure 20.6 shows how the levels move toward specificity with other organisms.
7.20.87	Notice how the dog shares a domain with the widest diversity of organisms, including plants and butterflies.
7.20.88	At each sublevel, the organisms become more similar because they are more closely related.
7.20.89	Historically, scientists classified organisms using characteristics, but as DNA technology developed, more precise phylogenies have been determined.
7.20.90	At each sublevel in the taxonomic classification system, organisms become more similar.
7.20.91	Dogs and wolves are the same species because they can breed and produce viable offspring, but they are different enough to be classified as different subspecies.
7.20.92	Recent genetic analysis and other advancements have found that some earlier phylogenetic classifications do not align with the evolutionary past; therefore, changes and updates must be made as new discoveries occur.
7.20.93	Recall that phylogenetic trees are hypotheses and are modified as data becomes available.
7.20.94	In addition, classification historically has focused on grouping organisms mainly by shared characteristics and does not necessarily illustrate how the various groups relate to each other from an evolutionary perspective.
7.20.95	For example, despite the fact that a hippopotamus resembles a pig more than a whale, the hippopotamus may be the closest living relative of the whale.
7.20.96	Determining Evolutionary Relationships Scientists must collect accurate information that allows them to make evolutionary connections among organisms.
7.20.97	Similar to detective work, scientists must use evidence to uncover the facts.
7.20.98	In the case of phylogeny, evolutionary investigations focus on two types of evidence: morphologic (form and function) and genetic.
7.20.99	Two Options for Similarities
7.20.100	In general, organisms that share similar physical features and genomes tend to be more closely related than those that do not.
7.20.101	Such features that overlap both morphologically (in form) and genetically are referred to as homologous structures; they stem from developmental similarities that are based on evolution.
7.20.102	For example, the bones in the wings of bats and birds have homologous structures.
7.20.103	Bat and bird wings are homologous structures, indicating that bats and birds share a common evolutionary past.
7.20.104	Notice
7.20.105	it is not simply a single bone, but rather a grouping of several bones arranged in a similar way.
7.20.106	The more complex the feature, the more likely any kind of overlap is due to a common evolutionary past.
7.20.107	Imagine two people from different countries both inventing a car with all the same parts and in exactly the same arrangement without any previous or shared knowledge.
7.20.108	That outcome would be highly improbable.
7.20.109	However, if two people both invented a hammer, it would be reasonable to conclude that both could have the original idea without the help of the other.
7.20.110	The same relationship between complexity and shared evolutionary history is true for homologous structures in organisms.
7.20.111	Misleading Appearances
7.20.112	Some organisms may be very closely related, even though a minor genetic change caused a major morphological difference to make them look quite different.
7.20.113	Similarly, unrelated organisms may be distantly related, but appear very much alike.
7.20.114	This usually happens because both organisms were in common adaptations that evolved within similar environmental conditions.
7.20.115	When similar characteristics occur because of environmental constraints and not due to a close evolutionary relationship, it is called an analogy or homoplasy.
7.20.116	For example, insects use wings to fly like bats and birds, but the wing structure and embryonic origin is completely different.
7.20.117	These are called analogous structures (Figure 20.8).
7.20.118	Similar traits can be either homologous or analogous.
7.20.119	Homologous structures share a similar embryonic origin; analogous organs have a similar function.
7.20.120	For example, the bones in the front flipper of a whale are homologous to the bones in the human arm.
7.20.121	These structures are not analogous.
7.20.122	The wings of a butterfly and the wings of a bird are analogous but not homologous.
7.20.123	Some structures are both analogous and homologous: the wings of a bird and the wings of a bat are both homologous and analogous.
7.20.124	Scientists must determine which type of similarity a feature exhibits to decipher the phylogeny of the organisms being studied.
7.20.125	The (c) wing of a honeybee is similar in shape to a (b) bird wing and (a) bat wing, and it serves the same function.
7.20.126	However, the honeybee wing is not composed of bones and has a distinctly different structure and embryonic origin.
7.20.127	These wing types (insect versus bat and bird) illustrate an analogy—similar structures that do not share an evolutionary history.
7.20.128	Molecular Comparisons
7.20.129	With the advancement of DNA technology, the area of molecular systematics, which describes the use of information on the molecular level including DNA analysis, has blossomed.
7.20.130	New computer programs not only confirm many earlier classified organisms, but also uncover previously made errors.
7.20.131	As with physical characteristics, even the DNA sequence can be tricky to read in some cases.
7.20.132	For some situations, two very closely related organisms can appear unrelated if a mutation occurred that caused a shift in the genetic code.
7.20.133	An insertion or deletion mutation would move each nucleotide base over one place, causing two similar codes to appear unrelated.
7.20.134	Sometimes two segments of DNA code in distantly related organisms randomly share a high percentage of bases in the same locations, causing these organisms to appear closely related when they are not.
7.20.135	For both of these situations, computer technologies have been developed to help identify the actual relationships, and, ultimately, the coupled use of both morphologic and molecular information is more effective in determining phylogeny.
7.20.136	Why Does Phylogeny Matter?
7.20.137	Evolutionary biologists could list many reasons why understanding phylogeny is important to everyday life in human society.
7.20.138	For botanists, phylogeny acts as a guide to discovering new plants that can be used to benefit people.
7.20.139	Think of all the ways humans use plants—food, medicine, and clothing are a few examples.
7.20.140	If a plant contains a compound that is effective in treating cancer, scientists might want to examine all of the relatives of that plant for other useful drugs.
7.20.141	A research team in China identified a segment of DNA thought to be common to some medicinal plants in the family Fabaceae (the legume family) and worked to identify which species had this segment (Figure 20.9).
7.20.142	After testing plant species in this family, the team found a DNA marker (a known location on a chromosome that enabled them to identify the species) present.
7.20.143	Then, using the DNA to uncover phylogenetic relationships, the team could identify whether a newly discovered plant was in this family and assess its potential medicinal properties.
7.20.144	Building Phylogenetic Trees
7.20.145	How do scientists construct phylogenetic trees?
7.20.146	After the homologous and analogous traits are sorted, scientists often organize the homologous traits using a system called cladistics.
7.20.147	This system sorts organisms into clades: groups of organisms that descended from a single ancestor.
7.20.148	For example, in Figure 20.10, all of the organisms in the orange region evolved from a single ancestor that had amniotic eggs.
7.20.149	Consequently, all of these organisms also have amniotic eggs and make a single clade, also called a monophyletic group.
7.20.150	Clades must include all of the descendants from a branch point.
7.20.151	Clades can vary in size depending on which branch point is being referenced.
7.20.152	The important factor is that all of the organisms in the clade or monophyletic group stem from a single point on the tree.
7.20.153	This can be remembered because monophyletic breaks down into “mono,” meaning one, and “phyletic,” meaning evolutionary relationship.
7.20.154	Figure 20.11 shows various examples of clades.
7.20.155	Notice how each clade comes from a single point, whereas the non-clade groups show branches that do not share a single point.
7.20.156	All the organisms within a clade stem from a single point on the tree.
7.20.157	A clade may contain multiple groups, as in the case of animals, fungi and plants, or a single group, as in the case of flagellates.
7.20.158	Groups that diverge at a different branch point, or that do not include all groups in a single branch point, are not considered clades.
7.20.159	Shared Characteristics Organisms evolve from common ancestors and then diversify.
7.20.160	Scientists use the phrase “descent with modification” because even though related organisms have many of the same characteristics and genetic codes, changes occur.
7.20.161	This pattern repeats over and over as one goes through the phylogenetic tree of life:
7.20.162	1.
7.20.163	A change in the genetic makeup of an organism leads to a new trait which becomes prevalent in the group.
7.20.164	2.
7.20.165	Many organisms descend from this point and have this trait.
7.20.166	3.
7.20.167	New variations continue to arise: some are adaptive and persist, leading to new traits.
7.20.168	4.
7.20.169	With new traits, a new branch point is determined (go back to step 1 and repeat).
7.20.170	If a characteristic is found in the ancestor of a group, it is considered a shared ancestral character because all of the organisms in the taxon or clade have that trait.
7.20.171	The vertebrate in Figure 20.10 is a shared ancestral character.
7.20.172	Now consider the amniotic egg characteristic in the same figure.
7.20.173	Only some of the organisms in Figure 20.10 have this trait, and to those that do, it is called a shared derived character because this trait derived at some point but does not include all of the ancestors in the tree.
7.20.174	The tricky aspect to shared ancestral and shared derived characters is the fact that these terms are relative.
7.20.175	The same trait can be considered one or the other depending on the particular diagram being used.
7.20.176	Returning to Figure 20.10, note that the amniotic egg is a shared ancestral character for the Amniota clade, while having hair is a shared derived character for some organisms in this group.
7.20.177	These terms help scientists distinguish between clades in the building of phylogenetic trees.
7.20.178	Choosing the Right Relationships Imagine being the person responsible for organizing all of the items in a department store properly—an overwhelming task.
7.20.179	Organizing the evolutionary relationships of all life on Earth proves much more difficult: scientists must span enormous blocks of time and work with information from long-extinct organisms.
7.20.180	Trying to decipher the proper connections, especially given the presence of homologies and analogies, makes the task of building an accurate tree of life extraordinarily difficult.
7.20.181	Add to that the advancement of DNA technology, which now provides large quantities of genetic sequences to be used and analyzed.
7.20.182	Taxonomy is a subjective discipline: many organisms have more than one connection to each other, so each taxonomist will decide the order of connections.
7.20.183	To aid in the tremendous task of describing phylogenies accurately, scientists often use a concept called maximum parsimony, which means that events occurred in the simplest, most obvious way.
7.20.184	For example, if a group of people entered a forest preserve to go hiking, based on the principle of maximum parsimony, one could predict that most of the people would hike on established trails rather than forge new ones.
7.20.185	For scientists deciphering evolutionary pathways, the same idea is used: the pathway of evolution probably includes the fewest major events that coincide with the evidence at hand.
7.20.186	Starting with all of the homologous traits in a group of organisms, scientists look for the most obvious and simple order of evolutionary events that led to the occurrence of those traits.
7.20.187	These tools and concepts are only a few of the strategies scientists use to tackle the task of revealing the evolutionary history of life on Earth.
7.20.188	Recently, newer technologies have uncovered surprising discoveries with unexpected relationships, such as the fact that people seem to be more closely related to fungi than fungi are to plants.
7.20.189	Sound unbelievable?
7.20.190	As the information about DNA sequences grows, scientists will become closer to mapping the evolutionary history of all life on Earth.
7.20.191	Perspectives on the Phylogenetic Tree
7.20.192	The concepts of phylogenetic modeling are constantly changing.
7.20.193	It is one of the most dynamic fields of study in all of biology.
7.20.194	Over the last several decades, new research has challenged scientists’ ideas about how organisms are related.
7.20.195	New models of these relationships have been proposed for consideration by the scientific community.
7.20.196	Many phylogenetic trees have been shown as models of the evolutionary relationship among species.
7.20.197	Phylogenetic trees originated with Charles Darwin, who sketched the first phylogenetic tree in 1837 (Figure 20.12a), which served as a pattern for subsequent studies for more than a century.
7.20.198	The concept of a phylogenetic tree with a single trunk representing a common ancestor, with the branches representing the divergence of species from this ancestor, fits well with the structure of many common trees, such as the oak (Figure 20.12b).
7.20.199	However, evidence from modern DNA sequence analysis and newly developed computer algorithms has caused skepticism about the validity of the standard tree model in the scientific community.
7.20.200	The (a) concept of the “tree of life” goes back to an 1837 sketch by Charles Darwin.
7.20.201	Like an (b) oak tree, the “tree of life” has a single trunk and many branches.
7.20.202	Limitations to the Classic Model Classical thinking about prokaryotic evolution, included in the classic tree model, is that species evolve clonally.
7.20.203	That is, they produce offspring themselves with only random mutations causing the descent into the variety of modern-day and extinct species known to science.
7.20.204	This view is somewhat complicated in eukaryotes that reproduce sexually, but the laws of Mendelian genetics explain the variation in offspring, again, to be a result of a mutation within the species.
7.20.205	The concept of genes being transferred between unrelated species was not considered as a possibility until relatively recently.
7.20.206	Horizontal gene transfer (HGT), also known as lateral gene transfer, is the transfer of genes between unrelated species.
7.20.207	HGT has been shown to be an ever-present phenomenon, with many evolutionists postulating a major role for this process in evolution, thus complicating the simple tree model.
7.20.208	Genes have been shown to be passed between species which are only distantly related using standard phylogeny, thus adding a layer of complexity to the understanding of phylogenetic relationships.
7.20.209	The various ways that HGT occurs in prokaryotes is important to understanding phylogenies.
7.20.210	Although at present HGT is not viewed as important to eukaryotic evolution, HGT does occur in this domain as well.
7.20.211	Finally, as an example of the ultimate gene transfer, theories of genome fusion between symbiotic or endosymbiotic organisms have been proposed to explain an event of great importance—
7.20.212	the evolution of the first eukaryotic cell, without which humans could not have come into existence.
7.20.213	Horizontal Gene Transfer Horizontal gene transfer (HGT) is the introduction of genetic material from one species to another species by mechanisms other than the vertical transmission from parent(s) to offspring.
7.20.214	These transfers allow even distantly related species to share genes, influencing their phenotypes.
7.20.215	It is thought that HGT is more prevalent in prokaryotes, but that only about 2% of the prokaryotic genome may be transferred by this process.
7.20.216	Some researchers believe such estimates are premature: the actual importance of HGT to evolutionary processes must be viewed as a work in progress.
7.20.217	As the phenomenon is investigated more thoroughly, it may be revealed to be more common.
7.20.218	Many scientists believe that HGT and mutation appear to be (especially in prokaryotes) a significant source of genetic variation, which is the raw material for the process of natural selection.
7.20.219	These transfers may occur between any two species that share an intimate relationship (Table 20.1).
7.20.220	HGT in Prokaryotes
7.20.221	The mechanism of HGT has been shown to be quite common in the prokaryotic domains of Bacteria and Archaea, significantly changing the way their evolution is viewed.
7.20.222	The majority of evolutionary models, such as in the Endosymbiont Theory, propose that eukaryotes descended from multiple prokaryotes, which makes HGT all the more important to understanding the phylogenetic relationships of all extant and extinct species.
7.20.223	The fact that genes are transferred among common bacteria is well known to microbiology students.
7.20.224	These gene transfers between species are the major mechanism whereby bacteria acquire resistance to antibiotics.
7.20.225	Classically, this type of transfer has been thought to occur by three different mechanisms: 1.
7.20.226	Transformation:
7.20.227	naked DNA is taken up by a bacteria 2.
7.20.228	Transduction:
7.20.229	genes are transferred using a virus 3.
7.20.230	Conjugation: the use a hollow tube called a pilus to transfer genes between organisms More recently,
7.20.231	a fourth mechanism of gene transfer between prokaryotes has been discovered.
7.20.232	Small, virus-like particles called gene transfer agents (GTAs) transfer random genomic segments from one species of prokaryote to another.
7.20.233	GTAs have been shown to be responsible for genetic changes, sometimes at a very high frequency compared to other evolutionary processes.
7.20.234	The first GTA was characterized in 1974 using purple, non-sulfur bacteria.
7.20.235	These GTAs, which are thought to be bacteriophages that lost the ability to reproduce on their own, carry random pieces of DNA from one organism to another.
7.20.236	The ability of GTAs to act with high frequency has been demonstrated in controlled studies using marine bacteria.
7.20.237	Gene transfer events in marine prokaryotes, either by GTAs or by viruses, have been estimated to be as high as 1013 per year in the Mediterranean Sea alone.
7.20.238	GTAs and viruses are thought to be efficient HGT vehicles with a major impact on prokaryotic evolution.
7.20.239	As a consequence of this modern DNA analysis, the idea that eukaryotes evolved directly from Archaea has fallen out of favor.
7.20.240	While eukaryotes share many features that are absent in bacteria, such as the TATA box (found in the promoter region of many genes), the discovery that some eukaryotic genes were more homologous with bacterial DNA than Archaea DNA made this idea less tenable.
7.20.241	Furthermore, the fusion of genomes from Archaea and Bacteria by endosymbiosis has been proposed as the ultimate event in eukaryotic evolution.
7.20.242	HGT in Eukaryotes
7.20.243	Although it is easy to see how prokaryotes exchange genetic material by HGT, it was initially thought that this process was absent in eukaryotes.
7.20.244	After all, prokaryotes are but single cells exposed directly to their environment, whereas the sex cells of multicellular organisms are usually sequestered in protected parts of the body.
7.20.245	It follows from this idea that the gene transfers between multicellular eukaryotes should be more difficult.
7.20.246	Indeed, it is thought that this process is rarer in eukaryotes and has a much smaller evolutionary impact than in prokaryotes.
7.20.247	In spite of this fact, HGT between distantly related organisms has been demonstrated in several eukaryotic species, and it is possible that more examples will be discovered in the future.
7.20.248	In plants, gene transfer has been observed in species that cannot cross-pollinate by normal means.
7.20.249	Transposons or “jumping genes” have been shown to transfer between rice and millet plant species.
7.20.250	Furthermore, fungal species feeding on yew trees, from which the anti-cancer drug TAXOL® is derived from the bark, have acquired the ability to make taxol themselves, a clear example of gene transfer.
7.20.251	In animals, a particularly interesting example of HGT occurs within the aphid species (Figure 20.13).
7.20.252	Aphids are insects that vary in color based on carotenoid content.
7.20.253	Carotenoids are pigments made by a variety of plants, fungi, and microbes, and they serve a variety of functions in animals, who obtain these chemicals from their food.
7.20.254	Humans require carotenoids to synthesize vitamin A, and we obtain them by eating orange fruits and vegetables: carrots, apricots, mangoes, and sweet potatoes.
7.20.255	On the other hand, aphids have acquired the ability to make the carotenoids on their own.
7.20.256	According to DNA analysis, this ability is due to the transfer of fungal genes into the insect by HGT, presumably as the insect consumed fungi for food.
7.20.257	A carotenoid enzyme called a desaturase is responsible for the red coloration seen in certain aphids, and it has been further shown that when this gene is inactivated by mutation, the aphids revert back to their more common green color (Figure 20.13).
7.20.258	(a) Red aphids get their color from red carotenoid pigment.
7.20.259	Genes necessary to make this pigment are present in certain fungi, and scientists speculate that aphids acquired these genes through HGT after consuming fungi for food.
7.20.260	If genes for making carotenoids are inactivated by mutation, the aphids revert back to (b) their green color.
7.20.261	Red coloration makes the aphids a lot more conspicuous to predators, but evidence suggests that red aphids are more resistant to insecticides than green ones.
7.20.262	Thus, red aphids may be more fit to survive in some environments than green ones.
7.20.263	Genome Fusion and the Evolution of Eukaryotes
7.20.264	Scientists believe the ultimate in HGT occurs through genome fusion between different species of prokaryotes when two symbiotic organisms become endosymbiotic.
7.20.265	This occurs when one species is taken inside the cytoplasm of another species, which ultimately results in a genome consisting of genes from both the endosymbiont and the host.
7.20.266	This mechanism is an aspect of the Endosymbiont Theory, which is accepted by a majority of biologists as the mechanism whereby eukaryotic cells obtained their mitochondria and chloroplasts.
7.20.267	However, the role of endosymbiosis in the development of the nucleus is more controversial.
7.20.268	Nuclear and mitochondrial DNA are thought to be of different (separate) evolutionary origin, with the mitochondrial DNA being derived from the circular genomes of bacteria that were engulfed by ancient prokaryotic cells.
7.20.269	Mitochondrial DNA can be regarded as the smallest chromosome.
7.20.270	Interestingly enough, mitochondrial DNA is inherited only from the mother.
7.20.271	The mitochondrial DNA degrades in sperm when the sperm degrades in the fertilized egg or in other instances when the mitochondria located in the flagellum of the sperm fails to enter the egg.
7.20.272	Within the past decade, the process of genome fusion by endosymbiosis has been proposed by James Lake of the UCLA/ NASA Astrobiology Institute to be responsible for the evolution of the first eukaryotic cells (Figure 20.14a).
7.20.273	Using DNA analysis and a new mathematical algorithm called conditioned reconstruction (CR), his laboratory proposed that eukaryotic cells developed from an endosymbiotic gene fusion between two species, one an Archaea and the other a Bacteria.
7.20.274	As mentioned, some eukaryotic genes resemble those of Archaea, whereas others resemble those from Bacteria.
7.20.275	An endosymbiotic fusion event, such as Lake has proposed, would clearly explain this observation.
7.20.276	On the other hand, this work is new and the CR algorithm is relatively unsubstantiated, which causes many scientists to resist this hypothesis.
7.20.277	More recent work by Lake (Figure 20.14b) proposes that gram-negative bacteria, which are unique within their domain in that they contain two lipid bilayer membranes, indeed resulted from an endosymbiotic fusion of archaeal and bacterial species.
7.20.278	The double membrane would be a direct result of the endosymbiosis, with the endosymbiont picking up the second membrane from the host as it was internalized.
7.20.279	This mechanism has also been used to explain the double membranes found in mitochondria and chloroplasts.
7.20.280	Lake’s work is not without skepticism, and the ideas are still debated within the biological science community.
7.20.281	In addition to Lake’s hypothesis, there are several other competing theories as to the origin of eukaryotes.
7.20.282	How did the eukaryotic nucleus evolve?
7.20.283	One theory is that the prokaryotic cells produced an additional membrane that surrounded the bacterial chromosome.
7.20.284	Some bacteria have the DNA enclosed by two membranes; however, there is no evidence of a nucleolus or nuclear pores.
7.20.285	Other proteobacteria also have membrane-bound chromosomes.
7.20.286	If the eukaryotic nucleus evolved this way, we would expect one of the two types of prokaryotes to be more closely related to eukaryotes.
7.20.287	The theory that mitochondria and chloroplasts are endosymbiotic in origin is now widely accepted.
7.20.288	More controversial is the proposal that (a) the eukaryotic nucleus resulted from the fusion of archaeal and bacterial genomes, and that (b) Gram-negative bacteria, which have two membranes, resulted from the fusion of Archaea and Grampositive bacteria, each of which has a single membrane.
7.20.289	The nucleus-first hypothesis proposes that the nucleus evolved in prokaryotes first (Figure 20.15a), followed by a later fusion of the new eukaryote with bacteria that became mitochondria.
7.20.290	The mitochondria-first hypothesis proposes that mitochondria were first established in a prokaryotic host (Figure 20.15b), which subsequently acquired a nucleus, by fusion or other mechanisms, to become the first eukaryotic cell.
7.20.291	Most interestingly, the eukaryote-first hypothesis proposes that prokaryotes actually evolved from eukaryotes by losing genes and complexity (Figure 20.15c).
7.20.292	All of these hypotheses are testable.
7.20.293	Only time and more experimentation will determine which hypothesis is best supported by data.
7.20.294	Three alternate hypotheses of eukaryotic and prokaryotic evolution are (a) the nucleus-first hypothesis, (b) the mitochondrion-first hypothesis, and (c) the eukaryote-first hypothesis.
7.20.295	Web and Network Models
7.20.296	The recognition of the importance of HGT, especially in the evolution of prokaryotes, has caused some to propose abandoning the classic “tree of life” model.
7.20.297	In 1999, W. Ford Doolittle proposed a phylogenetic model that resembles a web or a network more than a tree.
7.20.298	The hypothesis is that eukaryotes evolved not from a single prokaryotic ancestor, but from a pool of many species that were sharing genes by HGT mechanisms.
7.20.299	As shown in Figure 20.16a, some individual prokaryotes were responsible for transferring the bacteria that caused mitochondrial development to the new eukaryotes, whereas other species transferred the bacteria that gave rise to chloroplasts.
7.20.300	This model is often called the “ web of life.
7.20.301	”
7.20.302	In an effort to save the tree analogy, some have proposed using the Ficus tree (Figure 20.16b) with its multiple trunks as a phylogenetic to represent a diminished evolutionary role for HGT.
7.20.303	In the (a) phylogenetic model proposed by W. Ford Doolittle, the “tree of life” arose from a community of ancestral cells, has multiple trunks, and has connections between branches where horizontal gene transfer has occurred.
7.20.304	Visually, this concept is better represented by (b) the multi-trunked Ficus than by the single trunk of the oak similar to the tree drawn by Darwin Figure 20.12.
7.20.305	Ring of Life
7.20.306	Models Others have proposed abandoning any tree-like model of phylogeny in favor of a ring structure, the so-called “ ring of life” (Figure 20.17); a phylogenetic model where all three domains of life evolved from a pool of primitive prokaryotes.
7.20.307	Lake, again using the conditioned reconstruction algorithm, proposes a ring-like model in which species of all three domains—Archaea, Bacteria, and Eukarya—evolved from a single pool of gene-swapping prokaryotes.
7.20.308	His laboratory proposes that this structure is the best fit for data from extensive DNA analyses performed in his laboratory, and that the ring model is the only one that adequately takes HGT and genomic fusion into account.
7.20.309	However, other phylogeneticists remain highly skeptical of this model.
7.20.310	According to the “ring of life” phylogenetic model, the three domains of life evolved from a pool of primitive prokaryotes.
7.20.311	In summary, the “tree of life” model proposed by Darwin must be modified to include HGT.
7.20.312	Does this mean abandoning the tree model completely?
7.20.313	Even Lake argues that all attempts should be made to discover some modification of the tree model to allow it to accurately fit his data, and only the inability to do so will sway people toward his ring proposal.
7.20.314	This doesn’t mean a tree, web, or a ring will correlate completely to an accurate description of phylogenetic relationships of life.
7.20.315	A consequence of the new thinking about phylogenetic models is the idea that Darwin’s original conception of the phylogenetic tree is too simple, but made sense based on what was known at the time.
7.20.316	However, the search for a more useful model moves on: each model serving as hypotheses to be tested with the possibility of developing new models.
7.20.317	This is how science advances.
7.20.318	These models are used as visualizations to help construct hypothetical evolutionary relationships and understand the massive amount of data being analyzed.
7.21.0	VIRUSES
7.21.1	The tobacco mosaic virus (left), seen here by transmission electron microscopy, was the first virus to be discovered.
7.21.2	The virus causes disease in tobacco and other plants, such as the orchid.
7.21.3	Introduction
7.21.4	No one knows exactly when viruses emerged or from where they came, since viruses do not leave historical footprints such as fossils.
7.21.5	Modern viruses are thought to be a mosaic of bits and pieces of nucleic acids picked up from various sources along their respective evolutionary paths.
7.21.6	Viruses are acellular, parasitic entities that are not classified within any kingdom.
7.21.7	Unlike most living organisms, viruses are not cells and cannot divide.
7.21.8	Instead, they infect a host cell and use the host’s replication processes to produce identical progeny virus particles.
7.21.9	Viruses infect organisms as diverse as bacteria, plants, and animals.
7.21.10	They exist in a netherworld between a living organism and a nonliving entity.
7.21.11	Living things grow, metabolize, and reproduce.
7.21.12	Viruses replicate, but to do so, they are entirely dependent on their host cells.
7.21.13	They do not metabolize or grow, but are assembled in their mature form.
7.21.14	Viral Evolution, Morphology, and Classification Viruses are diverse entities.
7.21.15	They vary in their structure, their replication methods, and in their target hosts.
7.21.16	Nearly all forms of life—from bacteria and archaea to eukaryotes such as plants, animals, and fungi—have viruses that infect them.
7.21.17	While most biological diversity can be understood through evolutionary history, such as how species have adapted to conditions and environments, much about virus origins and evolution remains unknown.
7.21.18	Discovery and Detection Viruses were first discovered after the development of a porcelain filter, called the Chamberland-Pasteur filter, which could remove all bacteria visible in the microscope from any liquid sample.
7.21.19	In 1886, Adolph Meyer demonstrated that a disease of tobacco plants, tobacco mosaic disease, could be transferred from a diseased plant to a healthy one via liquid plant extracts.
7.21.20	In 1892, Dmitri Ivanowski showed that this disease could be transmitted in this way even after the Chamberland-Pasteur filter had removed all viable bacteria from the extract.
7.21.21	Still, it was many years before it was proven that these “filterable” infectious agents were not simply very small bacteria but were a new type of very small, disease-causing particle.
7.21.22	Virions, single virus particles, are very small, about 20–250 nanometers in diameter.
7.21.23	These individual virus particles are the infectious form of a virus outside the host cell.
7.21.24	Unlike bacteria (which are about 100-times larger), we cannot see viruses with a light microscope, with the exception of some large virions of the poxvirus family.
7.21.25	It was not until the development of the electron microscope in the late 1930s that scientists got their first good view of the structure of the tobacco mosaic virus (TMV) (Figure 21.1) and other viruses (Figure 21.2).
7.21.26	The surface structure of virions can be observed by both scanning and transmission electron microscopy, whereas the internal structures of the virus can only be observed in images from a transmission electron microscope.
7.21.27	The use of these technologies has allowed for the discovery of many viruses of all types of living organisms.
7.21.28	They were initially grouped by shared morphology.
7.21.29	Later, groups of viruses were classified by the type of nucleic acid they contained, DNA or RNA, and whether their nucleic acid was single- or double-stranded.
7.21.30	More recently, molecular analysis of viral replicative cycles has further refined their classification.
7.21.31	In these transmission electron micrographs, (a) a virus is dwarfed by the bacterial cell it infects, while (b) these E. coli cells are dwarfed by cultured colon cells.
7.21.32	Evolution of Viruses
7.21.33	Although biologists have accumulated a significant amount of knowledge about how present-day viruses evolve, much less is known about how viruses originated in the first place.
7.21.34	When exploring the evolutionary history of most organisms, scientists can look at fossil records and similar historic evidence.
7.21.35	However, viruses do not fossilize, so researchers must conjecture by investigating how today’s viruses evolve and by using biochemical and genetic information to create speculative virus histories.
7.21.36	While most findings agree that viruses don’t have a single common ancestor, scholars have yet to find a single hypothesis about virus origins that is fully accepted in the field.
7.21.37	One such hypothesis, called devolution or the regressive hypothesis, proposes to explain the origin of viruses by suggesting that viruses evolved from free-living cells.
7.21.38	However, many components of how this process might have occurred are a mystery.
7.21.39	A second hypothesis (called escapist or the progressive hypothesis) accounts for viruses having either an RNA or a DNA genome and suggests that viruses originated from RNA and DNA molecules that escaped from a host cell.
7.21.40	A third hypothesis posits a system of self-replication similar to that of other self-replicating molecules, likely evolving alongside the cells they rely on as hosts; studies of some plant pathogens support this hypothesis.
7.21.41	As technology advances, scientists may develop and refine further hypotheses to explain the origin of viruses.
7.21.42	The emerging field called virus molecular systematics attempts to do just that through comparisons of sequenced genetic material.
7.21.43	These researchers hope to one day better understand the origin of viruses, a discovery that could lead to advances in the treatments for the ailments they produce.
7.21.44	Viral Morphology Viruses are acellular, meaning they are biological entities that do not have a cellular structure.
7.21.45	They therefore lack most of the components of cells, such as organelles, ribosomes, and the plasma membrane.
7.21.46	A virion consists of a nucleic acid core, an outer protein coating or capsid, and sometimes an outer envelope made of protein and phospholipid membranes derived from the host cell.
7.21.47	Viruses may also contain additional proteins, such as enzymes.
7.21.48	The most obvious difference between members of viral families is their morphology, which is quite diverse.
7.21.49	An interesting feature of viral complexity is that the complexity of the host does not correlate with the complexity of the virion.
7.21.50	Some of the most complex virion structures are observed in bacteriophages, viruses that infect the simplest living organisms, bacteria.
7.21.51	Morphology Viruses come in many shapes and sizes, but these are consistent and distinct for each viral family.
7.21.52	All virions have a nucleic acid genome covered by a protective layer of proteins, called a capsid.
7.21.53	The capsid is made up of protein subunits called capsomeres.
7.21.54	Some viral capsids are simple polyhedral “spheres,” whereas others are quite complex in structure.
7.21.55	In general, the shapes of viruses are classified into four groups: filamentous, isometric (or icosahedral), enveloped, and head and tail.
7.21.56	Filamentous viruses are long and cylindrical.
7.21.57	Many plant viruses are filamentous, including TMV.
7.21.58	Isometric viruses have shapes that are roughly spherical, such as poliovirus or herpesviruses.
7.21.59	Enveloped viruses have membranes surrounding capsids.
7.21.60	Animal viruses, such as HIV, are frequently enveloped.
7.21.61	Head and tail viruses infect bacteria and have a head that is similar to icosahedral viruses and a tail shape like filamentous viruses.
7.21.62	Many viruses use some sort of glycoprotein to attach to their host cells via molecules on the cell called viral receptors (Figure 21.3).
7.21.63	For these viruses, attachment is a requirement for later penetration of the cell membrane, so they can complete their replication inside the cell.
7.21.64	The receptors that viruses use are molecules that are normally found on cell surfaces and have their own physiological functions.
7.21.65	Viruses have simply evolved to make use of these molecules for their own replication.
7.21.66	For example, HIV uses the CD4 molecule on T lymphocytes as one of its receptors.
7.21.67	CD4 is a type of molecule called a cell adhesion molecule, which functions to keep different types of immune cells in close proximity to each other during the generation of a T lymphocyte immune response.
7.21.68	The KSHV virus binds the xCT receptor on the surface of human cells.
7.21.69	xCT receptors protect cells against stress.
7.21.70	Stressed cells express more xCT receptors than non-stressed cells.
7.21.71	The KSHV virion causes cells to become stressed, thereby increasing expression of the receptor to which it binds.
7.21.72	Among the most complex virions known, the T4 bacteriophage, which infects the Escherichia coli bacterium, has a tail structure that the virus uses to attach to host cells and a head structure that houses its DNA.
7.21.73	Adenovirus, a non-enveloped animal virus that causes respiratory illnesses in humans, uses glycoprotein spikes protruding from its capsomeres to attach to host cells.
7.21.74	Non-enveloped viruses also include those that cause polio (poliovirus), plantar warts (papillomavirus), and hepatitis A (hepatitis A virus).
7.21.75	Enveloped virions like HIV, the causative agent in AIDS, consist of nucleic acid (RNA in the case of HIV) and capsid proteins surrounded by a phospholipid bilayer envelope and its associated proteins.
7.21.76	Glycoproteins embedded in the viral envelope are used to attach to host cells.
7.21.77	Other envelope proteins are the matrix proteins that stabilize the envelope and often play a role in the assembly of progeny virions.
7.21.78	Chicken pox, influenza, and mumps are examples of diseases caused by viruses with envelopes.
7.21.79	Because of the fragility of the envelope, non-enveloped viruses are more resistant to changes in temperature, pH, and some disinfectants than enveloped viruses.
7.21.80	Overall, the shape of the virion and the presence or absence of an envelope tell us little about what disease the virus may cause or what species it might infect, but they are still useful means to begin viral classification (Figure 21.4).
7.21.81	Viruses can be either complex in shape or relatively simple.
7.21.82	This figure shows three relatively complex virions: the bacteriophage T4, with its DNA-containing head group and tail fibers that attach to host cells; adenovirus, which uses spikes from its capsid to bind to host cells; and HIV, which uses glycoproteins embedded in its envelope to bind to host cells.
7.21.83	Notice that HIV has proteins called matrix proteins, internal to the envelope, which help stabilize virion shape.
7.21.84	Types of Nucleic Acid Unlike nearly all living organisms that use DNA as their genetic material, viruses may use either DNA or RNA as theirs.
7.21.85	The virus core contains the genome or total genetic content of the virus.
7.21.86	Viral genomes tend to be small, containing only those genes that encode proteins that the virus cannot get from the host cell.
7.21.87	This genetic material may be single- or doublestranded.
7.21.88	It may also be linear or circular.
7.21.89	While most viruses contain a single nucleic acid, others have genomes that have several, which are called segments.
7.21.90	In DNA viruses, the viral DNA directs the host cell’s replication proteins to synthesize new copies of the viral genome and to transcribe and translate that genome into viral proteins.
7.21.91	DNA viruses cause human diseases, such as chickenpox, hepatitis B, and some venereal diseases, like herpes and genital warts.
7.21.92	RNA viruses contain only RNA as their genetic material.
7.21.93	To replicate their genomes in the host cell, the RNA viruses encode enzymes that can replicate RNA into DNA, which cannot be done by the host cell.
7.21.94	These RNA polymerase enzymes are more likely to make copying errors than DNA polymerases, and therefore often make mistakes during transcription.
7.21.95	For this reason, mutations in RNA viruses occur more frequently than in DNA viruses.
7.21.96	This causes them to change and adapt more rapidly to their host.
7.21.97	Human diseases caused by RNA viruses include hepatitis C, measles, and rabies.
7.21.98	Virus Classification
7.21.99	To understand the features shared among different groups of viruses, a classification scheme is necessary.
7.21.100	As most viruses are not thought to have evolved from a common ancestor, however, the methods that scientists use to classify living things are not very useful.
7.21.101	Biologists have used several classification systems in the past, based on the morphology and genetics of the different viruses.
7.21.102	However, these earlier classification methods grouped viruses differently, based on which features of the virus they were using to classify them.
7.21.103	The most commonly used classification method today is called the Baltimore classification scheme and is based on how messenger RNA (mRNA) is generated in each particular type of virus.
7.21.104	Past Systems of Classification Viruses are classified in several ways: by factors such as their core content (Table 21.1 and Figure 21.3), the structure of their capsids, and whether they have an outer envelope.
7.21.105	The type of genetic material (DNA or RNA) and its structure (single- or double-stranded, linear or circular, and segmented or non-segmented) are used to classify the virus core structures.
7.21.106	Viruses are classified based on their core genetic material and capsid design.
7.21.107	(a)
7.21.108	Rabies virus has a single-stranded RNA (ssRNA) core and an enveloped helical capsid, whereas (b) variola virus, the causative agent of smallpox, has a double-stranded DNA (dsDNA) core and a complex capsid.
7.21.109	Rabies transmission occurs when saliva from an infected mammal enters a wound.
7.21.110	The virus travels through neurons in the peripheral nervous system to the central nervous system where it impairs brain function, and then travels to other tissues.
7.21.111	The virus can infect any mammal, and most die within weeks of infection.
7.21.112	Smallpox is a human virus transmitted by inhalation of the variola virus, localized in the skin, mouth, and throat, which causes a characteristic rash.
7.21.113	Before its eradication in 1979, infection resulted in a 30–35 percent mortality rate.
7.21.114	Viruses can also be classified by the design of their capsids (Figure 21.4 and Figure 21.5).
7.21.115	Capsids are classified as naked icosahedral, enveloped icosahedral, enveloped helical, naked helical, and complex (Figure 21.6 and Figure 21.7).
7.21.116	The type of genetic material (DNA or RNA) and its structure (single- or double-stranded, linear or circular, and segmented or nonsegmented) are used to classify the virus core structures (Table 21.2).
7.21.117	Adenovirus (left) is depicted with a double-stranded DNA genome enclosed in an icosahedral capsid that is 90–100 nm across.
7.21.118	The virus, shown clustered in the micrograph (right), is transmitted orally and causes a variety of illnesses in vertebrates, including human eye and respiratory infections.
7.21.119	( Transmission electron micrographs of various viruses show their structures.
7.21.120	The capsid of the (a) polio virus is naked icosahedral; (b) the Epstein-Barr virus capsid is enveloped icosahedral; (c) the mumps virus capsid is an enveloped helix; (d) the tobacco mosaic virus capsid is naked helical; and (e) the herpesvirus capsid is complex.
7.21.121	Baltimore Classification
7.21.122	The most commonly used system of virus classification was developed by Nobel Prize-winning biologist David Baltimore in the early 1970s.
7.21.123	In addition to the differences in morphology and genetics mentioned above, the Baltimore classification scheme groups viruses according to how the mRNA is produced during the replicative cycle of the virus.
7.21.124	Group I viruses contain double-stranded DNA (dsDNA) as their genome.
7.21.125	Their mRNA is produced by transcription in much the same way as with cellular DNA.
7.21.126	Group II viruses have single-stranded DNA (ssDNA) as their genome.
7.21.127	They convert their single-stranded genomes into a dsDNA intermediate before transcription to mRNA can occur.
7.21.128	Group III viruses use dsRNA as their genome.
7.21.129	The strands separate, and one of them is used as a template for the generation of mRNA using the RNA-dependent RNA polymerase encoded by the virus.
7.21.130	Group IV viruses have ssRNA as their genome with a positive polarity.
7.21.131	Positive polarity means that the genomic RNA can serve directly as mRNA.
7.21.132	Intermediates of dsRNA, called replicative intermediates, are made in the process of copying the genomic RNA.
7.21.133	Multiple, full-length RNA strands of negative polarity (complimentary to the positive-stranded genomic RNA) are formed from these intermediates, which may then serve as templates for the production of RNA with positive polarity, including both full-length genomic RNA and shorter viral mRNAs.
7.21.134	Group V viruses contain ssRNA genomes with a negative polarity, meaning that their sequence is complementary to the mRNA.
7.21.135	As with Group IV viruses, dsRNA intermediates are used to make copies of the genome and produce mRNA.
7.21.136	In this case, the negative-stranded genome can be converted directly to mRNA.
7.21.137	Additionally, fulllength positive RNA strands are made to serve as templates for the production of the negative-stranded genome.
7.21.138	Group VI viruses have diploid (two copies) ssRNA genomes that must be converted, using the enzyme reverse transcriptase, to dsDNA; the dsDNA is then transported to the nucleus of the host cell and inserted into the host genome.
7.21.139	Then, mRNA can be produced by transcription of the viral DNA that was integrated into the host genome.
7.21.140	Group VII viruses have partial dsDNA genomes and make ssRNA intermediates that act as mRNA, but are also converted back into dsDNA genomes by reverse transcriptase, necessary for genome replication.
7.21.141	The characteristics of each group in the Baltimore classification are summarized in Table 21.3 with examples of each group.
7.21.142	Virus Infections and Hosts certain species of hosts and only certain cells within that host.
7.21.143	Cells that a virus may use to replicate are called permissive.
7.21.144	For most viruses, the molecular basis for this specificity is that a particular surface molecule known as the viral receptor must be found on the host cell surface for the virus to attach.
7.21.145	Also, metabolic and host cell immune response differences seen in different cell types based on differential gene expression are a likely factor in which cells a virus may target for replication.
7.21.146	The permissive cell must make the substances that the virus needs or the virus will not be able to replicate there.
7.21.147	Steps of Virus Infections
7.21.148	A virus must use cell processes to replicate.
7.21.149	The viral replication cycle can produce dramatic biochemical and structural changes in the host cell, which may cause cell damage.
7.21.150	These changes, called cytopathic (causing cell damage) effects, can change cell functions or even destroy the cell.
7.21.151	Some infected cells, such as those infected by the common cold virus known as rhinovirus, die through lysis (bursting) or apoptosis (programmed cell death or “cell suicide”), releasing all progeny virions at once.
7.21.152	The symptoms of viral diseases result from the immune response to the virus, which attempts to control and eliminate the virus from the body, and from cell damage caused by the virus.
7.21.153	Many animal viruses, such as HIV (human immunodeficiency virus), leave the infected cells of the immune system by a process known as budding, where virions leave the cell individually.
7.21.154	During the budding process, the cell does not undergo lysis and is not immediately killed.
7.21.155	However, the damage to the cells that the virus infects may make it impossible for the cells to function normally, even though the cells remain alive for a period of time.
7.21.156	Most productive viral infections follow similar steps in the virus replication cycle: attachment, penetration, uncoating, replication, assembly, and release (Figure 21.8).
7.21.157	Attachment A virus attaches to a specific receptor site on the host cell membrane through attachment proteins in the capsid or via glycoproteins embedded in the viral envelope.
7.21.158	The specificity of this interaction determines the host—and the cells within the host—that can be infected by a particular virus.
7.21.159	This can be illustrated by thinking of several keys and several locks, where each key will fit only one specific lock.
7.21.160	Entry
7.21.161	The nucleic acid of bacteriophages enters the host cell naked, leaving the capsid outside the cell.
7.21.162	Plant and animal viruses can enter through endocytosis, in which the cell membrane surrounds and engulfs the entire virus.
7.21.163	Some enveloped viruses enter the cell when the viral envelope fuses directly with the cell membrane.
7.21.164	Once inside the cell, the viral capsid is degraded, and the viral nucleic acid is released, which then becomes available for replication and transcription.
7.21.165	Replication and Assembly
7.21.166	The replication mechanism depends on the viral genome.
7.21.167	DNA viruses usually use host cell proteins and enzymes to make additional DNA that is transcribed to messenger RNA (mRNA), which is then used to direct protein synthesis.
7.21.168	RNA viruses usually use the RNA core as a template for synthesis of viral genomic RNA and mRNA.
7.21.169	The viral mRNA directs the host cell to synthesize viral enzymes and capsid proteins, and assemble new virions.
7.21.170	Of course, there are exceptions to this pattern.
7.21.171	If a host cell does not provide the enzymes necessary for viral replication, viral genes supply the information to direct synthesis of the missing proteins.
7.21.172	Retroviruses, such as HIV, have an RNA genome that must be reverse transcribed into DNA, which then is incorporated into the host cell genome.
7.21.173	They are within group VI of the Baltimore classification scheme.
7.21.174	To convert RNA into DNA, retroviruses must contain genes that encode the virus-specific enzyme reverse transcriptase that transcribes an RNA template to DNA.
7.21.175	Reverse transcription never occurs in uninfected host cells—the needed enzyme reverse transcriptase is only derived from the expression of viral genes within the infected host cells.
7.21.176	The fact that HIV produces some of its own enzymes not found in the host has allowed researchers to develop drugs that inhibit these enzymes.
7.21.177	These drugs, including the reverse transcriptase inhibitor AZT, inhibit HIV replication by reducing the activity of the enzyme without affecting the host’s metabolism.
7.21.178	This approach has led to the development of a variety of drugs used to treat HIV and has been effective at reducing the number of infectious virions (copies of viral RNA) in the blood to non-detectable levels in many HIV-infected individuals.
7.21.179	Egress
7.21.180	The last stage of viral replication is the release of the new virions produced in the host organism, where they are able to infect adjacent cells and repeat the replication cycle.
7.21.181	As you’ve learned, some viruses are released when the host cell dies, and other viruses can leave infected cells by budding through the membrane without directly killing the cell.
7.21.182	In influenza virus infection, glycoproteins attach to a host epithelial cell.
7.21.183	As a result, the virus is engulfed.
7.21.184	RNA and proteins are made and assembled into new virions.
7.21.185	Different Hosts and Their Viruses
7.21.186	As you’ve learned, viruses are often very specific as to which hosts and which cells within the host they will infect.
7.21.187	This feature of a virus makes it specific to one or a few species of life on Earth.
7.21.188	On the other hand, so many different types of viruses exist on Earth that nearly every living organism has its own set of viruses that tries to infect its cells.
7.21.189	Even the smallest and simplest of cells, prokaryotic bacteria, may be attacked by specific types of viruses.
7.21.190	This transmission electron micrograph shows bacteriophages attached to a bacterial cell.
7.21.191	(credit: modification of work by Dr. Graham Beards; scale-bar data from Matt Russell)
7.21.192	Bacteriophages are viruses that infect bacteria (Figure 21.9).
7.21.193	When infection of a cell by a bacteriophage results in the production of new virions, the infection is said to be productive.
7.21.194	If the virions are released by bursting the cell, the virus replicates by means of a lytic cycle (Figure 21.10).
7.21.195	An example of a lytic bacteriophage is T4, which infects Escherichia coli found in the human intestinal tract.
7.21.196	Sometimes, however, a virus can remain within the cell without being released.
7.21.197	For example, when a temperate bacteriophage infects a bacterial cell, it replicates by means of a lysogenic cycle (Figure 21.10), and the viral genome is incorporated into the genome of the host cell.
7.21.198	When the phage DNA is incorporated into the host cell genome, it is called a prophage.
7.21.199	An example of a lysogenic bacteriophage is the λ (lambda) virus, which also infects the E. coli bacterium.
7.21.200	Viruses that infect plant or animal cells may also undergo infections where they are not producing virions for long periods.
7.21.201	An example is the animal herpesviruses, including herpes simplex viruses, the cause of oral and genital herpes in humans.
7.21.202	In a process called latency, these viruses can exist in nervous tissue for long periods of time without producing new virions, only to leave latency periodically and cause lesions in the skin where the virus replicates.
7.21.203	Even though there are similarities between lysogeny and latency, the term lysogenic cycle is usually reserved to describe bacteriophages.
7.21.204	Latency will be described in more detail below.
7.21.205	A temperate bacteriophage has both lytic and lysogenic cycles.
7.21.206	In the lytic cycle, the phage replicates and lyses the host cell.
7.21.207	In the lysogenic cycle, phage DNA is incorporated into the host genome, where it is passed on to subsequent generations.
7.21.208	Environmental stressors such as starvation or exposure to toxic chemicals may cause the prophage to excise and enter the lytic cycle.
7.21.209	Animal Viruses Animal viruses, unlike the viruses of plants and bacteria, do not have to penetrate a cell wall to gain access to the host cell.
7.21.210	Non-enveloped or “naked” animal viruses may enter cells in two different ways.
7.21.211	As a protein in the viral capsid binds to its receptor on the host cell, the virus may be taken inside the cell via a vesicle during the normal cell process of receptormediated endocytosis.
7.21.212	An alternative method of cell penetration used by non-enveloped viruses is for capsid proteins to undergo shape changes after binding to the receptor, creating channels in the host cell membrane.
7.21.213	The viral genome is then “injected” into the host cell through these channels in a manner analogous to that used by many bacteriophages.
7.21.214	Enveloped viruses also have two ways of entering cells after binding to their receptors: receptor-mediated endocytosis, or fusion.
7.21.215	Many enveloped viruses enter the cell by receptor-mediated endocytosis in a fashion similar to some non-enveloped viruses.
7.21.216	On the other hand, fusion only occurs with enveloped virions.
7.21.217	These viruses, which include HIV among others, use special fusion proteins in their envelopes to cause the envelope to fuse with the plasma membrane of the cell, thus releasing the genome and capsid of the virus into the cell cytoplasm.
7.21.218	After making their proteins and copying their genomes, animal viruses complete the assembly of new virions and exit the cell.
7.21.219	As we have already discussed using the example of HIV, enveloped animal viruses may bud from the cell membrane as they assemble themselves, taking a piece of the cell’s plasma membrane in the process.
7.21.220	On the other hand, non-enveloped viral progeny, such as rhinoviruses, accumulate in infected cells until there is a signal for lysis or apoptosis, and all virions are released together.
7.21.221	As you will learn in the next module, animal viruses are associated with a variety of human diseases.
7.21.222	Some of them follow the classic pattern of acute disease, where symptoms get increasingly worse for a short period followed by the elimination of the virus from the body by the immune system and eventual recovery from the infection.
7.21.223	Examples of acute viral diseases are the common cold and influenza.
7.21.224	Other viruses cause long-term chronic infections, such as the virus causing hepatitis C, whereas others, like herpes simplex virus, only cause intermittent symptoms.
7.21.225	Still other viruses, such as human herpesviruses 6 and 7, which in some cases can cause the minor childhood disease roseola, often successfully cause productive infections without causing any symptoms at all in the host, and thus we say these patients have an asymptomatic infection.
7.21.226	In hepatitis C infections, the virus grows and reproduces in liver cells, causing low levels of liver damage.
7.21.227	The damage is so low that infected individuals are often unaware that they are infected, and many infections are detected only by routine blood work on patients with risk factors such as intravenous drug use.
7.21.228	On the other hand, since many of the symptoms of viral diseases are caused by immune responses, a lack of symptoms is an indication of a weak immune response to the virus.
7.21.229	This allows for the virus to escape elimination by the immune system and persist in individuals for years, all the while producing low levels of progeny virions in what is known as a chronic viral disease.
7.21.230	Chronic infection of the liver by this virus leads to a much greater chance of developing liver cancer, sometimes as much as 30 years after the initial infection.
7.21.231	As already discussed, herpes simplex virus can remain in a state of latency in nervous tissue for months, even years.
7.21.232	As the virus “hides” in the tissue and makes few if any viral proteins, there is nothing for the immune response to act against, and immunity to the virus slowly declines.
7.21.233	Under certain conditions, including various types of physical and psychological stress, the latent herpes simplex virus may be reactivated and undergo a lytic replication cycle in the skin, causing the lesions associated with the disease.
7.21.234	Once virions are produced in the skin and viral proteins are synthesized, the immune response is again stimulated and resolves the skin lesions in a few days by destroying viruses in the skin.
7.21.235	As a result of this type of replicative cycle, appearances of cold sores and genital herpes outbreaks only occur intermittently, even though the viruses remain in the nervous tissue for life.
7.21.236	Latent infections are common with other herpesviruses as well, including the varicellazoster virus that causes chickenpox.
7.21.237	After having a chickenpox infection in childhood, the varicella-zoster virus can remain latent for many years and reactivate in adults to cause the painful condition known as “shingles”
7.21.238	(Figure 21.11ab).
7.21.239	(a)
7.21.240	Varicella-zoster, the virus that causes chickenpox, has an enveloped icosahedral capsid visible in this transmission electron micrograph.
7.21.241	Its double-stranded DNA genome becomes incorporated in the host DNA and can reactivate after latency in the form of (b) shingles, often exhibiting a rash.
7.21.242	Some animal-infecting viruses, including the hepatitis C virus discussed above, are known as oncogenic viruses: They have the ability to cause cancer.
7.21.243	These viruses interfere with the normal regulation of the host cell cycle either by either introducing genes that stimulate unregulated cell growth (oncogenes) or by interfering with the expression of genes that inhibit cell growth.
7.21.244	Oncogenic viruses can be either DNA or RNA viruses.
7.21.245	Cancers known to be associated with viral infections include cervical cancer caused by human papillomavirus (HPV)
7.21.246	(Figure 21.12), liver cancer caused by hepatitis B virus, T-cell leukemia, and several types of lymphoma.
7.21.247	HPV, or human papillomavirus, has a naked icosahedral capsid visible in this transmission electron micrograph and a double-stranded DNA genome that is incorporated into the host DNA.
7.21.248	The virus, which is sexually transmitted, is oncogenic and can lead to cervical cancer.
7.21.249	Plant Viruses Plant viruses, like other viruses, contain a core of either DNA or RNA.
7.21.250	You have already learned about one of these, the tobacco mosaic virus.
7.21.251	As plant viruses have a cell wall to protect their cells, these viruses do not use receptor-mediated endocytosis to enter host cells as is seen with animal viruses.
7.21.252	For many plant viruses to be transferred from plant to plant, damage to some of the plants’ cells must occur to allow the virus to enter a new host.
7.21.253	This damage is often caused by weather, insects, animals, fire, or human activities like farming or landscaping.
7.21.254	Additionally, plant offspring may inherit viral diseases from parent plants.
7.21.255	Plant viruses can be transmitted by a variety of vectors, through contact with an infected plant’s sap, by living organisms such as insects and nematodes, and through pollen.
7.21.256	When plants viruses are transferred between different plants, this is known as horizontal transmission, and when they are inherited from a parent, this is called vertical transmission.
7.21.257	Symptoms of viral diseases vary according to the virus and its host (Table 21.4).
7.21.258	One common symptom is hyperplasia, the abnormal proliferation of cells that causes the appearance of plant tumors known as galls.
7.21.259	Other viruses induce hypoplasia, or decreased cell growth, in the leaves of plants, causing thin, yellow areas to appear.
7.21.260	Still other viruses affect the plant by directly killing plant cells, a process known as cell necrosis.
7.21.261	Other symptoms of plant viruses include malformed leaves, black streaks on the stems of the plants, altered growth of stems, leaves, or fruits, and ring spots, which are circular or linear areas of discoloration found in a leaf.
7.21.262	Plant viruses can seriously disrupt crop growth and development, significantly affecting our food supply.
7.21.263	They are responsible for poor crop quality and quantity globally, and can bring about huge economic losses annually.
7.21.264	Others viruses may damage plants used in landscaping.
7.21.265	Some viruses that infect agricultural food plants include the name of the plant they infect, such as tomato spotted wilt virus, bean common mosaic virus, and cucumber mosaic virus.
7.21.266	In plants used for landscaping, two of the most common viruses are peony ring spot and rose mosaic virus.
7.21.267	There are far too many plant viruses to discuss each in detail, but symptoms of bean common mosaic virus result in lowered bean production and stunted, unproductive plants.
7.21.268	In the ornamental rose, the rose mosaic disease causes wavy yellow lines and colored splotches on the leaves of the plant.
7.21.269	Prevention and Treatment of Viral Infections Viruses cause a variety of diseases in animals, including humans, ranging from the common cold to potentially fatal illnesses like meningitis (Figure 21.13).
7.21.270	These diseases can be treated by antiviral drugs or by vaccines, but some viruses, such as HIV, are capable of both avoiding the immune response and mutating to become resistant to antiviral drugs.
7.21.271	Viruses can cause dozens of ailments in humans, ranging from mild illnesses to serious diseases.
7.21.272	Vaccines for Prevention
7.21.273	While we do have limited numbers of effective antiviral drugs, such as those used to treat HIV and influenza, the primary method of controlling viral disease is by vaccination, which is intended to prevent outbreaks by building immunity to a virus or virus family (Figure 21.14).
7.21.274	Vaccines may be prepared using live viruses, killed viruses, or molecular subunits of the virus.
7.21.275	The killed viral vaccines and subunit viruses are both incapable of causing disease.
7.21.276	Live viral vaccines are designed in the laboratory to cause few symptoms in recipients while giving them protective immunity against future infections.
7.21.277	Polio was one disease that represented a milestone in the use of vaccines.
7.21.278	Mass immunization campaigns in the 1950s (killed vaccine) and 1960s (live vaccine) significantly reduced the incidence of the disease, which caused muscle paralysis in children and generated a great amount of fear in the general population when regional epidemics occurred.
7.21.279	The success of the polio vaccine paved the way for the routine dispensation of childhood vaccines against measles, mumps, rubella, chickenpox, and other diseases.
7.21.280	The danger of using live vaccines, which are usually more effective than killed vaccines, is the low but significant danger that these viruses will revert to their disease-causing form by back mutations.
7.21.281	Live vaccines are usually made by attenuating (weakening) the “wild-type” (disease-causing) virus by growing it in the laboratory in tissues or at temperatures different from what the virus is accustomed to in the host.
7.21.282	Adaptations to these new cells or temperatures induce mutations in the genomes of the virus, allowing it to grow better in the laboratory while inhibiting its ability to cause disease when reintroduced into conditions found in the host.
7.21.283	These attenuated viruses thus still cause infection, but they do not grow very well, allowing the immune response to develop in time to prevent major disease.
7.21.284	Back mutations occur when the vaccine undergoes mutations in the host such that it readapts to the host and can again cause disease, which can then be spread to other humans in an epidemic.
7.21.285	This type of scenario happened as recently as 2007 in Nigeria where mutations in a polio vaccine led to an epidemic of polio in that country.
7.21.286	Some vaccines are in continuous development because certain viruses, such as influenza and HIV, have a high mutation rate compared to other viruses and normal host cells.
