7.21.287	With influenza, mutations in the surface molecules of the virus help the organism evade the protective immunity that may have been obtained in a previous influenza season, making it necessary for individuals to get vaccinated every year.
7.21.288	Other viruses, such as those that cause the childhood diseases measles, mumps, and rubella, mutate so infrequently that the same vaccine is used year after year.
7.21.289	Vaccines and Anti-viral Drugs for Treatment
7.21.290	In some cases, vaccines can be used to treat an active viral infection.
7.21.291	The concept behind this is that by giving the vaccine, immunity is boosted without adding more disease-causing virus.
7.21.292	In the case of rabies, a fatal neurological disease transmitted via the saliva of rabies virus-infected animals, the progression of the disease from the time of the animal bite to the time it enters the central nervous system may be 2 weeks or longer.
7.21.293	This is enough time to vaccinate an individual who suspects that they have been bitten by a rabid animal, and their boosted immune response is sufficient to prevent the virus from entering nervous tissue.
7.21.294	Thus, the potentially fatal neurological consequences of the disease are averted, and the individual only has to recover from the infected bite.
7.21.295	This approach is also being used for the treatment of Ebola, one of the fastest and most deadly viruses on earth.
7.21.296	Transmitted by bats and great apes, this disease can cause death in 70–90 percent of infected humans within 2 weeks.
7.21.297	Using newly developed vaccines that boost the immune response in this way, there is hope that affected individuals will be better able to control the virus, potentially saving a greater percentage of infected persons from a rapid and very painful death.
7.21.298	Another way of treating viral infections is the use of antiviral drugs.
7.21.299	These drugs often have limited success in curing viral disease, but in many cases, they have been used to control and reduce symptoms for a wide variety of viral diseases.
7.21.300	For most viruses, these drugs can inhibit the virus by blocking the actions of one or more of its proteins.
7.21.301	It is important that the targeted proteins be encoded by viral genes and that these molecules are not present in a healthy host cell.
7.21.302	In this way, viral growth is inhibited without damaging the host.
7.21.303	There are large numbers of antiviral drugs available to treat infections, some specific for a particular virus and others that can affect multiple viruses.
7.21.304	Antivirals have been developed to treat genital herpes (herpes simplex II) and influenza.
7.21.305	For genital herpes, drugs such as acyclovir can reduce the number and duration of episodes of active viral disease, during which patients develop viral lesions in their skin cells.
7.21.306	As the virus remains latent in nervous tissue of the body for life, this drug is not curative but can make the symptoms of the disease more manageable.
7.21.307	For influenza, drugs like Tamiflu (oseltamivir)
7.21.308	(Figure 21.15) can reduce the duration of “flu” symptoms by 1 or 2 days, but the drug does not prevent symptoms entirely.
7.21.309	Tamiflu works by inhibiting an enzyme (viral neuraminidase) that allows new virions to leave their infected cells.
7.21.310	Thus, Tamiflu inhibits the spread of virus from infected to uninfected cells.
7.21.311	Other antiviral drugs, such as Ribavirin, have been used to treat a variety of viral infections, although its mechanism of action against certain viruses remains unclear.
7.21.312	(a)
7.21.313	Tamiflu inhibits a viral enzyme called neuraminidase (NA) found in the influenza viral envelope.
7.21.314	(b)
7.21.315	Neuraminidase cleaves the connection between viral hemagglutinin (HA), also found in the viral envelope, and glycoproteins on the host cell surface.
7.21.316	Inhibition of neuraminidase prevents the virus from detaching from the host cell, thereby blocking further infection.
7.21.317	By far, the most successful use of antivirals has been in the treatment of the retrovirus HIV, which causes a disease that, if untreated, is usually fatal within 10–12 years after infection.
7.21.318	Anti-HIV drugs have been able to control viral replication to the point that individuals receiving these drugs survive for a significantly longer time than the untreated.
7.21.319	Anti-HIV drugs inhibit viral replication at many different phases of the HIV replicative cycle (Figure 21.16).
7.21.320	Drugs have been developed that inhibit the fusion of the HIV viral envelope with the plasma membrane of the host cell (fusion inhibitors), the conversion of its RNA genome into double-stranded DNA (reverse transcriptase inhibitors), the integration of the viral DNA into the host genome (integrase inhibitors), and the processing of viral proteins (protease inhibitors).
7.21.321	HIV, an enveloped, icosahedral virus, attaches to the CD4 receptor of an immune cell and fuses with the cell membrane.
7.21.322	Viral contents are released into the cell, where viral enzymes convert the single-stranded RNA genome into DNA and incorporate it into the host genome.
7.21.323	(credit: NIAID, NIH)
7.21.324	When any of these drugs are used individually, the high mutation rate of the virus allows it to easily and rapidly develop resistance to the drug, limiting the drug’s effectiveness.
7.21.325	The breakthrough in the treatment of HIV was the development of HAART, highly active anti-retroviral therapy, which involves a mixture of different drugs, sometimes called a drug “cocktail.
7.21.326	”
7.21.327	By attacking the virus at different stages of its replicative cycle, it is much more difficult for the virus to develop resistance to multiple drugs at the same time.
7.21.328	Still, even with the use of combination HAART therapy, there is concern that, over time, the virus will develop resistance to this therapy.
7.21.329	Thus, new anti-HIV drugs are constantly being developed with the hope of continuing the battle against this highly fatal virus.
7.21.330	Applied Virology
7.21.331	The study of viruses has led to the development of a variety of new ways to treat non-viral diseases.
7.21.332	Viruses have been used in gene therapy.
7.21.333	Gene therapy is used to treat genetic diseases such as severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID), a heritable, recessive disease in which children are born with severely compromised immune systems.
7.21.334	One common type of SCID is due to the lack of an enzyme, adenosine deaminase (ADA), which breaks down purine bases.
7.21.335	To treat this disease by gene therapy, bone marrow cells are taken from a SCID patient and the ADA gene is inserted.
7.21.336	This is where viruses come in, and their use relies on their ability to penetrate living cells and bring genes in with them.
7.21.337	Viruses such as adenovirus, an upper respiratory human virus, are modified by the addition of the ADA gene, and the virus then transports this gene into the cell.
7.21.338	The modified cells, now capable of making ADA, are then given back to the patients in the hope of curing them.
7.21.339	Gene therapy using viruses as carrier of genes (viral vectors), although still experimental, holds promise for the treatment of many genetic diseases.
7.21.340	Still, many technological problems need to be solved for this approach to be a viable method for treating genetic disease.
7.21.341	Another medical use for viruses relies on their specificity and ability to kill the cells they infect.
7.21.342	Oncolytic viruses are engineered in the laboratory specifically to attack and kill cancer cells.
7.21.343	A genetically modified adenovirus known as H101 has been used since 2005 in clinical trials in China to treat head and neck cancers.
7.21.344	The results have been promising, with a greater short-term response rate to the combination of chemotherapy and viral therapy than to chemotherapy treatment alone.
7.21.345	This ongoing research may herald the beginning of a new age of cancer therapy, where viruses are engineered to find and specifically kill cancer cells, regardless of where in the body they may have spread.
7.21.346	A third use of viruses in medicine relies on their specificity and involves using bacteriophages in the treatment of bacterial infections.
7.21.347	Bacterial diseases have been treated with antibiotics since the 1940s.
7.21.348	However, over time, many bacteria have developed resistance to antibiotics.
7.21.349	A good example is methicillinresistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA, pronounced “mersa”), an infection commonly acquired in hospitals.
7.21.350	This bacterium is resistant to a variety of antibiotics, making it difficult to treat.
7.21.351	The use of bacteriophages specific for such bacteria would bypass their resistance to antibiotics and specifically kill them.
7.21.352	Although phage therapy is in use in the Republic of Georgia to treat antibiotic-resistant bacteria, its use to treat human diseases has not been approved in most countries.
7.21.353	However, the safety of the treatment was confirmed in the United States when the U.S. Food and Drug Administration approved spraying meats with bacteriophages to destroy the food pathogen Listeria.
7.21.354	As more and more antibioticresistant strains of bacteria evolve, the use of bacteriophages might be a potential solution to the problem, and the development of phage therapy is of much interest to researchers worldwide.
7.21.355	Prions and viroids are pathogens (agents with the ability to cause disease) that have simpler structures than viruses but, in the case of prions, still can produce deadly diseases.
7.21.356	Prions Prions, so-called because they are proteinaceous, are infectious particles—smaller than viruses—that contain no nucleic acids (neither DNA nor RNA).
7.21.357	Historically, the idea of an infectious agent that did not use nucleic acids was considered impossible, but pioneering work by Nobel Prize-winning biologist Stanley Prusiner has convinced the majority of biologists that such agents do indeed exist.
7.21.358	Fatal neurodegenerative diseases, such as kuru in humans and bovine spongiform encephalopathy (BSE) in cattle (commonly known as “mad cow disease”) were shown to be transmitted by prions.
7.21.359	The disease was spread by the consumption of meat, nervous tissue, or internal organs between members of the same species.
7.21.360	Kuru, native to humans in Papua New Guinea, was spread from human to human via ritualistic cannibalism.
7.21.361	BSE, originally detected in the United Kingdom, was spread between cattle by the practice of including cattle nervous tissue in feed for other cattle.
7.21.362	Individuals with kuru and BSE show symptoms of loss of motor control and unusual behaviors, such as uncontrolled bursts of laughter with kuru, followed by death.
7.21.363	Kuru was controlled by inducing the population to abandon its ritualistic cannibalism.
7.21.364	On the other hand, BSE was initially thought to only affect cattle.
7.21.365	Cattle dying of the disease were shown to have developed lesions or “holes” in the brain, causing the brain tissue to resemble a sponge.
7.21.366	Later on in the outbreak, however, it was shown that a similar encephalopathy in humans known as variant Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD) could be acquired from eating beef from animals with BSE, sparking bans by various countries on the importation of British beef and causing considerable economic damage to the British beef industry (Figure 21.17).
7.21.367	BSE still exists in various areas, and although a rare disease, individuals that acquire CJD are difficult to treat.
7.21.368	The disease can be spread from human to human by blood, so many countries have banned blood donation from regions associated with BSE.
7.21.369	The cause of spongiform encephalopathies, such as kuru and BSE, is an infectious structural variant of a normal cellular protein called PrP (prion protein).
7.21.370	It is this variant that constitutes the prion particle.
7.21.371	PrP exists in two forms, PrPc, the normal form of the protein, and PrPsc, the infectious form.
7.21.372	Once introduced into the body, the PrPsc contained within the prion binds to PrPc and converts it to PrPsc.
7.21.373	This leads to an exponential increase of the PrPsc protein, which aggregates.
7.21.374	PrPsc is folded abnormally, and the resulting conformation (shape) is directly responsible for the lesions seen in the brains of infected cattle.
7.21.375	Thus, although not without some detractors among scientists, the prion seems likely to be an entirely new form of infectious agent, the first one found whose transmission is not reliant upon genes made of DNA or RNA.
7.21.376	(a) Endogenous normal prion protein (PrPc) is converted into the disease-causing form (PrPsc) when it encounters this variant form of the protein.
7.21.377	PrPsc may arise spontaneously in brain tissue, especially if a mutant form of the protein is present, or it may occur via the spread of misfolded prions consumed in food into brain tissue.
7.21.378	(b)
7.21.379	This prion-infected brain tissue, visualized using light microscopy, shows the vacuoles that give it a spongy texture, typical of transmissible spongiform encephalopathies.
7.21.380	Viroids Viroids are plant pathogens: small, single-stranded, circular RNA particles that are much simpler than a virus.
7.21.381	They do not have a capsid or outer envelope, but like viruses can reproduce only within a host cell.
7.21.382	Viroids do not, however, manufacture any proteins, and they only produce a single, specific RNA molecule.
7.21.383	Human diseases caused by viroids have yet to be identified.
7.21.384	Viroids are known to infect plants (Figure 21.18) and are responsible for crop failures and the loss of millions of dollars in agricultural revenue each year.
7.21.385	Some of the plants they infect include potatoes, cucumbers, tomatoes, chrysanthemums, avocados, and coconut palms.
7.21.386	These potatoes have been infected by the potato spindle tuber viroid (PSTV), which is typically spread when infected knives are used to cut healthy potatoes, which are then planted.
7.21.387	Virologist Virology is the study of viruses, and a virologist is an individual trained in this discipline.
7.21.388	Training in virology can lead to many different career paths.
7.21.389	Virologists are actively involved in academic research and teaching in colleges and medical schools.
7.21.390	Some virologists treat patients or are involved in the generation and production of vaccines.
7.21.391	They might participate in epidemiologic studies (Figure 21.19) or become science writers, to name just a few possible careers.
7.21.392	centers have departments of virology, and smaller hospitals usually have virology labs within their microbiology departments.
7.21.393	Volunteer in a virology lab for a semester or work in one over the summer.
7.21.394	Discussing the profession and getting a first-hand look at the work will help you decide whether a career in virology is right for you.
7.21.395	The American Society of Virology’s website (http://openstaxcollege.org/l/asv) is a good resource for information regarding training and careers in virology.
7.22.0	Certain prokaryotes can live in extreme environments such as the Morning Glory pool, a hot spring in Yellowstone National Park.
7.22.1	The spring’s vivid blue color is from the prokaryotes that thrive in its very hot waters.
7.22.2	In the recent past, scientists grouped living things into five kingdoms—animals, plants, fungi, protists, and prokaryotes—based on several criteria, such as the absence or presence of a nucleus and other membrane-bound organelles, the absence or presence of cell walls, multicellularity, and so on.
7.22.3	In the late 20th century, the pioneering work of Carl Woese and others compared sequences of small-subunit ribosomal RNA (SSU rRNA), which resulted in a more fundamental way to group organisms on Earth.
7.22.4	Based on differences in the structure of cell membranes and in rRNA, Woese and his colleagues proposed that all life on Earth evolved along three lineages, called domains.
7.22.5	The domain Bacteria comprises all organisms in the kingdom Bacteria, the domain Archaea comprises the rest of the prokaryotes, and the domain Eukarya comprises all eukaryotes—including organisms in the kingdoms Animalia, Plantae, Fungi, and Protista.
7.22.6	Two of the three domains—Bacteria and Archaea—are prokaryotic.
7.22.7	Prokaryotes were the first inhabitants on Earth, appearing 3.5 to 3.8 billion years ago.
7.22.8	These organisms are abundant and ubiquitous; that is, they are present everywhere.
7.22.9	In addition to inhabiting moderate environments, they are found in extreme conditions: from boiling springs to permanently frozen environments in Antarctica; from salty environments like the Dead Sea to environments under tremendous pressure, such as the depths of the ocean; and from areas without oxygen, such as a waste management plant, to radioactively contaminated regions, such as Chernobyl.
7.22.10	Prokaryotes reside in the human digestive system and on the skin, are responsible for certain illnesses, and serve an important role in the preparation of many foods.
7.22.11	Prokaryotes are ubiquitous.
7.22.12	They cover every imaginable surface where there is sufficient moisture, and they live on and inside of other living things.
7.22.13	In the typical human body, prokaryotic cells outnumber human body cells by about ten to one.
7.22.14	They comprise the majority of living things in all ecosystems.
7.22.15	Some prokaryotes thrive in environments that are inhospitable for most living things.
7.22.16	Prokaryotes recycle nutrients—essential substances (such as carbon and nitrogen)—and
7.22.17	they drive the evolution of new ecosystems, some of which are natural and others man-made.
7.22.18	Prokaryotes have been on Earth since long before multicellular life appeared.
7.22.19	Prokaryotes, the First Inhabitants of Earth
7.22.20	When and where did life begin?
7.22.21	What were the conditions on Earth when life began?
7.22.22	Prokaryotes were the first forms of life on Earth, and they existed for billions of years before plants and animals appeared.
7.22.23	The Earth and its moon are thought to be about 4.54 billion years old.
7.22.24	This estimate is based on evidence from radiometric dating of meteorite material together with other substrate material from Earth and the moon.
7.22.25	Early Earth had a very different atmosphere (contained less molecular oxygen) than it does today and was subjected to strong radiation; thus, the first organisms would have flourished where they were more protected, such as in ocean depths or beneath the surface of the Earth.
7.22.26	At this time too, strong volcanic activity was common on Earth, so it is likely that these first organisms—the first prokaryotes—were adapted to very high temperatures.
7.22.27	Early Earth was prone to geological upheaval and volcanic eruption, and was subject to bombardment by mutagenic radiation from the sun.
7.22.28	The first organisms were prokaryotes that could withstand these harsh conditions.
7.22.29	Microbial Mats Microbial mats or large biofilms may represent the earliest forms of life on Earth; there is fossil evidence of their presence starting about 3.5 billion years ago.
7.22.30	A microbial mat is a multi-layered sheet of prokaryotes (Figure 22.2) that includes mostly bacteria, but also archaea.
7.22.31	Microbial mats are a few centimeters thick, and they typically grow where different types of materials interface, mostly on moist surfaces.
7.22.32	The various types of prokaryotes that comprise them carry out different metabolic pathways, and that is the reason for their various colors.
7.22.33	Prokaryotes in a microbial mat are held together by a glue-like sticky substance that they secrete called extracellular matrix.
7.22.34	The first microbial mats likely obtained their energy from chemicals found near hydrothermal vents.
7.22.35	A hydrothermal vent is a breakage or fissure in the Earth’s surface that releases geothermally heated water.
7.22.36	With the evolution of photosynthesis about 3 billion years ago, some prokaryotes in microbial mats came to use a more widely available energy source—sunlight—whereas others were still dependent on chemicals from hydrothermal vents for energy and food.
7.22.37	This (a) microbial mat, about one meter in diameter, grows over a hydrothermal vent in the Pacific Ocean in a region known as the “Pacific Ring of Fire.
7.22.38	”
7.22.39	The mat helps retain microbial nutrients.
7.22.40	Chimneys such as the one indicated by the arrow allow gases to escape.
7.22.41	(b)
7.22.42	In this micrograph, bacteria are visualized using fluorescence microscopy.
7.22.43	Stromatolites Fossilized microbial mats represent the earliest record of life on Earth.
7.22.44	A stromatolite is a sedimentary structure formed when minerals are precipitated out of water by prokaryotes in a microbial mat
7.22.45	(Figure 22.3).
7.22.46	Stromatolites form layered rocks made of carbonate or silicate.
7.22.47	Although most stromatolites are artifacts from the past, there are places on Earth where stromatolites are still forming.
7.22.48	For example, growing stromatolites have been found in the Anza-Borrego Desert State Park in San Diego County, California.
7.22.49	These living stromatolites are located in Shark Bay, Australia.
7.22.50	(b)
7.22.51	These fossilized stromatolites, found in Glacier National Park, Montana, are nearly 1.5 billion years old.
7.22.52	The Ancient Atmosphere Evidence indicates that during the first two billion years of Earth’s existence, the atmosphere was anoxic, meaning that there was no molecular oxygen.
7.22.53	Therefore, only those organisms that can grow without oxygen— anaerobic organisms—were able to live.
7.22.54	Autotrophic organisms that convert solar energy into chemical energy are called phototrophs, and they appeared within one billion years of the formation of Earth.
7.22.55	Then, cyanobacteria, also known as blue-green algae, evolved from these simple phototrophs one billion years later.
7.22.56	Cyanobacteria (Figure 22.4) began the oxygenation of the atmosphere.
7.22.57	Increased atmospheric oxygen allowed the development of more efficient O2-utilizing catabolic pathways.
7.22.58	It also opened up the land to increased colonization, because some O2 is converted into O3 (ozone) and ozone effectively absorbs the ultraviolet light that would otherwise cause lethal mutations in DNA.
7.22.59	Ultimately, the increase in O2 concentrations allowed the evolution of other life forms.
7.22.60	This hot spring in Yellowstone National Park flows toward the foreground.
7.22.61	Cyanobacteria in the spring are green, and as water flows down the gradient, the intensity of the color increases as cell density increases.
7.22.62	The water is cooler at the edges of the stream than in the center, causing the edges to appear greener.
7.22.63	Microbes Are Adaptable: Life in Moderate and Extreme Environments
7.22.64	Some organisms have developed strategies that allow them to survive harsh conditions.
7.22.65	Prokaryotes thrive in a vast array of environments: Some grow in conditions that would seem very normal to us, whereas others are able to thrive and grow under conditions that would kill a plant or animal.
7.22.66	Almost all prokaryotes have a cell wall, a protective structure that allows them to survive in both hyper- and hypo-osmotic conditions.
7.22.67	Some soil bacteria are able to form endospores that resist heat and drought, thereby allowing the organism to survive until favorable conditions recur.
7.22.68	These adaptations, along with others, allow bacteria to be the most abundant life form in all terrestrial and aquatic ecosystems.
7.22.69	Other bacteria and archaea are adapted to grow under extreme conditions and are called extremophiles, meaning “lovers of extremes.
7.22.70	”
7.22.71	Extremophiles have been found in all kinds of environments: the depth of the oceans, hot springs, the Artic and the Antarctic, in very dry places, deep inside Earth, in harsh chemical environments, and in high radiation environments (Figure 22.5), just to mention a few.
7.22.72	These organisms give us a better understanding of prokaryotic diversity and open up the possibility of finding new prokaryotic species that may lead to the discovery of new therapeutic drugs or have industrial applications.
7.22.73	Because they have specialized adaptations that allow them to live in extreme conditions, many extremophiles cannot survive in moderate environments.
7.22.74	There are many different groups of extremophiles: They are identified based on the conditions in which they grow best, and several habitats are extreme in multiple ways.
7.22.75	For example, a soda lake is both salty and alkaline, so organisms that live in a soda lake must be both alkaliphiles and halophiles (Table 22.1).
7.22.76	Other extremophiles, like radioresistant organisms, do not prefer an extreme environment (in this case, one with high levels of radiation), but have adapted to survive in it.
7.22.77	Deinococcus radiodurans, visualized in this false color transmission electron micrograph, is a prokaryote that can tolerate very high doses of ionizing radiation.
7.22.78	It has developed DNA repair mechanisms that allow it to reconstruct its chromosome even if it has been broken into hundreds of pieces by radiation or heat.
7.22.79	Prokaryotes in the Dead Sea
7.22.80	One example of a very harsh environment is the Dead Sea, a hypersaline basin that is located between Jordan and Israel.
7.22.81	Hypersaline environments are essentially concentrated seawater.
7.22.82	In the Dead Sea, the sodium concentration is 10 times higher than that of seawater, and the water contains high levels of magnesium (about 40 times higher than in seawater) that would be toxic to most living things.
7.22.83	Iron, calcium, and magnesium, elements that form divalent ions (Fe2+, Ca2+, and Mg2+), produce what is commonly referred to as “hard” water.
7.22.84	Taken together, the high concentration of divalent cations, the acidic pH (6.0), and the intense solar radiation flux make the Dead Sea a unique, and uniquely hostile, ecosystem
7.22.85	[1] (Figure 22.6).
7.22.86	What sort of prokaryotes do we find in the Dead Sea?
7.22.87	The extremely salt-tolerant bacterial mats include Halobacterium, Haloferax volcanii (which is found in other locations, not only the Dead Sea), Halorubrum sodomense, and Halobaculum gomorrense, and the archaea Haloarcula marismortui, among others.
7.22.88	The Dead Sea is hypersaline.
7.22.89	Nevertheless, salt-tolerant bacteria thrive in this sea.
7.22.90	(b)
7.22.91	These halobacteria cells can form salt-tolerant bacterial mats.
7.22.92	Unculturable Prokaryotes and the Viable-but-Non-Culturable State Microbiologists typically grow prokaryotes in the laboratory using an appropriate culture medium containing all the nutrients needed by the target organism.
7.22.93	The medium can be liquid, broth, or solid.
7.22.94	After an incubation time at the right temperature, there should be evidence of microbial growth (Figure 22.7).
7.22.95	The process of culturing bacteria is complex and is one of the greatest discoveries of modern science.
7.22.96	German physician Robert Koch is credited with discovering the techniques for pure culture, including staining and using growth media.
7.22.97	His assistant Julius Petri invented the Petri dish whose use persists in today’s laboratories.
7.22.98	Koch worked primarily with the Mycobacterium tuberculosis bacterium that causes tuberculosis and developed postulates to identify disease-causing organisms that continue to be widely used in the medical community.
7.22.99	Koch’s postulates include that an organism can be identified as the cause of disease when it is present in all infected samples and absent in all healthy samples, and it is able to reproduce the infection after being cultured multiple times.
7.22.100	Today, cultures remain a primary diagnostic tool in medicine and other areas of molecular biology.
7.22.101	In these agar plates, the growth medium is supplemented with red blood cells.
7.22.102	Blood agar becomes transparent in the presence of hemolytic Streptococcus, which destroys red blood cells and is used to diagnose Streptococcus infections.
7.22.103	The plate on the left is inoculated with non-hemolytic Staphylococcus (large white colonies), and the plate on the right is inoculated with hemolytic Streptococcus (tiny clear colonies).
7.22.104	If you look closely at the right plate, you can see that the agar surrounding the bacteria has turned clear.
7.22.105	Some prokaryotes, however, cannot grow in a laboratory setting.
7.22.106	In fact, over 99 percent of bacteria and archaea are unculturable.
7.22.107	For the most part, this is due to a lack of knowledge as to what to feed these organisms and how to grow them; they have special requirements for growth that remain unknown to scientists, such as needing specific micronutrients, pH, temperature, pressure, co-factors, or co-metabolites.
7.22.108	Some bacteria cannot be cultured because they are obligate intracellular parasites and cannot be grown outside a host cell.
7.22.109	In other cases, culturable organisms become unculturable under stressful conditions, even though the same organism could be cultured previously.
7.22.110	Those organisms that cannot be cultured but are not dead are in a viable-but-non-culturable (VBNC) state.
7.22.111	The VBNC state occurs when prokaryotes respond to environmental stressors by entering a dormant state that allows their survival.
7.22.112	The criteria for entering into the VBNC state are not completely understood.
7.22.113	In a process called resuscitation, the prokaryote can go back to “normal” life when environmental conditions improve.
7.22.114	Is the VBNC state an unusual way of living for prokaryotes?
7.22.115	In fact, most of the prokaryotes living in the soil or in oceanic waters are non-culturable.
7.22.116	It has been said that only a small fraction, perhaps one percent, of prokaryotes can be cultured under laboratory conditions.
7.22.117	If these organisms are non-culturable, then how is it known whether they are present and alive?
7.22.118	Microbiologists use molecular techniques, such as the polymerase chain reaction (PCR), to amplify selected portions of DNA of prokaryotes, demonstrating their existence.
7.22.119	Recall that PCR can make billions of copies of a DNA segment in a process called amplification.
7.22.120	The Ecology of Biofilms Until a couple of decades ago, microbiologists used to think of prokaryotes as isolated entities living apart.
7.22.121	This model, however, does not reflect the true ecology of prokaryotes, most of which prefer to live in communities where they can interact.
7.22.122	A biofilm is a microbial community (Figure 22.8) held together in a gummy-textured matrix that consists primarily of polysaccharides secreted by the organisms, together with some proteins and nucleic acids.
7.22.123	Biofilms grow attached to surfaces.
7.22.124	Some of the best-studied biofilms are composed of prokaryotes, although fungal biofilms have also been described as well as some composed of a mixture of fungi and bacteria.
7.22.125	Biofilms are present almost everywhere: they can cause the clogging of pipes and readily colonize surfaces in industrial settings.
7.22.126	In recent, large-scale outbreaks of bacterial contamination of food, biofilms have played a major role.
7.22.127	They also colonize household surfaces, such as kitchen counters, cutting boards, sinks, and toilets, as well as places on the human body, such as the surfaces of our teeth.
7.22.128	Interactions among the organisms that populate a biofilm, together with their protective exopolysaccharidic (EPS) environment, make these communities more robust than free-living, or planktonic, prokaryotes.
7.22.129	The sticky substance that holds bacteria together also excludes most antibiotics and disinfectants, making biofilm bacteria hardier than their planktonic counterparts.
7.22.130	Overall, biofilms are very difficult to destroy because they are resistant to many common forms of sterilization.
7.22.131	There are many differences between prokaryotic and eukaryotic cells.
7.22.132	However, all cells have four common structures: the plasma membrane, which functions as a barrier for the cell and separates the cell from its environment; the cytoplasm, a jelly-like substance inside the cell; nucleic acids, the genetic material of the cell; and ribosomes, where protein synthesis takes place.
7.22.133	Prokaryotes come in various shapes, but many fall into three categories: cocci (spherical), bacilli (rod-shaped), and spirilli (spiral-shaped).
7.22.134	Prokaryotes fall into three basic categories based on their shape, visualized here using scanning electron microscopy: (a) cocci, or spherical (a pair is shown); (b) bacilli, or rod-shaped; and (c) spirilli, or spiral-shaped.
7.22.135	The Prokaryotic Cell Recall that prokaryotes (Figure 22.10) are unicellular organisms that lack organelles or other internal membrane-bound structures.
7.22.136	Therefore, they do not have a nucleus but instead generally have a single chromosome
7.22.137	—
7.22.138	a piece of circular, double-stranded DNA located in an area of the cell called the nucleoid.
7.22.139	Most prokaryotes have a cell wall outside the plasma membrane.
7.22.140	The features of a typical prokaryotic cell are shown.
7.22.141	Recall that prokaryotes are divided into two different domains, Bacteria and Archaea, which together with Eukarya, comprise the three domains of life.
7.22.142	Bacteria and Archaea are both prokaryotes but differ enough to be placed in separate domains.
7.22.143	An ancestor of modern Archaea is believed to have given rise to Eukarya, the third domain of life.
7.22.144	Archaeal and bacterial phyla are shown; the evolutionary relationship between these phyla is still open to debate.
7.22.145	The composition of the cell wall differs significantly between the domains Bacteria and Archaea.
7.22.146	The composition of their cell walls also differs from the eukaryotic cell walls found in plants (cellulose) or fungi and insects (chitin).
7.22.147	The cell wall functions as a protective layer, and it is responsible for the organism’s shape.
7.22.148	Some bacteria have an outer capsule outside the cell wall.
7.22.149	Other structures are present in some prokaryotic species, but not in others (Table 22.2).
7.22.150	For example, the capsule found in some species enables the organism to attach to surfaces, protects it from dehydration and attack by phagocytic cells, and makes pathogens more resistant to our immune responses.
7.22.151	Some species also have flagella (singular, flagellum) used for locomotion, and pili (singular, pilus) used for attachment to surfaces.
7.22.152	Plasmids, which consist of extrachromosomal DNA, are also present in many species of bacteria and archaea.
7.22.153	Phylum Proteobacteria is one of up to 52 bacteria phyla.
7.22.154	Proteobacteria is further subdivided into five classes, Alpha through Epsilon.
7.22.155	Chlamydia, Spirochetes, Cyanobacteria, and Gram-positive bacteria are described in this table.
7.22.156	Note that bacterial shape is not phylum-dependent; bacteria within a phylum may be cocci, rod-shaped, or spiral.
7.22.157	Archaea are separated into four phyla: the Korarchaeota, Euryarchaeota, Crenarchaeota, and Nanoarchaeota.
7.22.158	The Plasma Membrane
7.22.159	The plasma membrane is a thin lipid bilayer (6 to 8 nanometers) that completely surrounds the cell and separates the inside from the outside.
7.22.160	Its selectively permeable nature keeps ions, proteins, and other molecules within the cell and prevents them from diffusing into the extracellular environment, while other molecules may move through the membrane.
7.22.161	Recall that the general structure of a cell membrane is a phospholipid bilayer composed of two layers of lipid molecules.
7.22.162	In archaeal cell membranes, isoprene (phytanyl) chains linked to glycerol replace the fatty acids linked to glycerol in bacterial membranes.
7.22.163	Some archaeal membranes are lipid monolayers instead of bilayers.
7.22.164	Archaeal phospholipids differ from those found in Bacteria and Eukarya in two ways.
7.22.165	First, they have branched phytanyl sidechains instead of linear ones.
7.22.166	Second, an ether bond instead of an ester bond connects the lipid to the glycerol.
7.22.167	The Cell Wall
7.22.168	The cytoplasm of prokaryotic cells has a high concentration of dissolved solutes.
7.22.169	Therefore, the osmotic pressure within the cell is relatively high.
7.22.170	The cell wall is a protective layer that surrounds some cells and gives them shape and rigidity.
7.22.171	It is located outside the cell membrane and prevents osmotic lysis (bursting due to increasing volume).
7.22.172	The chemical composition of the cell walls varies between archaea and bacteria, and also varies between bacterial species.
7.22.173	Bacterial cell walls contain peptidoglycan, composed of polysaccharide chains that are cross-linked by unusual peptides containing both L- and D-amino acids including D-glutamic acid and D-alanine.
7.22.174	Proteins normally have only L-amino acids; as a consequence, many of our antibiotics work by mimicking D-amino acids and therefore have specific effects on bacterial cell wall development.
7.22.175	There are more than 100 different forms of peptidoglycan.
7.22.176	S-layer (surface layer) proteins are also present on the outside of cell walls of both archaea and bacteria.
7.22.177	Bacteria are divided into two major groups: Gram positive and Gram negative, based on their reaction to Gram staining.
7.22.178	Note that all Gram-positive bacteria belong to one phylum; bacteria in the other phyla (Proteobacteria, Chlamydias, Spirochetes, Cyanobacteria, and others) are Gram-negative.
7.22.179	The Gram staining method is named after its inventor, Danish scientist Hans Christian Gram (1853–1938).
7.22.180	The different bacterial responses to the staining procedure are ultimately due to cell wall structure.
7.22.181	Gram-positive organisms typically lack the outer membrane found in Gram-negative organisms (Figure 22.15).
7.22.182	Up to 90 percent of the cell wall in Gram-positive bacteria is composed of peptidoglycan, and most of the rest is composed of acidic substances called teichoic acids.
7.22.183	Teichoic acids may be covalently linked to lipids in the plasma membrane to form lipoteichoic acids.
7.22.184	Lipoteichoic acids anchor the cell wall to the cell membrane.
7.22.185	Gram-negative bacteria have a relatively thin cell wall composed of a few layers of peptidoglycan (only 10 percent of the total cell wall), surrounded by an outer envelope containing lipopolysaccharides (LPS) and lipoproteins.
7.22.186	This outer envelope is sometimes referred to as a second lipid bilayer.
7.22.187	The chemistry of this outer envelope is very different, however, from that of the typical lipid bilayer that forms plasma membranes.
7.22.188	Archaean cell walls do not have peptidoglycan.
7.22.189	There are four different types of Archaean cell walls.
7.22.190	One type is composed of pseudopeptidoglycan, which is similar to peptidoglycan in morphology but contains different sugars in the polysaccharide chain.
7.22.191	The other three types of cell walls are composed of polysaccharides, glycoproteins, or pure protein.
7.22.192	Reproduction Reproduction in prokaryotes is asexual and usually takes place by binary fission.
7.22.193	Recall that the DNA of a prokaryote exists as a single, circular chromosome.
7.22.194	Prokaryotes do not undergo mitosis.
7.22.195	Rather the chromosome is replicated and the two resulting copies separate from one another, due to the growth of the cell.
7.22.196	The prokaryote, now enlarged, is pinched inward at its equator and the two resulting cells, which are clones, separate.
7.22.197	Binary fission does not provide an opportunity for genetic recombination or genetic diversity, but prokaryotes can share genes by three other mechanisms.
7.22.198	In transformation, the prokaryote takes in DNA found in its environment that is shed by other prokaryotes.
7.22.199	If a nonpathogenic bacterium takes up DNA for a toxin gene from a pathogen and incorporates the new DNA into its own chromosome, it too may become pathogenic.
7.22.200	In transduction, bacteriophages, the viruses that infect bacteria, sometimes also move short pieces of chromosomal DNA from one bacterium to another.
7.22.201	Transduction results in a recombinant organism.
7.22.202	Archaea are not affected by bacteriophages but instead have their own viruses that translocate genetic material from one individual to another.
7.22.203	In conjugation, DNA is transferred from one prokaryote to another by means of a pilus, which brings the organisms into contact with one another.
7.22.204	The DNA transferred can be in the form of a plasmid or as a hybrid, containing both plasmid and chromosomal DNA.
7.22.205	These three processes of DNA exchange are shown in Figure 22.17.
7.22.206	Reproduction can be very rapid: a few minutes for some species.
7.22.207	This short generation time coupled with mechanisms of genetic recombination and high rates of mutation result in the rapid evolution of prokaryotes, allowing them to respond to environmental changes (such as the introduction of an antibiotic) very quickly.
7.22.208	Besides binary fission, there are three other mechanisms by which prokaryotes can exchange DNA.
7.22.209	In (a) transformation, the cell takes up prokaryotic DNA directly from the environment.
7.22.210	The DNA may remain separate as plasmid DNA or be incorporated into the host genome.
7.22.211	In (b) transduction, a bacteriophage injects DNA into the cell that contains a small fragment of DNA from a different prokaryote.
7.22.212	In (c) conjugation, DNA is transferred from one cell to another via a mating bridge that connects the two cells after the sex pilus draws the two bacteria close enough to form the bridge.
7.22.213	Prokaryotes are metabolically diverse organisms.
7.22.214	There are many different environments on Earth with various energy and carbon sources, and variable conditions.
7.22.215	Prokaryotes have been able to live in every environment by using whatever energy and carbon sources are available.
7.22.216	Prokaryotes fill many niches on Earth, including being involved in nutrient cycles such as nitrogen and carbon cycles, decomposing dead organisms, and thriving inside living organisms, including humans.
7.22.217	The very broad range of environments that prokaryotes occupy is possible because they have diverse metabolic processes.
7.22.218	Needs of Prokaryotes
7.22.219	The diverse environments and ecosystems on Earth have a wide range of conditions in terms of temperature, available nutrients, acidity, salinity, and energy sources.
7.22.220	Prokaryotes are very well equipped to make their living out of a vast array of nutrients and conditions.
7.22.221	To live, prokaryotes need a source of energy, a source of carbon, and some additional nutrients.
7.22.222	Macronutrients Cells are essentially a well-organized assemblage of macromolecules and water.
7.22.223	Recall that macromolecules are produced by the polymerization of smaller units called monomers.
7.22.224	For cells to build all of the molecules required to sustain life, they need certain substances, collectively called nutrients.
7.22.225	When prokaryotes grow in nature, they obtain their nutrients from the environment.
7.22.226	Nutrients that are required in large amounts are called macronutrients, whereas those required in smaller or trace amounts are called micronutrients.
7.22.227	Just a handful of elements are considered macronutrients—carbon, hydrogen, oxygen, nitrogen, phosphorus, and sulfur.
7.22.228	(A mnemonic for remembering these elements is the acronym CHONPS.)
7.22.229	Why are these macronutrients needed in large amounts?
7.22.230	They are the components of organic compounds in cells, including water.
7.22.231	Carbon is the major element in all macromolecules: carbohydrates, proteins, nucleic acids, lipids, and many other compounds.
7.22.232	Carbon accounts for about 50 percent of the composition of the cell.
7.22.233	Nitrogen represents 12 percent of the total dry weight of a typical cell and is a component of proteins, nucleic acids, and other cell constituents.
7.22.234	Most of the nitrogen available in nature is either atmospheric nitrogen (N2) or another inorganic form.
7.22.235	Diatomic (N2) nitrogen, however, can be converted into an organic form only by certain organisms, called nitrogen-fixing organisms.
7.22.236	Both hydrogen and oxygen are part of many organic compounds and of water.
7.22.237	Phosphorus is required by all organisms for the synthesis of nucleotides and phospholipids.
7.22.238	Sulfur is part of the structure of some amino acids such as cysteine and methionine, and is also present in several vitamins and coenzymes.
7.22.239	Other important macronutrients are potassium (K), magnesium (Mg), calcium (Ca), and sodium (Na).
7.22.240	Although these elements are required in smaller amounts, they are very important for the structure and function of the prokaryotic cell.
7.22.241	Micronutrients
7.22.242	In addition to these macronutrients, prokaryotes require various metallic elements in small amounts.
7.22.243	These are referred to as micronutrients or trace elements.
7.22.244	For example, iron is necessary for the function of the cytochromes involved in electron-transport reactions.
7.22.245	Some prokaryotes require other elements—such as boron (B), chromium (Cr), and manganese (Mn)—primarily as enzyme cofactors.
7.22.246	The Ways in Which Prokaryotes Obtain Energy Prokaryotes can use different sources of energy to assemble macromolecules from smaller molecules.
7.22.247	Phototrophs (or phototrophic organisms) obtain their energy from sunlight.
7.22.248	Chemotrophs (or chemosynthetic organisms) obtain their energy from chemical compounds.
7.22.249	Chemotrophs that can use organic compounds as energy sources are called chemoorganotrophs.
7.22.250	Those that can also use inorganic compounds as energy sources are called chemolitotrophs.
7.22.251	The Ways in Which Prokaryotes Obtain Carbon Prokaryotes not only can use different sources of energy but also different sources of carbon compounds.
7.22.252	Recall that organisms that are able to fix inorganic carbon are called autotrophs.
7.22.253	Autotrophic prokaryotes synthesize organic molecules from carbon dioxide.
7.22.254	In contrast, heterotrophic prokaryotes obtain carbon from organic compounds.
7.22.255	To make the picture more complex, the terms that describe how prokaryotes obtain energy and carbon can be combined.
7.22.256	Thus, photoautotrophs use energy from sunlight, and carbon from carbon dioxide and water, whereas chemoheterotrophs obtain energy and carbon from an organic chemical source.
7.22.257	Chemolitoautotrophs obtain their energy from inorganic compounds, and they build their complex molecules from carbon dioxide.
7.22.258	The table below (Table 22.3) summarizes carbon and energy sources in prokaryotes.
7.22.259	Role of Prokaryotes in Ecosystems Prokaryotes are ubiquitous: There is no niche or ecosystem in which they are not present.
7.22.260	Prokaryotes play many roles in the environments they occupy.
7.22.261	The roles they play in the carbon and nitrogen cycles are vital to life on Earth.
7.22.262	Prokaryotes and the Carbon Cycle Carbon is one of the most important macronutrients, and prokaryotes play an important role in the carbon cycle (Figure 22.18).
7.22.263	Carbon is cycled through Earth’s major reservoirs: land, the atmosphere, aquatic environments, sediments and rocks, and biomass.
7.22.264	The movement of carbon is via carbon dioxide, which is removed from the atmosphere by land plants and marine prokaryotes, and is returned to the atmosphere via the respiration of chemoorganotrophic organisms, including prokaryotes, fungi, and animals.
7.22.265	Although the largest carbon reservoir in terrestrial ecosystems is in rocks and sediments, that carbon is not readily available.
7.22.266	A large amount of available carbon is found in land plants.
7.22.267	Plants, which are producers, use carbon dioxide from the air to synthesize carbon compounds.
7.22.268	Related to this, one very significant source of carbon compounds is humus, which is a mixture of organic materials from dead plants and prokaryotes that have resisted decomposition.
7.22.269	Consumers such as animals use organic compounds generated by producers and release carbon dioxide to the atmosphere.
7.22.270	Then, bacteria and fungi, collectively called decomposers, carry out the breakdown (decomposition) of plants and animals and their organic compounds.
7.22.271	The most important contributor of carbon dioxide to the atmosphere is microbial decomposition of dead material (dead animals, plants, and humus) that undergo respiration.
7.22.272	In aqueous environments and their anoxic sediments, there is another carbon cycle taking place.
7.22.273	In this case, the cycle is based on one-carbon compounds.
7.22.274	In anoxic sediments, prokaryotes, mostly archaea, produce methane (CH4).
7.22.275	This methane moves into the zone above the sediment, which is richer in oxygen and supports bacteria called methane oxidizers that oxidize methane to carbon dioxide, which then returns to the atmosphere.
7.22.276	Prokaryotes play a significant role in continuously moving carbon through the biosphere.
7.22.277	Prokaryotes and the Nitrogen Cycle Nitrogen is a very important element for life because it is part of proteins and nucleic acids.
7.22.278	It is a macronutrient, and in nature, it is recycled from organic compounds to ammonia, ammonium ions, nitrate, nitrite, and nitrogen gas by myriad processes, many of which are carried out only by prokaryotes.
7.22.279	As illustrated in Figure 22.19, prokaryotes are key to the nitrogen cycle.
7.22.280	The largest pool of nitrogen available in the terrestrial ecosystem is gaseous nitrogen from the air, but this nitrogen is not usable by plants, which are primary producers.
7.22.281	Gaseous nitrogen is transformed, or “fixed” into more readily available forms such as ammonia through the process of nitrogen fixation.
7.22.282	Ammonia can be used by plants or converted to other forms.
7.22.283	Another source of ammonia is ammonification, the process by which ammonia is released during the decomposition of nitrogen-containing organic compounds.
7.22.284	Ammonia released to the atmosphere, however, represents only 15 percent of the total nitrogen released; the rest is as N2 and N2O. Ammonia is catabolized anaerobically by some prokaryotes, yielding N2 as the final product.
7.22.285	Nitrification is the conversion of ammonium to nitrite and nitrate.
7.22.286	Nitrification in soils is carried out by bacteria belonging to the genera Nitrosomas, Nitrobacter, and Nitrospira.
7.22.287	The bacteria performs the reverse process, the reduction of nitrate from the soils to gaseous compounds such as N2O, NO, and N2, a process called denitrification.
7.22.288	Devastating pathogen-borne diseases and plagues, both viral and bacterial in nature, have affected humans since the beginning of human history.
7.22.289	The true cause of these diseases was not understood at the time, and some people thought that diseases were a spiritual punishment.
7.22.290	Over time, people came to realize that staying apart from afflicted persons, and disposing of the corpses and personal belongings of victims of illness, reduced their own chances of getting sick.
7.22.291	Epidemiologists study how diseases affect a population.
7.22.292	An epidemic is a disease that occurs in an unusually high number of individuals in a population at the same time.
7.22.293	A pandemic is a widespread, usually worldwide, epidemic.
7.22.294	An endemic disease is a disease that is constantly present, usually at low incidence, in a population.
7.22.295	Long History of Bacterial Disease There are records about infectious diseases as far back as 3000 B.C.
7.22.296	A number of significant pandemics caused by bacteria have been documented over several hundred years.
7.22.297	Some of the most memorable pandemics led to the decline of cities and nations.
7.22.298	In the 21st century, infectious diseases remain among the leading causes of death worldwide, despite advances made in medical research and treatments in recent decades.
7.22.299	A disease spreads when the pathogen that causes it is passed from one person to another.
7.22.300	For a pathogen to cause disease, it must be able to reproduce in the host’s body and damage the host in some way.
7.22.301	The Plague of Athens
7.22.302	In 430 B.C., the Plague of Athens killed one-quarter of the Athenian troops that were fighting in the great Peloponnesian War and weakened Athens’ dominance and power.
7.22.303	The plague impacted people living in overcrowded Athens as well as troops aboard ships that had to return to Athens.
7.22.304	The source of the plague may have been identified recently when researchers from the University of Athens were able to use DNA from teeth recovered from a mass grave.
7.22.305	The scientists identified nucleotide sequences from a pathogenic bacterium, Salmonella enterica serovar Typhi (Figure 22.20), which causes typhoid fever.
7.22.306	[3] This disease is commonly seen in overcrowded areas and has caused epidemics throughout recorded history.
7.22.307	Salmonella enterica serovar Typhi, the causative agent of Typhoid fever, is a Gram-negative, rodshaped gamma protobacterium.
7.22.308	Typhoid fever, which is spread through feces, causes intestinal hemorrhage, high fever, delirium and dehydration.
7.22.309	Today, between 16 and 33 million cases of this re-emerging disease occur annually, resulting in over 200,000 deaths.
7.22.310	Carriers of the disease can be asymptomatic.
7.22.311	In a famous case in the early 1900s, a cook named Mary Mallon unknowingly spread the disease to over fifty people, three of whom died.
7.22.312	Other Salmonella serotypes cause food poisoning.
7.22.313	Bubonic Plagues From 541 to 750, an outbreak of what was likely a bubonic plague (the Plague of Justinian), eliminated one-quarter to onehalf of the human population in the eastern Mediterranean region.
7.22.314	The population in Europe dropped by 50 percent during this outbreak.
7.22.315	Bubonic plague would strike Europe more than once.
7.22.316	One of the most devastating pandemics was the Black Death (1346 to 1361) that is believed to have been another outbreak of bubonic plague caused by the bacterium Yersinia pestis.
7.22.317	It is thought to have originated initially in China and spread along the Silk Road, a network of land and sea trade routes, to the Mediterranean region and Europe, carried by rat fleas living on black rats that were always present on ships.
7.22.318	The Black Death reduced the world’s population from an estimated 450 million to about 350 to 375 million.
7.22.319	Bubonic plague struck London hard again in the mid-1600s (Figure 22.21).
7.22.320	In modern times, approximately 1,000 to 3,000 cases of plague arise globally each year.
7.22.321	Although contracting bubonic plague before antibiotics meant almost certain death, the bacterium responds to several types of modern antibiotics, and mortality rates from plague are now very low.
7.22.322	The (a) Great Plague of London killed an estimated 200,000 people, or about twenty percent of the city’s population.
7.22.323	The causative agent, the (b) bacterium Yersinia pestis, is a Gram-negative, rod-shaped bacterium from the class Gamma Proteobacteria.
7.22.324	The disease is transmitted through the bite of an infected flea, which is infected by a rodent.
7.22.325	Symptoms include swollen lymph nodes, fever, seizure, vomiting of blood, and (c) gangrene Migration of Diseases to New Populations
7.22.326	Over the centuries, Europeans tended to develop genetic immunity to endemic infectious diseases, but when European conquerors reached the western hemisphere, they brought with them disease-causing bacteria and viruses, which triggered epidemics that completely devastated populations of Native Americans, who had no natural resistance to many European diseases.
7.22.327	It has been estimated that up to 90 percent of Native Americans died from infectious diseases after the arrival of Europeans, making conquest of the New World a foregone conclusion.
7.22.328	Emerging and Re-emerging Diseases
7.22.329	The distribution of a particular disease is dynamic.
7.22.330	Therefore, changes in the environment, the pathogen, or the host population can dramatically impact the spread of a disease.
7.22.331	According to the World Health Organization (WHO) an emerging disease (Figure 22.22) is one that has appeared in a population for the first time, or that may have existed previously but is rapidly increasing in incidence or geographic range.
7.22.332	This definition also includes re-emerging diseases that were previously under control.
7.22.333	Approximately 75 percent of recently emerging infectious diseases affecting humans are zoonotic diseases, zoonoses, diseases that primarily infect animals and are transmitted to humans; some are of viral origin and some are of bacterial origin.
7.22.334	Brucellosis is an example of a prokaryotic zoonosis that is re-emerging in some regions, and necrotizing fasciitis (commonly known as flesh-eating bacteria) has been increasing in virulence for the last 80 years for unknown reasons.
7.22.335	The map shows regions where bacterial diseases are emerging or reemerging.
7.22.336	Some of the present emerging diseases are not actually new, but are diseases that were catastrophic in the past (Figure 22.23).
7.22.337	They devastated populations and became dormant for a while, just to come back, sometimes more virulent than before, as was the case with bubonic plague.
7.22.338	Other diseases, like tuberculosis, were never eradicated but were under control in some regions of the world until coming back, mostly in urban centers with high concentrations of immunocompromised people.
7.22.339	The WHO has identified certain diseases whose worldwide re-emergence should be monitored.
7.22.340	Among these are two viral diseases (dengue fever and yellow fever), and three bacterial diseases (diphtheria, cholera, and bubonic plague).
7.22.341	The war against infectious diseases has no foreseeable end.
7.22.342	Lyme disease often, but not always, results in (a) a characteristic bullseye rash.
7.22.343	The disease is caused by a (b) Gram-negative spirochete bacterium of the genus Borrelia.
7.22.344	The bacteria (c) infect ticks, which in turns infect mice.
7.22.345	Deer are the preferred secondary host, but the ticks also may feed on humans.
7.22.346	Untreated, the disease causes chronic disorders in the nervous system, eyes, joints, and heart.
7.22.347	The disease is named after Lyme, Connecticut, where an outbreak occurred in 1995 and has subsequently spread.
7.22.348	The disease is not new, however.
7.22.349	Genetic evidence suggests that Ötzi the Iceman, a 5,300-year-old mummy found in the Alps, was infected with Borrelia.
7.22.350	Biofilms and Disease Recall that biofilms are microbial communities that are very difficult to destroy.
7.22.351	They are responsible for diseases such as infections in patients with cystic fibrosis, Legionnaires’ disease, and otitis media.
7.22.352	They produce dental plaque and colonize catheters, prostheses, transcutaneous and orthopedic devices, contact lenses, and internal devices such as pacemakers.
7.22.353	They also form in open wounds and burned tissue.
7.22.354	In healthcare environments, biofilms grow on hemodialysis machines, mechanical ventilators, shunts, and other medical equipment.
7.22.355	In fact, 65 percent of all infections acquired in the hospital (nosocomial infections) are attributed to biofilms.
7.22.356	Biofilms are also related to diseases contracted from food because they colonize the surfaces of vegetable leaves and meat, as well as food-processing equipment that isn’t adequately cleaned.
7.22.357	Biofilm infections develop gradually; sometimes, they do not cause symptoms immediately.
7.22.358	They are rarely resolved by host defense mechanisms.
7.22.359	Once an infection by a biofilm is established, it is very difficult to eradicate, because biofilms tend to be resistant to most of the methods used to control microbial growth, including antibiotics.
7.22.360	Biofilms respond poorly or only temporarily to antibiotics; it has been said that they can resist up to 1,000 times the antibiotic concentrations used to kill the same bacteria when they are free-living or planktonic.
7.22.361	An antibiotic dose that large would harm the patient; therefore, scientists are working on new ways to get rid of biofilms.
7.22.362	Antibiotics:
7.22.363	Are We Facing a Crisis?
7.22.364	The word antibiotic comes from the Greek anti meaning “against” and bios meaning “life.
7.22.365	”
7.22.366	An antibiotic is a chemical, produced either by microbes or synthetically, that is hostile to the growth of other organisms.
7.22.367	Today’s news and media often address concerns about an antibiotic crisis.
7.22.368	Are the antibiotics that easily treated bacterial infections in the past becoming obsolete?
7.22.369	Are there new “superbugs”—bacteria that have evolved to become more resistant to our arsenal of antibiotics?
7.22.370	Is this the beginning of the end of antibiotics?
7.22.371	All these questions challenge the healthcare community.
7.22.372	One of the main causes of resistant bacteria is the abuse of antibiotics.
7.22.373	The imprudent and excessive use of antibiotics has resulted in the natural selection of resistant forms of bacteria.
7.22.374	The antibiotic kills most of the infecting bacteria, and therefore only the resistant forms remain.
7.22.375	These resistant forms reproduce, resulting in an increase in the proportion of resistant forms over non-resistant ones.
7.22.376	Another major misuse of antibiotics is in patients with colds or the flu, for which antibiotics are useless.
7.22.377	Another problem is the excessive use of antibiotics in livestock.
7.22.378	The routine use of antibiotics in animal feed promotes bacterial resistance as well.
7.22.379	In the United States, 70 percent of the antibiotics produced are fed to animals.
7.22.380	These antibiotics are given to livestock in low doses, which maximize the probability of resistance developing, and these resistant bacteria are readily transferred to humans.
7.22.381	One of the Superbugs: MRSA The imprudent use of antibiotics has paved the way for bacteria to expand populations of resistant forms.
7.22.382	For example, Staphylococcus aureus, often called “staph,” is a common bacterium that can live in the human body and is usually easily treated with antibiotics.
7.22.383	A very dangerous strain, however, methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) has made the news over the past few years (Figure 22.24).
7.22.384	This strain is resistant to many commonly used antibiotics, including methicillin, amoxicillin, penicillin, and oxacillin.
7.22.385	MRSA can cause infections of the skin, but it can also infect the bloodstream, lungs, urinary tract, or sites of injury.
7.22.386	While MRSA infections are common among people in healthcare facilities, they have also appeared in healthy people who haven’t been hospitalized but who live or work in tight populations (like military personnel and prisoners).
7.22.387	Researchers have expressed concern about the way this latter source of MRSA targets a much younger population than those residing in care facilities.
7.22.388	The Journal of the American Medical Association reported that, among MRSA-afflicted persons in healthcare facilities, the average age is 68, whereas people with “community-associated MRSA” ( CA-MRSA) have an average age of 23.
7.22.389	This scanning electron micrograph shows methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus bacteria, commonly known as MRSA.
7.22.390	S. aureus is not always pathogenic, but can cause diseases such as food poisoning and skin and respiratory infections.
7.22.391	In summary, the medical community is facing an antibiotic crisis.
7.22.392	Some scientists believe that after years of being protected from bacterial infections by antibiotics, we may be returning to a time in which a simple bacterial infection could again devastate the human population.
7.22.393	Researchers are developing new antibiotics, but it takes many years to of research and clinical trials, plus financial investments in the millions of dollars, to generate an effective and approved drug.
7.22.394	Foodborne Diseases Prokaryotes are everywhere: They readily colonize the surface of any type of material, and food is not an exception.
7.22.395	Most of the time, prokaryotes colonize food and food-processing equipment in the form of a biofilm.
7.22.396	Outbreaks of bacterial infection related to food consumption are common.
7.22.397	A foodborne disease (colloquially called “food poisoning”) is an illness resulting from the consumption the pathogenic bacteria, viruses, or other parasites that contaminate food.
7.22.398	Although the United States has one of the safest food supplies in the world, the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) has reported that “76 million people get sick, more than 300,000 are hospitalized, and 5,000 Americans die each year from foodborne illness.
7.22.399	”
7.22.400	The characteristics of foodborne illnesses have changed over time.
7.22.401	In the past, it was relatively common to hear about sporadic cases of botulism, the potentially fatal disease produced by a toxin from the anaerobic bacterium Clostridium botulinum.
7.22.402	Some of the most common sources for this bacterium were non-acidic canned foods, homemade pickles, and processed meat and sausages.
7.22.403	The can, jar, or package created a suitable anaerobic environment where Clostridium could grow.
7.22.404	Proper sterilization and canning procedures have reduced the incidence of this disease.
7.22.405	While people may tend to think of foodborne illnesses as associated with animal-based foods, most cases are now linked to produce.
7.22.406	There have been serious, produce-related outbreaks associated with raw spinach in the United States and with vegetable sprouts in Germany, and these types of outbreaks have become more common.
7.22.407	The raw spinach outbreak in 2006 was produced by the bacterium E. coli serotype O157:H7.
7.22.408	A serotype is a strain of bacteria that carries a set of similar antigens on its cell surface, and there are often many different serotypes of a bacterial species.
7.22.409	Most E. coli are not particularly dangerous to humans, but serotype O157:H7 can cause bloody diarrhea and is potentially fatal.
7.22.410	All types of food can potentially be contaminated with bacteria.
7.22.411	Recent outbreaks of Salmonella reported by the CDC occurred in foods as diverse as peanut butter, alfalfa sprouts, and eggs.
7.22.412	A deadly outbreak in Germany in 2010 was caused by E. coli contamination of vegetable sprouts (Figure 22.25).
7.22.413	The strain that caused the outbreak was found to be a new serotype not previously involved in other outbreaks, which indicates that E. coli is continuously evolving.
7.22.414	Vegetable sprouts grown at an organic farm were the cause of an (b) E. coli outbreak that killed 32 people and sickened 3,800 in Germany in 2011.
7.22.415	The strain responsible, E. coli O104:H4, produces Shiga toxin, a substance that inhibits protein synthesis in the host cell.
7.22.416	The toxin (c) destroys red blood cells resulting in bloody diarrhea.
7.22.417	Deformed red blood cells clog the capillaries of the kidney, which can lead to kidney failure, as happened to 845 patients in the 2011 outbreak.
7.22.418	Kidney failure is usually reversible, but some patients experience kidney problems years later.
7.22.419	Not all prokaryotes are pathogenic.
7.22.420	On the contrary, pathogens represent only a very small percentage of the diversity of the microbial world.
7.22.421	In fact, our life would not be possible without prokaryotes.
7.22.422	Just think about the role of prokaryotes in biogeochemical cycles.
7.22.423	Cooperation between Bacteria and Eukaryotes:
7.22.424	Nitrogen Fixation Nitrogen is a very important element to living things, because it is part of nucleotides and amino acids that are the building blocks of nucleic acids and proteins, respectively.
7.22.425	Nitrogen is usually the most limiting element in terrestrial ecosystems, with atmospheric nitrogen, N2, providing the largest pool of available nitrogen.
7.22.426	However, eukaryotes cannot use atmospheric, gaseous nitrogen to synthesize macromolecules.
7.22.427	Fortunately, nitrogen can be “fixed,” meaning it is converted into ammonia (NH3) either biologically or abiotically.
7.22.428	Abiotic nitrogen fixation occurs as a result of lightning or by industrial processes.
7.22.429	Biological nitrogen fixation (BNF) is exclusively carried out by prokaryotes: soil bacteria, cyanobacteria, and Frankia spp.
7.22.430	(filamentous bacteria interacting with actinorhizal plants such as alder, bayberry, and sweet fern).
7.22.431	After photosynthesis, BNF is the second most important biological process on Earth.
7.22.432	The equation representing the process is as follows N2 + 16ATP + 8e−
7.22.433	+
7.22.434	8H+
7.22.435	→
7.22.436	2NH3 + 16ADP + 16Pi
7.22.437	+ H2 where Pi stands for inorganic phosphate.
7.22.438	The total fixed nitrogen through BNF is about 100 to 180 million metric tons per year.
7.22.439	Biological processes contribute 65 percent of the nitrogen used in agriculture.
7.22.440	Cyanobacteria are the most important nitrogen fixers in aquatic environments.
7.22.441	In soil, members of the genus Clostridium are examples of free-living, nitrogen-fixing bacteria.
7.22.442	Other bacteria live symbiotically with legume plants, providing the most important source of BNF.
7.22.443	Symbionts may fix more nitrogen in soils than free-living organisms by a factor of 10.
7.22.444	Soil bacteria, collectively called rhizobia, are able to symbiotically interact with legumes to form nodules, specialized structures where nitrogen fixation occurs (Figure 22.27).
7.22.445	Nitrogenase, the enzyme that fixes nitrogen, is inactivated by oxygen, so the nodule provides an oxygen-free area for nitrogen fixation to take place.
7.22.446	This process provides a natural and inexpensive plant fertilizer, as it reduces atmospheric nitrogen to ammonia, which is easily usable by plants.
7.22.447	The use of legumes is an excellent alternative to chemical fertilization and is of special interest to sustainable agriculture, which seeks to minimize the use of chemicals and conserve natural resources.
7.22.448	Through symbiotic nitrogen fixation, the plant benefits from using an endless source of nitrogen: the atmosphere.
7.22.449	Bacteria benefit from using photosynthates (carbohydrates produced during photosynthesis) from the plant and having a protected niche.
7.22.450	Additionally, the soil benefits from being naturally fertilized.
7.22.451	Therefore, the use of rhizobia as biofertilizers is a sustainable practice.
7.22.452	Why are legumes so important?
7.22.453	Some, like soybeans, are key sources of agricultural protein.
7.22.454	Some of the most important grain legumes are soybean, peanuts, peas, chickpeas, and beans.
7.22.455	Other legumes, such as alfalfa, are used to feed cattle.
7.22.456	Soybean (Glycine max) is a legume that interacts symbiotically with the soil bacterium Bradyrhizobium japonicum to form specialized structures on the roots called nodules where nitrogen fixation occurs.
7.22.457	Early Biotechnology:
7.22.458	Cheese, Bread, Wine, Beer, and Yogurt
7.22.459	According to the United Nations Convention on Biological Diversity, biotechnology is “any technological application that uses biological systems, living organisms, or derivatives thereof, to make or modify products or processes for specific use.
7.22.460	"
7.22.461	[5] The concept of “specific use” involves some sort of commercial application.
7.22.462	Genetic engineering, artificial selection, antibiotic production, and cell culture are current topics of study in biotechnology.
7.22.463	However, humans have used prokaryotes before the term biotechnology was even coined.
7.22.464	In addition, some of the goods and services are as simple as cheese, bread, wine, beer, and yogurt, which employ both bacteria and other microbes, such as yeast, a fungus.
7.22.465	Some of the products derived from the use of prokaryotes in early biotechnology include (a) cheese, (b) wine, (c) beer and bread, and (d) yogurt.
7.22.466	Cheese production began around 4,000–7,000 years ago when humans began to breed animals and process their milk.
7.22.467	Fermentation in this case preserves nutrients: Milk will spoil relatively quickly, but when processed as cheese, it is more stable.
7.22.468	As for beer, the oldest records of brewing are about 6,000 years old and refer to the Sumerians.
7.22.469	Evidence indicates that the Sumerians discovered fermentation by chance.
7.22.470	Wine has been produced for about 4,500 years, and evidence suggests that cultured milk products, like yogurt, have existed for at least 4,000 years.
7.22.471	Using Prokaryotes to Clean up Our Planet: Bioremediation Microbial bioremediation is the use of prokaryotes (or microbial metabolism) to remove pollutants.
7.22.472	Bioremediation has been used to remove agricultural chemicals (pesticides, fertilizers) that leach from soil into groundwater and the subsurface.
7.22.473	Certain toxic metals and oxides, such as selenium and arsenic compounds, can also be removed from water by bioremediation.
7.22.474	The reduction of SeO4 -2 to SeO3 -2 and to Se0 (metallic selenium) is a method used to remove selenium ions from water.
7.22.475	Mercury is an example of a toxic metal that can be removed from an environment by bioremediation.
7.22.476	As an active ingredient of some pesticides, mercury is used in industry and is also a by-product of certain processes, such as battery production.
7.22.477	Methyl mercury is usually present in very low concentrations in natural environments, but it is highly toxic because it accumulates in living tissues.
7.22.478	Several species of bacteria can carry out the biotransformation of toxic mercury into nontoxic forms.
7.22.479	These bacteria, such as Pseudomonas aeruginosa, can convert Hg+2 into Hg0, which is nontoxic to humans.
7.22.480	One of the most useful and interesting examples of the use of prokaryotes for bioremediation purposes is the cleanup of oil spills.
7.22.481	The importance of prokaryotes to petroleum bioremediation has been demonstrated in several oil spills in recent years, such as the Exxon Valdez spill in Alaska (1989)
7.22.482	(Figure 22.29), the Prestige oil spill in Spain (2002), the spill into the Mediterranean from a Lebanon power plant (2006), and more recently, the BP oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico (2010).
7.22.483	To clean up these spills, bioremediation is promoted by the addition of inorganic nutrients that help bacteria to grow.
7.22.484	Hydrocarbon-degrading bacteria feed on hydrocarbons in the oil droplet, breaking down the hydrocarbons.
7.22.485	Some species, such as Alcanivorax borkumensis, produce surfactants that solubilize the oil, whereas other bacteria degrade the oil into carbon dioxide.
7.22.486	In the case of oil spills in the ocean, ongoing, natural bioremediation tends to occur, inasmuch as there are oil-consuming bacteria in the ocean prior to the spill.
7.22.487	In addition to naturally occurring oil-degrading bacteria, humans select and engineer bacteria that possess the same capability with increased efficacy and spectrum of hydrocarbon compounds that can be processed.
7.22.488	Under ideal conditions, it has been reported that up to 80 percent of the nonvolatile components in oil can be degraded within one year of the spill.
7.22.489	Other oil fractions containing aromatic and highly branched hydrocarbon chains are more difficult to remove and remain in the environment for longer periods of time.
7.22.490	Cleaning up oil after the Valdez spill in Alaska, workers hosed oil from beaches and then used a floating boom to corral the oil, which was finally skimmed from the water surface.
7.22.491	Some species of bacteria are able to solubilize and degrade the oil.
7.22.492	(b) One of the most catastrophic consequences of oil spills is the damage to fauna.
7.23.0	Protists range from the microscopic, single-celled (a) Acanthocystis turfacea and the (b) ciliate Tetrahymena thermophila, both visualized here using light microscopy, to the enormous, multicellular (c) kelps (Chromalveolata) that extend for hundreds of feet in underwater “forests.
7.23.1	”
7.23.2	Humans have been familiar with macroscopic organisms (organisms big enough to see with the unaided eye) since before there was a written history, and it is likely that most cultures distinguished between animals and land plants, and most probably included the macroscopic fungi as plants.
7.23.3	Therefore, it became an interesting challenge to deal with the world of microorganisms once microscopes were developed a few centuries ago.
7.23.4	Many different naming schemes were used over the last couple of centuries, but it has become the most common practice to refer to eukaryotes that are not land plants, animals, or fungi as protists.
7.23.5	This name was first suggested by Ernst Haeckel in the late nineteenth century.
7.23.6	It has been applied in many contexts and has been formally used to represent a kingdom-level taxon called Protista.
7.23.7	However, many modern systematists (biologists who study the relationships among organisms) are beginning to shy away from the idea of formal ranks such as kingdom and phylum.
7.23.8	Instead, they are naming taxa as groups of organisms thought to include all the descendants of a last common ancestor (monophyletic group).
7.23.9	During the past two decades, the field of molecular genetics has demonstrated that some protists are more related to animals, plants, or fungi than they are to other protists.
7.23.10	Therefore, not including animals, plants and fungi make the kingdom Protista a paraphyletic group, or one that does not include all descendents of its common ancestor.
7.23.11	For this reason, protist lineages originally classified into the kingdom Protista continue to be examined and debated.
7.23.12	In the meantime, the term “protist” still is used informally to describe this tremendously diverse group of eukaryotes.
7.23.13	Most protists are microscopic, unicellular organisms that are abundant in soil, freshwater, brackish, and marine environments.
7.23.14	They are also common in the digestive tracts of animals and in the vascular tissues of plants.
7.23.15	Others invade the cells of other protists, animals, and plants.
7.23.16	Not all protists are microscopic.
7.23.17	Some have huge, macroscopic cells, such as the plasmodia (giant amoebae) of myxomycete slime molds or the marine green alga Caulerpa, which can have single cells that can be several meters in size.
7.23.18	Some protists are multicellular, such as the red, green, and brown seaweeds.
7.23.19	It is among the protists that one finds the wealth of ways that organisms can grow.
7.23.20	Living things fall into three large groups: Archaea, Bacteria, and Eukarya.
