7.23.21	The first two have prokaryotic cells, and the third contains all eukaryotes.
7.23.22	A relatively sparse fossil record is available to help discern what the first members of each of these lineages looked like, so it is possible that all the events that led to the last common ancestor of extant eukaryotes will remain unknown.
7.23.23	However, comparative biology of extant organisms and the limited fossil record provide some insight into the history of Eukarya.
7.23.24	The earliest fossils found appear to be Bacteria, most likely cyanobacteria.
7.23.25	They are about 3.5 billion years old and are recognizable because of their relatively complex structure and, for prokaryotes, relatively large cells.
7.23.26	Most other prokaryotes have small cells, 1 or 2 μm in size, and would be difficult to pick out as fossils.
7.23.27	Most living eukaryotes have cells measuring 10 μm or greater.
7.23.28	Structures this size, which might be fossils, appear in the geological record about 2.1 billion years ago.
7.23.29	Characteristics of Eukaryotes Data from these fossils have led comparative biologists to the conclusion that living eukaryotes are all descendants of a single common ancestor.
7.23.30	Mapping the characteristics found in all major groups of eukaryotes reveals that the following characteristics must have been present in the last common ancestor, because these characteristics are present in at least some of the members of each major lineage.
7.23.31	1.
7.23.32	Cells with nuclei surrounded by a nuclear envelope with nuclear pores.
7.23.33	This is the single characteristic that is both necessary and sufficient to define an organism as a eukaryote.
7.23.34	All extant eukaryotes have cells with nuclei.
7.23.35	2.
7.23.36	Mitochondria.
7.23.37	Some extant eukaryotes have very reduced remnants of mitochondria in their cells, whereas other members of their lineages have “typical” mitochondria.
7.23.38	3.
7.23.39	A cytoskeleton containing the structural and motility components called actin microfilaments and microtubules.
7.23.40	All extant eukaryotes have these cytoskeletal elements.
7.23.41	4.
7.23.42	Flagella and cilia, organelles associated with cell motility.
7.23.43	Some extant eukaryotes lack flagella and/or cilia, but they are descended from ancestors that possessed them.
7.23.44	5.
7.23.45	Chromosomes, each consisting of a linear DNA molecule coiled around basic (alkaline) proteins called histones.
7.23.46	The few eukaryotes with chromosomes lacking histones clearly evolved from ancestors that had them.
7.23.47	6.
7.23.48	Mitosis, a process of nuclear division wherein replicated chromosomes are divided and separated using elements of the cytoskeleton.
7.23.49	Mitosis is universally present in eukaryotes.
7.23.50	7.
7.23.51	Sex, a process of genetic recombination unique to eukaryotes in which diploid nuclei at one stage of the life cycle undergo meiosis to yield haploid nuclei and subsequent karyogamy, a stage where two haploid nuclei fuse together to create a diploid zygote nucleus.
7.23.52	8.
7.23.53	Members of all major lineages have cell walls, and it might be reasonable to conclude that the last common ancestor could make cell walls during some stage of its life cycle.
7.23.54	However, not enough is known about eukaryotes’ cell walls and their development to know how much homology exists among them.
7.23.55	If the last common ancestor could make cell walls, it is clear that this ability must have been lost in many groups.
7.23.56	Endosymbiosis and the Evolution of Eukaryotes
7.23.57	In order to understand eukaryotic organisms fully, it is necessary to understand that all extant eukaryotes are descendants of a chimeric organism that was a composite of a host cell and the cell(s) of an alpha-proteobacterium that “took up residence” inside it.
7.23.58	This major theme in the origin of eukaryotes is known as endosymbiosis, one cell engulfing another such that the engulfed cell survives and both cells benefit.
7.23.59	Over many generations, a symbiotic relationship can result in two organisms that depend on each other so completely that neither could survive on its own.
7.23.60	Endosymbiotic events likely contributed to the origin of the last common ancestor of today’s eukaryotes and to later diversification in certain lineages of eukaryotes (Figure 23.5).
7.23.61	Before explaining this further, it is necessary to consider metabolism in prokaryotes.
7.23.62	Prokaryotic Metabolism
7.23.63	Many important metabolic processes arose in prokaryotes, and some of these, such as nitrogen fixation, are never found in eukaryotes.
7.23.64	The process of aerobic respiration is found in all major lineages of eukaryotes, and it is localized in the mitochondria.
7.23.65	Aerobic respiration is also found in many lineages of prokaryotes, but it is not present in all of them, and many forms of evidence suggest that such anaerobic prokaryotes never carried out aerobic respiration nor did their ancestors.
7.23.66	While today’s atmosphere is about one-fifth molecular oxygen (O2), geological evidence shows that it originally lacked O2.
7.23.67	Without oxygen, aerobic respiration would not be expected, and living things would have relied on fermentation instead.
7.23.68	At some point before, about 3.5 billion years ago, some prokaryotes began using energy from sunlight to power anabolic processes that reduce carbon dioxide to form organic compounds.
7.23.69	That is, they evolved the ability to photosynthesize.
7.23.70	Hydrogen, derived from various sources, was captured using light-powered reactions to reduce fixed carbon dioxide in the Calvin cycle.
7.23.71	The group of Gram-negative bacteria that gave rise to cyanobacteria used water as the hydrogen source and released O2 as a waste product.
7.23.72	Eventually, the amount of photosynthetic oxygen built up in some environments to levels that posed a risk to living organisms, since it can damage many organic compounds.
7.23.73	Various metabolic processes evolved that protected organisms from oxygen, one of which, aerobic respiration, also generated high levels of ATP.
7.23.74	It became widely present among prokaryotes, including in a group we now call alpha-proteobacteria.
7.23.75	Organisms that did not acquire aerobic respiration had to remain in oxygen-free environments.
7.23.76	Originally, oxygen-rich environments were likely localized around places where cyanobacteria were active, but by about 2 billion years ago, geological evidence shows that oxygen was building up to higher concentrations in the atmosphere.
7.23.77	Oxygen levels similar to today’s levels only arose within the last 700 million years.
7.23.78	Recall that the first fossils that we believe to be eukaryotes date to about 2 billion years old, so they appeared as oxygen levels were increasing.
7.23.79	Also, recall that all extant eukaryotes descended from an ancestor with mitochondria.
7.23.80	These organelles were first observed by light microscopists in the late 1800s, where they appeared to be somewhat worm-shaped structures that seemed to be moving around in the cell.
7.23.81	Some early observers suggested that they might be bacteria living inside host cells, but these hypotheses remained unknown or rejected in most scientific communities.
7.23.82	Endosymbiotic Theory
7.23.83	As cell biology developed in the twentieth century, it became clear that mitochondria were the organelles responsible for producing ATP using aerobic respiration.
7.23.84	In the 1960s, American biologist Lynn Margulis developed endosymbiotic theory, which states that eukaryotes may have been a product of one cell engulfing another, one living within another, and evolving over time until the separate cells were no longer recognizable as such.
7.23.85	In 1967, Margulis introduced new work on the theory and substantiated her findings through microbiological evidence.
7.23.86	Although Margulis’ work initially was met with resistance, this once-revolutionary hypothesis is now widely (but not completely) accepted, with work progressing on uncovering the steps involved in this evolutionary process and the key players involved.
7.23.87	Much still remains to be discovered about the origins of the cells that now make up the cells in all living eukaryotes.
7.23.88	Broadly, it has become clear that many of our nuclear genes and the molecular machinery responsible for replication and expression appear closely related to those in Archaea.
7.23.89	On the other hand, the metabolic organelles and genes responsible for many energy-harvesting processes had their origins in bacteria.
7.23.90	Much remains to be clarified about how this relationship occurred; this continues to be an exciting field of discovery in biology.
7.23.91	For instance, it is not known whether the endosymbiotic event that led to mitochondria occurred before or after the host cell had a nucleus.
7.23.92	Such organisms would be among the extinct precursors of the last common ancestor of eukaryotes.
7.23.93	Mitochondria One of the major features distinguishing prokaryotes from eukaryotes is the presence of mitochondria.
7.23.94	Eukaryotic cells may contain anywhere from one to several thousand mitochondria, depending on the cell’s level of energy consumption.
7.23.95	Each mitochondrion measures 1 to 10 or greater micrometers in length and exists in the cell as an organelle that can be ovoid to worm-shaped to intricately branched (Figure 23.2).
7.23.96	Mitochondria arise from the division of existing mitochondria; they may fuse together; and they may be moved around inside the cell by interactions with the cytoskeleton.
7.23.97	However, mitochondria cannot survive outside the cell.
7.23.98	As the atmosphere was oxygenated by photosynthesis, and as successful aerobic prokaryotes evolved, evidence suggests that an ancestral cell with some membrane compartmentalization engulfed a free-living aerobic prokaryote, specifically an alpha-proteobacterium, thereby giving the host cell the ability to use oxygen to release energy stored in nutrients.
7.23.99	Alpha-proteobacteria are a large group of bacteria that includes species symbiotic with plants, disease organisms that can infect humans via ticks, and many free-living species that use light for energy.
7.23.100	Several lines of evidence support that mitochondria are derived from this endosymbiotic event.
7.23.101	Most mitochondria are shaped like alpha-proteobacteria and are surrounded by two membranes, which would result when one membrane-bound organism was engulfed into a vacuole by another membrane-bound organism.
7.23.102	The mitochondrial inner membrane is extensive and involves substantial infoldings called cristae that resemble the textured, outer surface of alpha-proteobacteria.
7.23.103	The matrix and inner membrane are rich with the enzymes necessary for aerobic respiration.
7.23.104	In this transmission electron micrograph of mitochondria in a mammalian lung cell, the cristae, infoldings of the mitochondrial inner membrane, can be seen in cross-section.
7.23.105	Mitochondria divide independently by a process that resembles binary fission in prokaryotes.
7.23.106	Specifically, mitochondria are not formed from scratch (de novo) by the eukaryotic cell; they reproduce within it and are distributed with the cytoplasm when a cell divides or two cells fuse.
7.23.107	Therefore, although these organelles are highly integrated into the eukaryotic cell, they still reproduce as if they are independent organisms within the cell.
7.23.108	However, their reproduction is synchronized with the activity and division of the cell.
7.23.109	Mitochondria have their own (usually) circular DNA chromosome that is stabilized by attachments to the inner membrane and carries genes similar to genes expressed by alpha-proteobacteria.
7.23.110	Mitochondria also have special ribosomes and transfer RNAs that resemble these components in prokaryotes.
7.23.111	These features all support that mitochondria were once free-living prokaryotes.
7.23.112	Mitochondria that carry out aerobic respiration have their own genomes, with genes similar to those in alpha-proteobacteria.
7.23.113	However, many of the genes for respiratory proteins are located in the nucleus.
7.23.114	When these genes are compared to those of other organisms, they appear to be of alpha-proteobacterial origin.
7.23.115	Additionally, in some eukaryotic groups, such genes are found in the mitochondria, whereas in other groups, they are found in the nucleus.
7.23.116	This has been interpreted as evidence that genes have been transferred from the endosymbiont chromosome to the host genome.
7.23.117	This loss of genes by the endosymbiont is probably one explanation why mitochondria cannot live without a host.
7.23.118	Some living eukaryotes are anaerobic and cannot survive in the presence of too much oxygen.
7.23.119	Some appear to lack organelles that could be recognized as mitochondria.
7.23.120	In the 1970s to the early 1990s, many biologists suggested that some of these eukaryotes were descended from ancestors whose lineages had diverged from the lineage of mitochondrion-containing eukaryotes before endosymbiosis occurred.
7.23.121	However, later findings suggest that reduced organelles are found in most, if not all, anaerobic eukaryotes, and that all eukaryotes appear to carry some genes in their nuclei that are of mitochondrial origin.
7.23.122	In addition to the aerobic generation of ATP, mitochondria have several other metabolic functions.
7.23.123	One of these functions is to generate clusters of iron and sulfur that are important cofactors of many enzymes.
7.23.124	Such functions are often associated with the reduced mitochondrion-derived organelles of anaerobic eukaryotes.
7.23.125	Therefore, most biologists accept that the last common ancestor of eukaryotes had mitochondria.
7.23.126	Plastids
7.23.127	Some groups of eukaryotes are photosynthetic.
7.23.128	Their cells contain, in addition to the standard eukaryotic organelles, another kind of organelle called a plastid.
7.23.129	When such cells are carrying out photosynthesis, their plastids are rich in the pigment chlorophyll a and a range of other pigments, called accessory pigments, which are involved in harvesting energy from light.
7.23.130	Photosynthetic plastids are called chloroplasts.
7.23.131	This chloroplast cross-section illustrates its elaborate inner membrane organization.
7.23.132	Stacks of thylakoid membranes compartmentalize photosynthetic enzymes and provide scaffolding for chloroplast DNA.
7.23.133	(b)
7.23.134	In this micrograph of Elodea sp.
7.23.135	, the chloroplasts can be seen as small green spheres.
7.23.136	Like mitochondria, plastids appear to have an endosymbiotic origin.
7.23.137	This hypothesis was also championed by Lynn Margulis.
7.23.138	Plastids are derived from cyanobacteria that lived inside the cells of an ancestral, aerobic, heterotrophic eukaryote.
7.23.139	This is called primary endosymbiosis, and plastids of primary origin are surrounded by two membranes.
7.23.140	The best evidence is that this has happened twice in the history of eukaryotes.
7.23.141	In one case, the common ancestor of the major lineage/ supergroup Archaeplastida took on a cyanobacterial endosymbiont; in the other, the ancestor of the small amoeboid rhizarian taxon, Paulinella, took on a different cyanobacterial endosymbiont.
7.23.142	Almost all photosynthetic eukaryotes are descended from the first event, and only a couple of species are derived from the other.
7.23.143	Cyanobacteria are a group of Gram-negative bacteria with all the conventional structures of the group.
7.23.144	However, unlike most prokaryotes, they have extensive, internal membrane-bound sacs called thylakoids.
7.23.145	Chlorophyll is a component of these membranes, as are many of the proteins of the light reactions of photosynthesis.
7.23.146	Cyanobacteria also have the peptidoglycan wall and lipopolysaccharide layer associated with Gram-negative bacteria.
7.23.147	Chloroplasts of primary origin have thylakoids, a circular DNA chromosome, and ribosomes similar to those of cyanobacteria.
7.23.148	Each chloroplast is surrounded by two membranes.
7.23.149	In the group of Archaeplastida called the glaucophytes and in Paulinella, a thin peptidoglycan layer is present between the outer and inner plastid membranes.
7.23.150	All other plastids lack this relictual cyanobacterial wall.
7.23.151	The outer membrane surrounding the plastid is thought to be derived from the vacuole in the host, and the inner membrane is thought to be derived from the plasma membrane of the symbiont.
7.23.152	There is also, as with the case of mitochondria, strong evidence that many of the genes of the endosymbiont were transferred to the nucleus.
7.23.153	Plastids, like mitochondria, cannot live independently outside the host.
7.23.154	In addition, like mitochondria, plastids are derived from the division of other plastids and never built from scratch.
7.23.155	Researchers have suggested that the endosymbiotic event that led to Archaeplastida occurred 1 to 1.5 billion years ago, at least 5 hundred million years after the fossil record suggests that eukaryotes were present.
7.23.156	Not all plastids in eukaryotes are derived directly from primary endosymbiosis.
7.23.157	Some of the major groups of algae became photosynthetic by secondary endosymbiosis, that is, by taking in either green algae or red algae (both from Archaeplastida) as endosymbionts (Figure 23.4ab).
7.23.158	Numerous microscopic and genetic studies have supported this conclusion.
7.23.159	Secondary plastids are surrounded by three or more membranes, and some secondary plastids even have clear remnants of the nucleus of endosymbiotic alga.
7.23.160	Others have not “kept” any remnants.
7.23.161	There are cases where tertiary or higher-order endosymbiotic events are the best explanations for plastids in some eukaryotes.
7.23.162	Red algae and (b) green algae (visualized by light microscopy) share similar DNA sequences with photosynthetic cyanobacteria.
7.23.163	Scientists speculate that, in a process called endosymbiosis, an ancestral prokaryote engulfed a photosynthetic cyanobacterium that evolved into modern-day chloroplasts.
7.23.164	There are over 100,000 described living species of protists, and it is unclear how many undescribed species may exist.
7.23.165	Since many protists live as commensals or parasites in other organisms and these relationships are often species-specific, there is a huge potential for protist diversity that matches the diversity of hosts.
7.23.166	As the catchall term for eukaryotic organisms that are not animal, plant, or fungi, it is not surprising that very few characteristics are common to all protists.
7.23.167	Cell Structure
7.23.168	The cells of protists are among the most elaborate of all cells.
7.23.169	Most protists are microscopic and unicellular, but some true multicellular forms exist.
7.23.170	A few protists live as colonies that behave in some ways as a group of free-living cells and in other ways as a multicellular organism.
7.23.171	Still other protists are composed of enormous, multinucleate, single cells that look like amorphous blobs of slime, or in other cases, like ferns.
7.23.172	In fact, many protist cells are multinucleated; in some species, the nuclei are different sizes and have distinct roles in protist cell function.
7.23.173	Single protist cells range in size from less than a micrometer to three meters in length to hectares.
7.23.174	Protist cells may be enveloped by animal-like cell membranes or plant-like cell walls.
7.23.175	Others are encased in glassy silica-based shells or wound with pellicles of interlocking protein strips.
7.23.176	The pellicle functions like a flexible coat of armor, preventing the protist from being torn or pierced without compromising its range of motion.
7.23.177	Metabolism Protists exhibit many forms of nutrition and may be aerobic or anaerobic.
7.23.178	Protists that store energy by photosynthesis belong to a group of photoautotrophs and are characterized by the presence of chloroplasts.
7.23.179	Other protists are heterotrophic and consume organic materials (such as other organisms) to obtain nutrition.
7.23.180	Amoebas and some other heterotrophic protist species ingest particles by a process called phagocytosis, in which the cell membrane engulfs a food particle and brings it inward, pinching off an intracellular membranous sac, or vesicle, called a food vacuole (Figure 23.7).
7.23.181	The vesicle containing the ingested particle, the phagosome, then fuses with a lysosome containing hydrolytic enzymes to produce a phagolysosome, and the food particle is broken down into small molecules that can diffuse into the cytoplasm and be used in cellular metabolism.
7.23.182	Undigested remains ultimately are expelled from the cell via exocytosis.
7.23.183	The stages of phagocytosis include the engulfment of a food particle, the digestion of the particle using hydrolytic enzymes contained within a lysosome, and the expulsion of undigested materials from the cell.
7.23.184	Subtypes of heterotrophs, called saprobes, absorb nutrients from dead organisms or their organic wastes.
7.23.185	Some protists can function as mixotrophs, obtaining nutrition by photoautotrophic or heterotrophic routes, depending on whether sunlight or organic nutrients are available.
7.23.186	Motility
7.23.187	The majority of protists are motile, but different types of protists have evolved varied modes of movement (Figure 23.8).
7.23.188	Some protists have one or more flagella, which they rotate or whip.
7.23.189	Others are covered in rows or tufts of tiny cilia that they coordinately beat to swim.
7.23.190	Still others form cytoplasmic extensions called pseudopodia anywhere on the cell, anchor the pseudopodia to a substrate, and pull themselves forward.
7.23.191	Some protists can move toward or away from a stimulus, a movement referred to as taxis.
7.23.192	Movement toward light, termed phototaxis, is accomplished by coupling their locomotion strategy with a light-sensing organ.
7.23.193	Protists use various methods for transportation.
7.23.194	(a) Paramecium waves hair-like appendages called cilia to propel itself.
7.23.195	(b) Amoeba uses lobe-like pseudopodia to anchor itself to a solid surface and pull itself forward.
7.23.196	(c) Euglena uses a whip-like tail called a flagellum to propel itself.
7.23.197	Life Cycles Protists reproduce by a variety of mechanisms.
7.23.198	Most undergo some form of asexual reproduction, such as binary fission, to produce two daughter cells.
7.23.199	In protists, binary fission can be divided into transverse or longitudinal, depending on the axis of orientation; sometimes Paramecium exhibits this method.
7.23.200	Some protists such as the true slime molds exhibit multiple fission and simultaneously divide into many daughter cells.
7.23.201	Others produce tiny buds that go on to divide and grow to the size of the parental protist.
7.23.202	Sexual reproduction, involving meiosis and fertilization, is common among protists, and many protist species can switch from asexual to sexual reproduction when necessary.
7.23.203	Sexual reproduction is often associated with periods when nutrients are depleted or environmental changes occur.
7.23.204	Sexual reproduction may allow the protist to recombine genes and produce new variations of progeny that may be better suited to surviving in the new environment.
7.23.205	However, sexual reproduction is often associated with resistant cysts that are a protective, resting stage.
7.23.206	Depending on their habitat, the cysts may be particularly resistant to temperature extremes, desiccation, or low pH.
7.23.207	This strategy also allows certain protists to “
7.23.208	wait out” stressors until their environment becomes more favorable for survival or until they are carried (such as by wind, water, or transport on a larger organism) to a different environment, because cysts exhibit virtually no cellular metabolism.
7.23.209	Protist life cycles range from simple to extremely elaborate.
7.23.210	Certain parasitic protists have complicated life cycles and must infect different host species at different developmental stages to complete their life cycle.
7.23.211	Some protists are unicellular in the haploid form and multicellular in the diploid form, a strategy employed by animals.
7.23.212	Other protists have multicellular stages in both haploid and diploid forms, a strategy called alternation of generations that is also used by plants.
7.23.213	Habitats
7.23.214	Nearly all protists exist in some type of aquatic environment, including freshwater and marine environments, damp soil, and even snow.
7.23.215	Several protist species are parasites that infect animals or plants.
7.23.216	A few protist species live on dead organisms or their wastes, and contribute to their decay.
7.23.217	In the span of several decades, the Kingdom Protista has been disassembled because sequence analyses have revealed new genetic (and therefore evolutionary) relationships among these eukaryotes.
7.23.218	Moreover, protists that exhibit similar morphological features may have evolved analogous structures because of similar selective pressures—rather than because of recent common ancestry.
7.23.219	This phenomenon, called convergent evolution, is one reason why protist classification is so challenging.
7.23.220	The emerging classification scheme groups the entire domain Eukaryota into six “supergroups” that contain all of the protists as well as animals, plants, and fungi that evolved from a common ancestor (Figure 23.9).
7.23.221	The supergroups are believed to be monophyletic, meaning that all organisms within each supergroup are believed to have evolved from a single common ancestor, and thus all members are most closely related to each other than to organisms outside that group.
7.23.222	There is still evidence lacking for the monophyly of some groups.
7.23.223	This diagram shows a proposed classification of the domain Eukara.
7.23.224	Currently, the domain Eukarya is divided into six supergroups.
7.23.225	Within each supergroup are multiple kingdoms.
7.23.226	Dotted lines indicate suggested evolutionary relationships that remain under debate.
7.23.227	The classification of eukaryotes is still in flux, and the six supergroups may be modified or replaced by a more appropriate hierarchy as genetic, morphological, and ecological data accumulate.
7.23.228	Keep in mind that the classification scheme presented here is just one of several hypotheses, and the true evolutionary relationships are still to be determined.
7.23.229	When learning about protists, it is helpful to focus less on the nomenclature and more on the commonalities and differences that define the groups themselves.
7.23.230	Excavata
7.23.231	Many of the protist species classified into the supergroup Excavata are asymmetrical, single-celled organisms with a feeding groove “excavated” from one side.
7.23.232	This supergroup includes heterotrophic predators, photosynthetic species, and parasites.
7.23.233	Its subgroups are the diplomonads, parabasalids, and euglenozoans.
7.23.234	Diplomonads Among the Excavata are the diplomonads, which include the intestinal parasite, Giardia lamblia (Figure 23.10).
7.23.235	Until recently, these protists were believed to lack mitochondria.
7.23.236	Mitochondrial remnant organelles, called mitosomes, have since been identified in diplomonads, but these mitosomes are essentially nonfunctional.
7.23.237	Diplomonads exist in anaerobic environments and use alternative pathways, such as glycolysis, to generate energy.
7.23.238	Each diplomonad cell has two identical nuclei and uses several flagella for locomotion.
7.23.239	The mammalian intestinal parasite Giardia lamblia, visualized here using scanning electron microscopy, is a waterborne protist that causes severe diarrhea when ingested.
7.23.240	(credit: modification of work by Janice Carr, CDC; scale-bar data from Matt Russell)
7.23.241	Parabasalids
7.23.242	A second Excavata subgroup, the parabasalids, also exhibits semi-functional mitochondria.
7.23.243	In parabasalids, these structures function anaerobically and are called hydrogenosomes because they produce hydrogen gas as a byproduct.
7.23.244	Parabasalids move with flagella and membrane rippling.
7.23.245	Trichomonas vaginalis, a parabasalid that causes a sexually transmitted disease in humans, employs these mechanisms to transit through the male and female urogenital tracts.
7.23.246	T. vaginalis causes trichamoniasis, which appears in an estimated 180 million cases worldwide each year.
7.23.247	Whereas men rarely exhibit symptoms during an infection with this protist, infected women may become more susceptible to secondary infection with human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) and may be more likely to develop cervical cancer.
7.23.248	Pregnant women infected with T. vaginalis are at an increased risk of serious complications, such as pre-term delivery.
7.23.249	Euglenozoans Euglenozoans includes parasites, heterotrophs, autotrophs, and mixotrophs, ranging in size from 10 to 500 μm.
7.23.250	Euglenoids move through their aquatic habitats using two long flagella that guide them toward light sources sensed by a primitive ocular organ called an eyespot.
7.23.251	The familiar genus, Euglena, encompasses some mixotrophic species that display a photosynthetic capability only when light is present.
7.23.252	In the dark, the chloroplasts of Euglena shrink up and temporarily cease functioning, and the cells instead take up organic nutrients from their environment.
7.23.253	The human parasite, Trypanosoma brucei, belongs to a different subgroup of Euglenozoa, the kinetoplastids.
7.23.254	The kinetoplastid subgroup is named after the kinetoplast, a DNA mass carried within the single, oversized mitochondrion possessed by each of these cells.
7.23.255	This subgroup includes several parasites, collectively called trypanosomes, which cause devastating human diseases and infect an insect species during a portion of their life cycle.
7.23.256	T. brucei develops in the gut of the tsetse fly after the fly bites an infected human or other mammalian host.
7.23.257	The parasite then travels to the insect salivary glands to be transmitted to another human or other mammal when the infected tsetse fly consumes another blood meal.
7.23.258	T. brucei is common in central Africa and is the causative agent of African sleeping sickness, a disease associated with severe chronic fatigue, coma, and can be fatal if left untreated.
7.23.259	Trypanosoma brucei, the causative agent of sleeping sickness, spends part of its life cycle in the tsetse fly and part in humans.
7.23.260	Chromalveolata Current evidence suggests that species classified as chromalveolates are derived from a common ancestor that engulfed a photosynthetic red algal cell, which itself had already evolved chloroplasts from an endosymbiotic relationship with a photosynthetic prokaryote.
7.23.261	Therefore, the ancestor of chromalveolates is believed to have resulted from a secondary endosymbiotic event.
7.23.262	However, some chromalveolates appear to have lost red alga-derived plastid organelles or lack plastid genes altogether.
7.23.263	Therefore, this supergroup should be considered a hypothesis-based working group that is subject to change.
7.23.264	Chromalveolates include very important photosynthetic organisms, such as diatoms, brown algae, and significant disease agents in animals and plants.
7.23.265	The chromalveolates can be subdivided into alveolates and stramenopiles.
7.23.266	Alveolates: Dinoflagellates, Apicomplexians, and Ciliates
7.23.267	A large body of data supports that the alveolates are derived from a shared common ancestor.
7.23.268	The alveolates are named for the presence of an alveolus, or membrane-enclosed sac, beneath the cell membrane.
7.23.269	The exact function of the alveolus is unknown, but it may be involved in osmoregulation.
7.23.270	The alveolates are further categorized into some of the better-known protists: the dinoflagellates, the apicomplexans, and the ciliates.
7.23.271	Dinoflagellates exhibit extensive morphological diversity and can be photosynthetic, heterotrophic, or mixotrophic.
7.23.272	Many dinoflagellates are encased in interlocking plates of cellulose.
7.23.273	Two perpendicular flagella fit into the grooves between the cellulose plates, with one flagellum extending longitudinally and a second encircling the dinoflagellate (Figure 23.12).
7.23.274	Together, the flagella contribute to the characteristic spinning motion of dinoflagellates.
7.23.275	These protists exist in freshwater and marine habitats, and are a component of plankton, the typically microscopic organisms that drift through the water and serve as a crucial food source for larger aquatic organisms.
7.23.276	The dinoflagellates exhibit great diversity in shape.
7.23.277	Many are encased in cellulose armor and have two flagella that fit in grooves between the plates.
7.23.278	Movement of these two perpendicular flagella causes a spinning motion.
7.23.279	Some dinoflagellates generate light, called bioluminescence, when they are jarred or stressed.
7.23.280	Large numbers of marine dinoflagellates (billions or trillions of cells per wave) can emit light and cause an entire breaking wave to twinkle or take on a brilliant blue color (Figure 23.13).
7.23.281	For approximately 20 species of marine dinoflagellates, population explosions (also called blooms) during the summer months can tint the ocean with a muddy red color.
7.23.282	This phenomenon is called a red tide, and it results from the abundant red pigments present in dinoflagellate plastids.
7.23.283	In large quantities, these dinoflagellate species secrete an asphyxiating toxin that can kill fish, birds, and marine mammals.
7.23.284	Red tides can be massively detrimental to commercial fisheries, and humans who consume these protists may become poisoned.
7.23.285	Bioluminescence is emitted from dinoflagellates in a breaking wave, as seen from the New Jersey coast.
7.23.286	The apicomplexan protists are so named because their microtubules, fibrin, and vacuoles are asymmetrically distributed at one end of the cell in a structure called an apical complex (Figure 23.14).
7.23.287	The apical complex is specialized for entry and infection of host cells.
7.23.288	Indeed, all apicomplexans are parasitic.
7.23.289	This group includes the genus Plasmodium, which causes malaria in humans.
7.23.290	Apicomplexan life cycles are complex, involving multiple hosts and stages of sexual and asexual reproduction.
7.23.291	Apicomplexans are parasitic protists.
7.23.292	They have a characteristic apical complex that enables them to infect host cells.
7.23.293	(b) Plasmodium, the causative agent of malaria, has a complex life cycle typical of apicomplexans.
7.23.294	The ciliates, which include Paramecium and Tetrahymena, are a group of protists 10 to 3,000 micrometers in length that are covered in rows, tufts, or spirals of tiny cilia.
7.23.295	By beating their cilia synchronously or in waves, ciliates can coordinate directed movements and ingest food particles.
7.23.296	Certain ciliates have fused cilia-based structures that function like paddles, funnels, or fins.
7.23.297	Ciliates also are surrounded by a pellicle, providing protection without compromising agility.
7.23.298	The genus Paramecium includes protists that have organized their cilia into a plate-like primitive mouth, called an oral groove, which is used to capture and digest bacteria (Figure 23.15).
7.23.299	Food captured in the oral groove enters a food vacuole, where it combines with digestive enzymes.
7.23.300	Waste particles are expelled by an exocytic vesicle that fuses at a specific region on the cell membrane, called the anal pore.
7.23.301	In addition to a vacuole-based digestive system, Paramecium also uses contractile vacuoles, which are osmoregulatory vesicles that fill with water as it enters the cell by osmosis and then contract to squeeze water from the cell.
7.23.302	Paramecium has a primitive mouth (called an oral groove) to ingest food, and an anal pore to excrete it.
7.23.303	Contractile vacuoles allow the organism to excrete excess water.
7.23.304	Cilia enable the organism to move.
7.23.305	Paramecium has two nuclei, a macronucleus and a micronucleus, in each cell.
7.23.306	The micronucleus is essential for sexual reproduction, whereas the macronucleus directs asexual binary fission and all other biological functions.
7.23.307	The process of sexual reproduction in Paramecium underscores the importance of the micronucleus to these protists.
7.23.308	Paramecium and most other ciliates reproduce sexually by conjugation.
7.23.309	This process begins when two different mating types of Paramecium make physical contact and join with a cytoplasmic bridge (Figure 23.16).
7.23.310	The diploid micronucleus in each cell then undergoes meiosis to produce four haploid micronuclei.
7.23.311	Three of these degenerate in each cell, leaving one micronucleus that then undergoes mitosis, generating two haploid micronuclei.
7.23.312	The cells each exchange one of these haploid nuclei and move away from each other.
7.23.313	A similar process occurs in bacteria that have plasmids.
7.23.314	Fusion of the haploid micronuclei generates a completely novel diploid pre-micronucleus in each conjugative cell.
7.23.315	This pre-micronucleus undergoes three rounds of mitosis to produce eight copies, and the original macronucleus disintegrates.
7.23.316	Four of the eight pre-micronuclei become full-fledged micronuclei, whereas the other four perform multiple rounds of DNA replication and go on to become new macronuclei.
7.23.317	Two cell divisions then yield four new Paramecia from each original conjugative cell.
7.23.318	Stramenopiles:
7.23.319	Diatoms, Brown Algae, Golden Algae and Oomycetes
7.23.320	The other subgroup of chromalveolates, the stramenopiles, includes photosynthetic marine algae and heterotrophic protists.
7.23.321	The unifying feature of this group is the presence of a textured, or “hairy,” flagellum.
7.23.322	Many stramenopiles also have an additional flagellum that lacks hair-like projections (Figure 23.17).
7.23.323	Members of this subgroup range in size from singlecelled diatoms to the massive and multicellular kelp.
7.23.324	This stramenopile cell has a single hairy flagellum and a secondary smooth flagellum.
7.23.325	The diatoms are unicellular photosynthetic protists that encase themselves in intricately patterned, glassy cell walls composed of silicon dioxide in a matrix of organic particles (Figure 23.18).
7.23.326	These protists are a component of freshwater and marine plankton.
7.23.327	Most species of diatoms reproduce asexually, although some instances of sexual reproduction and sporulation also exist.
7.23.328	Some diatoms exhibit a slit in their silica shell, called a raphe.
7.23.329	By expelling a stream of mucopolysaccharides from the raphe, the diatom can attach to surfaces or propel itself in one direction.
7.23.330	Assorted diatoms, visualized here using light microscopy, live among annual sea ice in McMurdo Sound, Antarctica.
7.23.331	Diatoms range in size from 2 to 200 μm.
7.23.332	(credit: Prof. Gordon T. Taylor, Stony Brook University, NSF, NOAA)
7.23.333	During periods of nutrient availability, diatom populations bloom to numbers greater than can be consumed by aquatic organisms.
7.23.334	The excess diatoms die and sink to the sea floor where they are not easily reached by saprobes that feed on dead organisms.
7.23.335	As a result, the carbon dioxide that the diatoms had consumed and incorporated into their cells during photosynthesis is not returned to the atmosphere.
7.23.336	In general, this process by which carbon is transported deep into the ocean is described as the biological carbon pump, because carbon is “pumped” to the ocean depths where it is inaccessible to the atmosphere as carbon dioxide.
7.23.337	The biological carbon pump is a crucial component of the carbon cycle that maintains lower atmospheric carbon dioxide levels.
7.23.338	Like diatoms, golden algae are largely unicellular, although some species can form large colonies.
7.23.339	Their characteristic gold color results from their extensive use of carotenoids, a group of photosynthetic pigments that are generally yellow or orange in color.
7.23.340	Golden algae are found in both freshwater and marine environments, where they form a major part of the plankton community.
7.23.341	The brown algae are primarily marine, multicellular organisms that are known colloquially as seaweeds.
7.23.342	Giant kelps are a type of brown algae.
7.23.343	Some brown algae have evolved specialized tissues that resemble terrestrial plants, with root-like holdfasts, stem-like stipes, and leaf-like blades that are capable of photosynthesis.
7.23.344	The stipes of giant kelps are enormous, extending in some cases for 60 meters.
7.23.345	A variety of algal life cycles exists, but the most complex is alternation of generations, in which both haploid and diploid stages involve multicellularity.
7.23.346	Compare this life cycle to that of humans, for instance.
7.23.347	Haploid gametes produced by meiosis (sperm and egg) combine in fertilization to generate a diploid zygote that undergoes many rounds of mitosis to produce a multicellular embryo and then a fetus.
7.23.348	However, the individual sperm and egg themselves never become multicellular beings.
7.23.349	Terrestrial plants also have evolved alternation of generations.
7.23.350	In the brown algae genus Laminaria, haploid spores develop into multicellular gametophytes, which produce haploid gametes that combine to produce diploid organisms that then become multicellular organisms with a different structure from the haploid form (Figure 23.19).
7.23.351	Certain other organisms perform alternation of generations in which both the haploid and diploid forms look the same.
7.23.352	The water molds, oomycetes (“egg fungus”), were so-named based on their fungus-like morphology, but molecular data have shown that the water molds are not closely related to fungi.
7.23.353	The oomycetes are characterized by a cellulose-based cell wall and an extensive network of filaments that allow for nutrient uptake.
7.23.354	As diploid spores, many oomycetes have two oppositely directed flagella (one hairy and one smooth) for locomotion.
7.23.355	The oomycetes are nonphotosynthetic and include many saprobes and parasites.
7.23.356	The saprobes appear as white fluffy growths on dead organisms (Figure 23.20).
7.23.357	Most oomycetes are aquatic, but some parasitize terrestrial plants.
7.23.358	One plant pathogen is Phytophthora infestans, the causative agent of late blight of potatoes, such as occurred in the nineteenth century Irish potato famine.
7.23.359	A saprobic oomycete engulfs a dead insect.
7.23.360	(credit: modification of work by Thomas Bresson)
7.23.361	Rhizaria
7.23.362	The Rhizaria supergroup includes many of the amoebas, most of which have threadlike or needle-like pseudopodia (Figure 23.21).
7.23.363	Pseudopodia function to trap and engulf food particles and to direct movement in rhizarian protists.
7.23.364	These pseudopods project outward from anywhere on the cell surface and can anchor to a substrate.
7.23.365	The protist then transports its cytoplasm into the pseudopod, thereby moving the entire cell.
7.23.366	This type of motion, called cytoplasmic streaming, is used by several diverse groups of protists as a means of locomotion or as a method to distribute nutrients and oxygen.
7.23.367	Ammonia tepida, a Rhizaria species viewed here using phase contrast light microscopy, exhibits many threadlike pseudopodia.
7.23.368	Forams Foraminiferans, or forams, are unicellular heterotrophic protists, ranging from approximately 20 micrometers to several centimeters in length, and occasionally resembling tiny snails (Figure 23.22).
7.23.369	As a group, the forams exhibit porous shells, called tests that are built from various organic materials and typically hardened with calcium carbonate.
7.23.370	The tests may house photosynthetic algae, which the forams can harvest for nutrition.
7.23.371	Foram pseudopodia extend through the pores and allow the forams to move, feed, and gather additional building materials.
7.23.372	Typically, forams are associated with sand or other particles in marine or freshwater habitats.
7.23.373	Foraminiferans are also useful as indicators of pollution and changes in global weather patterns.
7.23.374	These shells from foraminifera sank to the sea floor.
7.23.375	(credit:
7.23.376	Deep East 2001, NOAA/OER)
7.23.377	Radiolarians A second subtype of Rhizaria, the radiolarians, exhibit intricate exteriors of glassy silica with radial or bilateral symmetry (Figure 23.23).
7.23.378	Needle-like pseudopods supported by microtubules radiate outward from the cell bodies of these protists and function to catch food particles.
7.23.379	The shells of dead radiolarians sink to the ocean floor, where they may accumulate in 100 meter-thick depths.
7.23.380	Preserved, sedimented radiolarians are very common in the fossil record.
7.23.381	This fossilized radiolarian shell was imaged using a scanning electron microscope.
7.23.382	(credit: modification of work by Hannes Grobe, Alfred Wegener Institute; scale-bar data from Matt Russell)
7.23.383	Archaeplastida Red algae and green algae are included in the supergroup Archaeplastida.
7.23.384	It was from a common ancestor of these protists that the land plants evolved, since their closest relatives are found in this group.
7.23.385	Molecular evidence supports that all Archaeplastida are descendents of an endosymbiotic relationship between a heterotrophic protist and a cyanobacterium.
7.23.386	The red and green algae include unicellular, multicellular, and colonial forms.
7.23.387	Red Algae Red algae, or rhodophytes, are primarily multicellular, lack flagella, and range in size from microscopic, unicellular protists to large, multicellular forms grouped into the informal seaweed category.
7.23.388	The red algae life cycle is an alternation of generations.
7.23.389	Some species of red algae contain phycoerythrins, photosynthetic accessory pigments that are red in color and outcompete the green tint of chlorophyll, making these species appear as varying shades of red.
7.23.390	Other protists classified as red algae lack phycoerythrins and are parasites.
7.23.391	Red algae are common in tropical waters where they have been detected at depths of 260 meters.
7.23.392	Other red algae exist in terrestrial or freshwater environments.
7.23.393	Green Algae: Chlorophytes and Charophytes
7.23.394	The most abundant group of algae is the green algae.
7.23.395	The green algae exhibit similar features to the land plants, particularly in terms of chloroplast structure.
7.23.396	That this group of protists shared a relatively recent common ancestor with land plants is well supported.
7.23.397	The green algae are subdivided into the chlorophytes and the charophytes.
7.23.398	The charophytes are the closest living relatives to land plants and resemble them in morphology and reproductive strategies.
7.23.399	Charophytes are common in wet habitats, and their presence often signals a healthy ecosystem.
7.23.400	The chlorophytes exhibit great diversity of form and function.
7.23.401	Chlorophytes primarily inhabit freshwater and damp soil, and are a common component of plankton.
7.23.402	Chlamydomonas is a simple, unicellular chlorophyte with a pear-shaped morphology and two opposing, anterior flagella that guide this protist toward light sensed by its eyespot.
7.23.403	More complex chlorophyte species exhibit haploid gametes and spores that resemble Chlamydomonas.
7.23.404	The chlorophyte Volvox is one of only a few examples of a colonial organism, which behaves in some ways like a collection of individual cells, but in other ways like the specialized cells of a multicellular organism (Figure 23.24).
7.23.405	Volvox colonies contain 500 to 60,000 cells, each with two flagella, contained within a hollow, spherical matrix composed of a gelatinous glycoprotein secretion.
7.23.406	Individual Volvox cells move in a coordinated fashion and are interconnected by cytoplasmic bridges.
7.23.407	Only a few of the cells reproduce to create daughter colonies, an example of basic cell specialization in this organism.
7.23.408	Volvox aureus is a green alga in the supergroup Archaeplastida.
7.23.409	This species exists as a colony, consisting of cells immersed in a gel-like matrix and intertwined with each other via hair-like cytoplasmic extensions.
7.23.410	True multicellular organisms, such as the sea lettuce, Ulva, are represented among the chlorophytes.
7.23.411	In addition, some chlorophytes exist as large, multinucleate, single cells.
7.23.412	Species in the genus Caulerpa exhibit flattened fern-like foliage and can reach lengths of 3 meters (Figure 23.25).
7.23.413	Caulerpa species undergo nuclear division, but their cells do not complete cytokinesis, remaining instead as massive and elaborate single cells.
7.23.414	Caulerpa taxifolia is a chlorophyte consisting of a single cell containing potentially thousands of nuclei.
7.23.415	Amoebozoa The amoebozoans characteristically exhibit pseudopodia that extend like tubes or flat lobes, rather than the hair-like pseudopodia of rhizarian amoeba (Figure 23.26).
7.23.416	The Amoebozoa include several groups of unicellular amoeba-like organisms that are free-living or parasites.
7.23.417	Amoebae with tubular and lobe-shaped pseudopodia are seen under a microscope.
7.23.418	These isolates would be morphologically classified as amoebozoans.
7.23.419	Slime Molds
7.23.420	A subset of the amoebozoans, the slime molds, has several morphological similarities to fungi that are thought to be the result of convergent evolution.
7.23.421	For instance, during times of stress, some slime molds develop into spore-generating fruiting bodies, much like fungi.
7.23.422	The slime molds are categorized on the basis of their life cycles into plasmodial or cellular types.
7.23.423	Plasmodial slime molds are composed of large, multinucleate cells and move along surfaces like an amorphous blob of slime during their feeding stage (Figure 23.27).
7.23.424	Food particles are lifted and engulfed into the slime mold as it glides along.
7.23.425	Upon maturation, the plasmodium takes on a net-like appearance with the ability to form fruiting bodies, or sporangia, during times of stress.
7.23.426	Haploid spores are produced by meiosis within the sporangia, and spores can be disseminated through the air or water to potentially land in more favorable environments.
7.23.427	If this occurs, the spores germinate to form ameboid or flagellate haploid cells that can combine with each other and produce a diploid zygotic slime mold to complete the life cycle.
7.23.428	The life cycle of the plasmodial slime mold is shown.
7.23.429	The brightly colored plasmodium in the inset photo is a single-celled, multinucleate mass.
7.23.430	The cellular slime molds function as independent amoeboid cells when nutrients are abundant (Figure 23.28).
7.23.431	When food is depleted, cellular slime molds pile onto each other into a mass of cells that behaves as a single unit, called a slug.
7.23.432	Some cells in the slug contribute to a 2–3-millimeter stalk, drying up and dying in the process.
7.23.433	Cells atop the stalk form an asexual fruiting body that contains haploid spores.
7.23.434	As with plasmodial slime molds, the spores are disseminated and can germinate if they land in a moist environment.
7.23.435	One representative genus of the cellular slime molds is Dictyostelium, which commonly exists in the damp soil of forests.
7.23.436	Cellular slime molds may exist as solitary or aggregated amoebas.
7.23.437	Opisthokonta
7.23.438	The opisthokonts include the animal-like choanoflagellates, which are believed to resemble the common ancestor of sponges and, in fact, all animals.
7.23.439	Choanoflagellates include unicellular and colonial forms, and number about 244 described species.
7.23.440	These organisms exhibit a single, apical flagellum that is surrounded by a contractile collar composed of microvilli.
7.23.441	The collar uses a similar mechanism to sponges to filter out bacteria for ingestion by the protist.
7.23.442	The morphology of choanoflagellates was recognized early on as resembling the collar cells of sponges, and suggesting a possible relationship to animals.
7.23.443	The Mesomycetozoa form a small group of parasites, primarily of fish, and at least one form that can parasitize humans.
7.23.444	Their life cycles are poorly understood.
7.23.445	These organisms are of special interest, because they appear to be so closely related to animals.
7.23.446	In the past, they were grouped with fungi and other protists based on their morphology.
7.23.447	Protists function in various ecological niches.
7.23.448	Whereas some protist species are essential components of the food chain and generators of biomass, others function in the decomposition of organic materials.
7.23.449	Still other protists are dangerous human pathogens or causative agents of devastating plant diseases.
7.23.450	Primary Producers/Food Sources Protists are essential sources of nutrition for many other organisms.
7.23.451	In some cases, as in plankton, protists are consumed directly.
7.23.452	Alternatively, photosynthetic protists serve as producers of nutrition for other organisms.
7.23.453	For instance, photosynthetic dinoflagellates called zooxanthellae use sunlight to fix inorganic carbon.
7.23.454	In this symbiotic relationship, these protists provide nutrients for coral polyps (Figure 23.29) that house them, giving corals a boost of energy to secrete a calcium carbonate skeleton.
7.23.455	In turn, the corals provide the protist with a protected environment and the compounds needed for photosynthesis.
7.23.456	This type of symbiotic relationship is important in nutrient-poor environments.
7.23.457	Without dinoflagellate symbionts, corals lose algal pigments in a process called coral bleaching, and they eventually die.
7.23.458	This explains why reefbuilding corals do not reside in waters deeper than 20 meters: insufficient light reaches those depths for dinoflagellates to photosynthesize.
7.23.459	Coral polyps obtain nutrition through a symbiotic relationship with dinoflagellates.
7.23.460	The protists themselves and their products of photosynthesis are essential—directly or indirectly—to the survival of organisms ranging from bacteria to mammals (Figure 23.30).
7.23.461	As primary producers, protists feed a large proportion of the world’s aquatic species.
7.23.462	(On land, terrestrial plants serve as primary producers.)
7.23.463	In fact, approximately one-quarter of the world’s photosynthesis is conducted by protists, particularly dinoflagellates, diatoms, and multicellular algae.
7.23.464	Virtually all aquatic organisms depend directly or indirectly on protists for food.
7.23.465	Protists do not create food sources only for sea-dwelling organisms.
7.23.466	For instance, certain anaerobic parabasalid species exist in the digestive tracts of termites and wood-eating cockroaches, where they contribute an essential step in the digestion of cellulose ingested by these insects as they bore through wood.
7.23.467	Human Pathogens
7.23.468	A pathogen is anything that causes disease.
7.23.469	Parasites live in or on an organism and harm the organism.
7.23.470	A significant number of protists are pathogenic parasites that must infect other organisms to survive and propagate.
7.23.471	Protist parasites include the causative agents of malaria, African sleeping sickness, and waterborne gastroenteritis in humans.
7.23.472	Other protist pathogens prey on plants, effecting massive destruction of food crops.
7.23.473	Plasmodium Species Members of the genus
7.23.474	Plasmodium must colonize both a mosquito and a vertebrate to complete their life cycle.
7.23.475	In vertebrates, the parasite develops in liver cells and goes on to infect red blood cells, bursting from and destroying the blood cells with each asexual replication cycle (Figure 23.31).
7.23.476	Of the four Plasmodium species known to infect humans, P. falciparum accounts for 50 percent of all malaria cases and is the primary cause of disease-related fatalities in tropical regions of the world.
7.23.477	In 2010, it was estimated that malaria caused between one-half and one million deaths, mostly in African children.
7.23.478	During the course of malaria, P. falciparum can infect and destroy more than one-half of a human’s circulating blood cells, leading to severe anemia.
7.23.479	In response to waste products released as the parasites burst from infected blood cells, the host immune system mounts a massive inflammatory response with episodes of delirium-inducing fever as parasites lyse red blood cells, spilling parasite waste into the bloodstream.
7.23.480	P. falciparum is transmitted to humans by the African malaria mosquito, Anopheles gambiae.
7.23.481	Techniques to kill, sterilize, or avoid exposure to this highly aggressive mosquito species are crucial to malaria control.
7.23.482	Red blood cells are shown to be infected with P. falciparum, the causative agent of malaria.
7.23.483	In this light microscopic image taken using a 100× oil immersion lens, the ring-shaped P. falciparum stains purple.
7.23.484	Trypanosomes Trypanosoma brucei, the parasite that is responsible for African sleeping sickness, confounds the human immune system by changing its thick layer of surface glycoproteins with each infectious cycle (Figure 23.32).
7.23.485	The glycoproteins are identified by the immune system as foreign antigens, and a specific antibody defense is mounted against the parasite.
7.23.486	However, T. brucei has thousands of possible antigens, and with each subsequent generation, the protist switches to a glycoprotein coating with a different molecular structure.
7.23.487	In this way, T. brucei is capable of replicating continuously without the immune system ever succeeding in clearing the parasite.
7.23.488	Without treatment, T. brucei attacks red blood cells, causing the patient to lapse into a coma and eventually die.
7.23.489	During epidemic periods, mortality from the disease can be high.
7.23.490	Greater surveillance and control measures lead to a reduction in reported cases; some of the lowest numbers reported in 50 years (fewer than 10,000 cases in all of sub-Saharan Africa) have happened since 2009.
7.23.491	In Latin America, another species, T. cruzi, is responsible for Chagas disease.
7.23.492	T. cruzi infections are mainly caused by a blood-sucking bug.
7.23.493	The parasite inhabits heart and digestive system tissues in the chronic phase of infection, leading to malnutrition and heart failure due to abnormal heart rhythms.
7.23.494	An estimated 10 million people are infected with Chagas disease, and it caused 10,000 deaths in 2008.
7.23.495	Trypanosomes are shown among red blood cells.
7.23.496	Plant Parasites Protist parasites of terrestrial plants include agents that destroy food crops.
7.23.497	The oomycete Plasmopara viticola parasitizes grape plants, causing a disease called downy mildew (Figure 23.33).
7.23.498	Grape plants infected with P. viticola appear stunted and have discolored, withered leaves.
7.23.499	The spread of downy mildew nearly collapsed the French wine industry in the nineteenth century.
7.23.500	Both downy and powdery mildews on this grape leaf are caused by an infection of P. viticola.
7.23.501	Phytophthora infestans is an oomycete responsible for potato late blight, which causes potato stalks and stems to decay into black slime
7.23.502	(Figure 23.34).
7.23.503	Widespread potato blight caused by P. infestans precipitated the well-known Irish potato famine in the nineteenth century that claimed the lives of approximately 1 million people and led to the emigration of at least 1 million more from Ireland.
7.23.504	Late blight continues to plague potato crops in certain parts of the United States and Russia, wiping out as much as 70 percent of crops when no pesticides are applied.
7.23.505	These unappetizing remnants result from an infection with P. infestans, the causative agent of potato late blight.
7.23.506	Agents of Decomposition
7.23.507	The fungus-like protist saprobes are specialized to absorb nutrients from nonliving organic matter, such as dead organisms or their wastes.
7.23.508	For instance, many types of oomycetes grow on dead animals or algae.
7.23.509	Saprobic protists have the essential function of returning inorganic nutrients to the soil and water.
7.23.510	This process allows for new plant growth, which in turn generates sustenance for other organisms along the food chain.
7.23.511	Indeed, without saprobe species, such as protists, fungi, and bacteria, life would cease to exist as all organic carbon became “tied up” in dead organisms.
7.24.0	Many species of fungus produce the familiar mushroom (a) which is a reproductive structure.
7.24.1	This (b) coral fungus displays brightly colored fruiting bodies.
7.24.2	This electron micrograph shows (c) the spore-bearing structures of Aspergillus, a type of toxic fungi found mostly in soil and plants.
7.24.3	The word fungus comes from the Latin word for mushrooms.
7.24.4	Indeed, the familiar mushroom is a reproductive structure used by many types of fungi.
7.24.5	However, there are also many fungi species that don't produce mushrooms at all.
7.24.6	Being eukaryotes, a typical fungal cell contains a true nucleus and many membrane-bound organelles.
7.24.7	The kingdom Fungi includes an enormous variety of living organisms collectively referred to as Eucomycota, or true Fungi.
7.24.8	While scientists have identified about 100,000 species of fungi, this is only a fraction of the 1.5 million species of fungus likely present on Earth.
7.24.9	Edible mushrooms, yeasts, black mold, and the producer of the antibiotic penicillin, Penicillium notatum, are all members of the kingdom Fungi, which belongs to the domain Eukarya.
7.24.10	Fungi, once considered plant-like organisms, are more closely related to animals than plants.
7.24.11	Fungi are not capable of photosynthesis: they are heterotrophic because they use complex organic compounds as sources of energy and carbon.
7.24.12	Some fungal organisms multiply only asexually, whereas others undergo both asexual reproduction and sexual reproduction with alternation of generations.
7.24.13	Most fungi produce a large number of spores, which are haploid cells that can undergo mitosis to form multicellular, haploid individuals.
7.24.14	Like bacteria, fungi play an essential role in ecosystems because they are decomposers and participate in the cycling of nutrients by breaking down organic materials to simple molecules.
7.24.15	Fungi often interact with other organisms, forming beneficial or mutualistic associations.
7.24.16	For example most terrestrial plants form symbiotic relationships with fungi.
7.24.17	The roots of the plant connect with the underground parts of the fungus forming mycorrhizae.
7.24.18	Through mycorrhizae, the fungus and plant exchange nutrients and water, greatly aiding the survival of both species Alternatively, lichens are an association between a fungus and its photosynthetic partner (usually an alga).
7.24.19	Fungi also cause serious infections in plants and animals.
7.24.20	For example, Dutch elm disease, which is caused by the fungus Ophiostoma ulmi, is a particularly devastating type of fungal infestation that destroys many native species of elm (Ulmus sp.) by infecting the tree’s vascular system.
7.24.21	The elm bark beetle acts as a vector, transmitting the disease from tree to tree.
7.24.22	Accidentally introduced in the 1900s, the fungus decimated elm trees across the continent.
7.24.23	Many European and Asiatic elms are less susceptible to Dutch elm disease than American elms.
7.24.24	In humans, fungal infections are generally considered challenging to treat.
7.24.25	Unlike bacteria, fungi do not respond to traditional antibiotic therapy, since they are eukaryotes.
7.24.26	Fungal infections may prove deadly for individuals with compromised immune systems.
7.24.27	Fungi have many commercial applications.
7.24.28	The food industry uses yeasts in baking, brewing, and cheese and wine making.
7.24.29	Many industrial compounds are byproducts of fungal fermentation.
7.24.30	Fungi are the source of many commercial enzymes and antibiotics.
7.24.31	Although humans have used yeasts and mushrooms since prehistoric times, until recently, the biology of fungi was poorly understood.
7.24.32	Up until the mid-20th century, many scientists classified fungi as plants.
7.24.33	Fungi, like plants, arose mostly sessile and seemingly rooted in place.
7.24.34	They possess a stem-like structure similar to plants, as well as having a root-like fungal mycelium in the soil.
7.24.35	In addition, their mode of nutrition was poorly understood.
7.24.36	Progress in the field of fungal biology was the result of mycology: the scientific study of fungi.
7.24.37	Based on fossil evidence, fungi appeared in the pre-Cambrian era, about 450 million years ago.
7.24.38	Molecular biology analysis of the fungal genome demonstrates that fungi are more closely related to animals than plants.
7.24.39	They are a polyphyletic group of organisms that share characteristics, rather than sharing a single common ancestor.
7.24.40	Cell Structure and Function Fungi are eukaryotes, and as such, have a complex cellular organization.
7.24.41	As eukaryotes, fungal cells contain a membranebound nucleus.
7.24.42	The DNA in the nucleus is wrapped around histone proteins, as is observed in other eukaryotic cells.
7.24.43	A few types of fungi have structures comparable to bacterial plasmids (loops of DNA); however, the horizontal transfer of genetic information from one mature bacterium to another rarely occurs in fungi.
7.24.44	Fungal cells also contain mitochondria and a complex system of internal membranes, including the endoplasmic reticulum and Golgi apparatus.
7.24.45	Unlike plant cells, fungal cells do not have chloroplasts or chlorophyll.
7.24.46	Many fungi display bright colors arising from other cellular pigments, ranging from red to green to black.
7.24.47	The poisonous Amanita muscaria (fly agaric) is recognizable by its bright red cap with white patches (Figure 24.2).
7.24.48	Pigments in fungi are associated with the cell wall and play a protective role against ultraviolet radiation.
7.24.49	Some fungal pigments are toxic.
7.24.50	The poisonous Amanita muscaria is native to temperate and boreal regions of North America.
7.24.51	Like plant cells, fungal cells have a thick cell wall.
7.24.52	The rigid layers of fungal cell walls contain complex polysaccharides called chitin and glucans.
7.24.53	Chitin, also found in the exoskeleton of insects, gives structural strength to the cell walls of fungi.
7.24.54	The wall protects the cell from desiccation and predators.
7.24.55	Fungi have plasma membranes similar to other eukaryotes, except that the structure is stabilized by ergosterol: a steroid molecule that replaces the cholesterol found in animal cell membranes.
7.24.56	Most members of the kingdom Fungi are nonmotile.
7.24.57	Flagella are produced only by the gametes in the primitive Phylum Chytridiomycota.
7.24.58	Growth
7.24.59	The vegetative body of a fungus is a unicellular or multicellular thallus.
7.24.60	Dimorphic fungi can change from the unicellular to multicellular state depending on environmental conditions.
7.24.61	Unicellular fungi are generally referred to as yeasts.
7.24.62	Saccharomyces cerevisiae (baker’s yeast) and Candida species (the agents of thrush, a common fungal infection) are examples of unicellular fungi.
7.24.63	Candida albicans is a yeast cell and the agent of candidiasis and thrush.
7.24.64	This organism has a similar morphology to coccus bacteria; however, yeast is a eukaryotic organism (note the nucleus).
7.24.65	Most fungi are multicellular organisms.
7.24.66	They display two distinct morphological stages: the vegetative and reproductive.
7.24.67	The vegetative stage consists of a tangle of slender thread-like structures called hyphae (singular, hypha), whereas the reproductive stage can be more conspicuous.
7.24.68	The mass of hyphae is a mycelium (Figure 24.4).
7.24.69	It can grow on a surface, in soil or decaying material, in a liquid, or even on living tissue.
7.24.70	Although individual hyphae must be observed under a microscope, the mycelium of a fungus can be very large, with some species truly being “the fungus humongous.
7.24.71	”
7.24.72	The giant Armillaria solidipes (honey mushroom) is considered the largest organism on Earth, spreading across more than 2,000 acres of underground soil in eastern Oregon; it is estimated to be at least 2,400 years old.
7.24.73	The mycelium of the fungus Neotestudina rosati can be pathogenic to humans.
7.24.74	The fungus enters through a cut or scrape and develops a mycetoma, a chronic subcutaneous infection.
7.24.75	Most fungal hyphae are divided into separate cells by endwalls called septa (singular, septum)
7.24.76	(Figure 24.5a, c).
7.24.77	In most phyla of fungi, tiny holes in the septa allow for the rapid flow of nutrients and small molecules from cell to cell along the hypha.
7.24.78	They are described as perforated septa.
7.24.79	The hyphae in bread molds (which belong to the Phylum Zygomycota) are not separated by septa.
7.24.80	Instead, they are formed by large cells containing many nuclei, an arrangement described as coenocytic hyphae.
7.24.81	Fungal hyphae may be (a) septated or (b) coenocytic (coeno- = "common"; -cytic = "cell") with many nuclei present in a single hypha.
7.24.82	A bright field light micrograph of (c)
7.24.83	Phialophora richardsiae shows septa that divide the hyphae.
7.24.84	Fungi thrive in environments that are moist and slightly acidic, and can grow with or without light.
7.24.85	They vary in their oxygen requirement.
7.24.86	Most fungi are obligate aerobes, requiring oxygen to survive.
7.24.87	Other species, such as the Chytridiomycota that reside in the rumen of cattle, are are obligate anaerobes, in that they only use anaerobic respiration because oxygen will disrupt their metabolism or kill them.
7.24.88	Yeasts are intermediate, being faculative anaerobes.
7.24.89	This means that they grow best in the presence of oxygen using aerobic respiration, but can survive using anaerobic respiration when oxygen is not available.
7.24.90	The alcohol produced from yeast fermentation is used in wine and beer production.
7.24.91	Nutrition Like animals, fungi are heterotrophs; they use complex organic compounds as a source of carbon, rather than fix carbon dioxide from the atmosphere as do some bacteria and most plants.
7.24.92	In addition, fungi do not fix nitrogen from the atmosphere.
7.24.93	Like animals, they must obtain it from their diet.
7.24.94	However, unlike most animals, which ingest food and then digest it internally in specialized organs, fungi perform these steps in the reverse order; digestion precedes ingestion.
7.24.95	First, exoenzymes are transported out of the hyphae, where they process nutrients in the environment.
7.24.96	Then, the smaller molecules produced by this external digestion are absorbed through the large surface area of the mycelium.
7.24.97	As with animal cells, the polysaccharide of storage is glycogen, rather than starch, as found in plants.
7.24.98	Fungi are mostly saprobes (saprophyte is an equivalent term): organisms that derive nutrients from decaying organic matter.
7.24.99	They obtain their nutrients from dead or decomposing organic matter: mainly plant material.
7.24.100	Fungal exoenzymes are able to break down insoluble polysaccharides, such as the cellulose and lignin of dead wood, into readily absorbable glucose molecules.
7.24.101	The carbon, nitrogen, and other elements are thus released into the environment.
7.24.102	Because of their varied metabolic pathways, fungi fulfill an important ecological role and are being investigated as potential tools in bioremediation.
7.24.103	For example, some species of fungi can be used to break down diesel oil and polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs).
7.24.104	Other species take up heavy metals, such as cadmium and lead.
7.24.105	Some fungi are parasitic, infecting either plants or animals.
7.24.106	Smut and Dutch elm disease affect plants, whereas athlete’s foot and candidiasis (thrush) are medically important fungal infections in humans.
7.24.107	In environments poor in nitrogen, some fungi resort to predation of nematodes (small non-segmented roundworms).
7.24.108	Species of Arthrobotrys fungi have a number of mechanisms to trap nematodes.
7.24.109	One mechanism involves constricting rings within the network of hyphae.
7.24.110	The rings swell when they touch the nematode, gripping it in a tight hold.
7.24.111	The fungus penetrates the tissue of the worm by extending specialized hyphae called haustoria.
7.24.112	Many parasitic fungi possess haustoria, as these structures penetrate the tissues of the host, release digestive enzymes within the host's body, and absorb the digested nutrients.
7.24.113	Reproduction Fungi reproduce sexually and/or asexually.
7.24.114	Perfect fungi reproduce both sexually and asexually, while the so-called imperfect fungi reproduce only asexually (by mitosis).
7.24.115	In both sexual and asexual reproduction, fungi produce spores that disperse from the parent organism by either floating on the wind or hitching a ride on an animal.
7.24.116	Fungal spores are smaller and lighter than plant seeds.
7.24.117	The giant puffball mushroom bursts open and releases trillions of spores.
7.24.118	The huge number of spores released increases the likelihood of landing in an environment that will support growth.
7.24.119	The (a) giant puff ball mushroom releases (b) a cloud of spores when it reaches maturity.
7.24.120	The dark cells in this bright field light micrograph are the pathogenic yeast Histoplasma capsulatum, seen against a backdrop of light blue tissue.
7.24.121	Histoplasma primarily infects lungs but can spread to other tissues, causing histoplasmosis, a potentially fatal disease.
7.24.122	The most common mode of asexual reproduction is through the formation of asexual spores, which are produced by one parent only (through mitosis) and are genetically identical to that parent (Figure 24.8).
7.24.123	Spores allow fungi to expand their distribution and colonize new environments.
7.24.124	They may be released from the parent thallus either outside or within a special reproductive sac called a sporangium.
7.24.125	Fungi may have both asexual and sexual stages of reproduction.
7.24.126	There are many types of asexual spores.
7.24.127	Conidiospores are unicellular or multicellular spores that are released directly from the tip or side of the hypha.
7.24.128	Other asexual spores originate in the fragmentation of a hypha to form single cells that are released as spores; some of these have a thick wall surrounding the fragment.
7.24.129	Yet others bud off the vegetative parent cell.
7.24.130	Sporangiospores are produced in a sporangium.
7.24.131	This bright field light micrograph shows the release of spores from a sporangium at the end of a hypha called a sporangiophore.
7.24.132	The organism is a Mucor sp.
7.24.133	fungus, a mold often found indoors.
7.24.134	Sexual Reproduction Sexual reproduction introduces genetic variation into a population of fungi.
7.24.135	In fungi, sexual reproduction often occurs in response to adverse environmental conditions.
7.24.136	During sexual reproduction, two mating types are produced.
7.24.137	When both mating types are present in the same mycelium, it is called homothallic, or self-fertile.
7.24.138	Heterothallic mycelia require two different, but compatible, mycelia to reproduce sexually.
7.24.139	Although there are many variations in fungal sexual reproduction, all include the following three stages (Figure 24.8).
7.24.140	First, during plasmogamy (literally, “marriage or union of cytoplasm”), two haploid cells fuse, leading to a dikaryotic stage where two haploid nuclei coexist in a single cell.
7.24.141	During karyogamy (“nuclear marriage”), the haploid nuclei fuse to form a diploid zygote nucleus.
7.24.142	Finally, meiosis takes place in the gametangia (singular, gametangium) organs, in which gametes of different mating types are generated.
7.24.143	At this stage, spores are disseminated into the environment.
7.24.144	The kingdom Fungi contains five major phyla that were established according to their mode of sexual reproduction or using molecular data.
7.24.145	Polyphyletic, unrelated fungi that reproduce without a sexual cycle, are placed for convenience in a sixth group called a “form phylum”.
7.24.146	Not all mycologists agree with this scheme.
7.24.147	Rapid advances in molecular biology and the sequencing of 18S rRNA (a part of RNA) continue to show new and different relationships between the various categories of fungi.
7.24.148	The five true phyla of fungi are the Chytridiomycota (Chytrids), the Zygomycota (conjugated fungi), the Ascomycota (sac fungi), the Basidiomycota (club fungi) and the recently described Phylum Glomeromycota.
7.24.149	An older classification scheme grouped fungi that strictly use asexual reproduction into Deuteromycota, a group that is no longer in use.
7.24.150	Note:
7.24.151	“-mycota
7.24.152	” is used to designate a phylum while “
7.24.153	-mycetes
7.24.154	” formally denotes a class or is used informally to refer to all members of the phylum.
7.24.155	Chytridiomycota:
7.24.156	The Chytrids
7.24.157	The only class in the Phylum Chytridiomycota is the Chytridiomycetes.
7.24.158	The chytrids are the simplest and most primitive Eumycota, or true fungi.
7.24.159	The evolutionary record shows that the first recognizable chytrids appeared during the late pre- Cambrian period, more than 500 million years ago.
7.24.160	Like all fungi, chytrids have chitin in their cell walls, but one group of chytrids has both cellulose and chitin in the cell wall.
7.24.161	Most chytrids are unicellular; a few form multicellular organisms and hyphae, which have no septa between cells (coenocytic).
7.24.162	They produce gametes and diploid zoospores that swim with the help of a single flagellum.
7.24.163	The ecological habitat and cell structure of chytrids have much in common with protists.
7.24.164	Chytrids usually live in aquatic environments, although some species live on land.
7.24.165	Some species thrive as parasites on plants, insects, or amphibians (Figure 24.10), while others are saprobes.
7.24.166	The chytrid species Allomyces is well characterized as an experimental organism.
7.24.167	Its reproductive cycle includes both asexual and sexual phases.
7.24.168	Allomyces produces diploid or haploid flagellated zoospores in a sporangium.
7.24.169	The chytrid Batrachochytrium dendrobatidis is seen in these light micrographs as transparent spheres growing on (a) a freshwater arthropod and (b) algae.
7.24.170	This chytrid causes skin diseases in many species of amphibians, resulting in species decline and extinction.
7.24.171	Zygomycota:
7.24.172	The Conjugated Fungi
7.24.173	The zygomycetes are a relatively small group of fungi belonging to the Phylum Zygomycota.
7.24.174	They include the familiar bread mold, Rhizopus stolonifer, which rapidly propagates on the surfaces of breads, fruits, and vegetables.
7.24.175	Most species are saprobes, living off decaying organic material; a few are parasites, particularly of insects.
