7.24.176	Zygomycetes play a considerable commercial role.
7.24.177	The metabolic products of other species of Rhizopus are intermediates in the synthesis of semi-synthetic steroid hormones.
7.24.178	Zygomycetes have a thallus of coenocytic hyphae in which the nuclei are haploid when the organism is in the vegetative stage.
7.24.179	The fungi usually reproduce asexually by producing sporangiospores (Figure 24.11).
7.24.180	The black tips of bread mold are the swollen sporangia packed with black spores (Figure 24.12).
7.24.181	When spores land on a suitable substrate, they germinate and produce a new mycelium.
7.24.182	Sexual reproduction starts when conditions become unfavorable.
7.24.183	Two opposing mating strains (type + and type –) must be in close proximity for gametangia from the hyphae to be produced and fuse, leading to karyogamy.
7.24.184	The developing diploid zygospores have thick coats that protect them from desiccation and other hazards.
7.24.185	They may remain dormant until environmental conditions are favorable.
7.24.186	When the zygospore germinates, it undergoes meiosis and produces haploid spores, which will, in turn, grow into a new organism.
7.24.187	This form of sexual reproduction in fungi is called conjugation (although it differs markedly from conjugation in bacteria and protists), giving rise to the name “conjugated fungi”.
7.24.188	Zygomycetes have asexual and asexual life cycles.
7.24.189	In the sexual life cycle, plus and minus mating types conjugate to form a zygosporangium.
7.24.190	Sporangia grow at the end of stalks, which appear as (a) white fuzz seen on this bread mold, Rhizopus stolonifer.
7.24.191	The (b) tips of bread mold are the spore-containing sporangia.
7.24.192	Ascomycota: The Sac Fungi
7.24.193	The majority of known fungi belong to the Phylum Ascomycota, which is characterized by the formation of an ascus (plural, asci), a sac-like structure that contains haploid ascospores.
7.24.194	Many ascomycetes are of commercial importance.
7.24.195	Some play a beneficial role, such as the yeasts used in baking, brewing, and wine fermentation, plus truffles and morels, which are held as gourmet delicacies.
7.24.196	Aspergillus oryzae is used in the fermentation of rice to produce sake.
7.24.197	Other ascomycetes parasitize plants and animals, including humans.
7.24.198	For example, fungal pneumonia poses a significant threat to AIDS patients who have a compromised immune system.
7.24.199	Ascomycetes not only infest and destroy crops directly; they also produce poisonous secondary metabolites that make crops unfit for consumption.
7.24.200	Filamentous ascomycetes produce hyphae divided by perforated septa, allowing streaming of cytoplasm from one cell to the other.
7.24.201	Conidia and asci, which are used respectively for asexual and sexual reproductions, are usually separated from the vegetative hyphae by blocked (non-perforated) septa.
7.24.202	Asexual reproduction is frequent and involves the production of conidiophores that release haploid conidiospores (Figure 24.13).
7.24.203	Sexual reproduction starts with the development of special hyphae from either one of two types of mating strains (Figure 24.13).
7.24.204	The “male” strain produces an antheridium and the “female” strain develops an ascogonium.
7.24.205	At fertilization, the antheridium and the ascogonium combine in plasmogamy without nuclear fusion.
7.24.206	Special ascogenous hyphae arise, in which pairs of nuclei migrate: one from the “male” strain and one from the “female” strain.
7.24.207	In each ascus, two or more haploid ascospores fuse their nuclei in karyogamy.
7.24.208	During sexual reproduction, thousands of asci fill a fruiting body called the ascocarp.
7.24.209	The diploid nucleus gives rise to haploid nuclei by meiosis.
7.24.210	The ascospores are then released, germinate, and form hyphae that are disseminated in the environment and start new mycelia.
7.24.211	The bright field light micrograph shows ascospores being released from asci in the fungus Talaromyces flavus var.
7.24.212	flavus.
7.24.213	Basidiomycota:
7.24.214	The Club Fungi
7.24.215	The fungi in the Phylum Basidiomycota are easily recognizable under a light microscope by their club-shaped fruiting bodies called basidia (singular, basidium), which are the swollen terminal cell of a hypha.
7.24.216	The basidia, which are the reproductive organs of these fungi, are often contained within the familiar mushroom, commonly seen in fields after rain, on the supermarket shelves, and growing on your lawn (Figure 24.15).
7.24.217	These mushroom-producing basidiomyces are sometimes referred to as “gill fungi” because of the presence of gill-like structures on the underside of the cap.
7.24.218	The “gills” are actually compacted hyphae on which the basidia are borne.
7.24.219	This group also includes shelf fungus, which cling to the bark of trees like small shelves.
7.24.220	In addition, the basidiomycota includes smuts and rusts, which are important plant pathogens; toadstools, and shelf fungi stacked on tree trunks.
7.24.221	Most edible fungi belong to the Phylum Basidiomycota; however, some basidiomycetes produce deadly toxins.
7.24.222	For example, Cryptococcus neoformans causes severe respiratory illness.
7.24.223	The fruiting bodies of a basidiomycete form a ring in a meadow, commonly called “fairy ring.
7.24.224	”
7.24.225	The best-known fairy ring fungus has the scientific name Marasmius oreades.
7.24.226	The body of this fungus, its mycelium, is underground and grows outward in a circle.
7.24.227	As it grows, the mycelium depletes the soil of nitrogen, causing the mycelia to grow away from the center and leading to the “fairy ring” of fruiting bodies where there is adequate soil nitrogen.
7.24.228	The lifecycle of basidiomycetes includes alternation of generations (Figure 24.16).
7.24.229	Spores are generally produced through sexual reproduction, rather than asexual reproduction.
7.24.230	The club-shaped basidium carries spores called basidiospores.
7.24.231	In the basidium, nuclei of two different mating strains fuse (karyogamy), giving rise to a diploid zygote that then undergoes meiosis.
7.24.232	The haploid nuclei migrate into basidiospores, which germinate and generate monokaryotic hyphae.
7.24.233	The mycelium that results is called a primary mycelium.
7.24.234	Mycelia of different mating strains can combine and produce a secondary mycelium that contains haploid nuclei of two different mating strains.
7.24.235	This is the dikaryotic stage of the basidiomyces lifecyle and and it is the dominant stage.
7.24.236	Eventually, the secondary mycelium generates a basidiocarp, which is a fruiting body that protrudes from the ground—this is what we think of as a mushroom.
7.24.237	The basidiocarp bears the developing basidia on the gills under its cap.
7.24.238	Asexual Ascomycota and Basidiomycota Imperfect fungi—those that do not display a sexual phase—use to be classified in the form phylum Deuteromycota, , a classification group no longer used in the present, ever-developing classification of organisms.
7.24.239	While Deuteromycota use to be a classification group, recent moleclular analysis has shown that the members classified in this group belong to the Ascomycota or the Basidiomycota classifications.
7.24.240	Since they do not possess the sexual structures that are used to classify other fungi, they are less well described in comparison to other members.
7.24.241	Most members live on land, with a few aquatic exceptions.
7.24.242	They form visible mycelia with a fuzzy appearance and are commonly known as mold.
7.24.243	Reproduction of the fungi in this group is strictly asexual and occurs mostly by production of asexual conidiospores (Figure 24.17).
7.24.244	Some hyphae may recombine and form heterokaryotic hyphae.
7.24.245	Genetic recombination is known to take place between the different nuclei.
7.24.246	Aspergillus niger is an asexually reproducing fungus (phylum Ascomycota) commonly found as a food contaminant.
7.24.247	The spherical structure in this light micrograph is a conidiophore.
7.24.248	The fungi in this group have a large impact on everyday human life.
7.24.249	The food industry relies on them for ripening some cheeses.
7.24.250	The blue veins in Roquefort cheese and the white crust on Camembert are the result of fungal growth.
7.24.251	The antibiotic penicillin was originally discovered on an overgrown Petri plate, on which a colony of Penicillium fungi killed the bacterial growth surrounding it.
7.24.252	Other fungi in this group cause serious diseases, either directly as parasites (which infect both plants and humans), or as producers of potent toxic compounds, as seen in the aflatoxins released by fungi of the genus Aspergillus.
7.24.253	Glomeromycota
7.24.254	The Glomeromycota is a newly established phylum which comprises about 230 species that all live in close association with the roots of trees.
7.24.255	Fossil records indicate that trees and their root symbionts share a long evolutionary history.
7.24.256	It appears that all members of this family form arbuscular mycorrhizae:
7.24.257	the hyphae interact with the root cells forming a mutually beneficial association where the plants supply the carbon source and energy in the form of carbohydrates to the fungus, and the fungus supplies essential minerals from the soil to the plant.
7.24.258	The glomeromycetes do not reproduce sexually and do not survive without the presence of plant roots.
7.24.259	Although they have coenocytic hyphae like the zygomycetes, they do not form zygospores.
7.24.260	DNA analysis shows that all glomeromycetes probably descended from a common ancestor, making them a monophyletic lineage.
7.24.261	Fungi play a crucial role in the balance of ecosystems.
7.24.262	They colonize most habitats on Earth, preferring dark, moist conditions.
7.24.263	They can thrive in seemingly hostile environments, such as the tundra, thanks to a most successful symbiosis with photosynthetic organisms like algae to produce lichens.
7.24.264	Fungi are not obvious in the way large animals or tall trees appear.
7.24.265	Yet, like bacteria, they are the major decomposers of nature.
7.24.266	With their versatile metabolism, fungi break down organic matter, which would not otherwise be recycled.
7.24.267	Habitats
7.24.268	Although fungi are primarily associated with humid and cool environments that provide a supply of organic matter, they colonize a surprising diversity of habitats, from seawater to human skin and mucous membranes.
7.24.269	Chytrids are found primarily in aquatic environments.
7.24.270	Other fungi, such as Coccidioides immitis, which causes pneumonia when its spores are inhaled, thrive in the dry and sandy soil of the southwestern United States.
7.24.271	Fungi that parasitize coral reefs live in the ocean.
7.24.272	However, most members of the Kingdom Fungi grow on the forest floor, where the dark and damp environment is rich in decaying debris from plants and animals.
7.24.273	In these environments, fungi play a major role as decomposers and recyclers, making it possible for members of the other kingdoms to be supplied with nutrients and live.
7.24.274	Decomposers and Recyclers
7.24.275	The food web would be incomplete without organisms that decompose organic matter (Figure 24.18).
7.24.276	Some elements—such as nitrogen and phosphorus—are required in large quantities by biological systems, and yet are not abundant in the environment.
7.24.277	The action of fungi releases these elements from decaying matter, making them available to other living organisms.
7.24.278	Trace elements present in low amounts in many habitats are essential for growth, and would remain tied up in rotting organic matter if fungi and bacteria did not return them to the environment via their metabolic activity.
7.24.279	Fungi are an important part of ecosystem nutrient cycles.
7.24.280	These bracket fungi growing on the side of a tree are the fruiting structures of a basidiomycete.
7.24.281	They receive their nutrients through their hyphae, which invade and decay the tree trunk.
7.24.282	The ability of fungi to degrade many large and insoluble molecules is due to their mode of nutrition.
7.24.283	As seen earlier, digestion precedes ingestion.
7.24.284	Fungi produce a variety of exoenzymes to digest nutrients.
7.24.285	The enzymes are either released into the substrate or remain bound to the outside of the fungal cell wall.
7.24.286	Large molecules are broken down into small molecules, which are transported into the cell by a system of protein carriers embedded in the cell membrane.
7.24.287	Because the movement of small molecules and enzymes is dependent on the presence of water, active growth depends on a relatively high percentage of moisture in the environment.
7.24.288	As saprobes, fungi help maintain a sustainable ecosystem for the animals and plants that share the same habitat.
7.24.289	In addition to replenishing the environment with nutrients, fungi interact directly with other organisms in beneficial, and sometimes damaging, ways.
7.24.290	Shelf fungi, so called because they grow on trees in a stack, attack and digest the trunk or branches of a tree.
7.24.291	While some shelf fungi are found only on dead trees, others can parasitize living trees and cause eventual death, so they are considered serious tree pathogens.
7.24.292	Mutualistic Relationships Symbiosis is the ecological interaction between two organisms that live together.
7.24.293	The definition does not describe the quality of the interaction.
7.24.294	When both members of the association benefit, the symbiotic relationship is called mutualistic.
7.24.295	Fungi form mutualistic associations with many types of organisms, including cyanobacteria, algae, plants, and animals.
7.24.296	Fungus/Plant Mutualism One of the most remarkable associations between fungi and plants is the establishment of mycorrhizae.
7.24.297	Mycorrhiza, which comes from the Greek words myco meaning fungus and rhizo meaning root, refers to the association between vascular plant roots and their symbiotic fungi.
7.24.298	Somewhere between 80 and 90 percent of all plant species have mycorrhizal partners.
7.24.299	In a mycorrhizal association, the fungal mycelia use their extensive network of hyphae and large surface area in contact with the soil to channel water and minerals from the soil into the plant.
7.24.300	In exchange, the plant supplies the products of photosynthesis to fuel the metabolism of the fungus.
7.24.301	There are a number of types of mycorrhizae.
7.24.302	Ectomycorrhizae (“outside” mycorrhiza) depend on fungi enveloping the roots in a sheath (called a mantle) and a Hartig net of hyphae that extends into the roots between cells (Figure 24.20).
7.24.303	The fungal partner can belong to the Ascomycota, Basidiomycota or Zygomycota.
7.24.304	In a second type, the Glomeromycete fungi form vesicular–arbuscular interactions with arbuscular mycorrhiza (sometimes called endomycorrhizae).
7.24.305	In these mycorrhiza, the fungi form arbuscules that penetrate root cells and are the site of the metabolic exchanges between the fungus and the host plant (Figure 24.20 and Figure 24.21).
7.24.306	The arbuscules (from the Latin for little trees) have a shrub-like appearance.
7.24.307	Orchids rely on a third type of mycorrhiza.
7.24.308	Orchids are epiphytes that form small seeds without much storage to sustain germination and growth.
7.24.309	Their seeds will not germinate without a mycorrhizal partner (usually a Basidiomycete).
7.24.310	After nutrients in the seed are depleted, fungal symbionts support the growth of the orchid by providing necessary carbohydrates and minerals.
7.24.311	Some orchids continue to be mycorrhizal throughout their lifecycle.
7.24.312	The (a) infection of Pinus radiata (Monterey pine) roots by the hyphae of Amanita muscaria (fly amanita) causes the pine tree to produce many small, branched rootlets.
7.24.313	The Amanita hyphae cover these small roots with a white mantle.
7.24.314	(b) Spores (round bodies) and hyphae (thread-like structures) are evident in this light micrograph of an arbuscular mycorrhiza between a fungus and the root of a corn plant.
7.24.315	Lichens Lichens display a range of colors and textures (Figure 24.22) and can survive in the most unusual and hostile habitats.
7.24.316	They cover rocks, gravestones, tree bark, and the ground in the tundra where plant roots cannot penetrate.
7.24.317	Lichens can survive extended periods of drought, when they become completely desiccated, and then rapidly become active once water is available again.
7.24.318	Lichens have many forms.
7.24.319	They may be (a) crust-like, (b) hair-like, or (c) leaf-like.
7.24.320	Lichens are not a single organism, but rather an example of a mutualism, in which a fungus (usually a member of the Ascomycota or Basidiomycota phyla) lives in close contact with a photosynthetic organism (a eukaryotic alga or a prokaryotic cyanobacterium)
7.24.321	(Figure 24.23).
7.24.322	Generally, neither the fungus nor the photosynthetic organism can survive alone outside of the symbiotic relationship.
7.24.323	The body of a lichen, referred to as a thallus, is formed of hyphae wrapped around the photosynthetic partner.
7.24.324	The photosynthetic organism provides carbon and energy in the form of carbohydrates.
7.24.325	Some cyanobacteria fix nitrogen from the atmosphere, contributing nitrogenous compounds to the association.
7.24.326	In return, the fungus supplies minerals and protection from dryness and excessive light by encasing the algae in its mycelium.
7.24.327	The fungus also attaches the symbiotic organism to the substrate.
7.24.328	This cross-section of a lichen thallus shows the (a) upper cortex of fungal hyphae, which provides protection; the (b) algal zone where photosynthesis occurs, the (c) medulla of fungal hyphae, and the (d) lower cortex, which also provides protection and may have (e) rhizines to anchor the thallus to the substrate.
7.24.329	The thallus of lichens grows very slowly, expanding its diameter a few millimeters per year.
7.24.330	Both the fungus and the alga participate in the formation of dispersal units for reproduction.
7.24.331	Lichens produce soredia, clusters of algal cells surrounded by mycelia.
7.24.332	Soredia are dispersed by wind and water and form new lichens.
7.24.333	Lichens are extremely sensitive to air pollution, especially to abnormal levels of nitrogen and sulfur.
7.24.334	The U.S. Forest Service and National Park Service can monitor air quality by measuring the relative abundance and health of the lichen population in an area.
7.24.335	Lichens fulfill many ecological roles.
7.24.336	Caribou and reindeer eat lichens, and they provide cover for small invertebrates that hide in the mycelium.
7.24.337	In the production of textiles, weavers used lichens to dye wool for many centuries until the advent of synthetic dyes.
7.24.338	Fungus/Animal Mutualism Fungi have evolved mutualisms with numerous insects in Phylum Arthropoda: jointed, legged invertebrates.
7.24.339	Arthropods depend on the fungus for protection from predators and pathogens, while the fungus obtains nutrients and a way to disseminate spores into new environments.
7.24.340	The association between species of Basidiomycota and scale insects is one example.
7.24.341	The fungal mycelium covers and protects the insect colonies.
7.24.342	The scale insects foster a flow of nutrients from the parasitized plant to the fungus.
7.24.343	In a second example, leaf-cutting ants of Central and South America literally farm fungi.
7.24.344	They cut disks of leaves from plants and pile them up in gardens (Figure 24.24).
7.24.345	Fungi are cultivated in these disk gardens, digesting the cellulose in the leaves that the ants cannot break down.
7.24.346	Once smaller sugar molecules are produced and consumed by the fungi, the fungi in turn become a meal for the ants.
7.24.347	The insects also patrol their garden, preying on competing fungi.
7.24.348	Both ants and fungi benefit from the association.
7.24.349	The fungus receives a steady supply of leaves and freedom from competition, while the ants feed on the fungi they cultivate.
7.24.350	A leaf cutting ant transports a leaf that will feed a farmed fungus.
7.24.351	Fungivores Animal dispersal is important for some fungi because an animal may carry spores considerable distances from the source.
7.24.352	Fungal spores are rarely completely degraded in the gastrointestinal tract of an animal, and many are able to germinate when they are passed in the feces.
7.24.353	Some dung fungi actually require passage through the digestive system of herbivores to complete their lifecycle.
7.24.354	The black truffle—a prized gourmet delicacy—is the fruiting body of an underground mushroom.
7.24.355	Almost all truffles are ectomycorrhizal, and are usually found in close association with trees.
7.24.356	Animals eat truffles and disperse the spores.
7.24.357	In Italy and France, truffle hunters use female pigs to sniff out truffles.
7.24.358	Female pigs are attracted to truffles because the fungus releases a volatile compound closely related to a pheromone produced by male pigs.
7.24.359	Parasitism describes a symbiotic relationship in which one member of the association benefits at the expense of the other.
7.24.360	Both parasites and pathogens harm the host; however, the pathogen causes a disease, whereas the parasite usually does not.
7.24.361	Commensalism occurs when one member benefits without affecting the other.
7.24.362	Plant Parasites and Pathogens
7.24.363	The production of sufficient good-quality crops is essential to human existence.
7.24.364	Plant diseases have ruined crops, bringing widespread famine.
7.24.365	Many plant pathogens are fungi that cause tissue decay and eventual death of the host (Figure 24.25).
7.24.366	In addition to destroying plant tissue directly, some plant pathogens spoil crops by producing potent toxins.
7.24.367	Fungi are also responsible for food spoilage and the rotting of stored crops.
7.24.368	For example, the fungus Claviceps purpurea causes ergot, a disease of cereal crops (especially of rye).
7.24.369	Although the fungus reduces the yield of cereals, the effects of the ergot's alkaloid toxins on humans and animals are of much greater significance.
7.24.370	In animals, the disease is referred to as ergotism.
7.24.371	The most common signs and symptoms are convulsions, hallucination, gangrene, and loss of milk in cattle.
7.24.372	The active ingredient of ergot is lysergic acid, which is a precursor of the drug LSD.
7.24.373	Smuts, rusts, and powdery or downy mildew are other examples of common fungal pathogens that affect crops.
7.24.374	Some fungal pathogens include (a) green mold on grapefruit, (b) powdery mildew on a zinnia, (c) stem rust on a sheaf of barley, and
7.24.375	(d) grey rot on grapes.
7.24.376	In wet conditions Botrytis cinerea, the fungus that causes grey rot, can destroy a grape crop.
7.24.377	However, controlled infection of grapes by Botrytis results in noble rot, a condition that produces strong and much-prized dessert wines.
7.24.378	Aflatoxins are toxic, carcinogenic compounds released by fungi of the genus Aspergillus.
7.24.379	Periodically, harvests of nuts and grains are tainted by aflatoxins, leading to massive recall of produce.
7.24.380	This sometimes ruins producers and causes food shortages in developing countries.
7.24.381	Animal and Human Parasites and Pathogens Fungi can affect animals, including humans, in several ways.
7.24.382	A mycosis is a fungal disease that results from infection and direct damage.
7.24.383	Fungi attack animals directly by colonizing and destroying tissues.
7.24.384	Mycotoxicosis is the poisoning of humans (and other animals) by foods contaminated by fungal toxins (mycotoxins).
7.24.385	Mycetismus describes the ingestion of preformed toxins in poisonous mushrooms.
7.24.386	In addition, individuals who display hypersensitivity to molds and spores develop strong and dangerous allergic reactions.
7.24.387	Fungal infections are generally very difficult to treat because, unlike bacteria, fungi are eukaryotes.
7.24.388	Antibiotics only target prokaryotic cells, whereas compounds that kill fungi also harm the eukaryotic animal host.
7.24.389	Many fungal infections are superficial; that is, they occur on the animal’s skin.
7.24.390	Termed cutaneous (“skin”) mycoses, they can have devastating effects.
7.24.391	For example, the decline of the world’s frog population in recent years may be caused by the chytrid fungus Batrachochytrium dendrobatidis, which infects the skin of frogs and presumably interferes with gaseous exchange.
7.24.392	Similarly, more than a million bats in the United States have been killed by white-nose syndrome, which appears as a white ring around the mouth of the bat.
7.24.393	It is caused by the cold-loving fungus Pseudogymnoascus destructans, which disseminates its deadly spores in caves where bats hibernate.
7.24.394	Mycologists are researching the transmission, mechanism, and control of P. destructans to stop its spread.
7.24.395	Fungi that cause the superficial mycoses of the epidermis, hair, and nails rarely spread to the underlying tissue (Figure 24.26).
7.24.396	These fungi are often misnamed “dermatophytes”, from the Greek words dermis meaning skin and phyte meaning plant, although they are not plants.
7.24.397	Dermatophytes are also called “ringworms” because of the red ring they cause on skin.
7.24.398	They secrete extracellular enzymes that break down keratin (a protein found in hair, skin, and nails), causing conditions such as athlete’s foot and jock itch.
7.24.399	These conditions are usually treated with over-the-counter topical creams and powders, and are easily cleared.
7.24.400	More persistent superficial mycoses may require prescription oral medications.
7.24.401	Ringworm presents as a red ring on skin; (b) Trichophyton violaceum, shown in this bright field light micrograph, causes superficial mycoses on the scalp; (c) Histoplasma capsulatum is an ascomycete that infects airways and causes symptoms similar to influenza.
7.24.402	Systemic mycoses spread to internal organs, most commonly entering the body through the respiratory system.
7.24.403	For example, coccidioidomycosis (valley fever) is commonly found in the southwestern United States, where the fungus resides in the dust.
7.24.404	Once inhaled, the spores develop in the lungs and cause symptoms similar to those of tuberculosis.
7.24.405	Histoplasmosis is caused by the dimorphic fungus Histoplasma capsulatum.
7.24.406	It also causes pulmonary infections, and in rarer cases, swelling of the membranes of the brain and spinal cord.
7.24.407	Treatment of these and many other fungal diseases requires the use of antifungal medications that have serious side effects.
7.24.408	Opportunistic mycoses are fungal infections that are either common in all environments, or part of the normal biota.
7.24.409	They mainly affect individuals who have a compromised immune system.
7.24.410	Patients in the late stages of AIDS suffer from opportunistic mycoses that can be life threatening.
7.24.411	The yeast Candida sp., a common member of the natural biota, can grow unchecked and infect the vagina or mouth (oral thrush) if the pH of the surrounding environment, the person’s immune defenses, or the normal population of bacteria are altered.
7.24.412	Mycetismus can occur when poisonous mushrooms are eaten.
7.24.413	It causes a number of human fatalities during mushroompicking season.
7.24.414	Many edible fruiting bodies of fungi resemble highly poisonous relatives, and amateur mushroom hunters are cautioned to carefully inspect their harvest and avoid eating mushrooms of doubtful origin.
7.24.415	The adage “there are bold mushroom pickers and old mushroom pickers, but are there no old, bold mushroom pickers
7.24.416	” is unfortunately true.
7.24.417	Although we often think of fungi as organisms that cause disease and rot food, fungi are important to human life on many levels.
7.24.418	As we have seen, they influence the well-being of human populations on a large scale because they are part of the nutrient cycle in ecosystems.
7.24.419	They have other ecosystem roles as well.
7.24.420	As animal pathogens, fungi help to control the population of damaging pests.
7.24.421	These fungi are very specific to the insects they attack, and do not infect animals or plants.
7.24.422	Fungi are currently under investigation as potential microbial insecticides, with several already on the market.
7.24.423	For example, the fungus Beauveria bassiana is a pesticide being tested as a possible biological control agent for the recent spread of emerald ash borer.
7.24.424	It has been released in Michigan, Illinois, Indiana, Ohio, West Virginia and Maryland.
7.24.425	The emerald ash borer is an insect that attacks ash trees.
7.24.426	It is in turn parasitized by a pathogenic fungus that holds promise as a biological insecticide.
7.24.427	The parasitic fungus appears as white fuzz on the body of the insect.
7.24.428	The mycorrhizal relationship between fungi and plant roots is essential for the productivity of farm land.
7.24.429	Without the fungal partner in root systems, 80–90 percent of trees and grasses would not survive.
7.24.430	Mycorrhizal fungal inoculants are available as soil amendments from gardening supply stores and are promoted by supporters of organic agriculture.
7.24.431	We also eat some types of fungi.
7.24.432	Mushrooms figure prominently in the human diet.
7.24.433	Morels, shiitake mushrooms, chanterelles, and truffles are considered delicacies (Figure 24.28).
7.24.434	The humble meadow mushroom, Agaricus campestris, appears in many dishes.
7.24.435	Molds of the genus Penicillium ripen many cheeses.
7.24.436	They originate in the natural environment such as the caves of Roquefort, France, where wheels of sheep milk cheese are stacked in order to capture the molds responsible for the blue veins and pungent taste of the cheese.
7.24.437	The morel mushroom is an ascomycete much appreciated for its delicate taste.
7.24.438	Fermentation—of grains to produce beer, and of fruits to produce wine
7.24.439	—is an ancient art that humans in most cultures have practiced for millennia.
7.24.440	Wild yeasts are acquired from the environment and used to ferment sugars into CO2 and ethyl alcohol under anaerobic conditions.
7.24.441	It is now possible to purchase isolated strains of wild yeasts from different wine-making regions.
7.24.442	Louis Pasteur was instrumental in developing a reliable strain of brewer’s yeast, Saccharomyces cerevisiae, for the French brewing industry in the late 1850s.
7.24.443	This was one of the first examples of biotechnology patenting.
7.24.444	Many secondary metabolites of fungi are of great commercial importance.
7.24.445	Antibiotics are naturally produced by fungi to kill or inhibit the growth of bacteria, limiting their competition in the natural environment.
7.24.446	Important antibiotics, such as penicillin and the cephalosporins, are isolated from fungi.
7.24.447	Valuable drugs isolated from fungi include the immunosuppressant drug cyclosporine (which reduces the risk of rejection after organ transplant), the precursors of steroid hormones, and ergot alkaloids used to stop bleeding.
7.24.448	Psilocybin is a compound found in fungi such as Psilocybe semilanceata and Gymnopilus junonius, which have been used for their hallucinogenic properties by various cultures for thousands of years.
7.24.449	As simple eukaryotic organisms, fungi are important model research organisms.
7.24.450	Many advances in modern genetics were achieved by the use of the red bread mold Neurospora crassa.
7.24.451	Additionally, many important genes originally discovered in S. cerevisiae served as a starting point in discovering analogous human genes.
7.24.452	As a eukaryotic organism, the yeast cell produces and modifies proteins in a manner similar to human cells, as opposed to the bacterium Escherichia coli, which lacks the internal membrane structures and enzymes to tag proteins for export.
7.24.453	This makes yeast a much better organism for use in recombinant DNA technology experiments.
7.24.454	Like bacteria, yeasts grow easily in culture, have a short generation time, and are amenable to genetic modification.
7.25.0	Seedless plants, like these horsetails (Equisetum sp.), thrive in damp, shaded environments under a tree canopy where dryness is rare.
7.25.1	An incredible variety of seedless plants populates the terrestrial landscape.
7.25.2	Mosses may grow on a tree trunk, and horsetails may display their jointed stems and spindly leaves across the forest floor.
7.25.3	Today, seedless plants represent only a small fraction of the plants in our environment; yet, three hundred million years ago, seedless plants dominated the landscape and grew in the enormous swampy forests of the Carboniferous period.
7.25.4	Their decomposition created large deposits of coal that we mine today.
7.25.5	Current evolutionary thought holds that all plants—green algae as well as land dwellers—are monophyletic; that is, they are descendants of a single common ancestor.
7.25.6	The evolutionary transition from water to land imposed severe constraints on plants.
7.25.7	They had to develop strategies to avoid drying out, to disperse reproductive cells in air, for structural support, and for capturing and filtering sunlight.
7.25.8	While seed plants developed adaptations that allowed them to populate even the most arid habitats on Earth, full independence from water did not happen in all plants.
7.25.9	Most seedless plants still require a moist environment.
7.25.10	The kingdom Plantae constitutes large and varied groups of organisms.
7.25.11	There are more than 300,000 species of catalogued plants.
7.25.12	Of these, more than 260,000 are seed plants.
7.25.13	Mosses, ferns, conifers, and flowering plants are all members of the plant kingdom.
7.25.14	Most biologists also consider green algae to be plants, although others exclude all algae from the plant kingdom.
7.25.15	The reason for this disagreement stems from the fact that only green algae, the Charophytes, share common characteristics with land plants (such as using chlorophyll a and b plus carotene in the same proportion as plants).
7.25.16	These characteristics are absent in other types of algae.
7.25.17	Plant Adaptations to Life on Land
7.25.18	As organisms adapted to life on land, they had to contend with several challenges in the terrestrial environment.
7.25.19	Water has been described as “the stuff of life.
7.25.20	”
7.25.21	The cell’s interior is a watery soup: in this medium, most small molecules dissolve and diffuse, and the majority of the chemical reactions of metabolism take place.
7.25.22	Desiccation, or drying out, is a constant danger for an organism exposed to air.
7.25.23	Even when parts of a plant are close to a source of water, the aerial structures are likely to dry out.
7.25.24	Water also provides buoyancy to organisms.
7.25.25	On land, plants need to develop structural support in a medium that does not give the same lift as water.
7.25.26	The organism is also subject to bombardment by mutagenic radiation, because air does not filter out ultraviolet rays of sunlight.
7.25.27	Additionally, the male gametes must reach the female gametes using new strategies, because swimming is no longer possible.
7.25.28	Therefore, both gametes and zygotes must be protected from desiccation.
7.25.29	The successful land plants developed strategies to deal with all of these challenges.
7.25.30	Not all adaptations appeared at once.
7.25.31	Some species never moved very far from the aquatic environment, whereas others went on to conquer the driest environments on Earth.
7.25.32	To balance these survival challenges, life on land offers several advantages.
7.25.33	First, sunlight is abundant.
7.25.34	Water acts as a filter, altering the spectral quality of light absorbed by the photosynthetic pigment chlorophyll.
7.25.35	Second, carbon dioxide is more readily available in air than in water, since it diffuses faster in air.
7.25.36	Third, land plants evolved before land animals; therefore, until dry land was colonized by animals, no predators threatened plant life.
7.25.37	This situation changed as animals emerged from the water and fed on the abundant sources of nutrients in the established flora.
7.25.38	In turn, plants developed strategies to deter predation: from spines and thorns to toxic chemicals.
7.25.39	Early land plants, like the early land animals, did not live very far from an abundant source of water and developed survival strategies to combat dryness.
7.25.40	One of these strategies is called tolerance.
7.25.41	Many mosses, for example, can dry out to a brown and brittle mat, but as soon as rain or a flood makes water available, mosses will absorb it and are restored to their healthy green appearance.
7.25.42	Another strategy is to colonize environments with high humidity, where droughts are uncommon.
7.25.43	Ferns, which are considered an early lineage of plants, thrive in damp and cool places such as the understory of temperate forests.
7.25.44	Later, plants moved away from moist or aquatic environments using resistance to desiccation, rather than tolerance.
7.25.45	These plants, like cacti, minimize the loss of water to such an extent they can survive in extremely dry environments.
7.25.46	The most successful adaptation solution was the development of new structures that gave plants the advantage when colonizing new and dry environments.
7.25.47	Four major adaptations are found in all terrestrial plants: the alternation of generations, a sporangium in which the spores are formed, a gametangium that produces haploid cells, and apical meristem tissue in roots and shoots.
7.25.48	The evolution of a waxy cuticle and a cell wall with lignin also contributed to the success of land plants.
7.25.49	These adaptations are noticeably lacking in the closely related green algae—another reason for the debate over their placement in the plant kingdom.
7.25.50	Alternation of Generations Alternation of generations describes a life cycle in which an organism has both haploid and diploid multicellular stages.
7.25.51	Alternation of generations between the 1n gametophyte and 2n sporophyte is shown.
7.25.52	Haplontic refers to a lifecycle in which there is a dominant haploid stage, and diplontic refers to a lifecycle in which the diploid is the dominant life stage.
7.25.53	Humans are diplontic.
7.25.54	Most plants exhibit alternation of generations, which is described as haplodiplodontic: the haploid multicellular form, known as a gametophyte, is followed in the development sequence by a multicellular diploid organism: the sporophyte.
7.25.55	The gametophyte gives rise to the gametes (reproductive cells) by mitosis.
7.25.56	This can be the most obvious phase of the life cycle of the plant, as in the mosses, or it can occur in a microscopic structure, such as a pollen grain, in the higher plants (a common collective term for the vascular plants).
7.25.57	The sporophyte stage is barely noticeable in lower plants (the collective term for the plant groups of mosses, liverworts, and lichens).
7.25.58	Towering trees are the diplontic phase in the lifecycles of plants such as sequoias and pines.
7.25.59	Protection of the embryo is a major requirement for land plants.
7.25.60	The vulnerable embryo must be sheltered from desiccation and other environmental hazards.
7.25.61	In both seedless and seed plants, the female gametophyte provides protection and nutrients to the embryo as it develops into the new generation of sporophyte.
7.25.62	This distinguishing feature of land plants gave the group its alternate name of embryophytes.
7.25.63	Sporangia in Seedless Plants
7.25.64	The sporophyte of seedless plants is diploid and results from syngamy (fusion) of two gametes.
7.25.65	The sporophyte bears the sporangia (singular, sporangium):
7.25.66	organs that first appeared in the land plants.
7.25.67	The term “sporangia” literally means “spore in a vessel,” as it is a reproductive sac that contains spores Figure 25.3.
7.25.68	Inside the multicellular sporangia, the diploid sporocytes, or mother cells, produce haploid spores by meiosis, where the 2n chromosome number is reduced to 1n (note that many plant sporophytes are polyploid: for example, durum wheat is tetraploid,
7.25.69	bread wheat is hexaploid, and some ferns are 1000-ploid).
7.25.70	The spores are later released by the sporangia and disperse in the environment.
7.25.71	Two different types of spores are produced in land plants, resulting in the separation of sexes at different points in the lifecycle.
7.25.72	Seedless nonvascular plants produce only one kind of spore and are called homosporous.
7.25.73	The gametophyte phase is dominant in these plants.
7.25.74	After germinating from a spore, the resulting gametophyte produces both male and female gametangia, usually on the same individual.
7.25.75	In contrast, heterosporous plants produce two morphologically different types of spores.
7.25.76	The male spores are called microspores, because of their smaller size, and develop into the male gametophyte; the comparatively larger megaspores develop into the female gametophyte.
7.25.77	Heterospory is observed in a few seedless vascular plants and in all seed plants.
7.25.78	Spore-producing sacs called sporangia grow at the ends of long, thin stalks in this photo of the moss Esporangios bryum.
7.25.79	When the haploid spore germinates in a hospitable environment, it generates a multicellular gametophyte by mitosis.
7.25.80	The gametophyte supports the zygote formed from the fusion of gametes and the resulting young sporophyte (vegetative form).
7.25.81	The cycle then begins anew.
7.25.82	The spores of seedless plants are surrounded by thick cell walls containing a tough polymer known as sporopollenin.
7.25.83	This complex substance is characterized by long chains of organic molecules related to fatty acids and carotenoids: hence the yellow color of most pollen.
7.25.84	Sporopollenin is unusually resistant to chemical and biological degradation.
7.25.85	In seed plants, which use pollen to transfer the male sperm to the female egg, the toughness of sporopollenin explains the existence of well-preserved pollen fossils.
7.25.86	Sporopollenin was once thought to be an innovation of land plants; however, the green algae Coleochaetes forms spores that contain sporopollenin.
7.25.87	Gametangia in Seedless Plants Gametangia (singular, gametangium) are structures observed on multicellular haploid gametophytes.
7.25.88	In the gametangia, precursor cells give rise to gametes by mitosis.
7.25.89	The male gametangium ( antheridium) releases sperm.
7.25.90	Many seedless plants produce sperm equipped with flagella that enable them to swim in a moist environment to the archegonia: the female gametangium.
7.25.91	The embryo develops inside the archegonium as the sporophyte.
7.25.92	Gametangia are prominent in seedless plants, but are very rarely found in seed plants.
7.25.93	Apical Meristems Shoots and roots of plants increase in length through rapid cell division in a tissue called the apical meristem, which is a small zone of cells found at the shoot tip or root tip (Figure 25.4).
7.25.94	The apical meristem is made of undifferentiated cells that continue to proliferate throughout the life of the plant.
7.25.95	Meristematic cells give rise to all the specialized tissues of the organism.
7.25.96	Elongation of the shoots and roots allows a plant to access additional space and resources: light in the case of the shoot, and water and minerals in the case of roots.
7.25.97	A separate meristem, called the lateral meristem, produces cells that increase the diameter of tree trunks.
7.25.98	Addition of new cells in a root occurs at the apical meristem.
7.25.99	Subsequent enlargement of these cells causes the organ to grow and elongate.
7.25.100	The root cap protects the fragile apical meristem as the root tip is pushed through the soil by cell elongation.
7.25.101	Additional Land Plant Adaptations
7.25.102	As plants adapted to dry land and became independent from the constant presence of water in damp habitats, new organs and structures made their appearance.
7.25.103	Early land plants did not grow more than a few inches off the ground, competing for light on these low mats.
7.25.104	By developing a shoot and growing taller, individual plants captured more light.
7.25.105	Because air offers substantially less support than water, land plants incorporated more rigid molecules in their stems (and later, tree trunks).
7.25.106	In small plants such as single-celled algae, simple diffusion suffices to distribute water and nutrients throughout the organism.
7.25.107	However, for plants to evolve larger forms, the evolution of vascular tissue for the distribution of water and solutes was a prerequisite.
7.25.108	The vascular system contains xylem and phloem tissues.
7.25.109	Xylem conducts water and minerals absorbed from the soil up to the shoot, while phloem transports food derived from photosynthesis throughout the entire plant.
7.25.110	A root system evolved to take up water and minerals from the soil, and to anchor the increasingly taller shoot in the soil.
7.25.111	In land plants, a waxy, waterproof cover called a cuticle protects the leaves and stems from desiccation.
7.25.112	However, the cuticle also prevents intake of carbon dioxide needed for the synthesis of carbohydrates through photosynthesis.
7.25.113	To overcome this, stomata or pores that open and close to regulate traffic of gases and water vapor appeared in plants as they moved away from moist environments into drier habitats.
7.25.114	Water filters ultraviolet-B (UVB) light, which is harmful to all organisms, especially those that must absorb light to survive.
7.25.115	This filtering does not occur for land plants.
7.25.116	This presented an additional challenge to land colonization, which was met by the evolution of biosynthetic pathways for the synthesis of protective flavonoids and other compounds: pigments that absorb UV wavelengths of light and protect the aerial parts of plants from photodynamic damage.
7.25.117	Plants cannot avoid being eaten by animals.
7.25.118	Instead, they synthesize a large range of poisonous secondary metabolites: complex organic molecules such as alkaloids, whose noxious smells and unpleasant taste deter animals.
7.25.119	These toxic compounds can also cause severe diseases and even death, thus discouraging predation.
7.25.120	Humans have used many of these compounds for centuries as drugs, medications, or spices.
7.25.121	In contrast, as plants co-evolved with animals, the development of sweet and nutritious metabolites lured animals into providing valuable assistance in dispersing pollen grains, fruit, or seeds.
7.25.122	Plants have been enlisting animals to be their helpers in this way for hundreds of millions of years.
7.25.123	Evolution of Land Plants
7.25.124	No discussion of the evolution of plants on land can be undertaken without a brief review of the timeline of the geological eras.
7.25.125	The early era, known as the Paleozoic, is divided into six periods.
7.25.126	It starts with the Cambrian period, followed by the Ordovician, Silurian, Devonian, Carboniferous, and Permian.
7.25.127	The major event to mark the Ordovician, more than 500 million years ago, was the colonization of land by the ancestors of modern land plants.
7.25.128	Fossilized cells, cuticles, and spores of early land plants have been dated as far back as the Ordovician period in the early Paleozoic era.
7.25.129	The oldest-known vascular plants have been identified in deposits from the Devonian.
7.25.130	One of the richest sources of information is the Rhynie chert, a sedimentary rock deposit found in Rhynie, Scotland (Figure 25.5), where embedded fossils of some of the earliest vascular plants have been identified.
7.25.131	This Rhynie chert contains fossilized material from vascular plants.
7.25.132	The area inside the circle contains bulbous underground stems called corms, and root-like structures called rhizoids.
7.25.133	Paleobotanists distinguish between extinct species, as fossils, and extant species, which are still living.
7.25.134	The extinct vascular plants, classified as zosterophylls and trimerophytes, most probably lacked true leaves and roots and formed low vegetation mats similar in size to modern-day mosses, although some trimetophytes could reach one meter in height.
7.25.135	The later genus Cooksonia, which flourished during the Silurian, has been extensively studied from well-preserved examples.
7.25.136	Imprints of Cooksonia show slender branching stems ending in what appear to be sporangia.
7.25.137	From the recovered specimens, it is not possible to establish for certain whether Cooksonia possessed vascular tissues.
7.25.138	Fossils indicate that by the end of the Devonian period, ferns, horsetails, and seed plants populated the landscape, giving rising to trees and forests.
7.25.139	This luxuriant vegetation helped enrich the atmosphere in oxygen, making it easier for air-breathing animals to colonize dry land.
7.25.140	Plants also established early symbiotic relationships with fungi, creating mycorrhizae: a relationship in which the fungal network of filaments increases the efficiency of the plant root system, and the plants provide the fungi with byproducts of photosynthesis.
7.25.141	The Major Divisions of Land Plants
7.25.142	The green algae and land plants are grouped together into a subphylum called the Streptophytina, and thus are called Streptophytes.
7.25.143	In a further division, land plants are classified into two major groups according to the absence or presence of vascular tissue, as detailed in Figure 25.6.
7.25.144	Plants that lack vascular tissue, which is formed of specialized cells for the transport of water and nutrients, are referred to as non-vascular plants.
7.25.145	Liverworts, mosses, and hornworts are seedless, non-vascular plants that likely appeared early in land plant evolution.
7.25.146	Vascular plants developed a network of cells that conduct water and solutes.
7.25.147	The first vascular plants appeared in the late Ordovician and were probably similar to lycophytes, which include club mosses (not to be confused with the mosses) and the pterophytes (ferns, horsetails, and whisk ferns).
7.25.148	Lycophytes and pterophytes are referred to as seedless vascular plants, because they do not produce seeds.
7.25.149	The seed plants, or spermatophytes, form the largest group of all existing plants, and hence dominate the landscape.
7.25.150	Seed plants include gymnosperms, most notably conifers (Gymnosperms), which produce “naked seeds,” and the most successful of all plants, the flowering plants (Angiosperms).
7.25.151	Angiosperms protect their seeds inside chambers at the center of a flower; the walls of the chamber later develop into a fruit.
7.25.152	Streptophytes Until recently, all photosynthetic eukaryotes were considered members of the kingdom Plantae.
7.25.153	The brown, red, and gold algae, however, have been reassigned to the Protista kingdom.
7.25.154	This is because apart from their ability to capture light energy and fix CO2, they lack many structural and biochemical traits that distinguish plants from protists.
7.25.155	The position of green algae is more ambiguous.
7.25.156	Green algae contain the same carotenoids and chlorophyll a and b as land plants, whereas other algae have different accessory pigments and types of chlorophyll molecules in addition to chlorophyll a. Both green algae and land plants also store carbohydrates as starch.
7.25.157	Cells in green algae divide along cell plates called phragmoplasts, and their cell walls are layered in the same manner as the cell walls of embryophytes.
7.25.158	Consequently, land plants and closely related green algae are now part of a new monophyletic group called Streptophyta.
7.25.159	The remaining green algae, which belong to a group called Chlorophyta, include more than 7000 different species that live in fresh or brackish water, in seawater, or in snow patches.
7.25.160	A few green algae even survive on soil, provided it is covered by a thin film of moisture in which they can live.
7.25.161	Periodic dry spells provide a selective advantage to algae that can survive water stress.
7.25.162	Some green algae may already be familiar, in particular Spirogyra and desmids.
7.25.163	Their cells contain chloroplasts that display a dizzying variety of shapes, and their cell walls contain cellulose, as do land plants.
7.25.164	Some green algae are single cells, such as Chlorella and Chlamydomonas, which adds to the ambiguity of green algae classification, because plants are multicellular.
7.25.165	Other algae, like Ulva (commonly called sea lettuce), form colonies.
7.25.166	Chlorophyta include (a) Spirogyra, (b) desmids, (c) Chlamydomonas, and (d) Ulva.
7.25.167	Desmids and Chlamydomonas are single-celled organisms, Spirogyra forms chains of cells, and Ulva forms colonies resembling leaves.
7.25.168	Reproduction of Green Algae Green algae reproduce both asexually, by fragmentation or dispersal of spores, or sexually, by producing gametes that fuse during fertilization.
7.25.169	In a single-celled organism such as Chlamydomonas, there is no mitosis after fertilization.
7.25.170	In the multicellular Ulva, a sporophyte grows by mitosis after fertilization.
7.25.171	Both Chlamydomonas and Ulva produce flagellated gametes.
7.25.172	Charales Green algae in the order Charales, and the coleochaetes (microscopic green algae that enclose their spores in sporopollenin), are considered the closest living relatives of embryophytes.
7.25.173	The Charales can be traced back 420 million years.
7.25.174	They live in a range of fresh water habitats and vary in size from a few millimeters to a meter in length.
7.25.175	The representative species is Chara (Figure 25.8), often called muskgrass or skunkweed because of its unpleasant smell.
7.25.176	Large cells form the thallus: the main stem of the alga.
7.25.177	Branches arising from the nodes are made of smaller cells.
7.25.178	Male and female reproductive structures are found on the nodes, and the sperm have flagella.
7.25.179	Unlike land plants, Charales do not undergo alternation of generations in their lifecycle.
7.25.180	Charales exhibit a number of traits that are significant in their adaptation to land life.
7.25.181	They produce the compounds lignin and sporopollenin, and form plasmodesmata that connect the cytoplasm of adjacent cells.
7.25.182	The egg, and later, the zygote, form in a protected chamber on the parent plant.
7.25.183	The representative alga, Chara, is a noxious weed in Florida, where it clogs waterways.
7.25.184	New information from recent, extensive DNA sequence analysis of green algae indicates that the Zygnematales are more closely related to the embryophytes than the Charales.
7.25.185	The Zygnematales include the familiar genus Spirogyra.
7.25.186	As techniques in DNA analysis improve and new information on comparative genomics arises, the phylogenetic connections between species will change.
7.25.187	Clearly, plant biologists have not yet solved the mystery of the origin of land plants.
7.25.188	Bryophytes are the group of plants that are the closest extant relative of early terrestrial plants.
7.25.189	The first bryophytes (liverworts) most likely appeared in the Ordovician period, about 450 million years ago.
7.25.190	Because of the lack of lignin and other resistant structures, the likelihood of bryophytes forming fossils is rather small.
7.25.191	Some spores protected by sporopollenin have survived and are attributed to early bryophytes.
7.25.192	By the Silurian period, however, vascular plants had spread through the continents.
7.25.193	This compelling fact is used as evidence that non-vascular plants must have preceded the Silurian period.
7.25.194	More than 25,000 species of bryophytes thrive in mostly damp habitats, although some live in deserts.
7.25.195	They constitute the major flora of inhospitable environments like the tundra, where their small size and tolerance to desiccation offer distinct advantages.
7.25.196	They generally lack lignin and do not have actual tracheids (xylem cells specialized for water conduction).
7.25.197	Rather, water and nutrients circulate inside specialized conducting cells.
7.25.198	Although the term non-tracheophyte is more accurate, bryophytes are commonly called nonvascular plants.
7.25.199	In a bryophyte, all the conspicuous vegetative organs—including the photosynthetic leaf-like structures, the thallus, stem, and the rhizoid that anchors the plant to its substrate—belong to the haploid organism or gametophyte.
7.25.200	The sporophyte is barely noticeable.
7.25.201	The gametes formed by bryophytes swim with a flagellum, as do gametes in a few of the tracheophytes.
7.25.202	The sporangium—the multicellular sexual reproductive structure—is present in bryophytes and absent in the majority of algae.
7.25.203	The bryophyte embryo also remains attached to the parent plant, which protects and nourishes it.
7.25.204	This is a characteristic of land plants.
7.25.205	The bryophytes are divided into three phyla: the liverworts or Hepaticophyta, the hornworts or Anthocerotophyta, and the mosses or true Bryophyta.
7.25.206	Liverworts Liverworts (Hepaticophyta) are viewed as the plants most closely related to the ancestor that moved to land.
7.25.207	Liverworts have colonized every terrestrial habitat on Earth and diversified to more than 7000 existing species (Figure 25.9).
7.25.208	Some gametophytes form lobate green structures, as seen in Figure 25.10.
7.25.209	The shape is similar to the lobes of the liver, and hence provides the origin of the name given to the phylum.
7.25.210	This 1904 drawing shows the variety of forms of Hepaticophyta.
7.25.211	A liverwort, Lunularia cruciata, displays its lobate, flat thallus.
7.25.212	The organism in the photograph is in the gametophyte stage.
7.25.213	Openings that allow the movement of gases may be observed in liverworts.
7.25.214	However, these are not stomata, because they do not actively open and close.
7.25.215	The plant takes up water over its entire surface and has no cuticle to prevent desiccation.
7.25.216	Figure 25.11 represents the lifecycle of a liverwort.
7.25.217	The cycle starts with the release of haploid spores from the sporangium that developed on the sporophyte.
7.25.218	Spores disseminated by wind or water germinate into flattened thalli attached to the substrate by thin, single-celled filaments.
7.25.219	Male and female gametangia develop on separate, individual plants.
7.25.220	Once released, male gametes swim with the aid of their flagella to the female gametangium (the archegonium), and fertilization ensues.
7.25.221	The zygote grows into a small sporophyte still attached to the parent gametophyte.
7.25.222	It will give rise, by meiosis, to the next generation of spores.
7.25.223	Liverwort plants can also reproduce asexually, by the breaking of branches or the spreading of leaf fragments called gemmae.
7.25.224	In this latter type of reproduction, the gemmae—small, intact, complete pieces of plant that are produced in a cup on the surface of the thallus (shown in Figure 25.11)—are splashed out of the cup by raindrops.
7.25.225	The gemmae then land nearby and develop into gametophytes.
7.25.226	The life cycle of a typical liverwort is shown.
7.25.227	(credit: modification of work by Mariana Ruiz Villareal)
7.25.228	Hornworts
7.25.229	The hornworts (Anthocerotophyta) belong to the broad bryophyte group.
7.25.230	They have colonized a variety of habitats on land, although they are never far from a source of moisture.
7.25.231	The short, blue-green gametophyte is the dominant phase of the lifecycle of a hornwort.
7.25.232	The narrow, pipe-like sporophyte is the defining characteristic of the group.
7.25.233	The sporophytes emerge from the parent gametophyte and continue to grow throughout the life of the plant.
7.25.234	Hornworts grow a tall and slender sporophyte.
7.25.235	Stomata appear in the hornworts and are abundant on the sporophyte.
7.25.236	Photosynthetic cells in the thallus contain a single chloroplast.
7.25.237	Meristem cells at the base of the plant keep dividing and adding to its height.
7.25.238	Many hornworts establish symbiotic relationships with cyanobacteria that fix nitrogen from the environment.
7.25.239	The lifecycle of hornworts (Figure 25.13) follows the general pattern of alternation of generations.
7.25.240	The gametophytes grow as flat thalli on the soil with embedded gametangia.
7.25.241	Flagellated sperm swim to the archegonia and fertilize eggs.
7.25.242	The zygote develops into a long and slender sporophyte that eventually splits open, releasing spores.
7.25.243	Thin cells called pseudoelaters surround the spores and help propel them further in the environment.
7.25.244	Unlike the elaters observed in horsetails, the hornwort pseudoelaters are single-celled structures.
7.25.245	The haploid spores germinate and give rise to the next generation of gametophyte.
7.25.246	The alternation of generation in hornworts is shown.
7.25.247	Mosses More than 10,000 species of mosses have been catalogued.
7.25.248	Their habitats vary from the tundra, where they are the main vegetation, to the understory of tropical forests.
7.25.249	In the tundra, the mosses’ shallow rhizoids allow them to fasten to a substrate without penetrating the frozen soil.
7.25.250	Mosses slow down erosion, store moisture and soil nutrients, and provide shelter for small animals as well as food for larger herbivores, such as the musk ox.
7.25.251	Mosses are very sensitive to air pollution and are used to monitor air quality.
7.25.252	They are also sensitive to copper salts, so these salts are a common ingredient of compounds marketed to eliminate mosses from lawns.
7.25.253	Mosses form diminutive gametophytes, which are the dominant phase of the lifecycle.
7.25.254	Green, flat structures—resembling true leaves, but lacking vascular tissue—are attached in a spiral to a central stalk.
7.25.255	The plants absorb water and nutrients directly through these leaf-like structures.
7.25.256	Some mosses have small branches.
7.25.257	Some primitive traits of green algae, such as flagellated sperm, are still present in mosses that are dependent on water for reproduction.
7.25.258	Other features of mosses are clearly adaptations to dry land.
7.25.259	For example, stomata are present on the stems of the sporophyte, and a primitive vascular system runs up the sporophyte’s stalk.
7.25.260	Additionally, mosses are anchored to the substrate—whether it is soil, rock, or roof tiles—by multicellular rhizoids.
7.25.261	These structures are precursors of roots.
7.25.262	They originate from the base of the gametophyte, but are not the major route for the absorption of water and minerals.
7.25.263	The lack of a true root system explains why it is so easy to rip moss mats from a tree trunk.
7.25.264	The moss lifecycle follows the pattern of alternation of generations as shown in Figure 25.14.
7.25.265	The most familiar structure is the haploid gametophyte, which germinates from a haploid spore and forms first a protonema—usually, a tangle of single-celled filaments that hug the ground.
7.25.266	Cells akin to an apical meristem actively divide and give rise to a gametophore, consisting of a photosynthetic stem and foliage-like structures.
7.25.267	Rhizoids form at the base of the gametophore.
7.25.268	Gametangia of both sexes develop on separate gametophores.
7.25.269	The male organ (the antheridium) produces many sperm, whereas the archegonium (the female organ) forms a single egg.
7.25.270	At fertilization, the sperm swims down the neck to the venter and unites with the egg inside the archegonium.
7.25.271	The zygote, protected by the archegonium, divides and grows into a sporophyte, still attached by its foot to the gametophyte.
7.25.272	The slender seta (plural, setae), as seen in Figure 25.15, contains tubular cells that transfer nutrients from the base of the sporophyte (the foot) to the sporangium or capsule.
7.25.273	This photograph shows the long slender stems, called setae, connected to capsules of the moss Thamnobryum alopecurum.
7.25.274	A structure called a peristome increases the spread of spores after the tip of the capsule falls off at dispersal.
7.25.275	The concentric tissue around the mouth of the capsule is made of triangular, close-fitting units, a little like “teeth”; these open and close depending on moisture levels, and periodically release spores.
7.25.276	The vascular plants, or tracheophytes, are the dominant and most conspicuous group of land plants.
7.25.277	More than 260,000 species of tracheophytes represent more than 90 percent of Earth’s vegetation.
7.25.278	Several evolutionary innovations explain their success and their ability to spread to all habitats.
7.25.279	Bryophytes may have been successful at the transition from an aquatic habitat to land, but they are still dependent on water for reproduction, and absorb moisture and nutrients through the gametophyte surface.
7.25.280	The lack of roots for absorbing water and minerals from the soil, as well as a lack of reinforced conducting cells, limits bryophytes to small sizes.
7.25.281	Although they may survive in reasonably dry conditions, they cannot reproduce and expand their habitat range in the absence of water.
7.25.282	Vascular plants, on the other hand, can achieve enormous heights, thus competing successfully for light.
7.25.283	Photosynthetic organs become leaves, and pipe-like cells or vascular tissues transport water, minerals, and fixed carbon throughout the organism.
7.25.284	In seedless vascular plants, the diploid sporophyte is the dominant phase of the lifecycle.
7.25.285	The gametophyte is now an inconspicuous, but still independent, organism.
7.25.286	Throughout plant evolution, there is an evident reversal of roles in the dominant phase of the lifecycle.
7.25.287	Seedless vascular plants still depend on water during fertilization, as the sperm must swim on a layer of moisture to reach the egg.
7.25.288	This step in reproduction explains why ferns and their relatives are more abundant in damp environments.
7.25.289	Vascular Tissue: Xylem and Phloem
7.25.290	The first fossils that show the presence of vascular tissue date to the Silurian period, about 430 million years ago.
7.25.291	The simplest arrangement of conductive cells shows a pattern of xylem at the center surrounded by phloem.
7.25.292	Xylem is the tissue responsible for the storage and long-distance transport of water and nutrients, as well as the transfer of water-soluble growth factors from the organs of synthesis to the target organs.
7.25.293	The tissue consists of conducting cells, known as tracheids, and supportive filler tissue, called parenchyma.
7.25.294	Xylem conductive cells incorporate the compound lignin into their walls, and are thus described as lignified.
7.25.295	Lignin itself is a complex polymer that is impermeable to water and confers mechanical strength to vascular tissue.
7.25.296	With their rigid cell walls, the xylem cells provide support to the plant and allow it to achieve impressive heights.
7.25.297	Tall plants have a selective advantage by being able to reach unfiltered sunlight and disperse their spores or seeds further away, thus expanding their range.
7.25.298	By growing higher than other plants, tall trees cast their shadow on shorter plants and limit competition for water and precious nutrients in the soil.
7.25.299	Phloem is the second type of vascular tissue; it transports sugars, proteins, and other solutes throughout the plant.
7.25.300	Phloem cells are divided into sieve elements (conducting cells) and cells that support the sieve elements.
7.25.301	Together, xylem and phloem tissues form the vascular system of plants.
7.25.302	Roots:
7.25.303	Support for the Plant Roots are not well preserved in the fossil record.
7.25.304	Nevertheless, it seems that roots appeared later in evolution than vascular tissue.
7.25.305	The development of an extensive network of roots represented a significant new feature of vascular plants.
7.25.306	Thin rhizoids attached bryophytes to the substrate, but these rather flimsy filaments did not provide a strong anchor for the plant; neither did they absorb substantial amounts of water and nutrients.
7.25.307	In contrast, roots, with their prominent vascular tissue system, transfer water and minerals from the soil to the rest of the plant.
7.25.308	The extensive network of roots that penetrates deep into the soil to reach sources of water also stabilizes trees by acting as a ballast or anchor.
7.25.309	The majority of roots establish a symbiotic relationship with fungi, forming mycorrhizae, which benefit the plant by greatly increasing the surface area for absorption of water and soil minerals and nutrients.
7.25.310	Leaves, Sporophylls, and Strobili A third innovation marks the seedless vascular plants.
7.25.311	Accompanying the prominence of the sporophyte and the development of vascular tissue, the appearance of true leaves improved their photosynthetic efficiency.
7.25.312	Leaves capture more sunlight with their increased surface area by employing more chloroplasts to trap light energy and convert it to chemical energy, which is then used to fix atmospheric carbon dioxide into carbohydrates.
7.25.313	The carbohydrates are exported to the rest of the plant by the conductive cells of phloem tissue.
7.25.314	The existence of two types of morphology suggests that leaves evolved independently in several groups of plants.
7.25.315	The first type of leaf is the microphyll, or “little leaf,
7.25.316	” which can be dated to 350 million years ago in the late Silurian.
7.25.317	A microphyll is small and has a simple vascular system.
7.25.318	A single unbranched vein—a bundle of vascular tissue made of xylem and phloem—runs through the center of the leaf.
7.25.319	Microphylls may have originated from the flattening of lateral branches, or from sporangia that lost their reproductive capabilities.
7.25.320	Microphylls are present in the club mosses and probably preceded the development of megaphylls, or “big leaves”, which are larger leaves with a pattern of branching veins.
7.25.321	Megaphylls most likely appeared independently several times during the course of evolution.
7.25.322	Their complex networks of veins suggest that several branches may have combined into a flattened organ, with the gaps between the branches being filled with photosynthetic tissue.
7.25.323	In addition to photosynthesis, leaves play another role in the life of the plants.
7.25.324	Pine cones, mature fronds of ferns, and flowers are all sporophylls—leaves that were modified structurally to bear sporangia.
7.25.325	Strobili are cone-like structures that contain sporangia.
7.25.326	They are prominent in conifers and are commonly known as pine cones.
7.25.327	Ferns and Other Seedless Vascular Plants
7.25.328	By the late Devonian period, plants had evolved vascular tissue, well-defined leaves, and root systems.
7.25.329	With these advantages, plants increased in height and size.
7.25.330	During the Carboniferous period, swamp forests of club mosses and horsetails—some specimens reaching heights of more than 30 m (100 ft)—covered most of the land.
7.25.331	These forests gave rise to the extensive coal deposits that gave the Carboniferous its name.
7.25.332	In seedless vascular plants, the sporophyte became the dominant phase of the lifecycle.
7.25.333	Water is still required for fertilization of seedless vascular plants, and most favor a moist environment.
7.25.334	Modern-day seedless tracheophytes include club mosses, horsetails, ferns, and whisk ferns.
7.25.335	Phylum Lycopodiophyta:
7.25.336	Club Mosses
7.25.337	The club mosses, or phylum Lycopodiophyta, are the earliest group of seedless vascular plants.
7.25.338	They dominated the landscape of the Carboniferous, growing into tall trees and forming large swamp forests.
7.25.339	Today’s club mosses are diminutive, evergreen plants consisting of a stem (which may be branched) and microphylls (Figure 25.16).
7.25.340	The phylum Lycopodiophyta consists of close to 1,200 species, including the quillworts (Isoetales), the club mosses (Lycopodiales), and spike mosses (Selaginellales), none of which are true mosses or bryophytes.
7.25.341	Lycophytes follow the pattern of alternation of generations seen in the bryophytes, except that the sporophyte is the major stage of the lifecycle.
7.25.342	The gametophytes do not depend on the sporophyte for nutrients.
7.25.343	Some gametophytes develop underground and form mycorrhizal associations with fungi.
7.25.344	In club mosses, the sporophyte gives rise to sporophylls arranged in strobili, cone-like structures that give the class its name.
7.25.345	Lycophytes can be homosporous or heterosporous.
7.25.346	In the club mosses such as Lycopodium clavatum, sporangia are arranged in clusters called strobili.
7.25.347	Phylum Monilophyta: Class Equisetopsida (Horsetails) Horsetails, whisk ferns and ferns belong to the phylum Monilophyta, with horsetails placed in the Class Equisetopsida.
7.25.348	The single genus Equisetum is the survivor of a large group of plants, known as Arthrophyta, which produced large trees and entire swamp forests in the Carboniferous.
7.25.349	The plants are usually found in damp environments and marshes.
7.25.350	Horsetails thrive in a marsh.
7.25.351	The stem of a horsetail is characterized by the presence of joints or nodes, hence the name Arthrophyta (arthro- = "joint"; -phyta = "plant").
7.25.352	Leaves and branches come out as whorls from the evenly spaced joints.
7.25.353	The needle-shaped leaves do not contribute greatly to photosynthesis, the majority of which takes place in the green stem.
7.25.354	Thin leaves originating at the joints are noticeable on the horsetail plant.
7.25.355	Horsetails were once used as scrubbing brushes and were nicknamed scouring brushes.
7.25.356	Silica collects in the epidermal cells, contributing to the stiffness of horsetail plants.
7.25.357	Underground stems known as rhizomes anchor the plants to the ground.
7.25.358	Modern-day horsetails are homosporous and produce bisexual gametophytes.
7.25.359	Phylum Monilophyta:
7.25.360	Class Psilotopsida (Whisk Ferns)
7.25.361	While most ferns form large leaves and branching roots, the whisk ferns, Class Psilotopsida, lack both roots and leaves, probably lost by reduction.
7.25.362	Photosynthesis takes place in their green stems, and small yellow knobs form at the tip of the branch stem and contain the sporangia.
7.25.363	Whisk ferns were considered an early pterophytes.
7.25.364	However, recent comparative DNA analysis suggests that this group may have lost both vascular tissue and roots through evolution, and is more closely related to ferns.
7.25.365	The whisk fern Psilotum nudum has conspicuous green stems with knob-shaped sporangia.
7.25.366	Phylum Monilophyta: Class Psilotopsida (Ferns)
7.25.367	With their large fronds, ferns are the most readily recognizable seedless vascular plants.
7.25.368	They are considered the most advanced seedless vascular plants and display characteristics commonly observed in seed plants.
7.25.369	More than 20,000 species of ferns live in environments ranging from tropics to temperate forests.
7.25.370	Although some species survive in dry environments, most ferns are restricted to moist, shaded places.
7.25.371	Ferns made their appearance in the fossil record during the Devonian period and expanded during the Carboniferous.
7.25.372	The dominant stage of the lifecycle of a fern is the sporophyte, which consists of large compound leaves called fronds.
7.25.373	Fronds fulfill a double role; they are photosynthetic organs that also carry reproductive organs.
7.25.374	The stem may be buried underground as a rhizome, from which adventitious roots grow to absorb water and nutrients from the soil; or, they may grow above ground as a trunk in tree ferns (Figure 25.20).
7.25.375	Adventitious organs are those that grow in unusual places, such as roots growing from the side of a stem.
7.25.376	Some specimens of this short tree-fern species can grow very tall.
7.25.377	The tip of a developing fern frond is rolled into a crozier, or fiddlehead (Figure 25.21a and Figure 25.21b).
7.25.378	Fiddleheads unroll as the frond develops.
7.25.379	Croziers, or fiddleheads, are the tips of fern fronds.
7.25.380	Most ferns produce the same type of spores and are therefore homosporous.
7.25.381	The diploid sporophyte is the most conspicuous stage of the lifecycle.
7.25.382	On the underside of its mature fronds, sori (singular, sorus) form as small clusters where sporangia develop.
7.25.383	Sori appear as small bumps on the underside of a fern frond.
7.25.384	Inside the sori, spores are produced by meiosis and released into the air.
7.25.385	Those that land on a suitable substrate germinate and form a heart-shaped gametophyte, which is attached to the ground by thin filamentous rhizoids.
7.25.386	Shown here are a young sporophyte (upper part of image) and a heart-shaped gametophyte.
7.25.387	The inconspicuous gametophyte harbors both sex gametangia.
7.25.388	Flagellated sperm released from the antheridium swim on a wet surface to the archegonium, where the egg is fertilized.
7.25.389	The newly formed zygote grows into a sporophyte that emerges from the gametophyte and grows by mitosis into the next generation sporophyte.
7.25.390	This landscaped border at a college campus was designed by students in the horticulture and landscaping department of the college.
7.25.391	The Importance of Seedless Vascular Plants Mosses and liverworts are often the first macroscopic organisms to colonize an area, both in a primary succession—where bare land is settled for the first time by living organisms—or in a secondary succession, where soil remains intact after a catastrophic event wipes out many existing species.
7.25.392	Their spores are carried by the wind, birds, or insects.
7.25.393	Once mosses and liverworts are established, they provide food and shelter for other species.
7.25.394	In a hostile environment, like the tundra where the soil is frozen, bryophytes grow well because they do not have roots and can dry and rehydrate rapidly once water is again available.
7.25.395	Mosses are at the base of the food chain in the tundra biome.
7.25.396	Many species—from small insects to musk oxen and reindeer—depend on mosses for food.
7.25.397	In turn, predators feed on the herbivores, which are the primary consumers.
7.25.398	Some reports indicate that bryophytes make the soil more amenable to colonization by other plants.
7.25.399	Because they establish symbiotic relationships with nitrogen-fixing cyanobacteria, mosses replenish the soil with nitrogen.
7.25.400	At the end of the nineteenth century, scientists observed that lichens and mosses were becoming increasingly rare in urban and suburban areas.
7.25.401	Since bryophytes have neither a root system for absorption of water and nutrients, nor a cuticle layer that protects them from desiccation, pollutants in rainwater readily penetrate their tissues; they absorb moisture and nutrients through their entire exposed surfaces.
7.25.402	Therefore, pollutants dissolved in rainwater penetrate plant tissues readily and have a larger impact on mosses than on other plants.
