7.25.403	The disappearance of mosses can be considered a bioindicator for the level of pollution in the environment.
7.25.404	Ferns contribute to the environment by promoting the weathering of rock, accelerating the formation of topsoil, and slowing down erosion by spreading rhizomes in the soil.
7.25.405	The water ferns of the genus
7.25.406	Azolla harbor nitrogen-fixing cyanobacteria and restore this important nutrient to aquatic habitats.
7.25.407	Seedless plants have historically played a role in human life through uses as tools, fuel, and medicine.
7.25.408	Dried peat moss, Sphagnum, is commonly used as fuel in some parts of Europe and is considered a renewable resource.
7.25.409	Sphagnum bogs (Figure 25.26) are cultivated with cranberry and blueberry bushes.
7.25.410	The ability of Sphagnum to hold moisture makes the moss a common soil conditioner.
7.25.411	Florists use blocks of Sphagnum to maintain moisture for floral arrangements.
7.25.412	Sphagnum acutifolium is dried peat moss and can be used as fuel.
7.25.413	The attractive fronds of ferns make them a favorite ornamental plant.
7.25.414	Because they thrive in low light, they are well suited as house plants.
7.25.415	More importantly, fiddleheads are a traditional spring food of Native Americans in the Pacific Northwest, and are popular as a side dish in French cuisine.
7.25.416	The licorice fern, Polypodium glycyrrhiza, is part of the diet of the Pacific Northwest coastal tribes, owing in part to the sweetness of its rhizomes.
7.25.417	It has a faint licorice taste and serves as a sweetener.
7.25.418	The rhizome also figures in the pharmacopeia of Native Americans for its medicinal properties and is used as a remedy for sore throat.
7.25.419	By far the greatest impact of seedless vascular plants on human life, however, comes from their extinct progenitors.
7.25.420	The tall club mosses, horsetails, and tree-like ferns that flourished in the swampy forests of the Carboniferous period gave rise to large deposits of coal throughout the world.
7.25.421	Coal provided an abundant source of energy during the Industrial Revolution, which had tremendous consequences on human societies, including rapid technological progress and growth of large cities, as well as the degradation of the environment.
7.25.422	Coal is still a prime source of energy and also a major contributor to global warming.
7.26.0	Seed plants dominate the landscape and play an integral role in human societies.
7.26.1	(a) Palm trees grow along the shoreline; (b) wheat is a crop grown in most of the world; (c) the flower of the cotton plant produces fibers that are woven into fabric; (d) the potent alkaloids of the beautiful opium poppy have influenced human life both as a medicinal remedy and as a dangerously addictive drug.
7.26.2	The lush palms on tropical shorelines do not depend on water for the dispersal of their pollen, fertilization, or the survival of the zygote—unlike mosses, liverworts, and ferns of the terrain.
7.26.3	Seed plants, such as palms, have broken free from the need to rely on water for their reproductive needs.
7.26.4	They play an integral role in all aspects of life on the planet, shaping the physical terrain, influencing the climate, and maintaining life as we know it.
7.26.5	For millennia, human societies have depended on seed plants for nutrition and medicinal compounds: and more recently, for industrial by-products, such as timber and paper, dyes, and textiles.
7.26.6	Palms provide materials including rattans, oils, and dates.
7.26.7	Wheat is grown to feed both human and animal populations.
7.26.8	The fruit of the cotton boll flower is harvested as a boll, with its fibers transformed into clothing or pulp for paper.
7.26.9	The showy opium poppy is valued both as an ornamental flower and as a source of potent opiate compounds.
7.26.10	The first plants to colonize land were most likely closely related to modern day mosses (bryophytes) and are thought to have appeared about 500 million years ago.
7.26.11	They were followed by liverworts (also bryophytes) and primitive vascul plants—the pterophytes—from which modern ferns are derived.
7.26.12	The lifecycle of bryophytes and pterophytes is characterized by the alternation of generations, like gymnosperms and angiosperms; what sets bryophytes and pterophytes apart from gymnosperms and angiosperms is their reproductive requirement for water.
7.26.13	The completion of the bryophyte and pterophyte life cycle requires water because the male gametophyte releases sperm, which must swim—propelled by their flagella—to reach and fertilize the female gamete or egg.
7.26.14	After fertilization, the zygote matures and grows into a sporophyte, which in turn will form sporangia or "spore vessels.
7.26.15	"
7.26.16	In the sporangia, mother cells undergo meiosis and produce the haploid spores.
7.26.17	Release of spores in a suitable environment will lead to germination and a new generation of gametophytes.
7.26.18	In seed plants, the evolutionary trend led to a dominant sporophyte generation, and at the same time, a systematic reduction in the size of the gametophyte: from a conspicuous structure to a microscopic cluster of cells enclosed in the tissues of the sporophyte.
7.26.19	Whereas lower vascular plants, such as club mosses and ferns, are mostly homosporous (produce only one type of spore), all seed plants, or spermatophytes, are heterosporous.
7.26.20	They form two types of spores: megaspores (female) and microspores (male).
7.26.21	Megaspores develop into female gametophytes that produce eggs, and microspores mature into male gametophytes that generate sperm.
7.26.22	Because the gametophytes mature within the spores, they are not free-living, as are the gametophytes of other seedless vascular plants.
7.26.23	Heterosporous seedless plants are seen as the evolutionary forerunners of seed plants.
7.26.24	Seeds and pollen—two critical adaptations to drought, and to reproduction that
7.26.25	doesn’t require water—distinguish seed plants from other (seedless) vascular plants.
7.26.26	Both adaptations were required for the colonization of land begun by the bryophytes and their ancestors.
7.26.27	Fossils place the earliest distinct seed plants at about 350 million years ago.
7.26.28	The first reliable record of gymnosperms dates their appearance to the Pennsylvanian period, about 319 million years ago (Figure 26.2).
7.26.29	Gymnosperms were preceded by progymnosperms, the first naked seed plants, which arose about 380 million years ago.
7.26.30	Progymnosperms were a transitional group of plants that superficially resembled conifers (cone bearers) because they produced wood from the secondary growth of the vascular tissues; however, they still reproduced like ferns, releasing spores into the environment.
7.26.31	Gymnosperms dominated the landscape in the early (Triassic) and middle (Jurassic) Mesozoic era.
7.26.32	Angiosperms surpassed gymnosperms by the middle of the Cretaceous (about 100 million years ago) in the late Mesozoic era, and today are the most abundant plant group in most terrestrial biomes.
7.26.33	Various plant species evolved in different eras.
7.26.34	Pollen and seed were innovative structures that allowed seed plants to break their dependence on water for reproduction and development of the embryo, and to conquer dry land.
7.26.35	The pollen grains are the male gametophytes, which contain the sperm (gametes) of the plant.
7.26.36	The small haploid (1n) cells are encased in a protective coat that prevents desiccation (drying out) and mechanical damage.
7.26.37	Pollen grains can travel far from their original sporophyte, spreading the plant’s genes.
7.26.38	The seed offers the embryo protection, nourishment, and a mechanism to maintain dormancy for tens or even thousands of years, ensuring germination can occur when growth conditions are optimal.
7.26.39	Seeds therefore allow plants to disperse the next generation through both space and time.
7.26.40	With such evolutionary advantages, seed plants have become the most successful and familiar group of plants, in part because of their size and striking appearance.
7.26.41	Evolution of Gymnosperms
7.26.42	The fossil plant Elkinsia polymorpha, a "seed fern" from the Devonian period—about 400 million years ago—is considered the earliest seed plant known to date.
7.26.43	Seed ferns (Figure 26.3) produced their seeds along their branches without specialized structures.
7.26.44	What makes them the first true seed plants is that they developed structures called cupules to enclose and protect the ovule—the female gametophyte and associated tissues—which develops into a seed upon fertilization.
7.26.45	Seed plants resembling modern tree ferns became more numerous and diverse in the coal swamps of the Carboniferous period.
7.26.46	This fossilized leaf is from Glossopteris, a seed fern that thrived during the Permian age (290–240 million years ago).
7.26.47	Fossil records indicate the first gymnosperms (progymnosperms) most likely originated in the Paleozoic era, during the middle Devonian period: about 390 million years ago.
7.26.48	Following the wet Mississippian and Pennsylvanian periods, which were dominated by giant fern trees, the Permian period was dry.
7.26.49	This gave a reproductive edge to seed plants, which are better adapted to survive dry spells.
7.26.50	The Ginkgoales, a group of gymnosperms with only one surviving species—the Gingko biloba—were the first gymnosperms to appear during the lower Jurassic.
7.26.51	Gymnosperms expanded in the Mesozoic era (about 240 million years ago), supplanting ferns in the landscape, and reaching their greatest diversity during this time.
7.26.52	The Jurassic period was as much the age of the cycads (palm-tree-like gymnosperms) as the age of the dinosaurs.
7.26.53	Gingkoales and the more familiar conifers also dotted the landscape.
7.26.54	Although angiosperms (flowering plants) are the major form of plant life in most biomes, gymnosperms still dominate some ecosystems, such as the taiga (boreal forests) and the alpine forests at higher mountain elevations (Figure 26.4) because of their adaptation to cold and dry growth conditions.
7.26.55	This boreal forest (taiga) has low-lying plants and conifer trees.
7.26.56	Seeds and Pollen as an Evolutionary Adaptation to Dry Land
7.26.57	Unlike bryophyte and fern spores (which are haploid cells dependent on moisture for rapid development of gametophytes), seeds contain a diploid embryo that will germinate into a sporophyte.
7.26.58	Storage tissue to sustain growth and a protective coat give seeds their superior evolutionary advantage.
7.26.59	Several layers of hardened tissue prevent desiccation, and free reproduction from the need for a constant supply of water.
7.26.60	Furthermore, seeds remain in a state of dormancy—induced by desiccation and the hormone
7.26.61	abscisic acid—until conditions for growth become favorable.
7.26.62	Whether blown by the wind, floating on water, or carried away by animals, seeds are scattered in an expanding geographic range, thus avoiding competition with the parent plant.
7.26.63	Pollen grains (Figure 26.5) are male gametophytes and are carried by wind, water, or a pollinator.
7.26.64	The whole structure is protected from desiccation and can reach the female organs without dependence on water.
7.26.65	Male gametes reach female gametophyte and the egg cell gamete though a pollen tube: an extension of a cell within the pollen grain.
7.26.66	The sperm of modern gymnosperms lack flagella, but in cycads and the Gingko, the sperm still possess flagella that allow them to swim down the pollen tube to the female gamete; however, they are enclosed in a pollen grain.
7.26.67	This fossilized pollen is from a Buckbean fen core found in Yellowstone National Park, Wyoming.
7.26.68	The pollen is magnified 1,054 times.
7.26.69	Evolution of Angiosperms Undisputed fossil records place the massive appearance and diversification of angiosperms in the middle to late Mesozoic era.
7.26.70	Angiosperms (“seed in a vessel”) produce a flower containing male and/or female reproductive structures.
7.26.71	Fossil evidence (Figure 26.6) indicates that flowering plants first appeared in the Lower Cretaceous, about 125 million years ago, and were rapidly diversifying by the Middle Cretaceous, about 100 million years ago.
7.26.72	Earlier traces of angiosperms are scarce.
7.26.73	Fossilized pollen recovered from Jurassic geological material has been attributed to angiosperms.
7.26.74	A few early Cretaceous rocks show clear imprints of leaves resembling angiosperm leaves.
7.26.75	By the mid-Cretaceous, a staggering number of diverse flowering plants crowd the fossil record.
7.26.76	The same geological period is also marked by the appearance of many modern groups of insects, including pollinating insects that played a key role in ecology and the evolution of flowering plants.
7.26.77	Although several hypotheses have been offered to explain this sudden profusion and variety of flowering plants, none have garnered the consensus of paleobotanists (scientists who study ancient plants).
7.26.78	New data in comparative genomics and paleobotany have, however, shed some light on the evolution of angiosperms.
7.26.79	Rather than being derived from gymnosperms, angiosperms form a sister clade (a species and its descendents) that developed in parallel with the gymnosperms.
7.26.80	The two innovative structures of flowers and fruit represent an improved reproductive strategy that served to protect the embryo, while increasing genetic variability and range.
7.26.81	Paleobotanists debate whether angiosperms evolved from small woody bushes, or were basal angiosperms related to tropical grasses.
7.26.82	Both views draw support from cladistics studies, and the so-called woody magnoliid hypothesis—which proposes that the early ancestors of angiosperms were shrubs—also offers molecular biological evidence.
7.26.83	The most primitive living angiosperm is considered to be Amborella trichopoda, a small plant native to the rainforest of New Caledonia, an island in the South Pacific.
7.26.84	Analysis of the genome of A. trichopoda has shown that it is related to all existing flowering plants and belongs to the oldest confirmed branch of the angiosperm family tree.
7.26.85	A few other angiosperm groups called basal angiosperms, are viewed as primitive because they branched off early from the phylogenetic tree.
7.26.86	Most modern angiosperms are classified as either monocots or eudicots, based on the structure of their leaves and embryos.
7.26.87	Basal angiosperms, such as water lilies, are considered more primitive because they share morphological traits with both monocots and eudicots.
7.26.88	This leaf imprint shows a Ficus speciosissima, an angiosperm that flourished during the Cretaceous period.
7.26.89	Flowers and Fruits as an Evolutionary Adaptation Angiosperms produce their gametes in separate organs, which are usually housed in a flower.
7.26.90	Both fertilization and embryo development take place inside an anatomical structure that provides a stable system of sexual reproduction largely sheltered from environmental fluctuations.
7.26.91	Flowering plants are the most diverse phylum on Earth after insects; flowers come in a bewildering array of sizes, shapes, colors, smells, and arrangements.
7.26.92	Most flowers have a mutualistic pollinator, with the distinctive features of flowers reflecting the nature of the pollination agent.
7.26.93	The relationship between pollinator and flower characteristics is one of the great examples of coevolution.
7.26.94	Following fertilization of the egg, the ovule grows into a seed.
7.26.95	The surrounding tissues of the ovary thicken, developing into a fruit that will protect the seed and often ensure its dispersal over a wide geographic range.
7.26.96	Not all fruits develop from an ovary; such structures are “false fruits.
7.26.97	”
7.26.98	Like flowers, fruit can vary tremendously in appearance, size, smell, and taste.
7.26.99	Tomatoes, walnut shells and avocados are all examples of fruit.
7.26.100	As with pollen and seeds, fruits also act as agents of dispersal.
7.26.101	Some may be carried away by the wind.
7.26.102	Many attract animals that will eat the fruit and pass the seeds through their digestive systems, then deposit the seeds in another location.
7.26.103	Cockleburs are covered with stiff, hooked spines that can hook into fur (or clothing) and hitch a ride on an animal for long distances.
7.26.104	The cockleburs that clung to the velvet trousers of an enterprising Swiss hiker, George de Mestral, inspired his invention of the loop and hook fastener he named Velcro.
7.26.105	Gymnosperms, meaning “naked seeds,” are a diverse group of seed plants and are paraphyletic.
7.26.106	Paraphyletic groups are those in which not all members are descendants of a single common ancestor.
7.26.107	Their characteristics include naked seeds, separate female and male gametes, pollination by wind, and tracheids (which transport water and solutes in the vascular system).
7.26.108	Gymnosperm seeds are not enclosed in an ovary; rather, they are exposed on cones or modified leaves.
7.26.109	Sporophylls are specialized leaves that produce sporangia.
7.26.110	The term strobilus (plural = strobili) describes a tight arrangement of sporophylls around a central stalk, as seen in cones.
7.26.111	Some seeds are enveloped by sporophyte tissues upon maturation.
7.26.112	The layer of sporophyte tissue that surrounds the megasporangium, and later, the embryo, is called the integument.
7.26.113	Gymnosperms were the dominant phylum in Mesozoic era.
7.26.114	They are adapted to live where fresh water is scarce during part of the year, or in the nitrogen-poor soil of a bog.
7.26.115	Therefore, they are still the prominent phylum in the coniferous biome or taiga, where the evergreen conifers have a selective advantage in cold and dry weather.
7.26.116	Evergreen conifers continue low levels of photosynthesis during the cold months, and are ready to take advantage of the first sunny days of spring.
7.26.117	One disadvantage is that conifers are more susceptible than deciduous trees to infestations because conifers do not lose their leaves all at once.
7.26.118	They cannot, therefore, shed parasites and restart with a fresh supply of leaves in spring.
7.26.119	The life cycle of a gymnosperm involves alternation of generations, with a dominant sporophyte in which the female gametophyte resides, and reduced gametophytes.
7.26.120	All gymnosperms are heterosporous.
7.26.121	The male and female reproductive organs can form in cones or strobili.
7.26.122	Male and female sporangia are produced either on the same plant, described as monoecious (“one home” or bisexual), or on separate plants, referred to as dioecious (“two homes” or unisexual) plants.
7.26.123	The life cycle of a conifer will serve as our example of reproduction in gymnosperms.
7.26.124	Life Cycle of a Conifer Pine trees are conifers (cone bearing) and carry both male and female sporophylls on the same mature sporophyte.
7.26.125	Therefore, they are monoecious plants.
7.26.126	Like all gymnosperms, pines are heterosporous and generate two different types of spores: male microspores and female megaspores.
7.26.127	In the male cones, or staminate cones, the microsporocytes give rise to pollen grains by meiosis.
7.26.128	In the spring, large amounts of yellow pollen are released and carried by the wind.
7.26.129	Some gametophytes will land on a female cone.
7.26.130	Pollination is defined as the initiation of pollen tube growth.
7.26.131	The pollen tube develops slowly, and the generative cell in the pollen grain divides into two haploid sperm cells by mitosis.
7.26.132	At fertilization, one of the sperm cells will finally unite its haploid nucleus with the haploid nucleus of a haploid egg cell.
7.26.133	Female cones, or ovulate cones, contain two ovules per scale.
7.26.134	One megaspore mother cell, or megasporocyte, undergoes meiosis in each ovule.
7.26.135	Three of the four cells break down; only a single surviving cell will develop into a female multicellular gametophyte, which encloses archegonia (an archegonium is a reproductive organ that contains a single large egg).
7.26.136	Upon fertilization, the diploid egg will give rise to the embryo, which is enclosed in a seed coat of tissue from the parent plant.
7.26.137	Fertilization and seed development is a long process in pine trees: it may take up to two years after pollination.
7.26.138	The seed that is formed contains three generations of tissues: the seed coat that originates from the sporophyte tissue, the gametophyte that will provide nutrients, and the embryo itself.
7.26.139	Figure 26.8 illustrates the life cycle of a conifer.
7.26.140	The sporophyte (2n) phase is the longest phase in the life of a gymnosperm.
7.26.141	The gametophytes (1n)—microspores and megaspores—are reduced in size.
7.26.142	It may take more than year between pollination and fertilization while the pollen tube grows towards the megasporocyte (2n), which undergoes meiosis into megaspores.
7.26.143	The megaspores will mature into eggs (1n).
7.26.144	Diversity of Gymnosperms Modern gymnosperms are classified into four phyla.
7.26.145	Coniferophyta, Cycadophyta, and Ginkgophyta are similar in their production of secondary cambium (cells that generate the vascular system of the trunk or stem and are partially specialized for water transportation) and their pattern of seed development.
7.26.146	However, the three phyla are not closely related phylogenetically to each other.
7.26.147	Gnetophyta are considered the closest group to angiosperms because they produce true xylem tissue.
7.26.148	Conifers (Coniferophyta) Conifers are the dominant phylum of gymnosperms, with the most variety of species (Figure 26.9).
7.26.149	Most are typically tall trees that usually bear scale-like or needle-like leaves.
7.26.150	Water evaporation from leaves is reduced by their thin shape and the thick cuticle.
7.26.151	Snow slides easily off needle-shaped leaves, keeping the load light and decreasing breaking of branches.
7.26.152	Adaptations to cold and dry weather explain the predominance of conifers at high altitudes and in cold climates.
7.26.153	Conifers include familiar evergreen trees such as pines, spruces, firs, cedars, sequoias, and yews.
7.26.154	A few species are deciduous and lose their leaves in fall.
7.26.155	The European larch and the tamarack are examples of deciduous conifers (Figure 26.9c).
7.26.156	Many coniferous trees are harvested for paper pulp and timber.
7.26.157	The wood of conifers is more primitive than the wood of angiosperms; it contains tracheids, but no vessel elements, and is therefore referred to as “soft wood.
7.26.158	”
7.26.159	Conifers are the dominant form of vegetation in cold or arid environments and at high altitudes.
7.26.160	Shown here are the (a) evergreen spruce Picea sp.
7.26.161	,
7.26.162	(b) juniper Juniperus sp.
7.26.163	, (c) sequoia Sequoia Semervirens, which is a deciduous gymnosperm, and (d) the tamarack Larix larcinia.
7.26.164	Notice the yellow leaves of the tamarack.
7.26.165	Cycads Cycads thrive in mild climates, and are often mistaken for palms because of the shape of their large, compound leaves.
7.26.166	Cycads bear large cones (Figure 26.10), and may be pollinated by beetles rather than wind: unusual for a gymnosperm.
7.26.167	They dominated the landscape during the age of dinosaurs in the Mesozoic, but only a hundred or so species persisted to modern times.
7.26.168	They face possible extinction, and several species are protected through international conventions.
7.26.169	Because of their attractive shape, they are often used as ornamental plants in gardens in the tropics and subtropics.
7.26.170	This Encephalartos ferox cycad has large cones and broad, fern-like leaves.
7.26.171	Gingkophytes
7.26.172	The single surviving species of the gingkophytes group is the Gingko biloba (Figure 26.11).
7.26.173	Its fan-shaped leaves—unique among seed plants because they feature a dichotomous venation pattern—turn yellow in autumn and fall from the tree.
7.26.174	For centuries, G. biloba was cultivated by Chinese Buddhist monks in monasteries, which ensured its preservation.
7.26.175	It is planted in public spaces because it is unusually resistant to pollution.
7.26.176	Male and female organs are produced on separate plants.
7.26.177	Typically, gardeners plant only male trees because the seeds produced by the female plant have an off-putting smell of rancid butter.
7.26.178	This plate from the 1870 book Flora Japonica, Sectio Prima (Tafelband) depicts the leaves and fruit of Gingko biloba, as drawn by Philipp Franz von Siebold and Joseph Gerhard Zuccarini.
7.26.179	Gnetophytes Gnetophytes are the closest relative to modern angiosperms, and include three dissimilar genera of plants: Ephedra, Gnetum, and Welwitschia (Figure 26.12).
7.26.180	Like angiosperms, they have broad leaves.
7.26.181	In tropical and subtropical zones, gnetophytes are vines or small shrubs.
7.26.182	Ephedra occurs in dry areas of the West Coast of the United States and Mexico.
7.26.183	Ephedra’s small, scale-like leaves are the source of the compound ephedrine, which is used in medicine as a potent decongestant.
7.26.184	Because ephedrine is similar to amphetamines, both in chemical structure and neurological effects, its use is restricted to prescription drugs.
7.26.185	Like angiosperms, but unlike other gymnosperms, all gnetophytes possess vessel elements in their xylem.
7.26.186	Ephedra viridis, known by the common name Mormon tea, grows on the West Coast of the United States and Mexico.
7.26.187	(b) Gnetum gnemon grows in Malaysia.
7.26.188	(c)
7.26.189	The large Welwitschia mirabilis can be found in the Namibian desert.
7.26.190	From their humble and still obscure beginning during the early Jurassic period, the angiosperms—or flowering plants—have evolved to dominate most terrestrial ecosystems (Figure 26.13).
7.26.191	With more than 250,000 species, the angiosperm phylum (Anthophyta) is second only to insects in terms of diversification.
7.26.192	These flowers grow in a botanical garden border in Bellevue, WA.
7.26.193	Flowering plants dominate terrestrial landscapes.
7.26.194	The vivid colors of flowers are an adaptation to pollination by animals such as insects and birds.
7.26.195	The success of angiosperms is due to two novel reproductive structures: flowers and fruit.
7.26.196	The function of the flower is to ensure pollination.
7.26.197	Flowers also provide protection for the ovule and developing embryo inside a receptacle.
7.26.198	The function of the fruit is seed dispersal.
7.26.199	They also protect the developing seed.
7.26.200	Different fruit structures or tissues on fruit—such as sweet flesh, wings, parachutes, or spines that grab—reflect the dispersal strategies that help spread seeds.
7.26.201	Flowers Flowers are modified leaves, or sporophylls, organized around a central stalk.
7.26.202	Although they vary greatly in appearance, all flowers contain the same structures: sepals, petals, carpels, and stamens.
7.26.203	The peduncle attaches the flower to the plant.
7.26.204	A whorl of sepals (collectively called the calyx) is located at the base of the peduncle and encloses the unopened floral bud.
7.26.205	Sepals are usually photosynthetic organs, although there are some exceptions.
7.26.206	For example, the corolla in lilies and tulips consists of three sepals and three petals that look virtually identical.
7.26.207	Petals, collectively the corolla, are located inside the whorl of sepals and often display vivid colors to attract pollinators.
7.26.208	Flowers pollinated by wind are usually small, feathery, and visually inconspicuous.
7.26.209	Sepals and petals together form the perianth.
7.26.210	The sexual organs (carpels and stamens) are located at the center of the flower.
7.26.211	As illustrated in Figure 26.14, styles, stigmas, and ovules constitute the female organ: the gynoecium or carpel.
7.26.212	Flower structure is very diverse, and carpels may be singular, multiple, or fused.
7.26.213	Multiple fused carpels comprise a pistil.
7.26.214	The megaspores and the female gametophytes are produced and protected by the thick tissues of the carpel.
7.26.215	A long, thin structure called a style leads from the sticky stigma, where pollen is deposited, to the ovary, enclosed in the carpel.
7.26.216	The ovary houses one or more ovules, each of which will develop into a seed upon fertilization.
7.26.217	The male reproductive organs, the stamens (collectively called the androecium), surround the central carpel.
7.26.218	Stamens are composed of a thin stalk called a filament and a sac-like structure called the anther.
7.26.219	The filament supports the anther, where the microspores are produced by meiosis and develop into pollen grains.
7.26.220	This image depicts the structure of a perfect flower.
7.26.221	Perfect flowers produce both male and female floral organs.
7.26.222	The flower shown has only one carpel, but some flowers have a cluster of carpels.
7.26.223	Together, all the carpels make up the gynoecium.
7.26.224	Fruit
7.26.225	As the seed develops, the walls of the ovary thicken and form the fruit.
7.26.226	The seed forms in an ovary, which also enlarges as the seeds grow.
7.26.227	In botany, a fertilized and fully grown, ripened ovary is a fruit.
7.26.228	Many foods commonly called vegetables are actually fruit.
7.26.229	Eggplants, zucchini, string beans, and bell peppers are all technically fruit because they contain seeds and are derived from the thick ovary tissue.
7.26.230	Acorns are nuts, and winged maple whirligigs (whose botanical name is samara) are also fruit.
7.26.231	Botanists classify fruit into more than two dozen different categories, only a few of which are actually fleshy and sweet.
7.26.232	Mature fruit can be fleshy or dry.
7.26.233	Fleshy fruit include the familiar berries, peaches, apples, grapes, and tomatoes.
7.26.234	Rice, wheat, and nuts are examples of dry fruit.
7.26.235	Another distinction is that not all fruits are derived from the ovary.
7.26.236	For instance, strawberries are derived from the receptacle and apples from the pericarp, or hypanthium.
7.26.237	Some fruits are derived from separate ovaries in a single flower, such as the raspberry.
7.26.238	Other fruits, such as the pineapple, form from clusters of flowers.
7.26.239	Additionally, some fruits, like watermelon and orange, have rinds.
7.26.240	Regardless of how they are formed, fruits are an agent of seed dispersal.
7.26.241	The variety of shapes and characteristics reflect the mode of dispersal.
7.26.242	Wind carries the light dry fruit of trees and dandelions.
7.26.243	Water transports floating coconuts.
7.26.244	Some fruits attract herbivores with color or perfume, or as food.
7.26.245	Once eaten, tough, undigested seeds are dispersed through the herbivore’s feces.
7.26.246	Other fruits have burs and hooks to cling to fur and hitch rides on animals.
7.26.247	The Life Cycle of an Angiosperm
7.26.248	The adult, or sporophyte, phase is the main phase of an angiosperm’s life cycle (Figure 26.15).
7.26.249	Like gymnosperms, angiosperms are heterosporous.
7.26.250	Therefore, they generate microspores, which will generate pollen grains as the male gametophytes, and megaspores, which will form an ovule that contains female gametophytes.
7.26.251	Inside the anthers’ microsporangia, male gametophytes divide by meiosis to generate haploid microspores, which, in turn, undergo mitosis and give rise to pollen grains.
7.26.252	Each pollen grain contains two cells: one generative cell that will divide into two sperm and a second cell that will become the pollen tube cell.
7.26.253	The ovule, sheltered within the ovary of the carpel, contains the megasporangium protected by two layers of integuments and the ovary wall.
7.26.254	Within each megasporangium, a megasporocyte undergoes meiosis, generating four megaspores—three small and one large.
7.26.255	Only the large megaspore survives; it produces the female gametophyte, referred to as the embryo sac.
7.26.256	The megaspore divides three times to form an eight-cell stage.
7.26.257	Four of these cells migrate to each pole of the embryo sac; two come to the equator, and will eventually fuse to form a 2n polar nucleus; the three cells away from the egg form antipodals, and the two cells closest to the egg become the synergids.
7.26.258	The mature embryo sac contains one egg cell, two synergids or “helper” cells, three antipodal cells, and two polar nuclei in a central cell.
7.26.259	When a pollen grain reaches the stigma, a pollen tube extends from the grain, grows down the style, and enters through the micropyle: an opening in the integuments of the ovule.
7.26.260	The two sperm cells are deposited in the embryo sac.
7.26.261	A double fertilization event then occurs.
7.26.262	One sperm and the egg combine, forming a diploid zygote—the future embryo.
7.26.263	The other sperm fuses with the 2n polar nuclei, forming a triploid cell that will develop into the endosperm, which is tissue that serves as a food reserve.
7.26.264	The zygote develops into an embryo with a radicle, or small root, and one (monocot) or two (dicot) leaf-like organs called cotyledons.
7.26.265	This difference in the number of embryonic leaves is the basis for the two major groups of angiosperms: the monocots and the eudicots.
7.26.266	Seed food reserves are stored outside the embryo, in the form of complex carbohydrates, lipids or proteins.
7.26.267	The cotyledons serve as conduits to transmit the broken-down food reserves from their storage site inside the seed to the developing embryo.
7.26.268	The seed consists of a toughened layer of integuments forming the coat, the endosperm with food reserves, and at the center, the well-protected embryo.
7.26.269	Most flowers are monoecious or bisexual, which means that they carry both stamens and carpels; only a few species selfpollinate.
7.26.270	Monoecious flowers are also known as “perfect” flowers because they contain both types of sex organs (Figure 26.14).
7.26.271	Both anatomical and environmental barriers promote cross-pollination mediated by a physical agent (wind or water), or an animal, such as an insect or bird.
7.26.272	Cross-pollination increases genetic diversity in a species.
7.26.273	Diversity of Angiosperms Angiosperms are classified in a single phylum: the Anthophyta.
7.26.274	Modern angiosperms appear to be a monophyletic group, which means that they originate from a single ancestor.
7.26.275	Flowering plants are divided into two major groups, according to the structure of the cotyledons, pollen grains, and other structures.
7.26.276	Monocots include grasses and lilies, and eudicots or dicots form a polyphyletic group.
7.26.277	Basal angiosperms are a group of plants that are believed to have branched off before the separation into monocots and eudicots because they exhibit traits from both groups.
7.26.278	They are categorized separately in many classification schemes.
7.26.279	The Magnoliidae (magnolia trees, laurels, and water lilies) and the Piperaceae (peppers) belong to the basal angiosperm group.
7.26.280	Basal Angiosperms
7.26.281	The Magnoliidae are represented by the magnolias: tall trees bearing large, fragrant flowers that have many parts and are considered archaic (Figure 26.16d).
7.26.282	Laurel trees produce fragrant leaves and small, inconspicuous flowers.
7.26.283	The Laurales grow mostly in warmer climates and are small trees and shrubs.
7.26.284	Familiar plants in this group include the bay laurel, cinnamon, spice bush (Figure 26.16a), and avocado tree.
7.26.285	The Nymphaeales are comprised of the water lilies, lotus (Figure 26.16c), and similar plants; all species thrive in freshwater biomes, and have leaves that float on the water surface or grow underwater.
7.26.286	Water lilies are particularly prized by gardeners, and have graced ponds and pools for thousands of years.
7.26.287	The Piperales are a group of herbs, shrubs, and small trees that grow in the tropical climates.
7.26.288	They have small flowers without petals that are tightly arranged in long spikes.
7.26.289	Many species are the source of prized fragrance or spices, for example the berries of Piper nigrum (Figure 26.16b) are the familiar black peppercorns that are used to flavor many dishes.
7.26.290	The (a) common spicebush belongs to the Laurales, the same family as cinnamon and bay laurel.
7.26.291	The fruit of (b) the Piper nigrum plant is black pepper, the main product that was traded along spice routes.
7.26.292	Notice the small, unobtrusive, clustered flowers.
7.26.293	(c) Lotus flowers, Nelumbo nucifera, have been cultivated since ancient times for their ornamental value; the root of the lotus flower is eaten as a vegetable.
7.26.294	The red seeds of (d) a magnolia tree, characteristic of the final stage, are just starting to appear.
7.26.295	Monocots Plants in the monocot group are primarily identified as such by the presence of a single cotyledon in the seedling.
7.26.296	Other anatomical features shared by monocots include veins that run parallel to the length of the leaves, and flower parts that are arranged in a three- or six-fold symmetry.
7.26.297	True woody tissue is rarely found in monocots.
7.26.298	In palm trees, vascular and parenchyma tissues produced by the primary and secondary thickening meristems form the trunk.
7.26.299	The pollen from the first angiosperms was monosulcate, containing a single furrow or pore through the outer layer.
7.26.300	This feature is still seen in the modern monocots.
7.26.301	Vascular tissue of the stem is not arranged in any particular pattern.
7.26.302	The root system is mostly adventitious and unusually positioned, with no major tap root.
7.26.303	The monocots include familiar plants such as the true lilies (which are at the origin of their alternate name of Liliopsida), orchids, grasses, and palms.
7.26.304	Many important crops are monocots, such as rice and other cereals, corn, sugar cane, and tropical fruits like bananas and pineapples.
7.26.305	The world’s major crops are flowering plants.
7.26.306	(a) Rice, (b) wheat, and (c) bananas are monocots, while (d) cabbage, (e) beans, and (f) peaches are dicots.
7.26.307	Eudicots Eudicots, or true dicots, are characterized by the presence of two cotyledons in the developing shoot.
7.26.308	Veins form a network in leaves, and flower parts come in four, five, or many whorls.
7.26.309	Vascular tissue forms a ring in the stem; in monocots, vascular tissue is scattered in the stem.
7.26.310	Eudicots can be herbaceous (like grasses), or produce woody tissues.
7.26.311	Most eudicots produce pollen that is trisulcate or triporate, with three furrows or pores.
7.26.312	The root system is usually anchored by one main root developed from the embryonic radicle.
7.26.313	Eudicots comprise two-thirds of all flowering plants.
7.26.314	The major differences between monocots and eudicots are summarized in Table 26.1.
7.26.315	Many species exhibit characteristics that belong to either group; as such, the classification of a plant as a monocot or a eudicot is not always clearly evident.
7.26.316	Without seed plants, life as we know it would not be possible.
7.26.317	Plants play a key role in the maintenance of terrestrial ecosystems through stabilization of soils, cycling of carbon, and climate moderation.
7.26.318	Large tropical forests release oxygen and act as carbon dioxide sinks.
7.26.319	Seed plants provide shelter to many life forms, as well as food for herbivores, thereby indirectly feeding carnivores.
7.26.320	Plant secondary metabolites are used for medicinal purposes and industrial production.
7.26.321	Animals and Plants: Herbivory Coevolution of flowering plants and insects is a hypothesis that has received much attention and support, especially because both angiosperms and insects diversified at about the same time in the middle Mesozoic.
7.26.322	Many authors have attributed the diversity of plants and insects to pollination and herbivory, or consumption of plants by insects and other animals.
7.26.323	This is believed to have been as much a driving force as pollination.
7.26.324	Coevolution of herbivores and plant defenses is observed in nature.
7.26.325	Unlike animals, most plants cannot outrun predators or use mimicry to hide from hungry animals.
7.26.326	A sort of arms race exists between plants and herbivores.
7.26.327	To “combat” herbivores, some plant seeds—such as acorn and unripened persimmon—are high in alkaloids and therefore unsavory to some animals.
7.26.328	Other plants are protected by bark, although some animals developed specialized mouth pieces to tear and chew vegetal material.
7.26.329	Spines and thorns (Figure 26.18) deter most animals, except for mammals with thick fur, and some birds have specialized beaks to get past such defenses.
7.26.330	Spines and (b) thorns are examples of plant defenses.
7.26.331	Herbivory has been used by seed plants for their own benefit in a display of mutualistic relationships.
7.26.332	The dispersal of fruit by animals is the most striking example.
7.26.333	The plant offers to the herbivore a nutritious source of food in return for spreading the plant’s genetic material to a wider area.
7.26.334	An extreme example of collaboration between an animal and a plant is the case of acacia trees and ants.
7.26.335	The trees support the insects with shelter and food.
7.26.336	In return, ants discourage herbivores, both invertebrates and vertebrates, by stinging and attacking leaf-eating insects.
7.26.337	Animals and Plants:
7.26.338	Pollination Grasses are a successful group of flowering plants that are wind pollinated.
7.26.339	They produce large amounts of powdery pollen carried over large distances by the wind.
7.26.340	The flowers are small and wisp-like.
7.26.341	Large trees such as oaks, maples, and birches are also wind pollinated.
7.26.342	More than 80 percent of angiosperms depend on animals for pollination: the transfer of pollen from the anther to the stigma.
7.26.343	Consequently, plants have developed many adaptations to attract pollinators.
7.26.344	The specificity of specialized plant structures that target animals can be very surprising.
7.26.345	It is possible, for example, to determine the type of pollinator favored by a plant just from the flower’s characteristics.
7.26.346	Many bird or insect-pollinated flowers secrete nectar, which is a sugary liquid.
7.26.347	They also produce both fertile pollen, for reproduction, and sterile pollen rich in nutrients for birds and insects.
7.26.348	Butterflies and bees can detect ultraviolet light.
7.26.349	Flowers that attract these pollinators usually display a pattern of low ultraviolet reflectance that helps them quickly locate the flower's center and collect nectar while being dusted with pollen (Figure 26.19).
7.26.350	Large, red flowers with little smell and a long funnel shape are preferred by hummingbirds, who have good color perception, a poor sense of smell, and need a strong perch.
7.26.351	White flowers opened at night attract moths.
7.26.352	Other animals—such as bats, lemurs, and lizards—can also act as pollinating agents.
7.26.353	Any disruption to these interactions, such as the disappearance of bees as a consequence of colony collapse disorders, can lead to disaster for agricultural industries that depend heavily on pollinated crops.
7.26.354	As a bee collects nectar from a flower, it is dusted by pollen, which it then disperses to other flowers.
7.26.355	The Importance of Seed Plants in Human Life Seed plants are the foundation of human diets across the world (Figure 26.20).
7.26.356	Many societies eat almost exclusively vegetarian fare and depend solely on seed plants for their nutritional needs.
7.26.357	A few crops (rice, wheat, and potatoes) dominate the agricultural landscape.
7.26.358	Many crops were developed during the agricultural revolution, when human societies made the transition from nomadic hunter–gatherers to horticulture and agriculture.
7.26.359	Cereals, rich in carbohydrates, provide the staple of many human diets.
7.26.360	Beans and nuts supply proteins.
7.26.361	Fats are derived from crushed seeds, as is the case for peanut and rapeseed (canola) oils, or fruits such as olives.
7.26.362	Animal husbandry also consumes large amounts of crops.
7.26.363	Staple crops are not the only food derived from seed plants.
7.26.364	Fruits and vegetables provide nutrients, vitamins, and fiber.
7.26.365	Sugar, to sweeten dishes, is produced from the monocot sugarcane and the eudicot sugar beet.
7.26.366	Drinks are made from infusions of tea leaves, chamomile flowers, crushed coffee beans, or powdered cocoa beans.
7.26.367	Spices come from many different plant parts:
7.26.368	saffron and cloves are stamens and buds, black pepper and vanilla are seeds, the bark of a bush in the Laurales family supplies cinnamon, and the herbs that flavor many dishes come from dried leaves and fruit, such as the pungent red chili pepper.
7.26.369	The volatile oils of flowers and bark provide the scent of perfumes.
7.26.370	Additionally, no discussion of seed plant contribution to human diet would be complete without the mention of alcohol.
7.26.371	Fermentation of plant-derived sugars and starches is used to produce alcoholic beverages in all societies.
7.26.372	In some cases, the beverages are derived from the fermentation of sugars from fruit, as with wines and, in other cases, from the fermentation of carbohydrates derived from seeds, as with beers.
7.26.373	Seed plants have many other uses, including providing wood as a source of timber for construction, fuel, and material to build furniture.
7.26.374	Most paper is derived from the pulp of coniferous trees.
7.26.375	Fibers of seed plants such as cotton, flax, and hemp are woven into cloth.
7.26.376	Textile dyes, such as indigo, were mostly of plant origin until the advent of synthetic chemical dyes.
7.26.377	Lastly, it is more difficult to quantify the benefits of ornamental seed plants.
7.26.378	These grace private and public spaces, adding beauty and serenity to human lives and inspiring painters and poets alike.
7.26.379	Humans rely on plants for a variety of reasons.
7.26.380	(a) Cacao beans were introduced in Europe from the New World, where they were used by Mesoamerican civilizations.
7.26.381	Combined with sugar, another plant product, chocolate is a popular food.
7.26.382	(b) Flowers like the tulip are cultivated for their beauty.
7.26.383	(c) Quinine, extracted from cinchona trees, is used to treat malaria, to reduce fever, and to alleviate pain.
7.26.384	(d)
7.26.385	This violin is made of wood.
7.26.386	The medicinal properties of plants have been known to human societies since ancient times.
7.26.387	There are references to the use of plants’ curative properties in Egyptian, Babylonian, and Chinese writings from 5,000 years ago.
7.26.388	Many modern synthetic therapeutic drugs are derived or synthesized de novo from plant secondary metabolites.
7.26.389	It is important to note that the same plant extract can be a therapeutic remedy at low concentrations, become an addictive drug at higher doses, and can potentially kill at high concentrations.
7.26.390	Table 26.3 presents a few drugs, their plants of origin, and their medicinal applications.
7.26.391	Biodiversity of Plants Biodiversity ensures a resource for new food crops and medicines.
7.26.392	Plant life balances ecosystems, protects watersheds, mitigates erosion, moderates climate and provides shelter for many animal species.
7.26.393	Threats to plant diversity, however, come from many angles.
7.26.394	The explosion of the human population, especially in tropical countries where birth rates are highest and economic development is in full swing, is leading to human encroachment into forested areas.
7.26.395	To feed the larger population, humans need to obtain arable land, so there is massive clearing of trees.
7.26.396	The need for more energy to power larger cities and economic growth therein leads to the construction of dams, the consequent flooding of ecosystems, and increased emissions of pollutants.
7.26.397	Other threats to tropical forests come from poachers, who log trees for their precious wood.
7.26.398	Ebony and Brazilian rosewood, both on the endangered list, are examples of tree species driven almost to extinction by indiscriminate logging.
7.26.399	The number of plant species becoming extinct is increasing at an alarming rate.
7.26.400	Because ecosystems are in a delicate balance, and seed plants maintain close symbiotic relationships with animals—
7.26.401	whether predators or pollinators—the disappearance of a single plant can lead to the extinction of connected animal species.
7.26.402	A real and pressing issue is that many plant species have not yet been catalogued, and so their place in the ecosystem is unknown.
7.26.403	These unknown species are threatened by logging, habitat destruction, and loss of pollinators.
7.26.404	They may become extinct before we have the chance to begin to understand the possible impacts from their disappearance.
7.26.405	Efforts to preserve biodiversity take several lines of action, from preserving heirloom seeds to barcoding species.
7.26.406	Heirloom seeds come from plants that were traditionally grown in human populations, as opposed to the seeds used for large-scale agricultural production.
7.26.407	Barcoding is a technique in which one or more short gene sequences, taken from a well-characterized portion of the genome, are used to identify a species through DNA analysis.
7.27.0	The leaf chameleon (Brookesia micra) was discovered in northern Madagascar in 2012.
7.27.1	At just over one inch long, it is the smallest known chameleon.
7.27.2	Animal evolution began in the ocean over 600 million years ago with tiny creatures that probably do not resemble any living organism today.
7.27.3	Since then, animals have evolved into a highly diverse kingdom.
7.27.4	Although over one million extant (currently living) species of animals have been identified, scientists are continually discovering more species as they explore ecosystems around the world.
7.27.5	The number of extant species is estimated to be between 3 and 30 million.
7.27.6	But what is an animal?
7.27.7	While we can easily identify dogs, birds, fish, spiders, and worms as animals, other organisms, such as corals and sponges, are not as easy to classify.
7.27.8	Animals vary in complexity—from sea sponges to crickets to chimpanzees—and scientists are faced with the difficult task of classifying them within a unified system.
7.27.9	They must identify traits that are common to all animals as well as traits that can be used to distinguish among related groups of animals.
7.27.10	The animal classification system characterizes animals based on their anatomy, morphology, evolutionary history, features of embryological development, and genetic makeup.
7.27.11	This classification scheme is constantly developing as new information about species arises.
7.27.12	Understanding and classifying the great variety of living species help us better understand how to conserve the diversity of life on earth.
7.27.13	Even though members of the animal kingdom are incredibly diverse, most animals share certain features that distinguish them from organisms in other kingdoms.
7.27.14	All animals are eukaryotic, multicellular organisms, and almost all animals have a complex tissue structure with differentiated and specialized tissues.
7.27.15	Most animals are motile, at least during certain life stages.
7.27.16	All animals require a source of food and are therefore heterotrophic, ingesting other living or dead organisms; this feature distinguishes them from autotrophic organisms, such as most plants, which synthesize their own nutrients through photosynthesis.
7.27.17	As heterotrophs, animals may be carnivores, herbivores, omnivores, or parasites (Figure 27.2ab).
7.27.18	Most animals reproduce sexually, and the offspring pass through a series of developmental stages that establish a determined and fixed body plan.
7.27.19	The body plan refers to the morphology of an animal, determined by developmental cues.
7.27.20	All animals are heterotrophs that derive energy from food.
7.27.21	The (a) black bear is an omnivore, eating both plants and animals.
7.27.22	The (b) heartworm
7.27.23	Dirofilaria immitis is a parasite that derives energy from its hosts.
7.27.24	It spends its larval stage in mosquitoes and its adult stage infesting the heart of dogs and other mammals, as shown here.
7.27.25	Complex Tissue Structure
7.27.26	As multicellular organisms, animals differ from plants and fungi because their cells don’t have cell walls, their cells may be embedded in an extracellular matrix (such as bone, skin, or connective tissue), and their cells have unique structures for intercellular communication (such as gap junctions).
7.27.27	In addition, animals possess unique tissues, absent in fungi and plants, which allow coordination (nerve tissue) of motility (muscle tissue).
7.27.28	Animals are also characterized by specialized connective tissues that provide structural support for cells and organs.
7.27.29	This connective tissue constitutes the extracellular surroundings of cells and is made up of organic and inorganic materials.
7.27.30	In vertebrates, bone tissue is a type of connective tissue that supports the entire body structure.
7.27.31	The complex bodies and activities of vertebrates demand such supportive tissues.
7.27.32	Epithelial tissues cover, line, protect, and secrete.
7.27.33	Epithelial tissues include the epidermis of the integument, the lining of the digestive tract and trachea, and make up the ducts of the liver and glands of advanced animals.
7.27.34	The animal kingdom is divided into Parazoa (sponges) and Eumetazoa (all other animals).
7.27.35	As very simple animals, the organisms in group Parazoa (“beside animal”) do not contain true specialized tissues; although they do possess specialized cells that perform different functions, those cells are not organized into tissues.
7.27.36	These organisms are considered animals since they lack the ability to make their own food.
7.27.37	Animals with true tissues are in the group Eumetazoa (“true animals”).
7.27.38	When we think of animals, we usually think of Eumetazoans, since most animals fall into this category.
7.27.39	The different types of tissues in true animals are responsible for carrying out specific functions for the organism.
7.27.40	This differentiation and specialization of tissues is part of what allows for such incredible animal diversity.
7.27.41	For example, the evolution of nerve tissues and muscle tissues has resulted in animals’ unique ability to rapidly sense and respond to changes in their environment.
7.27.42	This allows animals to survive in environments where they must compete with other species to meet their nutritional demands.
7.27.43	Animal Reproduction and Development
7.27.44	Most animals are diploid organisms, meaning that their body (somatic) cells are diploid and haploid reproductive (gamete) cells are produced through meiosis.
7.27.45	Some exceptions exist: For example, in bees, wasps, and ants, the male is haploid because it develops from unfertilized eggs.
7.27.46	Most animals undergo sexual reproduction: This fact distinguishes animals from fungi, protists, and bacteria, where asexual reproduction is common or exclusive.
7.27.47	However, a few groups, such as cnidarians, flatworm, and roundworms, undergo asexual reproduction, although nearly all of those animals also have a sexual phase to their life cycle.
7.27.48	Processes of Animal Reproduction and Embryonic Development During sexual reproduction, the haploid gametes of the male and female individuals of a species combine in a process called fertilization.
7.27.49	Typically, the small, motile male sperm fertilizes the much larger, sessile female egg.
7.27.50	This process produces a diploid fertilized egg called a zygote.
7.27.51	Some animal species—including sea stars and sea anemones, as well as some insects, reptiles, and fish—are capable of asexual reproduction.
7.27.52	The most common forms of asexual reproduction for stationary aquatic animals include budding and fragmentation, where part of a parent individual can separate and grow into a new individual.
7.27.53	In contrast, a form of asexual reproduction found in certain insects and vertebrates is called parthenogenesis (or “virgin beginning”), where unfertilized eggs can develop into new male offspring.
7.27.54	This type of parthenogenesis is called haplodiploidy.
7.27.55	These types of asexual reproduction produce genetically identical offspring, which is disadvantageous from the perspective of evolutionary adaptability because of the potential buildup of deleterious mutations.
7.27.56	However, for animals that are limited in their capacity to attract mates, asexual reproduction can ensure genetic propagation.
7.27.57	After fertilization, a series of developmental stages occur during which primary germ layers are established and reorganize to form an embryo.
7.27.58	During this process, animal tissues begin to specialize and organize into organs and organ systems, determining their future morphology and physiology.
7.27.59	Some animals, such as grasshoppers, undergo incomplete metamorphosis, in which the young resemble the adult.
7.27.60	Other animals, such as some insects, undergo complete metamorphosis where individuals enter one or more larval stages that may in differ in structure and function from the adult (Figure 27.3).
7.27.61	For the latter, the young and the adult may have different diets, limiting competition for food between them.
7.27.62	Regardless of whether a species undergoes complete or incomplete metamorphosis, the series of developmental stages of the embryo remains largely the same for most members of the animal kingdom.
7.27.63	The grasshopper undergoes incomplete metamorphosis.
7.27.64	(b)
7.27.65	The butterfly undergoes complete metamorphosis.
7.27.66	The process of animal development begins with the cleavage, or series of mitotic cell divisions, of the zygote (Figure 27.4).
7.27.67	Three cell divisions transform the single-celled zygote into an eight-celled structure.
7.27.68	After further cell division and rearrangement of existing cells, a 6–32-celled hollow structure called a blastula is formed.
7.27.69	Next, the blastula undergoes further cell division and cellular rearrangement during a process called gastrulation.
7.27.70	This leads to the formation of the next developmental stage, the gastrula, in which the future digestive cavity is formed.
7.27.71	Different cell layers (called germ layers) are formed during gastrulation.
7.27.72	These germ layers are programmed to develop into certain tissue types, organs, and organ systems during a process called organogenesis.
7.27.73	During embryonic development, the zygote undergoes a series of mitotic cell divisions, or cleavages, to form an eight-cell stage, then a hollow blastula.
7.27.74	During a process called gastrulation, the blastula folds inward to form a cavity in the gastrula.
7.27.75	The Role of Homeobox (Hox) Genes in Animal Development Since the early 19th century, scientists have observed that many animals, from the very simple to the complex, shared similar embryonic morphology and development.
7.27.76	Surprisingly, a human embryo and a frog embryo, at a certain stage of embryonic development, look remarkably alike.
7.27.77	For a long time, scientists did not understand why so many animal species looked similar during embryonic development but were very different as adults.
7.27.78	They wondered what dictated the developmental direction that a fly, mouse, frog, or human embryo would take.
7.27.79	Near the end of the 20th century, a particular class of genes was discovered that had this very job.
7.27.80	These genes that determine animal structure are called “homeotic genes,” and they contain DNA sequences called homeoboxes.
7.27.81	The animal genes containing homeobox sequences are specifically referred to as Hox genes.
7.27.82	This family of genes is responsible for determining the general body plan, such as the number of body segments of an animal, the number and placement of appendages, and animal head-tail directionality.
7.27.83	The first Hox genes to be sequenced were those from the fruit fly (Drosophila melanogaster).
7.27.84	A single Hox mutation in the fruit fly can result in an extra pair of wings or even appendages growing from the “wrong” body part.
7.27.85	While there are a great many genes that play roles in the morphological development of an animal, what makes Hox genes so powerful is that they serve as master control genes that can turn on or off large numbers of other genes.
7.27.86	Hox genes do this by coding transcription factors that control the expression of numerous other genes.
7.27.87	Hox genes are homologous in the animal kingdom, that is, the genetic sequences of Hox genes and their positions on chromosomes are remarkably similar across most animals because of their presence in a common ancestor, from worms to flies, mice, and humans (Figure 27.5).
7.27.88	One of the contributions to increased animal body complexity is that Hox genes have undergone at least two duplication events during animal evolution, with the additional genes allowing for more complex body types to evolve.
7.27.89	Scientists have developed a classification scheme that categorizes all members of the animal kingdom, although there are exceptions to most “rules” governing animal classification (Figure 27.6).
7.27.90	Animals are primarily classified according to morphological and developmental characteristics, such as a body plan.
7.27.91	One of the most prominent features of the body plan of true animals is that they are morphologically symmetrical.
7.27.92	This means that their distribution of body parts is balanced along an axis.
7.27.93	Additional characteristics include the number of tissue layers formed during development, the presence or absence of an internal body cavity, and other features of embryological development, such as the origin of the mouth and anus.
7.27.94	Animal Characterization Based on Body Symmetry
7.27.95	At a very basic level of classification, true animals can be largely divided into three groups based on the type of symmetry of their body plan: radially symmetrical, bilaterally symmetrical, and asymmetrical.
7.27.96	Asymmetry is a unique feature of Parazoa (Figure 27.7a).
7.27.97	Only a few animal groups display radial symmetry.
7.27.98	All types of symmetry are well suited to meet the unique demands of a particular animal’s lifestyle.
7.27.99	Radial symmetry is the arrangement of body parts around a central axis, as is seen in a drinking glass or pie.
7.27.100	It results in animals having top and bottom surfaces but no left and right sides, or front or back.
7.27.101	The two halves of a radially symmetrical animal may be described as the side with a mouth or “oral side,” and the side without a mouth (the “aboral side”).
7.27.102	This form of symmetry marks the body plans of animals in the phyla Ctenophora and Cnidaria, including jellyfish and adult sea anemones (Figure 27.7bc).
7.27.103	Radial symmetry equips these sea creatures (which may be sedentary or only capable of slow movement or floating) to experience the environment equally from all directions.
7.27.104	The (a) sponge is asymmetrical.
7.27.105	The (b) jellyfish and (c) anemone are radially symmetrical, and the (d) butterfly is bilaterally symmetrical.
7.27.106	Bilateral symmetry involves the division of the animal through a sagittal plane, resulting in two mirror image, right and left halves, such as those of a butterfly (Figure 27.7d), crab, or human body.
7.27.107	Animals with bilateral symmetry have a “head” and “tail”
7.27.108	(anterior vs. posterior), front and back
7.27.109	(dorsal vs. ventral), and right and left sides (Figure 27.8).
7.27.110	All true animals except those with radial symmetry are bilaterally symmetrical.
7.27.111	The evolution of bilateral symmetry that allowed for the formation of anterior and posterior (head and tail) ends promoted a phenomenon called cephalization, which refers to the collection of an organized nervous system at the animal’s anterior end.
7.27.112	In contrast to radial symmetry, which is best suited for stationary or limited-motion lifestyles, bilateral symmetry allows for streamlined and directional motion.
7.27.113	In evolutionary terms, this simple form of symmetry promoted active mobility and increased sophistication of resource-seeking and predator-prey relationships.
7.27.114	The bilaterally symmetrical human body can be divided into planes.
7.27.115	Animals in the phylum Echinodermata (such as sea stars, sand dollars, and sea urchins) display radial symmetry as adults, but their larval stages exhibit bilateral symmetry.
7.27.116	This is termed secondary radial symmetry.
7.27.117	They are believed to have evolved from bilaterally symmetrical animals; thus, they are classified as bilaterally symmetrical.
7.27.118	Animal Characterization Based on Features of Embryological Development
7.27.119	Most animal species undergo a separation of tissues into germ layers during embryonic development.
7.27.120	Recall that these germ layers are formed during gastrulation, and that they are predetermined to develop into the animal’s specialized tissues and organs.
7.27.121	Animals develop either two or three embryonic germs layers (Figure 27.9).
7.27.122	The animals that display radial symmetry develop two germ layers, an inner layer (endoderm) and an outer layer (ectoderm).
7.27.123	These animals are called diploblasts.
7.27.124	Diploblasts have a non-living layer between the endoderm and ectoderm.
7.27.125	More complex animals (those with bilateral symmetry) develop three tissue layers: an inner layer (endoderm), an outer layer (ectoderm), and a middle layer (mesoderm).
7.27.126	Animals with three tissue layers are called triploblasts.
7.27.127	Each of the three germ layers is programmed to give rise to particular body tissues and organs.
7.27.128	The endoderm gives rise to the lining of the digestive tract (including the stomach, intestines, liver, and pancreas), as well as to the lining of the trachea, bronchi, and lungs of the respiratory tract, along with a few other structures.
7.27.129	The ectoderm develops into the outer epithelial covering of the body surface, the central nervous system, and a few other structures.
7.27.130	The mesoderm is the third germ layer; it forms between the endoderm and ectoderm in triploblasts.
7.27.131	This germ layer gives rise to all muscle tissues (including the cardiac tissues and muscles of the intestines), connective tissues such as the skeleton and blood cells, and most other visceral organs such as the kidneys and the spleen.
7.27.132	Presence or Absence of a Coelom Further subdivision of animals with three germ layers (triploblasts) results in the separation of animals that may develop an internal body cavity derived from mesoderm, called a coelom, and those that do not.
7.27.133	This epithelial cell-lined coelomic cavity represents a space, usually filled with fluid, which lies between the visceral organs and the body wall.
7.27.134	It houses many organs such as the digestive system, kidneys, reproductive organs, and heart, and contains the circulatory system.
7.27.135	In some animals, such as mammals, the part of the coelom called the pleural cavity provides space for the lungs to expand during breathing.
7.27.136	The evolution of the coelom is associated with many functional advantages.
7.27.137	Primarily, the coelom provides cushioning and shock absorption for the major organ systems.
7.27.138	Organs housed within the coelom can grow and move freely, which promotes optimal organ development and placement.
7.27.139	The coelom also provides space for the diffusion of gases and nutrients, as well as body flexibility, promoting improved animal motility.
7.27.140	Triploblasts that do not develop a coelom are called acoelomates, and their mesoderm region is completely filled with tissue, although they do still have a gut cavity.
7.27.141	Examples of acoelomates include animals in the phylum Platyhelminthes, also known as flatworms.
7.27.142	Animals with a true coelom are called eucoelomates (or coelomates)
7.27.143	(Figure 27.10).
7.27.144	A true coelom arises entirely within the mesoderm germ layer and is lined by an epithelial membrane.
7.27.145	This membrane also lines the organs within the coelom, connecting and holding them in position while allowing them some free motion.
7.27.146	Annelids, mollusks, arthropods, echinoderms, and chordates are all eucoelomates.
7.27.147	A third group of triploblasts has a slightly different coelom derived partly from mesoderm and partly from endoderm, which is found between the two layers.
7.27.148	Although still functional, these are considered false coeloms, and those animals are called pseudocoelomates.
7.27.149	The phylum Nematoda (roundworms) is an example of a pseudocoelomate.
7.27.150	True coelomates can be further characterized based on certain features of their early embryological development.
7.27.151	Triploblasts may be (a) acoelomates, (b) eucoelomates, or (c) pseudocoelomates.
7.27.152	Acoelomates have no body cavity.
7.27.153	Eucoelomates have a body cavity within the mesoderm, called a coelom, which is lined with mesoderm.
7.27.154	Pseudocoelomates also have a body cavity, but it is sandwiched between the endoderm and mesoderm.
7.27.155	Embryonic Development of the Mouth Bilaterally symmetrical, tribloblastic eucoelomates can be further divided into two groups based on differences in their early embryonic development.
7.27.156	Protostomes include arthropods, mollusks, and annelids.
7.27.157	Deuterostomes include more complex animals such as chordates but also some simple animals such as echinoderms.
7.27.158	These two groups are separated based on which opening of the digestive cavity develops first: mouth or anus.
7.27.159	The word protostome comes from the Greek word meaning “mouth first,” and deuterostome originates from the word meaning “mouth second” (in this case, the anus develops first).
7.27.160	The mouth or anus develops from a structure called the blastopore (Figure 27.11).
7.27.161	The blastopore is the indentation formed during the initial stages of gastrulation.
7.27.162	In later stages, a second opening forms, and these two openings will eventually give rise to the mouth and anus (Figure 27.11).
7.27.163	It has long been believed that the blastopore develops into the mouth of protostomes, with the second opening developing into the anus; the opposite is true for deuterostomes.
7.27.164	Recent evidence has challenged this view of the development of the blastopore of protostomes, however, and the theory remains under debate.
7.27.165	Another distinction between protostomes and deuterostomes is the method of coelom formation, beginning from the gastrula stage.
7.27.166	The coelom of most protostomes is formed through a process called schizocoely, meaning that during development, a solid mass of the mesoderm splits apart and forms the hollow opening of the coelom.
7.27.167	Deuterostomes differ in that their coelom forms through a process called enterocoely.
7.27.168	Here, the mesoderm develops as pouches that are pinched off from the endoderm tissue.
7.27.169	These pouches eventually fuse to form the mesoderm, which then gives rise to the coelom.
7.27.170	The earliest distinction between protostomes and deuterostomes is the type of cleavage undergone by the zygote.
7.27.171	Protostomes undergo spiral cleavage, meaning that the cells of one pole of the embryo are rotated, and thus misaligned, with respect to the cells of the opposite pole.
7.27.172	This is due to the oblique angle of the cleavage.
7.27.173	Deuterostomes undergo radial cleavage, where the cleavage axes are either parallel or perpendicular to the polar axis, resulting in the alignment of the cells between the two poles.
7.27.174	Eucoelomates can be divided into two groups based on their early embryonic development.
7.27.175	In protostomes, part of the mesoderm separates to form the coelom in a process called schizocoely.
7.27.176	In deuterostomes, the mesoderm pinches off to form the coelom in a process called enterocoely.
7.27.177	It was long believed that the blastopore developed into the mouth in protostomes and into the anus in deuterostomes, but recent evidence challenges this belief.
7.27.178	There is a second distinction between the types of cleavage in protostomes and deuterostomes.
7.27.179	In addition to spiral cleavage, protostomes also undergo determinate cleavage.
7.27.180	This means that even at this early stage, the developmental fate of each embryonic cell is already determined.
7.27.181	A cell does not have the ability to develop into any cell type.
7.27.182	In contrast, deuterostomes undergo indeterminate cleavage, in which cells are not yet pre-determined at this early stage to develop into specific cell types.
7.27.183	These cells are referred to as undifferentiated cells.
7.27.184	This characteristic of deuterostomes is reflected in the existence of familiar embryonic stem cells, which have the ability to develop into any cell type until their fate is programmed at a later developmental stage.
7.27.185	Biologists strive to understand the evolutionary history and relationships of members of the animal kingdom, and all of life, for that matter.
7.27.186	The study of phylogeny aims to determine the evolutionary relationships between phyla.
7.27.187	Currently, most biologists divide the animal kingdom into 35 to 40 phyla.
7.27.188	Scientists develop phylogenetic trees, which serve as hypotheses about which species have evolved from which ancestors Recall that until recently, only morphological characteristics and the fossil record were used to determine phylogenetic relationships among animals.
7.27.189	Scientific understanding of the distinctions and hierarchies between anatomical characteristics provided much of this knowledge.
7.27.190	Used alone, however, this information can be misleading.
7.27.191	Morphological characteristics may evolve multiple times, and independently, through evolutionary history.
7.27.192	Analogous characteristics may appear similar between animals, but their underlying evolution may be very different.
7.27.193	With the advancement of molecular technologies, modern phylogenetics is now informed by genetic and molecular analyses, in addition to traditional morphological and fossil data.
7.27.194	With a growing understanding of genetics, the animal evolutionary tree has changed substantially and continues to change as new DNA and RNA analyses are performed on additional animal species.
7.27.195	Constructing an Animal Phylogenetic Tree
7.27.196	The current understanding of evolutionary relationships between animal, or Metazoa, phyla begins with the distinction between “true” animals with true differentiated tissues, called Eumetazoa, and animal phyla that do not have true differentiated tissues (such as the sponges), called Parazoa.
7.27.197	Both Parazoa and Eumetazoa evolved from a common ancestral organism that resembles the modern-day protists called choanoflagellates.
7.27.198	These protist cells strongly resemble the sponge choanocyte cells today.
7.27.199	Cells of the protist choanoflagellate resemble sponge choanocyte cells.
7.27.200	Beating of choanocyte flagella draws water through the sponge so that nutrients can be extracted and waste removed.
7.27.201	Eumetazoa are subdivided into radially symmetrical animals and bilaterally symmetrical animals, and are thus classified into clade Bilateria or Radiata, respectively.
7.27.202	As mentioned earlier, the cnidarians and ctenophores are animal phyla with true radial symmetry.
7.27.203	All other Eumetazoa are members of the Bilateria clade.
7.27.204	The bilaterally symmetrical animals are further divided into deuterostomes (including chordates and echinoderms) and two distinct clades of protostomes (including ecdysozoans and lophotrochozoans) (Figure 27.13ab).
7.27.205	Ecdysozoa includes nematodes and arthropods; they are so named for a commonly found characteristic among the group: exoskeletal molting (termed ecdysis).
7.27.206	Lophotrochozoa is named for two structural features, each common to certain phyla within the clade.
7.27.207	Some lophotrochozoan phyla are characterized by a larval stage called trochophore larvae, and other phyla are characterized by the presence of a feeding structure called a lophophore.
7.27.208	Animals that molt their exoskeletons, such as these (a) Madagascar hissing cockroaches, are in the clade Ecdysozoa.
7.27.209	(b) Phoronids are in the clade Lophotrochozoa.
7.27.210	The tentacles are part of a feeding structure called a lophophore.
7.27.211	Modern Advances in Phylogenetic Understanding Come from Molecular Analyses
7.27.212	The phylogenetic groupings are continually being debated and refined by evolutionary biologists.
7.27.213	Each year, new evidence emerges that further alters the relationships described by a phylogenetic tree diagram.
7.27.214	Nucleic acid and protein analyses have greatly informed the modern phylogenetic animal tree.
7.27.215	These data come from a variety of molecular sources, such as mitochondrial DNA, nuclear DNA, ribosomal RNA (rRNA), and certain cellular proteins.
7.27.216	Many evolutionary relationships in the modern tree have only recently been determined due to molecular evidence.
7.27.217	For example, a previously classified group of animals called lophophorates, which included brachiopods and bryozoans, were long-thought to be primitive deuterostomes.
7.27.218	Extensive molecular analysis using rRNA data found these animals to be protostomes, more closely related to annelids and mollusks.
7.27.219	This discovery allowed for the distinction of the protostome clade, the lophotrochozoans.
7.27.220	Molecular data have also shed light on some differences within the lophotrochozoan group, and some scientists believe that the phyla Platyhelminthes and Rotifera within this group should actually belong to their own group of protostomes termed Platyzoa.
7.27.221	Molecular research similar to the discoveries that brought about the distinction of the lophotrochozoan clade has also revealed a dramatic rearrangement of the relationships between mollusks, annelids, arthropods, and nematodes, and a new ecdysozoan clade was formed.
7.27.222	Due to morphological similarities in their segmented body types, annelids and arthropods were once thought to be closely related.
7.27.223	However, molecular evidence has revealed that arthropods are actually more closely related to nematodes, now comprising the ecdysozoan clade, and annelids are more closely related to mollusks, brachiopods, and other phyla in the lophotrochozoan clade.
7.27.224	These two clades now make up the protostomes.
7.27.225	Another change to former phylogenetic groupings because of molecular analyses includes the emergence of an entirely new phylum of worm called Acoelomorpha.
7.27.226	These acoel flatworms were long thought to belong to the phylum Platyhelminthes because of their similar “flatworm” morphology.
7.27.227	However, molecular analyses revealed this to be a false relationship and originally suggested that acoels represented living species of some of the earliest divergent bilaterians.
