7.27.228	More recent research into the acoelomorphs has called this hypothesis into question and suggested a closer relationship with deuterostomes.
7.27.229	The placement of this new phylum remains disputed, but scientists agree that with sufficient molecular data, their true phylogeny will be determined.
7.27.230	Many questions regarding the origins and evolutionary history of the animal kingdom continue to be researched and debated, as new fossil and molecular evidence change prevailing theories.
7.27.231	Some of these questions include the following: How long have animals existed on Earth?
7.27.232	What were the earliest members of the animal kingdom, and what organism was their common ancestor?
7.27.233	While animal diversity increased during the Cambrian period of the Paleozoic era, 530 million years ago, modern fossil evidence suggests that primitive animal species existed much earlier.
7.27.234	Pre-Cambrian Animal Life
7.27.235	The time before the Cambrian period is known as the Ediacaran period (from about 635 million years ago to 543 million years ago), the final period of the late Proterozoic Neoproterozoic Era (Figure 27.14).
7.27.236	It is believed that early animal life, termed Ediacaran biota, evolved from protists at this time.
7.27.237	Some protest species called choanoflagellates closely resemble the choanocyte cells in the simplest animals, sponges.
7.27.238	In addition to their morphological similarity, molecular analyses have revealed similar sequence homologies in their DNA.
7.27.239	Earth’s history is divided into eons, eras, and periods.
7.27.240	Note that the Ediacaran period starts in the Proterozoic eon and ends in the Cambrian period of the Phanerozoic eon.
7.27.241	(b) Stages on the geological time scale are represented as a spiral.
7.27.242	The earliest life comprising Ediacaran biota was long believed to include only tiny, sessile, soft-bodied sea creatures.
7.27.243	However, recently there has been increasing scientific evidence suggesting that more varied and complex animal species lived during this time, and possibly even before the Ediacaran period.
7.27.244	Fossils believed to represent the oldest animals with hard body parts were recently discovered in South Australia.
7.27.245	These sponge-like fossils, named Coronacollina acula, date back as far as 560 million years, and are believed to show the existence of hard body parts and spicules that extended 20–40 cm from the main body (estimated about 5 cm long).
7.27.246	Other fossils from the Ediacaran period are shown in Figure 27.15ab.
7.27.247	Fossils of (a) Cyclomedusa and (b) Dickinsonia date to 650 million years ago, during the Ediacaran period.
7.27.248	Another recent fossil discovery may represent the earliest animal species ever found.
7.27.249	While the validity of this claim is still under investigation, these primitive fossils appear to be small, one-centimeter long, sponge-like creatures.
7.27.250	These fossils from South Australia date back 650 million years, actually placing the putative animal before the great ice age extinction event that marked the transition between the Cryogenian period and the Ediacaran period.
7.27.251	Until this discovery, most scientists believed that there was no animal life prior to the Ediacaran period.
7.27.252	Many scientists now believe that animals may in fact have evolved during the Cryogenian period.
7.27.253	The Cambrian Explosion of Animal Life
7.27.254	The Cambrian period, occurring between approximately 542–488 million years ago, marks the most rapid evolution of new animal phyla and animal diversity in Earth’s history.
7.27.255	It is believed that most of the animal phyla in existence today had their origins during this time, often referred to as the Cambrian explosion (Figure 27.16).
7.27.256	Echinoderms, mollusks, worms, arthropods, and chordates arose during this period.
7.27.257	One of the most dominant species during the Cambrian period was the trilobite, an arthropod that was among the first animals to exhibit a sense of vision
7.27.258	(Figure 27.17abcd).
7.27.259	An artist’s rendition depicts some organisms from the Cambrian period.
7.27.260	These fossils (a–d) belong to trilobites, extinct arthropods that appeared in the early Cambrian period, 525 million years ago, and disappeared from the fossil record during a mass extinction at the end of the Permian period, about 250 million years ago.
7.27.261	The cause of the Cambrian explosion is still debated.
7.27.262	There are many theories that attempt to answer this question.
7.27.263	Environmental changes may have created a more suitable environment for animal life.
7.27.264	Examples of these changes include rising atmospheric oxygen levels and large increases in oceanic calcium concentrations that preceded the Cambrian period.
7.27.265	Some scientists believe that an expansive, continental shelf with numerous shallow lagoons or pools provided the necessary living space for larger numbers of different types of animals to co-exist.
7.27.266	There is also support for theories that argue that ecological relationships between species, such as changes in the food web, competition for food and space, and predator-prey relationships, were primed to promote a sudden massive coevolution of species.
7.27.267	Yet other theories claim genetic and developmental reasons for the Cambrian explosion.
7.27.268	The morphological flexibility and complexity of animal development afforded by the evolution of Hox control genes may have provided the necessary opportunities for increases in possible animal morphologies at the time of the Cambrian period.
7.27.269	Theories that attempt to explain why the Cambrian explosion happened must be able to provide valid reasons for the massive animal diversification, as well as explain why it happened when it did.
7.27.270	There is evidence that both supports and refutes each of the theories described above, and the answer may very well be a combination of these and other theories.
7.27.271	The oxygen concentration in Earth’s atmosphere rose sharply around 300 million years ago.
7.27.272	However, unresolved questions about the animal diversification that took place during the Cambrian period remain.
7.27.273	For example, we do not understand how the evolution of so many species occurred in such a short period of time.
7.27.274	Was there really an “explosion” of life at this particular time?
7.27.275	Some scientists question the validity of the this idea, because there is increasing evidence to suggest that more animal life existed prior to the Cambrian period and that other similar species’ so-called explosions (or radiations) occurred later in history as well.
7.27.276	Furthermore, the vast diversification of animal species that appears to have begun during the Cambrian period continued well into the following Ordovician period.
7.27.277	Despite some of these arguments, most scientists agree that the Cambrian period marked a time of impressively rapid animal evolution and diversification that is unmatched elsewhere during history.
7.27.278	Post-Cambrian Evolution and Mass Extinctions
7.27.279	The periods that followed the Cambrian during the Paleozoic Era are marked by further animal evolution and the emergence of many new orders, families, and species.
7.27.280	As animal phyla continued to diversify, new species adapted to new ecological niches.
7.27.281	During the Ordovician period, which followed the Cambrian period, plant life first appeared on land.
7.27.282	This change allowed formerly aquatic animal species to invade land, feeding directly on plants or decaying vegetation.
7.27.283	Continual changes in temperature and moisture throughout the remainder of the Paleozoic Era due to continental plate movements encouraged the development of new adaptations to terrestrial existence in animals, such as limbed appendages in amphibians and epidermal scales in reptiles.
7.27.284	Changes in the environment often create new niches (living spaces) that contribute to rapid speciation and increased diversity.
7.27.285	On the other hand, cataclysmic events, such as volcanic eruptions and meteor strikes that obliterate life, can result in devastating losses of diversity.
7.27.286	Such periods of mass extinction (Figure 27.19) have occurred repeatedly in the evolutionary record of life, erasing some genetic lines while creating room for others to evolve into the empty niches left behind.
7.27.287	The end of the Permian period (and the Paleozoic Era) was marked by the largest mass extinction event in Earth’s history, a loss of roughly 95 percent of the extant species at that time.
7.27.288	Some of the dominant phyla in the world’s oceans, such as the trilobites, disappeared completely.
7.27.289	On land, the disappearance of some dominant species of Permian reptiles made it possible for a new line of reptiles to emerge, the dinosaurs.
7.27.290	The warm and stable climatic conditions of the ensuing Mesozoic Era promoted an explosive diversification of dinosaurs into every conceivable niche in land, air, and water.
7.27.291	Plants, too, radiated into new landscapes and empty niches, creating complex communities of producers and consumers, some of which became very large on the abundant food available.
7.27.292	Another mass extinction event occurred at the end of the Cretaceous period, bringing the Mesozoic Era to an end.
7.27.293	Skies darkened and temperatures fell as a large meteor impact and tons of volcanic ash blocked incoming sunlight.
7.27.294	Plants died, herbivores and carnivores starved, and the mostly cold-blooded dinosaurs ceded their dominance of the landscape to more warm-blooded mammals.
7.27.295	In the following Cenozoic Era, mammals radiated into terrestrial and aquatic niches once occupied by dinosaurs, and birds, the warm-blooded offshoots of one line of the ruling reptiles, became aerial specialists.
7.27.296	The appearance and dominance of flowering plants in the Cenozoic Era created new niches for insects, as well as for birds and mammals.
7.27.297	Changes in animal species diversity during the late Cretaceous and early Cenozoic were also promoted by a dramatic shift in Earth’s geography, as continental plates slid over the crust into their current positions, leaving some animal groups isolated on islands and continents, or separated by mountain ranges or inland seas from other competitors.
7.27.298	Early in the Cenozoic, new ecosystems appeared, with the evolution of grasses and coral reefs.
7.27.299	Late in the Cenozoic, further extinctions followed by speciation occurred during ice ages that covered high latitudes with ice and then retreated, leaving new open spaces for colonization.
7.28.0	A brief look at any magazine pertaining to our natural world, such as National Geographic, would show a rich variety of vertebrates, especially mammals and birds.
7.28.1	To most people, these are the animals that attract our attention.
7.28.2	Concentrating on vertebrates, however, gives us a rather biased and limited view of biodiversity, because it ignores nearly 97 percent of the animal kingdom, namely the invertebrates.
7.28.3	Invertebrate animals are those without a cranium and defined vertebral column or spine.
7.28.4	In addition to lacking a spine, most invertebrates also lack an endoskeleton.
7.28.5	A large number of invertebrates are aquatic animals, and scientific research suggests that many of the world’s species are aquatic invertebrates that have not yet been documented.
7.28.6	The invertebrates, or invertebrata, are animals that do not contain bony structures, such as the cranium and vertebrae.
7.28.7	The simplest of all the invertebrates are the Parazoans, which include only the phylum Porifera: the sponges (Figure 28.2).
7.28.8	Parazoans (“beside animals”) do not display tissue-level organization, although they do have specialized cells that perform specific functions.
7.28.9	Sponge larvae are able to swim; however, adults are non-motile and spend their life attached to a substratum.
7.28.10	Since water is vital to sponges for excretion, feeding, and gas exchange, their body structure facilitates the movement of water through the sponge.
7.28.11	Structures such as canals, chambers, and cavities enable water to move through the sponge to nearly all body cells.
7.28.12	Sponges are members of the Phylum Porifera, which contains the simplest invertebrates.
7.28.13	Morphology of Sponges
7.28.14	The morphology of the simplest sponges takes the shape of a cylinder with a large central cavity, the spongocoel, occupying the inside of the cylinder.
7.28.15	Water can enter into the spongocoel from numerous pores in the body wall.
7.28.16	Water entering the spongocoel is extruded via a large common opening called the osculum.
7.28.17	However, sponges exhibit a range of diversity in body forms, including variations in the size of the spongocoel, the number of osculi, and where the cells that filter food from the water are located.
7.28.18	While sponges (excluding the hexactinellids) do not exhibit tissue-layer organization, they do have different cell types that perform distinct functions.
7.28.19	Pinacocytes, which are epithelial-like cells, form the outermost layer of sponges and enclose a jelly-like substance called mesohyl.
7.28.20	Mesohyl is an extracellular matrix consisting of a collagen-like gel with suspended cells that perform various functions.
7.28.21	The gel-like consistency of mesohyl acts like an endoskeleton and maintains the tubular morphology of sponges.
7.28.22	In addition to the osculum, sponges have multiple pores called ostia on their bodies that allow water to enter the sponge.
7.28.23	In some sponges, ostia are formed by porocytes, single tube-shaped cells that act as valves to regulate the flow of water into the spongocoel.
7.28.24	In other sponges, ostia are formed by folds in the body wall of the sponge.
7.28.25	Choanocytes (“collar cells”) are present at various locations, depending on the type of sponge, but they always line the inner portions of some space through which water flows (the spongocoel in simple sponges, canals within the body wall in more complex sponges, and chambers scattered throughout the body in the most complex sponges).
7.28.26	Whereas pinacocytes line the outside of the sponge, choanocytes tend to line certain inner portions of the sponge body that surround the mesohyl.
7.28.27	The structure of a choanocyte is critical to its function, which is to generate a water current through the sponge and to trap and ingest food particles by phagocytosis.
7.28.28	Note the similarity in appearance between the sponge choanocyte and choanoflagellates (Protista).
7.28.29	This similarity suggests that sponges and choanoflagellates are closely related and likely share a recent common ancestry.
7.28.30	The cell body is embedded in mesohyl and contains all organelles required for normal cell function, but protruding into the “open space” inside of the sponge is a mesh-like collar composed of microvilli with a single flagellum in the center of the column.
7.28.31	The cumulative effect of the flagella from all choanocytes aids the movement of water through the sponge: drawing water into the sponge through the numerous ostia, into the spaces lined by choanocytes, and eventually out through the osculum (or osculi).
7.28.32	In the meantime, food particles, including waterborne bacteria and algae, are trapped by the sieve-like collar of the choanocytes, slide down into the body of the cell, are ingested by phagocytosis, and become encased in a food vacuole.
7.28.33	Lastly, choanocytes will differentiate into sperm for sexual reproduction, where they will become dislodged from the mesohyl and leave the sponge with expelled water through the osculum.
7.28.34	The second crucial cells in sponges are called amoebocytes (or archaeocytes), named for the fact that they move throughout the mesohyl in an amoeba-like fashion.
7.28.35	Amoebocytes have a variety of functions: delivering nutrients from choanocytes to other cells within the sponge, giving rise to eggs for sexual reproduction (which remain in the mesohyl), delivering phagocytized sperm from choanocytes to eggs, and differentiating into more-specific cell types.
7.28.36	Some of these morespecific cell types include collencytes and lophocytes, which produce the collagen-like protein to maintain the mesohyl, sclerocytes, which produce spicules in some sponges, and spongocytes, which produce the protein spongin in the majority of sponges.
7.28.37	These cells produce collagen to maintain the consistency of the mesohyl.
7.28.38	The different cell types in sponges are shown in Figure 28.3.
7.28.39	In some sponges, sclerocytes secrete small spicules into the mesohyl, which are composed of either calcium carbonate or silica, depending on the type of sponge.
7.28.40	These spicules serve to provide additional stiffness to the body of the sponge.
7.28.41	The presence and composition of spicules/spongin are the differentiating characteristics of the three classes of sponges (Figure 28.4): Class Calcarea contains calcium carbonate spicules and no spongin, class Hexactinellida contains six-rayed siliceous spicules and no spongin, and class Demospongia contains spongin and may or may not have spicules; if present, those spicules are siliceous.
7.28.42	Spicules are most conspicuously present in class Hexactinellida, the order consisting of glass sponges.
7.28.43	Some of the spicules may attain giant proportions (in relation to the typical size range of glass sponges of 3 to 10 mm) as seen in Monorhaphis chuni, which grows up to 3 m long.
7.28.44	Clathrina clathrus belongs to class Calcarea, (b) Staurocalyptus spp.
7.28.45	(common name: yellow Picasso sponge) belongs to class Hexactinellida, and (c) Acarnus erithacus belongs to class Demospongia.
7.28.46	Physiological Processes in Sponges Sponges, despite being simple organisms, regulate their different physiological processes through a variety of mechanisms.
7.28.47	These processes regulate their metabolism, reproduction, and locomotion.
7.28.48	Digestion Sponges lack complex digestive, respiratory, circulatory, reproductive, and nervous systems.
7.28.49	Their food is trapped when water passes through the ostia and out through the osculum.
7.28.50	Bacteria smaller than 0.5 microns in size are trapped by choanocytes, which are the principal cells engaged in nutrition, and are ingested by phagocytosis.
7.28.51	Particles that are larger than the ostia may be phagocytized by pinacocytes.
7.28.52	In some sponges, amoebocytes transport food from cells that have ingested food particles to those that do not.
7.28.53	For this type of digestion, in which food particles are digested within individual cells, the sponge draws water through diffusion.
7.28.54	The limit of this type of digestion is that food particles must be smaller than individual cells.
7.28.55	All other major body functions in the sponge (gas exchange, circulation, excretion) are performed by diffusion between the cells that line the openings within the sponge and the water that is passing through those openings.
7.28.56	All cell types within the sponge obtain oxygen from water through diffusion.
7.28.57	Likewise, carbon dioxide is released into seawater by diffusion.
7.28.58	In addition, nitrogenous waste produced as a byproduct of protein metabolism is excreted via diffusion by individual cells into the water as it passes through the sponge.
7.28.59	Reproduction Sponges reproduce by sexual as well as asexual methods.
7.28.60	The typical means of asexual reproduction is either fragmentation (where a piece of the sponge breaks off, settles on a new substrate, and develops into a new individual) or budding (a genetically identical outgrowth grows from the parent and eventually detaches or remains attached to form a colony).
7.28.61	An atypical type of asexual reproduction is found only in freshwater sponges and occurs through the formation of gemmules.
7.28.62	Gemmules are environmentally resistant structures produced by adult sponges wherein the typical sponge morphology is inverted.
7.28.63	In gemmules, an inner layer of amoebocytes is surrounded by a layer of collagen (spongin) that may be reinforced by spicules.
7.28.64	The collagen that is normally found in the mesohyl becomes the outer protective layer.
7.28.65	In freshwater sponges, gemmules may survive hostile environmental conditions like changes in temperature and serve to recolonize the habitat once environmental conditions stabilize.
7.28.66	Gemmules are capable of attaching to a substratum and generating a new sponge.
7.28.67	Since gemmules can withstand harsh environments, are resistant to desiccation, and remain dormant for long periods, they are an excellent means of colonization for a sessile organism.
7.28.68	Sexual reproduction in sponges occurs when gametes are generated.
7.28.69	Sponges are monoecious (hermaphroditic), which means that one individual can produce both gametes (eggs and sperm) simultaneously.
7.28.70	In some sponges, production of gametes may occur throughout the year, whereas other sponges may show sexual cycles depending upon water temperature.
7.28.71	Sponges may also become sequentially hermaphroditic, producing oocytes first and spermatozoa later.
7.28.72	Oocytes arise by the differentiation of amoebocytes and are retained within the spongocoel, whereas spermatozoa result from the differentiation of choanocytes and are ejected via the osculum.
7.28.73	Ejection of spermatozoa may be a timed and coordinated event, as seen in certain species.
7.28.74	Spermatozoa carried along by water currents can fertilize the oocytes borne in the mesohyl of other sponges.
7.28.75	Early larval development occurs within the sponge, and free-swimming larvae are then released via the osculum.
7.28.76	Locomotion Sponges are generally sessile as adults and spend their lives attached to a fixed substratum.
7.28.77	They do not show movement over large distances like other free-swimming marine invertebrates.
7.28.78	However, sponge cells are capable of creeping along substrata via organizational plasticity.
7.28.79	Under experimental conditions, researchers have shown that sponge cells spread on a physical support demonstrate a leading edge for directed movement.
7.28.80	It has been speculated that this localized creeping movement may help sponges adjust to microenvironments near the point of attachment.
7.28.81	It must be noted, however, that this pattern of movement has been documented in laboratories, but it remains to be observed in natural sponge habitats.
7.28.82	Phylum Cnidaria includes animals that show radial or biradial symmetry and are diploblastic, that is, they develop from two embryonic layers.
7.28.83	Nearly all (about 99 percent) cnidarians are marine species.
7.28.84	Cnidarians contain specialized cells known as cnidocytes (“stinging cells”) containing organelles called nematocysts (stingers).
7.28.85	These cells are present around the mouth and tentacles, and serve to immobilize prey with toxins contained within the cells.
7.28.86	Nematocysts contain coiled threads that may bear barbs.
7.28.87	The outer wall of the cell has hairlike projections called cnidocils, which are sensitive to touch.
7.28.88	When touched, the cells are known to fire coiled threads that can either penetrate the flesh of the prey or predators of cnidarians (see Figure 28.5) or ensnare it.
7.28.89	These coiled threads release toxins into the target and can often immobilize prey or scare away predators.
7.28.90	Animals from the phylum Cnidaria have stinging cells called cnidocytes.
7.28.91	Cnidocytes contain large organelles called (a) nematocysts that store a coiled thread and barb.
7.28.92	When hairlike projections on the cell surface are touched, (b) the thread, barb, and a toxin are fired from the organelle.
7.28.93	Animals in this phylum display two distinct morphological body plans: polyp or “stalk” and medusa or “bell
7.28.94	” (Figure 28.6).
7.28.95	An example of the polyp form is Hydra spp.; perhaps the most well-known medusoid animals are the jellies (jellyfish).
7.28.96	Polyp forms are sessile as adults, with a single opening to the digestive system (the mouth) facing up with tentacles surrounding it.
7.28.97	Medusa forms are motile, with the mouth and tentacles hanging down from an umbrella-shaped bell.
7.28.98	Cnidarians have two distinct body plans, the medusa (a) and the polyp (b).
7.28.99	All cnidarians have two membrane layers, with a jelly-like mesoglea between them.
7.28.100	Some cnidarians are polymorphic, that is, they have two body plans during their life cycle.
7.28.101	An example is the colonial hydroid called an Obelia.
7.28.102	The sessile polyp form has, in fact, two types of polyps, shown in Figure 28.7.
7.28.103	The first is the gastrozooid, which is adapted for capturing prey and feeding; the other type of polyp is the gonozooid, adapted for the asexual budding of medusa.
7.28.104	When the reproductive buds mature, they break off and become free-swimming medusa, which are either male or female (dioecious).
7.28.105	The male medusa makes sperm, whereas the female medusa makes eggs.
7.28.106	After fertilization, the zygote develops into a blastula, which develops into a planula larva.
7.28.107	The larva is free swimming for a while, but eventually attaches and a new colonial reproductive polyp is formed.
7.28.108	The sessile form of Obelia geniculate has two types of polyps: gastrozooids, which are adapted for capturing prey, and gonozooids, which bud to produce medusae asexually.
7.28.109	All cnidarians show the presence of two membrane layers in the body that are derived from the endoderm and ectoderm of the embryo.
7.28.110	The outer layer (from ectoderm) is called the epidermis and lines the outside of the animal, whereas the inner layer (from endoderm) is called the gastrodermis and lines the digestive cavity.
7.28.111	Between these two membrane layers is a non-living, jelly-like mesoglea connective layer.
7.28.112	In terms of cellular complexity, cnidarians show the presence of differentiated cell types in each tissue layer, such as nerve cells, contractile epithelial cells, enzyme-secreting cells, and nutrient-absorbing cells, as well as the presence of intercellular connections.
7.28.113	However, the development of organs or organ systems is not advanced in this phylum.
7.28.114	The nervous system is primitive, with nerve cells scattered across the body.
7.28.115	This nerve net may show the presence of groups of cells in the form of nerve plexi (singular plexus) or nerve cords.
7.28.116	The nerve cells show mixed characteristics of motor as well as sensory neurons.
7.28.117	The predominant signaling molecules in these primitive nervous systems are chemical peptides, which perform both excitatory and inhibitory functions.
7.28.118	Despite the simplicity of the nervous system, it coordinates the movement of tentacles, the drawing of captured prey to the mouth, the digestion of food, and the expulsion of waste.
7.28.119	The cnidarians perform extracellular digestion in which the food is taken into the gastrovascular cavity, enzymes are secreted into the cavity, and the cells lining the cavity absorb nutrients.
7.28.120	The gastrovascular cavity has only one opening that serves as both a mouth and an anus, which is termed an incomplete digestive system.
7.28.121	Cnidarian cells exchange oxygen and carbon dioxide by diffusion between cells in the epidermis with water in the environment, and between cells in the gastrodermis with water in the gastrovascular cavity.
7.28.122	The lack of a circulatory system to move dissolved gases limits the thickness of the body wall and necessitates a non-living mesoglea between the layers.
7.28.123	There is no excretory system or organs, and nitrogenous wastes simply diffuse from the cells into the water outside the animal or in the gastrovascular cavity.
7.28.124	There is also no circulatory system, so nutrients must move from the cells that absorb them in the lining of the gastrovascular cavity through the mesoglea to other cells.
7.28.125	The phylum Cnidaria contains about 10,000 described species divided into four classes:
7.28.126	Anthozoa, Scyphozoa, Cubozoa, and Hydrozoa.
7.28.127	The anthozoans, the sea anemones and corals, are all sessile species, whereas the scyphozoans (jellyfish) and cubozoans (box jellies) are swimming forms.
7.28.128	The hydrozoans contain sessile forms and swimming colonial forms like the Portuguese Man O’ War.
7.28.129	Class Anthozoa
7.28.130	The class Anthozoa includes all cnidarians that exhibit a polyp body plan only; in other words, there is no medusa stage within their life cycle.
7.28.131	Examples include sea anemones (Figure 28.8), sea pens, and corals, with an estimated number of 6,100 described species.
7.28.132	Sea anemones are usually brightly colored and can attain a size of 1.8 to 10 cm in diameter.
7.28.133	These animals are usually cylindrical in shape and are attached to a substrate.
7.28.134	A mouth opening is surrounded by tentacles bearing cnidocytes.
7.28.135	The sea anemone is shown (a) photographed and (b) in a diagram illustrating its morphology.
7.28.136	A jelly is shown (a) photographed and (b) in a diagram illustrating its morphology.
7.28.137	In the jellyfish, a mouth opening is present on the underside of the animal, surrounded by tentacles bearing nematocysts.
7.28.138	Scyphozoans live most of their life cycle as free-swimming, solitary carnivores.
7.28.139	The mouth leads to the gastrovascular cavity, which may be sectioned into four interconnected sacs, called diverticuli.
7.28.140	In some species, the digestive system may be further branched into radial canals.
7.28.141	Like the septa in anthozoans, the branched gastrovascular cells serve two functions: to increase the surface area for nutrient absorption and diffusion; thus, more cells are in direct contact with the nutrients in the gastrovascular cavity.
7.28.142	In scyphozoans, nerve cells are scattered all over the body.
7.28.143	Neurons may even be present in clusters called rhopalia.
7.28.144	These animals possess a ring of muscles lining the dome of the body, which provides the contractile force required to swim through water.
7.28.145	Scyphozoans are dioecious animals, that is, the sexes are separate.
7.28.146	The gonads are formed from the gastrodermis and gametes are expelled through the mouth.
7.28.147	Planula larvae are formed by external fertilization; they settle on a substratum in a polypoid form known as scyphistoma.
7.28.148	These forms may produce additional polyps by budding or may transform into the medusoid form.
7.28.149	The life cycle (Figure 28.10) of these animals can be described as polymorphic, because they exhibit both a medusal and polypoid body plan at some point in their life cycle.
7.28.150	The lifecycle of a jellyfish includes two stages: the medusa stage and the polyp stage.
7.28.151	The polyp reproduces asexually by budding, and the medusa reproduces sexually.
7.28.152	Class Cubozoa
7.28.153	This class includes jellies that have a box-shaped medusa, or a bell that is square in cross-section; hence, are colloquially known as “box jellyfish.
7.28.154	”
7.28.155	These species may achieve sizes of 15–25 cm.
7.28.156	Cubozoans display overall morphological and anatomical characteristics that are similar to those of the scyphozoans.
7.28.157	A prominent difference between the two classes is the arrangement of tentacles.
7.28.158	This is the most venomous group of all the cnidarians (Figure 28.11).
7.28.159	The cubozoans contain muscular pads called pedalia at the corners of the square bell canopy, with one or more tentacles attached to each pedalium.
7.28.160	These animals are further classified into orders based on the presence of single or multiple tentacles per pedalium.
7.28.161	In some cases, the digestive system may extend into the pedalia.
7.28.162	Nematocysts may be arranged in a spiral configuration along the tentacles; this arrangement helps to effectively subdue and capture prey.
7.28.163	Cubozoans exist in a polypoid form that develops from a planula larva.
7.28.164	These polyps show limited mobility along the substratum and, like scyphozoans, may bud to form more polyps to colonize a habitat.
7.28.165	Polyp forms then transform into the medusoid forms.
7.28.166	The (a) tiny cubazoan jelly
7.28.167	Malo kingi is thimble shaped and, like all cubozoan jellies, (b) has four muscular pedalia to which the tentacles attach.
7.28.168	M. kingi is one of two species of jellies known to cause Irukandji syndrome, a condition characterized by excruciating muscle pain, vomiting, increased heart rate, and psychological symptoms.
7.28.169	Two people in Australia, where Irukandji jellies are most commonly found, are believed to have died from Irukandji stings.
7.28.170	(c) A sign on a beach in northern Australia warns swimmers of the danger.
7.28.171	Class Hydrozoa Hydrozoa includes nearly 3,200 species; most are marine, although some freshwater species are known (Figure 28.12).
7.28.172	Animals in this class are polymorphs, and most exhibit both polypoid and medusoid forms in their lifecycle, although this is variable.
7.28.173	The polyp form in these animals often shows a cylindrical morphology with a central gastrovascular cavity lined by the gastrodermis.
7.28.174	The gastrodermis and epidermis have a simple layer of mesoglea sandwiched between them.
7.28.175	A mouth opening, surrounded by tentacles, is present at the oral end of the animal.
7.28.176	Many hydrozoans form colonies that are composed of a branched colony of specialized polyps that share a gastrovascular cavity, such as in the colonial hydroid Obelia.
7.28.177	Colonies may also be free-floating and contain medusoid and polypoid individuals in the colony as in Physalia (the Portuguese Man O’War) or Velella (By-the-wind sailor).
7.28.178	Even other species are solitary polyps (Hydra) or solitary medusae (Gonionemus).
7.28.179	The true characteristic shared by all of these diverse species is that their gonads for sexual reproduction are derived from epidermal tissue, whereas in all other cnidarians they are derived from gastrodermal tissue.
7.28.180	Obelia, (b)
7.28.181	Physalia physalis, known as the Portuguese Man O‘ War, (c) Velella bae, and (d)
7.28.182	Hydra have different body shapes but all belong to the family Hydrozoa.
7.28.183	Animals belonging to superphylum Lophotrochozoa are protostomes, in which the blastopore, or the point of involution of the ectoderm or outer germ layer, becomes the mouth opening to the alimentary canal.
7.28.184	This is called protostomy or “first mouth.
7.28.185	”
7.28.186	In protostomy, solid groups of cells split from the endoderm or inner germ layer to form a central mesodermal layer of cells.
7.28.187	This layer multiplies into a band and then splits internally to form the coelom; this protostomic coelom is hence termed schizocoelom.
7.28.188	As lophotrochozoans, the organisms in this superphylum possess either a lophophore or trochophore larvae.
7.28.189	The lophophores include groups that are united by the presence of the lophophore, a set of ciliated tentacles surrounding the mouth.
7.28.190	Lophophorata include the flatworms and several other phyla.
7.28.191	These clades are upheld when RNA sequences are compared.
7.28.192	Trochophore larvae are characterized by two bands of cilia around the body.
7.28.193	The lophotrochozoans are triploblastic and possess an embryonic mesoderm sandwiched between the ectoderm and endoderm found in the diploblastic cnidarians.
7.28.194	These phyla are also bilaterally symmetrical, meaning that a longitudinal section will divide them into right and left sides that are symmetrical.
7.28.195	It also means the beginning of cephalization, the evolution of a concentration of nervous tissues and sensory organs in the head of the organism, which is where it first encounters its environment.
7.28.196	Phylum Platyhelminthes
7.28.197	The flatworms are acoelomate organisms that include many free-living and parasitic forms.
7.28.198	Most of the flatworms are classified in the superphylum Lophotrochozoa, which also includes the mollusks and annelids.
7.28.199	The Platyhelminthes consist of two lineages: the Catenulida and the Rhabditophora.
7.28.200	The Catenulida, or "chain worms" is a small clade of just over 100 species.
7.28.201	These worms typically reproduce asexually by budding.
7.28.202	However, the offspring do not fully attach from the parents and, resemble a chain in appearance.
7.28.203	All of the remaining flatworms discussed here are part of the Rhabditophora.
7.28.204	Many flatworms are parasitic, including important parasites of humans.
7.28.205	Flatworms have three embryonic tissue layers that give rise to surfaces that cover tissues (from ectoderm), internal tissues (from mesoderm), and line the digestive system (from endoderm).
7.28.206	The epidermal tissue is a single layer cells or a layer of fused cells (syncytium) that covers a layer of circular muscle above a layer of longitudinal muscle.
7.28.207	The mesodermal tissues include mesenchymal cells that contain collagen and support secretory cells that secrete mucus and other materials at the surface.
7.28.208	The flatworms are acoelomates, so their bodies are solid between the outer surface and the cavity of the digestive system.
7.28.209	Physiological Processes of Flatworms
7.28.210	The free-living species of flatworms are predators or scavengers.
7.28.211	Parasitic forms feed on the tissues of their hosts.
7.28.212	Most flatworms, such as the planarian shown in Figure 28.13, have a gastrovascular cavity rather than a complete digestive system.
7.28.213	In such animals, the “mouth” is also used to expel waste materials from the digestive system.
7.28.214	Some species also have an anal opening.
7.28.215	The gut may be a simple sac or highly branched.
7.28.216	Digestion is extracellular, with digested materials taken in to the cells of the gut lining by phagocytosis.
7.28.217	One group, the cestodes, lacks a digestive system.
7.28.218	Flatworms have an excretory system with a network of tubules throughout the body with openings to the environment and nearby flame cells, whose cilia beat to direct waste fluids concentrated in the tubules out of the body.
7.28.219	The system is responsible for the regulation of dissolved salts and the excretion of nitrogenous wastes.
7.28.220	The nervous system consists of a pair of nerve cords running the length of the body with connections between them and a large ganglion or concentration of nerves at the anterior end of the worm, where there may also be a concentration of photosensory and chemosensory cells.
7.28.221	There is neither a circulatory nor respiratory system, with gas and nutrient exchange dependent on diffusion and cell-cell junctions.
7.28.222	This necessarily limits the thickness of the body in these organisms, constraining them to be “flat” worms.
7.28.223	Most flatworm species are monoecious, and fertilization is typically internal.
7.28.224	Asexual reproduction is common in some groups.
7.28.225	The planarian is a flatworm that has a gastrovascular cavity with one opening that serves as both mouth and anus.
7.28.226	The excretory system is made up of tubules connected to excretory pores on both sides of the body.
7.28.227	The nervous system is composed of two interconnected nerve cords running the length of the body, with cerebral ganglia and eyespots at the anterior end.
7.28.228	Diversity of Flatworms Platyhelminthes are traditionally divided into four classes: Turbellaria, Monogenea, Trematoda, and Cestoda (Figure 28.14).
7.28.229	As discussed above, the relationships among members of these classes is being reassessed, with the turbellarians in particular now viewed as a paraphyletic group, a group that does not have a single common ancestor.
7.28.230	Phylum Platyhelminthes is divided into four classes.
7.28.231	(a) Class Turbellaria includes the Bedford’s flatworm (Pseudobiceros bedfordi), which is about 8–10 cm in length.
7.28.232	(b)
7.28.233	The parasitic class Monogenea includes Dactylogyrus spp.
7.28.234	Dactylogyrus, commonly called a gill fluke, is about 0.2 mm in length and has two anchors, indicated by arrows, that it uses to latch onto the gills of host fish.
7.28.235	(c)
7.28.236	The Trematoda class includes Fascioloides magna (right) and Fasciaola hepatica (two specimens of left, also known as the common liver fluke).
7.28.237	(d)
7.28.238	Class Cestoda includes tapeworms such as this Taenia saginata.
7.28.239	T. saginata, which infects both cattle and humans, can reach 4–10 meters in length; the specimen shown here is about 4 meters.
7.28.240	The class Turbellaria includes mainly free-living, marine species, although some species live in freshwater or moist terrestrial environments.
7.28.241	The ventral epidermis of turbellarians is ciliated and facilitates their locomotion.
7.28.242	Some turbellarians are capable of remarkable feats of regeneration in which they may regrow the body, even from a small fragment.
7.28.243	The monogeneans are ectoparasites, mostly of fish, with simple lifecycles that consist of a free-swimming larva that attaches to a fish to begin transformation to the parasitic adult form.
7.28.244	The parasite has only one host and that host is usually only one species.
7.28.245	The worms may produce enzymes that digest the host tissues or simply graze on surface mucus and skin particles.
7.28.246	Most monogeneans are hermaphroditic, but the male gametes develop first and so cross-fertilization is quite common.
7.28.247	The trematodes, or flukes, are internal parasites of mollusks and many other groups, including humans.
7.28.248	Trematodes have complex lifecycles that involve a primary host in which sexual reproduction occurs, and one or more secondary hosts in which asexual reproduction occurs.
7.28.249	The primary host is almost always a mollusk.
7.28.250	Trematodes are responsible for serious human diseases including schistosomiasis, a blood fluke.
7.28.251	The disease infects an estimated 200 million people in the tropics, leading to organ damage and chronic symptoms like fatigue.
7.28.252	Infection occurs when the human enters the water and a larva, released from the primary snail host, locates and penetrates the skin.
7.28.253	The parasite infects various organs in the body and feeds on red blood cells before reproducing.
7.28.254	Many of the eggs are released in feces and find their way into a waterway, where they are able to reinfect the primary snail host.
7.28.255	The cestodes, or tapeworms, are also internal parasites, mainly of vertebrates (Figure 28.15).
7.28.256	Tapeworms live in the intestinal tract of the primary host and remain fixed using a sucker on the anterior end, or scolex, of the tapeworm body.
7.28.257	The remaining body of the tapeworm is made up of a long series of units called proglottids, each of which may contain an excretory system with flame cells, but contain reproductive structures, both male and female.
7.28.258	Tapeworms do not possess a digestive system; instead, they absorb nutrients from the food matter passing them in the host’s intestine.
7.28.259	Proglottids are produced at the scolex and gradually migrate to the end of the tapeworm; at this point, they are “mature” and all structures except fertilized eggs have degenerated.
7.28.260	Most reproduction occurs by cross-fertilization.
7.28.261	The proglottid detaches from the body of the worm and is released into the feces of the organism.
7.28.262	The eggs are eaten by an intermediate host.
7.28.263	The juvenile worm infects the intermediate host and takes up residence, usually in muscle tissue.
7.28.264	When the muscle tissue is eaten by the primary host, the cycle is completed.
7.28.265	There are several tapeworm parasites of humans that are transmitted by eating uncooked or poorly cooked pork, beef, and fish.
7.28.266	Tapeworm (Taenia spp.)
7.28.267	infections occur when humans consume raw or undercooked infected meat.
7.28.268	Phylum Rotifera
7.28.269	The rotifers are a microscopic (about 100 μm to 30 mm) group of mostly aquatic organisms that get their name from the corona, a rotating, wheel-like structure that is covered with cilia at their anterior end (Figure 28.16).
7.28.270	Although their taxonomy is currently in flux, one treatment places the rotifers in three classes: Bdelloidea, Monogononta, and Seisonidea.
7.28.271	The classification of the group is currently under revision, however, as more phylogenetic evidence becomes available.
7.28.272	It is possible that the “spiny headed worms” currently in phylum Acanthocephala will be incorporated into this group in the future.
7.28.273	The body form of rotifers consists of a head (which contains the corona), a trunk (which contains the organs), and the foot.
7.28.274	Rotifers are typically free-swimming and truly planktonic organisms, but the toes or extensions of the foot can secrete a sticky material forming a holdfast to help them adhere to surfaces.
7.28.275	The head contains sensory organs in the form of a bilobed brain and small eyespots near the corona.
7.28.276	Shown are examples from two of the three classes of rotifer.
7.28.277	(a) Species from the class Bdelloidea are characterized by a large corona, shown separately from the whole animals in the center of this scanning electron micrograph.
7.28.278	(b) Polyarthra, from the class Monogononta, has a smaller corona than Bdelloid rotifers, and a single gonad, which give the class its name.
7.28.279	The rotifers are filter feeders that will eat dead material, algae, and other microscopic living organisms, and are therefore very important components of aquatic food webs.
7.28.280	Rotifers obtain food that is directed toward the mouth by the current created from the movement of the corona.
7.28.281	The food particles enter the mouth and travel to the mastax (pharynx with jawlike structures).
7.28.282	Food then passes by digestive and salivary glands, and into the stomach, then onto the intestines.
7.28.283	Digestive and excretory wastes are collected in a cloacal bladder before being released out the anus.
7.28.284	Rotifers are pseudocoelomates commonly found in fresh water and some salt water environments throughout the world.
7.28.285	Figure 28.17 shows the anatomy of a rotifer belonging to class Bdelloidea.
7.28.286	About 2,200 species of rotifers have been identified.
7.28.287	Rotifers are dioecious organisms (having either male or female genitalia) and exhibit sexual dimorphism (males and females have different forms).
7.28.288	Many species are parthenogenic and exhibit haplodiploidy, a method of gender determination in which a fertilized egg develops into a female and an unfertilized egg develops into a male.
7.28.289	In many dioecious species, males are short-lived and smaller with no digestive system and a single testis.
7.28.290	Females can produce eggs that are capable of dormancy for protection during harsh environmental conditions.
7.28.291	This illustration shows the anatomy of a bdelloid rotifer.
7.28.292	Phylum Nemertea
7.28.293	The Nemertea are colloquially known as ribbon worms.
7.28.294	Most species of phylum Nemertea are marine, predominantly benthic or bottom dwellers, with an estimated 900 species known.
7.28.295	However, nemertini have been recorded in freshwater and terrestrial habitats as well.
7.28.296	Most nemerteans are carnivores, feeding on worms, clams, and crustaceans.
7.28.297	Some species are scavengers, and some nemertini species, like Malacobdella grossa, have also evolved commensalistic relationships with some mollusks.
7.28.298	Some species have devastated commercial fishing of clams and crabs.
7.28.299	Nemerteans have almost no predators and two species are sold as fish bait.
7.28.300	Morphology Ribbon worms vary in size from 1 cm to several meters.
7.28.301	They show bilateral symmetry and remarkable contractile properties.
7.28.302	Because of their contractility, they can change their morphological presentation in response to environmental cues.
7.28.303	Animals in phylum
7.28.304	Nemertea show a flattened morphology, that is, they are flat from front to back, like a flattened tube.
7.28.305	Nemertea are soft and unsegmented animals.
7.28.306	The proboscis worm (Parborlasia corrugatus) is a scavenger that combs the sea floor for food.
7.28.307	The species is a member of the phylum Nemertea.
7.28.308	The specimen shown here was photographed in the Ross Sea, Antarctica.
7.28.309	A unique characteristic of this phylum is the presence of a proboscis enclosed in a rhynchocoel.
7.28.310	The proboscis serves to capture food and may be ornamented with barbs in some species.
7.28.311	The rhynchocoel is a fluid-filled cavity that extends from the head to nearly two-thirds of the length of the gut in these animals (Figure 28.19).
7.28.312	The proboscis may be extended or retracted by the retractor muscle attached to the wall of the rhynchocoel.
7.28.313	Digestive System
7.28.314	The nemertini show a very well-developed digestive system.
7.28.315	A mouth opening that is ventral to the rhynchocoel leads into the foregut, followed by the intestine.
7.28.316	The intestine is present in the form of diverticular pouches and ends in a rectum that opens via an anus.
7.28.317	Gonads are interspersed with the intestinal diverticular pouches and open outwards via genital pores.
7.28.318	A circulatory system consists of a closed loop of a pair of lateral blood vessels.
7.28.319	The circulatory system is derived from the coelomic cavity of the embryo.
7.28.320	Some animals may also have cross-connecting vessels in addition to lateral ones.
7.28.321	Although these are called blood vessels, since they are of coelomic origin, the circulatory fluid is colorless.
7.28.322	Some species bear hemoglobin as well as other yellow or green pigments.
7.28.323	The blood vessels are connected to the rhynchocoel.
7.28.324	The flow of fluid in these vessels is facilitated by the contraction of muscles in the body wall.
7.28.325	A pair of protonephridia, or primitive kidneys, is present in these animals to facilitate osmoregulation.
7.28.326	Gaseous exchange occurs through the skin in the nemertini.
7.28.327	Nervous System Nemertini have a ganglion or “brain” situated at the anterior end between the mouth and the foregut, surrounding the digestive system as well as the rhynchocoel.
7.28.328	A ring of four nerve masses called “ganglia” composes the brain in these animals.
7.28.329	Paired longitudinal nerve cords emerge from the brain ganglia and extend to the posterior end.
7.28.330	Ocelli or eyespots are present in pairs, in multiples of two in the anterior portion of the body.
7.28.331	It is speculated that the eyespots originate from neural tissue and not from the epidermis.
7.28.332	Reproduction Animals in phylum Nemertea show sexual dimorphism, although freshwater species may be hermaphroditic.
7.28.333	Eggs and sperm are released into the water, and fertilization occurs externally.
7.28.334	The zygote then develops into a planuliform larva.
7.28.335	In some nemertine species, a pilidium larva may develop inside the young worm, from a series of imaginal discs.
7.28.336	This larval form, characteristically shaped like a deerstalker cap, devours tissues from the young worm for survival before metamorphosing into the adult-like morphology.
7.28.337	Phylum Mollusca Phylum Mollusca is the predominant phylum in marine environments.
7.28.338	It is estimated that 23 percent of all known marine species are mollusks; there are over 75,000 described species, making them the second most diverse phylum of animals.
7.28.339	The name “mollusca”
7.28.340	signifies a soft body, since the earliest descriptions of mollusks came from observations of unshelled cuttlefish.
7.28.341	Mollusks are predominantly a marine group of animals; however, they are known to inhabit freshwater as well as terrestrial habitats.
7.28.342	Mollusks display a wide range of morphologies in each class and subclass, but share a few key characteristics, including a muscular foot, a visceral mass containing internal organs, and a mantle that may or may not secrete a shell of calcium carbonate.
7.28.343	Mollusks have a muscular foot, which is used for locomotion and anchorage, and varies in shape and function, depending on the type of mollusk under study.
7.28.344	In shelled mollusks, this foot is usually the same size as the opening of the shell.
7.28.345	The foot is a retractable as well as an extendable organ.
7.28.346	The foot is the ventral-most organ, whereas the mantle is the limiting dorsal organ.
7.28.347	Mollusks are eucoelomate, but the coelomic cavity is restricted to a cavity around the heart in adult animals.
7.28.348	The mantle cavity develops independently of the coelomic cavity.
7.28.349	The visceral mass is present above the foot, in the visceral hump.
7.28.350	This includes digestive, nervous, excretory, reproductive, and respiratory systems.
7.28.351	Mollusk species that are exclusively aquatic have gills for respiration, whereas some terrestrial species have lungs for respiration.
7.28.352	Additionally, a tongue-like organ called a radula, which bears chitinous tooth-like ornamentation, is present in many species, and serves to shred or scrape food.
7.28.353	The mantle (also known as the pallium) is the dorsal epidermis in mollusks; shelled mollusks are specialized to secrete a chitinous and hard calcareous shell.
7.28.354	Most mollusks are dioecious animals and fertilization occurs externally, although this is not the case in terrestrial mollusks, such as snails and slugs, or in cephalopods.
7.28.355	In some mollusks, the zygote hatches and undergoes two larval stages— trochophore and veliger—before becoming a young adult; bivalves may exhibit a third larval stage, glochidia.
7.28.356	Classification of Phylum Mollusca Phylum Mollusca is a very diverse (85,000 species) group of mostly marine species.
7.28.357	Mollusks have a dramatic variety of form, ranging from large predatory squids and octopus, some of which show a high degree of intelligence, to grazing forms with elaborately sculpted and colored shells.
7.28.358	This phylum can be segregated into seven classes: Aplacophora, Monoplacophora, Polyplacophora, Bivalvia, Gastropoda, Cephalopoda, and Scaphopoda.
7.28.359	Class Aplacophora
7.28.360	(“bearing no plates”) includes worm-like animals primarily found in benthic marine habitats.
7.28.361	These animals lack a calcareous shell but possess aragonite spicules on their epidermis.
7.28.362	They have a rudimentary mantle cavity and lack eyes, tentacles, and nephridia (excretory organs).
7.28.363	Members of class Monoplacophora (“bearing one plate”) posses a single, cap-like shell that encloses the body.
7.28.364	The morphology of the shell and the underlying animal can vary from circular to ovate.
7.28.365	A looped digestive system, multiple pairs of excretory organs, many gills, and a pair of gonads are present in these animals.
7.28.366	The monoplacophorans were believed extinct and only known via fossil records until the discovery of Neopilina galathaea in 1952.
7.28.367	Today, scientists have identified nearly two dozen extant species.
7.28.368	Animals in the class Polyplacophora (“bearing many plates”) are commonly known as “chitons” and bear an armor-like eight-plated shell (Figure 28.21).
7.28.369	These animals have a broad, ventral foot that is adapted for suction to rocks and other substrates, and a mantle that extends beyond the shell in the form of a girdle.
7.28.370	Calcareous spines may be present on the girdle to offer protection from predators.
7.28.371	Respiration is facilitated by ctenidia (gills) that are present ventrally.
7.28.372	These animals possess a radula that is modified for scraping.
7.28.373	The nervous system is rudimentary with only buccal or “cheek” ganglia present at the anterior end.
7.28.374	Eyespots are absent in these animals.
7.28.375	A single pair of nephridia for excretion is present.
7.28.376	This chiton from the class Polyplacaphora has the eight-plated shell that is indicative of its class.
7.28.377	Class Bivalvia (“two shells”) includes clams, oysters, mussels, scallops, and geoducks.
7.28.378	Members of this class are found in marine as well as freshwater habitats.
7.28.379	As the name suggests, bivalves are enclosed in a pair of shells (valves are commonly called “shells”) that are hinged at the dorsal end by shell ligaments as well as shell teeth (Figure 28.22).
7.28.380	The overall morphology is laterally flattened, and the head region is poorly developed.
7.28.381	Eyespots and statocysts may be absent in some species.
7.28.382	Since these animals are suspension feeders, a radula is absent in this class of mollusks.
7.28.383	Respiration is facilitated by a pair of ctenidia, whereas excretion and osmoregulation are brought about by a pair of nephridia.
7.28.384	Bivalves often possess a large mantle cavity.
7.28.385	In some species, the posterior edges of the mantle may fuse to form two siphons that serve to take in and exude water.
7.28.386	These mussels, found in the intertidal zone in Cornwall, England, are bivalves.
7.28.387	One of the functions of the mantle is to secrete the shell.
7.28.388	Some bivalves like oysters and mussels possess the unique ability to secrete and deposit a calcareous nacre or “mother of pearl” around foreign particles that may enter the mantle cavity.
7.28.389	This property has been commercially exploited to produce pearls.
7.28.390	Animals in class Gastropoda
7.28.391	(“stomach foot”) include well-known mollusks like snails, slugs, conchs, sea hares, and sea butterflies.
7.28.392	Gastropoda includes shell-bearing species as well as species with a reduced shell.
7.28.393	These animals are asymmetrical and usually present a coiled shell (Figure 28.23).
7.28.394	Shells may be planospiral (like a garden hose wound up), commonly seen in garden snails, or conispiral, (like a spiral staircase), commonly seen in marine conches.
7.28.395	Snails and (b) slugs are both gastropods, but slugs lack a shell.
7.28.396	The visceral mass in the shelled species displays torsion around the perpendicular axis on the center of the foot, which is the key characteristic of this group, along with a foot that is modified for crawling (Figure 28.24).
7.28.397	Most gastropods bear a head with tentacles, eyes, and a style.
7.28.398	A complex radula is used by the digestive system and aids in the ingestion of food.
7.28.399	Eyes may be absent in some gastropods species.
7.28.400	The mantle cavity encloses the ctenidia as well as a pair of nephridia.
7.28.401	During embryonic development of gastropods, the visceral mass undergoes torsion, or counterclockwise rotation of anatomical features.
7.28.402	As a result, the anus of the adult animal is located over the head.
7.28.403	Torsion is an independent process from coiling of the shell.
7.28.404	Class Cephalopoda
7.28.405	(“head foot” animals), include octopi, squids, cuttlefish, and nautilus.
7.28.406	Cephalopods are a class of shellbearing animals as well as mollusks with a reduced shell.
7.28.407	They display vivid coloration, typically seen in squids and octopi, which is used for camouflage.
7.28.408	All animals in this class are carnivorous predators and have beak-like jaws at the anterior end.
7.28.409	All cephalopods show the presence of a very well-developed nervous system along with eyes, as well as a closed circulatory system.
7.28.410	The foot is lobed and developed into tentacles, and a funnel, which is used as their mode of locomotion.
7.28.411	Suckers are present on the tentacles in octopi and squid.
7.28.412	Ctenidia are enclosed in a large mantle cavity and are serviced by large blood vessels, each with its own heart associated with it; the mantle has siphonophores that facilitate exchange of water.
7.28.413	Locomotion in cephalopods is facilitated by ejecting a stream of water for propulsion.
7.28.414	This is called “jet” propulsion.
7.28.415	A pair of nephridia is present within the mantle cavity.
7.28.416	Sexual dimorphism is seen in this class of animals.
7.28.417	Members of a species mate, and the female then lays the eggs in a secluded and protected niche.
7.28.418	Females of some species care for the eggs for an extended period of time and may end up dying during that time period.
7.28.419	Cephalopods such as squids and octopi also produce sepia or a dark ink, which is squirted upon a predator to assist in a quick getaway.
7.28.420	Reproduction in cephalopods is different from other mollusks in that the egg hatches to produce a juvenile adult without undergoing the trochophore and veliger larval stages.
7.28.421	In the shell-bearing Nautilus spp.
7.28.422	, the spiral shell is multi-chambered.
7.28.423	These chambers are filled with gas or water to regulate buoyancy.
7.28.424	The shell structure in squids and cuttlefish is reduced and is present internally in the form of a squid pen and cuttlefish bone, respectively.
7.28.425	Examples are shown in Figure 28.26.
7.28.426	The (a) nautilus, (b) giant cuttlefish, (c) reef squid, and (d) blue-ring octopus are all members of the class Cephalopoda.
7.28.427	Members of class Scaphopoda
7.28.428	(“boat feet”) are known colloquially as “tusk shells” or “tooth shells,” as evident when examining Dentalium, one of the few remaining scaphopod genera (Figure 28.27).
7.28.429	Scaphopods are usually buried in sand with the anterior opening exposed to water.
7.28.430	These animals bear a single conical shell, which has both ends open.
7.28.431	The head is rudimentary and protrudes out of the posterior end of the shell.
7.28.432	These animals do not possess eyes, but they have a radula, as well as a foot modified into tentacles with a bulbous end, known as captaculae.
7.28.433	Captaculae serve to catch and manipulate prey.
7.28.434	Ctenidia are absent in these animals.
7.28.435	Antalis vulgaris shows the classic Dentaliidae shape that gives these animals their common name of "tusk shell.
7.28.436	" Phylum Annelida Phylum Annelida includes segmented worms.
7.28.437	These animals are found in marine, terrestrial, and freshwater habitats, but a presence of water or humidity is a critical factor for their survival, especially in terrestrial habitats.
7.28.438	The name of the phylum is derived from the Latin word annellus, which means a small ring.
7.28.439	Animals in this phylum show parasitic and commensal symbioses with other species in their habitat.
7.28.440	Approximately 16,500 species have been described in phylum Annelida.
7.28.441	The phylum includes earthworms, polychaete worms, and leeches.
7.28.442	Annelids show protostomic development in embryonic stages and are often called “segmented worms” due to their key characteristic of metamerism, or true segmentation.
7.28.443	Morphology Annelids display bilateral symmetry and are worm-like in overall morphology.
7.28.444	Annelids have a segmented body plan wherein the internal and external morphological features are repeated in each body segment.
7.28.445	Metamerism allows animals to become bigger by adding “compartments” while making their movement more efficient.
7.28.446	This metamerism is thought to arise from identical teloblast cells in the embryonic stage, which give rise to identical mesodermal structures.
7.28.447	The overall body can be divided into head, body, and pygidium (or tail).
7.28.448	The clitellum is a reproductive structure that generates mucus that aids in sperm transfer and gives rise to a cocoon within which fertilization occurs; it appears as a fused band in the anterior third of the animal.
7.28.449	The clitellum, seen here as a protruding segment with different coloration than the rest of the body, is a structure that aids in annelid reproduction.
7.28.450	Hence, they are the most advanced worms.
7.28.451	A well-developed and complete digestive system is present in earthworms (oligochaetes) with a mouth, muscular pharynx, esophagus, crop, and gizzard being present.
7.28.452	The gizzard leads to the intestine and ends in an anal opening.
7.28.453	A cross-sectional view of a body segment of an earthworm (a terrestrial type of annelid) is shown in Figure 28.29; each segment is limited by a membranous septum that divides the coelomic cavity into a series of compartments.
7.28.454	Annelids possess a closed circulatory system of dorsal and ventral blood vessels that run parallel to the alimentary canal as well as capillaries that service individual tissues.
7.28.455	In addition, these vessels are connected by transverse loops in every segment.
7.28.456	These animals lack a well-developed respiratory system, and gas exchange occurs across the moist body surface.
7.28.457	Excretion is facilitated by a pair of metanephridia (a type of primitive “kidney” that consists of a convoluted tubule and an open, ciliated funnel) that is present in every segment towards the ventral side.
7.28.458	Annelids show well-developed nervous systems with a nerve ring of fused ganglia present around the pharynx.
7.28.459	The nerve cord is ventral in position and bears enlarged nodes or ganglia in each segment.
7.28.460	This schematic drawing shows the basic anatomy of annelids in a cross-sectional view.
7.28.461	Annelids may be either monoecious with permanent gonads (as in earthworms and leeches) or dioecious with temporary or seasonal gonads that develop (as in polychaetes).
7.28.462	However, cross-fertilization is preferred in hermaphroditic animals.
7.28.463	These animals may also show simultaneous hermaphroditism and participate in simultaneous sperm exchange when they are aligned for copulation.
7.28.464	Classification of Phylum Annelida Phylum Annelida contains the class Polychaeta (the polychaetes) and the class Oligochaeta (the earthworms, leeches and their relatives).
7.28.465	Earthworms are the most abundant members of the class Oligochaeta, distinguished by the presence of the clitellum as well as few, reduced chaetae (“
7.28.466	oligo- =
7.28.467	“few”; -chaetae =
7.28.468	“hairs”).
7.28.469	The number and size of chaetae are greatly diminished in Oligochaeta compared to the polychaetes (poly=many, chaetae = hairs).
7.28.470	The many chetae of polychaetes are also arranged within fleshy, flat, paired appendages that protrude from each segment called parapodia, which may be specialized for different functions in the polychates.
7.28.471	The subclass Hirudinea includes leeches such as Hirudo medicinalis and Hemiclepsis marginata.
7.28.472	The class Oligochaeta includes the subclass Hirudinia and the subclass Brachiobdella.
7.28.473	A significant difference between leeches and other annelids is the development of suckers at the anterior and posterior ends and a lack of chaetae.
7.28.474	Additionally, the segmentation of the body wall may not correspond to the internal segmentation of the coelomic cavity.
7.28.475	This adaptation possibly helps the leeches to elongate when they ingest copious quantities of blood from host vertebrates.
7.28.476	The subclass Brachiobdella includes species like Branchiobdella balcanica sketi and Branchiobdella astaci, worms that show similarity with leeches as well as oligochaetes.
7.28.477	The (a) earthworm, (b) leech, and (c) featherduster are all annelids.
7.28.478	Superphylum Ecdysozoa
7.28.479	The superphylum Ecdysozoa contains an incredibly large number of species.
7.28.480	This is because it contains two of the most diverse animal groups: phylum Nematoda (the roundworms) and Phylum Arthropoda (the arthropods).
7.28.481	The most prominant distinguising feature of Ecdysozoans is their tough external covering called the cuticle.
7.28.482	The cuticle provides a tough, but flexible exoskeleton tht protects these animals from water loss, predators and other aspects of the external environment.
7.28.483	All members of this superphylum periodically molt, or shed their cuticle as they grow.
7.28.484	After molting, they secrete a new cuticle that will last until their next growth phase.
7.28.485	The process of molting and replacing the cuticle is called ecdysis, which is how the superphylum derived its name.
7.28.486	Phylum Nematoda
7.28.487	The Nematoda, like most other animal phyla, are triploblastic and possess an embryonic mesoderm that is sandwiched between the ectoderm and endoderm.
7.28.488	They are also bilaterally symmetrical, meaning that a longitudinal section will divide them into right and left sides that are symmetrical.
7.28.489	Furthermore, the nematodes, or roundworms, possess a pseudocoelom and consist of both free-living and parasitic forms.
7.28.490	It has been said that were all the non-nematode matter of the biosphere removed, there would remain a shadow of the former world in the form of nematodes.
7.28.491	[1]
7.28.492	The arthropods, one of the most successful taxonomic groups on the planet, are coelomate organisms characterized by a hard exoskeleton and jointed appendages.
7.28.493	Both the nematodes and arthropods belong to the superphylum Ecdysozoa that is believed to be a clade consisting of all evolutionary descendants from one common ancestor.
7.28.494	The name derives from the word ecdysis, which refers to the shedding, or molting, of the exoskeleton.
7.28.495	The phyla in this group have a hard cuticle that covers their bodies, which must be periodically shed and replaced for them to increase in size.
7.28.496	Phylum Nematoda includes more than 28,000 species with an estimated 16,000 being parasitic in nature.
7.28.497	The name Nematoda is derived from the Greek word “Nemos,” which means “thread” and includes roundworms.
7.28.498	Nematodes are present in all habitats with a large number of individuals of each species present in each.
7.28.499	The free-living nematode, Caenorhabditis elegans has been extensively used as a model system in laboratories all over the world.
7.28.500	Morphology
7.28.501	In contrast with cnidarians, nematodes show a tubular morphology and circular cross-section.
7.28.502	These animals are pseudocoelomates and show the presence of a complete digestive system with a distinct mouth and anus.
7.28.503	This is in contrast with the cnidarians, where only one opening is present (an incomplete digestive system).
7.28.504	The cuticle of Nematodes is rich in collagen and a carbohydrate-protein polymer called chitin, and forms an external “skeleton” outside the epidermis.
7.28.505	The cuticle also lines many of the organs internally, including the pharynx and rectum.
7.28.506	The epidermis can be either a single layer of cells or a syncytium, which is a multinucleated cell formed from the fusion of uninucleated cells.
7.28.507	The overall morphology of these worms is cylindrical, as seen in Figure 28.31.
7.28.508	The head is radially symmetrical.
7.28.509	A mouth opening is present at the anterior end with three or six lips as well as teeth in some species in the form of cuticle extensions.
7.28.510	Some nematodes may present other external modifications like rings, head shields, or warts.
7.28.511	Rings, however, do not reflect true internal body segmentation.
7.28.512	The mouth leads to a muscular pharynx and intestine, which leads to a rectum and anal opening at the posterior end.
7.28.513	The muscles of nematodes differ from those of most animals: They have a longitudinal layer only, which accounts for the whip-like motion of their movement.
7.28.514	Scanning electron micrograph shows (a) the soybean cyst nematode (Heterodera glycines) and a nematode egg.
7.28.515	(b)
7.28.516	A schematic representation shows the anatomy of a typical nematode.
7.28.517	Excretory System
7.28.518	In nematodes, specialized excretory systems are not well developed.
7.28.519	Nitrogenous wastes may be lost by diffusion through the entire body or into the pseudocoelom (body cavity), where they are removed by specialized cells.
7.28.520	Regulation of water and salt content of the body is achieved by renette glands, present under the pharynx in marine nematodes.
7.28.521	Nervous system
7.28.522	Most nematodes possess four longitudinal nerve cords that run along the length of the body in dorsal, ventral, and lateral positions.
7.28.523	The ventral nerve cord is better developed than the dorsal or lateral cords.
7.28.524	All nerve cords fuse at the anterior end, around the pharynx, to form head ganglia or the “brain” of the worm (which take the form of a ring around the pharynx) as well as at the posterior end to form the tail ganglia.
7.28.525	In C. elegans, the nervous system accounts for nearly one-third of the total number of cells in the animal.
7.28.526	Reproduction Nematodes employ a variety of reproductive strategies that range from monoecious to dioecious to parthenogenic, depending upon the species under consideration.
7.28.527	C. elegans is a monoecious species and shows development of ova contained in a uterus as well as sperm contained in the spermatheca.
7.28.528	The uterus has an external opening known as the vulva.
7.28.529	The female genital pore is near the middle of the body, whereas the male’s is at the tip.
7.28.530	Specialized structures at the tail of the male keep him in place while he deposits sperm with copulatory spicules.
7.28.531	Fertilization is internal, and embryonic development starts very soon after fertilization.
7.28.532	The embryo is released from the vulva during the gastrulation stage.
7.28.533	The embryonic development stage lasts for 14 hours; development then continues through four successive larval stages with ecdysis between each stage—L1, L2, L3, and L4—ultimately leading to the development of a young male or female adult worm.
7.28.534	Adverse environmental conditions like overcrowding and lack of food can result in the formation of an intermediate larval stage known as the dauer larva.
7.28.535	A number of common parasitic nematodes serve as prime examples of parasitism.
7.28.536	These animals exhibit complex lifecycles that involve multiple hosts, and they can have significant medical and veterinary impacts.
7.28.537	Humans may become infected by Dracunculus medinensis, known as guinea worms, when they drink unfiltered water containing copepods.
7.28.538	Hookworms, such as Ancyclostoma and Necator, infest the intestines and feed on the blood of mammals, especially in dogs, cats, and humans.
7.28.539	Trichina worms (Trichinella) are the causal organism of trichinosis in humans, often resulting from the consumption of undercooked pork; Trichinella can infect other mammalian hosts as well.
7.28.540	Ascaris, a large intestinal roundworm, steals nutrition from its human host and may create physical blockage of the intestines.
7.28.541	The filarial worms, such as Dirofilaria and Wuchereria, are commonly vectored by mosquitoes, which pass the infective agents among mammals through their blood-sucking activity.
7.28.542	Dirofilaria immitis, a blood-infective parasite, is the notorious dog heartworm species.
7.28.543	Wuchereria bancrofti infects the lymph nodes of humans, resulting in the non-lethal but deforming condition called elephantiasis, in which parts of the body become swelled to gigantic proportions due to obstruction of lymphatic drainage and inflammation of lymphatic tissues.
7.28.544	The guinea worm Dracunculus medinensis infects about 3.5 million people annually, mostly in Africa.
7.28.545	(a) Here, the worm is wrapped around a stick so it can be extracted.
7.28.546	(b) Infection occurs when people consume water contaminated by infected copepods, but this can easily be prevented by simple filtration systems.
7.28.547	Phylum Arthropoda
7.28.548	The name “arthropoda
7.28.549	” means “jointed legs
7.28.550	” (in the Greek, “arthros” means “
7.28.551	joint” and “podos” means “leg”); it aptly describes the enormous number of invertebrates included in this phylum.
7.28.552	Arthropoda dominate the animal kingdom with an estimated 85 percent of known species included in this phylum and many arthropods yet undocumented.
7.28.553	The principal characteristics of all the animals in this phylum are functional segmentation of the body and presence of jointed appendages.
7.28.554	Arthropods also show the presence of an exoskeleton made principally of chitin, which is a waterproof, tough polysaccharide.
7.28.555	Phylum Arthropoda is the largest phylum in the animal world, and insects form the single largest class within this phylum.
7.28.556	Arthropods are eucoelomate, protostomic organisms.
7.28.557	Phylum Arthropoda includes animals that have been successful in colonizing terrestrial, aquatic, and aerial habitats.
7.28.558	This phylum is further classified into five subphyla: Trilobitomorpha (trilobites, all extinct), Hexapoda (insects and relatives), Myriapoda (millipedes, centipedes, and relatives), Crustaceans (crabs, lobsters, crayfish, isopods, barnacles, and some zooplankton), and Chelicerata (horseshoe crabs, arachnids, scorpions, and daddy longlegs).
7.28.559	Trilobites are an extinct group of arthropods found chiefly in the pre-Cambrian Era that are probably most closely related to the Chelicerata.
7.28.560	These are identified based on fossil records.
7.28.561	Trilobites, like the one in this fossil, are an extinct group of arthropods.
7.28.562	Morphology
7.28.563	A unique feature of animals in the arthropod phylum is the presence of a segmented body and fusion of sets of segments that give rise to functional body regions called tagma.
7.28.564	Tagma may be in the form of a head, thorax, and abdomen, or a cephalothorax and abdomen, or a head and trunk.
7.28.565	A central cavity, called the hemocoel (or blood cavity), is present, and the open circulatory system is regulated by a tubular or single-chambered heart.
7.28.566	Respiratory systems vary depending on the group of arthropod: insects and myriapods use a series of tubes (tracheae) that branch through the body, open to the outside through openings called spiracles, and perform gas exchange directly between the cells and air in the tracheae, whereas aquatic crustaceans utilize gills, terrestrial chelicerates employ book lungs, and aquatic chelicerates use book gills (Figure 28.35).
7.28.567	The book lungs of arachnids (scorpions, spiders, ticks and mites) contain a vertical stack of hemocoel wall tissue that somewhat resembles the pages of a book.
7.28.568	Between each of the "pages" of tissue is an air space.
7.28.569	This allows both sides of the tissue to be in contact with the air at all times, greatly increasing the efficiency of gas exchange.
7.28.570	The gills of crustaceans are filamentous structures that exchange gases with the surrounding water.
7.28.571	Groups of arthropods also differ in the organs used for excretion, with crustaceans possessing green glands and insects using Malpighian tubules, which work in conjunction with the hindgut to reabsorb water while ridding the body of nitrogenous waste.
7.28.572	The cuticle is the covering of an arthropod.
7.28.573	It is made up of two layers: the epicuticle, which is a thin, waxy water-resistant outer layer containing no chitin, and the layer beneath it, the chitinous procuticle.
7.28.574	Chitin is a tough, flexible polysaccharide.
7.28.575	In order to grow, the arthropod must shed the exoskeleton during a process called ecdysis (“to strip off”); this is a cumbersome method of growth, and during this time, the animal is vulnerable to predation.
7.28.576	The characteristic morphology of representative animals from each subphylum is described below.
7.28.577	The book lungs of (a) arachnids are made up of alternating air pockets and hemocoel tissue shaped like a stack of books.
7.28.578	The book gills of (b) crustaceans are similar to book lungs but are external so that gas exchange can occur with the surrounding water.
