7.28.579	Subphylum Hexapoda
7.28.580	The name Hexapoda denotes the presence of six legs (three pairs) in these animals as differentiated from the number of pairs present in other arthropods.
7.28.581	Hexapods are characterized by the presence of a head, thorax, and abdomen, constituting three tagma.
7.28.582	The thorax bears the wings as well as six legs in three pairs.
7.28.583	Many of the common insects we encounter on a daily basis—including ants, cockroaches, butterflies, and flies—are examples of Hexapoda.
7.28.584	Amongst the hexapods, the insects (Figure 28.36) are the largest class in terms of species diversity as well as biomass in terrestrial habitats.
7.28.585	Typically, the head bears one pair of sensory antennae, mandibles as mouthparts, a pair of compound eyes, and some ocelli (simple eyes) along with numerous sensory hairs.
7.28.586	The thorax bears three pairs of legs (one pair per segment) and two pairs of wings, with one pair each on the second and third thoracic segments.
7.28.587	The abdomen usually has eleven segments and bears reproductive apertures.
7.28.588	Hexapoda includes insects that are winged (like fruit flies) and wingless (like fleas).
7.28.589	Subphylum Myriapoda Subphylum Myriapoda includes arthropods with numerous legs.
7.28.590	Although the name is hyperbolic in suggesting that myriad legs are present in these invertebrates, the number of legs may vary from 10 to 750.
7.28.591	This subphylum includes 13,000 species; the most commonly found examples are millipedes and centipedes.
7.28.592	All myriapods are terrestrial animals and prefer a humid environment.
7.28.593	Myriapods are typically found in moist soils, decaying biological material, and leaf litter.
7.28.594	Subphylum Myriapoda is divided into four classes: Chilopoda, Symphyla, Diplopoda, and Pauropoda.
7.28.595	Centipedes like Scutigera coleoptrata (Figure 28.37) are classified as chilopods.
7.28.596	These animals bear one pair of legs per segment, mandibles as mouthparts, and are somewhat dorsoventrally flattened.
7.28.597	The legs in the first segment are modified to form forcipules (poison claws) that deliver poison to prey like spiders and cockroaches, as these animals are all predatory.
7.28.598	Millipedes bear two pairs of legs per diplosegment, a feature that results from embryonic fusion of adjacent pairs of body segments, are usually rounder in cross-section, and are herbivores or detritivores.
7.28.599	Millipedes have visibly more numbers of legs as compared to centipedes, although they do not bear a thousand legs.
7.28.600	(a)
7.28.601	The Scutigera coleoptrata centipede has up to 15 pairs of legs.
7.28.602	(b)
7.28.603	This North American millipede (Narceus americanus) bears many legs, although not a thousand, as its name might suggest.
7.28.604	Subphylum Crustacea Crustaceans are the most dominant aquatic arthropods, since the total number of marine crustacean species stands at 67,000, but there are also freshwater and terrestrial crustacean species.
7.28.605	Krill, shrimp, lobsters, crabs, and crayfish are examples of crustaceans (Figure 28.38).
7.28.606	Terrestrial species like the wood lice (Armadillidium spp.)
7.28.607	(also called pill bugs, rolly pollies, potato bugs, or isopods) are also crustaceans, although the number of non-aquatic species in this subphylum is relatively low.
7.28.608	The (a) crab and (b) shrimp krill are both crustaceans.
7.28.609	Crustaceans possess two pairs of antennae, mandibles as mouthparts, and biramous (“two branched”) appendages, which means that their legs are formed in two parts, as distinct from the uniramous (“one branched”) myriapods and hexapods.
7.28.610	Arthropods may have (a) biramous (two-branched) appendages or (b) uniramous (one-branched) appendages.
7.28.611	Unlike that of the Hexapoda, the head and thorax of most crustaceans is fused to form a cephalothorax (Figure 28.40), which is covered by a plate called the carapace, thus producing a body structure of two tagma.
7.28.612	Crustaceans have a chitinous exoskeleton that is shed by molting whenever the animal increases in size.
7.28.613	The exoskeletons of many species are also infused with calcium carbonate, which makes them even stronger than in other arthropods.
7.28.614	Crustaceans have an open circulatory system where blood is pumped into the hemocoel by the dorsally located heart.
7.28.615	Hemocyanin and hemoglobin are the respiratory pigments present in these animals.
7.28.616	The crayfish is an example of a crustacean.
7.28.617	It has a carapace around the cephalothorax and the heart in the dorsal thorax area.
7.28.618	Most crustaceans are dioecious, which means that the sexes are separate.
7.28.619	Some species like barnacles may be hermaphrodites.
7.28.620	Serial hermaphroditism, where the gonad can switch from producing sperm to ova, may also be seen in some species.
7.28.621	Fertilized eggs may be held within the female of the species or may be released in the water.
7.28.622	Terrestrial crustaceans seek out damp spaces in their habitats to lay eggs.
7.28.623	Larval stages— nauplius and zoea—are seen in the early development of crustaceans.
7.28.624	A cypris larva is also seen in the early development of barnacles.
7.28.625	All crustaceans go through different larval stages.
7.28.626	Shown are (a) the nauplius larval stage of a tadpole shrimp, (b) the cypris larval stage of a barnacle, and (c) the zoea larval stage of a green crab.
7.28.627	Crustaceans possess a tripartite brain and two compound eyes.
7.28.628	Most crustaceans are carnivorous, but herbivorous and detritivorous species are also known.
7.28.629	Crustaceans may also be cannibalistic when extremely high populations of these organisms are present.
7.28.630	Subphylum Chelicerata
7.28.631	This subphylum includes animals such as spiders, scorpions, horseshoe crabs, and sea spiders.
7.28.632	This subphylum is predominantly terrestrial, although some marine species also exist.
7.28.633	An estimated 77,000 species are included in subphylum Chelicerata.
7.28.634	Chelicerates are found in almost all habitats.
7.28.635	The body of chelicerates may be divided into two parts: prosoma and opisthosoma, which are basically the equivalents of cephalothorax (usually smaller) and abdomen (usually larger).
7.28.636	A “head” tagmum is not usually discernible.
7.28.637	The phylum derives its name from the first pair of appendages: the chelicerae (Figure 28.42), which are specialized, claw-like or fanglike mouthparts.
7.28.638	These animals do not possess antennae.
7.28.639	The second pair of appendages is known as pedipalps.
7.28.640	In some species, like sea spiders, an additional pair of appendages, called ovigers, is present between the chelicerae and pedipalps.
7.28.641	The chelicerae (first set of appendages) are well developed in the scorpion.
7.28.642	Chelicerae are mostly used for feeding, but in spiders, these are often modified into fangs that inject venom into their prey before feeding (Figure 28.43).
7.28.643	Members of this subphylum have an open circulatory system with a heart that pumps blood into the hemocoel.
7.28.644	Aquatic species have gills, whereas terrestrial species have either trachea or book lungs for gaseous exchange.
7.28.645	The trapdoor spider, like all spiders, is a member of the subphylum Chelicerata.
7.28.646	Most chelicerates ingest food using a preoral cavity formed by the chelicerae and pedipalps.
7.28.647	Some chelicerates may secrete digestive enzymes to pre-digest food before ingesting it.
7.28.648	Parasitic chelicerates like ticks and mites have evolved bloodsucking apparatuses.
7.28.649	The nervous system in chelicerates consists of a brain and two ventral nerve cords.
7.28.650	These animals use external fertilization as well as internal fertilization strategies for reproduction, depending upon the species and its habitat.
7.28.651	Parental care for the young ranges from absolutely none to relatively prolonged care.
7.28.652	The phyla Echinodermata and Chordata (the phylum in which humans are placed) both belong to the superphylum Deuterostomia.
7.28.653	Recall that protostome and deuterostomes
7.28.654	differ in certain aspects of their embryonic development, and they are named based on which opening of the digestive cavity develops first.
7.28.655	The word deuterostome comes from the Greek word meaning “mouth second,
7.28.656	” indicating that the anus is the first to develop.
7.28.657	There are a series of other developmental characteristics that differ between protostomes and deuterostomes, including the mode of formation of the coelom and the early cell division of the embryo.
7.28.658	In deuterostomes, internal pockets of the endodermal lining called the archenteron fuse to form the coelom.
7.28.659	The endodermal lining of the archenteron (or the primitive gut) forms membrane protrusions that bud off and become the mesodermal layer.
7.28.660	These buds, known as coelomic pouches, fuse to form the coelomic cavity, as they eventually separate from the endodermal layer.
7.28.661	The resultant coelom is termed an enterocoelom.
7.28.662	The archenteron develops into the alimentary canal, and a mouth opening is formed by invagination of ectoderm at the pole opposite the blastopore of the gastrula.
7.28.663	The blastopore forms the anus of the alimentary system in the juvenile and adult forms.
7.28.664	The fates of embryonic cells in deuterostomes can be altered if they are experimentally moved to a different location in the embryo due to indeterminant cleavage in early embryogenesis.
7.28.665	Phylum Echinodermata Echinodermata are so named owing to their spiny skin (from the Greek “echinos” meaning “spiny
7.28.666	” and “
7.28.667	dermos” meaning “skin”), and this phylum is a collection of about 7,000 described living species.
7.28.668	Echinodermata are exclusively marine organisms.
7.28.669	Sea stars (Figure 28.44), sea cucumbers, sea urchins, sand dollars, and brittle stars are all examples of echinoderms.
7.28.670	To date, no freshwater or terrestrial echinoderms are known.
7.28.671	Morphology and Anatomy Adult echinoderms exhibit pentaradial symmetry and have a calcareous endoskeleton made of ossicles, although the early larval stages of all echinoderms have bilateral symmetry.
7.28.672	The endoskeleton is developed by epidermal cells and may possess pigment cells, giving vivid colors to these animals, as well as cells laden with toxins.
7.28.673	Gonads are present in each arm.
7.28.674	In echinoderms like sea stars, every arm bears two rows of tube feet on the oral side.
7.28.675	These tube feet help in attachment to the substratum.
7.28.676	These animals possess a true coelom that is modified into a unique circulatory system called a water vascular system.
7.28.677	An interesting feature of these animals is their power to regenerate, even when over 75 percent of their body mass is lost.
7.28.678	This diagram shows the anatomy of a sea star.
7.28.679	Water Vascular System Echinoderms possess a unique ambulacral or water vascular system, consisting of a central ring canal and radial canals that extend along each arm.
7.28.680	Water circulates through these structures and facilitates gaseous exchange as well as nutrition, predation, and locomotion.
7.28.681	The water vascular system also projects from holes in the skeleton in the form of tube feet.
7.28.682	These tube feet can expand or contract based on the volume of water present in the system of that arm.
7.28.683	By using hydrostatic pressure, the animal can either protrude or retract the tube feet.
7.28.684	Water enters the madreporite on the aboral side of the echinoderm.
7.28.685	From there, it passes into the stone canal, which moves water into the ring canal.
7.28.686	The ring canal connects the radial canals (there are five in a pentaradial animal), and the radial canals move water into the ampullae, which have tube feet through which the water moves.
7.28.687	By moving water through the unique water vascular system, the echinoderm can move and force open mollusk shells during feeding.
7.28.688	Nervous System
7.28.689	The nervous system in these animals is a relatively simple structure with a nerve ring at the center and five radial nerves extending outward along the arms.
7.28.690	Structures analogous to a brain or derived from fusion of ganglia are not present in these animals.
7.28.691	Excretory System Podocytes, cells specialized for ultrafiltration of bodily fluids, are present near the center of echinoderms.
7.28.692	These podocytes are connected by an internal system of canals to an opening called the madreporite.
7.28.693	Reproduction Echinoderms are sexually dimorphic and release their eggs and sperm cells into water; fertilization is external.
7.28.694	In some species, the larvae divide asexually and multiply before they reach sexual maturity.
7.28.695	Echinoderms may also reproduce asexually, as well as regenerate body parts lost in trauma.
7.28.696	Classes of Echinoderms
7.28.697	This phylum is divided into five extant classes: Asteroidea (sea stars), Ophiuroidea (brittle stars), Echinoidea (sea urchins and sand dollars), Crinoidea (sea lilies or feather stars), and Holothuroidea (sea cucumbers) (Figure 28.45).
7.28.698	The most well-known echinoderms are members of class Asteroidea, or sea stars.
7.28.699	They come in a large variety of shapes, colors, and sizes, with more than 1,800 species known so far.
7.28.700	The key characteristic of sea stars that distinguishes them from other echinoderm classes includes thick arms (ambulacra) that extend from a central disk where organs penetrate into the arms.
7.28.701	Sea stars use their tube feet not only for gripping surfaces but also for grasping prey.
7.28.702	Sea stars have two stomachs, one of which can protrude through their mouths and secrete digestive juices into or onto prey, even before ingestion.
7.28.703	This process can essentially liquefy the prey and make digestion easier.
7.28.704	Brittle stars belong to the class Ophiuroidea.
7.28.705	Unlike sea stars, which have plump arms, brittle stars have long, thin arms that are sharply demarcated from the central disk.
7.28.706	Brittle stars move by lashing out their arms or wrapping them around objects and pulling themselves forward.
7.28.707	Sea urchins and sand dollars are examples of Echinoidea.
7.28.708	These echinoderms do not have arms, but are hemispherical or flattened with five rows of tube feet that help them in slow movement; tube feet are extruded through pores of a continuous internal shell called a test.
7.28.709	Sea lilies and feather stars are examples of Crinoidea.
7.28.710	Both of these species are suspension feeders.
7.28.711	Sea cucumbers of class Holothuroidea are extended in the oral-aboral axis and have five rows of tube feet.
7.28.712	These are the only echinoderms that demonstrate “functional” bilateral symmetry as adults, because the uniquely extended oral-aboral axis compels the animal to lie horizontally rather than stand vertically.
7.28.713	Different members of Echinodermata include the (a) sea star of class Asteroidea, (b) the brittle star of class Ophiuroidea, (c) the sea urchins of class Echinoidea, (d) the sea lilies belonging to class Crinoidea, and (e) sea cucumbers, representing class Holothuroidea.
7.28.714	Phylum Chordata Animals in the phylum Chordata share four key features that appear at some stage of their development: a notochord, a dorsal hollow nerve cord, pharyngeal slits, and a post-anal tail.
7.28.715	In some groups, some of these traits are present only during embryonic development.
7.28.716	In addition to containing vertebrate classes, the phylum Chordata contains two clades of invertebrates: Urochordata (tunicates) and Cephalochordata (lancelets).
7.28.717	Most tunicates live on the ocean floor and are suspension feeders.
7.28.718	Lancelets are suspension feeders that feed on phytoplankton and other microorganisms.
7.29.0	Examples of critically endangered vertebrate species include (a) the Siberian tiger (Panthera tigris), (b) the mountain gorilla (Gorilla beringei), and (c) the Philippine eagle (Pithecophega jefferyi).
7.29.1	Vertebrates are among the most recognizable organisms of the animal kingdom.
7.29.2	More than 62,000 vertebrate species have been identified.
7.29.3	The vertebrate species now living represent only a small portion of the vertebrates that have existed.
7.29.4	The best-known extinct vertebrates are the dinosaurs, a unique group of reptiles, which reached sizes not seen before or after in terrestrial animals.
7.29.5	They were the dominant terrestrial animals for 150 million years, until they died out in a mass extinction near the end of the Cretaceous period.
7.29.6	Although it is not known with certainty what caused their extinction, a great deal is known about the anatomy of the dinosaurs, given the preservation of skeletal elements in the fossil record.
7.29.7	Currently, a number of vertebrate species face extinction primarily due to habitat loss and pollution.
7.29.8	According to the International Union for the Conservation of Nature, more than 6,000 vertebrate species are classified as threatened.
7.29.9	Amphibians and mammals are the classes with the greatest percentage of threatened species, with 29 percent of all amphibians and 21 percent of all mammals classified as threatened.
7.29.10	Attempts are being made around the world to prevent the extinction of threatened species.
7.29.11	For example, the Biodiversity Action Plan is an international program, ratified by 188 countries, which is designed to protect species and habitats.
7.29.12	Vertebrates are members of the kingdom Animalia and the phylum Chordata (Figure 29.2).
7.29.13	Recall that animals that possess bilateral symmetry can be divided into two groups—protostomes and deuterostomes—based on their patterns of embryonic development.
7.29.14	The deuterostomes, whose name translates as “second mouth,” consist of two phyla: Chordata and Echinodermata.
7.29.15	Echinoderms are invertebrate marine animals that have pentaradial symmetry and a spiny body covering, a group that includes sea stars, sea urchins, and sea cucumbers.
7.29.16	The most conspicuous and familiar members of Chordata are vertebrates, but this phylum also includes two groups of invertebrate chordates.
7.29.17	Characteristics of Chordata Animals in the phylum Chordata share four key features that appear at some stage during their development: a notochord, a dorsal hollow nerve cord, pharyngeal slits, and a post-anal tail (Figure 29.3).
7.29.18	In some groups, some of these are present only during embryonic development.
7.29.19	The chordates are named for the notochord, which is a flexible, rod-shaped structure that is found in the embryonic stage of all chordates and in the adult stage of some chordate species.
7.29.20	It is located between the digestive tube and the nerve cord, and provides skeletal support through the length of the body.
7.29.21	In some chordates, the notochord acts as the primary axial support of the body throughout the animal’s lifetime.
7.29.22	In vertebrates, the notochord is present during embryonic development, at which time it induces the development of the neural tube and serves as a support for the developing embryonic body.
7.29.23	The notochord, however, is not found in the postnatal stage of vertebrates; at this point, it has been replaced by the vertebral column (that is, the spine).
7.29.24	The dorsal hollow nerve cord derives from ectoderm that rolls into a hollow tube during development.
7.29.25	In chordates, it is located dorsal to the notochord.
7.29.26	In contrast, other animal phyla are characterized by solid nerve cords that are located either ventrally or laterally.
7.29.27	The nerve cord found in most chordate embryos develops into the brain and spinal cord, which compose the central nervous system.
7.29.28	Pharyngeal slits are openings in the pharynx (the region just posterior to the mouth) that extend to the outside environment.
7.29.29	In organisms that live in aquatic environments, pharyngeal slits allow for the exit of water that enters the mouth during feeding.
7.29.30	Some invertebrate chordates use the pharyngeal slits to filter food out of the water that enters the mouth.
7.29.31	In vertebrate fishes, the pharyngeal slits are modified into gill supports, and in jawed fishes, into jaw supports.
7.29.32	In tetrapods, the slits are modified into components of the ear and tonsils.
7.29.33	Tetrapod literally means “four-footed,” which refers to the phylogenetic history of various groups that evolved accordingly, even though some now possess fewer than two pairs of walking appendages.
7.29.34	Tetrapods include amphibians, reptiles, birds, and mammals.
7.29.35	The post-anal tail is a posterior elongation of the body, extending beyond the anus.
7.29.36	The tail contains skeletal elements and muscles, which provide a source of locomotion in aquatic species, such as fishes.
7.29.37	In some terrestrial vertebrates, the tail also helps with balance, courting, and signaling when danger is near.
7.29.38	In humans, the post-anal tail is vestigial, that is, reduced in size and nonfunctional.
7.29.39	Chordates and the Evolution of Vertebrates Chordata also contains two clades of invertebrates: Urochordata and Cephalochordata.
7.29.40	Members of these groups also possess the four distinctive features of chordates at some point during their development.
7.29.41	Urochordata Members of Urochordata are also known as tunicates (Figure 29.4).
7.29.42	The name tunicate derives from the cellulose-like carbohydrate material, called the tunic, which covers the outer body of tunicates.
7.29.43	Although adult tunicates are classified as chordates, they do not have a notochord, a dorsal hollow nerve cord, or a post-anal tail, although they do have pharyngeal slits.
7.29.44	The larval form, however, possesses all four structures.
7.29.45	Most tunicates are hermaphrodites.
7.29.46	Tunicate larvae hatch from eggs inside the adult tunicate’s body.
7.29.47	After hatching, a tunicate larva swims for a few days until it finds a suitable surface on which it can attach, usually in a dark or shaded location.
7.29.48	It then attaches via the head to the surface and undergoes metamorphosis into the adult form, at which point the notochord, nerve cord, and tail disappear.
7.29.49	This photograph shows a colony of the tunicate Botrylloides violaceus.
7.29.50	(b)
7.29.51	The larval stage of the tunicate possesses all of the features characteristic of chordates: a notochord, a dorsal hollow nerve cord, pharyngeal slits, and a post-anal tail.
7.29.52	(c)
7.29.53	In the adult stage, the notochord, nerve cord, and tail disappear.
7.29.54	Most tunicates live a sessile existence on the ocean floor and are suspension feeders.
7.29.55	The primary foods of tunicates are plankton and detritus.
7.29.56	Seawater enters the tunicate’s body through its incurrent siphon.
7.29.57	Suspended material is filtered out of this water by a mucous net (pharyngeal slits) and is passed into the intestine via the action of cilia.
7.29.58	The anus empties into the excurrent siphon, which expels wastes and water.
7.29.59	Tunicates are found in shallow ocean waters around the world.
7.29.60	Cephalochordata Members of Cephalochordata possess a notochord, dorsal hollow nerve cord, pharyngeal slits, and a post-anal tail in the adult stage (Figure 29.5).
7.29.61	The notochord extends into the head, which gives the subphylum its name.
7.29.62	Extinct members of this subphylum include Pikaia, which is the oldest known cephalochordate.
7.29.63	Pikaia fossils were recovered from the Burgess shales of Canada and dated to the middle of the Cambrian age, making them more than 500 million years old.
7.29.64	Extant members of Cephalochordata are the lancelets, named for their blade-like shape.
7.29.65	Lancelets are only a few centimeters long and are usually found buried in sand at the bottom of warm temperate and tropical seas.
7.29.66	Like tunicates, they are suspension feeders.
7.29.67	The lancelet, like all cephalochordates, has a head.
7.29.68	Adult lancelets retain the four key features of chordates: a notochord, a dorsal hollow nerve cord, pharyngeal slits, and a post-anal tail.
7.29.69	Water from the mouth enters the pharyngeal slits, which filter out food particles.
7.29.70	The filtered water then collects in the atrium and exits through the atriopore.
7.29.71	Craniata and Vertebrata A cranium is a bony, cartilaginous, or fibrous structure surrounding the brain, jaw, and facial bones (Figure 29.6).
7.29.72	Most bilaterally symmetrical animals have a head; of these, those that have a cranium compose the clade Craniata.
7.29.73	Craniata includes the hagfishes (Myxini), which have a cranium but lack a backbone, and all of the organisms called “vertebrates.
7.29.74	” Craniata, including this fish (Dunkleosteus sp.), are characterized by the presence of a cranium, mandible, and other facial bones.
7.29.75	Vertebrates are members of the clade Vertebrata.
7.29.76	Vertebrates display the four characteristic features of the chordates; however, members of this group also share derived characteristics that distinguish them from invertebrate chordates.
7.29.77	Vertebrata is named for the vertebral column, composed of vertebrae, a series of separate bones joined together as a backbone (Figure 29.7).
7.29.78	In adult vertebrates, the vertebral column replaces the notochord, which is only seen in the embryonic stage.
7.29.79	Vertebrata are characterized by the presence of a backbone, such as the one that runs through the middle of this fish.
7.29.80	All vertebrates are in the Craniata clade and have a cranium.
7.29.81	Based on molecular analysis, vertebrates appear to be more closely related to lancelets (cephalochordates) than to tunicates (urochordates) among the invertebrate chordates.
7.29.82	This evidence suggests that the cephalochordates diverged from Urochordata and the vertebrates subsequently diverged from the cephalochordates.
7.29.83	This hypothesis is further supported by the discovery of a fossil in China from the genus Haikouella.
7.29.84	This organism seems to be an intermediate form between cephalochordates and vertebrates.
7.29.85	The Haikouella fossils are about 530 million years old and appear similar to modern lancelets.
7.29.86	These organisms had a brain and eyes, as do vertebrates, but lack the skull found in craniates.
7.29.87	[1]
7.29.88	This evidence suggests that vertebrates arose during the Cambrian explosion.
7.29.89	Recall that the “Cambrian explosion” is the name given to a relatively brief span of time during the Cambrian period during which many animal groups appeared and rapidly diversified.
7.29.90	Most modern animal phyla originated during the Cambrian explosion.
7.29.91	Vertebrates are the largest group of chordates, with more than 62,000 living species.
7.29.92	Vertebrates are grouped based on anatomical and physiological traits.
7.29.93	More than one classification and naming scheme is used for these animals.
7.29.94	Here we will consider the traditional groups Agnatha, Chondrichthyes, Osteichthyes, Amphibia, Reptilia, Aves, and Mammalia, which constitute classes in the subphylum Vertebrata.
7.29.95	Many modern authors classify birds within Reptilia, which correctly reflects their evolutionary heritage.
7.29.96	We consider them separately only for convenience.
7.29.97	Further, we will consider hagfishes and lampreys together as jawless fishes, the agnathans, although emerging classification schemes separate them into chordate jawless fishes (the hagfishes) and vertebrate jawless fishes (the lampreys).
7.29.98	Animals that possess jaws are known as gnathostomes, which means “jawed mouth.
7.29.99	” Gnathostomes include fishes and tetrapods—amphibians, reptiles, birds, and mammals.
7.29.100	Tetrapods can be further divided into two groups: amphibians and amniotes.
7.29.101	Amniotes are animals whose eggs are adapted for terrestrial living, and this group includes mammals, reptiles, and birds.
7.29.102	Amniotic embryos, developing in either an externally shed egg or an egg carried by the female, are provided with a water-retaining environment and are protected by amniotic membranes.
7.29.103	Modern fishes include an estimated 31,000 species.
7.29.104	Fishes were the earliest vertebrates, with jawless species being the earliest and jawed species evolving later.
7.29.105	They are active feeders, rather than sessile, suspension feeders.
7.29.106	Jawless fishes—the hagfishes and lampreys
7.29.107	—have a distinct cranium and complex sense organs including eyes, distinguishing them from the invertebrate chordates.
7.29.108	Jawless Fishes Jawless fishes are craniates that represent an ancient vertebrate lineage that arose over one half-billion years ago.
7.29.109	In the past, the hagfishes and lampreys were classified together as agnathans.
7.29.110	Today, hagfishes and lampreys are recognized as separate clades, primarily because lampreys are true vertebrates, whereas hagfishes are not.
7.29.111	A defining feature is the lack of paired lateral appendages (fins).
7.29.112	Some of the earliest jawless fishes were the ostracoderms (which translates to “shellskin”).
7.29.113	Ostracoderms were vertebrate fishes encased in bony armor, unlike present-day jawless fishes, which lack bone in their scales.
7.29.114	Myxini:
7.29.115	Hagfishes
7.29.116	The clade Myxini includes at least 20 species of hagfishes.
7.29.117	Hagfishes are eel-like scavengers that live on the ocean floor and feed on dead invertebrates, other fishes, and marine mammals (Figure 29.8).
7.29.118	Hagfishes are entirely marine and are found in oceans around the world, except for the polar regions.
7.29.119	A unique feature of these animals is the slime glands beneath the skin that release mucus through surface pores.
7.29.120	This mucus allows the hagfish to escape from the grip of predators.
7.29.121	Hagfish can also twist their bodies in a knot to feed and sometimes eat carcasses from the inside out.
7.29.122	Pacific hagfish are scavengers that live on the ocean floor.
7.29.123	The skeleton of a hagfish is composed of cartilage, which includes a cartilaginous notochord that runs the length of the body.
7.29.124	This notochord provides support to the hagfish’s body.
7.29.125	Hagfishes do not replace the notochord with a vertebral column during development, as do true vertebrates.
7.29.126	Petromyzontidae:
7.29.127	Lampreys
7.29.128	The clade Petromyzontidae includes approximately 35–40 or more species of lampreys.
7.29.129	Lampreys are similar to hagfishes in size and shape; however, lampreys possess some vertebral elements.
7.29.130	Lampreys lack paired appendages and bone, as do the hagfishes.
7.29.131	As adults, lampreys are characterized by a toothed, funnel-like sucking mouth.
7.29.132	Many species have a parasitic stage of their life cycle during which they are ectoparasites of fishes.
7.29.133	These parasitic sea lampreys attach to their lake trout host by suction and use their rough tongues to rasp away flesh in order to feed on the trout’s blood.
7.29.134	Lampreys live primarily in coastal and fresh waters, and have a worldwide distribution, except for in the tropics and polar regions.
7.29.135	Some species are marine, but all species spawn in fresh water.
7.29.136	Eggs are fertilized externally, and the larvae distinctly differ from the adult form, spending 3 to 15 years as suspension feeders.
7.29.137	Once they attain sexual maturity, the adults reproduce and die within days.
7.29.138	Lampreys possess a notochord as adults; however, this notochord is surrounded by a cartilaginous structure called an arcualia, which may resemble an evolutionarily early form of the vertebral column.
7.29.139	Gnathostomes:
7.29.140	Jawed Fishes Gnathostomes or “jaw-mouths” are vertebrates that possess jaws.
7.29.141	One of the most significant developments in early vertebrate evolution was the development of the jaw, which is a hinged structure attached to the cranium that allows an animal to grasp and tear its food.
7.29.142	The evolution of jaws allowed early gnathostomes to exploit food resources that were unavailable to jawless fishes.
7.29.143	Early gnathostomes also possessed two sets of paired fins, allowing the fishes to maneuver accurately.
7.29.144	Pectoral fins are typically located on the anterior body, and pelvic fins on the posterior.
7.29.145	Evolution of the jaw and paired fins permitted gnathostomes to expand from the sedentary suspension feeding of jawless fishes to become mobile predators.
7.29.146	The ability of gnathostomes to exploit new nutrient sources likely is one reason that they replaced most jawless fishes during the Devonian period.
7.29.147	Two early groups of gnathostomes were the acanthodians and placoderms (Figure 29.10), which arose in the late Silurian period and are now extinct.
7.29.148	Most modern fishes are gnathostomes that belong to the clades Chondrichthyes and Osteichthyes.
7.29.149	Dunkleosteous was an enormous placoderm from the Devonian period, 380–360 million years ago.
7.29.150	It measured up to 10 meters in length and weighed up to 3.6 tons.
7.29.151	Chondrichthyes:
7.29.152	Cartilaginous Fishes
7.29.153	The clade Chondrichthyes is diverse, consisting of sharks (Figure 29.11), rays, and skates, together with sawfishes and a few dozen species of fishes called chimaeras, or “ghost” sharks.
7.29.154	”
7.29.155	Chondrichthyes are jawed fishes that possess paired fins and a skeleton made of cartilage.
7.29.156	This clade arose approximately 370 million years ago in the early or middle Devonian.
7.29.157	They are thought to be descended from the placoderms, which had skeletons made of bone; thus, the cartilaginous skeleton of Chondrichthyes is a later development.
7.29.158	Parts of shark skeleton are strengthened by granules of calcium carbonate, but this is not the same as bone.
7.29.159	Most cartilaginous fishes live in marine habitats, with a few species living in fresh water for a part or all of their lives.
7.29.160	Most sharks are carnivores that feed on live prey, either swallowing it whole or using their jaws and teeth to tear it into smaller pieces.
7.29.161	Shark teeth likely evolved from the jagged scales that cover their skin, called placoid scales.
7.29.162	Some species of sharks and rays are suspension feeders that feed on plankton.
7.29.163	Hammerhead sharks tend to school during the day and hunt prey at night.
7.29.164	Sharks have well-developed sense organs that aid them in locating prey, including a keen sense of smell and electroreception, with the latter perhaps the most sensitive of any animal.
7.29.165	Organs called ampullae of Lorenzini allow sharks to detect the electromagnetic fields that are produced by all living things, including their prey.
7.29.166	Electroreception has only been observed in aquatic or amphibious animals.
7.29.167	Sharks, together with most fishes and aquatic and larval amphibians, also have a sense organ called the lateral line, which is used to detect movement and vibration in the surrounding water, and is often considered homologous to “hearing” in terrestrial vertebrates.
7.29.168	The lateral line is visible as a darker stripe that runs along the length of a fish’s body.
7.29.169	Sharks reproduce sexually, and eggs are fertilized internally.
7.29.170	Most species are ovoviviparous: The fertilized egg is retained in the oviduct of the mother’s body and the embryo is nourished by the egg yolk.
7.29.171	The eggs hatch in the uterus, and young are born alive and fully functional.
7.29.172	Some species of sharks are oviparous: They lay eggs that hatch outside of the mother’s body.
7.29.173	Embryos are protected by a shark egg case or “mermaid’s purse”
7.29.174	(Figure 29.12) that has the consistency of leather.
7.29.175	The shark egg case has tentacles that snag in seaweed and give the newborn shark cover.
7.29.176	A few species of sharks are viviparous: The young develop within the mother’s body and she gives live birth.
7.29.177	Shark embryos are clearly visible through these transparent egg cases.
7.29.178	The round structure is the yolk that nourishes the growing embryo.
7.29.179	Rays and skates comprise more than 500 species and are closely related to sharks.
7.29.180	They can be distinguished from sharks by their flattened bodies, pectoral fins that are enlarged and fused to the head, and gill slits on their ventral surface (Figure 29.13).
7.29.181	Like sharks, rays and skates have a cartilaginous skeleton.
7.29.182	Most species are marine and live on the sea floor, with nearly a worldwide distribution.
7.29.183	This stingray blends into the sandy bottom of the ocean floor.
7.29.184	Osteichthyes: Bony Fishes Members of the clade Osteichthyes, also called bony fishes, are characterized by a bony skeleton.
7.29.185	The vast majority of present-day fishes belong to this group, which consists of approximately 30,000 species, making it the largest class of vertebrates in existence today.
7.29.186	Nearly all bony fishes have an ossified skeleton with specialized bone cells (osteocytes) that produce and maintain a calcium phosphate matrix.
7.29.187	This characteristic has only reversed in a few groups of Osteichthyes, such as sturgeons and paddlefish, which have primarily cartilaginous skeletons.
7.29.188	The skin of bony fishes is often covered by overlapping scales, and glands in the skin secrete mucus that reduces drag when swimming and aids the fish in osmoregulation.
7.29.189	Like sharks, bony fishes have a lateral line system that detects vibrations in water.
7.29.190	All bony fishes use gills to breathe.
7.29.191	Water is drawn over gills that are located in chambers covered and ventilated by a protective, muscular flap called the operculum.
7.29.192	Many bony fishes also have a swim bladder, a gas-filled organ that helps to control the buoyancy of the fish.
7.29.193	Bony fishes are further divided into two extant clades: Actinopterygii (ray-finned fishes) and Sarcopterygii (lobe-finned fishes).
7.29.194	Actinopterygii, the ray-finned fishes, include many familiar fishes—tuna, bass, trout, and salmon (Figure 29.14a), among others.
7.29.195	Ray-finned fishes are named for their fins that are webs of skin supported by bony spines called rays.
7.29.196	In contrast, the fins of Sarcopterygii are fleshy and lobed, supported by bone (Figure 29.14b).
7.29.197	Living members of this clade include the less-familiar lungfishes and coelacanths.
7.29.198	The (a) sockeye salmon and (b) coelacanth are both bony fishes of the Osteichthyes clade.
7.29.199	The coelacanth, sometimes called a lobe-finned fish, was thought to have gone extinct in the Late Cretaceous period, 100 million years ago, until one was discovered in 1938 near the Comoros Islands between Africa and Madagascar.
7.29.200	Amphibians are vertebrate tetrapods.
7.29.201	Amphibia includes frogs, salamanders, and caecilians.
7.29.202	The term amphibian loosely translates from the Greek as “dual life,
7.29.203	” which is a reference to the metamorphosis that many frogs and salamanders undergo and their mixture of aquatic and terrestrial environments in their life cycle.
7.29.204	Amphibians evolved during the Devonian period and were the earliest terrestrial tetrapods.
7.29.205	Characteristics of Amphibians
7.29.206	As tetrapods, most amphibians are characterized by four well-developed limbs.
7.29.207	Some species of salamanders and all caecilians are functionally limbless; their limbs are vestigial.
7.29.208	An important characteristic of extant amphibians is a moist, permeable skin that is achieved via mucus glands that keep the skin moist; thus, exchange of oxygen and carbon dioxide with the environment can take place through it ( cutaneous respiration).
7.29.209	Additional characteristics of amphibians include pedicellate teeth—teeth in which the root and crown are calcified, separated by a zone of noncalcified tissue—and a papilla amphibiorum and papilla basilaris, structures of the inner ear that are sensitive to frequencies below and above 10,00 hertz, respectively.
7.29.210	Amphibians also have an auricular operculum, which is an extra bone in the ear that transmits sounds to the inner ear.
7.29.211	All extant adult amphibians are carnivorous, and some terrestrial amphibians have a sticky tongue that is used to capture prey.
7.29.212	Evolution of Amphibians
7.29.213	The fossil record provides evidence of the first tetrapods: now-extinct amphibian species dating to nearly 400 million years ago.
7.29.214	Evolution of tetrapods from fishes represented a significant change in body plan from one suited to organisms that respired and swam in water, to organisms that breathed air and moved onto land; these changes occurred over a span of 50 million years during the Devonian period.
7.29.215	One of the earliest known tetrapods is from the genus Acanthostega.
7.29.216	Acanthostega was aquatic; fossils show that it had gills similar to fishes.
7.29.217	However, it also had four limbs, with the skeletal structure of limbs found in present-day tetrapods, including amphibians.
7.29.218	Therefore, it is thought that Acanthostega lived in shallow waters and was an intermediate form between lobe-finned fishes and early, fully terrestrial tetrapods.
7.29.219	What preceded Acanthostega?
7.29.220	In 2006, researchers published news of their discovery of a fossil of a “tetrapod-like fish,” Tiktaalik roseae, which seems to be an intermediate form between fishes having fins and tetrapods having limbs (Figure 29.15).
7.29.221	Tiktaalik likely lived in a shallow water environment about 375 million years ago.
7.29.222	The recent fossil discovery of Tiktaalik roseae suggests evidence for an animal intermediate to finned fish and legged tetrapods.
7.29.223	The early tetrapods that moved onto land had access to new nutrient sources and relatively few predators.
7.29.224	This led to the widespread distribution of tetrapods during the early Carboniferous period, a period sometimes called the “age of the amphibians.
7.29.225	”
7.29.226	Modern Amphibians Amphibia comprises an estimated 6,770 extant species that inhabit tropical and temperate regions around the world.
7.29.227	Amphibians can be divided into three clades:
7.29.228	Urodela (“tailed-ones”), the salamanders; Anura (“tail-less ones”), the frogs; and Apoda (“legless ones”), the caecilians.
7.29.229	Urodela:
7.29.230	Salamanders Salamanders are amphibians that belong to the order Urodela.
7.29.231	Living salamanders (Figure 29.16) include approximately 620 species, some of which are aquatic, other terrestrial, and some that live on land only as adults.
7.29.232	Adult salamanders usually have a generalized tetrapod body plan with four limbs and a tail.
7.29.233	They move by bending their bodies from side to side, called lateral undulation, in a fish-like manner while “walking” their arms and legs fore and aft.
7.29.234	It is thought that their gait is similar to that used by early tetrapods.
7.29.235	Respiration differs among different species.
7.29.236	The majority of salamanders are lungless, and respiration occurs through the skin or through external gills.
7.29.237	Some terrestrial salamanders have primitive lungs; a few species have both gills and lungs.
7.29.238	Unlike frogs, virtually all salamanders rely on internal fertilization of the eggs.
7.29.239	The only male amphibians that possess copulatory structures are the caecilians, so fertilization among salamanders typically involves an elaborate and often prolonged courtship.
7.29.240	Such a courtship allows the successful transfer of sperm from male to female via a spermatophore.
7.29.241	Development in many of the most highly evolved salamanders, which are fully terrestrial, occurs during a prolonged egg stage, with the eggs guarded by the mother.
7.29.242	During this time, the gilled larval stage is found only within the egg capsule, with the gills being resorbed, and metamorphosis being completed, before hatching.
7.29.243	Hatchlings thus resemble tiny adults.
7.29.244	Anura:
7.29.245	Frogs Frogs are amphibians that belong to the order Anura (Figure 29.17).
7.29.246	Anurans are among the most diverse groups of vertebrates, with approximately 5,965 species that occur on all of the continents except Antarctica.
7.29.247	Anurans have a body plan that is more specialized for movement.
7.29.248	Adult frogs use their hind limbs to jump on land.
7.29.249	Frogs have a number of modifications that allow them to avoid predators, including skin that acts as camouflage.
7.29.250	Many species of frogs and salamanders also release defensive chemicals from glands in the skin that are poisonous to predators.
7.29.251	The Australian green tree frog is a nocturnal predator that lives in the canopies of trees near a water source.
7.29.252	Frog eggs are fertilized externally, and like other amphibians, frogs generally lay their eggs in moist environments.
7.29.253	A moist environment is required as eggs lack a shell and thus dehydrate quickly in dry environments.
7.29.254	Frogs demonstrate a great diversity of parental behaviors, with some species laying many eggs and exhibiting little parental care, to species that carry eggs and tadpoles on their hind legs or backs.
7.29.255	The life cycle of frogs, as other amphibians, consists of two distinct stages: the larval stage followed by metamorphosis to an adult stage.
7.29.256	The larval stage of a frog, the tadpole, is often a filter-feeding herbivore.
7.29.257	Tadpoles usually have gills, a lateral line system, long-finned tails, and lack limbs.
7.29.258	At the end of the tadpole stage, frogs undergo metamorphosis into the adult form (Figure 29.18).
7.29.259	During this stage, the gills, tail, and lateral line system disappear, and four limbs develop.
7.29.260	The jaws become larger and are suited for carnivorous feeding, and the digestive system transforms into the typical short gut of a predator.
7.29.261	An eardrum and air-breathing lungs also develop.
7.29.262	These changes during metamorphosis allow the larvae to move onto land in the adult stage.
7.29.263	A juvenile frog metamorphoses into a frog.
7.29.264	Here, the frog has started to develop limbs, but its tadpole tail is still evident.
7.29.265	Apoda:
7.29.266	Caecilians An estimated 185 species comprise caecilians, a group of amphibians that belong to the order Apoda.
7.29.267	Although they are vertebrates, a complete lack of limbs leads to their resemblance to earthworms in appearance.
7.29.268	They are adapted for a soilburrowing or aquatic lifestyle, and they are nearly blind.
7.29.269	These animals are found in the tropics of South America, Africa, and Southern Asia.
7.29.270	They have vestigial limbs, evidence that they evolved from a legged ancestor.
7.29.271	The amniotes —reptiles, birds, and mammals—are distinguished from amphibians by their terrestrially adapted egg, which is protected by amniotic membranes.
7.29.272	The evolution of amniotic membranes meant that the embryos of amniotes were provided with their own aquatic environment, which led to less dependence on water for development and thus allowed the amniotes to branch out into drier environments.
7.29.273	This was a significant development that distinguished them from amphibians, which were restricted to moist environments due their shell-less eggs.
7.29.274	Although the shells of various amniotic species vary significantly, they all allow retention of water.
7.29.275	The shells of bird eggs are composed of calcium carbonate and are hard, but fragile.
7.29.276	The shells of reptile eggs are leathery and require a moist environment.
7.29.277	Most mammals do not lay eggs (except for monotremes).
7.29.278	Instead, the embryo grows within the mother’s body; however, even with this internal gestation, amniotic membranes are still present.
7.29.279	Characteristics of Amniotes
7.29.280	The amniotic egg is the key characteristic of amniotes.
7.29.281	In amniotes that lay eggs, the shell of the egg provides protection for the developing embryo while being permeable enough to allow for the exchange of carbon dioxide and oxygen.
7.29.282	The albumin, or egg white, provides the embryo with water and protein, whereas the fattier egg yolk is the energy supply for the embryo, as is the case with the eggs of many other animals, such as amphibians.
7.29.283	However, the eggs of amniotes contain three additional extra-embryonic membranes: the chorion, amnion, and allantois (Figure 29.20).
7.29.284	Extra-embryonic membranes are membranes present in amniotic eggs that are not a part of the body of the developing embryo.
7.29.285	While the inner amniotic membrane surrounds the embryo itself, the chorion surrounds the embryo and yolk sac.
7.29.286	The chorion facilitates exchange of oxygen and carbon dioxide between the embryo and the egg’s external environment.
7.29.287	The amnion protects the embryo from mechanical shock and supports hydration.
7.29.288	The allantois stores nitrogenous wastes produced by the embryo and also facilitates respiration.
7.29.289	In mammals, membranes that are homologous to the extra-embryonic membranes in eggs are present in the placenta.
7.29.290	Additional derived characteristics of amniotes include waterproof skin, due to the presence of lipids, and costal (rib) ventilation of the lungs.
7.29.291	Evolution of Amniotes
7.29.292	The first amniotes evolved from amphibian ancestors approximately 340 million years ago during the Carboniferous period.
7.29.293	The early amniotes diverged into two main lines soon after the first amniotes arose.
7.29.294	The initial split was into synapsids and sauropsids.
7.29.295	Synapsids include all mammals, including extinct mammalian species.
7.29.296	Synapsids also include therapsids, which were mammal-like reptiles from which mammals evolved.
7.29.297	Sauropsids include reptiles and birds, and can be further divided into anapsids and diapsids.
7.29.298	The key differences between the synapsids, anapsids, and diapsids are the structures of the skull and the number of temporal fenestrae behind each eye
7.29.299	(Figure 29.21).
7.29.300	Temporal fenestrae are post-orbital openings in the skull that allow muscles to expand and lengthen.
7.29.301	Anapsids have no temporal fenestrae, synapsids have one, and diapsids have two.
7.29.302	Anapsids include extinct organisms and may, based on anatomy, include turtles.
7.29.303	However, this is still controversial, and turtles are sometimes classified as diapsids based on molecular evidence.
7.29.304	The diapsids include birds and all other living and extinct reptiles.
7.29.305	Compare the skulls and temporal fenestrae of anapsids, synapsids, and diapsids.
7.29.306	Anapsids have no openings, synapsids have one opening, and diapsids have two openings.
7.29.307	The diapsids diverged into two groups, the Archosauromorpha (“ancient lizard form”) and the Lepidosauromorpha (“scaly lizard form”) during the Mesozoic period (Figure 29.22).
7.29.308	The lepidosaurs include modern lizards, snakes, and tuataras.
7.29.309	The archosaurs include modern crocodiles and alligators, and the extinct pterosaurs (“winged lizard”) and dinosaurs (“terrible lizard”).
7.29.310	Clade Dinosauria includes birds, which evolved from a branch of dinosaurs.
7.29.311	In the past, the most common division of amniotes has been into the classes Mammalia, Reptilia, and Aves.
7.29.312	Birds are descended, however, from dinosaurs, so this classical scheme results in groups that are not true clades.
7.29.313	We will consider birds as a group distinct from reptiles for the purpose of this discussion with the understanding that this does not completely reflect phylogenetic history and relationships.
7.29.314	Characteristics of Reptiles Reptiles are tetrapods.
7.29.315	Limbless reptiles—snakes and other squamates—have vestigial limbs and, like caecilians, are classified as tetrapods because they are descended from four-limbed ancestors.
7.29.316	Reptiles lay eggs enclosed in shells on land.
7.29.317	Even aquatic reptiles return to the land to lay eggs.
7.29.318	They usually reproduce sexually with internal fertilization.
7.29.319	Some species display ovoviviparity, with the eggs remaining in the mother’s body until they are ready to hatch.
7.29.320	Other species are viviparous, with the offspring born alive.
7.29.321	One of the key adaptations that permitted reptiles to live on land was the development of their scaly skin, containing the protein keratin and waxy lipids, which reduced water loss from the skin.
7.29.322	This occlusive skin means that reptiles cannot use their skin for respiration, like amphibians, and thus all breathe with lungs.
7.29.323	Reptiles are ectotherms, animals whose main source of body heat comes from the environment.
7.29.324	This is in contrast to endotherms, which use heat produced by metabolism to regulate body temperature.
7.29.325	In addition to being ectothermic, reptiles are categorized as poikilotherms, or animals whose body temperatures vary rather than remain stable.
7.29.326	Reptiles have behavioral adaptations to help regulate body temperature, such as basking in sunny places to warm up and finding shady spots or going underground to cool down.
7.29.327	The advantage of ectothermy is that metabolic energy from food is not required to heat the body; therefore, reptiles can survive on about 10 percent of the calories required by a similarly sized endotherm.
7.29.328	In cold weather, some reptiles such as the garter snake brumate.
7.29.329	Brumation is similar to hibernation in that the animal becomes less active and can go for long periods without eating, but differs from hibernation in that brumating reptiles are not asleep or living off fat reserves.
7.29.330	Rather, their metabolism is slowed in response to cold temperatures, and the animal is very sluggish.
7.29.331	Evolution of Reptiles Reptiles originated approximately 300 million years ago during the Carboniferous period.
7.29.332	One of the oldest known amniotes is Casineria, which had both amphibian and reptilian characteristics.
7.29.333	One of the earliest undisputed reptiles was Hylonomus.
7.29.334	Soon after the first amniotes appeared, they diverged into three groups—synapsids, anapsids, and diapsids—during the Permian period.
7.29.335	The Permian period also saw a second major divergence of diapsid reptiles into archosaurs (predecessors of crocodilians and dinosaurs) and lepidosaurs (predecessors of snakes and lizards).
7.29.336	These groups remained inconspicuous until the Triassic period, when the archosaurs became the dominant terrestrial group due to the extinction of large-bodied anapsids and synapsids during the Permian-Triassic extinction.
7.29.337	About 250 million years ago, archosaurs radiated into the dinosaurs and the pterosaurs.
7.29.338	Although they are sometimes mistakenly called dinosaurs, the pterosaurs were distinct from true dinosaurs (Figure 29.23).
7.29.339	Pterosaurs had a number of adaptations that allowed for flight, including hollow bones (birds also exhibit hollow bones, a case of convergent evolution).
7.29.340	Their wings were formed by membranes of skin that attached to the long, fourth finger of each arm and extended along the body to the legs.
7.29.341	Pterosaurs, which existed from the late Triassic to the Cretaceous period (210 to 65.5 million years ago), possessed wings but are not believed to have been capable of powered flight.
7.29.342	Instead, they may have been able to soar after launching from cliffs.
7.29.343	The dinosaurs were a diverse group of terrestrial reptiles with more than 1,000 species identified to date.
7.29.344	Paleontologists continue to discover new species of dinosaurs.
7.29.345	Some dinosaurs were quadrupeds (Figure 29.24); others were bipeds.
7.29.346	Some were carnivorous, whereas others were herbivorous.
7.29.347	Dinosaurs laid eggs, and a number of nests containing fossilized eggs have been found.
7.29.348	It is not known whether dinosaurs were endotherms or ectotherms.
7.29.349	However, given that modern birds are endothermic, the dinosaurs that served as ancestors to birds likely were endothermic as well.
7.29.350	Some fossil evidence exists for dinosaurian parental care, and comparative biology supports this hypothesis since the archosaur birds and crocodilians display parental care.
7.29.351	Edmontonia was an armored dinosaur that lived in the late Cretaceous period, 145.5 to 65.6 million years ago.
7.29.352	Dinosaurs dominated the Mesozoic Era, which was known as the “age of reptiles.
7.29.353	”
7.29.354	The dominance of dinosaurs lasted until the end of the Cretaceous, the last period of the Mesozoic Era.
7.29.355	The Cretaceous-Tertiary extinction resulted in the loss of most of the large-bodied animals of the Mesozoic Era.
7.29.356	Birds are the only living descendants of one of the major clades of dinosaurs.
7.29.357	Modern Reptiles Class Reptilia includes many diverse species that are classified into four living clades.
7.29.358	These are the 25 species of Crocodilia, 2 species of Sphenodontia, approximately 9,200 Squamata species, and the Testudines, with about 325 species.
7.29.359	Crocodilia Crocodilia (“small lizard”) arose with a distinct lineage by the middle Triassic; extant species include alligators, crocodiles, and caimans.
7.29.360	Crocodilians (Figure 29.25) live throughout the tropics and subtropics of Africa, South America, Southern Florida, Asia, and Australia.
7.29.361	They are found in freshwater, saltwater, and brackish habitats, such as rivers and lakes, and spend most of their time in water.
7.29.362	Some species are able to move on land due to their semi-erect posture.
7.29.363	Crocodilians, such as this Siamese crocodile (Crocodylus siamensis), provide parental care for their offspring.
7.29.364	Sphenodontia Sphenodontia (“wedge tooth”) arose in the Mesozoic era and includes only one living genus, Tuatara, comprising two species that are found in New Zealand (Figure 29.26).
7.29.365	Tuataras measure up to 80 centimeters and weigh about 1 kilogram.
7.29.366	Although quite lizard-like in gross appearance, several unique features of the skull and jaws clearly define them and distinguish the group from the squamates.
7.29.367	This tuatara from New Zealand may resemble a lizard but belongs to a distinct lineage, the Sphenodontidae family.
7.29.368	Squamata Squamata (“scaly”) arose in the late Permian, and extant species include lizards and snakes.
7.29.369	Both are found on all continents except Antarctica.
7.29.370	Lizards and snakes are most closely related to tuataras, both groups having evolved from a lepidosaurian ancestor.
7.29.371	Squamata is the largest extant clade of reptiles (Figure 29.27).
7.29.372	Most lizards differ from snakes by having four limbs, although these have been variously lost or significantly reduced in at least 60 lineages.
7.29.373	Snakes lack eyelids and external ears, which are present in lizards.
7.29.374	Lizard species range in size from chameleons and geckos, which are a few centimeters in length, to the Komodo dragon, which is about 3 meters in length.
7.29.375	Most lizards are carnivorous, but some large species, such as iguanas, are herbivores.
7.29.376	This Jackson’s chameleon (Trioceros jacksonii) blends in with its surroundings.
7.29.377	Snakes are thought to have descended from either burrowing lizards or aquatic lizards over 100 million years ago (Figure 29.28).
7.29.378	Snakes comprise about 3,000 species and are found on every continent except Antarctica.
7.29.379	They range in size from 10 centimeter-long thread snakes to 10 meter-long pythons and anacondas.
7.29.380	All snakes are carnivorous and eat small animals, birds, eggs, fish, and insects.
7.29.381	The snake body form is so specialized that, in its general morphology, a “snake is a snake.
7.29.382	”
7.29.383	Their specializations all point to snakes having evolved to feed on relatively large prey (even though some current species have reversed this trend).
7.29.384	Although variations exist, most snakes have a skull that is very flexible, involving eight rotational joints.
7.29.385	They also differ from other squamates by having mandibles (lower jaws) without either bony or ligamentous attachment anteriorly.
7.29.386	Having this connection via skin and muscle allows for great expansion of the gape and independent motion of the two sides—both advantages in swallowing big items.
7.29.387	The garter snake belongs to the genus Thamnophis, the most widely distributed reptile genus in North America.
7.29.388	Testudines Turtles are members of the clade Testudines (“having a shell”)
7.29.389	(Figure 29.29).
7.29.390	Turtles are characterized by a bony or cartilaginous shell.
7.29.391	The shell consists of the ventral surface called the plastron and the dorsal surface called the carapace, which develops from the ribs.
7.29.392	The plastron is made of scutes or plates; the scutes can be used to differentiate species of turtles.
7.29.393	The two clades of turtles are most easily recognized by how they retract their necks.
7.29.394	The dominant group, which includes all North American species, retracts its neck in a vertical S-curve.
7.29.395	Turtles in the less speciose clade retract the neck with a horizontal curve.
7.29.396	Turtles arose approximately 200 million years ago, predating crocodiles, lizards, and snakes.
7.29.397	Similar to other reptiles, turtles are ectotherms.
7.29.398	They lay eggs on land, although many species live in or near water.
7.29.399	None exhibit parental care.
7.29.400	Turtles range in size from the speckled padloper tortoise at 8 centimeters (3.1 inches) to the leatherback sea turtle at 200 centimeters (over 6 feet).
7.29.401	The term “turtle” is sometimes used to describe only those species of Testudines that live in the sea, with the terms “tortoise” and “terrapin” used to refer to species that live on land and in fresh water, respectively.
7.29.402	The African spurred tortoise (Geochelone sulcata) lives at the southern edge of the Sahara Desert.
7.29.403	It is the third largest tortoise in the world.
7.29.404	The most obvious characteristic that sets birds apart from other modern vertebrates is the presence of feathers, which are modified scales.
7.29.405	While vertebrates like bats fly without feathers, birds rely on feathers and wings, along with other modifications of body structure and physiology, for flight.
7.29.406	Characteristics of Birds Birds are endothermic, and because they fly, they require large amounts of energy, necessitating a high metabolic rate.
7.29.407	Like mammals, which are also endothermic, birds have an insulating covering that keeps heat in the body: feathers.
7.29.408	Specialized feathers called down feathers are especially insulating, trapping air in spaces between each feather to decrease the rate of heat loss.
7.29.409	Certain parts of a bird’s body are covered in down feathers, and the base of other feathers have a downy portion, whereas newly hatched birds are covered in down.
7.29.410	Feathers not only act as insulation but also allow for flight, enabling the lift and thrust necessary to become airborne.
7.29.411	The feathers on a wing are flexible, so the collective feathers move and separate as air moves through them, reducing the drag on the wing.
7.29.412	Flight feathers are asymmetrical, which affects airflow over them and provides some of the lifting and thrusting force required for flight (Figure 29.30).
7.29.413	Two types of flight feathers are found on the wings, primary feathers and secondary feathers.
7.29.414	Primary feathers are located at the tip of the wing and provide thrust.
7.29.415	Secondary feathers are located closer to the body, attach to the forearm portion of the wing and provide lift.
7.29.416	Contour feathers are the feathers found on the body, and they help reduce drag produced by wind resistance during flight.
7.29.417	They create a smooth, aerodynamic surface so that air moves smoothly over the bird’s body, allowing for efficient flight.
7.29.418	Primary feathers are located at the wing tip and provide thrust; secondary feathers are located close to the body and provide lift.
7.29.419	Flapping of the entire wing occurs primarily through the actions of the chest muscles, the pectoralis and the supracoracoideus.
7.29.420	These muscles are highly developed in birds and account for a higher percentage of body mass than in most mammals.
7.29.421	These attach to a blade-shaped keel, like that of a boat, located on the sternum.
7.29.422	The sternum of birds is larger than that of other vertebrates, which accommodates the large muscles required to generate enough upward force to generate lift with the flapping of the wings.
7.29.423	Another skeletal modification found in most birds is the fusion of the two clavicles (collarbones), forming the furcula or wishbone.
7.29.424	The furcula is flexible enough to bend and provide support to the shoulder girdle during flapping.
7.29.425	An important requirement of flight is a low body weight.
7.29.426	As body weight increases, the muscle output required for flying increases.
7.29.427	The largest living bird is the ostrich, and while it is much smaller than the largest mammals, it is flightless.
7.29.428	For birds that do fly, reduction in body weight makes flight easier.
7.29.429	Several modifications are found in birds to reduce body weight, including pneumatization of bones.
7.29.430	Pneumatic bones are bones that are hollow, rather than filled with tissue (Figure 29.31).
7.29.431	They contain air spaces that are sometimes connected to air sacs, and they have struts of bone to provide structural reinforcement.
7.29.432	Pneumatic bones are not found in all birds, and they are more extensive in large birds than in small birds.
7.29.433	Not all bones of the skeleton are pneumatic, although the skulls of almost all birds are.
7.29.434	Many birds have hollow, pneumatic bones, which make flight easier.
7.29.435	Other modifications that reduce weight include the lack of a urinary bladder.
7.29.436	Birds possess a cloaca, a structure that allows water to be reabsorbed from waste back into the bloodstream.
7.29.437	Uric acid is not expelled as a liquid but is concentrated into urate salts, which are expelled along with fecal matter.
7.29.438	In this way, water is not held in the urinary bladder, which would increase body weight.
7.29.439	Most bird species only possess one ovary rather than two, further reducing body mass.
7.29.440	The air sacs that extend into bones to form pneumatic bones also join with the lungs and function in respiration.
7.29.441	Unlike mammalian lungs in which air flows in two directions, as it is breathed in and out, airflow through bird lungs travels in one direction (Figure 29.32).
7.29.442	Air sacs allow for this unidirectional airflow, which also creates a cross-current exchange system with the blood.
7.29.443	In a cross-current or counter-current system, the air flows in one direction and the blood flows in the opposite direction, creating a very efficient means of gas exchange.
7.29.444	Avian respiration is an efficient system of gas exchange with air flowing unidirectionally.
7.29.445	During inhalation, air passes from the trachea into posterior air sacs, then through the lungs to anterior air sacs.
7.29.446	The air sacs are connected to the hollow interior of bones.
7.29.447	During exhalation, air from air sacs passes into the lungs and out the trachea.
7.29.448	Evolution of Birds
7.29.449	The evolutionary history of birds is still somewhat unclear.
7.29.450	Due to the fragility of bird bones, they do not fossilize as well as other vertebrates.
7.29.451	Birds are diapsids, meaning they have two fenestrations or openings in their skulls.
7.29.452	Birds belong to a group of diapsids called the archosaurs, which also includes crocodiles and dinosaurs.
7.29.453	It is commonly accepted that birds evolved from dinosaurs.
7.29.454	Dinosaurs (including birds) are further subdivided into two groups, the Saurischia (“lizard like”) and the Ornithischia (“bird like”).
7.29.455	Despite the names of these groups, it was not the bird-like dinosaurs that gave rise to modern birds.
7.29.456	Rather, Saurischia diverged into two groups: One included the long-necked herbivorous dinosaurs, such as Apatosaurus.
7.29.457	The second group, bipedal predators called theropods, includes birds.
7.29.458	This course of evolution is suggested by similarities between theropod fossils and birds, specifically in the structure of the hip and wrist bones, as well as the presence of the wishbone, formed by the fusing of the clavicles.
7.29.459	One important fossil of an animal intermediate to dinosaurs and birds is Archaeopteryx, which is from the Jurassic period (Figure 29.33).
7.29.460	Archaeopteryx is important in establishing the relationship between birds and dinosaurs, because it is an intermediate fossil, meaning it has characteristics of both dinosaurs and birds.
7.29.461	Some scientists propose classifying it as a bird, but others prefer to classify it as a dinosaur.
7.29.462	The fossilized skeleton of Archaeopteryx looks like that of a dinosaur, and it had teeth whereas birds do not, but it also had feathers modified for flight, a trait associated only with birds among modern animals.
7.29.463	Fossils of older feathered dinosaurs exist, but the feathers do not have the characteristics of flight feathers.
7.29.464	(a) Archaeopteryx lived in the late Jurassic Period around 150 million years ago.
7.29.465	It had teeth like a dinosaur, but had (b) flight feathers like modern birds, which can be seen in this fossil.
7.29.466	It is still unclear exactly how flight evolved in birds.
7.29.467	Two main theories exist, the arboreal (“tree”) hypothesis and the terrestrial (
7.29.468	“land”) hypothesis.
7.29.469	The arboreal hypothesis posits that tree-dwelling precursors to modern birds jumped from branch to branch using their feathers for gliding before becoming fully capable of flapping flight.
7.29.470	In contrast to this, the terrestrial hypothesis holds that running was the stimulus for flight, as wings could be used to improve running and then became used for flapping flight.
7.29.471	Like the question of how flight evolved, the question of how endothermy evolved in birds still is unanswered.
7.29.472	Feathers provide insulation, but this is only beneficial if body heat is being produced internally.
7.29.473	Similarly, internal heat production is only viable if insulation is present to retain that heat.
7.29.474	It has been suggested that one or the other—feathers or endothermy—evolved in response to some other selective pressure.
7.29.475	During the Cretaceous period, a group known as the Enantiornithes was the dominant bird type (Figure 29.34).
7.29.476	Enantiornithes means “opposite birds,” which refers to the fact that certain bones of the feet are joined differently than the way the bones are joined in modern birds.
7.29.477	These birds formed an evolutionary line separate from modern birds, and they did not survive past the Cretaceous.
7.29.478	Along with the Enantiornithes, Ornithurae birds (the evolutionary line that includes modern birds) were also present in the Cretaceous.
7.29.479	After the extinction of Enantiornithes, modern birds became the dominant bird, with a large radiation occurring during the Cenozoic Era.
7.29.480	Referred to as Neornithes (“new birds”), modern birds are now classified into two groups, the Paleognathae (“old jaw”) or ratites, a group of flightless birds including ostriches, emus, rheas, and kiwis, and the Neognathae (“new jaw”), which includes all other birds.
7.29.481	Shanweiniao cooperorum was a species of Enantiornithes that did not survive past the Cretaceous period.
7.29.482	Mammals are vertebrates that possess hair and mammary glands.
7.29.483	Several other characteristics are distinctive to mammals, including certain features of the jaw, skeleton, integument, and internal anatomy.
7.29.484	Modern mammals belong to three clades: monotremes, marsupials, and eutherians (or placental mammals).
7.29.485	Characteristics of Mammals
7.29.486	The presence of hair is one of the most obvious signs of a mammal.
7.29.487	Although it is not very extensive on certain species, such as whales, hair has many important functions for mammals.
7.29.488	Mammals are endothermic, and hair provides insulation to retain heat generated by metabolic work.
7.29.489	Hair traps a layer of air close to the body, retaining heat.
7.29.490	Along with insulation, hair can serve as a sensory mechanism via specialized hairs called vibrissae, better known as whiskers.
7.29.491	These attach to nerves that transmit information about sensation, which is particularly useful to nocturnal or burrowing mammals.
7.29.492	Hair can also provide protective coloration or be part of social signaling, such as when an animal’s hair stands “on end.
7.29.493	”
7.29.494	Mammalian integument, or skin, includes secretory glands with various functions.
7.29.495	Sebaceous glands produce a lipid mixture called sebum that is secreted onto the hair and skin for water resistance and lubrication.
7.29.496	Sebaceous glands are located over most of the body.
7.29.497	Eccrine glands produce sweat, or perspiration, which is mainly composed of water.
7.29.498	In most mammals, eccrine glands are limited to certain areas of the body, and some mammals do not possess them at all.
7.29.499	However, in primates, especially humans, sweat figures prominently in thermoregulation, regulating the body through evaporative cooling.
7.29.500	Sweat glands are located over most of the body surface in primates.
7.29.501	Apocrine glands, or scent glands, secrete substances that are used for chemical communication, such as in skunks.
7.29.502	Mammary glands produce milk that is used to feed newborns.
7.29.503	While male monotremes and eutherians possess mammary glands, male marsupials do not.
7.29.504	Mammary glands likely are modified sebaceous or eccrine glands, but their evolutionary origin is not entirely clear.
7.29.505	The skeletal system of mammals possesses many unique features.
7.29.506	The lower jaw of mammals consists of only one bone, the dentary.
7.29.507	The jaws of other vertebrates are composed of more than one bone.
7.29.508	In mammals, the dentary bone joins the skull at the squamosal bone, while in other vertebrates, the quadrate bone of the jaw joins with the articular bone of the skull.
7.29.509	These bones are present in mammals, but they have been modified to function in hearing and form bones in the middle ear (Figure 29.35).
7.29.510	Other vertebrates possess only one middle ear bone, the stapes.
7.29.511	Mammals have three: the malleus, incus, and stapes.
7.29.512	The malleus originated from the articular bone, whereas the incus originated from the quadrate bone.
7.29.513	This arrangement of jaw and ear bones aids in distinguishing fossil mammals from fossils of other synapsids.
7.29.514	Bones of the mammalian inner ear are modified from bones of the jaw and skull.
7.29.515	The adductor muscle that closes the jaw is composed of two muscles in mammals: the temporalis and the masseter.
7.29.516	These allow side-to-side movement of the jaw, making chewing possible, which is unique to mammals.
7.29.517	Most mammals have heterodont teeth, meaning that they have different types and shapes of teeth rather than just one type and shape of tooth.
7.29.518	Most mammals are diphyodonts, meaning that they have two sets of teeth in their lifetime: deciduous or “baby” teeth, and permanent teeth.
7.29.519	Other vertebrates are polyphyodonts, that is, their teeth are replaced throughout their entire life.
7.29.520	Mammals, like birds, possess a four-chambered heart.
7.29.521	Mammals also have a specialized group of cardiac fibers located in the walls of their right atrium called the sinoatrial node, or pacemaker, which determines the rate at which the heart beats.
7.29.522	Mammalian erythrocytes (red blood cells) do not have nuclei, whereas the erythrocytes of other vertebrates are nucleated.
7.29.523	The kidneys of mammals have a portion of the nephron called the loop of Henle or nephritic loop, which allows mammals to produce urine with a high concentration of solutes, higher than that of the blood.
7.29.524	Mammals lack a renal portal system, which is a system of veins that moves blood from the hind or lower limbs and region of the tail to the kidneys.
7.29.525	Renal portal systems are present in all other vertebrates except jawless fishes.
7.29.526	A urinary bladder is present in all mammals.
7.29.527	Mammalian brains have certain characteristics that differ from other vertebrates.
7.29.528	In some, but not all mammals, the cerebral cortex, the outermost part of the cerebrum, is highly folded, allowing for a greater surface area than is possible with a smooth cortex.
7.29.529	The optic lobes, located in the midbrain, are divided into two parts in mammals, whereas other vertebrates possess a single, undivided lobe.
7.29.530	Eutherian mammals also possess a specialized structure that links the two cerebral hemispheres, called the corpus callosum.
7.29.531	Evolution of Mammals Mammals are synapsids, meaning they have a single opening in the skull.
7.29.532	They are the only living synapsids, as earlier forms became extinct by the Jurassic period.
7.29.533	The early non-mammalian synapsids can be divided into two groups, the pelycosaurs and the therapsids.
7.29.534	Within the therapsids, a group called the cynodonts are thought to be the ancestors of mammals.
7.29.535	Cynodonts, which first appeared in the Late Permian period 260 million years ago, are thought to be the ancestors of modern mammals.
7.29.536	A key characteristic of synapsids is endothermy, rather than the ectothermy seen in most other vertebrates.
7.29.537	The increased metabolic rate required to internally modify body temperature went hand in hand with changes to certain skeletal structures.
7.29.538	The later synapsids, which had more evolved characteristics unique to mammals, possess cheeks for holding food and heterodont teeth, which are specialized for chewing, mechanically breaking down food to speed digestion and releasing the energy needed to produce heat.
7.29.539	Chewing also requires the ability to chew and breathe at the same time, which is facilitated by the presence of a secondary palate.
7.29.540	A secondary palate separates the area of the mouth where chewing occurs from the area above where respiration occurs, allowing breathing to proceed uninterrupted during chewing.
7.29.541	A secondary palate is not found in pelycosaurs but is present in cynodonts and mammals.
7.29.542	The jawbone also shows changes from early synapsids to later ones.
7.29.543	The zygomatic arch, or cheekbone, is present in mammals and advanced therapsids such as cynodonts, but is not present in pelycosaurs.
7.29.544	The presence of the zygomatic arch suggests the presence of the masseter muscle, which closes the jaw and functions in chewing.
7.29.545	In the appendicular skeleton, the shoulder girdle of therian mammals is modified from that of other vertebrates in that it does not possess a procoracoid bone or an interclavicle, and the scapula is the dominant bone.
7.29.546	Mammals evolved from therapsids in the late Triassic period, as the earliest known mammal fossils are from the early Jurassic period, some 205 million years ago.
7.29.547	Early mammals were small, about the size of a small rodent.
7.29.548	Mammals first began to diversify in the Mesozoic Era, from the Jurassic to the Cretaceous periods, although most of these mammals were extinct by the end of the Mesozoic.
