7.29.549	During the Cretaceous period, another radiation of mammals began and continued through the Cenozoic Era, about 65 million years ago.
7.29.550	Living Mammals
7.29.551	The eutherians, or placental mammals, and the marsupials together comprise the clade of therian mammals.
7.29.552	Monotremes, or metatherians, form their sister clade.
7.29.553	There are three living species of monotremes: the platypus and two species of echidnas, or spiny anteaters.
7.29.554	The leatherybeaked platypus belongs to the family Ornithorhynchidae (“bird beak”), whereas echidnas belong to the family
7.29.555	Tachyglossidae (“sticky tongue”)
7.29.556	(Figure 29.37).
7.29.557	The platypus and one species of echidna are found in Australia, and the other species of echidna is found in New Guinea.
7.29.558	Monotremes are unique among mammals as they lay eggs, rather than giving birth to live young.
7.29.559	The shells of their eggs are not like the hard shells of birds, but are a leathery shell, similar to the shells of reptile eggs.
7.29.560	Monotremes have no teeth.
7.29.561	(a)
7.29.562	The platypus, a monotreme, possesses a leathery beak and lays eggs rather than giving birth to live young.
7.29.563	(b)
7.29.564	The echidna is another monotreme.
7.29.565	Marsupials are found primarily in Australia, though the opossum is found in North America.
7.29.566	Australian marsupials include the kangaroo, koala, bandicoot, Tasmanian devil (Figure 29.38), and several other species.
7.29.567	Most species of marsupials possess a pouch in which the very premature young reside after birth, receiving milk and continuing to develop.
7.29.568	Marsupials differ from eutherians in that there is a less complex placental connection: The young are born at an extremely early age and latch onto the nipple within the pouch.
7.29.569	The Tasmanian devil is one of several marsupials native to Australia.
7.29.570	Eutherians are the most widespread of the mammals, occurring throughout the world.
7.29.571	There are 18 to 20 orders of placental mammals.
7.29.572	Some examples are Insectivora, the insect eaters; Edentata, the toothless anteaters; Rodentia, the rodents; Cetacea, the aquatic mammals including whales; Carnivora, carnivorous mammals including dogs, cats, and bears; and Primates, which includes humans.
7.29.573	Eutherian mammals are sometimes called placental mammals because all species possess a complex placenta that connects a fetus to the mother, allowing for gas, fluid, and nutrient exchange.
7.29.574	While other mammals possess a less complex placenta or briefly have a placenta, all eutherians possess a complex placenta during gestation.
7.29.575	Order Primates of class Mammalia includes lemurs, tarsiers, monkeys, apes, and humans.
7.29.576	Non-human primates live primarily in the tropical or subtropical regions of South America, Africa, and Asia.
7.29.577	They range in size from the mouse lemur at 30 grams (1 ounce) to the mountain gorilla at 200 kilograms (441 pounds).
7.29.578	The characteristics and evolution of primates is of particular interest to us as it allows us to understand the evolution of our own species.
7.29.579	Characteristics of Primates
7.29.580	All primate species possess adaptations for climbing trees, as they all descended from tree-dwellers.
7.29.581	This arboreal heritage of primates has resulted in hands and feet that are adapted for brachiation, or climbing and swinging through trees.
7.29.582	These adaptations include, but are not limited to: 1) a rotating shoulder joint, 2) a big toe that is widely separated from the other toes and thumbs, which are widely separated from fingers (except humans), which allow for gripping branches, 3) stereoscopic vision, two overlapping fields of vision from the eyes, which allows for the perception of depth and gauging distance.
7.29.583	Other characteristics of primates are brains that are larger than those of most other mammals, claws that have been modified into flattened nails, typically only one offspring per pregnancy, and a trend toward holding the body upright.
7.29.584	Order Primates is divided into two groups: prosimians and anthropoids.
7.29.585	Prosimians include the bush babies of Africa, the lemurs of Madagascar, and the lorises, pottos, and tarsiers of Southeast Asia.
7.29.586	Anthropoids include monkeys, apes, and humans.
7.29.587	In general, prosimians tend to be nocturnal (in contrast to diurnal anthropoids) and exhibit a smaller size and smaller brain than anthropoids.
7.29.588	Evolution of Primates
7.29.589	The first primate-like mammals are referred to as proto-primates.
7.29.590	They were roughly similar to squirrels and tree shrews in size and appearance.
7.29.591	The existing fossil evidence (mostly from North Africa) is very fragmented.
7.29.592	These proto-primates remain largely mysterious creatures until more fossil evidence becomes available.
7.29.593	The oldest known primate-like mammals with a relatively robust fossil record is Plesiadapis (although some researchers do not agree that Plesiadapis was a protoprimate).
7.29.594	Fossils of this primate have been dated to approximately 55 million years ago.
7.29.595	Plesiadapiforms were protoprimates that had some features of the teeth and skeleton in common with true primates.
7.29.596	They were found in North America and Europe in the Cenozoic and went extinct by the end of the Eocene.
7.29.597	The first true primates were found in North America, Europe, Asia, and Africa in the Eocene Epoch.
7.29.598	These early primates resembled present-day prosimians such as lemurs.
7.29.599	Evolutionary changes continued in these early primates, with larger brains and eyes, and smaller muzzles being the trend.
7.29.600	By the end of the Eocene Epoch, many of the early prosimian species went extinct due either to cooler temperatures or competition from the first monkeys.
7.29.601	Anthropoid monkeys evolved from prosimians during the Oligocene Epoch.
7.29.602	By 40 million years ago, evidence indicates that monkeys were present in the New World (South America) and the Old World (Africa and Asia).
7.29.603	New World monkeys are also called Platyrrhini—a reference to their broad noses (Figure 29.39).
7.29.604	Old World monkeys are called Catarrhini—a reference to their narrow noses.
7.29.605	There is still quite a bit of uncertainty about the origins of the New World monkeys.
7.29.606	At the time the platyrrhines arose, the continents of South American and Africa had drifted apart.
7.29.607	Therefore, it is thought that monkeys arose in the Old World and reached the New World either by drifting on log rafts or by crossing land bridges.
7.29.608	Due to this reproductive isolation, New World monkeys and Old World monkeys underwent separate adaptive radiations over millions of years.
7.29.609	The New World monkeys are all arboreal, whereas Old World monkeys include arboreal and grounddwelling species.
7.29.610	The howler monkey is native to Central and South America.
7.29.611	It makes a call that sounds like a lion roaring.
7.29.612	Apes evolved from the catarrhines in Africa midway through the Cenozoic, approximately 25 million years ago.
7.29.613	Apes are generally larger than monkeys and they do not possess a tail.
7.29.614	All apes are capable of moving through trees, although many species spend most their time on the ground.
7.29.615	Apes are more intelligent than monkeys, and they have relatively larger brains proportionate to body size.
7.29.616	The apes are divided into two groups.
7.29.617	The lesser apes comprise the family Hylobatidae, including gibbons and siamangs.
7.29.618	The great apes include the genera Pan (chimpanzees and bonobos) (Figure 29.40a), Gorilla (gorillas), Pongo (orangutans), and Homo (humans)
7.29.619	(Figure 29.40b).
7.29.620	The very arboreal gibbons are smaller than the great apes; they have low sexual dimorphism (that is, the genders are not markedly different in size); and they have relatively longer arms used for swinging through trees.
7.29.621	The (a) chimpanzee is one of the great apes.
7.29.622	It possesses a relatively large brain and has no tail.
7.29.623	(b)
7.29.624	All great apes have a similar skeletal structure.
7.29.625	Human Evolution
7.29.626	The family Hominidae of order Primates includes the hominoids: the great apes (Figure 29.41).
7.29.627	Evidence from the fossil record and from a comparison of human and chimpanzee DNA suggests that humans and chimpanzees diverged from a common hominoid ancestor approximately 6 million years ago.
7.29.628	Several species evolved from the evolutionary branch that includes humans, although our species is the only surviving member.
7.29.629	The term hominin is used to refer to those species that evolved after this split of the primate line, thereby designating species that are more closely related to humans than to chimpanzees.
7.29.630	Hominins were predominantly bipedal and include those groups that likely gave rise to our species—including Australopithecus, Homo habilis, and Homo erectus—and those non-ancestral groups that can be considered “cousins” of modern humans, such as Neanderthals.
7.29.631	Determining the true lines of descent in hominins is difficult.
7.29.632	In years past, when relatively few hominin fossils had been recovered, some scientists believed that considering them in order, from oldest to youngest, would demonstrate the course of evolution from early hominins to modern humans.
7.29.633	In the past several years, however, many new fossils have been found, and it is clear that there was often more than one species alive at any one time and that many of the fossils found (and species named) represent hominin species that died out and are not ancestral to modern humans.
7.29.634	This chart shows the evolution of modern humans.
7.29.635	Very Early Hominins Three species of very early hominids have made news in the past few years.
7.29.636	The oldest of these, Sahelanthropus tchadensis, has been dated to nearly 7 million years ago.
7.29.637	There is a single specimen of this genus, a skull that was a surface find in Chad.
7.29.638	The fossil, informally called “Toumai,” is a mosaic of primitive and evolved characteristics, and it is unclear how this fossil fits with the picture given by molecular data, namely that the line leading to modern humans and modern chimpanzees apparently bifurcated about 6 million years ago.
7.29.639	It is not thought at this time that this species was an ancestor of modern humans.
7.29.640	A second, younger species, Orrorin tugenensis, is also a relatively recent discovery, found in 2000.
7.29.641	There are several specimens of Orrorin.
7.29.642	It is not known whether Orrorin was a human ancestor, but this possibility has not been ruled out.
7.29.643	Some features of Orrorin are more similar to those of modern humans than are the australopiths, although Orrorin is much older.
7.29.644	A third genus, Ardipithecus, was discovered in the 1990s, and the scientists who discovered the first fossil found that some other scientists did not believe the organism to be a biped (thus, it would not be considered a hominid).
7.29.645	In the intervening years, several more specimens of Ardipithecus, classified as two different species, demonstrated that the organism was bipedal.
7.29.646	Again, the status of this genus as a human ancestor is uncertain.
7.29.647	Early Hominins:
7.29.648	Genus Australopithecus Australopithecus (“southern ape”) is a genus of hominin that evolved in eastern Africa approximately 4 million years ago and went extinct about 2 million years ago.
7.29.649	This genus is of particular interest to us as it is thought that our genus, genus Homo, evolved from Australopithecus about 2 million years ago (after likely passing through some transitional states).
7.29.650	Australopithecus had a number of characteristics that were more similar to the great apes than to modern humans.
7.29.651	For example, sexual dimorphism was more exaggerated than in modern humans.
7.29.652	Males were up to 50 percent larger than females, a ratio that is similar to that seen in modern gorillas and orangutans.
7.29.653	In contrast, modern human males are approximately 15 to 20 percent larger than females.
7.29.654	The brain size of Australopithecus relative to its body mass was also smaller than modern humans and more similar to that seen in the great apes.
7.29.655	A key feature that Australopithecus had in common with modern humans was bipedalism, although it is likely that Australopithecus also spent time in trees.
7.29.656	Hominin footprints, similar to those of modern humans, were found in Laetoli, Tanzania and dated to 3.6 million years ago.
7.29.657	They showed that hominins at the time of Australopithecus were walking upright.
7.29.658	There were a number of Australopithecus species, which are often referred to as australopiths.
7.29.659	Australopithecus anamensis lived about 4.2 million years ago.
7.29.660	More is known about another early species, Australopithecus afarensis, which lived between 3.9 and 2.9 million years ago.
7.29.661	This species demonstrates a trend in human evolution: the reduction of the dentition and jaw in size.
7.29.662	A. afarensis (Figure 29.42) had smaller canines and molars compared to apes, but these were larger than those of modern humans.
7.29.663	Its brain size was 380–450 cubic centimeters, approximately the size of a modern chimpanzee brain.
7.29.664	It also had prognathic jaws, which is a relatively longer jaw than that of modern humans.
7.29.665	In the mid-1970s, the fossil of an adult female A. afarensis was found in the Afar region of Ethiopia and dated to 3.24 million years ago (Figure 29.43).
7.29.666	The fossil, which is informally called “Lucy,” is significant because it was the most complete australopith fossil found, with 40 percent of the skeleton recovered.
7.29.667	The skull of (a) Australopithecus afarensis, an early hominid that lived between two and three million years ago, resembled that of (b) modern humans but was smaller with a sloped forehead and prominent jaw.
7.29.668	This adult female Australopithecus afarensis skeleton, nicknamed Lucy, was discovered in the mid 1970s.
7.29.669	Australopithecus africanus lived between 2 and 3 million years ago.
7.29.670	It had a slender build and was bipedal, but had robust arm bones and, like other early hominids, may have spent significant time in trees.
7.29.671	Its brain was larger than that of A. afarensis at 500 cubic centimeters, which is slightly less than one-third the size of modern human brains.
7.29.672	Two other species, Australopithecus bahrelghazali and Australopithecus garhi, have been added to the roster of australopiths in recent years.
7.29.673	A Dead End: Genus Paranthropus
7.29.674	The australopiths had a relatively slender build and teeth that were suited for soft food.
7.29.675	In the past several years, fossils of hominids of a different body type have been found and dated to approximately 2.5 million years ago.
7.29.676	These hominids, of the genus Paranthropus, were relatively large and had large grinding teeth.
7.29.677	Their molars showed heavy wear, suggesting that they had a coarse and fibrous vegetarian diet as opposed to the partially carnivorous diet of the australopiths.
7.29.678	Paranthropus includes Paranthropus robustus of South Africa, and Paranthropus aethiopicus and Paranthropus boisei of East Africa.
7.29.679	The hominids in this genus went extinct more than 1 million years ago and are not thought to be ancestral to modern humans, but rather members of an evolutionary branch on the hominin tree that left no descendants.
7.29.680	Early Hominins:
7.29.681	Genus Homo
7.29.682	The human genus, Homo, first appeared between 2.5 and 3 million years ago.
7.29.683	For many years, fossils of a species called H. habilis were the oldest examples in the genus Homo, but in 2010, a new species called Homo gautengensis was discovered and may be older.
7.29.684	Compared to A. africanus, H. habilis had a number of features more similar to modern humans.
7.29.685	H. habilis had a jaw that was less prognathic than the australopiths and a larger brain, at 600–750 cubic centimeters.
7.29.686	However, H. habilis retained some features of older hominin species, such as long arms.
7.29.687	The name H. habilis means “handy man,” which is a reference to the stone tools that have been found with its remains.
7.29.688	H. erectus appeared approximately 1.8 million years ago (Figure 29.44).
7.29.689	It is believed to have originated in East Africa and was the first hominin species to migrate out of Africa.
7.29.690	Fossils of H. erectus have been found in India, China, Java, and Europe, and were known in the past as “
7.29.691	Java Man” or “Peking Man.
7.29.692	” H. erectus had a number of features that were more similar to modern humans than those of H. habilis.
7.29.693	H. erectus was larger in size than earlier hominins, reaching heights up to 1.85 meters and weighing up to 65 kilograms, which are sizes similar to those of modern humans.
7.29.694	Its degree of sexual dimorphism was less than earlier species, with males being 20 to 30 percent larger than females, which is close to the size difference seen in our species.
7.29.695	H. erectus had a larger brain than earlier species at 775–1,100 cubic centimeters, which compares to the 1,130–1,260 cubic centimeters seen in modern human brains.
7.29.696	H. erectus also had a nose with downward-facing nostrils similar to modern humans, rather than the forward facing nostrils found in other primates.
7.29.697	Longer, downward-facing nostrils allow for the warming of cold air before it enters the lungs and may have been an adaptation to colder climates.
7.29.698	Artifacts found with fossils of H. erectus suggest that it was the first hominin to use fire, hunt, and have a home base.
7.29.699	H. erectus is generally thought to have lived until about 50,000 years ago.
7.29.700	Homo erectus had a prominent brow and a nose that pointed downward rather than forward.
7.29.701	Humans:
7.29.702	Homo sapiens A number of species, sometimes called archaic Homo sapiens, apparently evolved from H. erectus starting about 500,000 years ago.
7.29.703	These species include Homo heidelbergensis, Homo rhodesiensis, and Homo neanderthalensis.
7.29.704	These archaic H. sapiens had a brain size similar to that of modern humans, averaging 1,200–1,400 cubic centimeters.
7.29.705	They differed from modern humans by having a thick skull, a prominent brow ridge, and a receding chin.
7.29.706	Some of these species survived until 30,000–10,000 years ago, overlapping with modern humans.
7.29.707	The Homo neanderthalensis used tools and may have worn clothing.
7.29.708	There is considerable debate about the origins of anatomically modern humans or Homo sapiens sapiens.
7.29.709	As discussed earlier, H. erectus migrated out of Africa and into Asia and Europe in the first major wave of migration about 1.5 million years ago.
7.29.710	It is thought that modern humans arose in Africa from H. erectus and migrated out of Africa about 100,000 years ago in a second major migration wave.
7.29.711	Then, modern humans replaced H. erectus species that had migrated into Asia and Europe in the first wave.
7.29.712	This evolutionary timeline is supported by molecular evidence.
7.29.713	One approach to studying the origins of modern humans is to examine mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA) from populations around the world.
7.29.714	Because a fetus develops from an egg containing its mother’s mitochondria (which have their own, non-nuclear DNA), mtDNA is passed entirely through the maternal line.
7.29.715	Mutations in mtDNA can now be used to estimate the timeline of genetic divergence.
7.29.716	The resulting evidence suggests that all modern humans have mtDNA inherited from a common ancestor that lived in Africa about 160,000 years ago.
7.29.717	Another approach to the molecular understanding of human evolution is to examine the Y chromosome, which is passed from father to son.
7.29.718	This evidence suggests that all men today inherited a Y chromosome from a male that lived in Africa about 140,000 years ago.
7.30.0	A locust leaf consists of leaflets arrayed along a central midrib.
7.30.1	Each leaflet is a complex photosynthetic machine, exquisitely adapted to capture sunlight and carbon dioxide.
7.30.2	An intricate vascular system supplies the leaf with water and minerals, and exports the products of photosynthesis.
7.30.3	Plants are as essential to human existence as land, water, and air.
7.30.4	Without plants, our day-to-day lives would be impossible because without oxygen from photosynthesis, aerobic life cannot be sustained.
7.30.5	From providing food and shelter to serving as a source of medicines, oils, perfumes, and industrial products, plants provide humans with numerous valuable resources.
7.30.6	When you think of plants, most of the organisms that come to mind are vascular plants.
7.30.7	These plants have tissues that conduct food and water, and they have seeds.
7.30.8	Seed plants are divided into gymnosperms and angiosperms.
7.30.9	Gymnosperms include the needle-leaved conifers—spruce, fir, and pine—as well as less familiar plants, such as ginkgos and cycads.
7.30.10	Their seeds are not enclosed by a fleshy fruit.
7.30.11	Angiosperms, also called flowering plants, constitute the majority of seed plants.
7.30.12	They include broadleaved trees (such as maple, oak, and elm), vegetables (such as potatoes, lettuce, and carrots), grasses, and plants known for the beauty of their flowers (roses, irises, and daffodils, for example).
7.30.13	While individual plant species are unique, all share a common structure: a plant body consisting of stems, roots, and leaves.
7.30.14	They all transport water, minerals, and sugars produced through photosynthesis through the plant body in a similar manner.
7.30.15	All plant species also respond to environmental factors, such as light, gravity, competition, temperature, and predation.
7.30.16	The Plant Body
7.30.17	By the end of this section, you will be able to: Describe the shoot organ system and the root organ system Distinguish between meristematic tissue and permanent tissue Identify and describe the three regions where plant growth occurs Summarize the roles of dermal tissue, vascular tissue, and ground tissue Compare simple plant tissue with complex plant tissue
7.30.18	Like animals, plants contain cells with organelles in which specific metabolic activities take place.
7.30.19	Unlike animals, however, plants use energy from sunlight to form sugars during photosynthesis.
7.30.20	In addition, plant cells have cell walls, plastids, and a large central vacuole: structures that are not found in animal cells.
7.30.21	Each of these cellular structures plays a specific role in plant structure and function.
7.30.22	Plant Organ Systems
7.30.23	In plants, just as in animals, similar cells working together form a tissue.
7.30.24	When different types of tissues work together to perform a unique function, they form an organ; organs working together form organ systems.
7.30.25	Vascular plants have two distinct organ systems: a shoot system, and a root system.
7.30.26	The shoot system consists of two portions: the vegetative (nonreproductive) parts of the plant, such as the leaves and the stems, and the reproductive parts of the plant, which include flowers and fruits.
7.30.27	The shoot system generally grows above ground, where it absorbs the light needed for photosynthesis.
7.30.28	The root system, which supports the plants and absorbs water and minerals, is usually underground.
7.30.29	Figure 30.2 shows the organ systems of a typical plant.
7.30.30	The shoot system of a plant consists of leaves, stems, flowers, and fruits.
7.30.31	The root system anchors the plant while absorbing water and minerals from the soil.
7.30.32	Plant Tissues Plants are multicellular eukaryotes with tissue systems made of various cell types that carry out specific functions.
7.30.33	Plant tissue systems fall into one of two general types: meristematic tissue, and permanent (or non-meristematic) tissue.
7.30.34	Cells of the meristematic tissue are found in meristems, which are plant regions of continuous cell division and growth.
7.30.35	Meristematic tissue cells are either undifferentiated or incompletely differentiated, and they continue to divide and contribute to the growth of the plant.
7.30.36	In contrast, permanent tissue consists of plant cells that are no longer actively dividing.
7.30.37	Meristematic tissues consist of three types, based on their location in the plant.
7.30.38	Apical meristems contain meristematic tissue located at the tips of stems and roots, which enable a plant to extend in length.
7.30.39	Lateral meristems facilitate growth in thickness or girth in a maturing plant.
7.30.40	Intercalary meristems occur only in monocots, at the bases of leaf blades and at nodes (the areas where leaves attach to a stem).
7.30.41	This tissue enables the monocot leaf blade to increase in length from the leaf base; for example, it allows lawn grass leaves to elongate even after repeated mowing.
7.30.42	Meristems produce cells that quickly differentiate, or specialize, and become permanent tissue.
7.30.43	Such cells take on specific roles and lose their ability to divide further.
7.30.44	They differentiate into three main types: dermal, vascular, and ground tissue.
7.30.45	Dermal tissue covers and protects the plant, and vascular tissue transports water, minerals, and sugars to different parts of the plant.
7.30.46	Ground tissue serves as a site for photosynthesis, provides a supporting matrix for the vascular tissue, and helps to store water and sugars.
7.30.47	Secondary tissues are either simple (composed of similar cell types) or complex (composed of different cell types).
7.30.48	Dermal tissue, for example, is a simple tissue that covers the outer surface of the plant and controls gas exchange.
7.30.49	Vascular tissue is an example of a complex tissue, and is made of two specialized conducting tissues: xylem and phloem.
7.30.50	Xylem tissue transports water and nutrients from the roots to different parts of the plant, and includes three different cell types: vessel elements and tracheids (both of which conduct water), and xylem parenchyma.
7.30.51	Phloem tissue, which transports organic compounds from the site of photosynthesis to other parts of the plant, consists of four different cell types: sieve cells (which conduct photosynthates), companion cells, phloem parenchyma, and phloem fibers.
7.30.52	Unlike xylem conducting cells, phloem conducting cells are alive at maturity.
7.30.53	The xylem and phloem always lie adjacent to each other (Figure 30.3).
7.30.54	In stems, the xylem and the phloem form a structure called a vascular bundle; in roots, this is termed the vascular stele or vascular cylinder.
7.30.55	This light micrograph shows a cross section of a squash (Curcurbita maxima) stem.
7.30.56	Each teardrop-shaped vascular bundle consists of large xylem vessels toward the inside and smaller phloem cells toward the outside.
7.30.57	Xylem cells, which transport water and nutrients from the roots to the rest of the plant, are dead at functional maturity.
7.30.58	Phloem cells, which transport sugars and other organic compounds from photosynthetic tissue to the rest of the plant, are living.
7.30.59	The vascular bundles are encased in ground tissue and surrounded by dermal tissue.
7.30.60	Stems
7.30.61	By the end of this section, you will be able to: Describe the main function and basic structure of stems Compare and contrast the roles of dermal tissue, vascular tissue, and ground tissue Distinguish between primary growth and secondary growth in stems Summarize the origin of annual rings List and describe examples of modified
7.30.62	stems
7.30.63	Stems are a part of the shoot system of a plant.
7.30.64	They may range in length from a few millimeters to hundreds of meters, and also vary in diameter, depending on the plant type.
7.30.65	Stems are usually above ground, although the stems of some plants, such as the potato, also grow underground.
7.30.66	Stems may be herbaceous (soft) or woody in nature.
7.30.67	Their main function is to provide support to the plant, holding leaves, flowers and buds; in some cases, stems also store food for the plant.
7.30.68	A stem may be unbranched, like that of a palm tree, or it may be highly branched, like that of a magnolia tree.
7.30.69	The stem of the plant connects the roots to the leaves, helping to transport absorbed water and minerals to different parts of the plant.
7.30.70	It also helps to transport the products of photosynthesis, namely sugars, from the leaves to the rest of the plant.
7.30.71	Plant stems, whether above or below ground, are characterized by the presence of nodes and internodes (Figure 30.4).
7.30.72	Nodes are points of attachment for leaves, aerial roots, and flowers.
7.30.73	The stem region between two nodes is called an internode.
7.30.74	The stalk that extends from the stem to the base of the leaf is the petiole.
7.30.75	An axillary bud is usually found in the axil—the area between the base of a leaf and the stem—where it can give rise to a branch or a flower.
7.30.76	The apex (tip) of the shoot contains the apical meristem within the apical bud.
7.30.77	Leaves are attached to the plant stem at areas called nodes.
7.30.78	An internode is the stem region between two nodes.
7.30.79	The petiole is the stalk connecting the leaf to the stem.
7.30.80	The leaves just above the nodes arose from axillary buds.
7.30.81	Stem Anatomy
7.30.82	The stem and other plant organs arise from the ground tissue, and are primarily made up of simple tissues formed from three types of cells: parenchyma, collenchyma, and sclerenchyma cells.
7.30.83	Parenchyma cells are the most common plant cells (Figure 30.5).
7.30.84	They are found in the stem, the root, the inside of the leaf, and the pulp of the fruit.
7.30.85	Parenchyma cells are responsible for metabolic functions, such as photosynthesis, and they help repair and heal wounds.
7.30.86	Some parenchyma cells also store starch.
7.30.87	The stem of common St John's Wort (Hypericum perforatum) is shown in cross section in this light micrograph.
7.30.88	The central pith (greenish-blue, in the center) and peripheral cortex (narrow zone 3–5 cells thick just inside the epidermis) are composed of parenchyma cells.
7.30.89	Vascular tissue composed of xylem (red) and phloem tissue (green, between the xylem and cortex) surrounds the pith.
7.30.90	Collenchyma cells are elongated cells with unevenly thickened walls (Figure 30.6).
7.30.91	They provide structural support, mainly to the stem and leaves.
7.30.92	These cells are alive at maturity and are usually found below the epidermis.
7.30.93	The “strings” of a celery stalk are an example of collenchyma cells.
7.30.94	Collenchyma cell walls are uneven in thickness, as seen in this light micrograph.
7.30.95	They provide support to plant structures.
7.30.96	Sclerenchyma cells also provide support to the plant, but unlike collenchyma cells, many of them are dead at maturity.
7.30.97	There are two types of sclerenchyma cells: fibers and sclereids.
7.30.98	Both types have secondary cell walls that are thickened with deposits of lignin, an organic compound that is a key component of wood.
7.30.99	Fibers are long, slender cells; sclereids are smaller-sized.
7.30.100	Sclereids give pears their gritty texture.
7.30.101	Humans use sclerenchyma fibers to make linen and rope.
7.30.102	Like the rest of the plant, the stem has three tissue systems: dermal, vascular, and ground tissue.
7.30.103	Each is distinguished by characteristic cell types that perform specific tasks necessary for the plant’s growth and survival.
7.30.104	Dermal Tissue
7.30.105	The dermal tissue of the stem consists primarily of epidermis, a single layer of cells covering and protecting the underlying tissue.
7.30.106	Woody plants have a tough, waterproof outer layer of cork cells commonly known as bark, which further protects the plant from damage.
7.30.107	Epidermal cells are the most numerous and least differentiated of the cells in the epidermis.
7.30.108	The epidermis of a leaf also contains openings known as stomata, through which the exchange of gases takes place (Figure 30.8).
7.30.109	Two cells, known as guard cells, surround each leaf stoma, controlling its opening and closing and thus regulating the uptake of carbon dioxide and the release of oxygen and water vapor.
7.30.110	Trichomes are hair-like structures on the epidermal surface.
7.30.111	They help to reduce transpiration (the loss of water by aboveground plant parts), increase solar reflectance, and store compounds that defend the leaves against predation by herbivores.
7.30.112	Openings called stomata (singular: stoma) allow a plant to take up carbon dioxide and release oxygen and water vapor.
7.30.113	The (a) colorized scanning-electron micrograph shows a closed stoma of a dicot.
7.30.114	Each stoma is flanked by two guard cells that regulate its (b) opening and closing.
7.30.115	The (c) guard cells sit within the layer of epidermal cells.
7.30.116	Vascular Tissue
7.30.117	The xylem and phloem that make up the vascular tissue of the stem are arranged in distinct strands called vascular bundles, which run up and down the length of the stem.
7.30.118	When the stem is viewed in cross section, the vascular bundles of dicot stems are arranged in a ring.
7.30.119	In plants with stems that live for more than one year, the individual bundles grow together and produce the characteristic growth rings.
7.30.120	In monocot stems, the vascular bundles are randomly scattered throughout the ground tissue.
7.30.121	In (a) dicot stems, vascular bundles are arranged around the periphery of the ground tissue.
7.30.122	The xylem tissue is located toward the interior of the vascular bundle, and phloem is located toward the exterior.
7.30.123	Sclerenchyma fibers cap the vascular bundles.
7.30.124	In (b) monocot stems, vascular bundles composed of xylem and phloem tissues are scattered throughout the ground tissue.
7.30.125	Xylem tissue has three types of cells: xylem parenchyma, tracheids, and vessel elements.
7.30.126	The latter two types conduct water and are dead at maturity.
7.30.127	Tracheids are xylem cells with thick secondary cell walls that are lignified.
7.30.128	Water moves from one tracheid to another through regions on the side walls known as pits, where secondary walls are absent.
7.30.129	Vessel elements are xylem cells with thinner walls; they are shorter than tracheids.
7.30.130	Each vessel element is connected to the next by means of a perforation plate at the end walls of the element.
7.30.131	Water moves through the perforation plates to travel up the plant.
7.30.132	Phloem tissue is composed of sieve-tube cells, companion cells, phloem parenchyma, and phloem fibers.
7.30.133	A series of sievetube cells (also called sieve-tube elements) are arranged end to end to make up a long sieve tube, which transports organic substances such as sugars and amino acids.
7.30.134	The sugars flow from one sieve-tube cell to the next through perforated sieve plates, which are found at the end junctions between two cells.
7.30.135	Although still alive at maturity, the nucleus and other cell components of the sieve-tube cells have disintegrated.
7.30.136	Companion cells are found alongside the sieve-tube cells, providing them with metabolic support.
7.30.137	The companion cells contain more ribosomes and mitochondria than the sieve-tube cells, which lack some cellular organelles.
7.30.138	Ground Tissue Ground tissue is mostly made up of parenchyma cells, but may also contain collenchyma and sclerenchyma cells that help support the stem.
7.30.139	The ground tissue towards the interior of the vascular tissue in a stem or root is known as pith, while the layer of tissue between the vascular tissue and the epidermis is known as the cortex.
7.30.140	Growth in Stems Growth in plants occurs as the stems and roots lengthen.
7.30.141	Some plants, especially those that are woody, also increase in thickness during their life span.
7.30.142	The increase in length of the shoot and the root is referred to as primary growth, and is the result of cell division in the shoot apical meristem.
7.30.143	Secondary growth is characterized by an increase in thickness or girth of the plant, and is caused by cell division in the lateral meristem.
7.30.144	Figure 30.10 shows the areas of primary and secondary growth in a plant.
7.30.145	Herbaceous plants mostly undergo primary growth, with hardly any secondary growth or increase in thickness.
7.30.146	Secondary growth or “wood” is noticeable in woody plants; it occurs in some dicots, but occurs very rarely in monocots.
7.30.147	In woody plants, primary growth is followed by secondary growth, which allows the plant stem to increase in thickness or girth.
7.30.148	Secondary vascular tissue is added as the plant grows, as well as a cork layer.
7.30.149	The bark of a tree extends from the vascular cambium to the epidermis.
7.30.150	Some plant parts, such as stems and roots, continue to grow throughout a plant’s life: a phenomenon called indeterminate growth.
7.30.151	Other plant parts, such as leaves and flowers, exhibit determinate growth, which ceases when a plant part reaches a particular size.
7.30.152	Primary Growth
7.30.153	Most primary growth occurs at the apices, or tips, of stems and roots.
7.30.154	Primary growth is a result of rapidly dividing cells in the apical meristems at the shoot tip and root tip.
7.30.155	Subsequent cell elongation also contributes to primary growth.
7.30.156	The growth of shoots and roots during primary growth enables plants to continuously seek water (roots) or sunlight (shoots).
7.30.157	The influence of the apical bud on overall plant growth is known as apical dominance, which diminishes the growth of axillary buds that form along the sides of branches and stems.
7.30.158	Most coniferous trees exhibit strong apical dominance, thus producing the typical conical Christmas tree shape.
7.30.159	If the apical bud is removed, then the axillary buds will start forming lateral branches.
7.30.160	Gardeners make use of this fact when they prune plants by cutting off the tops of branches, thus encouraging the axillary buds to grow out, giving the plant a bushy shape.
7.30.161	Secondary Growth
7.30.162	The increase in stem thickness that results from secondary growth is due to the activity of the lateral meristems, which are lacking in herbaceous plants.
7.30.163	Lateral meristems include the vascular cambium and, in woody plants, the cork cambium (see Figure 30.10).
7.30.164	The vascular cambium is located just outside the primary xylem and to the interior of the primary phloem.
7.30.165	The cells of the vascular cambium divide and form secondary xylem (tracheids and vessel elements) to the inside, and secondary phloem (sieve elements and companion cells) to the outside.
7.30.166	The thickening of the stem that occurs in secondary growth is due to the formation of secondary phloem and secondary xylem by the vascular cambium, plus the action of cork cambium, which forms the tough outermost layer of the stem.
7.30.167	The cells of the secondary xylem contain lignin, which provides hardiness and strength.
7.30.168	In woody plants, cork cambium is the outermost lateral meristem.
7.30.169	It produces cork cells (bark) containing a waxy substance known as suberin that can repel water.
7.30.170	The bark protects the plant against physical damage and helps reduce water loss.
7.30.171	The cork cambium also produces a layer of cells known as phelloderm, which grows inward from the cambium.
7.30.172	The cork cambium, cork cells, and phelloderm are collectively termed the periderm.
7.30.173	The periderm substitutes for the epidermis in mature plants.
7.30.174	In some plants, the periderm has many openings, known as lenticels, which allow the interior cells to exchange gases with the outside atmosphere (Figure 30.11).
7.30.175	This supplies oxygen to the living and metabolically active cells of the cortex, xylem and phloem.
7.30.176	Lenticels on the bark of this cherry tree enable the woody stem to exchange gases with the surrounding atmosphere.
7.30.177	Annual Rings
7.30.178	The activity of the vascular cambium gives rise to annual growth rings.
7.30.179	During the spring growing season, cells of the secondary xylem have a large internal diameter and their primary cell walls are not extensively thickened.
7.30.180	This is known as early wood, or spring wood.
7.30.181	During the fall season, the secondary xylem develops thickened cell walls, forming late wood, or autumn wood, which is denser than early wood.
7.30.182	This alternation of early and late wood is due largely to a seasonal decrease in the number of vessel elements and a seasonal increase in the number of tracheids.
7.30.183	It results in the formation of an annual ring, which can be seen as a circular ring in the cross section of the stem (Figure 30.12).
7.30.184	An examination of the number of annual rings and their nature (such as their size and cell wall thickness) can reveal the age of the tree and the prevailing climatic conditions during each season.
7.30.185	The rate of wood growth increases in summer and decreases in winter, producing a characteristic ring for each year of growth.
7.30.186	Seasonal changes in weather patterns can also affect the growth rate
7.30.187	—note how the rings vary in thickness.
7.30.188	Stem Modifications
7.30.189	Some plant species have modified stems that are especially suited to a particular habitat and environment (Figure 30.13).
7.30.190	A rhizome is a modified stem that grows horizontally underground and has nodes and internodes.
7.30.191	Vertical shoots may arise from the buds on the rhizome of some plants, such as ginger and ferns.
7.30.192	Corms are similar to rhizomes, except they are more rounded and fleshy (such as in gladiolus).
7.30.193	Corms contain stored food that enables some plants to survive the winter.
7.30.194	Stolons are stems that run almost parallel to the ground, or just below the surface, and can give rise to new plants at the nodes.
7.30.195	Runners are a type of stolon that runs above the ground and produces new clone plants at nodes at varying intervals: strawberries are an example.
7.30.196	Tubers are modified stems that may store starch, as seen in the potato (Solanum sp.).
7.30.197	Tubers arise as swollen ends of stolons, and contain many adventitious or unusual buds (familiar to us as the “eyes” on potatoes).
7.30.198	A bulb, which functions as an underground storage unit, is a modification of a stem that has the appearance of enlarged fleshy leaves emerging from the stem or surrounding the base of the stem, as seen in the iris.
7.30.199	Stem modifications enable plants to thrive in a variety of environments.
7.30.200	Shown are (a) ginger (Zingiber officinale) rhizomes, (b) a carrion flower (Amorphophallus titanum) corm
7.30.201	(c) Rhodes grass
7.30.202	(Chloris gayana) stolons, (d) strawberry (Fragaria ananassa) runners, (e) potato (Solanum tuberosum) tubers, and (f) red onion (Allium) bulbs.
7.30.203	Some aerial modifications of stems are tendrils and thorns (Figure 30.14).
7.30.204	Tendrils are slender, twining strands that enable a plant (like a vine or pumpkin) to seek support by climbing on other surfaces.
7.30.205	Thorns are modified branches appearing as sharp outgrowths that protect the plant; common examples include roses, Osage orange and devil’s walking stick.
7.30.206	Found in southeastern United States, (a) buckwheat vine (Brunnichia ovata) is a weedy plant that climbs with the aid of tendrils.
7.30.207	This one is shown climbing up a wooden stake.
7.30.208	(b) Thorns are modified branches.
7.30.209	Roots
7.30.210	By the end of this section, you will be able to: Identify the two types of root systems Describe the three zones of the root tip and summarize the role of each zone in root growth Describe the structure of the root List and describe examples of modified roots
7.30.211	The roots of seed plants have three major functions: anchoring the plant to the soil, absorbing water and minerals and transporting them upwards, and storing the products of photosynthesis.
7.30.212	Some roots are modified to absorb moisture and exchange gases.
7.30.213	Most roots are underground.
7.30.214	Some plants, however, also have adventitious roots, which emerge above the ground from the shoot.
7.30.215	Types of Root Systems Root systems are mainly of two types (Figure 30.15).
7.30.216	Dicots have a tap root system, while monocots have a fibrous root system.
7.30.217	A tap root system has a main root that grows down vertically, and from which many smaller lateral roots arise.
7.30.218	Dandelions are a good example; their tap roots usually break off when trying to pull these weeds, and they can regrow another shoot from the remaining root).
7.30.219	A tap root system penetrates deep into the soil.
7.30.220	In contrast, a fibrous root system is located closer to the soil surface, and forms a dense network of roots that also helps prevent soil erosion (lawn grasses are a good example, as are wheat, rice, and corn).
7.30.221	Some plants have a combination of tap roots and fibrous roots.
7.30.222	Plants that grow in dry areas often have deep root systems, whereas plants growing in areas with abundant water are likely to have shallower root systems.
7.30.223	(a) Tap root systems have a main root that grows down, while (b) fibrous root systems consist of many small roots.
7.30.224	Root Growth and Anatomy Root growth begins with seed germination.
7.30.225	When the plant embryo emerges from the seed, the radicle of the embryo forms the root system.
7.30.226	The tip of the root is protected by the root cap, a structure exclusive to roots and unlike any other plant structure.
7.30.227	The root cap is continuously replaced because it gets damaged easily as the root pushes through soil.
7.30.228	The root tip can be divided into three zones: a zone of cell division, a zone of elongation, and a zone of maturation and differentiation (Figure 30.16).
7.30.229	The zone of cell division is closest to the root tip; it is made up of the actively dividing cells of the root meristem.
7.30.230	The zone of elongation is where the newly formed cells increase in length, thereby lengthening the root.
7.30.231	Beginning at the first root hair is the zone of cell maturation where the root cells begin to differentiate into special cell types.
7.30.232	All three zones are in the first centimeter or so of the root tip.
7.30.233	A longitudinal view of the root reveals the zones of cell division, elongation, and maturation.
7.30.234	Cell division occurs in the apical meristem.
7.30.235	The root has an outer layer of cells called the epidermis, which surrounds areas of ground tissue and vascular tissue.
7.30.236	The epidermis provides protection and helps in absorption.
7.30.237	Root hairs, which are extensions of root epidermal cells, increase the surface area of the root, greatly contributing to the absorption of water and minerals.
7.30.238	Inside the root, the ground tissue forms two regions: the cortex and the pith (Figure 30.17).
7.30.239	Compared to stems, roots have lots of cortex and little pith.
7.30.240	Both regions include cells that store photosynthetic products.
7.30.241	The cortex is between the epidermis and the vascular tissue, whereas the pith lies between the vascular tissue and the center of the root.
7.30.242	Staining reveals different cell types in this light micrograph of a wheat (Triticum) root cross section.
7.30.243	Sclerenchyma cells of the exodermis and xylem cells stain red, and phloem cells stain blue.
7.30.244	Other cell types stain black.
7.30.245	The stele, or vascular tissue, is the area inside endodermis (indicated by a green ring).
7.30.246	Root hairs are visible outside the epidermis.
7.30.247	The vascular tissue in the root is arranged in the inner portion of the root, which is called the stele (Figure 30.18).
7.30.248	A layer of cells known as the endodermis separates the stele from the ground tissue in the outer portion of the root.
7.30.249	The endodermis is exclusive to roots, and serves as a checkpoint for materials entering the root’s vascular system.
7.30.250	A waxy substance called suberin is present on the walls of the endodermal cells.
7.30.251	This waxy region, known as the Casparian strip, forces water and solutes to cross the plasma membranes of endodermal cells instead of slipping between the cells.
7.30.252	This ensures that only materials required by the root pass through the endodermis, while toxic substances and pathogens are generally excluded.
7.30.253	The outermost cell layer of the root’s vascular tissue is the pericycle, an area that can give rise to lateral roots.
7.30.254	In dicot roots, the xylem and phloem of the stele are arranged alternately in an X shape, whereas in monocot roots, the vascular tissue is arranged in a ring around the pith.
7.30.255	In (left) typical dicots, the vascular tissue forms an X shape in the center of the root.
7.30.256	In (right) typical monocots, the phloem cells and the larger xylem cells form a characteristic ring around the central pith.
7.30.257	Root Modifications Root structures may be modified for specific purposes.
7.30.258	For example, some roots are bulbous and store starch.
7.30.259	Aerial roots and prop roots are two forms of aboveground roots that provide additional support to anchor the plant.
7.30.260	Tap roots, such as carrots, turnips, and beets, are examples of roots that are modified for food storage.
7.30.261	Many vegetables are modified roots.
7.30.262	Epiphytic roots enable a plant to grow on another plant.
7.30.263	For example, the epiphytic roots of orchids develop a spongy tissue to absorb moisture.
7.30.264	The banyan tree (Ficus sp.) begins as an epiphyte, germinating in the branches of a host tree; aerial roots develop from the branches and eventually reach the ground, providing additional support (Figure 30.20).
7.30.265	In screwpine (Pandanus sp.), a palm-like tree that grows in sandy tropical soils, aboveground prop roots develop from the nodes to provide additional support.
7.30.266	The (a) banyan tree, also known as the strangler fig, begins life as an epiphyte in a host tree.
7.30.267	Aerial roots extend to the ground and support the growing plant, which eventually strangles the host tree.
7.30.268	The (b) screwpine develops aboveground roots that help support the plant in sandy soils.
7.30.269	Leaves
7.30.270	By the end of this section, you will be able to: Identify the parts of a typical leaf Describe the internal structure and function of a leaf Compare and contrast simple leaves and compound leaves List and describe examples of modified leaves Leaves are the main sites for photosynthesis: the process by which plants synthesize food.
7.30.271	Most leaves are usually green, due to the presence of chlorophyll in the leaf cells.
7.30.272	However, some leaves may have different colors, caused by other plant pigments that mask the green chlorophyll.
7.30.273	The thickness, shape, and size of leaves are adapted to the environment.
7.30.274	Each variation helps a plant species maximize its chances of survival in a particular habitat.
7.30.275	Usually, the leaves of plants growing in tropical rainforests have larger surface areas than those of plants growing in deserts or very cold conditions, which are likely to have a smaller surface area to minimize water loss.
7.30.276	Structure of a Typical Leaf
7.30.277	Each leaf typically has a leaf blade called the lamina, which is also the widest part of the leaf.
7.30.278	Some leaves are attached to the plant stem by a petiole.
7.30.279	Leaves that do not have a petiole and are directly attached to the plant stem are called sessile leaves.
7.30.280	Small green appendages usually found at the base of the petiole are known as stipules.
7.30.281	Most leaves have a midrib, which travels the length of the leaf and branches to each side to produce veins of vascular tissue.
7.30.282	The edge of the leaf is called the margin.
7.30.283	Figure 30.21 shows the structure of a typical eudicot leaf.
7.30.284	Deceptively simple in appearance, a leaf is a highly efficient structure.
7.30.285	Within each leaf, the vascular tissue forms veins.
7.30.286	The arrangement of veins in a leaf is called the venation pattern.
7.30.287	Monocots and dicots differ in their patterns of venation (Figure 30.22).
7.30.288	Monocots have parallel venation; the veins run in straight lines across the length of the leaf without converging at a point.
7.30.289	In dicots, however, the veins of the leaf have a net-like appearance, forming a pattern known as reticulate venation.
7.30.290	One extant plant, the Ginkgo biloba, has dichotomous venation where the veins fork.
7.30.291	(a) Tulip (Tulipa), a monocot, has leaves with parallel venation.
7.30.292	The netlike venation in this (b) linden (Tilia cordata) leaf distinguishes it as a dicot.
7.30.293	The (c) Ginkgo biloba tree has dichotomous venation.
7.30.294	Leaf Arrangement
7.30.295	The arrangement of leaves on a stem is known as phyllotaxy.
7.30.296	The number and placement of a plant’s leaves will vary depending on the species, with each species exhibiting a characteristic leaf arrangement.
7.30.297	Leaves are classified as either alternate, spiral, or opposite.
7.30.298	Plants that have only one leaf per node have leaves that are said to be either alternate—meaning the leaves alternate on each side of the stem in a flat plane—or spiral, meaning the leaves are arrayed in a spiral along the stem.
7.30.299	In an opposite leaf arrangement, two leaves arise at the same point, with the leaves connecting opposite each other along the branch.
7.30.300	If there are three or more leaves connected at a node, the leaf arrangement is classified as whorled.
7.30.301	Leaf Form Leaves may be simple or compound (Figure 30.23).
7.30.302	In a simple leaf, the blade is either completely undivided—as in the banana leaf—or it has lobes, but the separation does not reach the midrib, as in the maple leaf.
7.30.303	In a compound leaf, the leaf blade is completely divided, forming leaflets, as in the locust tree.
7.30.304	Each leaflet may have its own stalk, but is attached to the rachis.
7.30.305	A palmately compound leaf resembles the palm of a hand, with leaflets radiating outwards from one point Examples include the leaves of poison ivy, the buckeye tree, or the familiar houseplant Schefflera sp.
7.30.306	(common name “umbrella plant”).
7.30.307	Pinnately compound leaves take their name from their feather-like appearance; the leaflets are arranged along the midrib, as in rose leaves (Rosa sp.), or the leaves of hickory, pecan, ash, or walnut trees.  
7.30.308	Leaves may be simple or compound.
7.30.309	In simple leaves, the lamina is continuous.
7.30.310	The (a) banana plant (Musa sp.) has simple leaves.
7.30.311	In compound leaves, the lamina is separated into leaflets.
7.30.312	Compound leaves may be palmate or pinnate.
7.30.313	In (b) palmately compound leaves, such as those of the horse chestnut (Aesculus hippocastanum), the leaflets branch from the petiole.
7.30.314	In (c) pinnately compound leaves, the leaflets branch from the midrib, as on a scrub hickory (Carya floridana).
7.30.315	The (d) honey locust has double compound leaves, in which leaflets branch from the veins.
7.30.316	Leaf Structure and Function
7.30.317	The outermost layer of the leaf is the epidermis; it is present on both sides of the leaf and is called the upper and lower epidermis, respectively.
7.30.318	Botanists call the upper side the adaxial surface (or adaxis) and the lower side the abaxial surface (or abaxis).
7.30.319	The epidermis helps in the regulation of gas exchange.
7.30.320	It contains stomata (Figure 30.24): openings through which the exchange of gases takes place.
7.30.321	Two guard cells surround each stoma, regulating its opening and closing.
7.30.322	Visualized at 500x with a scanning electron microscope, several stomata are clearly visible on (a) the surface of this sumac (Rhus glabra) leaf.
7.30.323	At 5,000x magnification, the guard cells of (b) a single stoma from lyre-leaved sand cress (Arabidopsis lyrata) have the appearance of lips that surround the opening.
7.30.324	In this (c) light micrograph cross-section of an A. lyrata leaf, the guard cell pair is visible along with the large, sub-stomatal air space in the leaf.
7.30.325	The epidermis is usually one cell layer thick; however, in plants that grow in very hot or very cold conditions, the epidermis may be several layers thick to protect against excessive water loss from transpiration.
7.30.326	A waxy layer known as the cuticle covers the leaves of all plant species.
7.30.327	The cuticle reduces the rate of water loss from the leaf surface.
7.30.328	Other leaves may have small hairs (trichomes) on the leaf surface.
7.30.329	Trichomes help to deter herbivory by restricting insect movements, or by storing toxic or bad-tasting compounds; they can also reduce the rate of transpiration by blocking air flow across the leaf surface.
7.30.330	Trichomes give leaves a fuzzy appearance as in this (a) sundew (Drosera sp.).
7.30.331	Leaf trichomes include (b) branched trichomes on the leaf of Arabidopsis lyrata and (c) multibranched trichomes on a mature Quercus marilandica leaf.
7.30.332	Below the epidermis of dicot leaves are layers of cells known as the mesophyll, or “middle leaf.
7.30.333	”
7.30.334	The mesophyll of most leaves typically contains two arrangements of parenchyma cells: the palisade parenchyma and spongy parenchyma (Figure 30.26).
7.30.335	The palisade parenchyma (also called the palisade mesophyll) has column-shaped, tightly packed cells, and may be present in one, two, or three layers.
7.30.336	Below the palisade parenchyma are loosely arranged cells of an irregular shape.
7.30.337	These are the cells of the spongy parenchyma (or spongy mesophyll).
7.30.338	The air space found between the spongy parenchyma cells allows gaseous exchange between the leaf and the outside atmosphere through the stomata.
7.30.339	In aquatic plants, the intercellular spaces in the spongy parenchyma help the leaf float.
7.30.340	Both layers of the mesophyll contain many chloroplasts.
7.30.341	Guard cells are the only epidermal cells to contain chloroplasts.
7.30.342	In the (a) leaf drawing, the central mesophyll is sandwiched between an upper and lower epidermis.
7.30.343	The mesophyll has two layers: an upper palisade layer comprised of tightly packed, columnar cells, and a lower spongy layer, comprised of loosely packed, irregularly shaped cells.
7.30.344	Stomata on the leaf underside allow gas exchange.
7.30.345	A waxy cuticle covers all aerial surfaces of land plants to minimize water loss.
7.30.346	These leaf layers are clearly visible in the (b) scanning electron micrograph.
7.30.347	The numerous small bumps in the palisade parenchyma cells are chloroplasts.
7.30.348	Chloroplasts are also present in the spongy parenchyma, but are not as obvious.
7.30.349	The bumps protruding from the lower surface of the leave are glandular trichomes, which differ in structure from the stalked trichomes in Figure 30.25.
7.30.350	Like the stem, the leaf contains vascular bundles composed of xylem and phloem (Figure 30.27).
7.30.351	The xylem consists of tracheids and vessels, which transport water and minerals to the leaves.
7.30.352	The phloem transports the photosynthetic products from the leaf to the other parts of the plant.
7.30.353	A single vascular bundle, no matter how large or small, always contains both xylem and phloem tissues.
7.30.354	This scanning electron micrograph shows xylem and phloem in the leaf vascular bundle from the lyreleaved sand cress (Arabidopsis lyrata).
7.30.355	Leaf Adaptations Coniferous plant species that thrive in cold environments, like spruce, fir, and pine, have leaves that are reduced in size and needle-like in appearance.
7.30.356	These needle-like leaves have sunken stomata and a smaller surface area: two attributes that aid in reducing water loss.
7.30.357	In hot climates, plants such as cacti have leaves that are reduced to spines, which in combination with their succulent stems, help to conserve water.
7.30.358	Many aquatic plants have leaves with wide lamina that can float on the surface of the water, and a thick waxy cuticle on the leaf surface that repels water.
7.30.359	Transport of Water and Solutes in Plants
7.30.360	By the end of this section, you will be able to:
7.30.361	Define water potential and explain how it is influenced by solutes, pressure, gravity, and the matric potential Describe how water potential, evapotranspiration, and stomatal regulation influence how water is transported in plants
7.30.362	Explain how photosynthates are transported in plants
7.30.363	The structure of plant roots, stems, and leaves facilitates the transport of water, nutrients, and photosynthates throughout the plant.
7.30.364	The phloem and xylem are the main tissues responsible for this movement.
7.30.365	Water potential, evapotranspiration, and stomatal regulation influence how water and nutrients are transported in plants.
7.30.366	To understand how these processes work, we must first understand the energetics of water potential.
7.30.367	Water Potential Plants are phenomenal hydraulic engineers.
7.30.368	Using only the basic laws of physics and the simple manipulation of potential energy, plants can move water to the top of a 116-meter-tall tree (Figure 30.31a).
7.30.369	Plants can also use hydraulics to generate enough force to split rocks and buckle sidewalks
7.30.370	(Figure 30.31b).
7.30.371	Plants achieve this because of water potential.
7.30.372	With heights nearing 116 meters, (a) coastal redwoods (Sequoia sempervirens) are the tallest trees in the world.
7.30.373	Plant roots can easily generate enough force to (b) buckle and break concrete sidewalks, much to the dismay of homeowners and city maintenance departments.
7.30.374	Water potential is a measure of the potential energy in water.
7.30.375	Plant physiologists are not interested in the energy in any one particular aqueous system, but are very interested in water movement between two systems.
7.30.376	In practical terms, therefore, water potential is the difference in potential energy between a given water sample and pure water (at atmospheric pressure and ambient temperature).
7.30.377	Water potential is denoted by the Greek letter ψ (psi) and is expressed in units of pressure (pressure is a form of energy) called megapascals (MPa).
7.30.378	The potential of pure water (Ψw pure H2O) is, by convenience of definition, designated a value of zero (even though pure water contains plenty of potential energy, that energy is ignored).
7.30.379	Water potential values for the water in a plant root, stem, or leaf are therefore expressed relative to Ψw pure H2O.
7.30.380	The water potential in plant solutions is influenced by solute concentration, pressure, gravity, and factors called matrix effects.
7.30.381	Water potential can be broken down into its individual components using the following equation: Ψsystem =
7.30.382	Ψtotal =
7.30.383	Ψs + Ψp + Ψg + Ψm where Ψs, Ψp, Ψg, and Ψm refer to the solute, pressure, gravity, and matric potentials, respectively.
7.30.384	“
7.30.385	System” can refer to the water potential of the soil water (Ψsoil), root water (Ψroot), stem water (Ψstem), leaf water (Ψleaf) or the water in the atmosphere (Ψatmosphere): whichever aqueous system is under consideration.
7.30.386	As the individual components change, they raise or lower the total water potential of a system.
7.30.387	When this happens, water moves to equilibrate, moving from the system or compartment with a higher water potential to the system or compartment with a lower water potential.
7.30.388	This brings the difference in water potential between the two systems (ΔΨ) back to zero (ΔΨ = 0).
7.30.389	Therefore, for water to move through the plant from the soil to the air (a process called transpiration), Ψsoil must be >
7.30.390	Ψroot >
7.30.391	Ψstem >
7.30.392	Ψleaf > Ψatmosphere.
7.30.393	Water only moves in response to ΔΨ, not in response to the individual components.
7.30.394	However, because the individual components influence the total Ψsystem, by manipulating the individual components (especially Ψs), a plant can control water movement.
7.30.395	Solute Potential Solute potential (Ψs), also called osmotic potential, is negative in a plant cell and zero in distilled water.
7.30.396	Typical values for cell cytoplasm are –0.5 to –1.0 MPa.
7.30.397	Solutes reduce water potential (resulting in a negative Ψw) by consuming some of the potential energy available in the water.
7.30.398	Solute molecules can dissolve in water because water molecules can bind to them via hydrogen bonds; a hydrophobic molecule like oil, which cannot bind to water, cannot go into solution.
7.30.399	The energy in the hydrogen bonds between solute molecules and water is no longer available to do work in the system because it is tied up in the bond.
7.30.400	In other words, the amount of available potential energy is reduced when solutes are added to an aqueous system.
7.30.401	Thus, Ψs decreases with increasing solute concentration.
7.30.402	Because Ψs is one of the four components of Ψsystem or Ψtotal, a decrease in Ψs will cause a decrease in Ψtotal.
7.30.403	The internal water potential of a plant cell is more negative than pure water because of the cytoplasm’s high solute content (Figure 30.32).
7.30.404	Because of this difference in water potential water will move from the soil into a plant’s root cells via the process of osmosis.
7.30.405	This is why solute potential is sometimes called osmotic potential.
7.30.406	Plant cells can metabolically manipulate Ψs (and by extension, Ψtotal) by adding or removing solute molecules.
7.30.407	Therefore, plants have control over Ψtotal via their ability to exert metabolic control over Ψs.
7.30.408	Pressure Potential Pressure potential (Ψp), also called turgor potential, may be positive or negative (Figure 30.32).
7.30.409	Because pressure is an expression of energy, the higher the pressure, the more potential energy in a system, and vice versa.
7.30.410	Therefore, a positive Ψp (compression) increases Ψtotal, and a negative Ψp (tension) decreases Ψtotal.
7.30.411	Positive pressure inside cells is contained by the cell wall, producing turgor pressure.
7.30.412	Pressure potentials are typically around 0.6–0.8 MPa, but can reach as high as 1.5 MPa in a well-watered plant.
7.30.413	A Ψp of 1.5 MPa equates to 210 pounds per square inch (1.5 MPa x 140 lb in-2 MPa-1
7.30.414	= 210 lb/in-2).
7.30.415	As a comparison, most automobile tires are kept at a pressure of 30–34 psi.
7.30.416	An example of the effect of turgor pressure is the wilting of leaves and their restoration after the plant has been watered (Figure 30.33).
7.30.417	Water is lost from the leaves via transpiration (approaching Ψp = 0 MPa at the wilting point) and restored by uptake via the roots.
7.30.418	A plant can manipulate Ψp via its ability to manipulate Ψs and by the process of osmosis.
7.30.419	If a plant cell increases the cytoplasmic solute concentration,
7.30.420	Ψs will decline, Ψtotal will decline, the ΔΨ between the cell and the surrounding tissue will decline, water will move into the cell by osmosis, and Ψp will increase.
7.30.421	Ψp is also under indirect plant control via the opening and closing of stomata.
7.30.422	Stomatal openings allow water to evaporate from the leaf, reducing Ψp and Ψtotal of the leaf and increasing ii between the water in the leaf and the petiole, thereby allowing water to flow from the petiole into the leaf.
7.30.423	When (a) total water potential (Ψtotal) is lower outside the cells than inside, water moves out of the cells and the plant wilts.
7.30.424	When (b) the total water potential is higher outside the plant cells than inside, water moves into the cells, resulting in turgor pressure (Ψp) and keeping the plant erect.
7.30.425	Gravity Potential Gravity potential (Ψg) is always negative to zero in a plant with no height.
7.30.426	It always removes or consumes potential energy from the system.
7.30.427	The force of gravity pulls water downwards to the soil, reducing the total amount of potential energy in the water in the plant (Ψtotal).
7.30.428	The taller the plant, the taller the water column, and the more influential Ψg becomes.
7.30.429	On a cellular scale and in short plants, this effect is negligible and easily ignored.
7.30.430	However, over the height of a tall tree like a giant coastal redwood, the gravitational pull of –0.1 MPa m-1 is equivalent to an extra 1 MPa of resistance that must be overcome for water to reach the leaves of the tallest trees.
7.30.431	Plants are unable to manipulate Ψg.
7.30.432	Matric Potential Matric potential (Ψm) is always negative to zero.
7.30.433	In a dry system, it can be as low as –2 MPa in a dry seed, and it is zero in a water-saturated system.
7.30.434	The binding of water to a matrix always removes or consumes potential energy from the system.
7.30.435	Ψm is similar to solute potential because it involves tying up the energy in an aqueous system by forming hydrogen bonds between the water and some other component.
7.30.436	However, in solute potential, the other components are soluble, hydrophilic solute molecules, whereas in Ψm, the other components are insoluble, hydrophilic molecules of the plant cell wall.
7.30.437	Every plant cell has a cellulosic cell wall and the cellulose in the cell walls is hydrophilic, producing a matrix for adhesion of water: hence the name matric potential.
7.30.438	Ψm is very large (negative) in dry tissues such as seeds or drought-affected soils.
7.30.439	However, it quickly goes to zero as the seed takes up water or the soil hydrates.
7.30.440	Ψm cannot be manipulated by the plant and is typically ignored in well-watered roots, stems, and leaves.
7.30.441	Movement of Water and Minerals in the Xylem Solutes, pressure, gravity, and matric potential are all important for the transport of water in plants.
7.30.442	Water moves from an area of higher total water potential (higher Gibbs free energy) to an area of lower total water potential.
7.30.443	Gibbs free energy is the energy associated with a chemical reaction that can be used to do work.
7.30.444	This is expressed as ΔΨ.
7.30.445	Transpiration is the loss of water from the plant through evaporation at the leaf surface.
7.30.446	It is the main driver of water movement in the xylem.
7.30.447	Transpiration is caused by the evaporation of water at the leaf–atmosphere interface; it creates negative pressure (tension) equivalent to –2 MPa at the leaf surface.
7.30.448	This value varies greatly depending on the vapor pressure deficit, which can be negligible at high relative humidity (RH) and substantial at low RH.
7.30.449	Water from the roots is pulled up by this tension.
7.30.450	At night, when stomata shut and transpiration stops, the water is held in the stem and leaf by the adhesion of water to the cell walls of the xylem vessels and tracheids, and the cohesion of water molecules to each other.
7.30.451	This is called the cohesion–tension theory of sap ascent.
7.30.452	Inside the leaf at the cellular level, water on the surface of mesophyll cells saturates the cellulose microfibrils of the primary cell wall.
7.30.453	The leaf contains many large intercellular air spaces for the exchange of oxygen for carbon dioxide, which is required for photosynthesis.
7.30.454	The wet cell wall is exposed to this leaf internal air space, and the water on the surface of the cells evaporates into the air spaces, decreasing the thin film on the surface of the mesophyll cells.
7.30.455	This decrease creates a greater tension on the water in the mesophyll cells (Figure 30.34), thereby increasing the pull on the water in the xylem vessels.
7.30.456	The xylem vessels and tracheids are structurally adapted to cope with large changes in pressure.
7.30.457	Rings in the vessels maintain their tubular shape, much like the rings on a vacuum cleaner hose keep the hose open while it is under pressure.
7.30.458	Small perforations between vessel elements reduce the number and size of gas bubbles that can form via a process called cavitation.
7.30.459	The formation of gas bubbles in xylem interrupts the continuous stream of water from the base to the top of the plant, causing a break termed an embolism in the flow of xylem sap.
7.30.460	The taller the tree, the greater the tension forces needed to pull water, and the more cavitation events.
7.30.461	In larger trees, the resulting embolisms can plug xylem vessels, making them non-functional.
7.30.462	Transpiration—
7.30.463	the loss of water vapor to the atmosphere through stomata—is a passive process, meaning that metabolic energy in the form of ATP is not required for water movement.
7.30.464	The energy driving transpiration is the difference in energy between the water in the soil and the water in the atmosphere.
7.30.465	However, transpiration is tightly controlled.
7.30.466	Control of Transpiration
7.30.467	The atmosphere to which the leaf is exposed drives transpiration, but also causes massive water loss from the plant.
7.30.468	Up to 90 percent of the water taken up by roots may be lost through transpiration.
7.30.469	Leaves are covered by a waxy cuticle on the outer surface that prevents the loss of water.
7.30.470	Regulation of transpiration, therefore, is achieved primarily through the opening and closing of stomata on the leaf surface.
7.30.471	Stomata are surrounded by two specialized cells called guard cells, which open and close in response to environmental cues such as light intensity and quality, leaf water status, and carbon dioxide concentrations.
7.30.472	Stomata must open to allow air containing carbon dioxide and oxygen to diffuse into the leaf for photosynthesis and respiration.
7.30.473	When stomata are open, however, water vapor is lost to the external environment, increasing the rate of transpiration.
7.30.474	Therefore, plants must maintain a balance between efficient photosynthesis and water loss.
7.30.475	Plants have evolved over time to adapt to their local environment and reduce transpiration(Figure 30.35).
7.30.476	Desert plant (xerophytes) and plants that grow on other plants (epiphytes) have limited access to water.
7.30.477	Such plants usually have a much thicker waxy cuticle than those growing in more moderate, well-watered environments (mesophytes).
7.30.478	Aquatic plants (hydrophytes) also have their own set of anatomical and morphological leaf adaptations.
7.30.479	Plants are suited to their local environment.
7.30.480	(a)
7.30.481	Xerophytes, like this prickly pear cactus (Opuntia sp.)
7.30.482	and (b) epiphytes such as this tropical Aeschynanthus perrottetii have adapted to very limited water resources.
7.30.483	The leaves of a prickly pear are modified into spines, which lowers the surface-to-volume ratio and reduces water loss.
7.30.484	Photosynthesis takes place in the stem, which also stores water.
7.30.485	(b) A. perottetii leaves have a waxy cuticle that prevents water loss.
7.30.486	(c) Goldenrod (Solidago sp.) is a mesophyte, well suited for moderate environments.
7.30.487	(d) Hydrophytes, like this fragrant water lily (Nymphaea odorata), are adapted to thrive in aquatic environments.
7.30.488	Xerophytes and epiphytes often have a thick covering of trichomes or of stomata that are sunken below the leaf’s surface.
7.30.489	Trichomes are specialized hair-like epidermal cells that secrete oils and substances.
7.30.490	These adaptations impede air flow across the stomatal pore and reduce transpiration.
7.30.491	Multiple epidermal layers are also commonly found in these types of plants.
7.30.492	Transportation of Photosynthates in the Phloem Plants need an energy source to grow.
7.30.493	In seeds and bulbs, food is stored in polymers (such as starch) that are converted by metabolic processes into sucrose for newly developing plants.
7.30.494	Once green shoots and leaves are growing, plants are able to produce their own food by photosynthesizing.
7.30.495	The products of photosynthesis are called photosynthates, which are usually in the form of simple sugars such as sucrose.
7.30.496	Structures that produce photosynthates for the growing plant are referred to as sources.
7.30.497	Sugars produced in sources, such as leaves, need to be delivered to growing parts of the plant via the phloem in a process called translocation.
7.30.498	The points of sugar delivery, such as roots, young shoots, and developing seeds, are called sinks.
7.30.499	Seeds, tubers, and bulbs can be either a source or a sink, depending on the plant’s stage of development and the season.
7.30.500	The products from the source are usually translocated to the nearest sink through the phloem.
7.30.501	For example, the highest leaves will send photosynthates upward to the growing shoot tip, whereas lower leaves will direct photosynthates downward to the roots.
7.30.502	Intermediate leaves will send products in both directions, unlike the flow in the xylem, which is always unidirectional (soil to leaf to atmosphere).
7.30.503	The pattern of photosynthate flow changes as the plant grows and develops.
7.30.504	Photosynthates are directed primarily to the roots early on, to shoots and leaves during vegetative growth, and to seeds and fruits during reproductive development.
7.30.505	They are also directed to tubers for storage.
7.30.506	Translocation: Transport from Source to Sink Photosynthates, such as sucrose, are produced in the mesophyll cells of photosynthesizing leaves.
7.30.507	From there they are translocated through the phloem to where they are used or stored.
7.30.508	Mesophyll cells are connected by cytoplasmic channels called plasmodesmata.
7.30.509	Photosynthates move through these channels to reach phloem sieve-tube elements (STEs) in the vascular bundles.
7.30.510	From the mesophyll cells, the photosynthates are loaded into the phloem STEs.
7.30.511	The sucrose is actively transported against its concentration gradient (a process requiring ATP) into the phloem cells using the electrochemical potential of the proton gradient.
7.30.512	This is coupled to the uptake of sucrose with a carrier protein called the sucrose-H+ symporter.
7.30.513	Phloem STEs have reduced cytoplasmic contents, and are connected by a sieve plate with pores that allow for pressuredriven bulk flow, or translocation, of phloem sap.
7.30.514	Companion cells are associated with STEs.
7.30.515	They assist with metabolic activities and produce energy for the STEs.
7.30.516	Phloem is comprised of cells called sieve-tube elements.
7.30.517	Phloem sap travels through perforations called sieve tube plates.
7.30.518	Neighboring companion cells carry out metabolic functions for the sieve-tube elements and provide them with energy.
7.30.519	Lateral sieve areas connect the sieve-tube elements to the companion cells.
7.30.520	Once in the phloem, the photosynthates are translocated to the closest sink.
7.30.521	Phloem sap is an aqueous solution that contains up to 30 percent sugar, minerals, amino acids, and plant growth regulators.
7.30.522	The high percentage of sugar decreases Ψs, which decreases the total water potential and causes water to move by osmosis from the adjacent xylem into the phloem tubes, thereby increasing pressure.
7.30.523	This increase in total water potential causes the bulk flow of phloem from source to sink (Figure 30.37).
