7.30.524	Sucrose concentration in the sink cells is lower than in the phloem STEs because the sink sucrose has been metabolized for growth, or converted to starch for storage or other polymers, such as cellulose, for structural integrity.
7.30.525	Unloading at the sink end of the phloem tube occurs by either diffusion or active transport of sucrose molecules from an area of high concentration to one of low concentration.
7.30.526	Water diffuses from the phloem by osmosis and is then transpired or recycled via the xylem back into the phloem sap.
7.30.527	Sucrose is actively transported from source cells into companion cells and then into the sieve-tube elements.
7.30.528	This reduces the water potential, which causes water to enter the phloem from the xylem.
7.30.529	The resulting positive pressure forces the sucrose-water mixture down toward the roots, where sucrose is unloaded.
7.30.530	Transpiration causes water to return to the leaves through the xylem vessels.
7.30.531	Plant Sensory Systems and Responses
7.30.532	By the end of this section, you will be able to: Describe how red and blue light affect plant growth and metabolic activities
7.30.533	Discuss gravitropism Understand how hormones affect plant growth and development Describe thigmotropism, thigmonastism, and thigmogenesis Explain how plants defend themselves from predators and respond to wounds Animals can respond to environmental factors by moving to a new location.
7.30.534	Plants, however, are rooted in place and must respond to the surrounding environmental factors.
7.30.535	Plants have sophisticated systems to detect and respond to light, gravity, temperature, and physical touch.
7.30.536	Receptors sense environmental factors and relay the information to effector systems—often through intermediate chemical messengers—to bring about plant responses.
7.30.537	Plant Responses to Light Plants have a number of sophisticated uses for light that go far beyond their ability to photosynthesize low-molecularweight sugars using only carbon dioxide, light, and water.
7.30.538	Photomorphogenesis is the growth and development of plants in response to light.
7.30.539	It allows plants to optimize their use of light and space.
7.30.540	Photoperiodism is the ability to use light to track time.
7.30.541	Plants can tell the time of day and time of year by sensing and using various wavelengths of sunlight.
7.30.542	Phototropism is a directional response that allows plants to grow towards, or even away from, light.
7.30.543	The sensing of light in the environment is important to plants; it can be crucial for competition and survival.
7.30.544	The response of plants to light is mediated by different photoreceptors, which are comprised of a protein covalently bonded to a lightabsorbing pigment called a chromophore.
7.30.545	Together, the two are called a chromoprotein.
7.30.546	The red/far-red and violet-blue regions of the visible light spectrum trigger structural development in plants.
7.30.547	Sensory photoreceptors absorb light in these particular regions of the visible light spectrum because of the quality of light available in the daylight spectrum.
7.30.548	In terrestrial habitats, light absorption by chlorophylls peaks in the blue and red regions of the spectrum.
7.30.549	As light filters through the canopy and the blue and red wavelengths are absorbed, the spectrum shifts to the farred end, shifting the plant community to those plants better adapted to respond to far-red light.
7.30.550	Blue-light receptors allow plants to gauge the direction and abundance of sunlight, which is rich in blue–green emissions.
7.30.551	Water absorbs red light, which makes the detection of blue light essential for algae and aquatic plants.
7.30.552	The Phytochrome System and the Red/Far-Red Response
7.30.553	The phytochromes are a family of chromoproteins with a linear tetrapyrrole chromophore, similar to the ringed tetrapyrrole light-absorbing head group of chlorophyll.
7.30.554	Phytochromes have two photo-interconvertible forms: Pr and Pfr.
7.30.555	Pr absorbs red light (~667 nm) and is immediately converted to Pfr.
7.30.556	Pfr absorbs far-red light (~730 nm) and is quickly converted back to Pr.
7.30.557	Absorption of red or far-red light causes a massive change to the shape of the chromophore, altering the conformation and activity of the phytochrome protein to which it is bound.
7.30.558	Pfr is the physiologically active form of the protein; therefore, exposure to red light yields physiological activity.
7.30.559	Exposure to far-red light inhibits phytochrome activity.
7.30.560	Together, the two forms represent the phytochrome system (Figure 30.38).
7.30.561	The phytochrome system acts as a biological light switch.
7.30.562	It monitors the level, intensity, duration, and color of environmental light.
7.30.563	The effect of red light is reversible by immediately shining far-red light on the sample, which converts the chromoprotein to the inactive Pr form.
7.30.564	Additionally, Pfr can slowly revert to Pr in the dark, or break down over time.
7.30.565	In all instances, the physiological response induced by red light is reversed.
7.30.566	The active form of phytochrome (Pfr) can directly activate other molecules in the cytoplasm, or it can be trafficked to the nucleus, where it directly activates or represses specific gene expression.
7.30.567	Once the phytochrome system evolved, plants adapted it to serve a variety of needs.
7.30.568	Unfiltered, full sunlight contains much more red light than far-red light.
7.30.569	Because chlorophyll absorbs strongly in the red region of the visible spectrum, but not in the far-red region, any plant in the shade of another plant on the forest floor will be exposed to red-depleted, far-red-enriched light.
7.30.570	The preponderance of far-red light converts phytochrome in the shaded leaves to the Pr (inactive) form, slowing growth.
7.30.571	The nearest non-shaded (or even less-shaded) areas on the forest floor have more red light; leaves exposed to these areas sense the red light, which activates the Pfr form and induces growth.
7.30.572	In short, plant shoots use the phytochrome system to grow away from shade and towards light.
7.30.573	Because competition for light is so fierce in a dense plant community, the evolutionary advantages of the phytochrome system are obvious.
7.30.574	In seeds, the phytochrome system is not used to determine direction and quality of light (shaded versus unshaded).
7.30.575	Instead, is it used merely to determine if there is any light at all.
7.30.576	This is especially important in species with very small seeds, such as lettuce.
7.30.577	Because of their size, lettuce seeds have few food reserves.
7.30.578	Their seedlings cannot grow for long before they run out of fuel.
7.30.579	If they germinated even a centimeter under the soil surface, the seedling would never make it into the sunlight and would die.
7.30.580	In the dark, phytochrome is in the Pr (inactive form) and the seed will not germinate; it will only germinate if exposed to light at the surface of the soil.
7.30.581	Upon exposure to light, Pr is converted to Pfr and germination proceeds.
7.30.582	The biologically inactive form of phytochrome (Pr) is converted to the biologically active form Pfr under illumination with red light.
7.30.583	Far-red light and darkness convert the molecule back to the inactive form.
7.30.584	Plants also use the phytochrome system to sense the change of season.
7.30.585	Photoperiodism is a biological response to the timing and duration of day and night.
7.30.586	It controls flowering, setting of winter buds, and vegetative growth.
7.30.587	Detection of seasonal changes is crucial to plant survival.
7.30.588	Although temperature and light intensity influence plant growth, they are not reliable indicators of season because they may vary from one year to the next.
7.30.589	Day length is a better indicator of the time of year.
7.30.590	As stated above, unfiltered sunlight is rich in red light but deficient in far-red light.
7.30.591	Therefore, at dawn, all the phytochrome molecules in a leaf quickly convert to the active Pfr form, and remain in that form until sunset.
7.30.592	In the dark, the Pfr form takes hours to slowly revert back to the Pr form.
7.30.593	If the night is long (as in winter), all of the Pfr form reverts.
7.30.594	If the night is short (as in summer), a considerable amount of Pfr may remain at sunrise.
7.30.595	By sensing the Pr/Pfr ratio at dawn, a plant can determine the length of the day/night cycle.
7.30.596	In addition, leaves retain that information for several days, allowing a comparison between the length of the previous night and the preceding several nights.
7.30.597	Shorter nights indicate springtime to the plant; when the nights become longer, autumn is approaching.
7.30.598	This information, along with sensing temperature and water availability, allows plants to determine the time of the year and adjust their physiology accordingly.
7.30.599	Short-day (longnight) plants use this information to flower in the late summer and early fall, when nights exceed a critical length (often eight or fewer hours).
7.30.600	Long-day (short-night) plants flower during the spring, when darkness is less than a critical length (often eight to 15 hours).
7.30.601	Not all plants use the phytochrome system in this way.
7.30.602	Flowering in day-neutral plants is not regulated by daylength.
7.30.603	The Blue Light Responses Phototropism—the directional bending of a plant toward or away from a light source—is a response to blue wavelengths of light.
7.30.604	Positive phototropism is growth towards a light source (Figure 30.39), while negative phototropism (also called skototropism) is growth away from light.
7.30.605	The aptly-named phototropins are protein-based receptors responsible for mediating the phototropic response.
7.30.606	Like all plant photoreceptors, phototropins consist of a protein portion and a light-absorbing portion, called the chromophore.
7.30.607	In phototropins, the chromophore is a covalently-bound molecule of flavin; hence, phototropins belong to a class of proteins called flavoproteins.
7.30.608	Other responses under the control of phototropins are leaf opening and closing, chloroplast movement, and the opening of stomata.
7.30.609	However, of all responses controlled by phototropins, phototropism has been studied the longest and is the best understood.
7.30.610	In their 1880 treatise The Power of Movements in Plants, Charles Darwin and his son Francis first described phototropism as the bending of seedlings toward light.
7.30.611	Darwin observed that light was perceived by the tip of the plant (the apical meristem), but that the response (bending) took place in a different part of the plant.
7.30.612	They concluded that the signal had to travel from the apical meristem to the base of the plant.
7.30.613	Azure bluets (Houstonia caerulea) display a phototropic response by bending toward the light.
7.30.614	In 1913, Peter Boysen-Jensen demonstrated that a chemical signal produced in the plant tip was responsible for the bending at the base.
7.30.615	He cut off the tip of a seedling, covered the cut section with a layer of gelatin, and then replaced the tip.
7.30.616	The seedling bent toward the light when illuminated.
7.30.617	However, when impermeable mica flakes were inserted between the tip and the cut base, the seedling did not bend.
7.30.618	A refinement of the experiment showed that the signal traveled on the shaded side of the seedling.
7.30.619	When the mica plate was inserted on the illuminated side, the plant did bend towards the light.
7.30.620	Therefore, the chemical signal was a growth stimulant because the phototropic response involved faster cell elongation on the shaded side than on the illuminated side.
7.30.621	We now know that as light passes through a plant stem, it is diffracted and generates phototropin activation across the stem.
7.30.622	Most activation occurs on the lit side, causing the plant hormone indole acetic acid (IAA) to accumulate on the shaded side.
7.30.623	Stem cells elongate under influence of IAA.
7.30.624	Cryptochromes are another class of blue-light absorbing photoreceptors that also contain a flavin-based chromophore.
7.30.625	Cryptochromes set the plants 24-hour activity cycle, also know as its circadian rhythem, using blue light cues.
7.30.626	There is some evidence that cryptochromes work together with phototropins to mediate the phototropic response.
7.30.627	Plant Responses to Gravity
7.30.628	Whether or not they germinate in the light or in total darkness, shoots usually sprout up from the ground, and roots grow downward into the ground.
7.30.629	A plant laid on its side in the dark will send shoots upward when given enough time.
7.30.630	Gravitropism ensures that roots grow into the soil and that shoots grow toward sunlight.
7.30.631	Growth of the shoot apical tip upward is called negative gravitropism, whereas growth of the roots downward is called positive gravitropism.
7.30.632	Amyloplasts (also known as statoliths) are specialized plastids that contain starch granules and settle downward in response to gravity.
7.30.633	Amyloplasts are found in shoots and in specialized cells of the root cap.
7.30.634	When a plant is tilted, the statoliths drop to the new bottom cell wall.
7.30.635	A few hours later, the shoot or root will show growth in the new vertical direction.
7.30.636	The mechanism that mediates gravitropism is reasonably well understood.
7.30.637	When amyloplasts settle to the bottom of the gravity-sensing cells in the root or shoot, they physically contact the endoplasmic reticulum (ER), causing the release of calcium ions from inside the ER.
7.30.638	This calcium signaling in the cells causes polar transport of the plant hormone IAA to the bottom of the cell.
7.30.639	In roots, a high concentration of IAA inhibits cell elongation.
7.30.640	The effect slows growth on the lower side of the root, while cells develop normally on the upper side.
7.30.641	IAA has the opposite effect in shoots, where a higher concentration at the lower side of the shoot stimulates cell expansion, causing the shoot to grow up.
7.30.642	After the shoot or root begin to grow vertically, the amyloplasts return to their normal position.
7.30.643	Other hypotheses—involving the entire cell in the gravitropism effect—have been proposed to explain why some mutants that lack amyloplasts may still exhibit a weak gravitropic response.
7.30.644	Growth Responses
7.30.645	A plant’s sensory response to external stimuli relies on chemical messengers (hormones).
7.30.646	Plant hormones affect all aspects of plant life, from flowering to fruit setting and maturation, and from phototropism to leaf fall.
7.30.647	Potentially every cell in a plant can produce plant hormones.
7.30.648	They can act in their cell of origin or be transported to other portions of the plant body, with many plant responses involving the synergistic or antagonistic interaction of two or more hormones.
7.30.649	In contrast, animal hormones are produced in specific glands and transported to a distant site for action, and they act alone.
7.30.650	Plant hormones are a group of unrelated chemical substances that affect plant morphogenesis.
7.30.651	Five major plant hormones are traditionally described: auxins (particularly IAA), cytokinins, gibberellins, ethylene, and abscisic acid.
7.30.652	In addition, other nutrients and environmental conditions can be characterized as growth factors.
7.30.653	Auxins
7.30.654	The term auxin is derived from the Greek word auxein, which means "to grow.
7.30.655	"
7.30.656	Auxins are the main hormones responsible for cell elongation in phototropism and gravitropism.
7.30.657	They also control the differentiation of meristem into vascular tissue, and promote leaf development and arrangement.
7.30.658	While many synthetic auxins are used as herbicides, IAA is the only naturally occurring auxin that shows physiological activity.
7.30.659	Apical dominance—the inhibition of lateral bud formation—is triggered by auxins produced in the apical meristem.
7.30.660	Flowering, fruit setting and ripening, and inhibition of abscission (leaf falling) are other plant responses under the direct or indirect control of auxins.
7.30.661	Auxins also act as a relay for the effects of the blue light and red/far-red responses.
7.30.662	Commercial use of auxins is widespread in plant nurseries and for crop production.
7.30.663	IAA is used as a rooting hormone to promote growth of adventitious roots on cuttings and detached leaves.
7.30.664	Applying synthetic auxins to tomato plants in greenhouses promotes normal fruit development.
7.30.665	Outdoor application of auxin promotes synchronization of fruit setting and dropping to coordinate the harvesting season.
7.30.666	Fruits such as seedless cucumbers can be induced to set fruit by treating unfertilized plant flowers with auxins.
7.30.667	Cytokinins
7.30.668	The effect of cytokinins was first reported when it was found that adding the liquid endosperm of coconuts to developing plant embryos in culture stimulated their growth.
7.30.669	The stimulating growth factor was found to be cytokinin, a hormone that promotes cytokinesis (cell division).
7.30.670	Almost 200 naturally occurring or synthetic cytokinins are known to date.
7.30.671	Cytokinins are most abundant in growing tissues, such as roots, embryos, and fruits, where cell division is occurring.
7.30.672	Cytokinins are known to delay senescence in leaf tissues, promote mitosis, and stimulate differentiation of the meristem in shoots and roots.
7.30.673	Many effects on plant development are under the influence of cytokinins, either in conjunction with auxin or another hormone.
7.30.674	For example, apical dominance seems to result from a balance between auxins that inhibit lateral buds, and cytokinins that promote bushier growth.
7.30.675	Gibberellins Gibberellins (GAs) are a group of about 125 closely related plant hormones that stimulate shoot elongation, seed germination, and fruit and flower maturation.
7.30.676	GAs are synthesized in the root and stem apical meristems, young leaves, and seed embryos.
7.30.677	In urban areas, GA antagonists are sometimes applied to trees under power lines to control growth and reduce the frequency of pruning.
7.30.678	GAs break dormancy (a state of inhibited growth and development) in the seeds of plants that require exposure to cold or light to germinate.
7.30.679	Abscisic acid is a strong antagonist of GA action.
7.30.680	Other effects of GAs include gender expression, seedless fruit development, and the delay of senescence in leaves and fruit.
7.30.681	Seedless grapes are obtained through standard breeding methods and contain inconspicuous seeds that fail to develop.
7.30.682	Because GAs are produced by the seeds, and because fruit development and stem elongation are under GA control, these varieties of grapes would normally produce small fruit in compact clusters.
7.30.683	Maturing grapes are routinely treated with GA to promote larger fruit size, as well as looser bunches (longer stems), which reduces the instance of mildew infection.
7.30.684	In grapes, application of gibberellic acid increases the size of fruit and loosens clustering.
7.30.685	Abscisic Acid
7.30.686	The plant hormone abscisic acid (ABA) was first discovered as the agent that causes the abscission or dropping of cotton bolls.
7.30.687	However, more recent studies indicate that ABA plays only a minor role in the abscission process.
7.30.688	ABA accumulates as a response to stressful environmental conditions, such as dehydration, cold temperatures, or shortened day lengths.
7.30.689	Its activity counters many of the growth-promoting effects of GAs and auxins.
7.30.690	ABA inhibits stem elongation and induces dormancy in lateral buds.
7.30.691	ABA induces dormancy in seeds by blocking germination and promoting the synthesis of storage proteins.
7.30.692	Plants adapted to temperate climates require a long period of cold temperature before seeds germinate.
7.30.693	This mechanism protects young plants from sprouting too early during unseasonably warm weather in winter.
7.30.694	As the hormone gradually breaks down over winter, the seed is released from dormancy and germinates when conditions are favorable in spring.
7.30.695	Another effect of ABA is to promote the development of winter buds; it mediates the conversion of the apical meristem into a dormant bud.
7.30.696	Low soil moisture causes an increase in ABA, which causes stomata to close, reducing water loss in winter buds.
7.30.697	Ethylene Ethylene is associated with fruit ripening, flower wilting, and leaf fall.
7.30.698	Ethylene is unusual because it is a volatile gas (C2H4).
7.30.699	Hundreds of years ago, when gas street lamps were installed in city streets, trees that grew close to lamp posts developed twisted, thickened trunks and shed their leaves earlier than expected.
7.30.700	These effects were caused by ethylene volatilizing from the lamps.
7.30.701	Aging tissues (especially senescing leaves) and nodes of stems produce ethylene.
7.30.702	The best-known effect of the hormone, however, is the promotion of fruit ripening.
7.30.703	Ethylene stimulates the conversion of starch and acids to sugars.
7.30.704	Some people store unripe fruit, such as avocadoes, in a sealed paper bag to accelerate ripening; the gas released by the first fruit to mature will speed up the maturation of the remaining fruit.
7.30.705	Ethylene also triggers leaf and fruit abscission, flower fading and dropping, and promotes germination in some cereals and sprouting of bulbs and potatoes.
7.30.706	Ethylene is widely used in agriculture.
7.30.707	Commercial fruit growers control the timing of fruit ripening with application of the gas.
7.30.708	Horticulturalists inhibit leaf dropping in ornamental plants by removing ethylene from greenhouses using fans and ventilation.
7.30.709	Nontraditional Hormones Recent research has discovered a number of compounds that also influence plant development.
7.30.710	Their roles are less understood than the effects of the major hormones described so far.
7.30.711	Jasmonates play a major role in defense responses to herbivory.
7.30.712	Their levels increase when a plant is wounded by a predator, resulting in an increase in toxic secondary metabolites.
7.30.713	They contribute to the production of volatile compounds that attract natural enemies of predators.
7.30.714	For example, chewing of tomato plants by caterpillars leads to an increase in jasmonic acid levels, which in turn triggers the release of volatile compounds that attract predators of the pest.
7.30.715	Oligosaccharins also play a role in plant defense against bacterial and fungal infections.
7.30.716	They act locally at the site of injury, and can also be transported to other tissues.
7.30.717	Strigolactones promote seed germination in some species and inhibit lateral apical development in the absence of auxins.
7.30.718	Strigolactones also play a role in the establishment of mycorrhizae, a mutualistic association of plant roots and fungi.
7.30.719	Brassinosteroids are important to many developmental and physiological processes.
7.30.720	Signals between these compounds and other hormones, notably auxin and GAs, amplifies their physiological effect.
7.30.721	Apical dominance, seed germination, gravitropism, and resistance to freezing are all positively influenced by hormones.
7.30.722	Root growth and fruit dropping are inhibited by steroids.
7.30.723	Plant Responses to Wind and Touch
7.30.724	The shoot of a pea plant winds around a trellis, while a tree grows on an angle in response to strong prevailing winds.
7.30.725	These are examples of how plants respond to touch or wind.
7.30.726	The movement of a plant subjected to constant directional pressure is called thigmotropism, from the Greek words thigma meaning “touch,” and tropism implying “direction.
7.30.727	”
7.30.728	Tendrils are one example of this.
7.30.729	The meristematic region of tendrils is very touch sensitive; light touch will evoke a quick coiling response.
7.30.730	Cells in contact with a support surface contract, whereas cells on the opposite side of the support expand
7.30.731	(Figure 30.14).
7.30.732	Application of jasmonic acid is sufficient to trigger tendril coiling without a mechanical stimulus.
7.30.733	A thigmonastic response is a touch response independent of the direction of stimulus Figure 30.24.
7.30.734	In the Venus flytrap, two modified leaves are joined at a hinge and lined with thin fork-like tines along the outer edges.
7.30.735	Tiny hairs are located inside the trap.
7.30.736	When an insect brushes against these trigger hairs, touching two or more of them in succession, the leaves close quickly, trapping the prey.
7.30.737	Glands on the leaf surface secrete enzymes that slowly digest the insect.
7.30.738	The released nutrients are absorbed by the leaves, which reopen for the next meal.
7.30.739	Thigmomorphogenesis is a slow developmental change in the shape of a plant subjected to continuous mechanical stress.
7.30.740	When trees bend in the wind, for example, growth is usually stunted and the trunk thickens.
7.30.741	Strengthening tissue, especially xylem, is produced to add stiffness to resist the wind’s force.
7.30.742	Researchers hypothesize that mechanical strain induces growth and differentiation to strengthen the tissues.
7.30.743	Ethylene and jasmonate are likely involved in thigmomorphogenesis.
7.30.744	Defense Responses against Herbivores and Pathogens Plants face two types of enemies: herbivores and pathogens.
7.30.745	Herbivores both large and small use plants as food, and actively chew them.
7.30.746	Pathogens are agents of disease.
7.30.747	These infectious microorganisms, such as fungi, bacteria, and nematodes, live off of the plant and damage its tissues.
7.30.748	Plants have developed a variety of strategies to discourage or kill attackers.
7.30.749	The first line of defense in plants is an intact and impenetrable barrier.
7.30.750	Bark and the waxy cuticle can protect against predators.
7.30.751	Other adaptations against herbivory include thorns, which are modified branches, and spines, which are modified leaves.
7.30.752	They discourage animals by causing physical damage and inducing rashes and allergic reactions.
7.30.753	A plant’s exterior protection can be compromised by mechanical damage, which may provide an entry point for pathogens.
7.30.754	If the first line of defense is breached, the plant must resort to a different set of defense mechanisms, such as toxins and enzymes.
7.30.755	Secondary metabolites are compounds that are not directly derived from photosynthesis and are not necessary for respiration or plant growth and development.
7.30.756	Many metabolites are toxic, and can even be lethal to animals that ingest them.
7.30.757	Some metabolites are alkaloids, which discourage predators with noxious odors (such as the volatile oils of mint and sage) or repellent tastes (like the bitterness of quinine).
7.30.758	Other alkaloids affect herbivores by causing either excessive stimulation (caffeine is one example) or the lethargy associated with opioids.
7.30.759	Some compounds become toxic after ingestion; for instance, glycol cyanide in the cassava root releases cyanide only upon ingestion by the herbivore.
7.30.760	Mechanical wounding and predator attacks activate defense and protection mechanisms both in the damaged tissue and at sites farther from the injury location.
7.30.761	Some defense reactions occur within minutes: others over several hours.
7.30.762	The infected and surrounding cells may die, thereby stopping the spread of infection.
7.30.763	Long-distance signaling elicits a systemic response aimed at deterring the predator.
7.30.764	As tissue is damaged, jasmonates may promote the synthesis of compounds that are toxic to predators.
7.30.765	Jasmonates also elicit the synthesis of volatile compounds that attract parasitoids, which are insects that spend their developing stages in or on another insect, and eventually kill their host.
7.30.766	The plant may activate abscission of injured tissue if it is damaged beyond repair.
7.31.0	For this (a) squash seedling (Cucurbita maxima) to develop into a mature plant bearing its (b) fruit, numerous nutritional requirements must be met.
7.31.1	Cucurbitaceae is a family of plants first cultivated in Mesoamerica, although several species are native to North America.
7.31.2	The family includes many edible species, such as squash and pumpkin, as well as inedible gourds.
7.31.3	In order to grow and develop into mature, fruit-bearing plants, many requirements must be met and events must be coordinated.
7.31.4	Seeds must germinate under the right conditions in the soil; therefore, temperature, moisture, and soil quality are important factors that play a role in germination and seedling development.
7.31.5	Soil quality and climate are significant to plant distribution and growth.
7.31.6	The young seedling will eventually grow into a mature plant, and the roots will absorb nutrients and water from the soil.
7.31.7	At the same time, the aboveground parts of the plant will absorb carbon dioxide from the atmosphere and use energy from sunlight to produce organic compounds through photosynthesis.
7.31.8	This chapter will explore the complex dynamics between plants and soils, and the adaptations that plants have evolved to make better use of nutritional resources.
7.31.9	Nutritional Requirements of Plants
7.31.10	By the end of this section, you will be able to: Describe how plants obtain nutrients List the elements and compounds required for proper plant nutrition Describe an essential nutrient Plants are unique organisms that can absorb nutrients and water through their root system, as well as carbon dioxide from the atmosphere.
7.31.11	Soil quality and climate are the major determinants of plant distribution and growth.
7.31.12	The combination of soil nutrients, water, and carbon dioxide, along with sunlight, allows plants to grow.
7.31.13	The Chemical Composition of Plants Since plants require nutrients in the form of elements such as carbon and potassium
7.31.14	, it is important to understand the chemical composition of plants.
7.31.15	The majority of volume in a plant cell is water; it typically comprises 80 to 90 percent of the plant’s total weight.
7.31.16	Soil is the water source for land plants, and can be an abundant source of water, even if it appears dry.
7.31.17	Plant roots absorb water from the soil through root hairs and transport it up to the leaves through the xylem.
7.31.18	As water vapor is lost from the leaves, the process of transpiration and the polarity of water molecules (which enables them to form hydrogen bonds) draws more water from the roots up through the plant to the leaves (Figure 31.2).
7.31.19	Plants need water to support cell structure, for metabolic functions, to carry nutrients, and for photosynthesis.
7.31.20	Water is absorbed through the root hairs and moves up the xylem to the leaves.
7.31.21	Plant cells need essential substances, collectively called nutrients, to sustain life.
7.31.22	Plant nutrients may be composed of either organic or inorganic compounds.
7.31.23	An organic compound is a chemical compound that contains carbon, such as carbon dioxide obtained from the atmosphere.
7.31.24	Carbon that was obtained from atmospheric CO2 composes the majority of the dry mass within most plants.
7.31.25	An inorganic compound does not contain carbon and is not part of, or produced by, a living organism.
7.31.26	Inorganic substances, which form the majority of the soil solution, are commonly called minerals: those required by plants include nitrogen (N) and potassium (K) for structure and regulation.
7.31.27	Essential Nutrients Plants require only light, water and about 20 elements to support all their biochemical needs: these 20 elements are called essential nutrients (Table 31.1).
7.31.28	For an element to be regarded as essential, three criteria are required: 1) a plant cannot complete its life cycle without the element; 2) no other element can perform the function of the element; and 3) the element is directly involved in plant nutrition.
7.31.29	Macronutrients and Micronutrients
7.31.30	The essential elements can be divided into two groups: macronutrients and micronutrients.
7.31.31	Nutrients that plants require in larger amounts are called macronutrients.
7.31.32	About half of the essential elements are considered macronutrients: carbon, hydrogen, oxygen, nitrogen, phosphorus, potassium, calcium, magnesium and sulfur.
7.31.33	The first of these macronutrients, carbon (C), is required to form carbohydrates, proteins, nucleic acids, and many other compounds; it is therefore present in all macromolecules.
7.31.34	On average, the dry weight (excluding water) of a cell is 50 percent carbon.
7.31.35	As shown in Figure 31.3, carbon is a key part of plant biomolecules.
7.31.36	Cellulose, the main structural component of the plant cell wall, makes up over thirty percent of plant matter.
7.31.37	It is the most abundant organic compound on earth.
7.31.38	Plants are able to make their own cellulose, but need carbon from the soil to do so.
7.31.39	The next most abundant element in plant cells is nitrogen (N); it is part of proteins and nucleic acids.
7.31.40	Nitrogen is also used in the synthesis of some vitamins.
7.31.41	Hydrogen and oxygen are macronutrients that are part of many organic compounds, and also form water.
7.31.42	Oxygen is necessary for cellular respiration; plants use oxygen to store energy in the form of ATP.
7.31.43	Phosphorus (P), another macromolecule, is necessary to synthesize nucleic acids and phospholipids.
7.31.44	As part of ATP, phosphorus enables food energy to be converted into chemical energy through oxidative phosphorylation.
7.31.45	Likewise, light energy is converted into chemical energy during photophosphorylation in photosynthesis, and into chemical energy to be extracted during respiration.
7.31.46	Sulfur is part of certain amino acids, such as cysteine and methionine, and is present in several coenzymes.
7.31.47	Sulfur also plays a role in photosynthesis as part of the electron transport chain, where hydrogen gradients play a key role in the conversion of light energy into ATP.
7.31.48	Potassium (K) is important because of its role in regulating stomatal opening and closing.
7.31.49	As the openings for gas exchange, stomata help maintain a healthy water balance; a potassium ion pump supports this process.
7.31.50	Magnesium (Mg) and calcium (Ca) are also important macronutrients.
7.31.51	The role of calcium is twofold: to regulate nutrient transport, and to support many enzyme functions.
7.31.52	Magnesium is important to the photosynthetic process.
7.31.53	These minerals, along with the micronutrients, which are described below, also contribute to the plant’s ionic balance.
7.31.54	In addition to macronutrients, organisms require various elements in small amounts.
7.31.55	These micronutrients, or trace elements, are present in very small quantities.
7.31.56	They include boron (B), chlorine (Cl), manganese (Mn), iron (Fe), zinc (Zn), copper (Cu), molybdenum (Mo), nickel (Ni), silicon (Si), and sodium (Na).
7.31.57	Deficiencies in any of these nutrients—particularly the macronutrients—can adversely affect plant growth (Figure 31.4.
7.31.58	Depending on the specific nutrient, a lack can cause stunted growth, slow growth, or chlorosis (yellowing of the leaves).
7.31.59	Extreme deficiencies may result in leaves showing signs of cell death.
7.31.60	Nutrient deficiency is evident in the symptoms these plants show.
7.31.61	This (a) grape tomato suffers from blossom end rot caused by calcium deficiency.
7.31.62	The yellowing in this (b) Frangula alnus results from magnesium deficiency.
7.31.63	Inadequate magnesium also leads to (c) intervenal chlorosis, seen here in a sweetgum leaf.
7.31.64	This (d) palm is affected by potassium deficiency.
7.31.65	The Soil
7.31.66	By the end of this section, you will be able to:
7.31.67	Describe how soils are formed Explain soil composition Describe a soil profile Plants obtain inorganic elements from the soil, which serves as a natural medium for land plants.
7.31.68	Soil is the outer loose layer that covers the surface of Earth.
7.31.69	Soil quality is a major determinant, along with climate, of plant distribution and growth.
7.31.70	Soil quality depends not only on the chemical composition of the soil, but also the topography (regional surface features) and the presence of living organisms.
7.31.71	In agriculture, the history of the soil, such as the cultivating practices and previous crops, modify the characteristics and fertility of that soil.
7.31.72	Soil develops very slowly over long periods of time, and its formation results from natural and environmental forces acting on mineral, rock, and organic compounds.
7.31.73	Soils can be divided into two groups: organic soils are those that are formed from sedimentation and primarily composed of organic matter, while those that are formed from the weathering of rocks and are primarily composed of inorganic material are called mineral soils.
7.31.74	Mineral soils are predominant in terrestrial ecosystems, where soils may be covered by water for part of the year or exposed to the atmosphere.
7.31.75	Soil Composition Soil consists of these major components (Figure 31.5): • inorganic mineral matter, about 40 to 45 percent of the soil volume • organic matter, about 5 percent of the soil volume • water and air, about 50 percent of the soil volume
7.31.76	The amount of each of the four major components of soil depends on the amount of vegetation, soil compaction, and water present in the soil.
7.31.77	A good healthy soil has sufficient air, water, minerals, and organic material to promote and sustain plant life.
7.31.78	The organic material of soil, called humus, is made up of microorganisms (dead and alive), and dead animals and plants in varying stages of decay.
7.31.79	Humus improves soil structure and provides plants with water and minerals.
7.31.80	The inorganic material of soil consists of rock, slowly broken down into smaller particles that vary in size.
7.31.81	Soil particles that are 0.1 to 2 mm in diameter are sand.
7.31.82	Soil particles between 0.002 and 0.1 mm are called silt, and even smaller particles, less than 0.002 mm in diameter, are called clay.
7.31.83	Some soils have no dominant particle size and contain a mixture of sand, silt, and humus; these soils are called loams.
7.31.84	Soil Formation Soil formation is the consequence of a combination of biological, physical, and chemical processes.
7.31.85	Soil should ideally contain 50 percent solid material and 50 percent pore space.
7.31.86	About one-half of the pore space should contain water, and the other half should contain air.
7.31.87	The organic component of soil serves as a cementing agent, returns nutrients to the plant, allows soil to store moisture, makes soil tillable for farming, and provides energy for soil microorganisms.
7.31.88	Most soil microorganisms—bacteria, algae, or fungi—are dormant in dry soil, but become active once moisture is available.
7.31.89	Soil distribution is not homogenous because its formation results in the production of layers; together, the vertical section of a soil is called the soil profile.
7.31.90	Within the soil profile, soil scientists define zones called horizons.
7.31.91	A horizon is a soil layer with distinct physical and chemical properties that differ from those of other layers.
7.31.92	Five factors account for soil formation: parent material, climate, topography, biological factors, and time.
7.31.93	Parent Material
7.31.94	The organic and inorganic material in which soils form is the parent material.
7.31.95	Mineral soils form directly from the weathering of bedrock, the solid rock that lies beneath the soil, and therefore, they have a similar composition to the original rock.
7.31.96	Other soils form in materials that came from elsewhere, such as sand and glacial drift.
7.31.97	Materials located in the depth of the soil are relatively unchanged compared with the deposited material.
7.31.98	Sediments in rivers may have different characteristics, depending on whether the stream moves quickly or slowly.
7.31.99	A fast-moving river could have sediments of rocks and sand, whereas a slow-moving river could have fine-textured material, such as clay.
7.31.100	Climate Temperature, moisture, and wind cause different patterns of weathering and therefore affect soil characteristics.
7.31.101	The presence of moisture and nutrients from weathering will also promote biological activity: a key component of a quality soil.
7.31.102	Topography Regional surface features (familiarly called “the lay of the land”) can have a major influence on the characteristics and fertility of a soil.
7.31.103	Topography affects water runoff, which strips away parent material and affects plant growth.
7.31.104	Steeps soils are more prone to erosion and may be thinner than soils that are relatively flat or level.
7.31.105	Biological factors
7.31.106	The presence of living organisms greatly affects soil formation and structure.
7.31.107	Animals and microorganisms can produce pores and crevices, and plant roots can penetrate into crevices to produce more fragmentation.
7.31.108	Plant secretions promote the development of microorganisms around the root, in an area known as the rhizosphere.
7.31.109	Additionally, leaves and other material that fall from plants decompose and contribute to soil composition.
7.31.110	Time Time is an important factor in soil formation because soils develop over long periods.
7.31.111	Soil formation is a dynamic process.
7.31.112	Materials are deposited over time, decompose, and transform into other materials that can be used by living organisms or deposited onto the surface of the soil.
7.31.113	Physical Properties of the Soil Soils are named and classified based on their horizons.
7.31.114	The soil profile has four distinct layers: 1)
7.31.115	O horizon; 2)
7.31.116	A horizon; 3) B horizon, or subsoil; and 4) C horizon, or soil base (Figure 31.6).
7.31.117	The O horizon has freshly decomposing organic matter—humus—at its surface, with decomposed vegetation at its base.
7.31.118	Humus enriches the soil with nutrients and enhances soil moisture retention.
7.31.119	Topsoil—
7.31.120	the top layer of soil—is usually two to three inches deep, but this depth can vary considerably.
7.31.121	For instance, river deltas like the Mississippi River delta have deep layers of topsoil.
7.31.122	Topsoil is rich in organic material; microbial processes occur there, and it is the “workhorse” of plant production.
7.31.123	The A horizon consists of a mixture of organic material with inorganic products of weathering, and it is therefore the beginning of true mineral soil.
7.31.124	This horizon is typically darkly colored because of the presence of organic matter.
7.31.125	In this area, rainwater percolates through the soil and carries materials from the surface.
7.31.126	The B horizon is an accumulation of mostly fine material that has moved downward, resulting in a dense layer in the soil.
7.31.127	In some soils, the B horizon contains nodules or a layer of calcium carbonate.
7.31.128	The C horizon, or soil base, includes the parent material, plus the organic and inorganic material that is broken down to form soil.
7.31.129	The parent material may be either created in its natural place, or transported from elsewhere to its present location.
7.31.130	Beneath the C horizon lies bedrock.
7.31.131	Some soils may have additional layers, or lack one of these layers.
7.31.132	The thickness of the layers is also variable, and depends on the factors that influence soil formation.
7.31.133	In general, immature soils may have O, A, and C horizons, whereas mature soils may display all of these, plus additional layers.
7.31.134	The San Joaquin soil profile has an O horizon, A horizon, B horizon, and C horizon.
7.31.135	Nutritional Adaptations of Plants
7.31.136	By the end of this section, you will be able to: Understand the nutritional adaptations of plants Describe mycorrhizae
7.31.137	Explain nitrogen fixation Plants obtain food in two different ways.
7.31.138	Autotrophic plants can make their own food from inorganic raw materials, such as carbon dioxide and water, through photosynthesis in the presence of sunlight.
7.31.139	Green plants are included in this group.
7.31.140	Some plants, however, are heterotrophic: they are totally parasitic and lacking in chlorophyll.
7.31.141	These plants, referred to as holo-parasitic plants, are unable to synthesize organic carbon and draw all of their nutrients from the host plant.
7.31.142	Plants may also enlist the help of microbial partners in nutrient acquisition.
7.31.143	Particular species of bacteria and fungi have evolved along with certain plants to create a mutualistic symbiotic relationship with roots.
7.31.144	This improves the nutrition of both the plant and the microbe.
7.31.145	The formation of nodules in legume plants and mycorrhization can be considered among the nutritional adaptations of plants.
7.31.146	However, these are not the only type of adaptations that we may find; many plants have other adaptations that allow them to thrive under specific conditions.
7.31.147	Nitrogen Fixation: Root and Bacteria Interactions Nitrogen is an important macronutrient because it is part of nucleic acids and proteins.
7.31.148	Atmospheric nitrogen, which is the diatomic molecule N2, or dinitrogen, is the largest pool of nitrogen in terrestrial ecosystems.
7.31.149	However, plants cannot take advantage of this nitrogen because they do not have the necessary enzymes to convert it into biologically useful forms.
7.31.150	However, nitrogen can be “fixed,” which means that it can be converted to ammonia (NH3) through biological, physical, or chemical processes.
7.31.151	As you have learned, biological nitrogen fixation (BNF) is the conversion of atmospheric nitrogen (N2) into ammonia (NH3), exclusively carried out by prokaryotes such as soil bacteria or cyanobacteria.
7.31.152	Biological processes contribute 65 percent of the nitrogen used in agriculture.
7.31.153	The following equation represents the process: N2 + 16 ATP + 8 e− +
7.31.154	8
7.31.155	H+
7.31.156	→
7.31.157	2NH3 +
7.31.158	16 ADP +
7.31.159	16 Pi + H2
7.31.160	The most important source of BNF is the symbiotic interaction between soil bacteria and legume plants, including many crops important to humans (Figure 31.9).
7.31.161	The NH3 resulting from fixation can be transported into plant tissue and incorporated into amino acids, which are then made into plant proteins.
7.31.162	Some legume seeds, such as soybeans and peanuts, contain high levels of protein, and serve among the most important agricultural sources of protein in the world.
7.31.163	Soil bacteria, collectively called rhizobia, symbiotically interact with legume roots to form specialized structures called nodules, in which nitrogen fixation takes place.
7.31.164	This process entails the reduction of atmospheric nitrogen to ammonia, by means of the enzyme nitrogenase.
7.31.165	Therefore, using rhizobia is a natural and environmentally friendly way to fertilize plants, as opposed to chemical fertilization that uses a nonrenewable resource, such as natural gas.
7.31.166	Through symbiotic nitrogen fixation, the plant benefits from using an endless source of nitrogen from the atmosphere.
7.31.167	The process simultaneously contributes to soil fertility because the plant root system leaves behind some of the biologically available nitrogen.
7.31.168	As in any symbiosis, both organisms benefit from the interaction: the plant obtains ammonia, and bacteria obtain carbon compounds generated through photosynthesis, as well as a protected niche in which to grow.
7.31.169	Soybean roots contain (a) nitrogen-fixing nodules.
7.31.170	Cells within the nodules are infected with Bradyrhyzobium japonicum, a rhizobia or “root-loving” bacterium.
7.31.171	The bacteria are encased in (b) vesicles inside the cell, as can be seen in this transmission electron micrograph.
7.31.172	Mycorrhizae:
7.31.173	The Symbiotic Relationship between Fungi and Roots
7.31.174	A nutrient depletion zone can develop when there is rapid soil solution uptake, low nutrient concentration, low diffusion rate, or low soil moisture.
7.31.175	These conditions are very common; therefore, most plants rely on fungi to facilitate the uptake of minerals from the soil.
7.31.176	Fungi form symbiotic associations called mycorrhizae with plant roots, in which the fungi actually are integrated into the physical structure of the root.
7.31.177	The fungi colonize the living root tissue during active plant growth.
7.31.178	Through mycorrhization, the plant obtains mainly phosphate and other minerals, such as zinc and copper, from the soil.
7.31.179	The fungus obtains nutrients, such as sugars, from the plant root (Figure 31.11).
7.31.180	Mycorrhizae help increase the surface area of the plant root system because hyphae, which are narrow, can spread beyond the nutrient depletion zone.
7.31.181	Hyphae can grow into small soil pores that allow access to phosphorus that would otherwise be unavailable to the plant.
7.31.182	The beneficial effect on the plant is best observed in poor soils.
7.31.183	The benefit to fungi is that they can obtain up to 20 percent of the total carbon accessed by plants.
7.31.184	Mycorrhizae functions as a physical barrier to pathogens.
7.31.185	It also provides an induction of generalized host defense mechanisms, and sometimes involves production of antibiotic compounds by the fungi.
7.31.186	Root tips proliferate in the presence of mycorrhizal infection, which appears as off-white fuzz in this image.
7.31.187	There are two types of mycorrhizae: ectomycorrhizae and endomycorrhizae.
7.31.188	Ectomycorrhizae form an extensive dense sheath around the roots, called a mantle.
7.31.189	Hyphae from the fungi extend from the mantle into the soil, which increases the surface area for water and mineral absorption.
7.31.190	This type of mycorrhizae is found in forest trees, especially conifers, birches, and oaks.
7.31.191	Endomycorrhizae, also called arbuscular mycorrhizae, do not form a dense sheath over the root.
7.31.192	Instead, the fungal mycelium is embedded within the root tissue.
7.31.193	Endomycorrhizae are found in the roots of more than 80 percent of terrestrial plants.
7.31.194	Nutrients from Other Sources
7.31.195	Some plants cannot produce their own food and must obtain their nutrition from outside sources.
7.31.196	This may occur with plants that are parasitic or saprophytic.
7.31.197	Some plants are mutualistic symbionts, epiphytes, or insectivorous.
7.31.198	Plant Parasites
7.31.199	A parasitic plant depends on its host for survival.
7.31.200	Some parasitic plants have no leaves.
7.31.201	An example of this is the dodder (Figure 31.12), which has a weak, cylindrical stem that coils around the host and forms suckers.
7.31.202	From these suckers, cells invade the host stem and grow to connect with the vascular bundles of the host.
7.31.203	The parasitic plant obtains water and nutrients through these connections.
7.31.204	The plant is a total parasite (a holoparasite) because it is completely dependent on its host.
7.31.205	Other parasitic plants (hemiparasites) are fully photosynthetic and only use the host for water and minerals.
7.31.206	There are about 4,100 species of parasitic plants.
7.31.207	The dodder is a holoparasite that penetrates the host’s vascular tissue and diverts nutrients for its own growth.
7.31.208	Note that the vines of the dodder, which has white flowers, are beige.
7.31.209	The dodder has no chlorophyll and cannot produce its own food.
7.31.210	Saprophytes
7.31.211	A saprophyte is a plant that does not have chlorophyll and gets its food from dead matter, similar to bacteria and fungi (note that fungi are often called saprophytes, which is incorrect, because fungi are not plants).
7.31.212	Plants like these use enzymes to convert organic food materials into simpler forms from which they can absorb nutrients (Figure 31.13).
7.31.213	Most saprophytes do not directly digest dead matter: instead, they parasitize fungi that digest dead matter, or are mycorrhizal, ultimately obtaining photosynthate from a fungus that derived photosynthate from its host.
7.31.214	Saprophytic plants are uncommon; only a few species are described.
7.31.215	Saprophytes, like this Dutchmen’s pipe (Monotropa hypopitys), obtain their food from dead matter and do not have chlorophyll.
7.31.216	Symbionts
7.31.217	A symbiont is a plant in a symbiotic relationship, with special adaptations such as mycorrhizae or nodule formation.
7.31.218	Fungi also form symbiotic associations with cyanobacteria and green algae (called lichens).
7.31.219	Lichens can sometimes be seen as colorful growths on the surface of rocks and trees (Figure 31.14).
7.31.220	The algal partner (phycobiont) makes food autotrophically, some of which it shares with the fungus; the fungal partner (mycobiont) absorbs water and minerals from the environment, which are made available to the green alga.
7.31.221	If one partner was separated from the other, they would both die.
7.31.222	Lichens, which often have symbiotic relationships with other plants, can sometimes be found growing on trees.
7.31.223	Epiphytes
7.31.224	An epiphyte is a plant that grows on other plants, but is not dependent upon the other plant for nutrition (Figure 31.15).
7.31.225	Epiphytes have two types of roots: clinging aerial roots, which absorb nutrients from humus that accumulates in the crevices of trees; and aerial roots, which absorb moisture from the atmosphere.
7.31.226	These epiphyte plants grow in the main greenhouse of the Jardin des Plantes in Paris.
7.31.227	Insectivorous Plants
7.31.228	An insectivorous plant has specialized leaves to attract and digest insects.
7.31.229	The Venus flytrap is popularly known for its insectivorous mode of nutrition, and has leaves that work as traps (Figure 31.16).
7.31.230	The minerals it obtains from prey compensate for those lacking in the boggy (low pH)
7.31.231	soil of its native North Carolina coastal plains.
7.31.232	There are three sensitive hairs in the center of each half of each leaf.
7.31.233	The edges of each leaf are covered with long spines.
7.31.234	Nectar secreted by the plant attracts flies to the leaf.
7.31.235	When a fly touches the sensory hairs, the leaf immediately closes.
7.31.236	Next, fluids and enzymes break down the prey and minerals are absorbed by the leaf.
7.31.237	Since this plant is popular in the horticultural trade, it is threatened in its original habitat.
7.31.238	A Venus flytrap has specialized leaves to trap insects.
7.32.0	Plants that reproduce sexually often achieve fertilization with the help of pollinators such as (a) bees, (b) birds, and (c) butterflies.
7.32.1	(credit a: modification of work by John Severns; credit b: modification of work by Charles J. Sharp; credit c: modification of work by "Galawebdesign"/Flickr)
7.32.2	Introduction Plants have evolved different reproductive strategies for the continuation of their species.
7.32.3	Some plants reproduce sexually, and others asexually, in contrast to animal species, which rely almost exclusively on sexual reproduction.
7.32.4	Plant sexual reproduction usually depends on pollinating agents, while asexual reproduction is independent of these agents.
7.32.5	Flowers are often the showiest or most strongly scented part of plants.
7.32.6	With their bright colors, fragrances, and interesting shapes and sizes, flowers attract insects, birds, and animals to serve their pollination needs.
7.32.7	Other plants pollinate via wind or water; still others self-pollinate.
7.32.8	Sexual reproduction takes place with slight variations in different groups of plants.
7.32.9	Plants have two distinct stages in their lifecycle: the gametophyte stage and the sporophyte stage.
7.32.10	The haploid gametophyte produces the male and female gametes by mitosis in distinct multicellular structures.
7.32.11	Fusion of the male and females gametes forms the diploid zygote, which develops into the sporophyte.
7.32.12	After reaching maturity, the diploid sporophyte produces spores by meiosis, which in turn divide by mitosis to produce the haploid gametophyte.
7.32.13	The new gametophyte produces gametes, and the cycle continues.
7.32.14	This is the alternation of generations, and is typical of plant reproduction The alternation of generations in angiosperms is depicted in this diagram.
7.32.15	The life cycle of higher plants is dominated by the sporophyte stage, with the gametophyte borne on the sporophyte.
7.32.16	In ferns, the gametophyte is free-living and very distinct in structure from the diploid sporophyte.
7.32.17	In bryophytes, such as mosses, the haploid gametophyte is more developed than the sporophyte.
7.32.18	During the vegetative phase of growth, plants increase in size and produce a shoot system and a root system.
7.32.19	As they enter the reproductive phase, some of the branches start to bear flowers.
7.32.20	Many flowers are borne singly, whereas some are borne in clusters.
7.32.21	The flower is borne on a stalk known as a receptacle.
7.32.22	Flower shape, color, and size are unique to each species, and are often used by taxonomists to classify plants.
7.32.23	Sexual Reproduction in Angiosperms
7.32.24	The lifecycle of angiosperms follows the alternation of generations explained previously.
7.32.25	The haploid gametophyte alternates with the diploid sporophyte during the sexual reproduction process of angiosperms.
7.32.26	Flowers contain the plant’s reproductive structures.
7.32.27	Flower Structure
7.32.28	A typical flower has four main parts—or whorls—known as the calyx, corolla, androecium, and gynoecium (Figure 32.3).
7.32.29	The outermost whorl of the flower has green, leafy structures known as sepals.
7.32.30	The sepals, collectively called the calyx, help to protect the unopened bud.
7.32.31	The second whorl is comprised of petals—usually, brightly colored—collectively called the corolla.
7.32.32	The number of sepals and petals varies depending on whether the plant is a monocot or dicot.
7.32.33	In monocots, petals usually number three or multiples of three; in dicots, the number of petals is four or five, or multiples of four and five.
7.32.34	Together, the calyx and corolla are known as the perianth.
7.32.35	The third whorl contains the male reproductive structures and is known as the androecium.
7.32.36	The androecium has stamens with anthers that contain the microsporangia.
7.32.37	The innermost group of structures in the flower is the gynoecium, or the female reproductive component(s).
7.32.38	The carpel is the individual unit of the gynoecium and has a stigma, style, and ovary.
7.32.39	A flower may have one or multiple carpels.
7.32.40	If all four whorls (the calyx, corolla, androecium, and gynoecium) are present, the flower is described as complete.
7.32.41	If any of the four parts is missing, the flower is known as incomplete.
7.32.42	Flowers that contain both an androecium and a gynoecium are called perfect, androgynous or hermaphrodites.
7.32.43	There are two types of incomplete flowers: staminate flowers contain only an androecium, and carpellate flowers have only a gynoecium
7.32.44	The corn plant has both staminate (male) and carpellate (female) flowers.
7.32.45	Staminate flowers, which are clustered in the tassel at the tip of the stem, produce pollen grains.
7.32.46	Carpellate flower are clustered in the immature ears.
7.32.47	Each strand of silk is a stigma.
7.32.48	The corn kernels are seeds that develop on the ear after fertilization.
7.32.49	Also shown is the lower stem and root.
7.32.50	If both male and female flowers are borne on the same plant, the species is called monoecious (meaning “one home”): examples are corn and pea.
7.32.51	Species with male and female flowers borne on separate plants are termed dioecious, or “two homes,” examples of which are C. papaya and Cannabis.
7.32.52	The ovary, which may contain one or multiple ovules, may be placed above other flower parts, which is referred to as superior; or, it may be placed below the other flower parts, referred to as inferior  
7.32.53	The (a) lily is a superior flower, which has the ovary above the other flower parts.
7.32.54	(b) Fuchsia is an inferior flower, which has the ovary beneath other flower parts.
7.32.55	(credit a photo: modification of work by Benjamin Zwittnig; credit b photo: modification of work by "Koshy Koshy"/Flickr)
7.32.56	Male Gametophyte (The Pollen Grain)
7.32.57	The male gametophyte develops and reaches maturity in an immature anther.
7.32.58	In a plant’s male reproductive organs, development of pollen takes place in a structure known as the microsporangium (Figure 32.6).
7.32.59	The microsporangia, which are usually bi-lobed, are pollen sacs in which the microspores develop into pollen grains.
7.32.60	These are found in the anther, which is at the end of the stamen—the long filament that supports the anther.
7.32.61	Shown is (a) a cross section of an anther at two developmental stages.
7.32.62	The immature anther (top) contains four microsporangia, or pollen sacs.
7.32.63	Each microsporangium contains hundreds of microspore mother cells that will each give rise to four pollen grains.
7.32.64	The tapetum supports the development and maturation of the pollen grains.
7.32.65	Upon maturation of the pollen (bottom), the pollen sac walls split open and the pollen grains (male gametophytes) are released.
7.32.66	(b)
7.32.67	In these scanning electron micrographs, pollen sacs are ready to burst, releasing their grains.
7.32.68	(credit b: modification of work by Robert R. Wise; scale-bar data from Matt Russell)
7.32.69	Within the microsporangium, the microspore mother cell divides by meiosis to give rise to four microspores, each of which will ultimately form a pollen grain (Figure 32.7).
7.32.70	An inner layer of cells, known as the tapetum, provides nutrition to the developing microspores and contributes key components to the pollen wall.
7.32.71	Mature pollen grains contain two cells: a generative cell and a pollen tube cell.
7.32.72	The generative cell is contained within the larger pollen tube cell.
7.32.73	Upon germination, the tube cell forms the pollen tube through which the generative cell migrates to enter the ovary.
7.32.74	During its transit inside the pollen tube, the generative cell divides to form two male gametes (sperm cells).
7.32.75	Upon maturity, the microsporangia burst, releasing the pollen grains from the anther.
7.32.76	Pollen develops from the microspore mother cells.
7.32.77	The mature pollen grain is composed of two cells: the pollen tube cell and the generative cell, which is inside the tube cell.
7.32.78	The pollen grain has two coverings: an inner layer (intine) and an outer layer (exine).
7.32.79	The inset scanning electron micrograph shows Arabidopsis lyrata pollen grains.
7.32.80	(credit “pollen micrograph”: modification of work by Robert R. Wise; scale-bar data from Matt Russell)
7.32.81	Each pollen grain has two coverings: the exine (thicker, outer layer) and the intine (Figure 32.7).
7.32.82	The exine contains sporopollenin, a complex waterproofing substance supplied by the tapetal cells.
7.32.83	Sporopollenin allows the pollen to survive under unfavorable conditions and to be carried by wind, water, or biological agents without undergoing damage.
7.32.84	Female Gametophyte (The Embryo Sac)
7.32.85	While the details may vary between species, the overall development of the female gametophyte has two distinct phases.
7.32.86	First, in the process of megasporogenesis, a single cell in the diploid megasporangium—an area of tissue in the ovules—undergoes meiosis to produce four megaspores, only one of which survives.
7.32.87	During the second phase, megagametogenesis, the surviving haploid megaspore undergoes mitosis to produce an eight-nucleate, seven-cell female gametophyte, also known as the megagametophyte or embryo sac.
7.32.88	Two of the nuclei—
7.32.89	the polar nuclei—move to the equator and fuse, forming a single, diploid central cell.
7.32.90	This central cell later fuses with a sperm to form the triploid endosperm.
7.32.91	Three nuclei position themselves on the end of the embryo sac opposite the micropyle and develop into the antipodal cells, which later degenerate.
7.32.92	The nucleus closest to the micropyle becomes the female gamete, or egg cell, and the two adjacent nuclei develop into synergid cells (Figure 32.8).
7.32.93	The synergids help guide the pollen tube for successful fertilization, after which they disintegrate.
7.32.94	Once fertilization is complete, the resulting diploid zygote develops into the embryo, and the fertilized ovule forms the other tissues of the seed.
7.32.95	A double-layered integument protects the megasporangium and, later, the embryo sac.
7.32.96	The integument will develop into the seed coat after fertilization and protect the entire seed.
7.32.97	The ovule wall will become part of the fruit.
7.32.98	The integuments, while protecting the megasporangium, do not enclose it completely, but leave an opening called the micropyle.
7.32.99	The micropyle allows the pollen tube to enter the female gametophyte for fertilization.
7.32.100	Sexual Reproduction in Gymnosperms
7.32.101	As with angiosperms, the lifecycle of a gymnosperm is also characterized by alternation of generations.
7.32.102	In conifers such as pines, the green leafy part of the plant is the sporophyte, and the cones contain the male and female gametophytes (Figure 32.9).
7.32.103	The female cones are larger than the male cones and are positioned towards the top of the tree; the small, male cones are located in the lower region of the tree.
7.32.104	Because the pollen is shed and blown by the wind, this arrangement makes it difficult for a gymnosperm to self-pollinate.
7.32.105	This image shows the life cycle of a conifer.
7.32.106	Pollen from male cones blows up into upper branches, where it fertilizes female cones.
7.32.107	Examples are shown of female and male cones.
7.32.108	(credit “female”: modification of work by “Geographer”/Wikimedia Commons; credit “male”:
7.32.109	modification of work by Roger Griffith)
7.32.110	Male Gametophyte
7.32.111	A male cone has a central axis on which bracts, a type of modified leaf, are attached.
7.32.112	The bracts are known as microsporophylls (Figure 32.10) and are the sites where microspores will develop.
7.32.113	The microspores develop inside the microsporangium.
7.32.114	Within the microsporangium, cells known as microsporocytes divide by meiosis to produce four haploid microspores.
7.32.115	Further mitosis of the microspore produces two nuclei: the generative nucleus, and the tube nucleus.
7.32.116	Upon maturity, the male gametophyte (pollen) is released from the male cones and is carried by the wind to land on the female cone.
7.32.117	Female Gametophyte
7.32.118	The female cone also has a central axis on which bracts known as megasporophylls (Figure 32.10) are present.
7.32.119	In the female cone, megaspore mother cells are present in the megasporangium.
7.32.120	The megaspore mother cell divides by meiosis to produce four haploid megaspores.
7.32.121	One of the megaspores divides to form the multicellular female gametophyte, while the others divide to form the rest of the structure.
7.32.122	The female gametophyte is contained within a structure called the archegonium.
7.32.123	These series of micrographs shows male and female gymnosperm gametophytes.
7.32.124	(a)
7.32.125	This male cone, shown in cross section, has approximately 20 microsporophylls, each of which produces hundreds of male gametophytes (pollen grains).
7.32.126	(b) Pollen grains are visible in this single microsporophyll.
7.32.127	(c)
7.32.128	This micrograph shows an individual pollen grain.
7.32.129	(d)
7.32.130	This cross section of a female cone shows portions of about 15 megasporophylls.
7.32.131	(e)
7.32.132	The ovule can be seen in this single megasporophyll.
7.32.133	(f)
7.32.134	Within this single ovule are the megaspore mother cell (MMC), micropyle, and a pollen grain.
7.32.135	(credit: modification of work by Robert R. Wise; scale-bar data from Matt Russell) Reproductive Process
7.32.136	Upon landing on the female cone, the tube cell of the pollen forms the pollen tube, through which the generative cell migrates towards the female gametophyte through the micropyle.
7.32.137	It takes approximately one year for the pollen tube to grow and migrate towards the female gametophyte.
7.32.138	The male gametophyte containing the generative cell splits into two sperm nuclei, one of which fuses with the egg, while the other degenerates.
7.32.139	After fertilization of the egg, the diploid zygote is formed, which divides by mitosis to form the embryo.
7.32.140	The scales of the cones are closed during development of the seed.
7.32.141	The seed is covered by a seed coat, which is derived from the female sporophyte.
7.32.142	Seed development takes another one to two years.
7.32.143	Once the seed is ready to be dispersed, the bracts of the female cones open to allow the dispersal of seed; no fruit formation takes place because gymnosperm seeds have no covering.
7.32.144	Angiosperms versus Gymnosperms Gymnosperm reproduction differs from that of angiosperms in several ways (Figure 32.11).
7.32.145	In angiosperms, the female gametophyte exists in an enclosed structure—
7.32.146	the ovule—which is within the ovary; in gymnosperms, the female gametophyte is present on exposed bracts of the female cone.
7.32.147	Double fertilization is a key event in the lifecycle of angiosperms, but is completely absent in gymnosperms.
7.32.148	The male and female gametophyte structures are present on separate male and female cones in gymnosperms, whereas in angiosperms, they are a part of the flower.
7.32.149	Lastly, wind plays an important role in pollination in gymnosperms because pollen is blown by the wind to land on the female cones.
7.32.150	Although many angiosperms are also wind-pollinated, animal pollination is more common.
7.32.151	(a) Angiosperms are flowering plants, and include grasses, herbs, shrubs and most deciduous trees, while (b) gymnosperms are conifers.
7.32.152	Both produce seeds but have different reproductive strategies.
7.32.153	(credit a: modification of work by Wendy Cutler; credit b: modification of work by Lews Castle UHI)
7.32.154	In angiosperms, pollination is defined as the placement or transfer of pollen from the anther to the stigma of the same flower or another flower.
7.32.155	In gymnosperms, pollination involves pollen transfer from the male cone to the female cone.
7.32.156	Upon transfer, the pollen germinates to form the pollen tube and the sperm for fertilizing the egg.
7.32.157	Pollination has been well studied since the time of Gregor Mendel.
7.32.158	Mendel successfully carried out self- as well as cross-pollination in garden peas while studying how characteristics were passed on from one generation to the next.
7.32.159	Today’s crops are a result of plant breeding, which employs artificial selection to produce the present-day cultivars.
7.32.160	A case in point is today's corn, which is a result of years of breeding that started with its ancestor, teosinte.
7.32.161	The teosinte that the ancient Mayans originally began cultivating had tiny seeds—vastly different from today’s relatively giant ears of corn.
7.32.162	Interestingly, though these two plants appear to be entirely different, the genetic difference between them is miniscule.
7.32.163	Pollination takes two forms: self-pollination and cross-pollination.
7.32.164	Self-pollination occurs when the pollen from the anther is deposited on the stigma of the same flower, or another flower on the same plant.
7.32.165	Cross-pollination is the transfer of pollen from the anther of one flower to the stigma of another flower on a different individual of the same species.
7.32.166	Self- pollination occurs in flowers where the stamen and carpel mature at the same time, and are positioned so that the pollen can land on the flower’s stigma.
7.32.167	This method of pollination does not require an investment from the plant to provide nectar and pollen as food for pollinators.
7.32.168	Living species are designed to ensure survival of their progeny; those that fail become extinct.
7.32.169	Genetic diversity is therefore required so that in changing environmental or stress conditions, some of the progeny can survive.
7.32.170	Self-pollination leads to the production of plants with less genetic diversity, since genetic material from the same plant is used to form gametes, and eventually, the zygote.
7.32.171	In contrast, cross-pollination—or out-crossing—leads to greater genetic diversity because the microgametophyte and megagametophyte are derived from different plants.
7.32.172	Because cross-pollination allows for more genetic diversity, plants have developed many ways to avoid self-pollination.
7.32.173	In some species, the pollen and the ovary mature at different times.
7.32.174	These flowers make self-pollination nearly impossible.
7.32.175	By the time pollen matures and has been shed, the stigma of this flower is mature and can only be pollinated by pollen from another flower.
7.32.176	Some flowers have developed physical features that prevent self-pollination.
7.32.177	The primrose is one such flower.
7.32.178	Primroses have evolved two flower types with differences in anther and stigma length: the pin-eyed flower has anthers positioned at the pollen tube’s halfway point, and the thrum-eyed flower’s stigma is likewise located at the halfway point.
7.32.179	Insects easily cross-pollinate while seeking the nectar at the bottom of the pollen tube.
7.32.180	This phenomenon is also known as heterostyly.
7.32.181	Many plants, such as cucumber, have male and female flowers located on different parts of the plant, thus making self-pollination difficult.
7.32.182	In yet other species, the male and female flowers are borne on different plants (dioecious).
7.32.183	All of these are barriers to self-pollination; therefore, the plants depend on pollinators to transfer pollen.
7.32.184	The majority of pollinators are biotic agents such as insects (like bees, flies, and butterflies), bats, birds, and other animals.
7.32.185	Other plant species are pollinated by abiotic agents, such as wind and water.
7.32.186	Pollination by Insects Bees are perhaps the most important pollinator of many garden plants and most commercial fruit trees (Figure 32.12).
7.32.187	The most common species of bees are bumblebees and honeybees.
7.32.188	Since bees cannot see the color red, bee-pollinated flowers usually have shades of blue, yellow, or other colors.
7.32.189	Bees collect energy-rich pollen or nectar for their survival and energy needs.
7.32.190	They visit flowers that are open during the day, are brightly colored, have a strong aroma or scent, and have a tubular shape, typically with the presence of a nectar guide.
7.32.191	A nectar guide includes regions on the flower petals that are visible only to bees, and not to humans; it helps to guide bees to the center of the flower, thus making the pollination process more efficient.
7.32.192	The pollen sticks to the bees’ fuzzy hair, and when the bee visits another flower, some of the pollen is transferred to the second flower.
7.32.193	Recently, there have been many reports about the declining population of honeybees.
7.32.194	Many flowers will remain unpollinated and not bear seed if honeybees disappear.
7.32.195	The impact on commercial fruit growers could be devastating.
7.32.196	Insects, such as bees, are important agents of pollination.
7.32.197	Many flies are attracted to flowers that have a decaying smell or an odor of rotting flesh.
7.32.198	These flowers, which produce nectar, usually have dull colors, such as brown or purple.
7.32.199	They are found on the corpse flower or voodoo lily (Amorphophallus), dragon arum (Dracunculus), and carrion flower (Stapleia, Rafflesia).
7.32.200	The nectar provides energy, whereas the pollen provides protein.
7.32.201	Wasps are also important insect pollinators, and pollinate many species of figs.
7.32.202	Butterflies, such as the monarch, pollinate many garden flowers and wildflowers, which usually occur in clusters.
7.32.203	These flowers are brightly colored, have a strong fragrance, are open during the day, and have nectar guides to make access to nectar easier.
7.32.204	The pollen is picked up and carried on the butterfly’s limbs.
7.32.205	Moths, on the other hand, pollinate flowers during the late afternoon and night.
7.32.206	The flowers pollinated by moths are pale or white and are flat, enabling the moths to land.
7.32.207	One well-studied example of a moth-pollinated plant is the yucca plant, which is pollinated by the yucca moth.
7.32.208	The shape of the flower and moth have adapted in such a way as to allow successful pollination.
7.32.209	The moth deposits pollen on the sticky stigma for fertilization to occur later.
7.32.210	The female moth also deposits eggs into the ovary.
7.32.211	As the eggs develop into larvae, they obtain food from the flower and developing seeds.
7.32.212	Thus, both the insect and flower benefit from each other in this symbiotic relationship.
7.32.213	The corn earworm moth and Gaura plant have a similar relationship.
7.32.214	A corn earworm sips nectar from a night-blooming Gaura plant.
7.32.215	Pollination by Bats
7.32.216	In the tropics and deserts, bats are often the pollinators of nocturnal flowers such as agave, guava, and morning glory.
7.32.217	The flowers are usually large and white or pale-colored; thus, they can be distinguished from the dark surroundings at night.
7.32.218	The flowers have a strong, fruity, or musky fragrance and produce large amounts of nectar.
7.32.219	They are naturally large and wide-mouthed to accommodate the head of the bat.
7.32.220	As the bats seek the nectar, their faces and heads become covered with pollen, which is then transferred to the next flower.
7.32.221	Pollination by Birds
7.32.222	Many species of small birds, such as the hummingbird (Figure 32.14) and sun birds, are pollinators for plants such as orchids and other wildflowers.
7.32.223	Flowers visited by birds are usually sturdy and are oriented in such a way as to allow the birds to stay near the flower without getting their wings entangled in the nearby flowers.
7.32.224	The flower typically has a curved, tubular shape, which allows access for the bird’s beak.
7.32.225	Brightly colored, odorless flowers that are open during the day are pollinated by birds.
7.32.226	As a bird seeks energy-rich nectar, pollen is deposited on the bird’s head and neck and is then transferred to the next flower it visits.
7.32.227	Botanists have been known to determine the range of extinct plants by collecting and identifying pollen from 200-year-old bird specimens from the same site.
7.32.228	Hummingbirds have adaptations that allow them to reach the nectar of certain tubular flowers.
7.32.229	Pollination by Wind
7.32.230	Most species of conifers, and many angiosperms, such as grasses, maples and oaks, are pollinated by wind.
7.32.231	Pine cones are brown and unscented, while the flowers of wind-pollinated angiosperm species are usually green, small, may have small or no petals, and produce large amounts of pollen.
