7.32.232	Unlike the typical insect-pollinated flowers, flowers adapted to pollination by wind do not produce nectar or scent.
7.32.233	In wind-pollinated species, the microsporangia hang out of the flower, and, as the wind blows, the lightweight pollen is carried with it (Figure 32.15).
7.32.234	The flowers usually emerge early in the spring, before the leaves, so that the leaves do not block the movement of the wind.
7.32.235	The pollen is deposited on the exposed feathery stigma of the flower (Figure 32.16).
7.32.236	These male (a) and female (b) catkins are from the goat willow tree (Salix caprea).
7.32.237	Note how both structures are light and feathery to better disperse and catch the wind-blown pollen.
7.32.238	Pollination by Water
7.32.239	Some weeds, such as Australian sea grass and pond weeds, are pollinated by water.
7.32.240	The pollen floats on water, and when it comes into contact with the flower, it is deposited inside the flower.
7.32.241	Double Fertilization
7.32.242	After pollen is deposited on the stigma, it must germinate and grow through the style to reach the ovule.
7.32.243	The microspores, or the pollen, contain two cells: the pollen tube cell and the generative cell.
7.32.244	The pollen tube cell grows into a pollen tube through which the generative cell travels.
7.32.245	The germination of the pollen tube requires water, oxygen, and certain chemical signals.
7.32.246	As it travels through the style to reach the embryo sac, the pollen tube’s growth is supported by the tissues of the style.
7.32.247	In the meantime, if the generative cell has not already split into two cells, it now divides to form two sperm cells.
7.32.248	The pollen tube is guided by the chemicals secreted by the synergids present in the embryo sac, and it enters the ovule sac through the micropyle.
7.32.249	Of the two sperm cells, one sperm fertilizes the egg cell, forming a diploid zygote; the other sperm fuses with the two polar nuclei, forming a triploid cell that develops into the endosperm.
7.32.250	Together, these two fertilization events in angiosperms are known as double fertilization (Figure 32.18).
7.32.251	After fertilization is complete, no other sperm can enter.
7.32.252	The fertilized ovule forms the seed, whereas the tissues of the ovary become the fruit, usually enveloping the seed.
7.32.253	In angiosperms, one sperm fertilizes the egg to form the 2n zygote, and the other sperm fertilizes the central cell to form the 3n endosperm.
7.32.254	This is called a double fertilization.
7.32.255	After fertilization, the zygote divides to form two cells: the upper cell, or terminal cell, and the lower, or basal, cell.
7.32.256	The division of the basal cell gives rise to the suspensor, which eventually makes connection with the maternal tissue.
7.32.257	The suspensor provides a route for nutrition to be transported from the mother plant to the growing embryo.
7.32.258	The terminal cell also divides, giving rise to a globular-shaped proembryo (Figure 32.19a).
7.32.259	In dicots (eudicots), the developing embryo has a heart shape, due to the presence of the two rudimentary cotyledons (Figure 32.19b).
7.32.260	In non-endospermic dicots, such as Capsella bursa, the endosperm develops initially, but is then digested, and the food reserves are moved into the two cotyledons.
7.32.261	As the embryo and cotyledons enlarge, they run out of room inside the developing seed, and are forced to bend (Figure 32.19c).
7.32.262	Ultimately, the embryo and cotyledons fill the seed (Figure 32.19d), and the seed is ready for dispersal.
7.32.263	Embryonic development is suspended after some time, and growth is resumed only when the seed germinates.
7.32.264	The developing seedling will rely on the food reserves stored in the cotyledons until the first set of leaves begin photosynthesis.
7.32.265	Shown are the stages of embryo development in the ovule of a shepherd’s purse (Capsella bursa).
7.32.266	After fertilization, the zygote divides to form an upper terminal cell and a lower basal cell.
7.32.267	(a)
7.32.268	In the first stage of development, the terminal cell divides, forming a globular pro-embryo.
7.32.269	The basal cell also divides, giving rise to the suspensor.
7.32.270	(b)
7.32.271	In the second stage, the developing embryo has a heart shape due to the presence of cotyledons.
7.32.272	(c)
7.32.273	In the third stage, the growing embryo runs out of room and starts to bend.
7.32.274	(d)
7.32.275	Eventually, it completely fills the seed.
7.32.276	(credit: modification of work by Robert R. Wise; scale-bar data from Matt Russell) Development of the Seed
7.32.277	The mature ovule develops into the seed.
7.32.278	A typical seed contains a seed coat, cotyledons, endosperm, and a single embryo.
7.32.279	The storage of food reserves in angiosperm seeds differs between monocots and dicots.
7.32.280	In monocots, such as corn and wheat, the single cotyledon is called a scutellum; the scutellum is connected directly to the embryo via vascular tissue (xylem and phloem).
7.32.281	Food reserves are stored in the large endosperm.
7.32.282	Upon germination, enzymes are secreted by the aleurone, a single layer of cells just inside the seed coat that surrounds the endosperm and embryo.
7.32.283	The enzymes degrade the stored carbohydrates, proteins and lipids, the products of which are absorbed by the scutellum and transported via a vasculature strand to the developing embryo.
7.32.284	Therefore, the scutellum can be seen to be an absorptive organ, not a storage organ.
7.32.285	The two cotyledons in the dicot seed also have vascular connections to the embryo.
7.32.286	In endospermic dicots, the food reserves are stored in the endosperm.
7.32.287	During germination, the two cotyledons therefore act as absorptive organs to take up the enzymatically released food reserves, much like in monocots (monocots, by definition, also have endospermic seeds).
7.32.288	Tobacco (Nicotiana tabaccum), tomato (Solanum lycopersicum), and pepper (Capsicum annuum) are examples of endospermic dicots.
7.32.289	In non-endospermic dicots, the triploid endosperm develops normally following double fertilization, but the endosperm food reserves are quickly remobilized and moved into the developing cotyledon for storage.
7.32.290	The two halves of a peanut seed (Arachis hypogaea) and the split peas (Pisum sativum) of split pea soup are individual cotyledons loaded with food reserves.
7.32.291	The seed, along with the ovule, is protected by a seed coat that is formed from the integuments of the ovule sac.
7.32.292	In dicots, the seed coat is further divided into an outer coat known as the testa and inner coat known as the tegmen.
7.32.293	The embryonic axis consists of three parts: the plumule, the radicle, and the hypocotyl.
7.32.294	The portion of the embryo between the cotyledon attachment point and the radicle is known as the hypocotyl (hypocotyl means “below the cotyledons”).
7.32.295	The embryonic axis terminates in a radicle (the embryonic root), which is the region from which the root will develop.
7.32.296	In dicots, the hypocotyls extend above ground, giving rise to the stem of the plant.
7.32.297	In monocots, the hypocotyl does not show above ground because monocots do not exhibit stem elongation.
7.32.298	The part of the embryonic axis that projects above the cotyledons is known as the epicotyl.
7.32.299	The plumule is composed of the epicotyl, young leaves, and the shoot apical meristem.
7.32.300	Upon germination in dicot seeds, the epicotyl is shaped like a hook with the plumule pointing downwards.
7.32.301	This shape is called the plumule hook, and it persists as long as germination proceeds in the dark.
7.32.302	Therefore, as the epicotyl pushes through the tough and abrasive soil, the plumule is protected from damage.
7.32.303	Upon exposure to light, the hypocotyl hook straightens out, the young foliage leaves face the sun and expand, and the epicotyl continues to elongate.
7.32.304	During this time, the radicle is also growing and producing the primary root.
7.32.305	As it grows downward to form the tap root, lateral roots branch off to all sides, producing the typical dicot tap root system.
7.32.306	In monocot seeds (Figure 32.21), the testa and tegmen of the seed coat are fused.
7.32.307	As the seed germinates, the primary root emerges, protected by the root-tip covering: the coleorhiza.
7.32.308	Next, the primary shoot emerges, protected by the coleoptile: the covering of the shoot tip.
7.32.309	Upon exposure to light (i.e. when the plumule has exited the soil and the protective coleoptile is no longer needed), elongation of the coleoptile ceases and the leaves expand and unfold.
7.32.310	At the other end of the embryonic axis, the primary root soon dies, while other, adventitious roots (roots that do not arise from the usual place – i.e. the root) emerge from the base of the stem.
7.32.311	This gives the monocot a fibrous root system.
7.32.312	As this monocot grass seed germinates, the primary root, or radicle, emerges first, followed by the primary shoot, or coleoptile, and the adventitious roots.
7.32.313	Seed Germination
7.32.314	Many mature seeds enter a period of inactivity, or extremely low metabolic activity: a process known as dormancy, which may last for months, years or even centuries.
7.32.315	Dormancy helps keep seeds viable during unfavorable conditions.
7.32.316	Upon a return to favorable conditions, seed germination takes place.
7.32.317	Favorable conditions could be as diverse as moisture, light, cold, fire, or chemical treatments.
7.32.318	After heavy rains, many new seedlings emerge.
7.32.319	Forest fires also lead to the emergence of new seedlings.
7.32.320	Some seeds require vernalization (cold treatment) before they can germinate.
7.32.321	This guarantees that seeds produced by plants in temperate climates will not germinate until the spring.
7.32.322	Plants growing in hot climates may have seeds that need a heat treatment in order to germinate, to avoid germination in the hot, dry summers.
7.32.323	In many seeds, the presence of a thick seed coat retards the ability to germinate.
7.32.324	Scarification, which includes mechanical or chemical processes to soften the seed coat, is often employed before germination.
7.32.325	Presoaking in hot water, or passing through an acid environment, such as an animal’s digestive tract, may also be employed.
7.32.326	Depending on seed size, the time taken for a seedling to emerge may vary.
7.32.327	Species with large seeds have enough food reserves to germinate deep below ground, and still extend their epicotyl all the way to the soil surface.
7.32.328	Seeds of small- seeded species usually require light as a germination cue.
7.32.329	This ensures the seeds only germinate at or near the soil surface (where the light is greatest).
7.32.330	If they were to germinate too far underneath the surface, the developing seedling would not have enough food reserves to reach the sunlight.
7.32.331	Development of Fruit and Fruit Types
7.32.332	After fertilization, the ovary of the flower usually develops into the fruit.
7.32.333	Fruits are usually associated with having a sweet taste; however, not all fruits are sweet.
7.32.334	Botanically, the term “fruit” is used for a ripened ovary.
7.32.335	In most cases, flowers in which fertilization has taken place will develop into fruits, and flowers in which fertilization has not taken place will not.
7.32.336	Some fruits develop from the ovary and are known as true fruits, whereas others develop from other parts of the female gametophyte and are known as accessory fruits.
7.32.337	The fruit encloses the seeds and the developing embryo, thereby providing it with protection.
7.32.338	Fruits are of many types, depending on their origin and texture.
7.32.339	The sweet tissue of the blackberry, the red flesh of the tomato, the shell of the peanut, and the hull of corn (the tough, thin part that gets stuck in your teeth when you eat popcorn) are all fruits.
7.32.340	As the fruit matures, the seeds also mature.
7.32.341	Fruits may be classified as simple, aggregate, multiple, or accessory, depending on their origin (Figure 32.22).
7.32.342	If the fruit develops from a single carpel or fused carpels of a single ovary, it is known as a simple fruit, as seen in nuts and beans.
7.32.343	An aggregate fruit is one that develops from more than one carpel, but all are in the same flower: the mature carpels fuse together to form the entire fruit, as seen in the raspberry.
7.32.344	Multiple fruit develops from an inflorescence or a cluster of flowers.
7.32.345	An example is the pineapple, where the flowers fuse together to form the fruit.
7.32.346	Accessory fruits (sometimes called false fruits) are not derived from the ovary, but from another part of the flower, such as the receptacle (strawberry) or the hypanthium (apples and pears).
7.32.347	Figure 32.22
7.32.348	There are four main types of fruits.
7.32.349	Simple fruits, such as these nuts, are derived from a single ovary.
7.32.350	Aggregate fruits, like raspberries, form from many carpels that fuse together.
7.32.351	Multiple fruits, such as pineapple, form from a cluster of flowers called an inflorescence.
7.32.352	Accessory fruit, like the apple, are formed from a part of the plant other than the ovary.
7.32.353	(credit "nuts": modification of work by Petr Kratochvil; credit "raspberries": modification of work by Cory Zanker; credit "pineapple": modification of work by Howie Le; credit "apple": modification of work by Paolo Neo)
7.32.354	Fruits generally have three parts: the exocarp (the outermost skin or covering), the mesocarp (middle part of the fruit), and the endocarp (the inner part of the fruit).
7.32.355	Together, all three are known as the pericarp.
7.32.356	The mesocarp is usually the fleshy, edible part of the fruit; however, in some fruits, such as the almond, the endocarp is the edible part.
7.32.357	In many fruits, two or all three of the layers are fused, and are indistinguishable at maturity.
7.32.358	Fruits can be dry or fleshy.
7.32.359	Furthermore, fruits can be divided into dehiscent or indehiscent types.
7.32.360	Dehiscent fruits, such as peas, readily release their seeds, while indehiscent fruits, like peaches, rely on decay to release their seeds.
7.32.361	Fruit and Seed Dispersal
7.32.362	The fruit has a single purpose: seed dispersal.
7.32.363	Seeds contained within fruits need to be dispersed far from the mother plant, so they may find favorable and less competitive conditions in which to germinate and grow.
7.32.364	Some fruit have built-in mechanisms so they can disperse by themselves, whereas others require the help of agents like wind, water, and animals (Figure 32.23).
7.32.365	Modifications in seed structure, composition, and size help in dispersal.
7.32.366	Wind- dispersed fruit are lightweight and may have wing-like appendages that allow them to be carried by the wind.
7.32.367	Some have a parachute-like structure to keep them afloat.
7.32.368	Some fruits—for example, the dandelion—have hairy, weightless structures that are suited to dispersal by wind.
7.32.369	Seeds dispersed by water are contained in light and buoyant fruit, giving them the ability to float.
7.32.370	Coconuts are well known for their ability to float on water to reach land where they can germinate.
7.32.371	Similarly, willow and silver birches produce lightweight fruit that can float on water.
7.32.372	Animals and birds eat fruits, and the seeds that are not digested are excreted in their droppings some distance away.
7.32.373	Some animals, like squirrels, bury seed-containing fruits for later use; if the squirrel does not find its stash of fruit, and if conditions are favorable, the seeds germinate.
7.32.374	Some fruits, like the cocklebur, have hooks or sticky structures that stick to an animal's coat and are then transported to another place.
7.32.375	Humans also play a big role in dispersing seeds when they carry fruits to new places and throw away the inedible part that contains the seeds.
7.32.376	All of the above mechanisms allow for seeds to be dispersed through space, much like an animal’s offspring can move to a new location.
7.32.377	Seed dormancy, which was described earlier, allows plants to disperse their progeny through time: something animals cannot do.
7.32.378	Dormant seeds can wait months, years, or even decades for the proper conditions for germination and propagation of the species.
7.32.379	Fruits and seeds are dispersed by various means.
7.32.380	(a) Dandelion seeds are dispersed by wind, the (b) coconut seed is dispersed by water, and the (c) acorn is dispersed by animals that cache and then forget it.
7.32.381	(credit a: modification of work by "Rosendahl"/Flickr; credit b: modification of work by Shine Oa; credit c: modification of work by Paolo Neo)
7.32.382	Many plants are able to propagate themselves using asexual reproduction.
7.32.383	This method does not require the investment required to produce a flower, attract pollinators, or find a means of seed dispersal.
7.32.384	Asexual reproduction produces plants that are genetically identical to the parent plant because no mixing of male and female gametes takes place.
7.32.385	Traditionally, these plants survive well under stable environmental conditions when compared with plants produced from sexual reproduction because they carry genes identical to those of their parents.
7.32.386	Many different types of roots exhibit asexual reproduction Figure 32.24.
7.32.387	The corm is used by gladiolus and garlic.
7.32.388	Bulbs, such as a scaly bulb in lilies and a tunicate bulb in daffodils, are other common examples.
7.32.389	A potato is a stem tuber, while parsnip propagates from a taproot.
7.32.390	Ginger and iris produce rhizomes, while ivy uses an adventitious root (a root arising from a plant part other than the main or primary root), and the strawberry plant has a stolon, which is also called a runner.
7.32.391	Different types of stems allow for asexual reproduction.
7.32.392	(a)
7.32.393	The corm of a garlic plant looks similar to (b) a tulip bulb, but the corm is solid tissue, while the bulb consists of layers of modified leaves that surround an underground stem.
7.32.394	Both corms and bulbs can self-propagate, giving rise to new plants.
7.32.395	(c) Ginger forms masses of stems called rhizomes that can give rise to multiple plants.
7.32.396	(d)
7.32.397	Potato plants form fleshy stem tubers.
7.32.398	Each eye in the stem tuber can give rise to a new plant.
7.32.399	(e) Strawberry plants form stolons: stems that grow at the soil surface or just below ground and can give rise to new plants.
7.32.400	(credit a: modification of work by Dwight Sipler; credit c: modification of work by Albert Cahalan, USDA ARS; credit d:
7.32.401	modification of work by Richard North; credit e: modification of work by Julie Magro)
7.32.402	Some plants can produce seeds without fertilization.
7.32.403	Either the ovule or part of the ovary, which is diploid in nature, gives rise to a new seed.
7.32.404	This method of reproduction is known as apomixis.
7.32.405	An advantage of asexual reproduction is that the resulting plant will reach maturity faster.
7.32.406	Since the new plant is arising from an adult plant or plant parts, it will also be sturdier than a seedling.
7.32.407	Asexual reproduction can take place by natural or artificial (assisted by humans) means.
7.32.408	Natural Methods of Asexual Reproduction Natural methods of asexual reproduction include strategies that plants have developed to self-propagate.
7.32.409	Many plants—like ginger, onion, gladioli, and dahlia—continue to grow from buds that are present on the surface of the stem.
7.32.410	In some plants, such as the sweet potato, adventitious roots or runners can give rise to new plants Figure 32.25.
7.32.411	In Bryophyllum and kalanchoe, the leaves have small buds on their margins.
7.32.412	When these are detached from the plant, they grow into independent plants; or, they may start growing into independent plants if the leaf touches the soil.
7.32.413	Some plants can be propagated through cuttings alone.
7.32.414	Artificial Methods of Asexual Reproduction
7.32.415	These methods are frequently employed to give rise to new, and sometimes novel, plants.
7.32.416	They include grafting, cutting, layering, and micropropagation.
7.32.417	Grafting Grafting has long been used to produce novel varieties of roses, citrus species, and other plants.
7.32.418	In grafting, two plant species are used; part of the stem of the desirable plant is grafted onto a rooted plant called the stock.
7.32.419	The part that is grafted or attached is called the scion.
7.32.420	Both are cut at an oblique angle (any angle other than a right angle), placed in close contact with each other, and are then held together Figure 32.26.
7.32.421	Matching up these two surfaces as closely as possible is extremely important because these will be holding the plant together.
7.32.422	The vascular systems of the two plants grow and fuse, forming a graft.
7.32.423	After a period of time, the scion starts producing shoots, and eventually starts bearing flowers and fruits.
7.32.424	Grafting is widely used in viticulture (grape growing) and the citrus industry.
7.32.425	Scions capable of producing a particular fruit variety are grated onto root stock with specific resistance to disease.
7.32.426	Grafting is an artificial method of asexual reproduction used to produce plants combining favorable stem characteristics with favorable root characteristics.
7.32.427	The stem of the plant to be grafted is known as the scion, and the root is called the stock.
7.32.428	Cutting Plants such as coleus and money plant are propagated through stem cuttings, where a portion of the stem containing nodes and internodes is placed in moist soil and allowed to root.
7.32.429	In some species, stems can start producing a root even when placed only in water.
7.32.430	For example, leaves of the African violet will root if kept in water undisturbed for several weeks.
7.32.431	Layering Layering is a method in which a stem attached to the plant is bent and covered with soil.
7.32.432	Young stems that can be bent easily without any injury are preferred.
7.32.433	Jasmine and bougainvillea (paper flower) can be propagated this way Figure 32.27.
7.32.434	In some plants, a modified form of layering known as air layering is employed.
7.32.435	A portion of the bark or outermost covering of the stem is removed and covered with moss, which is then taped.
7.32.436	Some gardeners also apply rooting hormone.
7.32.437	After some time, roots will appear, and this portion of the plant can be removed and transplanted into a separate pot.
7.32.438	In layering, a part of the stem is buried so that it forms a new plant.
7.32.439	(credit: modification of work by Pearson Scott Foresman, donated to the Wikimedia Foundation) Micropropagation Micropropagation (also called plant tissue culture) is a method of propagating a large number of plants from a single plant in a short time under laboratory conditions Figure 32.28.
7.32.440	This method allows propagation of rare, endangered species that may be difficult to grow under natural conditions, are economically important, or are in demand as disease-free plants.
7.32.441	Figure 32.28 Micropropagation is used to propagate plants in sterile conditions.
7.32.442	(credit: Nikhilesh Sanyal)
7.32.443	To start plant tissue culture, a part of the plant such as a stem, leaf, embryo, anther, or seed can be used.
7.32.444	The plant material is thoroughly sterilized using a combination of chemical treatments standardized for that species.
7.32.445	Under sterile conditions, the plant material is placed on a plant tissue culture medium that contains all the minerals, vitamins, and hormones required by the plant.
7.32.446	The plant part often gives rise to an undifferentiated mass known as callus, from which individual plantlets begin to grow after a period of time.
7.32.447	These can be separated and are first grown under greenhouse conditions before they are moved to field conditions.
7.32.448	Plant Life Spans
7.32.449	The length of time from the beginning of development to the death of a plant is called its life span.
7.32.450	The life cycle, on the other hand, is the sequence of stages a plant goes through from seed germination to seed production of the mature plant.
7.32.451	Some plants, such as annuals, only need a few weeks to grow, produce seeds and die.
7.32.452	Other plants, such as the bristlecone pine, live for thousands of years.
7.32.453	Some bristlecone pines have a documented age of 4,500 years Figure 32.29.
7.32.454	Even as some parts of a plant, such as regions containing meristematic tissue—the area of active plant growth consisting of undifferentiated cells capable of cell division—continue to grow, some parts undergo programmed cell death (apoptosis).
7.32.455	The cork found on stems, and the water-conducting tissue of the xylem, for example, are composed of dead cells.
7.32.456	The bristlecone pine, shown here in the Ancient Bristlecone Pine Forest in the White Mountains of eastern California, has been known to live for 4,500 years.
7.32.457	(credit: Rick Goldwaser) Plant species that complete their lifecycle in one season are known as annuals, an example of which is Arabidopsis, or mouse-ear cress.
7.32.458	Biennials such as carrots complete their lifecycle in two seasons.
7.32.459	In a biennial’s first season, the plant has a vegetative phase, whereas in the next season, it completes its reproductive phase.
7.32.460	Commercial growers harvest the carrot roots after the first year of growth, and do not allow the plants to flower.
7.32.461	Perennials, such as the magnolia, complete their lifecycle in two years or more.
7.32.462	In another classification based on flowering frequency, monocarpic plants flower only once in their lifetime; examples include bamboo and yucca.
7.32.463	During the vegetative period of their life cycle (which may be as long as 120 years in some bamboo species), these plants may reproduce asexually and accumulate a great deal of food material that will be required during their once-in-a-lifetime flowering and setting of seed after fertilization.
7.32.464	Soon after flowering, these plants die.
7.32.465	Polycarpic plants form flowers many times during their lifetime.
7.32.466	Fruit trees, such as apple and orange trees, are polycarpic; they flower every year.
7.32.467	Other polycarpic species, such as perennials, flower several times during their life span, but not each year.
7.32.468	By this means, the plant does not require all its nutrients to be channelled towards flowering each year.
7.32.469	As is the case with all living organisms, genetics and environmental conditions have a role to play in determining how long a plant will live.
7.32.470	Susceptibility to disease, changing environmental conditions, drought, cold, and competition for nutrients are some of the factors that determine the survival of a plant.
7.32.471	Plants continue to grow, despite the presence of dead tissue such as cork.
7.32.472	Individual parts of plants, such as flowers and leaves, have different rates of survival.
7.32.473	In many trees, the older leaves turn yellow and eventually fall from the tree.
7.32.474	Leaf fall is triggered by factors such as a decrease in photosynthetic efficiency, due to shading by upper leaves, or oxidative damage incurred as a result of photosynthetic reactions.
7.32.475	The components of the part to be shed are recycled by the plant for use in other processes, such as development of seed and storage.
7.32.476	This process is known as nutrient recycling.
7.32.477	The aging of a plant and all the associated processes is known as senescence, which is marked by several complex biochemical changes.
7.32.478	One of the characteristics of senescence is the breakdown of chloroplasts, which is characterized by the yellowing of leaves.
7.32.479	The chloroplasts contain components of photosynthetic machinery such as membranes and proteins.
7.32.480	Chloroplasts also contain DNA.
7.32.481	The proteins, lipids, and nucleic acids are broken down by specific enzymes into smaller molecules and salvaged by the plant to support the growth of other plant tissues.
7.32.482	The complex pathways of nutrient recycling within a plant are not well understood.
7.32.483	Hormones are known to play a role in senescence.
7.32.484	Applications of cytokinins and ethylene delay or prevent senescence; in contrast, abscissic acid causes premature onset of senescence.         
7.33.0	An arctic fox is a complex animal, well adapted to its environment.
7.33.1	It changes coat color with the seasons, and has longer fur in winter to trap heat.
7.33.2	(credit: modification of work by Keith Morehouse, USFWS).
7.33.3	Introduction
7.33.4	The arctic fox is an example of a complex animal that has adapted to its environment and illustrates the relationships between an animal’s form and function.
7.33.5	The structures of animals consist of primary tissues that make up more complex organs and organ systems.
7.33.6	Homeostasis allows an animal to maintain a balance between its internal and external environments.
7.33.7	Animals vary in form and function.
7.33.8	From a sponge to a worm to a goat, an organism has a distinct body plan that limits its size and shape.
7.33.9	Animals’ bodies are also designed to interact with their environments, whether in the deep sea, a rainforest canopy, or the desert.
7.33.10	Therefore, a large amount of information about the structure of an organism's body (anatomy) and the function of its cells, tissues and organs (physiology) can be learned by studying that organism's environment.
7.33.11	Body Plans Animals exhibit different types of body symmetry.
7.33.12	The sponge is asymmetrical, the sea anemone has radial symmetry, and the goat has bilateral symmetry.
7.33.13	Animal body plans follow set patterns related to symmetry.
7.33.14	They are asymmetrical, radial, or bilateral in form as illustrated in Figure 33.2.
7.33.15	Asymmetrical animals are animals with no pattern or symmetry; an example of an asymmetrical animal is a sponge.
7.33.16	Radial symmetry, as illustrated in Figure 33.2, describes when an animal has an up-and-down orientation: any plane cut along its longitudinal axis through the organism produces equal halves, but not a definite right or left side.
7.33.17	This plan is found mostly in aquatic animals, especially organisms that attach themselves to a base, like a rock or a boat, and extract their food from the surrounding water as it flows around the organism.
7.33.18	Bilateral symmetry is illustrated in the same figure by a goat.
7.33.19	The goat also has an upper and lower component to it, but a plane cut from front to back separates the animal into definite right and left sides.
7.33.20	Additional terms used when describing positions in the body are anterior (front), posterior (rear), dorsal (toward the back), and ventral (toward the stomach).
7.33.21	Bilateral symmetry is found in both land-based and aquatic animals; it enables a high level of mobility.
7.33.22	Limits on Animal Size and Shape Animals with bilateral symmetry that live in water tend to have a fusiform shape: this is a tubular shaped body that is tapered at both ends.
7.33.23	This shape decreases the drag on the body as it moves through water and allows the animal to swim at high speeds.
7.33.24	Table 33.1 lists the maximum speed of various animals.
7.33.25	Certain types of sharks can swim at fifty kilometers an hour and some dolphins at 32 to 40 kilometers per hour.
7.33.26	Land animals frequently travel faster, although the tortoise and snail are significantly slower than cheetahs.
7.33.27	Another difference in the adaptations of aquatic and land-dwelling organisms is that aquatic organisms are constrained in shape by the forces of drag in the water since water has higher viscosity than air.
7.33.28	On the other hand, land-dwelling organisms are constrained mainly by gravity, and drag is relatively unimportant.
7.33.29	For example, most adaptations in birds are for gravity not for drag.
7.33.30	Most animals have an exoskeleton, including insects, spiders, scorpions, horseshoe crabs, centipedes, and crustaceans.
7.33.31	Scientists estimate that, of insects alone, there are over 30 million species on our planet.
7.33.32	The exoskeleton is a hard covering or shell that provides benefits to the animal, such as protection against damage from predators and from water loss (for land animals); it also provides for the attachments of muscles.
7.33.33	As the tough and resistant outer cover of an arthropod, the exoskeleton may be constructed of a tough polymer such as chitin and is often biomineralized with materials such as calcium carbonate.
7.33.34	This is fused to the animal’s epidermis.
7.33.35	Ingrowths of the exoskeleton, called apodemes, function as attachment sites for muscles, similar to tendons in more advanced animals (Figure 33.3).
7.33.36	In order to grow, the animal must first synthesize a new exoskeleton underneath the old one and then shed or molt the original covering.
7.33.37	This limits the animal’s ability to grow continually, and may limit the individual’s ability to mature if molting does not occur at the proper time.
7.33.38	The thickness of the exoskeleton must be increased significantly to accommodate any increase in weight.
7.33.39	It is estimated that a doubling of body size increases body weight by a factor of eight.
7.33.40	The increasing thickness of the chitin necessary to support this weight limits most animals with an exoskeleton to a relatively small size.
7.33.41	The same principles apply to endoskeletons, but they are more efficient because muscles are attached on the outside, making it easier to compensate for increased mass.
7.33.42	Figure 33.3
7.33.43	Apodemes are ingrowths on arthropod exoskeletons to which muscles attach.
7.33.44	The apodemes on this crab leg are located above and below the fulcrum of the claw.
7.33.45	Contraction of muscles attached to the apodemes pulls the claw closed.
7.33.46	An animal with an endoskeleton has its size determined by the amount of skeletal system it needs in order to support the other tissues and the amount of muscle it needs for movement.
7.33.47	As the body size increases, both bone and muscle mass increase.
7.33.48	The speed achievable by the animal is a balance between its overall size and the bone and muscle that provide support and movement.
7.33.49	Limiting Effects of Diffusion on Size and Development
7.33.50	The exchange of nutrients and wastes between a cell and its watery environment occurs through the process of diffusion.
7.33.51	All living cells are bathed in liquid, whether they are in a single-celled organism or a multicellular one.
7.33.52	Diffusion is effective over a specific distance and limits the size that an individual cell can attain.
7.33.53	If a cell is a single-celled microorganism, such as an amoeba, it can satisfy all of its nutrient and waste needs through diffusion.
7.33.54	If the cell is too large, then diffusion is ineffective and the center of the cell does not receive adequate nutrients nor is it able to effectively dispel its waste.
7.33.55	An important concept in understanding how efficient diffusion is as a means of transport is the surface to volume ratio.
7.33.56	Recall that any three-dimensional object has a surface area and volume; the ratio of these two quantities is the surface- to-volume ratio.
7.33.57	Consider a cell shaped like a perfect sphere: it has a surface area of 4πr2, and a volume of (4/3)πr3.
7.33.58	The surface-to-volume ratio of a sphere is 3/r; as the cell gets bigger, its surface to volume ratio decreases, making diffusion less efficient.
7.33.59	The larger the size of the sphere, or animal, the less surface area for diffusion it possesses.
7.33.60	The solution to producing larger organisms is for them to become multicellular.
7.33.61	Specialization occurs in complex organisms, allowing cells to become more efficient at doing fewer tasks.
7.33.62	For example, circulatory systems bring nutrients and remove waste, while respiratory systems provide oxygen for the cells and remove carbon dioxide from them.
7.33.63	Other organ systems have developed further specialization of cells and tissues and efficiently control body functions.
7.33.64	Moreover, surface-to- volume ratio applies to other areas of animal development, such as the relationship between muscle mass and cross-sectional surface area in supporting skeletons, and in the relationship between muscle mass and the generation of dissipation of heat.
7.33.65	Animal Bioenergetics
7.33.66	All animals must obtain their energy from food they ingest or absorb.
7.33.67	These nutrients are converted to adenosine triphosphate (ATP) for short-term storage and use by all cells.
7.33.68	Some animals store energy for slightly longer times as glycogen, and others store energy for much longer times in the form of triglycerides housed in specialized adipose tissues.
7.33.69	No energy system is one hundred percent efficient, and an animal’s metabolism produces waste energy in the form of heat.
7.33.70	If an animal can conserve that heat and maintain a relatively constant body temperature, it is classified as a warm-blooded animal and called an endotherm.
7.33.71	The insulation used to conserve the body heat comes in the forms of fur, fat, or feathers.
7.33.72	The absence of insulation in ectothermic animals increases their dependence on the environment for body heat.
7.33.73	The amount of energy expended by an animal over a specific time is called its metabolic rate.
7.33.74	The rate is measured variously in joules, calories, or kilocalories (1000 calories).
7.33.75	Carbohydrates and proteins contain about 4.5 to 5 kcal/g, and fat contains about 9 kcal/g.
7.33.76	Metabolic rate is estimated as the basal metabolic rate (BMR) in endothermic animals at rest and as the standard metabolic rate (SMR) in ectotherms.
7.33.77	Human males have a BMR of 1600 to 1800 kcal/day, and human females have a BMR of 1300 to 1500 kcal/day.
7.33.78	Even with insulation, endothermal animals require extensive amounts of energy to maintain a constant body temperature.
7.33.79	An ectotherm such as an alligator has an SMR of 60 kcal/day.
7.33.80	Energy Requirements Related to Body Size
7.33.81	Smaller endothermic animals have a greater surface area for their mass than larger ones (Figure 33.4).
7.33.82	Therefore, smaller animals lose heat at a faster rate than larger animals and require more energy to maintain a constant internal temperature.
7.33.83	This results in a smaller endothermic animal having a higher BMR, per body weight, than a larger endothermic animal.
7.33.84	The mouse has a much higher metabolic rate than the elephant.
7.33.85	(credit “mouse
7.33.86	”:
7.33.87	modification of work by Magnus Kjaergaard; credit “elephant
7.33.88	”:
7.33.89	modification of work by “TheLizardQueen”/Flickr)
7.33.90	Energy Requirements Related to Levels of Activity
7.33.91	The more active an animal is, the more energy is needed to maintain that activity, and the higher its BMR or SMR.
7.33.92	The average daily rate of energy consumption is about two to four times an animal’s BMR or SMR.
7.33.93	Humans are more sedentary than most animals and have an average daily rate of only 1.5 times the BMR.
7.33.94	The diet of an endothermic animal is determined by its BMR.
7.33.95	For example: the type of grasses, leaves, or shrubs that an herbivore eats affects the number of calories that it takes in.
7.33.96	The relative caloric content of herbivore foods, in descending order, is tall grasses > legumes > short grasses
7.33.97	> forbs (any broad-leaved plant, not a grass)
7.33.98	> subshrubs > annuals/biennials.
7.33.99	Energy Requirements Related to Environment Animals adapt to extremes of temperature or food availability through torpor.
7.33.100	Torpor is a process that leads to a decrease in activity and metabolism and allows animals to survive adverse conditions.
7.33.101	Torpor can be used by animals for long periods, such as entering a state of hibernation during the winter months, in which case it enables them to maintain a reduced body temperature.
7.33.102	During hibernation, ground squirrels can achieve an abdominal temperature of 0° C (32° F), while a bear’s internal temperature is maintained higher at about 37° C (99° F).
7.33.103	If torpor occurs during the summer months with high temperatures and little water, it is called estivation.
7.33.104	Some desert animals use this to survive the harshest months of the year.
7.33.105	Torpor can occur on a daily basis; this is seen in bats and hummingbirds.
7.33.106	While endothermy is limited in smaller animals by surface to volume ratio, some organisms can be smaller and still be endotherms because they employ daily torpor during the part of the day that is coldest.
7.33.107	This allows them to conserve energy during the colder parts of the day, when they consume more energy to maintain their body temperature.
7.33.108	Animal Body Planes and Cavities A standing vertebrate animal can be divided by several planes.
7.33.109	A sagittal plane divides the body into right and left portions.
7.33.110	A midsagittal plane divides the body exactly in the middle, making two equal right and left halves.
7.33.111	A frontal plane (also called a coronal plane) separates the front from the back.
7.33.112	A transverse plane (or, horizontal plane) divides the animal into upper and lower portions.
7.33.113	This is sometimes called a cross section, and, if the transverse cut is at an angle, it is called an oblique plane.
7.33.114	Figure 33.5 illustrates these planes on a goat (a four-legged animal) and a human being.
7.33.115	Shown are the planes of a quadruped goat and a bipedal human.
7.33.116	The midsagittal plane divides the body exactly in half, into right and left portions.
7.33.117	The frontal plane divides the front and back, and the transverse plane divides the body into upper and lower portions.
7.33.118	Vertebrate animals have a number of defined body cavities, as illustrated in Figure 33.6.
7.33.119	Two of these are major cavities that contain smaller cavities within them.
7.33.120	The dorsal cavity contains the cranial and the vertebral (or spinal) cavities.
7.33.121	The ventral cavity contains the thoracic cavity, which in turn contains the pleural cavity around the lungs and the pericardial cavity, which surrounds the heart.
7.33.122	The ventral cavity also contains the abdominopelvic cavity, which can be separated into the abdominal and the pelvic cavities.
7.33.123	Figure 33.6 Vertebrate animals have two major body cavities.
7.33.124	The dorsal cavity, indicated in green, contains the cranial and the spinal cavity.
7.33.125	The ventral cavity, indicated in yellow, contains the thoracic cavity and the abdominopelvic cavity.
7.33.126	The thoracic cavity is separated from the abdominopelvic cavity by the diaphragm.
7.33.127	The thoracic cavity is separated into the abdominal cavity and the pelvic cavity by an imaginary line parallel to the pelvis bones.
7.33.128	(credit: modification of work by NCI)
7.33.129	The tissues of multicellular, complex animals are four primary types: epithelial, connective, muscle, and nervous.
7.33.130	Recall that tissues are groups of similar cells group of similar cells carrying out related functions.
7.33.131	These tissues combine to form organs—like the skin or kidney—that have specific, specialized functions within the body.
7.33.132	Organs are organized into organ systems to perform functions; examples include the circulatory system, which consists of the heart and blood vessels, and the digestive system, consisting of several organs, including the stomach, intestines, liver, and pancreas.
7.33.133	Organ systems come together to create an entire organism.
7.33.134	Epithelial Tissues Epithelial tissues cover the outside of organs and structures in the body and line the lumens of organs in a single layer or multiple layers of cells.
7.33.135	The types of epithelia are classified by the shapes of cells present and the number of layers of cells.
7.33.136	Epithelia composed of a single layer of cells is called simple epithelia; epithelial tissue composed of multiple layers is called stratified epithelia.
7.33.137	Table 33.2 summarizes the different types of epithelial tissues.
7.33.138	Squamous Epithelia Squamous epithelial cells are generally round, flat, and have a small, centrally located nucleus.
7.33.139	The cell outline is slightly irregular, and cells fit together to form a covering or lining.
7.33.140	When the cells are arranged in a single layer (simple epithelia), they facilitate diffusion in tissues, such as the areas of gas exchange in the lungs and the exchange of nutrients and waste at blood capillaries.
7.33.141	Squamous epithelia cells (a) have a slightly irregular shape, and a small, centrally located nucleus.
7.33.142	These cells can be stratified into layers, as in (b) this human cervix specimen.
7.33.143	(credit b: modification of work by Ed Uthman; scale-bar data from Matt Russell) Figure 33.7a illustrates a layer of squamous cells with their membranes joined together to form an epithelium.
7.33.144	Image Figure 33.7b illustrates squamous epithelial cells arranged in stratified layers, where protection is needed on the body from outside abrasion and damage.
7.33.145	This is called a stratified squamous epithelium and occurs in the skin and in tissues lining the mouth and vagina.
7.33.146	Cuboidal Epithelia Cuboidal epithelial cells, shown in Figure 33.8, are cube-shaped with a single, central nucleus.
7.33.147	They are most commonly found in a single layer representing a simple epithelia in glandular tissues throughout the body where they prepare and secrete glandular material.
7.33.148	They are also found in the walls of tubules and in the ducts of the kidney and liver.
7.33.149	Simple cuboidal epithelial cells line tubules in the mammalian kidney, where they are involved in filtering the blood.
7.33.150	Columnar Epithelia Columnar epithelial cells are taller than they are wide: they resemble a stack of columns in an epithelial layer, and are most commonly found in a single-layer arrangement.
7.33.151	The nuclei of columnar epithelial cells in the digestive tract appear to be lined up at the base of the cells, as illustrated in Figure 33.9.
7.33.152	These cells absorb material from the lumen of the digestive tract and prepare it for entry into the body through the circulatory and lymphatic systems.
7.33.153	Simple columnar epithelial cells absorb material from the digestive tract.
7.33.154	Goblet cells secret mucous into the digestive tract lumen.
7.33.155	Columnar epithelial cells lining the respiratory tract appear to be stratified.
7.33.156	However, each cell is attached to the base membrane of the tissue and, therefore, they are simple tissues.
7.33.157	The nuclei are arranged at different levels in the layer of cells, making it appear as though there is more than one layer, as seen in Figure 33.10.
7.33.158	This is called pseudostratified, columnar epithelia.
7.33.159	This cellular covering has cilia at the apical, or free, surface of the cells.
7.33.160	The cilia enhance the movement of mucous and trapped particles out of the respiratory tract, helping to protect the system from invasive microorganisms and harmful material that has been breathed into the body.
7.33.161	Goblet cells are interspersed in some tissues (such as the lining of the trachea).
7.33.162	The goblet cells contain mucous that traps irritants, which in the case of the trachea keep these irritants from getting into the lungs.
7.33.163	Pseudostratified columnar epithelia line the respiratory tract.
7.33.164	They exist in one layer, but the arrangement of nuclei at different levels makes it appear that there is more than one layer.
7.33.165	Goblet cells interspersed between the columnar epithelial cells secrete mucous into the respiratory tract.
7.33.166	Transitional Epithelia Transitional or uroepithelial cells appear only in the urinary system, primarily in the bladder and ureter.
7.33.167	These cells are arranged in a stratified layer, but they have the capability of appearing to pile up on top of each other in a relaxed, empty bladder, as illustrated in Figure 33.11.
7.33.168	As the urinary bladder fills, the epithelial layer unfolds and expands to hold the volume of urine introduced into it.
7.33.169	As the bladder fills, it expands and the lining becomes thinner.
7.33.170	In other words, the tissue transitions from thick to thin.
7.33.171	Connective Tissues Connective tissues are made up of a matrix consisting of living cells and a non-living substance, called the ground substance.
7.33.172	The ground substance is made of an organic substance (usually a protein) and an inorganic substance (usually a mineral or water).
7.33.173	The principal cell of connective tissues is the fibroblast.
7.33.174	This cell makes the fibers found in nearly all of the connective tissues.
7.33.175	Fibroblasts are motile, able to carry out mitosis, and can synthesize whichever connective tissue is needed.
7.33.176	Macrophages, lymphocytes, and, occasionally, leukocytes can be found in some of the tissues.
7.33.177	Some tissues have specialized cells that are not found in the others.
7.33.178	The matrix in connective tissues gives the tissue its density.
7.33.179	When a connective tissue has a high concentration of cells or fibers, it has proportionally a less dense matrix.
7.33.180	The organic portion or protein fibers found in connective tissues are either collagen, elastic, or reticular fibers.
7.33.181	Collagen fibers provide strength to the tissue, preventing it from being torn or separated from the surrounding tissues.
7.33.182	Elastic fibers are made of the protein elastin; this fiber can stretch to one and one half of its length and return to its original size and shape.
7.33.183	Elastic fibers provide flexibility to the tissues.
7.33.184	Reticular fibers are the third type of protein fiber found in connective tissues.
7.33.185	This fiber consists of thin strands of collagen that form a network of fibers to support the tissue and other organs to which it is connected.
7.33.186	The various types of connective tissues, the types of cells and fibers they are made of, and sample locations of the tissues is summarized in Table 33.3.
7.33.187	Loose/Areolar Connective Tissue Loose connective tissue, also called areolar connective tissue, has a sampling of all of the components of a connective tissue.
7.33.188	As illustrated in Figure 33.12, loose connective tissue has some fibroblasts; macrophages are present as well.
7.33.189	Collagen fibers are relatively wide and stain a light pink, while elastic fibers are thin and stain dark blue to black.
7.33.190	The space between the formed elements of the tissue is filled with the matrix.
7.33.191	The material in the connective tissue gives it a loose consistency similar to a cotton ball that has been pulled apart.
7.33.192	Loose connective tissue is found around every blood vessel and helps to keep the vessel in place.
7.33.193	The tissue is also found around and between most body organs.
7.33.194	In summary, areolar tissue is tough, yet flexible, and comprises membranes.
7.33.195	Loose connective tissue is composed of loosely woven collagen and elastic fibers.
7.33.196	The fibers and other components of the connective tissue matrix are secreted by fibroblasts.
7.33.197	Fibrous Connective Tissue Fibrous connective tissues contain large amounts of collagen fibers and few cells or matrix material.
7.33.198	The fibers can be arranged irregularly or regularly with the strands lined up in parallel.
7.33.199	Irregularly arranged fibrous connective tissues are found in areas of the body where stress occurs from all directions, such as the dermis of the skin.
7.33.200	Regular fibrous connective tissue, shown in Figure 33.13, is found in tendons (which connect muscles to bones) and ligaments (which connect bones to bones).
7.33.201	Fibrous connective tissue from the tendon has strands of collagen fibers lined up in parallel.
7.33.202	Cartilage Cartilage is a connective tissue with a large amount of the matrix and variable amounts of fibers.
7.33.203	The cells, called chondrocytes, make the matrix and fibers of the tissue.
7.33.204	Chondrocytes are found in spaces within the tissue called lacunae.
7.33.205	A cartilage with few collagen and elastic fibers is hyaline cartilage, illustrated in Figure 33.14.
7.33.206	The lacunae are randomly scattered throughout the tissue and the matrix takes on a milky or scrubbed appearance with routine histological stains.
7.33.207	Sharks have cartilaginous skeletons, as does nearly the entire human skeleton during a specific pre-birth developmental stage.
7.33.208	A remnant of this cartilage persists in the outer portion of the human nose.
7.33.209	Hyaline cartilage is also found at the ends of long bones, reducing friction and cushioning the articulations of these bones.
7.33.210	Hyaline cartilage consists of a matrix with cells called chondrocytes embedded in it.
7.33.211	The chondrocytes exist in cavities in the matrix called lacunae.
7.33.212	Elastic cartilage has a large amount of elastic fibers, giving it tremendous flexibility.
7.33.213	The ears of most vertebrate animals contain this cartilage as do portions of the larynx, or voice box.
7.33.214	Fibrocartilage contains a large amount of collagen fibers, giving the tissue tremendous strength.
7.33.215	Fibrocartilage comprises the intervertebral discs in vertebrate animals.
7.33.216	Hyaline cartilage found in movable joints such as the knee and shoulder becomes damaged as a result of age or trauma.
7.33.217	Damaged hyaline cartilage is replaced by fibrocartilage and results in the joints becoming “stiff.
7.33.218	” Bone Bone, or osseous tissue, is a connective tissue that has a large amount of two different types of matrix material.
7.33.219	The organic matrix is similar to the matrix material found in other connective tissues, including some amount of collagen and elastic fibers.
7.33.220	This gives strength and flexibility to the tissue.
7.33.221	The inorganic matrix consists of mineral salts—mostly calcium salts—that give the tissue hardness.
7.33.222	Without adequate organic material in the matrix, the tissue breaks; without adequate inorganic material in the matrix, the tissue bends.
7.33.223	There are three types of cells in bone: osteoblasts, osteocytes, and osteoclasts.
7.33.224	Osteoblasts are active in making bone for growth and remodeling.
7.33.225	Osteoblasts deposit bone material into the matrix and, after the matrix surrounds them, they continue to live, but in a reduced metabolic state as osteocytes.
7.33.226	Osteocytes are found in lacunae of the bone.
7.33.227	Osteoclasts are active in breaking down bone for bone remodeling, and they provide access to calcium stored in tissues.
7.33.228	Osteoclasts are usually found on the surface of the tissue.
7.33.229	Bone can be divided into two types: compact and spongy.
7.33.230	Compact bone is found in the shaft (or diaphysis) of a long bone and the surface of the flat bones, while spongy bone is found in the end (or epiphysis) of a long bone.
7.33.231	Compact bone is organized into subunits called osteons, as illustrated in Figure 33.15.
7.33.232	A blood vessel and a nerve are found in the center of the structure within the Haversian canal, with radiating circles of lacunae around it known as lamellae.
7.33.233	The wavy lines seen between the lacunae are microchannels called canaliculi; they connect the lacunae to aid diffusion between the cells.
7.33.234	Spongy bone is made of tiny plates called trabeculae these plates serve as struts to give the spongy bone strength.
7.33.235	Over time, these plates can break causing the bone to become less resilient.
7.33.236	Bone tissue forms the internal skeleton of vertebrate animals, providing structure to the animal and points of attachment for tendons.
7.33.237	Compact bone is a dense matrix on the outer surface of bone.
7.33.238	Spongy bone, inside the compact bone, is porous with web-like trabeculae.
7.33.239	(b) Compact bone is organized into rings called osteons.
7.33.240	Blood vessels, nerves, and lymphatic vessels are found in the central Haversian canal.
7.33.241	Rings of lamellae surround the Haversian canal.
7.33.242	Between the lamellae are cavities called lacunae.
7.33.243	Canaliculi are microchannels connecting the lacunae together.
7.33.244	(c)
7.33.245	Osteoblasts surround the exterior of the bone.
7.33.246	Osteoclasts bore tunnels into the bone and osteocytes are found in the lacunae.
7.33.247	Adipose Tissue Adipose tissue, or fat tissue, is considered a connective tissue even though it does not have fibroblasts or a real matrix and only has a few fibers.
7.33.248	Adipose tissue is made up of cells called adipocytes that collect and store fat in the form of triglycerides, for energy metabolism.
7.33.249	Adipose tissues additionally serve as insulation to help maintain body temperatures, allowing animals to be endothermic, and they function as cushioning against damage to body organs.
7.33.250	Under a microscope, adipose tissue cells appear empty due to the extraction of fat during the processing of the material for viewing, as seen in Figure 33.16.
7.33.251	The thin lines in the image are the cell membranes, and the nuclei are the small, black dots at the edges of the cells.
7.33.252	Adipose is a connective tissue is made up of cells called adipocytes.
7.33.253	Adipocytes have small nuclei localized at the cell edge.
7.33.254	Blood Blood is considered a connective tissue because it has a matrix, as shown in Figure 33.17.
7.33.255	The living cell types are red blood cells (RBC), also called erythrocytes, and white blood cells (WBC), also called leukocytes.
7.33.256	The fluid portion of whole blood, its matrix, is commonly called plasma.
7.33.257	Blood is a connective tissue that has a fluid matrix, called plasma, and no fibers.
7.33.258	Erythrocytes (red blood cells), the predominant cell type, are involved in the transport of oxygen and carbon dioxide.
7.33.259	Also present are various leukocytes (white blood cells) involved in immune response.
7.33.260	The cell found in greatest abundance in blood is the erythrocyte.
7.33.261	Erythrocytes are counted in millions in a blood sample: the average number of red blood cells in primates is 4.7 to 5.5 million cells per microliter.
7.33.262	Erythrocytes are consistently the same size in a species, but vary in size between species.
7.33.263	For example, the average diameter of a primate red blood cell is 7.5 μl, a dog is close at 7.0 μl, but a cat’s RBC diameter is 5.9 μl.
7.33.264	Sheep erythrocytes are even smaller at 4.6 μl.
7.33.265	Mammalian erythrocytes lose their nuclei and mitochondria when they are released from the bone marrow where they are made.
7.33.266	Fish, amphibian, and avian red blood cells maintain their nuclei and mitochondria throughout the cell’s life.
7.33.267	The principal job of an erythrocyte is to carry and deliver oxygen to the tissues.
7.33.268	Leukocytes are the predominant white blood cells found in the peripheral blood.
7.33.269	Leukocytes are counted in the thousands in the blood with measurements expressed as ranges: primate counts range from 4,800 to 10,800 cells per μl, dogs from 5,600 to 19,200 cells per μl, cats from 8,000 to 25,000 cells per μl, cattle from 4,000 to 12,000 cells per μl, and pigs from 11,000 to 22,000 cells per μl.
7.33.270	Lymphocytes function primarily in the immune response to foreign antigens or material.
7.33.271	Different types of lymphocytes make antibodies tailored to the foreign antigens and control the production of those antibodies.
7.33.272	Neutrophils are phagocytic cells and they participate in one of the early lines of defense against microbial invaders, aiding in the removal of bacteria that has entered the body.
7.33.273	Another leukocyte that is found in the peripheral blood is the monocyte.
7.33.274	Monocytes give rise to phagocytic macrophages that clean up dead and damaged cells in the body, whether they are foreign or from the host animal.
7.33.275	Two additional leukocytes in the blood are eosinophils and basophils—both help to facilitate the inflammatory response.
7.33.276	The slightly granular material among the cells is a cytoplasmic fragment of a cell in the bone marrow.
7.33.277	This is called a platelet or thrombocyte.
7.33.278	Platelets participate in the stages leading up to coagulation of the blood to stop bleeding through damaged blood vessels.
7.33.279	Blood has a number of functions, but primarily it transports material through the body to bring nutrients to cells and remove waste material from them.
7.33.280	Muscle Tissues There are three types of muscle in animal bodies: smooth, skeletal, and cardiac.
7.33.281	They differ by the presence or absence of striations or bands, the number and location of nuclei, whether they are voluntarily or involuntarily controlled, and their location within the body.
7.33.282	Table 33.4 summarizes these differences.
7.33.283	Smooth Muscle Smooth muscle does not have striations in its cells.
7.33.284	It has a single, centrally located nucleus, as shown in Figure 33.18.
7.33.285	Constriction of smooth muscle occurs under involuntary, autonomic nervous control and in response to local conditions in the tissues.
7.33.286	Smooth muscle tissue is also called non-striated as it lacks the banded appearance of skeletal and cardiac muscle.
7.33.287	The walls of blood vessels, the tubes of the digestive system, and the tubes of the reproductive systems are composed of mostly smooth muscle.
7.33.288	Smooth muscle cells do not have striations, while skeletal muscle cells do.
7.33.289	Cardiac muscle cells have striations, but, unlike the multinucleate skeletal cells, they have only one nucleus.
7.33.290	Cardiac muscle tissue also has intercalated discs, specialized regions running along the plasma membrane that join adjacent cardiac muscle cells and assist in passing an electrical impulse from cell to cell.
7.33.291	Skeletal Muscle Skeletal muscle has striations across its cells caused by the arrangement of the contractile proteins actin and myosin.
7.33.292	These muscle cells are relatively long and have multiple nuclei along the edge of the cell.
7.33.293	Skeletal muscle is under voluntary, somatic nervous system control and is found in the muscles that move bones.
7.33.294	Figure 33.18 illustrates the histology of skeletal muscle.
7.33.295	Cardiac Muscle Cardiac muscle, shown in Figure 33.18, is found only in the heart.
7.33.296	Like skeletal muscle, it has cross striations in its cells, but cardiac muscle has a single, centrally located nucleus.
7.33.297	Cardiac muscle is not under voluntary control but can be influenced by the autonomic nervous system to speed up or slow down.
7.33.298	An added feature to cardiac muscle cells is a line than extends along the end of the cell as it abuts the next cardiac cell in the row.
7.33.299	This line is called an intercalated disc: it assists in passing electrical impulse efficiently from one cell to the next and maintains the strong connection between neighboring cardiac cells.
7.33.300	Nervous Tissues Nervous tissues are made of cells specialized to receive and transmit electrical impulses from specific areas of the body and to send them to specific locations in the body.
7.33.301	The main cell of the nervous system is the neuron, illustrated in Figure 33.19.
7.33.302	The large structure with a central nucleus is the cell body of the neuron.
7.33.303	Projections from the cell body are either dendrites specialized in receiving input or a single axon specialized in transmitting impulses.
7.33.304	Some glial cells are also shown.
7.33.305	Astrocytes regulate the chemical environment of the nerve cell, and oligodendrocytes insulate the axon so the electrical nerve impulse is transferred more efficiently.
7.33.306	Other glial cells that are not shown support the nutritional and waste requirements of the neuron.
7.33.307	Some of the glial cells are phagocytic and remove debris or damaged cells from the tissue.
7.33.308	A nerve consists of neurons and glial cells.
7.33.309	The neuron has projections called dendrites that receive signals and projections called axons that send signals.
7.33.310	Also shown are two types of glial cells: astrocytes regulate the chemical environment of the nerve cell, and oligodendrocytes insulate the axon so the electrical nerve impulse is transferred more efficiently.
7.33.311	Animal organs and organ systems constantly adjust to internal and external changes through a process called homeostasis (“steady state”).
7.33.312	These changes might be in the level of glucose or calcium in blood or in external temperatures.
7.33.313	Homeostasis means to maintain dynamic equilibrium in the body.
7.33.314	It is dynamic because it is constantly adjusting to the changes that the body’s systems encounter.
7.33.315	It is equilibrium because body functions are kept within specific ranges.
7.33.316	Even an animal that is apparently inactive is maintaining this homeostatic equilibrium.
7.33.317	Homeostatic Process
7.33.318	The goal of homeostasis is the maintenance of equilibrium around a point or value called a set point.
7.33.319	While there are normal fluctuations from the set point, the body’s systems will usually attempt to go back to this point.
7.33.320	A change in the internal or external environment is called a stimulus and is detected by a receptor; the response of the system is to adjust the deviation parameter toward the set point.
7.33.321	For instance, if the body becomes too warm, adjustments are made to cool the animal.
7.33.322	If the blood’s glucose rises after a meal, adjustments are made to lower the blood glucose level by getting the nutrient into tissues that need it or to store it for later use.
7.33.323	Control of Homeostasis
7.33.324	When a change occurs in an animal’s environment, an adjustment must be made.
7.33.325	The receptor senses the change in the environment, then sends a signal to the control center (in most cases, the brain) which in turn generates a response that is signaled to an effector.
7.33.326	The effector is a muscle (that contracts or relaxes) or a gland that secretes.
7.33.327	Homeostatsis is maintained by negative feedback loops.
7.33.328	Positive feedback loops actually push the organism further out of homeostasis, but may be necessary for life to occur.
7.33.329	Homeostasis is controlled by the nervous and endocrine system of mammals.
7.33.330	Negative Feedback Mechanisms
7.33.331	Any homeostatic process that changes the direction of the stimulus is a negative feedback loop.
7.33.332	It may either increase or decrease the stimulus, but the stimulus is not allowed to continue as it did before the receptor sensed it.
7.33.333	In other words, if a level is too high, the body does something to bring it down, and conversely, if a level is too low, the body does something to make it go up.
7.33.334	Hence the term negative feedback.
7.33.335	An example is animal maintenance of blood glucose levels.
7.33.336	When an animal has eaten, blood glucose levels rise.
7.33.337	This is sensed by the nervous system.
7.33.338	Specialized cells in the pancreas sense this, and the hormone insulin is released by the endocrine system.
7.33.339	Insulin causes blood glucose levels to decrease, as would be expected in a negative feedback system, as illustrated in Figure 33.20.
7.33.340	However, if an animal has not eaten and blood glucose levels decrease, this is sensed in another group of cells in the pancreas, and the hormone glucagon is released causing glucose levels to increase.
7.33.341	This is still a negative feedback loop, but not in the direction expected by the use of the term “negative.
7.33.342	”
7.33.343	Another example of an increase as a result of the feedback loop is the control of blood calcium.
7.33.344	If calcium levels decrease, specialized cells in the parathyroid gland sense this and release parathyroid hormone (PTH), causing an increased absorption of calcium through the intestines and kidneys and, possibly, the breakdown of bone in order to liberate calcium.
7.33.345	The effects of PTH are to raise blood levels of the element.
7.33.346	Negative feedback loops are the predominant mechanism used in homeostasis.
7.33.347	Blood sugar levels are controlled by a negative feedback loop.
7.33.348	(credit: modification of work by Jon Sullivan)
7.33.349	Positive Feedback Loop
7.33.350	A positive feedback loop maintains the direction of the stimulus, possibly accelerating it.
7.33.351	Few examples of positive feedback loops exist in animal bodies, but one is found in the cascade of chemical reactions that result in blood clotting, or coagulation.
7.33.352	As one clotting factor is activated, it activates the next factor in sequence until a fibrin clot is achieved.
7.33.353	The direction is maintained, not changed, so this is positive feedback.
7.33.354	Another example of positive feedback is uterine contractions during childbirth, as illustrated in Figure 33.21.
7.33.355	The hormone oxytocin, made by the endocrine system, stimulates the contraction of the uterus.
7.33.356	This produces pain sensed by the nervous system.
7.33.357	Instead of lowering the oxytocin and causing the pain to subside, more oxytocin is produced until the contractions are powerful enough to produce childbirth.
7.33.358	Set Point
7.33.359	It is possible to adjust a system’s set point.
7.33.360	When this happens, the feedback loop works to maintain the new setting.
7.33.361	An example of this is blood pressure: over time, the normal or set point for blood pressure can increase as a result of continued increases in blood pressure.
7.33.362	The body no longer recognizes the elevation as abnormal and no attempt is made to return to the lower set point.
7.33.363	The result is the maintenance of an elevated blood pressure that can have harmful effects on the body.
7.33.364	Medication can lower blood pressure and lower the set point in the system to a more healthy level.
7.33.365	This is called a process of alteration of the set point in a feedback loop.
7.33.366	Changes can be made in a group of body organ systems in order to maintain a set point in another system.
7.33.367	This is called acclimatization.
7.33.368	This occurs, for instance, when an animal migrates to a higher altitude than it is accustomed to.
7.33.369	In order to adjust to the lower oxygen levels at the new altitude, the body increases the number of red blood cells circulating in the blood to ensure adequate oxygen delivery to the tissues.
7.33.370	Another example of acclimatization is animals that have seasonal changes in their coats: a heavier coat in the winter ensures adequate heat retention, and a light coat in summer assists in keeping body temperature from rising to harmful levels.
7.33.371	Homeostasis:
7.33.372	Thermoregulation Body temperature affects body activities.
7.33.373	Generally, as body temperature rises, enzyme activity rises as well.
7.33.374	For every ten degree centigrade rise in temperature, enzyme activity doubles, up to a point.
7.33.375	Body proteins, including enzymes, begin to denature and lose their function with high heat (around 50oC for mammals).
7.33.376	Enzyme activity will decrease by half for every ten degree centigrade drop in temperature, to the point of freezing, with a few exceptions.
7.33.377	Some fish can withstand freezing solid and return to normal with thawing.
7.33.378	Endotherms and Ectotherms Animals can be divided into two groups: some maintain a constant body temperature in the face of differing environmental temperatures, while others have a body temperature that is the same as their environment and thus varies with the environment.
7.33.379	Animals that do not control their body temperature are ectotherms.
7.33.380	This group has been called cold-blooded, but the term may not apply to an animal in the desert with a very warm body temperature.
7.33.381	In contrast to ectotherms, which rely on external temperatures to set their body temperatures, poikilotherms are animals with constantly varying internal temperatures.
7.33.382	An animal that maintains a constant body temperature in the face of environmental changes is called a homeotherm.
7.33.383	Endotherms are animals that rely on internal sources for body temperature but which can exhibit extremes in temperature.
7.33.384	These animals are able to maintain a level of activity at cooler temperature, which an ectotherm cannot due to differing enzyme levels of activity.
7.33.385	Heat can be exchanged between an animal and its environment through four mechanisms: radiation, evaporation, convection, and conduction (Figure 33.22).
7.33.386	Radiation is the emission of electromagnetic “heat” waves.
7.33.387	Heat comes from the sun in this manner and radiates from dry skin the same way.
7.33.388	Heat can be removed with liquid from a surface during evaporation.
7.33.389	This occurs when a mammal sweats.
7.33.390	Convection currents of air remove heat from the surface of dry skin as the air passes over it.
7.33.391	Heat will be conducted from one surface to another during direct contact with the surfaces, such as an animal resting on a warm rock.
7.33.392	Heat can be exchanged by four mechanisms: (a) radiation, (b) evaporation, (c) convection, or (d) conduction.
7.33.393	(credit b: modification of work by “Kullez”/Flickr; credit c: modification of work by Chad Rosenthal;
7.33.394	credit d:
7.33.395	modification of work by “stacey.d”/Flickr)
7.33.396	Heat Conservation and Dissipation Animals conserve or dissipate heat in a variety of ways.
7.33.397	In certain climates, endothermic animals have some form of insulation, such as fur, fat, feathers, or some combination thereof.
7.33.398	Animals with thick fur or feathers create an insulating layer of air between their skin and internal organs.
7.33.399	Polar bears and seals live and swim in a subfreezing environment and yet maintain a constant, warm, body temperature.
7.33.400	The arctic fox, for example, uses its fluffy tail as extra insulation when it curls up to sleep in cold weather.
7.33.401	Mammals have a residual effect from shivering and increased muscle activity: arrector pili muscles cause “goose bumps,” causing small hairs to stand up when the individual is cold; this has the intended effect of increasing body temperature.
7.33.402	Mammals use layers of fat to achieve the same end.
7.33.403	Loss of significant amounts of body fat will compromise an individual’s ability to conserve heat.
7.33.404	Endotherms use their circulatory systems to help maintain body temperature.
7.33.405	Vasodilation brings more blood and heat to the body surface, facilitating radiation and evaporative heat loss, which helps to cool the body.
7.33.406	Vasoconstriction reduces blood flow in peripheral blood vessels, forcing blood toward the core and the vital organs found there, and conserving heat.
7.33.407	Some animals have adaptions to their circulatory system that enable them to transfer heat from arteries to veins, warming blood returning to the heart.
7.33.408	This is called a countercurrent heat exchange; it prevents the cold venous blood from cooling the heart and other internal organs.
7.33.409	This adaption can be shut down in some animals to prevent overheating the internal organs.
7.33.410	The countercurrent adaption is found in many animals, including dolphins, sharks, bony fish, bees, and hummingbirds.
7.33.411	In contrast, similar adaptations can help cool endotherms when needed, such as dolphin flukes and elephant ears.
7.33.412	Some ectothermic animals use changes in their behavior to help regulate body temperature.
7.33.413	For example, a desert ectothermic animal may simply seek cooler areas during the hottest part of the day in the desert to keep from getting too warm.
7.33.414	The same animals may climb onto rocks to capture heat during a cold desert night.
7.33.415	Some animals seek water to aid evaporation in cooling them, as seen with reptiles.
7.33.416	Other ectotherms use group activity such as the activity of bees to warm a hive to survive winter.
7.33.417	Many animals, especially mammals, use metabolic waste heat as a heat source.
7.33.418	When muscles are contracted, most of the energy from the ATP used in muscle actions is wasted energy that translates into heat.
7.33.419	Severe cold elicits a shivering reflex that generates heat for the body.
7.33.420	Many species also have a type of adipose tissue called brown fat that specializes in generating heat.
7.33.421	Neural Control of Thermoregulation
7.33.422	The nervous system is important to thermoregulation, as illustrated in Figure 33.22.
7.33.423	The processes of homeostasis and temperature control are centered in the hypothalamus of the advanced animal brain.
7.33.424	The hypothalamus maintains the set point for body temperature through reflexes that cause vasodilation and sweating when the body is too warm, or vasoconstriction and shivering when the body is too cold.
7.33.425	It responds to chemicals from the body.
7.33.426	When a bacterium is destroyed by phagocytic leukocytes, chemicals called endogenous pyrogens are released into the blood.
7.33.427	These pyrogens circulate to the hypothalamus and reset the thermostat.
7.33.428	This allows the body’s temperature to increase in what is commonly called a fever.
7.33.429	An increase in body temperature causes iron to be conserved, which reduces a nutrient needed by bacteria.
7.33.430	An increase in body heat also increases the activity of the animal’s enzymes and protective cells while inhibiting the enzymes and activity of the invading microorganisms.
7.33.431	Finally, heat itself may also kill the pathogen.
7.33.432	A fever that was once thought to be a complication of an infection is now understood to be a normal defense mechanism.
7.34.0	For humans, fruits and vegetables are important in maintaining a balanced diet.
7.34.1	Introduction
7.34.2	All living organisms need nutrients to survive.
7.34.3	While plants can obtain the molecules required for cellular function through the process of photosynthesis, most animals obtain their nutrients by the consumption of other organisms.
7.34.4	At the cellular level, the biological molecules necessary for animal function are amino acids, lipid molecules, nucleotides, and simple sugars.
7.34.5	However, the food consumed consists of protein, fat, and complex carbohydrates.
7.34.6	Animals must convert these macromolecules into the simple molecules required for maintaining cellular functions, such as assembling new molecules, cells, and tissues.
7.34.7	The conversion of the food consumed to the nutrients required is a multi-step process involving digestion and absorption.
7.34.8	During digestion, food particles are broken down to smaller components, and later, they are absorbed by the body.
7.34.9	One of the challenges in human nutrition is maintaining a balance between food intake, storage, and energy expenditure.
7.34.10	Imbalances can have serious health consequences.
7.34.11	For example, eating too much food while not expending much energy leads to obesity, which in turn will increase the risk of developing illnesses such as type-2 diabetes and cardiovascular disease.
7.34.12	The recent rise in obesity and related diseases makes understanding the role of diet and nutrition in maintaining good health all the more important.
7.34.13	Animals obtain their nutrition from the consumption of other organisms.
