7.34.14	Depending on their diet, animals can be classified into the following categories: plant eaters (herbivores), meat eaters (carnivores), and those that eat both plants and animals (omnivores).
7.34.15	The nutrients and macromolecules present in food are not immediately accessible to the cells.
7.34.16	There are a number of processes that modify food within the animal body in order to make the nutrients and organic molecules accessible for cellular function.
7.34.17	As animals evolved in complexity of form and function, their digestive systems have also evolved to accommodate their various dietary needs.
7.34.18	Herbivores, Omnivores, and Carnivores Herbivores are animals whose primary food source is plant-based.
7.34.19	Examples of herbivores, as shown in Figure 34.2 include vertebrates like deer, koalas, and some bird species, as well as invertebrates such as crickets and caterpillars.
7.34.20	These animals have evolved digestive systems capable of handling large amounts of plant material.
7.34.21	Herbivores can be further classified into frugivores (fruit-eaters), granivores (seed eaters), nectivores (nectar feeders), and folivores (leaf eaters).
7.34.22	Herbivores, like this (a) mule deer and (b) monarch caterpillar, eat primarily plant material.
7.34.23	(credit a: modification of work by Bill Ebbesen; credit b: modification of work by Doug Bowman)
7.34.24	Carnivores are animals that eat other animals.
7.34.25	The word carnivore is derived from Latin and literally means “meat eater.
7.34.26	”
7.34.27	Wild cats such as lions, shown in Figure 34.3a and tigers are examples of vertebrate carnivores, as are snakes and sharks, while invertebrate carnivores include sea stars, spiders, and ladybugs, shown in Figure 34.3b.
7.34.28	Obligate carnivores are those that rely entirely on animal flesh to obtain their nutrients; examples of obligate carnivores are members of the cat family, such as lions and cheetahs.
7.34.29	Facultative carnivores are those that also eat non-animal food in addition to animal food.
7.34.30	Note that there is no clear line that differentiates facultative carnivores from omnivores; dogs would be considered facultative carnivores.
7.34.31	Carnivores like the (a) lion eat primarily meat.
7.34.32	The (b) ladybug is also a carnivore that consumes small insects called aphids.
7.34.33	(credit a: modification of work by Kevin Pluck; credit b: modification of work by Jon Sullivan) Omnivores are animals that eat both plant- and animal-derived food.
7.34.34	In Latin, omnivore means to eat everything.
7.34.35	Humans, bears (shown in Figure 34.4a), and chickens are example of vertebrate omnivores; invertebrate omnivores include cockroaches and crayfish (shown in Figure 34.4b).
7.34.36	Omnivores like the (a) bear and (b) crayfish eat both plant and animal based food.
7.34.37	(credit a: modification of work by Dave Menke; credit b: modification of work by Jon Sullivan)
7.34.38	Invertebrate Digestive Systems Animals have evolved different types of digestive systems to aid in the digestion of the different foods they consume.
7.34.39	The simplest example is that of a gastrovascular cavity and is found in organisms with only one opening for digestion.
7.34.40	Platyhelminthes (flatworms), Ctenophora (comb jellies), and Cnidaria (coral, jelly fish, and sea anemones) use this type of digestion.
7.34.41	Gastrovascular cavities, as shown in Figure 34.5a, are typically a blind tube or cavity with only one opening, the “mouth”, which also serves as an “anus”.
7.34.42	Ingested material enters the mouth and passes through a hollow, tubular cavity.
7.34.43	Cells within the cavity secrete digestive enzymes that break down the food.
7.34.44	The food particles are engulfed by the cells lining the gastrovascular cavity.
7.34.45	The alimentary canal, shown in Figure 34.5b, is a more advanced system: it consists of one tube with a mouth at one end and an anus at the other.
7.34.46	Earthworms are an example of an animal with an alimentary canal.
7.34.47	Once the food is ingested through the mouth, it passes through the esophagus and is stored in an organ called the crop; then it passes into the gizzard where it is churned and digested.
7.34.48	From the gizzard, the food passes through the intestine, the nutrients are absorbed, and the waste is eliminated as feces, called castings, through the anus.
7.34.49	A gastrovascular cavity has a single opening through which food is ingested and waste is excreted, as shown in this hydra and in this jellyfish medusa.
7.34.50	(b)
7.34.51	An alimentary canal has two openings: a mouth for ingesting food, and an anus for eliminating waste, as shown in this nematode.
7.34.52	Vertebrate Digestive Systems Vertebrates have evolved more complex digestive systems to adapt to their dietary needs.
7.34.53	Some animals have a single stomach, while others have multi-chambered stomachs.
7.34.54	Birds have developed a digestive system adapted to eating unmasticated food.
7.34.55	Monogastric:
7.34.56	Single-chambered Stomach
7.34.57	As the word monogastric suggests, this type of digestive system consists of one (“mono”) stomach chamber (“gastric”).
7.34.58	Humans and many animals have a monogastric digestive system as illustrated in Figure 34.6ab.
7.34.59	The process of digestion begins with the mouth and the intake of food.
7.34.60	The teeth play an important role in masticating (chewing) or physically breaking down food into smaller particles.
7.34.61	The enzymes present in saliva also begin to chemically break down food.
7.34.62	The esophagus is a long tube that connects the mouth to the stomach.
7.34.63	Using peristalsis, or wave-like smooth muscle contractions, the muscles of the esophagus push the food towards the stomach.
7.34.64	In order to speed up the actions of enzymes in the stomach, the stomach is an extremely acidic environment, with a pH between 1.5 and 2.5.
7.34.65	The gastric juices, which include enzymes in the stomach, act on the food particles and continue the process of digestion.
7.34.66	Further breakdown of food takes place in the small intestine where enzymes produced by the liver, the small intestine, and the pancreas continue the process of digestion.
7.34.67	The nutrients are absorbed into the blood stream across the epithelial cells lining the walls of the small intestines.
7.34.68	The waste material travels on to the large intestine where water is absorbed and the drier waste material is compacted into feces; it is stored until it is excreted through the rectum.
7.34.69	Humans and herbivores, such as the (b) rabbit, have a monogastric digestive system.
7.34.70	However, in the rabbit the small intestine and cecum are enlarged to allow more time to digest plant material.
7.34.71	The enlarged organ provides more surface area for absorption of nutrients.
7.34.72	Rabbits digest their food twice: the first time food passes through the digestive system, it collects in the cecum, and then it passes as soft feces called cecotrophes.
7.34.73	The rabbit re-ingests these cecotrophes to further digest them.
7.34.74	Avian Birds face special challenges when it comes to obtaining nutrition from food.
7.34.75	They do not have teeth and so their digestive system, shown in Figure 34.7, must be able to process un-masticated food.
7.34.76	Birds have evolved a variety of beak types that reflect the vast variety in their diet, ranging from seeds and insects to fruits and nuts.
7.34.77	Because most birds fly, their metabolic rates are high in order to efficiently process food and keep their body weight low.
7.34.78	The stomach of birds has two chambers: the proventriculus, where gastric juices are produced to digest the food before it enters the stomach, and the gizzard, where the food is stored, soaked, and mechanically ground.
7.34.79	The undigested material forms food pellets that are sometimes regurgitated.
7.34.80	Most of the chemical digestion and absorption happens in the intestine and the waste is excreted through the cloaca.
7.34.81	The avian esophagus has a pouch, called a crop, which stores food.
7.34.82	Food passes from the crop to the first of two stomachs, called the proventriculus, which contains digestive juices that break down food.
7.34.83	From the proventriculus, the food enters the second stomach, called the gizzard, which grinds food.
7.34.84	Some birds swallow stones or grit, which are stored in the gizzard, to aid the grinding process.
7.34.85	Birds do not have separate openings to excrete urine and feces.
7.34.86	Instead, uric acid from the kidneys is secreted into the large intestine and combined with waste from the digestive process.
7.34.87	This waste is excreted through an opening called the cloaca.
7.34.88	Ruminants Ruminants are mainly herbivores like cows, sheep, and goats, whose entire diet consists of eating large amounts of roughage or fiber.
7.34.89	They have evolved digestive systems that help them digest vast amounts of cellulose.
7.34.90	An interesting feature of the ruminants’ mouth is that they do not have upper incisor teeth.
7.34.91	They use their lower teeth, tongue and lips to tear and chew their food.
7.34.92	From the mouth, the food travels to the esophagus and on to the stomach.
7.34.93	To help digest the large amount of plant material, the stomach of the ruminants is a multi-chambered organ, as illustrated in Figure 34.8.
7.34.94	The four compartments of the stomach are called the rumen, reticulum, omasum, and abomasum.
7.34.95	These chambers contain many microbes that break down cellulose and ferment ingested food.
7.34.96	The abomasum is the “true” stomach and is the equivalent of the monogastric stomach chamber where gastric juices are secreted.
7.34.97	The four-compartment gastric chamber provides larger space and the microbial support necessary to digest plant material in ruminants.
7.34.98	The fermentation process produces large amounts of gas in the stomach chamber, which must be eliminated.
7.34.99	As in other animals, the small intestine plays an important role in nutrient absorption, and the large intestine helps in the elimination of waste.
7.34.100	Ruminant animals, such as goats and cows, have four stomachs.
7.34.101	The first two stomachs, the rumen and the reticulum, contain prokaryotes and protists that are able to digest cellulose fiber.
7.34.102	The ruminant regurgitates cud from the reticulum, chews it, and swallows it into a third stomach, the omasum, which removes water.
7.34.103	The cud then passes onto the fourth stomach, the abomasum, where it is digested by enzymes produced by the ruminant.
7.34.104	Pseudo-ruminants
7.34.105	Some animals, such as camels and alpacas, are pseudo-ruminants.
7.34.106	They eat a lot of plant material and roughage.
7.34.107	Digesting plant material is not easy because plant cell walls contain the polymeric sugar molecule cellulose.
7.34.108	The digestive enzymes of these animals cannot break down cellulose, but microorganisms present in the digestive system can.
7.34.109	Therefore, the digestive system must be able to handle large amounts of roughage and break down the cellulose.
7.34.110	Pseudo-ruminants have a three- chamber stomach in the digestive system.
7.34.111	However, their cecum—a pouched organ at the beginning of the large intestine containing many microorganisms that are necessary for the digestion of plant materials—is large and is the site where the roughage is fermented and digested.
7.34.112	These animals do not have a rumen but have an omasum, abomasum, and reticulum.
7.34.113	Parts of the Digestive System
7.34.114	The vertebrate digestive system is designed to facilitate the transformation of food matter into the nutrient components that sustain organisms.
7.34.115	Oral Cavity
7.34.116	The oral cavity, or mouth, is the point of entry of food into the digestive system, illustrated in Figure 34.9.
7.34.117	The food consumed is broken into smaller particles by mastication, the chewing action of the teeth.
7.34.118	All mammals have teeth and can chew their food.
7.34.119	The extensive chemical process of digestion begins in the mouth.
7.34.120	As food is being chewed, saliva, produced by the salivary glands, mixes with the food.
7.34.121	Saliva is a watery substance produced in the mouths of many animals.
7.34.122	There are three major glands that secrete saliva—the parotid, the submandibular, and the sublingual.
7.34.123	Saliva contains mucus that moistens food and buffers the pH of the food.
7.34.124	Saliva also contains immunoglobulins and lysozymes, which have antibacterial action to reduce tooth decay by inhibiting growth of some bacteria.
7.34.125	Saliva also contains an enzyme called salivary amylase that begins the process of converting starches in the food into a disaccharide called maltose.
7.34.126	Another enzyme called lipase is produced by the cells in the tongue.
7.34.127	Lipases are a class of enzymes that can break down triglycerides.
7.34.128	The lingual lipase begins the breakdown of fat components in the food.
7.34.129	The chewing and wetting action provided by the teeth and saliva prepare the food into a mass called the bolus for swallowing.
7.34.130	The tongue helps in swallowing—moving the bolus from the mouth into the pharynx.
7.34.131	The pharynx opens to two passageways: the trachea, which leads to the lungs, and the esophagus, which leads to the stomach.
7.34.132	The trachea has an opening called the glottis, which is covered by a cartilaginous flap called the epiglottis.
7.34.133	When swallowing, the epiglottis closes the glottis and food passes into the esophagus and not the trachea.
7.34.134	This arrangement allows food to be kept out of the trachea.
7.34.135	Digestion of food begins in the (a) oral cavity.
7.34.136	Food is masticated by teeth and moistened by saliva secreted from the (b) salivary glands.
7.34.137	Enzymes in the saliva begin to digest starches and fats.
7.34.138	With the help of the tongue, the resulting bolus is moved into the esophagus by swallowing.
7.34.139	(credit: modification of work by the National Cancer Institute)
7.34.140	Esophagus
7.34.141	The esophagus is a tubular organ that connects the mouth to the stomach.
7.34.142	The chewed and softened food passes through the esophagus after being swallowed.
7.34.143	The smooth muscles of the esophagus undergo a series of wave like movements called peristalsis that push the food toward the stomach, as illustrated in Figure 34.10.
7.34.144	The peristalsis wave is unidirectional—it moves food from the mouth to the stomach, and reverse movement is not possible.
7.34.145	The peristaltic movement of the esophagus is an involuntary reflex; it takes place in response to the act of swallowing.
7.34.146	The esophagus transfers food from the mouth to the stomach through peristaltic movements.
7.34.147	A ring-like muscle called a sphincter forms valves in the digestive system.
7.34.148	The gastro-esophageal sphincter is located at the stomach end of the esophagus.
7.34.149	In response to swallowing and the pressure exerted by the bolus of food, this sphincter opens, and the bolus enters the stomach.
7.34.150	When there is no swallowing action, this sphincter is shut and prevents the contents of the stomach from traveling up the esophagus.
7.34.151	Many animals have a true sphincter; however, in humans, there is no true sphincter, but the esophagus remains closed when there is no swallowing action.
7.34.152	Acid reflux or “heartburn” occurs when the acidic digestive juices escape into the esophagus.
7.34.153	Stomach A large part of digestion occurs in the stomach, shown in Figure 34.11.
7.34.154	The stomach is a saclike organ that secretes gastric digestive juices.
7.34.155	The pH in the stomach is between 1.5 and 2.5.
7.34.156	This highly acidic environment is required for the chemical breakdown of food and the extraction of nutrients.
7.34.157	When empty, the stomach is a rather small organ; however, it can expand to up to 20 times its resting size when filled with food.
7.34.158	This characteristic is particularly useful for animals that need to eat when food is available.
7.34.159	The stomach is also the major site for protein digestion in animals other than ruminants.
7.34.160	Protein digestion is mediated by an enzyme called pepsin in the stomach chamber.
7.34.161	Pepsin is secreted by the chief cells in the stomach in an inactive form called pepsinogen.
7.34.162	Pepsin breaks peptide bonds and cleaves proteins into smaller polypeptides; it also helps activate more pepsinogen, starting a positive feedback mechanism that generates more pepsin.
7.34.163	Another cell type—parietal cells—secrete hydrogen and chloride ions, which combine in the lumen to form hydrochloric acid, the primary acidic component of the stomach juices.
7.34.164	Hydrochloric acid helps to convert the inactive pepsinogen to pepsin.
7.34.165	The highly acidic environment also kills many microorganisms in the food and, combined with the action of the enzyme pepsin, results in the hydrolysis of protein in the food.
7.34.166	Chemical digestion is facilitated by the churning action of the stomach.
7.34.167	Contraction and relaxation of smooth muscles mixes the stomach contents about every 20 minutes.
7.34.168	The partially digested food and gastric juice mixture is called chyme.
7.34.169	Chyme passes from the stomach to the small intestine.
7.34.170	Further protein digestion takes place in the small intestine.
7.34.171	Gastric emptying occurs within two to six hours after a meal.
7.34.172	Only a small amount of chyme is released into the small intestine at a time.
7.34.173	The movement of chyme from the stomach into the small intestine is regulated by the pyloric sphincter.
7.34.174	When digesting protein and some fats, the stomach lining must be protected from getting digested by pepsin.
7.34.175	There are two points to consider when describing how the stomach lining is protected.
7.34.176	First, as previously mentioned, the enzyme pepsin is synthesized in the inactive form.
7.34.177	This protects the chief cells, because pepsinogen does not have the same enzyme functionality of pepsin.
7.34.178	Second, the stomach has a thick mucus lining that protects the underlying tissue from the action of the digestive juices.
7.34.179	When this mucus lining is ruptured, ulcers can form in the stomach.
7.34.180	Ulcers are open wounds in or on an organ caused by bacteria (Helicobacter pylori) when the mucus lining is ruptured and fails to reform.
7.34.181	Small Intestine Chyme moves from the stomach to the small intestine.
7.34.182	The small intestine is the organ where the digestion of protein, fats, and carbohydrates is completed.
7.34.183	The small intestine is a long tube-like organ with a highly folded surface containing finger- like projections called the villi.
7.34.184	The apical surface of each villus has many microscopic projections called microvilli.
7.34.185	These structures, illustrated in Figure 34.12, are lined with epithelial cells on the luminal side and allow for the nutrients to be absorbed from the digested food and absorbed into the blood stream on the other side.
7.34.186	The villi and microvilli, with their many folds, increase the surface area of the intestine and increase absorption efficiency of the nutrients.
7.34.187	Absorbed nutrients in the blood are carried into the hepatic portal vein, which leads to the liver.
7.34.188	There, the liver regulates the distribution of nutrients to the rest of the body and removes toxic substances, including drugs, alcohol, and some pathogens.
7.34.189	The human small intestine is over 6m long and is divided into three parts: the duodenum, the jejunum, and the ileum.
7.34.190	The “C-shaped,” fixed part of the small intestine is called the duodenum and is shown in Figure 34.11.
7.34.191	The duodenum is separated from the stomach by the pyloric sphincter which opens to allow chyme to move from the stomach to the duodenum.
7.34.192	In the duodenum, chyme is mixed with pancreatic juices in an alkaline solution rich in bicarbonate that neutralizes the acidity of chyme and acts as a buffer.
7.34.193	Pancreatic juices also contain several digestive enzymes.
7.34.194	Digestive juices from the pancreas, liver, and gallbladder, as well as from gland cells of the intestinal wall itself, enter the duodenum.
7.34.195	Bile is produced in the liver and stored and concentrated in the gallbladder.
7.34.196	Bile contains bile salts which emulsify lipids while the pancreas produces enzymes that catabolize starches, disaccharides, proteins, and fats.
7.34.197	These digestive juices break down the food particles in the chyme into glucose, triglycerides, and amino acids.
7.34.198	Some chemical digestion of food takes place in the duodenum.
7.34.199	Absorption of fatty acids also takes place in the duodenum.
7.34.200	The second part of the small intestine is called the jejunum, shown in Figure 34.11.
7.34.201	Here, hydrolysis of nutrients is continued while most of the carbohydrates and amino acids are absorbed through the intestinal lining.
7.34.202	The bulk of chemical digestion and nutrient absorption occurs in the jejunum.
7.34.203	The ileum, also illustrated in Figure 34.11 is the last part of the small intestine and here the bile salts and vitamins are absorbed into blood stream.
7.34.204	The undigested food is sent to the colon from the ileum via peristaltic movements of the muscle.
7.34.205	The ileum ends and the large intestine begins at the ileocecal valve.
7.34.206	The vermiform, “worm-like,” appendix is located at the ileocecal valve.
7.34.207	The appendix of humans secretes no enzymes and has an insignificant role in immunity.
7.34.208	Large Intestine
7.34.209	The large intestine, illustrated in Figure 34.13, reabsorbs the water from the undigested food material and processes the waste material.
7.34.210	The human large intestine is much smaller in length compared to the small intestine but larger in diameter.
7.34.211	It has three parts: the cecum, the colon, and the rectum.
7.34.212	The cecum joins the ileum to the colon and is the receiving pouch for the waste matter.
7.34.213	The colon is home to many bacteria or “intestinal flora” that aid in the digestive processes.
7.34.214	The colon can be divided into four regions, the ascending colon, the transverse colon, the descending colon and the sigmoid colon.
7.34.215	The main functions of the colon are to extract the water and mineral salts from undigested food, and to store waste material.
7.34.216	Carnivorous mammals have a shorter large intestine compared to herbivorous mammals due to their diet.
7.34.217	The large intestine reabsorbs water from undigested food and stores waste material until it is eliminated.
7.34.218	Rectum and Anus
7.34.219	The rectum is the terminal end of the large intestine, as shown in Figure 34.13.
7.34.220	The primary role of the rectum is to store the feces until defecation.
7.34.221	The feces are propelled using peristaltic movements during elimination.
7.34.222	The anus is an opening at the far-end of the digestive tract and is the exit point for the waste material.
7.34.223	Two sphincters between the rectum and anus control elimination: the inner sphincter is involuntary and the outer sphincter is voluntary.
7.34.224	Accessory Organs
7.34.225	The organs discussed above are the organs of the digestive tract through which food passes.
7.34.226	Accessory organs are organs that add secretions (enzymes) that catabolize food into nutrients.
7.34.227	Accessory organs include salivary glands, the liver, the pancreas, and the gallbladder.
7.34.228	The liver, pancreas, and gallbladder are regulated by hormones in response to the food consumed.
7.34.229	The liver is the largest internal organ in humans and it plays a very important role in digestion of fats and detoxifying blood.
7.34.230	The liver produces bile, a digestive juice that is required for the breakdown of fatty components of the food in the duodenum.
7.34.231	The liver also processes the vitamins and fats and synthesizes many plasma proteins.
7.34.232	The pancreas is another important gland that secretes digestive juices.
7.34.233	The chyme produced from the stomach is highly acidic in nature; the pancreatic juices contain high levels of bicarbonate, an alkali that neutralizes the acidic chyme.
7.34.234	Additionally, the pancreatic juices contain a large variety of enzymes that are required for the digestion of protein and carbohydrates.
7.34.235	The gallbladder is a small organ that aids the liver by storing bile and concentrating bile salts.
7.34.236	When chyme containing fatty acids enters the duodenum, the bile is secreted from the gallbladder into the duodenum.
7.34.237	Given the diversity of animal life on our planet, it is not surprising that the animal diet would also vary substantially.
7.34.238	The animal diet is the source of materials needed for building DNA and other complex molecules needed for growth, maintenance, and reproduction; collectively these processes are called biosynthesis.
7.34.239	The diet is also the source of materials for ATP production in the cells.
7.34.240	The diet must be balanced to provide the minerals and vitamins that are required for cellular function.
7.34.241	Food Requirements
7.34.242	What are the fundamental requirements of the animal diet?
7.34.243	The animal diet should be well balanced and provide nutrients required for bodily function and the minerals and vitamins required for maintaining structure and regulation necessary for good health and reproductive capability.
7.34.244	These requirements for a human are illustrated graphically in Figure 34.14.
7.34.245	Organic Precursors
7.34.246	The organic molecules required for building cellular material and tissues must come from food.
7.34.247	Carbohydrates or sugars are the primary source of organic carbons in the animal body.
7.34.248	During digestion, digestible carbohydrates are ultimately broken down into glucose and used to provide energy through metabolic pathways.
7.34.249	Complex carbohydrates, including polysaccharides, can be broken down into glucose through biochemical modification; however, humans do not produce the enzyme cellulase and lack the ability to derive glucose from the polysaccharide cellulose.
7.34.250	In humans, these molecules provide the fiber required for moving waste through the large intestine and a healthy colon.
7.34.251	The intestinal flora in the human gut are able to extract some nutrition from these plant fibers.
7.34.252	The excess sugars in the body are converted into glycogen and stored in the liver and muscles for later use.
7.34.253	Glycogen stores are used to fuel prolonged exertions, such as long-distance running, and to provide energy during food shortage.
7.34.254	Excess glycogen can be converted to fats, which are stored in the lower layer of the skin of mammals for insulation and energy storage.
7.34.255	Excess digestible carbohydrates are stored by mammals in order to survive famine and aid in mobility.
7.34.256	Another important requirement is that of nitrogen.
7.34.257	Protein catabolism provides a source of organic nitrogen.
7.34.258	Amino acids are the building blocks of proteins and protein breakdown provides amino acids that are used for cellular function.
7.34.259	The carbon and nitrogen derived from these become the building block for nucleotides, nucleic acids, proteins, cells, and tissues.
7.34.260	Excess nitrogen must be excreted as it is toxic.
7.34.261	Fats add flavor to food and promote a sense of satiety or fullness.
7.34.262	Fatty foods are also significant sources of energy because one gram of fat contains nine calories.
7.34.263	Fats are required in the diet to aid the absorption of fat-soluble vitamins and the production of fat-soluble hormones.
7.34.264	Essential Nutrients
7.34.265	While the animal body can synthesize many of the molecules required for function from the organic precursors, there are some nutrients that need to be consumed from food.
7.34.266	These nutrients are termed essential nutrients, meaning they must be eaten, and the body cannot produce them.
7.34.267	The omega-3 alpha-linolenic acid and the omega-6 linoleic acid are essential fatty acids needed to make some membrane phospholipids.
7.34.268	Vitamins are another class of essential organic molecules that are required in small quantities for many enzymes to function and, for this reason, are considered to be co-enzymes.
7.34.269	Absence or low levels of vitamins can have a dramatic effect on health, as outlined in Table 34.1 and Table 34.2.
7.34.270	Both fat-soluble and water-soluble vitamins must be obtained from food.
7.34.271	Minerals, listed in Table 34.3, are inorganic essential nutrients that must be obtained from food.
7.34.272	Among their many functions, minerals help in structure and regulation and are considered co-factors.
7.34.273	Certain amino acids also must be procured from food and cannot be synthesized by the body.
7.34.274	These amino acids are the “essential” amino acids.
7.34.275	The human body can synthesize only 11 of the 20 required amino acids; the rest must be obtained from food.
7.34.276	The essential amino acids are listed in Table 34.4.
7.34.277	Food Energy and ATP Animals need food to obtain energy and maintain homeostasis.
7.34.278	Homeostasis is the ability of a system to maintain a stable internal environment even in the face of external changes to the environment.
7.34.279	For example, the normal body temperature of humans is 37°C (98.6°F).
7.34.280	Humans maintain this temperature even when the external temperature is hot or cold.
7.34.281	It takes energy to maintain this body temperature, and animals obtain this energy from food.
7.34.282	The primary source of energy for animals is carbohydrates, mainly glucose.
7.34.283	Glucose is called the body’s fuel.
7.34.284	The digestible carbohydrates in an animal’s diet are converted to glucose molecules through a series of catabolic chemical reactions.
7.34.285	Adenosine triphosphate, or ATP, is the primary energy currency in cells; ATP stores energy in phosphate ester bonds.
7.34.286	ATP releases energy when the phosphodiester bonds are broken and ATP is converted to ADP and a phosphate group.
7.34.287	ATP is produced by the oxidative reactions in the cytoplasm and mitochondrion of the cell, where carbohydrates, proteins, and fats undergo a series of metabolic reactions collectively called cellular respiration.
7.34.288	For example, glycolysis is a series of reactions in which glucose is converted to pyruvic acid and some of its chemical potential energy is transferred to NADH and ATP.
7.34.289	ATP is required for all cellular functions.
7.34.290	It is used to build the organic molecules that are required for cells and tissues; it provides energy for muscle contraction and for the transmission of electrical signals in the nervous system.
7.34.291	When the amount of ATP is available in excess of the body’s requirements, the liver uses the excess ATP and excess glucose to produce molecules called glycogen.
7.34.292	Glycogen is a polymeric form of glucose and is stored in the liver and skeletal muscle cells.
7.34.293	When blood sugar drops, the liver releases glucose from stores of glycogen.
7.34.294	Skeletal muscle converts glycogen to glucose during intense exercise.
7.34.295	The process of converting glucose and excess ATP to glycogen and the storage of excess energy is an evolutionarily important step in helping animals deal with mobility, food shortages, and famine.
7.34.296	Obtaining nutrition and energy from food is a multi-step process.
7.34.297	For true animals, the first step is ingestion, the act of taking in food.
7.34.298	This is followed by digestion, absorption, and elimination.
7.34.299	In the following sections, each of these steps will be discussed in detail.
7.34.300	Ingestion
7.34.301	The large molecules found in intact food cannot pass through the cell membranes.
7.34.302	Food needs to be broken into smaller particles so that animals can harness the nutrients and organic molecules.
7.34.303	The first step in this process is ingestion.
7.34.304	Ingestion is the process of taking in food through the mouth.
7.34.305	In vertebrates, the teeth, saliva, and tongue play important roles in mastication (preparing the food into bolus).
7.34.306	While the food is being mechanically broken down, the enzymes in saliva begin to chemically process the food as well.
7.34.307	The combined action of these processes modifies the food from large particles to a soft mass that can be swallowed and can travel the length of the esophagus.
7.34.308	Digestion and Absorption Digestion is the mechanical and chemical break down of food into small organic fragments.
7.34.309	It is important to break down macromolecules into smaller fragments that are of suitable size for absorption across the digestive epithelium.
7.34.310	Large, complex molecules of proteins, polysaccharides, and lipids must be reduced to simpler particles such as simple sugar before they can be absorbed by the digestive epithelial cells.
7.34.311	Different organs play specific roles in the digestive process.
7.34.312	The animal diet needs carbohydrates, protein, and fat, as well as vitamins and inorganic components for nutritional balance.
7.34.313	How each of these components is digested is discussed in the following sections.
7.34.314	Carbohydrates The digestion of carbohydrates begins in the mouth.
7.34.315	The salivary enzyme amylase begins the breakdown of food starches into maltose, a disaccharide.
7.34.316	As the bolus of food travels through the esophagus to the stomach, no significant digestion of carbohydrates takes place.
7.34.317	The esophagus produces no digestive enzymes but does produce mucous for lubrication.
7.34.318	The acidic environment in the stomach stops the action of the amylase enzyme.
7.34.319	The next step of carbohydrate digestion takes place in the duodenum.
7.34.320	Recall that the chyme from the stomach enters the duodenum and mixes with the digestive secretion from the pancreas, liver, and gallbladder.
7.34.321	Pancreatic juices also contain amylase, which continues the breakdown of starch and glycogen into maltose, a disaccharide.
7.34.322	The disaccharides are broken down into monosaccharides by enzymes called maltases, sucrases, and lactases, which are also present in the brush border of the small intestinal wall.
7.34.323	Maltase breaks down maltose into glucose.
7.34.324	Other disaccharides, such as sucrose and lactose are broken down by sucrase and lactase, respectively.
7.34.325	Sucrase breaks down sucrose (or “table sugar”) into glucose and fructose, and lactase breaks down lactose (or “milk sugar”) into glucose and galactose.
7.34.326	The monosaccharides (glucose) thus produced are absorbed and then can be used in metabolic pathways to harness energy.
7.34.327	The monosaccharides are transported across the intestinal epithelium into the bloodstream to be transported to the different cells in the body.
7.34.328	The steps in carbohydrate digestion are summarized in Figure 34.16 and Table 34.5.
7.34.329	Digestion of carbohydrates is performed by several enzymes.
7.34.330	Starch and glycogen are broken down into glucose by amylase and maltase.
7.34.331	Sucrose (table sugar) and lactose (milk sugar) are broken down by sucrase and lactase, respectively.
7.34.332	Protein
7.34.333	A large part of protein digestion takes place in the stomach.
7.34.334	The enzyme pepsin plays an important role in the digestion of proteins by breaking down the intact protein to peptides, which are short chains of four to nine amino acids.
7.34.335	In the duodenum, other enzymes— trypsin, elastase, and chymotrypsin—act on the peptides reducing them to smaller peptides.
7.34.336	Trypsin elastase, carboxypeptidase, and chymotrypsin are produced by the pancreas and released into the duodenum where they act on the chyme.
7.34.337	Further breakdown of peptides to single amino acids is aided by enzymes called peptidases (those that break down peptides).
7.34.338	Specifically, carboxypeptidase, dipeptidase, and aminopeptidase play important roles in reducing the peptides to free amino acids.
7.34.339	The amino acids are absorbed into the bloodstream through the small intestines.
7.34.340	The steps in protein digestion are summarized in Figure 34.17 and Table 34.6.
7.34.341	Lipids Lipid digestion begins in the stomach with the aid of lingual lipase and gastric lipase.
7.34.342	However, the bulk of lipid digestion occurs in the small intestine due to pancreatic lipase.
7.34.343	When chyme enters the duodenum, the hormonal responses trigger the release of bile, which is produced in the liver and stored in the gallbladder.
7.34.344	Bile aids in the digestion of lipids, primarily triglycerides by emulsification.
7.34.345	Emulsification is a process in which large lipid globules are broken down into several small lipid globules.
7.34.346	These small globules are more widely distributed in the chyme rather than forming large aggregates.
7.34.347	Lipids are hydrophobic substances: in the presence of water, they will aggregate to form globules to minimize exposure to water.
7.34.348	Bile contains bile salts, which are amphipathic, meaning they contain hydrophobic and hydrophilic parts.
7.34.349	Thus, the bile salts hydrophilic side can interface with water on one side and the hydrophobic side interfaces with lipids on the other.
7.34.350	By doing so, bile salts emulsify large lipid globules into small lipid globules.
7.34.351	Why is emulsification important for digestion of lipids?
7.34.352	Pancreatic juices contain enzymes called lipases (enzymes that break down lipids).
7.34.353	If the lipid in the chyme aggregates into large globules, very little surface area of the lipids is available for the lipases to act on, leaving lipid digestion incomplete.
7.34.354	By forming an emulsion, bile salts increase the available surface area of the lipids many fold.
7.34.355	The pancreatic lipases can then act on the lipids more efficiently and digest them, as detailed in Figure 34.18.
7.34.356	Lipases break down the lipids into fatty acids and glycerides.
7.34.357	These molecules can pass through the plasma membrane of the cell and enter the epithelial cells of the intestinal lining.
7.34.358	The bile salts surround long-chain fatty acids and monoglycerides forming tiny spheres called micelles.
7.34.359	The micelles move into the brush border of the small intestine absorptive cells where the long-chain fatty acids and monoglycerides diffuse out of the micelles into the absorptive cells leaving the micelles behind in the chyme.
7.34.360	The long-chain fatty acids and monoglycerides recombine in the absorptive cells to form triglycerides, which aggregate into globules and become coated with proteins.
7.34.361	These large spheres are called chylomicrons.
7.34.362	Chylomicrons contain triglycerides, cholesterol, and other lipids and have proteins on their surface.
7.34.363	The surface is also composed of the hydrophilic phosphate "heads" of phospholipids.
7.34.364	Together, they enable the chylomicron to move in an aqueous environment without exposing the lipids to water.
7.34.365	Chylomicrons leave the absorptive cells via exocytosis.
7.34.366	Chylomicrons enter the lymphatic vessels, and then enter the blood in the subclavian vein.
7.34.367	Vitamins Vitamins can be either water-soluble or lipid-soluble.
7.34.368	Fat soluble vitamins are absorbed in the same manner as lipids.
7.34.369	It is important to consume some amount of dietary lipid to aid the absorption of lipid-soluble vitamins.
7.34.370	Water-soluble vitamins can be directly absorbed into the bloodstream from the intestine.
7.34.371	Elimination
7.34.372	The final step in digestion is the elimination of undigested food content and waste products.
7.34.373	The undigested food material enters the colon, where most of the water is reabsorbed.
7.34.374	Recall that the colon is also home to the microflora called “intestinal flora” that aid in the digestion process.
7.34.375	The semi-solid waste is moved through the colon by peristaltic movements of the muscle and is stored in the rectum.
7.34.376	As the rectum expands in response to storage of fecal matter, it triggers the neural signals required to set up the urge to eliminate.
7.34.377	The solid waste is eliminated through the anus using peristaltic movements of the rectum.
7.34.378	Common Problems with Elimination Diarrhea and constipation are some of the most common health concerns that affect digestion.
7.34.379	Constipation is a condition where the feces are hardened because of excess water removal in the colon.
7.34.380	In contrast, if enough water is not removed from the feces, it results in diarrhea.
7.34.381	Many bacteria, including the ones that cause cholera, affect the proteins involved in water reabsorption in the colon and result in excessive diarrhea.
7.34.382	Emesis Emesis, or vomiting, is elimination of food by forceful expulsion through the mouth.
7.34.383	It is often in response to an irritant that affects the digestive tract, including but not limited to viruses, bacteria, emotions, sights, and food poisoning.
7.34.384	This forceful expulsion of the food is due to the strong contractions produced by the stomach muscles.
7.34.385	The process of emesis is regulated by the medulla.
7.34.386	The brain is the control center for the sensation of hunger and satiety.
7.34.387	The functions of the digestive system are regulated through neural and hormonal responses.
7.34.388	Neural Responses to Food
7.34.389	In reaction to the smell, sight, or thought of food, like that shown in Figure 34.20, the first response is that of salivation.
7.34.390	The salivary glands secrete more saliva in response to stimulation by the autonomic nervous system triggered by food in preparation for digestion.
7.34.391	Simultaneously, the stomach begins to produce hydrochloric acid to digest the food.
7.34.392	Recall that the peristaltic movements of the esophagus and other organs of the digestive tract are under the control of the brain.
7.34.393	The brain prepares these muscles for movement as well.
7.34.394	When the stomach is full, the part of the brain that detects satiety signals fullness.
7.34.395	There are three overlapping phases of gastric control—the cephalic phase, the gastric phase, and the intestinal phase—each requires many enzymes and is under neural control as well.
7.34.396	Seeing a plate of food triggers the secretion of saliva in the mouth and the production of HCL in the stomach.
7.34.397	(credit: Kelly Bailey)
7.34.398	Digestive Phases
7.34.399	The response to food begins even before food enters the mouth.
7.34.400	The first phase of ingestion, called the cephalic phase, is controlled by the neural response to the stimulus provided by food.
7.34.401	All aspects—such as sight, sense, and smell—trigger the neural responses resulting in salivation and secretion of gastric juices.
7.34.402	The gastric and salivary secretion in the cephalic phase can also take place due to the thought of food.
7.34.403	Right now, if you think about a piece of chocolate or a crispy potato chip, the increase in salivation is a cephalic phase response to the thought.
7.34.404	The central nervous system prepares the stomach to receive food.
7.34.405	The gastric phase begins once the food arrives in the stomach.
7.34.406	It builds on the stimulation provided during the cephalic phase.
7.34.407	Gastric acids and enzymes process the ingested materials.
7.34.408	The gastric phase is stimulated by (1) distension of the stomach, (2) a decrease in the pH of the gastric contents, and (3) the presence of undigested material.
7.34.409	This phase consists of local, hormonal, and neural responses.
7.34.410	These responses stimulate secretions and powerful contractions.
7.34.411	The intestinal phase begins when chyme enters the small intestine triggering digestive secretions.
7.34.412	This phase controls the rate of gastric emptying.
7.34.413	In addition to gastrin emptying, when chyme enters the small intestine, it triggers other hormonal and neural events that coordinate the activities of the intestinal tract, pancreas, liver, and gallbladder.
7.34.414	Hormonal Responses to Food
7.34.415	The endocrine system controls the response of the various glands in the body and the release of hormones at the appropriate times.
7.34.416	One of the important factors under hormonal control is the stomach acid environment.
7.34.417	During the gastric phase, the hormone gastrin is secreted by G cells in the stomach in response to the presence of proteins.
7.34.418	Gastrin stimulates the release of stomach acid, or hydrochloric acid (HCl) which aids in the digestion of the proteins.
7.34.419	However, when the stomach is emptied, the acidic environment need not be maintained and a hormone called somatostatin stops the release of hydrochloric acid.
7.34.420	This is controlled by a negative feedback mechanism.
7.34.421	In the duodenum, digestive secretions from the liver, pancreas, and gallbladder play an important role in digesting chyme during the intestinal phase.
7.34.422	In order to neutralize the acidic chyme, a hormone called secretin stimulates the pancreas to produce alkaline bicarbonate solution and deliver it to the duodenum.
7.34.423	Secretin acts in tandem with another hormone called cholecystokinin (CCK).
7.34.424	Not only does CCK stimulate the pancreas to produce the requisite pancreatic juices, it also stimulates the gallbladder to release bile into the duodenum.
7.34.425	Another level of hormonal control occurs in response to the composition of food.
7.34.426	Foods high in lipids take a long time to digest.
7.34.427	A hormone called gastric inhibitory peptide is secreted by the small intestine to slow down the peristaltic movements of the intestine to allow fatty foods more time to be digested and absorbed.
7.34.428	Understanding the hormonal control of the digestive system is an important area of ongoing research.
7.34.429	Scientists are exploring the role of each hormone in the digestive process and developing ways to target these hormones.
7.34.430	Advances could lead to knowledge that may help to battle the obesity epidemic.
7.35.0	An athlete’s nervous system is hard at work during the planning and execution of a movement as precise as a high jump.
7.35.1	Parts of the nervous system are involved in determining how hard to push off and when to turn, as well as controlling the muscles throughout the body that make this complicated movement possible without knocking the bar down—all in just a few seconds.
7.35.2	(credit: modification of work by Shane T. McCoy, U.S. Navy)
7.35.3	Introduction
7.35.4	When you’re reading this book, your nervous system is performing several functions simultaneously.
7.35.5	The visual system is processing what is seen on the page; the motor system controls the turn of the pages (or click of the mouse); the prefrontal cortex maintains attention.
7.35.6	Even fundamental functions, like breathing and regulation of body temperature, are controlled by the nervous system.
7.35.7	A nervous system is an organism’s control center: it processes sensory information from outside (and inside) the body and controls all behaviors—from eating to sleeping to finding a mate.
7.35.8	Nervous systems throughout the animal kingdom vary in structure and complexity, as illustrated by the variety of animals shown in Figure 35.2.
7.35.9	Some organisms, like sea sponges, lack a true nervous system.
7.35.10	Others, like jellyfish, lack a true brain and instead have a system of separate but connected nerve cells (neurons) called a “nerve net.
7.35.11	”
7.35.12	Echinoderms such as sea stars have nerve cells that are bundled into fibers called nerves.
7.35.13	Flatworms of the phylum Platyhelminthes have both a central nervous system (CNS), made up of a small “brain” and two nerve cords, and a peripheral nervous system (PNS) containing a system of nerves that extend throughout the body.
7.35.14	The insect nervous system is more complex but also fairly decentralized.
7.35.15	It contains a brain, ventral nerve cord, and ganglia (clusters of connected neurons).
7.35.16	These ganglia can control movements and behaviors without input from the brain.
7.35.17	Octopi may have the most complicated of invertebrate nervous systems
7.35.18	—they have neurons that are organized in specialized lobes and eyes that are structurally similar to vertebrate species.
7.35.19	Nervous systems vary in structure and complexity.
7.35.20	In (a) cnidarians, nerve cells form a decentralized nerve net.
7.35.21	In (b) echinoderms, nerve cells are bundled into fibers called nerves.
7.35.22	In animals exhibiting bilateral symmetry such as (c) planarians, neurons cluster into an anterior brain that processes information.
7.35.23	In addition to a brain, (d) arthropods have clusters of nerve cell bodies, called peripheral ganglia, located along the ventral nerve cord.
7.35.24	Mollusks such as squid and (e) octopi, which must hunt to survive, have complex brains containing millions of neurons.
7.35.25	In (f) vertebrates, the brain and spinal cord comprise the central nervous system, while neurons extending into the rest of the body comprise the peripheral nervous system.
7.35.26	(credit e: modification of work by Michael Vecchione, Clyde F.E. Roper, and Michael J. Sweeney, NOAA; credit f: modification of work by NIH).
7.35.27	Compared to invertebrates, vertebrate nervous systems are more complex, centralized, and specialized.
7.35.28	While there is great diversity among different vertebrate nervous systems, they all share a basic structure: a CNS that contains a brain and spinal cord and a PNS made up of peripheral sensory and motor nerves.
7.35.29	One interesting difference between the nervous systems of invertebrates and vertebrates is that the nerve cords of many invertebrates are located ventrally whereas the vertebrate spinal cords are located dorsally.
7.35.30	There is debate among evolutionary biologists as to whether these different nervous system plans evolved separately or whether the invertebrate body plan arrangement somehow “flipped” during the evolution of vertebrates.
7.35.31	The nervous system is made up of neurons, specialized cells that can receive and transmit chemical or electrical signals, and glia, cells that provide support functions for the neurons by playing an information processing role that is complementary to neurons.
7.35.32	A neuron can be compared to an electrical wire
7.35.33	—it transmits a signal from one place to another.
7.35.34	Glia can be compared to the workers at the electric company who make sure wires go to the right places, maintain the wires, and take down wires that are broken.
7.35.35	Although glia have been compared to workers, recent evidence suggests that also usurp some of the signaling functions of neurons.
7.35.36	There is great diversity in the types of neurons and glia that are present in different parts of the nervous system.
7.35.37	There are four major types of neurons, and they share several important cellular components.
7.35.38	Neurons
7.35.39	The nervous system of the common laboratory fly, Drosophila melanogaster, contains around 100,000 neurons, the same number as a lobster.
7.35.40	This number compares to 75 million in the mouse and 300 million in the octopus.
7.35.41	A human brain contains around 86 billion neurons.
7.35.42	Despite these very different numbers, the nervous systems of these animals control many of the same behaviors—from basic reflexes to more complicated behaviors like finding food and courting mates.
7.35.43	The ability of neurons to communicate with each other as well as with other types of cells underlies all of these behaviors.
7.35.44	Most neurons share the same cellular components.
7.35.45	But neurons are also highly specialized—different types of neurons have different sizes and shapes that relate to their functional roles.
7.35.46	Parts of a Neuron
7.35.47	Like other cells, each neuron has a cell body (or soma) that contains a nucleus, smooth and rough endoplasmic reticulum, Golgi apparatus, mitochondria, and other cellular components.
7.35.48	Neurons also contain unique structures, illustrated in Figure 35.3 for receiving and sending the electrical signals that make neuronal communication possible.
7.35.49	Dendrites are tree-like structures that extend away from the cell body to receive messages from other neurons at specialized junctions called synapses.
7.35.50	Although some neurons do not have any dendrites, some types of neurons have multiple dendrites.
7.35.51	Dendrites can have small protrusions called dendritic spines, which further increase surface area for possible synaptic connections.
7.35.52	Once a signal is received by the dendrite, it then travels passively to the cell body.
7.35.53	The cell body contains a specialized structure, the axon hillock that integrates signals from multiple synapses and serves as a junction between the cell body and an axon.
7.35.54	An axon is a tube-like structure that propagates the integrated signal to specialized endings called axon terminals.
7.35.55	These terminals in turn synapse on other neurons, muscle, or target organs.
7.35.56	Chemicals released at axon terminals allow signals to be communicated to these other cells.
7.35.57	Neurons usually have one or two axons, but some neurons, like amacrine cells in the retina, do not contain any axons.
7.35.58	Some axons are covered with myelin, which acts as an insulator to minimize dissipation of the electrical signal as it travels down the axon, greatly increasing the speed on conduction.
7.35.59	This insulation is important as the axon from a human motor neuron can be as long as a meter—from the base of the spine to the toes.
7.35.60	The myelin sheath is not actually part of the neuron.
7.35.61	Myelin is produced by glial cells.
7.35.62	Along the axon there are periodic gaps in the myelin sheath.
7.35.63	These gaps are called nodes of Ranvier and are sites where the signal is
7.35.64	“recharged” as it travels along the axon.
7.35.65	It is important to note that a single neuron does not act alone
7.35.66	—neuronal communication depends on the connections that neurons make with one another (as well as with other cells, like muscle cells).
7.35.67	Dendrites from a single neuron may receive synaptic contact from many other neurons.
7.35.68	For example, dendrites from a Purkinje cell in the cerebellum are thought to receive contact from as many as 200,000 other neurons.
7.35.69	Types of Neurons There are different types of neurons, and the functional role of a given neuron is intimately dependent on its structure.
7.35.70	There is an amazing diversity of neuron shapes and sizes found in different parts of the nervous system (and across species), as illustrated by the neurons shown in Figure 35.4.
7.35.71	There is great diversity in the size and shape of neurons throughout the nervous system.
7.35.72	Examples include (a) a pyramidal cell from the cerebral cortex, (b) a Purkinje cell from the cerebellar cortex, and (c) olfactory cells from the olfactory epithelium and olfactory bulb.
7.35.73	While there are many defined neuron cell subtypes, neurons are broadly divided into four basic types: unipolar, bipolar, multipolar, and pseudounipolar.
7.35.74	Figure 35.5 illustrates these four basic neuron types.
7.35.75	Unipolar neurons have only one structure that extends away from the soma.
7.35.76	These neurons are not found in vertebrates but are found in insects where they stimulate muscles or glands.
7.35.77	A bipolar neuron has one axon and one dendrite extending from the soma.
7.35.78	An example of a bipolar neuron is a retinal bipolar cell, which receives signals from photoreceptor cells that are sensitive to light and transmits these signals to ganglion cells that carry the signal to the brain.
7.35.79	Multipolar neurons are the most common type of neuron.
7.35.80	Each multipolar neuron contains one axon and multiple dendrites.
7.35.81	Multipolar neurons can be found in the central nervous system (brain and spinal cord).
7.35.82	An example of a multipolar neuron is a Purkinje cell in the cerebellum, which has many branching dendrites but only one axon.
7.35.83	Pseudounipolar cells share characteristics with both unipolar and bipolar cells.
7.35.84	A pseudounipolar cell has a single process that extends from the soma, like a unipolar cell, but this process later branches into two distinct structures, like a bipolar cell.
7.35.85	Most sensory neurons are pseudounipolar and have an axon that branches into two extensions: one connected to dendrites that receive sensory information and another that transmits this information to the spinal cord.
7.35.86	Neurons are broadly divided into four main types based on the number and placement of axons: (1) unipolar, (2) bipolar, (3) multipolar, and (4) pseudounipolar.
7.35.87	Glia
7.35.88	While glia are often thought of as the supporting cast of the nervous system, the number of glial cells in the brain actually outnumbers the number of neurons by a factor of ten.
7.35.89	Neurons would be unable to function without the vital roles that are fulfilled by these glial cells.
7.35.90	Glia guide developing neurons to their destinations, buffer ions and chemicals that would otherwise harm neurons, and provide myelin sheaths around axons.
7.35.91	Scientists have recently discovered that they also play a role in responding to nerve activity and modulating communication between nerve cells.
7.35.92	When glia do not function properly, the result can be disastrous—most brain tumors are caused by mutations in glia.
7.35.93	Types of Glia There are several different types of glia with different functions, two of which are shown in Figure 35.7.
7.35.94	Astrocytes, shown in Figure 35.8a make contact with both capillaries and neurons in the CNS.
7.35.95	They provide nutrients and other substances to neurons, regulate the concentrations of ions and chemicals in the extracellular fluid, and provide structural support for synapses.
7.35.96	Astrocytes also form the blood-brain barrier—a structure that blocks entrance of toxic substances into the brain.
7.35.97	Astrocytes, in particular, have been shown through calcium imaging experiments to become active in response to nerve activity, transmit calcium waves between astrocytes, and modulate the activity of surrounding synapses.
7.35.98	Satellite glia provide nutrients and structural support for neurons in the PNS.
7.35.99	Microglia scavenge and degrade dead cells and protect the brain from invading microorganisms.
7.35.100	Oligodendrocytes, shown in Figure 35.8b form myelin sheaths around axons in the CNS.
7.35.101	One axon can be myelinated by several oligodendrocytes, and one oligodendrocyte can provide myelin for multiple neurons.
7.35.102	This is distinctive from the PNS where a single Schwann cell provides myelin for only one axon as the entire Schwann cell surrounds the axon.
7.35.103	Radial glia serve as scaffolds for developing neurons as they migrate to their end destinations.
7.35.104	Ependymal cells line fluid-filled ventricles of the brain and the central canal of the spinal cord.
7.35.105	They are involved in the production of cerebrospinal fluid, which serves as a cushion for the brain, moves the fluid between the spinal cord and the brain, and is a component for the choroid plexus.
7.35.106	Glial cells support neurons and maintain their environment.
7.35.107	Glial cells of the (a) central nervous system include oligodendrocytes, astrocytes, ependymal cells, and microglial cells.
7.35.108	Oligodendrocytes form the myelin sheath around axons.
7.35.109	Astrocytes provide nutrients to neurons, maintain their extracellular environment, and provide structural support.
7.35.110	Microglia scavenge pathogens and dead cells.
7.35.111	Ependymal cells produce cerebrospinal fluid that cushions the neurons.
7.35.112	Glial cells of the (b) peripheral nervous system include Schwann cells, which form the myelin sheath, and satellite cells, which provide nutrients and structural support to neurons.
7.35.113	Astrocytes and (b) oligodendrocytes are glial cells of the central nervous system.
7.35.114	(credit a: modification of work by Uniformed Services University; credit b: modification of work by Jurjen Broeke; scale-bar data from Matt Russell)
7.35.115	All functions performed by the nervous system—from a simple motor reflex to more advanced functions like making a memory or a decision—require neurons to communicate with one another.
7.35.116	While humans use words and body language to communicate, neurons use electrical and chemical signals.
7.35.117	Just like a person in a committee, one neuron usually receives and synthesizes messages from multiple other neurons before “making the decision” to send the message on to other neurons.
7.35.118	Nerve Impulse Transmission within a Neuron
7.35.119	For the nervous system to function, neurons must be able to send and receive signals.
7.35.120	These signals are possible because each neuron has a charged cellular membrane (a voltage difference between the inside and the outside), and the charge of this membrane can change in response to neurotransmitter molecules released from other neurons and environmental stimuli.
7.35.121	To understand how neurons communicate, one must first understand the basis of the baseline or ‘resting’ membrane charge.
7.35.122	Neuronal Charged Membranes
7.35.123	The lipid bilayer membrane that surrounds a neuron is impermeable to charged molecules or ions.
7.35.124	To enter or exit the neuron, ions must pass through special proteins called ion channels that span the membrane.
7.35.125	Ion channels have different configurations: open, closed, and inactive, as illustrated in Figure 35.9.
7.35.126	Some ion channels need to be activated in order to open and allow ions to pass into or out of the cell.
7.35.127	These ion channels are sensitive to the environment and can change their shape accordingly.
7.35.128	Ion channels that change their structure in response to voltage changes are called voltage-gated ion channels.
7.35.129	Voltage-gated ion channels regulate the relative concentrations of different ions inside and outside the cell.
7.35.130	The difference in total charge between the inside and outside of the cell is called the membrane potential.
7.35.131	Voltage-gated ion channels open in response to changes in membrane voltage.
7.35.132	After activation, they become inactivated for a brief period and will no longer open in response to a signal.
7.35.133	Resting Membrane Potential
7.35.134	A neuron at rest is negatively charged: the inside of a cell is approximately 70 millivolts more negative than the outside (−70 mV, note that this number varies by neuron type and by species).
7.35.135	This voltage is called the resting membrane potential; it is caused by differences in the concentrations of ions inside and outside the cell.
7.35.136	If the membrane were equally permeable to all ions, each type of ion would flow across the membrane and the system would reach equilibrium.
7.35.137	Because ions cannot simply cross the membrane at will, there are different concentrations of several ions inside and outside the cell, as shown in Table 35.1.
7.35.138	The difference in the number of positively charged potassium ions (K+) inside and outside the cell dominates the resting membrane potential (Figure 35.10).
7.35.139	When the membrane is at rest, K+ ions accumulate inside the cell due to a net movement with the concentration gradient.
7.35.140	The negative resting membrane potential is created and maintained by increasing the concentration of cations outside the cell (in the extracellular fluid) relative to inside the cell (in the cytoplasm).
7.35.141	The negative charge within the cell is created by the cell membrane being more permeable to potassium ion movement than sodium ion movement.
7.35.142	In neurons, potassium ions are maintained at high concentrations within the cell while sodium ions are maintained at high concentrations outside of the cell.
7.35.143	The cell possesses potassium and sodium leakage channels that allow the two cations to diffuse down their concentration gradient.
7.35.144	However, the neurons have far more potassium leakage channels than sodium leakage channels.
7.35.145	Therefore, potassium diffuses out of the cell at a much faster rate than sodium leaks in.
7.35.146	Because more cations are leaving the cell than are entering, this causes the interior of the cell to be negatively charged relative to the outside of the cell.
7.35.147	The actions of the sodium potassium pump help to maintain the resting potential, once established.
7.35.148	Recall that sodium potassium pumps brings two K+ ions into the cell while removing three Na+ ions per ATP consumed.
7.35.149	As more cations are expelled from the cell than taken in, the inside of the cell remains negatively charged relative to the extracellular fluid.
7.35.150	It should be noted that calcium ions (Cl–) tend to accumulate outside of the cell because they are repelled by negatively-charged proteins within the cytoplasm.
7.35.151	he (a) resting membrane potential is a result of different concentrations of Na+ and K+ ions inside and outside the cell.
7.35.152	A nerve impulse causes Na+ to enter the cell, resulting in (b) depolarization.
7.35.153	At the peak action potential, K+ channels open and the cell becomes
7.35.154	(c) hyperpolarized.
7.35.155	Action Potential
7.35.156	A neuron can receive input from other neurons and, if this input is strong enough, send the signal to downstream neurons.
7.35.157	Transmission of a signal between neurons is generally carried by a chemical called a neurotransmitter.
7.35.158	Transmission of a signal within a neuron (from dendrite to axon terminal) is carried by a brief reversal of the resting membrane potential called an action potential.
7.35.159	When neurotransmitter molecules bind to receptors located on a neuron’s dendrites, ion channels open.
7.35.160	At excitatory synapses, this opening allows positive ions to enter the neuron and results in depolarization of the membrane—a decrease in the difference in voltage between the inside and outside of the neuron.
7.35.161	A stimulus from a sensory cell or another neuron depolarizes the target neuron to its threshold potential (-55 mV).
7.35.162	Na+ channels in the axon hillock open, allowing positive ions to enter the cell (Figure 35.10 and Figure 35.11).
7.35.163	Once the sodium channels open, the neuron completely depolarizes to a membrane potential of about +40 mV. Action potentials are considered an "all-or nothing" event, in that, once the threshold potential is reached, the neuron always completely depolarizes.
7.35.164	Once depolarization is complete, the cell must now "reset" its membrane voltage back to the resting potential.
7.35.165	To accomplish this, the Na+ channels close and cannot be opened.
7.35.166	This begins the neuron's refractory period, in which it cannot produce another action potential because its sodium channels will not open.
7.35.167	At the same time, voltage-gated K+ channels open, allowing K+ to leave the cell.
7.35.168	As K+ ions leave the cell, the membrane potential once again becomes negative.
7.35.169	The diffusion of K+ out of the cell actually hyperpolarizes the cell, in that the membrane potential becomes more negative than the cell's normal resting potential.
7.35.170	At this point, the sodium channels will return to their resting state, meaning they are ready to open again if the membrane potential again exceeds the threshold potential.
7.35.171	Eventually the extra K+ ions diffuse out of the cell through the potassium leakage channels, bringing the cell from its hyperpolarized state, back to its resting membrane potential.
7.35.172	Myelin and the Propagation of the Action Potential
7.35.173	For an action potential to communicate information to another neuron, it must travel along the axon and reach the axon terminals where it can initiate neurotransmitter release.
7.35.174	The speed of conduction of an action potential along an axon is influenced by both the diameter of the axon and the axon’s resistance to current leak.
7.35.175	Myelin acts as an insulator that prevents current from leaving the axon; this increases the speed of action potential conduction.
7.35.176	In demyelinating diseases like multiple sclerosis, action potential conduction slows because current leaks from previously insulated axon areas.
7.35.177	The nodes of Ranvier, illustrated in Figure 35.13 are gaps in the myelin sheath along the axon.
7.35.178	These unmyelinated spaces are about one micrometer long and contain voltage gated Na+ and K+ channels.
7.35.179	Flow of ions through these channels, particularly the Na+ channels, regenerates the action potential over and over again along the axon.
7.35.180	This ‘jumping’ of the action potential from one node to the next is called saltatory conduction.
7.35.181	If nodes of Ranvier were not present along an axon, the action potential would propagate very slowly since Na+ and K+ channels would have to continuously regenerate action potentials at every point along the axon instead of at specific points.
7.35.182	Nodes of Ranvier also save energy for the neuron since the channels only need to be present at the nodes and not along the entire axon.
7.35.183	Nodes of Ranvier are gaps in myelin coverage along axons.
7.35.184	Nodes contain voltage-gated K+ and Na+ channels.
7.35.185	Action potentials travel down the axon by jumping from one node to the next.
7.35.186	Synaptic Transmission
7.35.187	The synapse or “gap” is the place where information is transmitted from one neuron to another.
7.35.188	Synapses usually form between axon terminals and dendritic spines, but this is not universally true.
7.35.189	There are also axon-to-axon, dendrite-to- dendrite, and axon-to-cell body synapses.
7.35.190	The neuron transmitting the signal is called the presynaptic neuron, and the neuron receiving the signal is called the postsynaptic neuron.
7.35.191	Note that these designations are relative to a particular synapse—most neurons are both presynaptic and postsynaptic.
7.35.192	There are two types of synapses: chemical and electrical.
7.35.193	Chemical Synapse
7.35.194	When an action potential reaches the axon terminal it depolarizes the membrane and opens voltage-gated Na+ channels.
7.35.195	Na+ ions enter the cell, further depolarizing the presynaptic membrane.
7.35.196	This depolarization causes voltage-gated Ca2
7.35.197	+ channels to open.
7.35.198	Calcium ions entering the cell initiate a signaling cascade that causes small membrane-bound vesicles, called synaptic vesicles, containing neurotransmitter molecules to fuse with the presynaptic membrane.
7.35.199	Synaptic vesicles are shown in Figure 35.14, which is an image from a scanning electron microscope.
7.35.200	This pseudocolored image taken with a scanning electron microscope shows an axon terminal that was broken open to reveal synaptic vesicles (blue and orange) inside the neuron.
7.35.201	(credit: modification of work by Tina Carvalho, NIH-NIGMS; scale-bar data from Matt Russell)
7.35.202	Fusion of a vesicle with the presynaptic membrane causes neurotransmitter to be released into the synaptic cleft, the extracellular space between the presynaptic and postsynaptic membranes, as illustrated in Figure 35.15.
7.35.203	The neurotransmitter diffuses across the synaptic cleft and binds to receptor proteins on the postsynaptic membrane.
7.35.204	Communication at chemical synapses requires release of neurotransmitters.
7.35.205	When the presynaptic membrane is depolarized, voltage-gated Ca2+ channels open and allow Ca2+ to enter the cell.
7.35.206	The calcium entry causes synaptic vesicles to fuse with the membrane and release neurotransmitter molecules into the synaptic cleft.
7.35.207	The neurotransmitter diffuses across the synaptic cleft and binds to ligand-gated ion channels in the postsynaptic membrane, resulting in a localized depolarization or hyperpolarization of the postsynaptic neuron.
7.35.208	The binding of a specific neurotransmitter causes particular ion channels, in this case ligand-gated channels, on the postsynaptic membrane to open.
7.35.209	Neurotransmitters can either have excitatory or inhibitory effects on the postsynaptic membrane, as detailed in Table 35.1.
7.35.210	For example, when acetylcholine is released at the synapse between a nerve and muscle (called the neuromuscular junction) by a presynaptic neuron, it causes postsynaptic Na+ channels to open.
7.35.211	Na+ enters the postsynaptic cell and causes the postsynaptic membrane to depolarize.
7.35.212	This depolarization is called an excitatory postsynaptic potential (EPSP) and makes the postsynaptic neuron more likely to fire an action potential.
7.35.213	Release of neurotransmitter at inhibitory synapses causes inhibitory postsynaptic potentials (IPSPs), a hyperpolarization of the presynaptic membrane.
7.35.214	For example, when the neurotransmitter GABA (gamma-aminobutyric acid) is released from a presynaptic neuron, it binds to and opens Cl- channels.
7.35.215	Cl- ions enter the cell and hyperpolarizes the membrane, making the neuron less likely to fire an action potential.
7.35.216	Once neurotransmission has occurred, the neurotransmitter must be removed from the synaptic cleft so the postsynaptic membrane can “reset” and be ready to receive another signal.
7.35.217	This can be accomplished in three ways: the neurotransmitter can diffuse away from the synaptic cleft, it can be degraded by enzymes in the synaptic cleft, or it can be recycled (sometimes called reuptake) by the presynaptic neuron.
7.35.218	Several drugs act at this step of neurotransmission.
7.35.219	For example, some drugs that are given to Alzheimer’s patients work by inhibiting acetylcholinesterase, the enzyme that degrades acetylcholine.
7.35.220	This inhibition of the enzyme essentially increases neurotransmission at synapses that release acetylcholine.
7.35.221	Once released, the acetylcholine stays in the cleft and can continually bind and unbind to postsynaptic receptors.
7.35.222	Electrical Synapse CNS and/or PNS CNS and/or PNS CNS CNS and/or PNS        
7.35.223	While electrical synapses are fewer in number than chemical synapses, they are found in all nervous systems and play important and unique roles.
7.35.224	The mode of neurotransmission in electrical synapses is quite different from that in chemical synapses.
7.35.225	In an electrical synapse, the presynaptic and postsynaptic membranes are very close together and are actually physically connected by channel proteins forming gap junctions.
7.35.226	Gap junctions allow current to pass directly from one cell to the next.
7.35.227	In addition to the ions that carry this current, other molecules, such as ATP, can diffuse through the large gap junction pores.
7.35.228	There are key differences between chemical and electrical synapses.
7.35.229	Because chemical synapses depend on the release of neurotransmitter molecules from synaptic vesicles to pass on their signal, there is an approximately one millisecond delay between when the axon potential reaches the presynaptic terminal and when the neurotransmitter leads to opening of postsynaptic ion channels.
7.35.230	Additionally, this signaling is unidirectional.
7.35.231	Signaling in electrical synapses, in contrast, is virtually instantaneous (which is important for synapses involved in key reflexes), and some electrical synapses are bidirectional.
7.35.232	Electrical synapses are also more reliable as they are less likely to be blocked, and they are important for synchronizing the electrical activity of a group of neurons.
7.35.233	For example, electrical synapses in the thalamus are thought to regulate slow-wave sleep, and disruption of these synapses can cause seizures.
7.35.234	Signal Summation
7.35.235	Sometimes a single EPSP is strong enough to induce an action potential in the postsynaptic neuron, but often multiple presynaptic inputs must create EPSPs around the same time for the postsynaptic neuron to be sufficiently depolarized to fire an action potential.
7.35.236	This process is called summation and occurs at the axon hillock, as illustrated in Figure 35.16.
7.35.237	Additionally, one neuron often has inputs from many presynaptic neurons—some excitatory and some inhibitory
7.35.238	—
7.35.239	so IPSPs can cancel out EPSPs and vice versa.
7.35.240	It is the net change in postsynaptic membrane voltage that determines whether the postsynaptic cell has reached its threshold of excitation needed to fire an action potential.
7.35.241	Together, synaptic summation and the threshold for excitation act as a filter so that random “noise” in the system is not transmitted as important information.
7.35.242	A single neuron can receive both excitatory and inhibitory inputs from multiple neurons, resulting in local membrane depolarization (EPSP input) and hyperpolarization (IPSP input).
7.35.243	All these inputs are added together at the axon hillock.
7.35.244	If the EPSPs are strong enough to overcome the IPSPs and reach the threshold of excitation, the neuron will fire.
7.35.245	Synaptic Plasticity Synapses are not static structures.
7.35.246	They can be weakened or strengthened.
7.35.247	They can be broken, and new synapses can be made.
7.35.248	Synaptic plasticity allows for these changes, which are all needed for a functioning nervous system.
7.35.249	In fact, synaptic plasticity is the basis of learning and memory.
7.35.250	Two processes in particular, long-term potentiation (LTP) and long-term depression (LTD) are important forms of synaptic plasticity that occur in synapses in the hippocampus, a brain region that is involved in storing memories.
7.35.251	Long-term Potentiation (LTP) Long-term potentiation (LTP) is a persistent strengthening of a synaptic connection.
7.35.252	LTP is based on the Hebbian principle: cells that fire together wire together.
7.35.253	There are various mechanisms, none fully understood, behind the synaptic strengthening seen with LTP.
7.35.254	One known mechanism involves a type of postsynaptic glutamate receptor, called NMDA (N-Methyl-D-aspartate) receptors, shown in Figure 35.18.
7.35.255	These receptors are normally blocked by magnesium ions; however, when the postsynaptic neuron is depolarized by multiple presynaptic inputs in quick succession (either from one neuron or multiple neurons), the magnesium ions are forced out allowing Ca ions to pass into the postsynaptic cell.
7.35.256	Next, Ca2+ ions entering the cell initiate a signaling cascade that causes a different type of glutamate receptor, called AMPA (α-amino-3-hydroxy-5-methyl-4-isoxazolepropionic acid) receptors, to be inserted into the postsynaptic membrane, since activated AMPA receptors allow positive ions to enter the cell.
7.35.257	So, the next time glutamate is released from the presynaptic membrane, it will have a larger excitatory effect (EPSP) on the postsynaptic cell because the binding of glutamate to these AMPA receptors will allow more positive ions into the cell.
7.35.258	The insertion of additional AMPA receptors strengthens the synapse and means that the postsynaptic neuron is more likely to fire in response to presynaptic neurotransmitter release.
7.35.259	Some drugs of abuse co-opt the LTP pathway, and this synaptic strengthening can lead to addiction.
7.35.260	Long-term Depression (LTD)
7.35.261	Long-term depression (LTD) is essentially the reverse of LTP: it is a long-term weakening of a synaptic connection.
7.35.262	One mechanism known to cause LTD also involves AMPA receptors.
