7.35.263	In this situation, calcium that enters through NMDA receptors initiates a different signaling cascade, which results in the removal of AMPA receptors from the postsynaptic membrane, as illustrated in Figure 35.18.
7.35.264	The decrease in AMPA receptors in the membrane makes the postsynaptic neuron less responsive to glutamate released from the presynaptic neuron.
7.35.265	While it may seem counterintuitive, LTD may be just as important for learning and memory as LTP.
7.35.266	The weakening and pruning of unused synapses allows for unimportant connections to be lost and makes the synapses that have undergone LTP that much stronger by comparison.
7.35.267	Calcium entry through postsynaptic NMDA receptors can initiate two different forms of synaptic plasticity: long-term potentiation (LTP) and long-term depression (LTD).
7.35.268	LTP arises when a single synapse is repeatedly stimulated.
7.35.269	This stimulation causes a calcium- and CaMKII-dependent cellular cascade, which results in the insertion of more AMPA receptors into the postsynaptic membrane.
7.35.270	The next time glutamate is released from the presynaptic cell, it will bind to both NMDA and the newly inserted AMPA receptors, thus depolarizing the membrane more efficiently.
7.35.271	LTD occurs when few glutamate molecules bind to NMDA receptors at a synapse (due to a low firing rate of the presynaptic neuron).
7.35.272	The calcium that does flow through NMDA receptors initiates a different calcineurin and protein phosphatase 1-dependent cascade, which results in the endocytosis of AMPA receptors.
7.35.273	This makes the postsynaptic neuron less responsive to glutamate released from the presynaptic neuron.
7.35.274	The central nervous system (CNS) is made up of the brain, a part of which is shown in Figure 35.19 and spinal cord and is covered with three layers of protective coverings called meninges (from the Greek word for membrane).
7.35.275	The outermost layer is the dura mater (Latin for “hard mother”).
7.35.276	As the Latin suggests, the primary function for this thick layer is to protect the brain and spinal cord.
7.35.277	The dura mater also contains vein-like structures that carry blood from the brain back to the heart.
7.35.278	The middle layer is the web-like arachnoid mater.
7.35.279	The last layer is the pia mater (Latin for “soft mother”), which directly contacts and covers the brain and spinal cord like plastic wrap.
7.35.280	The space between the arachnoid and pia maters is filled with cerebrospinal fluid (CSF).
7.35.281	CSF is produced by a tissue called choroid plexus in fluid-filled compartments in the CNS called ventricles.
7.35.282	The brain floats in CSF, which acts as a cushion and shock absorber and makes the brain neutrally buoyant.
7.35.283	CSF also functions to circulate chemical substances throughout the brain and into the spinal cord.
7.35.284	The entire brain contains only about 8.5 tablespoons of CSF, but CSF is constantly produced in the ventricles.
7.35.285	This creates a problem when a ventricle is blocked—
7.35.286	the CSF builds up and creates swelling and the brain is pushed against the skull.
7.35.287	This swelling condition is called hydrocephalus (“water head”) and can cause seizures, cognitive problems, and even death if a shunt is not inserted to remove the fluid and pressure.
7.35.288	The cerebral cortex is covered by three layers of meninges: the dura, arachnoid, and pia maters.
7.35.289	(credit: modification of work by Gray’s Anatomy) Brain
7.35.290	The brain is the part of the central nervous system that is contained in the cranial cavity of the skull.
7.35.291	It includes the cerebral cortex, limbic system, basal ganglia, thalamus, hypothalamus, and cerebellum.
7.35.292	There are three different ways that a brain can be sectioned in order to view internal structures: a sagittal section cuts the brain left to right, as shown in Figure 35.21b, a coronal section cuts the brain front to back, as shown in Figure 35.20a, and a horizontal section cuts the brain top to bottom.
7.35.293	Cerebral Cortex
7.35.294	The outermost part of the brain is a thick piece of nervous system tissue called the cerebral cortex, which is folded into hills called gyri (singular: gyrus) and valleys called sulci (singular: sulcus).
7.35.295	The cortex is made up of two hemispheres
7.35.296	—right and left—which are separated by a large sulcus.
7.35.297	A thick fiber bundle called the corpus callosum (Latin: “tough body”) connects the two hemispheres and allows information to be passed from one side to the other.
7.35.298	Although there are some brain functions that are localized more to one hemisphere than the other, the functions of the two hemispheres are largely redundant.
7.35.299	In fact, sometimes (very rarely) an entire hemisphere is removed to treat severe epilepsy.
7.35.300	While patients do suffer some deficits following the surgery, they can have surprisingly few problems, especially when the surgery is performed on children who have very immature nervous systems.
7.35.301	These illustrations show the (a) coronal and (b) sagittal sections of the human brain.
7.35.302	In other surgeries to treat severe epilepsy, the corpus callosum is cut instead of removing an entire hemisphere.
7.35.303	This causes a condition called split-brain, which gives insights into unique functions of the two hemispheres.
7.35.304	For example, when an object is presented to patients’ left visual field, they may be unable to verbally name the object (and may claim to not have seen an object at all).
7.35.305	This is because the visual input from the left visual field crosses and enters the right hemisphere and cannot then signal to the speech center, which generally is found in the left side of the brain.
7.35.306	Remarkably, if a split-brain patient is asked to pick up a specific object out of a group of objects with the left hand, the patient will be able to do so but will still be unable to vocally identify it.
7.35.307	Each cortical hemisphere contains regions called lobes that are involved in different functions.
7.35.308	Scientists use various techniques to determine what brain areas are involved in different functions: they examine patients who have had injuries or diseases that affect specific areas and see how those areas are related to functional deficits.
7.35.309	They also conduct animal studies where they stimulate brain areas and see if there are any behavioral changes.
7.35.310	They use a technique called transmagnetic stimulation (TMS) to temporarily deactivate specific parts of the cortex using strong magnets placed outside the head; and they use functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) to look at changes in oxygenated blood flow in particular brain regions that correlate with specific behavioral tasks.
7.35.311	These techniques, and others, have given great insight into the functions of different brain regions but have also showed that any given brain area can be involved in more than one behavior or process, and any given behavior or process generally involves neurons in multiple brain areas.
7.35.312	That being said, each hemisphere of the mammalian cerebral cortex can be broken down into four functionally and spatially defined lobes: frontal, parietal, temporal, and occipital.
7.35.313	Figure 35.21 illustrates these four lobes of the human cerebral cortex.
7.35.314	The human cerebral cortex includes the frontal, parietal, temporal, and occipital lobes.
7.35.315	The frontal lobe is located at the front of the brain, over the eyes.
7.35.316	This lobe contains the olfactory bulb, which processes smells.
7.35.317	The frontal lobe also contains the motor cortex, which is important for planning and implementing movement.
7.35.318	Areas within the motor cortex map to different muscle groups, and there is some organization to this map, as shown in Figure 35.22.
7.35.319	For example, the neurons that control movement of the fingers are next to the neurons that control movement of the hand.
7.35.320	Neurons in the frontal lobe also control cognitive functions like maintaining attention, speech, and decision- making.
7.35.321	Studies of humans who have damaged their frontal lobes show that parts of this area are involved in personality, socialization, and assessing risk.
7.35.322	Different parts of the motor cortex control different muscle groups.
7.35.323	Muscle groups that are neighbors in the body are generally controlled by neighboring regions of the motor cortex as well.
7.35.324	For example, the neurons that control finger movement are near the neurons that control hand movement.
7.35.325	The parietal lobe is located at the top of the brain.
7.35.326	Neurons in the parietal lobe are involved in speech and also reading.
7.35.327	Two of the parietal lobe’s main functions are processing somatosensation—touch sensations like pressure, pain, heat, cold—and processing proprioception—the sense of how parts of the body are oriented in space.
7.35.328	The parietal lobe contains a somatosensory map of the body similar to the motor cortex.
7.35.329	The occipital lobe is located at the back of the brain.
7.35.330	It is primarily involved in vision—seeing, recognizing, and identifying the visual world.
7.35.331	The temporal lobe is located at the base of the brain by your ears and is primarily involved in processing and interpreting sounds.
7.35.332	It also contains the hippocampus (Greek for “seahorse”)—a structure that processes memory formation.
7.35.333	The hippocampus is illustrated in Figure 35.24.
7.35.334	The role of the hippocampus in memory was partially determined by studying one famous epileptic patient, HM, who had both sides of his hippocampus removed in an attempt to cure his epilepsy.
7.35.335	His seizures went away, but he could no longer form new memories (although he could remember some facts from before his surgery and could learn new motor tasks).
7.35.336	Basal Ganglia Interconnected brain areas called the basal ganglia (or basal nuclei), shown in Figure 35.20b, play important roles in movement control and posture.
7.35.337	Damage to the basal ganglia, as in Parkinson’s disease, leads to motor impairments like a shuffling gait when walking.
7.35.338	The basal ganglia also regulate motivation.
7.35.339	For example, when a wasp sting led to bilateral basal ganglia damage in a 25-year-old businessman, he began to spend all his days in bed and showed no interest in anything or anybody.
7.35.340	But when he was externally stimulated—as when someone asked to play a card game with him—he was able to function normally.
7.35.341	Interestingly, he and other similar patients do not report feeling bored or frustrated by their state.
7.35.342	Thalamus
7.35.343	The thalamus (Greek for “inner chamber”), illustrated in Figure 35.24, acts as a gateway to and from the cortex.
7.35.344	It receives sensory and motor inputs from the body and also receives feedback from the cortex.
7.35.345	This feedback mechanism can modulate conscious awareness of sensory and motor inputs depending on the attention and arousal state of the animal.
7.35.346	The thalamus helps regulate consciousness, arousal, and sleep states.
7.35.347	A rare genetic disorder called fatal familial insomnia causes the degeneration of thalamic neurons and glia.
7.35.348	This disorder prevents affected patients from being able to sleep, among other symptoms, and is eventually fatal.
7.35.349	The limbic system regulates emotion and other behaviors.
7.35.350	It includes parts of the cerebral cortex located near the center of the brain, including the cingulate gyrus and the hippocampus as well as the thalamus, hypothalamus and amygdala.
7.35.351	Hypothalamus
7.35.352	Below the thalamus is the hypothalamus, shown in Figure 35.24.
7.35.353	The hypothalamus controls the endocrine system by sending signals to the pituitary gland, a pea-sized endocrine gland that releases several different hormones that affect other glands as well as other cells.
7.35.354	This relationship means that the hypothalamus regulates important behaviors that are controlled by these hormones.
7.35.355	The hypothalamus is the body’s thermostat—it makes sure key functions like food and water intake, energy expenditure, and body temperature are kept at appropriate levels.
7.35.356	Neurons within the hypothalamus also regulate circadian rhythms, sometimes called sleep cycles.
7.35.357	Limbic System
7.35.358	The limbic system is a connected set of structures that regulates emotion, as well as behaviors related to fear and motivation.
7.35.359	It plays a role in memory formation and includes parts of the thalamus and hypothalamus as well as the hippocampus.
7.35.360	One important structure within the limbic system is a temporal lobe structure called the amygdala (Greek for “almond”), illustrated in Figure 35.24.
7.35.361	The two amygdala are important both for the sensation of fear and for recognizing fearful faces.
7.35.362	The cingulate gyrus helps regulate emotions and pain.
7.35.363	Cerebellum
7.35.364	The cerebellum (Latin for “little brain”), shown in Figure 35.21, sits at the base of the brain on top of the brainstem.
7.35.365	The cerebellum controls balance and aids in coordinating movement and learning new motor tasks.
7.35.366	Brainstem
7.35.367	The brainstem, illustrated in Figure 35.21, connects the rest of the brain with the spinal cord.
7.35.368	It consists of the midbrain, medulla oblongata, and the pons.
7.35.369	Motor and sensory neurons extend through the brainstem allowing for the relay of signals between the brain and spinal cord.
7.35.370	Ascending neural pathways cross in this section of the brain allowing the left hemisphere of the cerebrum to control the right side of the body and vice versa.
7.35.371	The brainstem coordinates motor control signals sent from the brain to the body.
7.35.372	The brainstem controls several important functions of the body including alertness, arousal, breathing, blood pressure, digestion, heart rate, swallowing, walking, and sensory and motor information integration.
7.35.373	Spinal Cord Connecting to the brainstem and extending down the body through the spinal column is the spinal cord, shown in Figure 35.21.
7.35.374	The spinal cord is a thick bundle of nerve tissue that carries information about the body to the brain and from the brain to the body.
7.35.375	The spinal cord is contained within the bones of the vertebrate column but is able to communicate signals to and from the body through its connections with spinal nerves (part of the peripheral nervous system).
7.35.376	A cross-section of the spinal cord looks like a white oval containing a gray butterfly-shape, as illustrated in Figure 35.25.
7.35.377	Myelinated axons make up the “white matter” and neuron and glial cell bodies make up the “gray matter.
7.35.378	”
7.35.379	Gray matter is also composed of interneurons, which connect two neurons each located in different parts of the body.
7.35.380	Axons and cell bodies in the dorsal (facing the back of the animal) spinal cord convey mostly sensory information from the body to the brain.
7.35.381	Axons and cell bodies in the ventral (facing the front of the animal) spinal cord primarily transmit signals controlling movement from the brain to the body.
7.35.382	The spinal cord also controls motor reflexes.
7.35.383	These reflexes are quick, unconscious movements—like automatically removing a hand from a hot object.
7.35.384	Reflexes are so fast because they involve local synaptic connections.
7.35.385	For example, the knee reflex that a doctor tests during a routine physical is controlled by a single synapse between a sensory neuron and a motor neuron.
7.35.386	While a reflex may only require the involvement of one or two synapses, synapses with interneurons in the spinal column transmit information to the brain to convey what happened (the knee jerked, or the hand was hot).
7.35.387	In the United States, there around 10,000 spinal cord injuries each year.
7.35.388	Because the spinal cord is the information superhighway connecting the brain with the body, damage to the spinal cord can lead to paralysis.
7.35.389	The extent of the paralysis depends on the location of the injury along the spinal cord and whether the spinal cord was completely severed.
7.35.390	For example, if the spinal cord is damaged at the level of the neck, it can cause paralysis from the neck down, whereas damage to the spinal column further down may limit paralysis to the legs.
7.35.391	Spinal cord injuries are notoriously difficult to treat because spinal nerves do not regenerate, although ongoing research suggests that stem cell transplants may be able to act as a bridge to reconnect severed nerves.
7.35.392	Researchers are also looking at ways to prevent the inflammation that worsens nerve damage after injury.
7.35.393	One such treatment is to pump the body with cold saline to induce hypothermia.
7.35.394	This cooling can prevent swelling and other processes that are thought to worsen spinal cord injuries.
7.35.395	The peripheral nervous system (PNS) is the connection between the central nervous system and the rest of the body.
7.35.396	The CNS is like the power plant of the nervous system.
7.35.397	It creates the signals that control the functions of the body.
7.35.398	The PNS is like the wires that go to individual houses.
7.35.399	Without those “wires,” the signals produced by the CNS could not control the body (and the CNS would not be able to receive sensory information from the body either).
7.35.400	The PNS can be broken down into the autonomic nervous system, which controls bodily functions without conscious control, and the sensory-somatic nervous system, which transmits sensory information from the skin, muscles, and sensory organs to the CNS and sends motor commands from the CNS to the muscles.
7.35.401	The autonomic nervous system serves as the relay between the CNS and the internal organs.
7.35.402	It controls the lungs, the heart, smooth muscle, and exocrine and endocrine glands.
7.35.403	The autonomic nervous system controls these organs largely without conscious control; it can continuously monitor the conditions of these different systems and implement changes as needed.
7.35.404	Signaling to the target tissue usually involves two synapses: a preganglionic neuron (originating in the CNS) synapses to a neuron in a ganglion that, in turn, synapses on the target organ, as illustrated in Figure 35.26.
7.35.405	There are two divisions of the autonomic nervous system that often have opposing effects: the sympathetic nervous system and the parasympathetic nervous system.
7.35.406	Sympathetic Nervous System
7.35.407	The sympathetic nervous system is responsible for the “fight or flight” response that occurs when an animal encounters a dangerous situation.
7.35.408	One way to remember this is to think of the surprise a person feels when encountering a snake
7.35.409	(“snake” and “sympathetic” both begin with “s”).
7.35.410	Examples of functions controlled by the sympathetic nervous system include an accelerated heart rate and inhibited digestion.
7.35.411	These functions help prepare an organism’s body for the physical strain required to escape a potentially dangerous situation or to fend off a predator.
7.35.412	The sympathetic and parasympathetic nervous systems often have opposing effects on target organs.
7.35.413	Most preganglionic neurons in the sympathetic nervous system originate in the spinal cord, as illustrated in Figure 35.27.
7.35.414	The axons of these neurons release acetylcholine on postganglionic neurons within sympathetic ganglia (the sympathetic ganglia form a chain that extends alongside the spinal cord).
7.35.415	The acetylcholine activates the postganglionic neurons.
7.35.416	Postganglionic neurons then release norepinephrine onto target organs.
7.35.417	As anyone who has ever felt a rush before a big test, speech, or athletic event can attest, the effects of the sympathetic nervous system are quite pervasive.
7.35.418	This is both because one preganglionic neuron synapses on multiple postganglionic neurons, amplifying the effect of the original synapse, and because the adrenal gland also releases norepinephrine (and the closely related hormone epinephrine) into the blood stream.
7.35.419	The physiological effects of this norepinephrine release include dilating the trachea and bronchi (making it easier for the animal to breathe), increasing heart rate, and moving blood from the skin to the heart, muscles, and brain (so the animal can think and run).
7.35.420	The strength and speed of the sympathetic response helps an organism avoid danger, and scientists have found evidence that it may also increase LTP—allowing the animal to remember the dangerous situation and avoid it in the future.
7.35.421	Parasympathetic Nervous System
7.35.422	While the sympathetic nervous system is activated in stressful situations, the parasympathetic nervous system allows an animal to “rest and digest.
7.35.423	”
7.35.424	One way to remember this is to think that during a restful situation like a picnic, the parasympathetic nervous system is in control (“picnic” and
7.35.425	“parasympathetic” both start with “p”).
7.35.426	Parasympathetic preganglionic neurons have cell bodies located in the brainstem and in the sacral (toward the bottom) spinal cord, as shown in Figure 35.27.
7.35.427	The axons of the preganglionic neurons release acetylcholine on the postganglionic neurons, which are generally located very near the target organs.
7.35.428	Most postganglionic neurons release acetylcholine onto target organs, although some release nitric oxide.
7.35.429	The parasympathetic nervous system resets organ function after the sympathetic nervous system is activated (the common adrenaline dump you feel after a ‘fight-or-flight’ event).
7.35.430	Effects of acetylcholine release on target organs include slowing of heart rate, lowered blood pressure, and stimulation of digestion.
7.35.431	Sensory-Somatic Nervous System
7.35.432	The sensory-somatic nervous system is made up of cranial and spinal nerves and contains both sensory and motor neurons.
7.35.433	Sensory neurons transmit sensory information from the skin, skeletal muscle, and sensory organs to the CNS.
7.35.434	Motor neurons transmit messages about desired movement from the CNS to the muscles to make them contract.
7.35.435	Without its sensory- somatic nervous system, an animal would be unable to process any information about its environment (what it sees, feels, hears, and so on) and could not control motor movements.
7.35.436	Unlike the autonomic nervous system, which has two synapses between the CNS and the target organ, sensory and motor neurons have only one synapse—one ending of the neuron is at the organ and the other directly contacts a CNS neuron.
7.35.437	Acetylcholine is the main neurotransmitter released at these synapses.
7.35.438	Humans have 12 cranial nerves, nerves that emerge from or enter the skull (cranium), as opposed to the spinal nerves, which emerge from the vertebral column.
7.35.439	Each cranial nerve is accorded a name, which are detailed in Figure 35.28.
7.35.440	Some cranial nerves transmit only sensory information.
7.35.441	For example, the olfactory nerve transmits information about smells from the nose to the brainstem.
7.35.442	Other cranial nerves transmit almost solely motor information.
7.35.443	For example, the oculomotor nerve controls the opening and closing of the eyelid and some eye movements.
7.35.444	Other cranial nerves contain a mix of sensory and motor fibers.
7.35.445	For example, the glossopharyngeal nerve has a role in both taste (sensory) and swallowing (motor).
7.35.446	The human brain contains 12 cranial nerves that receive sensory input and control motor output for the head and neck.
7.35.447	Spinal nerves transmit sensory and motor information between the spinal cord and the rest of the body.
7.35.448	Each of the 31 spinal nerves (in humans) contains both sensory and motor axons.
7.35.449	The sensory neuron cell bodies are grouped in structures called dorsal root ganglia and are shown in Figure 35.29.
7.35.450	Each sensory neuron has one projection—with a sensory receptor ending in skin, muscle, or sensory organs—and another that synapses with a neuron in the dorsal spinal cord.
7.35.451	Motor neurons have cell bodies in the ventral gray matter of the spinal cord that project to muscle through the ventral root.
7.35.452	These neurons are usually stimulated by interneurons within the spinal cord but are sometimes directly stimulated by sensory neurons.
7.35.453	Spinal nerves contain both sensory and motor axons.
7.35.454	The somas of sensory neurons are located in dorsal root ganglia.
7.35.455	The somas of motor neurons are found in the ventral portion of the gray matter of the spinal cord.
7.35.456	A nervous system that functions correctly is a fantastically complex, well-oiled machine—synapses fire appropriately, muscles move when needed, memories are formed and stored, and emotions are well regulated.
7.35.457	Unfortunately, each year millions of people in the United States deal with some sort of nervous system disorder.
7.35.458	While scientists have discovered potential causes of many of these diseases, and viable treatments for some, ongoing research seeks to find ways to better prevent and treat all of these disorders.
7.35.459	Neurodegenerative Disorders Neurodegenerative disorders are illnesses characterized by a loss of nervous system functioning that are usually caused by neuronal death.
7.35.460	These diseases generally worsen over time as more and more neurons die.
7.35.461	The symptoms of a particular neurodegenerative disease are related to where in the nervous system the death of neurons occurs.
7.35.462	Spinocerebellar ataxia, for example, leads to neuronal death in the cerebellum.
7.35.463	The death of these neurons causes problems in balance and walking.
7.35.464	Neurodegenerative disorders include Huntington’s disease, amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, Alzheimer’s disease and other types of dementia disorders, and Parkinson’s disease.
7.35.465	Here, Alzheimer’s and Parkinson’s disease will be discussed in more depth.
7.35.466	Alzheimer’s Disease Alzheimer’s disease is the most common cause of dementia in the elderly.
7.35.467	In 2012, an estimated 5.4 million Americans suffered from Alzheimer’s disease, and payments for their care are estimated at $200 billion.
7.35.468	Roughly one in every eight people age 65 or older has the disease.
7.35.469	Due to the aging of the baby-boomer generation, there are projected to be as many as 13 million Alzheimer’s patients in the United States in the year 2050.
7.35.470	Symptoms of Alzheimer’s disease include disruptive memory loss, confusion about time or place, difficulty planning or executing tasks, poor judgment, and personality changes.
7.35.471	Problems smelling certain scents can also be indicative of Alzheimer’s disease and may serve as an early warning sign.
7.35.472	Many of these symptoms are also common in people who are aging normally, so it is the severity and longevity of the symptoms that determine whether a person is suffering from Alzheimer’s.
7.35.473	Alzheimer’s disease was named for Alois Alzheimer, a German psychiatrist who published a report in 1911 about a woman who showed severe dementia symptoms.
7.35.474	Along with his colleagues, he examined the woman’s brain following her death and reported the presence of abnormal clumps, which are now called amyloid plaques, along with tangled brain fibers called neurofibrillary tangles.
7.35.475	Amyloid plaques, neurofibrillary tangles, and an overall shrinking of brain volume are commonly seen in the brains of Alzheimer’s patients.
7.35.476	Loss of neurons in the hippocampus is especially severe in advanced Alzheimer’s patients.
7.35.477	Figure 35.30 compares a normal brain to the brain of an Alzheimer’s patient.
7.35.478	Many research groups are examining the causes of these hallmarks of the disease.
7.35.479	One form of the disease is usually caused by mutations in one of three known genes.
7.35.480	This rare form of early onset Alzheimer’s disease affects fewer than five percent of patients with the disease and causes dementia beginning between the ages of 30 and 60.
7.35.481	The more prevalent, late-onset form of the disease likely also has a genetic component.
7.35.482	One particular gene, apolipoprotein E (APOE) has a variant (E4) that increases a carrier’s likelihood of getting the disease.
7.35.483	Many other genes have been identified that might be involved in the pathology.
7.35.484	Unfortunately, there is no cure for Alzheimer’s disease.
7.35.485	Current treatments focus on managing the symptoms of the disease.
7.35.486	Because decrease in the activity of cholinergic neurons (neurons that use the neurotransmitter acetylcholine) is common in Alzheimer’s disease, several drugs used to treat the disease work by increasing acetylcholine neurotransmission, often by inhibiting the enzyme that breaks down acetylcholine in the synaptic cleft.
7.35.487	Other clinical interventions focus on behavioral therapies like psychotherapy, sensory therapy, and cognitive exercises.
7.35.488	Since Alzheimer’s disease appears to hijack the normal aging process, research into prevention is prevalent.
7.35.489	Smoking, obesity, and cardiovascular problems may be risk factors for the disease, so treatments for those may also help to prevent Alzheimer’s disease.
7.35.490	Some studies have shown that people who remain intellectually active by playing games, reading, playing musical instruments, and being socially active in later life have a reduced risk of developing the disease.
7.35.491	Compared to a normal brain (left), the brain from a patient with Alzheimer’s disease (right) shows a dramatic neurodegeneration, particularly within the ventricles and hippocampus.
7.35.492	(credit: modification of work by “Garrando”/Wikimedia Commons based on original images by ADEAR:
7.35.493	"Alzheimer's Disease Education and Referral Center, a service of the National Institute on Aging”)
7.35.494	Parkinson’s Disease Like Alzheimer’s disease, Parkinson’s disease is a neurodegenerative disease.
7.35.495	It was first characterized by James Parkinson in 1817.
7.35.496	Each year, 50,000-60,000 people in the United States are diagnosed with the disease.
7.35.497	Parkinson’s disease causes the loss of dopamine neurons in the substantia nigra, a midbrain structure that regulates movement.
7.35.498	Loss of these neurons causes many symptoms including tremor (shaking of fingers or a limb), slowed movement, speech changes, balance and posture problems, and rigid muscles.
7.35.499	The combination of these symptoms often causes a characteristic slow hunched shuffling walk, illustrated in Figure 35.31.
7.35.500	Patients with Parkinson’s disease can also exhibit psychological symptoms, such as dementia or emotional problems.
7.35.501	Although some patients have a form of the disease known to be caused by a single mutation, for most patients the exact causes of Parkinson’s disease remain unknown: the disease likely results from a combination of genetic and environmental factors (similar to Alzheimer’s disease).
7.35.502	Post-mortem analysis of brains from Parkinson’s patients shows the presence of Lewy bodies—abnormal protein clumps—in dopaminergic neurons.
7.35.503	The prevalence of these Lewy bodies often correlates with the severity of the disease.
7.35.504	There is no cure for Parkinson’s disease, and treatment is focused on easing symptoms.
7.35.505	One of the most commonly prescribed drugs for Parkinson’s is L-DOPA, which is a chemical that is converted into dopamine by neurons in the brain.
7.35.506	This conversion increases the overall level of dopamine neurotransmission and can help compensate for the loss of dopaminergic neurons in the substantia nigra.
7.35.507	Other drugs work by inhibiting the enzyme that breaks down dopamine.
7.35.508	Parkinson’s patients often have a characteristic hunched walk.
7.35.509	Neurodevelopmental Disorders Neurodevelopmental disorders occur when the development of the nervous system is disturbed.
7.35.510	There are several different classes of neurodevelopmental disorders.
7.35.511	Some, like Down Syndrome, cause intellectual deficits.
7.35.512	Others specifically affect communication, learning, or the motor system.
7.35.513	Some disorders like autism spectrum disorder and attention deficit/ hyperactivity disorder have complex symptoms.
7.35.514	Autism Autism spectrum disorder (ASD) is a neurodevelopmental disorder.
7.35.515	Its severity differs from person to person.
7.35.516	Estimates for the prevalence of the disorder have changed rapidly in the past few decades.
7.35.517	Current estimates suggest that one in 88 children will develop the disorder.
7.35.518	ASD is four times more prevalent in males than females.
7.35.519	A characteristic symptom of ASD is impaired social skills.
7.35.520	Children with autism may have difficulty making and maintaining eye contact and reading social cues.
7.35.521	They also may have problems feeling empathy for others.
7.35.522	Other symptoms of ASD include repetitive motor behaviors (such as rocking back and forth), preoccupation with specific subjects, strict adherence to certain rituals, and unusual language use.
7.35.523	Up to 30 percent of patients with ASD develop epilepsy, and patients with some forms of the disorder (like Fragile X) also have intellectual disability.
7.35.524	Because it is a spectrum disorder, other ASD patients are very functional and have good-to-excellent language skills.
7.35.525	Many of these patients do not feel that they suffer from a disorder and instead think that their brains just process information differently.
7.35.526	Except for some well-characterized, clearly genetic forms of autism (like Fragile X and Rett’s Syndrome), the causes of ASD are largely unknown.
7.35.527	Variants of several genes correlate with the presence of ASD, but for any given patient, many different mutations in different genes may be required for the disease to develop.
7.35.528	At a general level, ASD is thought to be a disease of “incorrect” wiring.
7.35.529	Accordingly, brains of some ASD patients lack the same level of synaptic pruning that occurs in non-affected people.
7.35.530	In the 1990s, a research paper linked autism to a common vaccine given to children.
7.35.531	This paper was retracted when it was discovered that the author falsified data, and follow-up studies showed no connection between vaccines and autism.
7.35.532	Treatment for autism usually combines behavioral therapies and interventions, along with medications to treat other disorders common to people with autism (depression, anxiety, obsessive compulsive disorder).
7.35.533	Although early interventions can help mitigate the effects of the disease, there is currently no cure for ASD.
7.35.534	Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD)
7.35.535	Approximately three to five percent of children and adults are affected by attention deficit/hyperactivity disorder (ADHD).
7.35.536	Like ASD, ADHD is more prevalent in males than females.
7.35.537	Symptoms of the disorder include inattention (lack of focus), executive functioning difficulties, impulsivity, and hyperactivity beyond what is characteristic of the normal developmental stage.
7.35.538	Some patients do not have the hyperactive component of symptoms and are diagnosed with a subtype of ADHD:
7.35.539	attention deficit disorder (ADD).
7.35.540	Many people with ADHD also show comorbitity, in that they develop secondary disorders in addition to ADHD.
7.35.541	Examples include depression or obsessive compulsive disorder (OCD).
7.35.542	Figure 35.32 provides some statistics concerning comorbidity with ADHD.
7.35.543	The cause of ADHD is unknown, although research points to a delay and dysfunction in the development of the prefrontal cortex and disturbances in neurotransmission.
7.35.544	According to studies of twins, the disorder has a strong genetic component.
7.35.545	There are several candidate genes that may contribute to the disorder, but no definitive links have been discovered.
7.35.546	Environmental factors, including exposure to certain pesticides, may also contribute to the development of ADHD in some patients.
7.35.547	Treatment for ADHD often involves behavioral therapies and the prescription of stimulant medications, which paradoxically cause a calming effect in these patients.
7.35.548	Many people with ADHD have one or more other neurological disorders.
7.35.549	(credit “chart design and illustration”:
7.35.550	modification of work by Leigh Coriale; credit “data”: Drs.
7.35.551	Biederman and Faraone, Massachusetts General Hospital).
7.35.552	Mental Illnesses Mental illnesses are nervous system disorders that result in problems with thinking, mood, or relating with other people.
7.35.553	These disorders are severe enough to affect a person’s quality of life and often make it difficult for people to perform the routine tasks of daily living.
7.35.554	Debilitating mental disorders plague approximately 12.5 million Americans (about 1 in 17 people) at an annual cost of more than $300 billion.
7.35.555	There are several types of mental disorders including schizophrenia, major depression, bipolar disorder, anxiety disorders and phobias, post-traumatic stress disorders, and obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD), among others.
7.35.556	The American Psychiatric Association publishes the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders (or DSM), which describes the symptoms required for a patient to be diagnosed with a particular mental disorder.
7.35.557	Each newly released version of the DSM contains different symptoms and classifications as scientists learn more about these disorders, their causes, and how they relate to each other.
7.35.558	A more detailed discussion of two mental illnesses—schizophrenia and major depression—is given below.
7.35.559	Schizophrenia Schizophrenia is a serious and often debilitating mental illness affecting one percent of people in the United States.
7.35.560	Symptoms of the disease include the inability to differentiate between reality and imagination, inappropriate and unregulated emotional responses, difficulty thinking, and problems with social situations.
7.35.561	People with schizophrenia can suffer from hallucinations and hear voices; they may also suffer from delusions.
7.35.562	Patients also have so-called “negative” symptoms like a flattened emotional state, loss of pleasure, and loss of basic drives.
7.35.563	Many schizophrenic patients are diagnosed in their late adolescence or early 20s.
7.35.564	The development of schizophrenia is thought to involve malfunctioning dopaminergic neurons and may also involve problems with glutamate signaling.
7.35.565	Treatment for the disease usually requires antipsychotic medications that work by blocking dopamine receptors and decreasing dopamine neurotransmission in the brain.
7.35.566	This decrease in dopamine can cause Parkinson’s disease-like symptoms in some patients.
7.35.567	While some classes of antipsychotics can be quite effective at treating the disease, they are not a cure, and most patients must remain medicated for the rest of their lives.
7.35.568	Depression Major depression affects approximately 6.7 percent of the adults in the United States each year and is one of the most common mental disorders.
7.35.569	To be diagnosed with major depressive disorder, a person must have experienced a severely depressed mood lasting longer than two weeks along with other symptoms including a loss of enjoyment in activities that were previously enjoyed, changes in appetite and sleep schedules, difficulty concentrating, feelings of worthlessness, and suicidal thoughts.
7.35.570	The exact causes of major depression are unknown and likely include both genetic and environmental risk factors.
7.35.571	Some research supports the “classic monoamine hypothesis,” which suggests that depression is caused by a decrease in norepinephrine and serotonin neurotransmission.
7.35.572	One argument against this hypothesis is the fact that some antidepressant medications cause an increase in norepinephrine and serotonin release within a few hours of beginning treatment—but clinical results of these medications are not seen until weeks later.
7.35.573	This has led to alternative hypotheses: for example, dopamine may also be decreased in depressed patients, or it may actually be an increase in norepinephrine and serotonin that causes the disease, and antidepressants force a feedback loop that decreases this release.
7.35.574	Treatments for depression include psychotherapy, electroconvulsive therapy, deep-brain stimulation, and prescription medications.
7.35.575	There are several classes of antidepressant medications that work through different mechanisms.
7.35.576	For example, monoamine oxidase inhibitors (MAO inhibitors) block the enzyme that degrades many neurotransmitters (including dopamine, serotonin, norepinephrine), resulting in increased neurotransmitter in the synaptic cleft.
7.35.577	Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) block the reuptake of serotonin into the presynaptic neuron.
7.35.578	This blockage results in an increase in serotonin in the synaptic cleft.
7.35.579	Other types of drugs such as norepinephrine-dopamine reuptake inhibitors and norepinephrine-serotonin reuptake inhibitors are also used to treat depression.
7.35.580	Other Neurological Disorders There are several other neurological disorders that cannot be easily placed in the above categories.
7.35.581	These include chronic pain conditions, cancers of the nervous system, epilepsy disorders, and stroke.
7.35.582	Epilepsy and stroke are discussed below.
7.35.583	Epilepsy Estimates suggest that up to three percent of people in the United States will be diagnosed with epilepsy in their lifetime.
7.35.584	While there are several different types of epilepsy, all are characterized by recurrent seizures.
7.35.585	Epilepsy itself can be a symptom of a brain injury, disease, or other illness.
7.35.586	For example, people who have intellectual disability or ASD can experience seizures, presumably because the developmental wiring malfunctions that caused their disorders also put them at risk for epilepsy.
7.35.587	For many patients, however, the cause of their epilepsy is never identified and is likely to be a combination of genetic and environmental factors.
7.35.588	Often, seizures can be controlled with anticonvulsant medications.
7.35.589	However, for very severe cases, patients may undergo brain surgery to remove the brain area where seizures originate.
7.35.590	Stroke A stroke results when blood fails to reach a portion of the brain for a long enough time to cause damage.
7.35.591	Without the oxygen supplied by blood flow, neurons in this brain region die.
7.35.592	This neuronal death can cause many different symptoms—depending on the brain area affected— including headache, muscle weakness or paralysis, speech disturbances, sensory problems, memory loss, and confusion.
7.35.593	Stroke is often caused by blood clots and can also be caused by the bursting of a weak blood vessel.
7.35.594	Strokes are extremely common and are the third most common cause of death in the United States.
7.35.595	On average one person experiences a stroke every 40 seconds in the United States.
7.35.596	Approximately 75 percent of strokes occur in people older than 65.
7.35.597	Risk factors for stroke include high blood pressure, diabetes, high cholesterol, and a family history of stroke.
7.35.598	Smoking doubles the risk of stroke.
7.35.599	Because a stroke is a medical emergency, patients with symptoms of a stroke should immediately go to the emergency room, where they can receive drugs that will dissolve any clot that may have formed.
7.35.600	These drugs will not work if the stroke was caused by a burst blood vessel or if the stroke occurred more than three hours before arriving at the hospital.
7.35.601	Treatment following a stroke can include blood pressure medication (to prevent future strokes) and (sometimes intense) physical therapy.
7.36.0	Introduction
7.36.1	In more advanced animals, the senses are constantly at work, making the animal aware of stimuli—such as light, or sound, or the presence of a chemical substance in the external environment—and monitoring information about the organism’s internal environment.
7.36.2	All bilaterally symmetric animals have a sensory system, and the development of any species’ sensory system has been driven by natural selection; thus, sensory systems differ among species according to the demands of their environments.
7.36.3	The shark, unlike most fish predators, is electrosensitive—that is, sensitive to electrical fields produced by other animals in its environment.
7.36.4	While it is helpful to this underwater predator, electrosensitivity is a sense not found in most land animals.
7.36.5	Senses provide information about the body and its environment.
7.36.6	Humans have five special senses: olfaction (smell), gustation (taste), equilibrium (balance and body position), vision, and hearing.
7.36.7	Additionally, we possess general senses, also called somatosensation, which respond to stimuli like temperature, pain, pressure, and vibration.
7.36.8	Vestibular sensation, which is an organism’s sense of spatial orientation and balance, proprioception (position of bones, joints, and muscles), and the sense of limb position that is used to track kinesthesia (limb movement) are part of somatosensation.
7.36.9	Although the sensory systems associated with these senses are very different, all share a common function: to convert a stimulus (such as light, or sound, or the position of the body) into an electrical signal in the nervous system.
7.36.10	This process is called sensory transduction.
7.36.11	There are two broad types of cellular systems that perform sensory transduction.
7.36.12	In one, a neuron works with a sensory receptor, a cell, or cell process that is specialized to engage with and detect a specific stimulus.
7.36.13	Stimulation of the sensory receptor activates the associated afferent neuron, which carries information about the stimulus to the central nervous system.
7.36.14	In the second type of sensory transduction, a sensory nerve ending responds to a stimulus in the internal or external environment: this neuron constitutes the sensory receptor.
7.36.15	Free nerve endings can be stimulated by several different stimuli, thus showing little receptor specificity.
7.36.16	For example, pain receptors in your gums and teeth may be stimulated by temperature changes, chemical stimulation, or pressure.
7.36.17	Reception
7.36.18	The first step in sensation is reception, which is the activation of sensory receptors by stimuli such as mechanical stimuli (being bent or squished, for example), chemicals, or temperature.
7.36.19	The receptor can then respond to the stimuli.
7.36.20	The region in space in which a given sensory receptor can respond to a stimulus, be it far away or in contact with the body, is that receptor’s receptive field.
7.36.21	Think for a moment about the differences in receptive fields for the different senses.
7.36.22	For the sense of touch, a stimulus must come into contact with body.
7.36.23	For the sense of hearing, a stimulus can be a moderate distance away (some baleen whale sounds can propagate for many kilometers).
7.36.24	For vision, a stimulus can be very far away; for example, the visual system perceives light from stars at enormous distances.
7.36.25	Transduction
7.36.26	The most fundamental function of a sensory system is the translation of a sensory signal to an electrical signal in the nervous system.
7.36.27	This takes place at the sensory receptor, and the change in electrical potential that is produced is called the receptor potential.
7.36.28	How is sensory input, such as pressure on the skin, changed to a receptor potential?
7.36.29	In this example, a type of receptor called a mechanoreceptor (as shown in Figure 36.2) possesses specialized membranes that respond to pressure.
7.36.30	Disturbance of these dendrites by compressing them or bending them opens gated ion channels in the plasma membrane of the sensory neuron, changing its electrical potential.
7.36.31	Recall that in the nervous system, a positive change of a neuron’s electrical potential (also called the membrane potential), depolarizes the neuron.
7.36.32	Receptor potentials are graded potentials: the magnitude of these graded (receptor) potentials varies with the strength of the stimulus.
7.36.33	If the magnitude of depolarization is sufficient (that is, if membrane potential reaches a threshold), the neuron will fire an action potential.
7.36.34	In most cases, the correct stimulus impinging on a sensory receptor will drive membrane potential in a positive direction, although for some receptors, such as those in the visual system, this is not always the case.
7.36.35	Mechanosensitive ion channels are gated ion channels that respond to mechanical deformation of the plasma membrane.
7.36.36	A mechanosensitive channel is connected to the plasma membrane and the cytoskeleton by hair- like tethers.
7.36.37	When pressure causes the extracellular matrix to move, the channel opens, allowing ions to enter or exit the cell.
7.36.38	(b) Stereocilia in the human ear are connected to mechanosensitive ion channels.
7.36.39	When a sound causes the stereocilia to move, mechanosensitive ion channels transduce the signal to the cochlear nerve.
7.36.40	Sensory receptors for different senses are very different from each other, and they are specialized according to the type of stimulus they sense: they have receptor specificity.
7.36.41	For example, touch receptors, light receptors, and sound receptors are each activated by different stimuli.
7.36.42	Touch receptors are not sensitive to light or sound; they are sensitive only to touch or pressure.
7.36.43	However, stimuli may be combined at higher levels in the brain, as happens with olfaction, contributing to our sense of taste.
7.36.44	Encoding and Transmission of Sensory Information
7.36.45	Four aspects of sensory information are encoded by sensory systems: the type of stimulus, the location of the stimulus in the receptive field, the duration of the stimulus, and the relative intensity of the stimulus.
7.36.46	Thus, action potentials transmitted over a sensory receptor’s afferent axons encode one type of stimulus, and this segregation of the senses is preserved in other sensory circuits.
7.36.47	For example, auditory receptors transmit signals over their own dedicated system, and electrical activity in the axons of the auditory receptors will be interpreted by the brain as an auditory stimulus—a sound.
7.36.48	The intensity of a stimulus is often encoded in the rate of action potentials produced by the sensory receptor.
7.36.49	Thus, an intense stimulus will produce a more rapid train of action potentials, and reducing the stimulus will likewise slow the rate of production of action potentials.
7.36.50	A second way in which intensity is encoded is by the number of receptors activated.
7.36.51	An intense stimulus might initiate action potentials in a large number of adjacent receptors, while a less intense stimulus might stimulate fewer receptors.
7.36.52	Integration of sensory information begins as soon as the information is received in the CNS, and the brain will further process incoming signals.
7.36.53	Perception Perception is an individual’s interpretation of a sensation.
7.36.54	Although perception relies on the activation of sensory receptors, perception happens not at the level of the sensory receptor, but at higher levels in the nervous system, in the brain.
7.36.55	The brain distinguishes sensory stimuli through a sensory pathway: action potentials from sensory receptors travel along neurons that are dedicated to a particular stimulus.
7.36.56	These neurons are dedicated to that particular stimulus and synapse with particular neurons in the brain or spinal cord.
7.36.57	All sensory signals, except those from the olfactory system, are transmitted though the central nervous system and are routed to the thalamus and to the appropriate region of the cortex.
7.36.58	Recall that the thalamus is a structure in the forebrain that serves as a clearinghouse and relay station for sensory (as well as motor) signals.
7.36.59	When the sensory signal exits the thalamus, it is conducted to the specific area of the cortex (Figure 36.3) dedicated to processing that particular sense.
7.36.60	How are neural signals interpreted?
7.36.61	Interpretation of sensory signals between individuals of the same species is largely similar, owing to the inherited similarity of their nervous systems; however, there are some individual differences.
7.36.62	A good example of this is individual tolerances to a painful stimulus, such as dental pain, which certainly differ.
7.36.63	In humans, with the exception of olfaction, all sensory signals are routed from the (a) thalamus to (b) final processing regions in the cortex of the brain.
7.36.64	(credit b: modification of work by Polina Tishina)
7.36.65	Somatosensation is a mixed sensory category and includes all sensation received from the skin and mucous membranes, as well from as the limbs and joints.
7.36.66	Somatosensation is also known as tactile sense, or more familiarly, as the sense of touch.
7.36.67	Somatosensation occurs all over the exterior of the body and at some interior locations as well.
7.36.68	A variety of receptor types—embedded in the skin, mucous membranes, muscles, joints, internal organs, and cardiovascular system—play a role.
7.36.69	Recall that the epidermis is the outermost layer of skin in mammals.
7.36.70	It is relatively thin, is composed of keratin-filled cells, and has no blood supply.
7.36.71	The epidermis serves as a barrier to water and to invasion by pathogens.
7.36.72	Below this, the much thicker dermis contains blood vessels, sweat glands, hair follicles, lymph vessels, and lipid-secreting sebaceous glands (Figure 36.4).
7.36.73	Below the epidermis and dermis is the subcutaneous tissue, or hypodermis, the fatty layer that contains blood vessels, connective tissue, and the axons of sensory neurons.
7.36.74	The hypodermis, which holds about 50 percent of the body’s fat, attaches the dermis to the bone and muscle, and supplies nerves and blood vessels to the dermis.
7.36.75	Mammalian skin has three layers: an epidermis, a dermis, and a hypodermis.
7.36.76	(credit: modification of work by Don Bliss, National Cancer Institute)
7.36.77	Somatosensory Receptors
7.36.78	Sensory receptors are classified into five categories: mechanoreceptors, thermoreceptors, proprioceptors, pain receptors, and chemoreceptors.
7.36.79	These categories are based on the nature of stimuli each receptor class transduces.
7.36.80	What is commonly referred to as “touch” involves more than one kind of stimulus and more than one kind of receptor.
7.36.81	Mechanoreceptors in the skin are described as encapsulated (that is, surrounded by a capsule) or unencapsulated (a group that includes free nerve endings).
7.36.82	A free nerve ending, as its name implies, is an unencapsulated dendrite of a sensory neuron.
7.36.83	Free nerve endings are the most common nerve endings in skin, and they extend into the middle of the epidermis.
7.36.84	Free nerve endings are sensitive to painful stimuli, to hot and cold, and to light touch.
7.36.85	They are slow to adjust to a stimulus and so are less sensitive to abrupt changes in stimulation.
7.36.86	There are three classes of mechanoreceptors: tactile, proprioceptors, and baroreceptors.
7.36.87	Mechanoreceptors sense stimuli due to physical deformation of their plasma membranes.
7.36.88	They contain mechanically gated ion channels whose gates open or close in response to pressure, touch, stretching, and sound.
7.36.89	”
7.36.90	There are four primary tactile mechanoreceptors in human skin: Merkel’s disks, Meissner’s corpuscles, Ruffini endings, and Pacinian corpuscle; two are located toward the surface of the skin and two are located deeper.
7.36.91	A fifth type of mechanoreceptor
7.36.92	, Krause end bulbs, are found only in specialized regions.
7.36.93	Merkel’s disks (shown in Figure 36.5) are found in the upper layers of skin near the base of the epidermis, both in skin that has hair and on glabrous skin, that is, the hairless skin found on the palms and fingers, the soles of the feet, and the lips of humans and other primates.
7.36.94	Merkel’s disks are densely distributed in the fingertips and lips.
7.36.95	They are slow-adapting, unencapsulated nerve endings, and they respond to light touch.
7.36.96	Light touch, also known as discriminative touch, is a light pressure that allows the location of a stimulus to be pinpointed.
7.36.97	The receptive fields of Merkel’s disks are small with well- defined borders.
7.36.98	That makes them finely sensitive to edges and they come into use in tasks such as typing on a keyboard.
7.36.99	Meissner’s corpuscles, (shown in Figure 36.6) also known as tactile corpuscles, are found in the upper dermis, but they project into the epidermis.
7.36.100	They, too, are found primarily in the glabrous skin on the fingertips and eyelids.
7.36.101	They respond to fine touch and pressure, but they also respond to low-frequency vibration or flutter.
7.36.102	They are rapidly adapting, fluid-filled, encapsulated neurons with small, well-defined borders and are responsive to fine details.
7.36.103	Like Merkel’s disks, Meissner’s corpuscles are not as plentiful in the palms as they are in the fingertips.
7.36.104	Meissner corpuscles in the fingertips, such as the one viewed here using bright field light microscopy, allow for touch discrimination of fine detail.
7.36.105	(credit: modification of work by "Wbensmith"/Wikimedia Commons; scale- bar data from Matt Russell)
7.36.106	Deeper in the epidermis, near the base, are Ruffini endings, which are also known as bulbous corpuscles.
7.36.107	They are found in both glabrous and hairy skin.
7.36.108	These are slow-adapting, encapsulated mechanoreceptors that detect skin stretch and deformations within joints, so they provide valuable feedback for gripping objects and controlling finger position and movement.
7.36.109	Thus, they also contribute to proprioception and kinesthesia.
7.36.110	Ruffini endings also detect warmth.
7.36.111	Note that these warmth detectors are situated deeper in the skin than are the cold detectors.
7.36.112	It is not surprising, then, that humans detect cold stimuli before they detect warm stimuli.
7.36.113	Pacinian corpuscles (seen in Figure 36.7) are located deep in the dermis of both glabrous and hairy skin and are structurally similar to Meissner’s corpuscles; they are found in the bone periosteum, joint capsules, pancreas and other viscera, breast, and genitals.
7.36.114	They are rapidly adapting mechanoreceptors that sense deep transient (but not prolonged) pressure and high-frequency vibration.
7.36.115	Pacinian receptors detect pressure and vibration by being compressed, stimulating their internal dendrites.
7.36.116	There are fewer Pacinian corpuscles and Ruffini endings in skin than there are Merkel’s disks and Meissner’s corpuscles.
7.36.117	Pacinian corpuscles, such as these visualized using bright field light microscopy, detect pressure (touch) and high-frequency vibration.
7.36.118	(credit: modification of work by Ed Uthman; scale-bar data from Matt Russell)
7.36.119	In proprioception, proprioceptive and kinesthetic signals travel through myelinated afferent neurons running from the spinal cord to the medulla.
7.36.120	Neurons are not physically connected, but communicate via neurotransmitters secreted into synapses or “gaps” between communicating neurons.
7.36.121	Once in the medulla, the neurons continue carrying the signals to the thalamus.
7.36.122	Muscle spindles are stretch receptors that detect the amount of stretch, or lengthening of muscles.
7.36.123	Related to these are Golgi tendon organs, which are tension receptors that detect the force of muscle contraction.
7.36.124	Proprioceptive and kinesthetic signals come from limbs.
7.36.125	Unconscious proprioceptive signals run from the spinal cord to the cerebellum, the brain region that coordinates muscle contraction, rather than to the thalamus, like most other sensory information.
7.36.126	Barorecptors detect pressure changes in an organ.
7.36.127	They are found in the walls of the carotid artery and the aorta where they monitor blood pressure, and in the lungs where they detect the degree of lung expansion.
7.36.128	Stretch receptors are found at various sites in the digestive and urinary systems.
7.36.129	In addition to these two types of deeper receptors, there are also rapidly adapting hair receptors, which are found on nerve endings that wrap around the base of hair follicles.
7.36.130	There are a few types of hair receptors that detect slow and rapid hair movement, and they differ in their sensitivity to movement.
7.36.131	Some hair receptors also detect skin deflection, and certain rapidly adapting hair receptors allow detection of stimuli that have not yet touched the skin.
7.36.132	Integration of Signals from Mechanoreceptors
7.36.133	The configuration of the different types of receptors working in concert in human skin results in a very refined sense of touch.
7.36.134	The nociceptive receptors—those that detect pain—are located near the surface.
7.36.135	Small, finely calibrated mechanoreceptors—Merkel’s disks and Meissner’s corpuscles—are located in the upper layers and can precisely localize even gentle touch.
7.36.136	The large mechanoreceptors—Pacinian corpuscles and Ruffini endings—are located in the lower layers and respond to deeper touch.
7.36.137	(Consider that the deep pressure that reaches those deeper receptors would not need to be finely localized.)
7.36.138	Both the upper and lower layers of the skin hold rapidly and slowly adapting receptors.
7.36.139	Both primary somatosensory cortex and secondary cortical areas are responsible for processing the complex picture of stimuli transmitted from the interplay of mechanoreceptors.
7.36.140	Density of Mechanoreceptors
7.36.141	The distribution of touch receptors in human skin is not consistent over the body.
7.36.142	In humans, touch receptors are less dense in skin covered with any type of hair, such as the arms, legs, torso, and face.
7.36.143	Touch receptors are denser in glabrous skin (the type found on human fingertips and lips, for example), which is typically more sensitive and is thicker than hairy skin (4 to 5 mm versus 2 to 3 mm).
7.36.144	How is receptor density estimated in a human subject?
7.36.145	The relative density of pressure receptors in different locations on the body can be demonstrated experimentally using a two-point discrimination test.
7.36.146	In this demonstration, two sharp points, such as two thumbtacks, are brought into contact with the subject’s skin (though not hard enough to cause pain or break the skin).
7.36.147	The subject reports if he or she feels one point or two points.
7.36.148	If the two points are felt as one point, it can be inferred that the two points are both in the receptive field of a single sensory receptor.
7.36.149	If two points are felt as two separate points, each is in the receptive field of two separate sensory receptors.
7.36.150	The points could then be moved closer and re-tested until the subject reports feeling only one point, and the size of the receptive field of a single receptor could be estimated from that distance.
7.36.151	Thermoreception
7.36.152	In addition to Krause end bulbs that detect cold and Ruffini endings that detect warmth, there are different types of cold receptors on some free nerve endings: thermoreceptors, located in the dermis, skeletal muscles, liver, and hypothalamus, that are activated by different temperatures.
7.36.153	Their pathways into the brain run from the spinal cord through the thalamus to the primary somatosensory cortex.
7.36.154	Warmth and cold information from the face travels through one of the cranial nerves to the brain.
7.36.155	You know from experience that a tolerably cold or hot stimulus can quickly progress to a much more intense stimulus that is no longer tolerable.
7.36.156	Any stimulus that is too intense can be perceived as pain because temperature sensations are conducted along the same pathways that carry pain sensations Pain Pain is the name given to nociception, which is the neural processing of injurious stimuli in response to tissue damage.
7.36.157	Pain is caused by true sources of injury, such as contact with a heat source that causes a thermal burn or contact with a corrosive chemical.
7.36.158	But pain also can be caused by harmless stimuli that mimic the action of damaging stimuli, such as contact with capsaicins, the compounds that cause peppers to taste hot and which are used in self-defense pepper sprays and certain topical medications.
7.36.159	Peppers taste “hot” because the protein receptors that bind capsaicin open the same calcium channels that are activated by warm receptors.
7.36.160	Nociception starts at the sensory receptors, but pain, inasmuch as it is the perception of nociception, does not start until it is communicated to the brain.
7.36.161	There are several nociceptive pathways to and through the brain.
7.36.162	Most axons carrying nociceptive information into the brain from the spinal cord project to the thalamus (as do other sensory neurons) and the neural signal undergoes final processing in the primary somatosensory cortex.
7.36.163	Interestingly, one nociceptive pathway projects not to the thalamus but directly to the hypothalamus in the forebrain, which modulates the cardiovascular and neuroendocrine functions of the autonomic nervous system.
7.36.164	Recall that threatening—or painful—stimuli stimulate the sympathetic branch of the visceral sensory system, readying a fight-or-flight response.
7.36.165	Taste, also called gustation, and smell, also called olfaction, are the most interconnected senses in that both involve molecules of the stimulus entering the body and bonding to receptors.
7.36.166	Smell lets an animal sense the presence of food or other animals—whether potential mates, predators, or prey—or other chemicals in the environment that can impact their survival.
7.36.167	Similarly, the sense of taste allows animals to discriminate between types of foods.
7.36.168	While the value of a sense of smell is obvious, what is the value of a sense of taste?
7.36.169	Different tasting foods have different attributes, both helpful and harmful.
7.36.170	For example, sweet-tasting substances tend to be highly caloric, which could be necessary for survival in lean times.
7.36.171	Bitterness is associated with toxicity, and sourness is associated with spoiled food.
7.36.172	Salty foods are valuable in maintaining homeostasis by helping the body retain water and by providing ions necessary for cells to function.
7.36.173	Tastes and Odors Both taste and odor stimuli are molecules taken in from the environment.
7.36.174	The primary tastes detected by humans are sweet, sour, bitter, salty and umami.
7.36.175	The first four tastes need little explanation.
7.36.176	The identification of umami as a fundamental taste occurred fairly recently—it was identified in 1908 by Japanese scientist Kikunae Ikeda while he worked with seaweed broth, but it was not widely accepted as a taste that could be physiologically distinguished until many years later.
7.36.177	The taste of umami, also known as savoriness, is attributable to the taste of the amino acid L-glutamate.
7.36.178	In fact, monosodium glutamate, or MSG, is often used in cooking to enhance the savory taste of certain foods.
7.36.179	What is the adaptive value of being able to distinguish umami?
7.36.180	Savory substances tend to be high in protein.
7.36.181	All odors that we perceive are molecules in the air we breathe.
7.36.182	If a substance does not release molecules into the air from its surface, it has no smell.
7.36.183	And if a human or other animal does not have a receptor that recognizes a specific molecule, then that molecule has no smell.
7.36.184	Humans have about 350 olfactory receptor subtypes that work in various combinations to allow us to sense about 10,000 different odors.
7.36.185	Compare that to mice, for example, which have about 1,300 olfactory receptor types, and therefore probably sense more odors.
7.36.186	Both odors and tastes involve molecules that stimulate specific chemoreceptors.
7.36.187	Although humans commonly distinguish taste as one sense and smell as another, they work together to create the perception of flavor.
7.36.188	A person’s perception of flavor is reduced if he or she has congested nasal passages.
7.36.189	Reception and Transduction Odorants (odor molecules) enter the nose and dissolve in the olfactory epithelium, the mucosa at the back of the nasal cavity (as illustrated in Figure 36.8).
7.36.190	The olfactory epithelium is a collection of specialized olfactory receptors in the back of the nasal cavity that spans an area about 5 cm2 in humans.
7.36.191	Recall that sensory cells are neurons.
7.36.192	An olfactory receptor, which is a dendrite of a specialized neuron, responds when it binds certain molecules inhaled from the environment by sending impulses directly to the olfactory bulb of the brain.
7.36.193	Humans have about 12 million olfactory receptors, distributed among hundreds of different receptor types that respond to different odors.
7.36.194	Twelve million seems like a large number of receptors, but compare that to other animals: rabbits have about 100 million, most dogs have about 1 billion, and bloodhounds—dogs selectively bred for their sense of smell—have about 4 billion.
7.36.195	The overall size of the olfactory epithelium also differs between species, with that of bloodhounds, for example, being many times larger than that of humans.
7.36.196	Olfactory neurons are bipolar neurons (neurons with two processes from the cell body).
7.36.197	Each neuron has a single dendrite buried in the olfactory epithelium, and extending from this dendrite are 5 to 20 receptor-laden, hair-like cilia that trap odorant molecules.
7.36.198	The sensory receptors on the cilia are proteins, and it is the variations in their amino acid chains that make the receptors sensitive to different odorants.
7.36.199	Each olfactory sensory neuron has only one type of receptor on its cilia, and the receptors are specialized to detect specific odorants, so the bipolar neurons themselves are specialized.
7.36.200	When an odorant binds with a receptor that recognizes it, the sensory neuron associated with the receptor is stimulated.
7.36.201	Olfactory stimulation is the only sensory information that directly reaches the cerebral cortex, whereas other sensations are relayed through the thalamus.
7.36.202	In the human olfactory system, (a) bipolar olfactory neurons extend from (b) the olfactory epithelium, where olfactory receptors are located, to the olfactory bulb.
7.36.203	(credit: modification of work by Patrick J. Lynch, medical illustrator; C. Carl Jaffe, MD, cardiologist)
7.36.204	Taste Detecting a taste (gustation) is fairly similar to detecting an odor (olfaction), given that both taste and smell rely on chemical receptors being stimulated by certain molecules.
7.36.205	The primary organ of taste is the taste bud.
7.36.206	A taste bud is a cluster of gustatory receptors (taste cells) that are located within the bumps on the tongue called papillae (singular: papilla) (illustrated in Figure 36.10).
7.36.207	There are several structurally distinct papillae.
7.36.208	Filiform papillae, which are located across the tongue, are tactile, providing friction that helps the tongue move substances, and contain no taste cells.
7.36.209	In contrast, fungiform papillae, which are located mainly on the anterior two-thirds of the tongue, each contain one to eight taste buds and also have receptors for pressure and temperature.
7.36.210	The large circumvallate papillae contain up to 100 taste buds and form a V near the posterior margin of the tongue.
7.36.211	Foliate, circumvallate, and fungiform papillae are located on different regions of the tongue.
7.36.212	(b) Foliate papillae are prominent protrusions on this light micrograph.
7.36.213	(credit a: modification of work by NCI; scale-bar data from Matt Russell)
7.36.214	In addition to those two types of chemically and mechanically sensitive papillae are foliate papillae—leaf-like papillae located in parallel folds along the edges and toward the back of the tongue, as seen in the Figure 36.10 micrograph.
7.36.215	Foliate papillae contain about 1,300 taste buds within their folds.
7.36.216	Finally, there are circumvallate papillae, which are wall-like papillae in the shape of an inverted “V” at the back of the tongue.
7.36.217	Each of these papillae is surrounded by a groove and contains about 250 taste buds.
7.36.218	Each taste bud’s taste cells are replaced every 10 to 14 days.
7.36.219	These are elongated cells with hair-like processes called microvilli at the tips that extend into the taste bud pore (illustrate in Figure 36.11).
7.36.220	Food molecules ( tastants) are dissolved in saliva, and they bind with and stimulate the receptors on the microvilli.
7.36.221	The receptors for tastants are located across the outer portion and front of the tongue, outside of the middle area where the filiform papillae are most prominent.
7.36.222	Pores in the tongue allow tastants to enter taste pores in the tongue.
7.36.223	(credit: modification of work by Vincenzo Rizzo)
7.36.224	In humans, there are five primary tastes, and each taste has only one corresponding type of receptor.
7.36.225	Thus, like olfaction, each receptor is specific to its stimulus (tastant).
7.36.226	Transduction of the five tastes happens through different mechanisms that reflect the molecular composition of the tastant.
7.36.227	A salty tastant (containing NaCl) provides the sodium ions (Na+) that enter the taste neurons and excite them directly.
7.36.228	Sour tastants are acids and belong to the thermoreceptor protein family.
7.36.229	Binding of an acid or other sour-tasting molecule triggers a change in the ion channel and these increase hydrogen ion (H+) concentrations in the taste neurons, thus depolarizing them.
7.36.230	Sweet, bitter, and umami tastants require a G-protein coupled receptor.
7.36.231	These tastants bind to their respective receptors, thereby exciting the specialized neurons associated with them.
7.36.232	Both tasting abilities and sense of smell change with age.
7.36.233	In humans, the senses decline dramatically by age 50 and continue to decline.
7.36.234	A child may find a food to be too spicy, whereas an elderly person may find the same food to be bland and unappetizing.
7.36.235	Smell and Taste in the Brain Olfactory neurons project from the olfactory epithelium to the olfactory bulb as thin, unmyelinated axons.
7.36.236	The olfactory bulb is composed of neural clusters called glomeruli, and each glomerulus receives signals from one type of olfactory receptor, so each glomerulus is specific to one odorant.
7.36.237	From glomeruli, olfactory signals travel directly to the olfactory cortex and then to the frontal cortex and the thalamus.
7.36.238	Recall that this is a different path from most other sensory information, which is sent directly to the thalamus before ending up in the cortex.
7.36.239	Olfactory signals also travel directly to the amygdala, thereafter reaching the hypothalamus, thalamus, and frontal cortex.
7.36.240	The last structure that olfactory signals directly travel to is a cortical center in the temporal lobe structure important in spatial, autobiographical, declarative, and episodic memories.
7.36.241	Olfaction is finally processed by areas of the brain that deal with memory, emotions, reproduction, and thought.
7.36.242	Taste neurons project from taste cells in the tongue, esophagus, and palate to the medulla, in the brainstem.
7.36.243	From the medulla, taste signals travel to the thalamus and then to the primary gustatory cortex.
7.36.244	Information from different regions of the tongue is segregated in the medulla, thalamus, and cortex.
7.36.245	Audition, or hearing, is important to humans and to other animals for many different interactions.
7.36.246	It enables an organism to detect and receive information about danger, such as an approaching predator, and to participate in communal exchanges like those concerning territories or mating.
7.36.247	On the other hand, although it is physically linked to the auditory system, the vestibular system is not involved in hearing.
7.36.248	Instead, an animal’s vestibular system detects its own movement, both linear and angular acceleration and deceleration, and balance.
7.36.249	Sound Auditory stimuli are sound waves, which are mechanical, pressure waves that move through a medium, such as air or water.
7.36.250	There are no sound waves in a vacuum since there are no air molecules to move in waves.
7.36.251	The speed of sound waves differs, based on altitude, temperature, and medium, but at sea level and a temperature of 20o C (68o F), sound waves travel in the air at about 343 meters per second.
7.36.252	As is true for all waves, there are four main characteristics of a sound wave: frequency, wavelength, period, and amplitude.
7.36.253	Frequency is the number of waves per unit of time, and in sound is heard as pitch.
7.36.254	High-frequency (≥15.000Hz) sounds are higher-pitched (short wavelength) than low-frequency (long wavelengths; ≤100Hz) sounds.
7.36.255	Frequency is measured in cycles per second, and for sound, the most commonly used unit is hertz (Hz), or cycles per second.
7.36.256	Most humans can perceive sounds with frequencies between 30 and 20,000 Hz.
7.36.257	Women are typically better at hearing high frequencies, but everyone’s ability to hear high frequencies decreases with age.
7.36.258	Dogs detect up to about 40,000 Hz; cats, 60,000 Hz; bats, 100,000 Hz; and dolphins 150,000 Hz, and American shad (Alosa sapidissima), a fish, can hear 180,000 Hz.
7.36.259	Those frequencies above the human range are called ultrasound.
7.36.260	Amplitude, or the dimension of a wave from peak to trough, in sound is heard as volume and is illustrated in Figure 36.12.
7.36.261	The sound waves of louder sounds have greater amplitude than those of softer sounds.
7.36.262	For sound, volume is measured in decibels (dB).
7.36.263	The softest sound that a human can hear is the zero point.
7.36.264	Humans speak normally at 60 decibels.
7.36.265	For sound waves, wavelength corresponds to pitch.
7.36.266	Amplitude of the wave corresponds to volume.
7.36.267	The sound wave shown with a dashed line is softer in volume than the sound wave shown with a solid line.
7.36.268	(credit:
7.36.269	NIH) Reception of Sound
7.36.270	In mammals, sound waves are collected by the external, cartilaginous part of the ear called the pinna, then travel through the auditory canal and cause vibration of the thin diaphragm called the tympanum or ear drum, the innermost part of the outer ear (illustrated in Figure 36.13).
7.36.271	Interior to the tympanum is the middle ear.
7.36.272	The middle ear holds three small bones called the ossicles, which transfer energy from the moving tympanum to the inner ear.
7.36.273	The three ossicles are the malleus (also known as the hammer), the incus (the anvil), and stapes (the stirrup).
7.36.274	The aptly named stapes looks very much like a stirrup.
