7.36.275	The three ossicles are unique to mammals, and each plays a role in hearing.
7.36.276	The malleus attaches at three points to the interior surface of the tympanic membrane.
7.36.277	The incus attaches the malleus to the stapes.
7.36.278	In humans, the stapes is not long enough to reach the tympanum.
7.36.279	If we did not have the malleus and the incus, then the vibrations of the tympanum would never reach the inner ear.
7.36.280	These bones also function to collect force and amplify sounds.
7.36.281	The ear ossicles are homologous to bones in a fish mouth: the bones that support gills in fish are thought to be adapted for use in the vertebrate ear over evolutionary time.
7.36.282	Many animals (frogs, reptiles, and birds, for example) use the stapes of the middle ear to transmit vibrations to the middle ear.
7.36.283	Sound travels through the outer ear to the middle ear, which is bounded on its exterior by the tympanic membrane.
7.36.284	The middle ear contains three bones called ossicles that transfer the sound wave to the oval window, the exterior boundary of the inner ear.
7.36.285	The organ of Corti, which is the organ of sound transduction, lies inside the cochlea.
7.36.286	(credit: modification of work by Lars Chittka, Axel Brockmann)
7.36.287	Transduction of Sound Vibrating objects, such as vocal cords, create sound waves or pressure waves in the air.
7.36.288	When these pressure waves reach the ear, the ear transduces this mechanical stimulus (pressure wave) into a nerve impulse (electrical signal) that the brain perceives as sound.
7.36.289	The pressure waves strike the tympanum, causing it to vibrate.
7.36.290	The mechanical energy from the moving tympanum transmits the vibrations to the three bones of the middle ear.
7.36.291	The stapes transmits the vibrations to a thin diaphragm called the oval window, which is the outermost structure of the inner ear.
7.36.292	The structures of the inner ear are found in the labyrinth, a bony, hollow structure that is the most interior portion of the ear.
7.36.293	Here, the energy from the sound wave is transferred from the stapes through the flexible oval window and to the fluid of the cochlea.
7.36.294	The vibrations of the oval window create pressure waves in the fluid (perilymph) inside the cochlea.
7.36.295	The cochlea is a whorled structure, like the shell of a snail, and it contains receptors for transduction of the mechanical wave into an electrical signal (as illustrated in Figure 36.14).
7.36.296	Inside the cochlea, the basilar membrane is a mechanical analyzer that runs the length of the cochlea, curling toward the cochlea’s center.
7.36.297	The mechanical properties of the basilar membrane change along its length, such that it is thicker, tauter, and narrower at the outside of the whorl (where the cochlea is largest), and thinner, floppier, and broader toward the apex, or center, of the whorl (where the cochlea is smallest).
7.36.298	Different regions of the basilar membrane vibrate according to the frequency of the sound wave conducted through the fluid in the cochlea.
7.36.299	For these reasons, the fluid-filled cochlea detects different wave frequencies (pitches) at different regions of the membrane.
7.36.300	When the sound waves in the cochlear fluid contact the basilar membrane, it flexes back and forth in a wave-like fashion.
7.36.301	Above the basilar membrane is the tectorial membrane.
7.36.302	The site of transduction is in the organ of Corti (spiral organ).
7.36.303	It is composed of hair cells held in place above the basilar membrane like flowers projecting up from soil, with their exposed short, hair-like stereocilia contacting or embedded in the tectorial membrane above them.
7.36.304	The inner hair cells are the primary auditory receptors and exist in a single row, numbering approximately 3,500.
7.36.305	The stereocilia from inner hair cells extend into small dimples on the tectorial membrane’s lower surface.
7.36.306	The outer hair cells are arranged in three or four rows.
7.36.307	They number approximately 12,000, and they function to fine tune incoming sound waves.
7.36.308	The longer stereocilia that project from the outer hair cells actually attach to the tectorial membrane.
7.36.309	All of the stereocilia are mechanoreceptors, and when bent by vibrations they respond by opening a gated ion channel (refer to Figure 36.2).
7.36.310	As a result, the hair cell membrane is depolarized, and a signal is transmitted to the chochlear nerve.
7.36.311	Intensity (volume) of sound is determined by how many hair cells at a particular location are stimulated.
7.36.312	The hair cells are arranged on the basilar membrane in an orderly way.
7.36.313	The basilar membrane vibrates in different regions, according to the frequency of the sound waves impinging on it.
7.36.314	Likewise, the hair cells that lay above it are most sensitive to a specific frequency of sound waves.
7.36.315	Hair cells can respond to a small range of similar frequencies, but they require stimulation of greater intensity to fire at frequencies outside of their optimal range.
7.36.316	The difference in response frequency between adjacent inner hair cells is about 0.2 percent.
7.36.317	Compare that to adjacent piano strings, which are about six percent different.
7.36.318	Place theory, which is the model for how biologists think pitch detection works in the human ear, states that high frequency sounds selectively vibrate the basilar membrane of the inner ear near the entrance port (the oval window).
7.36.319	Lower frequencies travel farther along the membrane before causing appreciable excitation of the membrane.
7.36.320	The basic pitch- determining mechanism is based on the location along the membrane where the hair cells are stimulated.
7.36.321	The place theory is the first step toward an understanding of pitch perception.
7.36.322	Considering the extreme pitch sensitivity of the human ear, it is thought that there must be some auditory “sharpening” mechanism to enhance the pitch resolution.
7.36.323	When sound waves produce fluid waves inside the cochlea, the basilar membrane flexes, bending the stereocilia that attach to the tectorial membrane.
7.36.324	Their bending results in action potentials in the hair cells, and auditory information travels along the neural endings of the bipolar neurons of the hair cells (collectively, the auditory nerve) to the brain.
7.36.325	When the hairs bend, they release an excitatory neurotransmitter at a synapse with a sensory neuron, which then conducts action potentials to the central nervous system.
7.36.326	The cochlear branch of the vestibulocochlear cranial nerve sends information on hearing.
7.36.327	The auditory system is very refined, and there is some modulation or “sharpening” built in.
7.36.328	The brain can send signals back to the cochlea, resulting in a change of length in the outer hair cells, sharpening or dampening the hair cells’ response to certain frequencies.
7.36.329	Higher Processing The inner hair cells are most important for conveying auditory information to the brain.
7.36.330	About 90 percent of the afferent neurons carry information from inner hair cells, with each hair cell synapsing with 10 or so neurons.
7.36.331	Outer hair cells connect to only 10 percent of the afferent neurons, and each afferent neuron innervates many hair cells.
7.36.332	The afferent, bipolar neurons that convey auditory information travel from the cochlea to the medulla, through the pons and midbrain in the brainstem, finally reaching the primary auditory cortex in the temporal lobe.
7.36.333	Vestibular Information
7.36.334	The stimuli associated with the vestibular system are linear acceleration (gravity) and angular acceleration and deceleration.
7.36.335	Gravity, acceleration, and deceleration are detected by evaluating the inertia on receptive cells in the vestibular system.
7.36.336	Gravity is detected through head position.
7.36.337	Angular acceleration and deceleration are expressed through turning or tilting of the head.
7.36.338	The vestibular system has some similarities with the auditory system.
7.36.339	It utilizes hair cells just like the auditory system, but it excites them in different ways.
7.36.340	There are five vestibular receptor organs in the inner ear: the utricle, the saccule, and three semicircular canals.
7.36.341	Together, they make up what’s known as the vestibular labyrinth that is shown in Figure 36.15.
7.36.342	The utricle and saccule respond to acceleration in a straight line, such as gravity.
7.36.343	The roughly 30,000 hair cells in the utricle and 16,000 hair cells in the saccule lie below a gelatinous layer, with their stereocilia projecting into the gelatin.
7.36.344	Embedded in this gelatin are calcium carbonate crystals
7.36.345	—like tiny rocks.
7.36.346	When the head is tilted, the crystals continue to be pulled straight down by gravity, but the new angle of the head causes the gelatin to shift, thereby bending the stereocilia.
7.36.347	The bending of the stereocilia stimulates the neurons, and they signal to the brain that the head is tilted, allowing the maintenance of balance.
7.36.348	It is the vestibular branch of the vestibulocochlear cranial nerve that deals with balance.
7.36.349	The structure of the vestibular labyrinth is shown.
7.36.350	(credit: modification of work by NIH)
7.36.351	The fluid-filled semicircular canals are tubular loops set at oblique angles.
7.36.352	They are arranged in three spatial planes.
7.36.353	The base of each canal has a swelling that contains a cluster of hair cells.
7.36.354	The hairs project into a gelatinous cap called the cupula and monitor angular acceleration and deceleration from rotation.
7.36.355	They would be stimulated by driving your car around a corner, turning your head, or falling forward.
7.36.356	One canal lies horizontally, while the other two lie at about 45 degree angles to the horizontal axis, as illustrated in Figure 36.15.
7.36.357	When the brain processes input from all three canals together, it can detect angular acceleration or deceleration in three dimensions.
7.36.358	When the head turns, the fluid in the canals shifts, thereby bending stereocilia and sending signals to the brain.
7.36.359	Upon cessation accelerating or decelerating—or just moving
7.36.360	—
7.36.361	the movement of the fluid within the canals slows or stops.
7.36.362	For example, imagine holding a glass of water.
7.36.363	When moving forward, water may splash backwards onto the hand, and when motion has stopped, water may splash forward onto the fingers.
7.36.364	While in motion, the water settles in the glass and does not splash.
7.36.365	Note that the canals are not sensitive to velocity itself, but to changes in velocity, so moving forward at 60mph with your eyes closed would not give the sensation of movement, but suddenly accelerating or braking would stimulate the receptors.
7.36.366	Higher Processing Hair cells from the utricle, saccule, and semicircular canals also communicate through bipolar neurons to the cochlear nucleus in the medulla.
7.36.367	Cochlear neurons send descending projections to the spinal cord and ascending projections to the pons, thalamus, and cerebellum.
7.36.368	Connections to the cerebellum are important for coordinated movements.
7.36.369	There are also projections to the temporal cortex, which account for feelings of dizziness; projections to autonomic nervous system areas in the brainstem, which account for motion sickness; and projections to the primary somatosensory cortex, which monitors subjective measurements of the external world and self-movement.
7.36.370	People with lesions in the vestibular area of the somatosensory cortex see vertical objects in the world as being tilted.
7.36.371	Finally, the vestibular signals project to certain optic muscles to coordinate eye and head movements.
7.36.372	Vision is the ability to detect light patterns from the outside environment and interpret them into images.
7.36.373	Animals are bombarded with sensory information, and the sheer volume of visual information can be problematic.
7.36.374	Fortunately, the visual systems of species have evolved to attend to the most-important stimuli.
7.36.375	The importance of vision to humans is further substantiated by the fact that about one-third of the human cerebral cortex is dedicated to analyzing and perceiving visual information.
7.36.376	Light
7.36.377	As with auditory stimuli, light travels in waves.
7.36.378	The compression waves that compose sound must travel in a medium—a gas, a liquid, or a solid.
7.36.379	In contrast, light is composed of electromagnetic waves and needs no medium; light can travel in a vacuum (Figure 36.16).
7.36.380	The behavior of light can be discussed in terms of the behavior of waves and also in terms of the behavior of the fundamental unit of light—a packet of electromagnetic radiation called a photon.
7.36.381	A glance at the electromagnetic spectrum shows that visible light for humans is just a small slice of the entire spectrum, which includes radiation that we cannot see as light because it is below the frequency of visible red light and above the frequency of visible violet light.
7.36.382	Certain variables are important when discussing perception of light.
7.36.383	Wavelength (which varies inversely with frequency) manifests itself as hue.
7.36.384	Light at the red end of the visible spectrum has longer wavelengths (and is lower frequency), while light at the violet end has shorter wavelengths (and is higher frequency).
7.36.385	The wavelength of light is expressed in nanometers (nm); one nanometer is one billionth of a meter.
7.36.386	Humans perceive light that ranges between approximately 380 nm and 740 nm.
7.36.387	Some other animals, though, can detect wavelengths outside of the human range.
7.36.388	For example, bees see near-ultraviolet light in order to locate nectar guides on flowers, and some non-avian reptiles sense infrared light (heat that prey gives off).
7.36.389	In the electromagnetic spectrum, visible light lies between 380 nm and 740 nm.
7.36.390	(credit: modification of work by NASA)
7.36.391	Wave amplitude is perceived as luminous intensity, or brightness.
7.36.392	The standard unit of intensity of light is the candela, which is approximately the luminous intensity of a one common candle.
7.36.393	Light waves travel 299,792 km per second in a vacuum, (and somewhat slower in various media such as air and water), and those waves arrive at the eye as long (red), medium (green), and short (blue) waves.
7.36.394	What is termed “white light” is light that is perceived as white by the human eye.
7.36.395	This effect is produced by light that stimulates equally the color receptors in the human eye.
7.36.396	The apparent color of an object is the color (or colors) that the object reflects.
7.36.397	Thus a red object reflects the red wavelengths in mixed (white) light and absorbs all other wavelengths of light.
7.36.398	Anatomy of the Eye
7.36.399	The photoreceptive cells of the eye, where transduction of light to nervous impulses occurs, are located in the retina (shown in Figure 36.17) on the inner surface of the back of the eye.
7.36.400	But light does not impinge on the retina unaltered.
7.36.401	It passes through other layers that process it so that it can be interpreted by the retina (Figure 36.17b).
7.36.402	The cornea, the front transparent layer of the eye, and the crystalline lens, a transparent convex structure behind the cornea, both refract (bend) light to focus the image on the retina.
7.36.403	The iris, which is conspicuous as the colored part of the eye, is a circular muscular ring lying between the lens and cornea that regulates the amount of light entering the eye.
7.36.404	In conditions of high ambient light, the iris contracts, reducing the size of the pupil at its center.
7.36.405	In conditions of low light, the iris relaxes and the pupil enlarges.
7.36.406	The main function of the lens is to focus light on the retina and fovea centralis.
7.36.407	The lens is dynamic, focusing and re- focusing light as the eye rests on near and far objects in the visual field.
7.36.408	The lens is operated by muscles that stretch it flat or allow it to thicken, changing the focal length of light coming through it to focus it sharply on the retina.
7.36.409	With age comes the loss of the flexibility of the lens, and a form of farsightedness called presbyopia results.
7.36.410	Presbyopia occurs because the image focuses behind the retina.
7.36.411	Presbyopia is a deficit similar to a different type of farsightedness called hyperopia caused by an eyeball that is too short.
7.36.412	For both defects, images in the distance are clear but images nearby are blurry.
7.36.413	Myopia (nearsightedness) occurs when an eyeball is elongated and the image focus falls in front of the retina.
7.36.414	In this case, images in the distance are blurry but images nearby are clear.
7.36.415	There are two types of photoreceptors in the retina: rods and cones, named for their general appearance as illustrated in Figure 36.18.
7.36.416	Rods are strongly photosensitive and are located in the outer edges of the retina.
7.36.417	They detect dim light and are used primarily for peripheral and nighttime vision.
7.36.418	Cones are weakly photosensitive and are located near the center of the retina.
7.36.419	They respond to bright light, and their primary role is in daytime, color vision.
7.36.420	Rods and cones are photoreceptors in the retina.
7.36.421	Rods respond in low light and can detect only shades of gray.
7.36.422	Cones respond in intense light and are responsible for color vision.
7.36.423	(credit: modification of work by Piotr Sliwa)
7.36.424	The fovea is the region in the center back of the eye that is responsible for acute vision.
7.36.425	The fovea has a high density of cones.
7.36.426	When you bring your gaze to an object to examine it intently in bright light, the eyes orient so that the object’s image falls on the fovea.
7.36.427	However, when looking at a star in the night sky or other object in dim light, the object can be better viewed by the peripheral vision because it is the rods at the edges of the retina, rather than the cones at the center, that operate better in low light.
7.36.428	In humans, cones far outnumber rods in the fovea.
7.36.429	Transduction of Light
7.36.430	The rods and cones are the site of transduction of light to a neural signal.
7.36.431	Both rods and cones contain photopigments.
7.36.432	In vertebrates, the main photopigment, rhodopsin, has two main parts Figure 36.19): an opsin, which is a membrane protein (in the form of a cluster of α-helices that span the membrane), and retinal—a molecule that absorbs light.
7.36.433	When light hits a photoreceptor, it causes a shape change in the retinal, altering its structure from a bent (cis) form of the molecule to its linear (trans) isomer.
7.36.434	This isomerization of retinal activates the rhodopsin, starting a cascade of events that ends with the closing of Na+ channels in the membrane of the photoreceptor.
7.36.435	Thus, unlike most other sensory neurons (which become depolarized by exposure to a stimulus) visual receptors become hyperpolarized and thus driven away from threshold (Figure 36.20).
7.36.436	Rhodopsin, the photoreceptor in vertebrates, has two parts: the trans-membrane protein opsin, and retinal.
7.36.437	When light strikes retinal, it changes shape from (b) a cis to a trans form.
7.36.438	The signal is passed to a G-protein called transducin, triggering a series of downstream events.
7.36.439	When light strikes rhodopsin, the G-protein transducin is activated, which in turn activates phosphodiesterase.
7.36.440	Phosphodiesterase converts cGMP to GMP, thereby closing sodium channels.
7.36.441	As a result, the membrane becomes hyperpolarized.
7.36.442	The hyperpolarized membrane does not release glutamate to the bipolar cell.
7.36.443	Trichromatic Coding There are three types of cones (with different photopsins), and they differ in the wavelength to which they are most responsive, as shown in Figure 36.21.
7.36.444	Some cones are maximally responsive to short light waves of 420 nm, so they are called S cones (“S” for “short”); others respond maximally to waves of 530 nm (M cones, for “medium”); a third group responds maximally to light of longer wavelengths, at 560 nm (L, or “long” cones).
7.36.445	With only one type of cone, color vision would not be possible, and a two-cone (dichromatic) system has limitations.
7.36.446	Primates use a three-cone (trichromatic) system, resulting in full color vision.
7.36.447	The color we perceive is a result of the ratio of activity of our three types of cones.
7.36.448	The colors of the visual spectrum, running from long-wavelength light to short, are red (700 nm), orange (600 nm), yellow (565 nm), green (497 nm), blue (470 nm), indigo (450 nm), and violet (425 nm).
7.36.449	Humans have very sensitive perception of color and can distinguish about 500 levels of brightness, 200 different hues, and 20 steps of saturation, or about 2 million distinct colors.  
7.36.450	Human rod cells and the different types of cone cells each have an optimal wavelength.
7.36.451	However, there is considerable overlap in the wavelengths of light detected.
7.36.452	Retinal Processing Visual signals leave the cones and rods, travel to the bipolar cells, and then to ganglion cells.
7.36.453	A large degree of processing of visual information occurs in the retina itself, before visual information is sent to the brain.
7.36.454	Photoreceptors in the retina continuously undergo tonic activity.
7.36.455	That is, they are always slightly active even when not stimulated by light.
7.36.456	In neurons that exhibit tonic activity, the absence of stimuli maintains a firing rate at a baseline; while some stimuli increase firing rate from the baseline, and other stimuli decrease firing rate.
7.36.457	In the absence of light, the bipolar neurons that connect rods and cones to ganglion cells are continuously and actively inhibited by the rods and cones.
7.36.458	Exposure of the retina to light hyperpolarizes the rods and cones and removes their inhibition of bipolar cells.
7.36.459	The now active bipolar cells in turn stimulate the ganglion cells, which send action potentials along their axons (which leave the eye as the optic nerve).
7.36.460	Thus, the visual system relies on change in retinal activity, rather than the absence or presence of activity, to encode visual signals for the brain.
7.36.461	Sometimes horizontal cells carry signals from one rod or cone to other photoreceptors and to several bipolar cells.
7.36.462	When a rod or cone stimulates a horizontal cell, the horizontal cell inhibits more distant photoreceptors and bipolar cells, creating lateral inhibition.
7.36.463	This inhibition sharpens edges and enhances contrast in the images by making regions receiving light appear lighter and dark surroundings appear darker.
7.36.464	Amacrine cells can distribute information from one bipolar cell to many ganglion cells.
7.36.465	You can demonstrate this using an easy demonstration to “
7.36.466	trick
7.36.467	” your retina and brain about the colors you are observing in your visual field.
7.36.468	Look fixedly at Figure 36.22 for about 45 seconds.
7.36.469	Then quickly shift your gaze to a sheet of blank white paper or a white wall.
7.36.470	You should see an afterimage of the Norwegian flag in its correct colors.
7.36.471	At this point, close your eyes for a moment, then reopen them, looking again at the white paper or wall; the afterimage of the flag should continue to appear as red, white, and blue.
7.36.472	What causes this?
7.36.473	According to an explanation called opponent process theory, as you gazed fixedly at the green, black, and yellow flag, your retinal ganglion cells that respond positively to green, black, and yellow increased their firing dramatically.
7.36.474	When you shifted your gaze to the neutral white ground, these ganglion cells abruptly decreased their activity and the brain interpreted this abrupt downshift as if the ganglion cells were responding now to their “opponent” colors: red, white, and blue, respectively, in the visual field.
7.36.475	Once the ganglion cells return to their baseline activity state, the false perception of color will disappear.
7.36.476	View this flag to understand how retinal processing works.
7.36.477	Stare at the center of the flag (indicated by the white dot) for 45 seconds, and then quickly look at a white background, noticing how colors appear.
7.36.478	Higher Processing
7.36.479	The myelinated axons of ganglion cells make up the optic nerves.
7.36.480	Within the nerves, different axons carry different qualities of the visual signal.
7.36.481	Some axons constitute the magnocellular (big cell) pathway, which carries information about form, movement, depth, and differences in brightness.
7.36.482	Other axons constitute the parvocellular (small cell) pathway, which carries information on color and fine detail.
7.36.483	Some visual information projects directly back into the brain, while other information crosses to the opposite side of the brain.
7.36.484	This crossing of optical pathways produces the distinctive optic chiasma (Greek, for “crossing”) found at the base of the brain and allows us to coordinate information from both eyes.
7.36.485	Once in the brain, visual information is processed in several places, and its routes reflect the complexity and importance of visual information to humans and other animals.
7.36.486	One route takes the signals to the thalamus, which serves as the routing station for all incoming sensory impulses except olfaction.
7.36.487	In the thalamus, the magnocellular and parvocellular distinctions remain intact, and there are different layers of the thalamus dedicated to each.
7.36.488	When visual signals leave the thalamus, they travel to the primary visual cortex at the rear of the brain.
7.36.489	From the visual cortex, the visual signals travel in two directions.
7.36.490	One stream that projects to the parietal lobe, in the side of the brain, carries magnocellular (“where”) information.
7.36.491	A second stream projects to the temporal lobe and carries both magnocellular (“where”) and parvocellular (
7.36.492	“
7.36.493	what”) information.
7.36.494	Another important visual route is a pathway from the retina to the superior colliculus in the midbrain, where eye movements are coordinated and integrated with auditory information.
7.36.495	Finally, there is the pathway from the retina to the suprachiasmatic nucleus (SCN) of the hypothalamus.
7.36.496	The SCN is a cluster of cells that is considered to be the body’s internal clock, which controls our circadian (day-long) cycle.
7.36.497	The SCN sends information to the pineal gland, which is important in sleep/wake patterns and annual cycles.
7.37.0	Introduction
7.37.1	An animal’s endocrine system controls body processes through the production, secretion, and regulation of hormones, which serve as chemical “messengers” functioning in cellular and organ activity and, ultimately, maintaining the body’s homeostasis.
7.37.2	The endocrine system plays a role in growth, metabolism, and sexual development.
7.37.3	In humans, common endocrine system diseases include thyroid disease and diabetes mellitus.
7.37.4	In organisms that undergo metamorphosis, the process is controlled by the endocrine system.
7.37.5	The transformation from tadpole to frog, for example, is complex and nuanced to adapt to specific environments and ecological circumstances.
7.37.6	Maintaining homeostasis within the body requires the coordination of many different systems and organs.
7.37.7	Communication between neighboring cells, and between cells and tissues in distant parts of the body, occurs through the release of chemicals called hormones.
7.37.8	Hormones are released into body fluids (usually blood) that carry these chemicals to their target cells.
7.37.9	At the target cells, which are cells that have a receptor for a signal or ligand from a signal cell, the hormones elicit a response.
7.37.10	The cells, tissues, and organs that secrete hormones make up the endocrine system.
7.37.11	Examples of glands of the endocrine system include the adrenal glands, which produce hormones such as epinephrine and norepinephrine that regulate responses to stress, and the thyroid gland, which produces thyroid hormones that regulate metabolic rates.
7.37.12	Although there are many different hormones in the human body, they can be divided into three classes based on their chemical structure: lipid-derived, amino acid-derived, and peptide (peptide and proteins) hormones.
7.37.13	One of the key distinguishing features of lipid-derived hormones is that they can diffuse across plasma membranes whereas the amino acid- derived and peptide hormones cannot.
7.37.14	Lipid-Derived Hormones (or Lipid-soluble Hormones)
7.37.15	Most lipid hormones are derived from cholesterol and thus are structurally similar to it, as illustrated in Figure 37.2.
7.37.16	The primary class of lipid hormones in humans is the steroid hormones.
7.37.17	Chemically, these hormones are usually ketones or alcohols; their chemical names will end in “-ol” for alcohols or “-one” for ketones.
7.37.18	Examples of steroid hormones include estradiol, which is an estrogen, or female sex hormone, and testosterone, which is an androgen, or male sex hormone.
7.37.19	These two hormones are released by the female and male reproductive organs, respectively.
7.37.20	Other steroid hormones include aldosterone and cortisol, which are released by the adrenal glands along with some other types of androgens.
7.37.21	Steroid hormones are insoluble in water, and they are transported by transport proteins in blood.
7.37.22	As a result, they remain in circulation longer than peptide hormones.
7.37.23	For example, cortisol has a half-life of 60 to 90 minutes, while epinephrine, an amino acid derived-hormone, has a half-life of approximately one minute.
7.37.24	The structures shown here represent (a) cholesterol, plus the steroid hormones (b) testosterone and (c) estradiol.
7.37.25	Amino Acid-Derived Hormones
7.37.26	The amino acid-derived hormones are relatively small molecules that are derived from the amino acids tyrosine and tryptophan, shown in Figure 37.3.
7.37.27	If a hormone is amino acid-derived, its chemical name will end in “-ine”.
7.37.28	Examples of amino acid-derived hormones include epinephrine and norepinephrine, which are synthesized in the medulla of the adrenal glands, and thyroxine, which is produced by the thyroid gland.
7.37.29	The pineal gland in the brain makes and secretes melatonin which regulates sleep cycles.
7.37.30	The hormone epinephrine, which triggers the fight-or-flight response, is derived from the amino acid tyrosine.
7.37.31	(b)
7.37.32	The hormone melatonin, which regulates circadian rhythms, is derived from the amino acid tryptophan.
7.37.33	Peptide Hormones
7.37.34	The structure of peptide hormones is that of a polypeptide chain (chain of amino acids).
7.37.35	The peptide hormones include molecules that are short polypeptide chains, such as antidiuretic hormone and oxytocin produced in the brain and released into the blood in the posterior pituitary gland.
7.37.36	This class also includes small proteins, like growth hormones produced by the pituitary, and large glycoproteins such as follicle-stimulating hormone produced by the pituitary.
7.37.37	Figure 37.4 illustrates these peptide hormones.
7.37.38	Secreted peptides like insulin are stored within vesicles in the cells that synthesize them.
7.37.39	They are then released in response to stimuli such as high blood glucose levels in the case of insulin.
7.37.40	Amino acid-derived and polypeptide hormones are water- soluble and insoluble in lipids.
7.37.41	These hormones cannot pass through plasma membranes of cells; therefore, their receptors are found on the surface of the target cells.
7.37.42	The structures of peptide hormones (a) oxytocin, (b) growth hormone, and (c) follicle-stimulating hormone are shown.
7.37.43	These peptide hormones are much larger than those derived from cholesterol or amino acids.
7.37.44	Hormones mediate changes in target cells by binding to specific hormone receptors.
7.37.45	In this way, even though hormones circulate throughout the body and come into contact with many different cell types, they only affect cells that possess the necessary receptors.
7.37.46	Receptors for a specific hormone may be found on many different cells or may be limited to a small number of specialized cells.
7.37.47	For example, thyroid hormones act on many different tissue types, stimulating metabolic activity throughout the body.
7.37.48	Cells can have many receptors for the same hormone but often also possess receptors for different types of hormones.
7.37.49	The number of receptors that respond to a hormone determines the cell’s sensitivity to that hormone, and the resulting cellular response.
7.37.50	Additionally, the number of receptors that respond to a hormone can change over time, resulting in increased or decreased cell sensitivity.
7.37.51	In up-regulation, the number of receptors increases in response to rising hormone levels, making the cell more sensitive to the hormone and allowing for more cellular activity.
7.37.52	When the number of receptors decreases in response to rising hormone levels, called down-regulation, cellular activity is reduced.
7.37.53	Receptor binding alters cellular activity and results in an increase or decrease in normal body processes.
7.37.54	Depending on the location of the protein receptor on the target cell and the chemical structure of the hormone, hormones can mediate changes directly by binding to intracellular hormone receptors and modulating gene transcription, or indirectly by binding to cell surface receptors and stimulating signaling pathways.
7.37.55	Intracellular Hormone Receptors Lipid-derived (soluble) hormones such as steroid hormones diffuse across the membranes of the endocrine cell.
7.37.56	Once outside the cell, they bind to transport proteins that keep them soluble in the bloodstream.
7.37.57	At the target cell, the hormones are released from the carrier protein and diffuse across the lipid bilayer of the plasma membrane of cells.
7.37.58	The steroid hormones pass through the plasma membrane of a target cell and adhere to intracellular receptors residing in the cytoplasm or in the nucleus.
7.37.59	The cell signaling pathways induced by the steroid hormones regulate specific genes on the cell's DNA.
7.37.60	The hormones and receptor complex act as transcription regulators by increasing or decreasing the synthesis of mRNA molecules of specific genes.
7.37.61	This, in turn, determines the amount of corresponding protein that is synthesized by altering gene expression.
7.37.62	This protein can be used either to change the structure of the cell or to produce enzymes that catalyze chemical reactions.
7.37.63	In this way, the steroid hormone regulates specific cell processes as illustrated in Figure 37.5.  
7.37.64	Other lipid-soluble hormones that are not steroid hormones, such as vitamin D and thyroxine, have receptors located in the nucleus.
7.37.65	The hormones diffuse across both the plasma membrane and the nuclear envelope, then bind to receptors in the nucleus.
7.37.66	The hormone-receptor complex stimulates transcription of specific genes.
7.37.67	Plasma Membrane Hormone Receptors Amino acid derived hormones and polypeptide hormones are not lipid-derived (lipid-soluble) and therefore cannot diffuse through the plasma membrane of cells.
7.37.68	Lipid insoluble hormones bind to receptors on the outer surface of the plasma membrane, via plasma membrane hormone receptors.
7.37.69	Unlike steroid hormones, lipid insoluble hormones do not directly affect the target cell because they cannot enter the cell and act directly on DNA.
7.37.70	Binding of these hormones to a cell surface receptor results in activation of a signaling pathway; this triggers intracellular activity and carries out the specific effects associated with the hormone.
7.37.71	In this way, nothing passes through the cell membrane; the hormone that binds at the surface remains at the surface of the cell while the intracellular product remains inside the cell.
7.37.72	The hormone that initiates the signaling pathway is called a first messenger, which activates a second messenger in the cytoplasm, as illustrated in Figure 37.6.
7.37.73	The amino acid-derived hormones epinephrine and norepinephrine bind to beta-adrenergic receptors on the plasma membrane of cells.
7.37.74	Hormone binding to receptor activates a G-protein, which in turn activates adenylyl cyclase, converting ATP to cAMP.
7.37.75	cAMP is a second messenger that mediates a cell-specific response.
7.37.76	An enzyme called phosphodiesterase breaks down cAMP, terminating the signal.
7.37.77	One very important second messenger is cyclic AMP (cAMP).
7.37.78	When a hormone binds to its membrane receptor, a G- protein that is associated with the receptor is activated; G-proteins are proteins separate from receptors that are found in the cell membrane.
7.37.79	When a hormone is not bound to the receptor, the G-protein is inactive and is bound to guanosine diphosphate, or GDP.
7.37.80	When a hormone binds to the receptor, the G-protein is activated by binding guanosine triphosphate, or GTP, in place of GDP.
7.37.81	After binding, GTP is hydrolysed by the G-protein into GDP and becomes inactive.
7.37.82	The activated G-protein in turn activates a membrane-bound enzyme called adenylyl cyclase.
7.37.83	Adenylyl cyclase catalyzes the conversion of ATP to cAMP.
7.37.84	cAMP, in turn, activates a group of proteins called protein kinases, which transfer a phosphate group from ATP to a substrate molecule in a process called phosphorylation.
7.37.85	The phosphorylation of a substrate molecule changes its structural orientation, thereby activating it.
7.37.86	These activated molecules can then mediate changes in cellular processes.
7.37.87	The effect of a hormone is amplified as the signaling pathway progresses.
7.37.88	The binding of a hormone at a single receptor causes the activation of many G-proteins, which activates adenylyl cyclase.
7.37.89	Each molecule of adenylyl cyclase then triggers the formation of many molecules of cAMP.
7.37.90	Further amplification occurs as protein kinases, once activated by cAMP, can catalyze many reactions.
7.37.91	In this way, a small amount of hormone can trigger the formation of a large amount of cellular product.
7.37.92	To stop hormone activity, cAMP is deactivated by the cytoplasmic enzyme phosphodiesterase, or PDE.
7.37.93	PDE is always present in the cell and breaks down cAMP to control hormone activity, preventing overproduction of cellular products.
7.37.94	The specific response of a cell to a lipid insoluble hormone depends on the type of receptors that are present on the cell membrane and the substrate molecules present in the cell cytoplasm.
7.37.95	Cellular responses to hormone binding of a receptor include altering membrane permeability and metabolic pathways, stimulating synthesis of proteins and enzymes, and activating hormone release.
7.37.96	Hormones have a wide range of effects and modulate many different body processes.
7.37.97	The key regulatory processes that will be examined here are those affecting the excretory system, the reproductive system, metabolism, blood calcium concentrations, growth, and the stress response.
7.37.98	Hormonal Regulation of the Excretory System
7.37.99	Maintaining a proper water balance in the body is important to avoid dehydration or over-hydration (hyponatremia).
7.37.100	The water concentration of the body is monitored by osmoreceptors in the hypothalamus, which detect the concentration of electrolytes in the extracellular fluid.
7.37.101	The concentration of electrolytes in the blood rises when there is water loss caused by excessive perspiration, inadequate water intake, or low blood volume due to blood loss.
7.37.102	An increase in blood electrolyte levels results in a neuronal signal being sent from the osmoreceptors in hypothalamic nuclei.
7.37.103	The pituitary gland has two components: anterior and posterior.
7.37.104	The anterior pituitary is composed of glandular cells that secrete protein hormones.
7.37.105	The posterior pituitary is an extension of the hypothalamus.
7.37.106	It is composed largely of neurons that are continuous with the hypothalamus.
7.37.107	The hypothalamus produces a polypeptide hormone known as antidiuretic hormone (ADH), which is transported to and released from the posterior pituitary gland.
7.37.108	The principal action of ADH is to regulate the amount of water excreted by the kidneys.
7.37.109	As ADH (which is also known as vasopressin) causes direct water reabsorption from the kidney tubules, salts and wastes are concentrated in what will eventually be excreted as urine.
7.37.110	The hypothalamus controls the mechanisms of ADH secretion, either by regulating blood volume or the concentration of water in the blood.
7.37.111	Dehydration or physiological stress can cause an increase of osmolarity above 300 mOsm/L, which in turn, raises ADH secretion and water will be retained, causing an increase in blood pressure.
7.37.112	ADH travels in the bloodstream to the kidneys.
7.37.113	Once at the kidneys, ADH changes the kidneys to become more permeable to water by temporarily inserting water channels, aquaporins, into the kidney tubules.
7.37.114	Water moves out of the kidney tubules through the aquaporins, reducing urine volume.
7.37.115	The water is reabsorbed into the capillaries lowering blood osmolarity back toward normal.
7.37.116	As blood osmolarity decreases, a negative feedback mechanism reduces osmoreceptor activity in the hypothalamus, and ADH secretion is reduced.
7.37.117	ADH release can be reduced by certain substances, including alcohol, which can cause increased urine production and dehydration.
7.37.118	Chronic underproduction of ADH or a mutation in the ADH receptor results in diabetes insipidus.
7.37.119	If the posterior pituitary does not release enough ADH, water cannot be retained by the kidneys and is lost as urine.
7.37.120	This causes increased thirst, but water taken in is lost again and must be continually consumed.
7.37.121	If the condition is not severe, dehydration may not occur, but severe cases can lead to electrolyte imbalances due to dehydration.
7.37.122	Another hormone responsible for maintaining electrolyte concentrations in extracellular fluids is aldosterone, a steroid hormone that is produced by the adrenal cortex.
7.37.123	In contrast to ADH, which promotes the reabsorption of water to maintain proper water balance, aldosterone maintains proper water balance by enhancing Na+ reabsorption and K+ secretion from extracellular fluid of the cells in kidney tubules.
7.37.124	Because it is produced in the cortex of the adrenal gland and affects the concentrations of minerals Na+ and K+, aldosterone is referred to as a mineralocorticoid, a corticosteroid that affects ion and water balance.
7.37.125	Aldosterone release is stimulated by a decrease in blood sodium levels, blood volume, or blood pressure, or an increase in blood potassium levels.
7.37.126	It also prevents the loss of Na+ from sweat, saliva, and gastric juice.
7.37.127	The reabsorption of Na+ also results in the osmotic reabsorption of water, which alters blood volume and blood pressure.
7.37.128	Aldosterone production can be stimulated by low blood pressure, which triggers a sequence of chemical release, as illustrated in Figure 37.7.
7.37.129	When blood pressure drops, the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS) is activated.
7.37.130	Cells in the juxtaglomerular apparatus, which regulates the functions of the nephrons of the kidney, detect this and release renin.
7.37.131	Renin, an enzyme, circulates in the blood and reacts with a plasma protein produced by the liver called angiotensinogen.
7.37.132	When angiotensinogen is cleaved by renin, it produces angiotensin
7.37.133	I, which is then converted into angiotensin II in the lungs.
7.37.134	Angiotensin II functions as a hormone and then causes the release of the hormone aldosterone by the adrenal cortex, resulting in increased Na+ reabsorption, water retention, and an increase in blood pressure.
7.37.135	Angiotensin II in addition to being a potent vasoconstrictor also causes an increase in ADH and increased thirst, both of which help to raise blood pressure.
7.37.136	ADH and aldosterone increase blood pressure and volume.
7.37.137	Angiotensin II stimulates release of these hormones.
7.37.138	Angiotensin II, in turn, is formed when renin cleaves angiotensinogen.
7.37.139	(credit: modification of work by Mikael Häggström) Hormonal Regulation of the Reproductive System Regulation of the reproductive system is a process that requires the action of hormones from the pituitary gland, the adrenal cortex, and the gonads.
7.37.140	During puberty in both males and females, the hypothalamus produces gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH), which stimulates the production and release of follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) and luteinizing hormone (LH) from the anterior pituitary gland.
7.37.141	These hormones regulate the gonads (testes in males and ovaries in females) and therefore are called gonadotropins.
7.37.142	In both males and females, FSH stimulates gamete production and LH stimulates production of hormones by the gonads.
7.37.143	An increase in gonad hormone levels inhibits GnRH production through a negative feedback loop.
7.37.144	Regulation of the Male Reproductive System
7.37.145	In males, FSH stimulates the maturation of sperm cells.
7.37.146	FSH production is inhibited by the hormone inhibin, which is released by the testes.
7.37.147	LH stimulates production of the sex hormones ( androgens) by the interstitial cells of the testes and therefore is also called interstitial cell-stimulating hormone.
7.37.148	The most widely known androgen in males is testosterone.
7.37.149	Testosterone promotes the production of sperm and masculine characteristics.
7.37.150	The adrenal cortex also produces small amounts of testosterone precursor, although the role of this additional hormone production is not fully understood.
7.37.151	Regulation of the Female Reproductive System
7.37.152	In females, FSH stimulates development of egg cells, called ova, which develop in structures called follicles.
7.37.153	Follicle cells produce the hormone inhibin, which inhibits FSH production.
7.37.154	LH also plays a role in the development of ova, induction of ovulation, and stimulation of estradiol and progesterone production by the ovaries, as illustrated in Figure 37.9.
7.37.155	Estradiol and progesterone are steroid hormones that prepare the body for pregnancy.
7.37.156	Estradiol produces secondary sex characteristics in females, while both estradiol and progesterone regulate the menstrual cycle.
7.37.157	Hormonal regulation of the female reproductive system involves hormones from the hypothalamus, pituitary, and ovaries.
7.37.158	In addition to producing FSH and LH, the anterior portion of the pituitary gland also produces the hormone prolactin (PRL) in females.
7.37.159	Prolactin stimulates the production of milk by the mammary glands following childbirth.
7.37.160	Prolactin levels are regulated by the hypothalamic hormones prolactin-releasing hormone (PRH) and prolactin-inhibiting hormone (PIH), which is now known to be dopamine.
7.37.161	PRH stimulates the release of prolactin and PIH inhibits it.
7.37.162	The posterior pituitary releases the hormone oxytocin, which stimulates uterine contractions during childbirth.
7.37.163	The uterine smooth muscles are not very sensitive to oxytocin until late in pregnancy when the number of oxytocin receptors in the uterus peaks.
7.37.164	Stretching of tissues in the uterus and cervix stimulates oxytocin release during childbirth.
7.37.165	Contractions increase in intensity as blood levels of oxytocin rise via a positive feedback mechanism until the birth is complete.
7.37.166	Oxytocin also stimulates the contraction of myoepithelial cells around the milk-producing mammary glands.
7.37.167	As these cells contract, milk is forced from the secretory alveoli into milk ducts and is ejected from the breasts in milk ejection (“let-down”) reflex.
7.37.168	Oxytocin release is stimulated by the suckling of an infant, which triggers the synthesis of oxytocin in the hypothalamus and its release into circulation at the posterior pituitary.
7.37.169	Hormonal Regulation of Metabolism Blood glucose levels vary widely over the course of a day as periods of food consumption alternate with periods of fasting.
7.37.170	Insulin and glucagon are the two hormones primarily responsible for maintaining homeostasis of blood glucose levels.
7.37.171	Additional regulation is mediated by the thyroid hormones.
7.37.172	Regulation of Blood Glucose Levels by Insulin and Glucagon Cells of the body require nutrients in order to function, and these nutrients are obtained through feeding.
7.37.173	In order to manage nutrient intake, storing excess intake and utilizing reserves when necessary, the body uses hormones to moderate energy stores.
7.37.174	Insulin is produced by the beta cells of the pancreas, which are stimulated to release insulin as blood glucose levels rise (for example, after a meal is consumed).
7.37.175	Insulin lowers blood glucose levels by enhancing the rate of glucose uptake and utilization by target cells, which use glucose for ATP production.
7.37.176	It also stimulates the liver to convert glucose to glycogen, which is then stored by cells for later use.
7.37.177	Insulin also increases glucose transport into certain cells, such as muscle cells and the liver.
7.37.178	This results from an insulin-mediated increase in the number of glucose transporter proteins in cell membranes, which remove glucose from circulation by facilitated diffusion.
7.37.179	As insulin binds to its target cell via insulin receptors and signal transduction, it triggers the cell to incorporate glucose transport proteins into its membrane.
7.37.180	This allows glucose to enter the cell, where it can be used as an energy source.
7.37.181	However, this does not occur in all cells: some cells, including those in the kidneys and brain, can access glucose without the use of insulin.
7.37.182	Insulin also stimulates the conversion of glucose to fat in adipocytes and the synthesis of proteins.
7.37.183	These actions mediated by insulin cause blood glucose concentrations to fall, called a hypoglycemic “low sugar” effect, which inhibits further insulin release from beta cells through a negative feedback loop.
7.37.184	Impaired insulin function can lead to a condition called diabetes mellitus, the main symptoms of which are illustrated in Figure 37.10.
7.37.185	This can be caused by low levels of insulin production by the beta cells of the pancreas, or by reduced sensitivity of tissue cells to insulin.
7.37.186	This prevents glucose from being absorbed by cells, causing high levels of blood glucose, or hyperglycemia (high sugar).
7.37.187	High blood glucose levels make it difficult for the kidneys to recover all the glucose from nascent urine, resulting in glucose being lost in urine.
7.37.188	High glucose levels also result in less water being reabsorbed by the kidneys, causing high amounts of urine to be produced; this may result in dehydration.
7.37.189	Over time, high blood glucose levels can cause nerve damage to the eyes and peripheral body tissues, as well as damage to the kidneys and cardiovascular system.
7.37.190	Oversecretion of insulin can cause hypoglycemia, low blood glucose levels.
7.37.191	This causes insufficient glucose availability to cells, often leading to muscle weakness, and can sometimes cause unconsciousness or death if left untreated.
7.37.192	The main symptoms of diabetes are shown.
7.37.193	(credit: modification of work by Mikael Häggström)
7.37.194	When blood glucose levels decline below normal levels, for example between meals or when glucose is utilized rapidly during exercise, the hormone glucagon is released from the alpha cells of the pancreas.
7.37.195	Glucagon raises blood glucose levels, eliciting what is called a hyperglycemic effect, by stimulating the breakdown of glycogen to glucose in skeletal muscle cells and liver cells in a process called glycogenolysis.
7.37.196	Glucose can then be utilized as energy by muscle cells and released into circulation by the liver cells.
7.37.197	Glucagon also stimulates absorption of amino acids from the blood by the liver, which then converts them to glucose.
7.37.198	This process of glucose synthesis is called gluconeogenesis.
7.37.199	Glucagon also stimulates adipose cells to release fatty acids into the blood.
7.37.200	These actions mediated by glucagon result in an increase in blood glucose levels to normal homeostatic levels.
7.37.201	Rising blood glucose levels inhibit further glucagon release by the pancreas via a negative feedback mechanism.
7.37.202	In this way, insulin and glucagon work together to maintain homeostatic glucose levels, as shown in Figure 37.11.
7.37.203	Regulation of Blood Glucose Levels by Thyroid Hormones
7.37.204	The basal metabolic rate, which is the amount of calories required by the body at rest, is determined by two hormones produced by the thyroid gland: thyroxine, also known as tetraiodothyronine or T4, and triiodothyronine, also known as T3.
7.37.205	These hormones affect nearly every cell in the body except for the adult brain, uterus, testes, blood cells, and spleen.
7.37.206	They are transported across the plasma membrane of target cells and bind to receptors on the mitochondria resulting in increased ATP production.
7.37.207	In the nucleus, T3 and T4 activate genes involved in energy production and glucose oxidation.
7.37.208	This results in increased rates of metabolism and body heat production, which is known as the hormone’s calorigenic effect.
7.37.209	T3 and T4 release from the thyroid gland is stimulated by thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH), which is produced by the anterior pituitary.
7.37.210	TSH binding at the receptors of the follicle of the thyroid triggers the production of T3 and T4 from a glycoprotein called thyroglobulin.
7.37.211	Thyroglobulin is present in the follicles of the thyroid, and is converted into thyroid hormones with the addition of iodine.
7.37.212	Iodine is formed from iodide ions that are actively transported into the thyroid follicle from the bloodstream.
7.37.213	A peroxidase enzyme then attaches the iodine to the tyrosine amino acid found in thyroglobulin.
7.37.214	T3 has three iodine ions attached, while T4 has four iodine ions attached.
7.37.215	T3 and T4 are then released into the bloodstream, with T4 being released in much greater amounts than T3.
7.37.216	As T3 is more active than T4 and is responsible for most of the effects of thyroid hormones, tissues of the body convert T4 to T3 by the removal of an iodine ion.
7.37.217	Most of the released T3 and T4 becomes attached to transport proteins in the bloodstream and is unable to cross the plasma membrane of cells.
7.37.218	These protein-bound molecules are only released when blood levels of the unattached hormone begin to decline.
7.37.219	In this way, a week’s worth of reserve hormone is maintained in the blood.
7.37.220	Increased T3 and T4 levels in the blood inhibit the release of TSH, which results in lower T3 and T4 release from the thyroid.
7.37.221	The follicular cells of the thyroid require iodides (anions of iodine) in order to synthesize T3 and T4.
7.37.222	Iodides obtained from the diet are actively transported into follicle cells resulting in a concentration that is approximately 30 times higher than in blood.
7.37.223	The typical diet in North America provides more iodine than required due to the addition of iodide to table salt.
7.37.224	Inadequate iodine intake, which occurs in many developing countries, results in an inability to synthesize T3 and T4 hormones.
7.37.225	The thyroid gland enlarges in a condition called goiter, which is caused by overproduction of TSH without the formation of thyroid hormone.
7.37.226	Thyroglobulin is contained in a fluid called colloid, and TSH stimulation results in higher levels of colloid accumulation in the thyroid.
7.37.227	In the absence of iodine, this is not converted to thyroid hormone, and colloid begins to accumulate more and more in the thyroid gland, leading to goiter.
7.37.228	Disorders can arise from both the underproduction and overproduction of thyroid hormones.
7.37.229	Hypothyroidism, underproduction of the thyroid hormones, can cause a low metabolic rate leading to weight gain, sensitivity to cold, and reduced mental activity, among other symptoms.
7.37.230	In children, hypothyroidism can cause cretinism, which can lead to mental retardation and growth defects.
7.37.231	Hyperthyroidism, the overproduction of thyroid hormones, can lead to an increased metabolic rate and its effects: weight loss, excess heat production, sweating, and an increased heart rate.
7.37.232	Graves’ disease is one example of a hyperthyroid condition.
7.37.233	Hormonal Control of Blood Calcium Levels Regulation of blood calcium concentrations is important for generation of muscle contractions and nerve impulses, which are electrically stimulated.
7.37.234	If calcium levels get too high, membrane permeability to sodium decreases and membranes become less responsive.
7.37.235	If calcium levels get too low, membrane permeability to sodium increases and convulsions or muscle spasms can result.
7.37.236	Blood calcium levels are regulated by parathyroid hormone (PTH), which is produced by the parathyroid glands, as illustrated in Figure 37.12.
7.37.237	PTH is released in response to low blood Ca2+ levels.
7.37.238	PTH increases Ca2+ levels by targeting the skeleton, the kidneys, and the intestine.
7.37.239	In the skeleton, PTH stimulates osteoclasts, which causes bone to be reabsorbed, releasing Ca2
7.37.240	+ from bone into the blood.
7.37.241	PTH also inhibits osteoblasts, reducing Ca2+ deposition in bone.
7.37.242	In the intestines, PTH increases dietary Ca2+ absorption, and in the kidneys, PTH stimulates reabsorption of the CA2+.
7.37.243	While PTH acts directly on the kidneys to increase Ca2+ reabsorption, its effects on the intestine are indirect.
7.37.244	PTH triggers the formation of calcitriol, an active form of vitamin D, which acts on the intestines to increase absorption of dietary calcium.
7.37.245	PTH release is inhibited by rising blood calcium levels.
7.37.246	Parathyroid hormone (PTH) is released in response to low blood calcium levels.
7.37.247	It increases blood calcium levels by targeting the skeleton, the kidneys, and the intestine.
7.37.248	(credit: modification of work by Mikael Häggström)
7.37.249	Hyperparathyroidism results from an overproduction of parathyroid hormone.
7.37.250	This results in excessive calcium being removed from bones and introduced into blood circulation, producing structural weakness of the bones, which can lead to deformation and fractures, plus nervous system impairment due to high blood calcium levels.
7.37.251	Hypoparathyroidism, the underproduction of PTH, results in extremely low levels of blood calcium, which causes impaired muscle function and may result in tetany (severe sustained muscle contraction).
7.37.252	The hormone calcitonin, which is produced by the parafollicular or C cells of the thyroid, has the opposite effect on blood calcium levels as does PTH.
7.37.253	Calcitonin decreases blood calcium levels by inhibiting osteoclasts, stimulating osteoblasts, and stimulating calcium excretion by the kidneys.
7.37.254	This results in calcium being added to the bones to promote structural integrity.
7.37.255	Calcitonin is most important in children (when it stimulates bone growth), during pregnancy (when it reduces maternal bone loss), and during prolonged starvation (because it reduces bone mass loss).
7.37.256	In healthy nonpregnant, unstarved adults, the role of calcitonin is unclear.
7.37.257	Hormonal Regulation of Growth Hormonal regulation is required for the growth and replication of most cells in the body.
7.37.258	Growth hormone (GH), produced by the anterior portion of the pituitary gland, accelerates the rate of protein synthesis, particularly in skeletal muscle and bones.
7.37.259	Growth hormone has direct and indirect mechanisms of action.
7.37.260	The first direct action of GH is stimulation of triglyceride breakdown (lipolysis) and release into the blood by adipocytes.
7.37.261	This results in a switch by most tissues from utilizing glucose as an energy source to utilizing fatty acids.
7.37.262	This process is called a glucose-sparing effect.
7.37.263	In another direct mechanism, GH stimulates glycogen breakdown in the liver; the glycogen is then released into the blood as glucose.
7.37.264	Blood glucose levels increase as most tissues are utilizing fatty acids instead of glucose for their energy needs.
7.37.265	The GH mediated increase in blood glucose levels is called a diabetogenic effect because it is similar to the high blood glucose levels seen in diabetes mellitus.
7.37.266	The indirect mechanism of GH action is mediated by insulin-like growth factors (IGFs) or somatomedins, which are a family of growth-promoting proteins produced by the liver, which stimulates tissue growth.
7.37.267	IGFs stimulate the uptake of amino acids from the blood, allowing the formation of new proteins, particularly in skeletal muscle cells, cartilage cells, and other target cells, as shown in Figure 37.13.
7.37.268	This is especially important after a meal, when glucose and amino acid concentration levels are high in the blood.
7.37.269	GH levels are regulated by two hormones produced by the hypothalamus.
7.37.270	GH release is stimulated by growth hormone-releasing hormone (GHRH) and is inhibited by growth hormone-inhibiting hormone (GHIH), also called somatostatin.
7.37.271	Growth hormone directly accelerates the rate of protein synthesis in skeletal muscle and bones.
7.37.272	Insulin- like growth factor 1 (IGF-1) is activated by growth hormone and also allows formation of new proteins in muscle cells and bone.
7.37.273	(credit: modification of work by Mikael Häggström)
7.37.274	A balanced production of growth hormone is critical for proper development.
7.37.275	Underproduction of GH in adults does not appear to cause any abnormalities, but in children it can result in pituitary dwarfism, in which growth is reduced.
7.37.276	Pituitary dwarfism is characterized by symmetric body formation.
7.37.277	In some cases, individuals are under 30 inches in height.
7.37.278	Oversecretion of growth hormone can lead to gigantism in children, causing excessive growth.
7.37.279	In some documented cases, individuals can reach heights of over eight feet.
7.37.280	In adults, excessive GH can lead to acromegaly, a condition in which there is enlargement of bones in the face, hands, and feet that are still capable of growth.
7.37.281	Hormonal Regulation of Stress
7.37.282	When a threat or danger is perceived, the body responds by releasing hormones that will ready it for the “fight-or-flight” response.
7.37.283	The effects of this response are familiar to anyone who has been in a stressful situation: increased heart rate, dry mouth, and hair standing up.
7.37.284	The sympathetic nervous system regulates the stress response via the hypothalamus.
7.37.285	Stressful stimuli cause the hypothalamus to signal the adrenal medulla (which mediates short-term stress responses) via nerve impulses, and the adrenal cortex, which mediates long-term stress responses, via the hormone adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH), which is produced by the anterior pituitary.
7.37.286	Short-term Stress Response
7.37.287	When presented with a stressful situation, the body responds by calling for the release of hormones that provide a burst of energy.
7.37.288	The hormones epinephrine (also known as adrenaline) and norepinephrine (also known as noradrenaline) are released by the adrenal medulla.
7.37.289	How do these hormones provide a burst of energy?
7.37.290	Epinephrine and norepinephrine increase blood glucose levels by stimulating the liver and skeletal muscles to break down glycogen and by stimulating glucose release by liver cells.
7.37.291	Additionally, these hormones increase oxygen availability to cells by increasing the heart rate and dilating the bronchioles.
7.37.292	The hormones also prioritize body function by increasing blood supply to essential organs such as the heart, brain, and skeletal muscles, while restricting blood flow to organs not in immediate need, such as the skin, digestive system, and kidneys.
7.37.293	Epinephrine and norepinephrine are collectively called catecholamines.
7.37.294	Long-term Stress Response Long-term stress response differs from short-term stress response.
7.37.295	The body cannot sustain the bursts of energy mediated by epinephrine and norepinephrine for long times.
7.37.296	Instead, other hormones come into play.
7.37.297	In a long-term stress response, the hypothalamus triggers the release of ACTH from the anterior pituitary gland.
7.37.298	The adrenal cortex is stimulated by ACTH to release steroid hormones called corticosteroids.
7.37.299	Corticosteroids turn on transcription of certain genes in the nuclei of target cells.
7.37.300	They change enzyme concentrations in the cytoplasm and affect cellular metabolism.
7.37.301	There are two main corticosteroids: glucocorticoids such as cortisol, and mineralocorticoids such as aldosterone.
7.37.302	These hormones target the breakdown of fat into fatty acids in the adipose tissue.
7.37.303	The fatty acids are released into the bloodstream for other tissues to use for ATP production.
7.37.304	The glucocorticoids primarily affect glucose metabolism by stimulating glucose synthesis.
7.37.305	Glucocorticoids also have anti-inflammatory properties through inhibition of the immune system.
7.37.306	For example, cortisone is used as an anti-inflammatory medication; however, it cannot be used long term as it increases susceptibility to disease due to its immune-suppressing effects.
7.37.307	Mineralocorticoids function to regulate ion and water balance of the body.
7.37.308	The hormone aldosterone stimulates the reabsorption of water and sodium ions in the kidney, which results in increased blood pressure and volume.
7.37.309	Hypersecretion of glucocorticoids can cause a condition known as Cushing’s disease, characterized by a shifting of fat storage areas of the body.
7.37.310	This can cause the accumulation of adipose tissue in the face and neck, and excessive glucose in the blood.
7.37.311	Hyposecretion of the corticosteroids can cause Addison’s disease, which may result in bronzing of the skin, hypoglycemia, and low electrolyte levels in the blood.
7.37.312	Hormone production and release are primarily controlled by negative feedback.
7.37.313	In negative feedback systems, a stimulus elicits the release of a substance; once the substance reaches a certain level, it sends a signal that stops further release of the substance.
7.37.314	In this way, the concentration of hormones in blood is maintained within a narrow range.
7.37.315	For example, the anterior pituitary signals the thyroid to release thyroid hormones.
7.37.316	Increasing levels of these hormones in the blood then give feedback to the hypothalamus and anterior pituitary to inhibit further signaling to the thyroid gland, as illustrated in Figure 37.14.
7.37.317	There are three mechanisms by which endocrine glands are stimulated to synthesize and release hormones: humoral stimuli, hormonal stimuli, and neural stimuli.
7.37.318	Humoral Stimuli
7.37.319	The term
7.37.320	“humoral” is derived from the term “humor,” which refers to bodily fluids such as blood.
7.37.321	A humoral stimulus refers to the control of hormone release in response to changes in extracellular fluids such as blood or the ion concentration in the blood.
7.37.322	For example, a rise in blood glucose levels triggers the pancreatic release of insulin.
7.37.323	Insulin causes blood glucose levels to drop, which signals the pancreas to stop producing insulin in a negative feedback loop.
7.37.324	Hormonal Stimuli Hormonal stimuli refers to the release of a hormone in response to another hormone.
7.37.325	A number of endocrine glands release hormones when stimulated by hormones released by other endocrine glands.
7.37.326	For example, the hypothalamus produces hormones that stimulate the anterior portion of the pituitary gland.
7.37.327	The anterior pituitary in turn releases hormones that regulate hormone production by other endocrine glands.
7.37.328	The anterior pituitary releases the thyroid-stimulating hormone, which then stimulates the thyroid gland to produce the hormones T3 and T4.
7.37.329	As blood concentrations of T3 and T4 rise, they inhibit both the pituitary and the hypothalamus in a negative feedback loop.
7.37.330	Neural Stimuli
7.37.331	In some cases, the nervous system directly stimulates endocrine glands to release hormones, which is referred to as neural stimuli.
7.37.332	Recall that in a short-term stress response, the hormones epinephrine and norepinephrine are important for providing the bursts of energy required for the body to respond.
7.37.333	Here, neuronal signaling from the sympathetic nervous system directly stimulates the adrenal medulla to release the hormones epinephrine and norepinephrine in response to stress.
7.37.334	Both the endocrine and nervous systems use chemical signals to communicate and regulate the body's physiology.
7.37.335	The endocrine system releases hormones that act on target cells to regulate development, growth, energy metabolism, reproduction, and many behaviors.
7.37.336	The nervous system releases neurotransmitters or neurohormones that regulate neurons, muscle cells, and endocrine cells.
7.37.337	Because the neurons can regulate the release of hormones, the nervous and endocrine systems work in a coordinated manner to regulate the body's physiology.
7.37.338	Hypothalamic-Pituitary Axis
7.37.339	The hypothalamus in vertebrates integrates the endocrine and nervous systems.
7.37.340	The hypothalamus is an endocrine organ located in the diencephalon of the brain.
7.37.341	It receives input from the body and other brain areas and initiates endocrine responses to environmental changes.
7.37.342	The hypothalamus acts as an endocrine organ, synthesizing hormones and transporting them along axons to the posterior pituitary gland.
7.37.343	It synthesizes and secretes regulatory hormones that control the endocrine cells in the anterior pituitary gland.
7.37.344	The hypothalamus contains autonomic centers that control endocrine cells in the adrenal medulla via neuronal control.
7.37.345	The pituitary gland, sometimes called the hypophysis or “master gland” is located at the base of the brain in the sella turcica, a groove of the sphenoid bone of the skull, illustrated in Figure 37.15.
7.37.346	It is attached to the hypothalamus via a stalk called the pituitary stalk (or infundibulum).
7.37.347	The anterior portion of the pituitary gland is regulated by releasing or release-inhibiting hormones produced by the hypothalamus, and the posterior pituitary receives signals via neurosecretory cells to release hormones produced by the hypothalamus.
7.37.348	The pituitary has two distinct regions—the anterior pituitary and the posterior pituitary—which between them secrete nine different peptide or protein hormones.
7.37.349	The posterior lobe of the pituitary gland contains axons of the hypothalamic neurons.
7.37.350	The pituitary gland is located at (a) the base of the brain and (b) connected to the hypothalamus by the pituitary stalk.
7.37.351	(credit a: modification of work by NCI; credit b: modification of work by Gray’s Anatomy)
7.37.352	Anterior Pituitary
7.37.353	The anterior pituitary gland, or adenohypophysis, is surrounded by a capillary network that extends from the hypothalamus, down along the infundibulum, and to the anterior pituitary.
7.37.354	This capillary network is a part of the hypophyseal portal system that carries substances from the hypothalamus to the anterior pituitary and hormones from the anterior pituitary into the circulatory system.
7.37.355	A portal system carries blood from one capillary network to another; therefore, the hypophyseal portal system allows hormones produced by the hypothalamus to be carried directly to the anterior pituitary without first entering the circulatory system.
7.37.356	The anterior pituitary produces seven hormones: growth hormone (GH), prolactin (PRL), thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH), melanin-stimulating hormone (MSH), adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH), follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH), and luteinizing hormone (LH).
7.37.357	Anterior pituitary hormones are sometimes referred to as tropic hormones, because they control the functioning of other organs.
7.37.358	While these hormones are produced by the anterior pituitary, their production is controlled by regulatory hormones produced by the hypothalamus.
7.37.359	These regulatory hormones can be releasing hormones or inhibiting hormones, causing more or less of the anterior pituitary hormones to be secreted.
7.37.360	These travel from the hypothalamus through the hypophyseal portal system to the anterior pituitary where they exert their effect.
7.37.361	Negative feedback then regulates how much of these regulatory hormones are released and how much anterior pituitary hormone is secreted.
7.37.362	Posterior Pituitary
7.37.363	The posterior pituitary is significantly different in structure from the anterior pituitary.
7.37.364	It is a part of the brain, extending down from the hypothalamus, and contains mostly nerve fibers and neuroglial cells, which support axons that extend from the hypothalamus to the posterior pituitary.
7.37.365	The posterior pituitary and the infundibulum together are referred to as the neurohypophysis.
7.37.366	The hormones antidiuretic hormone (ADH), also known as vasopressin, and oxytocin are produced by neurons in the hypothalamus and transported within these axons along the infundibulum to the posterior pituitary.
7.37.367	They are released into the circulatory system via neural signaling from the hypothalamus.
7.37.368	These hormones are considered to be posterior pituitary hormones, even though they are produced by the hypothalamus, because that is where they are released into the circulatory system.
7.37.369	The posterior pituitary itself does not produce hormones, but instead
7.37.370	stores hormones produced by the hypothalamus and releases them into the blood stream.
7.37.371	Thyroid Gland
7.37.372	The thyroid gland is located in the neck, just below the larynx and in front of the trachea, as shown in Figure 37.16.
7.37.373	It is a butterfly-shaped gland with two lobes that are connected by the isthmus.
7.37.374	It has a dark red color due to its extensive vascular system.
7.37.375	When the thyroid swells due to dysfunction, it can be felt under the skin of the neck.
7.37.376	This illustration shows the location of the thyroid gland.
7.37.377	The thyroid gland is made up of many spherical thyroid follicles, which are lined with a simple cuboidal epithelium.
7.37.378	These follicles contain a viscous fluid, called colloid, which stores the glycoprotein thyroglobulin, the precursor to the thyroid hormones.
7.37.379	The follicles produce hormones that can be stored in the colloid or released into the surrounding capillary network for transport to the rest of the body via the circulatory system.
7.37.380	Thyroid follicle cells synthesize the hormone thyroxine, which is also known as T4 because it contains four atoms of iodine, and triiodothyronine, also known as T3 because it contains three atoms of iodine.
7.37.381	Follicle cells are stimulated to release stored T3 and T4 by thyroid stimulating hormone (TSH), which is produced by the anterior pituitary.
7.37.382	These thyroid hormones increase the rates of mitochondrial ATP production.
7.37.383	A third hormone, calcitonin, is produced by parafollicular cells of the thyroid either releasing hormones or inhibiting hormones.
7.37.384	Calcitonin release is not controlled by TSH, but instead is released when calcium ion concentrations in the blood rise.
7.37.385	Calcitonin functions to help regulate calcium concentrations in body fluids.
7.37.386	It acts in the bones to inhibit osteoclast activity and in the kidneys to stimulate excretion of calcium.
7.37.387	The combination of these two events lowers body fluid levels of calcium.
7.37.388	Parathyroid Glands
7.37.389	Most people have four parathyroid glands; however, the number can vary from two to six.
7.37.390	These glands are located on the posterior surface of the thyroid gland, as shown in Figure 37.17.
7.37.391	Normally, there is a superior gland and an inferior gland associated with each of the thyroid’s two lobes.
7.37.392	Each parathyroid gland is covered by connective tissue and contains many secretory cells that are associated with a capillary network.
7.37.393	he parathyroid glands are located on the posterior of the thyroid gland.
7.37.394	(credit: modification of work by NCI)
7.37.395	The parathyroid glands produce parathyroid hormone (PTH).
7.37.396	PTH increases blood calcium concentrations when calcium ion levels fall below normal.
7.37.397	PTH (1) enhances reabsorption of Ca2+ by the kidneys, (2) stimulates osteoclast activity and inhibits osteoblast activity, and (3) it stimulates synthesis and secretion of calcitriol by the kidneys, which enhances Ca2+
7.37.398	absorption by the digestive system.
7.37.399	PTH is produced by chief cells of the parathyroid.
7.37.400	PTH and calcitonin work in opposition to one another to maintain homeostatic Ca2+ levels in body fluids.
7.37.401	Another type of cells, oxyphil cells, exist in the parathyroid but their function is not known.
7.37.402	These hormones encourage bone growth, muscle mass, and blood cell formation in children and women.
7.37.403	Adrenal Glands
7.37.404	The adrenal glands are associated with the kidneys; one gland is located on top of each kidney as illustrated in Figure 37.18.
7.37.405	The adrenal glands consist of an outer adrenal cortex and an inner adrenal medulla.
7.37.406	These regions secrete different hormones.
7.37.407	The location of the adrenal glands on top of the kidneys is shown.
7.37.408	(credit: modification of work by NCI)
7.37.409	Adrenal Cortex
7.37.410	The adrenal cortex is made up of layers of epithelial cells and associated capillary networks.
7.37.411	These layers form three distinct regions: an outer zona glomerulosa that produces mineralocorticoids, a middle zona fasciculata that produces glucocorticoids, and an inner zona reticularis that produces androgens.
7.37.412	The main mineralocorticoid is aldosterone, which regulates the concentration of Na+ ions in urine, sweat, pancreas, and saliva.
7.37.413	Aldosterone release from the adrenal cortex is stimulated by a decrease in blood concentrations of sodium ions, blood volume, or blood pressure, or by an increase in blood potassium levels.
7.37.414	The three main glucocorticoids are cortisol, corticosterone, and cortisone.
7.37.415	The glucocorticoids stimulate the synthesis of glucose and gluconeogenesis (converting a non-carbohydrate to glucose) by liver cells and they promote the release of fatty acids from adipose tissue.
