7.37.416	These hormones increase blood glucose levels to maintain levels within a normal range between meals.
7.37.417	These hormones are secreted in response to ACTH and levels are regulated by negative feedback.
7.37.418	Androgens are sex hormones that promote masculinity.
7.37.419	They are produced in small amounts by the adrenal cortex in both males and females.
7.37.420	They do not affect sexual characteristics and may supplement sex hormones released from the gonads.
7.37.421	Adrenal Medulla
7.37.422	The adrenal medulla contains large, irregularly shaped cells that are closely associated with blood vessels.
7.37.423	These cells are innervated by preganglionic autonomic nerve fibers from the central nervous system.
7.37.424	The adrenal medulla contains two types of secretory cells: one that produces epinephrine (adrenaline) and another that produces norepinephrine (noradrenaline).
7.37.425	Epinephrine is the primary adrenal medulla hormone accounting for 75 to 80 percent of its secretions.
7.37.426	Epinephrine and norepinephrine increase heart rate, breathing rate, cardiac muscle contractions, blood pressure, and blood glucose levels.
7.37.427	They also accelerate the breakdown of glucose in skeletal muscles and stored fats in adipose tissue.
7.37.428	The release of epinephrine and norepinephrine is stimulated by neural impulses from the sympathetic nervous system.
7.37.429	Secretion of these hormones is stimulated by acetylcholine release from preganglionic sympathetic fibers innervating the adrenal medulla.
7.37.430	These neural impulses originate from the hypothalamus in response to stress to prepare the body for the fight-or-flight response.
7.37.431	Pancreas
7.37.432	The pancreas, illustrated in Figure 37.19, is an elongated organ that is located between the stomach and the proximal portion of the small intestine.
7.37.433	It contains both exocrine cells that excrete digestive enzymes and endocrine cells that release hormones.
7.37.434	It is sometimes referred to as a heterocrine gland because it has both endocrine and exocrine functions.
7.37.435	The pancreas is found underneath the stomach and points toward the spleen.
7.37.436	(credit: modification of work by NCI)
7.37.437	The endocrine cells of the pancreas form clusters called pancreatic islets or the islets of Langerhans, as visible in the micrograph shown in Figure 37.20.
7.37.438	The pancreatic islets contain two primary cell types: alpha cells, which produce the hormone glucagon, and beta cells, which produce the hormone insulin.
7.37.439	These hormones regulate blood glucose levels.
7.37.440	As blood glucose levels decline, alpha cells release glucagon to raise the blood glucose levels by increasing rates of glycogen breakdown and glucose release by the liver.
7.37.441	When blood glucose levels rise, such as after a meal, beta cells release insulin to lower blood glucose levels by increasing the rate of glucose uptake in most body cells, and by increasing glycogen synthesis in skeletal muscles and the liver.
7.37.442	Together, glucagon and insulin regulate blood glucose levels.
7.37.443	Figure 37.20
7.37.444	The islets of Langerhans are clusters of endocrine cells found in the pancreas; they stain lighter than surrounding cells.
7.37.445	(credit: modification of work by Muhammad T. Tabiin, Christopher P. White, Grant Morahan, and Bernard E. Tuch; scale-bar data from Matt Russell)
7.37.446	Pineal Gland
7.37.447	The pineal gland produces melatonin.
7.37.448	The rate of melatonin production is affected by the photoperiod.
7.37.449	Collaterals from the visual pathways innervate the pineal gland.
7.37.450	During the day photoperiod, little melatonin is produced; however, melatonin production increases during the dark photoperiod (night).
7.37.451	In some mammals, melatonin has an inhibitory affect on reproductive functions by decreasing production and maturation of sperm, oocytes, and reproductive organs.
7.37.452	Melatonin is an effective antioxidant, protecting the CNS from free radicals such as nitric oxide and hydrogen peroxide.
7.37.453	Lastly, melatonin is involved in biological rhythms, particularly circadian rhythms such as the sleep-wake cycle and eating habits.
7.37.454	Gonads The gonads—
7.37.455	the male testes and female ovaries—produce steroid hormones.
7.37.456	The testes produce androgens, testosterone being the most prominent, which allow for the development of secondary sex characteristics and the production of sperm cells.
7.37.457	The ovaries produce estradiol and progesterone, which cause secondary sex characteristics and prepare the body for childbirth.
7.37.458	Organs with Secondary Endocrine Functions There are several organs whose primary functions are non-endocrine but that also possess endocrine functions.
7.37.459	These include the heart, kidneys, intestines, thymus, gonads, and adipose tissue.
7.37.460	The heart possesses endocrine cells in the walls of the atria that are specialized cardiac muscle cells.
7.37.461	These cells release the hormone atrial natriuretic peptide (ANP) in response to increased blood volume.
7.37.462	High blood volume causes the cells to be stretched, resulting in hormone release.
7.37.463	ANP acts on the kidneys to reduce the reabsorption of Na+, causing Na+ and water to be excreted in the urine.
7.37.464	ANP also reduces the amounts of renin released by the kidneys and aldosterone released by the adrenal cortex, further preventing the retention of water.
7.37.465	In this way, ANP causes a reduction in blood volume and blood pressure, and reduces the concentration of Na+ in the blood.
7.37.466	The gastrointestinal tract produces several hormones that aid in digestion.
7.37.467	The endocrine cells are located in the mucosa of the GI tract throughout the stomach and small intestine.
7.37.468	Some of the hormones produced include gastrin, secretin, and cholecystokinin, which are secreted in the presence of food, and some of which act on other organs such as the pancreas, gallbladder, and liver.
7.37.469	They trigger the release of gastric juices, which help to break down and digest food in the GI tract.
7.37.470	While the adrenal glands associated with the kidneys are major endocrine glands, the kidneys themselves also possess endocrine function.
7.37.471	Renin is released in response to decreased blood volume or pressure and is part of the renin-angiotensin- aldosterone system that leads to the release of aldosterone.
7.37.472	Aldosterone then causes the retention of Na+ and water, raising blood volume.
7.37.473	The kidneys also release calcitriol, which aids in the absorption of Ca2+ and phosphate ions.
7.37.474	Erythropoietin (EPO) is a protein hormone that triggers the formation of red blood cells in the bone marrow.
7.37.475	EPO is released in response to low oxygen levels.
7.37.476	Because red blood cells are oxygen carriers, increased production results in greater oxygen delivery throughout the body.
7.37.477	EPO has been used by athletes to improve performance, as greater oxygen delivery to muscle cells allows for greater endurance.
7.37.478	Because red blood cells increase the viscosity of blood, artificially high levels of EPO can cause severe health risks.
7.37.479	The thymus is found behind the sternum; it is most prominent in infants, becoming smaller in size through adulthood.
7.37.480	The thymus produces hormones referred to as thymosins, which contribute to the development of the immune response.
7.37.481	Adipose tissue is a connective tissue found throughout the body.
7.37.482	It produces the hormone leptin in response to food intake.
7.37.483	Leptin increases the activity of anorexigenic neurons and decreases that of orexigenic neurons, producing a feeling of satiety after eating, thus affecting appetite and reducing the urge for further eating.
7.37.484	Leptin is also associated with reproduction.
7.37.485	It must be present for GnRH and gonadotropin synthesis to occur.
7.37.486	Extremely thin females may enter puberty late; however, if adipose levels increase, more leptin will be produced, improving fertility.     
7.38.0	Introduction
7.38.1	The muscular and skeletal systems provide support to the body and allow for a wide range of movement.
7.38.2	The bones of the skeletal system protect the body’s internal organs and support the weight of the body.
7.38.3	The muscles of the muscular system contract and pull on the bones, allowing for movements as diverse as standing, walking, running, and grasping items.
7.38.4	Injury or disease affecting the musculoskeletal system can be very debilitating.
7.38.5	In humans, the most common musculoskeletal diseases worldwide are caused by malnutrition.
7.38.6	Ailments that affect the joints are also widespread, such as arthritis, which can make movement difficult and—in advanced cases—completely impair mobility.
7.38.7	In severe cases in which the joint has suffered extensive damage, joint replacement surgery may be needed.
7.38.8	Progress in the science of prosthesis design has resulted in the development of artificial joints, with joint replacement surgery in the hips and knees being the most common.
7.38.9	Replacement joints for shoulders, elbows, and fingers are also available.
7.38.10	Even with this progress, there is still room for improvement in the design of prostheses.
7.38.11	The state-of-the-art prostheses have limited durability and therefore wear out quickly, particularly in young or active individuals.
7.38.12	Current research is focused on the use of new materials, such as carbon fiber, that may make prostheses more durable.
7.38.13	A skeletal system is necessary to support the body, protect internal organs, and allow for the movement of an organism.
7.38.14	There are three different skeleton designs that fulfill these functions: hydrostatic skeleton, exoskeleton, and endoskeleton.
7.38.15	Hydrostatic Skeleton
7.38.16	A hydrostatic skeleton is a skeleton formed by a fluid-filled compartment within the body, called the coelom.
7.38.17	The organs of the coelom are supported by the aqueous fluid, which also resists external compression.
7.38.18	This compartment is under hydrostatic pressure because of the fluid and supports the other organs of the organism.
7.38.19	This type of skeletal system is found in soft-bodied animals such as sea anemones, earthworms, Cnidaria, and other invertebrates (Figure 38.2).
7.38.20	The skeleton of the red-knobbed sea star (Protoreaster linckii) is an example of a hydrostatic skeleton.
7.38.21	(credit:
7.38.22	“
7.38.23	Amada44”/Wikimedia Commons) Movement in a hydrostatic skeleton is provided by muscles that surround the coelom.
7.38.24	The muscles in a hydrostatic skeleton contract to change the shape of the coelom; the pressure of the fluid in the coelom produces movement.
7.38.25	For example, earthworms move by waves of muscular contractions of the skeletal muscle of the body wall hydrostatic skeleton, called peristalsis, which alternately shorten and lengthen the body.
7.38.26	Lengthening the body extends the anterior end of the organism.
7.38.27	Most organisms have a mechanism to fix themselves in the substrate.
7.38.28	Shortening the muscles then draws the posterior portion of the body forward.
7.38.29	Although a hydrostatic skeleton is well-suited to invertebrate organisms such as earthworms and some aquatic organisms, it is not an efficient skeleton for terrestrial animals.
7.38.30	Exoskeleton An exoskeleton is an external skeleton that consists of a hard encasement on the surface of an organism.
7.38.31	For example, the shells of crabs and insects are exoskeletons (Figure 38.3).
7.38.32	This skeleton type provides defence against predators, supports the body, and allows for movement through the contraction of attached muscles.
7.38.33	As with vertebrates, muscles must cross a joint inside the exoskeleton.
7.38.34	Shortening of the muscle changes the relationship of the two segments of the exoskeleton.
7.38.35	Arthropods such as crabs and lobsters have exoskeletons that consist of 30–50 percent chitin, a polysaccharide derivative of glucose that is a strong but flexible material.
7.38.36	Chitin is secreted by the epidermal cells.
7.38.37	The exoskeleton is further strengthened by the addition of calcium carbonate in organisms such as the lobster.
7.38.38	Because the exoskeleton is acellular, arthropods must periodically shed their exoskeletons because the exoskeleton does not grow as the organism grows.
7.38.39	Muscles attached to the exoskeleton of the Halloween crab (Gecarcinus quadratus) allow it to move.
7.38.40	Endoskeleton
7.38.41	An endoskeleton is a skeleton that consists of hard, mineralized structures located within the soft tissue of organisms.
7.38.42	An example of a primitive endoskeletal structure is the spicules of sponges.
7.38.43	The bones of vertebrates are composed of tissues, whereas sponges have no true tissues (Figure 38.4).
7.38.44	Endoskeletons provide support for the body, protect internal organs, and allow for movement through contraction of muscles attached to the skeleton.
7.38.45	Figure 38.4
7.38.46	The skeletons of humans and horses are examples of endoskeletons.
7.38.47	(credit: Ross Murphy)
7.38.48	The human skeleton is an endoskeleton that consists of 206 bones in the adult.
7.38.49	It has five main functions: providing support to the body, storing minerals and lipids, producing blood cells, protecting internal organs, and allowing for movement.
7.38.50	The skeletal system in vertebrates is divided into the axial skeleton (which consists of the skull, vertebral column, and rib cage), and the appendicular skeleton (which consists of the shoulders, limb bones, the pectoral girdle, and the pelvic girdle).
7.38.51	Human Axial Skeleton
7.38.52	The axial skeleton forms the central axis of the body and includes the bones of the skull, ossicles of the middle ear,
7.38.53	hyoid bone of the throat, vertebral column, and the thoracic cage (ribcage)
7.38.54	(Figure 38.5).
7.38.55	The function of the axial skeleton is to provide support and protection for the brain, the spinal cord, and the organs in the ventral body cavity.
7.38.56	It provides a surface for the attachment of muscles that move the head, neck, and trunk, performs respiratory movements, and stabilizes parts of the appendicular skeleton.
7.38.57	The axial skeleton consists of the bones of the skull, ossicles of the middle ear, hyoid bone, vertebral column, and rib cage.
7.38.58	(credit: modification of work by Mariana Ruiz Villareal)
7.38.59	The Skull
7.38.60	The bones of the skull support the structures of the face and protect the brain.
7.38.61	The skull consists of 22 bones, which are divided into two categories: cranial bones and facial bones.
7.38.62	The cranial bones are eight bones that form the cranial cavity, which encloses the brain and serves as an attachment site for the muscles of the head and neck.
7.38.63	The eight cranial bones are the frontal bone, two parietal bones, two temporal bones, occipital bone, sphenoid bone, and the ethmoid bone.
7.38.64	Although the bones developed separately in the embryo and fetus, in the adult, they are tightly fused with connective tissue and adjoining bones do not move (Figure 38.6).
7.38.65	The bones of the skull support the structures of the face and protect the brain.
7.38.66	(credit: modification of work by Mariana Ruiz Villareal)
7.38.67	The auditory ossicles of the middle ear transmit sounds from the air as vibrations to the fluid-filled cochlea.
7.38.68	The auditory ossicles consist of six bones: two malleus bones, two incus bones, and two stapes on each side.
7.38.69	These are the smallest bones in the body and are unique to mammals.
7.38.70	Fourteen facial bones form the face, provide cavities for the sense organs (eyes, mouth, and nose), protect the entrances to the digestive and respiratory tracts, and serve as attachment points for facial muscles.
7.38.71	The 14 facial bones are the nasal bones, the maxillary bones, zygomatic bones, palatine, vomer, lacrimal bones, the inferior nasal conchae, and the mandible.
7.38.72	All of these bones occur in pairs except for the mandible and the vomer
7.38.73	(Figure 38.7).
7.38.74	The cranial bones, including the frontal, parietal, and sphenoid bones, cover the top of the head.
7.38.75	The facial bones of the skull form the face and provide cavities for the eyes, nose, and mouth.
7.38.76	Although it is not found in the skull, the hyoid bone is considered a component of the axial skeleton.
7.38.77	The hyoid bone lies below the mandible in the front of the neck.
7.38.78	It acts as a movable base for the tongue and is connected to muscles of the jaw, larynx, and tongue.
7.38.79	The mandible articulates with the base of the skull.
7.38.80	The mandible controls the opening to the airway and gut.
7.38.81	In animals with teeth, the mandible brings the surfaces of the teeth in contact with the maxillary teeth.
7.38.82	The Vertebral Column
7.38.83	The vertebral column, or spinal column, surrounds and protects the spinal cord, supports the head, and acts as an attachment point for the ribs and muscles of the back and neck.
7.38.84	The adult vertebral column comprises 26 bones: the 24 vertebrae, the sacrum, and the coccyx bones.
7.38.85	In the adult, the sacrum is typically composed of five vertebrae that fuse into one.
7.38.86	The coccyx is typically 3–4 vertebrae that fuse into one.
7.38.87	Around the age of 70, the sacrum and the coccyx may fuse together.
7.38.88	We begin life with approximately 33 vertebrae, but as we grow, several vertebrae fuse together.
7.38.89	The adult vertebrae are further divided into the 7 cervical vertebrae, 12 thoracic vertebrae, and 5 lumbar vertebrae (Figure 38.8).
7.38.90	The vertebral column consists of seven cervical vertebrae (C1–7) twelve thoracic vertebrae (Th1–12), five lumbar vertebrae (L1–5), the os sacrum, and the coccyx.
7.38.91	(b)
7.38.92	Spinal curves increase the strength and flexibility of the spine.
7.38.93	(credit a: modification of work by Uwe Gille based on original work by Gray's Anatomy; credit b: modification of work by NCI, NIH)
7.38.94	Each vertebral body has a large hole in the center through which the nerves of the spinal cord pass.
7.38.95	There is also a notch on each side through which the spinal nerves, which serve the body at that level, can exit from the spinal cord.
7.38.96	The vertebral column is approximately 71 cm (28 inches) in adult male humans and is curved, which can be seen from a side view.
7.38.97	The names of the spinal curves correspond to the region of the spine in which they occur.
7.38.98	The thoracic and sacral curves are concave (curve inwards relative to the front of the body) and the cervical and lumbar curves are convex (curve outwards relative to the front of the body).
7.38.99	The arched curvature of the vertebral column increases its strength and flexibility, allowing it to absorb shocks like a spring (Figure 38.8).
7.38.100	Intervertebral discs composed of fibrous cartilage lie between adjacent vertebral bodies from the second cervical vertebra to the sacrum.
7.38.101	Each disc is part of a joint that allows for some movement of the spine and acts as a cushion to absorb shocks from movements such as walking and running.
7.38.102	Intervertebral discs also act as ligaments to bind vertebrae together.
7.38.103	The inner part of discs, the nucleus pulposus, hardens as people age and becomes less elastic.
7.38.104	This loss of elasticity diminishes its ability to absorb shocks.
7.38.105	The Thoracic Cage
7.38.106	The thoracic cage, also known as the ribcage, is the skeleton of the chest, and consists of the ribs, sternum, thoracic vertebrae, and costal cartilages (Figure 38.9).
7.38.107	The thoracic cage encloses and protects the organs of the thoracic cavity, including the heart and lungs.
7.38.108	It also provides support for the shoulder girdles and upper limbs, and serves as the attachment point for the diaphragm, muscles of the back, chest, neck, and shoulders.
7.38.109	Changes in the volume of the thorax enable breathing.
7.38.110	The sternum, or breastbone, is a long, flat bone located at the anterior of the chest.
7.38.111	It is formed from three bones that fuse in the adult.
7.38.112	The ribs are 12 pairs of long, curved bones that attach to the thoracic vertebrae and curve toward the front of the body, forming the ribcage.
7.38.113	Costal cartilages connect the anterior ends of the ribs to the sternum, with the exception of rib pairs 11 and 12, which are free-floating ribs.
7.38.114	The thoracic cage, or rib cage, protects the heart and the lungs.
7.38.115	(credit: modification of work by NCI, NIH)
7.38.116	Human Appendicular Skeleton
7.38.117	The appendicular skeleton is composed of the bones of the upper limbs (which function to grasp and manipulate objects) and the lower limbs (which permit locomotion).
7.38.118	It also includes the pectoral girdle, or shoulder girdle, that attaches the upper limbs to the body, and the pelvic girdle that attaches the lower limbs to the body (Figure 38.10).
7.38.119	The appendicular skeleton is composed of the bones of the pectoral limbs (arm, forearm, hand), the pelvic limbs (thigh, leg, foot), the pectoral girdle, and the pelvic girdle.
7.38.120	(credit: modification of work by Mariana Ruiz Villareal)
7.38.121	The Pectoral Girdle
7.38.122	The pectoral girdle bones provide the points of attachment of the upper limbs to the axial skeleton.
7.38.123	The human pectoral girdle consists of the clavicle (or collarbone) in the anterior, and the scapula (or shoulder blades) in the posterior (Figure 38.11).
7.38.124	Figure 38.11 (a) The pectoral girdle in primates consists of the clavicles and scapulae.
7.38.125	(b)
7.38.126	The posterior view reveals the spine of the scapula to which muscle attaches.
7.38.127	The clavicles are S-shaped bones that position the arms on the body.
7.38.128	The clavicles lie horizontally across the front of the thorax (chest) just above the first rib.
7.38.129	These bones are fairly fragile and are susceptible to fractures.
7.38.130	For example, a fall with the arms outstretched causes the force to be transmitted to the clavicles, which can break if the force is excessive.
7.38.131	The clavicle articulates with the sternum and the scapula.
7.38.132	The scapulae are flat, triangular bones that are located at the back of the pectoral girdle.
7.38.133	They support the muscles crossing the shoulder joint.
7.38.134	A ridge, called the spine, runs across the back of the scapula and can easily be felt through the skin (Figure 38.11).
7.38.135	The spine of the scapula is a good example of a bony protrusion that facilitates a broad area of attachment for muscles to bone.
7.38.136	The Upper Limb
7.38.137	The upper limb contains 30 bones in three regions: the arm (shoulder to elbow), the forearm (ulna and radius), and the wrist and hand (Figure 38.12).
7.38.138	The upper limb consists of the humerus of the upper arm, the radius and ulna of the forearm, eight bones of the carpus, five bones of the metacarpus, and 14 bones of the phalanges.
7.38.139	An articulation is any place at which two bones are joined.
7.38.140	The humerus is the largest and longest bone of the upper limb and the only bone of the arm.
7.38.141	It articulates with the scapula at the shoulder and with the forearm at the elbow.
7.38.142	The forearm extends from the elbow to the wrist and consists of two bones: the ulna and the radius.
7.38.143	The radius is located along the lateral (thumb) side of the forearm and articulates with the humerus at the elbow.
7.38.144	The ulna is located on the medial aspect (pinky-finger side) of the forearm.
7.38.145	It is longer than the radius.
7.38.146	The ulna articulates with the humerus at the elbow.
7.38.147	The radius and ulna also articulate with the carpal bones and with each other, which in vertebrates enables a variable degree of rotation of the carpus with respect to the long axis of the limb.
7.38.148	The hand includes the eight bones of the carpus (wrist), the five bones of the metacarpus (palm), and the 14 bones of the phalanges (digits).
7.38.149	Each digit consists of three phalanges, except for the thumb, when present, which has only two.
7.38.150	The Pelvic Girdle
7.38.151	The pelvic girdle attaches to the lower limbs of the axial skeleton.
7.38.152	Because it is responsible for bearing the weight of the body and for locomotion, the pelvic girdle is securely attached to the axial skeleton by strong ligaments.
7.38.153	It also has deep sockets with robust ligaments to securely attach the femur to the body.
7.38.154	The pelvic girdle is further strengthened by two large hip bones.
7.38.155	In adults, the hip bones, or coxal bones, are formed by the fusion of three pairs of bones: the ilium, ischium, and pubis.
7.38.156	The pelvis joins together in the anterior of the body at a joint called the pubic symphysis and with the bones of the sacrum at the posterior of the body.
7.38.157	The female pelvis is slightly different from the male pelvis.
7.38.158	Over generations of evolution, females with a wider pubic angle and larger diameter pelvic canal reproduced more successfully.
7.38.159	Therefore, their offspring also had pelvic anatomy that enabled successful childbirth (Figure 38.13).
7.38.160	o adapt to reproductive fitness, the (a) female pelvis is lighter, wider, shallower, and has a broader angle between the pubic bones than (b) the male pelvis.
7.38.161	The Lower Limb
7.38.162	The lower limb consists of the thigh, the leg, and the foot.
7.38.163	The bones of the lower limb are the femur (thigh bone), patella (kneecap), tibia and fibula (bones of the leg), tarsals (bones of the ankle), and metatarsals and phalanges (bones of the foot) (Figure 38.14).
7.38.164	The bones of the lower limbs are thicker and stronger than the bones of the upper limbs because of the need to support the entire weight of the body and the resulting forces from locomotion.
7.38.165	In addition to evolutionary fitness, the bones of an individual will respond to forces exerted upon them.
7.38.166	he lower limb consists of the thigh (femur), kneecap (patella), leg (tibia and fibula), ankle (tarsals), and foot (metatarsals and phalanges) bones.
7.38.167	The femur, or thighbone, is the longest, heaviest, and strongest bone in the body.
7.38.168	The femur and pelvis form the hip joint at the proximal end.
7.38.169	At the distal end, the femur, tibia, and patella form the knee joint.
7.38.170	The patella, or kneecap, is a triangular bone that lies anterior to the knee joint.
7.38.171	The patella is embedded in the tendon of the femoral extensors (quadriceps).
7.38.172	It improves knee extension by reducing friction.
7.38.173	The tibia, or shinbone, is a large bone of the leg that is located directly below the knee.
7.38.174	The tibia articulates with the femur at its proximal end, with the fibula and the tarsal bones at its distal end.
7.38.175	It is the second largest bone in the human body and is responsible for transmitting the weight of the body from the femur to the foot.
7.38.176	The fibula, or calf bone, parallels and articulates with the tibia.
7.38.177	It does not articulate with the femur and does not bear weight.
7.38.178	The fibula acts as a site for muscle attachment and forms the lateral part of the ankle joint.
7.38.179	The tarsals are the seven bones of the ankle.
7.38.180	The ankle transmits the weight of the body from the tibia and the fibula to the foot.
7.38.181	The metatarsals are the five bones of the foot.
7.38.182	The phalanges are the 14 bones of the toes.
7.38.183	Each toe consists of three phalanges, except for the big toe that has only two (Figure 38.15).
7.38.184	Variations exist in other species; for example, the horse’s metacarpals and metatarsals are oriented vertically and do not make contact with the substrate.
7.38.185	Bone, or osseous tissue, is a connective tissue that constitutes the endoskeleton.
7.38.186	It contains specialized cells and a matrix of mineral salts and collagen fibers.
7.38.187	The mineral salts primarily include hydroxyapatite, a mineral formed from calcium phosphate.
7.38.188	Calcification is the process of deposition of mineral salts on the collagen fiber matrix that crystallizes and hardens the tissue.
7.38.189	The process of calcification only occurs in the presence of collagen fibers.
7.38.190	The bones of the human skeleton are classified by their shape: long bones, short bones, flat bones, sutural bones, sesamoid bones, and irregular bones (Figure 38.16).
7.38.191	Shown are different types of bones: flat, irregular, long, short, and sesamoid.
7.38.192	Long bones are longer than they are wide and have a shaft and two ends.
7.38.193	The diaphysis, or central shaft, contains bone marrow in a marrow cavity.
7.38.194	The rounded ends, the epiphyses, are covered with articular cartilage and are filled with red bone marrow, which produces blood cells (Figure 38.17).
7.38.195	Most of the limb bones are long bones—for example, the femur, tibia, ulna, and radius.
7.38.196	Exceptions to this include the patella and the bones of the wrist and ankle.
7.38.197	The long bone is covered by articular cartilage at either end and contains bone marrow (shown in yellow in this illustration) in the marrow cavity.
7.38.198	Short bones, or cuboidal bones, are bones that are the same width and length, giving them a cube-like shape.
7.38.199	For example, the bones of the wrist (carpals) and ankle (tarsals) are short bones (Figure 38.16).
7.38.200	Flat bones are thin and relatively broad bones that are found where extensive protection of organs is required or where broad surfaces of muscle attachment are required.
7.38.201	Examples of flat bones are the sternum (breast bone), ribs, scapulae (shoulder blades), and the roof of the skull (Figure 38.16).
7.38.202	Irregular bones are bones with complex shapes.
7.38.203	These bones may have short, flat, notched, or ridged surfaces.
7.38.204	Examples of irregular bones are the vertebrae, hip bones, and several skull bones.
7.38.205	Sesamoid bones are small, flat bones and are shaped similarly to a sesame seed.
7.38.206	The patellae are sesamoid bones (Figure 38.18).
7.38.207	Sesamoid bones develop inside tendons and may be found near joints at the knees, hands, and feet.
7.38.208	The patella of the knee is an example of a sesamoid bone.
7.38.209	Sutural bones are small, flat, irregularly shaped bones.
7.38.210	They may be found between the flat bones of the skull.
7.38.211	They vary in number, shape, size, and position.
7.38.212	Bone Tissue Bones are considered organs because they contain various types of tissue, such as blood, connective tissue, nerves, and bone tissue.
7.38.213	Osteocytes, the living cells of bone tissue, form the mineral matrix of bones.
7.38.214	There are two types of bone tissue: compact and spongy.
7.38.215	Compact Bone Tissue Compact bone (or cortical bone) forms the hard external layer of all bones and surrounds the medullary cavity, or bone marrow.
7.38.216	It provides protection and strength to bones.
7.38.217	Compact bone tissue consists of units called osteons or Haversian systems.
7.38.218	Osteons are cylindrical structures that contain a mineral matrix and living osteocytes connected by canaliculi, which transport blood.
7.38.219	They are aligned parallel to the long axis of the bone.
7.38.220	Each osteon consists of lamellae, which are layers of compact matrix that surround a central canal called the Haversian canal.
7.38.221	The Haversian canal (osteonic canal) contains the bone’s blood vessels and nerve fibers (Figure 38.19).
7.38.222	Osteons in compact bone tissue are aligned in the same direction along lines of stress and help the bone resist bending or fracturing.
7.38.223	Therefore, compact bone tissue is prominent in areas of bone at which stresses are applied in only a few directions.
7.38.224	Spongy Bone Tissue
7.38.225	Whereas compact bone tissue forms
7.38.226	the outer layer of all bones, spongy bone or cancellous bone forms the inner layer of all bones.
7.38.227	Spongy bone tissue does not contain osteons that constitute compact bone tissue.
7.38.228	Instead, it consists of trabeculae, which are lamellae that are arranged as rods or plates.
7.38.229	Red bone marrow is found between the trabuculae.
7.38.230	Blood vessels within this tissue deliver nutrients to osteocytes and remove waste.
7.38.231	The red bone marrow of the femur and the interior of other large bones, such as the ileum, forms blood cells.
7.38.232	Spongy bone reduces the density of bone and allows the ends of long bones to compress as the result of stresses applied to the bone.
7.38.233	Spongy bone is prominent in areas of bones that are not heavily stressed or where stresses arrive from many directions.
7.38.234	The epiphyses of bones, such as the neck of the femur, are subject to stress from many directions.
7.38.235	Imagine laying a heavy framed picture flat on the floor.
7.38.236	You could hold up one side of the picture with a toothpick if the toothpick was perpendicular to the floor and the picture.
7.38.237	Now drill a hole and stick the toothpick into the wall to hang up the picture.
7.38.238	In this case, the function of the toothpick is to transmit the downward pressure of the picture to the wall.
7.38.239	The force on the picture is straight down to the floor, but the force on the toothpick is both the picture wire pulling down and the bottom of the hole in the wall pushing up.
7.38.240	The toothpick will break off right at the wall.
7.38.241	The neck of the femur is horizontal like the toothpick in the wall.
7.38.242	The weight of the body pushes it down near the joint, but the vertical diaphysis of the femur pushes it up at the other end.
7.38.243	The neck of the femur must be strong enough to transfer the downward force of the body weight horizontally to the vertical shaft of the femur (Figure 38.20).
7.38.244	Cell Types in Bones Bone consists of four types of cells: osteoblasts, osteoclasts, osteocytes, and osteoprogenitor cells.
7.38.245	Osteoblasts are bone cells that are responsible for bone formation.
7.38.246	Osteoblasts synthesize and secrete the organic part and inorganic part of the extracellular matrix of bone tissue, and collagen fibers.
7.38.247	Osteoblasts become trapped in these secretions and differentiate into less active osteocytes.
7.38.248	Osteoclasts are large bone cells with up to 50 nuclei.
7.38.249	They remove bone structure by releasing lysosomal enzymes and acids that dissolve the bony matrix.
7.38.250	These minerals, released from bones into the blood, help regulate calcium concentrations in body fluids.
7.38.251	Bone may also be resorbed for remodeling, if the applied stresses have changed.
7.38.252	Osteocytes are mature bone cells and are the main cells in bony connective tissue; these cells cannot divide.
7.38.253	Osteocytes maintain normal bone structure by recycling the mineral salts in the bony matrix.
7.38.254	Osteoprogenitor cells are squamous stem cells that divide to produce daughter cells that differentiate into osteoblasts.
7.38.255	Osteoprogenitor cells are important in the repair of fractures.
7.38.256	Development of Bone Ossification, or osteogenesis, is the process of bone formation by osteoblasts.
7.38.257	Ossification is distinct from the process of calcification; whereas calcification takes place during the ossification of bones, it can also occur in other tissues.
7.38.258	Ossification begins approximately six weeks after fertilization in an embryo.
7.38.259	Before this time, the embryonic skeleton consists entirely of fibrous membranes and hyaline cartilage.
7.38.260	The development of bone from fibrous membranes is called intramembranous ossification; development from hyaline cartilage is called endochondral ossification.
7.38.261	Bone growth continues until approximately age 25.
7.38.262	Bones can grow in thickness throughout life, but after age 25, ossification functions primarily in bone remodeling and repair.
7.38.263	Intramembranous Ossification Intramembranous ossification is the process of bone development from fibrous membranes.
7.38.264	It is involved in the formation of the flat bones of the skull, the mandible, and the clavicles.
7.38.265	Ossification begins as mesenchymal cells form a template of the future bone.
7.38.266	They then differentiate into osteoblasts at the ossification center.
7.38.267	Osteoblasts secrete the extracellular matrix and deposit calcium, which hardens the matrix.
7.38.268	The non-mineralized portion of the bone or osteoid continues to form around blood vessels, forming spongy bone.
7.38.269	Connective tissue in the matrix differentiates into red bone marrow in the fetus.
7.38.270	The spongy bone is remodeled into a thin layer of compact bone on the surface of the spongy bone.
7.38.271	Endochondral Ossification Endochondral ossification is the process of bone development from hyaline cartilage.
7.38.272	All of the bones of the body, except for the flat bones of the skull, mandible, and clavicles, are formed through endochondral ossification.
7.38.273	In long bones, chondrocytes form a template of the hyaline cartilage diaphysis.
7.38.274	Responding to complex developmental signals, the matrix begins to calcify.
7.38.275	This calcification prevents diffusion of nutrients into the matrix, resulting in chondrocytes dying and the opening up of cavities in the diaphysis cartilage.
7.38.276	Blood vessels invade the cavities, and osteoblasts and osteoclasts modify the calcified cartilage matrix into spongy bone.
7.38.277	Osteoclasts then break down some of the spongy bone to create a marrow, or medullary, cavity in the center of the diaphysis.
7.38.278	Dense, irregular connective tissue forms a sheath (periosteum) around the bones.
7.38.279	The periosteum assists in attaching the bone to surrounding tissues, tendons, and ligaments.
7.38.280	The bone continues to grow and elongate as the cartilage cells at the epiphyses divide.
7.38.281	In the last stage of prenatal bone development, the centers of the epiphyses begin to calcify.
7.38.282	Secondary ossification centers form in the epiphyses as blood vessels and osteoblasts enter these areas and convert hyaline cartilage into spongy bone.
7.38.283	Until adolescence, hyaline cartilage persists at the epiphyseal plate (growth plate), which is the region between the diaphysis and epiphysis that is responsible for the lengthwise growth of long bones (Figure 38.21).
7.38.284	Endochondral ossification is the process of bone development from hyaline cartilage.
7.38.285	The periosteum is the connective tissue on the outside of bone that acts as the interface between bone, blood vessels, tendons, and ligaments.
7.38.286	Growth of Bone Long bones continue to lengthen, potentially until adolescence, through the addition of bone tissue at the epiphyseal plate.
7.38.287	They also increase in width through appositional growth.
7.38.288	Lengthening of Long Bones Chondrocytes on the epiphyseal side of the epiphyseal plate divide; one cell remains undifferentiated near the epiphysis, and one cell moves toward the diaphysis.
7.38.289	The cells, which are pushed from the epiphysis, mature and are destroyed by calcification.
7.38.290	This process replaces cartilage with bone on the diaphyseal side of the plate, resulting in a lengthening of the bone.
7.38.291	Long bones stop growing at around the age of 18 in females and the age of 21 in males in a process called epiphyseal plate closure.
7.38.292	During this process, cartilage cells stop dividing and all of the cartilage is replaced by bone.
7.38.293	The epiphyseal plate fades, leaving a structure called the epiphyseal line or epiphyseal remnant, and the epiphysis and diaphysis fuse.
7.38.294	Thickening of Long Bones
7.38.295	Appositional growth is the increase in the diameter of bones by the addition of bony tissue at the surface of bones.
7.38.296	Osteoblasts at the bone surface secrete bone matrix, and osteoclasts on the inner surface break down bone.
7.38.297	The osteoblasts differentiate into osteocytes.
7.38.298	A balance between these two processes allows the bone to thicken without becoming too heavy.
7.38.299	Bone Remodeling and Repair Bone renewal continues after birth into adulthood.
7.38.300	Bone remodeling is the replacement of old bone tissue by new bone tissue.
7.38.301	It involves the processes of bone deposition by osteoblasts and bone resorption by osteoclasts.
7.38.302	Normal bone growth requires vitamins D, C, and A, plus minerals such as calcium, phosphorous, and magnesium.
7.38.303	Hormones such as parathyroid hormone, growth hormone, and calcitonin are also required for proper bone growth and maintenance.
7.38.304	Bone turnover rates are quite high, with five to seven percent of bone mass being recycled every week.
7.38.305	Differences in turnover rate exist in different areas of the skeleton and in different areas of a bone.
7.38.306	For example, the bone in the head of the femur may be fully replaced every six months, whereas the bone along the shaft is altered much more slowly.
7.38.307	Bone remodeling allows bones to adapt to stresses by becoming thicker and stronger when subjected to stress.
7.38.308	Bones that are not subject to normal stress, for example when a limb is in a cast, will begin to lose mass.
7.38.309	A fractured or broken bone undergoes repair through four stages: 1.
7.38.310	Blood vessels in the broken bone tear and hemorrhage, resulting in the formation of clotted blood, or a hematoma, at the site of the break.
7.38.311	The severed blood vessels at the broken ends of the bone are sealed by the clotting process, and bone cells that are deprived of nutrients begin to die.
7.38.312	2.
7.38.313	Within days of the fracture, capillaries grow into the hematoma, and phagocytic cells begin to clear away the dead cells.
7.38.314	Though fragments of the blood clot may remain, fibroblasts and osteoblasts enter the area and begin to reform bone.
7.38.315	Fibroblasts produce collagen fibers that connect the broken bone ends, and osteoblasts start to form spongy bone.
7.38.316	The repair tissue between the broken bone ends is called the fibrocartilaginous callus, as it is composed of both hyaline and fibrocartilage (Figure 38.22).
7.38.317	Some bone spicules may also appear at this point.
7.38.318	3.
7.38.319	The fibrocartilaginous callus is converted into a bony callus of spongy bone.
7.38.320	It takes about two months for the broken bone ends to be firmly joined together after the fracture.
7.38.321	This is similar to the endochondral formation of bone, as cartilage becomes ossified; osteoblasts, osteoclasts, and bone matrix are present.
7.38.322	4.
7.38.323	The bony callus is then remodelled by osteoclasts and osteoblasts, with excess material on the exterior of the bone and within the medullary cavity being removed.
7.38.324	Compact bone is added to create bone tissue that is similar to the original, unbroken bone.
7.38.325	This remodeling can take many months, and the bone may remain uneven for years.
7.38.326	After this bone is set, a callus will knit the two ends together.
7.38.327	(credit: Bill Rhodes)
7.38.328	The point at which two or more bones meet is called a joint, or articulation.
7.38.329	Joints are responsible for movement, such as the movement of limbs, and stability, such as the stability found in the bones of the skull.
7.38.330	Classification of Joints on the Basis of Structure
7.38.331	There are two ways to classify joints: on the basis of their structure or on the basis of their function.
7.38.332	The structural classification divides joints into bony, fibrous, cartilaginous, and synovial joints depending on the material composing the joint and the presence or absence of a cavity in the joint.
7.38.333	Fibrous Joints
7.38.334	The bones of fibrous joints are held together by fibrous connective tissue.
7.38.335	There is no cavity, or space, present between the bones and so most fibrous joints do not move at all, or are only capable of minor movements.
7.38.336	There are three types of fibrous joints: sutures, syndesmoses, and gomphoses.
7.38.337	Sutures are found only in the skull and possess short fibers of connective tissue that hold the skull bones tightly in place (Figure 38.23).
7.38.338	Sutures are fibrous joints found only in the skull.
7.38.339	Syndesmoses are joints in which the bones are connected by a band of connective tissue, allowing for more movement than in a suture.
7.38.340	An example of a syndesmosis is the joint of the tibia and fibula in the ankle.
7.38.341	The amount of movement in these types of joints is determined by the length of the connective tissue fibers.
7.38.342	Gomphoses occur between teeth and their sockets; the term refers to the way the tooth fits into the socket like a peg (Figure 38.24).
7.38.343	The tooth is connected to the socket by a connective tissue referred to as the periodontal ligament.
7.38.344	Gomphoses are fibrous joints between the teeth and their sockets.
7.38.345	(credit: modification of work by Gray's Anatomy)
7.38.346	Cartilaginous Joints Cartilaginous joints are joints in which the bones are connected by cartilage.
7.38.347	There are two types of cartilaginous joints: synchondroses and symphyses.
7.38.348	In a synchondrosis, the bones are joined by hyaline cartilage.
7.38.349	Synchondroses are found in the epiphyseal plates of growing bones in children.
7.38.350	In symphyses, hyaline cartilage covers the end of the bone but the connection between bones occurs through fibrocartilage.
7.38.351	Symphyses are found at the joints between vertebrae.
7.38.352	Either type of cartilaginous joint allows for very little movement.
7.38.353	Synovial Joints Synovial joints are the only joints that have a space between the adjoining bones (Figure 38.25).
7.38.354	This space is referred to as the synovial (or joint) cavity and is filled with synovial fluid.
7.38.355	Synovial fluid lubricates the joint, reducing friction between the bones and allowing for greater movement.
7.38.356	The ends of the bones are covered with articular cartilage, a hyaline cartilage, and the entire joint is surrounded by an articular capsule composed of connective tissue that allows movement of the joint while resisting dislocation.
7.38.357	Articular capsules may also possess ligaments that hold the bones together.
7.38.358	Synovial joints are capable of the greatest movement of the three structural joint types; however, the more mobile a joint, the weaker the joint.
7.38.359	Knees, elbows, and shoulders are examples of synovial joints.
7.38.360	Classification of Joints on the Basis of Function
7.38.361	The functional classification divides joints into three categories: synarthroses, amphiarthroses, and diarthroses.
7.38.362	A synarthrosis is a joint that is immovable.
7.38.363	This includes sutures, gomphoses, and synchondroses.
7.38.364	Amphiarthroses are joints that allow slight movement, including syndesmoses and symphyses.
7.38.365	Diarthroses are joints that allow for free movement of the joint, as in synovial joints.
7.38.366	Movement at Synovial Joints
7.38.367	The wide range of movement allowed by synovial joints produces different types of movements.
7.38.368	The movement of synovial joints can be classified as one of four different types: gliding, angular, rotational, or special movement.
7.38.369	Gliding Movement Gliding movements occur as relatively flat bone surfaces move past each other.
7.38.370	Gliding movements produce very little rotation or angular movement of the bones.
7.38.371	The joints of the carpal and tarsal bones are examples of joints that produce gliding movements.
7.38.372	Angular Movement Angular movements are produced when the angle between the bones of a joint changes.
7.38.373	There are several different types of angular movements, including flexion, extension, hyperextension, abduction, adduction, and circumduction.
7.38.374	Flexion, or bending, occurs when the angle between the bones decreases.
7.38.375	Moving the forearm upward at the elbow or moving the wrist to move the hand toward the forearm are examples of flexion.
7.38.376	Extension is the opposite of flexion in that the angle between the bones of a joint increases.
7.38.377	Straightening a limb after flexion is an example of extension.
7.38.378	Extension past the regular anatomical position is referred to as hyperextension.
7.38.379	This includes moving the neck back to look upward, or bending the wrist so that the hand moves away from the forearm.
7.38.380	Abduction occurs when a bone moves away from the midline of the body.
7.38.381	Examples of abduction are moving the arms or legs laterally to lift them straight out to the side.
7.38.382	Adduction is the movement of a bone toward the midline of the body.
7.38.383	Movement of the limbs inward after abduction is an example of adduction.
7.38.384	Circumduction is the movement of a limb in a circular motion, as in moving the arm in a circular motion.
7.38.385	Rotational Movement Rotational movement is the movement of a bone as it rotates around its longitudinal axis.
7.38.386	Rotation can be toward the midline of the body, which is referred to as medial rotation, or away from the midline of the body, which is referred to as lateral rotation.
7.38.387	Movement of the head from side to side is an example of rotation.
7.38.388	Special Movements
7.38.389	Some movements that cannot be classified as gliding, angular, or rotational are called special movements.
7.38.390	Inversion involves the soles of the feet moving inward, toward the midline of the body.
7.38.391	Eversion is the opposite of inversion, movement of the sole of the foot outward, away from the midline of the body.
7.38.392	Protraction is the anterior movement of a bone in the horizontal plane.
7.38.393	Retraction occurs as a joint moves back into position after protraction.
7.38.394	Protraction and retraction can be seen in the movement of the mandible as the jaw is thrust outwards and then back inwards.
7.38.395	Elevation is the movement of a bone upward, such as when the shoulders are shrugged, lifting the scapulae.
7.38.396	Depression is the opposite of elevation—movement downward of a bone, such as after the shoulders are shrugged and the scapulae return to their normal position from an elevated position.
7.38.397	Dorsiflexion is a bending at the ankle such that the toes are lifted toward the knee.
7.38.398	Plantar flexion is a bending at the ankle when the heel is lifted, such as when standing on the toes.
7.38.399	Supination is the movement of the radius and ulna bones of the forearm so that the palm faces forward.
7.38.400	Pronation is the opposite movement, in which the palm faces backward.
7.38.401	Opposition is the movement of the thumb toward the fingers of the same hand, making it possible to grasp and hold objects.
7.38.402	Types of Synovial Joints Synovial joints are further classified into six different categories on the basis of the shape and structure of the joint.
7.38.403	The shape of the joint affects the type of movement permitted by the joint (Figure 38.26).
7.38.404	These joints can be described as planar, hinge, pivot, condyloid, saddle, or ball-and-socket joints.
7.38.405	Different types of joints allow different types of movement.
7.38.406	Planar, hinge, pivot, condyloid, saddle, and ball-and-socket are all types of synovial joints.
7.38.407	Planar Joints Planar joints have bones with articulating surfaces that are flat or slightly curved faces.
7.38.408	These joints allow for gliding movements, and so the joints are sometimes referred to as gliding joints.
7.38.409	The range of motion is limited in these joints and does not involve rotation.
7.38.410	Planar joints are found in the carpal bones in the hand and the tarsal bones of the foot, as well as between vertebrae (Figure 38.27).
7.38.411	The joints of the carpal bones in the wrist are examples of planar joints.
7.38.412	(credit: modification of work by Brian C. Goss) Hinge Joints
7.38.413	In hinge joints, the slightly rounded end of one bone fits into the slightly hollow end of the other bone.
7.38.414	In this way, one bone moves while the other remains stationary, like the hinge of a door.
7.38.415	The elbow is an example of a hinge joint.
7.38.416	The knee is sometimes classified as a modified hinge joint (Figure 38.28).
7.38.417	The elbow joint, where the radius articulates with the humerus, is an example of a hinge joint.
7.38.418	(credit: modification of work by Brian C. Goss)
7.38.419	Pivot Joints Pivot joints consist of the rounded end of one bone fitting into a ring formed by the other bone.
7.38.420	This structure allows rotational movement, as the rounded bone moves around its own axis.
7.38.421	An example of a pivot joint is the joint of the first and second vertebrae of the neck that allows the head to move back and forth (Figure 38.29).
7.38.422	The joint of the wrist that allows the palm of the hand to be turned up and down is also a pivot joint.
7.38.423	The joint in the neck that allows the head to move back and forth is an example of a pivot joint.
7.38.424	Condyloid Joints Condyloid joints consist of an oval-shaped end of one bone fitting into a similarly oval-shaped hollow of another bone (Figure 38.30).
7.38.425	This is also sometimes called an ellipsoidal joint.
7.38.426	This type of joint allows angular movement along two axes, as seen in the joints of the wrist and fingers, which can move both side to side and up and down.
7.38.427	The metacarpophalangeal joints in the finger are examples of condyloid joints.
7.38.428	(credit: modification of work by Gray's Anatomy)
7.38.429	Saddle Joints Saddle joints are so named because the ends of each bone resemble a saddle, with concave and convex portions that fit together.
7.38.430	Saddle joints allow angular movements similar to condyloid joints but with a greater range of motion.
7.38.431	An example of a saddle joint is the thumb joint, which can move back and forth and up and down, but more freely than the wrist or fingers (Figure 38.31).
7.38.432	The carpometacarpal joints in the thumb are examples of saddle joints.
7.38.433	(credit: modification of work by Brian C. Goss)
7.38.434	Ball-and-Socket Joints Ball-and-socket joints possess a rounded, ball-like end of one bone fitting into a cuplike socket of another bone.
7.38.435	This organization allows the greatest range of motion, as all movement types are possible in all directions.
7.38.436	Examples of ball-and- socket joints are the shoulder and hip joints (Figure 38.32).
7.38.437	The shoulder joint is an example of a ball-and-socket joint.
7.38.438	Muscle cells are specialized for contraction.
7.38.439	Muscles allow for motions such as walking, and they also facilitate bodily processes such as respiration and digestion.
7.38.440	The body contains three types of muscle tissue: skeletal muscle, cardiac muscle, and smooth muscle (Figure 38.33).
7.38.441	The body contains three types of muscle tissue: skeletal muscle, smooth muscle, and cardiac muscle, visualized here using light microscopy.
7.38.442	Smooth muscle cells are short, tapered at each end, and have only one plump nucleus in each.
7.38.443	Cardiac muscle cells are branched and striated, but short.
7.38.444	The cytoplasm may branch, and they have one nucleus in the center of the cell.
7.38.445	(credit: modification of work by NCI, NIH; scale-bar data from Matt Russell)
7.38.446	Skeletal muscle tissue forms skeletal muscles, which attach to bones or skin and control locomotion and any movement that can be consciously controlled.
7.38.447	Because it can be controlled by thought, skeletal muscle is also called voluntary muscle.
7.38.448	Skeletal muscles are long and cylindrical in appearance; when viewed under a microscope, skeletal muscle tissue has a striped or striated appearance.
7.38.449	The striations are caused by the regular arrangement of contractile proteins (actin and myosin).
7.38.450	Actin is a globular contractile protein that interacts with myosin for muscle contraction.
7.38.451	Skeletal muscle also has multiple nuclei present in a single cell.
7.38.452	Smooth muscle tissue occurs in the walls of hollow organs such as the intestines, stomach, and urinary bladder, and around passages such as the respiratory tract and blood vessels.
7.38.453	Smooth muscle has no striations, is not under voluntary control, has only one nucleus per cell, is tapered at both ends, and is called involuntary muscle.
7.38.454	Cardiac muscle tissue is only found in the heart, and cardiac contractions pump blood throughout the body and maintain blood pressure.
7.38.455	Like skeletal muscle, cardiac muscle is striated, but unlike skeletal muscle, cardiac muscle cannot be consciously controlled and is called involuntary muscle.
7.38.456	It has one nucleus per cell, is branched, and is distinguished by the presence of intercalated disks.
7.38.457	Skeletal Muscle Fiber Structure
7.38.458	Each skeletal muscle fiber is a skeletal muscle cell.
7.38.459	These cells are incredibly large, with diameters of up to 100 μm and lengths of up to 30 cm.
7.38.460	The plasma membrane of a skeletal muscle fiber is called the sarcolemma.
7.38.461	The sarcolemma is the site of action potential conduction, which triggers muscle contraction.
7.38.462	Within each muscle fiber are myofibrils—long cylindrical structures that lie parallel to the muscle fiber.
7.38.463	Myofibrils run the entire length of the muscle fiber, and because they are only approximately 1.2 μm in diameter, hundreds to thousands can be found inside one muscle fiber.
7.38.464	They attach to the sarcolemma at their ends, so that as myofibrils shorten, the entire muscle cell contracts (Figure 38.34).
7.38.465	A skeletal muscle cell is surrounded by a plasma membrane called the sarcolemma with a cytoplasm called the sarcoplasm.
7.38.466	A muscle fiber is composed of many fibrils, packaged into orderly units.
7.38.467	The striated appearance of skeletal muscle tissue is a result of repeating bands of the proteins actin and myosin that are present along the length of myofibrils.
7.38.468	Dark A bands and light I bands repeat along myofibrils, and the alignment of myofibrils in the cell causes the entire cell to appear striated or banded.
7.38.469	Each I band has a dense line running vertically through the middle called a Z disc or Z line.
7.38.470	The Z discs mark the border of units called sarcomeres, which are the functional units of skeletal muscle.
7.38.471	One sarcomere is the space between two consecutive Z discs and contains one entire A band and two halves of an I band, one on either side of the A band.
7.38.472	A myofibril is composed of many sarcomeres running along its length, and as the sarcomeres individually contract, the myofibrils and muscle cells shorten (Figure 38.35).
7.38.473	A sarcomere is the region from one Z line to the next Z line.
7.38.474	Many sarcomeres are present in a myofibril, resulting in the striation pattern characteristic of skeletal muscle.
7.38.475	Myofibrils are composed of smaller structures called myofilaments.
7.38.476	There are two main types of filaments: thick filaments and thin filaments; each has different compositions and locations.
7.38.477	Thick filaments occur only in the A band of a myofibril.
7.38.478	Thin filaments attach to a protein in the Z disc called alpha-actinin and occur across the entire length of the I band and partway into the A band.
7.38.479	The region at which thick and thin filaments overlap has a dense appearance, as there is little space between the filaments.
7.38.480	Thin filaments do not extend all the way into the A bands, leaving a central region of the A band that only contains thick filaments.
7.38.481	This central region of the A band looks slightly lighter than the rest of the A band and is called the H zone.
7.38.482	The middle of the H zone has a vertical line called the M line, at which accessory proteins hold together thick filaments.
7.38.483	Both the Z disc and the M line hold myofilaments in place to maintain the structural arrangement and layering of the myofibril.
7.38.484	Myofibrils are connected to each other by intermediate, or desmin, filaments that attach to the Z disc.
7.38.485	Thick and thin filaments are themselves composed of proteins.
7.38.486	Thick filaments are composed of the protein myosin.
7.38.487	The tail of a myosin molecule connects with other myosin molecules to form the central region of a thick filament near the M line, whereas the heads align on either side of the thick filament where the thin filaments overlap.
7.38.488	The primary component of thin filaments is the actin protein.
7.38.489	Two other components of the thin filament are tropomyosin and troponin.
7.38.490	Actin has binding sites for myosin attachment.
7.38.491	Strands of tropomyosin block the binding sites and prevent actin–myosin interactions when the muscles are at rest.
7.38.492	Troponin consists of three globular subunits.
7.38.493	One subunit binds to tropomyosin, one subunit binds to actin, and one subunit binds Ca2+ ions.
7.38.494	Sliding Filament Model of Contraction For a muscle cell to contract, the sarcomere must shorten.
7.38.495	However, thick and thin filaments—the components of sarcomeres—do not shorten.
7.38.496	Instead, they slide by one another, causing the sarcomere to shorten while the filaments remain the same length.
7.38.497	The sliding filament theory of muscle contraction was developed to fit the differences observed in the named bands on the sarcomere at different degrees of muscle contraction and relaxation.
7.38.498	The mechanism of contraction is the binding of myosin to actin, forming cross-bridges that generate filament movement (Figure 38.36).
7.38.499	When (a) a sarcomere (b) contracts, the Z lines move closer together and the I band gets smaller.
7.38.500	The A band stays the same width and, at full contraction, the thin filaments overlap.
7.38.501	When a sarcomere shortens, some regions shorten whereas others stay the same length.
7.38.502	A sarcomere is defined as the distance between two consecutive Z discs or Z lines; when a muscle contracts, the distance between the Z discs is reduced.
7.38.503	The H zone—the central region of the A zone—contains only thick filaments and is shortened during contraction.
7.38.504	The I band contains only thin filaments and also shortens.
7.38.505	The A band does not shorten
7.38.506	—it remains the same length
7.38.507	—
7.38.508	but A bands of different sarcomeres move closer together during contraction, eventually disappearing.
7.38.509	Thin filaments are pulled by the thick filaments toward the center of the sarcomere until the Z discs approach the thick filaments.
7.38.510	The zone of overlap, in which thin filaments and thick filaments occupy the same area, increases as the thin filaments move inward.
7.38.511	ATP and Muscle Contraction
7.38.512	The motion of muscle shortening occurs as myosin heads bind to actin and pull the actin inwards.
7.38.513	This action requires energy, which is provided by ATP.
7.38.514	Myosin binds to actin at a binding site on the globular actin protein.
7.38.515	Myosin has another binding site for ATP at which enzymatic activity hydrolyzes ATP to ADP, releasing an inorganic phosphate molecule and energy.
7.38.516	ATP binding causes myosin to release actin, allowing actin and myosin to detach from each other.
7.38.517	After this happens, the newly bound ATP is converted to ADP and inorganic phosphate, Pi.
7.38.518	The enzyme at the binding site on myosin is called ATPase.
7.38.519	The energy released during ATP hydrolysis changes the angle of the myosin head into a “cocked” position.
7.38.520	The myosin head is then in a position for further movement, possessing potential energy, but ADP and Pi are still attached.
7.38.521	If actin binding sites are covered and unavailable, the myosin will remain in the high energy configuration with ATP hydrolyzed, but still attached.
7.38.522	If the actin binding sites are uncovered, a cross-bridge will form; that is, the myosin head spans the distance between the actin and myosin molecules.
7.38.523	Pi is then released, allowing myosin to expend the stored energy as a conformational change.
7.38.524	The myosin head moves toward the M line, pulling the actin along with it.
7.38.525	As the actin is pulled, the filaments move approximately 10 nm toward the M line.
7.38.526	This movement is called the power stroke, as it is the step at which force is produced.
7.38.527	As the actin is pulled toward the M line, the sarcomere shortens and the muscle contracts.
7.38.528	When the myosin head is “cocked,” it contains energy and is in a high-energy configuration.
7.38.529	This energy is expended as the myosin head moves through the power stroke; at the end of the power stroke, the myosin head is in a low-energy position.
7.38.530	After the power stroke, ADP is released; however, the cross-bridge formed is still in place, and actin and myosin are bound together.
7.38.531	ATP can then attach to myosin, which allows the cross-bridge cycle to start again and further muscle contraction can occur (Figure 38.37).
7.38.532	Regulatory Proteins
7.38.533	When a muscle is in a resting state, actin and myosin are separated.
7.38.534	To keep actin from binding to the active site on myosin, regulatory proteins block the molecular binding sites.
7.38.535	Tropomyosin blocks myosin binding sites on actin molecules, preventing cross-bridge formation and preventing contraction in a muscle without nervous input.
7.38.536	Troponin binds to tropomyosin and helps to position it on the actin molecule; it also binds calcium ions.
7.38.537	To enable a muscle contraction, tropomyosin must change conformation, uncovering the myosin-binding site on an actin molecule and allowing cross-bridge formation.
7.38.538	This can only happen in the presence of calcium, which is kept at extremely low concentrations in the sarcoplasm.
7.38.539	If present, calcium ions bind to troponin, causing conformational changes in troponin that allow tropomyosin to move away from the myosin binding sites on actin.
7.38.540	Once the tropomyosin is removed, a cross- bridge can form between actin and myosin, triggering contraction.
7.38.541	Cross-bridge cycling continues until Ca2+ ions and ATP are no longer available and tropomyosin again covers the binding sites on actin.
7.38.542	Excitation–Contraction Coupling Excitation–contraction coupling is the link (transduction) between the action potential generated in the sarcolemma and the start of a muscle contraction.
7.38.543	The trigger for calcium release from the sarcoplasmic reticulum into the sarcoplasm is a neural signal.
7.38.544	Each skeletal muscle fiber is controlled by a motor neuron, which conducts signals from the brain or spinal cord to the muscle.
7.38.545	The area of the sarcolemma on the muscle fiber that interacts with the neuron is called the motor end plate.
7.38.546	The end of the neuron’s axon is called the synaptic terminal, and it does not actually contact the motor end plate.
7.38.547	A small space called the synaptic cleft separates the synaptic terminal from the motor end plate.
7.38.548	Electrical signals travel along the neuron’s axon, which branches through the muscle and connects to individual muscle fibers at a neuromuscular junction.
7.38.549	The ability of cells to communicate electrically requires that the cells expend energy to create an electrical gradient across their cell membranes.
7.38.550	This charge gradient is carried by ions, which are differentially distributed across the membrane.
7.38.551	Each ion exerts an electrical influence and a concentration influence.
7.38.552	Just as milk will eventually mix with coffee without the need to stir, ions also distribute themselves evenly, if they are permitted to do so.
7.38.553	In this case, they are not permitted to return to an evenly mixed state.
7.38.554	The sodium–potassium ATPase uses cellular energy to move K+ ions inside the cell and Na+ ions outside.
7.38.555	This alone accumulates a small electrical charge, but a big concentration gradient.
7.38.556	There is lots of K+ in the cell and lots of Na+ outside the cell.
7.38.557	Potassium is able to leave the cell through K+ channels that are open 90% of the time, and it does.
7.38.558	However, Na+ channels are rarely open, so Na+ remains outside the cell.
7.38.559	When K+ leaves the cell, obeying its concentration gradient, that effectively leaves a negative charge behind.
7.38.560	So at rest, there is a large concentration gradient for Na+ to enter the cell, and there is an accumulation of negative charges left behind in the cell.
7.38.561	This is the resting membrane potential.
7.38.562	Potential in this context means a separation of electrical charge that is capable of doing work.
7.38.563	It is measured in volts, just like a battery.
7.38.564	However, the transmembrane potential is considerably smaller (0.07 V); therefore, the small value is expressed as millivolts (mV) or 70 mV. Because the inside of a cell is negative compared with the outside, a minus sign signifies the excess of negative charges inside the cell, −70 mV.
7.38.565	If an event changes the permeability of the membrane to Na+ ions, they will enter the cell.
7.38.566	That will change the voltage.
7.38.567	This is an electrical event, called an action potential, that can be used as a cellular signal.
7.38.568	Communication occurs between nerves and muscles through neurotransmitters.
7.38.569	Neuron action potentials cause the release of neurotransmitters from the synaptic terminal into the synaptic cleft, where they can then diffuse across the synaptic cleft and bind to a receptor molecule on the motor end plate.
7.38.570	The motor end plate possesses junctional folds—folds in the sarcolemma that create a large surface area for the neurotransmitter to bind to receptors.
7.38.571	The receptors are actually sodium channels that open to allow the passage of Na+ into the cell when they receive neurotransmitter signal.
7.38.572	Acetylcholine (ACh) is a neurotransmitter released by motor neurons that binds to receptors in the motor end plate.
7.38.573	Neurotransmitter release occurs when an action potential travels down the motor neuron’s axon, resulting in altered permeability of the synaptic terminal membrane and an influx of calcium.
7.38.574	The Ca2+ ions allow synaptic vesicles to move to and bind with the presynaptic membrane (on the neuron), and release neurotransmitter from the vesicles into the synaptic cleft.
7.38.575	Once released by the synaptic terminal, ACh diffuses across the synaptic cleft to the motor end plate, where it binds with ACh receptors.
7.38.576	As a neurotransmitter binds, these ion channels open, and Na+ ions cross the membrane into the muscle cell.
7.38.577	This reduces the voltage difference between the inside and outside of the cell, which is called depolarization.
7.38.578	As ACh binds at the motor end plate, this depolarization is called an end-plate potential.
7.38.579	The depolarization then spreads along the sarcolemma, creating an action potential as sodium channels adjacent to the initial depolarization site sense the change in voltage and open.
7.38.580	The action potential moves across the entire cell, creating a wave of depolarization.
7.38.581	ACh is broken down by the enzyme acetylcholinesterase (AChE) into acetyl and choline.
7.38.582	AChE resides in the synaptic cleft, breaking down ACh so that it does not remain bound to ACh receptors, which would cause unwanted extended muscle contraction (Figure 38.38).
7.38.583	After depolarization, the membrane returns to its resting state.
7.38.584	This is called repolarization, during which voltage- gated sodium channels close.
7.38.585	Potassium channels continue at 90% conductance.
7.38.586	Because the plasma membrane sodium–potassium ATPase always transports ions, the resting state (negatively charged inside relative to the outside) is restored.
7.38.587	The period immediately following the transmission of an impulse in a nerve or muscle, in which a neuron or muscle cell regains its ability to transmit another impulse, is called the refractory period.
7.38.588	During the refractory period, the membrane cannot generate another action potential. .
7.38.589	The refractory period allows the voltage-sensitive ion channels to return to their resting configurations.
7.38.590	The sodium potassium ATPase continually moves Na+ back out of the cell and K+ back into the cell, and the K+ leaks out leaving negative charge behind.
7.38.591	Very quickly, the membrane repolarizes, so that it can again be depolarized.
7.38.592	Control of Muscle Tension Neural control initiates the formation of actin–myosin cross-bridges, leading to the sarcomere shortening involved in muscle contraction.
7.38.593	These contractions extend from the muscle fiber through connective tissue to pull on bones, causing skeletal movement.
7.38.594	The pull exerted by a muscle is called tension, and the amount of force created by this tension can vary.
7.38.595	This enables the same muscles to move very light objects and very heavy objects.
7.38.596	In individual muscle fibers, the amount of tension produced depends on the cross-sectional area of the muscle fiber and the frequency of neural stimulation.
7.38.597	The number of cross-bridges formed between actin and myosin determine the amount of tension that a muscle fiber can produce.
7.38.598	Cross-bridges can only form where thick and thin filaments overlap, allowing myosin to bind to actin.
7.38.599	If more cross-bridges are formed, more myosin will pull on actin, and more tension will be produced.
7.38.600	The ideal length of a sarcomere during production of maximal tension occurs when thick and thin filaments overlap to the greatest degree.
7.38.601	If a sarcomere at rest is stretched past an ideal resting length, thick and thin filaments do not overlap to the greatest degree, and fewer cross-bridges can form.
7.38.602	This results in fewer myosin heads pulling on actin, and less tension is produced.
7.38.603	As a sarcomere is shortened, the zone of overlap is reduced as the thin filaments reach the H zone, which is composed of myosin tails.
7.38.604	Because it is myosin heads that form cross-bridges, actin will not bind to myosin in this zone, reducing the tension produced by this myofiber.
7.38.605	If the sarcomere is shortened even more, thin filaments begin to overlap with each other—reducing cross-bridge formation even further, and producing even less tension.
7.38.606	Conversely, if the sarcomere is stretched to the point at which thick and thin filaments do not overlap at all, no cross-bridges are formed and no tension is produced.
7.38.607	This amount of stretching does not usually occur because accessory proteins, internal sensory nerves, and connective tissue oppose extreme stretching.
7.38.608	The primary variable determining force production is the number of myofibers within the muscle that receive an action potential from the neuron that controls that fiber.
7.38.609	When using the biceps to pick up a pencil, the motor cortex of the brain only signals a few neurons of the biceps, and only a few myofibers respond.
7.38.610	In vertebrates, each myofiber responds fully if stimulated.
7.38.611	When picking up a piano, the motor cortex signals all of the neurons in the biceps and every myofiber participates.
7.38.612	This is close to the maximum force the muscle can produce.
7.38.613	As mentioned above, increasing the frequency of action potentials (the number of signals per second) can increase the force a bit more, because the tropomyosin is flooded with calcium.
7.39.0	 Lungs, which appear as nearly transparent tissue surrounding the heart in this X-ray of a dog (left), are the central organs of the respiratory system.
7.39.1	The left lung is smaller than the right lung to accommodate space for the heart.
7.39.2	A dog’s nose (right) has a slit on the side of each nostril.
7.39.3	When tracking a scent, the slits open, blocking the front of the nostrils.
7.39.4	This allows the dog to exhale though the now-open area on the side of the nostrils without losing the scent that is being followed.
7.39.5	(credit a: modification of work by Geoff Stearns; credit b: modification of work by Cory Zanker)
7.39.6	Introduction Breathing is an involuntary event.
7.39.7	How often a breath is taken and how much air is inhaled or exhaled are tightly regulated by the respiratory center in the brain.
7.39.8	Humans, when they aren’t exerting themselves, breathe approximately 15 times per minute on average.
7.39.9	Canines, like the dog in Figure 39.1, have a respiratory rate of about 15–30 breaths per minute.
7.39.10	With every inhalation, air fills the lungs, and with every exhalation, air rushes back out.
7.39.11	That air is doing more than just inflating and deflating the lungs in the chest cavity.
7.39.12	The air contains oxygen that crosses the lung tissue, enters the bloodstream, and travels to organs and tissues.
7.39.13	Oxygen (O2) enters the cells where it is used for metabolic reactions that produce ATP, a high-energy compound.
7.39.14	At the same time, these reactions release carbon dioxide (CO2) as a by-product.
7.39.15	CO2 is toxic and must be eliminated.
7.39.16	Carbon dioxide exits the cells, enters the bloodstream, travels back to the lungs, and is expired out of the body during exhalation.
7.39.17	The primary function of the respiratory system is to deliver oxygen to the cells of the body’s tissues and remove carbon dioxide, a cell waste product.
7.39.18	The main structures of the human respiratory system are the nasal cavity, the trachea, and lungs.
7.39.19	All aerobic organisms require oxygen to carry out their metabolic functions.
7.39.20	Along the evolutionary tree, different organisms have devised different means of obtaining oxygen from the surrounding atmosphere.
7.39.21	The environment in which the animal lives greatly determines how an animal respires.
7.39.22	The complexity of the respiratory system is correlated with the size of the organism.
7.39.23	As animal size increases, diffusion distances increase and the ratio of surface area to volume drops.
7.39.24	In unicellular organisms, diffusion across the cell membrane is sufficient for supplying oxygen to the cell (Figure 39.2).
7.39.25	Diffusion is a slow, passive transport process.
7.39.26	In order for diffusion to be a feasible means of providing oxygen to the cell, the rate of oxygen uptake must match the rate of diffusion across the membrane.
7.39.27	In other words, if the cell were very large or thick, diffusion would not be able to provide oxygen quickly enough to the inside of the cell.
7.39.28	Therefore, dependence on diffusion as a means of obtaining oxygen and removing carbon dioxide remains feasible only for small organisms or those with highly-flattened bodies, such as many flatworms (Platyhelminthes).
7.39.29	Larger organisms had to evolve specialized respiratory tissues, such as gills, lungs, and respiratory passages accompanied by complex circulatory systems, to transport oxygen throughout their entire body.
7.39.30	he cell of the unicellular algae Ventricaria ventricosa is one of the largest known, reaching one to five centimeters in diameter.
7.39.31	Like all single-celled organisms, V. ventricosa exchanges gases across the cell membrane.
7.39.32	Direct Diffusion For small multicellular organisms, diffusion across the outer membrane is sufficient to meet their oxygen needs.
7.39.33	Gas exchange by direct diffusion across surface membranes is efficient for organisms less than 1 mm in diameter.
7.39.34	In simple organisms, such as cnidarians and flatworms, every cell in the body is close to the external environment.
