7.39.35	Their cells are kept moist and gases diffuse quickly via direct diffusion.
7.39.36	Flatworms are small, literally flat worms, which ‘breathe’ through diffusion across the outer membrane (Figure 39.3).
7.39.37	The flat shape of these organisms increases the surface area for diffusion, ensuring that each cell within the body is close to the outer membrane surface and has access to oxygen.
7.39.38	If the flatworm had a cylindrical body, then the cells in the center would not be able to get oxygen.
7.39.39	This flatworm’s process of respiration works by diffusion across the outer membrane.
7.39.40	(credit: Stephen Childs)
7.39.41	Skin and Gills Earthworms and amphibians use their skin (integument) as a respiratory organ.
7.39.42	A dense network of capillaries lies just below the skin and facilitates gas exchange between the external environment and the circulatory system.
7.39.43	The respiratory surface must be kept moist in order for the gases to dissolve and diffuse across cell membranes.
7.39.44	Organisms that live in water need to obtain oxygen from the water.
7.39.45	Oxygen dissolves in water but at a lower concentration than in the atmosphere.
7.39.46	The atmosphere has roughly 21 percent oxygen.
7.39.47	In water, the oxygen concentration is much smaller than that.
7.39.48	Fish and many other aquatic organisms have evolved gills to take up the dissolved oxygen from water (Figure 39.4).
7.39.49	Gills are thin tissue filaments that are highly branched and folded.
7.39.50	When water passes over the gills, the dissolved oxygen in water rapidly diffuses across the gills into the bloodstream.
7.39.51	The circulatory system can then carry the oxygenated blood to the other parts of the body.
7.39.52	In animals that contain coelomic fluid instead of blood, oxygen diffuses across the gill surfaces into the coelomic fluid.
7.39.53	Gills are found in mollusks, annelids, and crustaceans.
7.39.54	This common carp, like many other aquatic organisms, has gills that allow it to obtain oxygen from water.
7.39.55	(credit: "Guitardude012"/Wikimedia Commons)
7.39.56	The folded surfaces of the gills provide a large surface area to ensure that the fish gets sufficient oxygen.
7.39.57	Diffusion is a process in which material travels from regions of high concentration to low concentration until equilibrium is reached.
7.39.58	In this case, blood with a low concentration of oxygen molecules circulates through the gills.
7.39.59	The concentration of oxygen molecules in water is higher than the concentration of oxygen molecules in gills.
7.39.60	As a result, oxygen molecules diffuse from water (high concentration) to blood (low concentration), as shown in Figure 39.5.
7.39.61	Similarly, carbon dioxide molecules in the blood diffuse from the blood (high concentration) to water (low concentration).
7.39.62	As water flows over the gills, oxygen is transferred to blood via the veins.
7.39.63	(credit "fish": modification of work by Duane Raver, NOAA)
7.39.64	Tracheal Systems Insect respiration is independent of its circulatory system; therefore, the blood does not play a direct role in oxygen transport.
7.39.65	Insects have a highly specialized type of respiratory system called the tracheal system, which consists of a network of small tubes that carries oxygen to the entire body.
7.39.66	The tracheal system is the most direct and efficient respiratory system in active animals.
7.39.67	The tubes in the tracheal system are made of a polymeric material called chitin.
7.39.68	Insect bodies have openings, called spiracles, along the thorax and abdomen.
7.39.69	These openings connect to the tubular network, allowing oxygen to pass into the body (Figure 39.6) and regulating the diffusion of CO2 and water vapor.
7.39.70	Air enters and leaves the tracheal system through the spiracles.
7.39.71	Some insects can ventilate the tracheal system with body movements.
7.39.72	Insects perform respiration via a tracheal system.
7.39.73	Mammalian Systems
7.39.74	In mammals, pulmonary ventilation occurs via inhalation (breathing).
7.39.75	During inhalation, air enters the body through the nasal cavity located just inside the nose (Figure 39.7).
7.39.76	As air passes through the nasal cavity, the air is warmed to body temperature and humidified.
7.39.77	The respiratory tract is coated with mucus to seal the tissues from direct contact with air.
7.39.78	Mucus is high in water.
7.39.79	As air crosses these surfaces of the mucous membranes, it picks up water.
7.39.80	These processes help equilibrate the air to the body conditions, reducing any damage that cold, dry air can cause.
7.39.81	Particulate matter that is floating in the air is removed in the nasal passages via mucus and cilia.
7.39.82	The processes of warming, humidifying, and removing particles are important protective mechanisms that prevent damage to the trachea and lungs.
7.39.83	Thus, inhalation serves several purposes in addition to bringing oxygen into the respiratory system.
7.39.84	From the nasal cavity, air passes through the pharynx (throat) and the larynx (voice box), as it makes its way to the trachea (Figure 39.7).
7.39.85	The main function of the trachea is to funnel the inhaled air to the lungs and the exhaled air back out of the body.
7.39.86	The human trachea is a cylinder about 10 to 12 cm long and 2 cm in diameter that sits in front of the esophagus and extends from the larynx into the chest cavity where it divides into the two primary bronchi at the midthorax.
7.39.87	It is made of incomplete rings of hyaline cartilage and smooth muscle (Figure 39.8).
7.39.88	The trachea is lined with mucus-producing goblet cells and ciliated epithelia.
7.39.89	The cilia propel foreign particles trapped in the mucus toward the pharynx.
7.39.90	The cartilage provides strength and support to the trachea to keep the passage open.
7.39.91	The smooth muscle can contract, decreasing the trachea’s diameter, which causes expired air to rush upwards from the lungs at a great force.
7.39.92	The forced exhalation helps expel mucus when we cough.
7.39.93	Smooth muscle can contract or relax, depending on stimuli from the external environment or the body’s nervous system.
7.39.94	The trachea and bronchi are made of incomplete rings of cartilage.
7.39.95	(credit: modification of work by Gray's Anatomy)
7.39.96	Lungs: Bronchi and Alveoli
7.39.97	The end of the trachea bifurcates (divides) to the right and left lungs.
7.39.98	The lungs are not identical.
7.39.99	The right lung is larger and contains three lobes, whereas the smaller left lung contains two lobes (Figure 39.9).
7.39.100	The muscular diaphragm, which facilitates breathing, is inferior to (below) the lungs and marks the end of the thoracic cavity.
7.39.101	Figure 39.9
7.39.102	The trachea bifurcates into the right and left bronchi in the lungs.
7.39.103	The right lung is made of three lobes and is larger.
7.39.104	To accommodate the heart, the left lung is smaller and has only two lobes.
7.39.105	In the lungs, air is diverted into smaller and smaller passages, or bronchi.
7.39.106	Air enters the lungs through the two primary (main) bronchi (singular: bronchus).
7.39.107	Each bronchus divides into secondary bronchi, then into tertiary bronchi, which in turn divide, creating smaller and smaller diameter bronchioles as they split and spread through the lung.
7.39.108	Like the trachea, the bronchi are made of cartilage and smooth muscle.
7.39.109	At the bronchioles, the cartilage is replaced with elastic fibers.
7.39.110	Bronchi are innervated by nerves of both the parasympathetic and sympathetic nervous systems that control muscle contraction (parasympathetic) or relaxation (sympathetic) in the bronchi and bronchioles, depending on the nervous system’s cues.
7.39.111	In humans, bronchioles with a diameter smaller than 0.5 mm are the respiratory bronchioles.
7.39.112	They lack cartilage and therefore rely on inhaled air to support their shape.
7.39.113	As the passageways decrease in diameter, the relative amount of smooth muscle increases.
7.39.114	The terminal bronchioles subdivide into microscopic branches called respiratory bronchioles.
7.39.115	The respiratory bronchioles subdivide into several alveolar ducts.
7.39.116	Numerous alveoli and alveolar sacs surround the alveolar ducts.
7.39.117	The alveolar sacs resemble bunches of grapes tethered to the end of the bronchioles (Figure 39.10).
7.39.118	In the acinar region, the alveolar ducts are attached to the end of each bronchiole.
7.39.119	At the end of each duct are approximately 100 alveolar sacs, each containing 20 to 30 alveoli that are 200 to 300 microns in diameter.
7.39.120	Gas exchange occurs only in alveoli.
7.39.121	Alveoli are made of thin-walled parenchymal cells, typically one-cell thick, that look like tiny bubbles within the sacs.
7.39.122	Alveoli are in direct contact with capillaries (one-cell thick) of the circulatory system.
7.39.123	Such intimate contact ensures that oxygen will diffuse from alveoli into the blood and be distributed to the cells of the body.
7.39.124	In addition, the carbon dioxide that was produced by cells as a waste product will diffuse from the blood into alveoli to be exhaled.
7.39.125	The anatomical arrangement of capillaries and alveoli emphasizes the structural and functional relationship of the respiratory and circulatory systems.
7.39.126	Because there are so many alveoli (~300 million per lung) within each alveolar sac and so many sacs at the end of each alveolar duct, the lungs have a sponge-like consistency.
7.39.127	This organization produces a very large surface area that is available for gas exchange.
7.39.128	The surface area of alveoli in the lungs is approximately 75 m2.
7.39.129	This large surface area, combined with the thin-walled nature of the alveolar parenchymal cells, allows gases to easily diffuse across the cells.
7.39.130	Figure 39.10 Terminal bronchioles are connected by respiratory bronchioles to alveolar ducts and alveolar sacs.
7.39.131	Each alveolar sac contains 20 to 30 spherical alveoli and has the appearance of a bunch of grapes.
7.39.132	Air flows into the atrium of the alveolar sac, then circulates into alveoli where gas exchange occurs with the capillaries.
7.39.133	Mucous glands secrete mucous into the airways, keeping them moist and flexible.
7.39.134	(credit: modification of work by Mariana Ruiz Villareal) Watch the following video (http://openstaxcollege.org/l/lungs_pulmonary) to review the respiratory system.
7.39.135	Protective Mechanisms
7.39.136	The air that organisms breathe contains particulate matter such as dust, dirt, viral particles, and bacteria that can damage the lungs or trigger allergic immune responses.
7.39.137	The respiratory system contains several protective mechanisms to avoid problems or tissue damage.
7.39.138	In the nasal cavity, hairs and mucus trap small particles, viruses, bacteria, dust, and dirt to prevent their entry.
7.39.139	If particulates do make it beyond the nose, or enter through the mouth, the bronchi and bronchioles of the lungs also contain several protective devices.
7.39.140	The lungs produce mucus—a sticky substance made of mucin, a complex glycoprotein, as well as salts and water—that traps particulates.
7.39.141	The bronchi and bronchioles contain cilia, small hair-like projections that line the walls of the bronchi and bronchioles (Figure 39.11).
7.39.142	These cilia beat in unison and move mucus and particles out of the bronchi and bronchioles back up to the throat where it is swallowed and eliminated via the esophagus.
7.39.143	In humans, for example, tar and other substances in cigarette smoke destroy or paralyze the cilia, making the removal of particles more difficult.
7.39.144	In addition, smoking causes the lungs to produce more mucus, which the damaged cilia are not able to move.
7.39.145	This causes a persistent cough, as the lungs try to rid themselves of particulate matter, and makes smokers more susceptible to respiratory ailments.
7.39.146	Figure 39.11
7.39.147	The bronchi and bronchioles contain cilia that help move mucus and other particles out of the lungs.
7.39.148	(credit: Louisa Howard, modification of work by Dartmouth Electron Microscope Facility) 39.2 | Gas Exchange across Respiratory Surfaces
7.39.149	The structure of the lung maximizes its surface area to increase gas diffusion.
7.39.150	Because of the enormous number of alveoli (approximately 300 million in each human lung), the surface area of the lung is very large (75 m2).
7.39.151	Having such a large surface area increases the amount of gas that can diffuse into and out of the lungs.
7.39.152	Basic Principles of Gas Exchange Gas exchange during respiration occurs primarily through diffusion.
7.39.153	Diffusion is a process in which transport is driven by a concentration gradient.
7.39.154	Gas molecules move from a region of high concentration to a region of low concentration.
7.39.155	Blood that is low in oxygen concentration and high in carbon dioxide concentration undergoes gas exchange with air in the lungs.
7.39.156	The air in the lungs has a higher concentration of oxygen than that of oxygen-depleted blood and a lower concentration of carbon dioxide.
7.39.157	This concentration gradient allows for gas exchange during respiration.
7.39.158	Partial pressure is a measure of the concentration of the individual components in a mixture of gases.
7.39.159	The total pressure exerted by the mixture is the sum of the partial pressures of the components in the mixture.
7.39.160	The rate of diffusion of a gas is proportional to its partial pressure within the total gas mixture.
7.39.161	This concept is discussed further in detail below.
7.39.162	Lung Volumes and Capacities Different animals have different lung capacities based on their activities.
7.39.163	Cheetahs have evolved a much higher lung capacity than humans; it helps provide oxygen to all the muscles in the body and allows them to run very fast.
7.39.164	Elephants also have a high lung capacity.
7.39.165	In this case, it is not because they run fast but because they have a large body and must be able to take up oxygen in accordance with their body size.
7.39.166	Human lung size is determined by genetics, gender, and height.
7.39.167	At maximal capacity, an average lung can hold almost six liters of air, but lungs do not usually operate at maximal capacity.
7.39.168	Air in the lungs is measured in terms of lung volumes and lung capacities (Figure 39.12 and Table 39.1).
7.39.169	Volume measures the amount of air for one function (such as inhalation or exhalation).
7.39.170	Capacity is any two or more volumes (for example, how much can be inhaled from the end of a maximal exhalation).
7.39.171	Figure 39.12 Human lung volumes and capacities are shown.
7.39.172	The total lung capacity of the adult male is six liters.
7.39.173	Tidal volume is the volume of air inhaled in a single, normal breath.
7.39.174	Inspiratory capacity is the amount of air taken in during a deep breath, and residual volume is the amount of air left in the lungs after forceful respiration.
7.39.175	The volume in the lung can be divided into four units: tidal volume, expiratory reserve volume, inspiratory reserve volume, and residual volume.
7.39.176	Tidal volume (TV) measures the amount of air that is inspired and expired during a normal breath.
7.39.177	On average, this volume is around one-half liter, which is a little less than the capacity of a 20-ounce drink bottle.
7.39.178	The expiratory reserve volume (ERV) is the additional amount of air that can be exhaled after a normal exhalation.
7.39.179	It is the reserve amount that can be exhaled beyond what is normal.
7.39.180	Conversely, the inspiratory reserve volume (IRV) is the additional amount of air that can be inhaled after a normal inhalation.
7.39.181	The residual volume (RV) is the amount of air that is left after expiratory reserve volume is exhaled.
7.39.182	The lungs are never completely empty: There is always some air left in the lungs after a maximal exhalation.
7.39.183	If this residual volume did not exist and the lungs emptied completely, the lung tissues would stick together and the energy necessary to re-inflate the lung could be too great to overcome.
7.39.184	Therefore, there is always some air remaining in the lungs.
7.39.185	Residual volume is also important for preventing large fluctuations in respiratory gases (O2 and CO2).
7.39.186	The residual volume is the only lung volume that cannot be measured directly because it is impossible to completely empty the lung of air.
7.39.187	This volume can only be calculated rather than measured.
7.39.188	Capacities are measurements of two or more volumes.
7.39.189	The vital capacity (VC) measures the maximum amount of air that can be inhaled or exhaled during a respiratory cycle.
7.39.190	It is the sum of the expiratory reserve volume, tidal volume, and inspiratory reserve volume.
7.39.191	The inspiratory capacity (IC) is the amount of air that can be inhaled after the end of a normal expiration.
7.39.192	It is, therefore, the sum of the tidal volume and inspiratory reserve volume.
7.39.193	The functional residual capacity (FRC) includes the expiratory reserve volume and the residual volume.
7.39.194	The FRC measures the amount of additional air that can be exhaled after a normal exhalation.
7.39.195	Lastly, the total lung capacity (TLC) is a measurement of the total amount of air that the lung can hold.
7.39.196	It is the sum of the residual volume, expiratory reserve volume, tidal volume, and inspiratory reserve volume.
7.39.197	Lung volumes are measured by a technique called spirometry.
7.39.198	An important measurement taken during spirometry is the forced expiratory volume (FEV), which measures how much air can be forced out of the lung over a specific period, usually one second (FEV1).
7.39.199	In addition, the forced vital capacity (FVC), which is the total amount of air that can be forcibly exhaled, is measured.
7.39.200	The ratio of these values ( FEV1/FVC ratio) is used to diagnose lung diseases including asthma, emphysema, and fibrosis.
7.39.201	If the FEV1/FVC ratio is high, the lungs are not compliant (meaning they are stiff and unable to bend properly), and the patient most likely has lung fibrosis.
7.39.202	Patients exhale most of the lung volume very quickly.
7.39.203	Conversely, when the FEV1/FVC ratio is low, there is resistance in the lung that is characteristic of asthma.
7.39.204	In this instance, it is hard for the patient to get the air out of his or her lungs, and it takes a long time to reach the maximal exhalation volume.
7.39.205	In either case, breathing is difficult and complications arise.
7.39.206	Gas Pressure and Respiration
7.39.207	The respiratory process can be better understood by examining the properties of gases.
7.39.208	Gases move freely, but gas particles are constantly hitting the walls of their vessel, thereby producing gas pressure.
7.39.209	Air is a mixture of gases, primarily nitrogen (N2; 78.6 percent), oxygen (O2; 20.9 percent), water vapor (H2O; 0.5 percent), and carbon dioxide (CO2; 0.04 percent).
7.39.210	Each gas component of that mixture exerts a pressure.
7.39.211	The pressure for an individual gas in the mixture is the partial pressure of that gas.
7.39.212	Approximately 21 percent of atmospheric gas is oxygen.
7.39.213	Carbon dioxide, however, is found in relatively small amounts, 0.04 percent.
7.39.214	The partial pressure for oxygen is much greater than that of carbon dioxide.
7.39.215	The partial pressure of any gas can be calculated by:
7.39.216	Patm, the atmospheric pressure, is the sum of all of the partial pressures of the atmospheric gases added together.
7.39.217	The pressure of the atmosphere at sea level is 760 mm Hg.
7.39.218	Therefore, the partial pressure of oxygen is: At high altitudes, Patm decreases but concentration does not change; the partial pressure decrease is due to the reduction in Patm.
7.39.219	When the air mixture reaches the lung, it has been humidified.
7.39.220	The pressure of the water vapor in the lung does not change the pressure of the air, but it must be included in the partial pressure equation.
7.39.221	For this calculation, the water pressure (47 mm Hg) is subtracted from the atmospheric pressure: These pressures determine the gas exchange, or the flow of gas, in the system.
7.39.222	Oxygen and carbon dioxide will flow according to their pressure gradient from high to low.
7.39.223	Therefore, understanding the partial pressure of each gas will aid in understanding how gases move in the respiratory system.
7.39.224	Gas Exchange across the Alveoli
7.39.225	In the body, oxygen is used by cells of the body’s tissues and carbon dioxide is produced as a waste product.
7.39.226	The ratio of carbon dioxide production to oxygen consumption is the respiratory quotient (RQ).
7.39.227	RQ varies between 0.7 and 1.0.
7.39.228	If just glucose were used to fuel the body, the RQ would equal one.
7.39.229	One mole of carbon dioxide would be produced for every mole of oxygen consumed.
7.39.230	Glucose, however, is not the only fuel for the body.
7.39.231	Protein and fat are also used as fuels for the body.
7.39.232	Because of this, less carbon dioxide is produced than oxygen is consumed and the RQ is, on average, about 0.7 for fat and about 0.8 for protein.
7.39.233	The RQ is used to calculate the partial pressure of oxygen in the alveolar spaces within the lung, the alveolar PO2 Above, the partial pressure of oxygen in the lungs was calculated to be 150 mm Hg.
7.39.234	However, lungs never fully deflate with an exhalation; therefore, the inspired air mixes with this residual air and lowers the partial pressure of oxygen within the alveoli.
7.39.235	This means that there is a lower concentration of oxygen in the lungs than is found in the air outside the body.
7.39.236	Knowing the RQ, the partial pressure of oxygen in the alveoli can be calculated:
7.39.237	With an RQ of 0.8 and a PCO2 in the alveoli of 40 mm Hg, the alveolar PO2 is equal to:
7.39.238	Notice that this pressure is less than the external air.
7.39.239	Therefore, the oxygen will flow from the inspired air in the lung ( PO2 = 150 mm Hg) into the bloodstream ( PO2 = 100 mm Hg)
7.39.240	(Figure 39.13).
7.39.241	In the lungs, oxygen diffuses out of the alveoli and into the capillaries surrounding the alveoli.
7.39.242	Oxygen (about 98 percent) binds reversibly to the respiratory pigment hemoglobin found in red blood cells (RBCs).
7.39.243	RBCs carry oxygen to the tissues where oxygen dissociates from the hemoglobin and diffuses into the cells of the tissues.
7.39.244	More specifically, alveolar PO2 is higher in the alveoli ( PALVO2 = 100 mm Hg) than blood PO2 (40 mm Hg) in the capillaries.
7.39.245	Because this pressure gradient exists, oxygen diffuses down its pressure gradient, moving out of the alveoli and entering the blood of the capillaries where O2 binds to hemoglobin.
7.39.246	At the same time, alveolar PCO2 is lower
7.39.247	PALVO2 = 40 mm Hg than blood PCO2 =
7.39.248	(45 mm Hg).
7.39.249	CO2 diffuses down its pressure gradient, moving out of the capillaries and entering the alveoli.
7.39.250	Oxygen and carbon dioxide move independently of each other; they diffuse down their own pressure gradients.
7.39.251	As blood leaves the lungs through the pulmonary veins, the venous PO2 = 100 mm Hg, whereas the venous PCO2 = 40 mm Hg.
7.39.252	As blood enters the systemic capillaries, the blood will lose oxygen and gain carbon dioxide because of the pressure difference of the tissues and blood.
7.39.253	In systemic capillaries, PO2 = 100 mm Hg, but in the tissue cells, PO2 = 40 mm Hg.
7.39.254	This pressure gradient drives the diffusion of oxygen out of the capillaries and into the tissue cells.
7.39.255	At the same time, blood PCO2 = 40 mm Hg and systemic tissue PCO2
7.39.256	= 45 mm Hg.
7.39.257	The pressure gradient drives CO2 out of tissue cells and into the capillaries.
7.39.258	The blood returning to the lungs through the pulmonary arteries has a venous PO2 = 40 mm Hg and a PCO2 = 45 mm Hg.
7.39.259	The blood enters the lung capillaries where the process of exchanging gases between the capillaries and alveoli begins again.
7.39.260	In short, the change in partial pressure from the alveoli to the capillaries drives the oxygen into the tissues and the carbon dioxide into the blood from the tissues.
7.39.261	The blood is then transported to the lungs where differences in pressure in the alveoli result in the movement of carbon dioxide out of the blood into the lungs, and oxygen into the blood.
7.39.262	Mammalian lungs are located in the thoracic cavity where they are surrounded and protected by the rib cage, intercostal muscles, and bound by the chest wall.
7.39.263	The bottom of the lungs is contained by the diaphragm, a skeletal muscle that facilitates breathing.
7.39.264	Breathing requires the coordination of the lungs, the chest wall, and most importantly, the diaphragm.
7.39.265	Types of Breathing Amphibians have evolved multiple ways of breathing.
7.39.266	Young amphibians, like tadpoles, use gills to breathe, and they don’t leave the water.
7.39.267	Some amphibians retain gills for life.
7.39.268	As the tadpole grows, the gills disappear and lungs grow.
7.39.269	These lungs are primitive and not as evolved as mammalian lungs.
7.39.270	Adult amphibians are lacking or have a reduced diaphragm, so breathing via lungs is forced.
7.39.271	The other means of breathing for amphibians is diffusion across the skin.
7.39.272	To aid this diffusion, amphibian skin must remain moist.
7.39.273	Birds face a unique challenge with respect to breathing: They fly.
7.39.274	Flying consumes a great amount of energy; therefore, birds require a lot of oxygen to aid their metabolic processes.
7.39.275	Birds have evolved a respiratory system that supplies them with the oxygen needed to enable flying.
7.39.276	Similar to mammals, birds have lungs, which are organs specialized for gas exchange.
7.39.277	Oxygenated air, taken in during inhalation, diffuses across the surface of the lungs into the bloodstream, and carbon dioxide diffuses from the blood into the lungs and expelled during exhalation.
7.39.278	The details of breathing between birds and mammals differ substantially.
7.39.279	In addition to lungs, birds have air sacs inside their body.
7.39.280	Air flows in one direction from the posterior air sacs to the lungs and out of the anterior air sacs.
7.39.281	The flow of air is in the opposite direction from blood flow, and gas exchange takes place much more efficiently.
7.39.282	This type of breathing enables birds to obtain the requisite oxygen, even at higher altitudes where the oxygen concentration is low.
7.39.283	This directionality of airflow requires two cycles of air intake and exhalation to completely get the air out of the lungs.
7.39.284	All mammals have lungs that are the main organs for breathing.
7.39.285	Lung capacity has evolved to support the animal’s activities.
7.39.286	During inhalation, the lungs expand with air, and oxygen diffuses across the lung’s surface and enters the bloodstream.
7.39.287	During exhalation, the lungs expel air and lung volume decreases.
7.39.288	In the next few sections, the process of human breathing will be explained.
7.39.289	The Mechanics of Human Breathing Boyle’s Law is the gas law that states that in a closed space, pressure and volume are inversely related.
7.39.290	As volume decreases, pressure increases and vice versa (Figure 39.15).
7.39.291	The relationship between gas pressure and volume helps to explain the mechanics of breathing.
7.39.292	This graph shows data from Boyle’s original 1662 experiment, which shows that pressure and volume are inversely related.
7.39.293	No units are given as Boyle used arbitrary units in his experiments.
7.39.294	There is always a slightly negative pressure within the thoracic cavity, which aids in keeping the airways of the lungs open.
7.39.295	During inhalation, volume increases as a result of contraction of the diaphragm, and pressure decreases (according to Boyle’s Law).
7.39.296	This decrease of pressure in the thoracic cavity relative to the environment makes the cavity less than the atmosphere (Figure 39.16a).
7.39.297	Because of this drop in pressure, air rushes into the respiratory passages.
7.39.298	To increase the volume of the lungs, the chest wall expands.
7.39.299	This results from the contraction of the intercostal muscles, the muscles that are connected to the rib cage.
7.39.300	Lung volume expands because the diaphragm contracts and the intercostals muscles contract, thus expanding the thoracic cavity.
7.39.301	This increase in the volume of the thoracic cavity lowers pressure compared to the atmosphere, so air rushes into the lungs, thus increasing its volume.
7.39.302	The resulting increase in volume is largely attributed to an increase in alveolar space, because the bronchioles and bronchi are stiff structures that do not change in size.
7.39.303	The lungs, chest wall, and diaphragm are all involved in respiration, both (a) inhalation and (b) expiration.
7.39.304	(credit: modification of work by Mariana Ruiz Villareal)
7.39.305	The chest wall expands out and away from the lungs.
7.39.306	The lungs are elastic; therefore, when air fills the lungs, the elastic recoil within the tissues of the lung exerts pressure back toward the interior of the lungs.
7.39.307	These outward and inward forces compete to inflate and deflate the lung with every breath.
7.39.308	Upon exhalation, the lungs recoil to force the air out of the lungs, and the intercostal muscles relax, returning the chest wall back to its original position (Figure 39.16b).
7.39.309	The diaphragm also relaxes and moves higher into the thoracic cavity.
7.39.310	This increases the pressure within the thoracic cavity relative to the environment, and air rushes out of the lungs.
7.39.311	The movement of air out of the lungs is a passive event.
7.39.312	No muscles are contracting to expel the air.
7.39.313	Each lung is surrounded by an invaginated sac.
7.39.314	The layer of tissue that covers the lung and dips into spaces is called the visceral pleura.
7.39.315	A second layer of parietal pleura lines the interior of the thorax (Figure 39.17).
7.39.316	The space between these layers, the intrapleural space, contains a small amount of fluid that protects the tissue and reduces the friction generated from rubbing the tissue layers together as the lungs contract and relax.
7.39.317	Pleurisy results when these layers of tissue become inflamed; it is painful because the inflammation increases the pressure within the thoracic cavity and reduces the volume of the lung.
7.39.318	A tissue layer called pleura surrounds the lung and interior of the thoracic cavity.
7.39.319	(credit: modification of work by NCI)
7.39.320	The Work of Breathing
7.39.321	The number of breaths per minute is the respiratory rate.
7.39.322	On average, under non-exertion conditions, the human respiratory rate is 12–15 breaths/minute.
7.39.323	The respiratory rate contributes to the alveolar ventilation, or how much air moves into and out of the alveoli.
7.39.324	Alveolar ventilation prevents carbon dioxide buildup in the alveoli.
7.39.325	There are two ways to keep the alveolar ventilation constant: increase the respiratory rate while decreasing the tidal volume of air per breath (shallow breathing), or decrease the respiratory rate while increasing the tidal volume per breath.
7.39.326	In either case, the ventilation remains the same, but the work done and type of work needed are quite different.
7.39.327	Both tidal volume and respiratory rate are closely regulated when oxygen demand increases.
7.39.328	There are two types of work conducted during respiration, flow-resistive and elastic work.
7.39.329	Flow-resistive refers to the work of the alveoli and tissues in the lung, whereas elastic work refers to the work of the intercostal muscles, chest wall, and diaphragm.
7.39.330	Increasing the respiration rate increases the flow-resistive work of the airways and decreases the elastic work of the muscles.
7.39.331	Decreasing the respiratory rate reverses the type of work required.
7.39.332	Surfactant The air-tissue/water interface of the alveoli has a high surface tension.
7.39.333	This surface tension is similar to the surface tension of water at the liquid-air interface of a water droplet that results in the bonding of the water molecules together.
7.39.334	Surfactant is a complex mixture of phospholipids and lipoproteins that works to reduce the surface tension that exists between the alveoli tissue and the air found within the alveoli.
7.39.335	By lowering the surface tension of the alveolar fluid, it reduces the tendency of alveoli to collapse.
7.39.336	Surfactant works like a detergent to reduce the surface tension and allows for easier inflation of the airways.
7.39.337	When a balloon is first inflated, it takes a large amount of effort to stretch the plastic and start to inflate the balloon.
7.39.338	If a little bit of detergent was applied to the interior of the balloon, then the amount of effort or work needed to begin to inflate the balloon would decrease, and it would become much easier to start blowing up the balloon.
7.39.339	This same principle applies to the airways.
7.39.340	A small amount of surfactant to the airway tissues reduces the effort or work needed to inflate those airways.
7.39.341	Babies born prematurely sometimes do not produce enough surfactant.
7.39.342	As a result, they suffer from respiratory distress syndrome, because it requires more effort to inflate their lungs.
7.39.343	Surfactant is also important for preventing collapse of small alveoli relative to large alveoli.
7.39.344	Lung Resistance and Compliance Pulmonary diseases reduce the rate of gas exchange into and out of the lungs.
7.39.345	Two main causes of decreased gas exchange are compliance (how elastic the lung is) and resistance (how much obstruction exists in the airways).
7.39.346	A change in either can dramatically alter breathing and the ability to take in oxygen and release carbon dioxide.
7.39.347	Examples of restrictive diseases are respiratory distress syndrome and pulmonary fibrosis.
7.39.348	In both diseases, the airways are less compliant and they are stiff or fibrotic.
7.39.349	There is a decrease in compliance because the lung tissue cannot bend and move.
7.39.350	In these types of restrictive diseases, the intrapleural pressure is more positive and the airways collapse upon exhalation, which traps air in the lungs.
7.39.351	Forced or functional vital capacity (FVC), which is the amount of air that can be forcibly exhaled after taking the deepest breath possible, is much lower than in normal patients, and the time it takes to exhale most of the air is greatly prolonged (Figure 39.18).
7.39.352	A patient suffering from these diseases cannot exhale the normal amount of air.
7.39.353	Obstructive diseases and conditions include emphysema, asthma, and pulmonary edema.
7.39.354	In emphysema, which mostly arises from smoking tobacco, the walls of the alveoli are destroyed, decreasing the surface area for gas exchange.
7.39.355	The overall compliance of the lungs is increased, because as the alveolar walls are damaged, lung elastic recoil decreases due to a loss of elastic fibers, and more air is trapped in the lungs at the end of exhalation.
7.39.356	Asthma is a disease in which inflammation is triggered by environmental factors.
7.39.357	Inflammation obstructs the airways.
7.39.358	The obstruction may be due to edema (fluid accumulation), smooth muscle spasms in the walls of the bronchioles, increased mucus secretion, damage to the epithelia of the airways, or a combination of these events.
7.39.359	Those with asthma or edema experience increased occlusion from increased inflammation of the airways.
7.39.360	This tends to block the airways, preventing the proper movement of gases (Figure 39.18).
7.39.361	Those with obstructive diseases have large volumes of air trapped after exhalation and breathe at a very high lung volume to compensate for the lack of airway recruitment.
7.39.362	The ratio of FEV1 (the amount of air that can be forcibly exhaled in one second after taking a deep breath) to FVC (the total amount of air that can be forcibly exhaled) can be used to diagnose whether a person has restrictive or obstructive lung disease.
7.39.363	In restrictive lung disease, FVC is reduced but airways are not obstructed, so the person is able to expel air reasonably fast.
7.39.364	In obstructive lung disease, airway obstruction results in slow exhalation as well as reduced FVC.
7.39.365	Thus, the FEV1/FVC ratio is lower in persons with obstructive lung disease (less than 69 percent) than in persons with restrictive disease (88 to 90 percent).
7.39.366	Dead Space: V/Q
7.39.367	Mismatch Pulmonary circulation pressure is very low compared to that of the systemic circulation.
7.39.368	It is also independent of cardiac output.
7.39.369	This is because of a phenomenon called recruitment, which is the process of opening airways that normally remain closed when cardiac output increases.
7.39.370	As cardiac output increases, the number of capillaries and arteries that are perfused (filled with blood) increases.
7.39.371	These capillaries and arteries are not always in use but are ready if needed.
7.39.372	At times, however, there is a mismatch between the amount of air (ventilation, V) and the amount of blood (perfusion, Q) in the lungs.
7.39.373	This is referred to as ventilation/perfusion (V/Q) mismatch.
7.39.374	There are two types of V/Q mismatch.
7.39.375	Both produce dead space, regions of broken down or blocked lung tissue.
7.39.376	Dead spaces can severely impact breathing, because they reduce the surface area available for gas diffusion.
7.39.377	As a result, the amount of oxygen in the blood decreases, whereas the carbon dioxide level increases.
7.39.378	Dead space is created when no ventilation and/or perfusion takes place.
7.39.379	Anatomical dead space or anatomical shunt, arises from an anatomical failure, while physiological dead space or physiological shunt, arises from a functional impairment of the lung or arteries.
7.39.380	An example of an anatomical shunt is the effect of gravity on the lungs.
7.39.381	The lung is particularly susceptible to changes in the magnitude and direction of gravitational forces.
7.39.382	When someone is standing or sitting upright, the pleural pressure gradient leads to increased ventilation further down in the lung.
7.39.383	As a result, the intrapleural pressure is more negative at the base of the lung than at the top, and more air fills the bottom of the lung than the top.
7.39.384	Likewise, it takes less energy to pump blood to the bottom of the lung than to the top when in a prone position.
7.39.385	Perfusion of the lung is not uniform while standing or sitting.
7.39.386	This is a result of hydrostatic forces combined with the effect of airway pressure.
7.39.387	An anatomical shunt develops because the ventilation of the airways does not match the perfusion of the arteries surrounding those airways.
7.39.388	As a result, the rate of gas exchange is reduced.
7.39.389	Note that this does not occur when lying down, because in this position, gravity does not preferentially pull the bottom of the lung down.
7.39.390	A physiological shunt can develop if there is infection or edema in the lung that obstructs an area.
7.39.391	This will decrease ventilation but not affect perfusion; therefore, the V/Q ratio changes and gas exchange is affected.
7.39.392	The lung can compensate for these mismatches in ventilation and perfusion.
7.39.393	If ventilation is greater than perfusion, the arterioles dilate and the bronchioles constrict.
7.39.394	This increases perfusion and reduces ventilation.
7.39.395	Likewise, if ventilation is less than perfusion, the arterioles constrict and the bronchioles dilate to correct the imbalance.
7.39.396	Once the oxygen diffuses across the alveoli, it enters the bloodstream and is transported to the tissues where it is unloaded, and carbon dioxide diffuses out of the blood and into the alveoli to be expelled from the body.
7.39.397	Although gas exchange is a continuous process, the oxygen and carbon dioxide are transported by different mechanisms.
7.39.398	Transport of Oxygen in the Blood
7.39.399	Although oxygen dissolves in blood, only a small amount of oxygen is transported this way.
7.39.400	Only 1.5 percent of oxygen in the blood is dissolved directly into the blood itself.
7.39.401	Most oxygen—98.5 percent—is bound to a protein called hemoglobin and carried to the tissues.
7.39.402	Hemoglobin Hemoglobin, or Hb, is a protein molecule found in red blood cells (erythrocytes) made of four subunits: two alpha subunits and two beta subunits (Figure 39.19).
7.39.403	Each subunit surrounds a central heme group that contains iron and binds one oxygen molecule, allowing each hemoglobin molecule to bind four oxygen molecules.
7.39.404	Molecules with more oxygen bound to the heme groups are brighter red.
7.39.405	As a result, oxygenated arterial blood where the Hb is carrying four oxygen molecules is bright red, while venous blood that is deoxygenated is darker red.
7.39.406	The protein inside (a) red blood cells that carries oxygen to cells and carbon dioxide to the lungs is (b) hemoglobin.
7.39.407	Hemoglobin is made up of four symmetrical subunits and four heme groups.
7.39.408	Iron associated with the heme binds oxygen.
7.39.409	It is the iron in hemoglobin that gives blood its red color.
7.39.410	It is easier to bind a second and third oxygen molecule to Hb than the first molecule.
7.39.411	This is because the hemoglobin molecule changes its shape, or conformation, as oxygen binds.
7.39.412	The fourth oxygen is then more difficult to bind.
7.39.413	The binding of oxygen to hemoglobin can be plotted as a function of the partial pressure of oxygen in the blood (x-axis) versus the relative Hb-oxygen saturation (y-axis).
7.39.414	The resulting graph—
7.39.415	an oxygen dissociation curve—is sigmoidal, or S-shaped (Figure 39.20).
7.39.416	As the partial pressure of oxygen increases, the hemoglobin becomes increasingly saturated with oxygen.
7.39.417	Factors That Affect Oxygen Binding
7.39.418	The oxygen-carrying capacity of hemoglobin determines how much oxygen is carried in the blood.
7.39.419	In addition to PO2 , other environmental factors and diseases can affect oxygen carrying capacity and delivery.
7.39.420	Carbon dioxide levels, blood pH, and body temperature affect oxygen-carrying capacity (Figure 39.20).
7.39.421	When carbon dioxide is in the blood, it reacts with water to form bicarbonate (HCO−3 ) and hydrogen ions (H+).
7.39.422	As the level of carbon dioxide in the blood increases, more H+ is produced and the pH decreases.
7.39.423	This increase in carbon dioxide and subsequent decrease in pH reduce the affinity of hemoglobin for oxygen.
7.39.424	The oxygen dissociates from the Hb molecule, shifting the oxygen dissociation curve to the right.
7.39.425	Therefore, more oxygen is needed to reach the same hemoglobin saturation level as when the pH was higher.
7.39.426	A similar shift in the curve also results from an increase in body temperature.
7.39.427	Increased temperature, such as from increased activity of skeletal muscle, causes the affinity of hemoglobin for oxygen to be reduced.
7.39.428	Diseases like sickle cell anemia and thalassemia decrease the blood’s ability to deliver oxygen to tissues and its oxygen- carrying capacity.
7.39.429	In sickle cell anemia, the shape of the red blood cell is crescent-shaped, elongated, and stiffened, reducing its ability to deliver oxygen (Figure 39.21).
7.39.430	In this form, red blood cells cannot pass through the capillaries.
7.39.431	This is painful when it occurs.
7.39.432	Thalassemia is a rare genetic disease caused by a defect in either the alpha or the beta subunit of Hb.
7.39.433	Patients with thalassemia produce a high number of red blood cells, but these cells have lower-than-normal levels of hemoglobin.
7.39.434	Therefore, the oxygen-carrying capacity is diminished.
7.39.435	Individuals with sickle cell anemia have crescent-shaped red blood cells.
7.39.436	(credit: modification of work by Ed Uthman; scale-bar data from Matt Russell)
7.39.437	Transport of Carbon Dioxide in the Blood Carbon dioxide molecules are transported in the blood from body tissues to the lungs by one of three methods: dissolution directly into the blood, binding to hemoglobin, or carried as a bicarbonate ion.
7.39.438	Several properties of carbon dioxide in the blood affect its transport.
7.39.439	First, carbon dioxide is more soluble in blood than oxygen.
7.39.440	About 5 to 7 percent of all carbon dioxide is dissolved in the plasma.
7.39.441	Second, carbon dioxide can bind to plasma proteins or can enter red blood cells and bind to hemoglobin.
7.39.442	This form transports about 10 percent of the carbon dioxide.
7.39.443	When carbon dioxide binds to hemoglobin, a molecule called carbaminohemoglobin is formed.
7.39.444	Binding of carbon dioxide to hemoglobin is reversible.
7.39.445	Therefore, when it reaches the lungs, the carbon dioxide can freely dissociate from the hemoglobin and be expelled from the body.
7.39.446	Third, the majority of carbon dioxide molecules (85 percent) are carried as part of the bicarbonate buffer system.
7.39.447	In this system, carbon dioxide diffuses into the red blood cells.
7.39.448	Carbonic anhydrase (CA) within the red blood cells quickly converts the carbon dioxide into carbonic acid (H2CO3).
7.39.449	Carbonic acid is an unstable intermediate moleculethat immediately dissociates into bicarbonate ions (HCO3 ) and hydrogen (H ) ions.
7.39.450	Since carbon dioxide is quickly converted into bicarbonate ions, this reaction allows for the continued uptake of carbon dioxide into the blood down its concentration gradient.
7.39.451	It also results in the production of H+ ions.
7.39.452	If too much H+ is produced, it can alter blood pH.
7.39.453	However, hemoglobin binds to the free H+ ions and thus limits shifts in pH.
7.39.454	The newly synthesized bicarbonate ion is transported out of the red blood cell into the liquid component of the blood in exchange for a chloride ion (Cl-); this is called the chloride shift.
7.39.455	When the blood reaches the lungs, the bicarbonate ion is transported back into the red blood cell in exchange for the chloride ion.
7.39.456	The H+ ion dissociates from the hemoglobin and binds to the bicarbonate ion.
7.39.457	This produces the carbonic acid intermediate, which is converted back into carbon dioxide through the enzymatic action of CA.
7.39.458	The carbon dioxide produced is expelled through the lungs during exhalation.
7.39.459	The benefit of the bicarbonate buffer system is that carbon dioxide is “soaked up” into the blood with little change to the pH of the system.
7.39.460	This is important because it takes only a small change in the overall pH of the body for severe injury or death to result.
7.39.461	The presence of this bicarbonate buffer system also allows for people to travel and live at high altitudes:
7.39.462	When the partial pressure of oxygen and carbon dioxide change at high altitudes, the bicarbonate buffer system adjusts to regulate carbon dioxide while maintaining the correct pH in the body.
7.39.463	Carbon Monoxide Poisoning
7.39.464	While carbon dioxide can readily associate and dissociate from hemoglobin, other molecules such as carbon monoxide (CO) cannot.
7.39.465	Carbon monoxide has a greater affinity for hemoglobin than oxygen.
7.39.466	Therefore, when carbon monoxide is present, it binds to hemoglobin preferentially over oxygen.
7.39.467	As a result, oxygen cannot bind to hemoglobin, so very little oxygen is transported through the body (Figure 39.22).
7.39.468	Carbon monoxide is a colorless, odorless gas and is therefore difficult to detect.
7.39.469	It is produced by gas-powered vehicles and tools.
7.39.470	Carbon monoxide can cause headaches, confusion, and nausea; long-term exposure can cause brain damage or death.
7.39.471	Administering 100 percent (pure) oxygen is the usual treatment for carbon monoxide poisoning.
7.39.472	Administration of pure oxygen speeds up the separation of carbon monoxide from hemoglobin.          
7.40.0	Introduction
7.40.1	Most animals are complex multicellular organisms that require a mechanism for transporting nutrients throughout their bodies and removing waste products.
7.40.2	The circulatory system has evolved over time from simple diffusion through cells in the early evolution of animals to a complex network of blood vessels that reach all parts of the human body.
7.40.3	This extensive network supplies the cells, tissues, and organs with oxygen and nutrients, and removes carbon dioxide and waste, which are byproducts of respiration.
7.40.4	At the core of the human circulatory system is the heart.
7.40.5	The size of a clenched fist, the human heart is protected beneath the rib cage.
7.40.6	Made of specialized and unique cardiac muscle, it pumps blood throughout the body and to the heart itself.
7.40.7	Heart contractions are driven by intrinsic electrical impulses that the brain and endocrine hormones help to regulate.
7.40.8	Understanding the heart’s basic anatomy and function is important to understanding the body’s circulatory and respiratory systems.
7.40.9	Gas exchange is one essential function of the circulatory system.
7.40.10	A circulatory system is not needed in organisms with no specialized respiratory organs because oxygen and carbon dioxide diffuse directly between their body tissues and the external environment.
7.40.11	However, in organisms that possess lungs and gills, oxygen must be transported from these specialized respiratory organs to the body tissues via a circulatory system.
7.40.12	Therefore, circulatory systems have had to evolve to accommodate the great diversity of body sizes and body types present among animals.
7.40.13	In all animals, except a few simple types, the circulatory system is used to transport nutrients and gases through the body.
7.40.14	Simple diffusion allows some water, nutrient, waste, and gas exchange into primitive animals that are only a few cell layers thick; however, bulk flow is the only method by which the entire body of larger more complex organisms is accessed.
7.40.15	Circulatory System Architecture
7.40.16	The circulatory system is effectively a network of cylindrical vessels: the arteries, veins, and capillaries that emanate from a pump, the heart.
7.40.17	In all vertebrate organisms, as well as some invertebrates, this is a closed-loop system, in which the blood is not free in a cavity.
7.40.18	In a closed circulatory system, blood is contained inside blood vessels and circulates unidirectionally from the heart around the systemic circulatory route, then returns to the heart again, as illustrated in Figure 40.2a.
7.40.19	As opposed to a closed system, arthropods—including insects, crustaceans, and most mollusks—have an open circulatory system, as illustrated in Figure 40.2b.
7.40.20	In an open circulatory system, the blood is not enclosed in the blood vessels but is pumped into a cavity called a hemocoel and is called hemolymph because the blood mixes with the interstitial fluid.
7.40.21	As the heart beats and the animal moves, the hemolymph circulates around the organs within the body cavity and then reenters the hearts through openings called ostia.
7.40.22	This movement allows for gas and nutrient exchange.
7.40.23	An open circulatory system does not use as much energy as a closed system to operate or to maintain; however, there is a trade-off with the amount of blood that can be moved to metabolically active organs and tissues that require high levels of oxygen.
7.40.24	In fact, one reason that insects with wing spans of up to two feet wide (70 cm) are not around today is probably because they were outcompeted by the arrival of birds 150 million years ago.
7.40.25	Birds, having a closed circulatory system, are thought to have moved more agilely, allowing them to get food faster and possibly to prey on the insects.
7.40.26	In (a) closed circulatory systems, the heart pumps blood through vessels that are separate from the interstitial fluid of the body.
7.40.27	Most vertebrates and some invertebrates, like this annelid earthworm, have a closed circulatory system.
7.40.28	In (b) open circulatory systems, a fluid called hemolymph is pumped through a blood vessel that empties into the body cavity.
7.40.29	Hemolymph returns to the blood vessel through openings called ostia.
7.40.30	Arthropods like this bee and most mollusks have open circulatory systems.
7.40.31	Circulatory System Variation in Animals
7.40.32	The circulatory system varies from simple systems in invertebrates to more complex systems in vertebrates.
7.40.33	The simplest animals, such as the sponges (Porifera) and rotifers (Rotifera), do not need a circulatory system because diffusion allows adequate exchange of water, nutrients, and waste, as well as dissolved gases, as shown in Figure 40.3a.
7.40.34	Organisms that are more complex
7.40.35	but still only have two layers of cells in their body plan, such as jellies (Cnidaria) and comb jellies (Ctenophora) also use diffusion through their epidermis and internally through the gastrovascular compartment.
7.40.36	Both their internal and external tissues are bathed in an aqueous environment and exchange fluids by diffusion on both sides, as illustrated in Figure 40.3b.
7.40.37	Exchange of fluids is assisted by the pulsing of the jellyfish body.
7.40.38	Simple animals consisting of a single cell layer such as the (a) sponge or only a few cell layers such as the (b) jellyfish do not have a circulatory system.
7.40.39	Instead, gases, nutrients, and wastes are exchanged by diffusion.
7.40.40	For more complex organisms, diffusion is not efficient for cycling gases, nutrients, and waste effectively through the body; therefore, more complex circulatory systems evolved.
7.40.41	Most arthropods and many mollusks have open circulatory systems.
7.40.42	In an open system, an elongated beating heart pushes the hemolymph through the body and muscle contractions help to move fluids.
7.40.43	The larger more complex crustaceans, including lobsters, have developed arterial-like vessels to push blood through their bodies, and the most active mollusks, such as squids, have evolved a closed circulatory system and are able to move rapidly to catch prey.
7.40.44	Closed circulatory systems are a characteristic of vertebrates; however, there are significant differences in the structure of the heart and the circulation of blood between the different vertebrate groups due to adaptation during evolution and associated differences in anatomy.
7.40.45	Figure 40.4 illustrates the basic circulatory systems of some vertebrates: fish, amphibians, reptiles, and mammals.
7.40.46	Fish have the simplest circulatory systems of the vertebrates: blood flows unidirectionally from the two- chambered heart through the gills and then the rest of the body.
7.40.47	(b) Amphibians have two circulatory routes: one for oxygenation of the blood through the lungs and skin, and the other to take oxygen to the rest of the body.
7.40.48	The blood is pumped from a three-chambered heart with two atria and a single ventricle.
7.40.49	(c) Reptiles also have two circulatory routes; however, blood is only oxygenated through the lungs.
7.40.50	The heart is three chambered, but the ventricles are partially separated so some mixing of oxygenated and deoxygenated blood occurs except in crocodilians and birds.
7.40.51	(d) Mammals and birds have the most efficient heart with four chambers that completely separate the oxygenated and deoxygenated blood; it pumps only oxygenated blood through the body and deoxygenated blood to the lungs.
7.40.52	As illustrated in Figure 40.4a Fish have a single circuit for blood flow and a two-chambered heart that has only a single atrium and a single ventricle.
7.40.53	The atrium collects blood that has returned from the body and the ventricle pumps the blood to the gills where gas exchange occurs and the blood is re-oxygenated; this is called gill circulation.
7.40.54	The blood then continues through the rest of the body before arriving back at the atrium; this is called systemic circulation.
7.40.55	This unidirectional flow of blood produces a gradient of oxygenated to deoxygenated blood around the fish’s systemic circuit.
7.40.56	The result is a limit in the amount of oxygen that can reach some of the organs and tissues of the body, reducing the overall metabolic capacity of fish.
7.40.57	In amphibians, reptiles, birds, and mammals, blood flow is directed in two circuits: one through the lungs and back to the heart, which is called pulmonary circulation, and the other throughout the rest of the body and its organs including the brain (systemic circulation).
7.40.58	In amphibians, gas exchange also occurs through the skin during pulmonary circulation and is referred to as pulmocutaneous circulation.
7.40.59	As shown in Figure 40.4b, amphibians have a three-chambered heart that has two atria and one ventricle rather than the two-chambered heart of fish.
7.40.60	The two atria (superior heart chambers) receive blood from the two different circuits (the lungs and the systems), and then there is some mixing of the blood in the heart’s ventricle (inferior heart chamber), which reduces the efficiency of oxygenation.
7.40.61	The advantage to this arrangement is that high pressure in the vessels pushes blood to the lungs and body.
7.40.62	The mixing is mitigated by a ridge within the ventricle that diverts oxygen-rich blood through the systemic circulatory system and deoxygenated blood to the pulmocutaneous circuit.
7.40.63	For this reason, amphibians are often described as having double circulation.
7.40.64	Most reptiles also have a three-chambered heart similar to the amphibian heart that directs blood to the pulmonary and systemic circuits, as shown in Figure 40.4c.
7.40.65	The ventricle is divided more effectively by a partial septum, which results in less mixing of oxygenated and deoxygenated blood.
7.40.66	Some reptiles (alligators and crocodiles) are the most primitive animals to exhibit a four-chambered heart.
7.40.67	Crocodilians have a unique circulatory mechanism where the heart shunts blood from the lungs toward the stomach and other organs during long periods of submergence, for instance, while the animal waits for prey or stays underwater waiting for prey to rot.
7.40.68	One adaptation includes two main arteries that leave the same part of the heart: one takes blood to the lungs and the other provides an alternate route to the stomach and other parts of the body.
7.40.69	Two other adaptations include a hole in the heart between the two ventricles, called the foramen of Panizza, which allows blood to move from one side of the heart to the other, and specialized connective tissue that slows the blood flow to the lungs.
7.40.70	Together these adaptations have made crocodiles and alligators one of the most evolutionarily successful animal groups on earth.
7.40.71	In mammals and birds, the heart is also divided into four chambers: two atria and two ventricles, as illustrated in Figure 40.4d.
7.40.72	The oxygenated blood is separated from the deoxygenated blood, which improves the efficiency of double circulation and is probably required for the warm-blooded lifestyle of mammals and birds.
7.40.73	The four-chambered heart of birds and mammals evolved independently from a three-chambered heart.
7.40.74	The independent evolution of the same or a similar biological trait is referred to as convergent evolution.
7.40.75	Hemoglobin is responsible for distributing oxygen, and to a lesser extent, carbon dioxide, throughout the circulatory systems of humans, vertebrates, and many invertebrates.
7.40.76	The blood is more than the proteins, though.
7.40.77	Blood is actually a term used to describe the liquid that moves through the vessels and includes plasma (the liquid portion, which contains water, proteins, salts, lipids, and glucose) and the cells (red and white cells) and cell fragments called platelets.
7.40.78	Blood plasma is actually the dominant component of blood and contains the water, proteins, electrolytes, lipids, and glucose.
7.40.79	The cells are responsible for carrying the gases (red cells) and immune the response (white).
7.40.80	The platelets are responsible for blood clotting.
7.40.81	Interstitial fluid that surrounds cells is separate from the blood, but in hemolymph, they are combined.
7.40.82	In humans, cellular components make up approximately 45 percent of the blood and the liquid plasma 55 percent.
7.40.83	Blood is 20 percent of a person’s extracellular fluid and eight percent of weight.
7.40.84	The Role of Blood in the Body Blood, like the human blood illustrated in Figure 40.5 is important for regulation of the body’s systems and homeostasis.
7.40.85	Blood helps maintain homeostasis by stabilizing pH, temperature, osmotic pressure, and by eliminating excess heat.
7.40.86	Blood supports growth by distributing nutrients and hormones, and by removing waste.
7.40.87	Blood plays a protective role by transporting clotting factors and platelets to prevent blood loss and transporting the disease-fighting agents or white blood cells to sites of infection.
7.40.88	The cells and cellular components of human blood are shown.
7.40.89	Red blood cells deliver oxygen to the cells and remove carbon dioxide.
7.40.90	White blood cells—including neutrophils, monocytes, lymphocytes, eosinophils, and basophils—are involved in the immune response.
7.40.91	Platelets form clots that prevent blood loss after injury.
7.40.92	Red Blood Cells Red blood cells, or erythrocytes (erythro- = “red”; -cyte =
7.40.93	“cell”), are specialized cells that circulate through the body delivering oxygen to cells; they are formed from stem cells in the bone marrow.
7.40.94	In mammals, red blood cells are small biconcave cells that at maturity do not contain a nucleus or mitochondria and are only 7–8 μm in size.
7.40.95	In birds and non- avian reptiles, a nucleus is still maintained in red blood cells.
7.40.96	The red coloring of blood comes from the iron-containing protein hemoglobin, illustrated in Figure 40.6a.
7.40.97	The principal job of this protein is to carry oxygen, but it also transports carbon dioxide as well.
7.40.98	Hemoglobin is packed into red blood cells at a rate of about 250 million molecules of hemoglobin per cell.
7.40.99	Each hemoglobin molecule binds four oxygen molecules so that each red blood cell carries one billion molecules of oxygen.
7.40.100	There are approximately 25 trillion red blood cells in the five liters of blood in the human body, which could carry up to 25 sextillion (25 × 1021) molecules of oxygen in the body at any time.
7.40.101	In mammals, the lack of organelles in erythrocytes leaves more room for the hemoglobin molecules, and the lack of mitochondria also prevents use of the oxygen for metabolic respiration.
7.40.102	Only mammals have anucleated red blood cells, and some mammals (camels, for instance) even have nucleated red blood cells.
7.40.103	The advantage of nucleated red blood cells is that these cells can undergo mitosis.
7.40.104	Anucleated red blood cells metabolize anaerobically (without oxygen), making use of a primitive metabolic pathway to produce ATP and increase the efficiency of oxygen transport.
7.40.105	Not all organisms use hemoglobin as the method of oxygen transport.
7.40.106	Invertebrates that utilize hemolymph rather than blood use different pigments to bind to the oxygen.
7.40.107	These pigments use copper or iron to the oxygen.
7.40.108	Invertebrates have a variety of other respiratory pigments.
7.40.109	Hemocyanin, a blue-green, copper-containing protein, illustrated in Figure 40.6b is found in mollusks, crustaceans, and some of the arthropods.
7.40.110	Chlorocruorin, a green-colored, iron-containing pigment is found in four families of polychaete tubeworms.
7.40.111	Hemerythrin, a red, iron-containing protein is found in some polychaete worms and annelids and is illustrated in Figure 40.6c.
7.40.112	Despite the name, hemerythrin does not contain a heme group and its oxygen-carrying capacity is poor compared to hemoglobin.
7.40.113	In most vertebrates, (a) hemoglobin delivers oxygen to the body and removes some carbon dioxide.
7.40.114	Hemoglobin is composed of four protein subunits, two alpha chains and two beta chains, and a heme group that has iron associated with it.
7.40.115	The iron reversibly associates with oxygen, and in so doing is oxidized from Fe2+ to Fe3+.
7.40.116	In most mollusks and some arthropods, (b) hemocyanin delivers oxygen.
7.40.117	Unlike hemoglobin, hemolymph is not carried in blood cells, but floats free in the hemolymph.
7.40.118	Copper instead of iron binds the oxygen, giving the hemolymph a blue- green color.
7.40.119	In annelids, such as the earthworm, and some other invertebrates,
7.40.120	(c) hemerythrin carries oxygen.
7.40.121	Like hemoglobin, hemerythrin is carried in blood cells and has iron associated with it, but despite its name, hemerythrin does not contain heme.
7.40.122	The small size and large surface area of red blood cells allows for rapid diffusion of oxygen and carbon dioxide across the plasma membrane.
7.40.123	In the lungs, carbon dioxide is released and oxygen is taken in by the blood.
7.40.124	In the tissues, oxygen is released from the blood and carbon dioxide is bound for transport back to the lungs.
7.40.125	Studies have found that hemoglobin also binds nitrous oxide (NO).
7.40.126	NO is a vasodilator that relaxes the blood vessels and capillaries and may help with gas exchange and the passage of red blood cells through narrow vessels.
7.40.127	Nitroglycerin, a heart medication for angina and heart attacks, is converted to NO to help relax the blood vessels and increase oxygen flow through the body.
7.40.128	A characteristic of red blood cells is their glycolipid and glycoprotein coating; these are lipids and proteins that have carbohydrate molecules attached.
7.40.129	In humans, the surface glycoproteins and glycolipids on red blood cells vary between individuals, producing the different blood types, such as A, B, and O. Red blood cells have an average life span of 120 days, at which time they are broken down and recycled in the liver and spleen by phagocytic macrophages, a type of white blood cell.
7.40.130	White Blood Cells White blood cells, also called leukocytes (leuko = white), make up approximately one percent by volume of the cells in blood.
7.40.131	The role of white blood cells is very different than that of red blood cells: they are primarily involved in the immune response to identify and target pathogens, such as invading bacteria, viruses, and other foreign organisms.
7.40.132	White blood cells are formed continually; some only live for hours or days, but some live for years.
7.40.133	The morphology of white blood cells differs significantly from red blood cells.
7.40.134	They have nuclei and do not contain hemoglobin.
7.40.135	The different types of white blood cells are identified by their microscopic appearance after histologic staining, and each has a different specialized function.
7.40.136	The two main groups, both illustrated in Figure 40.7 are the granulocytes, which include the neutrophils, eosinophils, and basophils, and the agranulocytes, which include the monocytes and lymphocytes.
7.40.137	Granulocytes—including neutrophils, eosinophils and basophils—are characterized by a lobed nucleus and granular inclusions in the cytoplasm.
7.40.138	Granulocytes are typically first-responders during injury or infection.
7.40.139	(b) Agranulocytes include lymphocytes and monocytes.
7.40.140	Lymphocytes, including B and T cells, are responsible for adaptive immune response.
7.40.141	Monocytes differentiate into macrophages and dendritic cells, which in turn respond to infection or injury.
7.40.142	Granulocytes contain granules in their cytoplasm; the agranulocytes are so named because of the lack of granules in their cytoplasm.
7.40.143	Some leukocytes become macrophages that either stay at the same site or move through the blood stream and gather at sites of infection or inflammation where they are attracted by chemical signals from foreign particles and damaged cells.
7.40.144	Lymphocytes are the primary cells of the immune system and include B cells, T cells, and natural killer cells.
7.40.145	B cells destroy bacteria and inactivate their toxins.
7.40.146	They also produce antibodies.
7.40.147	T cells attack viruses, fungi, some bacteria, transplanted cells, and cancer cells.
7.40.148	T cells attack viruses by releasing toxins that kill the viruses.
7.40.149	Natural killer cells attack a variety of infectious microbes and certain tumor cells.
7.40.150	One reason that HIV poses significant management challenges is because the virus directly targets T cells by gaining entry through a receptor.
7.40.151	Once inside the cell, HIV then multiplies using the T cell’s own genetic machinery.
7.40.152	After the HIV virus replicates, it is transmitted directly from the infected T cell to macrophages.
7.40.153	The presence of HIV can remain unrecognized for an extensive period of time before full disease symptoms develop.
7.40.154	Platelets and Coagulation Factors Blood must clot to heal wounds and prevent excess blood loss.
7.40.155	Small cell fragments called platelets (thrombocytes) are attracted to the wound site where they adhere by extending many projections and releasing their contents.
7.40.156	These contents activate other platelets and also interact with other coagulation factors, which convert fibrinogen, a water-soluble protein present in blood serum into fibrin (a non-water soluble protein), causing the blood to clot.
7.40.157	Many of the clotting factors require vitamin K to work, and vitamin K deficiency can lead to problems with blood clotting.
7.40.158	Many platelets converge and stick together at the wound site forming a platelet plug (also called a fibrin clot), as illustrated in Figure 40.8b.
7.40.159	The plug or clot lasts for a number of days and stops the loss of blood.
7.40.160	Platelets are formed from the disintegration of larger cells called megakaryocytes, like that shown in Figure 40.8a.
7.40.161	For each megakaryocyte, 2000–3000 platelets are formed with 150,000 to 400,000 platelets present in each cubic millimeter of blood.
7.40.162	Each platelet is disc shaped and 2–4 μm in diameter.
7.40.163	They contain many small vesicles but do not contain a nucleus.
7.40.164	Platelets are formed from large cells called megakaryocytes.
7.40.165	The megakaryocyte breaks up into thousands of fragments that become platelets.
7.40.166	(b) Platelets are required for clotting of the blood.
7.40.167	The platelets collect at a wound site in conjunction with other clotting factors, such as fibrinogen, to form a fibrin clot that prevents blood loss and allows the wound to heal.
7.40.168	Plasma and Serum
7.40.169	The liquid component of blood is called plasma, and it is separated by spinning or centrifuging the blood at high rotations (3000 rpm or higher).
7.40.170	The blood cells and platelets are separated by centrifugal forces to the bottom of a specimen tube.
7.40.171	The upper liquid layer, the plasma, consists of 90 percent water along with various substances required for maintaining the body’s pH, osmotic load, and for protecting the body.
7.40.172	The plasma also contains the coagulation factors and antibodies.
7.40.173	The plasma component of blood without the coagulation factors is called the serum.
7.40.174	Serum is similar to interstitial fluid in which the correct composition of key ions acting as electrolytes is essential for normal functioning of muscles and nerves.
7.40.175	Other components in the serum include proteins that assist with maintaining pH and osmotic balance while giving viscosity to the blood.
7.40.176	The serum also contains antibodies, specialized proteins that are important for defense against viruses and bacteria.
7.40.177	Lipids, including cholesterol, are also transported in the serum, along with various other substances including nutrients, hormones, metabolic waste, plus external substances, such as, drugs, viruses, and bacteria.
7.40.178	Human serum albumin is the most abundant protein in human blood plasma and is synthesized in the liver.
7.40.179	Albumin, which constitutes about half of the blood serum protein, transports hormones and fatty acids, buffers pH, and maintains osmotic pressures.
7.40.180	Immunoglobin is a protein antibody produced in the mucosal lining and plays an important role in antibody mediated immunity.
7.40.181	The heart is a complex muscle that pumps blood through the three divisions of the circulatory system: the coronary (vessels that serve the heart), pulmonary (heart and lungs), and systemic (systems of the body), as shown in Figure 40.10.
7.40.182	Coronary circulation intrinsic to the heart takes blood directly from the main artery (aorta) coming from the heart.
7.40.183	For pulmonary and systemic circulation, the heart has to pump blood to the lungs or the rest of the body, respectively.
7.40.184	In vertebrates, the lungs are relatively close to the heart in the thoracic cavity.
7.40.185	The shorter distance to pump means that the muscle wall on the right side of the heart is not as thick as the left side which must have enough pressure to pump blood all the way to your big toe.
7.40.186	Structure of the Heart
7.40.187	The heart muscle is asymmetrical as a result of the distance blood must travel in the pulmonary and systemic circuits.
7.40.188	Since the right side of the heart sends blood to the pulmonary circuit it is smaller than the left side which must send blood out to the whole body in the systemic circuit, as shown in Figure 40.11.
7.40.189	In humans, the heart is about the size of a clenched fist; it is divided into four chambers: two atria and two ventricles.
7.40.190	There is one atrium and one ventricle on the right side and one atrium and one ventricle on the left side.
7.40.191	The atria are the chambers that receive blood, and the ventricles are the chambers that pump blood.
7.40.192	The right atrium receives deoxygenated blood from the superior vena cava, which drains blood from the jugular vein that comes from the brain and from the veins that come from the arms, as well as from the inferior vena cava which drains blood from the veins that come from the lower organs and the legs.
7.40.193	In addition, the right atrium receives blood from the coronary sinus which drains deoxygenated blood from the heart itself.
7.40.194	This deoxygenated blood then passes to the right ventricle through the atrioventricular valve or the tricuspid valve, a flap of connective tissue that opens in only one direction to prevent the backflow of blood.
7.40.195	The valve separating the chambers on the left side of the heart valve is called the biscuspid or mitral valve.
7.40.196	After it is filled, the right ventricle pumps the blood through the pulmonary arteries, by-passing the semilunar valve (or pulmonic valve) to the lungs for re-oxygenation.
7.40.197	After blood passes through the pulmonary arteries, the right semilunar valves close preventing the blood from flowing backwards into the right ventricle.
7.40.198	The left atrium then receives the oxygen-rich blood from the lungs via the pulmonary veins.
7.40.199	This blood passes through the bicuspid valve or mitral valve (the atrioventricular valve on the left side of the heart) to the left ventricle where the blood is pumped out through aorta, the major artery of the body, taking oxygenated blood to the organs and muscles of the body.
7.40.200	Once blood is pumped out of the left ventricle and into the aorta, the aortic semilunar valve (or aortic valve) closes preventing blood from flowing backward into the left ventricle.
7.40.201	This pattern of pumping is referred to as double circulation and is found in all mammals.
7.40.202	The heart is composed of three layers; the epicardium, the myocardium, and the endocardium, illustrated in Figure 40.11.
7.40.203	The inner wall of the heart has a lining called the endocardium.
7.40.204	The myocardium consists of the heart muscle cells that make up the middle layer and the bulk of the heart wall.
7.40.205	The outer layer of cells is called the epicardium, of which the second layer is a membranous layered structure called the pericardium that surrounds and protects the heart; it allows enough room for vigorous pumping but also keeps the heart in place to reduce friction between the heart and other structures.
7.40.206	The heart has its own blood vessels that supply the heart muscle with blood.
7.40.207	The coronary arteries branch from the aorta and surround the outer surface of the heart like a crown.
7.40.208	They diverge into capillaries where the heart muscle is supplied with oxygen before converging again into the coronary veins to take the deoxygenated blood back to the right atrium where the blood will be re-oxygenated through the pulmonary circuit.
7.40.209	The heart muscle will die without a steady supply of blood.
7.40.210	Atherosclerosis is the blockage of an artery by the buildup of fatty plaques.
7.40.211	Because of the size (narrow) of the coronary arteries and their function in serving the heart itself, atherosclerosis can be deadly in these arteries.
7.40.212	The slowdown of blood flow and subsequent oxygen deprivation that results from atherosclerosis causes severe pain, known as angina, and complete blockage of the arteries will cause myocardial infarction: the death of cardiac muscle tissue, commonly known as a heart attack.
7.40.213	The Cardiac Cycle
7.40.214	The main purpose of the heart is to pump blood through the body; it does so in a repeating sequence called the cardiac cycle.
7.40.215	The cardiac cycle is the coordination of the filling and emptying of the heart of blood by electrical signals that cause the heart muscles to contract and relax.
7.40.216	The human heart beats over 100,000 times per day.
7.40.217	In each cardiac cycle, the heart contracts ( systole), pushing out the blood and pumping it through the body; this is followed by a relaxation phase ( diastole), where the heart fills with blood, as illustrated in Figure 40.12.
7.40.218	The atria contract at the same time, forcing blood through the atrioventricular valves into the ventricles.
7.40.219	Closing of the atrioventricular valves produces a monosyllabic “lup” sound.
7.40.220	Following a brief delay, the ventricles contract at the same time forcing blood through the semilunar valves into the aorta and the artery transporting blood to the lungs (via the pulmonary artery).
7.40.221	Closing of the semilunar valves produces a monosyllabic “dup” sound.
7.40.222	During (a) cardiac diastole, the heart muscle is relaxed and blood flows into the heart.
7.40.223	During (b) atrial systole, the atria contract, pushing blood into the ventricles.
7.40.224	During (c) atrial diastole, the ventricles contract, forcing blood out of the heart.
7.40.225	The pumping of the heart is a function of the cardiac muscle cells, or cardiomyocytes, that make up the heart muscle.
7.40.226	Cardiomyocytes, shown in Figure 40.13, are distinctive muscle cells that are striated like skeletal muscle but pump rhythmically and involuntarily like smooth muscle; they are connected by intercalated disks exclusive to cardiac muscle.
