7.40.227	They are self-stimulated for a period of time and isolated cardiomyocytes will beat if given the correct balance of nutrients and electrolytes.
7.40.228	Cardiomyocytes are striated muscle cells found in cardiac tissue.
7.40.229	(credit: modification of work by Dr. S. Girod, Anton Becker; scale-bar data from Matt Russell)
7.40.230	The autonomous beating of cardiac muscle cells is regulated by the heart’s internal pacemaker that uses electrical signals to time the beating of the heart.
7.40.231	The electrical signals and mechanical actions, illustrated in Figure 40.14, are intimately intertwined.
7.40.232	The internal pacemaker starts at the sinoatrial (SA) node, which is located near the wall of the right atrium.
7.40.233	Electrical charges spontaneously pulse from the SA node causing the two atria to contract in unison.
7.40.234	The pulse reaches a second node, called the atrioventricular (AV) node, between the right atrium and right ventricle where it pauses for approximately 0.1 second before spreading to the walls of the ventricles.
7.40.235	From the AV node, the electrical impulse enters the bundle of His, then to the left and right bundle branches extending through the interventricular septum.
7.40.236	Finally, the Purkinje fibers conduct the impulse from the apex of the heart up the ventricular myocardium, and then the ventricles contract.
7.40.237	This pause allows the atria to empty completely into the ventricles before the ventricles pump out the blood.
7.40.238	The electrical impulses in the heart produce electrical currents that flow through the body and can be measured on the skin using electrodes.
7.40.239	This information can be observed as an electrocardiogram (ECG)—a recording of the electrical impulses of the cardiac muscle.
7.40.240	The beating of the heart is regulated by an electrical impulse that causes the characteristic reading of an ECG.
7.40.241	The signal is initiated at the sinoatrial valve.
7.40.242	The signal then (a) spreads to the atria, causing them to contract.
7.40.243	The signal is (b) delayed at the atrioventricular node before it is passed on to the (c) heart apex.
7.40.244	The delay allows the atria to relax before the (d) ventricles contract.
7.40.245	The final part of the ECG cycle prepares the heart for the next beat.
7.40.246	Arteries, Veins, and Capillaries
7.40.247	The blood from the heart is carried through the body by a complex network of blood vessels (Figure 40.15).
7.40.248	Arteries take blood away from the heart.
7.40.249	The main artery is the aorta that branches into major arteries that take blood to different limbs and organs.
7.40.250	These major arteries include the carotid artery that takes blood to the brain, the brachial arteries that take blood to the arms, and the thoracic artery that takes blood to the thorax and then into the hepatic, renal, and gastric arteries for the liver, kidney, and stomach, respectively.
7.40.251	The iliac artery takes blood to the lower limbs.
7.40.252	The major arteries diverge into minor arteries, and then smaller vessels called arterioles, to reach more deeply into the muscles and organs of the body.
7.40.253	The major human arteries and veins are shown.
7.40.254	(credit: modification of work by Mariana Ruiz Villareal)
7.40.255	Arterioles diverge into capillary beds.
7.40.256	Capillary beds contain a large number (10 to 100) of capillaries that branch among the cells and tissues of the body.
7.40.257	Capillaries are narrow-diameter tubes that can fit red blood cells through in single file and are the sites for the exchange of nutrients, waste, and oxygen with tissues at the cellular level.
7.40.258	Fluid also crosses into the interstitial space from the capillaries.
7.40.259	The capillaries converge again into venules that connect to minor veins that finally connect to major veins that take blood high in carbon dioxide back to the heart.
7.40.260	Veins are blood vessels that bring blood back to the heart.
7.40.261	The major veins drain blood from the same organs and limbs that the major arteries supply.
7.40.262	Fluid is also brought back to the heart via the lymphatic system.
7.40.263	The structure of the different types of blood vessels reflects their function or layers.
7.40.264	There are three distinct layers, or tunics, that form the walls of blood vessels (Figure 40.16).
7.40.265	The first tunic is a smooth, inner lining of endothelial cells that are in contact with the red blood cells.
7.40.266	The endothelial tunic is continuous with the endocardium of the heart.
7.40.267	In capillaries, this single layer of cells is the location of diffusion of oxygen and carbon dioxide between the endothelial cells and red blood cells, as well as the exchange site via endocytosis and exocytosis.
7.40.268	The movement of materials at the site of capillaries is regulated by vasoconstriction, narrowing of the blood vessels, and vasodilation, widening of the blood vessels; this is important in the overall regulation of blood pressure.
7.40.269	Veins and arteries both have two further tunics that surround the endothelium: the middle tunic is composed of smooth muscle and the outermost layer is connective tissue (collagen and elastic fibers).
7.40.270	The elastic connective tissue stretches and supports the blood vessels, and the smooth muscle layer helps regulate blood flow by altering vascular resistance through vasoconstriction and vasodilation.
7.40.271	The arteries have thicker smooth muscle and connective tissue than the veins to accommodate the higher pressure and speed of freshly pumped blood.
7.40.272	The veins are thinner walled as the pressure and rate of flow are much lower.
7.40.273	In addition, veins are structurally different than arteries in that veins have valves to prevent the backflow of blood.
7.40.274	Because veins have to work against gravity to get blood back to the heart, contraction of skeletal muscle assists with the flow of blood back to the heart.
7.40.275	Arteries and veins consist of three layers: an outer tunica externa, a middle tunica media, and an inner tunica intima.
7.40.276	Capillaries consist of a single layer of epithelial cells, the tunica intima.
7.40.277	(credit: modification of work by NCI, NIH)
7.40.278	Blood pressure (BP) is the pressure exerted by blood on the walls of a blood vessel that helps to push blood through the body.
7.40.279	Systolic blood pressure measures the amount of pressure that blood exerts on vessels while the heart is beating.
7.40.280	The optimal systolic blood pressure is 120 mmHg.
7.40.281	Diastolic blood pressure measures the pressure in the vessels between heartbeats.
7.40.282	The optimal diastolic blood pressure is 80 mmHg.
7.40.283	Many factors can affect blood pressure, such as hormones, stress, exercise, eating, sitting, and standing.
7.40.284	Blood flow through the body is regulated by the size of blood vessels, by the action of smooth muscle, by one-way valves, and by the fluid pressure of the blood itself.
7.40.285	How Blood Flows Through the Body Blood is pushed through the body by the action of the pumping heart.
7.40.286	With each rhythmic pump, blood is pushed under high pressure and velocity away from the heart, initially along the main artery, the aorta.
7.40.287	In the aorta, the blood travels at 30 cm/sec.
7.40.288	As blood moves into the arteries, arterioles, and ultimately to the capillary beds, the rate of movement slows dramatically to about 0.026 cm/sec, one-thousand times slower than the rate of movement in the aorta.
7.40.289	While the diameter of each individual arteriole and capillary is far narrower than the diameter of the aorta, and according to the law of continuity, fluid should travel faster through a narrower diameter tube, the rate is actually slower due to the overall diameter of all the combined capillaries being far greater than the diameter of the individual aorta.
7.40.290	The slow rate of travel through the capillary beds, which reach almost every cell in the body, assists with gas and nutrient exchange and also promotes the diffusion of fluid into the interstitial space.
7.40.291	After the blood has passed through the capillary beds to the venules, veins, and finally to the main venae cavae, the rate of flow increases again but is still much slower than the initial rate in the aorta.
7.40.292	Blood primarily moves in the veins by the rhythmic movement of smooth muscle in the vessel wall and by the action of the skeletal muscle as the body moves.
7.40.293	Because most veins must move blood against the pull of gravity, blood is prevented from flowing backward in the veins by one-way valves.
7.40.294	Because skeletal muscle contraction aids in venous blood flow, it is important to get up and move frequently after long periods of sitting so that blood will not pool in the extremities.
7.40.295	Blood flow through the capillary beds is regulated depending on the body’s needs and is directed by nerve and hormone signals.
7.40.296	For example, after a large meal, most of the blood is diverted to the stomach by vasodilation of vessels of the digestive system and vasoconstriction of other vessels.
7.40.297	During exercise, blood is diverted to the skeletal muscles through vasodilation while blood to the digestive system would be lessened through vasoconstriction.
7.40.298	The blood entering some capillary beds is controlled by small muscles, called precapillary sphincters, illustrated in Figure 40.17.
7.40.299	If the sphincters are open, the blood will flow into the associated branches of the capillary blood.
7.40.300	If all of the sphincters are closed, then the blood will flow directly from the arteriole to the venule through the thoroughfare channel (see Figure 40.17).
7.40.301	These muscles allow the body to precisely control when capillary beds receive blood flow.
7.40.302	At any given moment only about 5-10% of our capillary beds actually have blood flowing through them.
7.40.303	Proteins and other large solutes cannot leave the capillaries.
7.40.304	The loss of the watery plasma creates a hyperosmotic solution within the capillaries, especially near the venules.
7.40.305	This causes about 85% of the plasma that leaves the capillaries to eventually diffuses back into the capillaries near the venules.
7.40.306	The remaining 15% of blood plasma drains out from the interstitial fluid into nearby lymphatic vessels (Figure 40.18).
7.40.307	The fluid in the lymph is similar in composition to the interstitial fluid.
7.40.308	The lymph fluid passes through lymph nodes before it returns to the heart via the vena cava.
7.40.309	Lymph nodes are specialized organs that filter the lymph by percolation through a maze of connective tissue filled with white blood cells.
7.40.310	The white blood cells remove infectious agents, such as bacteria and viruses, to clean the lymph before it returns to the bloodstream.
7.40.311	After it is cleaned, the lymph returns to the heart by the action of smooth muscle pumping, skeletal muscle action, and one-way valves joining the returning blood near the junction of the venae cavae entering the right atrium of the heart.
7.40.312	Fluid from the capillaries moves into the interstitial space and lymph capillaries by diffusion down a pressure gradient and also by osmosis.
7.40.313	Out of 7,200 liters of fluid pumped by the average heart in a day, over 1,500 liters is filtered.
7.40.314	(credit: modification of work by NCI, NIH)
7.40.315	Blood Pressure
7.40.316	The pressure of the blood flow in the body is produced by the hydrostatic pressure of the fluid (blood) against the walls of the blood vessels.
7.40.317	Fluid will move from areas of high to low hydrostatic pressures.
7.40.318	In the arteries, the hydrostatic pressure near the heart is very high and blood flows to the arterioles where the rate of flow is slowed by the narrow openings of the arterioles.
7.40.319	During systole, when new blood is entering the arteries, the artery walls stretch to accommodate the increase of pressure of the extra blood; during diastole, the walls return to normal because of their elastic properties.
7.40.320	The blood pressure of the systole phase and the diastole phase, graphed in Figure 40.19, gives the two pressure readings for blood pressure.
7.40.321	For example, 120/80 indicates a reading of 120 mm Hg during the systole and 80 mm Hg during diastole.
7.40.322	Throughout the cardiac cycle, the blood continues to empty into the arterioles at a relatively even rate.
7.40.323	This resistance to blood flow is called peripheral resistance.
7.40.324	Figure 40.19
7.40.325	Blood pressure is related to the blood velocity in the arteries and arterioles.
7.40.326	In the capillaries and veins, the blood pressure continues to decease but velocity increases.
7.40.327	Blood Pressure Regulation Cardiac output is the volume of blood pumped by the heart in one minute.
7.40.328	It is calculated by multiplying the number of heart contractions that occur per minute (heart rate) times the stroke volume (the volume of blood pumped into the aorta per contraction of the left ventricle).
7.40.329	Therefore, cardiac output can be increased by increasing heart rate, as when exercising.
7.40.330	However, cardiac output can also be increased by increasing stroke volume, such as if the heart contracts with greater strength.
7.40.331	Stroke volume can also be increased by speeding blood circulation through the body so that more blood enters the heart between contractions.
7.40.332	During heavy exertion, the blood vessels relax and increase in diameter, offsetting the increased heart rate and ensuring adequate oxygenated blood gets to the muscles.
7.40.333	Stress triggers a decrease in the diameter of the blood vessels, consequently increasing blood pressure.
7.40.334	These changes can also be caused by nerve signals or hormones, and even standing up or lying down can have a great effect on blood pressure.  
7.41.0	Just as humans recycle what we can and dump the remains into landfills, our bodies use and recycle what they can and excrete the remaining waste products.
7.41.1	Our bodies’ complex systems have developed ways to treat waste and maintain a balanced internal environment.
7.41.2	(credit: modification of work by Redwin Law)
7.41.3	Introduction
7.41.4	The daily intake recommendation for human water consumption is eight to ten glasses of water.
7.41.5	In order to achieve a healthy balance, the human body should excrete the eight to ten glasses of water every day.
7.41.6	This occurs via the processes of urination, defecation, sweating and, to a small extent, respiration.
7.41.7	The organs and tissues of the human body are soaked in fluids that are maintained at constant temperature, pH, and solute concentration, all crucial elements of homeostasis.
7.41.8	The solutes in body fluids are mainly mineral salts and sugars, and osmotic regulation is the process by which the mineral salts and water are kept in balance.
7.41.9	Osmotic homeostasis is maintained despite the influence of external factors like temperature, diet, and weather conditions.
7.41.10	Osmosis is the diffusion of water across a membrane in response to osmotic pressure caused by an imbalance of molecules on either side of the membrane.
7.41.11	Osmoregulation is the process of maintenance of salt and water balance ( osmotic balance) across membranes within the body’s fluids, which are composed of water, plus electrolytes and non-electrolytes.
7.41.12	An electrolyte is a solute that dissociates into ions when dissolved in water.
7.41.13	A non-electrolyte, in contrast, doesn’t dissociate into ions during water dissolution.
7.41.14	Both electrolytes and non-electrolytes contribute to the osmotic balance.
7.41.15	The body’s fluids include blood plasma, the cytosol within cells, and interstitial fluid, the fluid that exists in the spaces between cells and tissues of the body.
7.41.16	The membranes of the body (such as the pleural, serous, and cell membranes) are semi-permeable membranes.
7.41.17	Semi-permeable membranes are permeable (or permissive) to certain types of solutes and water.
7.41.18	Solutions on two sides of a semi-permeable membrane tend to equalize in solute concentration by movement of solutes and/or water across the membrane.
7.41.19	As seen in Figure 41.2, a cell placed in water tends to swell due to gain of water from the hypotonic or “low salt” environment.
7.41.20	A cell placed in a solution with higher salt concentration, on the other hand, tends to make the membrane shrivel up due to loss of water into the hypertonic or “high salt” environment.
7.41.21	Isotonic cells have an equal concentration of solutes inside and outside the cell; this equalizes the osmotic pressure on either side of the cell membrane which is a semi-permeable membrane.
7.41.22	Cells placed in a hypertonic environment tend to shrink due to loss of water.
7.41.23	In a hypotonic environment, cells tend to swell due to intake of water.
7.41.24	The blood maintains an isotonic environment so that cells neither shrink nor swell.
7.41.25	(credit: Mariana Ruiz Villareal)
7.41.26	The body does not exist in isolation.
7.41.27	There is a constant input of water and electrolytes into the system.
7.41.28	While osmoregulation is achieved across membranes within the body, excess electrolytes and wastes are transported to the kidneys and excreted, helping to maintain osmotic balance.
7.41.29	Need for
7.41.30	Osmoregulation Biological systems constantly interact and exchange water and nutrients with the environment by way of consumption of food and water and through excretion in the form of sweat, urine, and feces.
7.41.31	Without a mechanism to regulate osmotic pressure, or when a disease damages this mechanism, there is a tendency to accumulate toxic waste and water, which can have dire consequences.
7.41.32	Mammalian systems have evolved to regulate not only the overall osmotic pressure across membranes, but also specific concentrations of important electrolytes in the three major fluid compartments: blood plasma, extracellular fluid, and intracellular fluid.
7.41.33	Since osmotic pressure is regulated by the movement of water across membranes, the volume of the fluid compartments can also change temporarily.
7.41.34	Because blood plasma is one of the fluid components, osmotic pressures have a direct bearing on blood pressure.
7.41.35	Transport of Electrolytes across Cell Membranes Electrolytes, such as sodium chloride, ionize in water, meaning that they dissociate into their component ions.
7.41.36	In water, sodium chloride (NaCl), dissociates into the sodium ion (Na+) and the chloride ion (Cl–).
7.41.37	The most important ions, whose concentrations are very closely regulated in body fluids, are the cations sodium (Na+), potassium (K+), calcium (Ca+2), magnesium (Mg+2), and the anions chloride (Cl-), carbonate (CO3-2), bicarbonate (HCO3-), and phosphate(PO3-).
7.41.38	Electrolytes are lost from the body during urination and perspiration.
7.41.39	For this reason, athletes are encouraged to replace electrolytes and fluids during periods of increased activity and perspiration.
7.41.40	Osmotic pressure is influenced by the concentration of solutes in a solution.
7.41.41	It is directly proportional to the number of solute atoms or molecules and not dependent on the size of the solute molecules.
7.41.42	Because electrolytes dissociate into their component ions, they, in essence, add more solute particles into the solution and have a greater effect on osmotic pressure, per mass than compounds that do not dissociate in water, such as glucose.
7.41.43	Water can pass through membranes by passive diffusion.
7.41.44	If electrolyte ions could passively diffuse across membranes, it would be impossible to maintain specific concentrations of ions in each fluid compartment therefore they require special mechanisms to cross the semi-permeable membranes in the body.
7.41.45	This movement can be accomplished by facilitated diffusion and active transport.
7.41.46	Facilitated diffusion requires protein-based channels for moving the solute.
7.41.47	Active transport requires energy in the form of ATP conversion, carrier proteins, or pumps in order to move ions against the concentration gradient.
7.41.48	Concept of Osmolality and Milliequivalent
7.41.49	In order to calculate osmotic pressure, it is necessary to understand how solute concentrations are measured.
7.41.50	The unit for measuring solutes is the mole.
7.41.51	One mole is defined as the gram molecular weight of the solute.
7.41.52	For example, the molecular weight of sodium chloride is 58.44.
7.41.53	Thus, one mole of sodium chloride weighs 58.44 grams.
7.41.54	The molarity of a solution is the number of moles of solute per liter of solution.
7.41.55	The molality of a solution is the number of moles of solute per kilogram of solvent.
7.41.56	If the solvent is water, one kilogram of water is equal to one liter of water.
7.41.57	While molarity and molality are used to express the concentration of solutions, electrolyte concentrations are usually expressed in terms of milliequivalents per liter (mEq/L):
7.41.58	the mEq/L is equal to the ion concentration (in millimoles) multiplied by the number of electrical charges on the ion.
7.41.59	The unit of milliequivalent takes into consideration the ions present in the solution (since electrolytes form ions in aqueous solutions) and the charge on the ions.
7.41.60	Thus, for ions that have a charge of one, one milliequivalent is equal to one millimole.
7.41.61	For ions that have a charge of two (like calcium), one milliequivalent is equal to 0.5 millimoles.
7.41.62	Another unit for the expression of electrolyte concentration is the milliosmole (mOsm), which is the number of milliequivalents of solute per kilogram of solvent.
7.41.63	Body fluids are usually maintained within the range of 280 to 300 mOsm.
7.41.64	Osmoregulators and Osmoconformers Persons lost at sea without any fresh water to drink are at risk of severe dehydration because the human body cannot adapt to drinking seawater, which is hypertonic in comparison to body fluids.
7.41.65	Organisms such as goldfish that can tolerate only a relatively narrow range of salinity are referred to as stenohaline.
7.41.66	About 90 percent of all bony fish are restricted to either freshwater or seawater.
7.41.67	They are incapable of osmotic regulation in the opposite environment.
7.41.68	It is possible, however, for a few fishes like salmon to spend part of their life in fresh water and part in sea water.
7.41.69	Organisms like the salmon and molly that can tolerate a relatively wide range of salinity are referred to as euryhaline organisms.
7.41.70	This is possible because some fish have evolved osmoregulatory mechanisms to survive in all kinds of aquatic environments.
7.41.71	When they live in fresh water, their bodies tend to take up water because the environment is relatively hypotonic, as illustrated in Figure 41.3a.
7.41.72	In such hypotonic environments, these fish do not drink much water.
7.41.73	Instead, they pass a lot of very dilute urine, and they achieve electrolyte balance by active transport of salts through the gills.
7.41.74	When they move to a hypertonic marine environment, these fish start drinking sea water; they excrete the excess salts through their gills and their urine, as illustrated in Figure 41.3b.
7.41.75	Most marine invertebrates, on the other hand, may be isotonic with sea water ( osmoconformers).
7.41.76	Their body fluid concentrations conform to changes in seawater concentration.
7.41.77	Cartilaginous fishes’ salt composition of the blood is similar to bony fishes; however, the blood of sharks contains the organic compounds urea and trimethylamine oxide (TMAO).
7.41.78	This does not mean that their electrolyte composition is similar to that of sea water.
7.41.79	They achieve isotonicity with the sea by storing large concentrations of urea.
7.41.80	These animals that secrete urea are called ureotelic animals.
7.41.81	TMAO stabilizes proteins in the presence of high urea levels, preventing the disruption of peptide bonds that would occur in other animals exposed to similar levels of urea.
7.41.82	Sharks are cartilaginous fish with a rectal gland to secrete salt and assist in osmoregulation.
7.41.83	Fish are osmoregulators, but must use different mechanisms to survive in (a) freshwater or (b) saltwater environments.
7.41.84	(credit: modification of work by Duane Raver, NOAA)
7.41.85	Although the kidneys are the major osmoregulatory organ, the skin and lungs also play a role in the process.
7.41.86	Water and electrolytes are lost through sweat glands in the skin, which helps moisturize and cool the skin surface, while the lungs expel a small amount of water in the form of mucous secretions and via evaporation of water vapor.
7.41.87	Kidneys:
7.41.88	The Main Osmoregulatory Organ
7.41.89	The kidneys, illustrated in Figure 41.4, are a pair of bean-shaped structures that are located just below and posterior to the liver in the peritoneal cavity.
7.41.90	The adrenal glands sit on top of each kidney and are also called the suprarenal glands.
7.41.91	Kidneys filter blood and purify it.
7.41.92	All the blood in the human body is filtered many times a day by the kidneys; these organs use up almost 25 percent of the oxygen absorbed through the lungs to perform this function.
7.41.93	Oxygen allows the kidney cells to efficiently manufacture chemical energy in the form of ATP through aerobic respiration.
7.41.94	The filtrate coming out of the kidneys is called urine.
7.41.95	Kidneys filter the blood, producing urine that is stored in the bladder prior to elimination through the urethra.
7.41.96	(credit: modification of work by NCI)
7.41.97	Kidney Structure
7.41.98	Externally, the kidneys are surrounded by three layers, illustrated in Figure 41.5.
7.41.99	The outermost layer is a tough connective tissue layer called the renal fascia.
7.41.100	The second layer is called the perirenal fat capsule, which helps anchor the kidneys in place.
7.41.101	The third and innermost layer is the renal capsule.
7.41.102	Internally, the kidney has three regions—an outer cortex, a medulla in the middle, and the renal pelvis in the region called the hilum of the kidney.
7.41.103	The hilum is the concave part of the bean-shape where blood vessels and nerves enter and exit the kidney; it is also the point of exit for the ureters.
7.41.104	The renal cortex is granular due to the presence of nephrons—the functional unit of the kidney.
7.41.105	The medulla consists of multiple pyramidal tissue masses, called the renal pyramids.
7.41.106	In between the pyramids are spaces called renal columns through which the blood vessels pass.
7.41.107	The tips of the pyramids, called renal papillae, point toward the renal pelvis.
7.41.108	There are, on average, eight renal pyramids in each kidney.
7.41.109	The renal pyramids along with the adjoining cortical region are called the lobes of the kidney.
7.41.110	The renal pelvis leads to the ureter on the outside of the kidney.
7.41.111	On the inside of the kidney, the renal pelvis branches out into two or three extensions called the major calyces, which further branch into the minor calyces.
7.41.112	The ureters are urine-bearing tubes that exit the kidney and empty into the urinary bladder.
7.41.113	Because the kidney filters blood, its network of blood vessels is an important component of its structure and function.
7.41.114	The arteries, veins, and nerves that supply the kidney enter and exit at the renal hilum.
7.41.115	Renal blood supply starts with the branching of the aorta into the renal arteries (which are each named based on the region of the kidney they pass through) and ends with the exiting of the renal veins to join the inferior vena cava.
7.41.116	The renal arteries split into several segmental arteries upon entering the kidneys.
7.41.117	Each segmental artery splits further into several interlobar arteries and enters the renal columns, which supply the renal lobes.
7.41.118	The interlobar arteries split at the junction of the renal cortex and medulla to form the arcuate arteries.
7.41.119	The arcuate “bow shaped” arteries form arcs along the base of the medullary pyramids.
7.41.120	Cortical radiate arteries, as the name suggests, radiate out from the arcuate arteries.
7.41.121	The cortical radiate arteries branch into numerous afferent arterioles, and then enter the capillaries supplying the nephrons.
7.41.122	Veins trace the path of the arteries and have similar names, except there are no segmental veins.
7.41.123	As mentioned previously, the functional unit of the kidney is the nephron, illustrated in Figure 41.6.
7.41.124	Each kidney is made up of over one million nephrons that dot the renal cortex, giving it a granular appearance when sectioned sagittally.
7.41.125	There are two types of nephrons— cortical nephrons (85 percent), which are deep in the renal cortex, and juxtamedullary nephrons (15 percent), which lie in the renal cortex close to the renal medulla.
7.41.126	A nephron consists of three parts—a renal corpuscle, a renal tubule, and the associated capillary network, which originates from the cortical radiate arteries.
7.41.127	Renal Corpuscle
7.41.128	The renal corpuscle, located in the renal cortex, is made up of a network of capillaries known as the glomerulus and the capsule, a cup-shaped chamber that surrounds it, called the glomerular or Bowman's capsule.
7.41.129	Renal Tubule
7.41.130	The renal tubule is a long and convoluted structure that emerges from the glomerulus and can be divided into three parts based on function.
7.41.131	The first part is called the proximal convoluted tubule (PCT) due to its proximity to the glomerulus; it stays in the renal cortex.
7.41.132	The second part is called the loop of Henle, or nephritic loop, because it forms a loop (with descending and ascending limbs) that goes through the renal medulla.
7.41.133	The third part of the renal tubule is called the distal convoluted tubule (DCT) and this part is also restricted to the renal cortex.
7.41.134	The DCT, which is the last part of the nephron, connects and empties its contents into collecting ducts that line the medullary pyramids.
7.41.135	The collecting ducts amass contents from multiple nephrons and fuse together as they enter the papillae of the renal medulla.
7.41.136	Capillary Network within the Nephron
7.41.137	The capillary network that originates from the renal arteries supplies the nephron with blood that needs to be filtered.
7.41.138	The branch that enters the glomerulus is called the afferent arteriole.
7.41.139	The branch that exits the glomerulus is called the efferent arteriole.
7.41.140	Within the glomerulus, the network of capillaries is called the glomerular capillary bed.
7.41.141	Once the efferent arteriole exits the glomerulus, it forms the peritubular capillary network, which surrounds and interacts with parts of the renal tubule.
7.41.142	In cortical nephrons, the peritubular capillary network surrounds the PCT and DCT.
7.41.143	In juxtamedullary nephrons, the peritubular capillary network forms a network around the loop of Henle and is called the vasa recta.
7.41.144	Kidney Function and Physiology Kidneys filter blood in a three-step process.
7.41.145	First, the nephrons filter blood that runs through the capillary network in the glomerulus.
7.41.146	Almost all solutes, except for proteins, are filtered out into the glomerulus by a process called glomerular filtration.
7.41.147	Second, the filtrate is collected in the renal tubules.
7.41.148	Most of the solutes get reabsorbed in the PCT by a process called tubular reabsorption.
7.41.149	In the loop of Henle, the filtrate continues to exchange solutes and water with the renal medulla and the peritubular capillary network.
7.41.150	Water is also reabsorbed during this step.
7.41.151	Then, additional solutes and wastes are secreted into the kidney tubules during tubular secretion, which is, in essence, the opposite process to tubular reabsorption.
7.41.152	The collecting ducts collect filtrate coming from the nephrons and fuse in the medullary papillae.
7.41.153	From here, the papillae deliver the filtrate, now called urine, into the minor calyces that eventually connect to the ureters through the renal pelvis.
7.41.154	This entire process is illustrated in Figure 41.7.
7.41.155	Each part of the nephron performs a different function in filtering waste and maintaining homeostatic balance.
7.41.156	(1)
7.41.157	The glomerulus forces small solutes out of the blood by pressure.
7.41.158	(2)
7.41.159	The proximal convoluted tubule reabsorbs ions, water, and nutrients from the filtrate into the interstitial fluid, and actively transports toxins and drugs from the interstitial fluid into the filtrate.
7.41.160	The proximal convoluted tubule also adjusts blood pH by selectively secreting ammonia (NH3) into the filtrate, where it reacts with H+ to form NH4+.
7.41.161	The more acidic the filtrate, the more ammonia is secreted.
7.41.162	(3)
7.41.163	The descending loop of Henle is lined with cells containing aquaporins that allow water to pass from the filtrate into the interstitial fluid.
7.41.164	(4)
7.41.165	In the thin part of the ascending loop of Henle, Na+ and Cl- ions diffuse into the interstitial fluid.
7.41.166	In the thick part, these same ions are actively transported into the interstitial fluid.
7.41.167	Because salt but not water is lost, the filtrate becomes more dilute as it travels up the limb.
7.41.168	(5)
7.41.169	In the distal convoluted tubule, K+ and H+ ions are selectively secreted into the filtrate, while Na+, Cl-, and
7.41.170	HCO3- ions are reabsorbed to maintain pH and electrolyte balance in the blood.
7.41.171	(6)
7.41.172	The collecting duct reabsorbs solutes and water from the filtrate, forming dilute urine.
7.41.173	(credit: modification of work by NIDDK)
7.41.174	Glomerular Filtration Glomerular filtration filters out most of the solutes due to high blood pressure and specialized membranes in the afferent arteriole.
7.41.175	The blood pressure in the glomerulus is maintained independent of factors that affect systemic blood pressure.
7.41.176	The “leaky” connections between the endothelial cells of the glomerular capillary network allow solutes to pass through easily.
7.41.177	All solutes in the glomerular capillaries, except for macromolecules like proteins, pass through by passive diffusion.
7.41.178	There is no energy requirement at this stage of the filtration process.
7.41.179	Glomerular filtration rate (GFR) is the volume of glomerular filtrate formed per minute by the kidneys.
7.41.180	GFR is regulated by multiple mechanisms and is an important indicator of kidney function.
7.41.181	Tubular Reabsorption and Secretion Tubular reabsorption occurs in the PCT part of the renal tubule.
7.41.182	Almost all nutrients are reabsorbed, and this occurs either by passive or active transport.
7.41.183	Reabsorption of water and some key electrolytes are regulated and can be influenced by hormones.
7.41.184	Sodium (Na+) is the most abundant ion and most of it is reabsorbed by active transport and then transported to the peritubular capillaries.
7.41.185	Because Na+ is actively transported out of the tubule, water follows it to even out the osmotic pressure.
7.41.186	Water is also independently reabsorbed into the peritubular capillaries due to the presence of aquaporins, or water channels, in the PCT.
7.41.187	This occurs due to the low blood pressure and high osmotic pressure in the peritubular capillaries.
7.41.188	However, every solute has a transport maximum and the excess is not reabsorbed.
7.41.189	In the loop of Henle, the permeability of the membrane changes.
7.41.190	The descending limb is permeable to water, not solutes; the opposite is true for the ascending limb.
7.41.191	Additionally, the loop of Henle invades the renal medulla, which is naturally high in salt concentration and tends to absorb water from the renal tubule and concentrate the filtrate.
7.41.192	The osmotic gradient increases as it moves deeper into the medulla.
7.41.193	Because two sides of the loop of Henle perform opposing functions, as illustrated in Figure 41.8, it acts as a countercurrent multiplier.
7.41.194	The vasa recta around it acts as the countercurrent exchanger.
7.41.195	By the time the filtrate reaches the DCT, most of the urine and solutes have been reabsorbed.
7.41.196	If the body requires additional water, all of it can be reabsorbed at this point.
7.41.197	Further reabsorption is controlled by hormones, which will be discussed in a later section.
7.41.198	Excretion of wastes occurs due to lack of reabsorption combined with tubular secretion.
7.41.199	Undesirable products like metabolic wastes, urea, uric acid, and certain drugs, are excreted by tubular secretion.
7.41.200	Most of the tubular secretion happens in the DCT, but some occurs in the early part of the collecting duct.
7.41.201	Kidneys also maintain an acid-base balance by secreting excess H+ ions.
7.41.202	Although parts of the renal tubules are named proximal and distal, in a cross-section of the kidney, the tubules are placed close together and in contact with each other and the glomerulus.
7.41.203	This allows for exchange of chemical messengers between the different cell types.
7.41.204	For example, the DCT ascending limb of the loop of Henle has masses of cells called macula densa, which are in contact with cells of the afferent arterioles called juxtaglomerular cells.
7.41.205	Together, the macula densa and juxtaglomerular cells form the juxtaglomerular complex (JGC).
7.41.206	The JGC is an endocrine structure that secretes the enzyme renin and the hormone erythropoietin.
7.41.207	When hormones trigger the macula densa cells in the DCT due to variations in blood volume, blood pressure, or electrolyte balance, these cells can immediately communicate the problem to the capillaries in the afferent and efferent arterioles, which can constrict or relax to change the glomerular filtration rate of the kidneys.
7.41.208	Microorganisms and invertebrate animals use more primitive and simple mechanisms to get rid of their metabolic wastes than the mammalian system of kidney and urinary function.
7.41.209	Three excretory systems evolved in organisms before complex kidneys: vacuoles, flame cells, and Malpighian tubules.
7.41.210	Contractile Vacuoles in Microorganisms
7.41.211	The most fundamental feature of life is the presence of a cell.
7.41.212	In other words, a cell is the simplest functional unit of a life.
7.41.213	Bacteria are unicellular, prokaryotic organisms that have some of the least complex life processes in place; however, prokaryotes such as bacteria do not contain membrane-bound vacuoles.
7.41.214	The cells of microorganisms like bacteria, protozoa, and fungi are bound by cell membranes and use them to interact with the environment.
7.41.215	Some cells, including some leucocytes in humans, are able to engulf food by endocytosis—the formation of vesicles by involution of the cell membrane within the cells.
7.41.216	The same vesicles are able to interact and exchange metabolites with the intracellular environment.
7.41.217	In some unicellular eukaryotic organisms such as the amoeba, shown in Figure 41.9, cellular wastes and excess water are excreted by exocytosis, when the contractile vacuoles merge with the cell membrane and expel wastes into the environment.
7.41.218	Contractile vacuoles (CV) should not be confused with vacuoles, which store food or water.
7.41.219	Some unicellular organisms, such as the amoeba, ingest food by endocytosis.
7.41.220	The food vesicle fuses with a lysosome, which digests the food.
7.41.221	Waste is excreted by exocytosis.
7.41.222	Flame Cells of Planaria and Nephridia of Worms
7.41.223	As multi-cellular systems evolved to have organ systems that divided the metabolic needs of the body, individual organs evolved to perform the excretory function.
7.41.224	Planaria are flatworms that live in fresh water.
7.41.225	Their excretory system consists of two tubules connected to a highly branched duct system.
7.41.226	The cells in the tubules are called flame cells (or protonephridia) because they have a cluster of cilia that looks like a flickering flame when viewed under the microscope, as illustrated in Figure 41.10a.
7.41.227	The cilia propel waste matter down the tubules and out of the body through excretory pores that open on the body surface; cilia also draw water from the interstitial fluid, allowing for filtration.
7.41.228	Any valuable metabolites are recovered by reabsorption.
7.41.229	Flame cells are found in flatworms, including parasitic tapeworms and free-living planaria.
7.41.230	They also maintain the organism’s osmotic balance.
7.41.231	In the excretory system of the (a) planaria, cilia of flame cells propel waste through a tubule formed by a tube cell.
7.41.232	Tubules are connected into branched structures that lead to pores located all along the sides of the body.
7.41.233	The filtrate is secreted through these pores.
7.41.234	In (b) annelids such as earthworms, nephridia filter fluid from the coelom, or body cavity.
7.41.235	Beating cilia at the opening of the nephridium draw water from the coelom into a tubule.
7.41.236	As the filtrate passes down the tubules, nutrients and other solutes are reabsorbed by capillaries.
7.41.237	Filtered fluid containing nitrogenous and other wastes is stored in a bladder and then secreted through a pore in the side of the body.
7.41.238	Earthworms (annelids) have slightly more evolved excretory structures called nephridia, illustrated in Figure 41.10b.
7.41.239	A pair of nephridia is present on each segment of the earthworm.
7.41.240	They are similar to flame cells in that they have a tubule with cilia.
7.41.241	Excretion occurs through a pore called the nephridiopore.
7.41.242	They are more evolved than the flame cells in that they have a system for tubular reabsorption by a capillary network before excretion.
7.41.243	Malpighian Tubules of Insects Malpighian tubules are found lining the gut of some species of arthropods, such as the bee illustrated in Figure 41.11.
7.41.244	They are usually found in pairs and the number of tubules varies with the species of insect.
7.41.245	Malpighian tubules are convoluted, which increases their surface area, and they are lined with microvilli for reabsorption and maintenance of osmotic balance.
7.41.246	Malpighian tubules work cooperatively with specialized glands in the wall of the rectum.
7.41.247	Body fluids are not filtered as in the case of nephridia; urine is produced by tubular secretion mechanisms by the cells lining the Malpighian tubules that are bathed in hemolymph (a mixture of blood and interstitial fluid that is found in insects and other arthropods as well as most mollusks).
7.41.248	Metabolic wastes like uric acid freely diffuse into the tubules.
7.41.249	There are exchange pumps lining the tubules, which actively transport H+ ions into the cell and K+ or Na+ ions out; water passively follows to form urine.
7.41.250	The secretion of ions alters the osmotic pressure which draws water, electrolytes, and nitrogenous waste (uric acid) into the tubules.
7.41.251	Water and electrolytes are reabsorbed when these organisms are faced with low-water environments, and uric acid is excreted as a thick paste or powder.
7.41.252	Not dissolving wastes in water helps these organisms to conserve water; this is especially important for life in dry environments.
7.41.253	Malpighian tubules of insects and other terrestrial arthropods remove nitrogenous wastes and other solutes from the hemolymph.
7.41.254	Na+
7.41.255	and/or K+ ions are actively transported into the lumen of the tubules.
7.41.256	Water then enters the tubules via osmosis, forming urine.
7.41.257	The urine passes through the intestine, and into the rectum.
7.41.258	There, nutrients diffuse back into the hemolymph.
7.41.259	Na+
7.41.260	and/or K+ ions are pumped into the hemolymph, and water follows.
7.41.261	The concentrated waste is then excreted.
7.41.262	Of the four major macromolecules in biological systems, both proteins and nucleic acids contain nitrogen.
7.41.263	During the catabolism, or breakdown, of nitrogen-containing macromolecules, carbon, hydrogen, and oxygen are extracted and stored in the form of carbohydrates and fats.
7.41.264	Excess nitrogen is excreted from the body.
7.41.265	Nitrogenous wastes tend to form toxic ammonia, which raises the pH of body fluids.
7.41.266	The formation of ammonia itself requires energy in the form of ATP and large quantities of water to dilute it out of a biological system.
7.41.267	Animals that live in aquatic environments tend to release ammonia into the water.
7.41.268	Animals that excrete ammonia are said to be ammonotelic.
7.41.269	Terrestrial organisms have evolved other mechanisms to excrete nitrogenous wastes.
7.41.270	The animals must detoxify ammonia by converting it into a relatively nontoxic form such as urea or uric acid.
7.41.271	Mammals, including humans, produce urea, whereas reptiles and many terrestrial invertebrates produce uric acid.
7.41.272	Animals that secrete urea as the primary nitrogenous waste material are called ureotelic animals.
7.41.273	Nitrogenous Waste in Terrestrial Animals:
7.41.274	The Urea Cycle
7.41.275	The urea cycle is the primary mechanism by which mammals convert ammonia to urea.
7.41.276	Urea is made in the liver and excreted in urine.
7.41.277	The overall chemical reaction by which ammonia is converted to urea is 2 NH3 (ammonia)
7.41.278	+ CO2 + 3 ATP + H2O
7.41.279	→ H2N-CO-NH2 (urea) +
7.41.280	2 ADP +
7.41.281	4 Pi + AMP.
7.41.282	The urea cycle utilizes five intermediate steps, catalyzed by five different enzymes, to convert ammonia to urea, as shown in Figure 41.12.
7.41.283	The amino acid L-ornithine gets converted into different intermediates before being regenerated at the end of the urea cycle.
7.41.284	Hence, the urea cycle is also referred to as the ornithine cycle.
7.41.285	The enzyme ornithine transcarbamylase catalyzes a key step in the urea cycle and its deficiency can lead to accumulation of toxic levels of ammonia in the body.
7.41.286	The first two reactions occur in the mitochondria and the last three reactions occur in the cytosol.
7.41.287	Urea concentration in the blood, called blood urea nitrogen or BUN, is used as an indicator of kidney function.
7.41.288	Nitrogenous Waste in Birds and Reptiles:
7.41.289	Uric Acid Birds, reptiles, and most terrestrial arthropods convert toxic ammonia to uric acid or the closely related compound guanine (guano) instead of urea.
7.41.290	Mammals also form some uric acid during breakdown of nucleic acids.
7.41.291	Uric acid is a compound similar to purines found in nucleic acids.
7.41.292	It is water insoluble and tends to form a white paste or powder; it is excreted by birds, insects, and reptiles.
7.41.293	Conversion of ammonia to uric acid requires more energy and is much more complex than conversion of ammonia to urea Figure 41.13.
7.41.294	Nitrogenous waste is excreted in different forms by different species.
7.41.295	These include (a) ammonia, (b) urea, and (c) uric acid.
7.41.296	(credit a: modification of work by Eric Engbretson, USFWS; credit b: modification of work by B. "Moose" Peterson, USFWS; credit c: modification of work by Dave Menke, USFWS)
7.41.297	While the kidneys operate to maintain osmotic balance and blood pressure in the body, they also act in concert with hormones.
7.41.298	Hormones are small molecules that act as messengers within the body.
7.41.299	Hormones are typically secreted from one cell and travel in the bloodstream to affect a target cell in another portion of the body.
7.41.300	Different regions of the nephron bear specialized cells that have receptors to respond to chemical messengers and hormones.
7.41.301	Table 41.1 summarizes the hormones that control the osmoregulatory functions.
7.41.302	Epinephrine and Norepinephrine Epinephrine and norepinephrine are released by the adrenal medulla and nervous system respectively.
7.41.303	They are the flight/ fight hormones that are released when the body is under extreme stress.
7.41.304	During stress, much of the body’s energy is used to combat imminent danger.
7.41.305	Kidney function is halted temporarily by epinephrine and norepinephrine.
7.41.306	These hormones function by acting directly on the smooth muscles of blood vessels to constrict them.
7.41.307	Once the afferent arterioles are constricted, blood flow into the nephrons stops.
7.41.308	These hormones go one step further and trigger the renin-angiotensin- aldosterone system.
7.41.309	Renin-Angiotensin-Aldosterone
7.41.310	The renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system, illustrated in Figure 41.15 proceeds through several steps to produce angiotensin II, which acts to stabilize blood pressure and volume.
7.41.311	Renin (secreted by a part of the juxtaglomerular complex) is produced by the granular cells of the afferent and efferent arterioles.
7.41.312	Thus, the kidneys control blood pressure and volume directly.
7.41.313	Renin acts on angiotensinogen, which is made in the liver and converts it to angiotensin I. Angiotensin converting
7.41.314	enzyme (ACE) converts angiotensin
7.41.315	I to angiotensin II.
7.41.316	Angiotensin II raises blood pressure by constricting blood vessels.
7.41.317	It also triggers the release of the mineralocorticoid aldosterone from the adrenal cortex, which in turn stimulates the renal tubules to reabsorb more sodium.
7.41.318	Angiotensin II also triggers the release of anti-diuretic hormone (ADH) from the hypothalamus, leading to water retention in the kidneys.
7.41.319	It acts directly on the nephrons and decreases glomerular filtration rate.
7.41.320	Medically, blood pressure can be controlled by drugs that inhibit ACE (called ACE inhibitors).
7.41.321	The renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system increases blood pressure and volume.
7.41.322	The hormone ANP has antagonistic effects.
7.41.323	(credit: modification of work by Mikael Häggström)
7.41.324	Mineralocorticoids Mineralocorticoids are hormones synthesized by the adrenal cortex that affect osmotic balance.
7.41.325	Aldosterone is a mineralocorticoid that regulates sodium levels in the blood.
7.41.326	Almost all of the sodium in the blood is reclaimed by the renal tubules under the influence of aldosterone.
7.41.327	Because sodium is always reabsorbed by active transport and water follows sodium to maintain osmotic balance, aldosterone manages not only sodium levels but also the water levels in body fluids.
7.41.328	In contrast, the aldosterone also stimulates potassium secretion concurrently with sodium reabsorption.
7.41.329	In contrast, absence of aldosterone means that no sodium gets reabsorbed in the renal tubules and all of it gets excreted in the urine.
7.41.330	In addition, the daily dietary potassium load is not secreted and the retention of K+ can cause a dangerous increase in plasma K+ concentration.
7.41.331	Patients who have Addison's disease have a failing adrenal cortex and cannot produce aldosterone.
7.41.332	They lose sodium in their urine constantly, and if the supply is not replenished, the consequences can be fatal.
7.41.333	Antidiurectic Hormone
7.41.334	As previously discussed, antidiuretic hormone or ADH (also called vasopressin), as the name suggests, helps the body conserve water when body fluid volume, especially that of blood, is low.
7.41.335	It is formed by the hypothalamus and is stored and released from the posterior pituitary.
7.41.336	It acts by inserting aquaporins in the collecting ducts and promotes reabsorption of water.
7.41.337	ADH also acts as a vasoconstrictor and increases blood pressure during hemorrhaging.
7.41.338	Atrial Natriuretic Peptide Hormone
7.41.339	The atrial natriuretic peptide (ANP) lowers blood pressure by acting as a vasodilator.
7.41.340	It is released by cells in the atrium of the heart in response to high blood pressure and in patients with sleep apnea.
7.41.341	ANP affects salt release, and because water passively follows salt to maintain osmotic balance, it also has a diuretic effect.
7.41.342	ANP also prevents sodium reabsorption by the renal tubules, decreasing water reabsorption (thus acting as a diuretic) and lowering blood pressure.
7.41.343	Its actions suppress the actions of aldosterone, ADH, and renin.
7.42.0	In this compound light micrograph purple-stained neutrophil (upper left) and eosinophil (lower right) are white blood cells that float among red blood cells in this blood smear.
7.42.1	Neutrophils provide an early, rapid, and nonspecific defense against invading pathogens.
7.42.2	Eosinophils play a variety of roles in the immune response.
7.42.3	Red blood cells are about 7–8 μm in diameter, and a neutrophil is about 10–12μm.
7.42.4	The environment consists of numerous pathogens, which are agents, usually microorganisms, that cause diseases in their hosts.
7.42.5	A host is the organism that is invaded and often harmed by a pathogen.
7.42.6	Pathogens include bacteria, protists, fungi and other infectious organisms.
7.42.7	We are constantly exposed to pathogens in food and water, on surfaces, and in the air.
7.42.8	Mammalian immune systems evolved for protection from such pathogens; they are composed of an extremely diverse array of specialized cells and soluble molecules that coordinate a rapid and flexible defense system capable of providing protection from a majority of these disease agents.
7.42.9	Components of the immune system constantly search the body for signs of pathogens.
7.42.10	When pathogens are found, immune factors are mobilized to the site of an infection.
7.42.11	The immune factors identify the nature of the pathogen, strengthen the corresponding cells and molecules to combat it efficiently, and then halt the immune response after the infection is cleared to avoid unnecessary host cell damage.
7.42.12	The immune system can remember pathogens to which it has been exposed to create a more efficient response upon re-exposure.
7.42.13	This memory can last several decades.
7.42.14	Features of the immune system, such as pathogen identification, specific response, amplification, retreat, and remembrance are essential for survival against pathogens.
7.42.15	The immune response can be classified as either innate or active.
7.42.16	The innate immune response is always present and attempts to defend against all pathogens rather than focusing on specific ones.
7.42.17	Conversely, the adaptive immune response stores information about past infections and mounts pathogen-specific defenses.
7.42.18	Innate Immune Response
7.42.19	By the end of this section, you will be able to:
7.42.20	Describe physical and chemical immune barriers Explain immediate and induced innate immune responses Discuss natural killer cells Describe major histocompatibility class
7.42.21	I molecules
7.42.22	Summarize how the proteins in a complement system function to destroy extracellular pathogens
7.42.23	The immune system comprises both innate and adaptive immune responses.
7.42.24	Innate immunity occurs naturally because of genetic factors or physiology; it is not induced by infection or vaccination but works to reduce the workload for the adaptive immune response.
7.42.25	Both the innate and adaptive levels of the immune response involve secreted proteins, receptor-mediated signaling, and intricate cell-to-cell communication.
7.42.26	The innate immune system developed early in animal evolution, roughly a billion years ago, as an essential response to infection.
7.42.27	Innate immunity has a limited number of specific targets: any pathogenic threat triggers a consistent sequence of events that can identify the type of pathogen and either clear the infection independently or mobilize a highly specialized adaptive immune response.
7.42.28	For example, tears and mucus secretions contain microbicidal factors.
7.42.29	Physical and Chemical Barriers
7.42.30	Before any immune factors are triggered, the skin functions as a continuous, impassable barrier to potentially infectious pathogens.
7.42.31	Pathogens are killed or inactivated on the skin by desiccation (drying out) and by the skin’s acidity.
7.42.32	In addition, beneficial microorganisms that coexist on the skin compete with invading pathogens, preventing infection.
7.42.33	Regions of the body that are not protected by skin (such as the eyes and mucus membranes) have alternative methods of defense, such as tears and mucus secretions that trap and rinse away pathogens, and cilia in the nasal passages and respiratory tract that push the mucus with the pathogens out of the body.
7.42.34	Throughout the body are other defenses, such as the low pH of the stomach (which inhibits the growth of pathogens), blood proteins that bind and disrupt bacterial cell membranes, and the process of urination (which flushes pathogens from the urinary tract).
7.42.35	Despite these barriers, pathogens may enter the body through skin abrasions or punctures, or by collecting on mucosal surfaces in large numbers that overcome the mucus or cilia.
7.42.36	Some pathogens have evolved specific mechanisms that allow them to overcome physical and chemical barriers.
7.42.37	When pathogens do enter the body, the innate immune system responds with inflammation, pathogen engulfment, and secretion of immune factors and proteins.
7.42.38	Pathogen Recognition
7.42.39	An infection may be intracellular or extracellular, depending on the pathogen.
7.42.40	All viruses infect cells and replicate within those cells (intracellularly), whereas bacteria and other parasites may replicate intracellularly or extracellularly, depending on the species.
7.42.41	The innate immune system must respond accordingly: by identifying the extracellular pathogen and/ or by identifying host cells that have already been infected.
7.42.42	When a pathogen enters the body, cells in the blood and lymph detect the specific pathogen-associated molecular patterns (PAMPs) on the pathogen’s surface.
7.42.43	PAMPs are carbohydrate, polypeptide, and nucleic acid “
7.42.44	signatures” that are expressed by viruses, bacteria, and parasites but which differ from molecules on host cells.
7.42.45	The immune system has specific cells, described in Figure 42.2 and shown in Figure 42.3, with receptors that recognize these PAMPs.
7.42.46	A macrophage is a large phagocytic cell that engulfs foreign particles and pathogens.
7.42.47	Macrophages recognize PAMPs via complementary pattern recognition receptors (PRRs).
7.42.48	PRRs are molecules on macrophages and dendritic cells which are in contact with the external environment.
7.42.49	A monocyte is a type of white blood cell that circulates in the blood and lymph and differentiates into macrophages after it moves into infected tissue.
7.42.50	Dendritic cells bind molecular signatures of pathogens and promote pathogen engulfment and destruction.
7.42.51	Toll-like receptors (TLRs) are a type of PRR that recognizes molecules that are shared by pathogens but distinguishable from host molecules).
7.42.52	TLRs are present in invertebrates as well as vertebrates, and appear to be one of the most ancient components of the immune system.
7.42.53	TLRs have also been identified in the mammalian nervous system.
7.42.54	The characteristics and location of cells involved in the innate immune system are described.
7.42.55	Cells of the blood include (1) monocytes, (2) lymphocytes, (3) neutrophils, (4) red blood cells, and (5) platelets.
7.42.56	Note the very similar morphologies of the leukocytes (1, 2, 3).
7.42.57	Cytokine Release Affect The binding of PRRs with PAMPs triggers the release of cytokines, which signal that a pathogen is present and needs to be destroyed along with any infected cells.
7.42.58	A cytokine is a chemical messenger that regulates cell differentiation (form and function), proliferation (production), and gene expression to affect immune responses.
7.42.59	At least 40 types of cytokines exist in humans that differ in terms of the cell type that produces them, the cell type that responds to them, and the changes they produce.
7.42.60	One type cytokine, interferon, is illustrated in Figure 42.4.
7.42.61	One subclass of cytokines is the interleukin (IL), so named because they mediate interactions between leukocytes (white blood cells).
7.42.62	Interleukins are involved in bridging the innate and adaptive immune responses.
7.42.63	In addition to being released from cells after PAMP recognition, cytokines are released by the infected cells which bind to nearby uninfected cells and induce those cells to release cytokines, which results in a cytokine burst.
7.42.64	A second class of early-acting cytokines is interferons, which are released by infected cells as a warning to nearby uninfected cells.
7.42.65	One of the functions of an interferon is to inhibit viral replication.
7.42.66	They also have other important functions, such as tumor surveillance.
7.42.67	Interferons work by signaling neighboring uninfected cells to destroy RNA and reduce protein synthesis, signaling neighboring infected cells to undergo apoptosis (programmed cell death), and activating immune cells.
7.42.68	In response to interferons, uninfected cells alter their gene expression, which increases the cells’ resistance to infection.
7.42.69	One effect of interferon-induced gene expression is a sharply reduced cellular protein synthesis.
7.42.70	Virally infected cells produce more viruses by synthesizing large quantities of viral proteins.
7.42.71	Thus, by reducing protein synthesis, a cell becomes resistant to viral infection.
7.42.72	Interferons are cytokines that are released by a cell infected with a virus.
7.42.73	Response of neighboring cells to interferon helps stem the infection.
7.42.74	Phagocytosis and Inflammation
7.42.75	The first cytokines to be produced are pro-inflammatory; that is, they encourage inflammation, the localized redness, swelling, heat, and pain that result from the movement of leukocytes and fluid through increasingly permeable capillaries to a site of infection.
7.42.76	The population of leukocytes that arrives at an infection site depends on the nature of the infecting pathogen.
7.42.77	Both macrophages and dendritic cells engulf pathogens and cellular debris through phagocytosis.
7.42.78	A neutrophil is also a phagocytic leukocyte that engulfs and digests pathogens.
7.42.79	Neutrophils, shown in Figure 42.3, are the most abundant leukocytes of the immune system.
7.42.80	Neutrophils have a nucleus with two to five lobes, and they contain organelles, called lysosomes, that digest engulfed pathogens.
7.42.81	An eosinophil is a leukocyte that works with other eosinophils to surround a parasite; it is involved in the allergic response and in protection against helminthes (parasitic worms).
7.42.82	Neutrophils and eosinophils are particularly important leukocytes that engulf large pathogens, such as bacteria and fungi.
7.42.83	A mast cell is a leukocyte that produces inflammatory molecules, such as histamine, in response to large pathogens.
7.42.84	A basophil is a leukocyte that, like a neutrophil, releases chemicals to stimulate the inflammatory response as illustrated in Figure 42.5.
7.42.85	Basophils are also involved in allergy and hypersensitivity responses and induce specific types of inflammatory responses.
7.42.86	Eosinophils and basophils produce additional inflammatory mediators to recruit more leukocytes.
7.42.87	A hypersensitive immune response to harmless antigens, such as in pollen, often involves the release of histamine by basophils and mast cells.
7.42.88	In response to a cut, mast cells secrete histamines that cause nearby capillaries to dilate.
7.42.89	Neutrophils and monocytes leave the capillaries.
7.42.90	Monocytes mature into macrophages.
7.42.91	Neutrophils, dendritic cells and macrophages release chemicals to stimulate the inflammatory response.
7.42.92	Neutrophils and macrophages also consume invading bacteria by phagocytosis.
7.42.93	Cytokines also send feedback to cells of the nervous system to bring about the overall symptoms of feeling sick, which include lethargy, muscle pain, and nausea.
7.42.94	These effects may have evolved because the symptoms encourage the individual to rest and prevent them from spreading the infection to others.
7.42.95	Cytokines also increase the core body temperature, causing a fever, which causes the liver to withhold iron from the blood.
7.42.96	Without iron, certain pathogens, such as some bacteria, are unable to replicate; this is called nutritional immunity.
7.42.97	Natural Killer Cells Lymphocytes are leukocytes that are histologically identifiable by their large, darkly staining nuclei; they are small cells with very little cytoplasm, as shown in Figure 42.6.
7.42.98	Infected cells are identified and destroyed by natural killer (NK) cells, lymphocytes that can kill cells infected with viruses or tumor cells (abnormal cells that uncontrollably divide and invade other tissue).
7.42.99	T cells and B cells of the adaptive immune system also are classified as lymphocytes.
7.42.100	T cells are lymphocytes that mature in the thymus gland, and B cells are lymphocytes that mature in the bone marrow.
7.42.101	NK cells identify intracellular infections, especially from viruses, by the altered expression of major histocompatibility class (MHC)
7.42.102	I molecules on the surface of infected cells.
7.42.103	MHC
7.42.104	I molecules are proteins on the surfaces of all nucleated cells, thus they are scarce on red blood cells and platelets which are non-nucleated.
7.42.105	The function of MHC I molecules is to display fragments of proteins from the infectious agents within the cell to T-cells; healthy cells will be ignored, while “non-self” or foreign proteins will be attacked by the immune system.
7.42.106	MHC II molecules are found mainly on cells containing antigens (“non-self proteins”) and on lymphocytes.
7.42.107	MHC II molecules interact with helper T-cells to trigger the appropriate immune response, which may include the inflammatory response.
7.42.108	Lymphocytes, such as NK cells, are characterized by their large nuclei that actively absorb Wright stain and therefore appear dark colored under a microscope.
7.42.109	An infected cell (or a tumor cell) is usually incapable of synthesizing and displaying MHC
7.42.110	I molecules appropriately.
7.42.111	The metabolic resources of cells infected by some viruses produce proteins that interfere with MHC I processing and/ or trafficking to the cell surface.
7.42.112	The reduced MHC I on host cells varies from virus to virus and results from active inhibitors being produced by the viruses.
7.42.113	This process can deplete host MHC
7.42.114	I molecules on the cell surface, which NK cells detect as “unhealthy” or “abnormal” while searching for cellular MHC
7.42.115	I molecules.
7.42.116	Similarly, the dramatically altered gene expression of tumor cells leads to expression of extremely deformed or absent MHC
7.42.117	I molecules that also signal “
7.42.118	unhealthy” or “abnormal.
7.42.119	” NK cells are always active; an interaction with normal, intact MHC I molecules on a healthy cell disables the killing sequence, and the NK cell moves on.
7.42.120	After the NK cell detects an infected or tumor cell, its cytoplasm secretes granules comprised of perforin, a destructive protein that creates a pore in the target cell.
7.42.121	Granzymes are released along with the perforin in the immunological synapse.
7.42.122	A granzyme is a protease that digests cellular proteins and induces the target cell to undergo programmed cell death, or apoptosis.
7.42.123	Phagocytic cells then digest the cell debris left behind.
7.42.124	NK cells are constantly patrolling the body and are an effective mechanism for controlling potential infections and preventing cancer progression.
7.42.125	Complement
7.42.126	An array of approximately 20 types of soluble proteins, called a complement system, functions to destroy extracellular pathogens.
7.42.127	Cells of the liver and macrophages synthesize complement proteins continuously; these proteins are abundant in the blood serum and are capable of responding immediately to infecting microorganisms.
7.42.128	The complement system is so named because it is complementary to the antibody response of the adaptive immune system.
7.42.129	Complement proteins bind to the surfaces of microorganisms and are particularly attracted to pathogens that are already bound by antibodies.
7.42.130	Binding of complement proteins occurs in a specific and highly regulated sequence, with each successive protein being activated by cleavage and/or structural changes induced upon binding of the preceding protein(s).
7.42.131	After the first few complement proteins bind, a cascade of sequential binding events follows in which the pathogen rapidly becomes coated in complement proteins.
7.42.132	Complement proteins perform several functions.
7.42.133	The proteins serve as a marker to indicate the presence of a pathogen to phagocytic cells, such as macrophages and B cells, and enhance engulfment; this process is called opsonization.
7.42.134	Certain complement proteins can combine to form attack complexes that open pores in microbial cell membranes.
7.42.135	These structures destroy pathogens by causing their contents to leak, as illustrated in Figure 42.7.
7.42.136	The classic pathway for the complement cascade involves the attachment of several initial complement proteins to an antibody-bound pathogen followed by rapid activation and binding of many more complement proteins and the creation of destructive pores in the microbial cell envelope and cell wall.
7.42.137	The alternate pathway does not involve antibody activation.
7.42.138	Rather, C3 convertase spontaneously breaks down C3.
7.42.139	Endogenous regulatory proteins prevent the complement complex from binding to host cells.
7.42.140	Pathogens lacking these regulatory proteins are lysed.
7.42.141	Adaptive Immune Response
7.42.142	By the end of this section, you will be able to: Explain adaptive immunity Compare and contrast adaptive and innate immunity Describe cell-mediated immune response and humoral immune response Describe immune tolerance
7.42.143	The adaptive, or acquired, immune response takes days or even weeks to become established—much longer than the innate response; however, adaptive immunity is more specific to pathogens and has memory.
7.42.144	Adaptive immunity is an immunity that occurs after exposure to an antigen either from a pathogen or a vaccination.
7.42.145	This part of the immune system is activated when the innate immune response is insufficient to control an infection.
7.42.146	In fact, without information from the innate immune system, the adaptive response could not be mobilized.
7.42.147	There are two types of adaptive responses: the cellmediated immune response, which is carried out by T cells, and the humoral immune response, which is controlled by activated B cells and antibodies.
7.42.148	Activated T cells and B cells that are specific to molecular structures on the pathogen proliferate and attack the invading pathogen.
7.42.149	Their attack can kill pathogens directly or secrete antibodies that enhance the phagocytosis of pathogens and disrupt the infection.
7.42.150	Adaptive immunity also involves a memory to provide the host with long-term protection from reinfection with the same type of pathogen; on re-exposure, this memory will facilitate an efficient and quick response.
7.42.151	Antigen-presenting Cells Unlike NK cells of the innate immune system, B cells (B lymphocytes) are a type of white blood cell that gives rise to antibodies, whereas T cells (T lymphocytes) are a type of white blood cell that plays an important role in the immune response.
7.42.152	T cells are a key component in the cell-mediated response—the specific immune response that utilizes T cells to neutralize cells that have been infected with viruses and certain bacteria.
7.42.153	There are three types of T cells: cytotoxic, helper, and suppressor T cells.
7.42.154	Cytotoxic T cells destroy virus-infected cells in the cell-mediated immune response, and helper T cells play a part in activating both the antibody and the cell-mediated immune responses.
7.42.155	Suppressor T cells deactivate T cells and B cells when needed, and thus prevent the immune response from becoming too intense.
7.42.156	An antigen is a foreign or “non-self” macromolecule that reacts with cells of the immune system.
7.42.157	Not all antigens will provoke a response.
7.42.158	For instance, individuals produce innumerable “self” antigens and are constantly exposed to harmless foreign antigens, such as food proteins, pollen, or dust components.
7.42.159	The suppression of immune responses to harmless macromolecules is highly regulated and typically prevents processes that could be damaging to the host, known as tolerance.
7.42.160	The innate immune system contains cells that detect potentially harmful antigens, and then inform the adaptive immune response about the presence of these antigens.
7.42.161	An antigen-presenting cell (APC) is an immune cell that detects, engulfs, and informs the adaptive immune response about an infection.
7.42.162	When a pathogen is detected, these APCs will phagocytose the pathogen and digest it to form many different fragments of the antigen.
7.42.163	Antigen fragments will then be transported to the surface of the APC, where they will serve as an indicator to other immune cells.
7.42.164	Dendritic cells are immune cells that process antigen material; they are present in the skin (Langerhans cells) and the lining of the nose, lungs, stomach, and intestines.
7.42.165	Sometimes a dendritic cell presents on the surface of other cells to induce an immune response, thus functioning as an antigen-presenting cell.
7.42.166	Macrophages also function as APCs.
7.42.167	Before activation and differentiation, B cells can also function as APCs.
7.42.168	After phagocytosis by APCs, the phagocytic vesicle fuses with an intracellular lysosome forming phagolysosome.
7.42.169	Within the phagolysosome, the components are broken down into fragments; the fragments are then loaded onto MHC class I or MHC class II molecules and are transported to the cell surface for antigen presentation, as illustrated in Figure 42.8.
7.42.170	Note that T lymphocytes cannot properly respond to the antigen unless it is processed and embedded in an MHC II molecule.
7.42.171	APCs express MHC on their surfaces, and when combined with a foreign antigen, these complexes signal a “non-self” invader.
7.42.172	Once the fragment of antigen is embedded in the MHC II molecule, the immune cell can respond.
7.42.173	Helper T- cells are one of the main lymphocytes that respond to antigen-presenting cells.
7.42.174	Recall that all other nucleated cells of the body expressed MHC I molecules, which signal “healthy” or “normal.
7.42.175	”
7.42.176	An APC, such as a macrophage, engulfs and digests a foreign bacterium.
7.42.177	An antigen from the bacterium is presented on the cell surface in conjunction with an MHC II molecule Lymphocytes of the adaptive immune response interact with antigen-embedded MHC II molecules to mature into functional immune cells.
7.42.178	T and B Lymphocytes Lymphocytes in human circulating blood are approximately 80 to 90 percent T cells, shown in Figure 42.9, and 10 to 20 percent B cells.
7.42.179	Recall that the T cells are involved in the cell-mediated immune response, whereas B cells are part of the humoral immune response.
7.42.180	T cells encompass a heterogeneous population of cells with extremely diverse functions.
7.42.181	Some T cells respond to APCs of the innate immune system, and indirectly induce immune responses by releasing cytokines.
7.42.182	Other T cells stimulate B cells to prepare their own response.
7.42.183	Another population of T cells detects APC signals and directly kills the infected cells.
7.42.184	Other T cells are involved in suppressing inappropriate immune reactions to harmless or “self” antigens.
7.42.185	This scanning electron micrograph shows a T lymphocyte, which is responsible for the cell-mediated immune response.
7.42.186	T cells are able to recognize antigens.
7.42.187	T and B cells exhibit a common theme of recognition/binding of specific antigens via a complementary receptor, followed by activation and self-amplification/maturation to specifically bind to the particular antigen of the infecting pathogen.
7.42.188	T and B lymphocytes are also similar in that each cell only expresses one type of antigen receptor.
7.42.189	Any individual may possess a population of T and B cells that together express a near limitless variety of antigen receptors that are capable of recognizing virtually any infecting pathogen.
7.42.190	T and B cells are activated when they recognize small components of antigens, called epitopes, presented by APCs, illustrated in Figure 42.10.
7.42.191	Note that recognition occurs at a specific epitope rather than on the entire antigen; for this reason, epitopes are known as “antigenic determinants.
7.42.192	”
7.42.193	In the absence of information from APCs, T and B cells remain inactive, or naïve, and are unable to prepare an immune response.
7.42.194	The requirement for information from the APCs of innate immunity to trigger B cell or T cell activation illustrates the essential nature of the innate immune response to the functioning of the entire immune system.
7.42.195	An antigen is a macromolecule that reacts with components of the immune system.
7.42.196	A given antigen may contain several motifs that are recognized by immune cells.
7.42.197	Each motif is an epitope.
7.42.198	In this figure, the entire structure is an antigen, and the orange, salmon and green components projecting from it represent potential epitopes.
7.42.199	Naïve T cells can express one of two different molecules, CD4 or CD8, on their surface, as shown in Figure 42.11, and are accordingly classified as CD4+ or CD8+ cells.
7.42.200	These molecules are important because they regulate how a T cell will interact with and respond to an APC.
7.42.201	Naïve CD4+ cells bind APCs via their antigen-embedded MHC II molecules and are stimulated to become helper T (TH) lymphocytes, cells that go on to stimulate B cells (or cytotoxic T cells) directly or secrete cytokines to inform more and various target cells about the pathogenic threat.
7.42.202	In contrast, CD8+ cells engage antigen-embedded MHC
7.42.203	I molecules on APCs and are stimulated to become cytotoxic T lymphocytes (CTLs), which directly kill infected cells by apoptosis and emit cytokines to amplify the immune response.
7.42.204	The two populations of T cells have different mechanisms of immune protection, but both bind MHC molecules via their antigen receptors called T cell receptors (TCRs).
7.42.205	The CD4 or CD8 surface molecules differentiate whether the TCR will engage an MHC II or an MHC I molecule.
7.42.206	Because they assist in binding specificity, the CD4 and CD8 molecules are described as coreceptors.
7.42.207	Consider the innumerable possible antigens that an individual will be exposed to during a lifetime.
7.42.208	The mammalian adaptive immune system is adept in responding appropriately to each antigen.
7.42.209	Mammals have an enormous diversity of T cell populations, resulting from the diversity of TCRs.
7.42.210	Each TCR consists of two polypeptide chains that span the T cell membrane, as illustrated in Figure 42.12; the chains are linked by a disulfide bridge.
