7.42.211	Each polypeptide chain is comprised of a constant domain and a variable domain: a domain, in this sense, is a specific region of a protein that may be regulatory or structural.
7.42.212	The intracellular domain is involved in intracellular signaling.
7.42.213	A single T cell will express thousands of identical copies of one specific TCR variant on its cell surface.
7.42.214	The specificity of the adaptive immune system occurs because it synthesizes millions of different T cell populations, each expressing a TCR that differs in its variable domain.
7.42.215	This TCR diversity is achieved by the mutation and recombination of genes that encode these receptors in stem cell precursors of T cells.
7.42.216	The binding between an antigen-displaying MHC molecule and a complementary TCR “match” indicates that the adaptive immune system needs to activate and produce that specific T cell because its structure is appropriate to recognize and destroy the invading pathogen.
7.42.217	A T cell receptor spans the membrane and projects variable binding regions into the extracellular space to bind processed antigens via MHC molecules on APCs.
7.42.218	Helper T Lymphocytes
7.42.219	The TH lymphocytes function indirectly to identify potential pathogens for other cells of the immune system.
7.42.220	These cells are important for extracellular infections, such as those caused by certain bacteria, helminths, and protozoa.
7.42.221	TH lymphocytes recognize specific antigens displayed in the MHC II complexes of APCs.
7.42.222	There are two major populations of TH cells: TH1 and TH2.
7.42.223	TH1 cells secrete cytokines to enhance the activities of macrophages and other T cells.
7.42.224	TH1 cells activate the action of cyotoxic T cells, as well as macrophages.
7.42.225	TH2 cells stimulate naïve B cells to destroy foreign invaders via antibody secretion.
7.42.226	Whether a TH1 or a TH2 immune response develops depends on the specific types of cytokines secreted by cells of the innate immune system, which in turn depends on the nature of the invading pathogen.
7.42.227	The TH1-mediated response involves macrophages and is associated with inflammation.
7.42.228	Recall the frontline defenses of macrophages involved in the innate immune response.
7.42.229	Some intracellular bacteria, such as Mycobacterium tuberculosis, have evolved to multiply in macrophages after they have been engulfed.
7.42.230	These pathogens evade attempts by macrophages to destroy and digest the pathogen.
7.42.231	When M. tuberculosis infection occurs, macrophages can stimulate naïve T cells to become TH1 cells.
7.42.232	These stimulated T cells secrete specific cytokines that send feedback to the macrophage to stimulate its digestive capabilities and allow it to destroy the colonizing M. tuberculosis.
7.42.233	In the same manner, TH1-activated macrophages also become better suited to ingest and kill tumor cells.
7.42.234	In summary; TH1 responses are directed toward intracellular invaders while TH2 responses are aimed at those that are extracellular.
7.42.235	B Lymphocytes When stimulated by the TH2 pathway, naïve B cells differentiate into antibody-secreting plasma cells.
7.42.236	A plasma cell is an immune cell that secrets antibodies; these cells arise from B cells that were stimulated by antigens.
7.42.237	Similar to T cells, naïve B cells initially are coated in thousands of B cell receptors (BCRs), which are membrane-bound forms of Ig (immunoglobulin, or an antibody).
7.42.238	The B cell receptor has two heavy chains and two light chains connected by disulfide linkages.
7.42.239	Each chain has a constant and a variable region; the latter is involved in antigen binding.
7.42.240	Two other membrane proteins, Ig alpha and Ig beta, are involved in signaling.
7.42.241	The receptors of any particular B cell, as shown in Figure 42.13 are all the same, but the hundreds of millions of different B cells in an individual have distinct recognition domains that contribute to extensive diversity in the types of molecular structures to which they can bind.
7.42.242	In this state, B cells function as APCs.
7.42.243	They bind and engulf foreign antigens via their BCRs and then display processed antigens in the context of MHC II molecules to TH2 cells.
7.42.244	When a TH2 cell detects that a B cell is bound to a relevant antigen, it secretes specific cytokines that induce the B cell to proliferate rapidly, which makes thousands of identical (clonal) copies of it, and then it synthesizes and secretes antibodies with the same antigen recognition pattern as the BCRs.
7.42.245	The activation of B cells corresponding to one specific BCR variant and the dramatic proliferation of that variant is known as clonal selection.
7.42.246	This phenomenon drastically, but briefly, changes the proportions of BCR variants expressed by the immune system, and shifts the balance toward BCRs specific to the infecting pathogen.
7.42.247	B cell receptors are embedded in the membranes of B cells and bind a variety of antigens through their variable regions.
7.42.248	The signal transduction region transfers the signal into the cell.
7.42.249	T and B cells differ in one fundamental way: whereas T cells bind antigens that have been digested and embedded in MHC molecules by APCs, B cells function as APCs that bind intact antigens that have not been processed.
7.42.250	Although T and B cells both react with molecules that are termed “antigens,” these lymphocytes actually respond to very different types of molecules.
7.42.251	B cells must be able to bind intact antigens because they secrete antibodies that must recognize the pathogen directly, rather than digested remnants of the pathogen.
7.42.252	Bacterial carbohydrate and lipid molecules can activate B cells independently from the T cells.
7.42.253	Cytotoxic T Lymphocytes CTLs, a subclass of T cells, function to clear infections directly.
7.42.254	The cell-mediated part of the adaptive immune system consists of CTLs that attack and destroy infected cells.
7.42.255	CTLs are particularly important in protecting against viral infections; this is because viruses replicate within cells where they are shielded from extracellular contact with circulating antibodies.
7.42.256	When APCs phagocytize pathogens and present MHC I-embedded antigens to naïve CD8+ T cells that express complementary TCRs, the CD8+ T cells become activated to proliferate according to clonal selection.
7.42.257	These resulting CTLs then identify non-APCs displaying the same MHC I-embedded antigens (for example, viral proteins)—for example, the CTLs identify infected host cells.
7.42.258	Intracellularly, infected cells typically die after the infecting pathogen replicates to a sufficient concentration and lyses the cell, as many viruses do.
7.42.259	CTLs attempt to identify and destroy infected cells before the pathogen can replicate and escape, thereby halting the progression of intracellular infections.
7.42.260	CTLs also support NK lymphocytes to destroy early cancers.
7.42.261	Cytokines secreted by the TH1 response that stimulates macrophages also stimulate CTLs and enhance their ability to identify and destroy infected cells and tumors.
7.42.262	CTLs sense MHC I-embedded antigens by directly interacting with infected cells via their TCRs.
7.42.263	Binding of TCRs with antigens activates CTLs to release perforin and granzyme, degradative enzymes that will induce apoptosis of the infected cell.
7.42.264	Recall that this is a similar destruction mechanism to that used by NK cells.
7.42.265	In this process, the CTL does not become infected and is not harmed by the secretion of perforin and granzymes.
7.42.266	In fact, the functions of NK cells and CTLs are complementary and maximize the removal of infected cells, as illustrated in Figure 42.14.
7.42.267	If the NK cell cannot identify the “missing self” pattern of down-regulated MHC I molecules, then the CTL can identify it by the complex of MHC I with foreign antigens, which signals “altered self.
7.42.268	”
7.42.269	Similarly, if the CTL cannot detect antigen-embedded MHC I because the receptors are depleted from the cell surface, NK cells will destroy the cell instead.
7.42.270	CTLs also emit cytokines, such as interferons, that alter surface protein expression in other infected cells, such that the infected cells can be easily identified and destroyed.
7.42.271	Moreover, these interferons can also prevent virally infected cells from releasing virus particles.
7.42.272	Plasma cells and CTLs are collectively called effector cells: they represent differentiated versions of their naïve counterparts, and they are involved in bringing about the immune defense of killing pathogens and infected host cells.
7.42.273	Mucosal Surfaces and Immune Tolerance
7.42.274	The innate and adaptive immune responses discussed thus far comprise the systemic immune system (affecting the whole body), which is distinct from the mucosal immune system.
7.42.275	Mucosal immunity is formed by mucosa-associated lymphoid tissue, which functions independently of the systemic immune system, and which has its own innate and adaptive components.
7.42.276	Mucosa-associated lymphoid tissue (MALT), illustrated in Figure 42.15, is a collection of lymphatic tissue that combines with epithelial tissue lining the mucosa throughout the body.
7.42.277	This tissue functions as the immune barrier and response in areas of the body with direct contact to the external environment.
7.42.278	The systemic and mucosal immune systems use many of the same cell types.
7.42.279	Foreign particles that make their way to MALT are taken up by absorptive epithelial cells called M cells and delivered to APCs located directly below the mucosal tissue.
7.42.280	M cells function in the transport described, and are located in the Peyer’s patch, a lymphoid nodule.
7.42.281	APCs of the mucosal immune system are primarily dendritic cells, with B cells and macrophages having minor roles.
7.42.282	Processed antigens displayed on APCs are detected by T cells in the MALT and at various mucosal induction sites, such as the tonsils, adenoids, appendix, or the mesenteric lymph nodes of the intestine.
7.42.283	Activated T cells then migrate through the lymphatic system and into the circulatory system to mucosal sites of infection.
7.42.284	The topology and function of intestinal MALT is shown.
7.42.285	Pathogens are taken up by M cells in the intestinal epithelium and excreted into a pocket formed by the inner surface of the cell.
7.42.286	The pocket contains antigen-presenting cells such as dendritic cells, which engulf the antigens, then present them with MHC II molecules on the cell surface.
7.42.287	The dendritic cells migrate to an underlying tissue called a Peyer’s patch.
7.42.288	Antigen-presenting cells, T cells, and B cells aggregate within the Peyer’s patch, forming organized lymphoid follicles.
7.42.289	There, some T cells and B cells are activated.
7.42.290	Other antigen-loaded dendritic cells migrate through the lymphatic system where they activate B cells, T cells, and plasma cells in the lymph nodes.
7.42.291	The activated cells then return to MALT tissue effector sites.
7.42.292	IgA and other antibodies are secreted into the intestinal lumen.
7.42.293	MALT is a crucial component of a functional immune system because mucosal surfaces, such as the nasal passages, are the first tissues onto which inhaled or ingested pathogens are deposited.
7.42.294	The mucosal tissue includes the mouth, pharynx, and esophagus, and the gastrointestinal, respiratory, and urogenital tracts.
7.42.295	The immune system has to be regulated to prevent wasteful, unnecessary responses to harmless substances, and more importantly so that it does not attack “self.
7.42.296	”
7.42.297	The acquired ability to prevent an unnecessary or harmful immune response to a detected foreign substance known not to cause disease is described as immune tolerance.
7.42.298	Immune tolerance is crucial for maintaining mucosal homeostasis given the tremendous number of foreign substances (such as food proteins) that APCs of the oral cavity, pharynx, and gastrointestinal mucosa encounter.
7.42.299	Immune tolerance is brought about by specialized APCs in the liver, lymph nodes, small intestine, and lung that present harmless antigens to an exceptionally diverse population of regulatory T (Treg) cells, specialized lymphocytes that suppress local inflammation and inhibit the secretion of stimulatory immune factors.
7.42.300	The combined result of Treg cells is to prevent immunologic activation and inflammation in undesired tissue compartments and to allow the immune system to focus on pathogens instead.
7.42.301	In addition to promoting immune tolerance of harmless antigens, other subsets of Treg cells are involved in the prevention of the autoimmune response, which is an inappropriate immune response to host cells or self-antigens.
7.42.302	Another Treg class suppresses immune responses to harmful pathogens after the infection has cleared to minimize host cell damage induced by inflammation and cell lysis.
7.42.303	Immunological Memory
7.42.304	The adaptive immune system possesses a memory component that allows for an efficient and dramatic response upon reinvasion of the same pathogen.
7.42.305	Memory is handled by the adaptive immune system with little reliance on cues from the innate response.
7.42.306	During the adaptive immune response to a pathogen that has not been encountered before, called a primary response, plasma cells secreting antibodies and differentiated T cells increase, then plateau over time.
7.42.307	As B and T cells mature into effector cells, a subset of the naïve populations differentiates into B and T memory cells with the same antigen specificities, as illustrated in Figure 42.16.
7.42.308	A memory cell is an antigen-specific B or T
7.42.309	lymphocyte that does not differentiate into effector cells during the primary immune response, but that can immediately become effector cells upon re-exposure to the same pathogen.
7.42.310	During the primary immune response, memory cells do not respond to antigens and do not contribute to host defenses.
7.42.311	As the infection is cleared and pathogenic stimuli subside, the effectors are no longer needed, and they undergo apoptosis.
7.42.312	In contrast, the memory cells persist in the circulation.
7.42.313	If the pathogen is never encountered again during the individual’s lifetime, B and T memory cells will circulate for a few years or even several decades and will gradually die off, having never functioned as effector cells.
7.42.314	However, if the host is re-exposed to the same pathogen type, circulating memory cells will immediately differentiate into plasma cells and CTLs without input from APCs or TH cells.
7.42.315	One reason the adaptive immune response is delayed is because it takes time for naïve B and T cells with the appropriate antigen specificities to be identified and activated.
7.42.316	Upon reinfection, this step is skipped, and the result is a more rapid production of immune defenses.
7.42.317	Memory B cells that differentiate into plasma cells output tens to hundreds-fold greater antibody amounts than were secreted during the primary response, as the graph in Figure 42.17 illustrates.
7.42.318	This rapid and dramatic antibody response may stop the infection before it can even become established, and the individual may not realize they had been exposed.
7.42.319	In the primary response to infection, antibodies are secreted first from plasma cells.
7.42.320	Upon re-exposure to the same pathogen, memory cells differentiate into antibody-secreting plasma cells that output a greater amount of antibody for a longer period of time.
7.42.321	Vaccination is based on the knowledge that exposure to noninfectious antigens, derived from known pathogens, generates a mild primary immune response.
7.42.322	The immune response to vaccination may not be perceived by the host as illness but still confers immune memory.
7.42.323	When exposed to the corresponding pathogen to which an individual was vaccinated, the reaction is similar to a secondary exposure.
7.42.324	Because each reinfection generates more memory cells and increased resistance to the pathogen, and because some memory cells die, certain vaccine courses involve one or more booster vaccinations to mimic repeat exposures: for instance, tetanus boosters are necessary every ten years because the memory cells only live that long.
7.42.325	Mucosal Immune Memory
7.42.326	A subset of T and B cells of the mucosal immune system differentiates into memory cells just as in the systemic immune system.
7.42.327	Upon reinvasion of the same pathogen type, a pronounced immune response occurs at the mucosal site where the original pathogen deposited, but a collective defense is also organized within interconnected or adjacent mucosal tissue.
7.42.328	For instance, the immune memory of an infection in the oral cavity would also elicit a response in the pharynx if the oral cavity was exposed to the same pathogen.
7.42.329	Primary Centers of the Immune System
7.42.330	Although the immune system is characterized by circulating cells throughout the body, the regulation, maturation, and intercommunication of immune factors occur at specific sites.
7.42.331	The blood circulates immune cells, proteins, and other factors through the body.
7.42.332	Approximately 0.1 percent of all cells in the blood are leukocytes, which encompass monocytes (the precursor of macrophages) and lymphocytes.
7.42.333	The majority of cells in the blood are erythrocytes (red blood cells).
7.42.334	Lymph is a watery fluid that bathes tissues and organs with protective white blood cells and does not contain erythrocytes.
7.42.335	Cells of the immune system can travel between the distinct lymphatic and blood circulatory systems, which are separated by interstitial space, by a process called extravasation (passing through to surrounding tissue).
7.42.336	The cells of the immune system originate from hematopoietic stem cells in the bone marrow.
7.42.337	Cytokines stimulate these stem cells to differentiate into immune cells.
7.42.338	B cell maturation occurs in the bone marrow, whereas naïve T cells transit from the bone marrow to the thymus for maturation.
7.42.339	In the thymus, immature T cells that express TCRs complementary to self-antigens are destroyed.
7.42.340	This process helps prevent autoimmune responses.
7.42.341	On maturation, T and B lymphocytes circulate to various destinations.
7.42.342	Lymph nodes scattered throughout the body, as illustrated in Figure 42.20, house large populations of T and B cells, dendritic cells, and macrophages.
7.42.343	Lymph gathers antigens as it drains from tissues.
7.42.344	These antigens then are filtered through lymph nodes before the lymph is returned to circulation.
7.42.345	APCs in the lymph nodes capture and process antigens and inform nearby lymphocytes about potential pathogens.
7.42.346	(a) Lymphatic vessels carry a clear fluid called lymph throughout the body.
7.42.347	The liquid enters (b) lymph nodes through afferent vessels.
7.42.348	Lymph nodes are filled with lymphocytes that purge infecting cells.
7.42.349	The lymph then exits through efferent vessels.
7.42.350	The spleen houses B and T cells, macrophages, dendritic cells, and NK cells.
7.42.351	The spleen, shown in Figure 42.21, is the site where APCs that have trapped foreign particles in the blood can communicate with lymphocytes.
7.42.352	Antibodies are synthesized and secreted by activated plasma cells in the spleen, and the spleen filters foreign substances and antibody-complexed pathogens from the blood.
7.42.353	Functionally, the spleen is to the blood as lymph nodes are to the lymph.
7.42.354	The spleen is similar to a lymph node but is much larger and filters blood instead of lymph.
7.42.355	Blood enters the spleen through arteries and exits through veins.
7.42.356	The spleen contains two types of tissue: red pulp and white pulp.
7.42.357	Red pulp consists of cavities that store blood.
7.42.358	Within the red pulp, damaged red blood cells are removed and replaced by new ones.
7.42.359	White pulp is rich in lymphocytes that remove antigen-coated bacteria from the blood.
7.42.360	Antibodies
7.42.361	By the end of this section, you will be able to: Explain cross-reactivity Describe the structure and function of
7.42.362	antibodies Discuss antibody production
7.42.363	An antibody, also known as an immunoglobulin (Ig), is a protein that is produced by plasma cells after stimulation by an antigen.
7.42.364	Antibodies are the functional basis of humoral immunity.
7.42.365	Antibodies occur in the blood, in gastric and mucus secretions, and in breast milk.
7.42.366	Antibodies in these bodily fluids can bind pathogens and mark them for destruction by phagocytes before they can infect cells.
7.42.367	Antibody Structure
7.42.368	An antibody molecule is comprised of four polypeptides: two identical heavy chains (large peptide units) that are partially bound to each other in a “Y” formation, which are flanked by two identical light chains (small peptide units), as illustrated in Figure 42.22.
7.42.369	Bonds between the cysteine amino acids in the antibody molecule attach the polypeptides to each other.
7.42.370	The areas where the antigen is recognized on the antibody are variable domains and the antibody base is composed of constant domains.
7.42.371	In germ-line B cells, the variable region of the light chain gene has 40 variable (V) and five joining (J) segments.
7.42.372	An enzyme called DNA recombinase randomly excises most of these segments out of the gene, and splices one V segment to one J segment.
7.42.373	During RNA processing, all but one V and J segment are spliced out.
7.42.374	Recombination and splicing may result in over 106 possible VJ combinations.
7.42.375	As a result, each differentiated B cell in the human body typically has a unique variable chain.
7.42.376	The constant domain, which does not bind antibody, is the same for all antibodies.
7.42.377	(a) As a germ-line B cell matures, an enzyme called DNA recombinase randomly excises V and J segments from the light chain gene.
7.42.378	Splicing at the mRNA level results in further gene rearrangement.
7.42.379	As a result, (b) each antibody has a unique variable region capable of binding a different antigen.
7.42.380	Similar to TCRs and BCRs, antibody diversity is produced by the mutation and recombination of approximately 300 different gene segments encoding the light and heavy chain variable domains in precursor cells that are destined to become B cells.
7.42.381	The variable domains from the heavy and light chains interact to form the binding site through which an antibody can bind a specific epitope on an antigen.
7.42.382	The numbers of repeated constant domains in Ig classes are the same for all antibodies corresponding to a specific class.
7.42.383	Antibodies are structurally similar to the extracellular component of the BCRs, and B cell maturation to plasma cells can be visualized in simple terms as the cell acquires the ability to secrete the extracellular portion of its BCR in large quantities.
7.42.384	Antibody Classes Antibodies can be divided into five classes—IgM, IgG, IgA, IgD, IgE—based on their physiochemical, structural, and immunological properties.
7.42.385	IgGs, which make up about 80 percent of all antibodies, have heavy chains that consist of one variable domain and three identical constant domains.
7.42.386	IgA and IgD also have three constant domains per heavy chain, whereas IgM and IgE each have four constant domains per heavy chain.
7.42.387	The variable domain determines binding specificity and the constant domain of the heavy chain determines the immunological mechanism of action of the corresponding antibody class.
7.42.388	It is possible for two antibodies to have the same binding specificities but be in different classes and, therefore, to be involved in different functions.
7.42.389	After an adaptive defense is produced against a pathogen, typically plasma cells first secrete IgM into the blood.
7.42.390	BCRs on naïve B cells are of the IgM class and occasionally IgD class.
7.42.391	IgM molecules make up approximately ten percent of all antibodies.
7.42.392	Prior to antibody secretion, plasma cells assemble IgM molecules into pentamers (five individual antibodies) linked by a joining (J) chain, as shown in Figure 42.23.
7.42.393	The pentamer arrangement means that these macromolecules can bind ten identical antigens.
7.42.394	However, IgM molecules released early in the adaptive immune response do not bind to antigens as stably as IgGs, which are one of the possible types of antibodies secreted in large quantities upon re-exposure to the same pathogen.
7.42.395	Figure 42.23 summarizes the properties of immunoglobulins and illustrates their basic structures.
7.42.396	Immunoglobulins have different functions, but all are composed of light and heavy chains that form a Y-shaped structure.
7.42.397	IgAs populate the saliva, tears, breast milk, and mucus secretions of the gastrointestinal, respiratory, and genitourinary tracts.
7.42.398	Collectively, these bodily fluids coat and protect the extensive mucosa (4000 square feet in humans).
7.42.399	The total number of IgA molecules in these bodily secretions is greater than the number of IgG molecules in the blood serum.
7.42.400	A small amount of IgA is also secreted into the serum in monomeric form.
7.42.401	Conversely, some IgM is secreted into bodily fluids of the mucosa.
7.42.402	Similar to IgM, IgA molecules are secreted as polymeric structures linked with a J chain.
7.42.403	However, IgAs are secreted mostly as dimeric molecules, not pentamers.
7.42.404	IgE is present in the serum in small quantities and is best characterized in its role as an allergy mediator.
7.42.405	IgD is also present in small quantities.
7.42.406	Similar to IgM, BCRs of the IgD class are found on the surface of naïve B cells.
7.42.407	This class supports antigen recognition and maturation of B cells to plasma cells.
7.42.408	Antibody Functions Differentiated plasma cells are crucial players in the humoral response, and the antibodies they secrete are particularly significant against extracellular pathogens and toxins.
7.42.409	Antibodies circulate freely and act independently of plasma cells.
7.42.410	Antibodies can be transferred from one individual to another to temporarily protect against infectious disease.
7.42.411	For instance, a person who has recently produced a successful immune response against a particular disease agent can donate blood to a nonimmune recipient and confer temporary immunity through antibodies in the donor’s blood serum.
7.42.412	This phenomenon is called passive immunity; it also occurs naturally during breastfeeding, which makes breastfed infants highly resistant to infections during the first few months of life.
7.42.413	Antibodies coat extracellular pathogens and neutralize them, as illustrated in Figure 42.24, by blocking key sites on the pathogen that enhance their infectivity (such as receptors that “dock” pathogens on host cells).
7.42.414	Antibody neutralization can prevent pathogens from entering and infecting host cells, as opposed to the CTL-mediated approach of killing cells that are already infected to prevent progression of an established infection.
7.42.415	The neutralized antibody-coated pathogens can then be filtered by the spleen and eliminated in urine or feces.
7.42.416	Antibodies may inhibit infection by (a) preventing the antigen from binding its target, (b) tagging a pathogen for destruction by macrophages or neutrophils, or (c) activating the complement cascade.
7.42.417	Antibodies also mark pathogens for destruction by phagocytic cells, such as macrophages or neutrophils, because phagocytic cells are highly attracted to macromolecules complexed with antibodies.
7.42.418	Phagocytic enhancement by antibodies is called opsonization.
7.42.419	In a process called complement fixation, IgM and IgG in serum bind to antigens and provide docking sites onto which sequential complement proteins can bind.
7.42.420	The combination of antibodies and complement enhances opsonization even further and promotes rapid clearing of pathogens.
7.42.421	Affinity, Avidity, and Cross Reactivity
7.42.422	Not all antibodies bind with the same strength, specificity, and stability.
7.42.423	In fact, antibodies exhibit different affinities (attraction) depending on the molecular complementarity between antigen and antibody molecules, as illustrated in Figure 42.25.
7.42.424	An antibody with a higher affinity for a particular antigen would bind more strongly and stably, and thus would be expected to present a more challenging defense against the pathogen corresponding to the specific antigen.
7.42.425	(a)
7.42.426	Affinity refers to the strength of single interaction between antigen and antibody, while avidity refers to the strength of all interactions combined.
7.42.427	(b)
7.42.428	An antibody may cross react with different epitopes.
7.42.429	The term avidity describes binding by antibody classes that are secreted as joined, multivalent structures (such as IgM and IgA).
7.42.430	Although avidity measures the strength of binding, just as affinity does, the avidity is not simply the sum of the affinities of the antibodies in a multimeric structure.
7.42.431	The avidity depends on the number of identical binding sites on the antigen being detected, as well as other physical and chemical factors.
7.42.432	Typically, multimeric antibodies, such as pentameric IgM, are classified as having lower affinity than monomeric antibodies, but high avidity.
7.42.433	Essentially, the fact that multimeric antibodies can bind many antigens simultaneously balances their slightly lower binding strength for each antibody/antigen interaction.
7.42.434	Antibodies secreted after binding to one epitope on an antigen may exhibit cross reactivity for the same or similar epitopes on different antigens.
7.42.435	Because an epitope corresponds to such a small region (the surface area of about four to six amino acids), it is possible for different macromolecules to exhibit the same molecular identities and orientations over short regions.
7.42.436	Cross reactivity describes when an antibody binds not to the antigen that elicited its synthesis and secretion, but to a different antigen.
7.42.437	Cross reactivity can be beneficial if an individual develops immunity to several related pathogens despite having only been exposed to or vaccinated against one of them.
7.42.438	For instance, antibody cross reactivity may occur against the similar surface structures of various Gram-negative bacteria.
7.42.439	Conversely, antibodies raised against pathogenic molecular components that resemble self molecules may incorrectly mark host cells for destruction and cause autoimmune damage.
7.42.440	Patients who develop systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) commonly exhibit antibodies that react with their own DNA.
7.42.441	These antibodies may have been initially raised against the nucleic acid of microorganisms but later cross-reacted with self-antigens.
7.42.442	This phenomenon is also called molecular mimicry.
7.42.443	Antibodies of the Mucosal Immune System Antibodies synthesized by the mucosal immune system include IgA and IgM. Activated B cells differentiate into mucosal plasma cells that synthesize and secrete dimeric IgA, and to a lesser extent, pentameric IgM. Secreted IgA is abundant in tears, saliva, breast milk, and in secretions of the gastrointestinal and respiratory tracts.
7.42.444	Antibody secretion results in a local humoral response at epithelial surfaces and prevents infection of the mucosa by binding and neutralizing pathogens.
7.42.445	Disruptions in the Immune System
7.42.446	By the end of this section, you will be able to: Describe hypersensitivity Define autoimmunity A functioning immune system is essential for survival, but even the sophisticated cellular and molecular defenses of the mammalian immune response can be defeated by pathogens at virtually every step.
7.42.447	In the competition between immune protection and pathogen evasion, pathogens have the advantage of more rapid evolution because of their shorter generation time and other characteristics.
7.42.448	For instance, Streptococcus pneumoniae (bacterium that cause pneumonia and meningitis) surrounds itself with a capsule that inhibits phagocytes from engulfing it and displaying antigens to the adaptive immune system.
7.42.449	Staphylococcus aureus (bacterium that can cause skin infections, abscesses, and meningitis) synthesizes a toxin called leukocidin that kills phagocytes after they engulf the bacterium.
7.42.450	Other pathogens can also hinder the adaptive immune system.
7.42.451	HIV infects TH cells via their CD4 surface molecules, gradually depleting the number of TH cells in the body; this inhibits the adaptive immune system’s capacity to generate sufficient responses to infection or tumors.
7.42.452	As a result, HIV-infected individuals often suffer from infections that would not cause illness in people with healthy immune systems but which can cause devastating illness to immune-compromised individuals.
7.42.453	Maladaptive responses of immune cells and molecules themselves can also disrupt the proper functioning of the entire system, leading to host cell damage that could become fatal.
7.42.454	Immunodeficiency Failures, insufficiencies, or delays at any level of the immune response can allow pathogens or tumor cells to gain a foothold and replicate or proliferate to high enough levels that the immune system becomes overwhelmed.
7.42.455	Immunodeficiency is the failure, insufficiency, or delay in the response of the immune system, which may be acquired or inherited.
7.42.456	Immunodeficiency can be acquired as a result of infection with certain pathogens (such as HIV), chemical exposure (including certain medical treatments), malnutrition, or possibly by extreme stress.
7.42.457	For instance, radiation exposure can destroy populations of lymphocytes and elevate an individual’s susceptibility to infections and cancer.
7.42.458	Dozens of genetic disorders result in immunodeficiencies, including Severe Combined Immunodeficiency (SCID), Bare lymphocyte syndrome, and MHC II deficiencies.
7.42.459	Rarely, primary immunodeficiencies that are present from birth may occur.
7.42.460	Neutropenia is one form in which the immune system produces a below-average number of neutrophils, the body’s most abundant phagocytes.
7.42.461	As a result, bacterial infections may go unrestricted in the blood, causing serious complications.
7.42.462	Hypersensitivities Maladaptive immune responses toward harmless foreign substances or self antigens that occur after tissue sensitization are termed hypersensitivities.
7.42.463	The types of hypersensitivities include immediate, delayed, and autoimmunity.
7.42.464	A large proportion of the population is affected by one or more types of hypersensitivity.
7.42.465	Allergies
7.42.466	The immune reaction that results from immediate hypersensitivities in which an antibody-mediated immune response occurs within minutes of exposure to a harmless antigen is called an allergy.
7.42.467	In the United States, 20 percent of the population exhibits symptoms of allergy or asthma, whereas 55 percent test positive against one or more allergens.
7.42.468	Upon initial exposure to a potential allergen, an allergic individual synthesizes antibodies of the IgE class via the typical process of APCs presenting processed antigen to TH cells that stimulate B cells to produce IgE.
7.42.469	This class of antibodies also mediates the immune response to parasitic worms.
7.42.470	The constant domain of the IgE molecules interact with mast cells embedded in connective tissues.
7.42.471	This process primes, or sensitizes, the tissue.
7.42.472	Upon subsequent exposure to the same allergen, IgE molecules on mast cells bind the antigen via their variable domains and stimulate the mast cell to release the modified amino acids histamine and serotonin; these chemical mediators then recruit eosinophils which mediate allergic responses.
7.42.473	Figure 42.26 shows an example of an allergic response to ragweed pollen.
7.42.474	The effects of an allergic reaction range from mild symptoms like sneezing and itchy, watery eyes to more severe or even life-threatening reactions involving intensely itchy welts or hives, airway contraction with severe respiratory distress, and plummeting blood pressure.
7.42.475	This extreme reaction is known as anaphylactic shock.
7.42.476	If not treated with epinephrine to counter the blood pressure and breathing effects, this condition can be fatal.
7.42.477	On first exposure to an allergen, an IgE antibody is synthesized by plasma cells in response to a harmless antigen.
7.42.478	The IgE molecules bind to mast cells, and on secondary exposure, the mast cells release histamines and other modulators that affect the symptoms of allergy.
7.42.479	Delayed hypersensitivity is a cell-mediated immune response that takes approximately one to two days after secondary exposure for a maximal reaction to be observed.
7.42.480	This type of hypersensitivity involves the TH1 cytokine-mediated inflammatory response and may manifest as local tissue lesions or contact dermatitis (rash or skin irritation).
7.42.481	Delayed hypersensitivity occurs in some individuals in response to contact with certain types of jewelry or cosmetics.
7.42.482	Delayed hypersensitivity facilitates the immune response to poison ivy and is also the reason why the skin test for tuberculosis results in a small region of inflammation on individuals who were previously exposed to Mycobacterium tuberculosis.
7.42.483	That is also why cortisone is used to treat such responses: it will inhibit cytokine production.
7.42.484	Autoimmunity Autoimmunity is a type of hypersensitivity to self antigens that affects approximately five percent of the population.
7.42.485	Most types of autoimmunity involve the humoral immune response.
7.42.486	Antibodies that inappropriately mark self components as foreign are termed autoantibodies.
7.42.487	In patients with the autoimmune disease myasthenia gravis, muscle cell receptors that induce contraction in response to acetylcholine are targeted by antibodies.
7.42.488	The result is muscle weakness that may include marked difficultly with fine and/or gross motor functions.
7.42.489	In systemic lupus erythematosus, a diffuse autoantibody response to the individual’s own DNA and proteins results in various systemic diseases.
7.42.490	As illustrated in Figure 42.27, systemic lupus erythematosus may affect the heart, joints, lungs, skin, kidneys, central nervous system, or other tissues, causing tissue damage via antibody binding, complement recruitment, lysis, and inflammation.
7.42.491	Systemic lupus erythematosus is characterized by autoimmunity to the individual’s own DNA and/or proteins, which leads to varied dysfunction of the organs.
7.42.492	Autoimmunity can develop with time, and its causes may be rooted in molecular mimicry.
7.42.493	Antibodies and TCRs may bind self antigens that are structurally similar to pathogen antigens, which the immune receptors first raised.
7.42.494	As an example, infection with Streptococcus pyogenes (bacterium that causes strep throat) may generate antibodies or T cells that react with heart muscle, which has a similar structure to the surface of S. pyogenes.
7.42.495	These antibodies can damage heart muscle with autoimmune attacks, leading to rheumatic fever.
7.42.496	Insulin-dependent (Type 1) diabetes mellitus arises from a destructive inflammatory TH1 response against insulin-producing cells of the pancreas.
7.42.497	Patients with this autoimmunity must be injected with insulin that originates from other sources.
7.43.0	Female seahorses produce eggs for reproduction that are then fertilized by the male.
7.43.1	Unlike almost all other animals, the male seahorse then gestates the young until birth.
7.43.2	Animal reproduction is necessary for the survival of a species.
7.43.3	In the animal kingdom, there are innumerable ways that species reproduce.
7.43.4	Asexual reproduction produces genetically identical organisms (clones), whereas in sexual reproduction, the genetic material of two individuals combines to produce offspring that are genetically different from their parents.
7.43.5	During sexual reproduction the male gamete (sperm) may be placed inside the female’s body for internal fertilization, or the sperm and eggs may be released into the environment for external fertilization.
7.43.6	Seahorses, like the one shown in Figure 43.1, provide an example of the latter.
7.43.7	Following a mating dance, the female lays eggs in the male seahorse’s abdominal brood pouch where they are fertilized.
7.43.8	The eggs hatch and the offspring develop in the pouch for several weeks.
7.43.9	Reproduction Methods
7.43.10	By the end of this section, you will be able to: Describe advantages and disadvantages of asexual and sexual reproduction Discuss asexual reproduction methods
7.43.11	Discuss sexual reproduction methods
7.43.12	Animals produce offspring through asexual and/or sexual reproduction.
7.43.13	Both methods have advantages and disadvantages.
7.43.14	Asexual reproduction produces offspring that are genetically identical to the parent because the offspring are all clones of the original parent.
7.43.15	A single individual can produce offspring asexually and large numbers of offspring can be produced quickly.
7.43.16	In a stable or predictable environment, asexual reproduction is an effective means of reproduction because all the offspring will be adapted to that environment.
7.43.17	In an unstable or unpredictable environment asexually-reproducing species may be at a disadvantage because all the offspring are genetically identical and may not have the genetic variation to survive in new or different conditions.
7.43.18	On the other hand, the rapid rates of asexual reproduction may allow for a speedy response to environmental changes if individuals have mutations.
7.43.19	An additional advantage of asexual reproduction is that colonization of new habitats may be easier when an individual does not need to find a mate to reproduce.
7.43.20	During sexual reproduction the genetic material of two individuals is combined to produce genetically diverse offspring that differ from their parents.
7.43.21	The genetic diversity of sexually produced offspring is thought to give species a better chance of surviving in an unpredictable or changing environment.
7.43.22	Species that reproduce sexually must maintain two different types of individuals, males and females, which can limit the ability to colonize new habitats as both sexes must be present.
7.43.23	Asexual Reproduction Asexual reproduction occurs in prokaryotic microorganisms (bacteria) and in some eukaryotic single-celled and multicelled organisms.
7.43.24	There are a number of ways that animals reproduce asexually.
7.43.25	Fission Fission, also called binary fission, occurs in prokaryotic microorganisms and in some invertebrate, multi-celled organisms.
7.43.26	After a period of growth, an organism splits into two separate organisms.
7.43.27	Some unicellular eukaryotic organisms undergo binary fission by mitosis.
7.43.28	In other organisms, part of the individual separates and forms a second individual.
7.43.29	This process occurs, for example, in many asteroid echinoderms through splitting of the central disk.
7.43.30	Some sea anemones and some coral polyps (Figure 43.2) also reproduce through fission.
7.43.31	Budding Budding is a form of asexual reproduction that results from the outgrowth of a part of a cell or body region leading to a separation from the original organism into two individuals.
7.43.32	Budding occurs commonly in some invertebrate animals such as corals and hydras.
7.43.33	In hydras, a bud forms that develops into an adult and breaks away from the main body, as illustrated in Figure 43.3, whereas in coral budding, the bud does not detach and multiplies as part of a new colony.
7.43.34	Hydra reproduce asexually through budding.
7.43.35	Fragmentation Fragmentation is the breaking of the body into two parts with subsequent regeneration.
7.43.36	If the animal is capable of fragmentation, and the part is big enough, a separate individual will regrow.
7.43.37	For example, in many sea stars, asexual reproduction is accomplished by fragmentation.
7.43.38	Figure 43.4 illustrates a sea star for which an arm of the individual is broken off and regenerates a new sea star.
7.43.39	Fisheries workers have been known to try to kill the sea stars eating their clam or oyster beds by cutting them in half and throwing them back into the ocean.
7.43.40	Unfortunately for the workers, the two parts can each regenerate a new half, resulting in twice as many sea stars to prey upon the oysters and clams.
7.43.41	Fragmentation also occurs in annelid worms, turbellarians, and poriferans.
7.43.42	Sea stars can reproduce through fragmentation.
7.43.43	The large arm, a fragment from another sea star, is developing into a new individual.
7.43.44	Note that in fragmentation, there is generally a noticeable difference in the size of the individuals, whereas in fission, two individuals of approximate size are formed.
7.43.45	Parthenogenesis Parthenogenesis is a form of asexual reproduction where an egg develops into a complete individual without being fertilized.
7.43.46	The resulting offspring can be either haploid or diploid, depending on the process and the species.
7.43.47	Parthenogenesis occurs in invertebrates such as water flees, rotifers, aphids, stick insects, some ants, wasps, and bees.
7.43.48	Bees use parthenogenesis to produce haploid males (drones) and diploid females (workers).
7.43.49	If an egg is fertilized, a queen is produced.
7.43.50	The queen bee controls the reproduction of the hive bees to regulate the type of bee produced.
7.43.51	Some vertebrate animals—such as certain reptiles, amphibians, and fish—also reproduce through parthenogenesis.
7.43.52	Although more common in plants, parthenogenesis has been observed in animal species that were segregated by sex in terrestrial or marine zoos.
7.43.53	Two female Komodo dragons, a hammerhead shark, and a blacktop shark have produced parthenogenic young when the females have been isolated from males.
7.43.54	Sexual Reproduction Sexual reproduction is the combination of (usually haploid) reproductive cells from two individuals to form a third (usually diploid) unique offspring.
7.43.55	Sexual reproduction produces offspring with novel combinations of genes.
7.43.56	This can be an adaptive advantage in unstable or unpredictable environments.
7.43.57	As humans, we are used to thinking of animals as having two separate sexes—male and female—determined at conception.
7.43.58	However, in the animal kingdom, there are many variations on this theme.
7.43.59	Hermaphroditism Hermaphroditism occurs in animals where one individual has both male and female reproductive parts.
7.43.60	Invertebrates such as earthworms, slugs, tapeworms and snails, shown in Figure 43.5, are often hermaphroditic.
7.43.61	Hermaphrodites may selffertilize or may mate with another of their species, fertilizing each other and both producing offspring.
7.43.62	Self fertilization is common in animals that have limited mobility or are not motile, such as barnacles and clams.
7.43.63	Many snails are hermaphrodites.
7.43.64	When two individuals mate, they can produce up to one hundred eggs each.
7.43.65	Sex Determination Mammalian sex determination is determined genetically by the presence of X and Y chromosomes.
7.43.66	Individuals homozygous for X (XX) are female and heterozygous individuals (XY) are male.
7.43.67	The presence of a Y chromosome causes the development of male characteristics and its absence results in female characteristics.
7.43.68	The XY system is also found in some insects and plants.
7.43.69	Avian sex determination is dependent on the presence of Z and W chromosomes.
7.43.70	Homozygous for Z (ZZ) results in a male and heterozygous (ZW) results in a female.
7.43.71	The W appears to be essential in determining the sex of the individual, similar to the Y chromosome in mammals.
7.43.72	Some fish, crustaceans, insects (such as butterflies and moths), and reptiles use this system.
7.43.73	The sex of some species is not determined by genetics but by some aspect of the environment.
7.43.74	Sex determination in some crocodiles and turtles, for example, is often dependent on the temperature during critical periods of egg development.
7.43.75	This is referred to as environmental sex determination, or more specifically as temperature-dependent sex determination.
7.43.76	In many turtles, cooler temperatures during egg incubation produce males and warm temperatures produce females.
7.43.77	In some crocodiles, moderate temperatures produce males and both warm and cool temperatures produce females.
7.43.78	In some species, sex is both genetic- and temperature-dependent.
7.43.79	Individuals of some species change their sex during their lives, alternating between male and female.
7.43.80	If the individual is female first, it is termed protogyny or “first female,” if it is male first, its termed protandry or “first male.
7.43.81	”
7.43.82	Oysters, for example, are born male, grow, and become female and lay eggs; some oyster species change sex multiple times.
7.43.83	Fertilization
7.43.84	By the end of this section, you will be able to:
7.43.85	Discuss internal and external methods of fertilization Describe the methods used by animals for development of offspring during gestation Describe the anatomical adaptions that occurred in animals to facilitate reproduction Sexual reproduction starts with the combination of a sperm and an egg in a process called fertilization.
7.43.86	This can occur either inside ( internal fertilization) or outside ( external fertilization) the body of the female.
7.43.87	Humans provide an example of the former whereas seahorse reproduction is an example of the latter.
7.43.88	External Fertilization External fertilization usually occurs in aquatic environments where both eggs and sperm are released into the water.
7.43.89	After the sperm reaches the egg, fertilization takes place.
7.43.90	Most external fertilization happens during the process of spawning where one or several females release their eggs and the male(s) release sperm in the same area, at the same time.
7.43.91	The release of the reproductive material may be triggered by water temperature or the length of daylight.
7.43.92	Nearly all fish spawn, as do crustaceans (such as crabs and shrimp), mollusks (such as oysters), squid, and echinoderms (such as sea urchins and sea cucumbers).
7.43.93	Figure 43.6 shows salmon spawning in a shallow stream.
7.43.94	Frogs, like those shown in Figure 43.7, corals, molluscs, and sea cucumbers also spawn.
7.43.95	Salmon reproduce through spawning.
7.43.96	During sexual reproduction in toads, the male grasps the female from behind and externally fertilizes the eggs as they are deposited.
7.43.97	Pairs of fish that are not broadcast spawners may exhibit courtship behavior.
7.43.98	This allows the female to select a particular male.
7.43.99	The trigger for egg and sperm release (spawning) causes the egg and sperm to be placed in a small area, enhancing the possibility of fertilization.
7.43.100	External fertilization in an aquatic environment protects the eggs from drying out.
7.43.101	Broadcast spawning can result in a greater mixture of the genes within a group, leading to higher genetic diversity and a greater chance of species survival in a hostile environment.
7.43.102	For sessile aquatic organisms like sponges, broadcast spawning is the only mechanism for fertilization and colonization of new environments.
7.43.103	The presence of the fertilized eggs and developing young in the water provides opportunities for predation resulting in a loss of offspring.
7.43.104	Therefore, millions of eggs must be produced by individuals, and the offspring produced through this method must mature rapidly.
7.43.105	The survival rate of eggs produced through broadcast spawning is low.
7.43.106	Internal Fertilization Internal fertilization occurs most often in land-based animals, although some aquatic animals also use this method.
7.43.107	There are three ways that offspring are produced following internal fertilization.
7.43.108	In oviparity, fertilized eggs are laid outside the female’s body and develop there, receiving nourishment from the yolk that is a part of the egg.
7.43.109	This occurs in most bony fish, many reptiles, some cartilaginous fish, most amphibians, two mammals, and all birds.
7.43.110	Reptiles and insects produce leathery eggs, while birds and turtles produce eggs with high concentrations of calcium carbonate in the shell, making them hard.
7.43.111	Chicken eggs are an example of this second type.
7.43.112	In ovoviparity, fertilized eggs are retained in the female, but the embryo obtains its nourishment from the egg’s yolk and the young are fully developed when they are hatched.
7.43.113	This occurs in some bony fish (like the guppy Lebistes reticulatus), some sharks, some lizards, some snakes (such as the garter snake Thamnophis sirtalis), some vipers, and some invertebrate animals (like the Madagascar hissing cockroach Gromphadorhina portentosa).
7.43.114	In viviparity the young develop within the female, receiving nourishment from the mother’s blood through a placenta.
7.43.115	The offspring develops in the female and is born alive.
7.43.116	This occurs in most mammals, some cartilaginous fish, and a few reptiles.
7.43.117	Internal fertilization has the advantage of protecting the fertilized egg from dehydration on land.
7.43.118	The embryo is isolated within the female, which limits predation on the young.
7.43.119	Internal fertilization enhances the fertilization of eggs by a specific male.
7.43.120	Fewer offspring are produced through this method, but their survival rate is higher than that for external fertilization.
7.43.121	The Evolution of Reproduction Once multicellular organisms evolved and developed specialized cells, some also developed tissues and organs with specialized functions.
7.43.122	An early development in reproduction occurred in the Annelids.
7.43.123	These organisms produce sperm and eggs from undifferentiated cells in their coelom and store them in that cavity.
7.43.124	When the coelom becomes filled, the cells are released through an excretory opening or by the body splitting open.
7.43.125	Reproductive organs evolved with the development of gonads that produce sperm and eggs.
7.43.126	These cells went through meiosis, an adaption of mitosis, which reduced the number of chromosomes in each reproductive cell by half, while increasing the number of cells through cell division.
7.43.127	Complete reproductive systems were developed in insects, with separate sexes.
7.43.128	Sperm are made in testes and then travel through coiled tubes to the epididymis for storage.
7.43.129	Eggs mature in the ovary.
7.43.130	When they are released from the ovary, they travel to the uterine tubes for fertilization.
7.43.131	Some insects have a specialized sac, called a spermatheca, which stores sperm for later use, sometimes up to a year.
7.43.132	Fertilization can be timed with environmental or food conditions that are optimal for offspring survival.
7.43.133	Vertebrates have similar structures, with a few differences.
7.43.134	Non-mammals, such as birds and reptiles, have a common body opening, called a cloaca, for the digestive, excretory and reproductive systems.
7.43.135	Coupling between birds usually involves positioning the cloaca openings opposite each other for transfer of sperm.
7.43.136	Mammals have separate openings for the systems in the female and a uterus for support of developing offspring.
7.43.137	The uterus has two chambers in species that produce large numbers of offspring at a time, while species that produce one offspring, such as primates, have a single uterus.
7.43.138	Sperm transfer from the male to the female during reproduction ranges from releasing the sperm into the watery environment for external fertilization, to the joining of cloaca in birds, to the development of a penis for direct delivery into the female’s vagina in mammals.
7.43.139	Human Reproductive Anatomy and Gametogenesis
7.43.140	By the end of this section, you will be able to:
7.43.141	Describe human male and female reproductive anatomies Discuss the human sexual response Describe spermatogenesis and oogenesis and discuss their differences and similarities
7.43.142	As animals became more complex, specific organs and organ systems developed to support specific functions for the organism.
7.43.143	The reproductive structures that evolved in land animals allow males and females to mate, fertilize internally, and support the growth and development of offspring.
7.43.144	Human Reproductive Anatomy
7.43.145	The reproductive tissues of male and female humans develop similarly in utero until a low level of the hormone testosterone is released from male gonads.
7.43.146	Testosterone causes the undeveloped tissues to differentiate into male sexual organs.
7.43.147	When testosterone is absent, the tissues develop into female sexual tissues.
7.43.148	Primitive gonads become testes or ovaries.
7.43.149	Tissues that produce a penis in males produce a clitoris in females.
7.43.150	The tissue that will become the scrotum in a male becomes the labia in a female; that is, they are homologous structures.
7.43.151	Male Reproductive Anatomy
7.43.152	In the male reproductive system, the scrotum houses the testicles or testes (singular: testis), including providing passage for blood vessels, nerves, and muscles related to testicular function.
7.43.153	The testes are a pair of male reproductive organs that produce sperm and some reproductive hormones.
7.43.154	Each testis is approximately 2.5 by 3.8 cm (1.5 by 1 in) in size and divided into wedge-shaped lobules by connective tissue called septa.
7.43.155	Coiled in each wedge are seminiferous tubules that produce sperm.
7.43.156	Sperm are immobile at body temperature; therefore, the scrotum and penis are external to the body, as illustrated in Figure 43.8 so that a proper temperature is maintained for motility.
7.43.157	In land mammals, the pair of testes must be suspended outside the body at about 2° C lower than body temperature to produce viable sperm.
7.43.158	Infertility can occur in land mammals when the testes do not descend through the abdominal cavity during fetal development.
7.43.159	Sperm mature in seminiferous tubules that are coiled inside the testes, as illustrated in Figure 43.8.
7.43.160	The walls of the seminiferous tubules are made up of the developing sperm cells, with the least developed sperm at the periphery of the tubule and the fully developed sperm in the lumen.
7.43.161	The sperm cells are mixed with “nursemaid” cells called Sertoli cells which protect the germ cells and promote their development.
7.43.162	Other cells mixed in the wall of the tubules are the interstitial cells of Leydig.
7.43.163	These cells produce high levels of testosterone once the male reaches adolescence.
7.43.164	When the sperm have developed flagella and are nearly mature, they leave the testicles and enter the epididymis, shown in Figure 43.8.
7.43.165	This structure resembles a comma and lies along the top and posterior portion of the testes; it is the site of sperm maturation.
7.43.166	The sperm leave the epididymis and enter the vas deferens (or ductus deferens), which carries the sperm, behind the bladder, and forms the ejaculatory duct with the duct from the seminal vesicles.
7.43.167	During a vasectomy, a section of the vas deferens is removed, preventing sperm from being passed out of the body during ejaculation and preventing fertilization.
7.43.168	Semen is a mixture of sperm and spermatic duct secretions (about 10 percent of the total) and fluids from accessory glands that contribute most of the semen’s volume.
7.43.169	Sperm are haploid cells, consisting of a flagellum as a tail, a neck that contains the cell’s energy-producing mitochondria, and a head that contains the genetic material.
7.43.170	Figure 43.9 shows a micrograph of human sperm as well as a diagram of the parts of the sperm.
7.43.171	An acrosome is found at the top of the head of the sperm.
7.43.172	This structure contains lysosomal enzymes that can digest the protective coverings that surround the egg to help the sperm penetrate and fertilize the egg.
7.43.173	An ejaculate will contain from two to five milliliters of fluid with from 50–120 million sperm per milliliter.
7.43.174	Human sperm, visualized using scanning electron microscopy, have a flagellum, neck, and head.
7.43.175	The bulk of the semen comes from the accessory glands associated with the male reproductive system.
7.43.176	These are the seminal vesicles, the prostate gland, and the bulbourethral gland, all of which are illustrated in Figure 43.8.
7.43.177	The seminal vesicles are a pair of glands that lie along the posterior border of the urinary bladder.
7.43.178	The glands make a solution that is thick, yellowish, and alkaline.
7.43.179	As sperm are only motile in an alkaline environment, a basic pH is important to reverse the acidity of the vaginal environment.
7.43.180	The solution also contains mucus, fructose (a sperm mitochondrial nutrient), a coagulating enzyme, ascorbic acid, and local-acting hormones called prostaglandins.
7.43.181	The seminal vesicle glands account for 60 percent of the bulk of semen.
7.43.182	The penis, illustrated in Figure 43.8, is an organ that drains urine from the renal bladder and functions as a copulatory organ during intercourse.
7.43.183	The penis contains three tubes of erectile tissue running through the length of the organ.
7.43.184	These consist of a pair of tubes on the dorsal side, called the corpus cavernosum, and a single tube of tissue on the ventral side, called the corpus spongiosum.
7.43.185	This tissue will become engorged with blood, becoming erect and hard, in preparation for intercourse.
7.43.186	The organ is inserted into the vagina culminating with an ejaculation.
7.43.187	During intercourse, the smooth muscle sphincters at the opening to the renal bladder close and prevent urine from entering the penis.
7.43.188	An orgasm is a two-stage process: first, glands and accessory organs connected to the testes contract, then semen (containing sperm) is expelled through the urethra during ejaculation.
7.43.189	After intercourse, the blood drains from the erectile tissue and the penis becomes flaccid.
7.43.190	The walnut-shaped prostate gland surrounds the urethra, the connection to the urinary bladder.
7.43.191	It has a series of short ducts that directly connect to the urethra.
7.43.192	The gland is a mixture of smooth muscle and glandular tissue.
7.43.193	The muscle provides much of the force needed for ejaculation to occur.
7.43.194	The glandular tissue makes a thin, milky fluid that contains citrate (a nutrient), enzymes, and prostate specific antigen (PSA).
7.43.195	PSA is a proteolytic enzyme that helps to liquefy the ejaculate several minutes after release from the male.
7.43.196	Prostate gland secretions account for about 30 percent of the bulk of semen.
7.43.197	The bulbourethral gland, or Cowper’s gland, releases its secretion prior to the release of the bulk of the semen.
7.43.198	It neutralizes any acid residue in the urethra left over from urine.
7.43.199	This usually accounts for a couple of drops of fluid in the total ejaculate and may contain a few sperm.
7.43.200	Withdrawal of the penis from the vagina before ejaculation to prevent pregnancy may not work if sperm are present in the bulbourethral gland secretions.
7.43.201	The location and functions of the male reproductive organs are summarized in Table 43.1.
7.43.202	Female Reproductive Anatomy
7.43.203	A number of reproductive structures are exterior to the female’s body.
7.43.204	These include the breasts and the vulva, which consists of the mons pubis, clitoris, labia majora, labia minora, and the vestibular glands, all illustrated in Figure 43.10.
7.43.205	The location and functions of the female reproductive organs are summarized in Table 43.2.
7.43.206	The vulva is an area associated with the vestibule which includes the structures found in the inguinal (groin) area of women.
7.43.207	The mons pubis is a round, fatty area that overlies the pubic symphysis.
7.43.208	The clitoris is a structure with erectile tissue that contains a large number of sensory nerves and serves as a source of stimulation during intercourse.
7.43.209	The labia majora are a pair of elongated folds of tissue that run posterior from the mons pubis and enclose the other components of the vulva.
7.43.210	The labia majora derive from the same tissue that produces the scrotum in a male.
7.43.211	The labia minora are thin folds of tissue centrally located within the labia majora.
7.43.212	These labia protect the openings to the vagina and urethra.
7.43.213	The mons pubis and the anterior portion of the labia majora become covered with hair during adolescence; the labia minora is hairless.
7.43.214	The greater vestibular glands are found at the sides of the vaginal opening and provide lubrication during intercourse.
7.43.215	The reproductive structures of the human female are shown.
7.43.216	The breasts consist of mammary glands and fat.
7.43.217	The size of the breast is determined by the amount of fat deposited behind the gland.
7.43.218	Each gland consists of 15 to 25 lobes that have ducts that empty at the nipple and that supply the nursing child with nutrient- and antibody-rich milk to aid development and protect the child.
7.43.219	Internal female reproductive structures include ovaries, oviducts, the uterus, and the vagina, shown in Figure 43.10.
7.43.220	The pair of ovaries is held in place in the abdominal cavity by a system of ligaments.
7.43.221	Ovaries consist of a medulla and cortex: the medulla contains nerves and blood vessels to supply the cortex with nutrients and remove waste.
7.43.222	The outer layers of cells of the cortex are the functional parts of the ovaries.
7.43.223	The cortex is made up of follicular cells that surround eggs that develop during fetal development in utero.
7.43.224	During the menstrual period, a batch of follicular cells develops and prepares the eggs for release.
7.43.225	At ovulation, one follicle ruptures and one egg is released, as illustrated in Figure 43.11a.
7.43.226	Oocytes develop in (a) follicles, located in the ovary.
7.43.227	At the beginning of the menstrual cycle, the follicle matures.
7.43.228	At ovulation, the follicle ruptures, releasing the egg.
7.43.229	The follicle becomes a corpus luteum, which eventually degenerates.
7.43.230	The (b) follicle in this light micrograph has an oocyte at its center.
7.43.231	The oviducts, or fallopian tubes, extend from the uterus in the lower abdominal cavity to the ovaries, but they are not in contact with the ovaries.
7.43.232	The lateral ends of the oviducts flare out into a trumpet-like structure and have a fringe of fingerlike projections called fimbriae, illustrated in Figure 43.10b.
7.43.233	When an egg is released at ovulation, the fimbrae help the non-motile egg enter into the tube and passage to the uterus.
7.43.234	The walls of the oviducts are ciliated and are made up mostly of smooth muscle.
7.43.235	The cilia beat toward the middle, and the smooth muscle contracts in the same direction, moving the egg toward the uterus.
7.43.236	Fertilization usually takes place within the oviducts and the developing embryo is moved toward the uterus for development.
7.43.237	It usually takes the egg or embryo a week to travel through the oviduct.
7.43.238	Sterilization in women is called a tubal ligation; it is analogous to a vasectomy in males in that the oviducts are severed and sealed.
7.43.239	The uterus is a structure about the size of a woman’s fist.
7.43.240	This is lined with an endometrium rich in blood vessels and mucus glands.
7.43.241	The uterus supports the developing embryo and fetus during gestation.
7.43.242	The thickest portion of the wall of the uterus is made of smooth muscle.
7.43.243	Contractions of the smooth muscle in the uterus aid in passing the baby through the vagina during labor.
7.43.244	A portion of the lining of the uterus sloughs off during each menstrual period, and then builds up again in preparation for an implantation.
7.43.245	Part of the uterus, called the cervix, protrudes into the top of the vagina.
7.43.246	The cervix functions as the birth canal.
7.43.247	The vagina is a muscular tube that serves several purposes.
7.43.248	It allows menstrual flow to leave the body.
7.43.249	It is the receptacle for the penis during intercourse and the vessel for the delivery of offspring.
7.43.250	It is lined by stratified squamous epithelial cells to protect the underlying tissue.
7.43.251	Sexual Response during Intercourse
7.43.252	The sexual response in humans is both psychological and physiological.
7.43.253	Both sexes experience sexual arousal through psychological and physical stimulation.
7.43.254	There are four phases of the sexual response.
7.43.255	During phase one, called excitement, vasodilation leads to vasocongestion in erectile tissues in both men and women.
7.43.256	The nipples, clitoris, labia, and penis engorge with blood and become enlarged.
7.43.257	Vaginal secretions are released to lubricate the vagina to facilitate intercourse.
7.43.258	During the second phase, called the plateau, stimulation continues, the outer third of the vaginal wall enlarges with blood, and breathing and heart rate increase.
7.43.259	During phase three, or orgasm, rhythmic, involuntary contractions of muscles occur in both sexes.
7.43.260	In the male, the reproductive accessory glands and tubules constrict placing semen in the urethra, then the urethra contracts expelling the semen through the penis.
7.43.261	In women, the uterus and vaginal muscles contract in waves that may last slightly less than a second each.
7.43.262	During phase four, or resolution, the processes described in the first three phases reverse themselves and return to their normal state.
7.43.263	Men experience a refractory period in which they cannot maintain an erection or ejaculate for a period of time ranging from minutes to hours.
7.43.264	Gametogenesis (Spermatogenesis and Oogenesis)
7.43.265	Gametogenesis, the production of sperm and eggs, takes place through the process of meiosis.
7.43.266	During meiosis, two cell divisions separate the paired chromosomes in the nucleus and then separate the chromatids that were made during an earlier stage of the cell’s life cycle.
7.43.267	Meiosis produces haploid cells with half of each pair of chromosomes normally found in diploid cells.
7.43.268	The production of sperm is called spermatogenesis and the production of eggs is called oogenesis.
7.43.269	Spermatogenesis
7.43.270	During spermatogenesis, four sperm result from each primary spermatocyte.
7.43.271	Spermatogenesis, illustrated in Figure 43.12, occurs in the wall of the seminiferous tubules (Figure 43.8), with stem cells at the periphery of the tube and the spermatozoa at the lumen of the tube.
7.43.272	Immediately under the capsule of the tubule are diploid, undifferentiated cells.
7.43.273	These stem cells, called spermatogonia (singular: spermatagonium), go through mitosis with one offspring going on to differentiate into a sperm cell and the other giving rise to the next generation of sperm.
7.43.274	Meiosis starts with a cell called a primary spermatocyte.
7.43.275	At the end of the first meiotic division, a haploid cell is produced called a secondary spermatocyte.
7.43.276	This cell is haploid and must go through another meiotic cell division.
7.43.277	The cell produced at the end of meiosis is called a spermatid and when it reaches the lumen of the tubule and grows a flagellum, it is called a sperm cell.
7.43.278	Four sperm result from each primary spermatocyte that goes through meiosis.
7.43.279	Stem cells are deposited during gestation and are present at birth through the beginning of adolescence, but in an inactive state.
7.43.280	During adolescence, gonadotropic hormones from the anterior pituitary cause the activation of these cells and the production of viable sperm.
7.43.281	This continues into old age.
7.43.282	Oogenesis Oogenesis, illustrated in Figure 43.13, occurs in the outermost layers of the ovaries.
7.43.283	As with sperm production, oogenesis starts with a germ cell, called an oogonium (plural: oogonia), but this cell undergoes mitosis to increase in number, eventually resulting in up to about one to two million cells in the embryo.
7.43.284	The process of oogenesis occurs in the ovary’s outermost layer.
7.43.285	The cell starting meiosis is called a primary oocyte, as shown in Figure 43.13.
7.43.286	This cell will start the first meiotic division and be arrested in its progress in the first prophase stage.
7.43.287	At the time of birth, all future eggs are in the prophase stage.
7.43.288	At adolescence, anterior pituitary hormones cause the development of a number of follicles in an ovary.
7.43.289	This results in the primary oocyte finishing the first meiotic division.
7.43.290	The cell divides unequally, with most of the cellular material and organelles going to one cell, called a secondary oocyte, and only one set of chromosomes and a small amount of cytoplasm going to the other cell.
7.43.291	This second cell is called a polar body and usually dies.
7.43.292	A secondary meiotic arrest occurs, this time at the metaphase II stage.
7.43.293	At ovulation, this secondary oocyte will be released and travel toward the uterus through the oviduct.
7.43.294	If the secondary oocyte is fertilized, the cell continues through the meiosis II, producing a second polar body and a fertilized egg containing all 46 chromosomes of a human being, half of them coming from the sperm.
7.43.295	Egg production begins before birth, is arrested during meiosis until puberty, and then individual cells continue through at each menstrual cycle.
7.43.296	One egg is produced from each meiotic process, with the extra chromosomes and chromatids going into polar bodies that degenerate and are reabsorbed by the body.
7.43.297	Hormonal Control of Human Reproduction
7.43.298	By the end of this chapter, you will be able to: Describe the roles of male and female reproductive hormones Discuss the interplay of the ovarian and menstrual cycles Describe the process of menopause
7.43.299	The human male and female reproductive cycles are controlled by the interaction of hormones from the hypothalamus and anterior pituitary with hormones from reproductive tissues and organs.
7.43.300	In both sexes, the hypothalamus monitors and causes the release of hormones from the pituitary gland.
7.43.301	When the reproductive hormone is required, the hypothalamus sends a gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) to the anterior pituitary.
7.43.302	This causes the release of follicle stimulating hormone (FSH) and luteinizing hormone (LH) from the anterior pituitary into the blood.
7.43.303	Note that the body must reach puberty in order for the adrenals to release the hormones that must be present for GnRH to be produced.
7.43.304	Although FSH and LH are named after their functions in female reproduction, they are produced in both sexes and play important roles in controlling reproduction.
7.43.305	Other hormones have specific functions in the male and female reproductive systems.
7.43.306	Male Hormones
7.43.307	At the onset of puberty, the hypothalamus causes the release of FSH and LH into the male system for the first time.
7.43.308	FSH enters the testes and stimulates the Sertoli cells to begin facilitating spermatogenesis using negative feedback, as illustrated in Figure 43.14.
7.43.309	LH also enters the testes and stimulates the interstitial cells of Leydig to make and release testosterone into the testes and the blood.
7.43.310	Testosterone, the hormone responsible for the secondary sexual characteristics that develop in the male during adolescence, stimulates spermatogenesis.
7.43.311	These secondary sex characteristics include a deepening of the voice, the growth of facial, axillary, and pubic hair, and the beginnings of the sex drive.
7.43.312	Hormones control sperm production in a negative feedback system.
7.43.313	A negative feedback system occurs in the male with rising levels of testosterone acting on the hypothalamus and anterior pituitary to inhibit the release of GnRH, FSH, and LH.
7.43.314	The Sertoli cells produce the hormone inhibin, which is released into the blood when the sperm count is too high.
7.43.315	This inhibits the release of GnRH and FSH, which will cause spermatogenesis to slow down.
7.43.316	If the sperm count reaches 20 million/ml, the Sertoli cells cease the release of inhibin, and the sperm count increases.
7.43.317	Female Hormones
7.43.318	The control of reproduction in females is more complex.
7.43.319	As with the male, the anterior pituitary hormones cause the release of the hormones FSH and LH.
7.43.320	In addition, estrogens and progesterone are released from the developing follicles.
7.43.321	Estrogen is the reproductive hormone in females that assists in endometrial regrowth, ovulation, and calcium absorption; it is also responsible for the secondary sexual characteristics of females.
7.43.322	These include breast development, flaring of the hips, and a shorter period necessary for bone maturation.
7.43.323	Progesterone assists in endometrial re-growth and inhibition of FSH and LH release.
7.43.324	In females, FSH stimulates development of egg cells, called ova, which develop in structures called follicles.
7.43.325	Follicle cells produce the hormone inhibin, which inhibits FSH production.
7.43.326	LH also plays a role in the development of ova, induction of ovulation, and stimulation of estradiol and progesterone production by the ovaries.
7.43.327	Estradiol and progesterone are steroid hormones that prepare the body for pregnancy.
7.43.328	Estradiol produces secondary sex characteristics in females, while both estradiol and progesterone regulate the menstrual cycle.
7.43.329	The Ovarian Cycle and the Menstrual Cycle
7.43.330	The ovarian cycle governs the preparation of endocrine tissues and release of eggs, while the menstrual cycle governs the preparation and maintenance of the uterine lining.
7.43.331	These cycles occur concurrently and are coordinated over a 22–32 day cycle, with an average length of 28 days.
7.43.332	The first half of the ovarian cycle is the follicular phase shown in Figure 43.15.
7.43.333	Slowly rising levels of FSH and LH cause the growth of follicles on the surface of the ovary.
7.43.334	This process prepares the egg for ovulation.
7.43.335	As the follicles grow, they begin releasing estrogens and a low level of progesterone.
7.43.336	Progesterone maintains the endometrium to help ensure pregnancy.
7.43.337	The trip through the fallopian tube takes about seven days.
7.43.338	At this stage of development, called the morula, there are 30-60 cells.
7.43.339	If pregnancy implantation does not occur, the lining is sloughed off.
7.43.340	After about five days, estrogen levels rise and the menstrual cycle enters the proliferative phase.
