7.43.341	The endometrium begins to regrow, replacing the blood vessels and glands that deteriorated during the end of the last cycle.
7.43.342	Just prior to the middle of the cycle (approximately day 14), the high level of estrogen causes FSH and especially LH to rise rapidly, then fall.
7.43.343	The spike in LH causes ovulation: the most mature follicle, like that shown in Figure 43.16, ruptures and releases its egg.
7.43.344	The follicles that did not rupture degenerate and their eggs are lost.
7.43.345	The level of estrogen decreases when the extra follicles degenerate.
7.43.346	This mature egg follicle may rupture and release an egg.
7.43.347	Following ovulation, the ovarian cycle enters its luteal phase, illustrated in Figure 43.15 and the menstrual cycle enters its secretory phase, both of which run from about day 15 to 28.
7.43.348	The luteal and secretory phases refer to changes in the ruptured follicle.
7.43.349	The cells in the follicle undergo physical changes and produce a structure called a corpus luteum.
7.43.350	The corpus luteum produces estrogen and progesterone.
7.43.351	The progesterone facilitates the regrowth of the uterine lining and inhibits the release of further FSH and LH.
7.43.352	The uterus is being prepared to accept a fertilized egg, should it occur during this cycle.
7.43.353	The inhibition of FSH and LH prevents any further eggs and follicles from developing, while the progesterone is elevated.
7.43.354	The level of estrogen produced by the corpus luteum increases to a steady level for the next few days.
7.43.355	If no fertilized egg is implanted into the uterus, the corpus luteum degenerates and the levels of estrogen and progesterone decrease.
7.43.356	The endometrium begins to degenerate as the progesterone levels drop, initiating the next menstrual cycle.
7.43.357	The decrease in progesterone also allows the hypothalamus to send GnRH to the anterior pituitary, releasing FSH and LH and starting the cycles again.
7.43.358	Figure 43.17 visually compares the ovarian and uterine cycles as well as the commensurate hormone levels.
7.43.359	Menopause
7.43.360	As women approach their mid-40s to mid-50s, their ovaries begin to lose their sensitivity to FSH and LH.
7.43.361	Menstrual periods become less frequent and finally cease; this is menopause.
7.43.362	There are still eggs and potential follicles on the ovaries, but without the stimulation of FSH and LH, they will not produce a viable egg to be released.
7.43.363	The outcome of this is the inability to have children.
7.43.364	The side effects of menopause include hot flashes, heavy sweating (especially at night), headaches, some hair loss, muscle pain, vaginal dryness, insomnia, depression, weight gain, and mood swings.
7.43.365	Estrogen is involved in calcium metabolism and, without it, blood levels of calcium decrease.
7.43.366	To replenish the blood, calcium is lost from bone which may decrease the bone density and lead to osteoporosis.
7.43.367	Supplementation of estrogen in the form of hormone replacement therapy (HRT) can prevent bone loss, but the therapy can have negative side effects.
7.43.368	While HRT is thought to give some protection from colon cancer, osteoporosis, heart disease, macular degeneration, and possibly depression, its negative side effects include increased risk of: stroke or heart attack, blood clots, breast cancer, ovarian cancer, endometrial cancer, gall bladder disease, and possibly dementia.
7.43.369	Human Pregnancy and Birth
7.43.370	By the end of this section, you will be able to: Explain fetal development during the three trimesters of gestation Describe labor and delivery Compare the efficacy and duration of various types of contraception Discuss causes of infertility and the therapeutic options available Pregnancy begins with the fertilization of an egg and continues through to the birth of the individual.
7.43.371	The length of time of gestation varies among animals, but is very similar among the great apes: human gestation is 266 days, while chimpanzee gestation is 237 days, a gorilla’s is 257 days, and orangutan gestation is 260 days long.
7.43.372	The fox has a 57-day gestation.
7.43.373	Dogs and cats have similar gestations averaging 60 days.
7.43.374	The longest gestation for a land mammal is an African elephant at 640 days.
7.43.375	The longest gestations among marine mammals are the beluga and sperm whales at 460 days.
7.43.376	Human Gestation
7.43.377	Twenty-four hours before fertilization, the egg has finished meiosis and becomes a mature oocyte.
7.43.378	When fertilized (at conception) the egg becomes known as a zygote.
7.43.379	The zygote travels through the oviduct to the uterus (Figure 43.18).
7.43.380	The developing embryo must implant into the wall of the uterus within seven days, or it will deteriorate and die.
7.43.381	The outer layers of the zygote (blastocyst) grow into the endometrium by digesting the endometrial cells, and wound healing of the endometrium closes up the blastocyst into the tissue.
7.43.382	Another layer of the blastocyst, the chorion, begins releasing a hormone called human beta chorionic gonadotropin (β-HCG) which makes its way to the corpus luteum and keeps that structure active.
7.43.383	This ensures adequate levels of progesterone that will maintain the endometrium of the uterus for the support of the developing embryo.
7.43.384	Pregnancy tests determine the level of β-HCG in urine or serum.
7.43.385	If the hormone is present, the test is positive.
7.43.386	In humans, fertilization occurs soon after the oocyte leaves the ovary.
7.43.387	Implantation occurs eight or nine days later.
7.43.388	The gestation period is divided into three equal periods or trimesters.
7.43.389	During the first two to four weeks of the first trimester, nutrition and waste are handled by the endometrial lining through diffusion.
7.43.390	As the trimester progresses, the outer layer of the embryo begins to merge with the endometrium, and the placenta forms.
7.43.391	This organ takes over the nutrient and waste requirements of the embryo and fetus, with the mother’s blood passing nutrients to the placenta and removing waste from it.
7.43.392	Chemicals from the fetus, such as bilirubin, are processed by the mother’s liver for elimination.
7.43.393	Some of the mother’s immunoglobulins will pass through the placenta, providing passive immunity against some potential infections.
7.43.394	Internal organs and body structures begin to develop during the first trimester.
7.43.395	By five weeks, limb buds, eyes, the heart, and liver have been basically formed.
7.43.396	By eight weeks, the term fetus applies, and the body is essentially formed, as shown in Figure 43.19.
7.43.397	The individual is about five centimeters (two inches) in length and many of the organs, such as the lungs and liver, are not yet functioning.
7.43.398	Exposure to any toxins is especially dangerous during the first trimester, as all of the body’s organs and structures are going through initial development.
7.43.399	Anything that affects that development can have a severe effect on the fetus’ survival.
7.43.400	Fetal development is shown at nine weeks gestation.
7.43.401	During the second trimester, the fetus grows to about 30 cm (12 inches), as shown in Figure 43.20.
7.43.402	It becomes active and the mother usually feels the first movements.
7.43.403	All organs and structures continue to develop.
7.43.404	The placenta has taken over the functions of nutrition and waste and the production of estrogen and progesterone from the corpus luteum, which has degenerated.
7.43.405	The placenta will continue functioning up through the delivery of the baby.
7.43.406	This fetus is just entering the second trimester, when the placenta takes over more of the functions performed as the baby develops.
7.43.407	During the third trimester, the fetus grows to 3 to 4 kg (6 ½ -8 ½ lbs.) and about 50 cm (19-20 inches) long, as illustrated in Figure 43.21.
7.43.408	This is the period of the most rapid growth during the pregnancy.
7.43.409	Organ development continues to birth (and some systems, such as the nervous system and liver, continue to develop after birth).
7.43.410	The mother will be at her most uncomfortable during this trimester.
7.43.411	She may urinate frequently due to pressure on the bladder from the fetus.
7.43.412	There may also be intestinal blockage and circulatory problems, especially in her legs.
7.43.413	Clots may form in her legs due to pressure from the fetus on returning veins as they enter the abdominal cavity.
7.43.414	There is rapid fetal growth during the third trimester.
7.43.415	Labor and Birth Labor is the physical efforts of expulsion of the fetus and the placenta from the uterus during birth (parturition).
7.43.416	Toward the end of the third trimester, estrogen causes receptors on the uterine wall to develop and bind the hormone oxytocin.
7.43.417	At this time, the baby reorients, facing forward and down with the back or crown of the head engaging the cervix (uterine opening).
7.43.418	This causes the cervix to stretch and nerve impulses are sent to the hypothalamus, which signals for the release of oxytocin from the posterior pituitary.
7.43.419	The oxytocin causes the smooth muscle in the uterine wall to contract.
7.43.420	At the same time, the placenta releases prostaglandins into the uterus, increasing the contractions.
7.43.421	A positive feedback relay occurs between the uterus, hypothalamus, and the posterior pituitary to assure an adequate supply of oxytocin.
7.43.422	As more smooth muscle cells are recruited, the contractions increase in intensity and force.
7.43.423	There are three stages to labor.
7.43.424	During stage one, the cervix thins and dilates.
7.43.425	This is necessary for the baby and placenta to be expelled during birth.
7.43.426	The cervix will eventually dilate to about 10 cm.
7.43.427	During stage two, the baby is expelled from the uterus.
7.43.428	The uterus contracts and the mother pushes as she compresses her abdominal muscles to aid the delivery.
7.43.429	The last stage is the passage of the placenta after the baby has been born and the organ has completely disengaged from the uterine wall.
7.43.430	If labor should stop before stage two is reached, synthetic oxytocin, known as Pitocin, can be administered to restart and maintain labor.
7.43.431	An alternative to labor and delivery is the surgical delivery of the baby through a procedure called a Caesarian section.
7.43.432	This is major abdominal surgery and can lead to post-surgical complications for the mother, but in some cases it may be the only way to safely deliver the baby.
7.43.433	The mother’s mammary glands go through changes during the third trimester to prepare for lactation and breastfeeding.
7.43.434	When the baby begins suckling at the breast, signals are sent to the hypothalamus causing the release of prolactin from the anterior pituitary.
7.43.435	Prolactin causes the mammary glands to produce milk.
7.43.436	Oxytocin is also released, promoting the release of the milk.
7.43.437	The milk contains nutrients for the baby’s development and growth as well as immunoglobulins to protect the child from bacterial and viral infections.
7.43.438	Contraception and Birth Control
7.43.439	The prevention of a pregnancy comes under the terms contraception or birth control.
7.43.440	Strictly speaking, contraception refers to preventing the sperm and egg from joining.
7.43.441	Both terms are, however, frequently used interchangeably.
7.43.442	Table 43.3 lists common methods of contraception.
7.43.443	The failure rates listed are not the ideal rates that could be realized, but the typical rates that occur.
7.43.444	A failure rate is the number of pregnancies resulting from the method’s use over a twelve-month period.
7.43.445	Barrier methods, such as condoms, cervical caps, and diaphragms, block sperm from entering the uterus, preventing fertilization.
7.43.446	Spermicides are chemicals that are placed in the vagina that kill sperm.
7.43.447	Sponges, which are saturated with spermicides, are placed in the vagina at the cervical opening.
7.43.448	Combinations of spermicidal chemicals and barrier methods achieve lower failure rates than do the methods when used separately.
7.43.449	Nearly a quarter of the couples using barrier methods, natural family planning, or withdrawal can expect a failure of the method.
7.43.450	Natural family planning is based on the monitoring of the menstrual cycle and having intercourse only during times when the egg is not available.
7.43.451	A woman’s body temperature may rise a degree Celsius at ovulation and the cervical mucus may increase in volume and become more pliable.
7.43.452	These changes give a general indication of when intercourse is more or less likely to result in fertilization.
7.43.453	Withdrawal involves the removal of the penis from the vagina during intercourse, before ejaculation occurs.
7.43.454	This is a risky method with a high failure rate due to the possible presence of sperm in the bulbourethral gland’s secretion, which may enter the vagina prior to removing the penis.
7.43.455	Hormonal methods use synthetic progesterone (sometimes in combination with estrogen), to inhibit the hypothalamus from releasing FSH or LH, and thus prevent an egg from being available for fertilization.
7.43.456	The method of administering the hormone affects failure rate.
7.43.457	The most reliable method, with a failure rate of less than 1 percent, is the implantation of the hormone under the skin.
7.43.458	The same rate can be achieved through the sterilization procedures of vasectomy in the man or of tubal ligation in the woman, or by using an intrauterine device (IUD).
7.43.459	IUDs are inserted into the uterus and establish an inflammatory condition that prevents fertilized eggs from implanting into the uterine wall.
7.43.460	Compliance with the contraceptive method is a strong contributor to the success or failure rate of any particular method.
7.43.461	The only method that is completely effective at preventing conception is abstinence.
7.43.462	The choice of contraceptive method depends on the goals of the woman or couple.
7.43.463	Tubal ligation and vasectomy are considered permanent prevention, while other methods are reversible and provide short-term contraception.
7.43.464	Termination of an existing pregnancy can be spontaneous or voluntary.
7.43.465	Spontaneous termination is a miscarriage and usually occurs very early in the pregnancy, usually within the first few weeks.
7.43.466	This occurs when the fetus cannot develop properly and the gestation is naturally terminated.
7.43.467	Voluntary termination of a pregnancy is an abortion.
7.43.468	Laws regulating abortion vary between states and tend to view fetal viability as the criteria for allowing or preventing the procedure.
7.43.469	Infertility Infertility is the inability to conceive a child or carry a child to birth.
7.43.470	About 75 percent of causes of infertility can be identified; these include diseases, such as sexually transmitted diseases that can cause scarring of the reproductive tubes in either men or women, or developmental problems frequently related to abnormal hormone levels in one of the individuals.
7.43.471	Inadequate nutrition, especially starvation, can delay menstruation.
7.43.472	Stress can also lead to infertility.
7.43.473	Short-term stress can affect hormone levels, while long-term stress can delay puberty and cause less frequent menstrual cycles.
7.43.474	Other factors that affect fertility include toxins (such as cadmium), tobacco smoking, marijuana use, gonadal injuries, and aging.
7.43.475	If infertility is identified, several assisted reproductive technologies (ART) are available to aid conception.
7.43.476	A common type of ART is in vitro fertilization (IVF) where an egg and sperm are combined outside the body and then placed in the uterus.
7.43.477	Eggs are obtained from the woman after extensive hormonal treatments that prepare mature eggs for fertilization and prepare the uterus for implantation of the fertilized egg.
7.43.478	Sperm are obtained from the man and they are combined with the eggs and supported through several cell divisions to ensure viability of the zygotes.
7.43.479	When the embryos have reached the eight-cell stage, one or more is implanted into the woman’s uterus.
7.43.480	If fertilization is not accomplished by simple IVF, a procedure that injects the sperm into an egg can be used.
7.43.481	This is called intracytoplasmic sperm injection (ICSI) and is shown in Figure 43.22.
7.43.482	IVF procedures produce a surplus of fertilized eggs and embryos that can be frozen and stored for future use.
7.43.483	The procedures can also result in multiple births.
7.43.484	A sperm is inserted into an egg for fertilization during intracytoplasmic sperm injection (ICSI).
7.43.485	The process in which an organism develops from a single-celled zygote to a multi-cellular organism is complex and wellregulated.
7.43.486	The early stages of embryonic development are also crucial for ensuring the fitness of the organism.
7.43.487	Fertilization Fertilization, pictured in Figure 43.23a is the process in which gametes (an egg and sperm) fuse to form a zygote.
7.43.488	The egg and sperm each contain one set of chromosomes.
7.43.489	To ensure that the offspring has only one complete diploid set of chromosomes, only one sperm must fuse with one egg.
7.43.490	In mammals, the egg is protected by a layer of extracellular matrix consisting mainly of glycoproteins called the zona pellucida.
7.43.491	When a sperm binds to the zona pellucida, a series of biochemical events, called the acrosomal reactions, take place.
7.43.492	In placental mammals, the acrosome contains digestive enzymes that initiate the degradation of the glycoprotein matrix protecting the egg and allowing the sperm plasma membrane to fuse with the egg plasma membrane, as illustrated in Figure 43.23b.
7.43.493	The fusion of these two membranes creates an opening through which the sperm nucleus is transferred into the ovum.
7.43.494	The nuclear membranes of the egg and sperm break down and the two haploid genomes condense to form a diploid genome.
7.43.495	(a) Fertilization is the process in which sperm and egg fuse to form a zygote.
7.43.496	(b) Acrosomal reactions help the sperm degrade the glycoprotein matrix protecting the egg and allow the sperm to transfer its nucleus.
7.43.497	To ensure that no more than one sperm fertilizes the egg, once the acrosomal reactions take place at one location of the egg membrane, the egg releases proteins in other locations to prevent other sperm from fusing with the egg.
7.43.498	If this mechanism fails, multiple sperm can fuse with the egg, resulting in polyspermy.
7.43.499	The resulting embryo is not genetically viable and dies within a few days.
7.43.500	Cleavage and Blastula Stage
7.43.501	The development of multi-cellular organisms begins from a single-celled zygote, which undergoes rapid cell division to form the blastula.
7.43.502	The rapid, multiple rounds of cell division are termed cleavage.
7.43.503	Cleavage is illustrated in (Figure 43.24a).
7.43.504	After the cleavage has produced over 100 cells, the embryo is called a blastula.
7.43.505	The blastula is usually a spherical layer of cells (the blastoderm) surrounding a fluid-filled or yolk-filled cavity (the blastocoel).
7.43.506	Mammals at this stage form a structure called the blastocyst, characterized by an inner cell mass that is distinct from the surrounding blastula, shown in Figure 43.24b.
7.43.507	During cleavage, the cells divide without an increase in mass; that is, one large single-celled zygote divides into multiple smaller cells.
7.43.508	Each cell within the blastula is called a blastomere.
7.43.509	(a) During cleavage, the zygote rapidly divides into multiple cells without increasing in size.
7.43.510	(b)
7.43.511	The cells rearrange themselves to form a hollow ball with a fluid-filled or yolk-filled cavity called the blastula.
7.43.512	Cleavage can take place in two ways: holoblastic (total) cleavage or meroblastic (partial) cleavage.
7.43.513	The type of cleavage depends on the amount of yolk in the eggs.
7.43.514	In placental mammals (including humans) where nourishment is provided by the mother’s body, the eggs have a very small amount of yolk and undergo holoblastic cleavage.
7.43.515	Other species, such as birds, with a lot of yolk in the egg to nourish the embryo during development, undergo meroblastic cleavage.
7.43.516	In mammals, the blastula forms the blastocyst in the next stage of development.
7.43.517	Here the cells in the blastula arrange themselves in two layers: the inner cell mass, and an outer layer called the trophoblast.
7.43.518	The inner cell mass is also known as the embryoblast and this mass of cells will go on to form the embryo.
7.43.519	At this stage of development, illustrated in Figure 43.25 the inner cell mass consists of embryonic stem cells that will differentiate into the different cell types needed by the organism.
7.43.520	The trophoblast will contribute to the placenta and nourish the embryo.
7.43.521	The rearrangement of the cells in the mammalian blastula to two layers—the inner cell mass and the trophoblast—results in the formation of the blastocyst.
7.43.522	Gastrulation
7.43.523	The typical blastula is a ball of cells.
7.43.524	The next stage in embryonic development is the formation of the body plan.
7.43.525	The cells in the blastula rearrange themselves spatially to form three layers of cells.
7.43.526	This process is called gastrulation.
7.43.527	During gastrulation, the blastula folds upon itself to form the three layers of cells.
7.43.528	Each of these layers is called a germ layer and each germ layer differentiates into different organ systems.
7.43.529	The three germs layers, shown in Figure 43.26, are the endoderm, the ectoderm, and the mesoderm.
7.43.530	The ectoderm gives rise to the nervous system and the epidermis.
7.43.531	The mesoderm gives rise to the muscle cells and connective tissue in the body.
7.43.532	The endoderm gives rise to columnar cells found in the digestive system and many internal organs.
7.43.533	The three germ layers give rise to different cell types in the animal body.
7.43.534	43.7 | Organogenesis and Vertebrate Formation
7.43.535	By the end of this section, you will be able to: •
7.43.536	Describe the process of organogenesis •
7.43.537	Identify the anatomical axes formed in vertebrates Gastrulation leads to the formation of the three germ layers that give rise, during further development, to the different organs in the animal body.
7.43.538	This process is called organogenesis.
7.43.539	Organogenesis is characterized by rapid and precise movements of the cells within the embryo.
7.43.540	Organogenesis Organs form from the germ layers through the process of differentiation.
7.43.541	During differentiation, the embryonic stem cells express specific sets of genes which will determine their ultimate cell type.
7.43.542	For example, some cells in the ectoderm will express the genes specific to skin cells.
7.43.543	As a result, these cells will differentiate into epidermal cells.
7.43.544	The process of differentiation is regulated by cellular signaling cascades.
7.43.545	Scientists study organogenesis extensively in the lab in fruit flies (Drosophila) and the nematode Caenorhabditis elegans.
7.43.546	Drosophila have segments along their bodies, and the patterning associated with the segment formation has allowed scientists to study which genes play important roles in organogenesis along the length of the embryo at different time points.
7.43.547	The nematode C.elegans has roughly 1000 somatic cells and scientists have studied the fate of each of these cells during their development in the nematode life cycle.
7.43.548	There is little variation in patterns of cell lineage between individuals, unlike in mammals where cell development from the embryo is dependent on cellular cues.
7.43.549	In vertebrates, one of the primary steps during organogenesis is the formation of the neural system.
7.43.550	The ectoderm forms epithelial cells and tissues, and neuronal tissues.
7.43.551	During the formation of the neural system, special signaling molecules called growth factors signal some cells at the edge of the ectoderm to become epidermis cells.
7.43.552	The remaining cells in the center form the neural plate.
7.43.553	If the signaling by growth factors were disrupted, then the entire ectoderm would differentiate into neural tissue.
7.43.554	The neural plate undergoes a series of cell movements where it rolls up and forms a tube called the neural tube, as illustrated in Figure 43.28.
7.43.555	In further development, the neural tube will give rise to the brain and the spinal cord.
7.43.556	The central region of the ectoderm forms the neural tube, which gives rise to the brain and the spinal cord.
7.43.557	The mesoderm that lies on either side of the vertebrate neural tube will develop into the various connective tissues of the animal body.
7.43.558	A spatial pattern of gene expression reorganizes the mesoderm into groups of cells called somites with spaces between them.
7.43.559	The somites, illustrated in Figure 43.29 will further develop into the ribs, lungs, and segmental (spine) muscle.
7.43.560	The mesoderm also forms a structure called the notochord, which is rod-shaped and forms the central axis of the animal body.
7.43.561	In this five-week old human embryo, somites are segments along the length of the body.
7.43.562	Vertebrate Axis Formation
7.43.563	Even as the germ layers form, the ball of cells still retains its spherical shape.
7.43.564	However, animal bodies have lateral-medial (left-right), dorsal-ventral (back-belly), and anterior-posterior (head-feet) axes, illustrated in Figure 43.30.
7.43.565	Animal bodies have three axes for symmetry.
7.43.566	How are these established?
7.43.567	In one of the most seminal experiments ever to be carried out in developmental biology, Spemann and Mangold took dorsal cells from one embryo and transplanted them into the belly region of another embryo.
7.43.568	They found that the transplanted embryo now had two notochords: one at the dorsal site from the original cells and another at the transplanted site.
7.43.569	This suggested that the dorsal cells were genetically programmed to form the notochord and define the axis.
7.43.570	Since then, researchers have identified many genes that are responsible for axis formation.
7.43.571	Mutations in these genes leads to the loss of symmetry required for organism development.
7.43.572	Animal bodies have externally visible symmetry.
7.43.573	However, the internal organs are not symmetric.
7.43.574	For example, the heart is on the left side and the liver on the right.
7.43.575	The formation of the central left-right axis is an important process during development.
7.43.576	This internal asymmetry is established very early during development and involves many genes.
7.43.577	Research is still ongoing to fully understand the developmental implications of these genes.
7.44.0	The (a) deer tick carries the bacterium that produces Lyme disease in humans, often evident in (b) a symptomatic bull’s eye rash.
7.44.1	The (c) white-footed mouse is one well-known host to deer ticks carrying the Lyme disease bacterium.  
7.44.2	Why study ecology?
7.44.3	Perhaps you are interested in learning about the natural world and how living things have adapted to the physical conditions of their environment.
7.44.4	Or, perhaps you’re a future physician seeking to understand the connection between human health and ecology.
7.44.5	Humans are a part of the ecological landscape, and human health is one important part of human interaction with our physical and living environment.
7.44.6	Lyme disease, for instance, serves as one modern-day example of the connection between our health and the natural world (Figure 44.1).
7.44.7	More formally known as Lyme borreliosis, Lyme disease is a bacterial infection that can be transmitted to humans when they are bitten by the deer tick (Ixodes scapularis), which is the primary vector for this disease.
7.44.8	However, not all deer ticks carry the bacteria that will cause Lyme disease in humans, and I. scapularis can have other hosts besides deer.
7.44.9	In fact, it turns out that the probability of infection depends on the type of host upon which the tick develops: a higher proportion of ticks that live on white-footed mice carry the bacterium than do ticks that live on deer.
7.44.10	Knowledge about the environments and population densities in which the host species is abundant would help a physician or an epidemiologist better understand how Lyme disease is transmitted and how its incidence could be reduced.
7.44.11	he Scope of Ecology
7.44.12	By the end of this section, you will be able to: Define ecology and the four levels of ecological research Describe examples of the ways in which ecology requires the integration of different scientific disciplines Distinguish between abiotic and biotic components of the environment Recognize the relationship between abiotic and biotic components of the environment Ecology is the study of the interactions of living organisms with their environment.
7.44.13	One core goal of ecology is to understand the distribution and abundance of living things in the physical environment.
7.44.14	Attainment of this goal requires the integration of scientific disciplines inside and outside of biology, such as biochemistry, physiology, evolution, biodiversity, molecular biology, geology, and climatology.
7.44.15	Some ecological research also applies aspects of chemistry and physics, and it frequently uses mathematical models.
7.44.16	Levels of Ecological Study
7.44.17	When a discipline such as biology is studied, it is often helpful to subdivide it into smaller, related areas.
7.44.18	For instance, cell biologists interested in cell signaling need to understand the chemistry of the signal molecules (which are usually proteins) as well as the result of cell signaling.
7.44.19	Ecologists interested in the factors that influence the survival of an endangered species might use mathematical models to predict how current conservation efforts affect endangered organisms.
7.44.20	To produce a sound set of management options, a conservation biologist needs to collect accurate data, including current population size, factors affecting reproduction (like physiology and behavior), habitat requirements (such as plants and soils), and potential human influences on the endangered population and its habitat (which might be derived through studies in sociology and urban ecology).
7.44.21	Within the discipline of ecology, researchers work at four specific levels, sometimes discretely and sometimes with overlap: organism, population, community, and ecosystem.
7.44.22	Ecologists study within several biological levels of organization.
7.44.23	Organismal Ecology Researchers studying ecology at the organismal level are interested in the adaptations that enable individuals to live in specific habitats.
7.44.24	These adaptations can be morphological, physiological, and behavioral.
7.44.25	For instance, the Karner blue butterfly (Lycaeides melissa samuelis) (Figure 44.3) is considered a specialist because the females preferentially oviposit (that is, lay eggs) on wild lupine.
7.44.26	This preferential adaptation means that the Karner blue butterfly is highly dependent on the presence of wild lupine plants for its continued survival.
7.44.27	The Karner blue butterfly (Lycaeides melissa samuelis) is a rare butterfly that lives only in open areas with few trees or shrubs, such as pine barrens and oak savannas.
7.44.28	It can only lay its eggs on lupine plants.
7.44.29	After hatching, the larval caterpillars emerge and spend four to six weeks feeding solely on wild lupine (Figure 44.4).
7.44.30	The caterpillars pupate (undergo metamorphosis) and emerge as butterflies after about four weeks.
7.44.31	The adult butterflies feed on the nectar of flowers of wild lupine and other plant species.
7.44.32	A researcher interested in studying Karner blue butterflies at the organismal level might, in addition to asking questions about egg laying, ask questions about the butterflies’ preferred temperature (a physiological question) or the behavior of the caterpillars when they are at different larval stages (a behavioral question).
7.44.33	The wild lupine (Lupinus perennis) is the host plant for the Karner blue butterfly.
7.44.34	Population Ecology
7.44.35	A population is a group of interbreeding organisms that are members of the same species living in the same area at the same time.
7.44.36	(Organisms that are all members of the same species are called conspecifics.)
7.44.37	A population is identified, in part, by where it lives, and its area of population may have natural or artificial boundaries: natural boundaries might be rivers, mountains, or deserts, while examples of artificial boundaries include mowed grass, manmade structures, or roads.
7.44.38	The study of population ecology focuses on the number of individuals in an area and how and why population size changes over time.
7.44.39	Population ecologists are particularly interested in counting the Karner blue butterfly, for example, because it is classified as federally endangered.
7.44.40	However, the distribution and density of this species is highly influenced by the distribution and abundance of wild lupine.
7.44.41	Researchers might ask questions about the factors leading to the decline of wild lupine and how these affect Karner blue butterflies.
7.44.42	For example, ecologists know that wild lupine thrives in open areas where trees and shrubs are largely absent.
7.44.43	In natural settings, intermittent wildfires regularly remove trees and shrubs, helping to maintain the open areas that wild lupine requires.
7.44.44	Mathematical models can be used to understand how wildfire suppression by humans has led to the decline of this important plant for the Karner blue butterfly.
7.44.45	Community Ecology
7.44.46	A biological community consists of the different species within an area, typically a three-dimensional space, and the interactions within and among these species.
7.44.47	Community ecologists are interested in the processes driving these interactions and their consequences.
7.44.48	Questions about conspecific interactions often focus on competition among members of the same species for a limited resource.
7.44.49	Ecologists also study interactions among various species; members of different species are called heterospecifics.
7.44.50	Examples of heterospecific interactions include predation, parasitism, herbivory, competition, and pollination.
7.44.51	These interactions can have regulating effects on population sizes and can impact ecological and evolutionary processes affecting diversity.
7.44.52	For example, Karner blue butterfly larvae form mutualistic relationships with ants.
7.44.53	Mutualism is a form of a longterm relationship that has coevolved between two species and from which each species benefits.
7.44.54	For mutualism to exist between individual organisms, each species must receive some benefit from the other as a consequence of the relationship.
7.44.55	Researchers have shown that there is an increase in the probability of survival when Karner blue butterfly larvae (caterpillars) are tended by ants.
7.44.56	This might be because the larvae spend less time in each life stage when tended by ants, which provides an advantage for the larvae.
7.44.57	Meanwhile, the Karner blue butterfly larvae secrete a carbohydraterich substance that is an important energy source for the ants.
7.44.58	Both the Karner blue larvae and the ants benefit from their interaction.
7.44.59	Ecosystem Ecology Ecosystem ecology is an extension of organismal, population, and community ecology.
7.44.60	The ecosystem is composed of all the biotic components (living things) in an area along with the abiotic components (non-living things) of that area.
7.44.61	Some of the abiotic components include air, water, and soil.
7.44.62	Ecosystem biologists ask questions about how nutrients and energy are stored and how they move among organisms and the surrounding atmosphere, soil, and water.
7.44.63	The Karner blue butterflies and the wild lupine live in an oak-pine barren habitat.
7.44.64	This habitat is characterized by natural disturbance and nutrient-poor soils that are low in nitrogen.
7.44.65	The availability of nutrients is an important factor in the distribution of the plants that live in this habitat.
7.44.66	Researchers interested in ecosystem ecology could ask questions about the importance of limited resources and the movement of resources, such as nutrients, though the biotic and abiotic portions of the ecosystem.
7.44.67	Biogeography
7.44.68	By the end of this section, you will be able to: Define biogeography List and describe abiotic factors that affect the global distribution of plant and animal species Compare the impact of abiotic forces on aquatic and terrestrial environments  
7.44.69	Summarize the affect of abiotic factors on net primary productivity
7.44.70	Many forces influence the communities of living organisms present in different parts of the biosphere (all of the parts of Earth inhabited by life).
7.44.71	The biosphere extends into the atmosphere (several kilometers above Earth) and into the depths of the oceans.
7.44.72	Despite its apparent vastness to an individual human, the biosphere occupies only a minute space when compared to the known universe.
7.44.73	Many abiotic forces influence where life can exist and the types of organisms found in different parts of the biosphere.
7.44.74	The abiotic factors influence the distribution of biomes: large areas of land with similar climate, flora, and fauna.
7.44.75	Biogeography
7.44.76	Biogeography is the study of the geographic distribution of living things and the abiotic factors that affect their distribution.
7.44.77	Abiotic factors such as temperature and rainfall vary based mainly on latitude and elevation.
7.44.78	As these abiotic factors change, the composition of plant and animal communities also changes.
7.44.79	For example, if you were to begin a journey at the equator and walk north, you would notice gradual changes in plant communities.
7.44.80	At the beginning of your journey, you would see tropical wet forests with broad-leaved evergreen trees, which are characteristic of plant communities found near the equator.
7.44.81	As you continued to travel north, you would see these broad-leaved evergreen plants eventually give rise to seasonally dry forests with scattered trees.
7.44.82	You would also begin to notice changes in temperature and moisture.
7.44.83	At about 30 degrees north, these forests would give way to deserts, which are characterized by low precipitation.
7.44.84	Moving farther north, you would see that deserts are replaced by grasslands or prairies.
7.44.85	Eventually, grasslands are replaced by deciduous temperate forests.
7.44.86	These deciduous forests give way to the boreal forests found in the subarctic, the area south of the Arctic Circle.
7.44.87	Finally, you would reach the Arctic tundra, which is found at the most northern latitudes.
7.44.88	This trek north reveals gradual changes in both climate and the types of organisms that have adapted to environmental factors associated with ecosystems found at different latitudes.
7.44.89	However, different ecosystems exist at the same latitude due in part to abiotic factors such as jet streams, the Gulf Stream, and ocean currents.
7.44.90	If you were to hike up a mountain, the changes you would see in the vegetation would parallel those as you move to higher latitudes.
7.44.91	Ecologists who study biogeography examine patterns of species distribution.
7.44.92	No species exists everywhere; for example, the Venus flytrap is endemic to a small area in North and South Carolina.
7.44.93	An endemic species is one which is naturally found only in a specific geographic area that is usually restricted in size.
7.44.94	Other species are generalists: species which live in a wide variety of geographic areas; the raccoon, for example, is native to most of North and Central America.
7.44.95	Species distribution patterns are based on biotic and abiotic factors and their influences during the very long periods of time required for species evolution; therefore, early studies of biogeography were closely linked to the emergence of evolutionary thinking in the eighteenth century.
7.44.96	Some of the most distinctive assemblages of plants and animals occur in regions that have been physically separated for millions of years by geographic barriers.
7.44.97	Biologists estimate that Australia, for example, has between 600,000 and 700,000 species of plants and animals.
7.44.98	Approximately 3/4 of living plant and mammal species are endemic species found solely in Australia (Figure 44.6ab).
7.44.99	Australia is home to many endemic species.
7.44.100	The (a) wallaby (Wallabia bicolor), a medium-sized member of the kangaroo family, is a pouched mammal, or marsupial.
7.44.101	The (b) echidna (Tachyglossus aculeatus) is an egg-laying mammal.
7.44.102	Sometimes ecologists discover unique patterns of species distribution by determining where species are not found.
7.44.103	Hawaii, for example, has no native land species of reptiles or amphibians, and has only one native terrestrial mammal, the hoary bat.
7.44.104	Most of New Guinea, as another example, lacks placental mammals.
7.44.105	Plants can be endemic or generalists: endemic plants are found only on specific regions of the Earth, while generalists are found on many regions.
7.44.106	Isolated land masses—such as Australia, Hawaii, and Madagascar—often have large numbers of endemic plant species.
7.44.107	Some of these plants are endangered due to human activity.
7.44.108	The forest gardenia (Gardenia brighamii), for instance, is endemic to Hawaii; only an estimated 15–20 trees are thought to exist.
7.44.109	Listed as federally endangered, the forest gardenia is a small tree with distinctive flowers.
7.44.110	It is found only in five of the Hawaiian Islands in small populations consisting of a few individual specimens.
7.44.111	Energy Sources Energy from the sun is captured by green plants, algae, cyanobacteria, and photosynthetic protists.
7.44.112	These organisms convert solar energy into the chemical energy needed by all living things.
7.44.113	Light availability can be an important force directly affecting the evolution of adaptations in photosynthesizers.
7.44.114	For instance, plants in the understory of a temperate forest are shaded when the trees above them in the canopy completely leaf out in the late spring.
7.44.115	Not surprisingly, understory plants have adaptations to successfully capture available light.
7.44.116	One such adaptation is the rapid growth of spring ephemeral plants such as the spring beauty (Figure 44.8).
7.44.117	These spring flowers achieve much of their growth and finish their life cycle (reproduce) early in the season before the trees in the canopy develop leaves.
7.44.118	The spring beauty is an ephemeral spring plant that flowers early in the spring to avoid competing with larger forest trees for sunlight.
7.44.119	In aquatic ecosystems, the availability of light may be limited because sunlight is absorbed by water, plants, suspended particles, and resident microorganisms.
7.44.120	Toward the bottom of a lake, pond, or ocean, there is a zone that light cannot reach.
7.44.121	Photosynthesis cannot take place there and, as a result, a number of adaptations have evolved that enable living things to survive without light.
7.44.122	For instance, aquatic plants have photosynthetic tissue near the surface of the water; for example, think of the broad, floating leaves of a water lily—water lilies cannot survive without light.
7.44.123	In environments such as hydrothermal vents, some bacteria extract energy from inorganic chemicals because there is no light for photosynthesis.
7.44.124	The availability of nutrients in aquatic systems is also an important aspect of energy or photosynthesis.
7.44.125	Many organisms sink to the bottom of the ocean when they die in the open water; when this occurs, the energy found in that living organism is sequestered for some time unless ocean upwelling occurs.
7.44.126	Ocean upwelling is the rising of deep ocean waters that occurs when prevailing winds blow along surface waters near a coastline (Figure 44.9).
7.44.127	As the wind pushes ocean waters offshore, water from the bottom of the ocean moves up to replace this water.
7.44.128	As a result, the nutrients once contained in dead organisms become available for reuse by other living organisms.
7.44.129	Ocean upwelling is an important process that recycles nutrients and energy in the ocean.
7.44.130	As wind (green arrows) pushes offshore, it causes water from the ocean bottom (red arrows) to move to the surface, bringing up nutrients from the ocean depths.
7.44.131	In freshwater systems, the recycling of nutrients occurs in response to air temperature changes.
7.44.132	The nutrients at the bottom of lakes are recycled twice each year: in the spring and fall turnover.
7.44.133	The spring and fall turnover is a seasonal process that recycles nutrients and oxygen from the bottom of a freshwater ecosystem to the top of a body of water (Figure 44.10).
7.44.134	These turnovers are caused by the formation of a thermocline: a layer of water with a temperature that is significantly different from that of the surrounding layers.
7.44.135	In wintertime, the surface of lakes found in many northern regions is frozen.
7.44.136	However, the water under the ice is slightly warmer, and the water at the bottom of the lake is warmer yet at 4 °C to 5 °C (39.2 °F to 41 °F).
7.44.137	Water is densest at 4 °C; therefore, the deepest water is also the densest.
7.44.138	The deepest water is oxygen poor because the decomposition of organic material at the bottom of the lake uses up available oxygen that cannot be replaced by means of oxygen diffusion into the water due to the surface ice layer.
7.44.139	In springtime, air temperatures increase and surface ice melts.
7.44.140	When the temperature of the surface water begins to reach 4 °C, the water becomes heavier and sinks to the bottom.
7.44.141	The water at the bottom of the lake is then displaced by the heavier surface water and, thus, rises to the top.
7.44.142	As that water rises to the top, the sediments and nutrients from the lake bottom are brought along with it.
7.44.143	During the summer months, the lake water stratifies, or forms layers, with the warmest water at the lake surface.
7.44.144	As air temperatures drop in the fall, the temperature of the lake water cools to 4 °C; therefore, this causes fall turnover as the heavy cold water sinks and displaces the water at the bottom.
7.44.145	The oxygen-rich water at the surface of the lake then moves to the bottom of the lake, while the nutrients at the bottom of the lake rise to the surface (Figure 44.10).
7.44.146	During the winter, the oxygen at the bottom of the lake is used by decomposers and other organisms requiring oxygen, such as fish.
7.44.147	Temperature Temperature affects the physiology of living things as well as the density and state of water.
7.44.148	Temperature exerts an important influence on living things because few living things can survive at temperatures below 0 °C (32 °F) due to metabolic constraints.
7.44.149	It is also rare for living things to survive at temperatures exceeding 45 °C (113 °F); this is a reflection of evolutionary response to typical temperatures.
7.44.150	Enzymes are most efficient within a narrow and specific range of temperatures; enzyme degradation can occur at higher temperatures.
7.44.151	Therefore, organisms either must maintain an internal temperature or they must inhabit an environment that will keep the body within a temperature range that supports metabolism.
7.44.152	Some animals have adapted to enable their bodies to survive significant temperature fluctuations, such as seen in hibernation or reptilian torpor.
7.44.153	Similarly, some bacteria are adapted to surviving in extremely hot temperatures such as geysers.
7.44.154	Such bacteria are examples of extremophiles: organisms that thrive in extreme environments.
7.44.155	Temperature can limit the distribution of living things.
7.44.156	Animals faced with temperature fluctuations may respond with adaptations, such as migration, in order to survive.
7.44.157	Migration, the movement from one place to another, is an adaptation found in many animals, including many that inhabit seasonally cold climates.
7.44.158	Migration solves problems related to temperature, locating food, and finding a mate.
7.44.159	In migration, for instance, the Arctic Tern (Sterna paradisaea) makes a 40,000 km (24,000 mi) round trip flight each year between its feeding grounds in the southern hemisphere and its breeding grounds in the Arctic Ocean.
7.44.160	Monarch butterflies
7.44.161	(Danaus plexippus) live in the eastern United States in the warmer months and migrate to Mexico and the southern United States in the wintertime.
7.44.162	Some species of mammals also make migratory forays.
7.44.163	Reindeer (Rangifer tarandus) travel about 5,000 km (3,100 mi) each year to find food.
7.44.164	Amphibians and reptiles are more limited in their distribution because they lack migratory ability.
7.44.165	Not all animals that can migrate do so: migration carries risk and comes at a high energy cost.
7.44.166	Some animals hibernate or estivate to survive hostile temperatures.
7.44.167	Hibernation enables animals to survive cold conditions, and estivation allows animals to survive the hostile conditions of a hot, dry climate.
7.44.168	Animals that hibernate or estivate enter a state known as torpor: a condition in which their metabolic rate is significantly lowered.
7.44.169	This enables the animal to wait until its environment better supports its survival.
7.44.170	Some amphibians, such as the wood frog (Rana sylvatica), have an antifreeze-like chemical in their cells, which retains the cells’ integrity and prevents them from bursting.
7.44.171	Water Water is required by all living things because it is critical for cellular processes.
7.44.172	Since terrestrial organisms lose water to the environment by simple diffusion, they have evolved many adaptations to retain water.
7.44.173	•
7.44.174	Plants have a number of interesting features on their leaves, such as leaf hairs and a waxy cuticle, that serve to decrease the rate of water loss via transpiration.
7.44.175	• Freshwater organisms are surrounded by water and are constantly in danger of having water rush into their cells because of osmosis.
7.44.176	Many adaptations of organisms living in freshwater environments have evolved to ensure that solute concentrations in their bodies remain within appropriate levels.
7.44.177	One such adaptation is the excretion of dilute urine.
7.44.178	•
7.44.179	Marine organisms are surrounded by water with a higher solute concentration than the organism and, thus, are in danger of losing water to the environment because of osmosis.
7.44.180	These organisms have morphological and physiological adaptations to retain water and release solutes into the environment.
7.44.181	For example, Marine iguanas (Amblyrhynchus cristatus), sneeze out water vapor that is high in salt in order to maintain solute concentrations within an acceptable range while swimming in the ocean and eating marine plants.
7.44.182	Inorganic Nutrients and Soil Inorganic nutrients, such as nitrogen and phosphorus, are important in the distribution and the abundance of living things.
7.44.183	Plants obtain these inorganic nutrients from the soil when water moves into the plant through the roots.
7.44.184	Therefore, soil structure (particle size of soil components), soil pH, and soil nutrient content play an important role in the distribution of plants.
7.44.185	Animals obtain inorganic nutrients from the food they consume.
7.44.186	Therefore, animal distributions are related to the distribution of what they eat.
7.44.187	In some cases, animals will follow their food resource as it moves through the environment.
7.44.188	Other Aquatic Factors
7.44.189	Some abiotic factors, such as oxygen, are important in aquatic ecosystems as well as terrestrial environments.
7.44.190	Terrestrial animals obtain oxygen from the air they breathe.
7.44.191	Oxygen availability can be an issue for organisms living at very high elevations, however, where there are fewer molecules of oxygen in the air.
7.44.192	In aquatic systems, the concentration of dissolved oxygen is related to water temperature and the speed at which the water moves.
7.44.193	Cold water has more dissolved oxygen than warmer water.
7.44.194	In addition, salinity, current, and tide can be important abiotic factors in aquatic ecosystems.
7.44.195	Other Terrestrial Factors Wind can be an important abiotic factor because it influences the rate of evaporation and transpiration.
7.44.196	The physical force of wind is also important because it can move soil, water, or other abiotic factors, as well as an ecosystem’s organisms.
7.44.197	Fire is another terrestrial factor that can be an important agent of disturbance in terrestrial ecosystems.
7.44.198	Some organisms are adapted to fire and, thus, require the high heat associated with fire to complete a part of their life cycle.
7.44.199	For example, the jack pine—a coniferous tree—requires heat from fire for its seed cones to open (Figure 44.11).
7.44.200	Through the burning of pine needles, fire adds nitrogen to the soil and limits competition by destroying undergrowth.
7.44.201	The mature cones of the jack pine (Pinus banksiana) open only when exposed to high temperatures, such as during a forest fire.
7.44.202	A fire is likely to kill most vegetation, so a seedling that germinates after a fire is more likely to receive ample sunlight than one that germinates under normal conditions.
7.44.203	Abiotic Factors Influencing Plant Growth Temperature and moisture are important influences on plant production (primary productivity) and the amount of organic matter available as food (net primary productivity).
7.44.204	Net primary productivity is an estimation of all of the organic matter available as food; it is calculated as the total amount of carbon fixed per year minus the amount that is oxidized during cellular respiration.
7.44.205	In terrestrial environments, net primary productivity is estimated by measuring the aboveground biomass per unit area, which is the total mass of living plants, excluding roots.
7.44.206	This means that a large percentage of plant biomass which exists underground is not included in this measurement.
7.44.207	Net primary productivity is an important variable when considering differences in biomes.
7.44.208	Very productive biomes have a high level of aboveground biomass.
7.44.209	Annual biomass production is directly related to the abiotic components of the environment.
7.44.210	Environments with the greatest amount of biomass have conditions in which photosynthesis, plant growth, and the resulting net primary productivity are optimized.
7.44.211	The climate of these areas is warm and wet.
7.44.212	Photosynthesis can proceed at a high rate, enzymes can work most efficiently, and stomata can remain open without the risk of excessive transpiration; together, these factors lead to the maximal amount of carbon dioxide (CO2) moving into the plant, resulting in high biomass production.
7.44.213	The aboveground biomass produces several important resources for other living things, including habitat and food.
7.44.214	Conversely, dry and cold environments have lower photosynthetic rates and therefore less biomass.
7.44.215	The animal communities living there will also be affected by the decrease in available food.
7.44.216	Terrestrial Biomes
7.44.217	By the end of this section, you will be able to: Identify the two major abiotic factors that determine terrestrial biomes Recognize distinguishing characteristics of each of the eight major terrestrial biomes The Earth’s biomes are categorized into two major groups: terrestrial and aquatic.
7.44.218	Terrestrial biomes are based on land, while aquatic biomes include both ocean and freshwater biomes.
7.44.219	The eight major terrestrial biomes on Earth are each distinguished by characteristic temperatures and amount of precipitation.
7.44.220	Comparing the annual totals of precipitation and fluctuations in precipitation from one biome to another provides clues as to the importance of abiotic factors in the distribution of biomes.
7.44.221	Temperature variation on a daily and seasonal basis is also important for predicting the geographic distribution of the biome and the vegetation type in the biome.
7.44.222	The distribution of these biomes shows that the same biome can occur in geographically distinct areas with similar climates.
7.44.223	Tropical Wet Forest Tropical wet forests are also referred to as tropical rainforests.
7.44.224	This biome is found in equatorial regions (Figure 44.12).
7.44.225	The vegetation is characterized by plants with broad leaves that fall off throughout the year.
7.44.226	Unlike the trees of deciduous forests, the trees in this biome do not have a seasonal loss of leaves associated with variations in temperature and sunlight; these forests are
7.44.227	“
7.44.228	evergreen” year-round.
7.44.229	The temperature and sunlight profiles of tropical wet forests are very stable in comparison to that of other terrestrial biomes, with the temperatures ranging from 20 °C to 34 °C (68 °F to 93 °F).
7.44.230	When one compares the annual temperature variation of tropical wet forests with that of other forest biomes, the lack of seasonal temperature variation in the tropical wet forest becomes apparent.
7.44.231	This lack of seasonality leads to year-round plant growth, rather than the seasonal (spring, summer, and fall) growth seen in other biomes.
7.44.232	In contrast to other ecosystems, tropical ecosystems do not have long days and short days during the yearly cycle.
7.44.233	Instead, a constant daily amount of sunlight (11–12 hrs per day) provides more solar radiation, thereby, a longer period of time for plant growth.
7.44.234	The annual rainfall in tropical wet forests ranges from 125 to 660 cm (50–200 in) with some monthly variation.
7.44.235	While sunlight and temperature remain fairly consistent, annual rainfall is highly variable.
7.44.236	Tropical wet forests have wet months in which there can be more than 30 cm (11–12 in) of precipitation, as well as dry months in which there are fewer than 10 cm (3.5 in) of rainfall.
7.44.237	However, the driest month of a tropical wet forest still exceeds the annual rainfall of some other biomes, such as deserts.
7.44.238	Tropical wet forests have high net primary productivity because the annual temperatures and precipitation values in these areas are ideal for plant growth.
7.44.239	Therefore, the extensive biomass present in the tropical wet forest leads to plant communities with very high species diversities (Figure 44.13).
7.44.240	Tropical wet forests have more species of trees than any other biome; on average between 100 and 300 species of trees are present in a single hectare (2.5 acres) of South America.
7.44.241	One way to visualize this is to compare the distinctive horizontal layers within the tropical wet forest biome.
7.44.242	On the forest floor is a sparse layer of plants and decaying plant matter.
7.44.243	Above that is an understory of short shrubby foliage.
7.44.244	A layer of trees rises above this understory and is topped by a closed upper canopy—the uppermost overhead layer of branches and leaves.
7.44.245	Some additional trees emerge through this closed upper canopy.
7.44.246	These layers provide diverse and complex habitats for the variety of plants, fungi, animals, and other organisms within the tropical wet forests.
7.44.247	For instance, epiphytes are plants that grow on other plants, which typically are not harmed.
7.44.248	Epiphytes are found throughout tropical wet forest biomes.
7.44.249	Many species of animals use the variety of plants and the complex structure of the tropical wet forests for food and shelter.
7.44.250	Some organisms live several meters above ground and have adapted to this arboreal lifestyle.
7.44.251	Tropical wet forests, such as these forests of Madre de Dios, Peru, near the Amazon River, have high species diversity.
7.44.252	Savannas Savannas are grasslands with scattered trees, and they are located in Africa, South America, and northern Australia
7.44.253	(Figure 44.12).
7.44.254	Savannas are hot, tropical areas with temperatures averaging from 24 °C to 29 °C (75 °F to 84 °F) and an annual rainfall of 10–40 cm (3.9–15.7 in).
7.44.255	Savannas have an extensive dry season; for this reason, forest trees do not grow as well as they do in the tropical wet forest (or other forest biomes).
7.44.256	As a result, within the grasses and forbs (herbaceous flowering plants) that dominate the savanna, there are relatively few trees (Figure 44.14).
7.44.257	Since fire is an important source of disturbance in this biome, plants have evolved well-developed root systems that allow them to quickly re-sprout after a fire.
7.44.258	Savannas, like this one in Taita Hills Wildlife Sanctuary in Kenya, are dominated by grasses.
7.44.259	Subtropical Deserts Subtropical deserts exist between 15 ° and 30 ° north and south latitude and are centered on the Tropics of Cancer and Capricorn (Figure 44.12).
7.44.260	This biome is very dry; in some years, evaporation exceeds precipitation.
7.44.261	Subtropical hot deserts can have daytime soil surface temperatures above 60 °C (140 °F) and nighttime temperatures approaching 0 °C (32 °F).
7.44.262	In cold deserts, temperatures can be as high as 25 °C and can drop below -30 °C (-22 °F).
7.44.263	Subtropical deserts are characterized by low annual precipitation of fewer than 30 cm (12 in) with little monthly variation and lack of predictability in rainfall.
7.44.264	In some cases, the annual rainfall can be as low as 2 cm (0.8 in) in subtropical deserts located in central Australia
7.44.265	(“the Outback”) and northern Africa.
7.44.266	The vegetation and low animal diversity of this biome is closely related to this low and unpredictable precipitation.
7.44.267	Very dry deserts lack perennial vegetation that lives from one year to the next; instead, many plants are annuals that grow quickly and reproduce when rainfall does occur, then they die.
7.44.268	Many other plants in these areas are characterized by having a number of adaptations that conserve water, such as deep roots, reduced foliage, and water-storing stems (Figure 44.15).
7.44.269	Seed plants in the desert produce seeds that can be in dormancy for extended periods between rains.
7.44.270	Adaptations in desert animals include nocturnal behavior and burrowing.
7.44.271	To reduce water loss, many desert plants have tiny leaves or no leaves at all.
7.44.272	The leaves of ocotillo (Fouquieria splendens), shown here in the Sonora Desert near Gila Bend, Arizona, appear only after rainfall, and then are shed.
7.44.273	Chaparral
7.44.274	The chaparral is also called the scrub forest and is found in California, along the Mediterranean Sea, and along the southern coast of Australia (Figure 44.12).
7.44.275	The annual rainfall in this biome ranges from 65 cm to 75 cm (25.6–29.5 in), and the majority of the rain falls in the winter.
7.44.276	Summers are very dry and many chaparral plants are dormant during the summertime.
7.44.277	The chaparral vegetation, shown in Figure 44.16, is dominated by shrubs and is adapted to periodic fires, with some plants producing seeds that only germinate after a hot fire.
7.44.278	The ashes left behind after a fire are rich in nutrients like nitrogen that fertilize the soil and promote plant regrowth.
7.44.279	The chaparral is dominated by shrubs.
7.44.280	Temperate Grasslands Temperate grasslands are found throughout central North America, where they are also known as prairies; they are also in Eurasia, where they are known as steppes (Figure 44.12).
7.44.281	Temperate grasslands have pronounced annual fluctuations in temperature with hot summers and cold winters.
7.44.282	The annual temperature variation produces specific growing seasons for plants.
7.44.283	Plant growth is possible when temperatures are warm enough to sustain plant growth and when ample water is available, which occurs in the spring, summer, and fall.
7.44.284	During much of the winter, temperatures are low, and water, which is stored in the form of ice, is not available for plant growth.
7.44.285	Annual precipitation ranges from 25 cm to 75 cm (9.8–29.5 in).
7.44.286	Because of relatively lower annual precipitation in temperate grasslands, there are few trees except for those found growing along rivers or streams.
7.44.287	The dominant vegetation tends to consist of grasses and some prairies sustain populations of grazing animals Figure 44.17.
7.44.288	The vegetation is very dense and the soils are fertile because the subsurface of the soil is packed with the roots and rhizomes (underground stems) of these grasses.
7.44.289	The roots and rhizomes act to anchor plants into the ground and replenish the organic material (humus) in the soil when they die and decay.
7.44.290	The American bison (Bison bison), more commonly called the buffalo, is a grazing mammal that once populated American prairies in huge numbers.
7.44.291	Fires, mainly caused by lightning, are a natural disturbance in temperate grasslands.
7.44.292	When fire is suppressed in temperate grasslands, the vegetation eventually converts to scrub and dense forests.
7.44.293	Often, the restoration or management of temperate grasslands requires the use of controlled burns to suppress the growth of trees and maintain the grasses.
7.44.294	Temperate Forests Temperate forests are the most common biome in eastern North America, Western Europe, Eastern Asia, Chile, and New Zealand
7.44.295	(Figure 44.12).
7.44.296	This biome is found throughout mid-latitude regions.
7.44.297	Temperatures range between -30 °C and 30 °C (-22 °F to 86 °F) and drop to below freezing on an annual basis.
7.44.298	These temperatures mean that temperate forests have defined growing seasons during the spring, summer, and early fall.
7.44.299	Precipitation is relatively constant throughout the year and ranges between 75 cm and 150 cm (29.5–59 in).
7.44.300	Because of the moderate annual rainfall and temperatures, deciduous trees are the dominant plant in this biome (Figure 44.18).
7.44.301	Deciduous trees lose their leaves each fall and remain leafless in the winter.
7.44.302	Thus, no photosynthesis occurs in the deciduous trees during the dormant winter period.
7.44.303	Each spring, new leaves appear as the temperature increases.
7.44.304	Because of the dormant period, the net primary productivity of temperate forests is less than that of tropical wet forests.
7.44.305	In addition, temperate forests show less diversity of tree species than tropical wet forest biomes.
7.44.306	Deciduous trees are the dominant plant in the temperate forest.
7.44.307	The trees of the temperate forests leaf out and shade much of the ground; however, this biome is more open than tropical wet forests because trees in the temperate forests do not grow as tall as the trees in tropical wet forests.
7.44.308	The soils of the temperate forests are rich in inorganic and organic nutrients.
7.44.309	This is due to the thick layer of leaf litter on forest floors.
7.44.310	As this leaf litter decays, nutrients are returned to the soil.
7.44.311	The leaf litter also protects soil from erosion, insulates the ground, and provides habitats for invertebrates (such as the pill bug or roly-poly, Armadillidium vulgare) and their predators, such as the red-backed salamander (Plethodon cinereus).
7.44.312	Boreal Forests
7.44.313	The boreal forest, also known as taiga or coniferous forest, is found south of the Arctic Circle and across most of Canada, Alaska, Russia, and northern Europe (Figure 44.12).
7.44.314	This biome has cold, dry winters and short, cool, wet summers.
7.44.315	The annual precipitation is from 40 cm to 100 cm (15.7–39 in) and usually takes the form of snow.
7.44.316	Little evaporation occurs because of the cold temperatures.
7.44.317	The long and cold winters in the boreal forest have led to the predominance of cold-tolerant cone-bearing plants.
7.44.318	These are evergreen coniferous trees like pines, spruce, and fir, which retain their needle-shaped leaves year-round.
7.44.319	Evergreen trees can photosynthesize earlier in the spring than deciduous trees because less energy from the sun is required to warm a needle-like leaf than a broad leaf.
7.44.320	This benefits evergreen trees, which grow faster than deciduous trees in the boreal forest.
7.44.321	In addition, soils in boreal forest regions tend to be acidic with little available nitrogen.
7.44.322	Leaves are a nitrogen-rich structure and deciduous trees must produce a new set of these nitrogen-rich structures each year.
7.44.323	Therefore, coniferous trees that retain nitrogen-rich needles may have a competitive advantage over the broad-leafed deciduous trees.
7.44.324	The net primary productivity of boreal forests is lower than that of temperate forests and tropical wet forests.
7.44.325	The aboveground biomass of boreal forests is high because these slow-growing tree species are long lived and accumulate standing biomass over time.
7.44.326	Plant species diversity is less than that seen in temperate forests and tropical wet forests.
7.44.327	Boreal forests lack the pronounced elements of the layered forest structure seen in tropical wet forests.
7.44.328	The structure of a boreal forest is often only a tree layer and a ground layer (Figure 44.19).
7.44.329	When conifer needles are dropped, they decompose more slowly than broad leaves; therefore, fewer nutrients are returned to the soil to fuel plant growth.
7.44.330	The boreal forest (taiga) has low lying plants and conifer trees.
7.44.331	Arctic Tundra
7.44.332	The Arctic tundra lies north of the subarctic boreal forest and is located throughout the Arctic regions of the northern hemisphere (Figure 44.12).
7.44.333	The average winter temperature is -34 °C (-34 °F) and the average summer temperature is from 3 °C to 12 °C (37 °F–52 °F).
7.44.334	Plants in the arctic tundra have a very short growing season of approximately 10–12 weeks.
7.44.335	However, during this time, there are almost 24 hours of daylight and plant growth is rapid.
7.44.336	The annual precipitation of the Arctic tundra is very low with little annual variation in precipitation.
7.44.337	And, as in the boreal forests, there is little evaporation due to the cold temperatures.
7.44.338	Plants in the Arctic tundra are generally low to the ground (Figure 44.20).
7.44.339	There is little species diversity, low net primary productivity, and low aboveground biomass.
7.44.340	The soils of the Arctic tundra may remain in a perennially frozen state referred to as permafrost.
7.44.341	The permafrost makes it impossible for roots to penetrate deep into the soil and slows the decay of organic matter, which inhibits the release of nutrients from organic matter.
7.44.342	During the growing season, the ground of the Arctic tundra can be completely covered with plants or lichens.
7.44.343	Low-growing plants such as shrub willow dominate the tundra landscape, shown here in the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge.
7.44.344	Aquatic Biomes
7.44.345	By the end of this section, you will be able to: Describe the effects of abiotic factors on the composition of plant and animal communities in aquatic biomes Compare and contrast the characteristics of the ocean zones Summarize the characteristics of standing water and flowing water freshwater biomes Abiotic Factors Influencing Aquatic Biomes
7.44.346	Like terrestrial biomes, aquatic biomes are influenced by a series of abiotic factors.
7.44.347	The aquatic medium—water— has different physical and chemical properties than air, however.
7.44.348	Even if the water in a pond or other body of water is perfectly clear (there are no suspended particles), water, on its own, absorbs light.
7.44.349	As one descends into a deep body of water, there will eventually be a depth which the sunlight cannot reach.
7.44.350	While there are some abiotic and biotic factors in a terrestrial ecosystem that might obscure light (like fog, dust, or insect swarms), usually these are not permanent features of the environment.
7.44.351	The importance of light in aquatic biomes is central to the communities of organisms found in both freshwater and marine ecosystems.
7.44.352	In freshwater systems, stratification due to differences in density is perhaps the most critical abiotic factor and is related to the energy aspects of light.
7.44.353	The thermal properties of water (rates of heating and cooling) are significant to the function of marine systems and have major impacts on global climate and weather patterns.
7.44.354	Marine systems are also influenced by large-scale physical water movements, such as currents; these are less important in most freshwater lakes.
7.44.355	The ocean is categorized by several areas or zones (Figure 44.21).
7.44.356	All of the ocean’s open water is referred to as the pelagic realm (or zone).
7.44.357	The benthic realm (or zone) extends along the ocean bottom from the shoreline to the deepest parts of the ocean floor.
7.44.358	Within the pelagic realm is the photic zone, which is the portion of the ocean that light can penetrate (approximately 200 m or 650 ft).
7.44.359	At depths greater than 200 m, light cannot penetrate; thus, this is referred to as the aphotic zone.
7.44.360	The majority of the ocean is aphotic and lacks sufficient light for photosynthesis.
7.44.361	The deepest part of the ocean, the Challenger Deep (in the Mariana Trench, located in the western Pacific Ocean), is about 11,000 m (about 6.8 mi) deep.
7.44.362	To give some perspective on the depth of this trench, the ocean is, on average, 4267 m or 14,000 ft deep.
7.44.363	These realms and zones are relevant to freshwater lakes as well.
7.44.364	Marine Biomes
7.44.365	The ocean is the largest marine biome.
7.44.366	It is a continuous body of salt water that is relatively uniform in chemical composition; it is a weak solution of mineral salts and decayed biological matter.
7.44.367	Within the ocean, coral reefs are a second kind of marine biome.
7.44.368	Estuaries, coastal areas where salt water and fresh water mix, form a third unique marine biome.
7.44.369	Ocean
7.44.370	The physical diversity of the ocean is a significant influence on plants, animals, and other organisms.
7.44.371	The ocean is categorized into different zones based on how far light reaches into the water.
7.44.372	Each zone has a distinct group of species adapted to the biotic and abiotic conditions particular to that zone.
7.44.373	The intertidal zone, which is the zone between high and low tide, is the oceanic region that is closest to land (Figure 44.21).
7.44.374	Generally, most people think of this portion of the ocean as a sandy beach.
7.44.375	In some cases, the intertidal zone is indeed a sandy beach, but it can also be rocky or muddy.
7.44.376	The intertidal zone is an extremely variable environment because of tides.
7.44.377	Organisms are exposed to air and sunlight at low tide and are underwater most of the time, especially during high tide.
7.44.378	Therefore, living things that thrive in the intertidal zone are adapted to being dry for long periods of time.
7.44.379	The shore of the intertidal zone is also repeatedly struck by waves, and the organisms found there are adapted to withstand damage from the pounding action of the waves (Figure 44.22).
7.44.380	The exoskeletons of shoreline crustaceans (such as the shore crab, Carcinus maenas) are tough and protect them from desiccation (drying out) and wave damage.
7.44.381	Another consequence of the pounding waves is that few algae and plants establish themselves in the constantly moving rocks, sand, or mud.
7.44.382	Sea urchins, mussel shells, and starfish are often found in the intertidal zone, shown here in Kachemak Bay, Alaska.
7.44.383	The neritic zone (Figure 44.21) extends from the intertidal zone to depths of about 200 m (or 650 ft) at the edge of the continental shelf.
7.44.384	Since light can penetrate this depth, photosynthesis can occur in the neritic zone.
7.44.385	The water here contains silt and is well-oxygenated, low in pressure, and stable in temperature.
7.44.386	Phytoplankton and floating Sargassum (a type of free-floating marine seaweed) provide a habitat for some sea life found in the neritic zone.
7.44.387	Zooplankton, protists, small fishes, and shrimp are found in the neritic zone and are the base of the food chain for most of the world’s fisheries.
7.44.388	Beyond the neritic zone is the open ocean area known as the oceanic zone (Figure 44.21).
7.44.389	Within the oceanic zone there is thermal stratification where warm and cold waters mix because of ocean currents.
7.44.390	Abundant plankton serve as the base of the food chain for larger animals such as whales and dolphins.
7.44.391	Nutrients are scarce and this is a relatively less productive part of the marine biome.
7.44.392	When photosynthetic organisms and the protists and animals that feed on them die, their bodies fall to the bottom of the ocean where they remain; unlike freshwater lakes, the open ocean lacks a process for bringing the organic nutrients back up to the surface.
7.44.393	The majority of organisms in the aphotic zone include sea cucumbers (phylum Echinodermata) and other organisms that survive on the nutrients contained in the dead bodies of organisms in the photic zone.
7.44.394	Beneath the pelagic zone is the benthic realm, the deepwater region beyond the continental shelf (Figure 44.21).
7.44.395	The bottom of the benthic realm is comprised of sand, silt, and dead organisms.
7.44.396	Temperature decreases, remaining above freezing, as water depth increases.
7.44.397	This is a nutrient-rich portion of the ocean because of the dead organisms that fall from the upper layers of the ocean.
7.44.398	Because of this high level of nutrients, a diversity of fungi, sponges, sea anemones, marine worms, sea stars, fishes, and bacteria exist.
7.44.399	The deepest part of the ocean is the abyssal zone, which is at depths of 4000 m or greater.
7.44.400	The abyssal zone (Figure 44.21) is very cold and has very high pressure, high oxygen content, and low nutrient content.
7.44.401	There are a variety of invertebrates and fishes found in this zone, but the abyssal zone does not have plants because of the lack of light.
7.44.402	Hydrothermal vents are found primarily in the abyssal zone; chemosynthetic bacteria utilize the hydrogen sulfide and other minerals emitted from the vents.
7.44.403	These chemosynthetic bacteria use the hydrogen sulfide as an energy source and serve as the base of the food chain found in the abyssal zone.
7.44.404	Coral Reefs Coral reefs are ocean ridges formed by marine invertebrates living in warm shallow waters within the photic zone of the ocean.
7.44.405	They are found within 30˚ north and south of the equator.
7.44.406	The Great Barrier Reef is a well-known reef system located several miles off the northeastern coast of Australia.
