7.44.407	Other coral reef systems are fringing islands, which are directly adjacent to land, or atolls, which are circular reef systems surrounding a former landmass that is now underwater.
7.44.408	The coral organisms (members of phylum Cnidaria) are colonies of saltwater polyps that secrete a calcium carbonate skeleton.
7.44.409	These calcium-rich skeletons slowly accumulate, forming the underwater reef (Figure 44.23).
7.44.410	Corals found in shallower waters (at a depth of approximately 60 m or about 200 ft) have a mutualistic relationship with photosynthetic unicellular algae.
7.44.411	The relationship provides corals with the majority of the nutrition and the energy they require.
7.44.412	The waters in which these corals live are nutritionally poor and, without this mutualism, it would not be possible for large corals to grow.
7.44.413	Some corals living in deeper and colder water do not have a mutualistic relationship with algae; these corals attain energy and nutrients using stinging cells on their tentacles to capture prey.
7.44.414	It is estimated that more than 4,000 fish species inhabit coral reefs.
7.44.415	These fishes can feed on coral, the cryptofauna (invertebrates found within the calcium carbonate substrate of the coral reefs), or the seaweed and algae that are associated with the coral.
7.44.416	In addition, some fish species inhabit the boundaries of a coral reef; these species include predators, herbivores, or planktivores.
7.44.417	Predators are animal species that hunt and are carnivores or “flesh eaters.
7.44.418	”
7.44.419	Herbivores eat plant material, and planktivores eat plankton.
7.44.420	Coral reefs are formed by the calcium carbonate skeletons of coral organisms, which are marine invertebrates in the phylum Cnidaria.
7.44.421	Estuaries: Where the Ocean Meets Fresh Water Estuaries are biomes that occur where a source of fresh water, such as a river, meets the ocean.
7.44.422	Therefore, both fresh water and salt water are found in the same vicinity; mixing results in a diluted (brackish) saltwater.
7.44.423	Estuaries form protected areas where many of the young offspring of crustaceans, mollusks, and fish begin their lives.
7.44.424	Salinity is a very important factor that influences the organisms and the adaptations of the organisms found in estuaries.
7.44.425	The salinity of estuaries varies and is based on the rate of flow of its freshwater sources.
7.44.426	Once or twice a day, high tides bring salt water into the estuary.
7.44.427	Low tides occurring at the same frequency reverse the current of salt water.
7.44.428	The short-term and rapid variation in salinity due to the mixing of fresh water and salt water is a difficult physiological challenge for the plants and animals that inhabit estuaries.
7.44.429	Many estuarine plant species are halophytes: plants that can tolerate salty conditions.
7.44.430	Halophytic plants are adapted to deal with the salinity resulting from saltwater on their roots or from sea spray.
7.44.431	In some halophytes, filters in the roots remove the salt from the water that the plant absorbs.
7.44.432	Other plants are able to pump oxygen into their roots.
7.44.433	Animals, such as mussels and clams (phylum Mollusca), have developed behavioral adaptations that expend a lot of energy to function in this rapidly changing environment.
7.44.434	When these animals are exposed to low salinity, they stop feeding, close their shells, and switch from aerobic respiration (in which they use gills) to anaerobic respiration (a process that does not require oxygen).
7.44.435	When high tide returns to the estuary, the salinity and oxygen content of the water increases, and these animals open their shells, begin feeding, and return to aerobic respiration.
7.44.436	Freshwater Biomes Freshwater biomes include lakes and ponds (standing water) as well as rivers and streams (flowing water).
7.44.437	They also include wetlands, which will be discussed later.
7.44.438	Humans rely on freshwater biomes to provide aquatic resources for drinking water, crop irrigation, sanitation, and industry.
7.44.439	These various roles and human benefits are referred to as ecosystem services.
7.44.440	Lakes and ponds are found in terrestrial landscapes and are, therefore, connected with abiotic and biotic factors influencing these terrestrial biomes.
7.44.441	Lakes and Ponds Lakes and ponds can range in area from a few square meters to thousands of square kilometers.
7.44.442	Temperature is an important abiotic factor affecting living things found in lakes and ponds.
7.44.443	In the summer, thermal stratification of lakes and ponds occurs when the upper layer of water is warmed by the sun and does not mix with deeper, cooler water.
7.44.444	Light can penetrate within the photic zone of the lake or pond.
7.44.445	Phytoplankton (algae and cyanobacteria) are found here and carry out photosynthesis, providing the base of the food web of lakes and ponds.
7.44.446	Zooplankton, such as rotifers and small crustaceans, consume these phytoplankton.
7.44.447	At the bottom of lakes and ponds, bacteria in the aphotic zone break down dead organisms that sink to the bottom.
7.44.448	Nitrogen and phosphorus are important limiting nutrients in lakes and ponds.
7.44.449	Because of this, they are determining factors in the amount of phytoplankton growth in lakes and ponds.
7.44.450	When there is a large input of nitrogen and phosphorus (from sewage and runoff from fertilized lawns and farms, for example), the growth of algae skyrockets, resulting in a large accumulation of algae called an algal bloom.
7.44.451	Algal blooms (Figure 44.24) can become so extensive that they reduce light penetration in water.
7.44.452	As a result, the lake or pond becomes aphotic and photosynthetic plants cannot survive.
7.44.453	When the algae die and decompose, severe oxygen depletion of the water occurs.
7.44.454	Fishes and other organisms that require oxygen are then more likely to die, and resulting dead zones are found across the globe.
7.44.455	Lake Erie and the Gulf of Mexico represent freshwater and marine habitats where phosphorus control and storm water runoff pose significant environmental challenges.
7.44.456	The uncontrolled growth of algae in this lake has resulted in an algal bloom.
7.44.457	Rivers and Streams Rivers and streams are continuously moving bodies of water that carry large amounts of water from the source, or headwater, to a lake or ocean.
7.44.458	The largest rivers include the Nile River in Africa, the Amazon River in South America, and the Mississippi River in North America.
7.44.459	Abiotic features of rivers and streams vary along the length of the river or stream.
7.44.460	Streams begin at a point of origin referred to as source water.
7.44.461	The source water is usually cold, low in nutrients, and clear.
7.44.462	The channel (the width of the river or stream) is narrower than at any other place along the length of the river or stream.
7.44.463	Because of this, the current is often faster here than at any other point of the river or stream.
7.44.464	The fast-moving water results in minimal silt accumulation at the bottom of the river or stream; therefore, the water is clear.
7.44.465	Photosynthesis here is mostly attributed to algae that are growing on rocks; the swift current inhibits the growth of phytoplankton.
7.44.466	An additional input of energy can come from leaves or other organic material that falls into the river or stream from trees and other plants that border the water.
7.44.467	When the leaves decompose, the organic material and nutrients in the leaves are returned to the water.
7.44.468	Plants and animals have adapted to this fast-moving water.
7.44.469	For instance, leeches (phylum Annelida) have elongated bodies and suckers on both ends.
7.44.470	These suckers attach to the substrate, keeping the leech anchored in place.
7.44.471	Freshwater trout species (phylum Chordata) are an important predator in these fast-moving rivers and streams.
7.44.472	As the river or stream flows away from the source, the width of the channel gradually widens and the current slows.
7.44.473	This slow-moving water, caused by the gradient decrease and the volume increase as tributaries unite, has more sedimentation.
7.44.474	Phytoplankton can also be suspended in slow-moving water.
7.44.475	Therefore, the water will not be as clear as it is near the source.
7.44.476	The water is also warmer.
7.44.477	Worms (phylum Annelida) and insects (phylum Arthropoda) can be found burrowing into the mud.
7.44.478	The higher order predator vertebrates (phylum Chordata) include waterfowl, frogs, and fishes.
7.44.479	These predators must find food in these slow moving, sometimes murky, waters and, unlike the trout in the waters at the source, these vertebrates may not be able to use vision as their primary sense to find food.
7.44.480	Instead, they are more likely to use taste or chemical cues to find prey.
7.44.481	Wetlands Wetlands are environments in which the soil is either permanently or periodically saturated with water.
7.44.482	Wetlands are different from lakes because wetlands are shallow bodies of water whereas lakes vary in depth.
7.44.483	Emergent vegetation consists of wetland plants that are rooted in the soil but have portions of leaves, stems, and flowers extending above the water’s surface.
7.44.484	There are several types of wetlands including marshes, swamps, bogs, mudflats, and salt marshes (Figure 44.25).
7.44.485	The three shared characteristics among these types—what makes them wetlands—are their hydrology, hydrophytic vegetation, and hydric soils.
7.44.486	Located in southern Florida, Everglades National Park is vast array of wetland environments, including sawgrass marshes, cypress swamps, and estuarine mangrove forests.
7.44.487	Here, a great egret walks among cypress trees.
7.44.488	Freshwater marshes and swamps are characterized by slow and steady water flow.
7.44.489	Bogs develop in depressions where water flow is low or nonexistent.
7.44.490	Bogs usually occur in areas where there is a clay bottom with poor percolation.
7.44.491	Percolation is the movement of water through the pores in the soil or rocks.
7.44.492	The water found in a bog is stagnant and oxygen depleted because the oxygen that is used during the decomposition of organic matter is not replaced.
7.44.493	As the oxygen in the water is depleted, decomposition slows.
7.44.494	This leads to organic acids and other acids building up and lowering the pH of the water.
7.44.495	At a lower pH, nitrogen becomes unavailable to plants.
7.44.496	This creates a challenge for plants because nitrogen is an important limiting resource.
7.44.497	Some types of bog plants (such as sundews, pitcher plants, and Venus flytraps) capture insects and extract the nitrogen from their bodies.
7.44.498	Bogs have low net primary productivity because the water found in bogs has low levels of nitrogen and oxygen.
7.44.499	Climate and the Effects of Global Climate Change
7.44.500	By the end of this section, you will be able to: Define global climate change Summarize the effects of the Industrial Revolution on global atmospheric carbon dioxide concentration
7.44.501	Describe three natural factors affecting long-term global climate List two or more greenhouse gases and describe their role in the greenhouse effect
7.44.502	All biomes are universally affected by global conditions, such as climate, that ultimately shape each biome’s environment.
7.44.503	Scientists who study climate have noted a series of marked changes that have gradually become increasingly evident during the last sixty years.
7.44.504	Global climate change is the term used to describe altered global weather patterns, including a worldwide increase in temperature, due largely to rising levels of atmospheric carbon dioxide.
7.44.505	Climate and Weather A common misconception about global climate change is that a specific weather event occurring in a particular region (for example, a very cool week in June in central Indiana) is evidence of global climate change.
7.44.506	However, a cold week in June is a weather-related event and not a climate-related one.
7.44.507	These misconceptions often arise because of confusion over the terms climate and weather.
7.44.508	Climate refers to the long-term, predictable atmospheric conditions of a specific area.
7.44.509	The climate of a biome is characterized by having consistent temperature and annual rainfall ranges.
7.44.510	Climate does not address the amount of rain that fell on one particular day in a biome or the colder-than-average temperatures that occurred on one day.
7.44.511	In contrast, weather refers to the conditions of the atmosphere during a short period of time.
7.44.512	Weather forecasts are usually made for 48-hour cycles.
7.44.513	Long-range weather forecasts are available but can be unreliable.
7.44.514	To better understand the difference between climate and weather, imagine that you are planning an outdoor event in northern Wisconsin.
7.44.515	You would be thinking about climate when you plan the event in the summer rather than the winter because you have long-term knowledge that any given Saturday in the months of May to August would be a better choice for an outdoor event in Wisconsin than any given Saturday in January.
7.44.516	However, you cannot determine the specific day that the event should be held on because it is difficult to accurately predict the weather on a specific day.
7.44.517	Climate can be considered “average” weather.
7.44.518	Global Climate Change Climate change can be understood by approaching three areas of study: • current and past global climate change • causes of past and present-day global climate change • ancient and current results of climate change
7.44.519	It is helpful to keep these three different aspects of climate change clearly separated when consuming media reports about global climate change.
7.44.520	It is common for reports and discussions about global climate change to confuse the data showing that Earth’s climate is changing with the factors that drive this climate change.
7.44.521	Evidence for Global Climate Change
7.44.522	Since scientists cannot go back in time to directly measure climatic variables, such as average temperature and precipitation, they must instead indirectly measure temperature.
7.44.523	To do this, scientists rely on historical evidence of Earth’s past climate.
7.44.524	Antarctic ice cores are a key example of such evidence.
7.44.525	These ice cores are samples of polar ice obtained by means of drills that reach thousands of meters into ice sheets or high mountain glaciers.
7.44.526	Viewing the ice cores is like traveling backwards through time; the deeper the sample, the earlier the time period.
7.44.527	Trapped within the ice are bubbles of air and other biological evidence that can reveal temperature and carbon dioxide data.
7.44.528	Antarctic ice cores have been collected and analyzed to indirectly estimate the temperature of the Earth over the past 400,000 years (Figure 44.26a).
7.44.529	The 0 °C on this graph refers to the long-term average.
7.44.530	Temperatures that are greater than 0 °C exceed Earth’s long-term average temperature.
7.44.531	Conversely, temperatures that are less than 0 °C are less than Earth’s average temperature.
7.44.532	This figure shows that there have been periodic cycles of increasing and decreasing temperature.
7.44.533	Before the late 1800s, the Earth has been as much as 9 °C cooler and about 3 °C warmer.
7.44.534	Note that the graph in Figure 44.26b shows that the atmospheric concentration of carbon dioxide has also risen and fallen in periodic cycles; note the relationship between carbon dioxide concentration and temperature.
7.44.535	Figure 44.26b shows that carbon dioxide levels in the atmosphere have historically cycled between 180 and 300 parts per million (ppm) by volume.
7.44.536	Ice at the Russian Vostok station in East Antarctica was laid down over the course 420,000 years and reached a depth of over 3,000 m. By measuring the amount of CO2 trapped in the ice, scientists have determined past atmospheric CO2 concentrations.
7.44.537	Temperatures relative to modern day were determined from the amount of deuterium (an isotope of hydrogen) present.
7.44.538	Figure 44.26a does not show the last 2,000 years with enough detail to compare the changes of Earth’s temperature during the last 400,000 years with the temperature change that has occurred in the more recent past.
7.44.539	Two significant temperature anomalies, or irregularities, have occurred in the last 2000 years.
7.44.540	These are the Medieval Climate Anomaly (or the Medieval Warm Period) and the Little Ice Age.
7.44.541	A third temperature anomaly aligns with the Industrial Era.
7.44.542	The Medieval Climate Anomaly occurred between 900 and 1300 AD.
7.44.543	During this time period, many climate scientists think that slightly warmer weather conditions prevailed in many parts of the world; the higher-than-average temperature changes varied between 0.10 °C and 0.20 °C above the norm.
7.44.544	Although 0.10 °C does not seem large enough to produce any noticeable change, it did free seas of ice.
7.44.545	Because of this warming, the Vikings were able to colonize Greenland.
7.44.546	The Little Ice Age was a cold period that occurred between 1550 AD and 1850 AD.
7.44.547	During this time, a slight cooling of a little less than 1 °C was observed in North America, Europe, and possibly other areas of the Earth.
7.44.548	This 1 °C change in global temperature is a seemingly small deviation in temperature (as was observed during the Medieval Climate Anomaly); however, it also resulted in noticeable changes.
7.44.549	Historical accounts reveal a time of exceptionally harsh winters with much snow and frost.
7.44.550	The Industrial Revolution, which began around 1750, was characterized by changes in much of human society.
7.44.551	Advances in agriculture increased the food supply, which improved the standard of living for people in Europe and the United States.
7.44.552	New technologies were invented and provided jobs and cheaper goods.
7.44.553	These new technologies were powered using fossil fuels, especially coal.
7.44.554	The Industrial Revolution starting in the early nineteenth century ushered in the beginning of the Industrial Era.
7.44.555	When a fossil fuel is burned, carbon dioxide is released.
7.44.556	With the beginning of the Industrial Era, atmospheric carbon dioxide began to rise.
7.44.557	The atmospheric concentration of CO2 has risen steadily since the beginning of industrialization.
7.44.558	Current and Past Drivers of Global Climate Change
7.44.559	Since it is not possible to go back in time to directly observe and measure climate, scientists use indirect evidence to determine the drivers, or factors, that may be responsible for climate change.
7.44.560	The indirect evidence includes data collected using ice cores, boreholes (a narrow shaft bored into the ground), tree rings, glacier lengths, pollen remains, and ocean sediments.
7.44.561	The data shows a correlation between the timing of temperature changes and drivers of climate change: before the Industrial Era (pre-1780), there were three drivers of climate change that were not related to human activity or atmospheric gases.
7.44.562	The first of these is the Milankovitch cycles.
7.44.563	The Milankovitch cycles describe the effects of slight changes in the Earth’s orbit on Earth’s climate.
7.44.564	The length of the Milankovitch cycles ranges between 19,000 and 100,000 years.
7.44.565	In other words, one could expect to see some predictable changes in the Earth’s climate associated with changes in the Earth’s orbit at a minimum of every 19,000 years.
7.44.566	The variation in the sun’s intensity is the second natural factor responsible for climate change.
7.44.567	Solar intensity is the amount of solar power or energy the sun emits in a given amount of time.
7.44.568	There is a direct relationship between solar intensity and temperature.
7.44.569	As solar intensity increases (or decreases), the Earth’s temperature correspondingly increases (or decreases).
7.44.570	Changes in solar intensity have been proposed as one of several possible explanations for the Little Ice Age.
7.44.571	Finally, volcanic eruptions are a third natural driver of climate change.
7.44.572	Volcanic eruptions can last a few days, but the solids and gases released during an eruption can influence the climate over a period of a few years, causing short-term climate changes.
7.44.573	The gases and solids released by volcanic eruptions can include carbon dioxide, water vapor, sulfur dioxide, hydrogen sulfide, hydrogen, and carbon monoxide.
7.44.574	Generally, volcanic eruptions cool the climate.
7.44.575	This occurred in 1783 when volcanos in Iceland erupted and caused the release of large volumes of sulfuric oxide.
7.44.576	This led to haze-effect cooling, a global phenomenon that occurs when dust, ash, or other suspended particles block out sunlight and trigger lower global temperatures as a result; haze-effect cooling usually extends for one or more years.
7.44.577	In Europe and North America, hazeeffect cooling produced some of the lowest average winter temperatures on record in 1783 and 1784.
7.44.578	Greenhouse gases are probably the most significant drivers of the climate.
7.44.579	When heat energy from the sun strikes the Earth, gases known as greenhouse gases trap the heat in the atmosphere, as do the glass panes of a greenhouse keep heat from escaping.
7.44.580	The greenhouse gases that affect Earth include carbon dioxide, methane, water vapor, nitrous oxide, and ozone.
7.44.581	Approximately half of the radiation from the sun passes through these gases in the atmosphere and strikes the Earth.
7.44.582	This radiation is converted into thermal radiation on the Earth’s surface, and then a portion of that energy is re-radiated back into the atmosphere.
7.44.583	Greenhouse gases, however, reflect much of the thermal energy back to the Earth’s surface.
7.44.584	The more greenhouse gases there are in the atmosphere, the more thermal energy is reflected back to the Earth’s surface.
7.44.585	Greenhouse gases absorb and emit radiation and are an important factor in the greenhouse effect: the warming of Earth due to carbon dioxide and other greenhouse gases in the atmosphere.
7.44.586	Evidence supports the relationship between atmospheric concentrations of carbon dioxide and temperature: as carbon dioxide rises, global temperature rises.
7.44.587	Since 1950, the concentration of atmospheric carbon dioxide has increased from about 280 ppm to 382 ppm in 2006.
7.44.588	In 2011, the atmospheric carbon dioxide concentration was 392 ppm.
7.44.589	However, the planet would not be inhabitable by current life forms if water vapor did not produce its drastic greenhouse warming effect.
7.44.590	Scientists look at patterns in data and try to explain differences or deviations from these patterns.
7.44.591	The atmospheric carbon dioxide data reveal a historical pattern of carbon dioxide increasing and decreasing, cycling between a low of 180 ppm and a high of 300 ppm.
7.44.592	Scientists have concluded that it took around 50,000 years for the atmospheric carbon dioxide level to increase from its low minimum concentration to its higher maximum concentration.
7.44.593	However, starting recently, atmospheric carbon dioxide concentrations have increased beyond the historical maximum of 300 ppm.
7.44.594	The current increases in atmospheric carbon dioxide have happened very quickly—in a matter of hundreds of years rather than thousands of years.
7.44.595	What is the reason for this difference in the rate of change and the amount of increase in carbon dioxide?
7.44.596	A key factor that must be recognized when comparing the historical data and the current data is the presence of modern human society; no other driver of climate change has yielded changes in atmospheric carbon dioxide levels at this rate or to this magnitude.
7.44.597	Human activity releases carbon dioxide and methane, two of the most important greenhouse gases, into the atmosphere in several ways.
7.44.598	The primary mechanism that releases carbon dioxide is the burning of fossil fuels, such as gasoline, coal, and natural gas (Figure 44.28).
7.44.599	Deforestation, cement manufacture, animal agriculture, the clearing of land, and the burning of forests are other human activities that release carbon dioxide.
7.44.600	Methane (CH4) is produced when bacteria break down organic matter under anaerobic conditions.
7.44.601	Anaerobic conditions can happen when organic matter is trapped underwater (such as in rice paddies) or in the intestines of herbivores.
7.44.602	Methane can also be released from natural gas fields and the decomposition that occurs in landfills.
7.44.603	Another source of methane is the melting of clathrates.
7.44.604	Clathrates are frozen chunks of ice and methane found at the bottom of the ocean.
7.44.605	When water warms, these chunks of ice melt and methane is released.
7.44.606	As the ocean’s water temperature increases, the rate at which clathrates melt is increasing, releasing even more methane.
7.44.607	This leads to increased levels of methane in the atmosphere, which further accelerates the rate of global warming.
7.44.608	This is an example of the positive feedback loop that is leading to the rapid rate of increase of global temperatures.
7.44.609	The burning of fossil fuels in industry and by vehicles releases carbon dioxide and other greenhouse gases into the atmosphere.
7.44.610	Documented Results of Climate Change:
7.44.611	Past and Present Scientists have geological evidence of the consequences of long-ago climate change.
7.44.612	Modern-day phenomena such as retreating glaciers and melting polar ice cause a continual rise in sea level.
7.44.613	Meanwhile, changes in climate can negatively affect organisms.
7.44.614	Geological Climate Change Global warming has been associated with at least one planet-wide extinction event during the geological past.
7.44.615	The Permian extinction event occurred about 251 million years ago toward the end of the roughly 50-million-year-long geological time span known as the Permian period.
7.44.616	This geologic time period was one of the three warmest periods in Earth’s geologic history.
7.44.617	Scientists estimate that approximately 70 percent of the terrestrial plant and animal species and 84 percent of marine species became extinct, vanishing forever near the end of the Permian period.
7.44.618	Organisms that had adapted to wet and warm climatic conditions, such as annual rainfall of 300–400 cm (118–157 in) and 20 °C–30 °C (68 °F–86 °F) in the tropical wet forest, may not have been able to survive the Permian climate change.
7.44.619	Present Climate Change
7.44.620	A number of global events have occurred that may be attributed to climate change during our lifetimes.
7.44.621	Glacier National Park in Montana is undergoing the retreat of many of its glaciers, a phenomenon known as glacier recession.
7.44.622	In 1850, the area contained approximately 150 glaciers.
7.44.623	By 2010, however, the park contained only about 24 glaciers greater than 25 acres in size.
7.44.624	One of these glaciers is the Grinnell Glacier (Figure 44.29) at Mount Gould.
7.44.625	Between 1966 and 2005, the size of Grinnell Glacier shrank by 40 percent.
7.44.626	Similarly, the mass of the ice sheets in Greenland and the Antarctic is decreasing: Greenland lost 150–250 km3 of ice per year between 2002 and 2006.
7.44.627	In addition, the size and thickness of the Arctic sea ice is decreasing.
7.44.628	The effect of global warming can be seen in the continuing retreat of Grinnel Glacier.
7.44.629	The mean annual temperature in the park has increased 1.33 °C since 1900.
7.44.630	The loss of a glacier results in the loss of summer meltwaters, sharply reducing seasonal water supplies and severely affecting local ecosystems.
7.44.631	This loss of ice is leading to increases in the global sea level.
7.44.632	On average, the sea is rising at a rate of 1.8 mm per year.
7.44.633	However, between 1993 and 2010 the rate of sea level increase ranged between 2.9 and 3.4 mm per year.
7.44.634	A variety of factors affect the volume of water in the ocean, including the temperature of the water (the density of water is related to its temperature) and the amount of water found in rivers, lakes, glaciers, polar ice caps, and sea ice.
7.44.635	As glaciers and polar ice caps melt, there is a significant contribution of liquid water that was previously frozen.
7.44.636	In addition to some abiotic conditions changing in response to climate change, many organisms are also being affected by the changes in temperature.
7.44.637	Temperature and precipitation play key roles in determining the geographic distribution and phenology of plants and animals.
7.44.638	(Phenology is the study of the effects of climatic conditions on the timing of periodic lifecycle events, such as flowering in plants or migration in birds.)
7.44.639	Researchers have shown that 385 plant species in Great Britain are flowering 4.5 days sooner than was recorded earlier during the previous 40 years.
7.44.640	In addition, insect-pollinated species were more likely to flower earlier than wind-pollinated species.
7.44.641	The impact of changes in flowering date would be mitigated if the insect pollinators emerged earlier.
7.44.642	This mismatched timing of plants and pollinators could result in injurious ecosystem effects because, for continued survival, insect-pollinated plants must flower when their pollinators are present.
7.45.0	Asian carp jump out of the water in response to electrofishing.
7.45.1	The Asian carp in the inset photograph were harvested from the Little Calumet River in Illinois in May, 2010, using rotenone, a toxin often used as an insecticide, in an effort to learn more about the population of the species.
7.45.2	Imagine sailing down a river in a small motorboat on a weekend afternoon; the water is smooth and you are enjoying the warm sunshine and cool breeze when suddenly you are hit in the head by a 20-pound silver carp.
7.45.3	This is a risk now on many rivers and canal systems in Illinois and Missouri because of the presence of Asian carp.
7.45.4	This fish—actually a group of species including the silver, black, grass, and big head carp—has been farmed and eaten in China for over 1000 years.
7.45.5	It is one of the most important aquaculture food resources worldwide.
7.45.6	In the United States, however, Asian carp is considered a dangerous invasive species that disrupts community structure and composition to the point of threatening native species.
7.45.7	Population Demography
7.45.8	By the end of this section, you will be able to: Describe how ecologists measure population size and density Describe three different patterns of population distribution
7.45.9	Use life tables to calculate mortality rates Describe the three types of survivorship curves and relate them to specific populations Populations are dynamic entities.
7.45.10	Populations consist all of the species living within a specific area, and populations fluctuate based on a number of factors: seasonal and yearly changes in the environment, natural disasters such as forest fires and volcanic eruptions, and competition for resources between and within species.
7.45.11	The statistical study of population dynamics, demography, uses a series of mathematical tools to investigate how populations respond to changes in their biotic and abiotic environments.
7.45.12	Many of these tools were originally designed to study human populations.
7.45.13	For example, life tables, which detail the life expectancy of individuals within a population, were initially developed by life insurance companies to set insurance rates.
7.45.14	In fact, while the term “demographics” is commonly used when discussing humans, all living populations can be studied using this approach.
7.45.15	Population Size and Density
7.45.16	The study of any population usually begins by determining how many individuals of a particular species exist, and how closely associated they are with each other.
7.45.17	Within a particular habitat, a population can be characterized by its population size (N), the total number of individuals, and its population density, the number of individuals within a specific area or volume.
7.45.18	Population size and density are the two main characteristics used to describe and understand populations.
7.45.19	For example, populations with more individuals may be more stable than smaller populations based on their genetic variability, and thus their potential to adapt to the environment.
7.45.20	Alternatively, a member of a population with low population density (more spread out in the habitat), might have more difficulty finding a mate to reproduce compared to a population of higher density.
7.45.21	As is shown in Figure 45.2, smaller organisms tend to be more densely distributed than larger organisms.
7.45.22	Population Research Methods
7.45.23	The most accurate way to determine population size is to simply count all of the individuals within the habitat.
7.45.24	However, this method is often not logistically or economically feasible, especially when studying large habitats.
7.45.25	Thus, scientists usually study populations by sampling a representative portion of each habitat and using this data to make inferences about the habitat as a whole.
7.45.26	A variety of methods can be used to sample populations to determine their size and density.
7.45.27	For immobile organisms such as plants, or for very small and slow-moving organisms, a quadrat may be used (Figure 45.3).
7.45.28	A quadrat is a way of marking off square areas within a habitat, either by staking out an area with sticks and string, or by the use of a wood, plastic, or metal square placed on the ground.
7.45.29	After setting the quadrats, researchers then count the number of individuals that lie within their boundaries.
7.45.30	Multiple quadrat samples are performed throughout the habitat at several random locations.
7.45.31	All of this data can then be used to estimate the population size and population density within the entire habitat.
7.45.32	The number and size of quadrat samples depends on the type of organisms under study and other factors, including the density of the organism.
7.45.33	For example, if sampling daffodils, a 1 m2 quadrat might be used whereas with giant redwoods, which are larger and live much further apart from each other, a larger quadrat of 100 m2 might be employed.
7.45.34	This ensures that enough individuals of the species are counted to get an accurate sample that correlates with the habitat, including areas not sampled.
7.45.35	A scientist uses a quadrat to measure population size and density.
7.45.36	For mobile organisms, such as mammals, birds, or fish, a technique called mark and recapture is often used.
7.45.37	This method involves marking a sample of captured animals in some way (such as tags, bands, paint, or other body markings), and then releasing them back into the environment to allow them to mix with the rest of the population; later, a new sample is collected, including some individuals that are marked (recaptures) and some individuals that are unmarked.
7.45.38	Mark and recapture is used to measure the population size of mobile animals such as (a) bighorn sheep, (b) the California condor, and (c) salmon.
7.45.39	Using the ratio of marked and unmarked individuals, scientists determine how many individuals are in the sample.
7.45.40	From this, calculations are used to estimate the total population size.
7.45.41	This method assumes that the larger the population, the lower the percentage of tagged organisms that will be recaptured since they will have mixed with more untagged individuals.
7.45.42	For example, if 80 deer are captured, tagged, and released into the forest, and later 100 deer are captured and 20 of them are already marked, we can determine the population size (N) using the following equation: Therefore, there are an estimated 400 total individuals in the original population.
7.45.43	There are some limitations to the mark and recapture method.
7.45.44	Some animals from the first catch may learn to avoid capture in the second round, thus inflating population estimates.
7.45.45	Alternatively, animals may preferentially be retrapped (especially if a food reward is offered), resulting in an underestimate of population size.
7.45.46	Also, some species may be harmed by the marking technique, reducing their survival.
7.45.47	A variety of other techniques have been developed, including the electronic tracking of animals tagged with radio transmitters and the use of data from commercial fishing and trapping operations to estimate the size and health of populations and communities.
7.45.48	Species Distribution
7.45.49	In addition to measuring simple density, further information about a population can be obtained by looking at the distribution of the individuals.
7.45.50	Species dispersion patterns (or distribution patterns) show the spatial relationship between members of a population within a habitat at a particular point in time.
7.45.51	In other words, they show whether members of the species live close together or far apart, and what patterns are evident when they are spaced apart.
7.45.52	Individuals in a population can be more or less equally spaced apart, dispersed randomly with no predictable pattern, or clustered in groups.
7.45.53	These are known as uniform, random, and clumped dispersion patterns, respectively (Figure 45.5).
7.45.54	Uniform dispersion is observed in plants that secrete substances inhibiting the growth of nearby individuals (such as the release of toxic chemicals by the sage plant Salvia leucophylla, a phenomenon called allelopathy) and in animals like the penguin that maintain a defined territory.
7.45.55	An example of random dispersion occurs with dandelion and other plants that have wind-dispersed seeds that germinate wherever they happen to fall in a favorable environment.
7.45.56	A clumped dispersion may be seen in plants that drop their seeds straight to the ground, such as oak trees, or animals that live in groups (schools of fish or herds of elephants).
7.45.57	Clumped dispersions may also be a function of habitat heterogeneity.
7.45.58	Thus, the dispersion of the individuals within a population provides more information about how they interact with each other than does a simple density measurement.
7.45.59	Just as lower density species might have more difficulty finding a mate, solitary species with a random distribution might have a similar difficulty when compared to social species clumped together in groups.
7.45.60	Species may have uniform, random, or clumped distribution.
7.45.61	Territorial birds such as penguins tend to have uniform distribution.
7.45.62	Plants such as dandelions with wind-dispersed seeds tend to be randomly distributed.
7.45.63	Animals such as elephants that travel in groups exhibit clumped distribution.
7.45.64	Demography
7.45.65	While population size and density describe a population at one particular point in time, scientists must use demography to study the dynamics of a population.
7.45.66	Demography is the statistical study of population changes over time: birth rates, death rates, and life expectancies.
7.45.67	Each of these measures, especially birth rates, may be affected by the population characteristics described above.
7.45.68	For example, a large population size results in a higher birth rate because more potentially reproductive individuals are present.
7.45.69	In contrast, a large population size can also result in a higher death rate because of competition, disease, and the accumulation of waste.
7.45.70	Similarly, a higher population density or a clumped dispersion pattern results in more potential reproductive encounters between individuals, which can increase birth rate.
7.45.71	Lastly, a female-biased sex ratio (the ratio of males to females) or age structure (the proportion of population members at specific age ranges) composed of many individuals of reproductive age can increase birth rates.
7.45.72	In addition, the demographic characteristics of a population can influence how the population grows or declines over time.
7.45.73	If birth and death rates are equal, the population remains stable.
7.45.74	However, the population size will increase if birth rates exceed death rates; the population will decrease if birth rates are less than death rates.
7.45.75	Life expectancy is another important factor; the length of time individuals remain in the population impacts local resources, reproduction, and the overall health of the population.
7.45.76	These demographic characteristics are often displayed in the form of a life table.
7.45.77	Life Tables Life tables provide important information about the life history of an organism.
7.45.78	Life tables divide the population into age groups and often sexes, and show how long a member of that group is likely to live.
7.45.79	They are modeled after actuarial tables used by the insurance industry for estimating human life expectancy.
7.45.80	Life tables may include the probability of individuals dying before their next birthday (i.e., their mortality rate), the percentage of surviving individuals dying at a particular age interval, and their life expectancy at each interval.
7.45.81	An example of a life table is shown in Table 45.1 from a study of Dall mountain sheep, a species native to northwestern North America.
7.45.82	Notice that the population is divided into age intervals (column A).
7.45.83	The mortality rate (per 1000), shown in column D, is based on the number of individuals dying during the age interval (column B) divided by the number of individuals surviving at the beginning of the interval (Column C), multiplied by 1000.
7.45.84	For example, between ages three and four, 12 individuals die out of the 776 that were remaining from the original 1000 sheep.
7.45.85	This number is then multiplied by 1000 to get the mortality rate per thousand.
7.45.86	As can be seen from the mortality rate data (column D), a high death rate occurred when the sheep were between 6 and 12 months old, and then increased even more from 8 to 12 years old, after which there were few survivors.
7.45.87	The data indicate that if a sheep in this population were to survive to age one, it could be expected to live another 7.7 years on average, as shown by the life expectancy numbers in column E. Survivorship Curves
7.45.88	Another tool used by population ecologists is a survivorship curve, which is a graph of the number of individuals surviving at each age interval plotted versus time (usually with data compiled from a life table).
7.45.89	These curves allow us to compare the life histories of different populations (Figure 45.6).
7.45.90	Humans and most primates exhibit a Type I survivorship curve because a high percentage of offspring survive their early and middle years—death occurs predominantly in older individuals.
7.45.91	These types of species usually have small numbers of offspring at one time, and they give a high amount of parental care to them to ensure their survival.
7.45.92	Birds are an example of an intermediate or Type II survivorship curve because birds die more or less equally at each age interval.
7.45.93	These organisms also may have relatively few offspring and provide significant parental care.
7.45.94	Trees, marine invertebrates, and most fishes exhibit a Type III survivorship curve because very few of these organisms survive their younger years; however, those that make it to an old age are more likely to survive for a relatively long period of time.
7.45.95	Organisms in this category usually have a very large number of offspring, but once they are born, little parental care is provided.
7.45.96	Thus these offspring are “on their own” and vulnerable to predation, but their sheer numbers assure the survival of enough individuals to perpetuate the species.
7.45.97	Survivorship curves show the distribution of individuals in a population according to age.
7.45.98	Humans and most mammals have a Type I survivorship curve because death primarily occurs in the older years.
7.45.99	Birds have a Type II survivorship curve, as death at any age is equally probable.
7.45.100	Trees have a Type III survivorship curve because very few survive the younger years, but after a certain age, individuals are much more likely to survive.
7.45.101	45.2 | Life Histories and Natural Selection
7.45.102	By the end of this section, you will be able to:
7.45.103	• Describe how life history patterns are influenced by natural selection •
7.45.104	Explain different life history patterns and how different reproductive strategies affect species’ survival
7.45.105	A species’ life history describes the series of events over its lifetime, such as how resources are allocated for growth, maintenance, and reproduction.
7.45.106	Life history traits affect the life table of an organism.
7.45.107	A species’ life history is genetically determined and shaped by the environment and natural selection.
7.45.108	Life History Patterns and Energy Budgets Energy is required by all living organisms for their growth, maintenance, and reproduction; at the same time, energy is often a major limiting factor in determining an organism’s survival.
7.45.109	Plants, for example, acquire energy from the sun via photosynthesis, but must expend this energy to grow, maintain health, and produce energy-rich seeds to produce the next generation.
7.45.110	Animals have the additional burden of using some of their energy reserves to acquire food.
7.45.111	Furthermore, some animals must expend energy caring for their offspring.
7.45.112	Thus, all species have an energy budget: they must balance energy intake with their use of energy for metabolism, reproduction, parental care, and energy storage (such as bears building up body fat for winter hibernation).
7.45.113	Parental Care and Fecundity Fecundity is the potential reproductive capacity of an individual within a population.
7.45.114	In other words, fecundity describes how many offspring could ideally be produced if an individual has as many offspring as possible, repeating the reproductive cycle as soon as possible after the birth of the offspring.
7.45.115	In animals, fecundity is inversely related to the amount of parental care given to an individual offspring.
7.45.116	Species, such as many marine invertebrates, that produce many offspring usually provide little if any care for the offspring (they would not have the energy or the ability to do so anyway).
7.45.117	Most of their energy budget is used to produce many tiny offspring.
7.45.118	Animals with this strategy are often self-sufficient at a very early age.
7.45.119	This is because of the energy tradeoff these organisms have made to maximize their evolutionary fitness.
7.45.120	Because their energy is used for producing offspring instead of parental care, it makes sense that these offspring have some ability to be able to move within their environment and find food and perhaps shelter.
7.45.121	Even with these abilities, their small size makes them extremely vulnerable to predation, so the production of many offspring allows enough of them to survive to maintain the species.
7.45.122	Animal species that have few offspring during a reproductive event usually give extensive parental care, devoting much of their energy budget to these activities, sometimes at the expense of their own health.
7.45.123	This is the case with many mammals, such as humans, kangaroos, and pandas.
7.45.124	The offspring of these species are relatively helpless at birth and need to develop before they achieve self-sufficiency.
7.45.125	Plants with low fecundity produce few energy-rich seeds (such as coconuts and chestnuts) with each having a good chance to germinate into a new organism; plants with high fecundity usually have many small, energy-poor seeds (like orchids) that have a relatively poor chance of surviving.
7.45.126	Although it may seem that coconuts and chestnuts have a better chance of surviving, the energy tradeoff of the orchid is also very effective.
7.45.127	It is a matter of where the energy is used, for large numbers of seeds or for fewer seeds with more energy.
7.45.128	Early versus Late Reproduction
7.45.129	The timing of reproduction in a life history also affects species survival.
7.45.130	Organisms that reproduce at an early age have a greater chance of producing offspring, but this is usually at the expense of their growth and the maintenance of their health.
7.45.131	Conversely, organisms that start reproducing later in life often have greater fecundity or are better able to provide parental care, but they risk that they will not survive to reproductive age.
7.45.132	Examples of this can be seen in fishes.
7.45.133	Small fish like guppies use their energy to reproduce rapidly, but never attain the size that would give them defense against some predators.
7.45.134	Larger fish, like the bluegill or shark, use their energy to attain a large size, but do so with the risk that they will die before they can reproduce or at least reproduce to their maximum.
7.45.135	These different energy strategies and tradeoffs are key to understanding the evolution of each species as it maximizes its fitness and fills its niche.
7.45.136	In terms of energy budgeting, some species “blow it all” and use up most of their energy reserves to reproduce early before they die.
7.45.137	Other species delay having reproduction to become stronger, more experienced individuals and to make sure that they are strong enough to provide parental care if necessary.
7.45.138	Single versus Multiple Reproductive Events
7.45.139	Some life history traits, such as fecundity, timing of reproduction, and parental care, can be grouped together into general strategies that are used by multiple species.
7.45.140	Semelparity occurs when a species reproduces only once during its lifetime and then dies.
7.45.141	Such species use most of their resource budget during a single reproductive event, sacrificing their health to the point that they do not survive.
7.45.142	Examples of semelparity are bamboo, which flowers once and then dies, and the Chinook salmon (Figure 45.7a), which uses most of its energy reserves to migrate from the ocean to its freshwater nesting area, where it reproduces and then dies.
7.45.143	Scientists have posited alternate explanations for the evolutionary advantage of the Chinook’s post-reproduction death:
7.45.144	a programmed suicide caused by a massive release of corticosteroid hormones, presumably so the parents can become food for the offspring, or simple exhaustion caused by the energy demands of reproduction; these are still being debated.
7.45.145	Iteroparity describes species that reproduce repeatedly during their lives.
7.45.146	Some animals are able to mate only once per year, but survive multiple mating seasons.
7.45.147	The pronghorn antelope is an example of an animal that goes into a seasonal estrus cycle (“heat”): a hormonally induced physiological condition preparing the body for successful mating (Figure 45.7b).
7.45.148	Females of these species mate only during the estrus phase of the cycle.
7.45.149	A different pattern is observed in primates, including humans and chimpanzees, which may attempt reproduction at any time during their reproductive years, even though their menstrual cycles make pregnancy likely only a few days per month during ovulation.
7.45.150	The (a) Chinook salmon mates once and dies.
7.45.151	The (b) pronghorn antelope mates during specific times of the year during its reproductive life.
7.45.152	Primates, such as humans and (c) chimpanzees, may mate on any day, independent of ovulation.
7.45.153	45.3 | Environmental Limits to Population Growth
7.45.154	By the end of this section, you will be able to:
7.45.155	•
7.45.156	Explain the characteristics of and differences between exponential and logistic growth patterns • Give examples of exponential and logistic growth in natural populations
7.45.157	• Describe how natural selection and environmental adaptation led to the evolution of particular life history patterns
7.45.158	Although life histories describe the way many characteristics of a population (such as their age structure) change over time in a general way, population ecologists make use of a variety of methods to model population dynamics mathematically.
7.45.159	These more precise models can then be used to accurately describe changes occurring in a population and better predict future changes.
7.45.160	Certain models that have been accepted for decades are now being modified or even abandoned due to their lack of predictive ability, and scholars strive to create effective new models.
7.45.161	Exponential Growth Charles Darwin, in his theory of natural selection, was greatly influenced by the English clergyman Thomas Malthus.
7.45.162	Malthus published a book in 1798 stating that populations with unlimited natural resources grow very rapidly, and then population growth decreases as resources become depleted.
7.45.163	This accelerating pattern of increasing population size is called exponential growth.
7.45.164	The best example of exponential growth is seen in bacteria.
7.45.165	Bacteria are prokaryotes that reproduce by prokaryotic fission.
7.45.166	This division takes about an hour for many bacterial species.
7.45.167	If 1000 bacteria are placed in a large flask with an unlimited supply of nutrients (so the nutrients will not become depleted), after an hour, there is one round of division and each organism divides, resulting in 2000 organisms—an increase of 1000.
7.45.168	In another hour, each of the 2000 organisms will double, producing 4000, an increase of 2000 organisms.
7.45.169	After the third hour, there should be 8000 bacteria in the flask, an increase of 4000 organisms.
7.45.170	The important concept of exponential growth is that the population growth rate—the number of organisms added in each reproductive generation—is accelerating; that is, it is increasing at a greater and greater rate.
7.45.171	After 1 day and 24 of these cycles, the population would have increased from 1000 to more than 16 billion.
7.45.172	When the population size, N, is plotted over time, a J-shaped growth curve is produced (Figure 45.9).
7.45.173	The bacteria example is not representative of the real world where resources are limited.
7.45.174	Furthermore, some bacteria will die during the experiment and thus not reproduce, lowering the growth rate.
7.45.175	Therefore, when calculating the growth rate of a population, the death rate (D) (number organisms that die during a particular time interval) is subtracted from the birth rate (B) (number organisms that are born during that interval).
7.45.176	This is shown in the following formula: The birth rate is usually expressed on a per capita (for each individual) basis.
7.45.177	Thus, B (birth rate) = bN (the per capita birth rate “b” multiplied by the number of individuals “N”) and D (death rate) =
7.45.178	dN (the per capita death rate “
7.45.179	d” multiplied by the number of individuals “N”).
7.45.180	Additionally, ecologists are interested in the population at a particular point in time, an infinitely small time interval.
7.45.181	For this reason, the terminology of differential calculus is used to obtain the “instantaneous” growth rate, replacing the change in number and time with an instant-specific measurement of number and time.
7.45.182	Notice that the “d” associated with the first term refers to the derivative (as the term is used in calculus) and is different from the death rate, also called
7.45.183	“
7.45.184	d.
7.45.185	”
7.45.186	The difference between birth and death rates is further simplified by substituting the term “r
7.45.187	” (intrinsic rate of increase) for the relationship between birth and death rates: The value “r” can be positive, meaning the population is increasing in size; or negative, meaning the population is decreasing in size; or zero, where the population’s size is unchanging, a condition known as zero population growth.
7.45.188	A further refinement of the formula recognizes that different species have inherent differences in their intrinsic rate of increase (often thought of as the potential for reproduction), even under ideal conditions.
7.45.189	Obviously, a bacterium can reproduce more rapidly and have a higher intrinsic rate of growth than a human.
7.45.190	The maximal growth rate for a species is its biotic potential, or rmax, thus changing the equation to: When resources are unlimited, populations exhibit exponential growth, resulting in a J-shaped curve.
7.45.191	When resources are limited, populations exhibit logistic growth.
7.45.192	In logistic growth, population expansion decreases as resources become scarce, and it levels off when the carrying capacity of the environment is reached, resulting in an S-shaped curve.
7.45.193	Logistic Growth Exponential growth is possible only when infinite natural resources are available; this is not the case in the real world.
7.45.194	Charles Darwin recognized this fact in his description of the “struggle for existence,” which states that individuals will compete (with members of their own or other species) for limited resources.
7.45.195	The successful ones will survive to pass on their own characteristics and traits (which we know now are transferred by genes) to the next generation at a greater rate (natural selection).
7.45.196	To model the reality of limited resources, population ecologists developed the logistic growth model.
7.45.197	Carrying Capacity and the Logistic Model
7.45.198	In the real world, with its limited resources, exponential growth cannot continue indefinitely.
7.45.199	Exponential growth may occur in environments where there are few individuals and plentiful resources, but when the number of individuals gets large enough, resources will be depleted, slowing the growth rate.
7.45.200	Eventually, the growth rate will plateau or level off (Figure 45.9).
7.45.201	This population size, which represents the maximum population size that a particular environment can support, is called the carrying capacity, or K.
7.45.202	The formula we use to calculate logistic growth adds the carrying capacity as a moderating force in the growth rate.
7.45.203	The expression “K – N” is indicative of how many individuals may be added to a population at a given stage, and “K – N” divided by “K” is the fraction of the carrying capacity available for further growth.
7.45.204	Thus, the exponential growth model is restricted by this factor to generate the logistic growth equation:
7.45.205	Notice that when N is very small, (K-N)/K becomes close to K/K or 1, and the right side of the equation reduces to rmaxN, which means the population is growing exponentially and is not influenced by carrying capacity.
7.45.206	On the other hand, when N is large, (K-N)/K come close to zero, which means that population growth will be slowed greatly or even stopped.
7.45.207	Thus, population growth is greatly slowed in large populations by the carrying capacity K. This model also allows for the population of a negative population growth, or a population decline.
7.45.208	This occurs when the number of individuals in the population exceeds the carrying capacity (because the value of (K-N)/K is negative).
7.45.209	A graph of this equation yields an S-shaped curve (Figure 45.9), and it is a more realistic model of population growth than exponential growth.
7.45.210	There are three different sections to an S-shaped curve.
7.45.211	Initially, growth is exponential because there are few individuals and ample resources available.
7.45.212	Then, as resources begin to become limited, the growth rate decreases.
7.45.213	Finally, growth levels off at the carrying capacity of the environment, with little change in population size over time.
7.45.214	Role of Intraspecific Competition
7.45.215	The logistic model assumes that every individual within a population will have equal access to resources and, thus, an equal chance for survival.
7.45.216	For plants, the amount of water, sunlight, nutrients, and the space to grow are the important resources, whereas in animals, important resources include food, water, shelter, nesting space, and mates.
7.45.217	In the real world, phenotypic variation among individuals within a population means that some individuals will be better adapted to their environment than others.
7.45.218	The resulting competition between population members of the same species for resources is termed intraspecific competition (intra-
7.45.219	= “within”; -specific =
7.45.220	“species”).
7.45.221	Intraspecific competition for resources may not affect populations that are well below their carrying capacity—resources are plentiful and all individuals can obtain what they need.
7.45.222	However, as population size increases, this competition intensifies.
7.45.223	In addition, the accumulation of waste products can reduce an environment’s carrying capacity.
7.45.224	Examples of Logistic Growth Yeast, a microscopic fungus used to make bread and alcoholic beverages, exhibits the classical S-shaped curve when grown in a test tube (Figure 45.10a).
7.45.225	Its growth levels off as the population depletes the nutrients that are necessary for its growth.
7.45.226	In the real world, however, there are variations to this idealized curve.
7.45.227	Examples in wild populations include sheep and harbor seals (Figure 45.10b).
7.45.228	In both examples, the population size exceeds the carrying capacity for short periods of time and then falls below the carrying capacity afterwards.
7.45.229	This fluctuation in population size continues to occur as the population oscillates around its carrying capacity.
7.45.230	Still, even with this oscillation, the logistic model is confirmed.
7.45.231	Population Dynamics and Regulation
7.45.232	By the end of this section, you will be able to: Give examples of how the carrying capacity of a habitat may change Compare and contrast density-dependent growth regulation and density-independent growth regulation, giving examples Give examples of exponential and logistic growth in wild animal populations Describe how natural selection and environmental adaptation leads to the evolution of particular life-history patterns
7.45.233	The logistic model of population growth, while valid in many natural populations and a useful model, is a simplification of real-world population dynamics.
7.45.234	Implicit in the model is that the carrying capacity of the environment does not change, which is not the case.
7.45.235	The carrying capacity varies annually: for example, some summers are hot and dry whereas others are cold and wet.
7.45.236	In many areas, the carrying capacity during the winter is much lower than it is during the summer.
7.45.237	Also, natural events such as earthquakes, volcanoes, and fires can alter an environment and hence its carrying capacity.
7.45.238	Additionally, populations do not usually exist in isolation.
7.45.239	They engage in interspecific competition: that is, they share the environment with other species, competing with them for the same resources.
7.45.240	These factors are also important to understanding how a specific population will grow.
7.45.241	Nature regulates population growth in a variety of ways.
7.45.242	These are grouped into density-dependent factors, in which the density of the population at a given time affects growth rate and mortality, and density-independent factors, which influence mortality in a population regardless of population density.
7.45.243	Note that in the former, the effect of the factor on the population depends on the density of the population at onset.
7.45.244	Conservation biologists want to understand both types because this helps them manage populations and prevent extinction or overpopulation.
7.45.245	Density-dependent Regulation Most density-dependent factors are biological in nature (biotic), and include predation, inter- and intraspecific competition, accumulation of waste, and diseases such as those caused by parasites.
7.45.246	Usually, the denser a population is, the greater its mortality rate.
7.45.247	For example, during intra- and interspecific competition, the reproductive rates of the individuals will usually be lower, reducing their population’s rate of growth.
7.45.248	In addition, low prey density increases the mortality of its predator because it has more difficulty locating its food source.
7.45.249	An example of density-dependent regulation is shown in Figure 45.11 with results from a study focusing on the giant intestinal roundworm (Ascaris lumbricoides), a parasite of humans and other mammals.
7.45.250	[4] Denser populations of the parasite exhibited lower fecundity: they contained fewer eggs.
7.45.251	One possible explanation for this is that females would be smaller in more dense populations (due to limited resources) and that smaller females would have fewer eggs.
7.45.252	This hypothesis was tested and disproved in a 2009 study which showed that female weight had no influence.
7.45.253	[5] The actual cause of the densitydependence of fecundity in this organism is still unclear and awaiting further investigation.
7.45.254	In this population of roundworms, fecundity (number of eggs) decreases with population density.
7.45.255	[6] Density-independent Regulation and Interaction with Densitydependent Factors
7.45.256	Many factors, typically physical or chemical in nature (abiotic), influence the mortality of a population regardless of its density, including weather, natural disasters, and pollution.
7.45.257	An individual deer may be killed in a forest fire regardless of how many deer happen to be in that area.
7.45.258	Its chances of survival are the same whether the population density is high or low.
7.45.259	The same holds true for cold winter weather.
7.45.260	In real-life situations, population regulation is very complicated and density-dependent and independent factors can interact.
7.45.261	A dense population that is reduced in a density-independent manner by some environmental factor(s) will be able to recover differently than a sparse population.
7.45.262	For example, a population of deer affected by a harsh winter will recover faster if there are more deer remaining to reproduce.
7.45.263	Life Histories of K-selected and r-selected Species
7.45.264	While reproductive strategies play a key role in life histories, they do not account for important factors like limited resources and competition.
7.45.265	The regulation of population growth by these factors can be used to introduce a classical concept in population biology, that of K-selected versus r-selected species.
7.45.266	Early Theories about Life
7.45.267	History:
7.45.268	K-selected and r-selected Species
7.45.269	By the second half of the twentieth century, the concept of K- and r-selected species was used extensively and successfully to study populations.
7.45.270	The concept relates not only reproductive strategies, but also to a species’ habitat and behavior, especially in the way that they obtain resources and care for their young.
7.45.271	It includes length of life and survivorship factors as well.
7.45.272	For this analysis, population biologists have grouped species into the two large categories—K-selected and rselected— although they are really two ends of a continuum.
7.45.273	K-selected species are species selected by stable, predictable environments.
7.45.274	Populations of K-selected species tend to exist close to their carrying capacity (hence the term K-selected) where intraspecific competition is high.
7.45.275	These species have few, large offspring, a long gestation period, and often give long-term care to their offspring (Table B45_04_01).
7.45.276	While larger in size when born, the offspring are relatively helpless and immature at birth.
7.45.277	By the time they reach adulthood, they must develop skills to compete for natural resources.
7.45.278	In plants, scientists think of parental care more broadly: how long fruit takes to develop or how long it remains on the plant are determining factors in the time to the next reproductive event.
7.45.279	Examples of K-selected species are primates including humans), elephants, and plants such as oak trees (Figure 45.13a).
7.45.280	Oak trees grow very slowly and take, on average, 20 years to produce their first seeds, known as acorns.
7.45.281	As many as 50,000 acorns can be produced by an individual tree, but the germination rate is low as many of these rot or are eaten by animals such as squirrels.
7.45.282	In some years, oaks may produce an exceptionally large number of acorns, and these years may be on a two- or three-year cycle depending on the species of oak (r-selection).
7.45.283	As oak trees grow to a large size and for many years before they begin to produce acorns, they devote a large percentage of their energy budget to growth and maintenance.
7.45.284	The tree’s height and size allow it to dominate other plants in the competition for sunlight, the oak’s primary energy resource.
7.45.285	Furthermore, when it does reproduce, the oak produces large, energy-rich seeds that use their energy reserve to become quickly established (K-selection).
7.45.286	In contrast, r-selected species have a large number of small offspring (hence their r designation (Table 45.2).
7.45.287	This strategy is often employed in unpredictable or changing environments.
7.45.288	Animals that are r-selected do not give long-term parental care and the offspring are relatively mature and self-sufficient at birth.
7.45.289	Examples of r-selected species are marine invertebrates, such as jellyfish, and plants, such as the dandelion (Figure 45.13b).
7.45.290	Dandelions have small seeds that are wind dispersed long distances.
7.45.291	Many seeds are produced simultaneously to ensure that at least some of them reach a hospitable environment.
7.45.292	Seeds that land in inhospitable environments have little chance for survival since their seeds are low in energy content.
7.45.293	Note that survival is not necessarily a function of energy stored in the seed itself.
7.45.294	(a) Elephants are considered K-selected species as they live long, mature late, and provide long-term parental care to few offspring.
7.45.295	Oak trees produce many offspring that do not receive parental care, but are considered K-selected species based on longevity and late maturation.
7.45.296	(b) Dandelions and jellyfish are both considered r-selected species as they mature early, have short lifespans, and produce many offspring that receive no parental care.
7.45.297	Modern Theories of Life
7.45.298	History
7.45.299	The r- and K-selection theory, although accepted for decades and used for much groundbreaking research, has now been reconsidered, and many population biologists have abandoned or modified it.
7.45.300	Over the years, several studies attempted to confirm the theory, but these attempts have largely failed.
7.45.301	Many species were identified that did not follow the theory’s predictions.
7.45.302	Furthermore, the theory ignored the age-specific mortality of the populations which scientists now know is very important.
7.45.303	New demographic-based models of life history evolution have been developed which incorporate many ecological concepts included in r- and K-selection theory as well as population age structure and mortality factors.
7.45.304	Human Population Growth
7.45.305	By the end of this section, you will be able to: Discuss how human population growth can be exponential Explain how humans have expanded the carrying capacity of their habitat Relate population growth and age structure to the level of economic development in different countries Discuss the long-term implications of unchecked human population growth Concepts of animal population dynamics can be applied to human population growth.
7.45.306	Humans are not unique in their ability to alter their environment.
7.45.307	For example, beaver dams alter the stream environment where they are built.
7.45.308	Humans, however, have the ability to alter their environment to increase its carrying capacity sometimes to the detriment of other species (e.g., via artificial selection for crops that have a higher yield).
7.45.309	Earth’s human population is growing rapidly, to the extent that some worry about the ability of the earth’s environment to sustain this population, as long-term exponential growth carries the potential risks of famine, disease, and large-scale death.
7.45.310	Although humans have increased the carrying capacity of their environment, the technologies used to achieve this transformation have caused unprecedented changes to Earth’s environment, altering ecosystems to the point where some may be in danger of collapse.
7.45.311	The depletion of the ozone layer, erosion due to acid rain, and damage from global climate change are caused by human activities.
7.45.312	The ultimate effect of these changes on our carrying capacity is unknown.
7.45.313	As some point out, it is likely that the negative effects of increasing carrying capacity will outweigh the positive ones—the carrying capacity of the world for human beings might actually decrease.
7.45.314	The world’s human population is currently experiencing exponential growth even though human reproduction is far below its biotic potential (Figure 45.14).
7.45.315	To reach its biotic potential, all females would have to become pregnant every nine months or so during their reproductive years.
7.45.316	Also, resources would have to be such that the environment would support such growth.
7.45.317	Neither of these two conditions exists.
7.45.318	In spite of this fact, human population is still growing exponentially.
7.45.319	Human population growth since 1000 AD is exponential (dark blue line).
7.45.320	Notice that while the population in Asia (yellow line), which has many economically underdeveloped countries, is increasing exponentially, the population in Europe (light blue line), where most of the countries are economically developed, is growing much more slowly.
7.45.321	A consequence of exponential human population growth is the time that it takes to add a particular number of humans to the Earth is becoming shorter.
7.45.322	Figure 45.15 shows that 123 years were necessary to add 1 billion humans in 1930, but it only took 24 years to add two billion people between 1975 and 1999.
7.45.323	As already discussed, at some point it would appear that our ability to increase our carrying capacity indefinitely on a finite world is uncertain.
7.45.324	Without new technological advances, the human growth rate has been predicted to slow in the coming decades.
7.45.325	However, the population will still be increasing and the threat of overpopulation remains.
7.45.326	The time between the addition of each billion human beings to Earth decreases over time.
7.45.327	Overcoming Density-Dependent Regulation Humans are unique in their ability to alter their environment with the conscious purpose of increasing its carrying capacity.
7.45.328	This ability is a major factor responsible for human population growth and a way of overcoming density-dependent growth regulation.
7.45.329	Much of this ability is related to human intelligence, society, and communication.
7.45.330	Humans can construct shelter to protect them from the elements and have developed agriculture and domesticated animals to increase their food supplies.
7.45.331	In addition, humans use language to communicate this technology to new generations, allowing them to improve upon previous accomplishments.
7.45.332	Other factors in human population growth are migration and public health.
7.45.333	Humans originated in Africa, but have since migrated to nearly all inhabitable land on the Earth.
7.45.334	Public health, sanitation, and the use of antibiotics and vaccines have decreased the ability of infectious disease to limit human population growth.
7.45.335	In the past, diseases such as the bubonic plaque of the fourteenth century killed between 30 and 60 percent of Europe’s population and reduced the overall world population by as many as 100 million people.
7.45.336	Today, the threat of infectious disease, while not gone, is certainly less severe.
7.45.337	According to the World Health Organization, global death from infectious disease declined from 16.4 million in 1993 to 14.7 million in 1992.
7.45.338	To compare to some of the epidemics of the past, the percentage of the world's population killed between 1993 and 2002 decreased from 0.30 percent of the world's population to 0.24 percent.
7.45.339	Thus, it appears that the influence of infectious disease on human population growth is becoming less significant.
7.45.340	Age Structure, Population Growth, and Economic Development
7.45.341	The age structure of a population is an important factor in population dynamics.
7.45.342	Age structure is the proportion of a population at different age ranges.
7.45.343	Age structure allows better prediction of population growth, plus the ability to associate this growth with the level of economic development in the region.
7.45.344	Countries with rapid growth have a pyramidal shape in their age structure diagrams, showing a preponderance of younger individuals, many of whom are of reproductive age or will be soon (Figure 45.16).
7.45.345	This pattern is most often observed in underdeveloped countries where individuals do not live to old age because of less-than-optimal living conditions.
7.45.346	Age structures of areas with slow growth, including developed countries such as the United States, still have a pyramidal structure, but with many fewer young and reproductive-aged individuals and a greater proportion of older individuals.
7.45.347	Other developed countries, such as Italy, have zero population growth.
7.45.348	The age structure of these populations is more conical, with an even greater percentage of middle-aged and older individuals.
7.45.349	The actual growth rates in different countries are shown in Figure 45.17, with the highest rates tending to be in the less economically developed countries of Africa and Asia.
7.45.350	The percent growth rate of population in different countries is shown.
7.45.351	Notice that the highest growth is occurring in less economically developed countries in Africa and Asia.
7.45.352	Long-Term Consequences of Exponential Human Population
7.45.353	Growth
7.45.354	Many dire predictions have been made about the world’s population leading to a major crisis called the “population explosion.
7.45.355	”
7.45.356	In the 1968 book The Population Bomb, biologist Dr. Paul R. Ehrlich wrote, “
7.45.357	The battle to feed all of humanity is over.
7.45.358	In the 1970s hundreds of millions of people will starve to death in spite of any crash programs embarked upon now.
7.45.359	At this late date nothing can prevent a substantial increase in the world death rate.
7.45.360	”
7.45.361	[9] While many critics view this statement as an exaggeration, the laws of exponential population growth are still in effect, and unchecked human population growth cannot continue indefinitely.
7.45.362	Efforts to control population growth led to the one-child policy in China, which used to include more severe consequences, but now imposes fines on urban couples who have more than one child.
