7.45.363	Due to the fact that some couples wish to have a male heir, many Chinese couples continue to have more than one child.
7.45.364	The policy itself, its social impacts, and the effectiveness of limiting overall population growth are controversial.
7.45.365	In spite of population control policies, the human population continues to grow.
7.45.366	At some point the food supply may run out because of the subsequent need to produce more and more food to feed our population.
7.45.367	The United Nations estimates that future world population growth may vary from 6 billion (a decrease) to 16 billion people by the year 2100.
7.45.368	There is no way to know whether human population growth will moderate to the point where the crisis described by Dr. Ehrlich will be averted.
7.45.369	Another result of population growth is the endangerment of the natural environment.
7.45.370	Many countries have attempted to reduce the human impact on climate change by reducing their emission of the greenhouse gas carbon dioxide.
7.45.371	However, these treaties have not been ratified by every country, and many underdeveloped countries trying to improve their economic condition may be less likely to agree with such provisions if it means slower economic development.
7.45.372	Furthermore, the role of human activity in causing climate change has become a hotly debated socio-political issue in some developed countries, including the United States.
7.45.373	Thus, we enter the future with considerable uncertainty about our ability to curb human population growth and protect our environment.
7.45.374	Community Ecology
7.45.375	By the end of this section, you will be able to: Discuss the predator-prey cycle Give examples of defenses against predation and herbivory Describe the competitive exclusion principle Give examples of symbiotic relationships between species Describe community structure and succession Populations rarely, if ever, live in isolation from populations of other species.
7.45.376	In most cases, numerous species share a habitat.
7.45.377	The interactions between these populations play a major role in regulating population growth and abundance.
7.45.378	All populations occupying the same habitat form a community: populations inhabiting a specific area at the same time.
7.45.379	The number of species occupying the same habitat and their relative abundance is known as species diversity.
7.45.380	Areas with low diversity, such as the glaciers of Antarctica, still contain a wide variety of living things, whereas the diversity of tropical rainforests is so great that it cannot be counted.
7.45.381	Ecology is studied at the community level to understand how species interact with each other and compete for the same resources.
7.45.382	Predation and Herbivory Perhaps the classical example of species interaction is predation: the hunting of prey by its predator.
7.45.383	Nature shows on television highlight the drama of one living organism killing another.
7.45.384	Populations of predators and prey in a community are not constant over time: in most cases, they vary in cycles that appear to be related.
7.45.385	The most often cited example of predator-prey dynamics is seen in the cycling of the lynx (predator) and the snowshoe hare (prey), using nearly 200 year-old trapping data from North American forests (Figure 45.18).
7.45.386	This cycle of predator and prey lasts approximately 10 years, with the predator population lagging 1–2 years behind that of the prey population.
7.45.387	As the hare numbers increase, there is more food available for the lynx, allowing the lynx population to increase as well.
7.45.388	When the lynx population grows to a threshold level, however, they kill so many hares that hare population begins to decline, followed by a decline in the lynx population because of scarcity of food.
7.45.389	When the lynx population is low, the hare population size begins to increase due, at least in part, to low predation pressure, starting the cycle anew.
7.45.390	The cycling of lynx and snowshoe hare populations in Northern Ontario is an example of predator-prey dynamics.
7.45.391	The idea that the population cycling of the two species is entirely controlled by predation models has come under question.
7.45.392	More recent studies have pointed to undefined density-dependent factors as being important in the cycling, in addition to predation.
7.45.393	One possibility is that the cycling is inherent in the hare population due to density-dependent effects such as lower fecundity (maternal stress) caused by crowding when the hare population gets too dense.
7.45.394	The hare cycling would then induce the cycling of the lynx because it is the lynxes’ major food source.
7.45.395	The more we study communities, the more complexities we find, allowing ecologists to derive more accurate and sophisticated models of population dynamics.
7.45.396	Herbivory describes the consumption of plants by insects and other animals, and it is another interspecific relationship that affects populations.
7.45.397	Unlike animals, most plants cannot outrun predators or use mimicry to hide from hungry animals.
7.45.398	Some plants have developed mechanisms to defend against herbivory.
7.45.399	Other species have developed mutualistic relationships; for example, herbivory provides a mechanism of seed distribution that aids in plant reproduction.
7.45.400	Defense Mechanisms against Predation and Herbivory
7.45.401	The study of communities must consider evolutionary forces that act on the members of the various populations contained within it.
7.45.402	Species are not static, but slowly changing and adapting to their environment by natural selection and other evolutionary forces.
7.45.403	Species have evolved numerous mechanisms to escape predation and herbivory.
7.45.404	These defenses may be mechanical, chemical, physical, or behavioral.
7.45.405	Mechanical defenses, such as the presence of thorns on plants or the hard shell on turtles, discourage animal predation and herbivory by causing physical pain to the predator or by physically preventing the predator from being able to eat the prey.
7.45.406	Chemical defenses are produced by many animals as well as plants, such as the foxglove which is extremely toxic when eaten.
7.45.407	Figure 45.19 shows some organisms’ defenses against predation and herbivory.
7.45.408	The (a) honey locust tree (Gleditsia triacanthos) uses thorns, a mechanical defense, against herbivores, while the (b) Florida red-bellied turtle (Pseudemys nelsoni) uses its shell as a mechanical defense against predators.
7.45.409	(c) Foxglove (Digitalis sp.) uses a chemical defense:
7.45.410	toxins produced by the plant can cause nausea, vomiting, hallucinations, convulsions, or death when consumed.
7.45.411	(d)
7.45.412	The North American millipede (Narceus americanus) uses both mechanical and chemical defenses: when threatened, the millipede curls into a defensive ball and produces a noxious substance that irritates eyes and skin.
7.45.413	Many species use their body shape and coloration to avoid being detected by predators.
7.45.414	The tropical walking stick is an insect with the coloration and body shape of a twig which makes it very hard to see when stationary against a background of real twigs (Figure 45.20a).
7.45.415	In another example, the chameleon can change its color to match its surroundings (Figure 45.20b).
7.45.416	Both of these are examples of camouflage, or avoiding detection by blending in with the background.
7.45.417	(a)
7.45.418	The tropical walking stick and (b) the chameleon use body shape and/or coloration to prevent detection by predators.
7.45.419	Some species use coloration as a way of warning predators that they are not good to eat.
7.45.420	For example, the cinnabar moth caterpillar, the fire-bellied toad, and many species of beetle have bright colors that warn of a foul taste, the presence of toxic chemical, and/or the ability to sting or bite, respectively.
7.45.421	Predators that ignore this coloration and eat the organisms will experience their unpleasant taste or presence of toxic chemicals and learn not to eat them in the future.
7.45.422	This type of defensive mechanism is called aposematic coloration, or warning coloration.
7.45.423	(a)
7.45.424	The strawberry poison dart frog (Oophaga pumilio) uses aposematic coloration to warn predators that it is toxic, while the (b) striped skunk (Mephitis mephitis) uses aposematic coloration to warn predators of the unpleasant odor it produces.
7.45.425	While some predators learn to avoid eating certain potential prey because of their coloration, other species have evolved mechanisms to mimic this coloration to avoid being eaten, even though they themselves may not be unpleasant to eat or contain toxic chemicals.
7.45.426	In Batesian mimicry, a harmless species imitates the warning coloration of a harmful one.
7.45.427	Assuming they share the same predators, this coloration then protects the harmless ones, even though they do not have the same level of physical or chemical defenses against predation as the organism they mimic.
7.45.428	Many insect species mimic the coloration of wasps or bees, which are stinging, venomous insects, thereby discouraging predation.
7.45.429	Batesian mimicry occurs when a harmless species mimics the coloration of a harmful species, as is seen with the (a) bumblebee and (b) bee-like robber fly.
7.45.430	In Müllerian mimicry, multiple species share the same warning coloration, but all of them actually have defenses.
7.45.431	Figure 45.23 shows a variety of foul-tasting butterflies with similar coloration.
7.45.432	In Emsleyan/Mertensian mimicry, a deadly prey mimics a less dangerous one, such as the venomous coral snake mimicking the non-venomous milk snake.
7.45.433	This type of mimicry is extremely rare and more difficult to understand than the previous two types.
7.45.434	For this type of mimicry to work, it is essential that eating the milk snake has unpleasant but not fatal consequences.
7.45.435	Then, these predators learn not to eat snakes with this coloration, protecting the coral snake as well.
7.45.436	If the snake were fatal to the predator, there would be no opportunity for the predator to learn not to eat it, and the benefit for the less toxic species would disappear.
7.45.437	Several unpleasant-tasting Heliconius butterfly species share a similar color pattern with better-tasting varieties, an example of Müllerian mimicry.
7.45.438	Competitive Exclusion Principle Resources are often limited within a habitat and multiple species may compete to obtain them.
7.45.439	All species have an ecological niche in the ecosystem, which describes how they acquire the resources they need and how they interact with other species in the community.
7.45.440	The competitive exclusion principle states that two species cannot occupy the same niche in a habitat.
7.45.441	In other words, different species cannot coexist in a community if they are competing for all the same resources.
7.45.442	An example of this principle is shown in Figure 45.24, with two protozoan species, Paramecium aurelia and Paramecium caudatum.
7.45.443	When grown individually in the laboratory, they both thrive.
7.45.444	But when they are placed together in the same test tube (habitat), P. aurelia outcompetes P. caudatum for food, leading to the latter’s eventual extinction.
7.45.445	Paramecium aurelia and Paramecium caudatum grow well individually, but when they compete for the same resources, the P. aurelia outcompetes the P. caudatum.
7.45.446	This exclusion may be avoided if a population evolves to make use of a different resource, a different area of the habitat, or feeds during a different time of day, called resource partitioning.
7.45.447	The two organisms are then said to occupy different microniches.
7.45.448	These organisms coexist by minimizing direct competition.
7.45.449	Symbiosis Symbiotic relationships, or symbioses (plural), are close interactions between individuals of different species over an extended period of time which impact the abundance and distribution of the associating populations.
7.45.450	Most scientists accept this definition, but some restrict the term to only those species that are mutualistic, where both individuals benefit from the interaction.
7.45.451	In this discussion, the broader definition will be used.
7.45.452	Commensalism A commensal relationship occurs when one species benefits from the close, prolonged interaction, while the other neither benefits nor is harmed.
7.45.453	Birds nesting in trees provide an example of a commensal relationship (Figure 45.25).
7.45.454	The tree is not harmed by the presence of the nest among its branches.
7.45.455	The nests are light and produce little strain on the structural integrity of the branch, and most of the leaves, which the tree uses to get energy by photosynthesis, are above the nest so they are unaffected.
7.45.456	The bird, on the other hand, benefits greatly.
7.45.457	If the bird had to nest in the open, its eggs and young would be vulnerable to predators.
7.45.458	Another example of a commensal relationship is the clown fish and the sea anemone.
7.45.459	The sea anemone is not harmed by the fish, and the fish benefits with protection from predators who would be stung upon nearing the sea anemone.
7.45.460	The southern masked-weaver bird is starting to make a nest in a tree in Zambezi Valley, Zambia.
7.45.461	This is an example of a commensal relationship, in which one species (the bird) benefits, while the other (the tree) neither benefits nor is harmed.
7.45.462	Mutualism
7.45.463	A second type of symbiotic relationship is called mutualism, where two species benefit from their interaction.
7.45.464	Some scientists believe that these are the only true examples of symbiosis.
7.45.465	For example, termites have a mutualistic relationship with protozoa that live in the insect’s gut
7.45.466	(Figure 45.26a).
7.45.467	The termite benefits from the ability of bacterial symbionts within the protozoa to digest cellulose.
7.45.468	The termite itself cannot do this, and without the protozoa, it would not be able to obtain energy from its food (cellulose from the wood it chews and eats).
7.45.469	The protozoa and the bacterial symbionts benefit by having a protective environment and a constant supply of food from the wood chewing actions of the termite.
7.45.470	Lichens have a mutualistic relationship between fungus and photosynthetic algae or bacteria (Figure 45.26b).
7.45.471	As these symbionts grow together, the glucose produced by the algae provides nourishment for both organisms, whereas the physical structure of the lichen protects the algae from the elements and makes certain nutrients in the atmosphere more available to the algae.
7.45.472	(a) Termites form a mutualistic relationship with symbiotic protozoa in their guts, which allow both organisms to obtain energy from the cellulose the termite consumes.
7.45.473	(b)
7.45.474	Lichen is a fungus that has symbiotic photosynthetic algae living inside its cells.
7.45.475	Parasitism
7.45.476	A parasite is an organism that lives in or on another living organism and derives nutrients from it.
7.45.477	In this relationship, the parasite benefits, but the organism being fed upon, the host is harmed.
7.45.478	The host is usually weakened by the parasite as it siphons resources the host would normally use to maintain itself.
7.45.479	The parasite, however, is unlikely to kill the host, especially not quickly, because this would allow no time for the organism to complete its reproductive cycle by spreading to another host.
7.45.480	The reproductive cycles of parasites are often very complex, sometimes requiring more than one host species.
7.45.481	A tapeworm is a parasite that causes disease in humans when contaminated, undercooked meat such as pork, fish, or beef is consumed (Figure 45.27).
7.45.482	The tapeworm can live inside the intestine of the host for several years, benefiting from the food the host is bringing into its gut by eating, and may grow to be over 50 ft long by adding segments.
7.45.483	The parasite moves from species to species in a cycle, making two hosts necessary to complete its life cycle.
7.45.484	Another common parasite is Plasmodium falciparum, the protozoan cause of malaria, a significant disease in many parts of the world.
7.45.485	Living in human liver and red blood cells, the organism reproduces asexually in the gut of blood-feeding mosquitoes to complete its life cycle.
7.45.486	Thus malaria is spread from human to human by mosquitoes, one of many arthropod-borne infectious diseases.
7.45.487	This diagram shows the life cycle of a pork tapeworm (Taenia solium), a human worm parasite.
7.45.488	Characteristics of Communities Communities are complex entities that can be characterized by their structure (the types and numbers of species present) and dynamics (how communities change over time).
7.45.489	Understanding community structure and dynamics enables community ecologists to manage ecosystems more effectively.
7.45.490	Foundation Species Foundation species are considered the “base” or “bedrock” of a community, having the greatest influence on its overall structure.
7.45.491	They are usually the primary producers: organisms that bring most of the energy into the community.
7.45.492	Kelp, brown algae, is a foundation species, forming the basis of the kelp forests off the coast of California.
7.45.493	Foundation species may physically modify the environment to produce and maintain habitats that benefit the other organisms that use them.
7.45.494	An example is the photosynthetic corals of the coral reef (Figure 45.28).
7.45.495	Corals themselves are not photosynthetic, but harbor symbionts within their body tissues (dinoflagellates called zooxanthellae) that perform photosynthesis; this is another example of a mutualism.
7.45.496	The exoskeletons of living and dead coral make up most of the reef structure, which protects many other species from waves and ocean currents.
7.45.497	Coral is the foundation species of coral reef ecosystems.
7.45.498	Biodiversity, Species Richness, and Relative Species Abundance Biodiversity describes a community’s biological complexity: it is measured by the number of different species (species richness) in a particular area and their relative abundance (species evenness).
7.45.499	The area in question could be a habitat, a biome, or the entire biosphere.
7.45.500	Species richness is the term that is used to describe the number of species living in a habitat or biome.
7.45.501	Species richness varies across the globe (Figure 45.29).
7.45.502	One factor in determining species richness is latitude, with the greatest species richness occurring in ecosystems near the equator, which often have warmer temperatures, large amounts of rainfall, and low seasonality.
7.45.503	The lowest species richness occurs near the poles, which are much colder, drier, and thus less conducive to life in Geologic time (time since glaciations).
7.45.504	The predictability of climate or productivity is also an important factor.
7.45.505	Other factors influence species richness as well.
7.45.506	For example, the study of island biogeography attempts to explain the relatively high species richness found in certain isolated island chains, including the Galápagos Islands that inspired the young Darwin.
7.45.507	Relative species abundance is the number of individuals in a species relative to the total number of individuals in all species within a habitat, ecosystem, or biome.
7.45.508	Foundation species often have the highest relative abundance of species.
7.45.509	The greatest species richness for mammals in North and South America is associated with the equatorial latitudes.
7.45.510	Keystone Species
7.45.511	A keystone species is one whose presence is key to maintaining biodiversity within an ecosystem and to upholding an ecological community’s structure.
7.45.512	The intertidal sea star, Pisaster ochraceus, of the northwestern United States is a keystone species (Figure 45.30).
7.45.513	Studies have shown that when this organism is removed from communities, populations of their natural prey (mussels) increase, completely altering the species composition and reducing biodiversity.
7.45.514	Another keystone species is the banded tetra, a fish in tropical streams, which supplies nearly all of the phosphorus, a necessary inorganic nutrient, to the rest of the community.
7.45.515	If these fish were to become extinct, the community would be greatly affected.
7.45.516	The Pisaster ochraceus sea star is a keystone species.
7.45.517	Community Dynamics Community dynamics are the changes in community structure and composition over time.
7.45.518	Sometimes these changes are induced by environmental disturbances such as volcanoes, earthquakes, storms, fires, and climate change.
7.45.519	Communities with a stable structure are said to be at equilibrium.
7.45.520	Following a disturbance, the community may or may not return to the equilibrium state.
7.45.521	Succession describes the sequential appearance and disappearance of species in a community over time.
7.45.522	In primary succession, newly exposed or newly formed land is colonized by living things; in secondary succession, part of an ecosystem is disturbed and remnants of the previous community remain.
7.45.523	Primary Succession and
7.45.524	Pioneer Species Primary succession occurs when new land is formed or rock is exposed: for example, following the eruption of volcanoes, such as those on the Big Island of Hawaii.
7.45.525	As lava flows into the ocean, new land is continually being formed.
7.45.526	On the Big Island, approximately 32 acres of land is added each year.
7.45.527	First, weathering and other natural forces break down the substrate enough for the establishment of certain hearty plants and lichens with few soil requirements, known as pioneer species (Figure 45.32).
7.45.528	These species help to further break down the mineral rich lava into soil where other, less hardy species will grow and eventually replace the pioneer species.
7.45.529	In addition, as these early species grow and die, they add to an ever-growing layer of decomposing organic material and contribute to soil formation.
7.45.530	Over time the area will reach an equilibrium state, with a set of organisms quite different from the pioneer species.
7.45.531	During primary succession in lava on Maui, Hawaii, succulent plants are the pioneer species.
7.45.532	Secondary succession
7.45.533	A classic example of secondary succession occurs in oak and hickory forests cleared by wildfire (Figure 45.33).
7.45.534	Wildfires will burn most vegetation and kill those animals unable to flee the area.
7.45.535	Their nutrients, however, are returned to the ground in the form of ash.
7.45.536	Thus, even when areas are devoid of life due to severe fires, the area will soon be ready for new life to take hold.
7.45.537	Before the fire, the vegetation was dominated by tall trees with access to the major plant energy resource: sunlight.
7.45.538	Their height gave them access to sunlight while also shading the ground and other low-lying species.
7.45.539	After the fire, though, these trees are no longer dominant.
7.45.540	Thus, the first plants to grow back are usually annual plants followed within a few years by quickly growing and spreading grasses and other pioneer species.
7.45.541	Due to, at least in part, changes in the environment brought on by the growth of the grasses and other species, over many years, shrubs will emerge along with small pine, oak, and hickory trees.
7.45.542	These organisms are called intermediate species.
7.45.543	Eventually, over 150 years, the forest will reach its equilibrium point where species composition is no longer changing and resembles the community before the fire.
7.45.544	This equilibrium state is referred to as the climax community, which will remain stable until the next disturbance.
7.45.545	Secondary succession is shown in an oak and hickory forest after a forest fire.
7.45.546	45.7 |
7.45.547	Behavioral Biology:
7.45.548	Proximate and Ultimate Causes of Behavior
7.45.549	By the end of this section, you will be able to: •
7.45.550	Compare innate and learned behavior
7.45.551	• Discuss how movement and migration behaviors are a result of natural selection
7.45.552	•
7.45.553	Discuss the different ways members of a population communicate with each other
7.45.554	• Give examples of how species use energy for mating displays and other courtship behaviors •
7.45.555	Differentiate between various mating systems •
7.45.556	Describe different ways that species learn Behavior is the change in activity of an organism in response to a stimulus.
7.45.557	Behavioral biology is the study of the biological and evolutionary bases for such changes.
7.45.558	The idea that behaviors evolved as a result of the pressures of natural selection is not new.
7.45.559	Animal behavior has been studied for decades, by biologists in the science of ethology, by psychologists in the science of comparative psychology, and by scientists of many disciplines in the study of neurobiology.
7.45.560	Although there is overlap between these disciplines, scientists in these behavioral fields take different approaches.
7.45.561	Comparative psychology is an extension of work done in human and behavioral psychology.
7.45.562	Ethology is an extension of genetics, evolution, anatomy, physiology, and other biological disciplines.
7.45.563	Still, one cannot study behavioral biology without touching on both comparative psychology and ethology.
7.45.564	One goal of behavioral biology is to dissect out the innate behaviors, which have a strong genetic component and are largely independent of environmental influences, from the learned behaviors, which result from environmental conditioning.
7.45.565	Innate behavior, or instinct, is important because there is no risk of an incorrect behavior being learned.
7.45.566	They are “hard wired” into the system.
7.45.567	On the other hand, learned behaviors, although riskier, are flexible, dynamic, and can be altered according to changes in the environment.
7.45.568	Innate Behaviors: Movement and Migration Innate or instinctual behaviors rely on response to stimuli.
7.45.569	The simplest example of this is a reflex action, an involuntary and rapid response to stimulus.
7.45.570	To test the “knee-jerk” reflex, a doctor taps the patellar tendon below the kneecap with a rubber hammer.
7.45.571	The stimulation of the nerves there leads to the reflex of extending the leg at the knee.
7.45.572	This is similar to the reaction of someone who touches a hot stove and instinctually pulls his or her hand away.
7.45.573	Even humans, with our great capacity to learn, still exhibit a variety of innate behaviors.
7.45.574	Kinesis and Taxis
7.45.575	Another activity or movement of innate behavior is kinesis, or the undirected movement in response to a stimulus.
7.45.576	Orthokinesis is the increased or decreased speed of movement of an organism in response to a stimulus.
7.45.577	Woodlice, for example, increase their speed of movement when exposed to high or low temperatures.
7.45.578	This movement, although random, increases the probability that the insect spends less time in the unfavorable environment.
7.45.579	Another example is klinokinesis, an increase in turning behaviors.
7.45.580	It is exhibited by bacteria such as E. coli which, in association with orthokinesis, helps the organisms randomly find a more hospitable environment.
7.45.581	A similar, but more directed version of kinesis is taxis: the directed movement towards or away from a stimulus.
7.45.582	This movement can be in response to light (phototaxis), chemical signals (chemotaxis), or gravity (geotaxis) and can be directed toward (positive) or away (negative) from the source of the stimulus.
7.45.583	An example of a positive chemotaxis is exhibited by the unicellular protozoan Tetrahymena thermophila.
7.45.584	This organism swims using its cilia, at times moving in a straight line, and at other times making turns.
7.45.585	The attracting chemotactic agent alters the frequency of turning as the organism moves directly toward the source, following the increasing concentration gradient.
7.45.586	Fixed Action Patterns A fixed action pattern is a series of movements elicited by a stimulus such that even when the stimulus is removed, the pattern goes on to completion.
7.45.587	An example of such a behavior occurs in the three-spined stickleback, a small freshwater fish (Figure 45.34).
7.45.588	Males of this species develop a red belly during breeding season and show instinctual aggressiveness to other males during this time.
7.45.589	In laboratory experiments, researchers exposed such fish to objects that in no way resemble a fish in their shape, but which were painted red on their lower halves.
7.45.590	The male sticklebacks responded aggressively to the objects just as if they were real male sticklebacks.
7.45.591	Male three-spined stickleback fish exhibit a fixed action pattern.
7.45.592	During mating season, the males, which develop a bright red belly, react strongly to red-bottomed objects that in no way resemble fish.
7.45.593	Migration Migration is the long-range seasonal movement of animals.
7.45.594	It is an evolved, adapted response to variation in resource availability, and it is a common phenomenon found in all major groups of animals.
7.45.595	Birds fly south for the winter to get to warmer climates with sufficient food, and salmon migrate to their spawning grounds.
7.45.596	The popular 2005 documentary March of the Penguins followed the 62-mile migration of emperor penguins through Antarctica to bring food back to their breeding site and to their young.
7.45.597	Wildebeests (Figure 45.35) migrate over 1800 miles each year in search of new grasslands.
7.45.598	Wildebeests migrate in a clockwise fashion over 1800 miles each year in search of rain-ripened grass.
7.45.599	Although migration is thought of as innate behavior, only some migrating species always migrate (obligate migration).
7.45.600	Animals that exhibit facultative migration can choose to migrate or not.
7.45.601	Additionally, in some animals, only a portion of the population migrates, whereas the rest does not migrate (incomplete migration).
7.45.602	For example, owls that live in the tundra may migrate in years when their food source, small rodents, is relatively scarce, but not migrate during the years when rodents are plentiful.
7.45.603	Foraging Foraging is the act of searching for and exploiting food resources.
7.45.604	Feeding behaviors that maximize energy gain and minimize energy expenditure are called optimal foraging behaviors, and these are favored by natural section.
7.45.605	The painted stork, for example, uses its long beak to search the bottom of a freshwater marshland for crabs and other food.
7.45.606	The painted stork uses its long beak to forage.
7.45.607	Innate Behaviors:
7.45.608	Living in Groups Not all animals live in groups, but even those that live relatively solitary lives, with the exception of those that can reproduce asexually, must mate.
7.45.609	Mating usually involves one animal signaling another so as to communicate the desire to mate.
7.45.610	There are several types of energy-intensive behaviors or displays associated with mating, called mating rituals.
7.45.611	Other behaviors found in populations that live in groups are described in terms of which animal benefits from the behavior.
7.45.612	In selfish behavior, only the animal in question benefits; in altruistic behavior, one animal’s actions benefit another animal; cooperative behavior describes when both animals benefit.
7.45.613	All of these behaviors involve some sort of communication between population members.
7.45.614	Communication within a Species Animals communicate with each other using stimuli known as signals.
7.45.615	An example of this is seen in the three-spined stickleback, where the visual signal of a red region in the lower half of a fish signals males to become aggressive and signals females to mate.
7.45.616	Other signals are chemical (pheromones), aural (sound), visual (courtship and aggressive displays), or tactile (touch).
7.45.617	These types of communication may be instinctual or learned or a combination of both.
7.45.618	These are not the same as the communication we associate with language, which has been observed only in humans and perhaps in some species of primates and cetaceans.
7.45.619	A pheromone is a secreted chemical signal used to obtain a response from another individual of the same species.
7.45.620	The purpose of pheromones is to elicit a specific behavior from the receiving individual.
7.45.621	Pheromones are especially common among social insects, but they are used by many species to attract the opposite sex, to sound alarms, to mark food trails, and to elicit other, more complex behaviors.
7.45.622	Even humans are thought to respond to certain pheromones called axillary steroids.
7.45.623	These chemicals influence human perception of other people, and in one study were responsible for a group of women synchronizing their menstrual cycles.
7.45.624	The role of pheromones in human-to-human communication is still somewhat controversial and continues to be researched.
7.45.625	Songs are an example of an aural signal, one that needs to be heard by the recipient.
7.45.626	Perhaps the best known of these are songs of birds, which identify the species and are used to attract mates.
7.45.627	Other well-known songs are those of whales, which are of such low frequency that they can travel long distances underwater.
7.45.628	Dolphins communicate with each other using a wide variety of vocalizations.
7.45.629	Male crickets make chirping sounds using a specialized organ to attract a mate, repel other males, and to announce a successful mating.
7.45.630	Courtship displays are a series of ritualized visual behaviors (signals) designed to attract and convince a member of the opposite sex to mate.
7.45.631	These displays are ubiquitous in the animal kingdom.
7.45.632	Often these displays involve a series of steps, including an initial display by one member followed by a response from the other.
7.45.633	If at any point, the display is performed incorrectly or a proper response is not given, the mating ritual is abandoned and the mating attempt will be unsuccessful.
7.45.634	The mating display of the common stork is shown in Figure 45.37.
7.45.635	Aggressive displays are also common in the animal kingdom.
7.45.636	An example is when a dog bares its teeth when it wants another dog to back down.
7.45.637	Presumably, these displays communicate not only the willingness of the animal to fight, but also its fighting ability.
7.45.638	Although these displays do signal aggression on the part of the sender, it is thought that these displays are actually a mechanism to reduce the amount of actual fighting that occurs between members of the same species: they allow individuals to assess the fighting ability of their opponent and thus decide whether it is “worth the fight.
7.45.639	”
7.45.640	The testing of certain hypotheses using game theory has led to the conclusion that some of these displays may overstate an animal’s actual fighting ability and are used to “bluff” the opponent.
7.45.641	This type of interaction, even if “dishonest,” would be favored by natural selection if it is successful more times than not.
7.45.642	This stork’s courtship display is designed to attract potential mates.
7.45.643	Distraction displays are seen in birds and some fish.
7.45.644	They are designed to attract a predator away from the nest that contains their young.
7.45.645	This is an example of an altruistic behavior: it benefits the young more than the individual performing the display, which is putting itself at risk by doing so.
7.45.646	Many animals, especially primates, communicate with other members in the group through touch.
7.45.647	Activities such as grooming, touching the shoulder or root of the tail, embracing, lip contact, and greeting ceremonies have all been observed in the Indian langur, an Old World monkey.
7.45.648	Similar behaviors are found in other primates, especially in the great apes.
7.45.649	Altruistic Behaviors Behaviors that lower the fitness of the individual but increase the fitness of another individual are termed altruistic.
7.45.650	Examples of such behaviors are seen widely across the animal kingdom.
7.45.651	Social insects such as worker bees have no ability to reproduce, yet they maintain the queen so she can populate the hive with her offspring.
7.45.652	Meerkats keep a sentry standing guard to warn the rest of the colony about intruders, even though the sentry is putting itself at risk.
7.45.653	Wolves and wild dogs bring meat to pack members not present during a hunt.
7.45.654	Lemurs take care of infants unrelated to them.
7.45.655	Although on the surface, these behaviors appear to be altruistic, it may not be so simple.
7.45.656	There has been much discussion over why altruistic behaviors exist.
7.45.657	Do these behaviors lead to overall evolutionary advantages for their species?
7.45.658	Do they help the altruistic individual pass on its own genes?
7.45.659	And what about such activities between unrelated individuals?
7.45.660	One explanation for altruistic-type behaviors is found in the genetics of natural selection.
7.45.661	In the 1976 book, The Selfish Gene, scientist Richard Dawkins attempted to explain many seemingly altruistic behaviors from the viewpoint of the gene itself.
7.45.662	Although a gene obviously cannot be selfish in the human sense, it may appear that way if the sacrifice of an individual benefits related individuals that share genes that are identical by descent (present in relatives because of common lineage).
7.45.663	Mammal parents make this sacrifice to take care of their offspring.
7.45.664	Emperor penguins migrate miles in harsh conditions to bring food back for their young.
7.45.665	Selfish gene theory has been controversial over the years and is still discussed among scientists in related fields.
7.45.666	Even less-related individuals, those with less genetic identity than that shared by parent and offspring, benefit from seemingly altruistic behavior.
7.45.667	The activities of social insects such as bees, wasps, ants, and termites are good examples.
7.45.668	Sterile workers in these societies take care of the queen because they are closely related to it, and as the queen has offspring, she is passing on genes from the workers indirectly.
7.45.669	Thus, it is of fitness benefit for the worker to maintain the queen without having any direct chance of passing on its genes due to its sterility.
7.45.670	The lowering of individual fitness to enhance the reproductive fitness of a relative and thus one’s inclusive fitness evolves through kin selection.
7.45.671	This phenomenon can explain many superficially altruistic behaviors seen in animals.
7.45.672	However, these behaviors may not be truly defined as altruism in these cases because the actor is actually increasing its own fitness either directly (through its own offspring) or indirectly (through the inclusive fitness it gains through relatives that share genes with it).
7.45.673	Unrelated individuals may also act altruistically to each other, and this seems to defy the “selfish gene” explanation.
7.45.674	An example of this observed in many monkey species where a monkey will present its back to an unrelated monkey to have that individual pick the parasites from its fur.
7.45.675	After a certain amount of time, the roles are reversed and the first monkey now grooms the second monkey.
7.45.676	Thus, there is reciprocity in the behavior.
7.45.677	Both benefit from the interaction and their fitness is raised more than if neither cooperated nor if one cooperated and the other did not cooperate.
7.45.678	This behavior is still not necessarily altruism, as the “giving” behavior of the actor is based on the expectation that it will be the “receiver” of the behavior in the future, termed reciprocal altruism.
7.45.679	Reciprocal altruism requires that individuals repeatedly encounter each other, often the result of living in the same social group, and that cheaters (those that never “give back”) are punished.
7.45.680	Evolutionary game theory, a modification of classical game theory in mathematics, has shown that many of these so-called “altruistic behaviors” are not altruistic at all.
7.45.681	The definition of “pure” altruism, based on human behavior, is an action that benefits another without any direct benefit to oneself.
7.45.682	Most of the behaviors previously described do not seem to satisfy this definition, and game theorists are good at finding “selfish” components in them.
7.45.683	Others have argued that the terms “selfish” and “altruistic” should be dropped completely when discussing animal behavior, as they describe human behavior and may not be directly applicable to instinctual animal activity.
7.45.684	What is clear, though, is that heritable behaviors that improve the chances of passing on one’s genes or a portion of one’s genes are favored by natural selection and will be retained in future generations as long as those behaviors convey a fitness advantage.
7.45.685	These instinctual behaviors may then be applied, in special circumstances, to other species, as long as it doesn’t lower the animal’s fitness.
7.45.686	Finding Sex Partners
7.45.687	Not all animals reproduce sexually, but many that do have the same challenge: they need to find a suitable mate and often have to compete with other individuals to obtain one.
7.45.688	Significant energy is spent in the process of locating, attracting, and mating with the sex partner.
7.45.689	Two types of selection occur during this process and can lead to traits that are important to reproduction called secondary sexual characteristics: intersexual selection, the choosing of a mate where individuals of one sex choose mates of the other sex, and intrasexual selection, the competition for mates between species members of the same sex.
7.45.690	Intersexual selection is often complex because choosing a mate may be based on a variety of visual, aural, tactile, and chemical cues.
7.45.691	An example of intersexual selection is when female peacocks choose to mate with the male with the brightest plumage.
7.45.692	This type of selection often leads to traits in the chosen sex that do not enhance survival, but are those traits most attractive to the opposite sex (often at the expense of survival).
7.45.693	Intrasexual selection involves mating displays and aggressive mating rituals such as rams butting heads—the winner of these battles is the one that is able to mate.
7.45.694	Many of these rituals use up considerable energy but result in the selection of the healthiest, strongest, and/or most dominant individuals for mating.
7.45.695	Three general mating systems, all involving innate as opposed to learned behaviors, are seen in animal populations: monogamous, polygynous, and polyandrous.
7.45.696	In monogamous systems, one male and one female are paired for at least one breeding season.
7.45.697	In some animals, such as the gray wolf, these associations can last much longer, even a lifetime.
7.45.698	Several explanations have been proposed for this type of mating system.
7.45.699	The “mate-guarding hypothesis” states that males stay with the female to prevent other males from mating with her.
7.45.700	This behavior is advantageous in such situations where mates are scarce and difficult to find.
7.45.701	Another explanation is the “male-assistance hypothesis,” where males that remain with a female to help guard and rear their young will have more and healthier offspring.
7.45.702	Monogamy is observed in many bird populations where, in addition to the parental care from the female, the male is also a major provider of parental care for the chicks.
7.45.703	A third explanation for the evolutionary advantages of monogamy is the “female-enforcement hypothesis.
7.45.704	”
7.45.705	In this scenario, the female ensures that the male does not have other offspring that might compete with her own, so she actively interferes with the male’s signaling to attract other mates.
7.45.706	Polygynous mating refers to one male mating with multiple females.
7.45.707	In these situations, the female must be responsible for most of the parental care as the single male is not capable of providing care to that many offspring.
7.45.708	In resourced-based polygyny, males compete for territories with the best resources, and then mate with females that enter the territory, drawn to its resource richness.
7.45.709	The female benefits by mating with a dominant, genetically fit male; however, it is at the cost of having no male help in caring for the offspring.
7.45.710	An example is seen in the yellow-rumped honeyguide, a bird whose males defend beehives because the females feed on their wax.
7.45.711	As the females approach, the male defending the nest will mate with them.
7.45.712	Harem mating structures are a type of polygynous system where certain males dominate mating while controlling a territory with resources.
7.45.713	Elephant seals, where the alpha male dominates the mating within the group are an example.
7.45.714	A third type of polygyny is a lek system.
7.45.715	Here there is a communal courting area where several males perform elaborate displays for females, and the females choose their mate from this group.
7.45.716	This behavior is observed in several bird species including the sage grouse and the prairie chicken.
7.45.717	In polyandrous mating systems, one female mates with many males.
7.45.718	These types of systems are much rarer than monogamous and polygynous mating systems.
7.45.719	In pipefishes and seahorses, males receive the eggs from the female, fertilize them, protect them within a pouch, and give birth to the offspring (Figure 45.38).
7.45.720	Therefore, the female is able to provide eggs to several males without the burden of carrying the fertilized eggs.
7.45.721	Polyandrous mating, in which one female mates with many males, occurs in the (a) seahorse and the (b) pipefish.
7.45.722	Simple Learned Behaviors
7.45.723	The majority of the behaviors previously discussed were innate or at least have an innate component (variations on the innate behaviors may be learned).
7.45.724	They are inherited and the behaviors do not change in response to signals from the environment.
7.45.725	Conversely, learned behaviors, even though they may have instinctive components, allow an organism to adapt to changes in the environment and are modified by previous experiences.
7.45.726	Simple learned behaviors include habituation and imprinting—both are important to the maturation process of young animals.
7.45.727	Habituation Habituation is a simple form of learning in which an animal stops responding to a stimulus after a period of repeated exposure.
7.45.728	This is a form of non-associative learning, as the stimulus is not associated with any punishment or reward.
7.45.729	Prairie dogs typically sound an alarm call when threatened by a predator, but they become habituated to the sound of human footsteps when no harm is associated with this sound, therefore, they no longer respond to them with an alarm call.
7.45.730	In this example, habituation is specific to the sound of human footsteps, as the animals still respond to the sounds of potential predators.
7.45.731	Imprinting Imprinting is a type of learning that occurs at a particular age or a life stage that is rapid and independent of the species involved.
7.45.732	Hatchling ducks recognize the first adult they see, their mother, and make a bond with her.
7.45.733	A familiar sight is ducklings walking or swimming after their mothers (Figure 45.39).
7.45.734	This is another type of non-associative learning, but is very important in the maturation process of these animals as it encourages them to stay near their mother so they will be protected, greatly increasing their chances of survival.
7.45.735	However, if newborn ducks see a human before they see their mother, they will imprint on the human and follow it in just the same manner as they would follow their real mother.
7.45.736	The attachment of ducklings to their mother is an example of imprinting.
7.45.737	Conditioned
7.45.738	Behavior Conditioned behaviors are types of associative learning, where a stimulus becomes associated with a consequence.
7.45.739	During operant conditioning, the behavioral response is modified by its consequences, with regards to its form, strength, or frequency.
7.45.740	Classical Conditioning
7.45.741	In classical conditioning, a response called the conditioned response is associated with a stimulus that it had previously not been associated with, the conditioned stimulus.
7.45.742	The response to the original, unconditioned stimulus is called the unconditioned response.
7.45.743	The most cited example of classical conditioning is Ivan Pavlov’s experiments with dogs (Figure 45.40).
7.45.744	In Pavlov’s experiments, the unconditioned response was the salivation of dogs in response to the unconditioned stimulus of seeing or smelling their food.
7.45.745	The conditioning stimulus that researchers associated with the unconditioned response was the ringing of a bell.
7.45.746	During conditioning, every time the animal was given food, the bell was rung.
7.45.747	This was repeated during several trials.
7.45.748	After some time, the dog learned to associate the ringing of the bell with food and to respond by salivating.
7.45.749	After the conditioning period was finished, the dog would respond by salivating when the bell was rung, even when the unconditioned stimulus, the food, was absent.
7.45.750	Thus, the ringing of the bell became the conditioned stimulus and the salivation became the conditioned response.
7.45.751	Although it is thought by some scientists that the unconditioned and conditioned responses are identical, even Pavlov discovered that the saliva in the conditioned dogs had characteristic differences when compared to the unconditioned dog.
7.45.752	In the classic Pavlovian response, the dog becomes conditioned to associate the ringing of the bell with food.
7.45.753	It had been thought by some scientists that this type of conditioning required multiple exposures to the paired stimulus and response, but it is now known that this is not necessary in all cases, and that some conditioning can be learned in a single pairing experiment.
7.45.754	Classical conditioning is a major tenet of behaviorism, a branch of psychological philosophy that proposes that all actions, thoughts, and emotions of living things are behaviors that can be treated by behavior modification and changes in the environment.
7.45.755	Operant Conditioning
7.45.756	In operant conditioning, the conditioned behavior is gradually modified by its consequences as the animal responds to the stimulus.
7.45.757	A major proponent of such conditioning was psychologist B.F. Skinner, the inventor of the Skinner box.
7.45.758	Skinner put rats in his boxes that contained a lever that would dispense food to the rat when depressed.
7.45.759	While initially the rat would push the lever a few times by accident, it eventually associated pushing the lever with getting the food.
7.45.760	This type of learning is an example of operant conditioning.
7.45.761	Operant learning is the basis of most animal training.
7.45.762	The conditioned behavior is continually modified by positive or negative reinforcement, often a reward such as food or some type of punishment, respectively.
7.45.763	In this way, the animal is conditioned to associate a type of behavior with the punishment or reward, and, over time, can be induced to perform behaviors that they would not have done in the wild, such as the “tricks” dolphins perform at marine amusement park shows.
7.45.764	The training of dolphins by rewarding them with food is an example of positive reinforcement operant conditioning.
7.45.765	Cognitive Learning Classical and operant conditioning are inefficient ways for humans and other intelligent animals to learn.
7.45.766	Some primates, including humans, are able to learn by imitating the behavior of others and by taking instructions.
7.45.767	The development of complex language by humans has made cognitive learning, the manipulation of information using the mind, the most prominent method of human learning.
7.45.768	In fact, that is how students are learning right now by reading this book.
7.45.769	As students read, they can make mental images of objects or organisms and imagine changes to them, or behaviors by them, and anticipate the consequences.
7.45.770	In addition to visual processing, cognitive learning is also enhanced by remembering past experiences, touching physical objects, hearing sounds, tasting food, and a variety of other sensory-based inputs.
7.45.771	Cognitive learning is so powerful that it can be used to understand conditioning in detail.
7.45.772	In the reverse scenario, conditioning cannot help someone learn about cognition.
7.45.773	Classic work on cognitive learning was done by Wolfgang Köhler with chimpanzees.
7.45.774	He demonstrated that these animals were capable of abstract thought by showing that they could learn how to solve a puzzle.
7.45.775	When a banana was hung in their cage too high for them to reach, and several boxes were placed randomly on the floor, some of the chimps were able to stack the boxes one on top of the other, climb on top of them, and get the banana.
7.45.776	This implies that they could visualize the result of stacking the boxes even before they had performed the action.
7.45.777	This type of learning is much more powerful and versatile than conditioning.
7.45.778	Cognitive learning is not limited to primates, although they are the most efficient in using it.
7.45.779	Maze running experiments done with rats by H.C. Blodgett in the 1920s were the first to show cognitive skills in a simple mammal.
7.45.780	The motivation for the animals to work their way through the maze was a piece of food at its end.
7.45.781	In these studies, the animals in Group I were run in one trial per day and had food available to them each day on completion of the run (Figure 45.42).
7.45.782	Group II rats were not fed in the maze for the first six days and then subsequent runs were done with food for several days after.
7.45.783	Group III rats had food available on the third day and every day thereafter.
7.45.784	The results were that the control rats, Group I, learned quickly, and figured out how to run the maze in seven days.
7.45.785	Group III did not learn much during the three days without food, but rapidly caught up to the control group when given the food reward.
7.45.786	Group II learned very slowly for the six days with no reward to motivate them, and they did not begin to catch up to the control group until the day food was given, and then it took two days longer to learn the maze.
7.45.787	Group I (the green solid line) found food at the end of each trial, group II (the blue dashed line) did not find food for the first 6 days, and group III (the red dotted line) did not find food during runs on the first three days.
7.45.788	Notice that rats given food earlier learned faster and eventually caught up to the control group.
7.45.789	The orange dots on the group II and III lines show the days when food rewards were added to the mazes.
7.45.790	It may not be immediately obvious that this type of learning is different than conditioning.
7.45.791	Although one might be tempted to believe that the rats simply learned how to find their way through a conditioned series of right and left turns, E.C. Tolman proved a decade later that the rats were making a representation of the maze in their minds, which he called a “cognitive map.
7.45.792	”
7.45.793	This was an early demonstration of the power of cognitive learning and how these abilities were not just limited to humans.
7.45.794	Sociobiology Sociobiology is an interdisciplinary science originally popularized by social insect researcher E.O. Wilson in the 1970s.
7.45.795	Wilson defined the science as “the extension of population biology and evolutionary theory to social organization.
7.45.796	”
7.45.797	[10] The main thrust of sociobiology is that animal and human behavior, including aggressiveness and other social interactions, can be explained almost solely in terms of genetics and natural selection.
7.45.798	This science is controversial; noted scientist such as the late Stephen Jay Gould criticized the approach for ignoring the environmental effects on behavior.
7.45.799	This is another example of the “nature versus nurture” debate of the role of genetics versus the role of environment in determining an organism’s characteristics.
7.45.800	Sociobiology also links genes with behaviors and has been associated with “biological determinism,” the belief that all behaviors are hardwired into our genes.
7.45.801	No one disputes that certain behaviors can be inherited and that natural selection plays a role retaining them.
7.45.802	It is the application of such principles to human behavior that sparks this controversy, which remains active today.
7.46.0	In the southwestern United States, rainy weather causes an increase in production of pinyon nuts, causing the deer mouse population to explode.
7.46.1	Deer mice may carry a virus called Sin Nombre (a hantavirus) that causes respiratory disease in humans and has a high fatality rate.
7.46.2	In 1992–1993, wet El Niño weather caused a Sin Nombre epidemic.
7.46.3	Navajo healers, who were aware of the link between this disease and weather, predicted the outbreak.
7.46.4	In 1993, an interesting example of ecosystem dynamics occurred when a rare lung disease struck inhabitants of the southwestern United States.
7.46.5	This disease had an alarming rate of fatalities, killing more than half of early patients, many of whom were Native Americans.
7.46.6	These formerly healthy young adults died from complete respiratory failure.
7.46.7	The disease was unknown, and the Centers for Disease Control (CDC), the United States government agency responsible for managing potential epidemics, was brought in to investigate.
7.46.8	The scientists could have learned about the disease had they known to talk with the Navajo healers who lived in the area and who had observed the connection between rainfall and mice populations, thereby predicting the 1993 outbreak.
7.46.9	The cause of the disease, determined within a few weeks by the CDC investigators, was the hantavirus known as Sin Nombre, the virus with “no name.
7.46.10	”
7.46.11	With insights from traditional Navajo medicine, scientists were able to characterize the disease rapidly and institute effective health measures to prevent its spread.
7.46.12	This example illustrates the importance of understanding the complexities of ecosystems and how they respond to changes in the environment.
7.46.13	Ecology of Ecosystems
7.46.14	By the end of this section, you will be able to: Describe the basic types of ecosystems on
7.46.15	Earth Explain
7.46.16	the methods that ecologists use to study ecosystem structure and dynamics Identify the different methods of ecosystem modeling Differentiate between food chains and food webs and recognize the importance of each Life in an ecosystem is often about competition for limited resources, a characteristic of the theory of natural selection.
7.46.17	Competition in communities (all living things within specific habitats) is observed both within species and among different species.
7.46.18	The resources for which organisms compete include organic material from living or previously living organisms, sunlight, and mineral nutrients, which provide the energy for living processes and the matter to make up organisms’ physical structures.
7.46.19	Other critical factors influencing community dynamics are the components of its physical and geographic environment: a habitat’s latitude, amount of rainfall, topography (elevation), and available species.
7.46.20	These are all important environmental variables that determine which organisms can exist within a particular area.
7.46.21	An ecosystem is a community of living organisms and their interactions with their abiotic (non-living) environment.
7.46.22	Ecosystems can be small, such as the tide pools found near the rocky shores of many oceans, or large, such as the Amazon Rainforest in Brazil.
7.46.23	A (a) tidal pool ecosystem in Matinicus Island in Maine is a small ecosystem, while the (b) Amazon Rainforest in Brazil is a large ecosystem.
7.46.24	There are three broad categories of ecosystems based on their general environment: freshwater, ocean water, and terrestrial.
7.46.25	Within these broad categories are individual ecosystem types based on the organisms present and the type of environmental habitat.
7.46.26	Ocean ecosystems are the most common, comprising 75 percent of the Earth's surface and consisting of three basic types: shallow ocean, deep ocean water, and deep ocean surfaces (the low depth areas of the deep oceans).
7.46.27	The shallow ocean ecosystems include extremely biodiverse coral reef ecosystems, and the deep ocean surface is known for its large numbers of plankton and krill (small crustaceans) that support it.
7.46.28	These two environments are especially important to aerobic respirators worldwide as the phytoplankton perform 40 percent of all photosynthesis on Earth.
7.46.29	Although not as diverse as the other two, deep ocean ecosystems contain a wide variety of marine organisms.
7.46.30	Such ecosystems exist even at the bottom of the ocean where light is unable to penetrate through the water.
7.46.31	Freshwater ecosystems are the rarest, occurring on only 1.8 percent of the Earth's surface.
7.46.32	Lakes, rivers, streams, and springs comprise these systems; they are quite diverse, and they support a variety of fish, amphibians, reptiles, insects, phytoplankton, fungi, and bacteria.
7.46.33	Terrestrial ecosystems, also known for their diversity, are grouped into large categories called biomes, such as tropical rain forests, savannas, deserts, coniferous forests, deciduous forests, and tundra.
7.46.34	Grouping these ecosystems into just a few biome categories obscures the great diversity of the individual ecosystems within them.
7.46.35	For example, there is great variation in desert vegetation: the saguaro cacti and other plant life in the Sonoran Desert, in the United States, are relatively abundant compared to the desolate rocky desert of Boa Vista, an island off the coast of Western Africa.
7.46.36	Desert ecosystems, like all ecosystems, can vary greatly.
7.46.37	The desert in (a)
7.46.38	Saguaro National Park, Arizona, has abundant plant life, while the rocky desert of (b) Boa Vista island, Cape Verde, Africa, is devoid of plant life.
7.46.39	Ecosystems are complex with many interacting parts.
7.46.40	They are routinely exposed to various disturbances, or changes in the environment that effect their compositions: yearly variations in rainfall and temperature and the slower processes of plant growth, which may take several years.
7.46.41	Many of these disturbances are a result of natural processes.
7.46.42	For example, when lightning causes a forest fire and destroys part of a forest ecosystem, the ground is eventually populated by grasses, then by bushes and shrubs, and later by mature trees, restoring the forest to its former state.
7.46.43	The impact of environmental disturbances caused by human activities is as important as the changes wrought by natural processes.
7.46.44	Human agricultural practices, air pollution, acid rain, global deforestation, overfishing, eutrophication, oil spills, and illegal dumping on land and into the ocean are all issues of concern to conservationists.
7.46.45	Equilibrium is the steady state of an ecosystem where all organisms are in balance with their environment and with each other.
7.46.46	In ecology, two parameters are used to measure changes in ecosystems: resistance and resilience.
7.46.47	The ability of an ecosystem to remain at equilibrium in spite of disturbances is called resistance.
7.46.48	The speed at which an ecosystem recovers equilibrium after being disturbed, called its resilience.
7.46.49	Ecosystem resistance and resilience are especially important when considering human impact.
7.46.50	The nature of an ecosystem may change to such a degree that it can lose its resilience entirely.
7.46.51	This process can lead to the complete destruction or irreversible altering of the ecosystem.
7.46.52	Food Chains and Food Webs
7.46.53	The term “food chain” is sometimes used metaphorically to describe human social situations.
7.46.54	In this sense, food chains are thought of as a competition for survival, such as “who eats whom?
7.46.55	”
7.46.56	Someone eats and someone is eaten.
7.46.57	Therefore, it is not surprising that in our competitive “dog-eat-dog” society, individuals who are considered successful are seen as being at the top of the food chain, consuming all others for their benefit, whereas the less successful are seen as being at the bottom.
7.46.58	The scientific understanding of a food chain is more precise than in its everyday usage.
7.46.59	In ecology, a food chain is a linear sequence of organisms through which nutrients and energy pass: primary producers, primary consumers, and higher-level consumers are used to describe ecosystem structure and dynamics.
7.46.60	There is a single path through the chain.
7.46.61	Each organism in a food chain occupies what is called a trophic level.
7.46.62	Depending on their role as producers or consumers, species or groups of species can be assigned to various trophic levels.
7.46.63	In many ecosystems, the bottom of the food chain consists of photosynthetic organisms (plants and/or phytoplankton), which are called primary producers.
7.46.64	The organisms that consume the primary producers are herbivores: the primary consumers.
7.46.65	Secondary consumers are usually carnivores that eat the primary consumers.
7.46.66	Tertiary consumers are carnivores that eat other carnivores.
7.46.67	Higher-level consumers feed on the next lower tropic levels, and so on, up to the organisms at the top of the food chain: the apex consumers.
7.46.68	In the Lake Ontario food chain shown in Figure 46.4, the Chinook salmon is the apex consumer at the top of this food chain.
7.46.69	These are the trophic levels of a food chain in Lake Ontario at the United States-Canada border.
7.46.70	Energy and nutrients flow from photosynthetic green algae at the bottom to the top of the food chain: the Chinook salmon.
7.46.71	One major factor that limits the length of food chains is energy.
7.46.72	Energy is lost as heat between each trophic level due to the second law of thermodynamics.
7.46.73	Thus, after a limited number of trophic energy transfers, the amount of energy remaining in the food chain may not be great enough to support viable populations at yet a higher trophic level.
7.46.74	The loss of energy between trophic levels is illustrated by the pioneering studies of Howard T. Odum in the Silver Springs, Florida, ecosystem in the 1940s (Figure 46.5).
7.46.75	The primary producers generated 20,819 kcal/m2/yr (kilocalories per square meter per year), the primary consumers generated 3368 kcal/m2/yr, the secondary consumers generated 383 kcal/m2/yr, and the tertiary consumers only generated 21 kcal/m2/yr.
7.46.76	Thus, there is little energy remaining for another level of consumers in this ecosystem.
7.46.77	The relative energy in trophic levels in a Silver Springs, Florida, ecosystem is shown.
7.46.78	Each trophic level has less energy available and supports fewer organisms at the next level.
7.46.79	There is a one problem when using food chains to accurately describe most ecosystems.
7.46.80	Even when all organisms are grouped into appropriate trophic levels, some of these organisms can feed on species from more than one trophic level; likewise, some of these organisms can be eaten by species from multiple trophic levels.
7.46.81	In other words, the linear model of ecosystems, the food chain, is not completely descriptive of ecosystem structure.
7.46.82	A holistic model—which accounts for all the interactions between different species and their complex interconnected relationships with each other and with the environment—is a more accurate and descriptive model for ecosystems.
7.46.83	A food web is a graphic representation of a holistic, non-linear web of primary producers, primary consumers, and higher-level consumers used to describe ecosystem structure and dynamics.
7.46.84	This food web shows the interactions between organisms across trophic levels in the Lake Ontario ecosystem.
7.46.85	Primary producers are outlined in green, primary consumers in orange, secondary consumers in blue, and tertiary (apex) consumers in purple.
7.46.86	Arrows point from an organism that is consumed to the organism that consumes it.
7.46.87	Notice how some lines point to more than one trophic level.
7.46.88	For example, the opossum shrimp eats both primary producers and primary consumers.
7.46.89	A comparison of the two types of structural ecosystem models shows strength in both.
7.46.90	Food chains are more flexible for analytical modeling, are easier to follow, and are easier to experiment with, whereas food web models more accurately represent ecosystem structure and dynamics, and data can be directly used as input for simulation modeling.
7.46.91	Two general types of food webs are often shown interacting within a single ecosystem.
7.46.92	A grazing food web (such as the Lake Ontario food web in Figure 46.6) has plants or other photosynthetic organisms at its base, followed by herbivores and various carnivores.
7.46.93	A detrital food web consists of a base of organisms that feed on decaying organic matter (dead organisms), called decomposers or detritivores.
7.46.94	These organisms are usually bacteria or fungi that recycle organic material back into the biotic part of the ecosystem as they themselves are consumed by other organisms.
7.46.95	As all ecosystems require a method to recycle material from dead organisms, most grazing food webs have an associated detrital food web.
7.46.96	For example, in a meadow ecosystem, plants may support a grazing food web of different organisms, primary and other levels of consumers, while at the same time supporting a detrital food web of bacteria, fungi, and detrivorous invertebrates feeding off dead plants and animals.
7.46.97	Research into Ecosystem Dynamics: Ecosystem Experimentation and Modeling
7.46.98	The study of the changes in ecosystem structure caused by changes in the environment (disturbances) or by internal forces is called ecosystem dynamics.
7.46.99	Ecosystems are characterized using a variety of research methodologies.
7.46.100	Some ecologists study ecosystems using controlled experimental systems, while some study entire ecosystems in their natural state, and others use both approaches.
7.46.101	A holistic ecosystem model attempts to quantify the composition, interaction, and dynamics of entire ecosystems; it is the most representative of the ecosystem in its natural state.
7.46.102	A food web is an example of a holistic ecosystem model.
7.46.103	However, this type of study is limited by time and expense, as well as the fact that it is neither feasible nor ethical to do experiments on large natural ecosystems.
7.46.104	To quantify all different species in an ecosystem and the dynamics in their habitat is difficult, especially when studying large habitats such as the Amazon Rainforest, which covers 1.4 billion acres (5.5 million km2) of the Earth’s surface.
7.46.105	For these reasons, scientists study ecosystems under more controlled conditions.
7.46.106	Experimental systems usually involve either partitioning a part of a natural ecosystem that can be used for experiments, termed a mesocosm, or by re-creating an ecosystem entirely in an indoor or outdoor laboratory environment, which is referred to as a microcosm.
7.46.107	A major limitation to these approaches is that removing individual organisms from their natural ecosystem or altering a natural ecosystem through partitioning may change the dynamics of the ecosystem.
7.46.108	These changes are often due to differences in species numbers and diversity and also to environment alterations caused by partitioning (mesocosm) or re-creating (microcosm) the natural habitat.
7.46.109	Thus, these types of experiments are not totally predictive of changes that would occur in the ecosystem from which they were gathered.
7.46.110	As both of these approaches have their limitations, some ecologists suggest that results from these experimental systems should be used only in conjunction with holistic ecosystem studies to obtain the most representative data about ecosystem structure, function, and dynamics.
7.46.111	Scientists use the data generated by these experimental studies to develop ecosystem models that demonstrate the structure and dynamics of ecosystems.
7.46.112	Three basic types of ecosystem modeling are routinely used in research and ecosystem management: a conceptual model, an analytical model, and a simulation model.
7.46.113	A conceptual model is an ecosystem model that consists of flow charts to show interactions of different compartments of the living and nonliving components of the ecosystem.
7.46.114	A conceptual model describes ecosystem structure and dynamics and shows how environmental disturbances affect the ecosystem; however, its ability to predict the effects of these disturbances is limited.
7.46.115	Analytical and simulation models, in contrast, are mathematical methods of describing ecosystems that are indeed capable of predicting the effects of potential environmental changes without direct experimentation, although with some limitations as to accuracy.
7.46.116	An analytical model is an ecosystem model that is created using simple mathematical formulas to predict the effects of environmental disturbances on ecosystem structure and dynamics.
7.46.117	A simulation model is an ecosystem model that is created using complex computer algorithms to holistically model ecosystems and to predict the effects of environmental disturbances on ecosystem structure and dynamics.
7.46.118	Ideally, these models are accurate enough to determine which components of the ecosystem are particularly sensitive to disturbances, and they can serve as a guide to ecosystem managers (such as conservation ecologists or fisheries biologists) in the practical maintenance of ecosystem health.
7.46.119	Conceptual Models Conceptual models are useful for describing ecosystem structure and dynamics and for demonstrating the relationships between different organisms in a community and their environment.
7.46.120	Conceptual models are usually depicted graphically as flow charts.
7.46.121	The organisms and their resources are grouped into specific compartments with arrows showing the relationship and transfer of energy or nutrients between them.
7.46.122	Thus, these diagrams are sometimes called compartment models.
7.46.123	To model the cycling of mineral nutrients, organic and inorganic nutrients are subdivided into those that are bioavailable (ready to be incorporated into biological macromolecules) and those that are not.
7.46.124	For example, in a terrestrial ecosystem near a deposit of coal, carbon will be available to the plants of this ecosystem as carbon dioxide gas in a short-term period, not from the carbon-rich coal itself.
7.46.125	However, over a longer period, microorganisms capable of digesting coal will incorporate its carbon or release it as natural gas (methane, CH4), changing this unavailable organic source into an available one.
7.46.126	This conversion is greatly accelerated by the combustion of fossil fuels by humans, which releases large amounts of carbon dioxide into the atmosphere.
7.46.127	This is thought to be a major factor in the rise of the atmospheric carbon dioxide levels in the industrial age.
7.46.128	The carbon dioxide released from burning fossil fuels is produced faster than photosynthetic organisms can use it.
7.46.129	This process is intensified by the reduction of photosynthetic trees because of worldwide deforestation.
7.46.130	Most scientists agree that high atmospheric carbon dioxide is a major cause of global climate change.
7.46.131	Conceptual models are also used to show the flow of energy through particular ecosystems.
7.46.132	Figure 46.8 is based on Howard T. Odum’s classical study of the Silver Springs, Florida, holistic ecosystem in the mid-twentieth century.
7.46.133	[2] This study shows the energy content and transfer between various ecosystem compartments.
7.46.134	Analytical and Simulation Models
7.46.135	The major limitation of conceptual models is their inability to predict the consequences of changes in ecosystem species and/or environment.
7.46.136	Ecosystems are dynamic entities and subject to a variety of abiotic and biotic disturbances caused by natural forces and/or human activity.
7.46.137	Ecosystems altered from their initial equilibrium state can often recover from such disturbances and return to a state of equilibrium.
7.46.138	As most ecosystems are subject to periodic disturbances and are often in a state of change, they are usually either moving toward or away from their equilibrium state.
7.46.139	There are many of these equilibrium states among the various components of an ecosystem, which affects the ecosystem overall.
7.46.140	Furthermore, as humans have the ability to greatly and rapidly alter the species content and habitat of an ecosystem, the need for predictive models that enable understanding of how ecosystems respond to these changes becomes more crucial.
7.46.141	Analytical models often use simple, linear components of ecosystems, such as food chains, and are known to be complex mathematically; therefore, they require a significant amount of mathematical knowledge and expertise.
7.46.142	Although analytical models have great potential, their simplification of complex ecosystems is thought to limit their accuracy.
7.46.143	Simulation models that use computer programs are better able to deal with the complexities of ecosystem structure.
7.46.144	A recent development in simulation modeling uses supercomputers to create and run individual-based simulations, which accounts for the behavior of individual organisms and their effects on the ecosystem as a whole.
7.46.145	These simulations are considered to be the most accurate and predictive of the complex responses of ecosystems to disturbances.
7.46.146	Energy Flow through Ecosystems
7.46.147	By the end of this section, you will be able to: Describe how organisms acquire energy in a food web and in associated food chains Explain how the efficiency of energy transfers between trophic levels affects ecosystem structure and dynamics Discuss trophic levels and how ecological pyramids are used to model them All living things require energy in one form or another.
7.46.148	Energy is required by most complex metabolic pathways (often in the form of adenosine triphosphate, ATP), especially those responsible for building large molecules from smaller compounds, and life itself is an energy-driven process.
7.46.149	Living organisms would not be able to assemble macromolecules (proteins, lipids, nucleic acids, and complex carbohydrates) from their monomeric subunits without a constant energy input.
