7.46.150	It is important to understand how organisms acquire energy and how that energy is passed from one organism to another through food webs and their constituent food chains.
7.46.151	Food webs illustrate how energy flows directionally through ecosystems, including how efficiently organisms acquire it, use it, and how much remains for use by other organisms of the food web.
7.46.152	How Organisms Acquire Energy in a Food Web Energy is acquired by living things in three ways: photosynthesis, chemosynthesis, and the consumption and digestion of other living or previously living organisms by heterotrophs.
7.46.153	Photosynthetic and chemosynthetic organisms are both grouped into a category known as autotrophs: organisms capable of synthesizing their own food (more specifically, capable of using inorganic carbon as a carbon source).
7.46.154	Photosynthetic autotrophs (photoautotrophs) use sunlight as an energy source, whereas chemosynthetic autotrophs (chemoautotrophs) use inorganic molecules as an energy source.
7.46.155	Autotrophs are critical for all ecosystems.
7.46.156	Without these organisms, energy would not be available to other living organisms and life itself would not be possible.
7.46.157	Photoautotrophs, such as plants, algae, and photosynthetic bacteria, serve as the energy source for a majority of the world’s ecosystems.
7.46.158	These ecosystems are often described by grazing food webs.
7.46.159	Photoautotrophs harness the solar energy of the sun by converting it to chemical energy in the form of ATP (and NADP).
7.46.160	The energy stored in ATP is used to synthesize complex organic molecules, such as glucose.
7.46.161	Chemoautotrophs are primarily bacteria that are found in rare ecosystems where sunlight is not available, such as in those associated with dark caves or hydrothermal vents at the bottom of the ocean (Figure 46.9).
7.46.162	Many chemoautotrophs in hydrothermal vents use hydrogen sulfide (H2S), which is released from the vents as a source of chemical energy.
7.46.163	This allows chemoautotrophs to synthesize complex organic molecules, such as glucose, for their own energy and in turn supplies energy to the rest of the ecosystem.
7.46.164	Swimming shrimp, a few squat lobsters, and hundreds of vent mussels are seen at a hydrothermal vent at the bottom of the ocean.
7.46.165	As no sunlight penetrates to this depth, the ecosystem is supported by chemoautotrophic bacteria and organic material that sinks from the ocean’s surface.
7.46.166	This picture was taken in 2006 at the submerged NW Eifuku volcano off the coast of Japan by the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA).
7.46.167	The summit of this highly active volcano lies 1535 m below the surface.
7.46.168	Productivity within Trophic Levels Productivity within an ecosystem can be defined as the percentage of energy entering the ecosystem incorporated into biomass in a particular trophic level.
7.46.169	Biomass is the total mass, in a unit area at the time of measurement, of living or previously living organisms within a trophic level.
7.46.170	Ecosystems have characteristic amounts of biomass at each trophic level.
7.46.171	For example, in the English Channel ecosystem the primary producers account for a biomass of 4 g/m2 (grams per meter squared), while the primary consumers exhibit a biomass of 21 g/m2.
7.46.172	The productivity of the primary producers is especially important in any ecosystem because these organisms bring energy to other living organisms by photoautotrophy or chemoautotrophy.
7.46.173	The rate at which photosynthetic primary producers incorporate energy from the sun is called gross primary productivity.
7.46.174	An example of gross primary productivity is shown in the compartment diagram of energy flow within the Silver Springs aquatic ecosystem as shown (Figure 46.8).
7.46.175	In this ecosystem, the total energy accumulated by the primary producers (gross primary productivity) was shown to be 20,810 kcal/m2/yr.
7.46.176	Because all organisms need to use some of this energy for their own functions (like respiration and resulting metabolic heat loss) scientists often refer to the net primary productivity of an ecosystem.
7.46.177	Net primary productivity is the energy that remains in the primary producers after accounting for the organisms’ respiration and heat loss.
7.46.178	The net productivity is then available to the primary consumers at the next trophic level.
7.46.179	In our Silver Spring example, 13,187 of the 20,810 kcal/m2/yr were used for respiration or were lost as heat, leaving 7,632 kcal/m2/yr of energy for use by the primary consumers.
7.46.180	Ecological Efficiency: The Transfer of Energy between Trophic Levels
7.46.181	As illustrated in Figure 46.8, large amounts of energy are lost from the ecosystem from one trophic level to the next level as energy flows from the primary producers through the various trophic levels of consumers and decomposers.
7.46.182	The main reason for this loss is the second law of thermodynamics, which states that whenever energy is converted from one form to another, there is a tendency toward disorder (entropy) in the system.
7.46.183	In biologic systems, this means a great deal of energy is lost as metabolic heat when the organisms from one trophic level consume the next level.
7.46.184	In the Silver Springs ecosystem example (Figure 46.8), we see that the primary consumers produced 1103 kcal/m2/yr from the 7618 kcal/m2/yr of energy available to them from the primary producers.
7.46.185	The measurement of energy transfer efficiency between two successive trophic levels is termed the trophic level transfer efficiency (TLTE) and is defined by the formula: In Silver Springs, the TLTE between the first two trophic levels was approximately 14.8 percent.
7.46.186	The low efficiency of energy transfer between trophic levels is usually the major factor that limits the length of food chains observed in a food web.
7.46.187	The fact is, after four to six energy transfers, there is not enough energy left to support another trophic level.
7.46.188	In the Lake Ontario example shown in Figure 46.6, only three energy transfers occurred between the primary producer, (green algae), and the apex consumer (Chinook salmon).
7.46.189	Ecologists have many different methods of measuring energy transfers within ecosystems.
7.46.190	Some transfers are easier or more difficult to measure depending on the complexity of the ecosystem and how much access scientists have to observe the ecosystem.
7.46.191	In other words, some ecosystems are more difficult to study than others, and sometimes the quantification of energy transfers has to be estimated.
7.46.192	Another main parameter that is important in characterizing energy flow within an ecosystem is the net production efficiency.
7.46.193	Net production efficiency (NPE) allows ecologists to quantify how efficiently organisms of a particular trophic level incorporate the energy they receive into biomass; it is calculated using the following formula: Net consumer productivity is the energy content available to the organisms of the next trophic level.
7.46.194	Assimilation is the biomass (energy content generated per unit area) of the present trophic level after accounting for the energy lost due to incomplete ingestion of food, energy used for respiration, and energy lost as waste.
7.46.195	Incomplete ingestion refers to the fact that some consumers eat only a part of their food.
7.46.196	For example, when a lion kills an antelope, it will eat everything except the hide and bones.
7.46.197	The lion is missing the energy-rich bone marrow inside the bone, so the lion does not make use of all the calories its prey could provide.
7.46.198	Thus, NPE measures how efficiently each trophic level uses and incorporates the energy from its food into biomass to fuel the next trophic level.
7.46.199	In general, cold-blooded animals (ectotherms), such as invertebrates, fish, amphibians, and reptiles, use less of the energy they obtain for respiration and heat than warm-blooded animals (endotherms), such as birds and mammals.
7.46.200	The extra heat generated in endotherms, although an advantage in terms of the activity of these organisms in colder environments, is a major disadvantage in terms of NPE.
7.46.201	Therefore, many endotherms have to eat more often than ectotherms to get the energy they need for survival.
7.46.202	In general, NPE for ectotherms is an order of magnitude (10x) higher than for endotherms.
7.46.203	For example, the NPE for a caterpillar eating leaves has been measured at 18 percent, whereas the NPE for a squirrel eating acorns may be as low as 1.6 percent.
7.46.204	The inefficiency of energy use by warm-blooded animals has broad implications for the world's food supply.
7.46.205	It is widely accepted that the meat industry uses large amounts of crops to feed livestock, and because the NPE is low, much of the energy from animal feed is lost.
7.46.206	For example, it costs about 1¢ to produce 1000 dietary calories (kcal) of corn or soybeans, but approximately $0.19 to produce a similar number of calories growing cattle for beef consumption.
7.46.207	The same energy content of milk from cattle is also costly, at approximately $0.16 per 1000 kcal.
7.46.208	Much of this difference is due to the low NPE of cattle.
7.46.209	Thus, there has been a growing movement worldwide to promote the consumption of non-meat and non-dairy foods so that less energy is wasted feeding animals for the meat industry.
7.46.210	Modeling Ecosystems Energy Flow:
7.46.211	Ecological Pyramids
7.46.212	The structure of ecosystems can be visualized with ecological pyramids, which were first described by the pioneering studies of Charles Elton in the 1920s.
7.46.213	Ecological pyramids show the relative amounts of various parameters (such as number of organisms, energy, and biomass) across trophic levels.
7.46.214	Pyramids of numbers can be either upright or inverted, depending on the ecosystem.
7.46.215	As shown in Figure 46.10, typical grassland during the summer has a base of many plants and the numbers of organisms decrease at each trophic level.
7.46.216	However, during the summer in a temperate forest, the base of the pyramid consists of few trees compared with the number of primary consumers, mostly insects.
7.46.217	Because trees are large, they have great photosynthetic capability, and dominate other plants in this ecosystem to obtain sunlight.
7.46.218	Even in smaller numbers, primary producers in forests are still capable of supporting other trophic levels.
7.46.219	Another way to visualize ecosystem structure is with pyramids of biomass.
7.46.220	This pyramid measures the amount of energy converted into living tissue at the different trophic levels.
7.46.221	Using the Silver Springs ecosystem example, this data exhibits an upright biomass pyramid (Figure 46.10), whereas the pyramid from the English Channel example is inverted.
7.46.222	The plants (primary producers) of the Silver Springs ecosystem make up a large percentage of the biomass found there.
7.46.223	However, the phytoplankton in the English Channel example make up less biomass than the primary consumers, the zooplankton.
7.46.224	As with inverted pyramids of numbers, this inverted pyramid is not due to a lack of productivity from the primary producers, but results from the high turnover rate of the phytoplankton.
7.46.225	The phytoplankton are consumed rapidly by the primary consumers, thus, minimizing their biomass at any particular point in time.
7.46.226	However, phytoplankton reproduce quickly, thus they are able to support the rest of the ecosystem.
7.46.227	Pyramid ecosystem modeling can also be used to show energy flow through the trophic levels.
7.46.228	Notice that these numbers are the same as those used in the energy flow compartment diagram in Figure 46.8.
7.46.229	Pyramids of energy are always upright, and an ecosystem without sufficient primary productivity cannot be supported.
7.46.230	All types of ecological pyramids are useful for characterizing ecosystem structure.
7.46.231	However, in the study of energy flow through the ecosystem, pyramids of energy are the most consistent and representative models of ecosystem structure.
7.46.232	Consequences of Food Webs:
7.46.233	Biological Magnification One of the most important environmental consequences of ecosystem dynamics is biomagnification.
7.46.234	Biomagnification is the increasing concentration of persistent, toxic substances in organisms at each trophic level, from the primary producers to the apex consumers.
7.46.235	Many substances have been shown to bioaccumulate, including classical studies with the pesticide dichlorodiphenyltrichloroethane (DDT), which was published in the 1960s bestseller, Silent Spring, by Rachel Carson.
7.46.236	DDT was a commonly used pesticide before its dangers became known.
7.46.237	In some aquatic ecosystems, organisms from each trophic level consumed many organisms of the lower level, which caused DDT to increase in birds (apex consumers) that ate fish.
7.46.238	Thus, the birds accumulated sufficient amounts of DDT to cause fragility in their eggshells.
7.46.239	This effect increased egg breakage during nesting and was shown to have adverse effects on these bird populations.
7.46.240	The use of DDT was banned in the United States in the 1970s.
7.46.241	Other substances that biomagnify are polychlorinated biphenyls (PCBs), which were used in coolant liquids in the United States until their use was banned in 1979, and heavy metals, such as mercury, lead, and cadmium.
7.46.242	These substances were best studied in aquatic ecosystems, where fish species at different trophic levels accumulate toxic substances brought through the ecosystem by the primary producers.
7.46.243	As illustrated in a study performed by the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) in the Saginaw Bay of Lake Huron (Figure 46.11), PCB concentrations increased from the ecosystem’s primary producers (phytoplankton) through the different trophic levels of fish species.
7.46.244	The apex consumer (walleye) has more than four times the amount of PCBs compared to phytoplankton.
7.46.245	Also, based on results from other studies, birds that eat these fish may have PCB levels at least one order of magnitude higher than those found in the lake fish.
7.46.246	This chart shows the PCB concentrations found at the various trophic levels in the Saginaw Bay ecosystem of Lake Huron.
7.46.247	Numbers on the x-axis reflect enrichment with heavy isotopes of nitrogen (15N), which is a marker for increasing trophic level.
7.46.248	Notice that the fish in the higher trophic levels accumulate more PCBs than those in lower trophic levels.
7.46.249	Other concerns have been raised by the accumulation of heavy metals, such as mercury and cadmium, in certain types of seafood.
7.46.250	The United States Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) recommends that pregnant women and young children should not consume any swordfish, shark, king mackerel, or tilefish because of their high mercury content.
7.46.251	These individuals are advised to eat fish low in mercury: salmon, tilapia, shrimp, pollock, and catfish.
7.46.252	Biomagnification is a good example of how ecosystem dynamics can affect our everyday lives, even influencing the food we eat.
7.46.253	Biogeochemical Cycles
7.46.254	By the end of this section, you will be able to: Discuss the biogeochemical cycles of water, carbon, nitrogen, phosphorus, and sulfur Explain how human activities have impacted these cycles and the potential consequences for Earth Energy flows directionally through ecosystems, entering as sunlight (or inorganic molecules for chemoautotrophs) and leaving as heat during the many transfers between trophic levels.
7.46.255	However, the matter that makes up living organisms is conserved and recycled.
7.46.256	The six most common elements associated with organic molecules—carbon, nitrogen, hydrogen, oxygen, phosphorus, and sulfur—take a variety of chemical forms and may exist for long periods in the atmosphere, on land, in water, or beneath the Earth’s surface.
7.46.257	Geologic processes, such as weathering, erosion, water drainage, and the subduction of the continental plates, all play a role in this recycling of materials.
7.46.258	Because geology and chemistry have major roles in the study of this process, the recycling of inorganic matter between living organisms and their environment is called a biogeochemical cycle.
7.46.259	Water contains hydrogen and oxygen, which is essential to all living processes.
7.46.260	The hydrosphere is the area of the Earth where water movement and storage occurs: as liquid water on the surface and beneath the surface or frozen (rivers, lakes, oceans, groundwater, polar ice caps, and glaciers), and as water vapor in the atmosphere.
7.46.261	Carbon is found in all organic macromolecules and is an important constituent of fossil fuels.
7.46.262	Nitrogen is a major component of our nucleic acids and proteins and is critical to human agriculture.
7.46.263	Phosphorus, a major component of nucleic acid (along with nitrogen), is one of the main ingredients in artificial fertilizers used in agriculture and their associated environmental impacts on our surface water.
7.46.264	Sulfur, critical to the 3–D folding of proteins (as in disulfide binding), is released into the atmosphere by the burning of fossil fuels, such as coal.
7.46.265	The cycling of these elements is interconnected.
7.46.266	For example, the movement of water is critical for the leaching of nitrogen and phosphate into rivers, lakes, and oceans.
7.46.267	Furthermore, the ocean itself is a major reservoir for carbon.
7.46.268	Thus, mineral nutrients are cycled, either rapidly or slowly, through the entire biosphere, from one living organism to another, and between the biotic and abiotic world.
7.46.269	The Water (Hydrologic) Cycle Water is the basis of all living processes.
7.46.270	The human body is more than 1/2 water and human cells are more than 70 percent water.
7.46.271	Thus, most land animals need a supply of fresh water to survive.
7.46.272	However, when examining the stores of water on Earth, 97.5 percent of it is non-potable salt water (Figure 46.12).
7.46.273	Of the remaining water, 99 percent is locked underground as water or as ice.
7.46.274	Thus, less than 1 percent of fresh water is easily accessible from lakes and rivers.
7.46.275	Many living things, such as plants, animals, and fungi, are dependent on the small amount of fresh surface water supply, a lack of which can have massive effects on ecosystem dynamics.
7.46.276	Humans, of course, have developed technologies to increase water availability, such as digging wells to harvest groundwater, storing rainwater, and using desalination to obtain drinkable water from the ocean.
7.46.277	Although this pursuit of drinkable water has been ongoing throughout human history, the supply of fresh water is still a major issue in modern times.
7.46.278	Only 2.5 percent of water on Earth is fresh water, and less than 1 percent of fresh water is easily accessible to living things.
7.46.279	Water cycling is extremely important to ecosystem dynamics.
7.46.280	Water has a major influence on climate and, thus, on the environments of ecosystems, some located on distant parts of the Earth.
7.46.281	Most of the water on Earth is stored for long periods in the oceans, underground, and as ice.
7.46.282	Figure 46.13 illustrates the average time that an individual water molecule may spend in the Earth’s major water reservoirs.
7.46.283	Residence time is a measure of the average time an individual water molecule stays in a particular reservoir.
7.46.284	A large amount of the Earth’s water is locked in place in these reservoirs as ice, beneath the ground, and in the ocean, and, thus, is unavailable for short-term cycling (only surface water can evaporate).
7.46.285	This graph shows the average residence time for water molecules in the Earth’s water reservoirs.
7.46.286	There are various processes that occur during the cycling of water, shown in Figure 46.14.
7.46.287	These processes include the following: • evaporation/sublimation • condensation/precipitation • subsurface water flow • surface runoff/snowmelt
7.46.288	• streamflow
7.46.289	The water cycle is driven by the sun’s energy as it warms the oceans and other surface waters.
7.46.290	This leads to the evaporation (water to water vapor) of liquid surface water and the sublimation (ice to water vapor) of frozen water, which deposits large amounts of water vapor into the atmosphere.
7.46.291	Over time, this water vapor condenses into clouds as liquid or frozen droplets and is eventually followed by precipitation (rain or snow), which returns water to the Earth’s surface.
7.46.292	Rain eventually permeates into the ground, where it may evaporate again if it is near the surface, flow beneath the surface, or be stored for long periods.
7.46.293	More easily observed is surface runoff: the flow of fresh water either from rain or melting ice.
7.46.294	Runoff can then make its way through streams and lakes to the oceans or flow directly to the oceans themselves.
7.46.295	Rain and surface runoff are major ways in which minerals, including carbon, nitrogen, phosphorus, and sulfur, are cycled from land to water.
7.46.296	The environmental effects of runoff will be discussed later as these cycles are described.
7.46.297	Water from the land and oceans enters the atmosphere by evaporation or sublimation, where it condenses into clouds and falls as rain or snow.
7.46.298	Precipitated water may enter freshwater bodies or infiltrate the soil.
7.46.299	The cycle is complete when surface or groundwater reenters the ocean.
7.46.300	The Carbon Cycle Carbon is the second most abundant element in living organisms.
7.46.301	Carbon is present in all organic molecules, and its role in the structure of macromolecules is of primary importance to living organisms.
7.46.302	Carbon compounds contain especially high energy, particularly those derived from fossilized organisms, mainly plants, which humans use as fuel.
7.46.303	Since the 1800s, the number of countries using massive amounts of fossil fuels has increased.
7.46.304	Since the beginning of the Industrial Revolution, global demand for the Earth’s limited fossil fuel supplies has risen; therefore, the amount of carbon dioxide in our atmosphere has increased.
7.46.305	This increase in carbon dioxide has been associated with climate change and other disturbances of the Earth’s ecosystems and is a major environmental concern worldwide.
7.46.306	Thus, the “carbon footprint” is based on how much carbon dioxide is produced and how much fossil fuel countries consume.
7.46.307	The carbon cycle is most easily studied as two interconnected sub-cycles: one dealing with rapid carbon exchange among living organisms and the other dealing with the long-term cycling of carbon through geologic processes.
7.46.308	The entire carbon cycle is shown in Figure 46.15.
7.46.309	The Carbon Cycle Carbon is the second most abundant element in living organisms.
7.46.310	Carbon is present in all organic molecules, and its role in the structure of macromolecules is of primary importance to living organisms.
7.46.311	Carbon compounds contain especially high energy, particularly those derived from fossilized organisms, mainly plants, which humans use as fuel.
7.46.312	Since the 1800s, the number of countries using massive amounts of fossil fuels has increased.
7.46.313	Since the beginning of the Industrial Revolution, global demand for the Earth’s limited fossil fuel supplies has risen; therefore, the amount of carbon dioxide in our atmosphere has increased.
7.46.314	This increase in carbon dioxide has been associated with climate change and other disturbances of the Earth’s ecosystems and is a major environmental concern worldwide.
7.46.315	Thus, the “carbon footprint” is based on how much carbon dioxide is produced and how much fossil fuel countries consume.
7.46.316	The carbon cycle is most easily studied as two interconnected sub-cycles: one dealing with rapid carbon exchange among living organisms and the other dealing with the long-term cycling of carbon through geologic processes.
7.46.317	The entire carbon cycle is shown in Figure 46.15.
7.46.318	The Biological Carbon Cycle Living organisms are connected in many ways, even between ecosystems.
7.46.319	A good example of this connection is the exchange of carbon between autotrophs and heterotrophs within and between ecosystems by way of atmospheric carbon dioxide.
7.46.320	Carbon dioxide is the basic building block that most autotrophs use to build multi-carbon, high energy compounds, such as glucose.
7.46.321	The energy harnessed from the sun is used by these organisms to form the covalent bonds that link carbon atoms together.
7.46.322	These chemical bonds thereby store this energy for later use in the process of respiration.
7.46.323	Most terrestrial autotrophs obtain their carbon dioxide directly from the atmosphere, while marine autotrophs acquire it in the dissolved form (carbonic acid, H2CO3 −).
7.46.324	However carbon dioxide is acquired, a by-product of the process is oxygen.
7.46.325	The photosynthetic organisms are responsible for depositing approximately 21 percent oxygen content of the atmosphere that we observe today.
7.46.326	Heterotrophs and autotrophs are partners in biological carbon exchange (especially the primary consumers, largely herbivores).
7.46.327	Heterotrophs acquire the high-energy carbon compounds from the autotrophs by consuming them, and breaking them down by respiration to obtain cellular energy, such as ATP.
7.46.328	The most efficient type of respiration, aerobic respiration, requires oxygen obtained from the atmosphere or dissolved in water.
7.46.329	Thus, there is a constant exchange of oxygen and carbon dioxide between the autotrophs (which need the carbon) and the heterotrophs (which need the oxygen).
7.46.330	Gas exchange through the atmosphere and water is one way that the carbon cycle connects all living organisms on Earth.
7.46.331	The Biogeochemical Carbon Cycle
7.46.332	The movement of carbon through the land, water, and air is complex, and in many cases, it occurs much more slowly geologically than as seen between living organisms.
7.46.333	Carbon is stored for long periods in what are known as carbon reservoirs, which include the atmosphere, bodies of liquid water (mostly oceans), ocean sediment, soil, land sediments (including fossil fuels), and the Earth’s interior.
7.46.334	As stated, the atmosphere is a major reservoir of carbon in the form of carbon dioxide and is essential to the process of photosynthesis.
7.46.335	The level of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere is greatly influenced by the reservoir of carbon in the oceans.
7.46.336	The exchange of carbon between the atmosphere and water reservoirs influences how much carbon is found in each location, and each one affects the other reciprocally.
7.46.337	Carbon dioxide (CO2) from the atmosphere dissolves in water and combines with water molecules to form carbonic acid, and then it ionizes to carbonate and bicarbonate ions.
7.46.338	Carbon dioxide reacts with water to form bicarbonate and carbonate ions.
7.46.339	The equilibrium coefficients are such that more than 90 percent of the carbon in the ocean is found as bicarbonate ions.
7.46.340	Some of these ions combine with seawater calcium to form calcium carbonate (CaCO3), a major component of marine organism shells.
7.46.341	These organisms eventually form sediments on the ocean floor.
7.46.342	Over geologic time, the calcium carbonate forms limestone, which comprises the largest carbon reservoir on Earth.
7.46.343	On land, carbon is stored in soil as a result of the decomposition of living organisms (by decomposers) or from weathering of terrestrial rock and minerals.
7.46.344	This carbon can be leached into the water reservoirs by surface runoff.
7.46.345	Deeper underground, on land and at sea, are fossil fuels: the anaerobically decomposed remains of plants that take millions of years to form.
7.46.346	Fossil fuels are considered a non-renewable resource because their use far exceeds their rate of formation.
7.46.347	A non-renewable resource, such as fossil fuel, is either regenerated very slowly or not at all.
7.46.348	Another way for carbon to enter the atmosphere is from land (including land beneath the surface of the ocean) by the eruption of volcanoes and other geothermal systems.
7.46.349	Carbon sediments from the ocean floor are taken deep within the Earth by the process of subduction: the movement of one tectonic plate beneath another.
7.46.350	Carbon is released as carbon dioxide when a volcano erupts or from volcanic hydrothermal vents.
7.46.351	Carbon dioxide is also added to the atmosphere by the animal husbandry practices of humans.
7.46.352	The large numbers of land animals raised to feed the Earth’s growing population results in increased carbon dioxide levels in the atmosphere due to farming practices and the respiration and methane production.
7.46.353	This is another example of how human activity indirectly affects biogeochemical cycles in a significant way.
7.46.354	Although much of the debate about the future effects of increasing atmospheric carbon on climate change focuses on fossils fuels, scientists take natural processes, such as volcanoes and respiration, into account as they model and predict the future impact of this increase.
7.46.355	The Nitrogen Cycle Getting nitrogen into the living world is difficult.
7.46.356	Plants and phytoplankton are not equipped to incorporate nitrogen from the atmosphere (which exists as tightly bonded, triple covalent N2) even though this molecule comprises approximately 78 percent of the atmosphere.
7.46.357	Nitrogen enters the living world via free-living and symbiotic bacteria, which incorporate nitrogen into their macromolecules through nitrogen fixation (conversion of N2).
7.46.358	Cyanobacteria live in most aquatic ecosystems where sunlight is present; they play a key role in nitrogen fixation.
7.46.359	Cyanobacteria are able to use inorganic sources of nitrogen to “fix” nitrogen.
7.46.360	Rhizobium bacteria live symbiotically in the root nodules of legumes (such as peas, beans, and peanuts) and provide them with the organic nitrogen they need.
7.46.361	Free-living bacteria, such as Azotobacter, are also important nitrogen fixers.
7.46.362	Organic nitrogen is especially important to the study of ecosystem dynamics since many ecosystem processes, such as primary production and decomposition, are limited by the available supply of nitrogen.
7.46.363	As shown in Figure 46.17, the nitrogen that enters living systems by nitrogen fixation is successively converted from organic nitrogen back into nitrogen gas by bacteria.
7.46.364	This process occurs in three steps in terrestrial systems: ammonification, nitrification, and denitrification.
7.46.365	First, the ammonification process converts nitrogenous waste from living animals or from the remains of dead animals into ammonium (NH4 +) by certain bacteria and fungi.
7.46.366	Second, the ammonium is converted to nitrites (NO2 −) by nitrifying bacteria, such as Nitrosomonas, through nitrification.
7.46.367	Subsequently, nitrites are converted to nitrates (NO3 −) by similar organisms.
7.46.368	Third, the process of denitrification occurs, whereby bacteria, such as Pseudomonas and Clostridium, convert the nitrates into nitrogen gas, allowing it to re-enter the atmosphere.
7.46.369	Human activity can release nitrogen into the environment by two primary means: the combustion of fossil fuels, which releases different nitrogen oxides, and by the use of artificial fertilizers in agriculture, which are then washed into lakes, streams, and rivers by surface runoff.
7.46.370	Atmospheric nitrogen is associated with several effects on Earth’s ecosystems including the production of acid rain (as nitric acid, HNO3) and greenhouse gas (as nitrous oxide, N2O) potentially causing climate change.
7.46.371	A major effect from fertilizer runoff is saltwater and freshwater eutrophication, a process whereby nutrient runoff causes the excess growth of microorganisms, depleting dissolved oxygen levels and killing ecosystem fauna.
7.46.372	A similar process occurs in the marine nitrogen cycle, where the ammonification, nitrification, and denitrification processes are performed by marine bacteria.
7.46.373	Some of this nitrogen falls to the ocean floor as sediment, which can then be moved to land in geologic time by uplift of the Earth’s surface and thereby incorporated into terrestrial rock.
7.46.374	Although the movement of nitrogen from rock directly into living systems has been traditionally seen as insignificant compared with nitrogen fixed from the atmosphere, a recent study showed that this process may indeed be significant and should be included in any study of the global nitrogen cycle.
7.46.375	The Phosphorus Cycle Phosphorus is an essential nutrient for living processes; it is a major component of nucleic acid and phospholipids, and, as calcium phosphate, makes up the supportive components of our bones.
7.46.376	Phosphorus is often the limiting nutrient (necessary for growth) in aquatic ecosystems (Figure 46.18).
7.46.377	Phosphorus occurs in nature as the phosphate ion (PO4 3−).
7.46.378	In addition to phosphate runoff as a result of human activity, natural surface runoff occurs when it is leached from phosphate-containing rock by weathering, thus sending phosphates into rivers, lakes, and the ocean.
7.46.379	This rock has its origins in the ocean.
7.46.380	Phosphate-containing ocean sediments form primarily from the bodies of ocean organisms and from their excretions.
7.46.381	However, in remote regions, volcanic ash, aerosols, and mineral dust may also be significant phosphate sources.
7.46.382	This sediment then is moved to land over geologic time by the uplifting of areas of the Earth’s surface.
7.46.383	Phosphorus is also reciprocally exchanged between phosphate dissolved in the ocean and marine ecosystems.
7.46.384	The movement of phosphate from the ocean to the land and through the soil is extremely slow, with the average phosphate ion having an oceanic residence time between 20,000 and 100,000 years.
7.46.385	In nature, phosphorus exists as the phosphate ion (PO4 3−).
7.46.386	Weathering of rocks and volcanic activity releases phosphate into the soil, water, and air, where it becomes available to terrestrial food webs.
7.46.387	Phosphate enters the oceans via surface runoff, groundwater flow, and river flow.
7.46.388	Phosphate dissolved in ocean water cycles into marine food webs.
7.46.389	Some phosphate from the marine food webs falls to the ocean floor, where it forms sediment.
7.46.390	Excess phosphorus and nitrogen that enters these ecosystems from fertilizer runoff and from sewage causes excessive growth of microorganisms and depletes the dissolved oxygen, which leads to the death of many ecosystem fauna, such as shellfish and finfish.
7.46.391	This process is responsible for dead zones in lakes and at the mouths of many major rivers.
7.46.392	Dead zones occur when phosphorus and nitrogen from fertilizers cause excessive growth of microorganisms, which depletes oxygen and kills fauna.
7.46.393	Worldwide, large dead zones are found in coastal areas of high population density.
7.46.394	A dead zone is an area within a freshwater or marine ecosystem where large areas are depleted of their normal flora and fauna; these zones can be caused by eutrophication, oil spills, dumping of toxic chemicals, and other human activities.
7.46.395	The number of dead zones has been increasing for several years, and more than 400 of these zones were present as of 2008.
7.46.396	One of the worst dead zones is off the coast of the United States in the Gulf of Mexico, where fertilizer runoff from the Mississippi River basin has created a dead zone of over 8463 square miles.
7.46.397	Phosphate and nitrate runoff from fertilizers also negatively affect several lake and bay ecosystems including the Chesapeake Bay in the eastern United States.
7.46.398	The Sulfur Cycle Sulfur is an essential element for the macromolecules of living things.
7.46.399	As a part of the amino acid cysteine, it is involved in the formation of disulfide bonds within proteins, which help to determine their 3-D folding patterns, and hence their functions.
7.46.400	As shown in Figure 46.20, sulfur cycles between the oceans, land, and atmosphere.
7.46.401	Atmospheric sulfur is found in the form of sulfur dioxide (SO2) and enters the atmosphere in three ways: from the decomposition of organic molecules, from volcanic activity and geothermal vents, and from the burning of fossil fuels by humans.
7.46.402	Sulfur dioxide from the atmosphere becomes available to terrestrial and marine ecosystems when it is dissolved in precipitation as weak sulfuric acid or when it falls directly to the Earth as fallout.
7.46.403	Weathering of rocks also makes sulfates available to terrestrial ecosystems.
7.46.404	Decomposition of living organisms returns sulfates to the ocean, soil and atmosphere.
7.46.405	On land, sulfur is deposited in four major ways: precipitation, direct fallout from the atmosphere, rock weathering, and geothermal vents (Figure 46.21).
7.46.406	Atmospheric sulfur is found in the form of sulfur dioxide (SO2), and as rain falls through the atmosphere, sulfur is dissolved in the form of weak sulfuric acid (H2SO4).
7.46.407	Sulfur can also fall directly from the atmosphere in a process called fallout.
7.46.408	Also, the weathering of sulfur-containing rocks releases sulfur into the soil.
7.46.409	These rocks originate from ocean sediments that are moved to land by the geologic uplifting of ocean sediments.
7.46.410	Terrestrial ecosystems can then make use of these soil sulfates ( SO4− ), and upon the death and decomposition of these organisms, release the sulfur back into the atmosphere as hydrogen sulfide (H2S) gas.
7.46.411	At this sulfur vent in Lassen Volcanic National Park in northeastern California, the yellowish sulfur deposits are visible near the mouth of the vent.
7.46.412	Sulfur enters the ocean via runoff from land, from atmospheric fallout, and from underwater geothermal vents.
7.46.413	Some ecosystems (Figure 46.9) rely on chemoautotrophs using sulfur as a biological energy source.
7.46.414	This sulfur then supports marine ecosystems in the form of sulfates.
7.46.415	Human activities have played a major role in altering the balance of the global sulfur cycle.
7.46.416	The burning of large quantities of fossil fuels, especially from coal, releases larger amounts of hydrogen sulfide gas into the atmosphere.
7.46.417	As rain falls through this gas, it creates the phenomenon known as acid rain.
7.46.418	Acid rain is corrosive rain caused by rainwater falling to the ground through sulfur dioxide gas, turning it into weak sulfuric acid, which causes damage to aquatic ecosystems.
7.46.419	Acid rain damages the natural environment by lowering the pH of lakes, which kills many of the resident fauna; it also affects the man-made environment through the chemical degradation of buildings.
7.46.420	For example, many marble monuments, such as the Lincoln Memorial in Washington, DC, have suffered significant damage from acid rain over the years.
7.46.421	These examples show the wide-ranging effects of human activities on our environment and the challenges that remain for our future.
7.47.0	Lake Victoria in Africa, shown in this satellite image, was the site of one of the most extraordinary evolutionary findings on the planet, as well as a casualty of devastating biodiversity loss.
7.47.1	In the 1980s, biologists working in Lake Victoria in Africa discovered one of the most extraordinary products of evolution on the planet.
7.47.2	Located in the Great Rift Valley, Lake Victoria is a large lake about 68,900 km2 in area (larger than Lake Huron, the second largest of North America’s Great Lakes).
7.47.3	Biologists were studying species of a family of fish called cichlids.
7.47.4	They found that as they sampled for fish in different locations of the lake, they never stopped finding new species, and they identified nearly 500 evolved types of cichlids.
7.47.5	But while studying these variations, they quickly discovered that the invasive Nile Perch was destroying the lake’s cichlid population, bringing hundreds of cichlid species to extinction with devastating rapidity.
7.47.6	The Biodiversity Crisis
7.47.7	By the end of this section, you will be able to: Define biodiversity Describe biodiversity as the equilibrium of naturally fluctuating rates of extinction and speciation Identify historical causes of high extinction rates in Earth’s history Traditionally, ecologists have measured biodiversity, a general term for the variety present in the biosphere, by taking into account both the number of species and their commonness.
7.47.8	Biodiversity can be estimated at a number of levels of organization of living things.
7.47.9	These estimation indexes, which came from information theory, are most useful as a first step in quantifying biodiversity between and within ecosystems; they are less useful when the main concern among conservation biologists is simply the loss of biodiversity.
7.47.10	However, biologists recognize that measures of biodiversity, in terms of species diversity, may help focus efforts to preserve the biologically or technologically important elements of biodiversity.
7.47.11	The Lake Victoria cichlids provide an example through which we can begin to understand biodiversity.
7.47.12	The biologists studying cichlids in the 1980s discovered hundreds of cichlid species representing a variety of specializations to particular habitat types and specific feeding strategies: eating plankton floating in the water, scraping and then eating algae from rocks, eating insect larvae from the bottom, and eating the eggs of other species of cichlid.
7.47.13	The cichlids of Lake Victoria are the product of an adaptive radiation.
7.47.14	An adaptive radiation is a rapid (less than three million years in the case of the Lake Victoria cichlids) branching through speciation of a phylogenetic tree into many closely related species; typically, the species “radiate” into different habitats and niches.
7.47.15	The Galápagos finches are an example of a modest adaptive radiation with 15 species.
7.47.16	The cichlids of Lake Victoria are an example of a spectacular adaptive radiation that includes about 500 species.
7.47.17	At the time biologists were making this discovery, some species began to quickly disappear.
7.47.18	A culprit in these declines was a species of large fish that was introduced to Lake Victoria by fisheries to feed the people living around the lake.
7.47.19	The Nile perch was introduced in 1963, but lay low until the 1980s when its populations began to surge.
7.47.20	The Nile perch population grew by consuming cichlids, driving species after species to the point of extinction (the disappearance of a species).
7.47.21	In fact, there were several factors that played a role in the extinction of perhaps 200 cichlid species in Lake Victoria: the Nile perch, declining lake water quality due to agriculture and land clearing on the shores of Lake Victoria, and increased fishing pressure.
7.47.22	Scientists had not even catalogued all of the species present
7.47.23	—
7.47.24	so many were lost that were never named.
7.47.25	The diversity is now a shadow of what it once was.
7.47.26	The cichlids of Lake Victoria are a thumbnail sketch of contemporary rapid species loss that occurs all over Earth and is caused by human activity.
7.47.27	Extinction is a natural process of macroevolution that occurs at the rate of about one out of 1 million species becoming extinct per year.
7.47.28	The fossil record reveals that there have been five periods of mass extinction in history with much higher rates of species loss, and the rate of species loss today is comparable to those periods of mass extinction.
7.47.29	However, there is a major difference between the previous mass extinctions and the current extinction we are experiencing: human activity.
7.47.30	Specifically, three human activities have a major impact: destruction of habitat, introduction of exotic species, and over-harvesting.
7.47.31	Predictions of species loss within the next century, a tiny amount of time on geological timescales, range from 10 percent to 50 percent.
7.47.32	Extinctions on this scale have only happened five other times in the history of the planet, and they have been caused by cataclysmic events that changed the course of the history of life in each instance.
7.47.33	Earth is now in one of those times.
7.47.34	Types of Biodiversity Scientists generally accept that the term biodiversity describes the number and kinds of species in a location or on the planet.
7.47.35	Species can be difficult to define, but most biologists still feel comfortable with the concept and are able to identify and count eukaryotic species in most contexts.
7.47.36	Biologists have also identified alternate measures of biodiversity, some of which are important for planning how to preserve biodiversity.
7.47.37	Genetic diversity is one of those alternate concepts.
7.47.38	Genetic diversity or variation is the raw material for adaptation in a species.
7.47.39	A species’ future potential for adaptation depends on the genetic diversity held in the genomes of the individuals in populations that make up the species.
7.47.40	The same is true for higher taxonomic categories.
7.47.41	A genus with very different types of species will have more genetic diversity than a genus with species that look alike and have similar ecologies.
7.47.42	If there were a choice between one of these genera of species being preserved, the one with the greatest potential for subsequent evolution is the most genetically diverse one.
7.47.43	It would be ideal not to have to make such choices, but increasingly this may be the norm.
7.47.44	Many genes code for proteins, which in turn carry out the metabolic processes that keep organisms alive and reproducing.
7.47.45	Genetic diversity can be measured as chemical diversity in that different species produce a variety of chemicals in their cells, both the proteins as well as the products and byproducts of metabolism.
7.47.46	This chemical diversity has potential benefit for humans as a source of pharmaceuticals, so it provides one way to measure diversity that is important to human health and welfare.
7.47.47	Humans have generated diversity in domestic animals, plants, and fungi.
7.47.48	This diversity is also suffering losses because of migration, market forces, and increasing globalism in agriculture, especially in heavily populated regions such as China, India, and Japan.
7.47.49	The human population directly depends on this diversity as a stable food source, and its decline is troubling biologists and agricultural scientists.
7.47.50	It is also useful to define ecosystem diversity, meaning the number of different ecosystems on the planet or in a given geographic area (Figure 47.2).
7.47.51	Whole ecosystems can disappear even if some of the species might survive by adapting to other ecosystems.
7.47.52	The loss of an ecosystem means the loss of interactions between species, the loss of unique features of coadaptation, and the loss of biological productivity that an ecosystem is able to create.
7.47.53	An example of a largely extinct ecosystem in North America is the prairie ecosystem.
7.47.54	Prairies once spanned central North America from the boreal forest in northern Canada down into Mexico.
7.47.55	They are now all but gone, replaced by crop fields, pasture lands, and suburban sprawl.
7.47.56	Many of the species survive, but the hugely productive ecosystem that was responsible for creating the most productive agricultural soils is now gone.
7.47.57	As a consequence, soils are disappearing or must be maintained at greater expense.
7.47.58	The variety of ecosystems on Earth—from (a) coral reef to
7.47.59	(b) prairie—enables a great diversity of species to exist.
7.47.60	Current Species Diversity
7.47.61	Despite considerable effort, knowledge of the species that inhabit the planet is limited.
7.47.62	A recent estimate suggests that the eukaryote species for which science has names, about 1.5 million species, account for less than 20 percent of the total number of eukaryote species present on the planet (8.7 million species, by one estimate).
7.47.63	Estimates of numbers of prokaryotic species are largely guesses, but biologists agree that science has only begun to catalog their diversity.
7.47.64	Even with what is known, there is no central repository of names or samples of the described species; therefore, there is no way to be sure that the 1.5 million descriptions is an accurate number.
7.47.65	It is a best guess based on the opinions of experts in different taxonomic groups.
7.47.66	Given that Earth is losing species at an accelerating pace, science is very much in the place it was with the Lake Victoria cichlids: knowing little about what is being lost.
7.47.67	Table 47.1 presents recent estimates of biodiversity in different groups.
7.47.68	There are various initiatives to catalog described species in accessible ways, and the internet is facilitating that effort.
7.47.69	Nevertheless, it has been pointed out that at the current rate of species description, which according to the State of Observed Species Report is 17,000 to 20,000 new species per year, it will take close to 500 years to finish describing life on this planet.
7.47.70	[4]
7.47.71	Over time, the task becomes both increasingly impossible and increasingly easier as extinction removes species from the planet.
7.47.72	Naming and counting species may seem an unimportant pursuit given the other needs of humanity, but it is not simply an accounting.
7.47.73	Describing species is a complex process by which biologists determine an organism’s unique characteristics and whether or not that organism belongs to any other described species.
7.47.74	It allows biologists to find and recognize the species after the initial discovery, and allows them to follow up on questions about its biology.
7.47.75	In addition, the unique characteristics of each species make it potentially valuable to humans or other species on which humans depend.
7.47.76	Understanding these characteristics is the value of finding and naming species.
7.47.77	Patterns of Biodiversity Biodiversity is not evenly distributed on Earth.
7.47.78	Lake Victoria contained almost 500 species of cichlids alone, ignoring the other fish families present in the lake.
7.47.79	All of these species were found only in Lake Victoria; therefore, the 500 species of cichlids were endemic.
7.47.80	Endemic species are found in only one location.
7.47.81	Endemics with highly restricted distributions are particularly vulnerable to extinction.
7.47.82	Higher taxonomic levels, such as genera and families, can also be endemic.
7.47.83	Lake Huron contains about 79 species of fish, all of which are found in many other lakes in North America.
7.47.84	What accounts for the difference in fish diversity in these two lakes?
7.47.85	Lake Victoria is a tropical lake, while Lake Huron is a temperate lake.
7.47.86	Lake Huron in its present form is only about 7,000 years old, while Lake Victoria in its present form is about 15,000 years old.
7.47.87	Biogeographers have suggested these two factors, latitude and age, are two of several hypotheses to explain biodiversity patterns on the planet.
7.47.88	One of the oldest observed patterns in ecology is that species biodiversity in almost every taxonomic group increases as latitude declines.
7.47.89	In other words, biodiversity increases closer to the equator.
7.47.90	This map illustrates the number of amphibian species across the globe and shows the trend toward higher biodiversity at lower latitudes.
7.47.91	A similar pattern is observed for most taxonomic groups.
7.47.92	It is not yet clear why biodiversity increases closer to the equator, but hypotheses include the greater age of the ecosystems in the tropics versus temperate regions that were largely devoid of life or drastically impoverished during the last glaciation.
7.47.93	The idea is that greater age provides more time for speciation.
7.47.94	Another possible explanation is the increased energy the tropics receive from the sun versus the decreased energy that temperate and polar regions receive.
7.47.95	It is not entirely clear how greater energy input could translate into more species.
7.47.96	The complexity of tropical ecosystems may promote speciation by increasing the heterogeneity, or number of ecological niches, in the tropics relative to higher latitudes.
7.47.97	The greater heterogeneity provides more opportunities for coevolution, specialization, and perhaps greater selection pressures leading to population differentiation.
7.47.98	However, this hypothesis suffers from some circularity—ecosystems with more species encourage speciation, but how did they get more species to begin with?
7.47.99	The tropics have been perceived as being more stable than temperate regions, which have a pronounced climate and day-length seasonality.
7.47.100	The tropics have their own forms of seasonality, such as rainfall, but they are generally assumed to be more stable environments and this stability might promote speciation.
7.47.101	Regardless of the mechanisms, it is certainly true that all levels of biodiversity are greatest in the tropics.
7.47.102	Additionally, the rate of endemism is highest, and there are more biodiversity hotspots.
7.47.103	However, this richness of diversity also means that knowledge of species is lowest, and there is a high potential for biodiversity loss.
7.47.104	Conservation of Biodiversity
7.47.105	In 1988, British environmentalist Norman Myers developed a conservation concept to identify areas rich in species and at significant risk for species loss: biodiversity hotspots.
7.47.106	Biodiversity hotspots are geographical areas that contain high numbers of endemic species.
7.47.107	The purpose of the concept was to identify important locations on the planet for conservation efforts, a kind of conservation triage.
7.47.108	By protecting hotspots, governments are able to protect a larger number of species.
7.47.109	The original criteria for a hotspot included the presence of 1500 or more endemic plant species and 70 percent of the area disturbed by human activity.
7.47.110	There are now 34 biodiversity hotspots (Figure 47.4) containing large numbers of endemic species, which include half of Earth’s endemic plants.
7.47.111	Conservation International has identified 34 biodiversity hotspots, which cover only 2.3 percent of the Earth’s surface but have endemic to them 42 percent of the terrestrial vertebrate species and 50 percent of the world’s plants.
7.47.112	Biodiversity Change through Geological Time
7.47.113	The number of species on the planet, or in any geographical area, is the result of an equilibrium of two evolutionary processes that are ongoing: speciation and extinction.
7.47.114	Both are
7.47.115	natural “
7.47.116	birth”
7.47.117	and “death” processes of macroevolution.
7.47.118	When speciation rates begin to outstrip extinction rates, the number of species will increase; likewise, the number of species will decrease when extinction rates begin to overtake speciation rates.
7.47.119	Throughout Earth’s history, these two processes have fluctuated—sometimes leading to dramatic changes in the number of species on Earth as reflected in the fossil record.
7.47.120	Percent extinction occurrences as reflected in the fossil record have fluctuated throughout Earth’s history.
7.47.121	Sudden and dramatic losses of biodiversity, called mass extinctions, have occurred five times.
7.47.122	Paleontologists have identified five strata in the fossil record that appear to show sudden and dramatic (greater than half of all extant species disappearing from the fossil record) losses in biodiversity.
7.47.123	These are called mass extinctions.
7.47.124	There are many lesser, yet still dramatic, extinction events, but the five mass extinctions have attracted the most research.
7.47.125	An argument can be made that the five mass extinctions are only the five most extreme events in a continuous series of large extinction events throughout the Phanerozoic (since 542 million years ago).
7.47.126	In most cases, the hypothesized causes are still controversial; however, the most recent event seems clear.
7.47.127	The Five Mass Extinctions
7.47.128	The fossil record of the mass extinctions was the basis for defining periods of geological history, so they typically occur at the transition point between geological periods.
7.47.129	The transition in fossils from one period to another reflects the dramatic loss of species and the gradual origin of new species.
7.47.130	These transitions can be seen in the rock strata.
7.47.131	Table 47.2 provides data on the five mass extinctions.
7.47.132	The Ordovician-Silurian extinction event is the first recorded mass extinction and the second largest.
7.47.133	During this period, about 85 percent of marine species (few species lived outside the oceans) became extinct.
7.47.134	The main hypothesis for its cause is a period of glaciation and then warming.
7.47.135	The extinction event actually consists of two extinction events separated by about 1 million years.
7.47.136	The first event was caused by cooling, and the second event was due to the subsequent warming.
7.47.137	The climate changes affected temperatures and sea levels.
7.47.138	Some researchers have suggested that a gamma-ray burst, caused by a nearby supernova, is a possible cause of the Ordovician-Silurian extinction.
7.47.139	The gamma-ray burst would have stripped away the Earth’s ozone layer causing intense ultraviolet radiation from the sun and may account for climate changes observed at the time.
7.47.140	The hypothesis is speculative, but extraterrestrial influences on Earth’s history are an active line of research.
7.47.141	Recovery of biodiversity after the mass extinction took from 5 to 20 million years, depending on the location.
7.47.142	The late Devonian extinction may have occurred over a relatively long period of time.
7.47.143	It appears to have affected marine species and not the plants or animals inhabiting terrestrial habitats.
7.47.144	The causes of this extinction are poorly understood.
7.47.145	The end-Permian extinction was the largest in the history of life.
7.47.146	Indeed, an argument could be made that Earth nearly became devoid of life during this extinction event.
7.47.147	The planet looked very different before and after this event.
7.47.148	Estimates are that 96 percent of all marine species and 70 percent of all terrestrial species were lost.
7.47.149	It was at this time, for example, that the trilobites, a group that survived the Ordovician–Silurian extinction, became extinct.
7.47.150	The causes for this mass extinction are not clear, but the leading suspect is extended and widespread volcanic activity that led to a runaway global-warming event.
7.47.151	The oceans became largely anoxic, suffocating marine life.
7.47.152	Terrestrial tetrapod diversity took 30 million years to recover after the end-Permian extinction.
7.47.153	The Permian extinction dramatically altered Earth’s biodiversity makeup and the course of evolution.
7.47.154	The causes of the Triassic–Jurassic extinction event are not clear and hypotheses of climate change, asteroid impact, and volcanic eruptions have been argued.
7.47.155	The extinction event occurred just before the breakup of the supercontinent Pangaea, although recent scholarship suggests that the extinctions may have occurred more gradually throughout the Triassic.
7.47.156	The causes of the end-Cretaceous extinction event are the ones that are best understood.
7.47.157	It was during this extinction event about 65 million years ago that the dinosaurs, the dominant vertebrate group for millions of years, disappeared from the planet (with the exception of a theropod clade that gave rise to birds).
7.47.158	Indeed, every land animal that weighed more then 25 kg became extinct.
7.47.159	The cause of this extinction is now understood to be the result of a cataclysmic impact of a large meteorite, or asteroid, off the coast of what is now the Yucatán Peninsula.
7.47.160	This hypothesis, proposed first in 1980, was a radical explanation based on a sharp spike in the levels of iridium (which rains down from space in meteors at a fairly constant rate but is otherwise absent on Earth’s surface) at the rock stratum that marks the boundary between the Cretaceous and Paleogene periods (Figure 47.6).
7.47.161	This boundary marked the disappearance of the dinosaurs in fossils as well as many other taxa.
7.47.162	The researchers who discovered the iridium spike interpreted it as a rapid influx of iridium from space to the atmosphere (in the form of a large asteroid) rather than a slowing in the deposition of sediments during that period.
7.47.163	It was a radical explanation, but the report of an appropriately aged and sized impact crater in 1991 made the hypothesis more believable.
7.47.164	Now an abundance of geological evidence supports the theory.
7.47.165	Recovery times for biodiversity after the end-
7.47.166	Cretaceous extinction are shorter, in geological time, than for the end-Permian extinction, on the order of 10 million years.
7.47.167	The Pleistocene Extinction
7.47.168	The Pleistocene Extinction is one of the lesser extinctions, and a recent one.
7.47.169	It is well known that the North American, and to some degree Eurasian, megafauna, or large animals, disappeared toward the end of the last glaciation period.
7.47.170	The extinction appears to have happened in a relatively restricted time period of 10,000–12,000 years ago.
7.47.171	In North America, the losses were quite dramatic and included the woolly mammoths (last dated about 4,000 years ago in an isolated population), mastodon, giant beavers, giant ground sloths, saber-toothed cats, and the North American camel, just to name a few.
7.47.172	The possibility that the rapid extinction of these large animals was caused by over-hunting was first suggested in the 1900s.
7.47.173	Research into this hypothesis continues today.
7.47.174	It seems likely that over-hunting caused many pre-written history extinctions in many regions of the world.
7.47.175	In general, the timing of the Pleistocene extinctions correlated with the arrival of humans and not with climate-change events, which is the main competing hypothesis for these extinctions.
7.47.176	The extinctions began in Australia about 40,000 to 50,000 years ago, just after the arrival of humans in the area: a marsupial lion, a giant one-ton wombat, and several giant kangaroo species disappeared.
7.47.177	In North America, the extinctions of almost all of the large mammals occurred 10,000–12,000 years ago.
7.47.178	All that are left are the smaller mammals such as bears, elk, moose, and cougars.
7.47.179	Finally, on many remote oceanic islands, the extinctions of many species occurred coincident with human arrivals.
7.47.180	Not all of the islands had large animals, but when there were large animals, they were lost.
7.47.181	Madagascar was colonized about 2,000 years ago and the large mammals that lived there became extinct.
7.47.182	Eurasia and Africa do not show this pattern, but they also did not experience a recent arrival of humans.
7.47.183	Humans arrived in Eurasia hundreds of thousands of years ago after the origin of the species in Africa.
7.47.184	This topic remains an area of active research and hypothesizing.
7.47.185	It seems clear that even if climate played a role, in most cases human hunting precipitated the extinctions.
7.47.186	Present-Time Extinctions
7.47.187	The sixth, or Holocene, mass extinction appears to have begun earlier than previously believed and has mostly to do with the activities of Homo sapiens.
7.47.188	Since the beginning of the Holocene period, there are numerous recent extinctions of individual species that are recorded in human writings.
7.47.189	Most of these are coincident with the expansion of the European colonies since the 1500s.
7.47.190	One of the earlier and popularly known examples is the dodo bird.
7.47.191	The dodo bird lived in the forests of Mauritius, an island in the Indian Ocean.
7.47.192	The dodo bird became extinct around 1662.
7.47.193	It was hunted for its meat by sailors and was easy prey because the dodo, which did not evolve with humans, would approach people without fear.
7.47.194	Introduced pigs, rats, and dogs brought to the island by European ships also killed dodo young and eggs.
7.47.195	Steller's sea cow became extinct in 1768; it was related to the manatee and probably once lived along the northwest coast of North America.
7.47.196	Steller's sea cow was first discovered by Europeans in 1741 and was hunted for meat and oil.
7.47.197	The last sea cow was killed in 1768.
7.47.198	That amounts to 27 years between the sea cow’s first contact with Europeans and extinction of the species.
7.47.199	In 1914, the last living passenger pigeon died in a zoo in Cincinnati, Ohio.
7.47.200	This species had once darkened the skies of North America during its migrations, but it was hunted and suffered from habitat loss through the clearing of forests for farmland.
7.47.201	In 1918, the last living Carolina parakeet died in captivity.
7.47.202	This species was once common in the eastern United States, but it suffered from habitat loss.
7.47.203	The species was also hunted because it ate orchard fruit when its native foods were destroyed to make way for farmland.
7.47.204	The Japanese sea lion, which inhabited a broad area around Japan and the coast of Korea, became extinct in the 1950s due to fishermen.
7.47.205	The Caribbean monk seal was distributed throughout the Caribbean Sea but was driven to extinction via hunting by 1952.
7.47.206	These are only a few of the recorded extinctions in the past 500 years.
7.47.207	The International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN) keeps a list of extinct and endangered species called the Red List.
7.47.208	The list is not complete, but it describes 380 extinct species of vertebrates after 1500 AD, 86 of which were driven extinct by overhunting or overfishing.
7.47.209	Estimates of Present-Time Extinction Rates Estimates of extinction rates are hampered by the fact that most extinctions are probably happening without observation.
7.47.210	The extinction of a bird or mammal is likely to be noticed by humans, especially if it has been hunted or used in some other way.
7.47.211	But there are many organisms that are of less interest to humans (not necessarily of less value) and many that are undescribed.
7.47.212	The background extinction rate is estimated to be about one per million species per year (E/MSY).
7.47.213	For example, assuming there are about ten million species in existence, the expectation is that ten species would become extinct each year (each year represents ten million species per year).
7.47.214	One contemporary extinction rate estimate uses the extinctions in the written record since the year 1500.
7.47.215	For birds alone this method yields an estimate of 26 E/MSY.
7.47.216	However, this value may be underestimated for three reasons.
7.47.217	First, many species would not have been described until much later in the time period, so their loss would have gone unnoticed.
7.47.218	Second, the number of recently extinct species is increasing because extinct species now are being described from skeletal remains.
7.47.219	And third, some species are probably already extinct even though conservationists are reluctant to name them as such.
7.47.220	Taking these factors into account raises the estimated extinction rate closer to 100 E/MSY.
7.47.221	The predicted rate by the end of the century is 1500 E/MSY.
7.47.222	A second approach to estimating present-time extinction rates is to correlate species loss with habitat loss by measuring forest-area loss and understanding species-area relationships.
7.47.223	The species-area relationship is the rate at which new species are seen when the area surveyed is increased.
7.47.224	Studies have shown that the number of species present increases as the size of the island increases.
7.47.225	This phenomenon has also been shown to hold true in other habitats as well.
7.47.226	Turning this relationship around, if the habitat area is reduced, the number of species living there will also decline.
7.47.227	Estimates of extinction rates based on habitat loss and species-area relationships have suggested that with about 90 percent habitat loss an expected 50 percent of species would become extinct.
7.47.228	Species-area estimates have led to species extinction rate calculations of about 1000 E/MSY and higher.
7.47.229	In general, actual observations do not show this amount of loss and suggestions have been made that there is a delay in extinction.
7.47.230	Recent work has also called into question the applicability of the species-area relationship when estimating the loss of species.
7.47.231	This work argues that the species-area relationship leads to an overestimate of extinction rates.
7.47.232	A better relationship to use may be the endemics-area relationship.
7.47.233	Using this method would bring estimates down to around 500 E/MSY in the coming century.
7.47.234	Note that this value is still 500 times the background rate.
7.47.235	Studies have shown that the number of species present increases with the size of the habitat.
7.47.236	The Importance of Biodiversity to Human Life
7.47.237	By the end of this section, you will be able to: Identify chemical diversity benefits to humans Identify biodiversity components that support human agriculture Describe ecosystem services
7.47.238	It may not be clear why biologists are concerned about biodiversity loss.
7.47.239	When biodiversity loss is thought of as the extinction of the passenger pigeon, the dodo bird, and even the woolly mammoth, the loss may appear to be an emotional one.
7.47.240	But is the loss practically important for the welfare of the human species?
7.47.241	From the perspective of evolution and ecology, the loss of a particular individual species is unimportant (however, the loss of a keystone species can lead to ecological disaster).
7.47.242	Extinction is a normal part of macroevolution.
7.47.243	But the accelerated extinction rate means the loss of tens of thousands of species within our lifetimes, and it is likely to have dramatic effects on human welfare through the collapse of ecosystems and in added costs to maintain food production, clean air and water, and human health.
7.47.244	Agriculture began after early hunter-gatherer societies first settled in one place and heavily modified their immediate environment.
7.47.245	This cultural transition has made it difficult for humans to recognize their dependence on undomesticated living things on the planet.
7.47.246	Biologists recognize the human species is embedded in ecosystems and is dependent on them, just as every other species on the planet is dependent.
7.47.247	Technology smoothes out the extremes of existence, but ultimately the human species cannot exist without its ecosystem.
7.47.248	Human Health Contemporary societies that live close to the land often have a broad knowledge of the medicinal uses of plants growing in their area.
7.47.249	Most plants produce secondary plant compounds, which are toxins used to protect the plant from insects and other animals that eat them, but some of which also work as medication.
7.47.250	For centuries in Europe, older knowledge about the medical uses of plants was compiled in herbals—books that identified plants and their uses.
7.47.251	Humans are not the only species to use plants for medicinal reasons: the great apes, orangutans, chimpanzees, bonobos, and gorillas have all been observed self-medicating with plants.
7.47.252	Modern pharmaceutical science also recognizes the importance of these plant compounds.
7.47.253	Examples of significant medicines derived from plant compounds include aspirin, codeine, digoxin, atropine, and vincristine (Figure 47.8).
7.47.254	Many medicines were once derived from plant extracts but are now synthesized.
7.47.255	It is estimated that, at one time, 25 percent of modern drugs contained at least one plant extract.
7.47.256	That number has probably decreased to about 10 percent as natural plant ingredients are replaced by synthetic versions.
7.47.257	Antibiotics, which are responsible for extraordinary improvements in health and lifespans in developed countries, are compounds largely derived from fungi and bacteria.
7.47.258	Catharanthus roseus, the Madagascar periwinkle, has various medicinal properties.
7.47.259	Among other uses, it is a source of vincristine, a drug used in the treatment of lymphomas.
7.47.260	In recent years, animal venoms and poisons have excited intense research for their medicinal potential.
7.47.261	By 2007, the FDA had approved five drugs based on animal toxins to treat diseases such as hypertension, chronic pain, and diabetes.
7.47.262	Another five drugs are undergoing clinical trials, and at least six drugs are being used in other countries.
7.47.263	Other toxins under investigation come from mammals, snakes, lizards, various amphibians, fish, snails, octopuses, and scorpions.
7.47.264	Aside from representing billions of dollars in profits, these medicines improve people’s lives.
7.47.265	Pharmaceutical companies are actively looking for new compounds synthesized by living organisms that can function as medicine.
7.47.266	It is estimated that 1/3 of pharmaceutical research and development is spent on natural compounds and that about 35 percent of new drugs brought to market between 1981 and 2002 were from natural compounds.
7.47.267	The opportunities for new medications will be reduced in direct proportion to the disappearance of species.
7.47.268	Agricultural Diversity
7.47.269	Since the beginning of human agriculture more than 10,000 years ago, human groups have been breeding and selecting crop varieties.
7.47.270	This crop diversity matched the cultural diversity of highly subdivided populations of humans.
7.47.271	For example, potatoes were domesticated beginning around 7,000 years ago in the central Andes of Peru and Bolivia.
7.47.272	The potatoes grown in that region belong to seven species and the number of varieties likely is in the thousands.
7.47.273	Each variety has been bred to thrive at particular elevations and soil and climate conditions.
7.47.274	The diversity is driven by the diverse demands of the topography, the limited movement of people, and the demands created by crop rotation for different varieties that will do well in different fields.
7.47.275	Potatoes are only one example of human-generated diversity.
7.47.276	Every plant, animal, and fungus that has been cultivated by humans has been bred from original wild ancestor species into diverse varieties arising from the demands for food value, adaptation to growing conditions, and resistance to pests.
7.47.277	The potato demonstrates a well-known example of the risks of low crop diversity: the tragic Irish potato famine when the single variety grown in Ireland became susceptible to a potato blight, wiping out the crop.
7.47.278	The loss of the crop led to famine, death, and mass emigration.
7.47.279	Resistance to disease is a chief benefit to maintaining crop biodiversity, and lack of diversity in contemporary crop species carries similar risks.
7.47.280	Seed companies, which are the source of most crop varieties in developed countries, must continually breed new varieties to keep up with evolving pest organisms.
7.47.281	These same seed companies, however, have participated in the decline of the number of varieties available as they focus on selling fewer varieties in more areas of the world.
7.47.282	The ability to create new crop varieties relies on the diversity of varieties available and the accessibility of wild forms related to the crop plant.
7.47.283	These wild forms are often the source of new gene variants that can be bred with existing varieties to create varieties with new attributes.
7.47.284	Loss of wild species related to a crop will mean the loss of potential in crop improvement.
7.47.285	Maintaining the genetic diversity of wild species related to domesticated species ensures our continued food supply.
7.47.286	Since the 1920s, government agriculture departments have maintained seed banks of crop varieties as a way to maintain crop diversity.
7.47.287	This system has flaws because, over time, seed banks are lost through accidents, and there is no way to replace them.
7.47.288	In 2008, the Svalbard Global Seed Vault (Figure 47.9) began storing seeds from around the world as a backup system to the regional seed banks.
7.47.289	If a regional seed bank stores varieties in Svalbard, losses can be replaced from Svalbard.
7.47.290	The seed vault is located deep into the rock of an arctic island.
7.47.291	Conditions within the vault are maintained at ideal temperature and humidity for seed survival, but the deep underground location of the vault in the arctic means that failure of the vault’s systems will not compromise the climatic conditions inside the vault.
7.47.292	Crop success s is largely dependent on the quality of the soil.
7.47.293	Although some agricultural soils are rendered sterile using controversial cultivation and chemical treatments, most contain a huge diversity of organisms that maintain nutrient cycles—breaking down organic matter into nutrient compounds that crops need for growth.
7.47.294	These organisms also maintain soil texture that affects water and oxygen dynamics in the soil that are necessary for plant growth.
7.47.295	If farmers had to maintain arable soil using alternate means, the cost of food would be much higher than it is now.
7.47.296	These kinds of processes are called ecosystem services.
7.47.297	They occur within ecosystems, such as soil ecosystems, as a result of the diverse metabolic activities of the organisms living there, but they provide benefits to human food production, drinking water availability, and breathable air.
7.47.298	Other key ecosystem services related to food production are plant pollination and crop pest control.
7.47.299	Over 150 crops in the United States require pollination to produce.
7.47.300	One estimate of the benefit of honeybee pollination within the United States is $1.6 billion per year; other pollinators contribute up to $6.7 billion more.
7.47.301	Many honeybee populations are managed by apiarists who rent out their hives’ services to farmers.
7.47.302	Honeybee populations in North America have been suffering large losses caused by a syndrome known as colony collapse disorder, whose cause is unclear.
7.47.303	Other pollinators include a diverse array of other bee species and various insects and birds.
7.47.304	Loss of these species would make growing crops requiring pollination impossible, increasing dependence on other crops.
7.47.305	Finally, humans compete for their food with crop pests, most of which are insects.
7.47.306	Pesticides control these competitors; however, pesticides are costly and lose their effectiveness over time as pest populations adapt.
